column2: WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Some days ago in this space an account was given of legislation considered and completed by the House and the Senate in the course of April 13, to support the statement that the Eighty-first Congress is a hard-working, not a "do-nothing," body.
BERLIN, April 21 -- Communists in Western Germany demanded today resumption of normal trade between the Western and Eastern zones of occupation.

Liquor consumption for the country as a whole during 1949 will be almost the same as last year, Ted Thomas, general sales manager of Schenley Distributors, Inc., told more than 500 distributors yesterday at a regional sales meeting in the Essex House.

Opera came to the Bronx when the Columbia Grand Opera Company made its bow last night. A large audience heard Puccini's "Tosca" and the opera's billboards intermingled with those of coming movies, in Fordham Road's Windsor Theatre.

TOKYO, April 21 -- Thirteen foreign shipping companies and approximately 130 Japanese exporters are being sued by the Japanese Government on charges of violating an anti-monopoly act. They were ordered yesterday to file a written reply before May 10 and appear for a hearing May 20.

I see that Dr. Nourse, the President's economic adviser, suggested it might be well to try to squeeze military appropriations under the Atlantic pact out of our forthcoming $16 billion domestic military budget. Mr. Truman replied, in effect, that Dr. Nourse was only an economist.

The Rubel Corporation has purchased the coal yard and fuel plant at 200 Morgan Avenue, Brooklyn, from the Coal and Fuel Associates, Inc., of which Louis Goldstein is president. The new owner will use the property as a branch distributing unit for fuel oil and coal.

An armed robber walked yesterday into the R. M. Haan Candy Company offices at 44-35 Twenty-first Street, Long Island City, Queens, asked for the boss, demanded a payroll of about $2,500 that had arrived a half hour earlier in an armored car and escaped with it in a stolen car.

JERSEY CITY, April 21 -- Fashioning eight runs in the third inning through the medium of three homers, Jersey City's Little Giants turned back the Rochester Red Wings, 9 to 6, in the opening game of the International League season here today.

Defense Secretary Johnson's directive against racial discrimination in the armed services is sound in principle and practical in its approach. We don't want second-class citizenship among our nation's defenders any more than we want second-class citizenship in the nation itself.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Secretary of State Acheson's visit to the Foreign Relations Committee this afternoon is just the beginning of a long argument over implementing the North Atlantic treaty.

SAN REMO, Italy, April 20 -Count Carlo Sforza, Italian Foreign Minister, has reported back to his Government that Secretary of State Acheson told him that the United States firmly sympathized with Italy's demographic and economic problems as connected with North Africa, and the future of this country's former colonies there.

ALBANY, April 21 -- Representative William L. Pfeiffer of Buffalo was chosen unanimously today to succeed Glen R. Bedenkapp of Lewiston as Republican State Chairman. Mr. Bedenkapp resigned in February just before his appointment as a member of the Public Service Commission.

ROME, April 21 -- Foreign Minister Count Carlo Sforza's failure to obtain from the United States any assurances about the final disposition of Italy's pre-Fascist colonies has caused severe attacks to be leveled at him by the Italian press. Some newspapers do not hesitate to say that he will find a very hostile atmosphere on his return home.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The British Trades Union Congress is expected to issue invitations soon to the preliminary meeting of "free trade unions" to form a new world labor federation. It is the understanding of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations that the conference to form the new federation is to be held in Geneva on June 25 and 26.

The program for military aid to Europe to put teeth into the North Atlantic Treaty has now been submitted by Secretary of State Acheson to the Foreign Relations Committee of the Senate. It is a program for $1,130,000,000 aid to our Atlantic associates supplemented by help, already taken into account, for Greece and Turkey, a total of about $1,450,000,000.

Noranda Mines, Ltd., of Toronto, Canada, yesterday became the first large primary copper producer to reduce the price of primary copper by 2 cents to 21 1/2 cents a pound, following earlier price cuts by custom smelters here. American primary producers at the close of business yesterday continued to quote 23 1/2 cents a pound, spokesmen said.

The $38,000,000 Rochester Telephone Corporation, an independent communications company serving 167,000 subscribers in Rochester, N. Y., and surrounding territory, reported yesterday that operating revenues last year rose 13.2 per cent to $9,759,619, compared with $8,621,203 in 1947.

Spats and Dry Fly won the co-features of the proceedings at Jamaica yesterday, but it was a claiming race, run in the second spot, that stirred up the most chatter among the 25,691 customers. Reason for the fuss: Isidor Bieber's Rocklye, 7 to 20 in the betting, was disqualified from first and placed last after the stewards had taken a 13-minute time-out to look at the movies.

New York's police job is gigantic and the statistics show it is being generally well done. The city has an area of 320 square miles, with 5,723 miles of streets laid out. In the five boroughs there are nearly 26,000 acres of parks; the Park Department estimates 101,804,000 visits were made either to parks or the city's 510 playgrounds in 1948.
NANKING, Friday, April 22 (AP) -- United States citizens were urged today by the American Embassy to consider quitting Nanking "now" before it becomes a battleground of the civil war.

In an interview at 331 Madison Avenue, former State Senator Abraham Kaplan, campaign manager for Municipal Court Justice Benjamin Shalleck, Democratic nominee for Representative in the Twentieth Congressional District at the special election on May 17, announced yesterday the plan of campaign to seek Mr. Shalleck's election and to defeat Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., candidate on the Liberal party and independent Four Freedoms party tickets.

The American edition of a twenty-four-volume history of the Roman Catholic Church, designed to cover its story from the beginning down to the present, will be published by Macmillan. The first two volumes, "The History of the Primitive Church," by Jules Lebreton, S. J., and Jacques Zeiller, will be published on May 10.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 21 -- Negotiations for the purchase of the United Artists Distributing Company by the Nasser brothers collapsed late tonight, it was announced by the prospective purchasers.

KARACHI, Pakistan, April 21 -Joint defense arrangements between India and Pakistan are foreseen by Khwaja Nazimuddin, Governor General of Pakistan. When these would develop, he said in an interview today, would depend upon factors now at issue between the two Dominions and perhaps also upon external considerations.

The ancient bell of the Mission of San Antonio de Padua near King City, Calif., was rung yesterday in City Hall Plaza by Deputy Mayor John J. Bennett at a ceremony sponsored by the National Conference of Christians and Jews.

SEOUL, Korea, April 21 -- The Korean press in general offered favorable editorial comment today on President Syngman Rhee's announcement this week of the beginning of discussions with the United States authorities here concerning withdrawal of United States troops from Korea.
Three one-man shows of paintings opening this week reveal what odd and curious things happen to the world of natural appearances as it filters through the individual modern artist's vision.
If California has its Capistrano, can the Bronx be far behind? For Perriette has returned to the borough and has set up housekeeping again.
The cotton futures market turned steady after some early liquidation on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday and final prices were 1 to 17 points net higher.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., April 21 -- The United Mine Workers Union made it plain today that it intended to press for a shorter work-day, higher welfare payments and a "share-the-work" plan, despite warnings by employers that the industry could not support increased labor costs this year.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- President Truman told a news conference today that no "peace feelers" had come his way from Soviet Russia. He declined to comment, however, on published reports that informal overtures had been made by the Kremlin looking to the removal of the Berlin blockade preliminary to four-power talks on Germany.

NEWARK, N. J., April 21 (AP) -Oscar Judd, the only native Canadian in the Toronto line-up, spoiled Newark's International League opening today when he hurled the Maple Leafs to a 5-0 four-hit triumph before 11,703 fans in Ruppert Stadium.

With Jerry Madalena starring at bat, City College's baseball team annexed its fourth metropolitan conference league game yesterday by pounding out a 14-to-8 triumph against Manhattan at Van Cortlandt Park.
The use of his right-handed hitting power paid dividends to Casey Stengel yesterday at the Stadium.

Production gains of as much as 30 per cent per employe without cutting wages were reported yesterday when employes have been convinced that new methods are being introduced in their interests as well as those of the company making work changes.

Loans to business by banks in this area dropped $133,000,000 during the week ended on last Wednesday -- the largest single weekly decline on record. According to the data covering the reporting New York City member banks, issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, last week was the eighth consecutive week in which there was a decline.

PANAMA, April 21 -- A confession to Panamanian police by Wilson Walter Brown, a former major in the United States Army, has resulted in the arrest of former President Harmodio Arias; the secretary of the National University, Frederico Velasquez, and Anibal and Arturo Illueca, brothers of Assemblyman Jorge Illueca, and others opposing the Domingo Diaz regime.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, April 21 (AP) -- The executive committee of the International Olympic Committee and sixteen international sports federations met here today to streamline the program for the 1952 Olympic Games in Helsinki.

CINCINNATI, April 21 -- Cincinnati poured on the power today, two home runs and three doubles helping pitcher Johnny Vander Meet to an easy 5-to-0 victory over the St. Louis Cards. The victory gave Cincinnati undisputed possession of first place in the National League.

Asserting that the Democratic party since its foundation by Thomas Jefferson always had led in legislative and executive policies for the advancement of the welfare of the great masses of the people, Vice President Alben W. Barkley declared last night that the result of the last election constituted a mandate for enactment of the pledges President Truman and he had made during the campaign.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 21 -"The Human Conflict," a photoplay by Ranald MacDougall, has been scheduled for production by Jerry Wald at Warner Brothers, with Joan Crawford, David Brian and possibly John Garfield heading the cast, the studio announced today.

A new shipment of pleated paper lampshades designed by Kaare Klint and Gunnar Biilmann Petersen was exhibited yesterday at Bonniers, 605 Madison Avenue. The shades, which vary in size from six to sixteen inches and come in a range of soft pastels as well as white, are surprisingly flexible and versatile, changing shape according to the frames used with them.
CLEVELAND, April 21 -- Creation of the United Church of Christ, the country's newest large religious denomination with a potential membership of nearly 2,000,000, became a virtual certainty today.

German housewives look ten years older than American housewives of the same age because they have none of the labor-saving devices used in homes and kitchens here. This observation was made yesterday by two German women teachers, Dr. Anna Buchler of Munich and Dr. Gertrude Weismantel of Fulda, Hesse, at Pratt Institute in Brooklyn, where they are spending a week studying American education.

ST. LOUIS, April 21 (AP) -- Steve Gromek pitched a strange two-hitter today as the Cleveland Indians downed the St. Louis Browns, 8 -- 2. The only hits off him were home runs by Jack Graham and Dick Kokos in the fifth.

CHICAGO, April 21 -- At no time today were wheat futures below the finish of the previous day and closing trades on the Board of Trade were at gains of 5/8 to 1 3/4 cents a bushel, May being inclined to drag. Corn was unsettled but rallied late in position with wheat, and closed with gains of 3/8 to 5/8 cent.

The Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company, in its statement of operation for the first quarter of 1949, announced yesterday that sales reached a new high of $70,735,310, about 6 per cent more than the $66,731,935 volume for the initial three months of 1948.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., April 21 -- Westchester County, which has tried in vain for thirty years to obtain a liberal arts co-educational university, began exploration of a new avenue this afternoon, when officials met with John K. Weiss, secretary of the board of trustees of the State University of New York.

Those who go once in a while down to the sea in boats have everything almost shipshape for what is forecast to be the most enthusiastic pleasure-boat season in the metropolitan area. In fact, preparations are so extensive that boat-owners are warned moorings will be scarce.

Breaking out of the narrow rut in which it has operated four weeks, prices on the New York Stock Exchange dropped fractions to three points yesterday in the heaviest volume of business this month. Final prices generally were at their lows for the day, with only a handful of issues advancing.

Approval of construction contracts totaling $2,194,619 for work at New York and New Jersey installations of the Port of New York Authority was voted yesterday by the Authority's Commissioners at their monthly meeting in the Port Authority Building, 111 Eighth Avenue.

LONDON, April 21 -- British Government officials were pessimistic here today over the chances of effecting a diplomatic contact with the Chinese Communists and bringing the Yangtze incident to a satisfactory conclusion.

SLIGHTLY disillusioned by the brand of hospitality which they received in Brooklyn, the New York Giants will return to the Polo Grounds today for a home opening of their own. These secondary inaugurals never have quite as much color or appeal as the originals because a couple of days' play elsewhere has rubbed off some of the gloss and anticipation.
SHANGHAI, April 21 (AP) -- The daring RAF Sunderland's landing near the Amethyst was made "under heavy gunfire."

Shareholders of the Shell Union Oil Corporation at their annual meeting here yesterday elected four new directors, increasing the board membership to eighteen. The new officials are Cason J. Callaway, a director of United States Steel Corporation and the Chemical Bank and Trust Company; Stanley W. Duhig, H. Bloemgarten and J. W. Boyle, all associated with Shell companies.

BOSTON, April 21 (AP) -- A Methodist weekly publication defended Boston College today for discharging three teachers who contended the college taught heresy to Roman Catholicism. The publication added it was "the kind of heresy we like."

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- After nearly twelve hours of often-heated continuous debate, the Senate approved at 11:40 o'clock tonight the multi-billion-dollar national housing bill. The margin was 57 to 13, the largest ever recorded in the Senate for such a bill.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- President Truman accepted today with "deep regret" the long-expected resignation of Kenneth C. Royall as Secretary of the Army.
HOUSTON, Tex., April 21 -- For the second time in less than a year, the Brown Shipyard here has changed hands.

LONDON, April 21 -- Leopold S. Amery, veteran British statesman and long-time political associate of Winston Churchill, severely criticized today the United States foreign economic policies as embodied in the Havana economic charter.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Representatives of the youth councils of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, who opened a four-day conference at Howard University last night, were told today that mature judgment dictated that half a loaf, if properly cooked, was better than no loaf at all.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 21 -- The Social Committee of the United Nations General Assembly voted, 20 to 13, today to include in a proposed convention on news gathering an article that would permit governments signing it to demand official corrections of news reports that they considered injurious to "national prestige and dignity."

SAN FRANCISCO, April 21 -- Longshore gangs often are idle for a week at a time and wages of dock workers have dropped 20 per cent since Jan. 1 in this port, according to statistics presented today at a National Labor Relations Board hearing by Lincoln Fairley, economist of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, CIO.

DAMASCUS, Syria, April 21 -Gen. Husni Zayim, the Syrian Premier, made a good-will visit today to King Farouk of Egypt, traveling to Cairo by air. He was received at the King's estate. His visit was considered here preliminary to formal Egyptian recognition of the new Syrian regime.

PHILADELPHIA, April 21 (AP) -Sun Oil Company and Standard Oil Company of Ohio announced today that they have formed a new company to build and operate a 1,000-mile pipeline to carry crude petroleum from Texas to Ohio. The line will cost about $56,000,000.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 21 -Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, today accused the United States and Britain of planning to establish military, air and naval bases in the former Italian colonies "near the Near East, near the Middle East, near the Caucasus perchance" to fill in gaps in their "military-strategic reckoning."
The State of Arkansas announced yesterday that it would offer for sale on June 9 an issue of $7,000,000 highway bonds dated July 1, 1949, due May 1, 1950 to 1969 and callable in 1959

Opposition to the onward sweep of the three masters representing continental countries stiffened perceptibly in the eighth round at the Easter Chess Festival in Southsea, England, yesterday. Their games remained unfinished when time was called, according to a report from London.

The largest number of shareholders ever to attend an annual meeting of the National Dairy Products Corporation yesterday heard L. A. Van Bomel, president, discuss first - quarter earnings which he predicted would be slightly better than those of last year.

In your editorial of April 10, "Education in Georgia," you cite figures showing the small amount of money spent in public school education in Georgia and other states, and at the same time point out the large sums spent in New York. You then discuss the behavior of the Georgia State Legislature and of the Governor in negating increased expenditures.

Never the one to stand pat, particularly with a losing combination, Leo Durocher made some radical changes in his line-up yesterday at Ebbets Field and the result was most gratifying. Benching Bill Righey, Willard Marshall and Walker Cooper, switching Sid Gordon to the outfield and inserting Bobby Rhawn, Jack Lohrke and Mickey Livingston, the peppy pilot saw his giants defeat the Dodgers.

SHANGHAI, April 21 -- Two more British warships -- the heavy cruiser London and the sloop Black Swan -- were damaged today by Chinese Communist shellfire that raked them as they moved up the Yangtze River.

An issue of $4,100,000 of bonds guaranteed by the Commonwealth of Massachusetts and intended to finance the acquisition and operation of the summer-resort steamship service connecting Martha's Vineyard and Nantucket with the mainland, will be placed on the market here today by an investment banking syndicate headed by the First Boston Corporation and Hayden, Stone Co.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Secretary of State Acheson has informed the Senate Foreign Relations Committee that the United States will not send any of its secret weapons to the European signatories of the North Atlantic pact.

Newspapers were warned yesterday to prepare for an advertising promotion war "of unprecedented scope and intensity." In urging this action at the annual convention of the National Newspaper Promotion Association in the Roosevelt Hotel, Harold V. Manzer, president of the Newspaper Advertising Executives Association, said that the chief danger will be failure to sell newspapers' unrivaled advantages.
WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- A plan to change the system of electing Presidents of the United States was backed today by the National Grange as a way to pick the "best man" for the job.

The forty-six-story Singer building on lower Broadway, one of the city's oldest skyscrapers, was plunged into darkness yesterday by a short circuit and basement fire that put all electrical service out of commission. One man was burned critically, eight persons were rescued from stalled elevators and business for many of the 200 companies in the building was disrupted.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The Government and employers of printers in two unfair labor practice cases argued today before the National Labor Relations Board today that the International Typographical Union (AFL) should be held equally responsible with its locals for failure to bargain in good faith.

Supplies of spring greens are at a new high for the season this week-end. With iceberg lettuce arriving from Arizona in increasingly large shipments, the tariff has dropped 10 cents a head since last Friday. In its survey of retail food prices, the city Department of Markets found most stores offering lettuce for 19 cents.
An independent group of stockholders of the Merritt-Chapman and Scott Corporation said yesterday that it had won its battle for stockholder representation on the company's board of directors.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, April 21 -- Amid scenes of excitement not witnessed here for years the upper chamber of the States General voted today in favor of the minor annexations of German territory as set forth in the Paris protocol of March 26, agreed upon by representatives of the United States, Britain, France, the Netherlands, Belgium and Luxembourg.

Independent furniture stores are stocking more unpainted furniture to bolster lagging sales volume, Frederick S. Hubert, Eastern managing director, National Retail Furniture Association, reported yesterday. He said some stores which have not handled the merchandise up to now are taking it on after noting success of other outlets with it.

Production of Lenox, the oldest brand of fine china in the United States, is at last back to normal. The makers have brought out two new patterns in dinner ware and two stores here are opening new Lenox china departments.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, New York, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering not more than $400,000,000 of ten-year, 3 1/8 per cent, convertible debentures, due on June 20, 1959.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Following is the vote by which the Senate passed the long-range housing bill:

A scanning of the public prints discloses that references to "thought control" appear to be becoming more frequent. Those who are moved to mention the subject seem to be in agreement that it is a topic to be treated with respect, if not awe, but they apparently are not wholly in accord as to the direction from which thought control, on totalitarian lines, may be expected to come -if, that is, it indeed is coming.

A new and simple device with which any doctor can obtain a sample for a test for cancer of the womb in two to three minutes was described yesterday in a report from research workers at the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University.

CHICAGO, April 21 -- With many votes undecided, shareholders of Montgomery Ward Co. will convene tomorrow morning for their annual meeting, the first since the disturbances in the management that began last June and erupted again this month, sweeping out of office an even dozen of the company executives and directors.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 21 -Having checked inflation and brought down the cost of farm products, the French Government must now attempt to lower the prices of industrial goods as the next step in bringing about permanent recovery, Rene Mayer, head of the French delegation to the United Nations General Assembly, said today.

Col. John H. Allen of the Army's Civil Affairs Division yesterday was decorated by the Netherlands Government for being instrumental in restoring to the Dutch more than $17,000,000 worth of valuable materials and diamonds that had been looted by the Germans during the war.

NANKING, April 21 -- The two top Communist leaders -- Mao Tzetung, party chairman, and Gen. Chu Teh, commander in chief of the Communist army -- gave the official go-ahead signal today for an offensive that promises to become the greatest single military operation in modern Chinese history.
Towne Togs, Inc., manufacturer of infants' and children's outer-wear, and Appleman Glass Works, Bergenfield, N. J., clothes dryers and heating panels, to the Stanley-Guerin Company.

An estimated 7,500 New Yorkers paid reverent tribute yesterday to the Rev. Dr. Stephen S. Wise as he lay in state for the second day below the flower-banked altar of the Free Synagogue, 40 West Sixty-eighth Street.

LONDON, April 21 -- Instead of the usual intimate family party, King George VI gave a luncheon today on his elder daughter's twentythird birthday for the Prime Ministers of the British Commonwealth countries, who have assembled here to consider the future relationship of his crown to the Dominion Governments.

WILMINGTON, N. C., April 21 (AP) -- Paul O'Leary, 20-year-old newcomer to pro golf from Bismarck, N. D., shot an eight-under-par 64 today to take the first-round lead in the first $10,000 Wilmington open.

In the five years since Congress enacted legislation designed to aid disabled men and women, 220,000 persons have been rehabilitated into successful employment, Michael J. Shortley, director of the Federal Security Agency's office of vocational rehabilitation, reported last night.
PHILADELPHIA, April 21 (AP) -The Boston Red Sox "walked" to a 4-0 victory over the Philadelphia Athletics today to salvage the series final after dropping the first two.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The first formal round-table discussion of motion-picture production problems on an international scale were begun here today when the joint Anglo-American Film Council, organized two years ago, met for the first time.

SALONIKA, Greece, April 21 -- After deliberating three hours the jury hearing the case of the killing of George Polk, American radio correspondent, gave a finding today of guilty of complicity before and after the fact, against Gregory Stachtopoulos, Greek Leftist newspaper man.

" IT'S not as easy to make a living by writing as most people think," says Kenneth Roberts in "I Wanted to Write."* And then a few lines lower on the same page he tells how The Saturday Evening Post bought the first short story he ever wrote for $500. Although Mr. Roberts is no paragon of consistency, he is not so inconsistent as this particular paradox might

Declaring that the Republican party "cannot get back into power unless it leads the fight on vital social questions," Edward Corsi, State Industrial Commissioner, yesterday called for a "debate within the party in advance of 1952."

The Public Service Commission has authorized Bee Line, Inc., to increase fares on its bus service in Nassau County by 20 per cent, except on the route between Freeport and Jones Beach, which is operated only during the summer, it was announced yesterday.

After declines in early trading, coffee futures rallied sharply and continued strong on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Demand from local trade interests, and scattered short-covering advanced prices for contract "S" 10 to 29 points. There also was support from producer interests.

Seeking to carry good garment business through the balance of the spring season, retailers are pressing for quick delivery of promotional types of low-end and popular price dresses, it was learned yesterday. Resident offices and manufacturers reported a growing volume of orders for May delivery with some items being accepted for June as well.

SALEM, N. Y., April 21 -- After considerable creeping and crawling in the process of stalking several woodchucks, we arrived at the conclusion that one man's "zero" is another man's "clean miss" when it comes to sighting in a woodchuck rifle.

PRAGUE, April 21 -- Miltiades Porphyrogenis, Communist leader and Minister of Justice of the "Democratic Government of Free Greece," predicted here today that the Greek guerrillas' "Democratic Army would in 1949 score successes as decisive for ultimate victory as those scored by Mao Tzetung in China in 1948."
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- President Truman announced today that he was appointing David K. E. Bruce of Virginia as Ambassador to France to succeed Jefferson Caffery.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Department store sales in the week ended April 16 were 7 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. Percentage changes from like periods of 1948 follow:

PRAGUE, April 21 -- Miltiades Porphyrogenis, Communist leader and Minister of Justice of the "Democratic Government of Free Greece," predicted here today that the Greek guerrillas' "Democratic Army would in 1949 score successes as decisive for ultimate victory as those scored by Mao Tzetung in China in 1948."
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- President Truman announced today that he was appointing David K. E. Bruce of Virginia as Ambassador to France to succeed Jefferson Caffery.
LONDON, April 21 -- Further gains were scored by British Government bonds as a result of a steady investment demand in the stock market here today. Gains up to a half-point were made.

The third annual Seton Hall relay carnival will get under way today at Newark City Stadium. Twenty-five events, involving high, prep, junior high and grammar schools, comprise the program, which will start at 3 P. M. The meet's college phase and additional schoolboy races are scheduled for tomorrow.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 21 -- The Soviet bloc today adopted stalling tactics to delay a final vote by the United Nations Ad Hoc Political Committee on the issue of alleged human rights violations in the Hungarian and Bulgarian political trials.

Last year the New York City Cancer Committee granted funds to help operate twelve detection and prevention centers where New Yorkers without apparent cancer symptoms could obtain a thorough examination at moderate cost.

The report by Dr. Philip S. Hench and Dr. Edward C. Kendall from the Mayo Clinic yesterday on the discovery of Compound E is heartening news to the seven million persons in this country who suffer from arthritis.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- President Truman told a group of Protestant editors today that it was impossible for him to attend church every Sunday because of the burdens of his office, but when he did attend "the church treats me just the way I want to be treated."

Taking matters into their own hands and with a free rein from adult advisers, teen-age school children of Greenwich Village have banded together to combat delinquency and to erase religious and racial barriers between youngsters in their area.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill, April 21 -- Chancellor Robert M. Hutchins of the University of Chicago today told the Illinois Seditious Activities Investigation Commission that there was no subversive activity at the university.

DETROIT, April 21 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox scored their first victory of the American League campaign today as they slowed down rookie outfielder Johnny Groth and the Detroit Tigers with a 5 -- 2 decision.

The Oratorio Society of New York has been functioning for seventy-six seasons, and it does not see any need to change its ways much. At Christmas time it has been doing "The Messiah" by Handel for many, many years, said at Easter time it presents a complete performance of Bach's B minor Mass. Last night's presentation of the full iVfass at Carnegie Hall was the s.ociety's twenty-third.

The people of Holland are at a loss to understand the attitude of the United States on the question of Indonesia. They are more than bewildered to see her siding with Russia in thwarting Holland and insisting on re-establishing in Java a so-called government of corrupt and incompetent leaders who during the Japanese occupation had acted as collaborators.

FLANKFORT, Germany, April 21 -- The American and British Military Governments have turned down for a second time a request of the German bizonal administration for official participation in the shaping of a civil aviation program for Germany.

Federal Judge Samuel H. Kaufman adjourned yesterday until May 2 the hearing on a petition by three bondholders in the Third Avenue Transit Corporation for its reorganization under the Federal Bankruptcy Act. He directed attorneys for the bondholders to bring into court at that time a complete record of dealings with the company's securities by two of the petitioners, their companies and their families.

PARIS, April 21 -- A new poster appeared today on the walls and palings of the French capital to vie for attention with Pablo Picasso's dove announcing the World Congress of the Partisans of Peace. It proclaims an international day of resistance to dictatorship and war on April 30.

PARIS, April 21 -- The torrent of oratory aimed at the so-called capitalistic warmongers and the Governments of the West went on today before the second day's audience of the World Congress of the Partisans of Peace in the Salle Pleyel.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Labor must play an important role in the problems affecting the future utilization of the German coal, iron and steel industries, Maurice J. Tobin, Secretary of Labor, declared tonight at a dinner for the Central Committee of the International Metal Workers Federation.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The State Department announced today that it would consult with the "interested signatories" to the peace treaties with Hungary, Rumania and Bulgaria. The action will be taken with a view to undertaking "further appropriate action" regarding violation of the human rights clauses of the treaties by those countries through their religious and political persecutions.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- President Truman will spell out this national health program tomorrow in a special message to Congress calling for compulsory insurance and six other measures that would cost billions. He told his news conference today that he was considering making a radio address to persuade Congress that every gainfully-employed person should be covered by government insurance to meet the medical, dental and hospital expenses of his family.
ALBANY, April 21 -- Four bills designed to tighten adoption procedures to eliminate the black market for babies received Governor Dewey's approval today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 21 -- Yugoslav propaganda services accused the Czech Government today of having delivered large quanties of strategic materials to the "Monarcho-Fascist" Government of Athens, thereby aiding and abetting the fight against "the Greek Democratic Army."

DETROIT, April 21 -- Two University of Chicago physicians reported today to the Federation of American Societies for Experimental Biology that they had succeeded in keeping part of an animal's brain alive outside its body to permit study of the functions of the nervous system.
HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 21 (AP) -- Mrs. Helen K. Haggerty's Rampart won the Conowingo Purse by a length and a half today from Pilaster, the favorite, before 9,154 fans.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- A banking expert in airline financing told a Senate Commerce subcommittee today that Government subsidy policies for the airlines frightened away investors, thereby complicating an already serious situation.
Mayor O'Dwyer demanded yesterday there be no more "talk" about beach pollution now that the city's four-year, $95,000,000 sanitation program was underway.
The George Foster Peabody Radio Awards were presented yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Radio Executives Club of New York held at the Hotel Roosevelt.

A new catechism, setting forth the teachings of the Roman Catholic Church in a modern world, was made public yesterday. It was the first major revision in sixty years, but it carries the same doctrines the church has taught for centuries.

Bernard Baruch considers the study of economics, ethics, logic and philosophy of "great importance" for business men and those preparing for a business career, he told students of the City College School of Business Administration yesterday when they made him honorary editor-in-chief of the undergraduate day session's weekly newspaper, The Ticker.

PARIS, April 21 -- The appointment of David K. E. Bruce as Am bassador to France to succeed Jefferson Caffery was received with satisfaction today in official circles which hitherto had declined to confirm reports that this change was impending.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on April 16, 1949, totaled 765,890 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 8,106 cars, or 1.1 per cent, more than for the preceding week, 18,721 cars, or 2.4 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week last year and 99,954 cars, or 11.5 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week two years ago.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Hoyt Haddock, executive secretary of the CIO Maritime Committee here, charged today that "Italy had enough passenger ships of her own" and that she should not receive additional ships under the Marshall Plan.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The Administration's $1,130,000,000 program of military aid to North Atlantic pact countries went under careful, but not hostile, Senatorial scrutiny today.

BALTIMORE, April 22 (AP) -- Carroll B. Huntress, vice president of the Republic Coal and Coke Company, called tonight for a "head-on" countering of what he termed the movement toward public ownership of electric power utilities.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 22 (AP) -- Five scientists and two pilots were found dead today in the wreckage of an airplane which crashed in the Sierra Nevada Feb. 3.

SHANGHAI, Saturday, April 23 -- Nationalist forces abandoned their capital of Nanking to the advancing Communist armies today and the Communists sent word they would cross the Yangtze in force and enter Nanking at 7 A. M. Sunday (6 P. M. Saturday EST).

Msgr. Francis P. Connelly, pastor of Our Lady of Refuge Roman Catholic Church, Ocean and Foster Avenues, Flatbush, Brooklyn, and director of Holy Name Societies in the Brooklyn Roman Catholic Diocese, will celebrate the forty-fifth anniversary of his ordination tomorrow.

A Federal statutory court reserved decision yesterday after the completion of arguments on the Government's request for a decree requiring three major motion picture companies to divorce their production - distribution activities from their theatre-owning business.

Recent reports in THE TIMES about the resurgent German nationalism in connection with the depressing influx of ten to thirteen million unabsorbed expellees or Volksdeutsche make it clear beyond doubt that Germany and the democratization of the German people is still our problem.

Twice a year a short, bespectacled man in tweeds leaves the Howard Clock Sales and Service Corporation at 132 West Broadway on a tour of duty that has earned for him the cognomen of "Father Time." He is Walter Humphrey, chief clock turner whose duties herald the advent and departure of daylight saving time.
MOSCOW, April 22 -- Moscow's savings banks are booming, the Soviet press reports, with deposits increased by 340,000,000 rubles from January, 1948, to April 1, 1949.

"THE visitor who discusses Italy and the world in a typically Florentine setting of great art and enchanting nature that Bernard Berenson presides over with such wit and grace," Anne O'Hare McCormick wrote in a dispatch to this paper from Florence last winter, "begins to recover a lost sense of proportion and discern the permanent behind the transitory."
A Queens church group announced yesterday that it had made its own test of the parable of the talents -- and come out with a profit of almost 1,000 per cent.

ST. LOUIS, April 22 (AP) -- A four-hit pitching job by Al Brazle and a long-distance hitting spree by his mates gave the St. Louis Cardinals a 9-2 verdict over the Chicago Cubs today for their first victory of the season.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -- 4 five-month downward slide in basic living costs was reversed last month, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- James M. Landis, former chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, told a Senate committee today that there are too many airlines. The system needs to be revamped, he said and a new basis of rate-making devised, based on routes and not on company-wide systems.
Under a dripping gray sky the Giants opened the 1949 National League season at the Polo Grounds yesterday, but something more than rain splashed over the plate.
HALIFAX, N. S., April 22 (Canadian Press) -- The Canadian deep-sea strike had repercussions in courts on three continents today but all was quiet on waterfronts at home.
Visitations to 200,000 prisoners in 1,200 penal institutions all over the country will be made tomorrow by members of the Salvation Army on its thirty-fourth annual Prison Sunday.

NANKING, Saturday, April 23 (AP) -- This tottering capital of Nationalist China was abandoned by its officials and its garrison today as Communist troops smashed across the river and landed near Nanking's railroad station, just outside the city's walls.

Credit another triumph to the Ballet Theatre, for its "Giselle" at the Metropolitan Opera House last night with Nana Gollner, Igor Youskevitch and Diana Adams was no less than that. Apparently this hackneyed, sentimental, rich and wonderful old work responds whenever there is anybody around to treat it with respect and affection.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, April 22 (AP) -- A plan to lease the Struthers Iron and Steel Company's old blast furnace to the General Motors Corporation for $200,000 a year was blocked here today by a temporary injunction granted in Common Pleas Court to a Struthers minority stockholder.

Lumber production for the week ended April 16 was 1.9 per cent above the like week last year, according to reports wired yesterday to THE NEW YORK TIMES by trade associations. Shipments were 5.3 per cent above last year and orders were down 7.3 per cent.

CHICAGO, April 22 -- A warning that "Israel must cease and desist in its efforts to establish itself on a world-wide 'Jewish' nationalism that is shattering the basis of our American national integration" was voiced here today by Lessing J. Rosenwald of Jenkintown, Pa., president of the American Council for Judaism.

Prices on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday recovered most of their early losses and final quotations were only irregularly lower for the day. Only a handful of issues showed net changes for the session of a point or more. The close was at or near the best for the day.

Walter Cartier, Greenwich Village middleweight, scored a knockout victory over Vinnie Cidone of Coney Island in the scheduled 10-round feature bout at the St. Nicholas arena last night. The end came in 1:18 of the first round when Referee Eddie Joseph halted the action after Cidone had gone to the canvas the fourth time.

For the third successive day, collectors, dealers and museum representatives vied with each other yesterday for art objects from the Joseph Brummer collection, on sale at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.

The number of state and local mental hygiene groups in the United States has almost doubled in the last year, Marian McBee, director of the division of state and local organizations for the National Committee for Mental Hygiene, disclosed yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, April 22 -- The National Catholic Educational Association, in a resolution adopted at the closing session of its forty-sixth annual convention, applied today to the Federal Government for financial support of parochial schools.

LONDON, April 22 -- Such progress was made today at the first plenary session of the British Commonwealth Prime Ministers in London that a decision on India's future status in the Commonwealth already was taking shape.
PINEHURST, N. C., April 22 (AP) -- Harvie Ward and Frank Stranahan today gained the final of the North and South amateur golf tournament for the second successive year.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 22 -- By a narrow margin, the Social Committee of the General Assembly today rejected a Mexican proposal to write into a proposed convention on news-gathering a requirement that the press accept corrections from foreign governments.

Securities dealers face a schedule of varied and moderately heavy marketing next week, with underwriters carrying over their heaviest inventory of unsold new corporate securities in a long while. The float is estimated at about $100,000,000, apart from $36,000,000 of railroad equipment-trust serials.

Fred W. Hooper's Olympia, foaled three years ago on April 23, goes after the price of a flock of birthday parties today. The Kentucky Derby favorite has the chance to pick up $31,850 in the silver anniversary running of the $40,000 added Wood Memorial at Old Jamaica.

PARIS, April 22 --The lifting of the Berlin blockade, should it take place, would open the way for a resumption of four-power talks on Germany but would not imply a cancellation of or postponement in the application of the Washington accords, Foreign Minister Robert Schuman told a press conference today.

Objections to S. 1008, the Delivered Pricing Moratorium Bill, as revised by the Judiciary sub-committee and reported to the full committee, have been filed with the Senate Judiciary Committee by W. A. Quinlan, general counsel of he United States Wholesale Grocers' Association.

DETROIT, April 22 -- Union workers have voted overwhelmingly in favor of an immediate strike against the Ford Motor Company to enforce modification of an alleged speed-up at the huge River Rouge plant.
If the nation is to survive, former President Herbert Hoover said last night, no new special projects no matter how worthy should be undertaken until "the cold war" is ended.

The members of the Republican County Committee of the Twentieth Congressional District last night nominated William H. McIntyre, veteran of the first World War and supervisor of claims of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, as a candidate for Representative at the special election on May 17.

The Equity Library Theatre, now in its sixth season of play production, has merited the warm applause of all those who have enjoyed its presentations. The ELT was established in order to give professional actors who were not working a chance to practice their trade.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Senate and House fiscal leaders tentatively approved today a proposal for repeal of the law requiring Congress to make its own advance estimates of Government expenditures and receipts each year.

RICHMOND, Va., April 22 -- The old admonition that expectant mothers should "think beautiful thoughts" may not have been so far off, a research physiologist indicated here today in a talk before a conference of educators, child specialists, psychologists and physicians.

The waterfront "public loader mystery" moved one step closer to solution yesterday. Leaders in the shipping industry signified their compliance with a request of Commissioner of Investigation John M. Murtagh that the companies themselves take over and regulate public loaders on the piers as the first step in the port's drive against waterfront racketeering.
Sample orders in excess of $1,000,000 have already been placed by trade buyers at the Military Government German Industry Exhibit at 30 Rockefeller Plaza, officials of the fair reported yesterday.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, April 22 -- The Governor General of South Africa, Maj. Gideon Brand van Zyl, gave formal assent today to the South-West Africa Affairs Bill, which, in the view of the Government here, ends the mandate over the former German colony entrusted to South Africa by the League of Nations.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., April 22 -One-third of all cases of high blood pressure among business men result from emotional upsets and could easily be avoided, Dr. Oscar B. Anderson, chairman of the Psychology Department of Adelphi College, declared here today.

LONDON, April 22 -- Viscount Hall, First Lord of the Admiralty, said today that the attacks on British naval vessels in the Yangtze had been "deliberately carried out, for what purpose we have yet to learn."

BERLIN, April 22 -- The withdrawal of all occupation troops from Germany will be demanded at the forthcoming meeting of the Communist - dominated People's Congress in Berlin, Wilhelm Koenen, chairman of the People's Council Secretariat, announced tonight at a meeting in the Soviet sector of the city.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 22 -- The collapse late last night of the deal for the Nasser brothers to buy the United Artists Distributing Company was attributed today to last-minute restriction of bank credits which were to have implemented the purchase.
WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -A new Agriculture Department order is aimed at keeping all traces of DDT out of the United States milk supply.

Tomorrow evening at the Waldorf-Astoria, the American Theatre Wing will present the third annual set of Antoinette Perry Awards to twelve of the theatre's elect for outstanding contributions to the current theatrical season.

If one judges by the number of Chinese restaurants in the city, New Yorkers find the Oriental cuisine just about the most popular of the foreign foods. Our readers, too, are continually asking us how to do fried rice, shrimps with lobster sauce, won ton soup, etc.

Department store dollar volume in fair-traded and nationally advertised silver plated flatware and holloware has decreased substantially in the first quarter, a department store executive reported yesterday. He said the decline is due almost entirely to free supply of this type plated ware in so-called discount houses which cut fair trade prices.

FRANKFORT, Germany, April 22 -- United States Military Government public safety officials heard today a detailed report belittling the effectiveness of the Soviet zone police force as a military potential. This force was recently organized by the Russians, and for a while there was wide speculation about it as a Communist-led German "army."

A new sewage sedimentation and chlorination system is under construction at Sea Gate, Coney Island, to help purify the beach watters in that area, Adolph N. Weiss. secretary of the Sea Gate Association, announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, April 22 -- Sewell L. Avery was re-elected a director of Montgomery Ward Co. today by the largest vote cast for any of the four nominees, Mr. Avery received this decisive vote despite the open opposition of a number of large stockholders who pointedly withheld their support from him.

SHANGHAI, April 22 -- The ordeal of the British escort vessel Amethyst, trapped on the Yangtze by the Communist advance, continued today with no apparent hope of relief. She buried seventeen of her dead in the murky Yangtze after a plane carrying a clergyman for the burial service was damaged by gunfire.
IRWIN, Pa., April 22 (AP) -- Big trucks lined several Pennsylvania highways today in sporadic "park-downs" by truckers protesting the state's weigh limits. Many were on the Pennsylvania Turnpike.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The Navy is issuing film "badges" to all personnel working in range of atomic radiation and other forms of radioactivity in a move to detect and measure the degree of exposure to the potentially dangerous rays, it was announced today.

Three men and three women were indicted by a special Federal grand jury yesterday on ten counts charging them with diverting 6,000,000 pounds of rationed sugar to the black market in 1946 and early 1947 at a profit of $500,000.

Provided no more downpours mar the weatherman's schedule for the next couple of days, the fly fisherman should have his first really good session of the season this week-end on the New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and Pennsylvania streams.

In a final business session of a three-day annual meeting in the Roosevelt Hotel, the National Newspaper Promotion Association yesterday elected Frederick N. Lowe, promotion manager of The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette, as its new president.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Czechoslovak commercial delegation has been here for several days, it was learned today, with the view of negotiating with the United States for credits, a commercial agreement and a settlement for United States properties that have been nationalized in Czechoslovakia.

The Government's attempt to force the Aluminum Company of America to divest itself of some of its holdings suffered a severe setback yesterday when Henry J. Kaiser testified in Federal Court that his Permanente Metals Corporation, a relative newcomer to the aluminum field, was not afraid of Alcoa's competition.

High-ranking British experts in international tournament at the Easter Chess Festival at Southsea, England, fared well in play yesterday, according to a report from London. Their aim is the Southern Counties Chess Union championship, which will go to the player with the best total among the natives.

Today's newcomer at the Little Carnegie is "Miranda," a J. Arthur Rank comedy-fantasy with Glynis Johns in the role, supported by Griffith Jones, Googie Withers, John McCallum and Margaret Rutherford. Ken Annakin directed Peter Blackmore's scenario of his own play of the same name, Betty Box produced and Eagle Lion is handling the American distribution of the film.
CHICAGO, April 22 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox fashioned a four-run fourth inning, including Gus Zernial's homer, for a 5-2 home opener victory over the St. Louis Browns before 9,568 fans today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 22 -- Directors of the St. Benedict Center, blacklisted - Roman Catholic forum institution, appealed today to Pope Pius XII for "an ex cathedra pronouncement" on the church's new catechism. They held that parts of it contradicted basic dogma.

An account of what happened to Tuscany and its art treasures during the Italian campaign will be issued on May 2 by Princeton University Press, entitled "Florentine Art Under Fire." The author, Frederick Hartt, served in Tuscany as regional Monuments and Fine Arts Officer.

"We shall enact comprehensive housing legislation, including provisions for slum clearance and low-rent housing projects initiated by local agencies. This nation is shamed by the failure of the Republican Eightieth Congress to pass the vitally needed general housing legislation as recommended by the President."

MIAMI, Fla., April 22 -- A neatly kept home of a 74-year-old spinster who died Monday "without friends or relatives" contained almost $100,000, and more probably is hidden away in its furnishings, court officials reported today.

The eightieth anniversary of the Fulton Market Fishmongers Association was celebrated yesterday, at a luncheon in Sloppy Louie's Restaurant on South Street. There was little speechmaking, plenty of fish.

International law gives belligerents in war superior rights over neutrals who venture into the fighting area. It would be easy to cite passages applicable to the incidents on the Yangtze River which began Wednesday when the Chinese Communists fired on the British sloop Amethyst, and which have resulted in the deaths of at least forty-four men and injuries to at least eighty-two others.

Confident that the New York Harness Racing Commission will come through with the necessary license, the Algam Corporation announced yesterday it was going ahead with plans to conduct the sport next year at the Empire City track.
The proposed huge new convention hall, sports arena and 2,000-car parking garage at Columbus Circle has been "put on the shelf" for an indefinite period, it was disclosed last night.

The five-story town house in early French Renaissance style at 5 East Sixty-seventh Street, near Fifth Avenue, was sold by the estate of Mrs. Arthur R. Lippincott to a buyer for occupancy in a transaction reported yesterday by Pease Elliman, the brokers in the deal.

SHANGHAI, April 22 -- Probably the deciding factor that turned back the British heavy cruiser London yesterday in her thrust up the Yangtze was the silencing of her eight-inch gun turrets by United States-made anti-tank guns.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Potato price supports, to date, for the 1948 crop, have cost the Federal Government more than $200,000,000, Charles F. Brannan, Secretary of Agriculture, disclosed in a report issued today.

Progress is being made in developing the first national sample of performance standards for manual work in industrial production, Herbert A. Lynch, project engineer of New York University College of Engineering, declared yesterday. He addressed more than 900 members of the Society for the Advancement of Management yesterday at the Statler Hotel.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -- Top officials of wireless, cable and telegraph companies talked with Senator Ernest W. McFarland, Democrat of Arizona, today about the need for legislation to permit mergers within the industry. Mr. McFarland is chairman of a commerce subcommittee which is to make a broad inquiry into the whole communications field.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -- A demand that the American Society of Newspaper Editors arbitrarily bar any unworthy journalists from its ranks was made today.

Two defense witnesses in the Coast Guard hearing into misconduct charges against twenty-three members of the crew of the freighter Flying Arrow testified yesterday to receiving beatings at the hands of the vessel's second assistant engineer, Jean A. Brown. The ship is owned and operated by Isbrandtsen Company, Inc., of 26 Broadway.

James J. Norris, European director of War Relief Services, National Catholic Welfare Conference, said yesterday that America had become aware of the national problem of displaced persons, particularly the 12,000,000 now seeking relief in Germany.

NEWARK, N. J., April 22 -Bishop Loughlin High School and it Brooklyn neighbor, Boys High, carried off top honors as the third annual Seton Hall College Relays got under way in rainswept Newark City School Stadium today.

The NBC television network, from 5 to 5:30 P. M. next Wednesday, will offer a special program from Washington designed to test the practicability of using television in the field of social studies at the high school level. The experiment telecast will attempt to explain, in turn, the legislative, executive and judicial branches of the Federal Government.

Bronislav Gimpel, who has given three recitals in this city during the past decade, appeared last night at Carnegie Hall in a series of three concertos, which he performed with an orchestra of forty-five pieces. He also was announced on the printed program as conductor of these works, which consisted of the Mozart Concerto in A major, and the Beethoven and Mendelssohn examples in the category.

ANNECY, France, April 22 -- The Colombian delegation to the Annecy trade conference announced today that a customs union incorporating Colombia, Panama, Venezuela and Ecuador was in the process of formation.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Investors and builders attending a conference called by the Department of Commerce in the interest of the Negro in business were told today by an official of the Federal Housing Administration that the biggest obstacle to housing for Negroes throughout the country was community prejudice against "little people, no matter what race or color."

After early advances of about 30 to 35 points, coffee futures prices declined sharply on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Final prices in the contract "S" were 20 to 29 points lower. Contract "D" also eased off after early steadiness in thin volume. At the close, prices were 15 to 19 points lower.
WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture says farmers should hold down their 1949 acreage because of a heavy pile-up of stocks of flaxseed and linseed oil.

Some of the Senatorial criticism of the Justice Department's new "spy bill" is well taken. The measure upon which hearings are now being held before a Senate Judiciary sub-committee has a laudable purpose; it is intended to strengthen the laws against espionage and sabotage and thus "to enhance further the security of the United States."

Great advantages in furthering the peacetime benefits of atomic power would result from international agreements, under which only low-level nuclear reactors of the type used in the production of radio-isotopes would be constructed for the next thirty years.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Paul Reynaud, the French war-time Premier who is now on a visit to this country, discussed today the recent incursion of Chinese Communist troops into Indo-China and their repulse by French troops.

Other unions in New York's brewing industry were reported ready yesterday to join in mediation efforts under the auspices of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation service to end the twenty-two-day walkout of 6,000 workers in eleven breweries.
Investigators of the strange slaying Thursday morning of John Garris, Metropolitan Opera tenor in Atlanta, Ga., arrived here yesterday and questioned several friends of the singer.

Air Force Reserve training centers will receive more tactical equipment than ever before if the Bureau of the Budget approves the new $80,000,000 program now under consideration, it was disclosed last night.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -- President Truman appealed to Congress anew today for a system of compulsory insurance to meet everyone's medical, dental and hospital expenses.

Husky Ed Funai of N. Y. U. blanked Colgate for five and two-thirds innings yesterday at Ohio Field, then Dave Busfield lined a triple to deep left field to end the hurler's no-hit effort. But the Violets began another winning streak by defeating the Red Raiders, 3 -- 1, for Funai's third victory against no losses. Rain halted the game after six and a half innings.
One of the most characteristic and outstanding features of the American way of life has been the development of cooperation between antagonists in the field of politics.

In an expansion move, the Bilkays Express Company have acquired title to the unimproved plot at 345-57 Thomas Street, Newark, N. J., from the United Advertising Corporation. The property, measuring 174 by 104 feet, adjoins the truck terminal of the express firm, and will be used for storing trucks, according to Leslie Blau, broker in the transaction.

FORT LEAVENWORTH, Kans., April 22 -- The formation of the Senior Reserve Commanders Association of the Army of the United States was announced here today, following a meeting Tuesday night of division commanders and staff officers representing twenty-five combat divisons of the Organized Reserve.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- General Douglas MacArthur, Supreme Commander for the Allied Powers in Tokyo, today fixed an official exchange rate of 360 Japanese yen to the dollar, to become effective April 25.

HOUSTON, Tex., April 22 (AP) -- Two San Francisco players upset the national champion, Richard (Pancho) Gonzales, and the Wimbledon titlist, Bob Falkenburg, today in the quarter-finals of the fifteenth River Oaks tennis tournament.

The crossing of the Yangtze by the Communists, coinciding with the shelling of British ships, brings into focus the vast, amorphous struggle reaching its climax in China. We see at last the Chinese situation as it is. Heretofore, except on the West Coast, the Chinese war has seemed remote and vague to most Americans.
BONN, Germany, April 22 (AP) -- The Western Allies yielded a bit today in their stand on what the proposed new West German constitution must provide.

Negotiations between Macy's and Local 1-S, independent, representing 7,500 store workers, were broken off yesterday by the union, which immediately called a "mobilization meeting" of key personnel for next Wednesday.

WILMINGTON, N. C., April 22 (AP) -- Paul O'Leary of Bismarck, N. D., faltered in the rain and wind today but shot a 2-under-par 70 that kept him in front in the $10,000 Wilmington open golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, said today at the close of a two-day conference with representatives of state and city governments on "Taxation Problems of Mutual Concern," that the views expressed would receive the immediate attention of the Treasury.

The International Business Machines Corporation and its subsidiaries, for the three months ended March 31, reported yesterday a net income of $12,888,310 before provision for United States and Canadian income taxes. This compared with $11,038,281 for the corresponding 1948 period.

A funeral service for the Rov. Dr. Stephen S. Wise, founder and rabbi of the Free Synagogue, was held yesterday in Carnegie Hall, where 18,000 persons jammed the auditorium and the surrounding streets to pay a final tribute to the Jewish leader.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The Federal Reserve Board announced today that, effective April 27, installment credit regulations would be relaxed further. The time limit for completing installment purchases will be increased from twenty-one to twenty-four months and the down payment, on everything but automobiles, will be cut from 15 to 10 per cent.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 22 -- Switzerland has denounced all commercial agreements with the United States, British and French zones of Germany, effective April 30, it was announced here today. At the same time, Swiss spokesmen indicated that talks looking toward new agreements would open in Frankfort on May 2.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 22 -- The Arab League faces a major crisis as a result of the Syrian coup, a reliable Arab source here declared tonight.
WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -- Congressional hearings on a proposed long-range program for the rehabilitation of the Navajo and Hopi Indians of the Southwest virtually were concluded today.

PARIS, April 22 -- Orders of the French Government tonight forbidding street demonstrations provoked angry protests from delegates to the current World Congress of Partisans of Peace, who thus indicated they had planned a parade in connection with the mass meeting they have set for Sunday.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Loyalty Day parades and other ceremonies to rival the traditional Communist May Day demonstrations have been arranged in at least five cities, leaders of a new country-wide movement announced here today.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 22 -- The United Nations Ad Hoc Political Committee adopted today by a vote of 34 to 6 a Bolivian resolution noting with deep concern accusations that Hungary and Bulgaria had violated human rights in the recent religious trials.

ROME, April 22 -- The Vatican newspaper Osservatore Romano, in an editorial to be published tomorrow, will warn Catholics that the World Congress of the Partisans of Peace being held in Paris is another Moscow-inspired maneuver to undermine the solidarity of the Western nations as part of Soviet plans for the domination of Europe.

Liquor commissioners from seventeen states which operate their own liquor stores (excluding Wyoming which only distributes) declared yesterday that resistance to prices is growing but high taxes block price cuts that would relieve the situation.

ALBANY, April 22 -- The Board of Regents voted today to set up a special committee to devise means to implement provisions of the Feinberg Law that requires the board to purge the school system of teachers with subversive leanings.
WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -- Carl Scheib limited Washington to four hits tonight as the Athletics injected two of their five hits into a two-run first inning to defeat the Senators, 2 -- 0.

The New York City Housing Authority received bids yesterday on issues of temporary loan notes totaling $31,611,000 for the financing of the Gowanus Houses and the Albany Houses in Brooklyn, and the Bronx River Houses, in the Bronx, three state-aided projects.

Women still are "on the lowest rung of the political ladder" in this country, Mrs. Anne X. Alpern, city solicitor of Pittsburgh, declared yesterday at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street.

With more major bridge construction and reconstruction under way now than at any time in the city's history, New York is rapidly hitting its stride in building and enlarging these facilities, Frederick H. Zurmuhlen, Commissioner of Public Works, announced yesterday.

HAMBURG, Germany, April 22 -- German shipbuilders and owners of shipping lines have greeted with mixed reactions the agreement among the Military Governors of the three Western zones that relaxes in part existing limitations on shipbuilding activities.

The Standard Oil Company of Indiana has borrowed $50,000,000 from thirteen investing institutions on 2.90 per cent notes due on April 1, 1979, Dr. Robert Wilson, chairman of the board, announced yesterday. The notes are repayable in fifteen equal annual installments starting April 1, 1965. Morgan, Stanley Co. arranged the loan.

Seven months ago the President appointed a special commission, headed by William H. Davis, to recommend procedure for the settlement of labor disputes in the Government's atomic energy plants. The Commission's proposals, which have now been submitted to the President, follow the general philosophy of the Railway Labor Act of 1926.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Prospects for a renewal of cordial trade relations between the American and British motion-picture industries loomed brighter today than at any time in the last two years after two days of "frank" conversation by the six-man committee that comprises the Joint Anglo-American Film Council.

ROME, April 22 -- The Cabinet Council made a special point, after a meeting today, of announcing its confidence in Foreign Minister Count Carlo Sforza, who has been the target of attacks in the press for his failure to reach a satisfactory solution of the Italian colonial problem.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The Daughters of the American Revolution in a resolution of thanks to President Truman today pledged "to use our strength and influence to combat the forces of Socialistic planning invading our country."

BOSTON, April 22 -- Casey Stengel employed his special Fenway Park line-up this afternoon. It was loaded with right-handed batters, even against the right-handed starter, Tex Hughson, and was intended to take advantage of the near-by left field wall.
WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -- The text of President Truman's message to Congress today on health insurance follows:

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Senate Armed Services subcommittee investigating United States military justice in the Malmedy cases interrogated key figures today against the background of an eyewitness story told unemotionally by a survivor of the Nazi massacre of United States prisoners of war from the Battle of the Bulge.
The Swedish American liner Stockholm, trim from stem to stern after a ten-day overhaul in a Goeteborg shipyard, docked at Pier 97 North River yesterday with 321 passengers.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 22 -- Usually well-informed sources said today they understood that Jacob A. Malik, Soviet representative to the United Nations, recently had made a preliminary approach to a United States representative here with regard to the possibility of raising the Soviet blockade of Berlin.

MOBILE, Ala., April 22 -- Capital investment by the natural gas industry within the next five years will amount to $3,300,000,000. Wister H Ligon of Nashville, Tenn., president of the Southern Gas Association, announced at Biloxi, Miss., last night at the association's convention.

LOS ANGELES, April 22 -- Although there is a notorious entertainment industry in the wide Los Angeles area that overshadows normal culture, the theatre looks after its own clients satisfactorily. The fabulous Lunts have just been experimenting with S. N. Behrman's "I Know My Love" to the contentment of the general public, nimbly reassorting the time sequence of the plot from performance to performance in an effort to discover the most effective formula.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The Administration is working feverishly on a new series of amendments to its labor relations bill because confidential reports indicate that the Thomas-Lesinski bill cannot be passed in its present form.

One of the gravest problems confronting weekly and semi-weekly newspapers is the Post Office bill before Congress, which would increase second class mail rates from three to seven times, it was reported yesterday at the annual spring meeting of the National Editorial Association at the Statler Hotel.
Mayor O'Dwyer accepted yesterday "with deep reluctance and regret" the resignation submitted on April 6 by Abe Stark, commissioner of the city's Department of Commerce.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., April 22 -- Calling for a clear-cut policy on academic freedom and greater job security," members of the campus chapter of the American Association of University Professors today charged "incredible ineptness" and "lack of vigor" in handling administration policies by Rutgers University officials.

ALBANY, April 22 -- A series of bills liberalizing retirement requirements for New York City municipal employes and New York City teachers, particularly veterans, were approved today by Governor Dewey.

TOKYO, April 22 -- The Japanese Government is planning to place a legal curb on the public utility strikes that have been impeding the industrial recovery of the nation, now the No. 1 objective of the Allied occupation.

CHICAGO, April 22 -- Wheat reacted on the Board of Trade here today after showing early strength, and closed 1/4 to 3/4 cent a bushel lower. Corn was 1 1/4 cents lower to 3/8 cent higher; oats, 1/8 cent higher to 1/8 cent lower; rye, 1/4 cent lower to 1/4 cent higher, and soybeans, 1 to 1 3/4 cents lower. Lard finished 5 cents higher to 2 cents lower for 100 pounds.

After hearing charges that the daily double was a contributing cause to juvenile delinquency, Supreme Court Justice John E. McGeehan reserved decision on a motion to declare that form of betting illegal at New York State tracks.

I note that a proposal to broadcast music and commercial plugs on the Staten Island ferry boats is held up only by disagreement over the sponsorship of the commercials; Staten Island "civic" groups, it appears, are fearful of competition from Manhattan advertisers.
America, a national weekly, published by the Jesuit Fathers, strongly defends the action of Archbishop Cushing in "silencing" Father Feeney, also a Jesuit, for his part in the "heresy" dispute.

Daylight time will begin at 2 A. M. tomorrow and everybody's watches and clocks should be ticking an hour ahead of standard time when the public gets up for breakfast. The fast time will continue until the last Sunday in September.

American Communists have planned their revolution for the time when the Soviet Union is ready to invade the United States from Siberia by way of Alaska, Canada and Detroit, according to yesterday's evidence at the Communist trial.
NANKING, Saturday, April 23 -- Nanking was abandoned by civil, military and police authorities this morning, and local Communists took over a railway station outside the north gate.

Today's events: Burl Ives, ballad singer, Town Hall, 3 o'clock; Willem Van Den Andel, piano, Town Hall, 5:30; Levinia Darve, soprano; Maria Rosy-Leyritz, piano; Irene Elliot, mezzo-soprano, Carl Fischer Hall, 5:30.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Average primary market commodity prices declined 0.4 per cent in the week ended April 19, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index was 156.9 per cent of the 1926 average, 0.8 per cent lower than four weeks ago and 4.8 per cent lower than the comparable week in 1948. No major group advanced over the week.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Foy D. Kohler, charge d'affaires of the American Embassy in Moscow, was appointed today chief of the international broadcasting division of the State Department's Office of International Information. In that capacity he will have charge of the programs of the Voice of America with headquarters in New York.

TEL AVIV, Israel, April 22 -- Israel is about to launch an austerity program in connection with her four-year reconstruction plans. There is little doubt that Premier David Ben-Gurion, who is relinquishing his post as Minister of Defense, will head the economic board that has been proposed.
CAMDEN, N. J., April 22 -- Fisticuffs marked the strike at the Rice Holman automobile plant in Suburban Pennsauken here today.

HOBOKEN, N. J., April 22 -- Municipal officials and representatives of business and industry here presented their arguments today for the sale or lease of four Government-owned piers to the city. They appeared at an informal hearing by four members of the United States Maritime Commission at the City Hall.

CLEVELAND, April 22 (AP) -- Mickey Vernon celebrated his thirty-first birthday today with a tenth-inning single that gave the world champion Cleveland Indians a 4-to-3 victory over the Detroit Tigers before a home opening-day crowd of 63,725.

VIENNA, April 22 -- After privately putting their case for the lessening of the occupation burden on Austria before Samuel Reber and Marcel Berthelot, United States and French delegates to the Austrian treaty conference in London, leaders of the Austrian Socialist party today demanded amendment of the Austrian control agreement to this end.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Ambassador Robert D. Murphy, the State Department's ranking expert on Germany and acting director of its German and Austrian Division, left hurriedly in an Army plane tonight for Berlin to confer with Gen. Lucius D. Clay, with British and French officials and with German political leaders.

High school students from the Hi-Y Council of the Brooklyn and Queens Young Men's Christian association yesterday took over the City Council chamber in City hall and showed how it should be done. They passed thirtee "local laws" and killed one in less than two hours.

The prospects are good when it comes to finding pretty little cotton tops for they are making millinery news for summer. No longer reserved for baby's bonnet, they will be appearing on the smartest young women's heads when warm weather arrives.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- President Truman's message calling for a multi-billion-dollar health program is expected to intensify the efforts of friends and foes of the principle of compulsory health insurance, it was indicated today.

Millinery manufacturers will seek to hold the gains made this spring by stepping up the cooperative promotional effort, it was learned yesterday from Sam Finkelstein, executive administrator of Millinery Promotions, Inc.
