The group, comprising representatives of associations, the union and suppliers, will seek to double their budget for the coming year, he said following the annual meeting in the Astor Hotel.

The steel tugboat Grace Moran, first of five new harbor craft being built for the Moran Towing and Transportation Company, Inc., arrived here yesterday morning and received the traditional Port of New York reception. An escort of twenty tugs and the customary water display by New York City fireboats welcomed the new vessel.

BERLIN, April 22 -- The Anglo-American airlift is supporting Berlin's export trade at the rate of more than $14,000,000 yearly in addition to supplying food and fuel, it was learned authoritatively today.

Assurance that the other communities on the metropolitan waterways also would be required to undertake sewage pollution abatement programs similar to New York's was given yesterday by Seth Hess, executive director of the Interstate Sanitation Commission.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., April 22 -- Dr. Edward J. Sparling, President of Roosevelt College, Chicago, today told the Illinois Seditious Activities Investigation Commission that there were no Communists on the Roosevelt College faculty so far as he knew.
With cotton brokers on the New York Cotton Exchange largely concentrating on evening-up the May position, the cotton futures market closed irregular yesterday, 2 points higher to 17 points lower.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 22 -- Transmittal of a jointly sponsored Uruguayan-Guatemalan note asking United Nations investigation of charges of violation of human rights by the new military junta in Venezuela was postponed today in the face of heavy pressure exerted primarily by the United States.

An unwitting turn of a stolen car in the wrong direction along a one-way street in Queens ended yesterday with three young men and a girl being held on burglary charges and a charge of assault against one man.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., April 22 (AP) -- Miss Barbara Jensen, 19-year-old San Francisco girl, won two titles in opening events of the national A. A. U. women's indoor swimming meet today.

LONDON, April 22 -- The Yangtze incident in China had no appreciable effect in the stock markets here today other than to cause buyers to adopt a go-slow policy. It was left to two recently favored sections, gilt-edge stocks and gold-mining shares, to provide the bright spots.

Retail sales declined during the week, according to estimates made here. Department store sales were believed to be about 10 per cent below the corresponding week last year. Sales last week were up 2 per cent.

DETRIOT, April 22 -- The most powerful anti-allergy chemical developed so far, more than twenty-five times as potent as the drugs now commonly used to combat hay fever, bronchial asthma, food allergies and related conditions, was announced here today at the closing sessions of the annual meeting of the Federation of American Societies for Experimental Biology.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The coal industry today asserted that coal miners have almost reached their goal of the six-hour day and five-day week.

Henry Ford 2d said yesterday in an analysis of automotive trends that the American public was not ready to give general acceptance to smaller cars. The Ford Motor Company, of which he is president, is not considering the manufacture of a lighter vehicle in the $1,000 class in the near future, he added.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., April 22 -- Thirteen mines and nine mills in the Tri-State area zinc industry, formerly the principal producing region of this country, are closing down immediately because of the 13-cent price for zinc, industry members revealed here today.
JERSEY CITY, N. J., April 22 -One hundred' years ago tomorrow two small and struggling railroad companies joined forces and became known as the Central Railroad Company of New Jersey.

PITTSBURGH, April 22 (AP) -- Ralph Kiner, with a grand-slam homer, and Clyde McCullough, with a run-scoring triple, enabled the Pirates to come from behind today and win their home opener from Cincinnati, 5 -- 4.
LEXINGTON, Ky., April 22 (AP) -- Calumet Farm Trainer Ben Jones said tonight he suspected that De Luxe, his No. 1 Kentucky Derby prospect, was "tampered with" before he ran at Keeneland today.

WARSAW, April 23 (AP) -- The Polish Government today handed far-reaching powers to Hilary Minc to coordinate economic activities of all branches of state administration and to direct the new siv-year recovery program.

American colleges and universities in recent months have shown an increasing interest in the field of conservation of natural and human resources. New courses have been added to college curricula, and various institutions report that conservation, as a subject of study, is attracting greater numbers of students.

LONDON, April 23 -- The six committees of the Westminster Economic Conference of the European Movement, sponsored by Winston Churchill, completed their deliberations here today and prepared to turn over to a plenary session tomorrow several draft resolutions on how to achieve European economic unity.

I heartily concur with Woodrow Wyatt ("Chaos-Breeders in Southeast Asia") that only by effective social reform can communism be bested in Asia. However, in his article on the native nationalistic movements, I should like to have seen him refer to the Viet-Nam resistance movement in French Indo-China.

A twelve - game championship schedule that takes in every club in the National Football League with the exception of Los Angeles has been announced by the New York Giants for their silver jubilee season next fall. The pennant drive begins Sept. 25, with the Steelers in Pittsburgh, and closes Dec. 11, with the championship Eagles in Philadelphia.

TWENTY - FIVE inscribed plaques will be awarded by the Falk Publishing Company to camera club members whose prints, in the opinion of a jury of picture editors, show a high degree of photographic achievement.

IN Paris today there are no post-war shortages -- at least as far as music is concerned. In fact, in the field of orchestral music there is a possible surplus. No fewer than four symphony orchestras give regular weekly or biweekly concerts.

THE author of this non-technical book on mental disease and emotional disturbances not ordinarily labeled as insanity, has attempted a difficult task. Briefly, he undertakes to reduce the question of deviations from the norm of sanity to simple principles, so that people may understand and avoid emotional difficulties.

Simulating combat conditions in Bergen and Rockland Counties, 468 members of the 410th Engineer Brigade used seven two-seat fighter planes and an extensive radio network yesterday as they worked out problems on the ground.
Irving M. Selis, who is blind, said yesterday that with $5,000,000, he, as president, could make the Associated Blind, Inc., help the sightless as they have never been helped before.

Alone of all the twenty-eight competitors to emerge undefeated, Nicholas Rossolimo, champion of France, yesterday added greatly to his laurels by winning the first prize in the international tournament concluded at the Chess Festival in Southsea, England, according to a report received from London.

PRAGUE, April 23 -- Ernst Fischer, Austrian delegate to the "Little Peace Conference," today charged Americans were building underground munitions depots and airdromes as part of a "military zone" in the Tyrol and he proposed a meeting between Premier Stalin and President Truman as a means of preserving peace.
PERMIT me, as the sister of the author of "Ceremony of Innocence," to correct certain statements made by Jennifer Graham [in a letter] in your issue of March 20, 1949.

* * * The name Vyshinski should be spelled with "y" in the first syllable and is derived from the word vyshina, which means height. It is not derived from the word vyshnya, meaning cherry. A name derived from cherry is, for instance, Vishnievski, who was a famous actor of the Russian Art Theatre. * * *

THE mention of Chester A. Riley in the same breath with Lynn Belvedere -- or even in the same Sunday article -- is an insult for which we beg the amiable forgiveness of the friends of Mr. Belvedere. No more absurd association could be found for the famous nonpareil; no more extravagant elevation could be made for Mr. Riley, the bum.

IN discussing the failure of the National Council for a Permanent Fair Employment Practices Commission to attain its objective since 1943, Prof. Louis Coleridge Kesselman of the University of Louisville is engaged with a problem that has important aspects for democracy and reform -- and one which will undoubtedly soon agitate the Eighty-first Congress.

ENDOWED with exceptional perceptions and a great capacity for observing and understanding, Sydney Clark has long displayed a combination of talents that has made him one of the best, as he is one of the most prolific, writers of books on travel.

David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, AFL, asserted yesterday that the labor movement had its own Marshall Plan long before the European Recovery Program became a reality.

SOME day there may be a great book on the contemporary Argentine scene. That scene took form with the so-called Colonels' Revolution of June, 1943, and its hero to date is President Domingo Peron. It has affected the climate of Argentine literature but has still to be recorded by it.

MOST weedy turf is starved turf. It is starved because insufficient quantities of plant food have been supplied to meet the growth requirements of the grass, and to build up a turf that is dense enough to keep out weeds.

ATLANTA, Ga., April 23 -- People in the Southeastern States are expressing a growing awareness of the inadequacy of their schools, teachers' low pay and the necessity of improving educational facilities for Negroes. Civic organizations and leading newspapers in Georgia this week stepped up their campaign to obtain salary increases for the state's teachers.

RECENTLY in Argentina, next month in Moscow -- in fact, almost any time of the year at some place -- people gather for international chess tournaments, one of the more static forms of global competition.

THE spate of so-called "music appreciation" courses in American colleges of late years has been interpreted in some quarters as a reason for congratulation. This writer thought some interesting conclusions might result from a questionnaire designed to ascertain what our American colleges are doing with Beethoven.

DALLAS, April 23 -- Last-minute Easter shopping accounted for most of the rise in department store sales last week. Business otherwise remained on a fairly steady trend and continued to inch downward in some lines. Texas oil production for May was ordered cut again by the Railroad Commission.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, April 23 -- The rural pastor no longer is the "forgotten man of Methodism," in the opinion of the Rev. Elliott Fisher, superintendent of the Department of Town and Country Work, Board of Missions and Church Extension, New York City.

ON THE DUTCH - GERMAN BORDER, April 23 -- Dutch, Belgian and Luxembourg forces moved in on schedule last night and today to take over sections of the Western German borderland assigned to them by the recent six-power conference in Paris.

NANKING, April 23 -- This former Nationalist capital awaiting "liberation" by the Communist army, was in a chaotic state today. Bedraggled Government troops moved south and thousands of local residents went on a looting spree that stripped Government buildings, military headquarters, official residences and a number of boarded-up food shops.

The thirty-four old-timers brushed specks off their white jackets piped in silver. They gazed proudly at their gold-striped blue trousers. They adjusted towery bearskin shakos and gold epaulets wistfully.

WHEN a viewer tunes on his set, he captures a rapid succession of electrical impulses from the air which his television receiver transforms into scenes and images. Since the sound portion of a television program is broadcast simultaneously with the image, the result is complete coordination between the reproduced picture and accompanying sound.

Efforts to reach a compromise settlement in the controversy between the Rev. Dr. John Howard Melish, rector of Holy Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Brooklyn Heights, and nine former vestrymen, came to an abrupt end yesterday when the elderly rector announced that he would appeal tomorrow a Supreme Court order issued Wednesday upholding an episcopal mandate removing him from his pulpit.

PARIS, April 23 -- Bao Dai, former Emperor of Annam, is expected to leave Cannes by air tomorrow for Dalat, French Indo-China. His departure was made possible by today's 55-6 vote of the Territorial Assembly of Cochin China in favor of union with Viet Nam.

FACILITIES to carry network television programs to additional cities and to build the mass audiences necessary for the medium's commercial support will continue to be expanded in the months immediately ahead.
New York City will be asked by the Transport Workers Union, CIO, within the next few weeks to increase the wages of its 35,000 transit employes by 21 cents an hour, it became known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Documentary evidence of an elaborate scheme by the Communist-controlled Polish Government to obtain United States military secrets through a country-wide espionage network, with headquarters at the Polish Embassy here, was made public today.

DUESSELDORF, April 23 -- The inter-fractional meetings of the German parties that began yesterday at Bonn adjourned this evening without any perceptible basis for a compromise on the united front that they hope to present on Monday in a session in Frankfort with the Western Military Governors.

BOSTON, April 23 -- In the semi-darkness over the Charles River this evening, Harvard's varsity crew annexed the Compton Cup for the eighth time in succession by beating Princeton, M.I.T. and Rutgers over a distance of one mile and three-quarters.

NEGLEY FARSON, ex-foreign correspondent and author of "Way of a Transgressor," has written a first-person novel narrated by one Richard Fenner, ex-foreign correspondent who also writes a book. Fenner-Farson is a professional boat-lover.

MAX BEERBOHM said: "Fate wrote her a most tremendous tragedy -- and she played it in tights." Winston Churchill said: "Men occasionally stumble over the truth, but most of them pick themselves up and hurry off as if nothing had happened."
David Shulman, writing to THE TIMES Magazine about my article, "The First Ten Since 1900," has a right to disagree with my selection of the

BOSTON, April 23 -- Considering that large segments of New England industry are in a semi-depressed condition or worse, local merchants were surprised at the gains in store sales during the pre-Easter period. For the week immediately before Easter, the gain in New England was larger than in any other Federal Reserve District and much larger than for the country as a whole.
New York's firemen interrupted their activities yesterday to hold open house for the city's Boy Scouts.

OLAF, a gray Norwegian elk-hound, was a descendant of the dogs that sailed with the Vikings. When the crate in which he was being shipped west fell from a delivery truck, Olaf found himself free in the wilderness of the Sawtooth Mountains of Idaho.

DIRECTLY and indirectly, Nick Charles is responsible for a lot Plotwise,. "The Thin Man" was the weakest of Dashiell Hammett's stories; but Nick and his Nora were so amusing that no one much cared. Thereby started the tradition that a murder involving Bright Young People didn't especially have to make sense.
HARTFORD, Conn., April 23 (AP) -- The chairman of the State Development Commission wants to bar Paul Robeson, Negro singer, from Connecticut, where he has his home at Enfield.

WARRENTON, Va., April 23 -- Never worry, 15-year-old chocolate mare owned by Thomas Stokes of Philadelphia, came from behind over the last fence today to win by a neck the 24th running of the Virginia Gold Cup. A crowd of 10,000 lined the Broadview course for the six-race card.
SALT LAKE CITY, April 23 -- Springtime brought clamor aplenty to the Rockies this week, with matters of state-wide and local interest claiming major attention.
Secretary of State Dean Acheson will appear here this week before publishers' functions, lending an international flavor to newspaper week, which opens tomorrow at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

J. P. MARQUAND, the author of the best selling "Point of No Return," had just returned from Nassau. Tall, in his middle fifties, Mr. Marquand looked fit. He was quite ready, he said, to answer questions. He felt he was an expert at answering questions.

ONE of the most valuable of the public services rendered by the New York Academy of Medicine is its sponsorship of the annual series of lectures to the laity. Given by some of the most eminent authorities in medicine and education, the lectures are a far cry from the "How to cure this!" or "Don't do that!" talks to which non-medical audiences are frequently subjected.

PARIS, April 23 -- There was an uproar in the Salle Pleyel today when for the first time since the Congress of the Partisans of Peace was opened Wednesday a delegate dared to differ with the theme of the congress that the Soviet Union is the seat of peace and the United States the center of war plans.
ALBANY, April 23 -- The predicted postwar upward trend in New York State's juvenile delinquency rate has failed to materialize, the State Youth Commission reported today.

TEL AVIV, Israel, April 23 -- New evidence that immigration into Israel was reaching the saturation point was given tonight when the Jewish Agency announced that 10,000 tents had been purchased to accommodate the latest arrivals. The expenditure comes close to $4,000,000.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 23 -- The Pacific Coast showed many signs of spring fever this week, and one aspect of it was the confusion existing over the adoption of daylight saving time. In the face of strong regional sentiment against daylight saving, a few cities planned to adopt it.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- By renewing his often-voiced appeal to Congress for a compulsory health insurance system, President Truman has added fresh fuel to a controversy that already had reached the proportions of a major national issue.

Notified that they would be called to testify before the House Ways and Means Committee in Washington this week at a hearing on the Social Security Act, officers of the National Council of Salesmen's Organizations held a series of conferences last week to consolidate the evidence which they hope will help effect the repeal of the Gearhart amendment.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 23 -- Franco-Yugoslav negotiations for a long term trade agreement were interrupted today by the departure of the French delegation for Paris.

WHILE we have had many opportunities through exhibitions to become familiar with the work of the other principal post-impressionists, it has remained for the current benefit exhibition at the Knoedler Galleries to enable us to obtain a comparable perspective on the work of Seurat.

In a recent issue of the American Journal of Public Health, it was suggested that in the 1950 elections to the Hall of Fame, consideration be given to Dorothea Lynde Dix, pioneer in the United States for better care of the mentally ill.

Two Mayo Clinic scientists, Dr. Philip S. Hench, whose specialty is joint diseases, and Dr. Edward C. Kendall, who isolated thyroxin years ago, came out last week with the report that a hormone obtained from the "bark" of the adrenal glands, which lie just above the kidneys, restores crippled sufferers from rheumatic arthritis.

TEN weeks of travel through six European countries for $1,800 for the two of us -- that is how my husband and I did Europe. We traveled on a budget, but we did not ride a single bicycle and slept only twice in a youth hostel.
Under the heading "Separatist Party Strong in Bavaria," referring to the Bavarian party, an article by Drew Middleton was published in your paper recently.
The long-awaited Administration plan for rearmament of Western Europe presented to Congress last week, is a keystone in our program for European security.

The plan of Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan to provide Government funds to farmers as compensation against low prices for their products was termed "idotic" here yesterday by Gov. Val R. Peterson of Nebraska.

Cancer research was prominently in the news last week because of some striking results reported at the Detroit meeting of the American Association for Cancer Research. There is little doubt that the announcement of Dr. Charles B. Huggins of the University of Chicago attracted most attention -- and this because it dealt with that old dream, a test for hidden, incipient cancer as simple as a Wassermann.
WITH the lifting in early summer of the current moratorium on new construction of stations, American television will be entering the second and third phases of its impressive post-war development.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 23 -- The fifty-eight member countries of the United Nations will meet in plenary session Monday at Flushing Meadow, Queens, to take up the Soviet Union's refusal to let Russian wives of foreigners join their husbands abroad.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The United States today published "The Gift of Freedom," a 150-page illustrated book whose purpose is to show foreign workers the forces that have made America great and the elements that make up the American workers' high standard of living.

INSTEAD of diminishing in this mechanical age the cowboy legend looms larger than ever. From rompers to chaps seems to be the order of today, for the yearning to ride the range hits small boys earlier than it did a generation ago.

CHICAGO, April 23 -- The number of persons unemployed in the Seventh Federal Reserve District has increased to 575,000 currently compared with about 200,000 in November and 325,000 a year ago, the Reserve Board estimated. However, the number employed in the area is about the same as last year.

The projected three-week "peace" tour of Henry A. Wallace with three members of European parliaments will embrace speaking engagements in fifteen cities throughout the country, Mr. Wallace announced yesterday.

One big inning, the third, when seven runs crossed the plate, sufficed for Columbia to defeat Cornell, 9 -- 5, in their Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League meeting at Baker Field yesterday. Bob Swanson, ace right-hander of the Lions, went all the way and though pressed in the closing frames, had enough of a lead to coast home.
CHICAGO, April 23 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox unloaded 16 hits against five St. Louis pitchers today to score their third straight victory by outpointing the Browns, 12-5, before 8,086 persons.

TEST patterns are put on the air by the telecasters not only for engineers and radio service men, but also to offer the set owner a steady target on which to train his receiver. The patterns contain characteristics for determining the fidelity of reception of a television station's signal and for identifying distortion thus making it easier to eliminate.

NEW YORK CITY is the first municipality in the nation with its own Television Unit. On Feb. 1 of this year Mayor O'Dwyer created a television department, staffed with a minimum of personnel, guided by a modest budget and faced with an exciting challenge.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 23 -- Egypt joined Lebanon and Saudi Arabia today in recognizing the Government set up in Syria by Gen. Husni Zayim. The recognition by Saudi Arabia and Lebanon was announced in Damascus earlier today.

Since it is in the interest of some organized groups to seek to exaggerate the earnings of business enterprise generally, and particularly those of corporations, the importance of correctly recording business transactions and of compiling reliable statistics from such records has been justifiably emphasized.

WHEN Gertrude Stein said that twentieth century French paintings were really made by Spaniards living in Paris, she was thinking of her particular idols, Picasso and Juan Gris. However, she might well have added Joan Miro for, as the important retrospective group of his paintings from 1923 to 1927, at the Pierre Matisse Gallery, triumphantly shows, the impact of Miro's vision upon modern painting has been as memorable
BUCHAREST, Rumania April 23 -- Rumanian Communists apparently took another step today to strengthen the Communist Information Bureau wing in the party and the Government.

SWITZERLAND sends official word that two commemorative series will be released on May 16 -- one for the centenary of the Swiss Federal Post, the other for the seventy-fifth anniversary of the Universal Postal Union. Dated 1849-1949, the firs group comprises 5-centimes gray, yellow, red, post-horn; 20c violet, yellow, gray, mail coach drawn by five horses; 30c brown, yellow, gray, motor coach with trailer.

CHICAGO, April 23 (AP) -- Grains did little on the Board of Trade today. Lard provided most of the market's interest, futures making fairly sharp gains following an expanded demand at higher prices for loose lard.

Seven employes of the Swedish American Line who have worked for the steamship company for twenty-five years or more were honored yesterday with the gold medal of the 182-year-old Swedish Patriotic Society for their contributions to Swedish commerce and to Swedish-American relations.

ST. LOUIS, April 23 (AP) -- The Cubs pounded across eight runs in the seventh inning to whip the Cardinals, 11 to 7, in the National League's first night game of the season before 21,964 fans tonight.

NANKING, April 23 -- The collapse of the Nationalist Yangtze River line as the Communists began this inherently difficult military operation has driven home the point that the Chinese Communists -- confronted by a battered, demoralized and divided Government force -- are apparently capable of going almost anywhere they want to go in Kuomintang China.
Enactment of the $90,000,000 Navajo-Hopi rehabilitation bill now before Congress was urged yesterday by three authorities of the Association on American Indian Affairs, 48 East Eighty-sixth Street.

THE saints of England and Ireland, like the other inhabitants of those islands, are revealed in "A Procession of Saints" to be rather practical and down- to-earth. Since the time of St. Alban, that Christian Roman officer martyred in Britain in 303 A. D., the Church in England and Ireland has not lacked for saints.

TELEVISION in the Soviet Union is still in its infancy, and progress planned for the next few years will be slow, reports from that country indicate. Soviet television experimentation and broadcasting began well before the last war but were set back substantially during the struggle and are only now recovering lost ground.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 23 (AP) -- Ben Jones, trainer for Calumet Farm, said chemical tests today, "proved definitely" that De Luxe, his Kentucky Derby hopeful, was drugged before yesterday's poor showing in a race at near-by Keeneland.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Louis Johnson, Secretary of Defense, ordered all work stopped today on the Navy's super-aircraft carrier, the 65,000-ton United States.

Four airlines operating out of the New York metropolitan area announced additions and changes in schedules yesterday.
