For three decades the city of Nanking, a metropolis of about 2,000,000 people on the banks of the Yangtze 235 miles from the China Sea, has been the symbol of the Chinese Republic.

Within the next forty-five days the state highway departments of Texas, Virginia and Ohio will test roads in which powdered natural rubber is incorporated with asphalt. Rubber roads were introduced in Holland and the Netherlands East Indies before the war.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican, of Ohio, told a meeting of newspaper editors today the issue of the day at home and abroad was totalitarianism versus human liberty and that the Republican party stood for liberty.

HAVE you noticed that when you scratch a big man, you often find a small town? And that the smaller the town, the bigger the place it is to be from? Maybe you've come to wonder how it is that so many of the high horsepower people come from wht you would call a one horsepower town. That poses quite a problem. A lot of other people come from there too.

PRIMED by the ERP pump and by the flow of Army appropriations, post-war industry in western Germany is reviving rapidly. Motion pictures, however, move only fitfully with the current. The vital cinematic urge that created such pre-Nazi masterpieces as "Passion," "The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari," "Variety," "Metropolis" and "The Last Laugh," has not yet emerged from the stupor of years of subservience to the Nazi dictatorship.

MANY preconceived notions about discussion programs on television have proved in practice to be unfounded. For the program devoted to a consideration of topical issues there is only one basic need: Get the right subject to discuss and get the right people to do the discussing.

IN his foreword Mr. Howard says that "the importance of an absorbing hobby to a happy, varied and well-rounded life can hardly be exaggerated. My hobby has been the sea and everything connected with it, including yacht cruising and yacht racing."
Behind the pageantry, the shifting light, the feats on high trapeze and tight wire at the circus is Pat Valdo, director of performance for Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey.

Depressed by a series of defeats in its sixteen-year battle with public power on all levels of government, the private utility industry celebrated a victory of far-reaching significance last week when the United States Supreme Court refused to review a bitterly contested issue involving the South Carolina Public Service Authority and the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation.
ABOVE the sound of the tired chorus that has long been intoning lamentations for the deplorable state of the theatre there have recently been heard fresh, soaring tones of hope.

" YOUTH does not last. Life itself does not last. Why, then, should love? Shall one not love because love does not last?" With such philosophical overtones Eleanor Farjeon charts the progression of a love affair through impulse, ecstasy and the inevitable disillusion. It is almost too French.
AT the beginning of what is surely the most exciting and possibly the most important book on the English novel to appear in the last three decades, Dr. Leavis says:

PHILADELPHIA, April 23 -- In a game that reflected no great credit on either team, the Dodgers outscrambled the Phils in the latters' delayed home opener today by an 8 -- 6 score and, among other things, ran their Shibe Park winning streak to eight straight games. The Brooks had won the last seven here during the 1948 campaign.

Through the centuries, during which angling developed from a crude method of obtaining food to a practice that in some circles is recognized as an art, hundreds of widely recognized artificial fly patterns were developed, but the methods of tying or "dressing" these flies has remained the same.

The Controllership Foundation, research arm of the Controllers Institute of America, last week began work on an intensive study of job description and evaluation of employes in controllers departments of various types of businesses. The study, most comprehensive yet attempted in the field, will consider standards in a representative sample of companies throughout the country with a view toward improving them.

CELESTE was a beauty of the early Nineteen Hundreds with a rope of golden hair. Unlike her predecessors, "Kitty" and "Duchess Hotspur," she was an eminently good girl -- surrounded by a seductive aura of sin. Her beautiful mother, Dolly Wills, had been a queen of the Barbary Coast and now owned a de luxe gambling club and (wickeder yet) chambres separees.

ST. LOUIS, April 23 -- Further improvement in collections has been reported here by the large wholesale houses, which now describe them as "good." They say it indicates merchants throughout the country not only are paying off debts as fast as they pare down inventories, but that their financial condition by and large is strong.

CHICAGO, April 23 (AP) -- Why does big business absorb small firms in the $250,000 to $5,000,000 class? "Because," says a management research firm, "small business has failed to develop" an executive hierarchy capable of running it after the death of the founder.
CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., April 23 -- Secretary of the Navy John L. Sullivan said today that the Navy would operate strictly in the field of naval missions.

A relative lull, lasting almost three months, was broken by the decisive political and military movements in China during the past week. The "exploration" of a ground for compromise and peace that had occupied the ruling circles in the Government party since the retirement of President Chiang Kai-shek was rudely ended in a Communist ultimatum demanding abject surrender and then blown to bits by the violent crossing of the Yangtze.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The dramatic story of the Russian blockade of Berlin and the joint United States - British airlift will be illustrated in the Library of Congress by the photographs of Henry Reis of THE NEW YORK TIMES, it was announced today by the library.

MANUFACTURERS of television receivers now have achieved mass production. With sets coming off the line at the rate of about 120,000 units per month, there is today a highly competitive market. It has brought about price reductions and the introduction of larger screens to tempt the buyer.

MEMPHIS, Tenn. -- More than 100,000 visitors are expected here for the fifteenth Cotton Carnival, which will run from Sunday, May 8, through the following Sunday. Billed as "The Nation's Party in the Land of Cotton," the carnival will offer its guests parades, free exhibits, street dancing, concerts, fireworks and several lavish balls.

ZURICH, Switzerland, April 23 (UP) -- One of the biggest Yugoslav contracts with a United States concern since Marshal Tito's break with the Communist Information Bureau was signed in Belgrade this week, an American consulting engineer said today.

FRENCH LICK, Ind., April 23 -- No more certain of the economic outlook than any other segment of the business community, the executive council of the American Bankers Association is assembling here today for its annual deliberations. Three hundred and fifty bank officer members, representing institutions in all sections of the country, are scheduled to attend the council sessions, which will get under way tomorrow.

SARTRE'S name, I understand, is associated with a fashionable brand of cafe philosophy, and since for every so-called "existentialist" one finds quite a few "suctorialists" (if I may coin a polite term), this made-in-England translation of Sartre's first novel, "La Nausee" (published in Paris in 1938) should enjoy some success.

MANY writers inside and outside Spain have written novels about the ritual ballet miscalled bullfighting, a literal translation of the word the Greeks had for it, tauromachy, much practiced in Crete, home of the minotaur.

EVIDENCE of the extraordinary public interest in art is provided by the recent issue of "The Pocket Book of Old Masters." Artists whose paintings are reproduced include Leonardo, Raphael, Michelangelo, Titian, Brueghel, Rubens, Rembrandt, El Greco, Velasquez and Vermeer.

GENEVA, April 23 -- The future of the Arab refugees, internationalization of Jerusalem and the permanent frontiers of Israel are subjects that the United Nations Conciliation Commission hopes will be discussed by Israel and the three Arab states gathering at Lausanne next Tuesday, a United Nations spokesman said here-today.

FRANKLIN DELANO ROOSEVELT JR., 34, the fourth of the late President's five children, has become the first of them to put his name before the voters in an election for public office. He has entered this tough arena of politics on a higher level than his father did. F. D. R. Sr.'s first candidacy, forty years ago, was for the New York State Senate from Dutchess County.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 23 -- Fellowships for the study of problems of industrial administration have been won by ten young executives in a nation-wide competition, it was announced today by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., April 23 -- Cheered on by thousands of spectators, ninety-six union house painters today set what was claimed as a world record by slapping a complete coat of white paint on a house in two minutes and thirty-two seconds.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., April 23 (AP) -- Miss Maureen O'Brien entered the winner's circle of the national A.A.U. women's indoor swim meet today.

SHANGHAI, April 23 -- The British Consul General here strongly implied tonight that Britain would use force if necessary to rescue the sloop Amethyst and her sixty remaining personnel from a Chinese Communist trap in the Yangtze River.

IN light of its present reputation, Harvard football would not appear to be a likely subject for a book. Mr. Bealle has recalled enough of past glories, however, to make a history of surprising, if parochial, interest.
Following is the address of President Chaim Weizmann of Israel delivered at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night:

CHUQUICAMATA, Chile, April 14 -- The world's richest copper deposit here is the site of a $130,000,000 conversion project which will fundamentally alter the process of extracting the metal from the vast elliptical pit set more than 9,000 feet high in the barren Chilean pampa.
GENEVA, April 14 -- The International Refugee Organization of the United Nations now operates the world's largest civil transportation fleet, according to the organization's headquarters here.
The Kentucky Derby favorite won the $46,400 Wood Memorial at Jamaica yesterday -- but it was a tight squeeze. It also was the most exciting race of the New York season.

The daylight is longer, much longer, now, and the dusk itself has a persistence that it lacked two months ago. Then the sun hovered for a brief moment on the western horizon, plunged out of sight and left the world to darkness. Now it seems to hover there several moments, and it vanishes in a glow that lingers, a soft twilight that fades slowly into darkness.

TORONTO. SOME time late in 1950 the first four Canadian television transmitters are scheduled to go on the air at Toronto and Montreal. The Canadian Government has announced a loan of $4,000,000 to the publicly owned Canadian Broadcasting Corporation to build one station each in Montreal and Toronto and to build a programming headquarters.

TOKYO, April 9 -- Japan's most important and most hotly contested post-war experiment in government control of heavy industry now has ended its first year with somewhat less than total success. Under government management since April 1948, Japanese coal mines have fallen 3 1/2 per cent short of producing the quota given them under the five-year program for industrial rehabilitation endorsed by the Allies last year.

The wool goods trade is experiencing a revival of "private treaty" deals as large cutters of both men's and women's clothing negotiate "inside" prices with fabric manufacturers, it was pointed out last week. Concessions for quantity orders, cutters revealed, ranged up to 30 cents a yard or about 7 per cent on popular ranges of worsteds.

For years Dr. Charles G. Abbott of the Smithsonian Institution has been measuring the amount of heat received by the earth from the sun. To him the sun is a variable star. There are day-to-day variations in its radiation that average as little as 0.75 per cent -- so little that skeptics attribute them to errors that cannot be avoided.

OF all kinds of actors, the best equipped to swim the television channels are the vaudevillians and the stage-trained artists. Both of these know how to start out from one shore and make land on the other without waterwings of written lines to read, as in radio, or a director's helping hand to tell the cameras to "cut," if the actor flounders, as in the movies.

TWO Sunday afternoons ago this department, on a day magical with spring, journeyed up to Marymount College, at Tarrytown-on-the-Hudson, to take part in a forum organized by the Catholic Poetry Society of America for the discussion of poetry's present and its immediate future.

CHICAGO, April 23 (AP) -- Montgomery Ward Co. today could concentrate on selling merchandise. It had gone through another managerial test yesterday and Sewell L. Avery, its 75-year-old chairman, was still on top. The stockholders had given him a heavy vote of approval, re-electing him a director, and the directors promptly re-elected him chairman of their board and chief executive officer of the nation's second largest merchandising concern.

SAFETY, economy and durability are among the assets claimed for the new "three-dimensional" nylon car upholstery which is now being adopted by the automotive industry and is scheduled for use in many of the 1950 models.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., April 23 -- Testimony that the University of Chicago does not hamper student participation in left-wing activities and that some of its faculty have numerous "Communist-front" affiliations was introduced today as hearings of the Illinois Seditious Activities Investigation Commission ended.

DURING a campaign talk in 1920 Warren G. Harding said airily that "government is a simple thing." A year in the White House was enough to change his mind. "I can't make a damn thing out of this tax problem," he exploded to a secretary one day. "I listen to one side and they seem right -- and then -- God!

NEW DELHI, India, April 18 -- Mrs. Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit, attractive younger sister of Prime Minister Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, is going to Washington in May as India's new Ambassador to the United States. She goes with the hope that the great pacifist spirit of India and the country's leadership in Asia will be supported by the material strength of the United States.

BOSTON, April 23 -- The dismissal of three lay members of the Boston College faculty and a lay teacher at its affiliated Jesuit high school in a dispute over Roman Catholic doctrine attracted wide attention this week among New Englanders of all faiths.
WORCESTER, Mass., April 23-- Yale defeated Holy Cross, 6 to 4, today by registering two runs in the eighth to break a 4-to-4 deadlock. Bob Goodyear, victor on the mound, allowed six hits.
THE tourist in Mexico who has explorer's blood in his veins and likes to get places ahead of the crowd might do well to include Chiapas in his itinerary.

A large number of apparel reorders was received by the wholesale apparel market here last week, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office. Stimulated by good values in all ready-to-wear lines, stores are open to buy, and lower retail prices are holding sales at a satisfactory level in most sections of the country, it was said.

IN Mr. Churchill's memoirs a character who is regularly named, and never without gratitude, is Professor Lindemann, now Lord Cherwell, known to all his friends as "The Prof." Who is this figure who has possessed the confidence and shared the power of the greatest and, for five years, most powerful Englishman of our time?

THOUGH it was published in Paris in 1913, and deals with the Dreyfus case of the late Nineties, "Jean Barois" is not in the least out of date as far as Anglo-American literature is concerned. Its first appearance in English finds it quite at home in a decade in which "Brideshead Revisited," "All the King's Men" and the novels of C. S. Lewis have had popular success.
PHILADELPHIA, April 23 -- Ray Dooney led the attack as Penn defeated Army, 6-4, at Riverfield today in the first Eastern League game for both teams.

CHICAGO, April 23 -- Thousands of Central Westerners who are still hunting suitable homes and apartments wer cheered this week by reports of a growing building boom in the metropolitan centers of this area.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- President Truman paid a surprise visit this morning to the United States medical center at Bethesda, Md., and found four "very important patients" recovering from recent illnesses, according to a White House announcement after his return.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The civil war in China is now reaching its climax. The Communists this week took over the ports and cities along the Southern Yangtze almost at will. In the process, they attacked the warships of Britain and defied the protests of London.

LIGHTNING a television show is important because it controls the very mood of the performance. Those responsible for it, therefore, must work closely with the producer and the director to get the effect the latter are trying to achieve.

The general failure of American colleges and universities to prepare students for positions in government foreign service and in international business has resulted in this country's setting the "short end of the stick," according to Representative Christian A. Herter of Massachusetts, director of the School of Advanced International Studies in Washington.

Re the first diagram in THE TIMES Magazine showing the relative position of the sun, moon and earth as they would appear at the time of the lunar eclipse on April 12 -- unless I am in error, the orbital motions have been reversed.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- This week five members of the United States Senate took a brief tour through their own backyard and discovered for themselves how squalid and disgraceful are the notorious slums "within the shadow of the nation's Capitol."

AFTER drinking deep of the Pierian spring for more than half a century, Percy MacKaye has presented practical men with some very formidable problems. He has written four consecutive plays about the "Hamlet" legend -- all of them long, all of them fretted with mystic symbolism, all of them composed in verse in the Shakespearean model.

The killing of 8-year-old Jackie Goldsmith, whose mutilated body was found a week ago Friday on the abandoned site of Starlight Park in the Bronx, was said by the police of that borough to have been solved early this morning when they arrested a 36-year-old ex-convict for the crime.

BERLIN, April 23 -- British officials said today that they would soon seek modification of the payments agreement with the bizonal area in an effort to ease the dollar drain on the British Treasury resulting from unbalanced Anglo-German trade.

Retail trade here had a sharp post-Easter reaction last week. Department store sales were estimated to show a 10 per cent decline under a year ago. Promotions took the lead in apparel and the post-Easter upturn in home furnishings sales was disappointingly small.

THE post-war blossoming of television, while spreading a degree of entertainment and edification across the nation, has generated mainly apprehensive bewilderment in Hollywood, the world capital of mass-production entertainment. Television is the first threat to the motion-picture industry's domination of that field in its generation of existence.
ALEXANDRIA, Va. -- Less than half an hour by car from Washington or eighteen minutes by train lies this historic suburban city, which this year is observing the 200th anniversary of its founding.
How Charles G. Spiegler's recital of academic frustration jolted me into my own feverish past. I had it too, ten wacky years of it, in a $4,000,000 high school in Detroit.

The appointment of Assemblyman Owen McGivern as executive chairman of the Citizens Committee for the election of Justice Benjamin Shalleck, Democratic candidate for Representative in the Twentieth Congressional District at the special election on May 17, was announced yesterday by former State Senator Abraham Kaplan, Shalleck campaign manager. Mr. McGivern was a candidate for the nomination obtained by Mr. Shalleck.

A REVOLUTIONARY type of passenger train -- shorter, faster, lighter and four feet lower than the conventional streamliner -- was demonstrated at Hoboken last week by the American Car and Foundry Company which is building two such trains for the Spanish railways.

GOOD entertainment is the basis of any show for any age, and the two prime requisites for any program are simplicity and good taste. Once the planner of a program for children realizes that these are the simple rules, he should relax.

Willem Van Den Andel, Dutch pianist, who was last heard here in October, 1944, gave a recital late yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. It included works by Sweelinck, Haydn, Mozart, Beethoven, Brahms and Chopin, and five pieces by the pianist himself.

A Canadian company announces it will build a pulp mill to manufacture cigarette paper from fruit orchard trimmings. Today most cigarette paper comes from flax straw. In 1936 studies began in Toronto on the possibility of making pulp from fruit-tree trimmings. Two years later the Pulp and Paper Research Institute of Canada experimentally made about 1,400 pounds of pulp with this raw material.

LATE last mouth, without much ceremony, the plug was pulled in Prague, and down the drain went 400 Czechoslovak book publishers, large and small. Under a law passed by Parliament on March 24, control of Czechoslovak book production and distribution was formally vested in the State.

PHILADELPHIA, April 23 -- Immediate pre-Easter sales reported by seven women's wear shops in Central Philadelphia were 29 per cent ahead of a year ago and for the four-week period exceeded the like 1948 period by 14 per cent.

As a continuous memorial to the late Dr. John H. Finley, retired editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES and former president of City College, the college will begin on May 5 a series of annual public lectures on "The Newspaper and Society." Arthur Hays Sulzberger, president and publisher of THE TIMES, will open the series with a lecture on "The Press -- Its Past, Present and Future."

Please accept my thanks and appreciation for the public service you have performed in bringing to the attention of your readers the plight of New York City's secondary school teachers burdened with paper work at the expense of their teaching ("The Fourth 'R' -- Redtape," by C. G. Spiegler).

VIENNA, April 23 -- For permitting black marketers and the Hungarian Communist party to make huge profits out of United States cigarettes at the expense of Austria, United States tobacco firms were severely criticized today by the Socialist party organ Arbeiter Zeitung.

High school students, interested in sports participation and sports writing, expressed divergent views yesterday in a discussion of overemphasis on sports in this country at the Youth Forum, sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast by WQXR.

WITH the fast growing interdependence of the liberal nations today, it is a pleasure to read as timely a book as "Liberalism and the Challenge of Fascism." It will be hard to find another that will better explain to Americans -- and to the British and French -- the essence and the differences of liberalism in Britain and France.

DELIBERATE forgeries and copies of art objects that come to be passed off -- innocently or knowingly -- for the originals constitute a perennial problem for the art world, particularly for museums, dealers and private collectors. Hans Tietze, an art scholar and writer of international standing, has taken up this thorny and usually by-passed problem and contributed a very readable and illuminating discussion of the factors involved.

TEL AVIV, Israel, April 23 -- The division of Old and New Jerusalem, which seems to be one of the world's perplexing problems, may be solved on the home grounds. While the United Nations Conciliation Commission is preparing to go to Lausanne to discuss the refugee question and ultimate peace, Arabs and Jews have met here without benefit of the United Nations to settle their immediate problems.

EZEIZA, Argentina -- The greatest airport in Latin America and unquestionably one of the greatest in the world has just been named by President Juan Domingo Peron and already giant transports up to the DC-6 class are practicing on the outsize runways.

THE sports stories collected from issues of The Saturday Evening Post by Red Smith, New York Herald Tribune columnist and eminent authority on cricket, include a few near-classics, a little slick deadwood and, in the main, light and readable tales of struggles on the gridiron, the diamond, the links, the road (for a Boston marathon), the racetrack, and the limed greensward (or tennis court), and in the squared circle.

THIS is the story of woman's problems, and the greatest of these is love. The intricacies of this problem glimmer obliquely through a richly stocked family tree, a thickly detailed genre background of jelly making, picnic preparation, the care and feeding of infants, and the history of Mormonism. Yet they do come through.

EARLIER in the year when business was sagging, the advice was given to watch this month. Seasonal movements had once more returned in the markets after a long lapse during the war and post-war years, and April was the month to watch.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 23 -- The Yale track team experienced little difficulty in its outdoor inaugural, rolling up 94 points to easily capture a triangular meet with Dartmouth and Columbia on the Dewitt Cuyler field today. Dartmouth took second place with 41 points, while the Lions tallied 38.

AS a man who has delved deeply in that mysterious cinematic field labeled "special effects" and one who has successfully directed these past five years, Byron Haskin is ready and anxious to enter independent production.

The International Children's Emergency Fund of the United Nations is $28,000,000 short of its minimum needs for this year and is facing a crisis, according to those engaged in providing supplementary food, clothing and medical care for children whose lives are still blighted from the war.

BUTLER, Md., April 23 -- Cormac, 6-year-old bay gelding with his 16-year-old owner up, withstood a desperate drive by Pine Pep today to win Maryland's forty-seventh Grand National Steeplechase. Eugene Weymouth, a student at Baltimore's McDonogh School, sent Cormac into the lead after two miles and stayed there in a neck finish.

WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) -- The report of the House Committee on Un-American Activities says Dr. Zlotowski was connected at times with various American colleges and universities but that the latest word the Committee had on him was that he was in Poland.

Whether radio and television are serving the nation's children -- and how well -- will be the topic under discussion at a panel session on children's programs to be held during Ohio State University's nineteenth annual Institute for Education by Radio, May 5 to 8.

M. SAINT - FOIX examines Mozart's symphonies with the sensuous delight of a horticulturist admiring a bed of roses. His book seems to exhale the atmosphere of a hothouse. Far from the agitated tempo of modern life, he traces the composer's symphonic development, lingering over the final great trilogy: the E Flat, G Minor and C Major ("Jupiter") Symphonies.

Dr. Chaim Weizmann, first President of the State of Israel, pledged his fledgling nation last night to insure the safety of the Holy Places in Jerusalem, and to accept and encourage the fullest international controls for their immunity and protection.

TOO much work and too much color are common faults of midsummer gardens. In the heat of July and August, masses of brilliant color are apt to make high temperatures seem even hotter. A greater proportion of green may require less labor and certainly provides a cooler-looking view.

MINNEAPOLIS, April 23 -- Building permits for the first quarter in the Ninth Federal Reserve District exceeded those of the same period last year, the bank in Minneapolis reported. The total was $25,525,950 as against $24,732,690, an increase of $793,260. A breakdown by states showed that most of the new construction activity was centered in Minnesota, where value of permits climbed from $17,000,000 to nearly $20,000,000.

Small and medium-sized manufacturers need stronger Government aid in their quest for Marshall Plan export business, it was pointed out last week by Della M. Grattan, president of the D. M. Grattan advertising agency. Increased exports which will help sustain a high degree of industrial activity, she said, are easily possible with the broadening of the base of European Cooperation Administration purchases to include smaller manufacturing units.

SHANGHAI, April 23 -- Acting President Li Tsung-jen and Pre mier Ho Ying-chin flew from Nanking this morning to a destination which American pilots arriving here from the capital identified as Kweilin, home city of the "Kwangsi clique" in South China, headed by General Li.
SHANGHAI, April 23 (AP) -- The Nationalist garrison vowed today to defend Shanghai from the Communists, "come what may."

" Gromyko==Thunder" takes liberties with the Russian language. Gromyko is a real name. Its derivation is obscure. It may have and may have not derived from grom, meaning thunder. The derivation of Vishinsky from vyshnya (cherry). Kravchenko from korova (cow), or Kosygin (not Kozygin) from koza (goat), cannot be justified.

THE aerial is one of the indispensable parts of the home television receiver; the better the aerial, the better the reception. The problem of outdoor aerials is probably one of the most acute confronting television in the larger cities, but in many cases indoor aerials are proving satisfactory.

AT least 2,500 of New York City's 3,000 bars -- roughly 85 percent -- have invested in television sets. But like anything which intrudes itself on established ways in a bar, television has become a controversial point. Principally, bartenders and proprietors are not agreed among themselves whether it any longer helps business.
The National Maritime Union, which supposedly ousted all Communists and Communist sympathizers from official posts last July, is split anew over the Communist issue, it became known yesterday.

LOOKING at television does no permanent harm to the eye, according to leading ophthalmologists. While extended viewing may result in eye-fatigue, particularly in children, the specialists note that it does not in itself cause physical injury to the eye.
WILMINGTON, N. C., April 23 (AP) -- They kept the heat on young Paul O'Leary today but couldn't budge him out of the lead in the $10,000 Wilmington open golf tournament.

HOUSTON, Tex., April 23 (AP) Ted Schroeder and Bill Talbert, the nation's No. 2 and No. 4 amateur players, turned in convincing victories today to move into the final of the River Oaks tennis tournament.

DESPITE the conflicting views in the sports world over the effect of television on attendance at sports events, one definite fact appears to be taking shape: Sports will become less and less a factor in network television programming and, conversely, will consume a greater number of hours on local television stations. In this, television is following the precedent of radio.

TELEVISION programs fall into two categories: planned, rehearsed shows which originate in the studios, and pick-ups from distant points, called "remotes." In charge of each program, of course, is a director.

WHITE epimedium has long been one of the best-loved plants in our garden, and according to Bailey's Encyclopedia, it is as distinctive in its own way as an orchid. Epimedium may be planted as a groundcover in shady places, along woodland paths, or as an edging for shady beds.

BERLIN, April 23 -- Perhaps the most interesting paradox in Europe today is that the Soviet Union, which almost a year ago imposed the blockade of Berlin in order to bring about a meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers and halt construction of a state in Western Germany, now is in the position to achieve these objectives by lifting that blockade.
IN addition to regularly scheduled commercial television broadcasting, two supplementary services have been proposed by two different companies.

MISS SCOTT, author of the memorable "The Story of Mrs. Murphy," has set her new novel in Puritan Massachusetts but her heroine is the reverse of Puritan in the present, accepted sense. She is Cassie Harris, who entered happily into a decorously arranged marriage with Ebenezer Rawson, traveling merchant, and then fell in love with him.

IT would be difficult to select today a more representative figure of the man of culture, in the classical sense, than Bernard Berenson. This fact gives a particular significance to his "Sketch for a Self-Portrait." It is the study of the development of a personality, an intellectual autobiography of the greatest living critic of Italian painting and one of the most brilliant conversationalists of our time.

RONALD REAGAN, president of the Screen Actors Guild, who has just returned from making a picture in England for Warner Brothers, last week discussed with vigor the trend toward American production abroad, which his Guild, in concert with other Hollywood labor groups, is fighting.

MOSCOW, April 23 -- The Soviet Central Statistical administration today submitted an optimistic report on production under the five-year plan for the first quarter of this year, declaring gross Soviet industrial production increased 23 per cent over the first quarter of 1948.

Mayor William O'Dwyer has designated tomorrow as Greater New York Fund Day, marking the opening of the fund's twelfth annual appeal in the city, it was announced yesterday. The statement was included in a proclamation to be read by the Mayor as he accepts the first Greater New York Fund flag at City Hall tomorrow at 12:30 P. M.

PRINCETON, N. J., April 23 -- Representing a quarter-century of planning and nearly three years of construction, Princeton University's new Harvey S. Firestone Memorial Library will be dedicated formally next Saturday. This will mark the official opening of what Dr. Harold W. Dodds, Princeton president, has termed "a liberal arts university in itself."

Today is the 302d day of the Soviet blockade of the Western sectors (pop. 2,250,000) of Berlin. In that time the airlift -- the West's chief answer to the blockade -- has grown spectacularly. In the first airlift operation two B-17's flew ten tons of food into Berlin.

The Seafarers International Union, AFL, emerged as victor in the National Labor Relations Board election aboard nine vessels of the Marine Division of the Cities Service Company, it was announced yesterday at the union's Atlantic and Gulf District headquarters, 51 Beaver Street.

RIVERSIDE, Calif., April 23 (AP) -- John E. Owen, 68 years old, wealthy real estate man, was fatally shot, Sheriff's investigators said today, by his secretary, a divorcee, apparently after a quarrel over a gift he had received from the actress, Irene Rich.

Following the same principle that impelled Mohammed to go to the mountain, the New York City Youth Board soon will assign eleven friendly, experienced persons to seek out children who, for whatever reason, have not visited the play areas and recreational facilities provided for them.
MAJOR ELIOT, who likes short paragraphs, starts this book off with something close to the irreducible minimum in paragraphs. It is simply: "We want peace."

A FAMILY of young people working together against adversity is always a challenging theme to both writer and reader. Mr. and Mrs. Jones have made excellent use of it in this stimulating novel for teen-aged readers.

LAWRENCE, Kan., April 23 (AP) -- Don Gerhmann of Wisconsin ran the fastest outdoor mile of the season today to win the Glenn Cunningham race, feature of the Kansas Relays, in 4 minutes 10.1 seconds. He beat graduate student Jerry Thompson of Texas by a good 30 yards.

OMAHA, Neb., April 23 -- More words were written and spoken in the Midwest this week about highway improvements than on any other topic. There was almost unanimous agreement on the objectives: (1) improvement of winter-battered existing highways, (2) extension of the hard roads and (2) construction of all-weather farm-to-market roads.

While most steel officials stoutly insist that the industry "contemplates" no changes in base steel prices for the near future, a series of recent developments gives assurance that the nation's steel bill for 1949 will be substantially lower than last year's record $8,000,000,000 tab for steel supplies.

THE so-called "death sentence" passed last week by the Civil Aeronautics Board on the irregular carriers, which have been providing cut-rate air coach services, may not be as summary as it at first appeared. The methods of enforcement outlined in the CAB order would make it possible for many of the large irregulars to continue in business into and perhaps through the summer vacation travel season.

A new high record was set in 1948 by corporations in financing their business operations from undistributed profits, a survey by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, released in its annual report, disclosed last week. Only two-fifths of corporation capital needs were obtained from outside sources.
SANTA FE, N. M., April 23 -- The conservation and exploitation of natural resources was a subject of dominant interest this week in the Southwest.
RICHMOND, Va., April 23 -- A Virginia Congressman, home for the Easter recess, put his finger on the mood of the Upper South this week and found the region "pretty well satisfied with things."

JUST a week ago an attempt was made by one very foolhardy person (me) to select the ten greatest moments in baseball history. Oddly enough, there were not too many complaints at the choices made but what disagreements there were bordered on the rather violent side. Naturally enough, the original job was a thankless task.

Redoubled efforts to bring Christ's Gospel to non-Christians "in all parts of the world," were urged in a statement on world problems approved by the executive board of the United Lutheran Church in America, made public yesterday.

A CONTINUOUS supply of greens and roots for the table, from the first peas to the last frost-resistant broccoli, is the pride of the experienced vegetable gardener. And by adding a half dozen all-but-forgotten pot herbs, this "out-of-the-garden" season can be extended at least one month at either end.

THERE is a certain group of plants that might well be called "white elephants." They are passed on from one gardener who has "lots of it" to another who, up until this point, was probably doing all right on his own.

Twenty-six years ago today the dean of St. Matthews Protestant Episcopal Cathedral, Dallas, Tex., came to New York to become rector of the Church of the Transfiguration, 1 East Twenty - ninth Street. He was taking over a close-knit parish in a residential area.

A THREE-lesson course that packs in the basic, practical essentials for quick results is working out successfully for teen-age photographers at the Henry Street Settlement. As the classes approach the end, next month, of the Settlement's first photography term, which started in November, the instructor, Miss Rae Russell, a professional photographer, feels satisfied that her teaching formula has served effectively to maintain interest and to develop ability.

TELEVISION today stands on its own as a new industry and entertainment medium. In the last twelve months its growth has been so rapid and diverse that it is now accepted as an important factor in the country's economic, cultural and social future.

THE annual Narcissus Show of the Horticultural Society of New York Will be held in the Colonnades Ball Room of the Essex House, Fifty-ninth Street and Central Park South, on Monday from 2 P. M. to 10 P. M. and on Tuesday from 10 A. M. to 6 P. M. Although some of the earliest kinds have finished blooming, a representative collection is expected.

Large metal-working companies in New York and New England are completing internal adjustments to operate profitably at average price levels 10 per cent below 1948 peaks. Last week, in a wide variety of lines, such price levels were either announced or prepared for announcement on or before May 1.

THERE'S little use denying that modern furniture is expensive. We mean furniture of the best, "museum approved" design. To young people furnishing a home on anything from a shoestring up to an average-medium budget, the prices look prohibitive.

THE works of sculpture shown here are from "Modern Sculpture: Teaching Portfolio No. 1" (The Museum of Modern Art, New York. $7.50). The portfolio of forty plates was "prepared in conjunction with the Museum's Educational Program" and was designed as the first of a series treating the varied aspects of modern art for the layman's benefit.
ATLANTA, April 23 (AP) -- One battered bullet was the only clue police said they had today in the slaying of John Garris, 36 years old, tenor in the Metropolitan Opera Company.
SHANGHAI, Sunday, April 24 -- Chinese Communist troops today triumphantly occupied Nanking, reports filtering in from that Nationalist capital said.

READERS of Miss Rice's mystery novels fall into two categories: those who are knocked cold by her humor and those who are left cold. Both now have a chance to see how they like their Rice straight, for here she "abandons fun and games and for the first time tries her hand at a straight, suspenseful murder yarn," just as the jacket copy says.

NUMEROUS Left Bank "literary" cafes, such as the Flore and the Deux Magots, in the shadow of the eleventh century abbey-church of St. Germain des Pres, are embarrassed hosts nowadays to a postwar generation, fanatical disciples of the philosopher Jean-Paul Sartre -- who is busy disclaiming them and their activities.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., April 23 -- Cornell swept Onondaga Lake's outlet in three abbreviated crew races with Syracuse today, driving to a half-length victory in the feature varsity event after winning by open water in each of the freshman and junior varsity preliminaries.

Under the guidance of Mrs. Homer Lichtenwalter of Baltusrol, the Women's New Jersey Golf Association's tournament schedule has just been released and a full list of events are ahead of the golfing women in New Jersey.
SHANGHAI, Sunday, April 24 (UP) -- Vast Chinese Communist armies were driving into South China against little or no resistance today and Shanghai, the country's largest city, was in imminent peril.

KIT STORM, readers of this series may remember, is an artist who sketches crimes for the New York police, and his wife Sherry writes novels in which the key-clues lie in Kit's sketches. All of this provides much fun for the puzzle-minded.

THE life of John Augustus Sutter, like the lives of Byron and Napoleon, is an inevitable challenge to the talents of the historic novelist and the writer of fictional biography. But the cold facts of Sutter's life and times fall so neatly into a dramatic pattern that they leave such writers little scope for conscious manipulation.

CHICAGO, April 23 -- The American Council for Judaism, at its fifth annual conference here today, adopted a statement reaffirming its basic position that "Americans of Jewish faith must strive to achieve political, civic, cultural and social integration with the American people" and stressing the council's adherence to the universal traditions of Judaism in opposition to "Jewish nationalism."

ROME. IN the small towns of Italy, like Civitavecchia and Maniago, which are pictured on these pages, you can see what American aid means in terms of people back at work, destroyed utilities being rebuilt, and food and coal coming in.

LELAND STOWE'S latest book on affairs national and international, "Target: You," shows the author in a rather confusing literary mood, at times reminiscent of the instructor in Social Science I, at other times of the platform speaker.

YOU can't believe everything you see on television; the video medium plays tricks on shapes, colors and designs. This is particularly true in the case of costumes designed for TV, according to Paul duPont, stage and ballet costume designer who is in charge of costumes for the Admiral Broadway Revue and the Ford Television Theatre.

Rushing seven runs across the plate in a torrid third inning and then staving off a ninth-inning rally by the Violet, St. John's University dropped New York University from the ranks of the unbeaten in Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference play yesterday by taking a 7-6 decision at Ohio Field.

KENNETH ROBERTS' memoirs quicken the reader with their vitality. His historical novels are among the few still primarily attractive to a male audience, and, reading these pages, it is easy to see why. He has plunged into life and research with equal zest.

Maritime labor groups have indicated that they will redouble their efforts to whittle down the budget of the United States Maritime Service and curtail the training program it finances when the measure is taken up by the Senate.

THE reviews of "South Pacific" have been magnificent, but they don't quite satisfy me. Merely superlative and ecstatic tributes don't do it justice. The standard Broadway term -- "a rave" -- suggests delirium or frenzy, and doesn't adequately convey the sense of deeper understanding which should accompany the homage we pay to a great work of art.
FREQUENCY modulation radio is steadily becoming established as the superior medium of sound broadcasting, and its growth in the last two years has been comparable to that of television.
THE three-cent stamp which Congress authorized for the tercentenary of the founding of what is now Annapolis, will be issued on May 23 with first-day sale in the Maryland city.

TELEVISION until now has specialized in entertainment, chiefly because such programming offered the quickest possible transition from experimental to commercial status. Yet from here on the television industry faces still greater possibilities in the non-entertainment fields.

BERLIN, April 23 -- The reported informal conversations between officials of the Soviet Union and the West over the Berlin situation have introduced a new element into the debate over the constitution for a German federal republic, one that may delay even further the agreement on that document, according to well-informed United States sources.
HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 23 (AP) -- Some 19,000 fans today saw the sensational Coaltown lope around this track alone.
After a morning of dire forebodings, the weather took a surprisingly fine turn yesterday and so, too, did the Giants.

" IRONY" is one of those protean words that tend to elude absolute definition. In this book Mr. Sedgewick, Professor Emeritus of English and special lecturer at the University of Colombia (Canada) does his best to pin down the meaning it assumes when used with reference to drama, and while he has not contributed much that is new to our understanding of dramatic irony, he has provided a clear synthesis of its main aspects.
ANNECY, France, April 23 -- The Netherlands has asked Britain, France and the United States for clarification of the tariff policy of Western Germany, it was learned here today.

TELEVISION in England is expanding rapidly and has ambitious plans for the future. Today it is confined largely to the London area, where an estimated 150,000 sets are in use, but within a year television service is scheduled to be extended to the provinces by means of relay stations erected near Birmingham and Huddersfield.

THE conglomerate, jumbled boom town of Los Alamos, "Capital of the Atomic Age," is opening a new chapter in its short and mysterious history. Born in emergency, built in secrecy, developed in frenzied haste, it is now in the midst of a five-year program of transition from a temporary war cantonment to a permanent scientific-industrial city.

ALBANY, April 23 -- Governor Dewey announced today his approval of a bill setting up a commission to draft and promulgate a state building code. In doing so he expressed a hope that it would be able to effect substantial savings in housing construction costs.

" GREEN Light for Death" rides along using the roughest rules of the road. Johnny Liddell, an affable, good-looking "shamus," can dish it out to a pretty redhead or take it in the squad room when the police gorillas get to work on him.

THE fourteen tales in this attractive collection were heard by the author as a child. She has retold them with suitable adaptations, based upon genuine understanding of the tastes of American children. The stories possess dramatic quality, humor and a gently insinuated doctrine of human kindness and generosity.
BOSTON, April 23 -- The Yankees' headlong dash on the American League victory trail was rudely checked at Fenway Park this afternoon under circumstances that were noisy and painful.

Benjamin Fine's article in THE TIMES of April 17, in which he relayed the argument of the United States Chamber of Commerce against "Federal aid" to education, merely rehashes old arguments which have been completely answered time after time.

TELEVISION intends to follow a policy of self-regulation in maintaining standards of good taste in programming. To date the industry has suffered only isolated criticisms of its behavior. Most of these complaints have been directed at the material of a comedian or so.

In "Alcoholism -- a Neglected Malady," Joseph Hirsh mentions the program of the National Research Council, of which he is a consultant. This program provides for "thoroughgoing research into the causes, mechanism and possible cures for alcoholism." * * *

In promotions here last week retailers stressed summer dresses, flared-back toppers, frame-heel nylon stockings and summer garden and wrought-iron furniture, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the Retail News Bureau, Inc.
WINNIPEG, Man., April 23 -- Canada disclosed today the arrest of a veteran Soviet spy who, officials said, admitted he had entered the Dominion illegally as a fifth-column worker for the Russians.

The fifth and final autograph copy of the Gettysburg Address, in the top rank of importance among American historical documents, will be auctioned on Wednesday evening at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan is making the most of the Government's potato-support program as "a horrible example" in order to sell the long - range farm program which he presented to Congress two weeks ago.

WHEN a television set comes into the home, it reverses traditional requirements for arrangement of the furniture in the living room. Three modern living rooms specifically designed for television are shown above.

MANY correspondents express interest and concern with the subject of the "Decline of Strings" and concomitant matters treated in the last two weeks in these columns None, it seems to us, has struck more directly at the roots of the question than George Szell, conductor of the Cleveland Orchestra. Mr. Szell's letter follows:

CAPITOL RECORDS, which has established itself firmly in the popular field, has begun to compete with the major companies in the symphonic, operatic and chamber music repertory. It has acquired American rights to the records made by Telefunken, a German company, and is releasing them under a Capitol-Telefunken label.

ROME, April 23 -- On Easter Sunday, almost exactly one year after the general election that brought the Christian Democrats into power, Premier Alcide de Gasperi announced the main lines of his eagerly awaited land reform.

TELEVISION'S rise to prominence as a new service to the American people proceeds at such an accelerated pace that its record of achievement may be regarded as one of the most important industrial developments of recent times.

PHILADELPHIA, April 23 -- Pennsylvania celebrated "Rusty Callow Day" by staging a sweep of the four boat races with Yale and Columbia in the Blackwell Cup Regatta on the Schuylkill today for its biggest triumph on the water in recent years.

PEARL BUCK once admitted she couldn't be happy without writing novels. She should not be unhappy, for she has had thirty-four books published since 1930, including sixteen novels, of which "Kinfolk" is the latest.

PARIS, April 23 -- On the surface France's economic situation has never been better since the liberation and there has never been a greater temptation to relax and enjoy the pleasures of this early and encouraging spring. Improvement in living conditions is everywhere notable and the future seems secure.

EVA BURMEISTER is the director of a children's home where there are forty-five, and sometimes more, in the family. But the Lakeside Children's Center of Milwaukee, Wis., has a very different atmosphere from the orphanages of fiction and Hollywood or from those in real life where regimentation and fixed rules of conduct prevail.
THE variety of commercials on television today is perhaps their most distinguishing feature. If the better ones still seek the element of surprise, others are beginning to suffer from repetition.

A majority of the independent business and professional members of the National Federation of Independent Business, Inc., favor elimination of wartime excise tax and the prohibiting of Communists to run for office in the government. These and other findings are contained in the federation's latest report on the sunding of nationwide independent business and professional opinion, and were made public yesterday in Washington.

Asserting that a realistic foreign policy would have saved China from the Communists, Gov. Val Peterson of Nebraska declared yesterday that the Republican party must make up its mind to "stand for a realistic foreign policy based on national survival."

HARDY primroses, or primulas, so perfect for the shady garden, also thrive at the edge of a brook, massed under flowering trees, along a shrub border, or even on the north side of a building. The first ones come into bloom while the daffodil display is at its height, and still other varieties flower as late as June.

IN thinking about radio in the era of television, people are apt to reason in terms of network operations and forget about the hundreds of successful independent stations throughout the country which have made a place for themselves and are going to keep that place by serving the community as no television operation can.

NOT many years ago the Old Testament was read with little regard for the history of the ancient world and with almost no secular information about the background of authors and events. Literary and archeological discoveries of recent decades have brought with them greater understanding of the Scriptures and more, not less, credibility to the biblical narratives.

DETROIT, April 23 -- The issue-behind-the-issue in the strike that has been voted against the Ford Motor Company by 60,000 workers in its River Rouge plant is the control of assembly line speed, the key to the miracle of American mass production.

APPARENTLY oblivious to the attention currently being given his name across the nation, Monty Stratton, the former Chicago White Sox pitcher, can be found most any afternoon fishing contentedly on a small lake just outside this community.

WELL, the Ballet Theatre has pulled itself together and is back in action after its year of disturbed somnolence. For that we should be grateful. We would be well advised, however, to hold our breath a little longer, for what has been shown thus far is not entirely reassuring.
Cotton trading on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday was fairly heavy and final prices were 6 to 22 points net higher.

SHANGHAI, April 23 -- Another British seaman from the Amethyst died here during the past twenty-four hours, after surviving a cross-country hike from the ship in the Yangtze to the railroad and the train trip to Shanghai. [Other reports said a seaman, previously listed as dead, had been found among the survivors, hence the total of deaths remained at forty-four.]

I have feel very sorry for you that you have to spend your precious times about me. I am a Japanese boy of 15 years old and during the daytime I have work at Tokyo branch office of A.A.P.-Reuters, Limited.

Dr. James A. Corscaden, Clinical Professor of Obstetrics and Gynecology at the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University, reported yesterday that 76 per cent of the women treated in recent years at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center for cancer of the cervix in its early stages had been cured.

The Federal Reserve Board has just taken the third step in less than two months to combat the possible spread of deflation. Effective next Wednesday, April 27, it announces, installment credit regulations will be further relaxed. The time limit for completing installment purchases will be increased from twenty-one to twenty-four months, and the down payment will be reduced from 15 to 10 per cent, except in the case of automobiles.
The San Carlo Opera Company's twelfth annual spring run at the Center Theatre, in Rockefeller Center, will begin Wednesday, May 4, with Verdi's "Aida," it was announced yesterday.

The season for annual meetings is in full swing. Probably the peak was reached last week when several of the major companies held their yearly stockholders' get-togethers. Encouraged by management to be present, stockholders attended the sessions in unprecedented numbers.

PINEHURST, N. C., April 23 -- Three down twice in the morning round. Frank Stranahan drew even at lunch time and then moved on to a 2-and-1 victory today over Harvie Ward in the north and south amateur golf final.

Elfield A. Johnson has been promoted to general manager of Burr Stores, the Butler Brothers retail department stores, with full responsibility for all operations. Kirk A. Wickersham will succeed Mr. Johnson as manager of the Burr store in Butte, Mont.

THE excavations at the east end of Forty-second Street, where the United Nations is to have its permanent Manhattan home, will some day soon be the scene of fluttering flags and triumphant bands while President Truman lays the traditional cornerstone.
ALL I know about television is that I want to get into it as soon as possible -- before Milton Berle uses up all my jokes.

ANDRE FRANCOIS-PONCET was French Ambassador to Germany and then to Italy during the nine years before the second World War. He was an ambassador in the great tradition of French diplomacy at its best: he had the lucidity, the passion for logic, the realism, the distrust of political emotion, and the intellectual integrity which Harold Nicolson attributes to French diplomatists, and he had these qualities without their defects.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- College chapters of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People refused today to condemn President Truman for the failure of Congress to approve civil-rights measures.

Net profits of the W. A. Sheaffer Pen Company for the fiscal year ended on Feb. 28 were $2,471,162, or $3.06 a share, C. R. Sheaffer, president, told stockholders in his annual report, released yesterday. This compared with $1,825,582, or $2.25 a share earned in the previous fiscal year.

Henry J. Kaiser, noted industrialist, expects to have some of the top thrills of his life during the next three months. While executive assistants of his enormous empire continue mining ore, building autos, constructing ships, producing cement, fabricating aluminum, making steel, developing his small airplanes and helicopters, planning new airports and other Kaiser projects, the boss himself is monkeying with a 32-foot speed boat that probably will make international sports history.
YOUR mental health is probably pretty sound if you get along with yourself, and with other people, put your best effort into whatever you do, and get satisfaction out of it.

BY the relatively simple process -- in Hollywood, that is -- of never growing any younger, and doing all the dirty work with a smile, Charles Bickford has managed to remain one of the town's most persistently employed film performers.

BOMBAY, India, April 23 -- The first step toward progressive nationalization of Indian shipping will be taken within the next three weeks with flotation of the 7,000,000 ($28,000,000) India-Far Eastern-Australian Shipping Corporation.
THE city motorist, eager to get away from skyscrapers and cement sidewalks as spring advances, can find a variety of rewarding trips no farther away than the Hudson Valley.

The stock market last week broke out of the narrow trading range which had prevailed since late in March, and this month's modest gains were erased. The weakness was centered in Thursday's session when, for the first time this month, the volume on the New York Stock Exchange passed the million-share mark. The break on that day was the worst since Feb. 10.
LONDON, April 23 (Reuters) -- Soccer and Rugby results in Britain today:

LAKE SUCCESS -- The touring American motorist who finds himself abroad, confronted by bewildering foreign signposts and unfamiliar traffic laws, may soon find conditions more to his liking -- if the United Nations has its way.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., April 23 -- Rejuvenated, perhaps by the rain which halted proceedings at the end of an inning and a half of play, Fordham came from behind to turn in a 14-7 Metropolitan Baseball Conference triumph over Hofstra today at the Flying Dutchmen's diamond.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- A characteristic reaction to the Supreme Court's 5-4 ruling this week in the Rice divorce case came from a lawyer who, with the shrug of a shoulder, described it as just "one more decision" in the field of divorce law.

DIE-HARDS in the radio-television industry insist there will always be a market for straight radio sets. The pro-television faction takes no issue with this but points to the price and production record since the middle of last year to drive home its contention that, from now on, straight radio will play a secondary role.

Pitted against a picked eleven representing the New York State Soccer Football Association at Eintracht Oval in Astoria, the Intercollegiate All-Americans yesterday gave a good account of themselves against their more experienced opponents.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The quandary of a sovereign and democratic government when it faces a crucial labor relations problem was illustrated this week with the release of a special commission's report on the handling of labor disputes in atomic-energy plants.

CLEVELAND, April 23 (AP) -- Prince Hal Newhouser pitched effectively in the clutches and Johnny Groth scored the winning run as the Detroit Tigers beat the Cleveland Indians, 5 to 4, in ten innings here today.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., April 23 -- The Boulder Brook Club's annual spring horse show opened a two-day stand in the indoor arena today with Joe Green of Warrenton, Va., riding his aged bay gelding Up and Going to an early lead for the jumper championship.

EDUCATION is America's largest industry. Over one-fifth of the total population are "school people" -- teachers and the taught. What passes for education in our schools is therefore everybody's business, for, as Justice Robert Jackson has pointed out, "Modern society needs to fear little except men, and what is worse it needs to fear only the educated men."

IF it is to fulfill its destiny, television will have to program itself -- as must all mass media -with features that appeal to everyone. Certainly, the medium must be such as to serve all kinds of people in all parts of the country and in different age, income and educational brackets -all, or almost all, of the different kinds of Americans there are.

MINNEAPOLIS, April 23 (AP) -- Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder said today that some of Europe's Marshall Plan countries may have to make their goods cheaper to American buyers before 1952 by lowering their exchange rates. That is the year in which American recovery aid is due to end.

With no easing of the dollar shortage in world markets in sight, signs are increasing that Congress will be asked to enact legislation protecting American exporters against risk of loss in foreign currency transfers.

Many people are now studying the Russian language who were not much interested in it before Soviet Russia clamped down the Iron Curtain. Some of these are in the colleges, some have private teachers and some are "on their own."
ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 23 -- Al Quirk hurled Dartmouth to a 9-2 Eastern Intercollegiate league baseball victory over Navy today.

Social ostracism and economic discrimination were held responsible yesterday for crime and poverty among the 200,000 Puerto Rican migrants in New York, by speakers at a conference held at the New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West Sixty-fourth Street.

CHICKEN ITZA is the scene of Mrs. Knight's latest novel and the author is so skillful in evoking the magnificence of the ancient, jungle-surrounded city that the actual mystery story -- a murder investigation involving a group of tourists at a near-by resort hotel -- is forced into second place.

Disclosure last week of plans for an international survey on all causes of high damage losses currently plaguing American foreign trade was criticized yesterday by export shipper and packaging trade spokesmen.

THE fascination of fancy-leafed caladiums lies in their brilliant foliage which provides color as soon as the first leaf unfurls. Bulbs should be started indoors now for early summer accents on porch or terrace.

The recent American and British notes to Bulgaria, Hungary and Rumania charging violation of peace treaties, and the debates at the U. N. regarding religious persecutions in these countries, are welcome demonstrations that the Western World continues to be deeply concerned over the fate of the peoples behind the Iron Curtain.
WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Athletics slugged out a 14-to-1 victory over the Washington Senators today, slamming Ray Scarborough and Ed Klieman for twenty hits.
The heads-up play of one of his star pupils paid off last night as Billy Ylvisaker scored eight goals to lead Al Parsells' Ramapo Polo Club to the Squadron A spring championship.

Dr. Ralph W. Gerard and Robert D. Tschirgi of the University of Chicago have succeeded for the first time in making a segment of the nervous system work outside the body. After this achievement, scientists should be able to find out what part the nervous system plays in metabolism (conversion of food into energy and tissue) and in the genesis of nervous diseases.

I have just finished reading "Those Americans" in your Magazine. Of course I have read all of this criticism before, but it never ceases to amaze me afresh. How can people who so glibly accuse us of immaturity be so immature themselves and not recognize it?

Two sharp departures from the line of optimistic public utterances by retailers recently were made last week. Two of the largest store groups in the country made public admissions that sales, as computed by the amount of money taken in this year, will probably fall well below 1948.

Twenty-five hundred persons marched in a parade yesterday from Central Park West and 110th Street to the equestrian statue of Simon Bolivar on "Bolivar Hill" just inside Central Park at Eighty-fifth Street.

IF, as some believe, history is geography in motion, the writers of these books expect plenty of history to be made in the next decade or two. Ages of exploration may come and go, but there is always more to explore. Even when we get to know mother earth inside out, there will always be the ocean floors and the stratosphere.

Through the cooperation of theatre owners and the public, the New York Fire Department has been able to keep spotless its record of not having lost a single life in a theatre fire since some time in the nineteenth century, Fire Commissioner Frank J. Quayle said yesterday.

TELEVISION today offers a growing variety of programs running from midmorning until late at night. The shows in the daytime hours mostly follow the pattern of radio -- women's features and popular musical offerings. In the afternoon there are the ball games and presentations for children. The major attractions which best exemplify the progress of television programming in the past year come on after 6 o'clock at night.

TOKYO, April 24 -- Because Japanese business generally expected that Washington would set a 300-to-the-dollar rate for the yen, announcement of the 360 figure generally has been greeted with outspoken relief.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) -- Lou Brissie dealt Washington its sixth straight defeat today, holding the Senators to five hits as the Athletics hammered three pitchers for twelve blows and an 8-3 victory.

ATLANTA, April 24 (AP) -- Police Chief Herbert Jenkins said today that ballistics experts of the Federal Bureau of Investigation were unable to identify a Belgian-made .38 caliber pistol as the death weapon in the slaying of John Garris, Metropolitan Opera tenor.
Current "feuding" between Protestants and Roman Catholics was deplored yesterday by the Rev. Karl M. Chworowsky, pastor of the Flatbush Unitarian Church of Brooklyn.

The man in the street is in no position to decide whether a 65,000-ton aircraft carrier is worth more than the land-based bombers that can be bought with the same money. He may, indeed, wonder if a sum ranging in various estimates from about $223,000,000 to as much as $1,000,000,000 might not be a good deal to tie up in a vessel which might conceivably be destroyed in ten minutes.

Consolidated net income of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) last year averaged $1,000,000 a day after charges and taxes, according to the company's 1948 report released for publication today. Total net income was at a new peak of $365,604,976, equal to $12.44 each on the 29,385,435 capital shares outstanding.

Potential buying power of the nation's teenagers approximates eight billion dollars a year, according to results of the second part of the Gilbert Youth Research Organization survey in the radio field announced over the week-end by the National Broadcasting Company.

MOSCOW, April 24 -- The Communist party's Central Committee called today for friendship of the peoples of Britain, the United States and the Soviet Union as "the best guarantee of a stable peace" in slogans issued for the annual May Day parade and demonstration.

The Rev. Adam Clayton Powell Jr., member of Congress from the Twenty-second district and pastor of the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem, said yesterday that "by no stretch of the imagination" was Paul Robeson qualified to speak for all Negroes in the United States.
WASHINGTON, April 24 (UP) -- A study released by the Brookings Institution today called on Congress to re-examine the 1944 law which gave war veterans preference for Government jobs.

Sybil Shearer, the complete individualist among dancers, yesterday afternoon gave a solo recital at Carnegie Hall, and set us all back on our heels. Her program consisted of a single cycle of eight untitled dances to the music of various composers from Bach to Bartok.

FRANKFORT, Germany, April 24 -- A three-point program to strengthen the campaign for a democratic school system in Germany was outlined here by Dr. Alonzo G. Grace, director of the United States Military Government education and cultural relations program.
Petticoat fever, strictly in the fashion sense, may be quelled at certain times, but there comes the day -- like today -- when it rages again.

SHANGHAI, Monday, April 25 -- Communist armies today snapped shut a trap on 300,000 Nationalist soldiers between Shanghai and Hangchow. The Communists, rushing southward after their crossing of the Yangtze, by-passed Shanghai and captured Kashing, vital rail junction city, in a slash toward the sea.

Pound sterling last week shook off the nervousness which has dominated its market since early month. A strong demand for prompt transfers brought the rate back to $4.03 1/4, a gain of 3/8 cent, while the discounts on 30-90 days' hardened 3/4 to 1 1/2 cents, with six months' narrowed by 1 1/2 cents, with a closing spread of 10 to 11 cents under spot.

An automatic washer that is so flexible in operation that any phase of the complete cycle may repeated or omitted as desired, will be introduced in department stores here about June 1 by the Maytag Company. The new automatic is outstanding in appearance because of its plain cabinet of white enamel, devoid of chrome trim, and notable also for its lack of gadgets.

CHICAGO, April 24 (AP) -- Randy Gumpert pitched a three-hit shutout to give the White Sox their fifth straight victory over the Browns, 4 -- 0, in the second game of a double-header today. The Chicagoans rallied with two runs in the ninth to win the opener, 2 -- 1, before 14,841 fans.

One of the great collections of art in this country, that formed by the late Jules S. Bache, has been formally transferred to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, after exhibition in the institution since 1944.
Two alleged burglars, injured in a struggle with two patrolmen on the dark rooftop of the five-story building at 49 East Thirty-fourth Street, were in the prison ward in Bellevue Hospital yesterday.

MOSCOW, April 24 -- Archibald R. Johnstone, veteran British journalist and for the last two years editor of the official British weekly newspaper, Britanski Soyuznik [British Ally], in Moscow, announced in a letter published by Pravda today his resignation of the editorship, his renunciation of British citizenship and his assumption of Soviet citizenship.
MOSCOW, April 24 -- The elaborate celebration of the Russian Oxthodox Easter opened last night with the traditional midnight services conducted by Patriarch Alexei at Moscow's Yelokhovsky Cathedral.

BOSTON, April 24 -- Gene Woodling stroked two hits in a 12-hit Yankee assault on Red Sox hurling this afternoon before 34,678 fans at Fenway Park and they figured largely in a Yankee rout of the Sox that was measured by 9 to 4.

John Saiu, 36-year-old ex-convict with a record of five penitentiary terms, was held without bail in Bronx Magistrate's Court yesterday for the murder of Jackie Goldsmith, 8, whose strangled body was found in the Bronx on April 15.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., April 24 -- Dominating their respective divisions, the thoroughbred hunter Central Drive, brown gelding owned by Mr. and Mrs. E. O. Smith Jr. of Dover, Mass., and the aged jumper Up and Going, owned and ridden by Joe Green of Warrenton, Va., annexed championships as the two-day Boulder Brook Club indoor horse show closed tonight.

FRENCH LICK, Ind., April 24 -- Measured optimism over the business outlook appears to prevail among the bankers assembled here today for the annual spring meeting of the American Bankers Association's executive council. While conceding that current developments have increased the banking industry's responsibilities, most of these bankers expressed a strong feeling of relief that threat of an immediate depression has disappeared.

Rand Smith, baritone from Boston, gave a recital yesterday afternoon at Times Hall. He was heard in a group of Purcell offerings; lieder by Schumann and Strauss; the arioso, "At Evening Hour" from Bach's "St. Matthew Passion"; "It Is Enough" from Mendelssohn's "Elijah" and contemporary songs by Garner Read, Frederic Hart, John Duke and Ernest Bacon.

JOE M'CARTHY had a birthday last week, his sixty-second. A few days previously his Boston Red Sox had opened their season as a highly regarded championship favorite. Marse Joe was handed a present on his birthday by the Bosox, his first victory of the year. He would like to regard it as a happy omen, because this would be one pennant he'd rather win than any other.

NANKING, April 24 (AP) -- Six hundred thousand Communists -- 200,000 in Gen. Chen Keng's Second Field Army southwest of Nanking, and 400,000 in Gen. Chen Yi's Third Field Army east and southeast of Nanking -- today were pursuing Nationalist forces moving south.

ROME, April 24 -- The statement of Dr. Chaim Weizmann, President of Israel, in New York that the Israeli Government was ready to recognize the interests and concerns of Christianity regarding the immunity and protection of holy places was welcomed in Vatican circles today as a conciliatory and reassuring gesture.

Throughout the history of American farm policy since the enactment of the original Agricultural Adjustment Act in 1933, one subject has been debated more continuously and more spiritedly, perhaps, than any other. That is the subject of Farm Parity.

MILAN, April 24 -- Aiming at creating a highly efficient international selling organization to serve as an instrument for European rehabilitation, the Milan Samples Fair this year established a new all-time world record. At the 1949 Fair twenty-two countries were represented by official displays as against eighteen in 1948, a record until then, and only four in 1947.
WASHINGTON, April 24 (UP) -- Jobless veterans and those who found it hard to make a go of their own businesses have cost the Government nearly $3,400,000,000 since the end of the war.

Unemployment insurance claimants will be required, starting today, to list the names and addresses of all employers for whom they worked last year, State Industrial Commissioner Edward Corsi announced yesterday. He said this applied to nearly 500,000 unemployed workers in this state.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Congress moves into the heart of President Truman's Fair Deal program this week with the opening of consideration on the House floor of the Administration's new labor bill to replace the Taft-Hartley Act.

PITTSBURGH, April 24 -- The national steel ingot rate was off a half point last week to 99 per cent of rated capacity. It was expected that it might slip a little more this week in view of a reduced output at electric steel furnaces.

You published on April 18 a letter from the national board of the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom stating opposition to the North Atlantic Pact upon the ground among others that "we believe that military alliances would make war more likely.
" The long-stemmed American Beauty," a name coined some time ago for the girl 5 feet 7 inches tall or over, is fast becoming the pampered baby of the fashion industry.

Two facts emerge from the reports concerning the lifting of the Berlin blockade. It is certain that Soviet representatives have broached the subject in the Western capitals and at Lake Success, and it is just as certain that the Western Governments are reluctant to respond to these overtures.
HOLLYWOOD, Fla., April 24 -- Twelve hundred women from every part of the country met today in this beach resort to discuss issues ranging from health insurance to the North Atlantic Security pact.
