ALBANY, April 24 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey signed today the Halpern bill creating a commission to formulate a long-range master plan to meet the mental health needs of the state. The measure carries out one of his major recommendations to the 1949 Legislature.

PARIS, April 24 -- The mass demonstration for Soviet peace that was organized by the World Congress of Partisans of Peace was held today in Buffalo Stadium, in the Paris suburb of Montrouge in orderly fashion and without any incidents.

CHICAGO, April 24 -- Government loans on 1948 wheat, will mature on Saturday and experts on the Board of Trade expect defaults on 250,000,000 bushels or more. The grain will be turned over to the Government which will start to move it out of farm and country elevator storage in the Southwest immediately to make room for the oncoming harvest.
CHICAGO, April 24 (AP) -- The Polish Americans of Chicago defeated the Pittsburgh Morgans by 3 -- 2 today in the first contest of their best-of-three series for the Western Open soccer title.

Dr. Eliezer Rieger, head of the Department of Education at the Hebrew University on Mount Scopus in Jerusalem, told a round-table conference of American educators at the Biltmore Hotel yesterday that Israel needed 1,500 to 2,000 new teachers annually.

One more obstacle to the restoration of peace and order in Indo-China has been removed by the vote of the Ter- ritorial Assembly in Cochin China to join in the projected Viet Nam state with which the French hope to replace the hostile Viet Nam Republic. The former Emperor of Annam, Bao Dai, had made such a ballot a prerequisite to his return to Indo-China to set up a government that would cooperate with France.

SHANGHAI, April 24 (UP) -- Editors of the Nationalist newspaper Central Daily News in Nanking were told they could continue publishing, but that they would have to rename their paper Emancipation News. Other Nanking newspapers also were authorized to publish, but they could print only dispatches of the Communist New China News Agency.

The Armenian National Chorus, conducted by Mihran Toumadjan, which made its debut here in June, presented its second concert of Armenian music yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. Most of the well-prepared program was given over to folksongs transposed and arranged by Komitas Wardapet.
While bagpipes skirled and drums rolled outside, 3,500 persons filed into the Cathedral of St. John the Divine yesterday to observe St. George's Day, in honor of the patron saint of England.

Teachers in the social science departments of fifty-nine of the major colleges and universities in the East went on record yesterday asking that teachers be judged primarily on the basis of scholarship and competence.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., April 24 -- The cornerstone of the $300,000 temple of Congregation Beth El of the Oranges and Maplewood was laid today at exercises at which Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll was the principal speaker. The structure, at Irvington Avenue and Kilburn Place, was also dedicated.

VIENNA, April 24 (Overseas News Agency) -- Members of the world-famous Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra, of the Vienna State Opera Orchestra and of its chorus, have left the Austrian Musicians Union as a protest against the leadership of the union.

DETROIT, Monday, April 25 -- The Packard Motor Car Company's plant was closed at 12:01 A. M., Eastern Daylight Time, today by a strike of 9,000 employes, members of Local 190 of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, who accused the management of barring the plant to a union committee seeking to negotiate a new contract.

PHILADELPHIA, April 24 -- The F. Wayland Ayer Cup, highest recognition in the nineteenth annual exhibition of newspaper typography conducted by N. W. Ayer Son, Inc., has been awarded to THE NEW YORK TIMES for excellence in typography, make-up and press work.

The American Heart Association, 1775 Broadway, has allocated research awards totaling $250,000 to twenty-six investigators and six medical schools and hospitals for studies in heart and circulatory disease, it was announced yesterday by A. W. Robertson, chairman of the board.

CAPE HENRY, Va., April 24 -- Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce, outlined today a program that he said was needed to implement President Truman's Inaugural Day pledge of American assistance to the industrially undeveloped areas of the world.
With a number of interesting openings and other events planned for this week, the local art season shows little sign as yet of any seasonal slackening off.

With the season for doctorate theses coming up, this clearly is the moment to raise one question: Why has there never been, and if there has been, why have there not been many, monographs on a baffling subject? It is not concerned with the reason the pretty girls always married elsewhere, or that the grass is greener in the distant pasture, although, to be sure, it is a variation of these.
Communism has "stolen" the Christian technique of personal conversion, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, pastor emeritus of the Riverside Church, said yesterday.

MOUNT MISERY, N. J., April 24 -- Joint flood control maneuvers, directed over the weekend from "disaster" headquarters set up here to coordinate the operations of the Coast Guard and civilian organizations in relief and rescue work, ended today with only a few "kinks" to be ironed out.

LONDON, Monday, April 25 -- For the third successive day, Harry Pollitt, general secretary of the British Communist party, was menaced last night by an angry crowd in a seaport town after he had attempted to speak about the shelling of British ships by the Chinese Communists.
JERSEY CITY, N. J., April 24 -- (AP) -- Jersey City captured both ends of a double-header from Buffalo today, taking the opener, 5-4 in ten innings and the nightcap, 5-3, in seven stanzas.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 24 -- Large-scale log rolling went on here and in New York most of this week-end as opposing sides formed solidly for the coming United Nations battle on two major issues, the immediate admission of Israel into the world organization and the proposal to let member countries exchange envoys again with Spain.
NEWARK, N. J., April 24 (AP) -- Coming from behind in both games, the Newark Bears handed Montreal a twin thumping today by 3-1 and 6-5 margins.

SHANGHAI, April 24 -- The Communist record-breaking offensive swept on unchecked today. After "liberating" the national capital in the early morning hours, the Communist armies swept on around the Shanghai area. To the north they engulfed long-besieged Taiyuan.

Dr. Emanuel Neumann, president of the Zionist Organization of America, denounced yesterday the realignment of "hostile elements" against Israel. He asserted that the activities of the American Council for Judaism "showed a certain amount of coordination with corresponding anti - Zionist propaganda emanating from non-Jewish sources."

A new half-hour series titled "That Wonderful Man" will be seen Thursdays at 9 P. M. over CBS-TV, starting June 2. A situation comedy dealing with a young man who makes good in New York, the program will be sponsored by the Toni Company.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 24 -Premier Riad es Solh of Lebanon went to Damascus today to confer with Premier Husni Zayim of Syria on general coordination of the policies of the two countries.

Such cold as this morning's is probably the last surprise of spring. The meadows and upland fields, the pasture slopes and hardwood ridges are green with the season's promise. It tests man's patience to wait through a period of rains and cold, clouds and cold winds, but when the time of hesitancy is over fifth month beauty comes with a rush.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, April 24 -- Although Peru and Venezuela have avoided a challenge to their delegations to the regional meeting of the International Labor Organization beginning here tomorrow, by the simple means of not sending any, the issue will come up anyway in the form of a condem natory resolution, it was learned today.

Nellise Child's "Sister Oakes" was presented at the Lenox Hill Playhouse for four performances over the week-end by the Experimental Theatre under the sponsorship of the American National Theatre and Academy. It was the fifth production in the season's Invitational Series by the ET.

Any strange glint that a visitor to the staid precincts of the Forty-second Street Library may find today in the eyes of Socrates, Washington Irving or the other plaster busts there should be attributed to the sort of party that might happen once in a hundred years -- and in this case did.

In one of the cleanest cup games in the National Challenge competition of the United States Soccer Football Association ever witnessed, the Philadelphia Nationals of the American Soccer League defeated the New York Sport Club, 5 to 1, at Sterling Oval yesterday.

BONN, Germany, April 24 -- A compromise was reached here in principle by the two major parties today on two sections of the draft of the Western German constitution over which they had been at loggerheads. The compromise will be submitted tomorrow at Frankfort to the United States, British and French Military Governors.

The quarterly report of the Corn Products Refining Company and its subsidiary sales companies, issued for publication today, shows a net income of $3,314.562 for the three months ended on March 31. This is after all charges including a provision of $1,870,000 for Federal income taxes, and is equivalent to $1.14 a share on the outstanding common stock after preferred dividends.
Restoration of liberty to Eastern Europe and Asia was declared yesterday morning in an address here by Senator Herbert R. O'Conor of Maryland to be of utmost urgency.
A "report on community stewardship," an innovation in trade union procedure, was made public yesterday by the State Congress of Industrial Organizations, through its president, Louis Hollander.

SHANGHAI, April 24 -- The many fears of a city about to be besieged are coursing through this metropolis of 5,500,000. Soldiers are jumpy, remembering the Communist-led insurrection that won Shanghai in 1927. The foreign population senses a growing danger of riots that may take an anti-foreign turn. Refugees numbering perhaps 1,000,000 cling fearfully to their few possessions.
BATAVIA, Java, April 20 -- Republican Premier Mohammed Hatta flew to Batavia this afternoon to direct his delegation at Dutch-Indonesian talks during the next few days.
WILMINGTON, N. C., April 24 (AP) -- Henry Ransom of St. Andrews, Ill., today pulled up the last rung of a steady climb to take first place in the $10,000 Wilmington open golf tournament with a 276.

Cardinal Spellman presided in the sanctuary of St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday as the Catholic Chapel Choir of the United States Military Academy at West Point sang the musical setting of the solemn mass of Low Sunday. Msgr. George G. Murdock, former Catholic chaplain at the academy, was the celebrant.

HOUSTON, Tex., April 24 (AP) -- Ted Schroeder, smooth playing United States Davis Cup star, defeated Bill Talbert of Wilmington, Del., today in the men's singles final of the fifteenth annual River Oaks tennis tournament.

I am, fortunately, unable to match recent stories by your correspondents of the great skill of taxi drivers in bouncing manhole covers in Manhattan and Brooklyn. In bucolic Cortland we sleep soundly o' nights and we love our taxi drivers.

As far as maritime labor is concerned the American Merchant Marine is rapidly approaching a crisis with the number of ships in operation growing smaller and the number of jobs diminishing in proportion, according to observers in the field.

In the theatrical scheme of things, it isn't unusual for actors to branch out as playwrights. Making their local debuts as such tonight is the collaborating team of Thomas Coley and William Roerick, whose comedy, "The Happiest Years," starring Peggy Wood, arrives at the Lyceum.

The summer student travel program may get additional help in Washington today when Senator Ralph E. Flanders, Republican, of Vermont, appears before the Senate Appropriations Committee to seek allocation of funds to bring the transport Gen. M. C. Meigs up to Coast Guard safety standards.
ROME, April 24 (AP) -- The International Olympic Committee started its 1949 meeting in Rome today on the keynote of smaller games.
The Department Medal of Honor, the highest award in the Police Department, was granted yesterday to two patrolmen for exceptional heroism in 1948. One of the awards was posthumous.

While the Western World watches in stunned and helpless silence, the Communist armies are spreading out in China at a pace that no purely Chinese led armies have ever attained before, and the tramp of their victory-flushed soldiery proclaims the rise of the red sun over the most populous country on earth.
ST. LOUIS, April 24 (AP) -- Joe Garagiola slammed the ball against the right-center field wall to bring in Enos Slaughter for a St. Louis Cardinal ninth-inning 5-to-4 victory over the Cubs today.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The question of supporting the Atlantic Pact with arms to the eleven member countries came increasingly to the fore this week-end as the Senate Foreign Relations Committee prepared to open hearings Wednesday on ratification of the treaty.

CHICAGO, April 24 -- The corn market on the Board of Trade here was influenced last week to a large extent by the action of wheat, although there was some selling based on larger country offerings when May advanced above $1.36 a bushel.

Offerings in the market for tax-exempt bonds this week will be featured tomorrow by the sale of $40,000,000 of electric plant revenue bonds of the Los Angeles, Calif., Department of Water and Power. The department sold a smaller issue in November, last year, at an interest cost of 2.543 per cent.
FRANKFORT, Germany, April 20 -- It was one thing to talk about delivering coal -- among other essentials -- to Berlin in the airlift. It was quite another to figure out how.

Harry Kratzer has rejoined American Textile Converters, Inc., as general director in charge of sales, distribution and merchandising. Mr. Kratzer was formerly general sales director of the company. He was until recently a merchandise sales and management consultant.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Initial moves to combat the expected "militant" demands of John L. Lewis will be planned here at a national conference of the bituminous industry on Wednesday.

For a few minutes last evening Harry Zack and his wife, Trudie, were robbed of their jewelry and money in their apartment at 1010 Dorchester Road in Flatbush, Brooklyn. But a few minutes after they had handed over the family's valuables at gunpoint they had them back and two chagrined stick-up men had left the apartment all but apologizing.

Reorders in the wholesale apparel market here last week centered on summer suits, low-end toppers retail priced from $10.95 to $14.95, and cotton dresses retail priced under $9, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

PARIS, April 24 -- Instead of advancing the cause of peace, the world Congress of Partisans of Peace in Paris has damaged it, according to Dr. Sidney Hook of New York University and James T. Farrel, author, who are here for the meeting that will be held here April 30 against dictatorship and war.

LONDON, April 24 -- A warning of the dangers for British shipping in the policies of the British Labor Government was given today by F. A. Bates, chairman of the Cunard Steamship Company, in a statement issued to the company's stockholders.
BUFFALO, April 24 (AP) -- Capt. Edward C. Barrett, 49 years old, of the Buffalo Police Department was shot to death in a tavern early today and a precinct detective was charged with the killing.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls during the period April 16 to 22 are given in the appended tabulation:

Municipal Court Justice Benjamin Shalleck, Democratic candidate for Representative in the Twentieth Congressional District, who is recovering from an operation for appendicitis, will formally open his campaign today.
ALBANY, April 24 -- Governor Dewey, in compliance with a resolution adopted by the Legislature last month, issued a proclamation today designating Sunday, May 1, as Loyalty Day.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., April 24 (AP) -- Miss Zoe Ann Olsen showed the courage of which champions are made today as she swept to an easy victory in the three-meter diving event of the women's National A. A. U. indoor swim meet.

CHICAGO, April 24 -- The American Council for Judaism closed its three-day annual conference today with the adoption of a resolution pledging the organization to full cooperation in all efforts toward "revitalization of Judaism in America."

LAKE SUCCESS, April 24 -- The International Labor Organization called upon the economically underdeveloped nations of Latin America today to take stock of their resources and manpower and then plan collectively to gain the fullest benefit from President Truman's "bold new program."

WILDWOOD, N. J., April 24 (AP) -- Ellis Taylor, 31-year-old former Delaware State amateur golf champion, today annexed the twenty -sixth annual-Eastern Inaugural tournament at the Wildwood Golf and Country Club.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 24 -- Mario Vitale, twenty-one-year-old Italian fisherman with no theatrical experience, will appear opposite Ingrid Berg-man in "After The Storm," the picture Roberto Rossellini is producing and directing for RKO in Italy, the studio here has been notified by the director.

Vladimir Havsky, 26-year-old pianist, gave his first New York recital last night at Town Hall. Born in China of Russian parents, the young musician came to this country in 1940, and continued his studies here after many appearances in the land of his birth.
The old story about the bride's biscuits would never have come into existence if the bride had gone to school to Mrs. Lorraine S. Houlihan, state extension home economist.

The living conditions of "half the people of the world" who live in the western Pacific and southeast Asia are "almost intolerable," Dr. Herbert V. Evatt, president of the United Nations General Assembly said yesterday.

A policy emphasized by Mayor O'Dwyer from the start of his administration moves nearer to fulfillment with the signing by Governor Dewey of the measure, still to go to referendum, to exempt from city debt limit $150,000,000 in borrowing power to build hospitals.

Arthur Miller's drama, "Death of a Salesman" and the Cole Porter-Sam and Bella Spewack musical, "Kiss Me, Kate," won Antoinette Perry awards for outstanding contribution to the theatre here last night. Two British performers, Rex Harrison and Martita Hunt won prizes for their respective roles in "Anne of the Thousand Days" and "The Madwoman of Chaillot."

PARIS, April 24 -- A diplomatic suggestion has been made and is now under discussion that Greece's northern frontiers with Albania, Yugoslavia and Bulgaria should be guaranteed either by the United Nations or by the Big Four Powers.
BOSTON, Mass., April 24 -- The United States Army transport General R. L. Howze arrived today from Bremerhaven, Germany, with 940 displaced persons from eleven European countries.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., April 24 (AP) -- Edgar Dame of Revere, Mass., captured the senior men's North American indoor speed skating championship last night at the Broadmoor Ice Palace.

Customs collections at this port continued in a downward trend last month, being $1,526,921 below the total in March, 1948, according to a report by Harry M. Durning, Collector of the Port. Last month's aggregate of $18,213,498, Mr. Durning said, included $13,137,059 in duties and $5,076,439 in fines, penalties and fees.

SHREWSBURY, N. J., April 24 -- George Ford Morris, who has been painting portraits of America's most famous horses for nearly sixty years, has what is said to be the nation's greatest collection of equine art.

NANKING, April 24 -- The 1,000,000 inhabitants of Nanking, former capital of Nationalist China, awoke this morning to find the Communists in control of their city. The Communist troops entered at 2:30 A. M., with the first contingents marching in behind a civilian jeep carrying several Communist officers and three members of the "Nanking Municipal Security Maintenance Committee."

PARIS, April 24 -- French steel production for March reached the highest level it ever had attained. It stood at 827,000 tons, compared to 809,000 tons, which was the average production for the record year of 1929. Last February production was 720,000 tons; in January 734,000 tons, in December, 1948, 711,000 tons, and in November 682,000 tons.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The State Department said tonight that both it and the Attorney General concurred in the decision that Pierre Cot of France and Konni Zilliacus of Britain were "inadmissable" to this country. Their applications for visas enabling them, as members of European parliaments, to take part in a lecture tour of the United States were, accordingly, denied.

CHICAGO, April 24 -- Following is the text of the statement by Dr. Elmer L. Henderson, chairman of the board of the American Medical Association, on President Truman's proposed national compulsory health insurance programs:

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Although there is a general concession that President Truman's compulsory health insurance program has no chance of approval at this session of Congress, the verbal fight over it, pro and con, continued today.

Heavy advertising budgets, particularly since early March, lent optimistic overtones to the opinions of newspaper publishers interviewed here yesterday on the business outlook for the remainder of 1949.

ALBANY, April 24 -- Five bills dealing with the compensation and appointment of Official Referees, including one bill that would have increased from $9,000 to $11,500 the annual salary of any Municipal Court Official Referee assigned to the Supreme Court or City Court, were vetoed today by Gov. Thomas E. Dewey.

The post office system is fundamentally a public service and salaries of its employes should have nothing to do with the determination of postal rates, speakers declared yesterday afternoon at a meeting of letter carriers and clerks in the High School of Commerce, 155 West Sixty-fifth Street.

Paul Robeson will do himself and the cause of the American Negro a dis- service if he carries out his resolution not to sing again but to devote his life to making speeches. Mr. Robeson is a great artist and a powerful and pas- sionate personality. That he should determine to devote his great gifts and his great energy to the betterment of the racial group from which he comes is natural and praiseworthy.

The pattern of future air services over the Atlantic was further clouded over the week-end by two actions taken in Washington by the Civil Aeronautics Board, with notifications to interested parties served here on Saturday.

SHANGHAI, April 24 (UP) -- Long columns of service troops threaded their way through the city today carrying what appeared to be boxes of ammunition up to the hastily prepared defense lines of mud and concrete pillboxes.

PITTSBURGH, April 24 (AP) -- Third Sacker Eddie Bockman smashed out two home runs in the nightcap today to give the Pittsburgh Pirates a 3-to-1 victory over the Cincinnati Reds and an even split in their doubleheader. The Reds captured the ten-inning opener, 3 to 2.

In the autobiography of the late Morris R. Cohen, one of City College's most distinguished sons and teachers he pointed out that in times past the college administration had displayed a lack of wisdom in its relations with the students by emphasizing the desirability of good manners to the exclusion of devotion to liberal principles.

Fair pitching, a fine, opportune offense and a flawless defense gave the Giants a 6-2 victory over the Braves before 26,007 fans at the Polo Grounds yesterday. Sheldon (Available) Jones, who never has bowed to the Braves, was helped by Bobby Thomson's three-run homer in the first and his mates bobbed up with three double plays to keep the visitors at a respectable distance.

The first step toward a possible integration of the city's rapid transit lines with the commuter services of railroads using Grand Central Terminal and Pennsylvania Station has been taken with the approval of Mayor O'Dwyer, it was disclosed yesterday.

BRISTOL, Conn., April 24 -- The title of best obedience dog in the world record trials of the Obedience Dog Training Club of Forestville today went to the golden retriever, Featherquest Trigger, CDX, owned and handled by Mrs. Marjorie B. Perry.

CHICAGO, April 24 -- The American Medical Association charged today that President Truman's message to Congress Friday in which he outlined his national compulsory health insurance program contained "a great deal of double talk" and warned that "what he actually proposes would regiment doctors and patients alike under a vast bureaucracy."

Not so long ago Dr. Karl T. Compton appeared before the Senate Committee on Military Affairs and drew a picture of what would have happened if some military agency of the Government had decided earlier in the century that the automotive engine had military potentialities and therefore refused to permit the publication of studies on high-octane fuels, metallurgy and thermodynamics.

" A Barbarian in Asia," a book of travel impressions by Henry Michaux, French poet and painter, will be brought out by New Directions on May 13. It deals with travels in India, Burma, Malaya, Ceylon, China and Japan. It has been translated from the French by Sylvia Beach, the original publisher of James Joyce's "Ulysses."

The need for skilled service in the adoption field is so great today that only a partnership of public and private agencies can cope with it, according to the 1948 annual report of the Spence-Chapin Adoption Service, 304 East Thirty-third Street, made public yesterday.

Cotton manufacturers say they are cutting their mill prices the limit to stimulate buying and stabilize the textile industry. According to a review by The Associated Press. They say they are getting close to the point where the prices that they charge just about equal the cost of making cloth.

PHILADELPHIA, April 24 -- The weather was cold and the Dodgers were not so hot as they struggled through their first double-header of the season at Shibe Park today, blowing the first game to the Phils, 7 -- 4, and barely salvaging the nightcap, 6 -- 5.

The third of the concerts called Aristo Artists was given at Town Hall late yesterday afternoon. Four young singers who had previously been heard elsewhere joined forces in solo, duets and a quartet, for the benefit of a large, enthusiastic audience.

The Ballet Espanol Ana Maria, which made its local debut last summer in the Carnegie "Pops," last night gave the first of three scheduled performances at the Ziegfeld Theatre. With an orchestra in the pit, gold curtains, and a new set by Salvador Dali, it was obviously done on the grand scale.
WARSAW, April 24 (AP) -- The Roman Catholic hierarchy told Poland's millions of Catholics today to ignore attacks on priests printed in the controlled press of the Communist-led Government.
LOS ANGELES, April 24 (AP) -- Argentina routed the United States, 11 to 6 in the third and deciding match of their international polo series today before 15,875 spectators.

If the Archbishop of Canterbury, rather than the Bishop of Long Island, had been called upon to settle the dispute over the Rev. Dr. John Howard Melish, the 74-year-old clergyman "would still be in his pulpit," in the opinion of yesterday's preacher at Holy Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church in Brooklyn.

A ray of hope dawned yesterday for Mr. and Mrs. Andrew C. Hoffman, who flew here from New Orleans on Sunday with their blind 7-month-old twins, Dennis and Kenneth. For after a two-hour-examination of the babies by specialists at the Institute of Ophthalmology at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, the parents were told that Dennis had partial vision and that Kenneth could undergo an operation with a chance that sight might be provided for him.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., April 25 -- Dr. George W. Taylor of the faculty of the Wharton School of Finance and Commerce of the University of Pennsylvania, said today that the basic approach to new labor legislation should be to repeal as much as possible of that now existing.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, April 25 -- A virtual revolution in industrial packaging, which envisages "pushbutton" distribution eventually, has been started by members of the National Supply and Machinery Distributors Association, representing an industry which sells more than $3,000,000,000 of products annually. Officials revealed these objectives today at the public auditorium at the opening of the annual convention attended by more than 2,200 executives.

The deportation of Mrs. Beatrice Siskind Johnson, an alien and longtime Communist party minor official, has been recommended by Warren Miller, presiding officer at her deportation hearing, it was announced yesterday by Edward J. Shaughnessy, district director of the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The Republican party has made the recapture of the farm vote its top priority objective in its fight to regain Congress in 1950 and the Presidency in 1952, it was announced today.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The Supreme Court, in a 4-to-4 decision, upheld today a Federal Trade Commission order which outlawed the "basing point" pricing system for rigid steel, conduit manufacturers.
WASHINGTON, April 25 (UP) -- Dr. Chaim Weizmann, President of Israel, denied today that his country had any desire to conquer neighboring Arab territory, as allegedly feared by some Arab leaders.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The policy committee of the United Mine Workers of America today agreed upon certain demands to be served on the bituminous coal operators for inclusion in the new agreement, which will replace the one expiring on June 30.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Additional facts on the Administration's policy of helping arm other countries are now available in Washington.

NAP RUCKER was just a young fellow himself in those days and his dreams were the dreams of youth as he envisioned himself pitching in the big leagues some time in the near future. But he only was serving his apprenticeship then with Augusta of the Sally League, an easy-going chap leading an easy-going life. There was no hustle or bustle to it and the formula rarely changed.

ROME, April 25 (Reuters) -- An Italian dressmaker today predicted that Italy will be swept by the "Margaret look" -- fashions from clothes to be worn by Princess Margaret on her Italian tour, which starts on Wednesday.

LONDON, April 25 -- In their search for a formula to keep India in the British Commonwealth after she becomes a republic, Commonwealth Prime Ministers worked overtime tonight. After a meeting in the afternoon they reassembled at 9 o'clock for their third plenary session.

AMMAN, Transjordan, April 25 -- King Abdullah inaugurated today in Shuna, in northern Transjordan near the Jodan River, the Wadi el Arab irrigation project, which is expected to play a decisive role in the development of the new Arab state with its more than doubled population.

DETROIT, April 25 -- With a walkout at the Packard Motor Car Company settled in a union victory only a few hours after it had started, Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, moved today to forestall precipitant strike action against the Ford Motor Company.

The study to be made by various agencies looking to possible integration of travel facilities for commuters into New York City is one phase of what must be a continuing effort to see the metropolitan region whole. The New York Central, the New Haven and the Long Island Railroads have their own commuter problem, a problem which has put the Long Island road into bankruptcy.

A comprehensive job of restoring the entire exterior of New York's City Hall rather than piecemeal replacement of worn and faulty portions of the ancient stonework will be recommended soon to the Board of Estimate by Commissioner of Public Works William H. Zurmuhlen, it became known yesterday.
HOLLYWOOD, Fla., April 25 -- Full support of the Atlantic pact by the country's largest women's organization was virtually assured here today.
The report of the board of directors of The Associated Press to the annual meeting of members follows:

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development intends to stick to making loans on economic rather than "social or relief grounds," Robert L. Garner, vice president, told a news conference today.

Charles A. Richards Jr., a chemist, was found dead of gas poisoning yesterday in his apartment at 210 East Sixty-eighth Street under circumstances that led the medical examiner's office to believe he may have turned off the gas jets himself to prevent an explosion after inhaling enough gas to cause death.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- A new concept of the origin of our solar system, suggesting that billions of systems similar to our own exist in the universe, with new ones still being born in the vastness of space, was outlined here today at the annual meeting of the National Academy of Sciences by Dr. Otto Struve, director of the Yerkes Observatory, University of Chicago.

To mark its tenth anniversary of television broadcasting, the National Broadcasting Company has scheduled a special hour-long telecast for Saturday night, 8 to 9 o'clock. Officials are rounding up the major NBC-TV performers to appear on the program, which will be presented over the entire television network.

One of the young professional stars of the district, 26-year-old Jack Burke of the Metropolis Club, shared top honors yesterday with veteran Jack Patroni of Apawamis in the metropolitan sector's qualifying round for the national P.G.A. championship.

PINEHURST, N. C., April 25 (AP) -- A breath-taking 38, 32 -- 70, which was 4 under par and a record for the event, gave Miss Grace Lenczyk, national champion of Hartford, Conn., the qualifying medal today in the forty-seventh annual North and South women's amateur golf tournament.

PITTSBURGH, April 25 (AP) -- Truett (Rip) Sewell, veteran Pittsburgh Pirate right-hander, hung the Indian sign on the Chicago Cubs for the second time of the season tonight as he hurled the Bucs to an 8-2 victory.

The sixty-third annual convention of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, which opened yesterday morning at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, spent the first day discussing labor relations in the newspaper industry.

STATE COLLEGE, Miss., April 25 -- The buzzard can still teach aerodynamics to man, according to Dr. August W. Raspet, who is beginning here a series of observations of the soaring scavenger from a sail plane in behalf of the Engineering Department of Mississippi State College.

Magistrate Morris Rothenberg replied yesterday to the criticism, made on Saturday at the annual meeting of the American Council for Judaism in Chicago, of him for disqualifying himself in the case of three Jewish boys brought before him on charges of pelting Ernest Bevin, Britain's Foreign Minister, with tomatoes.

NANKING, April 25 -- Twelve Communist soldiers forced their way into the home of United States Ambassador J. Leighton Stuart on Shanghai Road at 6:45 A. M. today, awakened the 73-year-old diplomat and demanded the right to inspect the premises.

Recent mind-reading of the bond market by underwriting syndicates was vindicated by Wall Street developments yesterday afternoon. Within an hour of the deadline sale of $8,000,000 Texas Electric Service bonds, orders from insurance companies started to eat away at the substantial unsold parts of the $50,000,000 Commonwealth Edison Company 3s of 1999, and the New England Telephone Telegraph 3s of 1974, and by mid-afternoon both issues were reported "cleaned up."

ALBANY, April 25 -- Four related bills affecting New York City school teachers were approved to day by Governor Dewey. They have the effect of permitting the Board of Education to continue its current practice of assigning teachers to subjects other than the one for which they are licensed.

It is not a model parade that is taking place at Lord Taylor's this week, but rather an exhibition as static as that at Madame Tussaud's wax works. There is, however, this difference. The store's figures are of beautiful girls clad in the latest summer styles and not of world celebrities as they are in the famed London exhibit. The costumes the models wear are by Claire McCardell, known for her American fashions.

One tricky single by the rookie first-baseman, Dick Kryhoski, the first of two blows he contributed to a sparse assault, meant the difference between victory and defeat for the Yankees yesterday in their first meeting of the campaign with Connie Mack's Athletics at the Stadium.

It is not often that a man sits for forty years on the federal bench. Even less often are those forty years a record of continuous growth and continuous achievement. Judge Learned Hand of the United States Court of Appeals, who completes his own forty years on the bench today, is far more than an example of judicial longevity.

WEST POINT, N. Y., April 25 -- A four-run rally in the seventh enabled St. John's to come from behind and defeat Army, 6 to 3, at Doubleday Field today. It was St. John's sixth straight victory in a string that began again Hofstra ten days ago.

In the greatest surface action in naval history, the Battle of Leyte Gulf in World War II, an error in our command judgment imperiled our whole striking force in the liberation of the Philippines, Admiral Thomas C. Kinkaid declared last night.

LONDON, April 25 -- The Foreign Ministers' deputies of the Big Four powers, who resumed their discussions of an Austrian peace treaty here today following a two-week Easter recess, found themselves plunged almost immediately into the now familiar three-to-one deadlock. As usual, the Soviet Union was in the minority.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The State Department directed a "vigorous protest" today to Chinese Communist military authorities at Nanking over violation of the diplomatic immunity of United States Ambassador J. Leighton Stuart whose home was invaded by armed Communist troops.

CHICAGO, April 25 -- Data showing how thirty-three editors and publishers, mostly of down-state Illinois newspapers, were carried on the "compensation for personal service payroll" of former Gov. Dwight H. Green for a total of $305,000 have caused a sensation in Illinois.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was active yesterday and final prices were irregular, 24 points higher to 7 points lower.

ROME, April 25 -- The Communist contention that Italy's adherence to the North Atlantic treaty has caused a revulsion of feeling throughout the country and turned many voters against the dominant Christian Democratic party was belied by the results of the municipal election in Civita Castellana, near Rome, it was announced today.

The land of the bean and cod is now turning out extra-fine coffee. A machine that can be set up in a retail store, where it roasts coffee beans and dispenses them, ground or whole, at the touch of a button, is in production in Boston.

A lapse on what appeared to be a double-play ball gave City College a run in the tenth inning and a 4-3 victory over Kings Point yesterday in a Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference game at Van Cortlandt Park. Joe Palank's throw to second nipped Herb Horowitz, but the twin killing failed as Dick McGuire's peg to first went wide, allowing Bill VanderDoes to scamper across with the winning tally.

The North American Company, once one of the major electric-utility holding systems in the nation, expects to complete its divestment program under the Holding Company Act by the end of 1949. This was reported yesterday by Herbert C. Freeman, the president, to 150 stockholders at the fifty-ninth annual meeting at 60 Broadway.

SEATTLE, April 25 -- Kindly stop worrying about the theatrical culture of Seattle. Anybody in Seattle can go to the theatre once or twice a week for a dollar. Maurice Evans and his excellent company are just concluding an engagement with "Man and Superman," which costs $3.75.

Monarch-Saphin Stores will grant trade-in allowances on used television receivers to be applied against the list price of new sets purchased beginning today, Albert Saphin, president, announced yesterday during a press conference in the Seymour Hotel.

PRAGUE, April 25 -- After having passed a "peace manifesto" accusing the West of preparing war and approving the formation of a committee to perpetuate their work -- identical with the Paris resolutions -- 276 delegates from seventeen countries tonight wound up a five-day little peace congress here.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- A judge testifying before the House Committee on Un-American Activities accused the American Slav Congress today of being "the most dangerous fifth column operating among our Slavic population."

DETROIT, April 25 -- A halt in the car price reduction trend in the event of an epidemic of spring strikes in the automotive industry was forecast today by George T. Christopher, president of the Packard Motor Car Company.

Recommendation was made yesterday to President Truman by the United States Council of the International Chamber of Commerce that he appoint a committee of Government officials and business and financial leaders to explore the whole field of implementation of Point 4 of the President's inaugural address. Point 4 calls for a "bold new program" for the development of underdeveloped areas of the world.
BOSTON, April 25 (AP) -- Mel Parnell, Boston lefthander, today pitched his second shut-out of the season as the Red Sox defeated the Senators, 2 -- 0.

While Billy Southworth went all the way with Bill Voiselle, a seasoned righthander, Burt Shotton experimented with a trio of rookies yesterday at Ebbets Field. The result was a 3-0 victory for the Braves over the Dodgers, who suffered their first shut-out of the campaign.

Reports from conservation agencies throughout the country, compiled by the Wildlife Management Institute, indicate that the small-game populations are on the upswing in most areas, with substantial increases in waterfowl and some shorebirds.

Judith Anderson's starring vehicle, "Medea," will be the first legitimate offering with a professional Broadway cast to play Washington since the Actors Equity ban on Negro discrimination in the capital playhouses, it was announced yesterday.

Stressing a dynamic program of expanding distribution by business and a "national prosperity budget" by Government to facilitate attainment of maximum markets, Leon H. Keyserling, vice chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said yesterday that to have a higher standard of living "we will have to find markets for $400,000,000,000 in goods and services during the next ten years, or an average of $40,000,000,000 a year over 1948."

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, April 25 -- The President of Uruguay, Luis Batlle Berres, opened the inter-American regional conference of the International Labor Organization with a plea that social progress should not be sought at the expense of civil liberties.
Two masked specialists in jewel thefts entered a Brooklyn apartment yesterday, tied up a mother, her son and a delivery boy and left with two rings and a wrist watch valued at $9,700.

Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty, who is awaiting appeal from his sentence to life imprisonment, is the subject of two biographies scheduled for summer publication. Scribner will bring out one by Bela Fabian, a member of the executive committee of the Hungarian government in exile.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Administration forces predicted today that they would defeat the Wood labor relations bill, which is opposed by organized labor. Republicans, however, voiced confidence that this substitute for the Administration-supported Lesinski bill would be passed, possibly with some amendments, by Friday.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- President Truman, who vetoed forty-three bills of the Eightieth Congress last year, opened up on the Eighty-first Congress today with four vetoes.

FRENCH LICK, Ind., April 25 -- Resentment among bankers over policies of the Federal Reserve Board that "encroach" upon their activities in the banking field has become especially marked at the meeting of the executive council of the American Bankers Association, now in session here. Three hundred and fifty bank officers, members of the council, are attending the "off-the-record" meeting, which will continue through tomorrow.

The Associated Press at its meeting yesterday in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel re-elected five members of its board of directors and added one new member. The balloting took place at the morning session and the results were announced late last night.
WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- The Senate approved today by voice vote a bill giving the Commodity Credit Corporation authority to acquire a nation-wide system of storage facilities for farm crops.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Self-help and Federal aid have changed the lot of Negro farmers in the South, agents of the Farmers Home Administration of the Department of Agriculture said today. Sharecroppers, by buying land and studying agriculture, have become successful small farmers, agency personnel said.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (UP) -- The Senate Armed Services Committee today tentatively approved legislation to tighten unification of the armed forces by giving new powers to Secretary of Defense Louis Johnson and authorizing a chairman for the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

SHANGHAI, Tuesday, April 26 -- The United States Navy and Marines today made hasty preparations for the evacuation of Shanghai. They are seeking to get all ships, including the Marine transport Chilton, out of the Whangpoo River befor the Communist artillery comes within range of its narrow channel.
PRINCETON, N. J., April 25 -- Ray Lindquist's ninth-inning single with the bases loaded helped the Dartmouth varsity notch a 6-2 Eastern Intercollegiate League victory over Princeton here today.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES recently Arthur Krock took up the question of the long overdue "reorganization of the two major political parties," both split wide open, and reported a quiet movement afoot "to try to get citizens of reasonable like mind under the same label and scrap those bearing the words 'Democrat' and 'Republican.'"

Seventy-four department store buyers here from Goldblatt Bros., Chicago, to purchase $6,000,000 worth of merchandise in five days beginning yesterday, reported that prices and merchandise were greatly improved over last year. Manufacturers appeared anxious to please and "hundreds" of their salesmen had to be turned away yesterday, according to Louis Goldblatt, executive vice president in charge of merchandising.
Herbert Hoover declared last night that governmental welfare agencies had their place in American life "provided the cloak of welfare is not used as a disguise for Karl Marx."

The press of April 21 quoted Paul Robeson as saying "American Negroes won't fight Russia." If Mr. Robeson made such a statement he was expressing his own personal views and not representing the mass of Negro young people who will be called upon to fight in the event that America goes to war again.
The Department of Sanitation declared the winter officially over yesterday -- despite an early morning temperature of 38.7 degrees -- and started putting its snow-fighting equipment into mothballs.

Thousands of pre - school - age children, most of whose parents have no private physicians, have been turned away recently from the city's seventy-two child health Stations because of a shortage of public health nurses, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that 576,000,000 bushels of wheat were in storage on April 1. Stocks were larger than on April 1 in any other years except 1942 and 1943.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- A majority of the Federal Power Commission objected today to proposed amendments to the Natural Gas Act. They said the changes would open the way to higher costs for the ultimate consumer.

It is good news that I read in THE TIMES of today about the Scandinavian states being "disturbed over Israel's failure to find and punish the murderers of Count Folke Bernadotte, the U. N. Mediator for Palestine." This is the first mention I have seen in our newspapers for many months of that peculiarly shocking crime.

A cross-section of spring in the country came to the city yesterday when the annual narcissus show of the Horticultural Society of New York opened in the Essex House on Central Park South. The exhibition to which the public is invited will be open today from 10 A. M. to 6 P. M.
PARIS, April 25 -- With the immense drama of China unfolding, for the moment there appears to be an easing of the crisis on the European frontiers between the Western and Soviet blocs.

Little lessons in finance for teenage girls just learning to handle their own money are included in a gaily illustrated booklet, "A Miss and Her Money," just published by the Institute of Life Insurance, 60 East Forty-second Street. Copies are available for parents, youth counselors and youngsters themselves.

Sidor Belarsky, bass, who recently returned from Palestine, devoted his program at Carnegie Hall last night to "Songs of Israel." He had the assistance of Lazar Weiner, who accompanied two groups at the piano, and of Siegfried Landau, who led the orchestra of thirty-five musicians.

Federal Judge Harold R. Medina left the bench temporarily yesterday at the Communist trial to prevent defense counsel from "goading" him into action that might prove "a source of difficulty." The judge wrathfully accused Eugene Dennis, general secretary of the Communist party and one of the defendants, along with defense lawyers, of "disorderly, disobedient and disrespectful" conduct.
A six-week cruise to Haifa, Israel, aboard the new Portuguese liner Patria will be offered in mid-summer by the Flomarcy Company, Inc., 90 Broad Street.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 25 -- Except for the San Francisco Bay area, West Coast shipping did slightly better in the first quarter of 1949 than correspondingly last year, when measured in terms of longshore hours worked, according to a report submitted to the dock workers by the Waterfront Employers Association.

Wool futures renewed their decline yesterday in quiet trading. Wool-top contracts dropped 2 to 2.5 cents a pound in sales of only 40,000 pounds, while grease-wool futures were off 0.5 to 1 cent a pound in transactions of 180,000 pounds

Music by Charles Ives, Erich Itor Kahn and Karol Rathaus -- all of it new or largely unfamiliar -- was on the agenda at last night's concert presented by the United States Section of the International Society for Contempoarry Music at the Museum of Modern Art.

Drifting irregularly lower after a quiet and mixed opening, stock prices yesterday closed the dullest session in two weeks on the New York Stock Exchange. Although several large blocks of low-price utility shares changed hands shortly after the bell, sales dropped to 740,000 shares from 890,000 shares on Friday.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 25 -- In a mood of compromise, Dr. Raul Noriega of Mexico told the Social Committee of the United Nations General Assembly tonight that he was prepared to drop a Mexican amendment to the controversial "states' rights" article in the future news-gathering convention.

All four candidates for Representative of the Twentieth Congressional District formally opened their campaigns yesterday for the seat of the late Sol Bloom when they outlined their positions on domestic and foreign issues at a luncheon of the West of Central Park Association.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The Government is putting about $300,000,000 of public funds into support of civil aviation in the current fiscal year, which ends June 30, the Bureau of the Budget reported today.

The annual meeting of news and business executives of The United Press began yesterday in the offices of the news agency at 220 East Forty-second Street with a discussion of efforts to gain more freedom for news correspondents throughout the world.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat, of Nevada, said today that a Senate judiciary subcommittee had "conclusive and alarming evidence" of "extensive subversive activity being carried on in this country" under direction of foreign agents.

NANKING, April 25 -- Law and order has returned to Nanking and this former Nationalist capital has settled down in the back water of the Chinese civil war waiting for a full fledged Communist political takeover.

All twenty-three crew members of the freighter Flying Arrow, who have been accused of misconduct, complied with an order of the ship's captain to be ready to sail from Singapore at midnight Jan. 19, according to the testimony yesterday of David Beynon, a member of the crew, at a Coast Guard hearing at 80 Lafayette Street.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 25 -- Negotiations over the week-end failed to produce an agreement on a compromise plan for a five-nation administration of Libya, it was learned today, and the debate will be resumed tomorrow in the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly.

CHIEM SEE, Germany, April 25 -- Development of an educational Marshall Plan to unite the Western democracies in closer cultural bonds was proposed by leading educators at the opening of the first international conference on comparative education.

Plans for the opening of approximately forty plants throughout the country before the end of the year in which industrial wastes will be converted to a soil conditioner, were announced yesterday at a press luncheon in the 21 Club.
LONDON, April 25 -- The Admiralty announced tonight that the 8,000-ton Fiji-class cruiser Jamaica had been ordered from her station in Bermuda to the Far East immediately.

The United States Court of Appeals reversed yesterday the contempt-of-court conviction and six-month jail sentence imposed on William Rosen early last month for refusing to answer Federal grand jury questions concerning an automobile formerly owned by Alger Hiss.

LONDON, April 25 -- The Westminster Economic Conference of the European Movement, of which Winston Churchill is a president of honor, closed here today after a week of deliberation. Delegates from twenty-one nations paid tribute to the work done in furthering European economic unity.
President Truman's Inaugural Address presented a four-point program for combating communism on a worldwide scale. The fourth of these points was new. Said the President:

No doubt most newspaper readers select their favorite journals primarily for content. They may also be influenced, more or less consciously, by the manner in which this content is displayed. It is to this latter element that the judges in the annual F. Wayland Ayer Cup contest address themselves.

Net income of the Republic Aviation Corporation in the first three months of this year declined to $254,055 from $1,282,558 earned in the initial quarter of 1948, according to the report released today. Sales totaled $9,706,107, against $14,374,928 last year.

CHICAGO, April 25 -- Grain markets fluctuated in a nervous manner on the Board of Trade here today with new-crop deliveries of wheat developing independent weakness as the result of selling induced by a forecast for rain over the greater part of the North American winter and spring wheat areas.
The resolution of tribute to the late Frank B. Noyes, adopted by the board of directors of The Associated Press and read at the annual meeting yesterday, follows:

An issue of $40,000,000 of debentures of National Distillers Products Corporation, one of the largest issues of long-term industrial securities registered for the public market in recent months, will be offered to investors today by an underwriting syndicate headed by Glore, Forgan Company and Harriman Ripley Jr Co., Inc. The bonds bear interest of 3 1/8 per cent and are priced at 101.31 to yield 3.05 per cent to maturity.

Eugene T. Rossides, an outstanding Columbia University football player, was named yesterday as the first recipient of a scholarship established in the School of Law by Walter D. Fletcher, a university trustee.
A successor to the old pro-Communist Greater New York CIO Council was organized last night, with a pledge that the Communist party would be "exiled forever" from control over its affairs.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Ten Administration stalwarts, introducing in both houses of Congress the omnibus bill to carry out President Truman's national health program, said today that its provision for universal medical insurance offered the only democratic approach to a demonstrated national need.
Organized baseball asked in Federal Court yesterday for dismissal of Danny Gardella's $300,000 damage suit on the ground that baseball is not a monopoly in violation of the anti-trust-laws.

ST. LOUIS, April 25 (AP) -- The Cardinals routed their old jinx, Ken Raffensberger, with a four-run rally in the second inning and went on to defeat the Cincinnati Reds, 9 -- 3, tonight before 11,500 fans.

LONDON, April 25 -- Developments in the Chinese situation were responsible for the go-slow policy seen in the stock market here today. Althoug there was no nervous selling, jobbers were cautious and movements of prices generally were small.
Eleven years ago today Germany notified the United States that the Reich had decided to withdraw from participation in the New York World's Fair of 1939.

ANNECY, France, April 25 -- Congressional delay in passing an extension of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act is causing serious apprehension among other major world trading countries at the trade tariff conference here as to the future of United States trade policy.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The Avco Manufacturing Corporation of New York filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 387,041 shares of its $3 par value common stock.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- An order handed down by the Supreme Court today was taken to mean that employers must bargain with labor unions on retirement pension plans. The high court did not express itself on this important matter; but, by its refusal to review an individual case, it left undisturbed a Federal Circuit Court decision which carried out the principle affected.

Serge Rubinstein, the international financier, pleaded not guilty in Federal court yesterday to two indictments charging mail fraud and violation of the Securities Exchange Acts in connection with a $3,000,000 stock-rigging scheme.
LONDON, Tuesday, April 26 -- Russia said today she would lift the blockade of Berlin if the Western powers would set a date for the Big Four Foreign Ministers' meeting on Germany.

Reporting on operations last year of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway Company, Clark Hungerford, president, reported yesterday in the report for 1948 that dieselization had a favorable effect upon operating efficiency and aided in meeting added expenses brought on by increased costs of materials and labor.

FRANKFORT, Germany, April 25 -- Samuel L. Wahrhaftig, former Military Government civil administration official, who was recalled to the United States and dismissed on charges of disloyalty in favor of German Communists, returned here today. Mr. Wahrhaftig, who flew in on a commercial plane, said that he was gathering affidavits in a legal battle to clear his name.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Official silence blanketed today, but failed to diminish, persistent reports that John L. Sullivan, Secretary of the Navy, had presented his resignation to President Truman.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 25 -- Attorney Thomas J. Dodd, war crimes prosecutor at Nuremberg, today refused a Polish decoration because he sees "no distinction or difference" between the present "tyranny" in Poland and that which prevailed when the Germans occupied the country.

Disregarding charges by the Soviet bloc that capitalistic governments discriminated against women, the General Assembly yesterday adopted a resolution holding that the refusal of the Soviet Union to allow Russian wives to join their husbands abroad was a violation of the United Nations Charter.

TRENTON, N. J., April 25 -- Lloyd B. Marsh of Paterson, Republican State Chairman for six years, probably will relinquish his political position tomorrow to State Treasurer John J. Dickerson of Palisades Park, it was learned tonight.
LONDON, April 25 -- Tonight "they brought out the fatted calf, roasted it and served it to Danny Kaye on a red carpet," said Leonard Mosley, writing for tomorrow morning's Daily Express.

SHANGHAI, April 25 -- The Shanghai garrison command yesterday clamped down on the foreign press. The garrison detained two foreign correspondents, rounded up editors of English-language newspapers and suspended one newspaper from publication.

The Soviet bloc's attack on the United Nations Interim Committee (Little Assembly) continued yesterday as Dr. Juliusz Katz-Suchy, the Polish representative, opposed in a lengthy speech before the United Nations General Assembly three draft resolutions of the ad hoc Political Committee on the study of methods for the promotion of international cooperation in the political fields.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., April 25 (AP) -- The Florida East Coast Railway Company has been ordered by Federal Court to pay $3,375,000 in interest on its $45,000,000 of first and refunding 5 per cent bonds.

The four-hundreth anniversary of the landing of St. Francis Xavier in Japan will be celebrated this spring by a pilgrimage to that country, mostly by air, it was announced yesterday by the Most Rev. Thomas J. McDonnell, national director of the Society for the Propagation of the Faith, and Northwest Airlines.

The Adams Express Company in its quarterly report issued yesterday announced net assets of $37,930,690 as of March 31, equal to $26.95 a share on the 1,407,100 shares then outstanding. At the close of the same quarter last year, the company reported net assets of $40,627,558 equal to $27.50 on 1,477,187 shares outstanding at that time.

NANTES, France, April 24 -- In an industrial region in a rural setting that stretches from Nantes to St. Nazaire at the mouth of the Loire River, United States dollars are doing something today to restore what American bombs helped to destroy five years ago.
SHANGHAI, April 25 (AP) -- The announcement by the United States Navy that its ships would soon move to the lower Yangtze estuary to avoid involvement in the civil war said:

SHANGHAI, April 25 (UP) -- The Government has rushed 30,000 troops to Soochow, fifty miles west of Shanghai, to reinforce two divisions already braced for an impending Communist assault against the gateway to Shanghai.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- The National Labor Relations Board ruled today that licensed news venders of four New York daily newspapers were independent contractors, and that the newspapers were not compelled by Federal labor law to bargain with them as employes.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- In wo cases where the Supreme Court split identically, practices of the Army system of courts-martial were upheld by the high tribunal by 6 to 3 today.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- The Supreme Court was told today that two men involved in a pro football gambling scandal were illegally convicted of bribery. Harvey Stemmer and David Krakower, the defendants, are under sentences of five to ten years.

After a tour of Harlem yesterday Mayor O'Dwyer announced a coordinated drive by city agencies to clean up vacant lots teeming with assorted refuse. Wherever possible the vacant lots will be put into condition for use as play space. The Mayor said that sixty Harlem lots -- some owned by private individuals and some controlled by the city -- needed immediate attention.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- A high Republican Congressional source said tonight that Gov. Chester Bowles of Connecticut would announce tomorrow the appointment of Senator Raymond E. Baldwin to the state's Supreme Court of Errors. Governor Bowles is a Democrat and Senator Baldwin a Republican.

The Consolidated Vultee Aircraft Corporation had net income of "slightly less than $1,000,000" in the first quarter of the current fiscal year, after twelve successive quarters of deficits, Floyd B. Odlum, chairman, told stockholders yesterday at the annual meeting in San Diego, Calif.
FRANKFORT, Germany, April 25 -- Western Germany is speeding toward the foundation of a new state and a new destiny tonight.
RANGOON, Burma, April 25 (AP) -- The Burmese Government announced today that two separate insurgent forces had struck southward toward Rangoon.
SHANGHAI, April 25 (AP) -- Chinese Communists sloshed through the rain ten miles northwest of Shanghai tonight, but secrecy covered their major maneuver aimed...

HALIFAX, N. S., April 25 (Canadian Press) -- The twenty-five-man crew of the Canadian Conqueror today split over union allegiance when the freighter arrived in Montreal on the twenty-sixth day of the Canadian Seamen's Union deep-sea strike.

Protestant denominational groups in East Harlem have joined to fight juvenile delinquency by setting up churches in rented stores, it was reported last night at a dinner of the New York City Mission Society at the Shelton Hotel.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 25 -- Sol Lesser, independent film producer, has purchased screen rights to Upton Sinclair's novels about Lanny Budd, fictional war correspondent and secret agent, Lesser announced today. The deal gives Lesser the rights to nine novels already published and to all future novels concerning the Lanny Budd character, including one that is now completed and awaiting publication.

The Federal Trade Commission has dismissed a complaint, issued against the Tailored Woman in 1944, in which it was contended that the term, Persian Lamb, could be used only to describe fur obtained from fun-blooded karakul sheep raised on the Iranian Plateau area of Russia and Iran.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 25 -- A sharp rebuke administered to Republican legislators by Gov. Earl Warren was viewed today as widening an area of disagreement between Mr. Warren and some elements of the Republican party in California in advance of the campaign for Governor in 1950.

The Armco Steel Corporation reported yesterday, in its statement covering the quarter ended with last March, a net income of $8,621,791, compared with $5,867,347 earned in the initial three months of 1948.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 25 -- Cyrus S. Ching, director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, said today that "in the field of labor-relations, we must keep in mind today the effect that any evidence of disunity within this nation has on our international relations."

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores dropped 9 per cent last week below the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Sales for the four weeks ended last Saturday were unchanged.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 25 -- Borba, official newspaper of the Yugoslav Communist party, attacked today the Belgrade correspondents of Tass, Pravda and the Soviet Information Bureau for allegedly having failed to write a single word about Yugoslavia, although they have been working and traveling extensively in this country for almost a year.
PHILADELPHIA, April 25 -- It took a combination of circumstances to bring the Giants home in front today as they opened a two-game series with Ed Sawyer's Phillies.

ROME, April 25 -- Circles close to the Vatican Secretariat of State made clear today that any effort on the part of lay powers for the protection of holy places in Palestine should have, as one of its main goals, internationalization of both the new and old quarters of Jerusalem.

Col. Jackson A. Dykman chancellor of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island, said yesterday that neither Bishop James Pernette De Wolfe nor the former vestrymen of Holy Trinity Church in Brooklyn had ever agreed to a compromise settlement of their dispute with the Rev. Dr. John Howard Melish.

Demands for wage increases ranging as high as 41 per cent for ship radio operators were made yesterday by the American Radio Association, CIO, as contract negotiations between that group and the Committee for the Companies and Agents, Atlantic and Gulf Coasts, opened at the offices of the American Merchant Marine Institute, 11 Broadway.
SHANGHAI, Tuesday, April 26 -- Communists' thrusts from their many bridgeheads across the Yangtze appeared to be slowing down last night after they had advanced forty to fifty miles.

Four young children, representing three types of Catholic school groups, yesterday afternoon presented to Cardinal Spellman contributions collected by their classmates for the $500,000 bishop's fund for victims of war, which started Sunday in the New York Archdiocese.

There are many things -- soap flakes and washing machines, chocolate and other foods -- that Mrs. Christine vom Stein would like to take back with her to Germany. But the most important thing, she said yesterday, is the sense of individual worth and responsibility.

NEWARK, N. J., April 25 -- Involving an estimated $50,000 worth of merchandise, the furniture and personal effects of the late Mr. and Mrs. Henry Diffany who, at the ago of 80, were found dead in their antiques-cluttered home at 1106 Broad Street, went on sale this afternoon a day ahead of schedule at L. Bamberger Co.

The twentieth anniversary of David Dubinsky's accession to a position of leadership in the International Ladies Garment Workers Union has brought well-earned tributes not only from President Truman and other distinguished citizens of the United States but from leaders in the rest of the free world.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The chief duty and responsibility of the Secretary of Defense, when military appropriations are insufficient to execute the full security programs of all the units of the armed services, is to decide how the money is to be spent. That, with the approval of the President, is what Secretary Johnson was doing when he ordered that construction work be stopped on the Navy's 65,000-ton super-carrier, the United States.

Built-in units have been widely acclaimed for their space-saving qualities in small rooms, but apartment renters often have shied away from them because such units usually are hard to take along when moving day comes. Overcoming this disadvantage is the type of semi-built-ins designed by the interior decorating firm of Kim Hoffmann Stephen Heidrich for the apartment of the Louis Melameds in Stuyvesant Town.

PARIS, April 25 -- The partisans of peace closed their five-day attack on capitalism today with a manifesto against war on the Soviet Union and by the creation of a Permanent Council of Resistance against such a war.

OLIVET, Mich., April 25 -- Dr. Alvin S. Johnson, president emeritus of the New School for Social Research, New York, has accepted the presidency of the proposed Shipherd College, it was announced today by the founding committee.

Spring has been jumping the gun everywhere, from Bear Mountain to the Polo Grounds, but it will be official on Gramercy Park only today. This is the day when the district's annual flower show opens at the National Arts Club.

The Bank of New York and Fifth Avenue Bank sold the five- story apartment house at 1443 Washington Avenue, northwest corner of St. Paul's Place, the Bronx, to the Gaylor Realty Company. The property, on a plot 65 by 100 feet, accommodates thirty- six families and is assessed at $55,000.
Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg of Michigan, ranking minority member of the Foreign Relations Committee, declared here last night that Russia alone held the keys to peace in the world.

Utilizing machinery, designed primarily for acetate staple fiber, the Celanese Corporation of America has perfected and started production of a new fiber containing acetate and a large percentage of viscose, it was anounced yesterday.

Unknown to most Americans, racial discrimination is about to be enacted into federal law when the House reconvenes on April 25 and votes on the pending deficiency appropriation bill, H. R. 2632. The bill, passed by the Senate and now in conference committee, contains a trick rider which, in effect, deprives 100,000 United States citizens living in Arizona and New Mexico, who happen to be of Indian blood, of social security benefits.
The message from Gen. Lucius D. Clay to the members of The Associated Press at their annual luncheon follows:

A series of demands that, if granted in full, would add $72,000,000 to the cost of running city-owned subway, bus and elevated lines, was approved unanimously last night by the Transport Workers Union, CIO.

A new building construction and general contracting firm has been formed by Paul Tishman, former senior vice president and director of the Tishman Realty and Construction Corporation. It is to be known as the Paul Tishman Company, Inc.

The State Department and the Department of Justice have rejected the visa applications of Pierre Cot, a member of the French Chamber of Deputies, and Konni Zilliacus, a member of the British House of Commons, who wished to come over and make some speeches. The two Departments did this after "failing to find anything in the national interest" to justify letting the two men come in.

The favorite players at Jamaica yesterday had to wait until the feature event to see a public choice win a race. Beaten five times in a row by horses that did not figure, the form followers were rescued in the Distraction Classified Handicap when Barrage stepped home to a convincing triumph against six others.

To commemorate the fiftieth anniversary of his connection with the Yiddish stage, Edwin A. Relkin, producer and manager, will be honored tonight at a testimonial performance of "Hershel, the Jester,'' starring Maurice Schwartz, at the Yiddish Art Theatre.

Full-dress debate in the United Nations General Assembly on the case of Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty, sentenced to life imprisonment by Hungary for treason, was deferred yesterday at Flushing Meadow by request of the United States.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Unless contributory social insurance is strengthened and enlarged now, it may be displaced "by its more demanding step-sisters, assistance and relief," J. Douglas Brown, dean of the faculty of Princeton University, said today.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (UP) -- Charles F. Brannan, Secretary of Agriculture, declared today it was impossible to estimate how much his new farm program would cost. He asserted, however, that it should result in sharply lower food prices.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The Federal court trying Judith Coplon on espionage charges began impaneling jurors late today, after Judge Albert Reeves, visiting Missouri judge, denied a defense motion to quash one of two indictments against her.

Gleaming in a coat of black and white paint and with much of her interior altered to meet modern trans-Atlantic luxury requirements, the Italian liner Saturnia arrived yesterday after an extensive reconditioning job in a Genoa shipyard.

The inclusion of Germany in an association of Western European countries was advocated yesterday by Gen. Lucius D. Clay, American Military Governor of Germany, as the most effective way to end the threat of Communist expansion.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -- President Truman cut his request for European recovery funds today by $157,800,000 below the amount already authorized by Congress to carry on through the fiscal year 1950.

ALL the time I was reading Arthur Meeker's "Prairie Avenue,"* which is the Literary Guild's selection for May, the shadow of another book seemed to lie across its pages and I was faithful to it in my fashion. Mr. Meeker's baroque and ornately furnished novel is a sickly sweet tale about a lady of great charm who was lost among the commercial giants of the Middle West several generations ago.

Yesterday's customers in the "cafe" of the Hotel Lafayette at Ninth Street and University Place bought some strange wares. These were heaped on the marble-topped tables, hung on the walls and piled in corners, an unending miscellany garnered from every room in the famous half-century-old inn and knocked down to the highest bidder.

ROME, April 26 (UP) -- Representatives of American cities seeking the 1956 Olympic games have agreed to let the International Olympic Committee nominate one site, so the United States can present a unified front in the bidding, it was disclosed today. Sponsor of the plan was John Jewett Garland, a United States representative to the current meeting of the I. O. C.

Quartermaster procurements for the first nine months of the current fiscal year have set a new post-war record, it was pointed out yesterday by Col. John J. Madigan, executive officer of the New York Quartermaster Purchasing Office. For the nine-month period ended March 31, he said, expenditures were $353,200,000, compared with $229,800,000 for the whole fiscal year of 1948, and $294,000,000 for 1947.

The fashions presented in the Oval Room at the Ritz-Carlton yesterday at the luncheon hour had the look that is associated with the American teen-ager and college girl. The clothes came from the St. Louis market and, keyed to summer weather, were largely cottons.

At Wilmington the other day Guy W. Vaughan retired as chairman of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation, stepping out of the cockpit of American aviation after nearly thirty-three years as an active member of the flight crew. Many things distinguish his record. He came from the automobile business, where, after the turn of the century, he was engine designer and builder, racing driver, Gordon Bennett Cup winner and motor-car manufacturer.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (UP) -- Senator Pat McCarran, chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, split with President Truman over the displaced-persons issue today, possibly foreshadowing a fight in the Senate.

LONDON, April 26 -- The Prime Ministers of the British Commonwealth were reliably reported tonight to have reached a final decision on India's future status in the Commonwealth. Political quarters thought that the Prime Ministers soon would announce arrangements whereby India, while becoming a republic, would continue to acknowledge the British Crown as a symbol of the Commonwealth's unity.

It is encouraging to learn that New York City is proceeding as rapidly as possible with essential construction of bridges. Many years probably will elapse before existing needs and steadily pressing new ones can be met, but in the meantime such traffic sore spots as congestion at the Manhattan Plaza of the Williamsburg Bridge and bottlenecks at two points on heavily traveled Bruckner Boulevard in the Bronx will be cured.

CLEVELAND, April 26 (AP) -- Manager Lou Boudreau hit his first homer of the season and Bob Lemon hurled his first shut-out of the year today as the Cleveland Indians defeated the St. Louis Browns, 1 to 0.
MOSCOW, April 26 -- The Soviet Union in the opinion of Moscow diplomatic observers now stands ready to resolve specific conflicts with the West through direct diplomatic contacts.
