HOLLYWOOD, Fla., April 26 -A vigorous dispute over compulsory health insurance was brewing today at the fifty-eighth annual convention of the General Federation of Women's Clubs.

What was described as the largest single air cargo order in commercial aviation history was begun yesterday by American Safety Razor Corporation, Brooklyn. The shipment comprised more than 25,000,000 razor blades, weighing (with their packaging) 112 tons. It is also the first time a manufacturer with large national distribution has used air freight as a prime cargo carrier.

Benjamin J. Davis Jr., Communist member of the City Council, who was elected twice under proportional representation, announced yesterday that he would be a candidate for re-election to the Council from the Twenty-first Councilmanic District, identical with the Twenty-first Senatorial District.

The strengthening of Europe is made more imperative by the Communist victory in Asia. As the Chinese Red armies close in on the "international city" of Shanghai, meeting place of East and West and China's real open door, Moscow's long-cherished and grandiose plan for a Soviet Eurasia begins to take actual shape.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,802, against 1,138 last week and 1,210 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 711 arrivals yesterday compared with 709 last Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, April 26 (UP) -- The Department of Commerce reported today a "substantial and significant" increase in savings by consumers.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, April 26 -- Three of the four expected delegations from the Arab states arrived at Lausanne today, in response to invitations by the United Nations Palestine Conciliation Commission, for exploratory discussions of refugee and other political questions with the commission.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Certificated airlines of this country increased their earnings in international and domestic services by more than $143,000,000 between 1946 and 1948, although this was "a period of declining traffic for common carriers," the Air Transport Association reported here today.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- John L. Sullivan resigned as Secretary of the Navy today in protest against what he called the arbitrary abandonment of the Navy's "indispensable" super-aircraft carrier, the 65,000-ton United States.

George Barrett's dispatch from Lake Success regarding the decision of the United Nations to set up a special chamber for prayer and meditation emphasizes anew the tragic dilemma implicit in the very concept of a political organization on a global scale.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 26 -- Retail sales volume has developed a leveling off trend after an almost continuous upward spiral since 1940, J. Gordon Dakins, general manager of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, New York City, reported here today.
Election of Charles M. Wheeler as a vice president of Union Switch and Signal Company, with headquarters in Swissvale, Pa., was announced today. He has been with the company since Sept. 1, 1927.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Democratic leaders agreed today on repeal of the law requiring Congress to make its own advance estimates of Government expenditures and receipts each year. House and Senate approval is expected soon.
WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) -Following is the text of a statement on the basic principles for the merger of the three Western zones of occupation in Germany, released today by the State Department:
ROME, April 26 (AP) -- Although overshadowed by the hot contest for the Summer Games, a quieter struggle for the 1956 Winter Olympics developed at the International Olympic Committee meeting today.

NEWMARKET, England, April 26 (AP) -- The Two Thousand Guineas, first 3-year-old classic of the British racing season scheduled here tomorrow, shaped up tonight as a two-horse race between Abernant and Star King. Ten other probable starters, including an American-owned outsider, fill out the field for the one-mile event starting at 2:55 P. M. (10:55 A. M., Eastern daylight saving time).

Three new issues of securities having a par value of $16,020,000 and consisting of public-utility bonds, railroad equipment certificates and finance company preferred stock, will be offered to investors today by underwriting syndicates here, as follows:

The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization may be able to do more to unify mankind and create conditions conducive to peace than anything else yet attempted, Anne McCormack told an audience of city school teachers yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, April 26 -- The Metropolitan Opera Company opened a two-week engagement at the Shrine Auditorium here tonight with a performance of "Rigoletto," starring Nadine Connor and Leonard Warren.
Federal Judge Sylvester J. Ryan yesterday gave two business partners who had pleaded guilty to income tax evasion a chance to decide which one would go to jail first.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Resentment was high among Republicans as the Senate learned today that Senator Raymond E. Baldwin, Republican, of Connecticut, planned to resign to accept an appointment to the Connecticut Supreme Court of Errors.

James Monroe High, defending champion in the Bronx division of the P. S. A. L. baseball competition, defeated Samuel Gompers, 10 -- 4, at St. Mary's Park in the Bronx yesterday. Dominic Zanni's five-hit pitching and a homer with one on by Rocky Kriaris featured the victory.
TRENTON, N. J., April 26 -- With the Governorship at stake, the Republican and Democratic state organizations started vigorous campaigns today at party conventions.

Prices on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday timidly worked higher on a slightly improved volume of business. Gains were limited and only a few issues moved up a point or more. The steel and automobile shares were in greatest demand. A substantial number of issues remained under pressure and eased moderately.

RIO DE JANEIRO, April 26 (AP) -- The Magdalen, launched at Belfast less than a year ago, sailed from London March 9. [When the ship ran aground, she was en route from Buenos Aires to Rio de Janeiro, according to the line's passenger agent in New York.]
WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Following is a chronology of main events in the East-West conflict over Berlin:

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, April 26 -- The regional conference of the International Labor Organization went into the committee stage today, with the Bolivian delegate seeking means to raise the question of army control of the Patino tin mines since October, 1948. Bolivia has an important Congressional election this Sunday.

A girl photographer from Greenwich Village testified at the Communist trial yesterday that she had spent the last seven years in the New York Communist movement as an undercover agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

The Rev. Dr. Stephen S. Wise, founder and rabbi of the Free Synagogue and Zionist leader who died last Tuesday at the age of 75, left an estate of approximately $50,000. This was disclosed yesterday when his will was filed for probate with Surrogate William T. Collins.

PARIS, April 26 -- Two unconnected events occurred in France today to give strong impetus toward attaining an improvement of the financial situation that might lead to greater stability of the currency. First, the Marshall Plan mission here released 25,000,000,000 more francs from the counterpart fund.

If democracy is going to win out in the world the United States must have "moral conviction and spiritual leadership as well as economic and military strength," Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt declared yesterday. She spoke at the monthly luncheon of the Sales Executives Club at the Hotel Roosevelt.

Coffee futures were active and steady on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Trade demand and producer support advanced prices sharply in early trading, but they eased somewhat later in the day on profit-taking and scattered long liquidation.

All "hate movements" must be wiped out in this country, Representative Brooks Hays, Democrat, of Arkansas, declared yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the National Conference of Christians and Jews food industries division at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Comfort and aid to the ill cancer patient is the goal of the Field Army of the American Cancer Society. Staffed by women who serve without pay, the Field Army prepares surgical dressings from old linen for hospitals throughout the metropolitan area, as well as for individual patients.
FLEMINGTON, N. J., April 26 (AP) -- Eastman Kodak Company announced today a small increase in sales in the first quarter of 1949 over last year's volume.
The Los Angeles Department of Water and Power borrowed yesterday $40,000,000 on electric plant revenue bonds due from 1950 to 1989 at an interest cost of 2.3572 per cent.

Welbilt Stove Company, Inc., will increase its 1949 production of gas ranges 40 to 50 per cent compared with last year, A. P. Hirsch, president, revealed in an interview yesterday. The company is the only factor in the industry which expects to end the year with a gain in both unit and dollar volume, he said.

One of the potentially beneficial results of last November's elections was that it offered an opportunity to Congress for re-examining the nation's labor laws and making such constructive changes as it deemed desirable in the light of nearly two years' experience with the Labor-Management Relations Law of 1947.

Louis M. Simon, executive secretary of Actors Equity, yesterday was authorized by the Equity Council, the union's governing board, to represent the union at a conference called by the President's Committee on Religion and Welfare of the Armed Forces to be held in Washington on May 26.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -- A new plan to cut government spending "scientifically" and ward off a rise in taxes was put before the Senate today.

One hundred and fifty of New York's leading restaurateurs sat down to dinner last night and heard a homily on what's wrong with people who eat out today. The answer, supplied by Paul Henkel, president of the Society of Restaurateurs, was too much hurry and indigestion.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that Power Petroleum, Ltd., Toronto, Ont., Canada, had filed a registration statement covering 1,150,000 shares of $1 par value common to be offered to the public at 50 cents each.

With three parades scheduled in the city for Saturday, sponsors of the Loyalty Day parade in Manhattan estimated yesterday that they would have 150,000 marchers, double the number that paraded last year.

Net income of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., and subsidiary companies for the twelve months ended on March 31, was $33,909,749, after all operating expenses, taxes, and other charges, the company announced yesterday. The net was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $2.09 a share on the common stock.

The defense rested its case yesterday afternoon at the Coast Guard hearing into misconduct charges brought against twenty-three crew members of the freighter Flying Arrow. Earlier the defense had sought to show through the testimony of several witnesses, that the crew had been intimidated and threatened by Jean A. Brown, the ship's second assistant engineer.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- John L. Lewis is expected in the next few days to ask the bituminous coal operators to sit down with the United Mine Workers of America and talk about a new contract. The present one expires on June 30.

DETROIT, April 26 -- A "bipartisan" effort today by the Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers, CIO, to avert strike action at the Lincoln and River Rouge plants produced only a timetable of confusion.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, April 26 -- A new business index which may prove to be the most sensitive indicator in existence of changes in business trends was revealed today by a research committee of the American Supply and Machinery Manufacturers Association at the annual convention here.

Consolidated net earnings of the Texas Company in the first three months of this year were estimated yesterday at $28,870,111, or $2.09 each on the 13,797,624 capital shares outstanding by W. S. S. Rodgers, chairman, at the annual stockholders' meeting held here. In the first quarter of 1948, the company had reported a net income of $27,974,839, or $2.08 a share.

Members of the Barnard Alumnae Association have contributed $23,561 to the college since July 1, 1948, Miss MaeBell Beith, chairman of the alumnae fund committee, announced last night at a meeting of 300 alumnae fund workers with Dean Millicent McIntosh in Barnard Hall.

Prof. George S. Counts of Columbia's Teachers College, has signed a contract with Houghton Mifflin for a book indicting Russian totalitarianism. Tentatively titled "The Country of the Blind," it is a study of the party line as it is unwound by the Central Committee of the Politbureau.

Combing four pitchers for a total of seventeen hits, the Manhattan College baseball team registered its first Metropolitan Collegiate Conference victory in six starts this season by walloping Hofstra College of Hempstead, 16 to 8, at Van Cortlandt Park Stadium yesterday.

It was Fluellen in "Henry V," if Shakespeare is remembered aright, who argued in a heated Welsh accent that "leeks is goot." Yes, delicious, and at the moment plentiful, but alas for palates, too little known. They are but one of the vegetables crowding produce stalls; the flowers that bloom in the spring are no more profuse than the season's greens.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The highly publicized salaries of radio stars contrast sharply with statistics showing that one-fourth of the free-lance actors and singers in that business made less than $1,000 in 1947, the Department of Labor reported today. Its studies covered the earnings of radio announcers, actors, singers and sound-effects artists.

Shipping interests and city officials engaged in the months-old waterfront crime investigation are expected to meet in the next few days for the first full-scale conference on elimination of illicit pier practices costing users of the port millions of dollars, it was learned yesterday.

The gold medal "for distinguished achievement" of the National Institute of Arts and Letters has been won by Frederick Law Olmsted of Brookline, Mass., one of the nation's foremost authorities on city planning and landscape architecture, it was announced yesterday.

FRENCH LICK, Ind., April 26 -- Bank earnings this year, in most instances, are likely to hold at about the same levels as in 1948, despite indications of weakness in some sections of the economy. This view was expressed here today by representative bankers attending the closing sessions of the executive council of the American Bankers Association.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 26 (AP) -- Stockholders of the United Aircraft Corporation were told today that first-quarter revenues "declined sharply" because of "unusual conditions" in two of the corporation's divisions.

Angered because Richard Johnson, 12 years old, of 863 Melrose Avenue, the Bronx, refused to lend him a penny several days ago, a 13-year-old boy, whose name was withheld, stabbed and critically wounded young Johnson at 12:50 P. M. yesterday in front of Public School 3, 157th Street between Melrose and Cortland Avenues, the Bronx.

SHANGHAI, April 26 (UP) -- Shanghai, which remained calm when the Communists broke the Yangtze river line, today began to show signs of panic. Business was almost at a standstill, the money market was chaotic.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) -- Arthur J. Altmeyer, Social Security Commissioner, issued a statement saying that Mr. Hoover's letter "indicates a basic misunderstanding of our American social-security system." Contributory social insurance is the first line of defense against insecurity, he asserted, and public assistance, that is, relief, is a second line of defense.

Lewis Harmon, who operates the Chapel Playhouse in Guilford, Conn., announced yesterday that its summer season would begin July 2. Arthur Earle will be the resident director. Edwin Wittstein has been signed as designer and technical director.

TEL AVIV, Israel, April 26 -- While hundreds of ex-servicemen and newly arrived immigrants demonstrated against unemployment outside, the Knesset (assembly) heard plans today for a comprehensive building program over the next four years coupled with an austerity campaign that will make the Israelis tighten their belts in British style.

The Havana charter for an International Trade Organization yesterday was praised as "the best hope of restoring world trade" and denounced as "aid to socialistic planners at the risk of undermining our own economic system" in a debate between William L. Batt, president of SKF Industries, Inc., and Philip Cortney, president of Coty, Inc., at the luncheon of the Export Managers Club at the Commodore Hotel.

Henry J. Kaiser denied in Federal Court yesterday that he had intended any threat to the Government when he testified last week concerning a $33,000,000 offer his Permanente Metals Company had made for four government-owned aluminum plants which it now operates.

PHILADELPHIA, April 26 -- The Giants' springtime winning streak that had mounted to four straight crashed to earth today on the impact of a Del Ennis two-run homer which capped a three-tally eleventh inning for Eddie Sawyer's Phillies.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The Senate Foreign Relations committee will open hearings tomorrow on the North Atlantic treaty.

DUESSELDORF, April 26 -- Bavarian objections to specific items in yesterday's agreement at Frankfort with Military Governors of the three Western zones found expression today in a session in Koenigs-winter of key personalities of the Christian Democratic party and its Bavarian ally, the Christian Social Union.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The Economic Cooperation Administration cut off new shipments of cotton to Shanghai today in view of of its prospective fall before the advancing Communist armies.

Survival of the middleman in American business is being threatened, A. H. Finley, national field director of the National Association of Tobacco Distributors, Inc., told about 500 members of the industry yesterday at their annual convention in the Statler Hotel.
PINEHURST, N. C., April 26 (AP) -- Favorites moved safely by the first round of match play today in the forty-seventh annual women's North and South Amateur golf championship.

Two films arrive at midtown theatres today. At the Astor, "We Were Strangers," a drama about the revolt in Cuba in 1933, starring John Garfield, Jennifer Jones and Pedro Armendariz, will have its local premiere. John Huston directed and S. P. Eagle produced the independently-made Horizon production for Columbia release.

Shipping representatives and maritime labor will appear on opposite sides when a subcommittee of the House of Representatives opens hearings today on the controversial question of Panamanian shipping.

BALTIMORE, April 26 -- Designed to cover a wide field of research on automotive fuels a 4,000-square-foot laboratory will be dedicated here tomorrow night by the American Oil Company and the Pan-American Oil Company. Included in the equipment are devices for experiments to benefit the drivers of cars of today and the future.

A list of twenty-four amendments to the present contract between the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, CIO, and the Committee for the Companies and Agents -- Atlantic and Gulf Coasts -- was submitted by the union yesterday afternoon in the first meeting held in negotiations for a new agreement.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -- President Truman today appointed William H. Davis of New York City, veteran labor relations authority, chairman of the Atomic Energy Labor Relations Panel.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (UP) -- The Most Rev. Richard J. Cushing, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Boston, today called on Catholic youth to help produce "decent" peace treaties and effective world organizations.

The sustained post-war economic expansion of the West Coast keeps well up in the financial news. Signs of slowdown in capital expenditure by industry may be multiplying, but the money-hunger of California's privately owned and publicly owned utility systems is still far from sated.

CHICAGO, April 26 -- Grain markets turned strong in the late trading on the Board of Trade here today after an easy start. There was nothing in the general run of the news to account for the right-about-face action, but the close was about at the top, with wheat 1 1/4 to 2 1/4 cents a bushel higher, new-crop months showing the most strength.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 26 -- The keel for the President Adams, second of the new round-the-world passenger liners to be built for American President Lines, will be laid tomorrow at the Camden (N. J.) yard of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation, it was announced today by George Killion, president of the steamship company.

The Panama Canal had so many historic footnotes, false starts and disappointed hopes that it is somewhat startling to find a company, formed to develop the isthmus, still active and celebrating its hundredth anniversary. The Panama Railroad Company, organized in New York in April, 1849, began by building the first railroad between the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans on the American/continent -- its completion antedating by fourteen years the first transcontinental railroad in the United States.

CHICAGO, April 26 (AP) -- Tony Zale, former world middleweight champion, today announced his retirement from the ring -- thus stepping aside as the No. 1 contender for the crown held by Marcel Cerdan.

The struggle between East and West over Germany is entering a new phase with a rush resembling the break-up of a log jam. Late Monday night, after many months of weary haggling, the Western Powers and the Germans were at last able to agree on the formation of a German Federal Republic and a German Government operating under Allied authority.

A selection of the delicately proportioned Czechoslovak glassware that has been designed by leading artists and architects for the firm of J. L. Lobmeyr since the middle of the nineteenth century will go on exhibit today at the Museum of Modern Art.

RIO DE JANEIRO, April 26 -- The British Royal Mail luxury liner Magdalena today broke in two in Guanabara Bay, about five miles from the Brazilian shore, as she was being towed to land after having run aground yesterday on a reef outside the bay.

Net income of Remington Rand, Inc., for the fiscal year ended on March 31, was about $9,650,000, slightly in excess of $2 a common share. James H. Rand, chairman and president, reported in the preliminary statement yesterday. A year before, the net income was at a record $15,129,048, or $3.26 a common share.

Progress on sewage treatment plants being built indicates that a large part of the waters of the northerly section of New York will be relatively free of direct pollution well before the end of the five-year period set for completion of the $95,000,000 first or primary phase of the city's treatment plant construction program.
DAYTON, Ohio, April 26 (AP) -- The Dayton Journal Herald said tonight that the Air Force, after an extensive investigation, had decided that flying saucers "are not a joke."

The presumably crippled Yankees continued their amazing show of early foot yesterday. For the second straight day the league-leading Bombers scored a one-run decision over the Athletics at the Stadium. Gerry Coleman's two-run homer in the eighth inning turned the trick, 5 -- 4, before 12,507 spectators.
Collective bargaining has resulted in increased union participation in management functions, a Yale University economics professor declared yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 26 -- In a settlement of Polan Banks' $670,000 damage suit against RKO, the studio has purchased Banks' photoplay, "Carriage Entrance"; has taken over his commitment with Ann Sheridan to star in it and has engaged Banks to produce the film, paying an undisclosed lump sum to cover the entire deal, it was learned today from the studio.

LONDON, April 26 -- A grim and sober House of Commons heard Prime Minister Clement R. Atlee relate in detail today the story of how Chinese Communist batteries had shelled four British warships on the Yangtze River, killing forty-two British seamen and wounding fifty-three.

BARTLESVILLE, Okla., April 26 (AP) -- Phillips Petroleum Company reported today a first-quarter net profit of $12,713,254, or $2.10 a share. This compared with $18,154,148, or $3 a share, in the 1948 period. Directors declared the regular quarterly dividend of 75 cents a share, payable on June 1 to holders of record of May 6.
Five races are listed for the Childs Cup rowing regatta on the Harlem Saturday on the schedule announced yesterday by Columbia University.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Minority groups can expect little comfort from the Supreme Court decision ruling restrictive housing covenants unenforceable in courts of law unless power is given federal agencies to go a step further by withholding federal funds from housing developments that discriminate, according to officials of the Housing and Home Finance Agency.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- American businessmen anticipate "little change" in sales during 1949 from the record level of 1948, the Office of Business Economics of the Department of Commerce announced today.

Pravda was reported on April 13 to have described a projected American-British-Dutch expedition in search of Noah's Ark on Mount Ararat as a "Biblical Masquerade." They assert that the real interest behind such an expedition is based on the present political importance of the area, the strategic border region where Turkey, Iran and the Armenian Soviet Socialist Republic meet.

Ozzie and Harriet have come to a parting of the ways with the International Silver Company, sponsors of their radio program for five years. The last of the domestic comedy series, heard Sunday nights over CBS from 6:30 to 7 o'clock, will be on June 26, after which the program will take its usual summer hiatus.

Annually, at this season of the year, newsmen from all parts of this most news-conscious of all countries gather in convention. The American Society of Newspaper Editors has just wound up its sessions in Washington. This week the members of The Associated Press and of the American Newspaper Publishers Association are meeting in New York. All three conventions have been well attended.
DAMASCUS, Syria, April 26 -- Premier Husni Zayim ordered Syria's border with the Kingdom of Jordan closed today and issued a defiant challenge to its King, Abdullah.

Prospects of a strike by building service workers in thousands of Manhattan apartment houses faded appreciably yesterday with the announcement that "some progress" had been made toward a settlement of the differences.
For the first time in history a news dispatch was sent directly and simultaneously last night from London to newspapers and radio stations on three continents.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Former President Herbert Hoover called on Congress today to reduce social security taxes, rather than raise them, and to meet the increased needs of the aged out of general revenues by direct relief. He voiced numerous misgivings about the present system in a letter to Representative Robert L. Doughton of North Carolina, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee.

LONDON, April 26 -- The state will collect in death duties 3,369,000 (about $13,476,000) from the fortune left by the seventh Viscount Portman, it became known today. That is three-quarters of the present ascertainable value of the estate of Lord Portman, who died last September, and the largest payment in death duties ever known under the existing law.

Plans for enlarging the Katy Ferguson House for unmarried young Negro mothers were announced yesterday at the annual meeting of the board of the home. Justice Jane M. Bolin told the meeting that the house was of great value to the Domestic Relations Courts of New York.

Isidor Bieber, the racetracker, philosopher and Shakespearean scholar whose Palestinian will go after the Kentucky Derby jackpot a week from Saturday, had the main-event winner at Jamaica yesterday. Up Beat did the job for him -- and for the players of favorites in the crowd of 21,669 -- in the $5,000 added Glenmore Classified Handicap.
SHANGHAI, April 26 (UP) -- A new peril had arisen today within Shanghai -- a soaring inflation which brought with it the menace of widespread strikes.

Applauded by an audience for fashion rightness and low prices, picturesque large brims and simple small hats were the two silhouettes selected for summer by twenty manufacturers participating in a showing yesterday of millinery to retail from $2 to $15.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange became irregular yesterday and closed 5 to 14 points lower in the old-crop months, but 12 to 18 points higher on new-crop months.

The Ballet Theatre started its second week at the Metropolitan Opera House last night in good form and good spirit and with everything clearly under control. The program contained two novelties: the first appearance of Nora Kaye in George Balanchine's "Theme and Variations" and the season's only presentation of Keith Lester's "Pas de Quatre."
EWING TOWNSHIP, N. J., April 26 -- The case of Harry Hoffman's fence is bringing tempers to the exploding point here.

Directors of the American Can Company, after the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday at Jersey City, elected Dudley W. Figgis as chairman of the board, following the retirement of Maurice J. Sullivan as chief executive officer.
High production costs in mechanical departments have replaced the newsprint shortage as the principal operating problem of the country's publishers, it was reported yesterday.

Valentin A. Gubitchev, the Soviet engineer whose trial on charges of espionage will begin here Monday, was released yesterday in $100,000 bail, but his freedom was severely hedged about by restrictions on his activities.
PARIS, April 26 -- Indications have been received that the United States does not intend to abandon its diplomatic outposts in Communist-occupied China unless forced to do so.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 26 -- Rafik Asha, the Syrian representative, told the Political Committee of the United Nations General Assembly today that Syria would not accept a proposed agreement between Latin-American and Arab-Asiatic countries on the disposition of the former Italian colonies in Africa.

ARTHUR, Ill., April 26 (AP) -- A 16-year-old boy, spanked for passing notes in school, shot and seriously wounded Mrs. Nina Donahoo, 57 years old, a teacher at the White School west of here. She was wounded in the groin by a pistol bullet.

PARIS, April 26 -- The Paris Military Authority ruled today that it had no case against two of seven Communists arrested between Feb. 26 and March 3 on the charge of communicating secret documents pertaining to national defense to unqualified persons.
WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) -- Following is the text of the State Department's statement on negotiations to lift the Berlin blockade:

ALBANY, April 26 -- Governor Dewey approved today the so-called "State Bill" authorizing cities to acquire land in blighted areas and resell it to private developers as part of a slum-clearance program. At the same time he vetoed the so-called "Federal" Bill designed to accomplish the same purpose on an even broader scale.

The annual spring luncheon in aid of the Lots for Little Thrift Shop, a permanent thrift shop at 902 Third Avenue, was held yesterday in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. Many parties were given at the event.

A bed at home can be nearly as much a hospital bed as one in an institution, Dr. E. M. Bluestone, executive director of Montefiore Hospital, which has conducted a successful experiment in home care of patients, declared yesterday.

FULLERTON, Calif., April 26 -- Before a cheering crowd of several thousand at the little country airport from which William Barris and Richard Riedel took off six weeks ago they brought their small single-engine cabin monoplane safely back to earth just before noon today.

New York University got more than it bargained for against a spirited Brooklyn College nine in Flatbush yesterday, but stout relief pitching by Ed Funai in the late innings enabled the defending champions to defeat the Kingsmen, 5-4, in a Metropolitan Conference contest.

LONDON, April 26 -- First statistics published here since before the war showed that in the first quarter of 1949 Japan had under construction seventy-eight steamers and motorships totaling 144,880 tons.

With the official opening of the Brooklyn phase of the Greater New York Fund campaign set for tomorrow, Borough President John Cashmore issued yesterday a proclamation calling on "every one of our citizens to acquaint himself with the inspiring fund story and to support this worthy endeavor."

The United States Steel Corporation announced yesterday earnings of $49,928,670 for the first quarter of this year, highest for any three-month period since 1929, and an increase in the quarterly dividend on the common stock from $1.25 to $1.50 a share.
LONDON, April 26 -- Far Eastern developments weighed heavily on the stock market here today. Jobbers marked down prices as a precaution and business was at a minimum.
Obviously too much is done for children. New shoes every month or so. Bubble gum. Each spring a trip to the circus and each fall a trip to a football game. Rewards for good marks at school.

The International Business Machines Corporation is planning to do more manufacturing abroad, utilizing its local funds, which are subject to foreign exchange restrictions, Thomas J. Watson, president, informed a large attendance of shareholders at the annual meeting yesterday.

IN his playing days George Sauer never was mousetrapped. Not until he became a coach did that most disconcerting of all football maneuvers take him unawares. By way of giving a bit of variety to it, the mousetrapping was done by his friends rather than by the enemy, an item which makes it all more than a trifle on the unusual side.

BERLIN, April 26 -- Western resolution to push organization of a federal German republic is meeting slight but potentially important hesitancy among Western German politicians who see a meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers on all Germany on the horizon.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The 3,500 Comstock Prize, awarded by the National Academy of Sciences every five years, was presented here tonight at the annual dinner of the academy to Dr. Merle A. Tuve, director of the Department of Terrestrial Magnetism, Carnegie Institution of Washington.

A new code of ethics committee has been formed by the American Marketing Association to govern application of a set of standards and code on research practices and use of research material in advertising, it was learned yesterday. Don West, research director of McCall Corporation and head of the special committee that drew up the code last year, is chairman of the new group.

VIENNA, April 26 -- The non-arrival in Vienna of 1,000 Hungarian Jews who were expected to come here via Bratislava yesterday in the same fashion as 1,200 who arrived last Friday has led Jewish authorities here to fear that the 1,000 have been sent back to Hungary by the Czechoslovakian Government.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Senator John W. Bricker and Representative Clarence J. Brown, Republicans, of Ohio, offered a bill today that calls for $1,250,000,000 in Federal grants for school construction over five years.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The Administrative Board of the National Catholic Welfare Conference issued today a statement to "insist that internationalization of Jerusalem be implemented." Pope Pius recently made a similar request.

CHICAGO, April 26 (AP) -- Johnny Groth, 22-year-old Detroit rookie outfield sensation, swung an accurate bat at the start and finish as the Tigers toppled the White Sox by 6 -- 2 and then 7 -- 5 in ten innings in a double-header before 13,799 persons today.

Manager Barney Shotton yesterday decided to remove Cal Abrams from his starting line-up for the first time and replace the Brooklyn boy with Gene Hermanski, the Newark haberdasher -- and the results must have astonished even the self-contained Dodger pilot.

PITTSBURGH, April 26 (AP) -- "Eventually" lower steel prices but a "hold-the-line policy" in regard to wages in the steel industry were predicted today by Ernest T. Weir, president of the National Steel Corporation, at the annual meeting of stockholders.
ROCHESTER, N. Y., April 26 (AP) -- A clergyman was ordered held today as a material witness in the pistol-slaying of his 25-year-old wife, whose body was found in the Genesee River.

CHIEM SEE, Germany, April 26 -- Hundreds of former Nazi party members are returning to their old teaching positions in German elementary and secondary schools, educators attending the first International Conference of Comparative Education warned today.

AMMAN, Jordan, April 26 -- The Criminal Court here today sentenced to death three Palestinians, one a subject of the Hashemite Jordan Kingdom, on a charge of having attempted to assassinate King Abdullah March 26. Four were found guilty of placing a land mine on a highway near the King's winter palace in the Jordan valley.

NEWARK, N. J., April 26 -- Three former members of the Harrison (N. J.) Housing Authority were found guilty tonight of conspiring to defraud the Government in the operation of housing. A jury in the Federal Court here deliberated ten hours before bringing in the verdict of guilty at 10:05 P. M. Federal Judge William F. Smith set no date for sentencing. All three men were continued in bail of $1,000 each.
WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) -- Congressional spy hunters questioned an alleged Communist espionage agent and two atomic scientists today without producing evidence of any deals between them.

The special Federal grand jury that for the last four months has been investigating subversive activities charged yesterday that increasing efforts were being made by enemies of this country to obtain information relating to our national defense and security.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 26 -- Top United Nations circles -- delegation and secretariat -- were officially delighted today that the facilities of the world organization had been used to help break the Berlin deadlock.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., April 26 -- The resignation of Dr. William N. Leonard, associate professor of economics, as vice president of the New Brunswick chapter of the American Association of University Professors was announced today in the dispute over administration policies at Rutgers University.

What started a year ago as a whirlwind drive to raise $185,000 for a Broadway musical, entitled "The Happiest Days," wound up yesterday in General Sessions, where the two producers were accused of stealing $39,000 from hopeful backers of the project.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Broad hints that Judith Coplon contemplates marriage to Valentin Gubitchev, the Soviet engineer arrested with her in New York, were a feature of the second day of the espionage trial of the 27-year-old woman.

PARIS, April 26 -- French Government circles today took a favorable view toward the resumption of four-power talks on Germany, provided that the Soviet Union puts forward no further conditions than those contained in the Tass statement today.

Federal Judge Edward A. Conger set aside yesterday the $1,150,000 verdict a jury had awarded on Feb. 15 to James A. Moffett, former Federal Housing Administrator, in his suit against the Arabian American Oil Company. The Court directed that judgment be entered for the company.

LONDON, April 26 -- British diplomatic quarters thought today that Soviet proposals for lifting mutual restrictions on transport in Berlin might come to something if the Soviet Union did not impose any conditions for a meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers.

Although the average fly fisherman is directing an unwavering gaze toward the Catskill streams and wondering just when the upstate waters will be "right," a number of salt water hopefuls are looking toward Peconic Bay and waiting impatiently for the first good run of weakfish.

Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State Chairman, has endorsed the candidacy of Benjamin Shalleck, Tammany's selection for Representative in Congress from the Twentieth district, Manhattan, it was announced yesterday.

William E. Boyland, a Bronx real estate man, was sworn in as president of the Tax Commission yesterday before the resignation of his predecessor had been announced. The appointment came as a surprise.

TOKYO, April 26 -- There is a growing conviction here that the Soviet Union has been delaying consistently the repatriation of Japanese war prisoners because of its reluctance to uncover the heavy death toll among Japanese in Siberian prison camps at a time when the Communists are attempting to picture themselves as the champions of Asiatic freedom as against the "colonial ambitions" of the West.
HARTFORD, April 26 -- Gov. Chester Bowles today nominated Senator Raymond E. Baldwin, Republican, of Connecticut, to the State Supreme Court of Errors.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The House plunged into debate today on one of the year's most controversial issues, labor legislation, with Administration forces reportedly ready to make some concessions in an effort to assure passage of the Administration's (Lesinski) Taft-Hartley repealer. A vote is not expected until Friday, at the earliest.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The United States Government said today that "the way appears clear" for ending the Berlin blockade and resuming peace talks with the Russians in the Big Four Council of Foreign Ministers.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The United States emphasized that it was determined to expedite the formation of a German federal republic in Western Germany today by publishing the regulations that will control the proposed German federation.

Many persons suffering from cardiac ailments who are afraid to work may overcome their fears and be rehabilitated for a return to normal community living if their attitude toward their illness can be changed.

Paul W. Shields was elected to the new office of chairman and chief executive officer of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation at yesterday's organizational meeting of directors. Guy W. Vaughan retired from the chairmanship and declined nomination as a director at the annual stockholders' meeting last week.

Reversing a customary policy of meeting indoors in closed session, the Board of Health convened yesterday under sunny skies on a street corner in Harlem and adopted a resolution putting teeth into a drive to make property owners remove refuse from their vacant lots.

Antoine of Paris hair stylist for Saks Fifth Avenue, sailed yesterday on the S. S. America, taking with him sketches of American coiffures for the chic mademoiselles of Paris. He held a press party on shipboard at which three models presented the hair styles that are M. Antoine's American versions.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 26 -- A tentative move by Australia to postpone debate on Spain in the United Nations General Assembly will, if introduced, meet determined opposition from both Brazil and Poland, it was learned today.

SHANGHAI, April 26 -- While Communist armies about fifty miles west of this city appeared to be catching their breath for a second day, the Communist radio asserted that Communist troops crossing the Yangtze near Wuhu had surrounded and wiped out most of two Nationalist armies.
Eleven years ago today the Sixth Avenue "El" was condemned to the scrap yard when the city agreed to buy the line for $12,500,000.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., April 26 -- The late Joseph Medill Patterson, president of the News Syndicate, which publishes The Daily News in New York, left an $11,186,052 net estate that faces a state tax of $1,571,210 and a Federal tax approaching $5,500,000, it was learned here today.

Freda Trepel, pianist from Winnipeg, Canada, who had her first New York recital five years ago, gave her second last night at Town Hall. Her program included the Bach-Busoni Organ Prelude and Fugue in D major, Beethoven's Sonata "Les Adieux," a Chopin group and shorter pieces by Kabalevsky, Prokofieff and Liszt.
The text of the presentment by the Federal grand jury investigating espionage follows:

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Hugo Skala, the chief financial expert and second ranking member of the Czechoslovak commercial mission that arrived here last week to conduct negotiations with the State Department, has forsaken the mission and appealed for political asylum in this country because he has had enough of communism, it was revealed today.

Policemen broke into a tiny sealed room on the top floor of a three-story Brooklyn building late yesterday and brought out a mumbling, bearded 33-year-old man who had lived in the cell for ten years. Later he told the police that he had shut himself in the room because he "didn't like the way the world was going."

WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) -- The texts of the letter by John L. Sullivan, Secretary of the Navy, to Louis Johnson, Secretary of Defense, Mr. Sullivan's letter of resignation to President Truman and the President's reply were as follows:

While the state charged yesterday in Queens County Court that Dominick San Antonio, 22-year-old veteran, deliberately shot and killed a patrolman following a hold-up, the defense acknowledged the killing but indicated it would try to prove that San Antonio was mentally disturbed at the time.

The long-hoped-for resurgence of vaudeville at the Palace is now a certainty. Yesterday Sol A. Schwartz, vice president and general manager of the RKO chain of 110 theatres throughout the country, announced that the new policy would go into effect May 19.
If you don't think as I do about compulsory health insurance, you are not fair-minded nor far-sighted. That is the twist given in the Frothingham committee report to President Truman.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 26 -- Over British and United States opposition, the Social Committee of the United Nations General Assembly today approved a Mexican proposal to write into a proposed future treaty convention on newsgathering a series of duties and responsibilities that correspondents would be obliged to fulfill.
BINGHAMTON, N. Y., April 26 (AP) -- Five hundred employes have been laid off by the Ansco Division of the General Aniline and Film Corporation in the last week, the company disclosed today.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., April 26 -- Dr. Frank H. Lahey of the Lahey Clinic, Boston, former president of the American Medical Association, indicated today that he did not expect Congress to take any action this year on President Truman's proposed national compulsory health insurance program.

Directors of the American Smelting and Refining Company, at the annual meeting in Jersey City, yesterday elected Kenneth C. Brownell as president. He formerly was executive vice president and succeeds H. Y. Walker who retired at the age of 70.
LONDON, April 26 -- I returned last month from a visit of some weeks to Australia. It is a land of opportunity. It is a land of giant distances which embrace every variety of climate and opportunity.

The Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, pastor of Christ Church, Methodist, and chaplain of New York University, has been named director of the university's Hall of Fame for Great Americans, Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase announced yesterday.

To the people of Norway, closer to the threat of aggression than any other western European nation, the Atlantic pact has brought a feeling of "serenity and positive relief" and the belief that the "cold war has been stopped in its tracks," Charles Ulrick Bay, Ambassador to the Scandinavian country, said here yesterday.
VIENNA, April 27 -- Recent inquiries by United States authorities in Austria into alleged diversion of Marshall Plan goods to Russia and her satellites have led to some interesting conclusions.

A technological revolution in the graphic arts that will speed up the process of putting out a newspaper and substantially reduce costs was forecast yesterday by C. M. Flint, research director for the American Newspaper Publishers Association.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The House and Senate definitely will not assemble in joint session to hear the following message from President Truman -- or a comparable one from any President -- until Americans, like Macaulay's ancient Romans, "all are for the State; and none is for the party":

A new furniture store will open today at 53 East Thirty-fourth Street. It is called "Today's House," and on display will be an unusually comprehensive collection of furniture, most of which has never been shown before.
MOSCOW, April 27 -- The Soviet press today made no mention of reports from Washington and London on the likelihood of a new Foreign Ministers Council session to discuss Germany at an early date.

LONDON, April 27 -- The Foreign ministers' deputies who met here today for their 157th session to discuss an Austrian peace treaty neared agreement on another of the remaining sixteen unagreed articles in the treaty draft.

Special offerings of a limited number of patterns -- discontinued or otherwise -- by several carpet manufacturers at 10 to 20 per cent discounts have resulted in little or no increase in retail orders, executives of two large mills reported yesterday. Buyers said they are not ordering the patterns because consumers are not buying them despite substantially lower retail prices.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 27 -- Requests for a Peruvian exit permit for the left-wing Apra party leader, Raul Haya de la Torre, to attend the Council for Human Rights Conference, to open here on May 9, apparently were rebuffed today as the Peruvian and Colombian United Nations delegations agreed that the International Court of Justice would have juridicial rights over the political refugee.

Leon H. Keyserling, vice chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, became involved yesterday in a heated exchange with Prof. Jacob Viner of Princeton University, past president of the American Economic Association, over whether he was speaking "his master's voice."

The Supreme Court, in a four-to-four decision, has just upheld an order of the Federal Trade Commission prohibiting makers of rigid steel conduit from selling or distributing their product under a so-called "basing point" delivered price system. (The "basing point" system is one under which prices, including freight charges are set at a place, or places, other than the actual point of shipment.)

Clarence B. Randall, formerly assistant to the president, yesterday was elected president of the Inland Steel Company of Chicago, succeeding Wilfred Sykes, who was made chairman of the executive committee. Joseph L. Block, vice president in charge of sales, was elected vice chairman of the board of directors.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Thirty-six more organizations were listed as "subversive" in a grouping made public today by the United States Civil Service Commission. The list was promulgated, like other past ones, under laws stipulating that the Attorney Generall shall designate such organizations and that their names then be circulated to the executive departments and agencies.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The pressure from impatient victors who want the spoils impelled Democratic party chieftains and President Truman to confer at the White House today on patronage problems and policy.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Despite a decline in industrial production in March and early April, the Federal Reserve Board said today that there was an increase in the number of passenger cars assembled in that period.

Just before dawn yesterday an Air Force pilot of a Douglas C-47, that had been on the Berlin airlift ditched his plane within a hundred yards of the Coast Guard's station cutter Sebago, 610 miles from Newfoundland. He and his crew were picked up unscratched.

The Kimberly School for Girls signed a contract yesterday for the purchase of the sixty-five-year-old Montclair Athletic Club in Montclair, N. J., and will use it as the new quarters of the school. The price was reported to be "more than $200,000."

PARIS, April 27 -- "The 'cold war' is not over, but the ice is broken," said a Paris Leftist newspaper today. It appeared to convey the sentiment in France, including official quarters, as the talks on a projected meeting of the Big Four Foreign Ministers on Germany moved forward on the official level.
Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, yesterday pledged his organization's assistance to city officials engaged in an inquiry into waterfront crime.

The need for better housing and playground facilities in the East Harlem area was stressed by Clyde Murray, headworker of Union Settlement, 237 East 104th Street, at the annual meeting of the settlement association yesterday. John Crosby Brown was elected chairman of the board of directors at the session.

The agreement by which India enters the British Commonwealth as a republic underscores the unique adaptability of the British system and the extraordinary evolution of the Empire. The advantages of an unwritten Constitution, which is not hampered by words in overcoming realities, were never better exemplified than in the compromise formula which allows a republic to function freely within a monarchical framework.

It may not be cheese cake as it's known at Reuben's and Lindy's, but nevertheless it's called that -- and it's delicious. There are six layers. Three are of sponge cake, three of a blend of pot cheese with heavy cream and butter. Sprinkled on top is a sort of caramelized sugar, rich but not too sweet

The ninety-six-foot four-masted brigantine Yankee, returning from a romantic and adventuresome cruise around the world, passed blithely through the harbor under auxiliary power yesterday. Customs, Coast Guard and other Government agencies had been watching for the vessel for several days, but missed her.

The Alleghany Corporation, of which Robert R. Young is chairman, has purchased control of Investors Syndicate of Minneapolis, Minn., one of the largest real estate investing and management companies in the United States, with assets in excess of $270,000,000, it was learned late yesterday.

NEWARK, N. J., April 27 -- The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the Western Electric Company, Inc., its subsidiary, filed today a formal answer in the Federal District Court here, denying charges brought by the Department of Justice in a civil suit that both companies had violated the Sherman Anti-trust Act in the manufacture and sale of telephone equipment and supplies.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The letter protesting abandonment of the super-aircraft carrier United States that John L. Sullivan, Secretary of the Navy, sent yesterday to Louis Johnson, Secretary of Defense, had been addressed first to President Truman.

Alrick H. Man Jr. of New York and Lieut. Col. James H. Bishop of Culver (Ind.) Military Academy have been named to serve, respectively, as non-playing captain of the United States Davis Cup team and chairman of the Davis Cup Selection Committee for 1949.

Competing advertising media -- newspapers, magazines, radio and television -- were urged yesterday to work together for the common aim of selling the function of advertising as a key force in continued American prosperity. This principle provided the theme for the main afternoon session of the American Newspaper Publishers Association's convention in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., April 27 -- A fourteenth-inning single by Glenn Flanders broke up a brilliant pitchers' duel between Columbia's Bob Swanson and Brown's Bill Hayes and Giles Powell and chased home Joel Kern with the tally that gave the Bruins a 3-2 Eastern Intercollegiate League triumph at Aldrich Field today.

The American Newspaper Publishers Association, which has been helping to advise Japanese publishers, received a thank you note yesterday from Masanori Ito, president of the Japan Newspaper Publishers and Editors Association.
The last doubt that the Hudson River Day Line would resume operations this year disappeared yesterday with the issuance of a final pier permit by the Department of Marine and Aviation.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Judith Coplon read a deeply secret FBI report on Communist spy work in the United States while she was an employe of the Department of Justice, the Fed eral Government charged today at her trial for espionage. It said her perusal of the report was shown by a written memorandum found in her pocketbook when she was arrested in New York March 4 and which was presented in court here today.

It is approximately a year since the Ballet Theatre has performed Antony Tudor's "Pillar of Fire" anywhere, but in last night's presentation of it at the Metropolitan Opera House there was certainly no evidence of any such lapse of time.

The New York Life Insurance Company sold the six-story apartment building containing two stores and twenty-two suites on a lot 39 by 100 feet at 597 East 138th Street, the Bronx, to an investing client of the Clark-Robinson Corporation, broker.

PATERSON, N. J., April 27 -- Democracy as practiced in the United States is far from perfect, but it is still the form of government that offers most to the world, it was decided today by six high school seniors from New Jersey schools who sat as the panel at the Youth Forum sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and held at the East Side High School here.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- The State Department gave notice today the United States would refuse to sign a proposed United Nations pact on news freedom unless a "completely unacceptable" new provision was removed.
CLEVELAND, April 27 (AP) -- The Indians pounded five pitchers for thirteen hits, including two home runs, a triple and a pair of doubles, for an 11-to-3 victory over the White Sox today.
Beginning at 8 o'clock this morning, twelve detectives under two acting lieutenants will be on permanent duty in Central Park, it became known last night.

Fewer than half of the 644,000 new families formed in the New York, New Jersey, Connecticut metropolitan area between 1940 and 1948, have been accommodated in homes built during that time, the Regional Plan Association reported yesterday.

Unless the city stops talking about the traffic problem and acts to create off-street parking facilities, business in the midtown area will be destroyed, Capt. William J. Pedrick, Collector of Internal Revenue for the Second District, declared yesterday.

Gasoline stocks in the United States declined 1,173,000 barrels to 124,749,000 last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Supplies of light fuel oil, however, increased 474,000 barrels to 49,643,000 and heavy grade fuel oil increased 177,000 to 60,207,000.

Seeking to aid their country in its quest for hard currency, Netherlands textile manufacturers will concentrate their efforts on building up exports to the United States, according to a trade delegation exhibiting products at the Netherlands Chamber of Commerce, 41 East Forty - second Street.

DETROIT, April 27 (AP) -- Right-handed Karl Drews, aided by some healthy slugging by Bob Dillinger and Paul Lehner, put the Browns back on the victory road today as he beat the Tigers, 4 to 3, in twelve innings.

NEWARK, N. J., April 27 (AP) -- Russ Derry went on a slugging binge today and powered the Rochester Red Wings to a 12-to-5 triumph over Newark in the opener of a three-game series. Derry collected his fourth and fifth homers of the season plus a single to drive in six runs.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Studies on animals providing the first experimental evidence that alcoholism may be caused by an inherited block that prevents the proper utilization of essential factors in the diet were described here today at the annual meeting of the National Academy of Sciences by Prof. Roger J. Williams of the University of Texas.

SHANGHAI, April 27 (AP) -- The withdrawal of foreigners from threatened Shanghai continued today. The United States liner President Wilson is due to sail tomorrow with 250 Americans aboard, cutting the American colony here to about 1,800.

The state of North Dakota announced yesterday that it would receive bids May 11 on $27,000,000 of veterans' bonus bonds dated May 15, 1949, and due July 15, 1950 to 1958. Interest is not to exceed 1 3/4 per cent.

Despite the Truman Administration's policy for easing consumer credit loans, the Federal Housing Administration has not moved to lower interest rates on its home modernization loans, inquiry disclosed yesterday.

ROBERT LOWRY'S stories, praised by Hemingway, laureled in various anthologies and other lit'ry variants of the share-cropping system, have now been gathered into a book called "The Wolf That Fed Us,"* in oblique homage to the town where so many GI's a few years ago tried to turn a three-day, pass into a Roman holiday.

A ten-count indictment charging violation of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 was returned by a Federal grand jury yesterday against William A. Hancock, 31-year-old employe of a Boston investment company in connection with a scheme which allegedly netted him and another man $160,000.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations asked today that a specific requirement be written into the National Housing Bill that families displaced in slum clearance operations be given preference to rent or buy in the redeveloped area.
SHANGHAI, April 27 -- Communist armies renewed their offensive today and drove to within less than fifty miles of this metropolis after having taken Soochow.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- "There must be no 'let down' in work of overseas relief at this time," Mrs. J. Selby Spurck of California, national chairman of the Committee on War Relief for the National Council of Catholic Women, stressed before a meeting of the board today.
Fordham led St. John's by 9 -- 4 with two out in the ninth yesterday and lost the game and the chance to go to the top of the Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference.

The Colorado Fuel and Iron Corporation has declared a special dividend of $1 on the common stock, payable on May 23. The company also pays 25 cents quarterly. The last previous extra was 25 cents, paid in June last year.
NEWMARKET, England, April 27 (AP) -- A 10-to-1 outsider, Nimbus, won the classic 2,000 guineas by a nose today in a thrilling stretch duel with Abernant, the heavily backed favorite.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Curtis E. Calder, New York utilities executive, appeared for a few hours today to have become the next Secretary of the Army, but he denied tonight that he had accepted the position as of now or sixty days hence.

CHIEM SEE, Germany, April 27 -- Communist and Fascist teachers should not be permitted to remain on university faculties under the cloak of academic freedom, educators attending the first International Conference on Comparative Education declared here today.

CHICAGO, April 27 -- Grain markets closed irregular on the Board of Trade here today, a feature of the trading being the relative strength in May wheat and corn. A considerable part of the trade was of a professional character, but the May-July spreads widened out.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- As a prelude to the first test on a new Republican plan designed to force reductions of 5 to 20 per cent in all Government department and agency appropriations, the Senate rejected today a proposal to strike $125,000,000 from the $2,396,337,263 Labor-Federal Security money bill, and instead added $31,165,000 to it.

NANTES, France, April 26 -- In a large warehouse forming part of the tinplate works of a company called J. J. Carnaud et Forges de Basse Indre, just south of Nantes, are stacked many bales of tinplate, each about as big as a large trunk. On the outside of each bale is the United States emblem with this notation in French: "Supplied by the United States for the Recovery of Europe."

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The 200-member United Mine Workers policy committee today authorized the union's officers to negotiate with the bituminous coal operators in order to attain the union's "desired objectives."

The cancellation of the supercarrier United States by Secretary of Defense Louis Johnson last Saturday followed by the resignation of John L. Sullivan, Secretary of the Navy, in protest probably is the first of several moves that may stir up a hornet's nest of controversy in Washington.

Commenting on the present wave of simple Chinese - inspired furniture as compared with the more ornate oriental type popular here in the past, Alan Priest, curator of Far Eastern Art at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, declared last night that the difference in design was a matter of "cold cash" to the Chinese, not a question of earlier or finer works.

The Noel Coward comedy, "Private Lives," starring Tallulah Bankhead, announced yesterday that it will terminate its local engagement at the Plymouth Theatre after the Saturday evening performance of May 14. By that time, the attraction will have chalked up a total of 256 performances.

The CIO in this city has set up a new council to replace the one that was disbanded by the national CIO for "slavish adherence" to the Communist party line. Two-thirds of the delegates attending the organization meeting of the new body made clear their determination to renounce Communist policies and follow those of the national CIO.

Simultaneous reports from the Girl Scouts of the United States and the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York revealed yesterday a national membership of 1,,265,251 in 1948 and a local enrollment of about 36,000. The national membership included 292,536 adult volunteers who served as sponsors, troop leaders, council members and advisers.
A formula to guarantee five years of peace in the city's strife-ridden general trucking industry has been recommended to 10,000 truck drivers by their union leaders, it became known last night.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The Senators won a ball game tonight!

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Continuation of European recovery aid at an annual rate of about $2,000,000,000 for at least four years after the present 1952 expiration date was proposed today by Seymour E. Harris, Harvard economics professor, in a report to the Foreign Policy Association.

Increased efficiency in the promotion by the United States of trade among European nations is the best way to advance European recovery, Paul Reynaud, former Premier of France and one of Europe's foremost financial authorities, said last night in an address at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Federal Judge Harold R. Medina charged defense counsel at the Communist trial yesterday with staging "rumpuses" in court to prevent him from conducting an orderly trial and with carrying attacks on him "beyond all reason."

DETROIT, April 27 -- The Ford Motor Company told the United Automobile Workers, CIO, today that a complaint of a speed-up on the assembly lines was unfounded and that any strike action because of it would be regarded as a violation of the union contract.

The fifth and final manuscript of Lincoln's Gettysburg Address, written on three sheets of ordinary blue-lined tablet paper, was sold at auction last night for $54,000 at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.

BRIDGEPORT, Pa., April 27 -- James Lees Sons Company had net earnings of $1,028,500 for the March quarter on sales of $12,630,816, Joseph L. Eastwick, president, reported to stockholders at the annual meeting of the company here yesterday. Earnings equaled $1.22 per common share, compared with $1.26 a share last year. The sales were about 2 per cent lower than in 1948.
LONDON, April 27 -- Talks on lifting of the Berlin blockade led to better conditions in the stock market here today.

Albert B. Ashforth, Inc., announced yesterday that it has been appointed exclusive eastern renting agent for the proposed Merchandise Mart to be erected in Dallas, Tex. The company will be represented in the project by Loren D. Keys and Donald B. Callender, vice presidents.
HAGERSTOWN, Md., April 27 (AP) -- Sherman Fairchild staged an unorthodox "stay away" strike today to force postponement of the annual meeting of the airplane manufacturing corporation he founded.

FRANKFORT, Germany, April 27 -- Lieut. Gen. Clarence R. Huebner, deputy chief of the European Command of the United States Army, and other high military officers today pronounced this month's maneuvers of the United States forces in Germany a success; but they cited with concern a critical lack of physicians in the Army.

New pedestrian overpasses scheduled for final approval by the Board of Estimate today at an aggregate cost of $220,000 will remove traffic lights from the segment of the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive between Ninety-sixth Street and 125th Street, Borough President Hugo E. Rogers of Manhattan announced yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 27 -- The Social Committee of the General Assembly today approved a United States proposal whereby governments signing the proposed convention on news-gathering would agree to extend it to their territories or colonies "as soon as possible."

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The United Biscuit Company of America, Chicago, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 80,000 shares of no-par value cumulative preferred stock that is to be offered to the public at a price to be filed by amendment.

America's fastest growing sport it is called in the literature put out by the enthusiasts who promote it. Spring is the time it gets going. And, believe it or not, it is harness racing with trotting horses, a distinctive American entertainment as compared with the running races to which our English cousins are so devoted -- though, to be sure, there was a time when Englishmen also went in for trotters.

The discussions at Lake Success of an international code on newsgathering illustrate once more the truth of the old adage that the result of an attempt to define a freedom is frequently to limit it. At present no restrictions on the free transmission of news are imposed by international treaty: such obstacles as exist are to be found only in the censorship set up by individual nations.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, April 27 -- A five-point recommendation for reduction of manufacturers' distribution costs, and long-term improvement of "distributor relations," was made here today. The program was laid before more than 2,000 members of the annual convention of the American Supply and Machinery Manufacturers' Association, the National Supply and Machinery Distributors Association and the Southern Supply and Machinery Distributors' Association.

In a letter appearing on the TIMES: editorial page of April 25, signed by Will Maslow and Bertram Diamond of the American Jewish Congress, referring to the charges made against Professor Knickerbocker of City College, there appears the statement that "devotion to decent principles requires that facts be correctly determined and evaluated."
ROME, April 27 (UP) -- The International Olympic Committee today passed a rule designed to protect sports from the increasing influence of political pressure.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, April 27 -- The United Nations Conciliation Commission for Palestine opened discussions with Israeli, Egyptian and Lebanese delegations today on the settlement of political questions in Palestine.

LONDON, Thursday, April 28 -By means of a simple declaration by the Governments of the British Commonwealth India's continued membership in the Commonwealth was assured today. The declaration was made at the end of the Commonwealth Prime Ministers' conference in London.

ROME, April 27 (AP) -- Nine cities wanting to hold the 1956 Olympic Games, including half a dozen from the United States which can't agree on a single candidate, will begin presenting their arguments to the International Olympic Committee here tomorrow morning.

PINEHURST, N. C., April 27 (AP) -- The four favorites moved into the semi-finals of the North and South women's golf tournament today. However, two had to go to the last hole to make it and a third was carried to the seventeenth green.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 27 -- Jacob A. Malik, Soviet representative to the United Nations, today gave oral assurances to Dr. Philip C. Jessup, the United States roving Ambassador, that the Soviet Union would raise the blockade of Berlin on the two conditions announced earlier this week by Tass, the official Soviet news agency.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 27 -- Kathryn Grayson and Mario Lanza were named today by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer for the leading roles in the prospective American version of the 1937 French film, "Kiss of Fire," which the studio acquired recently.

It is a privilege to urge support once more for the drive of the Greater New York Fund, 11 West Forty-second Street, New York 18, which provides services that protect the health and promote the well-being of all of us who live or earn our living in New York City.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The Senate Finance Committee approved today the House-passed bill to repeal all Federal taxes on oleomargarine. Some of these have been levied for sixty-three years in the interest of protecting butter from competition.

The first biography in sixty years to be based on the original manuscripts of Ralph Waldo Emerson will be published by Scribner on May 23. Ralph L. Rusk, the author, had the use of the family collection of unpublished lectures, sermons, journals, account books and thousands of letters never used before by a biographer.

Marcel Cerdan, holder of the world middleweight championship, will defend his crown under the promotion of the Tournament of Champions on June 21, it was announced yesterday by Murray Goodman, spokesman for the group.

The Long Island Rail Road officially became an orphan yesterday. Its trains ran with the same legendary devotion to schedule, but for the first time since it was purchased by the Pennsylvania it was completely on its own.

Development of merchandising and promotional campaigns to tap new markets in the development of United States foreign trade and the democratic way of life was urged yesterday by John F. McKiernan, director of the New York regional office of the Department of Commerce, in an address at the luncheon meeting of the Export Advertising Association at the Shelton Hotel.

With the negotiation of a truce between Israel and Syria expected within a week, the United Nations is well on the way toward effecting the full restoration of peace in the Holy Land, Dr. Ralph J. Bunche said yesterday. The acting United Nations mediator for Palestine declared, however, that the Israeli Government still faced severe tests of statesmanship in achieving mutually beneficial relations with neighboring Arab states.
LONDON, Thursday, April 28 (AP) -- Following is a statement on the Commonwealth conference issued today by Prime Minister Attlee's office:

Maurice Kreger bought for occupancy the one-family residence with six rooms and garage at 140-01 Sixty-ninth Road, in the Arrowbrook Park housing development, Kew Gardens Hills, Queens, Lane Realty, sales representatives, reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Brig. Gen. Josef Schejbal, who since 1947 has been military and air attache of the Czechoslovak Embassy, resigned today and requested the State Department to give him political asylum in the United States. This is expected to be granted.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 27 -- The people of Libya are determined to resist the return of Italian rule -- with arms if necessary -- according to a Libyan spokesman who testified today before the United Nations General Assembly's Political Committee.
Word has just arrived from Maine that Moosehead, the largest and one of the most popular salmon and lake trout waters of that state, is now wide open to fishing, and Rangeley Lake is almost clear.

Tobacco prices will "very likely" go lower with competition keener in the near future, John Bromell, chief wholesale specialist, Marketing Division, Office of Domestic Commerce, declared yesterday. He addressed about 800 members of the industry at the annual convention in the Statler Hotel.

One of the most enterprising little theatre groups staging shows these days is the Lighthouse Players of the New York Association for the Blind. Their productions, employing the services of a talented group of blind actresses and some sighted guest players, are presented after painstaking rehearsals for many weeks.

Dominick San Antonio, who has been on trial for the killing of on policeman and the shooting others, pleaded guilty yesterday to a reduced charge of second-degree murder in Queens County Court Long Island City. He also pleaded guilty to a second indictment charging first-degree robbery, violation of the Sullivan Law an other charges.
MOSCOW, April 27 (UP) -- Eugen S. Varga, a noted Russian economist who had disagreed sharply with the official Soviet interpretation of Western politics and economics, today retracted his "errors.''

BOSTON, April 27 (AP) -- For the second time this season Vern Stephens drove in five runs in a single game as he walloped two mighty home runs to lead the Red Sex to a 10-6 victory over the Athletics today before 12,677 fans.

Paillard Products, Inc., American factory branch for Paillard, Ltd., Switzerland, to Roy S. Durstine, Inc. The company makes Bolex motion picture cameras, Kern-Paillard lenses and Hermes typewriters. National magazines, newspapers and trade publications.

Reporting on operations of the General Foods Corporation and its consolidated subsidiaries, Clarence Francis, chairman, informed the annual meeting of shareholders yesterday that net sales of $127,802,860 for the March quarter this year were the highest on record, comparing with the $120,027,500 volume in the initial three months of 1948. He noted that sales for March were the greatest for any single month in the company's history.

Ed Wynn may appear next fall over CBS television in a show televised "live" on the West Coast and then kinescoped for later showings on CBS's Eastern and Midwestern networks. Negotiations in progress between CBS and the William Morris agency if successful, may result in the Wynn show, now planned as a half-hour weekly show, being the first West Coast television show to be seen in the East on kinescope film.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- (AP) -- The text of Secretary Acheson's statement today on the North Atlantic treaty to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee follows:

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, April 27 -- Venezuela is disposed to invite a mission of the International Labor Organization to study the labor conditions prevailing under the military junta, it was learned today. A resolution condemning alleged violations of labor union freedom in Venezuela and Peru is in preparation in the workers' group of the regional ILO conference being held here.

CHICAGO, April 27 (AP) -- Cincinnati's Johnny Vander Meer developed a spell of wildness that turned into a six-run rally for the Cubs in the fourth inning today. Chicago breezed from there to an 8-3 victory before a Ladies' Day turnout of 23,223.

LONDON, April 27 -- The first full-scale inquest by the general council of the Trades Union Congress, representing 8,000,000 workers, into the austerity budget produced vigorous criticism of the Government here today.
