A throng of several hundred members of society filled the Starlight Room of the Waldorf-Astoria last night for the annual "Gay Thirties" dinner dance in aid of the Boys' Club of New York, an organization founded in 1876. The beneficiary through its two centers, respectively at 287 East Tenth Street and 321 East 11th Street offers educational and recreational opportunities to more than 5,000 youths.
BERLIN, April 27 -- The single authorized road link between this blockaded city and the Western zones of Germany is closed as tightly as ever.

Ocean Brief, the mare that needed a hole in her head to make her a topnotcher, gave the King Ranch first money of $12,025 in the $18,450 Correction Handicap at Jamaica yesterday. Outrun for only a few yards in the backstretch, she paced the field of ten around the turn and through the stretch to take the photo decision from Mrs. F. Ambrose Clark's $50,000 filly, Alfoxie.

The first of a series of meetings of a special "task group" of the National Security Resources Board was held yesterday in the Atlantic Coast District headquarters of the Maritime Commission, 45 Broadway. Brig. Gen. Robert H. Wylie of San Francisco, manager of the Board of State Harbor Commissioners, is chairman of the committee.

The account of the discovery of unique archaeological remains in the Northwest, in the course of the River Basin Studies program to salvage such remains before they are forever destroyed by flooding, needs the further commentary that the House of Representatives is stopping this valuable scientific program by slashing the entire item for the studies from the Interior Department appropriation.

TORONTO, April 27 (Canadian Press) -- Permanent removal of United States import duties on Canadian copper and nickel was urged by Robert C. Stanley of New York, chairman of the board of the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., at today's annual meeting.

Giving a new twist to collective bargaining procedure, the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, CIO, called on General Electric, Westinghouse and other big electrical manufacturers yesterday to give each of their 600,000 workers the equivalent of a wage increase of $500 a year.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The Administration is ready to throw its strength behind five amendments to the Lesinski bill repealing the Taft-Hartley Labor Act. The decision was reached today with the acquiescence of labor leaders.

CHICAGO, April 27 -- A new national railroad policy involving "more adequate" depreciation allowances, increased earnings, revision of subsidies to competing carriers and less regulation was recommended tonight by Robert B. McColl, president of the American Locomotive Company.

CAMDEN, S. C., April 27 -- Youths of Camden were urged today by Bernard Baruch, a native son of Camden, to guard against those who would seek to destroy their faith in the American form of government, and were told that "were our Government destroyed the result would only be intolerance and injustice on a truly terrible scale, as has happened wherever freedom has been destroyed."

Cantor, Fitzgerald Co., Inc., announced yesterday the offering of an issue of common stock of Hotelevision, Inc., an innovation intended to enable hotels to transmit television from one master control to any number of rooms. The financing consists of 480,000 shares of class A stock at $1 a share.

BUFFALO, N. Y., April 27 -- Because of greatly increased demand, machine tool builders are developing highspeed wheelheads which operate at 5,000 surface feet per minute or more, Leroy B. Morrill, electrical engineer, The Heald Machine Company, Worcester, Mass., disclosed today.

Jean Chauvel, permanent French delegate to the United Nations Security Council, and former secretary general of foreign affairs of the French Republic, was the guest of honor at a dinner party given last night at the Pierre by Richard de Rochemont.
BERLIN, April 27 -- A high United States official predicted today that the Soviet blockade of Berlin would be lifted in the "next three or four days."

ALBANY, April 27 -- A bill permitting New York City employes who elect to retire at fifty-five years of age to get a one-sixth increase in their pension allowances was signed today by Governor Dewey at the request of Mayor O'Dwyer and the New York City Council.

Pete Milne's inside-the-park pinch home run with the bases filled in the seventh inning gave the Giants an 11-to-8 comeback triumph over the Dodgers yesterday at the Polo Grounds. This outcome, squaring the season's series between the local rivals, knocked the Brooks out of the National League lead and put the Giants in first place along with the Pirates.

A central clearing house for medical films, the Medical Film Institute, was opened yesterday at the Academy of Medicine building, 2 East 103d Street, under the auspices of the Audio-Visual Committee of the Association of American Medical Colleges.

The two-family dwelling on a lot 20 by 100 feet at 1318 East Tenth Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by the Hilka Realty Corporation to Seymour Mazur through Eisberg-Lenz, Inc., broker. It is assessed for $17,000 and was built about a year ago. The sale was for cash over a first mortgage of $12,000 held by the Knickerbocker Federal Savings and Loan Association.
PARIS, April 27 -- Overskirts for all hours and separate fichus for beach and evening are the themes of Molyneux's midseason opening.

PHILADELPHIA, April 27 (AP) -- Warren Spahn of the Braves pitched his first victory of the season tonight as he blanked the Phillies with three hits, 2 -- 0. Boston bunched three of its six hits off Robin Roberts for both runs in the second inning.

Hopeful that the split in the Democratic vote would give William H. McIntyre, Republican nominee for Representative in the Twentieth Congressional District a chance of success at the special election on May 17, his supporters opened headquarters yesterday in the Fifth Assembly District Republican Club, 51 West Eighty-sixth Street.
The text of the address of Paul Reynaud last night at the dinner of the United States Associates of the International Chamber of Commerce at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, follows:
The cotton futures market closed irregular on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday and final prices were 13 points lower to 8 points higher.

Advocates of big government and "Marxist-inspired textbook writers" were denounced yesterday by David W. Howe, retiring president of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, as threats to a free American press.

Despite protests of business men, farmers and civic leaders from upstate communities, the trustees of the bankrupt and strike-bound New York, Ontario Western Railroad asked the Federal court yesterday for permission to seek an Interstate Commerce Commission order discontinuing the line in whole or in part.

ST. LOUIS -- April 27 (AP) -- The Pirates pushed over four runs in the first inning, then went on to a 7-to-1 victory over the Cardinals tonight. Murry Dickson hurled Pittsburgh into a first-place tie with the Giants.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson appealed today for Senate ratification of the North Atlantic treaty as a guard over the liberties of the twelve nations that signed it and as a way of "waging peace."

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Sharp cuts by the House in appropriations for continuing the Selective Service System -- from a requested $16,000,000 to $4,000,000 -- if not restored at least in major portion by the Senate, simply means the end of a going organization for providing soldiers in an emergency, Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey said today.

Six prizes totaling $40,000 were awarded yesterday to three novelists and three playwrights by The Christophers, a group founded four years age by a Marryknoll Missioner to promote Christian principle in public life.

The Roman Catholic Church has expressed no objections to the proposed reform of the calendar, which has been placed on the provisional agenda for consideration by the United Nations General Assembly in September, a church history authority and exponent of a revised world calendar declared here yesterday.

In an active turnover, cottonseed oil futures moved to new high ground for the current upturn on the New York Produce Exchange yesterday. Influenced by strong cash oil markets in the South and higher lard markets, trade and speculative buying entered the market in volume.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended April 20:

"Adventure in Baltimore," an RKO drama set in that city at the turn of the century and starring Robert Young, Shirley Temple and John Agar, which arrives at the Capitol, is this morning's lone film newcomer. Richard Wallace directed and Richard H. Berger produced the Dore Schary presentation from a screen play by Lionel Houser and a story by Lesser Samuels and Christopher Isherwood.

James L. Rogers, a student in the Department of Journalism of the University of Texas, Austin, Tex., received a gold medal and $500 in cash yesterday as the winner of the eighth annual journalism contest of the American Newspaper Publishers Association.

In a transaction adding to their realty holdings in the Dyckman section of Manhattan, Fischer-Landis, Inc., operators, have purchased two five-story apartment houses with a total of fifty apartments at 565-69 Academy Street, northeast corner of Post Avenue, from the Academy Company, it was announced yesterday.

Stocks continued to improve selectively in yesterday's trading on the New York Stock Exchange and final prices generally were modestly higher, with the steel shares the feature. Business declined to 830,000 shares from 870,000 on Tuesday.

BONN, Germany, April 27 -Plenary sessions of the Parliamentary Council here have been scheduled for May 11 through 14, Dr. Konrad Adenauer announced today. Final readings of a draft constitution for the Western German state will be held during that interval.

Bache Co., investment bankers, observed yesterday the seventieth anniversary of the company's association with Wall Street with a luncheon at the Bankers Club. Among guests were Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange and Edward C. Werle, chairman of the board of the New York Curb Exchange.

Dr. Isaac Halevi Herzog, Israel's chief rabbi, arriving yesterday afternoon at the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, said that unless Israel's housing situation was remedied immediately "a condition may arise that may cause us to consider a curtailment of immigration."
BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 27 (AP) -- Reports from Damascus today said the Syrian border with the Kingdom of Jordan had been reopened as suddenly as it was closed 24 hours before.
HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 27 (AP) -- Mrs. Danny Shea's Busy Morning won from Larry MacPhail's Marian Ann by a nose in the $7,500-added Havre de Grace Breeders' Stakes today.
About 40 per cent of the $1,130,000,000 - North Atlantic arms-aid program will represent the value of surplus United States equipment to be transferred to European nations, it was learned yesterday.

E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. and its wholly owned subsidiaries, in a report covering the quarter ended with last March, to be released today, disclosed the net income at $43,581,325, compared with $30,195,371 for the initial three months of last year.

In a quick turnover of an East Side property which he bought recently, Frederick Brown, the operator, has resold the five-story business building at 26 East Fifty-sixth Street, adjoining the southwest corner of Madison Avenue, to the Moritz Realty Corporation.

In your issue of April 25 C. L. Sulzberger writes from Paris of a diplomatic suggestion that Greece's frontiers with Albania, Yugoslavia and Bulgaria be guaranteed either by the U. N. or the Big Four. This would entail, he infers, de jure recognition of present de facto borders, and this, he says, is an unwelcome fact to the Greeks, in view of their claims upon northern Epirus.
SHANGHAI, April 27 (AP) -- Two Communist columns bore down today on this greatest city in all Asia from the west and northwest.

The General Motors Corporation yesterday reported net sales of $1,282,324,474 and net income of $136,763,338 for the first quarter of 1949. Both figures were the highest for any three-month period in the corporation's history.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- President Truman's compulsory health insurance plan was laid aside by a Senate subcommittee today under an agreement to defer a showdown on the floor until the session starting next January.

LONDON, April 27 -- A minor but gratifying agreement incidental to current Commonwealth talks here was announced to the British public tonight. In a joint statement, Australian Prime Minister Joseph B. Chifley and British Food Minister John Strachey said Britain would take all of Australia's exportable meat surplus up to a specified ceiling for the next fifteen years.
WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- The New York State Farm Bureau Federation asked Congress today to extend to farmers and farm workers the coverage of Social Security, old age and survivors' insurance.
Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan defended his proposed farm income support program last night as an important element in an economic stabilization program for the whole national economy.

Henry A. Wallace, Progressive party leader and its candidate for President last November, disappointed 400 persons last night at the Hotel Commodore when at the last minute he decided not to deliver a speech he had prepared.

Trucks operated by newspapers established a new record for safety in 1948, David W. Howe, president of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, announced yesterday at the association's convention at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -Export control of about 500 items, covering a wide range of commodities, was abolished today by the Department of Commerce. Charles Sawyer, Secretary, said that these items now may be shipped to any destination in the world without a validated export license.
The Jewish Museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue, has opened two new exhibitions -- one of oils and graphic work by Isaac Lichtenstein and the other of oils and water-colors by Louise D. Kayser.

PARIS, April 9.7 -- Fernand Buret, 36-year-old former cannoneer, was sentenced to five years in prison with military disqualification by a French military court in Metz today for killing his commanding officer under unusual circumstances during the Battle of France almost nine years ago.

WASHINGTON, Apirl 27 (AP) -- Army engineers recommended to the House Public Works Committee today three New York river and harbor projects estimated to cost a total of $1,678,000. These are the projects, recommended by Col. W. S. Moore:

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- This country will not get its money's worth in defense until the problem is attacked in its entirety instead of in the present "piecemeal fashion,'' Maj. Gen. Otto L. Nelson Jr. tonight told the National Council of the League of Women Voters.
HOLLYWOOD, Fla., April 27 -An ambitious plan for sponsoring foreign study by Americans was described today at the annual convention of the General Federation of Women's Clubs.

SHANGHAI, April 27 -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek today returned to the public arena for the first time since his "retirement" on Jan. 21. After flying to threatened Shanghai, he appealed to the nation for a redoubled fight against communism.

Underwriting circles expect that a refunding of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority's $125,000,000 debt commitment to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation through a new offering of tax-exempt bonds to the public will come to market by the end of next week.

RANGOON, Burma, April 27 (AP) -- Burmese editors said in a published survey today that bandit gangs crossing the frontier from China and Siam were a grave danger to the Burma Union, long torn by civil war.

Six hundred business, professional and civic leaders attended a dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night in honor of former Supreme Court Justice Joseph M. Proskauer, honorary president of the American Jewish Committee. The dinner, sponsored by the Joint Defense Appeal on behalf of the United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York, brought pledges totaling $3,750,000 for the fund.
The Board of Estimate adopted unanimously yesterday a budget of $1,197,434,294 to meet the cost of running the City Government in the fiscal year beginning July 1.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- There are many ways in which a Secretary of State can present a treaty to the Senate, but the best way is to tell the Senators everything. This astonishes them, then bores them stiff, and eventually minimizes the ordeal.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- American ship owners and operators were urged by their chief spokesman in Congress today to "reconcile or compromise their differences and unite upon a program which they and the Maritime Commission can jointly recommend to Congress."

First local dealer deliveries of the new Radio Corporation of America sixteen-inch direct view tube television receiver console combination will begin in one week, Irving Sarnoff, vice president, Bruno-New York, Inc., RCA metropolitan area distributor, revealed yesterday.
PRAGUE, April 27 (UP) -- Czechoslovak anti-Communists are circulating chain letters demanding "secret and free elections" under United Nations sponsorship, it was reported today.

BOSTON, April 27 -- The Church Congress, Protestant Episcopal, heard today proposals for a review board on remarriages after divorce and for a restatement of doctrine as a prerequisite to discussing unity with other religions.

Paul Makushak, who was dug out Tuesday night from a tiny cell in a Greenpoint tenement where he had immured himself for ten years, said from his bed in a hospital psychiatric ward yesterday that he preferred life in his closet.

The Down Town Glee Club, under George Mead, gave its annual spring concert last night at Carnegie Hall. Mildred Dilling, harpist was the assisting artist. Stuart Ross presided at the piano and Clinton Reed at the organ.

Getting something done in community health or welfare problems depends on stimulating the active support of the public rather than leaving matters to medical specialists, according to speakers who addressed the annual meeting of the Health Council of Greater New York at the Biltmore Hotel yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 28 -- The social committee of the General Assembly tonight approved a statement of press aims and responsibilities that will serve as a preamble to the United Nations future news-gathering convention.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The North Atlantic treaty and accompanying American aid to its European members would draw up for the United States a line of security "over there instead of on the Atlantic Seaboard," Louis Johnson, Secretary of Defense, asserted today.

The new executive budget forwarded to the City Council reveals that Mayor O'Dwyer and the Board of Estimate held the line effectively against the demands made at public hearings. The cost of running the city government in the fiscal year starting July 1 is put at $1,197,434,294.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., April 28 -- Dr. William T. Salter, Yale University pharmacologist, received the 1948 Iodine Educational Bureau Research Award here today at the ninety-sixth convention of the American Pharmaceutical Association.

Antique examples of Chinese cloisonne were viewed by the trustees, advisory committee and associates of the China Institute, 125 East Sixty-fifth Street, yesterday afternoon preliminary to the public showing beginning at 9 o'clock this morning.

CHICAGO, April 28 (UP) -- Traffic accidents in the first three months of 1949 killed 6,610 persons in this country, an increase of 2 per cent over deaths in the same period last year, the National Safety Council said tonight.

Since comparisons are inevitable let's be blunt about it. "Life With Mother," which was announced yesterday to close June 4 after a run of 265 performances at the Empire, has fared nowheres near as well as its famous predecessor, "Life With Father.

ROME. April 28 -- The Cabinet Council this morning again expressed unanimous approval of Foreign Minister Carlo Sforza's efforts in the United States for the return of Italy's pre-Fascist colonies. Count Sforza tomorrow will address both the Senate and Chamber Foreign Affairs Committees.

An armed truce was reached yesterday between the Long Island Rail Road and George F. Young, president of the Central Queens Allied Civic Council, who had charged the road with violation of that section of the Sanitary Code covering smoke nuisance by trains.

Great Britain has not yet reached a point where devaluation of the pound sterling is essential and premature action may well have adverse repercussions, according to a major conclusion of an eighty-five-page study just completed by the International Finance Committee of the National Foreign Trade Council, Inc., entitled "Sterling Since the Convertibility Crisis."

Whatever their short-term advantages, limitations upon production of necessary commodities and services inevitably make a nation poorer, not richer, Richard F. Uhlmann, president of the Chicago Board of Trade, said here yesterday.
Six exhibitions opening this week prove that the last accusation that could be leveled at the metropolitan art scene is lack of variety.

THE number of places on this distraught globe where trouble is now simmering and may boil over at any moment is so great that it would be an alert citizen who could list them. If China's submergence beneath the Communist tide seems the most dismal today something equally momentous may happen tomorrow in Germany or Austria, Greece or Korea, or, for that matter, anywhere except Antarctica.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The Senate, by a vote of 44 to 37, ordered its Appropriations Committee today to slash at least 5 per cent off proposed operational spending by the Department of Labor and the Federal Security Agency during the fiscal year beginning July 1.

The proposed appropriation of $4,500,000 for nation-wide maintenance of the Selective Service organization would not permit the New York City Selective Service Commission more than five employes, with its share of the money, Col. Candler Cobb, director of the service here, said yesterday.

At the invitation of the Govment of Southern Rhodesia, Farrell Lines is opening a "special nonresident account" in that country that will make it possible for the American-flag steamship company to accept freight payments in Rhodesian currency, W. Clifford Shields, Farrell vice president, announced yesterday.

The hopes for an end of the Berlin blockade, and therewith the removal of the most dangerous point of friction in the whole "cold war," grow brighter as a result of Soviet assurances that there are no other conditions attached to the latest Moscow offer except the two announced by Tass.

LONDON, April 28 -- The first post-war dinner of Britain's famed Royal Academy, which was held in a setting of pre-war splendor here tonight, was unexpectedly enlivened by an outburst of artistic temperament that almost put the after-dinner speeches of Winston Churchill, the Archbishop of Canterbury and the Duke of Gloucester in the shade.

The destinies of freedom-loving people of the whole world rest in the hands of the United States, Vincent R. Impellitteri, president of the City Council, said yesterday. He spoke before 600 delegates at the opening session of the annual convention of the New York Catholic War Veterans in the New Yorker Hotel.

A $381,000,000 call on its War Loan accounts with the Class B banks was issued yesterday by the United States Treasury. The call, based on balances on April 27, is payable in instalments on May 3, 4 and 5. For the banks in this district, the daily total amounts to $31,733,000, while the national aggregate each day is $127,066,000.

Through economy and making "the highest use of all natural resources," mankind may almost indefinitely postpone the prospect of a "have-not world," Harvey S. Mudd, president of the Cyprus Mines Corporation, declared last night at the Columbia University Club, 4 West Forty-third Street.

Lew Hahn, president of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, today called on all appliance manufacturers to promptly reduce prices to "a point where the public will feel again the impulse to buy."

Passage of legislation to eliminate the current practice of interstate sales of cigarettes to avoid state taxes was urged yesterday in a resolution adopted by the National Association of Tobacco Distributors at their annual convention in the Statler Hotel.

ROUEN, France, April 28 -- At the end of World War II Rouen, France's great fluvial port on the Seine, eighty-seven miles from Paris and fifty-five miles from the sea, ancient capital of the Province of Normandy, lay devastated, with many of its monuments in ruins, its port a shambles, its commerce almost halted.

One year's research on the possibilities of new, revolutionary techniques of printing has so impressed the country's newspaper publishers that they acted yesterday to place the program on a permanent basis.

Sean MacBride, Minister for External Affairs of Eire, and Irish-born Mayor O'Dwyer joined yesterday in a plea for complete independence of Ireland. An audience of 500 persons who attended an official reception to Mr. MacBride in the City Council chamber at City Hall heard the two officials express the hope that such independence soon would be attained.

Because of the need for additional facilities for the care of the aged, the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York has undertaken a $2,850,000 building project to provide a six-building annex to its Home for Aged and Infirm Hebrews, it was announced yesterday.

DETROIT, April 28 -- The United Automobile Workers, CIO, gave the Ford Motor Company another chance today to come to terms on two immediate strike threats and warned that a fund of $4,000,000 would be available to finance a national midsummer walkout against the concern should it be necessary to enforce the union's 1949 economic demands.

A drop of $71,000,000 in business loans by banks in this area last week virtually wiped out the remainder of the increase in such borrowings since last year's low point on April 28, a year ago, according to the data issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
Four Columbia University professors, including Dr. Harry J. Carman, dean of Columbia College, revealed yesterday that they are opposed to fighting communism by outlawing the Communist party.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 28 -- Konstantin E. Zinchenko, former press chief of the Moscow Foreign Office, was appointed today to fill the United Nations post of chief Assistant Secretary General in charge of Security Council affairs.

Bankers, business men and political leaders in Brooklyn began yesterday the twelfth annual campaign of the Greater New York Fund by pledging their support of a borough-wide campaign for $750,000 of the goal of $8,000,000 set by the New York campaign.
Eleven years ago today Manhattan sweltered with a pre-season heat wave when the mercury climbed to 85 degrees and broke a 50-year-record.

Federated Department Stores, Inc., in its fiscal year ended with last Jan. 29, had the highest sales volume and dollar earnings in its history, according to the annual report of Fred Lazarus Jr., president, to be released today.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- President Truman's accent on party loyalty as the test of patronage privileges stirred Southern anger on Capitol Hill today, where the House spent an inconclusive day debating labor legislation.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on April 23, 1949, totaled 769,336 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 3,446 cars, or 0.4 per cent more than for the preceding week, 82,590 cars, or 9.7 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 124,376 cars, or 13.9 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week two years ago.

CHICAGO, April 28 (AP) -- Shell egg futures prices continued their steady rise today in the largest trade of the year to date on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Net gains amounted to about 1/4 cent a dozen, with the aggregate since Easter running around 1 1/2 cents a dozen for October delivery.

ALBANY, April 28 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey approved today a bill authorizing the Board of Regents, for the first time in the state's history, to establish state scholarships for professional education in medicine and dentistry.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The reluctant Curtis E. Calder was still President Truman's first choice today to be the new Secretary of the Army.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 28 -- Arthur Rebner, playwright, today filed a copyright infringement suit against Loew's, Inc. (Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer), Joseph Pasternak and Hans Wilhelm for $750,000 damages, alleging that the 1948 Metro film, "On an Island With You," which Pasternak produced and on which Wilhelm collaborated as a writer, was plagiarized from the Rebner play "With You on a Desert Island," staged in Berlin in 1930.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The Southern Coal Producers Association today had voted to abstain "for the present" from further conferences with coal operators from the North, West and Far West.
WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- President Truman asked Congress today to authorize United States membership in the International Trade Organization.

Many labor, nationality, religious, patriotic, youth and political groups as well as the principal veterans' groups will be represented in the line of march of the Loyalty Day parade in Manhattan tomorrow, sponsors of the patriotic demonstration said yesterday.

After a two-year trial period, leaders of a new medical project to locate child victims of rheumatic fever on the lower East Side and to assure that they receive proper medical attention called their plan a success yesterday.

While no manufacturing short cut was offered to produce a $1,000 standard-sized car, other economic factors were stressed yesterday at the annual metropolitan council luncheon of the Automobile Old Timers at the Roosevelt Hotel.

Expansion of its services to newspaper, radio and television clients and completion of the last link in a round-the-world radioprinter news network were announced yesterday by International News Service.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Declaring that the hourly wage rate no longer is the total labor cost in business, the United States Chamber of Commerce asserted today that the typical American worker in 1947 received benefits from his employer of more than $424 above his wages.

LONDON, April 28 -- Welcoming India's continued adherence to the British Commonwealth, Winston Churchill looked forward today to a still wider association of nations, including the United States and a united Europe.

" Rubens," a forty-five-minute documentary dealing with the work of the Flemish master and produced and directed in Belgium by Paul Haesaerts and Henri Storck, will have its local premiere today at the Elysee. Sponsored by the Belgian Ministries of Education and Communications, "Rubens" has an English narration by Stephane Cordier.

ROSELLE PARK, N. J., April 28 -- Three hundred dollars in one, five and ten dollar bills went with the wind when a sudden gust whipped the money from the seat of an automobile and stirred a wild scramble by pedestrians for the flying banknotes in the business section here at noon today.
LONDON, April 28 -- Apart from activity in selected stocks, most sections of the stock market here were quiet today.

Gustave Ring's Argentine-bred Respingo, winner as the outsider in a field of five last Saturday, was the winner as the odds-on favorite in the four-horse main act of the racing show at Jamaica yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The United States Navy has no intention of running out on Americans in Shanghai, President Truman said today, and he took pains to praise the Navy for doing an excellent job everywhere in China.

Norman M. Tucker, new marketing director of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, replied yesterday to Lake Success criticisms of the bank's lending practices by asserting that "one of the strongest" arguments for the bank's policy was that "our loans take quite a while."

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Earl J. McGrath, Commissioner of Education, told the annual convention of the American College Public Relations Association today that colleges in this country were performing two of their four main functions well but must come to grips with the other two.

Warning that American education is a "tragic failure" because of overemphasis on specialization, a group of the nation's foremost educators and scholars announced last night plans for unifying all college and university courses of study.

DETROIT, April 28 -- Emphasizing the introduction of the new "Ultramatic Drive" which eliminates gear shifting, the 1950 Packard "Golden Anniversary" line of cars was presented today by the Packard Motor Car Company. There are fourteen body types that will be displayed next week by dealers throughout the country, including those in the New York metropolitan area.

CHICAGO, April 28 (AP) -- Lefty Ken Raffensberger hurled a masterful seven-hitter to give the Reds a 2-0 triumph over the Cubs today before 7,582 chilled fans. It was his second victory in three starts.

The cancellation of the Navy's supercarrier, and the subsequent resignation of Secretary of the Navy Sullivan, may provide the powder train that win lead to explosive events in the National Military Establishment.
LONDON, April 28 (AP) -- The Royal Mail Line said today that it was abandoning its rights to the luxury liner Magdalena, which split and sank Tuesday near the mouth of Rio de Janeiro Harbor.
The time has come, he said -- and sighed, To talk of birds and trees; The sort of thing the countryfied Converse about with ease.

In slashing the appropriation for the Selective Service System to one-fourth the requested amount the House of Representatives is being penny wise and pound foolish. True economy demands a better allocation of funds so as to get more service from the same or less money.

MANILA, Friday, April 29 -- Mrs. Aurora Aragon Quezon, widow of the first President of the Philippines; two members of her family and ten other persons were killed in ambush yesterday in Hukbalahap-ridden Nueva Ecija province in north central Luzon.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Department store sales in the week ended April 23 were 10 per cent below sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1949:

LONDON, April 28 -- Need for closer cooperation among European Liberals, with the eventual goal of "a European Liberal party," was agreed upon tonight at the final session here of the conference of International Liberal Parliamentarians.

Pain and illness were forgotten for thirty minutes yesterday morning in the children's ward of Fordham Hospital, the Bronx. It was laughter and cheers -- and with good reason. From the Big Show came Felix Adler and tiny Frankie Saluto, in full clown's regalia. They high jinksed, they cavorted.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, April 28 -- A flurry in the labor group during a subcommission resolution on Peru and Venezuela at a plenary sitting enlivened today's session of the International Labor Office regional conference.
PHILADELPHIA, April 28 (AP) -- Three-hit pitching by Vern Bickford and timely hitting gave the Braves a 6-1 victory over the Phillies today.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Louis Johnson, Secretary of Defense, today named James C. Evans, Negro engineer and former professor, to be his civilian assistant for problems relating to racial equality.

ALBANY, April 28 -- On the ground that the measure was improperly drawn, Governor Dewey vetoed today a bill that would have transferred to the Federal Government three New York State monuments in Virginia commemorating the part of New York State troops in the Second Battle of Bull Run.

A middle of the road course, involving a policy of constructive liberalism, was advocated for the Republican party in a speech last night by Wayne Morse, United States Senator from Oregon. Mr. Morse spoke at the thirty-seventh annual dinner of the New York Young Republican Club at the Delmonico Hotel.

The fourteen-nation steering committee of the United Nations General Assembly met at Flushing Meadow yesterday to devise a speed-up program for the current session, but the delegates bogged down so completely in procedural arguments that the "time-saving" project was put off for a second attempt today.

With exceptionally wide-open competition in prospect, the fifty fifth annual University of Pennsylvania Relay Carnival will get under way today at Franklin Field. A record field of nearly 3,500 athletes from 519 schools and colleges will churn up the cinders in the eighty-four events of the two-day Philadelphia merry-go-round.

Shadowy sheers were wafted in as the big fabric news for summer yesterday in the Russeks showing at the Plaza Hotel. There were gossamer chiffons, airy voiles, crisp marquisettes, organdy and lace with diaphanous full skirts that stirred in the slightest breeze, each created to look ice-cool on warm days in town or romantically pretty at night.

With announcement yesterday of its new Golden Anniversary cars and ultramatic drive, the Packard Motor Car Company disclosed that it will spend $4,000,000 this year on advertising the new models. The campaign, largest in Packard history, will devote more than $2,500,000 to newspaper space alone.

India is watching plans for application of Point 4 of President Truman's "bold new program" with intense interest as the possible solution of her problems, Ivan F. Baker, vice president and treasurer of the Westinghouse Electric International Company, said here yesterday.

FRANKFORT, Germany, April 28 -- In anticipation of creation of a West German government, German authorities in the bizonal economic administration are planning for the establishment of trade consulates in foreign countries.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., April 28 -- A $150,000,000 super-turnpike to be constructed from Alpine in Bergen County, near the New York line, to Deepwater at the southwestern border of the state is scheduled for operation within two years, according to an estimate issued today by the newly created New Jersey Turnpike Authority.

AMMAN, Jordan, April 28 -- The Jordanian Government is undoubtedly disappointed at the lack of enthusiasm for the Greater Syria idea shown by the new regime in Syria. The Jordanian Government has made it clear, however, that despite the uncooperative attitude of Syrian Premier Husni Zayim, it has no hostile intentions toward Syria.
A million New Yorkers belong to families in which the principal breadwinner is unemployed, a survey indicated yesterday.

Dr. Carlos Davila, Chilean Ambassador and former Provisional President of his country, expressed the view here last night that the United States is overemphasizing military alliances to combat an ideological, a psychological and an economic war.

And a good time was had by all -- by all the Dodgers, that is. For the treatment handed the Giants at the Polo Grounds yesterday, when the Brooks romped to a 15-2 victory, was too humiliating for any home team to endure.

Heavy selling in May wheat on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday took the spotlight away from the securities markets, as prices on the New York Stock Exchange drifted slightly lower. Trading in stocks was the dullest and narrowest since Monday, with sales of 770,000 shares, comparing with the 830,000 shares dealt in on Wednesday.

BOSTON, April 28 (AP) -- Ted Williams had a perfect day at the plate, belting his first homer, as the Red Sox swept a two-game series with the Athletics, 12 -- 5, today before a chilled ladies' day crowd bf 10,823 at wind-swept Fenway Park.
CHICAGO, April 28 (UP) -- Officials of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers rejected today a Presidential fact-finding board report which denied them a second engineer on big Diesel locomotives.

The need and importance of volunteers helping out in social welfare work was stressed by Raymond M. Hilliard, City Commissioner of Welfare, in an address last night at the forty-fifth annual dinner of the Big Brother Movement, in the New Yorker Hotel.
A traveling salesman for a wholesale kitchen accessory concern engaged in some wholesale business with the law yesterday, paying $225 in fines on sixteen parking summonses dating back to 1946.

PARIS, April 28 -- Jefferson Caffery, United States Ambassador to France since the liberation, in a farewell address to the American Club of Paris today paid tribute to the "miracle" of France's progress toward recovery during his long term here as Ambassador.

Arrow shirt prices for next fall, with the exception of one range of fancy shirts, will remain unchanged, according to announcement yesterday by Barry T. Leithead, president of Cluett, Peabody Co., Inc. Staple whites will be continued at their present levels, with no contemplated reductions.
LAKE SUCCESS, April 28 -- Britain will submit a formal resolution giving to the United Nations General Assembly the right to grant independence to Libya after ten years, it was learned today.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The determination of Republicans to recapture the farm vote, the No. 1 objective for the 1950 and 1952 elections, was being translated today into a concrete program of action.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- An official of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York said today his company had offered "a fair price" to acquire control of the Long Island Lighting Company and two subsidiaries.

After an ownership of about two years, the twelve-story and penthouse apartment building at 2260-2268 Broadway and 213-19 West Eighty-first Street, the northeast corner, has been resold by the Waybro Realty Corporation to a corporation controlled by Brown, Simon Furtsch, builders who now are erecting an apartment house at 15 to 21 West Eighty- fourth Street.

De Witt M. Lockman, portrait painter and president of the Art Commission Associates, has been elected president of the National Academy of Design, it was announced yesterday. He succeeds Hobart Nichols, who had held the post since 1939, and who is now president emeritus.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Dr. Edward U. Condon, director of the National Bureau of Standards, warned tonight "there is growing in this country a wave of anti-intellectualism which is violently opposed to free speech and free discussion, unless the views expressed happen to fit its own stereotype."

MOSCOW, April 28 -- Moscow bustled today with preparations for a great May Day celebration with workmen busy putting up miles of red bunting and massive newly painted portraits of Stalin and other Soviet leaders on almost every building in Moscow's center.

The B'nai B'rith Chorus of the Metropolitan Council of New York, conducted by Morris Levine, made its debut last night at Town Hall. Evelyn Sachs, the Metropolitan contralto, appeared as assisting artist with the organization, originally formed in 1946 as a small music recreation group and now composed of eighty-five mixed voices.
Brooklyn College overcame Hofstra, 8 to 7, in a Metropolitan Conference game on the Kingsmen's diamond yesterday by scoring four runs in the eighth. A Hofstra two-run spurt in the ninth fell short.
SHANGHAI, April 28 -- Evacuation of Americans from Shanghai was officially completed today. The total left on the consulate register was about 2,000.

Mrs. Ira H. Campbell was elected president of the Women's National Republican Club yesterday at a meeting of its board of governors, after a meeting at which the governors were elected. She succeeds Mrs. Walter H. Mallory, who was elected first vice president.

Operations of the United States Rubber Company in the first three months of this year resulted in a profit of $3,375,069 after taxes and all charges, according to the report to be issued to stockholders today.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Reacting grimly to the debacle which saw his Yankees thrust into defeat last night when on the threshold of victory, Manager Casey Stengel today shook up his batting order and pointed his damaged craft back in the right direction.

RASTHAUS ON CHIEM SEE, Germany, April 28 -- Educators attending the first World Conference on Comparative Education today urged establishment of international universities in Europe to be supported by nations of the world.

Chickens for frying, broiling or roasting and fowl for braising or fricasseeing are among the most attractive offerings in the stores this week-end. In its survey of retail food prices yesterday the City Department of Markets found that 2-cent declines now bring roasters to 55 cents a pound, fowl to 57. Chain stores and large independents feature the birds at even lower prices.

No event of the season has been awaited with keener interest than Nora Kaye's first appearance in "Giselle," which duly occurred last night at the Metropolitan Opera House. And in the Ballet Theatre's fine production of perhaps the most famous of traditional ballets, our most distinguished ballerina definitely did not let us down.

DUBLIN, April 28 (AP) -- The Irish Olympic Council got mad today at the Olympic Committee. Wearers of the green saw red over an announcement from Rome that the 'new Republic of Eire" had been recognized by the I. O. C., which gave its blessing to a separate Olympic committee for the republic.

Coffee futures were active and closed easier on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Prices held steady most of the day on trade demand and scattered new buying. Profit-taking and long liquidation provided the selling. Prices eased off reportedly on weakness in grain futures.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The 44-to-37 roll-call vote by which the Senate today sent back a $2,400,000,000 Labor-Security money bill to its Appropriations Committee with instructions to reduce it 5 per cent in certain items, or about $15,400,000, follows:

FROM as far back as even the oldest inhabitant can remember, the traditional communique from the Penn Relays has stated that there will be "3,000 athletes from 500 colleges and schools" competing in the cinderpath festival. But this year something new has been added. It has become 3,500 athletes from 519 colleges and schools, which would indicate that the baton-passing carnival still is growing.

The first meeting for the negotiation of a new contract between the National Maritime Union, CIO, and the Committee for the Companies and Agents -- Atlantic and Gulf Coasts, will be held on Monday afternoon in the offices of the American Merchant Marine Institute, 11 Broadway, it was announced yesterday. The present agreement expires on June 15.

A drive against sales rackets preying upon workers of New York industrial and commercial companies has been started by the Better Business Bureau of New York, it was announced yesterday. The bureau will bring its information service directly to thousands of employes of member firms in a plan designed to cut down monetary losses and consequent inefficiency, according to John C. Wood, president.
ROME, April 28 (AP) -- The International Olympic Committee tonight awarded the 1956 summer games to Melbourne, Australia, sending the Olympics to the Southern Hemisphere for the first time.

Moving to meet the city's deadline for ending all dumping of garbage in landfills by the end of 1951, the Department of Public Works brought before the Board of Estimate yesterday the initial contracts for construction of the $7,865,000 Gansevoort incinerator at the foot of Bloomfield and Gansevoort Streets.

EASTON, Pa., April 28 -- Dom Scazzero's single in the seventh inning drove in the winning run to give New York University a 2-1 victory over Lafayette College today. Tom Casey, Violet pitcher, shaded Fred Robbins in a mound duel.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 28 points lower to 3 points higher yesterday. All deliveries but -- October, 1950, nominal -- were lower.

The New York County Democratic Committee last night adopted a resolution changing the party rule to regularize previous local action to divide Tammany leaderships in three Assembly districts, the Ninth, Fourteenth and Fifteenth.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- President Truman declared today his belief that the Russians were acting in good faith in their proposal regarding Berlin.

CHICAGO, April 28 -- May wheat led the grain markets downward on the Board of Trade here today, off 8 cents a bushel at one time as the result of general liquidation. The break in wheat started a selling movement in other grains and lard, and all declined rapidly, corn being off as much as 5 1/8 cents a bushel at one time.

In recent years America and England have become more than friendly in many ways. American soldiers came to England, British airmen came to the United States, and they formed new opinions of each other's country. The GI no doubt found that not every Englishman spoke with an Oxford accent; and the Britisher found that not every American had a swimming bath in the back garden, nor did they shoot each other on the slightest pretext.
Leo (The Lip) Durocher, pugnacious manager of the New York Giants and stormy petrel of professional baseball, is in trouble again.

I firmly believe that all of us, which naturally includes our legislators at Washington, should get behind House Bill 3272, which was recently introduced by Congressman Byrnes of Wisconsin, the purpose of which is to mitigate the effect of double taxation of corporate income by allowing a limited credit against the income tax of the shareholder receiving dividends. My reasons are twofold.

The City of Cleveland sold yesterday bond issues totaling $7,900,000 and maturing on Sept. 1, 1950 to 1974, to a banking syndicate headed by the Harris Trust and Savings Bank at an interest cost of 1,9161 per cent. The bid was 100.5299 for 1 1/2s and 2s.

Union leaders agreed yesterday to suspend for six months the strike that has kept the New York, Ontario Western Railroad idle since April 18. They predicted that normal operations would be restored by this afternoon.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 28 -- The United States and Britain will ask the impending Council of Foreign Ministers to agree upon the merger of Soviet-occupied Germany with the nascent Western German Government to form a single federal state, authoritative sources disclosed today.

Plans for the alteration of the three - story structure at 2017 Grand Concourse, the Bronx, into a medical profession building were revealed yesterday with the announcement of the sale of the property by the Amrul Corporation, of which Dr. M. A. Mason is president, to the Harlesam Building Corporation, headed by Sampson Levy, architect.

PARIS, April 28 -- Emigration plans presented to the Economic Cooperation Administration by Italy provide for the relocation of nearly 1,000,000 Italian citizens during the next four years, according to an announcement issued here today.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Carnegie Mines, Ltd., Montreal, Canada, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 500,000 shares of common stock that is to be offered to the public at 60 cents a share.
The text of Secretary of State Dean Acheson's aduress at the annual dinner of the Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association follows:

Brooklyn State Hospital threw open its doors to the public for two hours yesterday afternoon. It was believed to be one of the first times that a mental hospital in this area has invited visitors to an "open house," and it marked the first annual observance of national Mental Health Week.

Television coverage of the United Nations' General Assembly, Security Council and Political Committee will begin on Monday under arrangements just completed by CBS, NBC and the United Nations. Television cameras will be installed at Flushing Meadow and Lake Success for the remainder of the General Assembly, and will permit instantaneous feeds to the two networks when news breaks occur.
DETROIT, April 28 (AP) -- Johnny Groth, the Tigers' sensational rookie, hit his second grand slam homer today but the Browns bounced back to beat Detroit, 9 -- 6.

During the general debate on labor legislation in the House on Wednesday Representative Arthur G. Klein of New York called for a one-day general strike (he termed it a "national work stoppage") as a means of demonstrating to "reactionary Republicans and Dixiecrats" that American labor is solidly behind the pending Administration bill.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The Federal Reserve Board announced late today that effective next week the reserve requirements of the 7,000 member banks of the Federal Reserve System would be reduced by $1,200,000,000.
LAUSANNE, Switzerland, April 28 -- The Israeli Government has told the United Nations Conciliation Commission for Palestine that it will not permit the return of Arab refugees to its territory.

Last year was described as "one of readjustment and struggle" for the American Cable and Radio Corporation part of the International Telephone and Telegraph System, in its annual report to stockholders yesterday.

The Bank of the Manhattan Company plans to increase its capital from $20,000,000 to $25,000,000 by the sale of 500,000 shares of new stock, it was announced yesterday by J. Stewart Baker, chairman, after a meeting of the directors.
Communists organized a big "concentration" drive in basic New York industries last summer, according to yesterday's evidence at the Communist trial.

Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday designated the period from Tuesday through May 14 as "Spring Clean-Up Weeks," and urged the people to cooperate with the Department of Sanitation in brightening the city's appearance.

Tonight's events: "Carmen," City Opera Company, City Center, 8:15 o'clock; Marymount College Glee Club, Giovanni Camajani, conductor, Town Hall, 8:30; Gwendolyn Haber, piano, Carnegie Recital Hall 8:30; Welsh Singers, Frances Williams, conductor, William Cooper, baritone, Carl Fischer Hall, 8:30; Juilliard Orchestra, Dean Dixon, conductor, Juilliard School, 8:30.

Henry Ford 2d. president of the Ford Motor Company, said last night that business and industry had been losing the confidence of the American people and were not today "politically strong enough for the job they have to do."

Historic memorabilia of the Confederate States of America were placed on exhibition last night by the New York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, in cooperation with two New York divisions of Confederate societies.

The nine-story and penthouse apartment building housing forty- seven families at 123 Waverly Place, in the Greenwich Village section, has been sold by Edna C. Romaine to an investor in a transaction reported yesterday by John J. Reynolds, Inc., the broker.

The United Nations General Assembly, against the expected solid opposition of the Soviet bloc, adopted yesterday three of four draft resolutions on international cooperation recommended by the Interim Committee (Little Assembly).

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- President Truman's civil rights program was presented to Congress today, fourteen months and twenty-six days after he outlined it to members at great political peril in a special message.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The six Republican members of the Congressional Joint Committee on the Economic Report today unanimously indicted the Presidentially sponsored economic program as a proposal "that we set up in this country a planned and controlled economy and increase taxation for that purpose."

There was Standing-Room-Only in the Northern Lights Theatre in the Hudson Bay area when an American Theatre Wing troupe appeared there last Sunday and Monday for two performances of "The Butter and Egg Man," by George S. Kaufman.

LONDON, April 28 -- The powerful National Union of Railwaymen decided today to make immediate application for a ten-shilling ($2) a week increase in pay for nearly half a million railway workers in addition to an upward revision of overtime pay.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- During the week ended April 27, member bank reserve balances decreased $378,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
The departure of the Italian liner Saturnia, on the return leg of her first voyage after a $2,000,000 reconditioning job, was delayed almost five hours yesterday by engine trouble.
LEXINGTON, Ky., April 28 (AP) -- Halt, Mrs. Royce G. Martin's eligible, threw the Kentucky Derby wide open today with a nose victory in the $20,000 added Blue Grass Stakes at Keeneland.

Nine Bulgarian anti-Communist political refugees who came here a week ago as stowaways on the Egyptian-flag liner Khedive Ismail, might become perpetual guests of the steamship line, according to fears expressed by agents of the ship.

Among the fifty-two changes in the New York laws concerning the conservation of fish and game, affecting the hunters and fishermen of the state, the majority constitute measures which were urged by sportsmen's groups from several areas.

Improved pension rights for 17,620 employes of the municipal transit lines who were employed on the IRT and BMT systems in 1940 when those lines were taken over by the city were unanimously voted yesterday by the Board of Estimate.
HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 28 (AP) -- Mrs E. duPont Weir's steady 5-year-old gelding, Royal Governor, came on in the stretch today to pick up the $2,275 winner's share in the Edgewood purse.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Judith Coplon and Valentin Gubitchev, the Soviet engineer, shared a mutual affection, but he told her he was a married man, the jury was told today at the former Justice Department employe's trial for espionage.
HOLLYWOOD, Fla., April 28 -- By an overwhelming majority, the General Federation of Women's Clubs voted today to oppose any form of compulsory health insurance.

Sales of residential properties in Brooklyn through the Charles Partridge Real Estate Company, broker, were reported yesterday! as follows: two-family house assessed for $10,500 at 669 Fifty- sixth Street for Mary T. Hendersen to Gladys J. Waage, with Wolf Stillman acting as co-brokers; one - family dwelling at 447-A Washington Avenue, assessed for $14,000, for Mrs. D. L. May to Lillian Draycott.

The Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., in the first quarter of this year had net earnings of about $26,000,000 after charges and taxes, B. Brewster Jennings, president, told stockholders at their annual meeting here yesterday.

CONCORDIA, Kan., April 28 -- Gov. Val Peterson of Nebraska said today that the Missouri Basin Inter-Agency Committee must do a better job of coordinating valley development work or give way to a Missouri Valley Authority.

Strengthening of the United Nations and its transformation into a world federal government must be a primary goal of American foreign policy, Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., declared yesterday in a statement to Cord Meyer Jr., president of the United World Federalists.

CLEVELAND, April 28 -- Unity among the free countries "is the one great argument that will convince the Kremlin of the futility of plans to communize Europe," Paul G. Hoffman, head of the Economic Cooperation Administration, said tonight.

The sharp diversion of fruit and vegetable produce from the lower Manhattan waterfront as a result of increased railroad unloading costs has caused the Port of New York Authority to drop its plans for construction of a $34,500,000 produce terminal and railroad car-float station between Watts and Chambers Streets, it was shown yesterday.

The Right Rev. Dora Augustine Morris, Lord Abbot of the Anglican Benedictine Abbey, Nashdom, England, speaking last night at the St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty- third Street, called upon Christians to follow a current trend toward reconciliation.

PITTSBURGH, April 28 -- Sharply conflicting opinions on the effect of oil imports on the industry in this country were presented today by the two chief speakers at the conference of the Eastern District, American Petroleum Institute.

LONDON, April 28 -- The Covent Garden Opera Company, which has just completed a tour of the provinces, will finish its present season at the Royal Opera House on June 11 with "The Marriage of Figaro." Guest artists for the final weeks will be Winnifred Heidt, her husband, Eugene Conley, and Joan Hammond.

Rabbi Stephen S. Wise completed in long-hand shortly before his death the manuscript of his autobiography, "Challenging Years." The book is being edited by his children, James Waterman Wise, director of the Council Against Intolerance, and Justine Wise Polier, justice of the Domestic Relations Court.

BERLIN, April 28 -- Armed British military police held possession of three canal locks in their sector of Berlin tonight after having frustrated a Russian attempt to block canal traffic and gain partial control over the airlift supplying the blockaded city.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- President Truman's program to broaden and liberalize the social-security system reached the decisive stage in Congress today amid doubt that action would be completed this year.

Dan Ferris, secretary-treasurer of the National Amateur Athletic Union, said yesterday the selection of Melbourne as the site for the 1956 Olympic Games put "a greater burden on the United States athletes than ever before."

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- This was homecoming day for Warren R. Austin, chief American delegate to the United Nations. Before being appointed to the post three years ago, he was a United States Senator from Vermont.
PARIS, April 28 -- Marcel Rochas displays his talent for the choice and contrast of fabrics in midsummer gowns by stressing floating panels and overskirts.

PINEHURST, N. C., April 28 (AP) -- Peggy Kirk of Findlay, Ohio, today defeated Mrs. Estelle Lawson Page of Chapel Hill, N. C., in the semi-finals of the women's North and South golf championship by 1 up.
Summer theatres yesterday began making plans for the coming season.

BERLIN, April 28 -- A draft peace treaty for Germany has been explained to German Communist leaders by the Russians, who intend to submit the treaty at an expected meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers, both Western and German sources said today.

ALBANY, April 28 -- The De Salvio bill that paves the way for restoration of old Fort Clinton in Battery Park and its preservation as a national monument was approved today by Governor Dewey at the request of Mayor O'Dwyer and the New York City Council.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- An Interstate Commerce Commission examiner recommended today that that agency approve proposals of Agwilines, Inc., Bull Steamship Line and Southern Steamship Company to increase rail-ocean class rates from piers at New York, Philadelphia and Boston, and interior Eastern points to points in the Southwest.

NEWARK, N. J., April 28 -- An alleged racket, apparently successful for ten years, which had all the external trappings of a charitable enterprise and the internal mechanics of a high-pressure sales organization, came to light here today with the transfer of police custody of Richard M. Hanan to the Bergen County prosecutor's office.

Food prices will drop gradually from 5 to 7 1/2 per cent below present retail levels between now and the end of the year, Nathan Cummings, chairman of the board of Consolidated Grocers Corporation, world's largest wholesale grocery chain, predicted in an interview here yesterday.

The Police Commissioner's Confidential Squad, the department's strongest check on its own men suspected of wrongdoing and on gambling and vice, was abolished yesterday by Commissioner William P. O'Brien

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Top officials of the Congress of Industrial Organizations indicated today the Left-wing members of the executive board would soon be curbed for actions said to contravene official CIO policy.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- President Truman moved today to improve the organization of the Maritime Commission and its relationship with other branches of the Government by appointing Maj. Gen. Philip B. Fleming as its chairman.
Several hundred blind children are looking forward to camp this summer. It is their own mountain-lake camp at Hardwick, Vt., made possible each year through the gifts of many kind friends.
CHICAGO, April 28 -- Henry A. Wallace tonight told a nationwide radio audience that Russia's indicated willingness to lift the Berlin blockade opened the way to peace.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The North Atlantic pact will advance international cooperation through its assurance of security to member nations against aggression, Dr. Philip C. Jessup, American Ambassador at large and central figure in preliminary talks with Russia over lifting of the Berlin blockade, said here tonight.

SHANGHAI, April 28 -- Communist armies driving toward this city along three routes moved inexorably toward their goal today. The center spearhead, according to Nationalist communiques, advanced ten miles since yesterday to within about thirty-six miles of Shanghai.
Gen. George C. Kenney, commanding officer of the Air University, Maxwell Air Base, Montgomery, Ala., last night became the sixth person to receive the Gen. William E. Mitchell Memorial Award.

An appeal from the State Supreme Court judgment upholding the ouster of the Rev. Dr. John Howard Melish as rector of the Holy Trinity Church, Brooklyn, by Bishop James Pernette De Wolfe of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island was initiated yesterday.

FRANKFORT, Germany, April 28 -- United States Army agents reported tonight the arrest of nine Germans who, they said, tried to sell four and a half pounds of uranium ore for 10,000,000 Deutschemarks ($3,300,000).
ST. LOUIS, April 28 (AP) -- Steady pitching by Al Brazle, who scattered eight hits, helped the Cardinals to a 4-2 verdict over the Pirates today.

A City Council meeting is like a baseball game at Ebbetts Field, home of the Brooklyn Dodgers. Anything can happen and usually does. Councilman Edward Rager, Manhattan Republican and sponsor of numerous anti-Communist resolutions, proved it yesterday.

CHICAGO, April 28 -- The Chicago Stock Exchange today asked its members to approve a plan for consolidation of regional stock exchanges in the Middle West. The plan was drafted by representatives of exchanges in Chicago, Cincinnati, Cleveland, Minneapolis-St. Paul and St. Louis.
MANILA, Friday, April 29 (AP) -- President Quirino today ordered a full-scale campaign by the army and constabulary against the killers of Mrs. Quezon and members of her party.

Proposals for cutting the retail price of milk locally were made here yesterday by distributors meeting with members of the New York State Temporary Commission on Agriculture, which last month issued a report that held production cost reductions were possible.

The recommendations to President Truman by the United States Council of the International Chamber of Commerce that grow out of Point Four in his inaugural address were supplemented by a striking report on international investments. Such investments by private capital were stressed by the President when, in Point Four, he said they were essential to his "bold new program to develop the underdeveloped areas of the world."

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Senator Raymond E. Baldwin, Republican, of Connecticut, said today his decision to quit the Senate for a place on the Connecticut Supreme Court of Errors was not prompted by any "lack of faith in the future of the Republican party."

Secretary of State Dean Acheson told American newspaper publishers last night that three-power plans for a Western German state did not preclude the possibility of an agreement with Russia for a settlement of the whole German problem.

The ambush murder of three members of the Quezon family, two famous wartime guerrilla leaders, a rising young politician and a renowned scientist will be greeted here, as it has been in the Philippines, with grief, horror and disappointment. The Philippines has lost in Mrs. Quezon a gracious lady who was widely beloved and honored for her leadership in many good causes.

NEWARK, N. J., April 28 -- The Llangollen Farm of Mrs. E. Cooper Person from Upperville, Va., and Miss Ellie Wood Keith furnished the highlights as the twenty-third and biggest Newark horse show began its four-day run at the Essex Troop Armory tonight.

Secretary of State Dean Acheson told American newspaper publishers last night that three-power plans for a Western German state did not preclude the possibility of an agreement with Russia for a settlement of the whole German problem.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- X-ray beams with energies of 335,000,000 volts, five times more powerful than any hitherto produced, have been successfully used in the artificial creation of mesons, fundamental particles of nature regarded as the "cosmic cement" that holds the universe together. This was made known today in two reports from the University of California radiation laboratories.

WASHINGTON, D. C., April 29 -- Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange, declared here tonight that life insurance companies, because of their great influence on the markets for capital, should undertake "on their own initiative" a searching analysis of every phase of their functions and operations.

BERLIN, April 29 -- The Russians tacitly admitted defeat today in their latest attempt to upset the airlift supplying of blockaded Berlin by inviting British officials to a formal confer ence tomorrow to settle the dispute over control of the vital canal locks in the British sector.
LONDON, April 29 -- Britain is trying to establish "friendly relations" with the Chinese Communist Government, a Foreign Office spokesman said today.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 29 -- A Mexican attempt to make freedom of information subject to the laws and "reasons of public order" in states signing a draft convention on freedom of information was abandoned today in the Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee of the United Nations General Assembly after the United States and Britain had strongly assailed the proposal.

ROME, April 29 -- Sir Stafford Cripps, British Chancellor of the Exchequer, arrived in Rome this afternoon for a stay of six days during the course of which he will confer with the President of the Republic and the principal members of the Cabinet and will be received in audience by the Pope. He intends to leave May 4 for Naples for a brief vacation.
SEOUL, Korea, April 29 -- President Syngman Rhee today returned to the capital from a 1,500-mile week-long tour of the southern provinces.

BOSTON, April 29 -- The Giants, with the venerable Frank Frisch holding the reins and Sid Gordon wielding a devastating bat, waged a heroic uphill battle tonight and, after more than three hours of struggling and ten innings of play, they succeeded in flooring the Braves, 10 to 9, in the opener of a four-game series. The triumph sent the Giants to first place in the flag race.
Three major conflicts must be resolved before a final decision is reached on restoring or demolishing old Fort Clinton in Battery Park, it was reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The Truman Administration was accused today by Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg of "dangerously" tending to undervalue the North Atlantic treaty and to overstate the accompanying program of military aid to its European members.

The inspection tour of Harlem made early this week by Mayor O'Dwyer is bearing fruit in a drive by several city departments to clean up vacant lots and make playgrounds out of some of them. The initial setbacks reveal, however, as we remarked several months ago, that a basic problem is to educate the people of Harlem to take more pride in their surroundings.

The Steering Committee of the United Nations General Assembly recommended yesterday quick consideration of Israel's bid for membership in the world organization by voting to shift the item from the overloaded Political Committee to the idle Ad Hoc Committee.

ALBANY, April 29 -- Of 1,198 bills passed this year, 858 have become law and 340 have been vetoed by Governor Dewey, who completed action today on measures left with him on final adjournment of the Legislature. The time in which the Governor can act on bills expired tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The provision in the United Nations Charter permitting regional arrangements like the North Atlantic pact and the hemisphere mutual defense treaty of Rio de Janeiro has "proved to be the strongest pillar of support for the whole collective security system," George A. Finch, vice president of the American Society of International Law, told the organization's annual meeting today.

North American Aviation, Inc., in its preliminary unaudited statement covering the six months ended with last March, reported yesterday its net profit at $3,012,658 after all charges, including $1,954,000 for provision for taxes. This compares with $753,439 earned in the same half of the preceding fiscal year.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The Senate approved promptly today a program for greater care of child health in the schools, but soon afterward fell into a major controversy over Federal aid to education itself.

CHICAGO, April 29 (AP) -- Forrest (Smoky) Burgess, rookie catcher who led the Southern Association in batting last season, cracked a pinch single with the bases loaded to give the Cubs a 5-4 victory in a 12-inning struggle with the Cardinals before 13,363 at Wrigley Field today.
HOLLYWOOD, Fla., April 29 -- The General Federation of Women's Clubs ended its annual convention today with a unanimous vote in support of the North Atlantic pact.

ATHENS, April 29 -- The pilot of a Dakota airliner of the Soviet-Rumanian Airways was forced to fly his craft to Greece and land at Mikra airfield at Salonika today. A young Rumanian anti-Communist student aboard held up the pilot with a revolver and made him go off the route from Timisoara, Western Rumania, to Bucharest.

BOSTON, April 29 -- Dr. Serge Koussevitzky gave Boston today its final Friday afternon concert of the Boston Symphony Orchestra in his official capacity as conductor. He retires tomorrow night after twenty-five years on the podium.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., April 29 -- Charges of indiscriminate dismissal of faculty members at Rutgers University will be answered at a special assembly on May 9, it was announced today by President Robert C. Clothier.

Industrial distributors are being protected against inventory losses under a new price reduction policy applying to self-tapping screws, under which prices will be reduced 11 per cent on May 2, Louis Goldburg, president, Parker-Kalon Corporation, New York hardware manufacturers, revealed here yesterday.

New ways to build walls will be the topic of a luncheon meeting of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects on Tuesday at the Architectural League Building on East Fortieth Street. R. A. Biggs of the Pittsburgh Corning Glass Company will be one of the speakers.

The President's "bold new plan," that was commended in a leading editorial recently in THE NEW YORK TIMES, has received the strong endorsement of the United States Council of the International Chamber of Commerce, and there are multiplying evidences that the whole country is uniting behind the plan, just as it has united behind Paul Hoffman in ECA.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Four air-freight companies specializing exclusively in cargo service today won the right to compete with the mail-passenger airlines in the regularly scheduled movement of goods. Permissive certificates issued by the Civil Aeronautics Board for five years were the first in United States aviation history.
LAKE SUCCESS, April 29 -- Negotiations over the lifting of the Berlin blockade were resumed unexpectedly today at the request of Jacob A. Malik, the Soviet representative to the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The Air Transport Association, whose membership includes the regular certificated airlines, today charged the large irregular airlines with having instituted virtually regular services and with having asked the Civil Aeronautics Board to make their operations legal.

PINEHURST, N. C., April 29 (AP) -- Miss Peggy Kirk of Findlay, Ohio, halted Miss Grace Lenczyk, national champion, of Hartford, Conn., 5 and 4, today in a rain-soaked North and South women's amateur golf tournament final.

RANGOON, Burma, April 29 (AP) -- The Burmese Government announced today that it had strengthened its hold on Mandalay by regaining forty-six miles of territory in central Burma from rebelling Karens and Communists.

NEWARK, N. J., April 29 -- Mrs. Don J. Ferraro's Black Watch and the Hale Stable's General split the jumper honors and the Llangollen Farm's Madam Sniper stepped into a clear-cut lead for the conformation hunter title as the twenty-third Newark horse show continued at the Essex Troop Armory tonight.

MEXICO CITY, April 29 -- All purchasers of Mexican sweepstakes tickets for the Kentucky Derby were warned today by the Interior Ministry that sale of these tickets was not authorized by the Mexican Government.

For an hour yesterday morning Macy's department store was ringed by more than 1,000 pickets, members of Local 1-S, independent, in a demonstration against the company's position in contract negotiations.

BERLIN, April 29 -- Germany must place "its own demands" before the Council of Foreign Ministers, Dr. Kurt Schumacher, leader of the Social Democratic party, declared in a statement regarded by some observers as marking the emergence of Germany as the fifth power in any discussion of the country's future.

The Ballet Espanol Ana Maria gave its third and final performances at the Ziegfeld Theatre last night. The program contained "Capricho Espanol" to Rimsky-Korsakoff's music, a repetition of De Falla's "El Amor Brujo" and a number of divertissements.
The American family of today, often described as disintegrating, may be merely adapting to new needs to survive -- changing rather than deteriorating.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Judge Gordon Simpson, former chairman of an Army review board that has recommended commutation of the death sentences for twelve Nazis convicted of the Malmedy massacre of American war prisoners in 1944, told a Senate investigating committee today that he had seen no evidence of brutality to gain confessions and that he was convinced the defendants were guilty.
Noah Dietrich, executive vice president of the Hughes Tool Company, has been elected a director of Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., it was announced yesterday.

"The Guinea Pig," a British-made drama with a public school background, is today's lone film newcomer. It will be presented at the Little Carnegie. Richard Attenborough, Sheila Sim and Robert Flemyng head the cast of the picture, which was directed by Roy Boulting and produced by Filippo del Giudice as the first of his Pilgrim Pictures, Ltd., productions.

CONCORDIA, Kan., April 29 -- The Department of Agriculture's comprehensive thirty-year program for agricultural development of the Missouri River Valley will stress the role of the Soil Conservation Service.
