BUCHAREST, Rumania, April 29 (AP) -- Foreign diplomats were ordered today to stay out of about two-thirds of Rumanian territory, including a belt thirty miles wide around the frontiers.

Thirty-seven Customs Port Patrol officers, all veterans with three to seven years service in the New York area, face dismissal from their jobs as of May 31 as a result of a decision by the United States Civil Service Commission, it became known yesterday.
TRENTON, N. J., April 29 -- Tentative drafts of party platforms, in which the Republicans commended the administration of Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll and the Democrats condemned it, were completed today.

Announcement of the pending release of $1,200,000,000 of required reserves of banks brought rising prices and the most activity of the year to that part of the bond market in which bank investments figure prominently.
PITTSBURGH, April 29 (UP) -- The Carnegie Hero Fund Commission today announced thirteen awards, four of them posthumous, for heroic rescue efforts.

An over-all view of graduation dresses for this season shows organdy and pique receiving top honors. Following the style trends, designers have obviously made a concerted effort to create dresses which will serve the sweet girl graduate through the summer months.
LONDON, April 29 -- Somewhat contradictory developments in the Berlin situation made for renewed caution in the stock markets here today and the week ended on a quiet note.

HALIFAX, April 29 (Canadian Press) -- Two violent outbreaks on the St. John, N. B., waterfront today brought the arrest of sixty- one members of the left wing Canadian Seamen's Union on the twenty-ninth turbulent day of the union's strike.

The huge trucks that lumber through New York's streets are a vital element in the business life of our community. When they stop rolling, ships are tied up in the harbor, railroads embargo incoming freight and commercial establishments suffer losses running into many millions of dollars.

Modern Venetian figurines that craftsmen on the island of Murano fashion of many layers of molten glass, creating just the colors and shapes desired, have been carefully mounted to form decorative lamps by Agnes Morgen at her studio-home, 63-50 Wetherole Street, Rego Park, Queens.

DETROIT, April 29 -- In an open rebellion against the top leadership of their union, nearly 300 members of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, staged a wildcat walkout today in the River Rouge plant of the Ford Motor Company in the presence of a special committee named by the UAW International Executive Board to check the validity of their request for authorization to strike.

In making the round this week, the gallery-goer will come across five painters who, though differing sharply from each other, explore in common the border country between naturalism and out-and-out abstraction.

Miss Angela Calomiris testified at the Communist trial yesterday that she reported to the Federal Bureau of Investigation on activities of Communists at meetings of various labor, political and pressure groups, which she attended.

Widespread highway construction and rehabilitation programs are under way throughout the country to eliminate a potential blight to motor transportation created by deteriorated and inadequate thoroughfares, particularly in the Midwest.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- For this country to stockpile too many planes, bombs and battleships would be to place "damaging economic chains upon our productive machinery," Charles E. Wilson, president of the General Electric Company, asserted here tonight.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 29 -- Ronald Reagan, whose exclusive contract with Warner Brothers is being rewritten on a non-exclusive basis, has been signed by Universal-International to appear in one picture annually for five years, U-I announced today.

Retail sales declined during the week, according to estimates made here yesterday. Department store sales were believed to be about 6 per cent below the corresponding week last year. Sales last week !were 10 per cent below a year ago.

Fourteen delegations were named yesterday by the United Nations General Assembly to draw up a detailed report on the mechanics of forming an armed guard to serve with missions of the world peace organization.

With reasonable logic, Vic Raschi figured that sooner or later he would beat the Red Sox, a trick he never before had achieved. Downed once in 1947 and three times last year, the big right-hander was seeking his first positive decision over the powerful Boston aggregation when he took the mound for the Yankees before 24,069 fans at the Stadium yesterday.

President Truman has called on Americans to "emphasize spiritual values in family life" during the seventh annual National Family Week, starting tomorrow and ending May 8. Special programs will be conducted under the auspices of an inter-faith committee.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 29 -- A voluntary wage increase of 5 cents an hour was given to all longshore gang foremen in the San Francisco Bay area today by the Waterfront Employers Association. The increase, which will make the foremen's basic hourly pay $1.97, or 15 cents higher than the basic stevedore rate, is effective on Monday.
One of the first direct moves by members of the liquor industry to combat taxes which they consider unfair, will be made soon with Government approval, it was learned here yesterday.

Studies and planning for the implementation of President Truman's "Point Four" are going forward. Some concrete, if modest, proposals may be expected in the near future. It is natural that a program of such magnitude should be shaped up slowly, but it is also important that this movement toward better international understanding should gain as much and as rapid headway as is possible.

LONDON, April 29 -- Winston Churchill and Anthony Eden, the two foremost leaders of the Conservative party, sounded the keynote here today of the party's campaign for return to power in the general elections next year. Between them they denounced the Labor party's policies and Mr. Eden proposed as a substitute a four-point program that, he said, would be the basis of Conservative domestic policy if the party were returned to office.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Moscow apparently is trying to keep the Russian people in the dark while carrying on negotiations to lift the Berlin blockade, officials said today.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- In a session on fund-raising the American College Public Relations Association was told good news today in a move to scotch what was described as "the fallacious and pernicious doctrine that generous giving to colleges is drying up."

WASHINGTON, April 29 (UP) -- The Senate Appropriations Committee added $40,000,000 to a Federal spending bill today in the face of a coalition economy drive to cut President Truman's budget and avoid a tax increase.

Nineteen British parents, the vanguard of thousands of fathers and mothers who plan to visit their daughters, married to American ex-Service men, this summer, were among 1,049 passengers on the United States liner Washington when she arrived yesterday.

Cast aside by its corporate parent, deserted by its executive vice presidents, thrown upon the mercy of a realistic judiciary, the Long Island Rail Road found sympathy yesterday in a most unexpected quarter. The commuters were kind to it.

MOSCOW, April 29 -- Basing its statement on preliminary reports from the southern regions, Komsomolskaya Pravda, newspaper of Soviet youth, declared today the "Soviet people are performing miracles" in carrying out the Government's vast shelter belt forestation program.
Tony Pellone, veteran welter-weight from Greenwich Village, gained the decision over Joe Miceli of the East Side in the star bout of ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.

During May the spotlight is to be turned on the work of the Police Athletic League with the children of New York City. Such work takes money, and this is the time of year when the organization goes to the public for well-earned support.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.5 per cent in the week ended Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. The index was 156.1 per cent of the 1926 average, 1.3 per cent lower than four weeks ago and 4.5 per cent lower than the comparable week in 1948.

LONDON, April 29 -- When Sir Alfred J. Munnings, president of the Royal Academy, who blurted out his disapproval of modern art to a nation-wide radio audience last night, mounted the steps to the academy's 181st exhibition today he was greeted with cries of approval.

A message last night from Dr. Sidney Hook, New York University Professor of Philosophy, to the Socialist party May Day dinner here emphasized that only the judgment of his peers should determine an educator's rights.

JERUSALEM, April 29 -- The Presbyterian Church will resume soon its educational and health activities in the Holy Land. The Rev. Andrew Scott-Morrison, Moderator of the Jerusalem Presbytery of the Church of Scotland, is now on a mission to Israel, arranging for the release of some of the church properties used by the Israeli Army.

Patrons of the Cafe Lucca may wish for a return to the good old days when that restaurant offered a complete dinner with wine for 45 cents. Not so Bartolomeo Rissetto, who is celebrating his thirty-fifth year as owner of the establishment at 110 West Forty-fourth Street.

CHICAGO, April 29 -- Commission-house selling developed today in the May deliveries of wheat, corn and oats on the Board of Trade, with some selling of these months against purchases of the deferred contracts, resulting in irregular markets.

Further "substantial progress" in negotiations between Manhattan apartment house owners and a union of building service workers was reported yesterday by Arthur S. Meyer, chairman of the State Mediation Board.

PHILADELPHIA, April 29 (AP) -- Southpaw Lou Brissie, aided by a two-run ninth-inning rally, scored his third straight pitching triumph today as the Philadelphia Athletics defeated Washington, 6 -- 5, to end a four-game losing streak.

Calumet Farm's Coaltown, up to this point in the proceedings the horse of the year, will favor Jamaica with his presence today. He'll attempt to make his 1949 record seven for seven when he goes to the post in the $50,000 added Gallant Fox Handicap, a mile-and-three-sixteenths run won a year ago by Calumet's Faultless.
SHANGHAI, April 29 -- By forced marches and amphibious flanking moves across Tai Lake, Communists have cut off retreat of what appears to be most of the Nationalist troops along the lower Yangtze.

The "spring allergy injection season" opened yesterday at the Murray Hill Health Service, where the Community Service Society of New York maintains a medical and dental clinic for the marginal income group.

PHILADELPHIA, April 29 -- A canny front-running effort by Reggie Pearman on the anchor half-mile staved off a mighty bid by Olympic champion Mal Whitfield and gave New York University a smashing triumph over Ohio State in the sprint medley today as the fifty-fifth annual Pennsylvania Relays opened under sunny skies at Franklin Field.

From a feast at the Polo Grounds the Dodgers yesterday returned to a near-famine at Ebbets Field. After wearing out five of Leo Durocher's pitchers on Thursday, Manager Barney Shotton's boys were stopped by just one frail southpaw in Brooklyn.

City Hall's promises to do something about modernizing New York's water-front antedate the Second World War. Mayor O'Dwyer's concern over deterioration of pier facilities was expressed early in his administration. Commissioner Reinicke had his five-year plan. Commissioner Minetti has his ten-year plan.

ELIZABETH, N. J., April 29 -- As Justin McAghon, a Federal conciliator, continued tonight mediation of the contract dispute between the Singer Manufacturing Company and Local 401, United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America, CIO, in an effort to avert a walkout authorized for Monday by a vote of the plant's 7,000 union employes, both sides prepared for a strike.
WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) -- The Economic Cooperation Administration announced today four agreements to help finance distribution of American publications in Western Europe.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Oscar R. Ewing, Federal Security Administrator, accused former President Herbert Hoover today of a lack of understanding of the American approach to Social Security.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The International Harvester Company, Chicago, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 1,200,000 shares of its no-par-value common stock.

C. Grant Keck has purchased a vacant plot of land, 25 by 100 feet, on the west side of Twenty-ninth Street, 125 feet south of Forty-first Avenue, In Long Island City, Queens, from Allwyn Earl Syminton and plans to improve it with a commercial building.

ALBANY, April 29 -- Counsel for the American Jewish Congress and other petitioners today urged the commissioner of education, Francis T. Spaulding, to "satisfy public conscience" by ordering the New York City Board of Higher Education to conduct a public hearing into charges of anti-Semitism against Prof. William E. Knickerbocker, chairman of the department of Romance languages at the City College of New York.

The Health Department announced yesterday it would throw its entire inspection force behind "Operation Sanitary" -- the spring cleaning drive sponsored by Mayor O'Dwyer to brighten the city's appearance -- with an all-out attack on insanitary garbage disposal and unsightly dumps.

IT didn't take long for Commissioner Happy Chandler to hop on his trusty steed and, in the fashion of Don Quixote, begin tilting with his favorite windmill. What's the rush? Chandler never burst a blood vessel in knocking down such real toughies as Larry MacPhail and Branch Rickey. But Leo Durocher has been a soft touch for him.

RASTHAUS, ON CHIEM SEE, Germany, April 29 -- Creation of an international commission to eliminate nationalist projudice and bias from history textbooks was recommended today at the closing session of the World Conference on Comparative Education as a way to develop a union of Democratic nations.

Three of four men arrested on Thursday after a brief battle with the police and Secret Service agents were held in $50,000 bail each yesterday by Federal Judge Sylvester J. Ryan on a charge of possessing $11,000 in counterfeit currency.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Hearings on President Truman's compulsory health insurance plan will open before a Senate Labor and Public Welfare subcommittee on May 16, it was announced today.

OSSINING, N. Y., April 29 -- Fire Chief Frank M. McLoughlin of Sing Sing Prison will retire tomorrow after thirty years of safeguarding the lives and health of some of the toughest murderers and crooks ever put behind bars, but he was regretful today that he was to leave the men.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- A knotty patronage problem was delivered to the White House today in the wake of the Democratic party loyalty test for Federal jobs which President Truman accented yesterday.

Italy is moving toward a more liberal trade policy, with stepped-up industrial imports planned and the tourist dollar playing a growing role, according to advices to Leo J. Wollemborg, associate editor of Economic News From Italy.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- United States occupation officials have failed to smash a single one of Germany's giant monopolies under a crack-down law now two years old, investigators said today.

PHILADELPHIA, April 29 -- Mrs. Ward Wheelock, socially prominent wife of a Philadelphia and New York advertising executive, was found dead today in a bathtub at the Wheelock estate in suburban Haverford.

The recent 24.5 per cent increase in newsprint allowances for British newspapers has brought them a 22.06 per cent advertising revenue gain for January and February of this year, over the like period of 1948, according to a report received yesterday from the Legion Publishing Company, Ltd., of London.

Gant Gaither's production of "Gayden," the new play by Mignon and Robert McLaughlin, will make its local debut on Tuesday evening, May 10, at the Plymouth Theatre, it was announced yesterday. Now testing its wings at Boston's Plymouth Theatre, the production stars Fay Bainter and features Jay Robinson, English performer, in the title role.

Queries on the legal form of ownership under which the nation's approximately 3,000,000 members of the distributive and service trades operate are now being supplied to New York City business men by the Bureau of the Census, Department of Commerce, it was announced yesterday.

The United Nations General Assembly took up yesterday the case of Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty, Hungarian prelate sentenced to life imprisonment as a traitor, and the trial and conviction of fifteen Bulgarian Protestant clergymen. The United States led off an attack against Hungary and Bulgaria for resorting to "the shabbiest sort of excuses" to liquidate anti-totalitarian church leaders.

CHICAGO, April 29 -- Progress toward solution of differences between the American Medical Association and sponsors of voluntary health plans was reported here today. Another conference at which the two groups' problems will be discussed was set for June 4 at Atlantic City, to be held in conjunction with the AMA's annual meeting.

Stock prices continued to drag in a narrow range yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, lacking enthusiasm for a substantial move in either direction. Changes were confined mostly to fractions, with all news -- good or bad -- being ignored.
PLAINFIELD, N. J., April 29 -- A play-off was necessary to decide two of the four places allotted the New Jersey sector in the National P. G. A. trials over the Plainfield Country Club course today.

John Santo, former international officer of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, who has been under technical arrest since 1941 in an alien deportation proceeding, has received permission from the Department of Justice to leave the United States voluntarily within sixty days.

PITTSBURGH, April 29 -- A move by the Polish worker delegates to have the plenary session of the coal mines committee of the International Labor Organization adopt a resolution "to take action to stop * * * persecution against the trade union movement" was defeated here today by a vote of 34 to 8.

Headed by Prof. Arthur Upham Pope, chancellor of the Asia Institute, 7 East Seventieth Street, a group of nineteen persons that will make a sixteen-day tour of Iran, left La Guardia Airport yesterday aboard a chartered airliner. The tourists will make brief visits to Paris, Rome, Istanbul and Baghdad, en route to Teheran.
A variety of the year's most important fabrics are being featured today in a fashion show to be presented by Ohrbach's to the students of Hunter College in the main theatre at 2 P. M.

While the Atlantic Pact emissaries come and go, and the delegates of the United Nations come and stay for a time, the American consciousness becomes nervously aware once more of "protocol." It is a dread word, shattering whatever is left of our insular peace of mind.
CHICAGO, April 29 -- The country's railroads and their five operating unions wrote an agreement today providing for more liberal vacation allowances for about 300,000 employes.

Net income of the AlleghenyLudlum Steel Corporation for the first quarter of 1949 amounted to $1,542.195, equal to $1.09 a common share, compared with $1,307,471, or $1.01 a share, in the similar period of last year, H. G. Batcheller, president, reported yesterday at the annual meeting in Pittsburgh.

CHICAGO, April 29 -- Denouncing the North Atlantic pact in an address titled "The Only Way to Peace" here tonight, Henry A. Wallace, the Progressive Party's 1948 Presidential nominee, told the American people:
The Communist party of New York State has raised $650,000, the state's quota in the party's $2,000,000 fund drive, according to an announcement by the State Committee in The Daily Worker yesterday.

GENEVA, April 29 -- The French Government has denied a visa to a Czechoslovak correspondent to attend the United Nations-sponsored trade conference in Annecy, France, thirty miles from the Geneva headquarters of the United Nations.

I An analysis of the Tennessee Z Valley Authority, its doctrine and its policy in action, will be published on May 14 by the University !of C]ioornia. It will be entitled "TVA and The Grass Roots." Philip Selznick, the author also discusses the implications of the "grass roofs" doctrine for regional agencies in the federal system,

Eleven years ago today Manhattan and Queens residents witnessed parades and motorcades, including 300 floats, together with mechanized Army and Navy detachments, in a spectacular pre-view of the New York World's Fair.

Elias Howe became famous by inventing a machine that would sew, but Mrs. Ruth Lawrence, Birmingham, Ala., housewife, made a bid for fame yesterday by introducing a gadget designed to remove machine stitching. She hopes thereby to save time and tempers for homemakers who must lengthen children's clothing periodically or change hemlines with fashions.

PRINCETON, N. J., April 29 -- Dr. Errett Weir McDiarmid, president of the American Library Association, declared here tonight that libraries must devote "wholehearted and sincere efforts" toward providing an informed citizenship if American democracy is to survive.

PARIS, April 28 -- For more than six months a controversy over their respective spheres has been in full swing between Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery, head of the Permanent Defense Organization of Western Europe, and Gen. Jean de Lattre de Tassigny, Commander in Chief of the Land Forces of the Western European Union. This dispute makes their cooperation difficult, if not impossible.

"Studio One," the CBS television network's hour-long dramatic series seen at 7 P. M. on Sundays will switch to Wednesday night from 10 to 11, starting May 11, at which time the programs will be sponsored by the Westinghouse Electric Corporation.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., April 29 -- Traffic on the Westchester parkways is increasing in volume so rapidly that work on new roads should be speeded, the county park commission told the board of supervisors today in a twenty-sixth annual report.
WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) -- The Economic Cooperation Administration took steps today to assure the United States lumber industry a chance to compete for European recovery orders.

PHILADELPHIA, April 29 -- Through utilization of the Redman process, now ready for commercial use, shrink-controlled knitgoods will soon be on the market, the annual meeting of the Underwear Institute was told today.
LONDON, April 29 (AP) -- Sir Thomas Beecham complained today that the world of music is "one vast infernal hullabaloo."
MANILA, April 29 (AP) -- Philippine constabulary were reported engaged in battle tonight with the ambush slayers of Mrs. Aurora Quezon in the jungle-clad mountains ninety miles northeast of Manila.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) -- The first "sizeable" decrease in manufacturers' inventories since the war was reported for March today by the Department of Commerce. The March downturn had been foreshadowed by declining industrial production and factory employment for several months.

Lilacs and tulips, and a host of other favorites now in full bloom are too irresistible to leave all of them flowering in the garden. A few are bound to be picked so that they can be enjoyed indoors as well.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., April 29 -- Music as a hobby for housewives and business men will hit crescendo in Westchester this spring when a year's rehearsals culminate in concerts by groups ranging from neighborhood string quartets to a seven-state chorus of 2,000 voices.

With only one thing in common, the starting time, rival Loyalty and May Day parades will get under way at opposite ends of Manhattan at 1 P. M. today. In Brooklyn, where the idea of a loyalty counter-demonstration was originated in 1946 by the Veterans of Foreign Wars, the march will begin at 11 A. M.

On the heights across the Rhine from the ravaged town of Bonn stands the famous Hotel Petersburg, scene of the meeting with Hitler which Neville Chamberlain sought in his desperate attempt to prevent war. The near-by towns of Godesberg and Koenigswinter, where the German party leaders have been holding flurried meetings this week, are within sight of this historic meeting place.

A Trade Union Committee for the Election of Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., Liberal and Four Freedoms party candidate for Representative in the Twentieth Congressional District, was formed yesterday at a luncheon meeting in the New Yorker Hotel.

CHICAGO, April 29 -- The University of Chicago replied today to a hostile "surprise" witness who had testified in hearings by a state commission investigating alleged subversive activities at the university.

Favorable action by the City Council should be taken on the proposed local law to prohibit a driver from leaving his vehicle alone without stopping the engine and removing the ignition key. This measure, which stems from the Youth Counsel Bureau of the District Attorney's office, conforms to the thinking of law-enforcement officers in many parts of the country.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 29 -- Bobby Wolcott of Princeton University stopped Harvard with two hits for a 1-0 Eastern Intercollegiate Leage triumph at Soldiers Field today.

A one-time Communist "martyr," who fled an indictment on a murder conspiracy charge in North Carolina and became an official in a Russian tractor plant, is embarking today on a country-wide tour to address labor unions as part of his anti-Communist crusade.

The most extensive cancer education program ever undertaken in any school system in the country has been started by the New York City Cancer Committee and the Board of Education, it became known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The coalition of Republicans and Southern Democrats had everything its own way in preliminary skirmishes on pending labor legislation in the House today. After six and one-half hours of debate, much of it angry political slugging, the score was this:

It was encouraging to have Hanson Baldwin take Representative Clarence Cannon, chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, to task for his statement: "As in the last war, let us equip soldiers from other nations and let them send their boys into the holocausts instead of sending our own boys."
DETROIT, April 29 (AP) -- The Indians staged a three-run uprising in the ninth inning today to beat the Tigers, 4 -- 1, for Lefty Gene Bearden's second victory of the season over Detroit

Richard H. Crowe, former assistant manager of the National City Bank branch at 195 Broadway, was released in $10,000 bail yesterday after he pleaded not guilty "with a specification of insanity" to an indictment charging him with the theft of $883,660 from the bank.

Directors of the Autocar Company took no action yesterday on dividends on the three series of $20 5 per cent cumulative convertible preferred stock. In the past, regular quarterly dividends of 25 cents on the three series, A, B and C, were made.

VIENNA, April 29 -- At today's Allied Council meeting, the Soviet High Commissioner blocked a Western proposal for the abolition of all internal travel controls in Austria and nullified an Austro-Italian agreement to waive visa requirements.

Alonzo Graseano Moron, a graduate of the trades and industry department, was elected yesterday the first Negro president of Hampton Institute. He was the unanimous choice of the board of trustees in session here.

Plans for the further improvement of the Subtreasury building as the site of the Federal Hall National Historic Monument at Wall and Nassau Streets were disclosed yesterday during a special ceremony held in observance of the 160th anniversary of George Washington's inauguration as first President of the United States.

Rising costs of operation caused a drop in net earnings of the Bell Telephone Company of Pennsylvania despite a substantial increase in the company's operating revenues, a report for the twelve months ended March 31 showed yesterday.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 29 (AP) -- Eight undergraduates of St. John's College formed a picket line at the Naval Academy's main gate today in protest over the visit here of a Spanish training ship.

A new mill price break in the lumber market has sent common grades of some Western softwoods tumbling as much as $8 a thousand board feet in the last week, local distributors reported yesterday. The price drops are regarded as ominous since fluctuations in lumber prices do not normally exceed 50 cents to $1 a thousand in a week.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Dean Acheson, Secretary of State, told Congress today that as of March 31, World War II surplus property overseas which originally cost $9,236,000,000 had been sold for $1,771,000,000, or 19.2 cents on the dollar. The job of disposing of overseas surplus is 99 per cent completed, he reported. The remaining surplus goods are valued at $54,764,000.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- British trade unions officials have indicated to their United States colleagues that they hope to enroll 40,000,000 trade unionists in all parts of the world within the next eight or nine months in the newly projected global labor federation.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court refused yesterday to stay execution of a judgment handed down on April 20 by Justice Meier Steinbrink upholding an episcopal mandate removing the Rev. Dr. John Howard Melish from the rectorship of Holy Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church in Brooklyn.

Wild life, whispering weeds and spreading jungles have taken over the bright new World of Tomorrow that opened ten years ago today on Flushing Meadow. Within sight of the tailored greenery around the United Nations Assembly Hall animals prowl and primeval forces reclaim the soil that was dedicated to peace for mankind.

ATHENS, April 29 -- Lieut. Gen. James A. Van Fleet, chief of the United States military mission here, today described the position of the Greek Army with relation to the Communist-led rebels as "most encouraging," but he cautioned against over-optimism.

An all-cash offer of $816,000 for the eighteen-story and penthouse apartment building at the northeast corner of Madison Avenue and Ninety-sixth Street is being considered by Supreme Court Justice William C. Hecht, who accepted offers for the property at a court sale on Thursday.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) -- In a move aimed to bolster weakening prices of hogs the Department of Agriculture made today a supplemental export allocation of about 73,000,000 pounds of pork for the three months ending June 30.

Voice of America broadcasts to the Soviet Union have encountered in the last thirty-six hours "far and away the worst jamming" in their history, it was announced yesterday by Charles W. Thayer, chief of the State Department's international broadcasting division.
DES MOINES, April 29 (AP) -- Don Gehrmann twice came from behind with brilliant sprints today to bring a double victory for Wisconsin in the opening day of the fortieth annual Drake Relays.

FRANKFORT, Germany, April 29 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay and Gen. Sir Brian Robertson, the United States and British Military Governors, approved in principle today the law for the equalization of economic burdens adopted by the bizonal Economic Council last September but held up since then by Washington and London.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Fellow workers in the Department of Justice swore to a Federal Court jury today that Judith Coplon made persistent efforts to read highly confidential documents on foreign espionage in the United States, before and after the work of examining such reports was taken away from her.
WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) -- The Federal Housing Administration today eliminated the requirement that persons borrowing for home repair and modernization put up 10 per cent of the job costs in cash.
Leo Durocher, manager of the New York Giants, was suspended from baseball yesterday for the second time in two years.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) -- Farm prices eased about one-tenth of 1 per cent between mid-March and mid-April, the Agriculture Department reported today. Drops in the prices farmers received for dairy products, hogs and truck crops were offset by rises for cotton, lambs, grapefruit and oranges.

Anthony Barbieri sold the two-story two-family house at 123 Ninety-third Street, Brooklyn, to Edward D. Dudar. The Colonial Realty Company was the broker. The Bay Ridge Savings Bank made a purchase money mortgage of $10,000 in connection with the transaction.

A great number of Germans came to this country as fugitives from Nazi persecution. They are American citizens now and hope that the United States will help them extract from Germany some kind of indemnity for their losses. Without governmental aid they are powerless.
RIO DE JANEIRO, April 29 (AP) -- Technicians here today studied the possibilities of putting together again the split and partially sunken British luxury liner Magdalena.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The "kick-off" of the National Savings Bond drive, originally set for May 15, a Sunday night, will take place the following night instead, the Treasury announced tonight.

Ten Bulgarian stowaways who arrived here a week ago on the Egyptian-flag liner Khedive Ismail were "securely" aboard the vessel when it sailed yesterday for the return voyage to Mediterranean ports. All ten escaped from the Hoboken pier Wednesday night, but the last of them was picked up yesterday.

Coffee futures were steady in moderate trading activity on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Demand by local trade interests advanced prices in contract "S" 15 to 18 points. Firmness in actual coffee lent strength to the futures market.
ROME, April 29 -- The Pope today urged the Catholic clergy to intensify its efforts in what he indicated was the present struggle between the Church and communism.

With competition forcing prices below the break-even point, rayon lining manufacturers are planning to curtail production further, it was learned yesterday. Production schedules in some instances, textile men said, call for cuts ranging up to 50 per cent.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The President's Committee on Religion and Welfare in the Armed Forces reported today that recreation and family housing were the two critical morale problems facing service men.

The Christian Church can play a distinctive role in the development of the United Nations by helping to reduce the divisive effect of extreme nationalism and by creating a "world-wide moral sensitiveness," John Foster Dulles declared last night.

In February, 1948, President Truman sent Congress a special message on civil rights. He did this, as he knew, at great risk to his chances in the fall elections. He knew that he would lose Southern votes if he persisted in one of the most courageous acts of his Administration.

The Erie Railroad announced yesterday that it had filed new tariffs for its Northern New Jersey commuter trains. The proposed fares were described as an average increase of 18 per cent, effective June 1.

WHEN his dog Snorky is hurt by an automobile, Bob Vincent rushes him to a veterinary hospital. Bob's visit results in his getting a job there for the summer and finally to his decision to become an animal doctor.

Paralyzed in all four extremities as a result of a broken neck suffered in a fall off a horse, a girl of 20 from one of the Southern states came to New York last year for rehabilitation training. Had the point of injury to her spinal cord been only a fraction of an inch lower, it would have been possible for her to use her hands.

All the students said they read comics -- from the 11-year-old girl who reads "a couple" before bedtime to the boy of 13 who "averages about thirty a day." They agreed there was no harm in reading about the adventures of Donald Duck or other "funny characters," but that comics were "largely harmful" and that crime was "overemphasized."

WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -Dr. H. Trendley Dean, director of the National Institute of Dental Research, was named today to receive the 1949 Gorgas Award for "outstanding contributions in the field of military medicine."

WHEN Mr. Homer Perkins, virtuous but undistinguished American, being in good health and spirits, quits his domicile shortly after 8 in the morning and arrives at his place of business shortly before 9, still in good health and spirits, there is no story. From this fact stem wars and rumors of wars, speeches by Vishinsky, and other deplorable phenomena too numerous to mention; therefore, this fact should be eliminated.

LONDON, April 30 -- England and Czechoslovakia won their way into the second round of European Zone Davis Cup tennis play today as France, South Africa and Denmark jumped into commanding 2 to 0 leads in their first-round competition.

LONDON, April 30 -- Sir Hartley Shawcross, the Attorney General, accused Conservative propagandists today of having deliberately encouraged false hopes of relief in the budget. He denied that Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, had produced a "misery" budget.

PARIS, April 30 -- Gen. Nguyen Xuan, president of the provisional Indo-Chinese Government, indicated today the possibility that Ho Chi Minh, insurrectionist leader, might participate in a new government to be formed by Emperor Bao Dai.

MUNICH, Germany, April 30 -As part of an exchange plan to promote good-will, a project has been developed to send German engineers, agriculturists, professional men and unskilled laborers to the United States for two years to get job experience.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 30 -The Communist advance in China, accompanied by the evacuation program for Americans in Shanghai, was a leading topic of discussion all along the West Coast this week.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 30 (AP) -- A United States-Canadian Chamber of Commerce committee endorsed the North Atlantic pact today as a means of progressively advancing the cause of peace.

The State Department has indicated in a letter to Secretary General Trygve Lie that it is not disposed to continue support of the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund after the present appropriation by this country's Government runs out, according to Washington and United Nations sources.

An exhibition of the pioneer work by the Scottish team of David Octavius Hill and Robert Adamson, and the English photographer, Mrs. Julia Margaret Cameron, opened last week at the Museum of Modern Art.

THE most amazing part about the bizarre who-hit-whom Polo Grounds mystery is the way public opinion has rallied to the support of Leo Durocher, hitherto the most hated man in baseball. What waverers there were promptly jumped over on the Lip's side of the fence when the impatient Happy Chandler hastily suspended the Giant manager without any factual basis for it, a condemnatory action in itself.

A star combination from England captured four straight games yesterday to set the pace in the women's invitation lacrosse tournament sponsored by the New York Women's Lacrosse Association at Hunter College field. These victories raised the touring team's record to eight triumphs without a defeat since coming to the United States in March.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 30 -Following the gains in retail business activity in the Twelfth District for the last three weeks, retail sales went into a general post-Easter slump last week. Severe declines from a year ago were registered in all areas.
RIO DE JANEIRO, April 30 (UP) -- The bow of the British luxury liner Magdalena finally sank from sight today and gradually settled to the bottom of Rio harbor.

PERHAPS it is too much to hope that the young Southerners who read "Exploring the South" in school can persuade their parents to read behind them; and it is beyond the bounds of probability that large numbers of adult readers elsewhere will become familiar with it.

THE shiny-eyed boy of 13 stood on tiptoes, stretching and straining from his perch on the seat of his father's grocery wagon to catch a glimpse of the first running of the Kentucky Derby. With unrestrained eagerness and enthusiasm, he saw Aristides, the famed "little red horse," romp to victory in the inaugural Run for the Roses.

With Mother's Day just a week away, retailers here and across the country are engaged in the heaviest promotions ever held during the event's thirty-five years of official existence. The fact that merchants regard Mother's Day sales as "extra" business and that stores are sorely in need of all the business they can get, because of high operating expenses, accounts for these efforts.

A slight improvement in business, perhaps seasonal, was reported for April by the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents, in a report released for publication today by its chairman, Robert C. Swanton, who is also director of purchases for the Winchester Repeating Arms Corporation, a division of Olin Industries, Inc., New Haven, Conn.
THIS is a review by a Democratic politician of a Republican politician's book. And an excellent book it is.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, April 30 -- The solution of the Arab refugee problem calls for a major settlement and rehabilitation effort on an international scale, Walter Eytan, director general of the Israeli Foreign Office, said here today.

IN her new novel, Miss Bridge has set her Highland Scottish village digging into half-obliterated ruins of ancient forts, summoning not only solid artifacts but the shadowy figures of Deirdre and the sons of Usna who had long worked themselves into the tales and topography of the area.

BERLIN, April 30 -- For the first time since they succumbed to the evil rule of Adolf Hitler, close to fifty million Germans in Western Germany must exercise their political judgment on a question whose solution will be fateful for all of Europe as well as for all Germans.
GLADIOLUS are now available in almost every color of the rainbow. To make the lists more confusing, every basic color has varieties in different sizes and forms.

amount in excess of the same month a year ago, but the total of the first four months of 1949 declined substantially from the corresponding period last year. The survey of investment industrial facilities in April revealed a total of $6,759,000, compared with $5,848,000 in the 1948 period.

An enterprise in the formation of venture capital that was only an abstract idea three years ago is now making its second visit to the public capital market with a record of practical accomplishment behind it and with the promise of a repeat performance ahead.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 30 -- The Iraqi Government still refuses to enter upon any negotiations with Israel until the plight of the Arab refugees from Palestine is relieved. No Iraqi delegation has been sent to Lausanne to confer with the United Nations Conciliation Commission and none will be sent, Foreign Minister Fadhel Jamali said today.

DALLAS, April 30 -- Post-Easter department store sales in the Eleventh Federal Reserve District took a sizable drop from sales of the corresponding period of last year and also were well under sales for the preceding week. Rainy weather affected sales to some extent, also lower prices, but by any scale consumers bought less during the period.

FOR the next four weeks theatre lovers should find the City Center an exciting place indeed, especially at bargain prices. Starting tomorrow, Judith Anderson will be at the Fifty-fifth Street Auditorium for two weeks with "Medea," and right after that will come Maurice Evans in the Shavian jest, "Man and Superman."

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The prospect that most of China may now come under the control of the advancing Chinese Communists is thoroughly appreciated here and its gravity not minimized, even though there might not necessarily be direct control of the country by the Kremlin.

The House of Representatives last week went back to work after an Easter holiday -- and a talk with the voters. As the House met, the corridors and the galleries were packed with hundreds of lobbyists. Elsewhere in Washington there were rounds of conferences -- in the quarters of the AFL, the CIO, the Department of Labor.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat, of Nevada, asked the Civil Aeronautics Board today to defer action on its order designed to tighten restrictions on the operation of non-scheduled airlines.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 30 -- With both friends and foes of the Franco regime predicting a quick victory, the political committee of the United Nations General Assembly will start debate next week on proposals to restore Spain to partial membership in the community of civilized nations.

The Red Cross Blood Program of the Greater New York Chapter reported yesterday that 5,700 patients in 202 voluntary and municipal hospitals received blood in the first year of operations of the collection program. The first anniversary will be observed Wednesday in the chapter house, 315 Lexington Avenue, at 4 P. M.

Union officials reported yesterday a program of social services in the laundry industry of this city. The Laundry Workers Joint Board, CIO, said that protection afforded by the union from loan sharks and poor quality merchandise had helped union members make ends meet in a low-income industry.

THE publication recently of the American Youth Hostels' foreign travel booklet for 1949 inspired thousands of hostelers to check their bikes and budgets to see whether they could qualify for a junket abroad this coming summer.

a polling service which draws considerable financial sustenance from motion-picture producers, has just completed a survey that conveys the somewhat disquieting news that "critics are people." According to ARI, "it may be surprising, but it is a fact that the motion-picture critics of New York City's newspapers, with few exceptions, gave high praise to the pictures which the moviegoing public found the most enjoyable of the year."

The United Nations General Assembly gave its backing yesterday to a Western-power move to take action, under machinery set up by the peace treaties, on the trials of Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty, Hungarian Primate, and the fifteen Bulgarian Protestant clergymen.

Apparently convinced that the current business situation reflects no more than a desirable adjustment organized banking, nevertheless, is considering an aggressive campaign to combat deflation. No concrete plans have yet been formulated, nor is the matter likely to receive any advance publicity, since the bankers are most anxious to avoid "rocking the boat."

SUPPOSE England became a centralized Tory state. Not the crude, aggressive dictatorship of a Hitler, but a socialist government in reverse -- one in which a conservative bureaucracy introduced planned economy, but an economy in which it was the idle rich who were encouraged, the man-about-town who was publicly supported, and the worker and the intellectual who were frowned on and demoted.

ATLANTA, Ga., April 30 -Fresh demands for local actions to curb Ku Klux Klan activities were heard in this area following United States Attorney General Tom Clark's addition of the KKK to the list of organizations "advocating force and violence to deny others their constitutional rights."

EZIO PINZA and Mary Martin, co-stars of the Broadway success, "South Pacific," will appear over the "Telephone Hour" on Monday, May 16, from 9 to 9:30 P. M. They will sing selections from the Rodgers-Hammerstein score of the new hit.
Thirty high school students from Elkhart, Ind., came to town yesterday and demonstrated that they could "do the town" on a budget of $5.50 apiece.

CENTER MORICHES, L. I., April 30 -- The provisional closing of Moriches Bay to the taking of shellfish, beginning tomorrow, has been decided by the State Conservation Department to protect New York State's shellfish industry.
WASHINGTON, April 30 (UP) -- In a new withdrawal of United States armed forces from the Pacific, the Air Force today ordered its Pacific Air Command dissolved on June 1.

LONDON, April 30 (UP) -- A Communist purge of Russian cultural, scientific and artistic life has been renewed in the field of architecture, where "American influences" are under attack, it was disclosed today.

THE byline of R. H. Markham in The Christian Science Monitor has for decades preceded dispatches distinguished by three-dimensional reporting, compassion for human suffering, and engaging simplicity of style. Mr. Markham, for many years Balkan correspondent of one of the world's finest newspapers, has retained as a journalist his affection for the peasants of southeastern Europe that earlier moved him as a missionary educator.
ANNUAL flowers are a mainstay of the summer garden. They are grown from seed every year and now that the earth and air are warm, any of them may be planted outdoors.

The steel industry is prepared to present a united front of resistance to a fourth round of wage increases or extension of security benefits to employes if, as seems certain, such be the demands of steel labor unions in contract negotiations due to be reopened around the middle of the month.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Coalition forces in the House will offer at least four more "softening" amendments to the Wood bill in their strategy to enact a modified Taft-Hartley Act and block the Administration's Lesinski Measure.
Ivan D. Eby, a member of the Moore-McCormack Lines since 1920, has been elected vice president of the steamship company, Albert V. Moore, president, announced yesterday.

WALKING through the exhibition of European old master drawings at the Schaeffer Gallery forces the spectator to wonder at the astonishingly high average of their quality. How brilliant they are at their best.

THE teachers said, "We have wonderful parents; they do anything we ask them to do," and "Our parents go to bat for us"; they told of principals who gave them a free hand and of teachers who worked well together, of good relationships between personnel -- "We have a janitor with a wonderful philosophy who is very cooperative," one teacher said.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -The naval observatory, trying to keep watches accurate, has set up a station at Richmond, Fla., to correct an error that runs as much as 0.004 of a second some days.

DES MOINES, Iowa, April 30 (AP) -- Paul Bienz, stocky Tulane sprinter, and two tall hurdlers, Paige Christiansen of Michigan State and Dick Ault of Missouri, won feature events at the fortieth Drake relays today.

Cancer fund coin cans went on display at hundreds of newsstands in Manhattan yesterday as the New York City Cancer Committee entered the final phase of its $1,250,000 drive for research, education and service.

Another effort is being made to raise the price of the Federal Duck Stamp from $1 to $2, and while the sportsmen seem to be united in the conviction that more funds are required for enforcement of waterfowl regulations they do not like the idea of providing additional funds for the acquisition of "inviolate" refuges.

BOSTON, April 30 -- Department store sales in Boston for the week ended April 23, 1.3 per cent below the corresponding week of last year, was a smaller post-Easter letdown than most merchants had expected. Sentiment among department store executives continues on the cautious side.

A new and serious hitch in the long-delayed plans for a $25,000,000 convention hall, sports arena and parking garage in the Columbus Circle district appeared yesterday with the announcement that private interests had acquired a large part of the proposed site for a parking garage project of their own.

THE earliest of the spireas is now in flower. Although not a large family, varieties of this hardy, adaptable shrub will give a continuous display of showy blossoms throughout the summer and into the fall.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- There are fundamental differences between the popular national health service of Great Britain and the compulsory health insurance program of President Truman. However, the objectives are virtually identical. Many details are similar. And it is easy to get into an argument over whether either constitutes "socialized medicine."
WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -Gov. Thomas E. Dewey received today what amounted to an invitation from Washington Republicans to run for the Senate in New York next fall.

Women's straw hats and handbags, linen suits, denim playclothes, pastel cashmere sweaters, nylon gloves and summer home furnishings were featured in retail promotions here last week, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the Retail News Bureau, Inc.

At last week's meeting of the National Academy of Sciences in Washington, Dr. Robert J. Williams of the University of Texas presented on behalf of himself and his associates, L. Joe Berry and Ernest Beerstecher Jr., a theory, supported by some experimental evidence, that the taste for alcohol is part of a drinker's metabolic pattern and that it can probably be corrected by proper attention to nutrition.

Charles G. Spiegler's "The Fourth 'R' -- Redtape" is an account of the pathetic consequences of the effort of modern educators "to do too much for too many with too little and too few." The consequence is too bad.

Harvard University will shortly establish a Laboratory of Human Development to study the behavior of children and the part that schools can play in preparing students for happy and productive lives. As a preliminary step, the center will survey the early childhood origins of the social motives.

A foreign policy conference designed to present the United States' problems and policies to a section of the "grass roots" of America will be held July 22-28 at Colgate University. The program, consisting of speeches and panel and forum discussions, will be partially financed by the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace and will be presented with the cooperation of the State Department and the United Nations.

HILLSIDE, N. J., April 30 -- J. Raymond Carringer, who started work forty-five years ago in the tank-car repair shop of the Standard Oil Company of Indiana and rose to be vice president, director and general manager of manufacturing operations of the Esso Standard Oil Company, retired today.

GO West, old man, and you invade the territory of the central or arena style of staging. To most Easterners it is virtually a new type of theatre. The actors perform with props but virtually without scenery on the floor in the center of a hall; the public sits in rows of seats that circle the hall and enclose the playing area.

MANY readers' knowledge of modern Welsh literature is probably limited to a fond remembrance of "How Green Was My Valley." From that book may be recalled the daily grind in the coal pits, the sudden tragedy of industrial accidents and the awesome choral singing.

FRANKFORT, Germany, April 30 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor, said today that the dangerous cartels in Germany had been dissolved and a "further break-up of German enterprise would be a political and not a security measure."

PHILADELPHIA, April 30 (AP) -- Bespectacled right-hander Paul Calvert survived a ninth-inning Philadelphia rally to pitch Washington to a 4-3 victory today. A pair of home runs accounted for all of Washington's tallies.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (UP) -Dr. James Boyd, director of the Bureau of Mines, said today that coal mine accidents could be reduced by 50 to 75 per cent if operators and niners would end their "bickering and rancor."

DURING the nearly thirty years in which Faith Baldwin has been writing novels, nine million copies, according to her publishers, have been published. Light romancers, of course, have always their devoted following, but the reason for Miss Baldwin's popularity is to be found only partially in the inevitably happy and well-contrived ending.

SAO PAULO, Brazil, April 30 -- The Brazilian Labor Party, formed and headed by former President Getulio D. Vargas and calilng itself a workers' political organization, set out in its platform, adopted here today, a major premise of combating commission.

The "Fellow-Traveler," though a true reactionary, is often an impractical seeker after perfection and you and Mr. Sydney Hook have performed an important public service in disclosing his techniques and associations.

TOKYO, April 30 -- With pencils sharpened, Japanese business men and economists are trying to figure the effects upon the nation's livelihood of the 360-year-to-the dollar exchange rate announced last week.

IN their long and turbulent history the Yugoslav peoples have been engaged most of the time in undeclared wars. What makes the current war of vituperation, blockade and blackmail especially noteworthy is that this time it is being fought out against the "big brother" in the Kremlin.

Imprisoned on Ellis Island since Jan. 24 because he arrived here eight days after his twenty-first birthday, a technical bar, a Czechoslovak farmboy will gaze at the Statue of Liberty through barred windows tomorrow while a lawyer seeks passage of a "private" Congressional bill to admit him to this country because of "special circumstances."
Loyalty parades as part of May Day celebrations were hailed as an offset to Communist influence by Rabbi William F. Rosenblum in Temple Israel, 210 West Ninety-first Street, yesterday.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., April 30 -Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, who gained national attention last Nov. 2 by smashing all Illinois election records in winning the Governorship from a favored Republican incumbent, now is on the threshold of another important test of his program, this time in the State Legislature.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- One of the most formidable lobbies ever formed to press its views upon Congress is being operated by the Administration, labor and industry to influence action on a new labor relations bill. The "battle of the lobbies" over the bill, unlike the House of Representatives, has taken no recess over the week-end.

FREDERIC R. MANN, head of the Seaboard Container Corporation, who resigned as vice president of the Robin Hood Dell Concerts in 1945 because he disagreed with the way they were being run, is back now as president -- on his own terms.

IF the amateur moviemaker would look at his town or countryside with the curiosity of a Robinson Crusoe, his films would show immediate improvement. Robert J. Flaherty, "father of the documentary film," said here last week.

TO an American looking at a map of Italy, the Province of Lucania would certainly seem the place least likely to excite literature. In the instep of the boot, wedged between Apulia and Calabria, it is poor, backward, un-picturesque and lacking in the rich tradition of the northern provinces.

" Landmark on the Road to Religious Freedom," by Gerald W. Johnson, is a misnomer. The fact is that Maryland's Constitution was one of three of the thirteen original states which restricted public office to Christians.

Toward the end of his essay on "The Fellow-Traveler" Prof. Sidney Hook writes: "American liberals should not be frightened off from active support of worthy cause merely because Communists and fellow-travelers profess to advocate them, too." * * *

Referring to Edward Toledano's article on Arab motion pictures, "Supercolossal, Arab-Style." the undersigned has been in Alexandria, Cairo, Beirut, Damascus and even Casablanca, which inspired the article, and has seen films in the 200-seat houses which the "fellaheen" attend as well as in the luxurious Royal Opera, Cairo. In no place has he noticed unaccompanied women being kicked in the stomach by men for refusing their advances.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (UP) -Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat, of Virginia, demanded today that Secretary of State Dean Acheson tell Congress whether any secret promises had been made to supply North Atlantic Pact nations with American arms.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 30 -Jacob A. Malik, the Soviet representative to the United Nations, gave his tacit agreement Friday to the stipulation of the Western powers that the proposed meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers on the German question must not interfere with their plans for the establishment of a Western German government, it was learned tonight.
Mayor O'Dwyer has proclaimed the week beginning tomorrow as Goodwill Week, it was announced yesterday.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, April 30 -- Westerners this week were giving more thought to international affairs than has been their habit in the past six months. Sizable sidewalk crowds gathered daily outside newspaper offices in cities where overseas bulletins are posted -- with the conversations of most observers focused on Chinese Communist advances and the growing possibility of an end to the Berlin blockade.

ONE day eighty-five years ago -- in May, 1864 -- Hawthorne and Franklin Pierce, ex-President of the United States, drove past Lake Winnipesaukee to the Pemigewasset House, a hotel at Plymouth, N. H., and took rooms for the night.

THE newest novel by Faith Baldwin, "Golden Shoestring," is a unique Baldwin product in at least one respect: it did not get serialized in a magazine before it became a book. Just about the first that didn't in the past twenty years, Miss Baldwin says.

A meeting between a squad of Eastern College All-Stars and the New York Giants of the National Football League has been arranged for the annual Fresh Air Fund football game, it was announced yesterday. The eleventh classic has been set for the night of Thursday, Sept. 1, at the Polo Grounds.

Re Woodrow Wyatt's "Chaos-Breeders in Southeast Asia," it is clearly high time that the Western powers adopt a vigorous democratic policy for aiding the moderate nationalist elements in the whole of the Far East.

Brownie, the shaggy little mongrel dog, one part Eskimo and other parts undetermined, who has been pining for his master on the docks of the Bayway Refinery of the Standard Oil Company in Linden, N. J., for the past two months, will receive world-wide billing tomorrow.

Faced with the prospect of losing its hold on first place in the Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference, New York University came up with three runs in the seventh to vanquish its Brornx rivals from Fordham University, 5 -- 3, at Ohio Field yesterday.
SHANGHAI, Sunday, May 1 (UP) -- Communist armies thrust closer to Shanghai and Hangchow today, but the Communists had failed to fulfill their boast -- they were not celebrating May Day in Shanghai.

FOR a good many years Arturo Toscanini carried on no diplomatic relations with Tchaikovsky. It was a unilateral policy, since Tchaikovsky, of course, was past caring. The maestro did not explain, and no explanation was necessary.

BOSTON, April 30 -- After several months of reading about increased layoffs in industry, New Englanders this week hailed the news that 700 of the 2,300 idle workers at the Waltham (Mass.) Watch Company had returned to work under a reorganization plan.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., April 30 (AP) -- Paul E. Fitzpatrick, chairman of the New York State Democratic Committee, said today that, despite "unprecedented national prosperity," Gov. Thomas E. Dewey's administration had plunged the state into its greatest debt in history.

IT seems obvious by now that Foley and Hibbs will never meet -- editorially speaking. We refer, of course, to the reasonably well-felt, sometimes well-written non-story that Martha Foley taps for honors in her yearly anthology.

COLUMBIA, Mo., April 30 (AP) -"Farewell to No. 3," an Associated Press photograph of Babe Ruth in his old Yankee uniform, was put first in the sports category of the sixth annual "news-pictures-of-the-year" competition at the University of Missouri.

The Procter Gamble Company and its subsidiaries had a net profit of $33,581,913 after all charges, including provision of $17,620,000 for taxes, in the nine months ended on March 31, its report disclosed yesterday.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., April 30 -- More effective teaching of American heritage and ideals was urged here today at the forty-fifth annual spring meeting of the Middle States Council for the Social Studies.

Once again Barney Shotton's pitching came unstitched yesterday and the Philadelphia Blue Jays, merrily seizing the loose strands, wove them into a 12-4 victory over the Dodgers at Ebbets Field. It was the worst beating the Brooks have suffered thus far.

" DARING Newspaperman Exposes Powers Behind City Throne" -- that might be the headline over the story of this novel. Allan Chase, who wrote "Falange," an anti-Fascist expose, turns this time to corruption on a more intimate level -- the American city controlled by the boss, abetted by some low citizens courting favor and getting caught in the ruthless municipal machine.

AMMAN, Jordan, April 30 -- The Arab Legion radio at Ramallah which is now the principal radio voice for areas under the Jordanian Government, said today it was felt that in the coming parliamentary elections Syrians would show they were for a greater Syria.

BRUSSELS, April 30 (AP) -- An international cotton advisory committee meeting here has agreed on the necessity to enlarge consumption of cotton throughout the world. This decision was taken in view of bringing about a balance of consumption and production.

IN "Strategic Intelligence for American World Policy" sherman Kent, Professor of History at Yale University and a wartime intelligence director in the OSS, brings thorough scholarship and practical experience to the consideration of a subject of primary importance to those charged with the responsibility for the foreign policy and security of this country and of vital concern to the rest of us who would suffer the awful consequences of their failure.

A Secretary of State must do more than conduct the nation's foreign policy. He must also often go "over to the Hill" to sell that policy to Congress, particularly to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. The task calls for diplomacy. The Senate committeemen tend to be jealous of their role as chief Congressional custodians of foreign affairs.

GREGOROVIUS called his life of Lucrezia Borgia "a chapter from the morals of the Italian Renaissance." In outrage and fascination he described the lives of the Borgias and many others, in their vileness and their magnificence, quoting letters and diaries to support the charges of crime and license.

DUSSELDORF, Germany, April 30 -- German industrialists and employers in the Ruhr area have been more than usually receptive to the activities here of the Moral Rearmament group, which currently has a hundred representatives living with families of workers. Some German officials also have become interested in the movement.
OTTAWA, April 30 -- Canada's twentieth Parliament was dissolved today and on June 27 its successor will be elected.

LIKE such writers as Ngaio Marsh and Anthony Gilbert, E. C. R. Lorac went many long years without attracting the attention of a major American publisher. I am thankful that she is at last receiving proper recognition.

BUENOS AIRES, April 29 -- The Japanese trade mission will open an office in the Argentine Chamber of Commerce building on Monday. The mission will acquaint officials here with the products Japan now has available for export. At the same time Japanese technical experts who make up part of the mission, which arrived here last night, will study prospects of acquiring Argentine products.

MINNEAPOLIS, April 30 -- Railroads serving the Ninth Federal Reserve District reflected the general decline in the volume of trade in their quarterly reports to the Interstate Commerce Commission this week. The eight roads showed a drop of more than ten million dollars in the operating revenues for the first quarter, as compared to the same period last year.
The Crown Linree Corporation, manufacturer of Crown bags, will move from 120 West Thirty-first Street to 10 East Thirty-third Street, effective tomorrow.

The continuing shortage of qualified school administrators and well-trained elementary teachers is threatening to disrupt the nation's public education system, according to two reports released last week.
PHOENIX, Ariz., April 30 -Problems of flood control and irrigation, in which Federal action is a key factor, kept attention in the Southwest focused on Washington this week.

" Mysticism in Art" is the subject of the free lecture to be given on Tuesday at 6 P. M. at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street. Mrs. Rachel Wischnitzer, author, will be the speaker.
To those like myself who frequently despair and lose all hope, the article, "Rededication," by R. L. Duffus, is both inspiring and revivifying. Poetic and powerful, it is symbolic of Easter itself.

Strenuous organizing efforts of Communist and kindred organizations bore mixed fruit yesterday in the annual May Day parade of left-wing groups down Eighth Avenue. For the first time the parade of left-wing groups was held here on the last day of April to vie with the marches of Loyalty Day paraders.

Donald Johnston, baritone, who won the American Theatre Wing's first concert award last year, gave a recital in Town Hall yesterday afternoon. As in his first appearance, he displayed a voice of many pleasing characteristics plus innate musicianship and sensibility.

A MAY Festival with more than 4,000 Brooklyn high school girls participating will open officially Brooklyn Botanic Garden Week, Monday at 1 P. M. A benefit dinner will be held in the administration building on Tuesday evening.

New York City had parades yesterday of those who believe in individual freedom and of those who are doing their best to destroy it. Today there will be more parades all over the world. In Moscow the troops will turn out to demonstrate the means by which the Russian Communists assert their version of the brotherhood of man.

Steps to widen investor protection by bringing unregistered corporations with at least $3,000,000 in assets and 300 security holders under the same regulations as those now filing reports with the Government, will be taken by the Securities and Exchange Commission in a Congressional program for improving the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, Louis Loss, associate general counsel of the SEC, stated last week.

FREYA STARK is the author of "Valleys of the Assassins," "East Is West," and other travel books which have sometimes been compared to Doughty's work. But surely she has never surpassed this present distillation of experience and insight, these "personal oddments of philosophy I have to help me on my way."

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities has resumed spy-hunting and associated business under new management. This new management results from a widespread demand for a change -- a change not only in the personnel of the committee but in its procedures.

I WAS pleased to note that Francis Steegmuller, in his review of the Andre Gide Journals in the April 3 issue, "wonders" too about M. Gide. Gide stands as a strong personality apart from his writing. Reading about him I get much the same impression as I do of Oscar Wilde and Bernard Shaw -- they might be of any profession, they seem to outshine their own writings.

AMMAN, Jordan, April 30 -Through indifference to the fate of the Jordan River water rights the Jordanian delegation to the Lausanne conference is in danger of giving away the country's only hope of becoming self-supporting, according to competent observers here.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (UP) -Senator Wayne L. Morse, Republican, of Oregon, revealed today that he recently received Democratic "inquiries" as to whether he would resign his Senate seat to accept a Federal circuit judgeship in San Francisco.

GLEN COVE, L. I., April 30 -- The fifty-seven-room mansion built by the elder J. P. Morgan on East Island in Long Island Sound will be in the June tax sale, according to city officials and representatives of the real estate concern that now owns it.

THE barnstorming Farbman Sinfonietta, which deserts St. Louis each spring and fall for a breezy six weeks' tour of the States and Canada, is composed of nineteen men, a girl and a conductor who call a 17-ton Greyhound bus their home.

Tommy Henrich's two-run homer in the ninth lifted the Yankees to a 4-3 victory over the Red Sox yesterday. Despite Peewee Reese's two homers, the Dodgers lost to the Phils, 12 -- 4, and the Giants were beaten, 4 -- 0, by Johnny Sain of the Braves.
DETROIT, April 30 (AP) -- Right-hander Virgil Trucks ended the Detroit Tigers' three-game losing streak as he pitched them to a 7-5 victory over the Cleveland Indians today before 50,610 fans.

FOR THIS WEEK: Fertilize perennials with a commercial plant food such as 5-10-5. If scattered in a ring around each plant, fertilizer may be hoed or watered into the soil. Feed rose bushes if it hasn't been done this spring. . . . Turn over the compost heap started last fall, taking care to leave a depression in the center to gather water. Sprinkle with lime.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Officials in Washington are inclined to agree with President Truman that the Russians are now negotiating in good faith to end the Berlin blockade and reopen discussions in the Council of Foreign Ministers on the future of Germany as a whole.

Drawing a sharp distinction between the performance of the scheduled airlines and private flying, Dr. Clifford C. Furnas, director of the Cornell Laboratory, has thrown light on a situation which often is confusing. Flying accidents are all too likely to be lumped together in the public mind, and an unwarranted distrust of scheduled air travel is thus created.

SO many loose impressions are provoked by the use of the term "escape" in connection with movie entertainment that we hate to mention the word, let alone call it in reference to a happy experience. But, frankly, we can't escape it in talking about "The Wizard of Oz," which, in its current revival, is one of the nicest attractions to be seen.

ST. LOUIS, April 30 (AP) -- Billy Pierce allowed six hits and struck out eight as the White Sox nosed out the Browns by 5 to 4 today. But Pierce had to have help from Matt Surkont to stop a late Brownie rally.

ALL pictures, both foreign and domestic, shown in Germany must be approved by Military Government prior to exhibition. Our censorship has not been unduly rigorous but has sought to encourage the showing of features with educational or what the Army calls "reorientation" values.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 30 (AP) -- The Chinese Communists also promised "to protect all foreign nationals in China who engage in normal vocations."

THE production of "Pinky" marks another break with the long-standing taboo against films dealing with the problems of racial and religious prejudice. Last season saw "Gentleman's Agreement" and "Crossfire," both of which were concerned with anti-Semitism.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 30 -Harvard University's crews, rowing under ideal conditions, scored a clean sweep over Boston University and M. I. T. in a triangular regatta over the mile and three-quarter course on the calm Charles River today.
THREE long-awaited streamliners are expected to be in service soon to brighten the passenger transportation picture this summer.

THE state of the motion-picture story market is always a good index of Hollywood's production prospects, and the fact that the major studios have bought approximately sixty story properties since Jan. 1 is regarded as assurance that the gentle improvement already noted the quantity of production will continue for most of the year.

Recent history has made so many zigzags that turning points are more common than punctuation marks. Yet last week was quite a week even in a long series of crucial weeks. On one side of the world the Chinese Red armies swept across the slow-moving waters of the Yangtze and startled the West with the specter of a Communist China.

Pupils of Public School 33, 418 West Twenty-eighth Street, have no objection to being kept after classes -- in fact they like to stay late at this one of the city's four "all-day neighborhood schools." The boys and girls also take pleasure in going to school during the summer.

MANILA, Sunday, May 1 (UP) -Luis M. Taruc, chief of the rebel Hukbalahaps, denied today that the Hukbalahaps had been guilty of the ambush massacre of Mrs. Aurora Aragon Quezon and eleven others. Mr. Taruc asserted that Mrs. Quezon had contributed money to the "Huk" movement.
OUT here in the great Northwest there's a new legend growing, and it suggests that almost every man, woman and teen-ager plays a musical instrument.

YOUNG readers who first met Paul Carter and Bill Kingsley in Mr. Retan's book, "Wanted: Two Bikes," which was laid in a country town in Pennsylvania, will welcome this new tale about that resourceful pair. Paul and Bill arc planning to go camping, but a robbery at the store owned by Paul's father delays things.
Retail trade here improved somewhat last week, but sales volume continues to run below that of a year ago. Department store sales were estimated as about 6 per cent under the comparable week of 1948.
CONCORDIA, Kan., April 30--The Missouri Basin Inter-Agency Committee faces today the biggest challenge in its brief history.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Three important paintings recently were donated to the National Gallery of Art for its American collection, it was announced today by the director, David L. Finley.

HOLTSVILLE, L. I., April 30 -- Dr. Edwin P. Kolb, one of the state's pioneers in county tuberculosis work, retired today as superintendent of the Suffolk Sanatorium here, a job he accepted thirty-three years ago with a great deal of misgiving.

IN "presenting the achievement of modern British and American critics" the editor of this anthology, who is Assistant Professor of English Literature at the University of Kansas, has undertaken the difficult task of portraying the magnitude, complexity and high merit of a significant literary movement.

A STORY from Vienna in THE NEW YORK TIMES reports the great success of the American play, "Harvey," the first performance of which was attended by the President of the Austrian Republic and the most distinguished representatives of the Viennese public.

Behind the effective hurling of Tellef (Red) Tellefsen, Columbia's baseball team racked up its second Eastern Intercollegiate League triumph in four starts yesterday by beating Pennsylvania, 8 to 3, before an alumni day crowd of 2,000 at Baker Field.

Dr. Chaim Weizmann, Israel's first president, in a message that opened the first American Conference for Hebrew Language and Culture, asserted last night that the "day is not far when the spiritual life of American Jewry will be strongly inter-related with the cultural values of Israel."
" CRUSADE IN EUROPE," the twenty-six-week series of films depicting the history of World War II based on General Eisenhower's book, will make its debut this Thursday on ABC-TV at 9 P. M.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- A trial examiner for the National Labor Relations Board upheld secondary boycott charges today against two unions that engaged in the boycott, but recommended dismissal of similar charges against two other unions that encouraged the boycott by striking and picketing for recognition.

THE Republic of Azerbaijan will probably be familiar only to youthful stamp collectors. But to Ali, a young Mohammedan of Tartar blood, this Caucasian land was his whole world in the turbulent year 1918.
