Even in Aii's town Agdam, racial and religious tensions were strong, and Ali's parents might not have died of cholera had the Mohammedans not refused the care offered by the Christian hospital.
MOSCOW, April 30 -- The Communist parties of the world now number far more than 20,000,000 members, according to a comprehensive analysis published by S. Ivanov in the journal, Problems of Economics.

THERE is an old saying that "a crop well planted is a crop half grown." Successful gladiolus culture depends on healthy corms, proper planting, good culture during growing season, and control of insects and disease.

Unsure gropings into the past to discover the place of man's origin and the so-called "missing link" are at an end! This quest of the ages has been fulfilled by the discovery of a series of fossil remains in the Union of South Africa, the most recent having been taken from rock on April 1.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 30 -California, which needs some 500,000 agricultural workers at its peak season to harvest $2,000,000,000 worth of crops, has the largest potential of farm labor in its history, according to present evidence.

THE time has come for a thorough re-examination of America's course in Asia since the war and its policy for the future. The events of the last few months -- and especially of the last two weeks in China -- call for fresh thinking and a fresh start.
WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -- The chairman of the President's Commission on Civil Rights said tonight that Communists did not believe in civil rights except for themselves.

FOR the fourth time in two months the Federal Reserve Board has voted "Yes" on the deflation issue. Reserve requirements for the member banks will be lowered this week. Previously the board had made it easier to buy securities by reducing cash margins from 75 to 50 per cent and then installment credit terms were liberalized for consumers in two successive moves.

SUMMER cruising lies directly ahead for most of the half million powered pleasure craft whose owners are now giving them their annual overhauling. This year the Coast Guard and its civilian auxiliary are shaping up the most ambitious program they have ever attempted for making these small boats as safe as possible.
FOUR years ago today, the German Admiral Karl Doenitz gave the German people the news on the radio that Adolf Hitler "had met a hero's death at his post" in the Reich Chancellery in Berlin.

IN a season such as the present one of the Ballet Theatre a great deal goes on that never gets recorded in daily reviews or Sunday summings-up, since neither time nor space nor the boundary of one's attention is exactly unlimited. Accordingly, today's stint is going to be completely indulgent, rambling hither and yon, bothering not at all with making a point.

SHANGHAI, April 30 (UP) -Military authorities tightened security measures within this city today to guard against rioting resulting from the soaring inflation that had made China's money almost worthless.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -The National Grange recommended today the creation of a Federal "marketing commission" with broad powers for keeping the American farmer out of trouble and in good economic health. A. S. Goss, head of the Grange, told a House Agriculture subcommittee that his national farm organization favored a non-political board to work with the Secretary of Agriculture in anticipating and dealing with farm crises.

LONDON. CAN we get a settlement with Russia? The events of the past week bring that question sharply to the fore. But before we can answer it we must first determine what we mean by a settlement. If we mean the formal withdrawal of Soviet pressure from, for example, Eastern Europe, which is what many unfortunate political refugees would demand, then obviously there can be no settlement without war.
The world's tallest structure, the Empire State Building, marks its eighteenth birthday today. Its doors were opened to the public on May 1, 1931, with many celebrities on hand for the occasion.

A SURPRISE for plane travelers to the West Indies is the new air terminal just opened at San Juan, P. R. The spacious center was constructed by Puerto Rico's Air Transportation Authority in what had been a United States Navy hangar at an estimated cost of $3,000,000.

There is no ground for some shippers' fears that an approaching international survey on all causes of American export shipment damage would distort the amount due to inadequate packaging, it was declared yesterday by James B. Young, vice president of the Barber Steamship Lines, Inc.
UNKNOWN to most tourists, a large and modern hotel is operated by the United States Government at one of the most beautiful sites overlooking the Hudson River.

THE trend in the automotive industry toward general adoption of automatic gearshifting was emphasized further last week by the introduction of "Ultramatic Drive" by the Packard Motor Car Company. This appliance is the result of sixteen years of research and the expenditure of more than $7,000,000 on a tooling program.

LEO STRAUSS is a scholar who knows his own mind. He holds Charles E. Merriam's chair in political science at the University of Chicago. He is author of a brilliant analysis of Hobbes, and of many other studies in political thought.

MUNICH, Germany, April 30 (UP) -- Catholic Bishop Hans Meiser today accused United States authorities of using brutality and "religious interference" against inmates of the near-by Landsberg war-crimes prison.

LONDON, April 30 -- A May Day order broadcast to Soviet armed forces tonight said that "the Soviet people never forget the danger of a new war which ruling circles of the United States of America want to unleash."

WASHINGTON. ROBERT A. TAFT seems at times -- and his manner does little to dispel the notion -- to be at war with a very large part of the politically habitable American world, if not all of it. Just now he is in a special state of belligerency. He is preparing for a struggle that will be more than a fight for his own political life.
The American Ethnological Society opened its annual two-day meeting yesterday at City College, Lexington Avenue and Twenty-third Street.
Do youngsters anywhere still hang May baskets, or has May Day become wholly a date of social significance?

THIS is one of those novels which end with the hero striding "on in the gathering dusk" as he resolves to write the novel one has just finished reading. Here the device is used to tell of Prairie Avenue's decline and fall" in Chicago.

MR. TREVOR-ROPER, who reviewed the "Memoirs of Alfred Rosenberg," which we recently published, devoted two and a half columns to a dissertation on the subject's career and hardly a line on the work itself. It is true that Mr. Trevor-Roper did allude to the jacket copy, but such an evaluation is not generally regarded as reportage on the contents.

TOKYO, April 30 -- The Japanese Government today placed before the Diet's lower house a controversial proposal to revise the postwar labor laws to bring the newly organized trade unions in line with the industrial recovery program sponsored by the Allied occupation.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was active yesterday and final prices were 4 to 14 points net higher.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 30 -Hostility toward private foreign investors on the part of governments in many underdeveloped countries is giving way to increasing eagerness to attract their capital into ambitious projects conceived under the "bold new program" of President Truman's inaugural address, pledging American technical assistance to economically backward areas throughout the world.

It simply isn't true, as current reports have it, that the health of almost a hundred persons has been affected by experimental smog with which United States Public Health Service technicians are seeking to determine at Donora, Pa., the cause of last fall's disaster, says Dr. Leonard A. Scheele, Surgeon General of the service.

PRINCETON, N. J., April 30 -In a setting of academic pageantry, the new $6,000,000 Harvey S. Firestone Memorial Library was dedicated here today in the presence of 2,500 scholars, bibliophiles, members of the faculty and friends of Princeton University.

THE most valuable use to which a high card can be put is to kill another high card -- but not quite so high -- held by the opponents. Whenever possible an experienced player reserves his high cards for this purpose.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Congress defaulted today on its statutory obligation to make its own advance estimates of Government receipts and expenditures.
Arthur Daley in "Baseball's 'Ten Greatest Moments'" omitted a world series game with undoubtedly the most exciting ending.
Eleven years ago Chancellor Adolph Hitler told the German people that the Reich had solved the problem of capital and labor and that other nations were coming around to the Nazi point of view.
CHICAGO, April 30 (AP) -- A disputed inside-the-park home run by Glenn Nelson salvaged a 4-to-3 victory for the St. Louis Cardinals over the Chicago Cubs today before 30,775 fans.

WAYNESBORO, Va., April 30 -- Swannanoa, the mountain-top home of Dr. Walter Russell, the sculptor, four miles east of here, will be dedicated as a "shrine of beauty" on Monday by Colgate W. Darden, president of the University of Virginia and former Governor of Virginia.
Dental inlays, bridges, gold crowns or sets of false teeth many New Yorkers are wearing may have been constructed illegally.

As the first step in a broad program to widen and modernize the Manhattan plazas of the East River bridges, work is soon to begin on the improvement of Delancey Street from the Bowery east to the entrance to the Williamsburg Bridge, according to plans now being completed by the Board of Transportation and Manhattan Borough President Hugo E. Rogers.

SIR THOMAS BEECHAM was 70 years old last Friday. He told questioning reporters that ha didn't feel that way at all; in fact, that he didn't feel any differently than he had felt and would feel for many years to come, and that he would go on conducting to the end of his days, "which is a hell of a way off."
THIS department has received the following letter from the National Broadcasting Company on the subject of the network's handling of news on television:

WHEN Andre Simon, president of the Wine and Food Society of London, visited New York he lamented that "American diets no longer observe the seasons." Changes in food make meals interesting, he argued.

May I take exception to the letter of Max Bachmann in THE TIMES of April 24, in which he defends the Bavarian party. He is only right in saying that the average American does not know enough about German politics. If he knew more about it he would know what Mr. Bachmann avoids mentioning.

JUST a week after the New York opening of "South Pacific," Ezio Pinza went through as trying a performance as any in his thirty years on the operatic stage. When he reached for a high note in "Some Enchanted Evening" his voice turned hoarse, and later in a duet with Mary Martin it cracked.

Mention of General Coxey in THE TIMES brings memory of his army of 20,000 unemployed men marching on to Washington in 1894, demanding legislation that should give them work, and that the Government should print the money with which to pay wages.

The decision in the suit brought by Continental Distillery Corporation against Webb's City, Inc., (Fla.) is "no green light to undercut the price levels of fair trade," according to George M. Chapman. He is a member of the law firm of Rogers, Hoge and Hills, counsel for Sterling Drug Company, a party plaintiff in the case.
ALLENTOWN, Pa., April 30 (AP) -- America's best salesman is the rank-and-file newspaper man, Senator Francis J. Myers, Democrat, of Pennsylvania, said tonight.

OF all the spring flowers, none is more welcome or more charming than the daffodil. Around New York they have been in full bloom for two weeks or more and, now that the season is waning, notes on varieties may be studied for fall planting.

A YEAR ago this husband and wife team gave us one of the finest animal stories of 1948, "Vulpes, the Red Fox." The central figure of their new book is a mink, perhaps the most vicious and least lovable of all wild creatures.

LONDON, April 30 -- The British Commonwealth of Nations has just passed through an important transformation. For the first time in history it will include among its members a republic which refuses to pledge allegiance to the Crown.

CHICAGO, April 30 (AP) -- Moderate selling pressure toward the close of the market today on the Board of Trade reduced or canceled early gains in grains, soybeans and lard. The market was not active and dealings were confined mostly to local traders.

NEWARK, N. J., April 30 -- Foxchasers of the Llangollen Farm of Upperville, Va., led for both the conformation and working hunter championships at the end of the third day of competition in the Newark horse show tonight. The jumper division was headed by Mrs. Don J. Ferrado's Black Watch going into the final day of the annual event in the Essex Troop Armory.

A thorough reorganization of the city's higher education facilities, both as to physical plant and curriculums, is contemplated under a program already approved by the Board of Higher Education and now before the Board of Estimate for financing, it was indicated yesterday.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., April 30 -The Federal aid secondary highway to be constructed from Commack to Patchogue is to be a memorial to Suffolk County veterans of all wars in which the United States has participated.
CHICAGO, April 30 (AP) -- A University of Chicago professor says an industrial sociologist on the staff of American business company is a necessity.

DETROIT, April 30 -- About 200 of the 3,500 employes in the B Building of the River Rouge plant, the central spot in the clash between the Ford Motor Company and Local 600 of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, over a speed-up issue, showed up today to hear international leaders of the union explain why immediate ratification of an overwhelming strike vote had not been approved.

Plans for expansion of the Life Saving Service of the City of New York, which marked its fortieth anniversary last week, were announced yesterday by Augustus G. Miller of 78 Pell Street, the Bronx, a founder and former president.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- James H. Doolittle, retired lieutenant-general of the Air Force, urged today a three-phase program for peace with the Soviet Union based on military preparedness, worldwide education for freedom and the improvement of "mankind" through religion.
Would you kindly convey this message to Arthur Kramer, in appreciation of his "Service Unification March" in THE TIMES Magazine of April 10:

OMAHA, Neb., April 30 -- Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan's request for Congressional permission to try out his new farm plan immediately in support of the sagging hog market turned the spotlight more brightly this week on the drop in pork prices.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 30 -Yale's new low rowing cadence, unsuccessful on its unveiling against Pennsylvania a week ago, carried the Elis to a decisive victory over Navy and Cornell in that order today on the Severn course of a mile and three quarters.

Clarification of the policy of the United States Government toward favoring purchases by foreign countries from merchant exporters here rather than manufacturers and mill sources is expected to result from a meeting to be held in Washington on Tuesday, it was reported here last week.

TEL AVIV, Israel, April 19 -In the Israeli Knesset (Assembly) recently, a left-wing Assemblyman from the Opposition benches criticized the Government of Premier David Ben-Gurion for having banned the debarkation of passengers in the Haifa harbor on Saturdays.
This is a red-letter day for pleasure boat skippers. By long tradition the date of May 1 marks the downhill, eleventh hour finale of fitting-out for another season afloat.
CERTAIN qualities are the objectives in developing new gladiolus. Color should be distinctive and clean, the plants should be inherently healthy, and growth should be uniformly good.

For a time yesterday at the Stadium it appeared the DiMaggio influence would crush Yankee hopes of victory over the Red Sox. The crippled Joe was side-lined with his famous aching heel, but the Little Professor, Dom, was doing all the hitting -- for Boston, of course.

IN 1857, when the Englishman Charles Mackay visited the United States, he was so struck by the widespread habit of chewing tobacco that he thought the American Eagle, instead of grasping in its talons the thunderbolt of Jove, should be portrayed as holding aloft a spittoon.

Tornadoes flailed Texas, Oklahoma and Kansas yesterday, killing at least five persons, injuring eighty-three and damaging property up to $2,000,000. There were torrential rain and at some points hailstones as large as baseballs.

Protests against world communism and Soviet expansion in Europe dominated the Loyalty Day Parade in Manhattan yesterday as an estimated 117,000 marchers of diverse national origin joined in the Fifth Avenue demonstration.

PHILADELPHIA, April 30 -Matching its great feat of 1945, Bishop Loughlin of Brooklyn today completed a triple victory in the high school division of the Pennsylvania Relays. Performing even beyond expectations, the Purple and Gold charges of Bill Miles added the mile and two-mile relay titles to the distance medley honors they had gained yesterday.

CINCINNATI, April 30 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Reds, picked by many of the experts to finish last in the National League pennant race, took over the loop's No. 1 spot today with an 8-4 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.

The Civil Aeronautics Board's tentative decision to issue five-year certificates of public convenience and necessity to four out of five all-freight airlines that sought such permission was protested here yesterday by the one airline failing to get a certificate.

JACOB A. RIIS, the hundredth anniversary of whose birth is observed this week, was one of those first-generation Americans who breathed deep draughts of our free air, absorbed our democracy through every pore, made our land their own, enriched it by their indefatigable efforts, and left it their eternal debtor by their works, their loyalty and their abounding gratitude.

BOSTON, April 30 -- Johnny Sain and Larry Jansen, a couple of top grade pitchers who have been having a little trouble getting off the mark this spring, tried it again on this crisp, sunny afternoon and one of them finally made it.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 30 -- Dick Kreutzer's line single to right center with the bases loaded in the tenth inning enabled Yale to win its opening Eastern Intercollegiate League game from Navy today, 5 -- 4. It was the fifth consecutive triumph for the Bulldogs.

If Dr. R. W. Porter, General Electric engineer, is right, to build a man-carrying rocket that could fly to the moon and back would be the equivalent of building a super-aircraft carrier. The rocket would be about 500 feet long, about the height of a thirty-two-story building, and weigh about 2,000 tons.

THE North American Gladiolus Council instituted a few years ago a trial garden system for the testing of new varieties. So many were being added each year that it was next to impossible for anyone to keep up with the novelties.

Unlike some boastful grandpas, the H. J. Heinz Company on this, its eightieth anniversary, can truthfully state its slogan for success as "variety is the spice of life!" Away back in 1869, 25-year-old Henry John Heinz gave it a potent start with horseradish.
TOKYO -- Japan hopes to sell a million dollars' worth of tourism this year. For an occupied country, rich in scenery but otherwise poor, that is a major effort.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The National Bureau of Standards is developing three types of atomic clocks, in which the never-varying vibrations of atoms or molecules will take the place of the rotating earth as the official standard of time.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 30 -- The Central Committee of the Yugoslav Communist party issued today a 2,500-word May Day proclamation asserting that the international working class movement was being threatened by the Communist Information Bureau's dictatorial policies of inequality as well as by "imperialist * * * plans to provoke a new war."

ROME, April 30 -- Sir Stafford Cripps, British Chancellor of the Exchequer, held out but slight hope to the Italians today that they would be allowed to transfer their sterling credits to the dollar area at any time in the near future.

DR. DAVILA is a former Chilean Ambassador to the United States who for a brief time in the politically turbulent early Nineteen Thirties was President of his republic. Also, since he has spent the greater part of the past twenty years in this country mainly engaged in inter-American journalistic operations, he has had an all but unmatched volume of experience with the gringo and Latin-American civilizations.

ELECTRICAL energy has always fascinated man. The story of those individuals who have sought its secrets -- from the Greek astronomer Thales in the sixth century, B. C., to contemporary scientists who are trying to understand the cosmic rays -makes an unusual book.

THE vast mysteries of Time, as defined by our calendar, are unrolled in a panorama made thrilling by the scope and graphic beauty of this book. It reaches back through history to Babylonia, and outward through space to the sun, moon and stars.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, April 30 -- Apparent reluctance of Washington to focus the spotlight on violations of democracy within the Hemisphere has been a source of discouragement to the more democratic American nations, such as Uruguay.

For the first time since 1946, foreign orders for American machine tools are again approaching normal levels. Tell Berna, general manager of the National Machine Tool Builders' Association, disclosed in Cleveland yesterday. Adding to this brighter outlook there is a definitely promising indication from distributors that the trend of domestic sales is upward, according to reports from New York, Cleveland, Chicago and other distributing centers.

THE brightest luminary of the Paris theatre season has been 80-year-old Paul Claudel, Catholic poet, playwright and former Ambassador to Washington, who has rung the bell with two hitherto unproduced plays -- "Le Partage De Midi," written in 1905, and "Le Pain Dur," written in 1914.

For two years Associate professor Julian M. Sturtevant of Yale has been perfecting a twin calorimeter so sensitive that it can record a temperature change of only a few thousandths of a degree in an hour. With this instrument he is studying the heat change that takes place when pepsin, an enzyme, loses its ability to aid the process of digestion.

The Federated Metals Division of American Smelting and Refining Company has developed a patented machine casting method of making a new type of tin-lead bar solder, after five years of laboratory research and pilot plant development, officials revealed here yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 30 -- To the score or more proposals thus far drafted concerning the disposition of Italy's former colonies by the United Nations General Assembly, the Government of Egypt intends to add another plan calling for two governors general to administer the three Libyan provinces, it was learned today.

CHIEMSEE, Germany, April 30 -- In the first post-war educational conference of its kind, delegates from Western European countries met here this week to find solutions for major school problems confronting democratic lands. Called under the auspices of the Education and Cultural Relations Division of American Military Government in Germany, the sessions brought together many of the world's foremost educators.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., April 30 -- State Senator Bernard W. Vogel of Middlesex County called today for a special session of the ten-member legislative committee on Rutgers University to inquire into charges of indiscriminate dismissal of faculty members and suppression of academic freedom on the campus.

RICHARD EBERHART'S "Brotherhood of Men" borrows the manner and devices of Old English heroic poetry to tell a story of modern heroism. His half narrative, half philosophical account of the history of the American soldiers taken prisoner on Corregidor by the Japanese is a tale of forbearance and resolution fit for a gleeman to sing in a mead hall.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (UP) -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations warned today that an economic policy of "letting nature take its course" was leading the country "down the road to reduced production and employment."
Twenty thousand building service workers won weekly increases of $3.50 each yesterday, and simultaneously the threat of a strike in 2,000 apartment buildings in Manhattan vanished.

The past week was an eventful one in the two great areas of struggle in which the United States is vitally concerned --Western Europe and the Far East. It was also a week in which there was demonstrated again the nature of the Russian strategy, a strategy that Washington calls "the hot-cold technique."

Nifty relief twirling by Gerry Brown and lusty hitting carried St. John's University to a 10-4 conquest of Brooklyn College, in a Metropolitan Baseball Conference struggle at Dexter Park, Woodhaven, yesterday. With their fifth victory in six league starts, the Redmen remained in a first-place tie with New York University.
RICHMOND, Va., April 30 -- The Upper South turned its eyes toward Washington this week as pending legislation in the fields of medical care and public housing claimed top attention.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, announced today the union was willing to negotiate a separate agreement with the Southern Coal Producers Association. He made the unusual suggestion that the conferences take place in Bluefield, W. Va., and permitted an inference that he would not personally participate.

THE trouble with making a half-way promise to return to a topic, by means of that insidious word "perhaps," as I did two weeks ago when writing about the New York of the novelists, is that one's conscience is too easily salved when another subject, and then another, puts out a beckoning finger.
DENVER, April 30 (AP) -- The American Council of Christian Churches has attacked a proposed plan for "Brotherhood Week" as "a gross perversion of the scriptural teaching on this subject."

WHEN Nature abhors she is loud in her protest. The creature that violates the laws of being cannot take shape. The creature that lives in violation of Nature's law is quickly destroyed. Sterility, a stunted existence, early disintegration -these are her curses, the marks of her rigor.

SHANGHAI, Sunday, May 1 (AP) -- Shanghai's peril mounted today, but indications that it was cut off by rail from the rest of China proved erroneous. Railway officials announced trains still were running from Shanghai to the supporting city of Hangchow.

WASHINGTON, Pa., April 30 (UP) -- Senator Kenneth S. Wherry said tonight that the money needed for President Truman's "fair deal" social security program, over a fifty-year period would make seven stacks of silver dollars reaching to the Moon, with sufficient left over to pay off the national debt of the United States.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Just as the second World War relegated the mighty dreadnought to the military museum, Louis Johnson, Secretary of Defense, last Saturday ended the hopes of naval strategists for a new role of primacy through the aircraft carrier.

With the gradual evacuation of European DP camps and the resultant easing off in high financial requirements for carrying on relief and rehabilitation work abroad, more money than ever is now being earmarked by the United Jewish Appeal and other Jewish agencies for regional and local Jewish communal services in this country.

The installation in the Brooklyn Borough Testing Laboratory of a giant sewer pipe testing machine costing $19,000 and designed to reduce the number of sewer-pipe breaks under the borough's streets each year was made known yesterday at Brooklyn Borough Hall.

The Bureau of Mines will dedicate two new coal-to-oil demonstration plants -- the forerunners of a new basic industry in the United States -- on the anniversary of V-E Day, May 8, at Louisiana, Mo., less than 100 miles above St. Louis on the Mississippi River.

TWENTY years ago this summer, railway passengers scurrying through New York's Penn Station broke their hurried strides to gape at a giant airplane mounted in the main waiting room. For most of the observers it was the largest airplane they had ever seen.

Representative Wiliam L. Pfeiffer, in his frst visit to New York since his recent election as Republican State Chairman, announced yesterday his intention of improving the party organization in preparation for the election of an Associate Judge of the Court of Appeals and the local elections this year and the state election in 1950.
HARRISBURG, Neb., April 30 (UP) -- Carl A. Gettman, pastor of the Methodist Church here, resigned today to protest "the program of the Methodist Church which praises Russia and Stalin."

WARSAW, April 30 -- The Polish secret police raided All Saints Church here at dawn one day this week and arrested the parish priest, Father Zygmunt Kaczynski, 55, a close confidant of Polish Primate Stefan Vishinsky and former Minister of Education in the emigre Polish Government in London, it was learned today.

With many retailers planning store-wide sales during May, buyers looked for off-price merchandise in the wholesale apparel market here last week, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buying office.

Soccer-playing seamen, after a ten-year hiatus, will once again vie for the Caroline De Lancey Coll Challenge Trophy, according to arrangements now under way between the Y.M.C.A. Seamen's House, 550 West Twentieth Street, and a group of seamen's welfare officers representing seven nations.

New York commuters, a tribe which is increasing, could not have been very much surprised when informed, more or less officially, last week that the congestion at the two big New York railroad stations had about reached the limit.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, April 30 -- Miguel Miranda, former director of Argentine economy, said here today that his health had been "80 per cent" restored and that when his heart was again normal, within a few months, he would be ready to return to Buenos Aires to confront those who, he said, had been "lying" about him.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., April 30 -- Brown University scored its second straight Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League triumph and its fourth victory in seven games this year when it turned back Princeton, 6 -- 1, at Aldrich Field today.

THE plays treated in this new book by Professor Tillyard of Cambridge are the three so-called "dark comedies," "Troilus and Cressida," "All's Well That Ends Well" and "Measure for Measure" and, joined to them unconventionally, "Hamlet."

CLEVELAND, April 30 -- The Cleveland Cap Screw Company has started construction of a $300,000 laboratory at its No. 2 plant here and will spend $200,000 on equipment, Joseph W. Fribley, president, said in a surprise announcement at a dinner for employes.

PARIS, April 30 -- As the climax of a day dedicated to "Resistance to Dictatorship and War" 15,000 Parisians crowded tonight into the Velodrome d'Hiver, the city's biggest sports arena, to hear orators from several countries proclaim their solidarity with the forces of peace and liberty in the world.

The American shipping industry, which has taken an active part in seeking limitation on the post-war revival of the German and Japanese merchant marine, is disturbed by evidence that the Supreme Command for the Allied Powers in Japan is now fully committed to strong Japanese resurgence as a maritime power.
I read with much amusement your recent Topics column dealing with the proposed commemorative stamp upon the anniversary of the great episode in biblical history, the Deluge.

BUENOS AIRES, April 30 -- The largest airport in the world, according to statistics provided by Argentine officials, was dedicated here today by President Juan D. Peron and the Minister of Public Works, Gen. Juan Pistarini. The field bears the latter's name.

SHANGHAI, April 30 -- A Chinese Communist broadcast demanded tonight that the United States, Britain and France "withdraw quickly their armed forces, warships, military aircraft and marines" from China.
LONDON, April 30 -- The oil that might lubricate the wheels of progress in the Arab states and Israel has been flowing slowly for a year because of the war in Palestine and its political aftermath.

LORD MACAULAY -- and more sensible men have agreed with him -- ranked Jane Austen second only to Shakespeare. R. W. Chapman, the foremost scholarly authority we have on the great Jane, thinks this sort of claim has done her reputation more herm than good.
MONTREAL, April 30 (Canadian Press) -- The Montreal freighter Tricape steamed into port today leaving little doubt that her crew would join the Canadian seamen's union (T.L.C.) strike.

WITH the magnificent Braque retrospective exhibition current at the Museum of Modern Art and the well selected recent show of cubist work put on at the Buchholz Gallery by Curt Valentin, just closing, the newly opened exhibition of paintings by Jacques Villon at the Louis Carre Gallery is very timely.

Although New York's wholesale markets are suffering from jittery nerves as the result of continuing pressure for promotional merchandise, the immediate outlook for trade in women's apparel lines has several bright spots, it was pointed out last week.

FOUR weeks in a row for "Point of No Return" at the top of the best-seller ladder to the right. It begins to look as if J. P. Marquand's novel had settled down for a long spring reign. A new leader for the general list, however: Fulton Oursler's "The Greatest Story Ever Told."

The breach between the Army's two civilian components, the National Guard and the Organized Reserves, seemingly patched up at one time or another since the war, has widened more than ever in the past few weeks, it was learned yesterday.

Retail orders for dinnerware have steadily decreased for the last sixty days and production has been further curtailed in practically all potteries, the United States Potters Association reported last week. The association said overall operations are now at 80 per cent of capacity throughout the industry.

THE Ballet Theatre goes into its final week at the Metropolitan today. Antony Tudor's "Undertow" will have its only performance on Wednesday. Jerome Robbins' "Facsimile" will not be done after all. No time to prepare it.

SHANGHAI, April 30 -- A Chinese Communist broadcast demanded tonight that the United States, Britain and France "withdraw quickly their armed forces, warships, military aircraft and marines" from China.
BERLIN, April 30 -- An agreement between British and Russian Military Government officials today ended four days of bickering over the use of canals through the British sector of Berlin.

The first complete report of a four-year study of family tensions relating to crime prevention and rehabilitation of juvenile delinquents will be made by Dr. David Abrahamsen of Columbia University's Psychiatry Department next Saturday at the university's first all-day Forum for the Study and Prevention of Crime.

IT was fish that first drew Europeans to the northeastern shores of North America. From their discovery in the times of the Tudor kings, the commercial fisheries of the great continental shelf from Cape Cod to Labrador and the older ones off Greenland and Iceland have been a rich subsidiary source of food for the Western World.

Princeton's varsity sprint crew upset pre-race speculations and won the historic Childs Cup on the Harlem yesterday afternoon, leading the favored Pennsylvania eight by a little more than a length, with Columbia trailing the Quakers by two lengths.

Although conversations with Russia for lifting the Berlin blockade may help clarify the European situation, they had little effect on financial markets last week. Stock prices kept within a narrow range for the entire period, despite highly favorable earnings and dividend reports by the nation's leading corporations.

TOWARD the end of the last century there existed in Cambridge, Mass., across the Common from the Harvard College Yard, something called the Society for the Collegiate Instruction of Women. The students of this society sang a song -- not entirely original -- one stanza of which went like this:

THE flowering dogwood display this spring promises to be the most beautiful in years, according to Dr. F. A. Bartlett of the Bartlett Tree Expert Company. The fat buds were unmarred by winter damage, and, like most trees, advanced a week or more, because of the early spring.

TWO men in mackinaws, hunter's caps and rubber shoe pacs trudge up to a stately Douglas fir tree. Behind them they drag a dumpy mechanical contraption, which they belt to the tree. One of the men pours fluid from a gasoline can into a little rectangular tank attached to the metal device.
PARIS, April 30 -- Italy's inclusion as an original signatory of the North Atlantic defense pact has come as a bad shock to Turkey, according to information reaching Paris.

AMERICANS are still the best tippers on transatlantic ships, but even they are not tipping as much as they did before World War II. It has long been a standard practice to budget shipboard tips at the rate of 10 per cent of the total amount paid for passage.

A STORY with an "Annam, Jordan" dateline in THE NEW YORK TIMES last Wednesday brought information of philatelic significance -- namely, that foreign correspondents in Annam had been officially informed that "Transjordan" was no longer the country's name and thereafter "Jordan" must be used in news dispatches. "Hashemite Jordan Kingdom" is the title mentioned in the country's Constitution.

RIP REARDON comes home from the wars to find his wife, Georgette, dead -- suicide the official story says -- and Ynez, Spanish, enigmatic and beautiful, ensconced in his house. Home is Port Afrique, somewhere in French West Africa.

For more than three hours yesterday the residents of Brooklyn gave their answer to left-wing May Day celebrations in the second annual Loyalty Day parade. An estimated 70,000 persons marched the two-mile route from Grand Army Plaza to Borough Hall.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (UP) -- The chief of the Air Materiel Command predicted today that the Air Force would have ready for operational use within a year a 12,000-pound bomb -- about the estimated weight of an atomic bomb -- that can be guided all the way to the target.
PHILADELPHIA, April 30 -Loaded for bear, New York University found itself with only small game to beat in the mile relay finale of the fifty-fifth annual Pennsylvania Relays today.

WEST POINT, N. Y., April 30 -- Dartmouth College remained at the top of the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League today by virtue of its third straight victory, an 11-to-9 triumph over Army at Doubleday Field.

Fine English and French period furniture and decorations from the stock Of Symons Galleries, Inc., 12 East Fifty-third Street, will be auctioned from Thursday through Saturday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Stret.

Roosevelt Jr., was attacked yesterday as "a cheap political trick" by Abraham Kaplan, campaign manager for Municipal Court Justice Benjamin Shalleck, Democratic candidate for Representative.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., April 30 -- Pushing six runs across in the last four innings, City College defeated Hofstra, 6 -- 4, in a Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference engagement.

Underlining the critical nature of events, Under-Secretary of State James E. Webb advised me in a conference at the department several days ago: "Our policy in China is under the most serious consideration at this time."

AS the art season begins to run down and the big annual and biennial exhibitions, one by one, are left behind, it becomes possible to take stock once more of the big group show problem -- a problem that presents angles unknown to geometry and thorns the horticulturist never heard of.

PHILADELPHIA, April 30 -During the week ended April 23 retail sales showed a 9 per cent drop from the like week last year in (1) reporting department stores throughout the Third Federal Reserve District, (2) department stores in Central Philadelphia, and (3) Philadelphia women's apparel stores.

Pastel shirts will continue in strong favor for next fall, according to 71 per cent of retailers replying to a style survey made by the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers, and issued here yesterday. From a sectional standpoint, 100 per cent of Midwestern and Far Western stores, 85 per cent of Eastern retailers and 50 per cent of Southern establishments expect the vogue to continue.

The New York City Board of Estimate is a body with legislative powers made up of the top executives in the city government. Its members are the Mayor, Controller, the President of the City Council and the five Borough Presidents. The members have different voting power on the board -- the Mayor, the Controller and the Council President have three votes each, the Brooklyn and Manhattan Borough Presidents two each, the others one.

Jockey Steve Brooks had a joyride around the Jamaica track yesterday on Calumet Farm's remarkable Coaltown. He didn't have to work a bit -- at least it looked that way -- as the great 4-year-old cut loose with another of his high-octane runs to win $38,600 of the $56,700 at stake in the Gallant Fox Handicap.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (UP) -House spy hunters have subpoenaed a woman employe of the United Nations in an attempt to find out how unwanted Federal workers get on United Nations' payrolls, it was learned tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Dr. Jessup will have other meetings with Mr. Malik on the Berlin blockade problem. Whether these will be merely to confirm understandings already reached or for further discussion of details was a question left unanswered here today.

Apparently, Leo Durocher will maintain a policy of silence until he appears before Commissioner A. B. Chandler at Cincinnati on Tuesday. The suspended manager of the Giants, sidelined by the baseball commissioner following an alleged attack on a fan last Thursday at the Polo Grounds, spent yesterday at home, listening to a broadcast of his team's game with the Braves.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -President Truman got a pay check today but probably for only one-third of the $12,500 April pay to which he is entitled under his recent increase.
CLEVELAND, April 30 -- In his second major appearance of a fifteen-day cross-country tour, Henry A. Wallace said here tonight that America had more warmongers than any other nation in the world.

HAVING tasted on more than one occasion the bitter and the sweet fruits of movie-making, Sir Alexander Korda can view with philosophical calm the present troubled state of the British motion-picture industry.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 30 -- An Alaska "gold rush" for construction jobs is bringing disillusionment to thousands of unemployed workers from the States, according to Federal officials who are about to set up a program designed to discourage the migration of job seekers to the territory on a haphazard basis.

No thinking person can look at the sun and its planets without wondering how such a system came into being. On the basis of the speculations of Kant and Swedenborg the French mathematical physicist Laplace formulated the nebular hypothesis. According to Laplace the sun and its attendants were once a huge, spinning mass of gas.

THERE is a difference of opinion as to how valuable the schools can be in teaching youth to be tolerant and fair minded. Some educators believe that the home, the church and the community are the most influential factors in molding the character of the growing child.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Despite a vigorous battle to get permanent control over installment credit and increased power over the required reserves of banks of the Federal Reserve System, the Federal Reserve Board may have to be satisfied with much less than it has requested of Congress.

LONDON, April 30 -- Princess Elizabeth, the Duke of Edinburgh and the Duke of Gloucester were among the 100,000 soccer fans who saw the Wolverhampton Wanderers battle through to a 3-1 victory over Leicester City in the final game for the Football Association Cup at Wembley Stadium today.
Let us put an end to the buncombe and platitudes being ceremoniously mouthed about the American composer's opportunities for performance.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The House is expected to pass tomorrow a bill legalizing the wholesale killings of the starlings, or purple grackles, that throng the capital's air.

NINGHSIA, China, April 5 -- One thousand broadswords whirled in the sharp desert sunlight and 1,000 voices shouted, "Kill!" as the climax of a military demonstration today welcoming Maj. Gen. Claire L. Chennault to this Chinese Moslem stronghold.

Diverse trends were shown in new financing here in April. Public offerings of bonds declined from the volumes of the preceding month and of April, 1948, while equity flotations rose to the best level for any month since June, 1948, and were the largest for an April in three years.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (UP) -- Maurice J. Tobin, Secretary of Labor, said today that the United States has "nothing to fear" from socialism. Speaking on a radio program, he was asked if this nation might be "in danger" of becoming socialistic because of its close contact through the Marshall Plan with socialist and labor governments in Europe.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 1 -- Plans for a "one-world" motion picture, illustrating the need for world unification, to be made by John Huston, with the advice of a group of other film producers, were announced today by Sam Spiegel, Huston's partner in Horizon Pictures, the company which will produce the film.

SHANGHAI, May 1 -- A May Day message broadcast tonight by the Central Committee of the Chinese Communist party asserted that eight Nationalist armies had been "annihilated en masse" south of the Yangtze in the ten days since Communist troops had crossed the river. Two days ago the Communists had reported that most of seven armies had been wiped out.

The only scheduled novelty of the Ballet Theatre's week-end at the Metropolitan Opera House was the season's first presentation on Saturday afternoon of "Petruchka" with Bambi Linn as the Dancer for the first time, along with Hugh Laing in the title role, Dimitri Romanoff as the Blackamoor and Edward Caton as the Charlatan.
SHANGHAI, May 1 (UP) -- An informant in Hangchow said that the city, 125 miles southwest of here, had been practically abandoned by its Nationalist defenders.

HONOLULU, May 1 (AP) -- Picket lines were thrown around docks at three of the six Hawaiian Island ports today as the CIO International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union called out 2,000 stevedores on strike. They seek a thirty-two-cent-an-hour pay increase.
The Metropolitan Golf Association today releases its 1949 golf calendar, which assures plenty of activity for the tournament player and spectator alike.

ST. LOUIS, May 1 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sex won their seventh game in as many starts against the St. Louis Browns today as they swept both halves of a double-header, 7 to 6 and 14 to 11. The rampant Sockers pounded nine Brownie pitchers for a total of twenty-nine hits.

Just to keep New Yorkers reminded of the great part the city's subways play in their lives, the Board of Transportation said yesterday that during 1948 city subway trains operated over 241 miles of routes consisting of 738 miles of tracks. Surface lines traversed 578 miles of routes.
HONG KONG, May 1 (AP) -- Among hundreds of Chinese refugees pouring into this British colony are many political and economic figures of the Nationalist Government.

A papal bull, "Unam Sanctam," issued by Pope Boniface VIII in 1302, was quoted yesterday morning in a holy communion meditation by the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street, as apparently supporting the position of the Roman Catholic lay teachers dismissed recently at Boston College.

CHICAGO, May 1 -- A total of 190,000,000 bushels of cash wheat stored in elevators is now owned by the Government, according to trade reports, with an additional large amount likely to be turned over on defaulted farm-stored loans and under purchase agreements on May 31, the time for redeeming the latter grain being thirty days later than on that held in elevators.

Patsy Parr. 11-year-old Canadian pianist, who appeared here as soloist a year ago at one of the Carnegie Pop concerts, gave her first New York recital last night at Town Hall. The gifted child was heard in a program devoted chiefly to short pieces, including three of her own compositions.
NEWARK, May 1 (AP) -- The Newark Bears and the Buffalo Bisons battled to a 5-5 draw today with the Bears tying the game with a two-run rally in the sixth inning before rain halted the game.

LONDON, May 1 -- It is of little use to consider the problem of Malaya in isolation. It is part of the problem of Southeast Asia, an area of the world that lies dangerously open to Communist infiltration. The Twentieth Century has witnessed an awakening of nationalism in Southeast Asia as elsewhere.
Reporting, April 27, that ex-President Hoover had written to Chairman Doughton of the Committee on Ways and Means on the subject of old-age and survivor's insurance, THE TIMES said:

For some time the foreign policy of the United States has assumed that the principal means for resisting the rise of communism and the Soviet Union is military power. Our Government has enlisted the support of the press, the radio, and the screen, dominated as they are by the extreme fear of the well-to-do of communism, to persuade the American public that this military emphasis is necessary.

Activity in the wholesale garment markets here last week centered on summer merchandise promotional goods, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. Retailers reported a good response to intense Mother's Day promotions.

If theatregoers want to get full value for their money at bargain prices they are directed to Judith Anderson and her starring vehicle, "Medea," freely adapted by Robinson Jeffers from the tragedy of that name by Euripides. From tonight through May 14 "Medea" will occupy the City Center.

A two-fold appeal for generous contributions to the Bishops' Fund for Victims of War and for more displaced-persons sponsors within the Archdiocese of New York was made yesterday by the Rev. Gustav J. Schultheiss, archdiocesan director of War Relief Services, National Catholic Welfare Conference, the relief agency of the Bishops' Fund.
ZURICH, May 1 -- When the stock exchange here closed yesterday, quotations of many German and Austrian bonds had shown advances of more than 200 per cent over the prices at the end of 1948.
SHANGHAI, May 1 -- Although the tread of Communist armies was not far beyond the horizon, there were no parades this May Day on the streets of the city that shelters the bulk of China's proletariat.

The retirement of Capt. Harold T. McCaw, who has commanded vessels of the United States Lines for eighteen years, was announced yesterday by the steamship company. He is one of the few remaining American shipmasters who learned his trade in sailing vessels.
Theodore O. Thackrey, former editor and publisher of The New York Post, has worked out arrangements to publish a new daily New York newspaper within a fortnight, it was reported last night.
W. Winfield Challenger, formerly director of printing of N. W. Ayer Son, Inc., has been appointed business manager of the Intaglio Service Corporation, manufacturer of printing plates.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Monday, May 2 -- The first strike in the history of the Singer Manufacturing Company's sewing machine plant here began early today when a token picket line was established. The full effect of the strike was expected to be felt at 6:30 A. M. when most of the 9,000 employes usually report for work.

Books by John Gunther and George Orwell, author of "Animal Farm," will be distributed in July by the Book of the Month Club. Mr. Gunther's "Behind the Curtain," a report on the Russian satellite countries, will be published by Harper on June 15.
The possibility that there may be spirited opposition to the re-election of Dr. Ordway Tead as chairman of the Board of Higher Education at its annual meeting on May 16 developed yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 1 -- Trade in lard futures was enlivened on the Board of Trade last week by removal of hedges against further sales to England. Federal funds have been provided for the purchase of about 70,000,000 pounds of lard, of which it is estimated around 50 per cent has been obtained so far.

The report on "community stewardship" released by the State Congress of Industrial Organizations is a refreshing departure from accepted trade union procedure. It is designed to call public attention to the scope of CIO activities in promoting public welfare and educational projects and in "discharging union responsibilities to the community."

Big league baseball used to be a lusty, robust game. Now, every time Leo Durocher bats an eye some fan claims he was punched, kicked and torn limb from limb. In the old days players figured spectators paid to watch games land not to spend the afternoon abusing the performers by making slurring remarks about their relatives by marriage and forebears.

KARACHI, Pakistan, April 21 -- The obscure Moslem Princely States that acceded to Pakistan when India was partitioned in August 1947, will continue to retain the political identity that some of them have had for hundreds of years. The policy of the Pakistani States Ministry is to keep some of the autocratic rulers strong, instead of weakening them, as India has done with all of the fabulous Maharajas of the Hindu States.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The United States Chamber of Commerce at its annual meeting this week will be asked by its policy committee to oppose the main points of President Truman's labor and economic controls program.

The shipping industry is preparing to marshal impressive opposition to the impending labor-union boycott of ships of the Panama flag and to proposed legislation cutting off virtually all means of transferring American - registered vessels to any foreign flag.

A national cooperative promotion campaign, said to be the largest yet devoted to a single rayon fabric, is being opened this week by the American Bemberg Corporation, with the support of more than ten manufacturers and a large number of stores, it was learned over the week-end.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (UP) -- The Very Rev. Hunter Guthrie, S. J., new president of Georgetown University, said tonight that too many colleges were playing squarely into the hands of the Kremlin by failing to teach religion and morals.

FRANKFORT, Germany, May 1 -- A delegation of sixteen Germans including nine top executives, will shortly go to Washington to take up positions of responsibility under the European Recovery Program. These jobs are now being discharged by the Department of Army on behalf of the bizonal area.

OTTAWA, May 1 (Canadian Press) -- Engineers have started survey work on the construction of more than 1,000 miles of pipe lines which will carry natural gas to the Pacific Coast from Northern British Columbia and Alberta, Frank McMahon of Calgary, Alta., said today.
Eleven years ago today sand hogs from the Jersey side of the Hudson met their New York co-workers under the Hudson River as the two halves of the north side of the Lincoln Tunnel were joined.

ROME, May 1 -- Two separate May Day celebrations were held in Rome this morning. The Free or anti-Communist unions for the first time held a rally of their own in competition with the one organized by the Communist-dominated General Confederation of Labor.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 1 -- The International Labor Organization warned the Governments of the twenty-one American republics today that a continued low living scale for farm laborers would imperil the living standards of non-agricultural workers as well.

The competitive phase of the All-England women's lacrosse team tour came to a close yesterday as the British athletes, displaying their usual all-around brilliancy, wound up their stand at Hunter College in the Bronx with an unbeaten record in six games played during the two-day event.
A Queens police lieutenant recovered his stolen car yesterday afternoon and a man who was riding in it is lucky to be alive.

Every act of injustice against human rights anywhere in the world is a challenge to the freedom enjoyed by citizens of the United States, Senator Irving M. Ives declared yesterday in an address to 2,000 Polish-Americans at an anti-Communist Loyalty Day Rally in Manhattan Center.

Prospective revenues of the municipal transit lines from the higher fares in effect since July 1, 1948, do not justify another round of wage increases for the 40,000 employes of the city system, according to a report made public yesterday by the Citizens Budget Commission.

W. J. Oudendyk's letter in your issue of April 22 on the dispute in Indonesia appears to be a rather belated attempt to justify Dutch action in breaking agreement with the Republican Government. The challenge Mr. Oudendyk throws out to the U. N. and the United States would presumably be answered by them.
Brooklyn Botanic Garden Week opened yesterday, a little late this year.
CINCINNATI, May 1 (AP) -- Baseball Commissioner A. B. Chandler suspended Leo Durocher from baseball last Friday as a safety measure following an alleged altercation with a fan, it was learned today.

MOUNT WASHINGTON, N. H., May 1 (AP) -- A skier tentatively identified as Dr. Paul H. Schiller, 40 years old, or Orange Park, Fla., slipped and fell into a 100-foot crevice atop the headwall of Tuckerman Range, Mount Washington, today.

Prices of cotton for future delivery continued last week to fluctuate irregularly, but the general tendency was to improve, especially in the more distant months. At the week's end active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net gains of 4 to 47 points, compared with changes ranging from a decline of 5 points to an advance of 29 points in the previous week.
DETROIT, May 1 -- Henry A. Wallace, leader of the Progressive party, assailed the North Atlantic treaty today as "a pact of destruction."

PARIS, May 1 -- Charles de Gaulle addressed the May Day workers' festival in the Bois de Boulogne today and furiously attacked the Allied plan for Germany adopted by the three Western powers in Washington.

COGNAC, France, April 25 -- Despite their austerity policy the British are buying far more cognac than the Americans, according to producers of that distinguished liqueur, long an important French export. Venezuela appears to rank third, after the British and the Americans, as a purchaser of this town's single product while continental Europe is almost gone as a market for it.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls during the period April 23 to 29 are given in the appended tabulation:

WASHINGTON, May 1 (UP) -The Federal Trade Commission today accused the Bond Stores, Inc., of operating two bogus "missing heirs" agencies to catch unsuspecting customers who fail to meet their clothing bills.

PHILADELPHIA, May 1 (AP) -- The Athletics took both ends of a double-header from Washington today, winning the seven-inning second game, 7--3, as Hank Majeski and Mike Guerra pounded home runs. The rookie left-hander, Alex Kellner, was the winner in the contest halted because of the Pennsylvania Sunday blue law.
Pause before swallowing a pill the next time your head aches. There may be trouble all right but there is a chance it is as much psychological as physical.

Pound sterling milled about in nervous fashion last week as it reacted to a fresh crop of devaluation rumors which centered in the markets of Tuesday and Wednesday. However, a late-week summation of the sterling situation by the National Foreign Trade Council forced a change in sentiment, once again, followed by an upward recoil in values canceling out earlier losses.

A new concept of metropolitan life and growth, designed to recapture some of the quiet pleasures of the small town and suburbs for families whose homes are within the shadow of skyscrapers, has been worked out by the Community Service Society for the guidance of the City Planning Commission in its broad rezoning and re-development program for New York.

BERLIN, May 1 -- This was a day given over to uninhibited oratory and the brassy strains of the "Internationale" in the Soviet sector, but only one sound and one sight stirred the watchers on the sidewalks. This was the rhythmic beat of the boots of 5,000 uniformed East zone police.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 1 -- An air-raid alert was sounded in Jerusalem tonight when local fighting between Israeli forces and Arabs broke out just below the city. The clash occurred after the Arab Legion had withdrawn to permit Israelis to take over a stretch along the railway, under the terms of the agreement signed at Rhodes between Israel and Jordan.

LONDON, May 1 -- The biggest shop window in the world is the twenty-five miles of exhibitors' stands at the giant British Industries Fair opening here and in Birmingham tomorrow -- and it will be the biggest national trade exhibition ever. It will last through May 13.
Five new films, including an importation from Russia, are slated to arrive in midtown theatres this week. The programs follow:

Before 54,328 fans, the season's largest local crowd, and in their first Sunday at home, the Yankees absorbed their worst beating of the season yesterday, an 11-2 drubbing administered by Joe McCarthy's Red Sox. Three Boston home runs highlighted the assault.

The Florence and Daniel Guggenheim Foundation is making its annual present to the people of Manhattan and Brooklyn in the form of free outdoor concerts by the Goldman Band, Harry F. Guggenheim, foundation president, announced yesterday. The series will open on the Mall in Central Park on June 17.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 1 (AP) -- Herbert Hoover will get the 1948 Humanitarian Award from Variety Clubs International at their thirteenth annual convention opening tomorrow.
Tornadoes roaring through Texas, Oklahoma and Kansas Saturday night left nine persons dead and eighty-five injured in their destructive wakes, The Associated Press reported last night.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 1 -- As sure an indication of spring as can be found on the Princeton University campus will be the appearance this week of the beer-jacketed senior class vocalizing from the steps of Nassau Hall.

LONDON, May 1 -- Although not actually depressed, the stock markets remained last week in the dull rut that has held them for some time. The city does not feel at all happy about the business outlook, while current political events are scarcely calculated to inspire confidence in the view of most people.
TEANECK, N. J., May 1 -- Mrs. Ethel Gallagher has been blind for thirteen years but she is regarded as one of this community's most useful citizens.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange in April was smaller than in the previous month and was the dullest for an April since 1944. Sales crossed the million-share mark in only one session, when the turnover amounted to 1,304,610 shares on April 21.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) -- A Roman Catholic group said today that the present United States policy toward China abandons most of the Chinese people "to the destruction of their fundamental rights and freedoms."

TORONTO, May 1 (Canadian Press) -- Shareholders of Ebro Irrigation and Power Company, Ltd., at a meeting here yesterday passed a resolution stating that seizure of the company's assets in Spanish bankruptcy proceedings is unjustified and unlawful.

The Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, which is getting used to being picketed over other people's disagreements, will be picketed today by representatives of 6,400 striking New York brewery workers. The picketing will be aimed at the annual convention of the United States Brewers Foundation, opening at the hotel this morning.
Plans for doubling output of the Electric Boat Company's post-war developed printing machinery division were disclosed last week by Harold W. Gegenheimer, division manager.

It is now doubtful whether the necessary expansion of exports from the participating countries under the European Recovery Plan can take place as the automatic result of the envisaged expansion of production, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

CHICAGO, May 1 -- Although prices of corn dipped sharply at one time last week on the Board of Trade in sympathy with wheat, there was a fair rally later as the result of continued light country offerings and a belief that it will be some time before there is an increase in farmer selling.

LONDON, May 1 -- The centenary of the founding of Harrod's, largest department store in the British Isles, will be celebrated here tomorrow in the presence of the Lord Mayor of London. To mark the occasion, the store management has constructed in its Central Hall a replica of the original store, founded in 1849 by Henry Charles Harrod.

A survey of American foundations has disclosed an unwillingness on the part of many to disclose information about their interests, operations and financial status, it was reported yesterday by Raymond T. Rich, chairman of Raymond Rich Associates.

The report in THE TIMES of April 18 that the American radio station in Berlin is soon to cease functioning because of the lack of necessary funds eloquently attests to our short-sightedness. Surely our policy-makers should appreciate the urgent need for this informational medium as a morale builder during the present period of international tension.

BOSTON, May 1 -- The Marshall Plan and military preparedness are essential steps against the encroachment of Russian imperialism, but they are not enough to solve the world's problems, Sean MacBride, Ireland's Minister of External Affairs, warned tonight.

Those wishful thinkers who have suggested that we could (and should) go about doing business as usual with the Chinese Communists may get their eyes opened if there are a few more statements in the vein of the most recent Communist "invitation" for the West to cooperate. The Chinese Communists are doing their best to make us understand what they mean by cooperation.

AMMAN, Jordan, May 1 -- A concerted propaganda effort is being made by certain Governments in the Middle East to create the impression that the United States is a rival of Britain in this area. The issue has been brought to a serious stage by the spread of reports to the effect that the United States favors Syrian opposition to the two Hashemite kingdoms of Jordan and Iraq.
LONDON, May 1 (AP) -- The tennis teams of France, Denmark and South Africa today joined Czechoslovakia and Great Britain as first-round winners in the European Zone Davis Cup eliminations.

BOSTON, May 1 (UP) -- Symphony Hall, where Bostonians stamped their feet and wept last night when Serge Koussevitzky retired as leader of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, was transformed into a vast banquet hall today for a public testimonial to the noted conductor.

The appeal for reinstatement of James Kutcher, legless war veteran who was ousted from his Government job for membership in the Socialist Workers party, has been denied by the Loyalty Review Board, it was disclosed yesterday.
Burglars who wet their whistle while they worked forced a safe early yesterday in the basement of a bar and grill at 246-248 Canal Street, a cork-pop from Police Headquarters.

The first American Conference for Hebrew and Language and Culture, closing a two-day session yesterday, adopted a comprehensive program for widespread dissemination of the Hebrew language and culture in this country, aimed at teaching Hebrew to 1,000,000 Jews.

Listening to Tina Leser, recently returned from a three and a half month trip around the world, is like rubbing Aladdin's lamp, for before the interviewer's eyes rise pictures of fabulous faraway lands. Nor are they just verbal images.

CHICAGO, May 1 -- Seeding of oats is virtually completed in all sections of the country with the winter variety expected to start to be harvested in the Southwest in about a month. The crop in the Central West is reported as coming up to a good stand as there has been ample moisture in this section of the country.

Another crowded week in the metropolitan art world brings the usual variety of one-man and group shows. Of special interest among today's openings are that of paintings by the veteran French artist, Raoul Dufy, at the Niveau Gallery; "Desert Paintings" by John Ferren at Kleeman; and water colors by Arthur G. Dove at the Downtown Gallery.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The Government will answer tomorrow the big question for 14,000,000 renters: Does the new law let my rent go up?

BURBANK, Calif., May 1 -- The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation announced here today that the Civil Aeronautics Administration has permitted increases of as much as 5,000 pounds in the payload of the four-engined Constellation plane. Translated into terms of passenger revenue, the company said this would add as much as $2,800,000 a year to the gross of each such ship making a weekly round trip between New York and London.

With thirty-four welfare, civic and religious organizations throughout the city cooperating, Goodwill Week officially gets under way today and will continue until May 8, during which time New York's citizens will be asked to donate used or unwanted personal and household commodities to Goodwill Industries of New York, Inc., a nonprofit, interfaith and interracial organization dedicated to the training and employment of physically and mentally handicapped persons.

DETROIT, May 1 -- A minimum of 2,000,000 more sales people are needed to keep the country's production at a prosperity level, Walter C. Ayers, a director of the Detroit Sales Executives Club and executive vice president of Brooke, Smith, French Dorrance, Inc., New York and Detroit advertising agency, said here today.
MOSCOW, May 1 -- A spectacular display of Soviet jet aircraft, including a new MIG that Radio Moscow described as "the fastest plane in the world," marked impressive May Day ceremonies in Red Square.

Making the most optimistic statement on the current Soviet-American conversations, Dr. Evatt, President of the General Assembly of the United Nations, has declared that there is now every reason to anticipate the ending of the long protracted and most dangerous Berlin dispute and the early lifting of the blockade.

Eighteen hundred Schrafft employes, their families and friends filled the grand ballroom of the Commodore Hotel yesterday for the group's tenth annual communion breakfast after mass at Holy Innocents Church, 128 West Thirty-seventh Street.
ALBANY, May 1 -- Governor Dewey said at a news conference today that this year's session of the State Legislature was "the most constructive" of the seven that had been held since he became Governor.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 1 (UP) -- Gen. Hoyt S. Vandenberg, Air Force Chief of Staff, said tonight that a forty-eight-group air armada could do no more than guarantee "prevention of an early defeat" and bring hope of "eventual" victory.

The French have many sauces and one religion, the old saying goes, and Americans many religions and one sauce. The national favorite is, of course, the milk thickened with butter and flour that goes by the name of white sauce.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The high point of the debate in the House on repeal of the Taft-Hartley Act will come Tuesday when Speaker Sam Rayburn goes to the floor to state how far Administration forces are willing to go toward stiffening proposals for a new labor law.

Twelve-year-old Louise Barba of 798 East 170th Street, the Bronx, received the Paddy Reilly Hero Medal yesterday for her "heroism in rescuing six puppies, three kittens and a parrot" from a store fire two weeks ago. The presentation was made at the annual Greenwich Village Humane League pet show, held in front of the league's office at 57 Eighth Avenue.
The Rev. Dr. John Howard Melish of Holy Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church in Brooklyn is a patient in Long Island College Hospital, it was learned yesterday.

When one considers how quickly man has been known to rise to defend his feathered friends against harm, the recent warning by the National Audubon Society that the improper use of DDT and other powerful new insecticides is killing off birds, bees and other useful creatures at an appalling rate seems to have been received with surprisingly few expressions of concern.

One billion fewer yards of cotton cloth will be produced in the first six months of 1949 than were turned out by the mills in the corresponding period in 1948, it was predicted over the week-end by W. Ray Bell, president of the Association of Cotton Textile Merchants of New York.

BUENOS AIRES, May 1 -- President Juan Peron, in a traditional address for the opening of Congress, expressed today the determination of his regime to take over all public services now in private hands. He said he would prefer to do so through agreement with the present owners, but would do so through expropriation "when necessary."

Condemnation of Communist tactics at home and abroad was voiced yesterday by Vice President Alben W. Barkley, Cardinal Spellman and Msgr. Fulton J. Sheen before a rain-swept crowd of 30,000 at the Polo Grounds.

J. R. Williston Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange, have announced that the business of Arrowsmith, Post Welch, now dissolved, has been consolidated with theirs and that of F. Donald Arrowsmith and John H. Welch will be admitted as general partners.

Housewives and career women -- 1,500 of them -- have stopped looking wistfully at the handwrought silver and textiles, the pottery, jewelry and cabinetwork of well-known craftsmen and set about turning out their own at the Craft Students League, 745 Tenth Avenue.

PARIS, May 1 -- Following readjustment of monetary parities on April 27, gold and currencies have somewhat recovered. Up to April 5 the decline that had been going on for three months had not been Interrupted. Gold and currencies that day hit the lowest level.

The serious problems involved in the forthcoming negotiations for a new coal wage agreement should not be obscured by the maneuvering between the Southern Coal Producers Association and John L. Lewis over the time and place of negotiations. The effort by the Southern producers to win a tactical advantage over Mr. Lewis by forcing separate recognition of their association has had exactly the kind of result one would expect.

DETROIT, May 1 (AP) -- Dick Wakefield's three-run homer in the first inning gave the Tigers a 3-2 victory over Pitcher Bob Lemon and the Indians today. Lemon hurled a two-hitter while winning pitcher, Hal Newhouser, was touched for eight blows.

VIENNA, May 1 -- A statement by Chancellor Leopold Figl that, unless the current London negotiations resulted in a peace treaty for Austria, his Government would insist that the Austrian treaty issue go before the projected Big Four Foreign Ministers' conference and have priority over the German question, Stood out in today's May Day celebrations here.

CINCINNATI, May 1 (AP) -- Pittsburgh and Cincinnati divided a doubleheader today and the Pirates' 10-4 opening-game triumph knocked the Reds out of first place in the National League. The Reds won the rain-marred nightcap, 5 -- 2.

The charge of Abraham Kaplan, campaign manager for Municipal Court Justice Benjamin Shalleck, Democratic candidate for Representative in the Twentieth Congressional District, that Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. was using his position as chairman of the Committee for the First Anniversary of the State of Israel for political purposes was denounced yesterday as "a serious error in judgment."

The influence of the American administrators of ECA on the changing pattern of Europe is one aspect of the Marshall Plan that has not been sufficiently noted. They are at work in every country receiving American aid, advising, inspecting, passing on projects, allocating funds. Nothing quite like these economic missionaries has ever been let loose on the world.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The International Refugee Organization announced today that shipping space has been provided for 10,153 displaced persons to sail for this country in May. This rate was described as satisfactory by officials of the agency.

The five-story apartment house for thirty families at 2027-29 Bathgate Avenue, the Bronx, was sold by the General Synod of the Reformed Church in America to the Ceber Realty Company in a deal arranged by Max Marks and the Eugene J. Busher Company, brokers.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 1 -- Yugoslavia's military and moral preparedness was driven home today to diplomatic and military representatives of foreign powers, including those of the Soviet Union and its satellite states, by a mammoth parade.
Although yesterday was her day off, Mrs. Madeline McGarry, a clerk in the Lost Property Bureau at Police Headquarters, was not able to escape her work.

TOKYO, May 1 -- Hundreds of thousands of workers marked the May Day celebration today with demonstrations in the major Japanese cities calling for the overthrow of the conservative Government of Premier Shigeru Yoshida and attacking the Allied policy of aid in the economic rehabilitation of Japan.
BERLIN, May 1 -- Major educational reforms designed to make the German school program more democratic are now under way in all the states within the American zone, a survey made here shows.

COLUMBIA, Mo., May 1 -- Four pictures by photographers for THE NEW YORK TIMES were named among the best-of-show prints in the sixth annual News Pictures of the Year competition, sponsored jointly by the University of Missouri School of Journalism and Encyclopaedia Britannica Book of the Year.

BOSTON, May 1 -- The Giants plowed into the Braves with great fervor today, but the recoil was something for which neither the Polo Grounders nor their leader pro tem, the venerable Frank Francis Frisch, seemed fully prepared.

The approach to the final step of formal approval of the application by the Arnold Bernstein Line, Inc., for an operating and a construction subsidy, in connection with a passenger and cargo service between New York and Antwerp and Rotterdam, was taken over the week-end by the Maritime Commission in ruling that present American-flag steamship service on the route is anadequate.
Want a maid? The State Labor Department says it is easier to get one now than it has been since the early days of World War II.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 1 -- The two-day conference at Yale of Young Republicans from Eastern colleges ended today with a talk by Representative Hugh D. Scott Jr., Republican national chairman, in which he characterized the Democratic party as "the party of privilege on the Potomac."
