Boredom is the "most dreaded" of all modern diseases, the Rev. Dr. Robert J. McCracken, pastor of Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street, said yesterday in his sermon.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- State and local governments had record payrolls of $795,000,000 in October, the Census Bureau reported today. The total of state, county and city employes also reached a new high of almost 4,000,000, or about twice the total of Federal employes outside the armed forces.

NEWARK, N. J., May 1 -- Adventure, the chestnut gelding that finished on top for Mrs. E. Cooper Person's Upperville, Va., Llangollen Farm at the National last November, glittered again in the metropolitan area tonight by taking the conformation hunter championship of the annual Newark Horse Show at Essex Troop Armory.

PITTSBURGH, May 1 -- If there was any doubt that the steel industry in general was back to a normal and competitive market it was gone last week. Most companies here and in other areas have been "selling" steel over the last several weeks.

The drafting of fourth-round collective bargaining programs will be completed in all the country's principal basic industries this week. Unions representing 3,000,000 workers in steel, coal, automobiles and electrical manufacturing will be in the field for higher wages, shorter work-weeks and employer-financed welfare programs.

Congress made its first real move at the end of last week to do something about Government economy. In the House all of the money bills coming out of the Appropriations Committee thus far have been duly passed. But when the first such bill came to the Senate floor on Thursday, that body did something it had not previously done since 1932.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, May 1 -- The Soviet Union's drive against Zionism, which has also extended into the countries under Moscow's control, now appears to be developing into what is at least a minor anti-Semitic -- as distinct from an anti-Zionist -- trend.

In an attempt to find basic causes of anti-social behavior in young persons brought before the city's magistrate's courts, a psychiatric clinic will be opened today in the Criminal Courts Building, 100 Centre Street.

The New York City Opera Company last night closed its sixth and most successful spring season. The box office report showed that its business exceeded by 3 per cent the business done at the City Center last spring when the opera attendance began to reach the near-capacity mark.

The Jewish Agency for Palestine announced yesterday that it had organized a committee to eliminate "unauthorized and illegitimate" fund-raising cmapaigns. The action was taken to establish the United Jewish Appeal as the central fund-raising group in this country in behalf of Israel.

In a lower Manhattan purchase for occupancy, the eleven-story loft building at 4 and 6 Washington Place, corner of Mercer Street, has been acquired by the Stylebuilt Frame Company, manufacturer of picture frames, from Clara Rosenfeld and others.

NORFOLK, Va., May 1 (AP) -- The carrier Midway disembarked its feminine cargo today, and thus ended a Navy headache. But the ladies, Representatives Reva Beck Bosone and Chase Going Woodhouse, and Mrs. May Craig, a newspaper woman, were a little indignant that their presence on the flat-top's week-end cruise had caused such a hullabaloo.

PATERSON, N. J., May 1 -- Parents and their children go to school together in an unusual project maintained in Passaic County by members of Elks lodges in Paterson, Passaic and Clifton. Back of the special endeavor is one of the greatest human tragedies -- cerebral palsy.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 1 -- Arab states must unite in a federation to save themselves from the threats of communism and Zionism, Fadil Jamali, Foreign Minister of Iraq, declared today. He said that Iraq neither wished to dominate nor be dominated by Syria or any other neighbor, but he saw a formal federation as a vital and urgent need.

Jewish centers are in an unparalleled position to provide leadership in American Jewish communities, Frank L. Weil, chairman of President Truman's Committee on Religion and Welfare for the Armed Services, said yesterday.

SALT LAKE CITY, May 1 -- Although touring companies are infrequent in Salt Lake City, the community has a long tradition of devotion to the theatre and has settled down to a workable local program. This season Broadway has provided two or three performances each of "Carousel," "Born Yesterday," Judith Anderson in "Medea" and Maurice Evans in "Man and Superman" -- all at $4.40 for the best seats.

The Philadelphia Nationals, having qualified for the national cup finals a week ago, gained their second objective, yesterday, at Sterling Oval by winning the Lewis Cup competition, sponsored by the American Soccer League.

The four-story and six-story apartment houses with a total of thirty families at 227-29 and 231 East Twenty-first Street were purchased by the Estate of Morris B. Baer, Inc., from Herbert K. Goodkind in a deal negotiated by Louis Carreau, Inc., broker.

IRVINGTON, N. J., May 1 -- The housing problem to residents in the vicinity of Chancellor Avenue and Park Place in this municipality is more vexing than to most of the nation. They have seen the framework of a four-story, twenty-seven family apartment house being erected at that intersection and then suddenly stopped last June -- less than half completed.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 1 -- Periodic meetings of the chiefs of state of the eleven countries on the United Nations Security Council -- Kings, Presidents and Premiers -- were formally suggested to the fifty-eight member nations here today as a means to raise the prestige and political level of the world peace organization.

PARIS, May 1 -- Splashing insets of color fagoting, give character to Jacques Griffe's midsummer models, in reality extremely simple. Over tailored pedal pushers and a halter bra in black sailcloth is worn a jacket of many colors. The yoke is black, then comes a band of daffodil, then grass green, then tangerine at the flaring hemline.

LONDON, May 1 -- Prime Minister Attlee and his principal deputy and chief party strategist, Herbert Morrison, set the line today for the Labor party's campaign for re-election in 1950 in separate May Day speeches.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (UP) -- The first of about twenty agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, most of whom reportedly "shadowed" Judith Coplon to her meetings with a married Soviet engineer, are scheduled to testify tomorrow at her espionage trial.

Sorry, indeed, was the Dodgers' week-end at home. It wound up yesterday with the Phillies hanging a 4-2 knockout on the chins of Burt Shotton's lads, who dropped their third in a row and the darkness that enveloped Ebbets Field was not altogether caused by the weather, because the sun never shines on the second division.
CHICAGO, May 1 (AP) -- Harry (The Cat) Brecheen scattered thirteen hits to coast in behind a fifteen-hit attack by the Cardinals to defeat the Cubs, 8 to 3, before 24,383 today.

An outbound tanker and a freighter collided last night in a heavy fog near Ambrose Lightship, which marks the entrance to New York Harbor. A large hole was torn in the side of the freighter, the 7,180-ton Jalaketu, inbound from Genoa, Italy, but late reports said she was in no danger of sinking.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., May 1 -- The brigantine Yankee with Capt. Irving Johnson of Hadley, Mass., commanding returned to her home port of Gloucester today after completing a 45,000-mile voyage around the world by the western route. She docked at the Rocky Neck Marine Railways at 2 P. M., eighteen months after she had sailed on Nov. 2, 1947.
PHILADELPHIA, May 1 -- American Jews were urged today to support their own religious and educational institutions as zealously as they extended aid to Jews in Israel and Europe.

The Japanese people observe today, with a national holiday, but with mixed feelings, the second anniversary of their post-war Constitution. This Constitution, adopted with scrupulous observance of the democratic formalities, but actually written and imposed by the Military Government of General MacArthur, was to assure the Japanese nation a new birth in peace and freedom, and in many respects it has been a remarkable success.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) -- The story of how the agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation shadowed Judith Coplon and her alleged Russian sweetheart weeks before their arrest was told today to a jury at Miss Coplon's espionage trial.

LONDON, May 2 -- The new British Gas 3 per cent guaranteed stock burned brightly in the stock market here today when dealings started at a premium of 11-16s. The new stock, redeemable from 1990 to 1995 was in good demand and the price gradually rose to close at 1 1/4 premium in contrast with discounts ruling when dealings started in railway and electricity stocks.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 2 -- The Yugoslav Government is planning to submit a request to the United States Export-Import Bank for a loan in excess of $20,000,000.

Jacob A. Riis was born in Denmark a hundred years ago today. He came to New York at the age of 21, and died thirty-five years ago. He had, as his friend Theodore Roosevelt said, "a passion for righteousness" and, it might be added, a gift for making people ashamed of themselves when they deserved to be.

WASHINGTON, Many 2 (AP) -- Rodney M. Lockwood, president of the National Association of Home Builders, estimated today that the Government's plan for 1,050,000 public housing units would cost more than $19,333,000,000.
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The Supreme Court stood today by its 1948 decision against restrictive covenants in residential developments, refusing to hear a new case against Negroes.

WAYNESBORO, Va., May 2 -- Swannanoa, the home of Dr. Walter Russell, sculptor, four miles east of here, was dedicated as a "shrine of beauty" this afternoon by Colgate W. Darden Jr., president of the University of Virginia and former Governor of Virginia.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- James E. Palmer Jr., an assistant attorney general in charge of prosecuting Communist cases uncovered in the Federal loyalty program, was elected president of the Federal Bar Association by acclamation tonight.

DETROIT, May 2 -- The United Automobile Workers, CIO, accused the Ford Motor Company today of slowing its final assembly line speeds last week just before a union investigating committee appeared at the River Rouge plant to verify charges by Local 600 that a speed-up was being imposed.
ST. LOUIS, May 2 (AP) -- An executive of the Missouri Pacific Railroad expressed the fear today that an attempt is under way to wrest control of the road's Gulf Coast Lines from the Mopac trustee.

FRANKFORT, Germany, May 2 -- Cautious authorities pointed out here today that the actual mechanics of lifting the blockade of Berlin are so technical and complicated that Allied and Russian negotiators in the United States may be required to make important decisions on the mode of traffic as well as overall policy.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The first United States negotiator of the North Atlantic defensive treaty interpreted it today as offering to its European members no absolute and unconditional guarantee of instant American action even if they were invaded in force.
WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today that Government support prices for this year's rye crop will average $1.20 a bushel compared with $1.29 for last year's crop.

A pair of armed Brooklyn holdup men believed to be the same who had staged a series of house robberies in recent weeks enhanced their reputation for polite dealing yesterday and increased their take by $3,000 worth of jewelry.

Manuel Herrarte, 25 - year - old Guatemalan pianist, gave his first New York recital last night at Town Hall. His program included first performances of three dances of his own and a suite of five brief movements by Ricardo Castillo, also of Guatemala.
CHICAGO, May 2 (AP) -- Dr. Halstead G. Murray, an industrial physician, reported today that an antiallergy drug has been found to be effective in controlling symptoms of the common cold.

The Esso Standard Oil Company has sold the eight-story commercial building at 214-16 West Fourteenth Street. The buyer, who is reported planning on occupying a substantial portion of the property, was identified only as a client of David I. Shivitz, attorney.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 2 -- The railway line between Jerusalem and the coastal plain was in Israeli hands today after yesterday's southward advance by Israelis to new positions about 200 yards beyond the tracks. The Israeli move was carried out in accordance with an armistice decision.

With the fabric price level still regarded as the major bottleneck in the men's and boys' clothing situation, considerable attention has centered at this time on reports that the woolen mills plan to open their spring (1950) lines earlier than usual.

PARIS. May 2 -- Before departing for London to attend the conference on the European union, Foreign Minister Robert Schuman today declared that he expected to learn before the end of this week that a four-power meeting on Germany was imminent.

The Alleghany Corporation soon will offer to exchange some of its holdings of Chesapeake Ohio Railway common stock for about 50 per cent of its outstanding prior-preferred shares and about 10 per cent of the Series A preferred shares, according to a letter sent to stockholders by Allan P. Kirby, president of Alleghany.
Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a decline of 3 per cent in April, compared with the same month last year, according to the survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Knox County, Tenn., announced yesterday that it would receive bids June 1 on issues of bonds totaling $3,675,000. The borrowing will consist of $3,175,000 of school bonds due from 1950 to 1969 and $500,000 of bridge bonds due from 1950 to 1969 and callable in 1961.

Appointment of two Fiberglas executives as corporate vice presidents and a third as a divisional vice president was announced in Toledo, Ohio, yesterday by Harold Boeschenstein, president of Owens - Corning Fiberglas Corporation.

BOSTON, May 2 -- Tighe E. Woods said today that he would need 1,500 additional employes nationally to help landlords fill out an expected "flood" of petitions for rent increases. He added that he was aware the agency already was suffering from payless days while awaiting a deficiency appropriation.

The 150,000th soldier's body to be returned to this country under the Army War Dead Program will be among the 5,319 arriving here tomorrow aboard the transport Haiti Victory, it was announced yesterday by the New York Port of Embarkation.

BERLIN, May 2 -- Bavarian nationalist monarchism has emerged as a strong factor in the struggle for West German acceptance of a federal German republic. The leaders of the Separatist Bavarian party over the week-end pledged support of the idea of Bavarian autonomy and threatened to break with any centralized German state whether it was sponsored by the Western powers or by all four occupying nations.

Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, admitted yesterday that he was investigating six teachers regarding membership in the Communist party but denied charges that he was conducting a "witch hunt."

Most domestic steamship lines face the loss of their city pier permits by June 30 unless they designate authorized pier loaders meantime, it was declared yesterday by John M. Murtagh, Investigation Commissioner.

Soviet economists are going to make another effort this year and next to produce an official textbook on political economy as it is now viewed by Stalinist-Leninist ideologists, it became known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The Senate, by a vote of 68 to 11, killed a plan today under which a proposed $300,000,000 a year Federal aid to education fund would be distributed uniformly among all states, whether they were "rich" or "poor."

Former Acting Mayor Joseph V. McKee, long an enemy of Tammany Hall and a close friend of Edward J. Flynn, Bronx Democratic leader, was sworn in yesterday by Mayor O'Dwyer as New York City Commissioner of Commerce, a dollar-a-year position.

Not until the formula announced by the office of Tighe E. Woods, the Housing Expediter; has been applied to actual operating experience will it be possible to determine whether it assures landlords "fair net operating income," Walter La M. Sparry, vice president of the Real Estate Board of New York, said last night.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The office of the Housing Expediter ruled today that even the largest landlords were entitled to keep at least 20 per cent of gross operating income under the fair net operating income provision of the new rent control law.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The aviation business probably could turn its losses into a profit by lowering fares by 25 per cent and thereby extending its market, a leading executive told a Senate Commerce subcommittee today.
" Spring Clean-Up Weeks" opened yesterday with city employes and citizens active in all parts of the city in an effort to brighten the city's appearance.

BUFFALO, May 2 -- Top-ranking officers of the Medical Society of the State of New York sounded an impassioned "call to arms" against Federal health insurance plans here today at the opening of the annual meeting of the society in the Statler Hotel.

BAGHDAD, May 2 -- Iraq is inaugurating a drive to strengthen the Arab states by a revision of the Arab League statutes to produce closer and more effective cooperation on policy, an authoritative source said today.

MADRID, May 2 (AP) -- Reliable sources said today that Spain had begun negotiations for a loan from the United States Export-Import Bank in Washington. Although Spain has not mentioned any amount in the negotiations, she wants about $200,000,000 for reconstruction and rehabilitation projects.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 2 -- A proposal that 1,000 longshoremen be dropped from the registration list of Local 10 of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, CIO, for a period of four months as a move to increase employment and wages here will be made at a "stop work" meeting on Wednesday by James Kearney, president, and other officers of the local.

Hugh D. Scott Jr., chairman of the Republican National Committee, yesterday expressed his confidence in the campaign of William H. McIntyre, Republican candidate for Congress in the three-cornered contest being waged in the Twentieth Congressional District of Manhattan.

They sound exotic, and they are Cherimoyas, pitayas and granadillas are their names. Avianca Airline has flown in about two dozen each of these foreign fruits from Bogota, Colombia, for the benefit dinner to be given tonight by the trustees of the Brooklyn
WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) -- The volume of installment credit, reversing a two-month downtrend, swung up in March after the first of two relaxations in credit control terms by the Federal Reserve Board.

The United Nations General Assembly voted yesterday to shift both Israel's application for membership and the Indonesian dispute from the overloaded Political Committee to the idle Ad Hoc Committee for prompt action on the two controversial issues.

Thankful for all that has been done in the effort to bring vision to their seven-month-old twins, blind since birth, Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Hoffman of New Orleans and their two infants will leave for home this morning by airplane from La Guardia Airport, Queens.

A slight, fair-haired boy of 9 took the witness stand yesterday in General Sessions to testify against his mother, who had been accused of burning his hand so severely over a gas flame that part of his little finger had to be amputated.

Argentine subsidiaries of American Foreign Power Company, Inc., are using every legal means possible in their fight against the government's policy of expropriation of public utilities, W. S. Robertson, president of American Foreign Power, advised stockholders in his annual report yesterday.

Mrs. Anita McCormick Blaine, 83-year-old Chicago philanthropist, was disclosed yesterday as the backer of a New York daily newspaper, The Compass, that is scheduled to make its appearance here in the next two weeks.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 2 -- In a revision of its plans for pre-Derby scrimmaging, Fred W. Hooper's stable has entered both the "flying colts," Olympia and Ocean Drive, in tomorrow's $10,000 added Derby Trial over the mile course at Churchill Downs.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., May 2 -- Isolation from mammalian tissues of a substance that activates a clot-dissolving factor in the blood plasma and plays an important role in maintaining the consistency of the blood in proper balance, was reported here today.
J. J. Samuels has been named head of purchasing of specialty products for Tele-tone Radio Corporation. He was formerly director of purchasing for Bendix home radio and television division.

State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein started action in Supreme Court yesterday to enjoin the six trustees of Sailors Snug Harbor from charging 375 aged and disabled seamen for their maintenance at the charitable institution's Staten Island home.
WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) -- The office of the Housing Expediter issued tonight the following news release announcing rental adjustment policy under the new Federal Rent Control Act:

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- President Truman told a group of farm radio program directors today that he had "a policy in mind" to assure a fair share of the national income to labor and industry as well as to farmers. What the policy was or how it would be worked out was not disclosed.

A new high record in sales and earnings was established by the City Stores Company and its subsidiaries in the fiscal year ended on Jan. 31, according to the annual report to be released today. Sales of $168,104,985 increased 8.6 per cent over the $154,795,916 volume of the preceding year.

Today's radio audience might be increased by more than a third if programs included soothing, cheering, human interest and personalizing elements, according to a survey of the listening habits of nearly 3,000 women in New York, Chicago and Kansas City.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The Democratic House leadership took the bit in its teeth tonight and decided to offer tomorrow a substitute for the Wood labor relations bill, which labor regards as "almost as bad as the Taft-Hartley law." The substitute will contain six major concessions to the Wood bill advocates.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 2 -- With one hundred booths overflowing with antiques, the Eastern States Antiques Fair opened this afternoon at the Westchester County Center. Hours are 1 to 11 P.M. daily except Saturday, the last day, when the fair will close at 6 P. M.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., May 2 -- Bishop Fred Pierce Corson of Philadelphia, president of the Board of Education of the Methodist Episcopal Church, tonight blamed pagan parents and not young people for the present disorder of society.

Civic leaders decried yesterday the fact that for the first time in sixty years New York has no private institution where judges can send emotionally disturbed Protestant girls who come into conflict with the law.

Leo Durocher, flanked by the official Giants' family, including Horace Stoneham, Garry Schumacher and Eddie Brannick, flew to Cincinnati late yesterday, aboard an American Air Lines plane. All were confident that Durocher would be completely exonerated of the charge that he struck a fan last week.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) -- A proposal for a Congressional investigation of the life insurance industry was approved today by the Senate Judiciary Committee. The resolution would authorize a $100,000 fact-finding study to be made by a joint Senate-House committee.
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- President Truman spent a half hour in Union Station today looking over a medical exhibit that the Veterans Administration had set up in the huge concourse.

Two of four men alleged to have mugged a 59-year-old church custodian early yesterday morning later were captured, after an automobile and foot chase of a dozen blocks that ended on the roof of a building on Avenue of the Americas and Fifty-seventh Street.

How the Americans and the British met the Russian blockade of Berlin with their joint airlift is shown in a collection of photographs that went on display yesterday in the north corridor of the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.

PEEKSKILL, N. Y., May 2 -- Following one of the most spirited campaigns in local school history, an election will be held tomorrow to fill three unsalaried positions on the Board of Education. There are eight candidates for the three posts, which heretofore have been difficult to fill.

Arthur Miller's "Death of a Salesman" won the Pulitzer Prize yesterday as the best American play of the 1948-49 season and Robert E. Sherwood received the biography prize for his "Roose velt and Hopkins." The award for the best novel by an American author went to "Guard of Honor," by James Gould Cozzens.

The current building up of more and better cooperative advertising was said by key advertising sources yesterday to be the forerunner of further increasing volume. Growing interest in cooperative campaigns by manufacturers was cited also as reflecting a more determined effort toward harder competitive pushing at the point of sale.

The past week-end gave the Catskill trout fishermen clear streams, excellent water temperatures and plenty of sunlight, but the fly hatches were very thin, and those who persisted with the dry fly received a scant reward for their efforts.

In sulphurous language, City Councilman Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, paid his respects yesterday to the Citizens Budget Commission for suggesting that the revenue of the municipal transit system would not be sufficient to support higher wages for the members of Mr. Quill's union this year.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (UP) -- Senator Elmer Thomas, Democrat, of Oklahoma, Chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee, today introduced an Administration bill which would give the Government wide control over futures trading on the nation's commodity exchanges.
DETROIT, May 2 -- The Packard Motor Car Company announced price cuts today ranging from $103 to $246 on six of its Golden Anniversary models.

SHANGHAI, Tuesday, May 3 -- The Communist radio said tonight that one Communist army column had reached Kimen, in Anhwei Province and joined with Communist guerrillas already operating in that hilly area 200 miles southwest of Nanking.

CINCINNATI, May 2 -- Emphasizing that the big question of 1949 is not whether business generally will be good but what industries and companies are going to make the most of the situation, Ross D. Siragusa, president and chairman of the board of the Admiral Corporation, outlined a six-point selling program for the electrical industry here today.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The poll tax was characterized as a "fascist racket in complete defiance of American democratic principles" as public hearings began today on one important aspect of the civil-rights program so strongly supported by President Truman.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- A committee to promote public understanding of the International Trade Organization was formed here today. William L. Batt, president of SKF Industries, Inc., Philadelphia, was named chairman.

A 15-year-old good-will ambassador from Mexico, Javier Najera Torres, arrived in this country yesterday for a two-week visit. Mayor O'Dwyer welcomed him at City Hall with a big hug and excellent Spanish.

WEST POINT, N. Y., May 2 -- An infield error and a wild pitch in the tenth inning enabled the Dodgers to come from behind and nip Army, 4 to 3, in their annual exhibition game at Doubleday Field today.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The United States Supreme Court today unanimously reversed a decision of the Federal District Court of Rhode Island which had barred the use of documents in a civil anti-trust suit which had originally been subpoenaed for a criminal action.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 2 (AP) -- Bolivians engaged in sporadic gun battles today and the Government declared a state of siege.

New York State insurance payments to unemployed workers are running nearly twice as high this year as they were a year ago. Statistics made public last night by Edward Corsi, State Industrial Commissioner, showed that job insurance payments in the period from Jan. 1 to April 22 were $46,892,190 higher than in the same period last year.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The Supreme Court today upheld the convictions of Harvey Stemmer and David Krakower, who were sentenced to serve five to ten years each for offering bribes to two members of the New York Giants, a professional football team.
Sketches of the winners of the Pulitzer awards follow:

TOKYO, May 2 -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur promised the Japanese today a further relaxation of occupation controls and said Japan's continued occupation was caused by international "events and circumstances."
Prices on the New York Stock Exchange fluctuated irregularly yesterday in quiet trading. Changes in either direction were small, with some of the chemical shares showing the most strength.

Frank J. Taylor, president of the American Merchant Marine Institute, said yesterday that the demands of the National Maritime Union, CIO, contained in a proposed contract to replace one expiring June 15, would cost the shipping operators involved more than $17,000,000 a year.
Joset Walker, designer of sportswear and town clothes, has placed the unmistakable signature that is her theory of fashion on each and every piece in her summer collection.

A pick-up in reorders for medium price and better dresses is reflected among converters of rayon fabrics catering to that trade, it was learned yesterday. The market for better grades of novelty fabrics, textile men said, shows considerable stability with the cutters' willingness to order for both nearby and future requirements.

GREAT NECK, L. I., May 2 -- The Long Island Professional Golfer's Association combined business with pleasure today, inaugurating the group's tournament schedule with an amateur-pro event at the Fresh Meadow Country Club during the day and then holding the annual business session at the clubhouse tonight.

BORDEAUX, France, April 28 -- In these days of mass production, mass consumption, state controls, high taxes and "austerity," the ancient art of making fine wines is not a huge financial success. Such is the testimony of those who ought to know, in this region of historic wines lying along the lower Gironde River.
LONDON, May 2 -- With a heavy accent on sales to the United States and Canada, the British Industries Fair, biggest national trade exhibition in the world, opened today.

George La Falgio, 133, Bronx lightweight, scored a spectacular second-round knockout victory over Joey Brocato, 134, East Side, in the scheduled eight-round feature bout at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.

BAD NAUHEIM, Germany, May 2 -- Major educational reforms designed to liberalize higher education and make German universities more democratic are now planned in the American zone, it was learned here today.

BERLIN, May 2 -- The Soviet Union and the United States apparently had reached today a slight but not critical disagreement on the timing of the Council of Foreign Ministers and the lifting of the blockade.

HE was "a man of Lu of obscure origin, who ever accomplished very much while he as alive." He died some 2,500 years ago, a disappointed old man, who had never been granted his dream of political office and so an opportunity to put into practice the ideals of government which he preached to his devoted disciples.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The cruder aspects of politics have become visible in Washington lately with more than customary clarity. They have been openly revealed in their least attractive and most ruthless forms, though at the same time there has been no slackening in negotiations behind the barn door.
WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) -- The Supreme Court refused today to reconsider its recent ruling that states are free to ban the slowdown as a labor union tactic.
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The United States is negotiating with Great Britain for permission to fire supersonic guided missiles across the Bahamas in long-range tests of the weapons of the future.

The news from Washington that fair and wise amendment of the existing Displaced Persons Act is meeting heavy sledding is dismaying. Three and a half years have gone by since President Truman urged the Departments of State, War and Justice to do what they could to expedite the lawful immigration of refugees of the European war to the United States.

ANNECY, France, May 2 -- The prospective relaxation of the blockade between East and West Germany has changed the entire prospect for East-West European trade, in the opinion of experts here and in Geneva.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The net working capital of American corporations, exclusive of banks and insurance companies, increased $4,200,000,000 in 1948 to $64,800,000,000, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.
As was confidently expected by the majority in the crowd of 26,380 fans at Jamaica yesterday, Mrs. Andy Schuttinger's Chestnut colt Ferd streaked home to victory in the $10,000 added Youthful Stakes.

Under a full day of cross-examination at the Communist trial yesterday Miss Angela Calomiris remained unshaken in her testimony that Communists of the United States teach violent revolution in party schools. Instead of backing down in any way, she struck more blows against the defense.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was steady yesterday, holding within a narrow range, and final prices were 2 to 9 points net higher.

Out of the collapse of an ambitious mail-order business operated from Wilmington, Del., and dealing mostly in cigarettes, a Newark bankruptcy receiver has found pouring into his lap a mountain of complaints, cigarette orders and bewildered inquiries from all over the country, and as far away as the Philippines.

With Mother's Day on next Sunday's calendar, city observance of the occasion began here yesterday. Something new was added to the commemoration when Welfare Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard named Mrs. Albert Mikovich "foster mother of the year" and cited eighteen other foster mothers.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Secretary of State Acheson, former Under-Secretary of State Robert A. Lovett and the Senate Foreign Relations Committee are now engaged in an argument that troubled Thomas Jefferson and Alexander Hamilton approximately 148 years ago.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The United Light and Railways Company, Chicago, received permission from the Securities and Exchange Commission today to borrow $19,500,000 from four banks. It proposes to use the funds, together with treasury cash, to redeem its prior preferred stock.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Ratification of the North Atlantic pact and legislation to provide arms for the signatory nations were demanded today by Representative John W. McCormack, Democrat, of Massachusetts, the House majority leader, to halt the ideological and imperialistic moves of Russia.

Charles Van Newkirk, a former merchant marine engineer accused of shooting Ellsworth Buck, former president of the Board of Education, on April 5 in St. George, S. I., was indicted yesterday by the Richmond County grand jury on two counts. They charged first-degree assault and violation of the Sullivan Law.
PHILADELPHIA, May 2 -- About 6,500 employes in twenty - two plants and warehouses of the Philco Corporation remained away from work today to enforce demands for higher wages and a pension plan.
Following is the text of a statewide radio address by Gov. Thomas E. Dewey on the 1949 session of the Legislature, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

CAMDEN, N. J., May 2 -- The Industrial Union of Marine and Ship-building Workers, CIO, announced today a program calling for substantial fourth-round wage increases, a thirty-five-hour week and other benefits.
Raymond Barbas, president of Jean Patou, refused to reveal the coming changes in the fall and winter Paris silhouette.
CHICAGO, May 2 (AP) -- The White Sox today denied that Manager Jack Onslow had slapped a $500 fine on Catcher Joe Tipton for "tipping pitches" against the Browns at St. Louis yesterday, as reported.
The Textile Workers Union, CIO, will mark its tenth anniversary May 14 with the holding of a "convention by radio," Emil Rieve, president of the union, announced yesterday.

NEWARK, N. J., May 2 -- A plan to reorganize Chancellor Park Corporation, which owns an unfinished twenty-seven-apartment building at 831-41 Chancellor Avenue, Irvington, was approved today by Senior Federal Judge Guy L. Fake as having been filed in good faith.

The Bronx Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association, 1511 Fulton Avenue, the Bronx, has just observed a distinguished fortieth anniversary. As the oldest and largest Jewish community center in the Bronx, the organization serves an estimated Jewish population of 750,000.

HOBOKEN, N. J., May 2 -- Stockholders of the United States Steel Corporation approved a proposal to split the common stock three-for-one at their annual meeting here today. They also re-elected five directors and defeated a resolution to shift the site of the annual meeting to New York City.

Bruno Walter and the Philharmonic-Symphony won the "best symphony of the year" citation with their recording of Mahler's Fifth Symphony, it was announced yesterday. It marked the third annual award of the magazine Review of Recorded Music.

There does not seem to be any great let-up in new financing requisitions on the market for tax-exempt bonds. The Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Commission's $141,500,000 refunding operation, which may be released to the market tomorrow. is only the first of a succession of extraordinary transactions facing the municipal bond market in coming weeks.
An exhibition of theatrical mementos will be held May 12 through May 15 at 47B Washington Square South under the auspices of the 1949 Greenwich Village Fresh Air Fund Arts Festival.

Virginia Mishnun's comment in THE TIMES for April 26 that the pending deficiency bill H. R. 2632 enacts "racial discrimination * * * into federal law" is an overexcited misstatement. May I explain the facts?

JACKSON, Miss., May 2 (AP) -- Bob McKee, an announcer for a Jackson radio station, reported on his disk-jockey program last night that "the moon is falling into the sun and the Mississippi River basin is an earthquake danger area."

Kings County Judge Louis Goldstein, in dismissing yesterday a first-degree murder indictment against a 20-year-old defendant, accused District Attorney Miles F. McDonald of being "remiss in his duty" in moving for a charge against the youth.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 2 -- "Make Mine Laughs," a composite film described as "an hour of vaudeville," has been scheduled for production by George Bilson at RKO, the studio announced today. Gil Lamb has been signed to play the master of ceremonies for the film, which Richard Fleischer will direct.

ALBANY, May 2 -- Governor Dewey, in a radio report from the Executive Mansion on the accomplishments of the 1949 session of the Legislature, said tonight that the state, despite its record $936,000,000 budget, was taking in taxes less of the dollar income of the people than it did eight years ago.

The policy of the Western powers toward Spain is the very worst that could be imagined both for Spain and for the Western powers. I shall spare your readers all discussion of the first point. We Spaniards, having committed the abominable crime of civil war, must submit to the historical punishment which that crime entails.
Dr. Walter Consuelo Langsam, president of Wagner Memorial Lutheran College, Stapleton, S. I., is considered a leading candidate for the presidency of Queens College, it was learned last night.

To help city homemakers tidy up their apartments and houses during the spring clean-up weeks that started officially yesterday, the National Board of Fire Underwriters has issued suggestions for doing two jobs at once. They aim not only at a general cleaning but at getting rid of fire hazards.

BOSTON, May 2 -- Dr. Serge Koussevitzky, who retired Saturday after twenty-five years as conductor of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, was honored tonight at a civic dinner in the hall where he rose to international fame.

ROME, May 2 -- The Foreign Ministry today announced early resumption of normal diplomatic relations between Italy and Albania, which have remained interrupted since the end of the war. The Italian Minister in Tirana and the Albanian Minister in Rome are to be appointed in the near future.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 2 (AP) -- Byron Horne, 26-year-old midget race-car driver from Scenery Hill, Pa., was injured critically today in the first accident of the season at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway.

After some eight months of wreaking bloody vengeance on stages from coast to coast, Judith Anderson returned to the City Center last night in her portrayal of "Medea." According to the records, this was Miss Anderson's 501st performance in Robinson

CINCINNATI, May 2 -- Leo Durocher, whose spectacular and at times turbulent career in baseball is believed to be hanging in the balance pending the outcome of his momentous hearing before Commissioner A. B. Chandler tomorrow, may not have to wait long to hear the final verdict.

A leading custom smelter reduced the price of copper to 18 1/2 cents here yesterday, and trade sources stated that other custom smelters were expected to follow. This 1 1/2 cent reduction from the former 20 cent price quoted by custom smelters, now leaves a spread of 5 cents between the price of custom smelters, and 23 1/2 cents quoted by primary producers.

Debate on the bitterly contested issue of labor legislation, suspended last Friday, is scheduled for resumption today. A compromise measure, agreed on by Democratic leaders last night and intended to steer a middle road between the two rival successor bills to the Taft-Hartley Act is now ready to come to the floor.

" The Stratton Story," Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's dramatization of the career of the noted Chicago White Sox pitcher with James Stewart playing Stratton, will have its local premiere at the Radio City Music Hall on Thursday, May 12, it was reported yesterday.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores dropped 9 per cent last week below the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The decline for the four weeks ended last Saturday was 4 per cent.
CHICAGO, May 2 -- The Commission on World Peace of the Methodist Church withheld its support of the North Atlantic treaty today and urged a "calm and objective appraisal" of communism.

Both the 7,180-ton Indian freighter Jalaketu and the 10,172-ton Esso Standard Oil Company leased tanker Marine Leader moved into piers in Brooklyn and New Jersey under their own steam yesterday despite their crash in the harbor fog at 7:15 P. M. on Sunday.

Debate on the bitterly contested issue of labor legislation, suspended last Friday, is scheduled for resumption today. A compromise measure, agreed on by Democratic leaders last night and intended to steer a middle road between the two rival successor bills to the Taft-Hartley Act is now ready to come to the floor.

MONTREAL, May 2 (UP) -- Pentti Lund, 23-year-old Finnish-born right wing of the New York Rangers, today was named winner of the Calder Memorial Trophy as the National Hockey League's outstanding rookie for the 1948-49 season.

Mayor O'Dwyer delivered last night his most calculated snub of Tammany Hall. On the night of the first fund-raising dinner that the Hall has staged in its more than 150 years of existence, the Mayor chose to deliver a lecture on party practices to a newly formed organization dedicated to wiping out Tammany as a political force.

ALBANY, May 2 -- Miss Mary Good Krone, director of the Miscellaneous Tax Bureau of the State Tax Department, said today that the stiffened cigarette tax law would be enforced without employment of "Gestapo" methods.

Cutting classes at New York University does not mean necessarily that students are deserting academic duties because of the spring sunshine. For 220 young men and women it means cutting and splicing films in the only eastern university motion picture department that grants a bachelor of arts degree in movie making.

SEOUL, Korea, May 2 -- President Syngman Rhee today complimented the National Assembly for passage of an Administration-sponsored land reform program that will make it possible for purchase of land by more than 1,000,000 Korean tenant farmers. Mr. Rhee is expected to sign the bill this week.

New Stages, Inc., the downtown producing group, will offer tonight its final production of the season at 159 Bleecker Street. It is Edward Caulfield's new comedy, "Bruno and Sidney." Philip Loeb has directed and Robert Gundlach has designed the scenery.

I note with dismay the facts occasioning the statement of Dr. Harry J. Carman, president of the New York Adult Education Council, decrying the reduction in the Board of Education budget for the purposes of adult education, as reported in THE NEW YORK TIMES of April 17.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The Circuit Court of Appeals here today denied the right of the Civil Aeronautics Board to issue an arbitrary suspension order against an airline, and thereby opened a whole field of new questions in conduct of the nation's airline system.
If you find your waiter recording your conversation on the back of his menu, don't turn him over to the police as an enemy spy. He probably is just gathering material for a book he plans to write.

CHICAGO, May 2 -- In a dispatch today from Springfield, the state capital, George Thiem, a staff writer for The Chicago Daily News, reported that he had discovered "more names of Illinois editors and publishers on the state payroll of former Gov. Dwight H. Green (Republican), swelling the total to thirty-seven and the amount collected to more than $400,000."

LAKE SUCCESS, May 2 -- Representatives of the three Western powers decided today to propose that the Soviet Union raise the blockade of Berlin by the middle of next week and that the Council of Foreign Ministers convene in Paris around May 25 to take up the German question as a whole.

The one grand and glorious occasion for 14,00 of New York's underprivileged children came yesterday morning. They jammed every available seat in Madison Square Garden for a special showing of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus.

Deadline bidding for two new issues of A-rated public utility bonds totaling $5,500,000 was lively among underwriting houses yesterday. In all, seventeen bids were submitted. The bids, moreover, reflected the general willingness of the bond houses to price long-term A-rated public utility credit to yield less than 2.95 per cent to investing institutions.

" The Rise of Russia in Asia," by David J. Dallin, his seventh book to be published here by the Yale University Press, will be brought out on May 18. The book traces Russian expansion in the East from its beginnings under the Czars to 1930.

In a setting of 'spring flowers, a dinner dance was given last night in the Terrace Room of the Plaza in behalf of Friends of Greece, Inc. Proceeds from the fete will be directed to the Pendelis Preventorium for tubercular children in. Athens.
The amiable Prof. Wright Thomas of Cortland, N. Y., has accused either you or me of tampering with the vernacular. This is a grave charge, and I hasten to absolve you of all blame. I am at fault.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 2 -- A British proposal -- laying down four freedoms in the field of information -- was accepted today by the Social Committee of the General Assembly as the first article for a United Nations convention on "freedom of information."

While approximately 600 striking brewery workers picketed the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday, the United States Brewers Association met in the hotel for its annual convention -- the first to be held in this city in ten years.

Wool futures gained yesterday in a day of light trading. Grease wool contracts closed 1/2 cent to 1 cent up in transactions involving 36,000 pounds. Wool-top futures rose 1.5 cents to 2.5 cents on the day's trading, which involved 75,000 pounds.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 2 -- The British delegation to the United Nations General Assembly will probably introduce a resolution tomorrow under which Cyrenaica would be administered by Britain until 1959, and the General Assembly would then decide whether all of Libya should become independent, informed sources said tonight.
The first permanent psychiatric clinic in the magistrate's courts was opened yesterday in the offices of Chief Magistrate Edgar Bromberger in the Criminal Courts Building, 100 Centre Street.

MOSCOW, May 2 -- Marshal Semyon K. Timoshenko, one of the Soviet Union's outstanding commanders in World War II, was reported in dispatches describing the May Day observance at Minsk to have reviewed the parade as commander of the district, which guards Russia's western approaches.

ELIZABETH, N. J., May 2 -- Seven thousand employes, represented by Local 401, United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America, CIO, went on strike at the Singer Manufacturing Company plant today, causing another 2,000 supervisory and non-union workers to be idle, in the first walkout of the seventy-year history of the city's major industry.

Yesterday's Pulitzer Prize announcements contained, as is always the case, some familiar and some unfamiliar names. Few will question the soundness of the drama award to Arthur Miller for his "Death of a Salesman" or of the award in biography to Robert E. Sherwood for his "Roosevelt and Hopkins."

Reporting on operations of the American Viscose Corporation in the quarter ended on March 31, Frank H. Reichel, president and board chairman, informed shareholders at the annual meeting held yesterday in Marcus Hook, Pa., that the net profit was $6,553,000, equal to $3.06 a common share.

The Housing Expediter's "fair net operating return" formula cannot give landlords the relief they need and will produce only "negligible" rises in individual rents, Herbert B. Brill, executive secretary of the Metropolitan Fair Rent Committee, declared last night.

Here for the first time to tour the United States and Canada, with ten appearances in all, twenty-three members of the famous Belfast Celtic Soccer Club of Ireland debarked yesterday from the steamship Mauretania of the Cunard-White Star Line.

Councilman Michael J. Quill, as president of the Transport Workers Union, has a low boiling point and he is now very angry at the Citizens Budget Commission for laying the facts on the line about transit finances. The Budget Commission had only discovered what everybody knows, including Mr. Quill, that revenues from the higher fare are just breaking even with operating expenses.

PHILADELPHIA, May 3 (AP) -- Mixing three hits with three bases on balls and a hit batsman, the Phillies scored six runs in the seventh and defeated the Cardinals, 7 -- 3, tonight, in the first game of their series at Shibe Park.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The House tonight approved the Wood labor relations bill containing the basic features of the Taft-Hartley Act, thus dealing to the Administration and labor leaders a stunning blow. The vote was 217 to 203.
WASHINGTON, May 3 (UP) -- Following is the text of Gen. Omar N. Bradley's statement today on the North Atlantic security pact before the Senate Foreign Relation Committee:

DETROIT, May 3 -- There is no assurance in the declining death rate from tuberculosis that the disease is being wiped out, Dr. Herbert R. Edwards, executive director of the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association, told the annual meeting of the National Tuberculosis Association today.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The American and Foreign Power Company, Inc., New York, was directed today by the Securities and Exchange Commission to reorganize on a basis providing for a single class of common stock and such debt securities as will meet the existing circumstances under the standards of the Public Utility Holding Company Act.

Fog laid a hampering hand on shipping activity in the Port of New York yesterday, delaying the arrival or departure of fifty-one vessels, including the fastest liner in the world, the Cunard White Star's Queen Mary, and three other passenger ships.

In a transaction that is due to create a new educational center in the Gramercy Park district, the Catholic Archbishopric of New York has contracted to purchase the big headquarters buildings of the Russell Sage Foundation at Lexington Avenue and Twenty-second Street, it became known last night.
In his forty-two years with the New York County Division of Jurors, Max G. Neuhauser served thousands of notices from the Battery to Inwood. The other day he received a summons himself.

E. T. Stannard, president of the Kennecott Copper Corporation, told stockholders yesterday at their annual meeting here that he plans to retire at the end of this year after thirty-nine years of service with the company and its subsidiaries. He said he would remain as director and consultant to the corporation.

LONDON, May 3 -- Persistent rumors that the pound sterling might be devalued, rumors that have been denied repeatedly by British officials, were still causing concern in London today, especially because of their effect on the British export drive to North America.
WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The only surprise in President Truman's announcement that he had accepted the resignation of General Lucius D. Clay as United States Military Governor in Germany was its timing.
A St. Louis business man testified at the Communist trial yesterday that he had been a member of the Communist party since 1945 as an undercover agent for the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) -- Senator Edwin C. Johnson, Democrat, of Colorado, said today the Postoffice Department was "not very anxious" to have the confusion over air-mail pay and airline subsidies cleared up.

LONDON, May 3 -- Contracts totaling $40,000,000 for construction of six 40,000-ton tankers, the largest ever to be built, are being negotiated here with five British shipbuilding companies, it was disclosed today by Warren Graham, president of the Graham Shipyards of Oakland, Calif. Mr. Graham is representing the Eagle Oil and Refining Company of Los Angeles, which will eventually own and operate the tankers under the Liberian flag.

Dr. Lowrie J. Porter, president of the American Association of Orthodontists, asked the group yesterday to urge Congress to defeat any legislation containing the principle of compulsory health insurance. The association will act on the proposal at a business session today.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 3 -- Declaring that "an approximation of justice is better than no justice at all," Hector McNeil, head of the British delegation to the General Assembly, today introduced a resolution calling for the independence of Libya in 1959, with Cyrenaica to be administered meanwhile by Britain under a United Nations trusteeship.

Coffee futures were easy on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Prices reacted after the advances of recent days. Scattered long liquidation and profit-taking was absorbed by trade buying. The undertone at the close was steady.

BOSTON, May 3 (AP) -- Right-hander Walt Dubiel, who joined the Cubs in a winter trade, tonight pitched a five-hit shut-out in leading the Chicagoans to a 4-0 victory over the Braves. A crowd of 15,096 saw only one of the Tribesmen reach third base.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 3 -- Israel's application for membership in the United Nations withstood strong attempts by Pakistan today to have the discussion before the Ad Hoc Political Committee buried in the committee's agenda and to have the Security Council's recommendation for admission declared invalid.

DETROIT, May 3 (AP) -- The Tigers and Red Sox scored fourteen runs apiece in regulation time but were unable to get a run across in the extra innings as their marathon contest went into the record books as a 14-14 tie in thirteen innings today.

VIENNA, May 3 -- The Austrian Government announced tonight that negotiations with the International Refugee Organization over the vexing question of who is to pay expenses of DP's in Austria had laid the basis for a compromise satisfactory to both sides and that this compromise had been approved at a sitting of the Cabinet today.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, May 3 -- Miltiades Porphyrogenis, Minister of Justice of the "Free Democratic Government of the Greek Mountains," announced here today his government was willing to negotiate peace with "the Monarcho-Fascists" of Athens and would welcome the appointment of a United Nations mediator similar to Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, Mediator for Palestine.

At their shrine of art in Bleecker Street the forward-looking people of New Stages are producing one of the dampest whiz-bangs of the season. It is Edward Caulfield's "Bruno and Sidney," which scurried hopefully around the stage last evening.
The first anniversary of Israel's independence will be observed in New York today.

Sam Lipshitz bought the forty-four-family building at 1384 Grand Concourse, the Bronx, from Mrs. Annie Birnbach and gave in part the forty-one-family house at 2088 Mohegan Avenue. The transaction was negotiated by Pearce Mayer, brokers.
BERLIN, May 3 -- Announcement today of the retirement by May 15 of General Clay has shaken the American colony in Berlin and in the United States zone of occupation.

A leading case-goods manufacturer has brought out a new line of bedroom furniture at prices 5 to 10 per cent below previous quotations, a well known retail furniture source reported yesterday. Aside from closeouts, the reduc- tion marks the first post-war fur- niture price cut by a major pro- ducer, it was said.

Earnings reports of industrial corporations thus far available for the first quarter of this year, in general make a better showing than had been expected, according to the Monthly Letter of the National City Bank of New York, to be published today.
CAMDEN, N. J., May 3 (AP) -- New Jersey's 142-day racing season opened today with Hal Price Headley's Plumper whipping the highly regarded Mr. Ace in the six-furlong feature at Garden State.
TETERBORO, N. J., May 3 -- Mrs. Vera B. Martucci was elected tonight Mayor of this borough of forty inhabitants by her colleagues on the Council. One of the colleagues was her husband, James.

Transport Workers Union officials announced last night that 4,000 employes of the Third Avenue Transit Corporation would strike at 4 A. M., Monday, in protest over the company's dismissal of two bus drivers and "failure to comply" with a recent Public Service Commission order to improve service.
A report describing the "pattern" of religious suppression in Russian satellite countries was made public yesterday by the American Jewish Committee.
The State of Tennessee announced yesterday that it would receive bids on May 16 on issues of bonds totaling $12,900,000. Dated June 1, 1949, the bonds will become due June 1, 1955 to 1959.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The Air Force today announced a plan for the substantial strengthening of its radar aircraft-warning system in Alaska. This specific military facility has been called one of the weak links of the nation's defenses.
WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) -- The full Interstate Commerce Commission will sit tomorrow to hear final argument on the long-disputed "Geneva steel rates."

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Three signatures affixed with simple ceremonies to a sheaf of contracts today completed negotiations for construction of the largest passenger liner ever to fly the United States flag.

The Dodgers have several causes for concern, but most of them vanish when Ralph Branca takes the hill. Brooklyn's big right-hander did another fine job yesterday. Registering his fourth straight victory, he shut out Cincinnati, 3 to 0, with six hits as the Brooks opened their home stand against the Western clubs.

Staging a ninth-inning outbreak that produced two runs with one out, St. John's University stretched its winning streak to nine games and gained outright possession of the lead in the Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference yesterday by topping New York University, 4 to 3, at Dexter Park, Woodhaven.

Freemasonry is comparable to "a wise coach who sees to it that the game of living is played among brothers with enthusiasm and vitality," Branch Rickey, president of the Brooklyn Dodgers, declared last night at the Astor Hotel. The baseball executive spoke at a dinner of the 168th annual communication of the New York State Grand Lodge of Masons.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 3 -- Three newspaper men have been appointed to serve with the university members on the committee for selecting the 1949-50 Nieman Fellows, Harvard University said today.

ST. LOUIS, May 3 -- The Yankees launched their first Western swing with a 5-to-3 victory over the Browns at Sportsman's Park today before a scant 3,430 spectators, but it took a master stroke by Old Reliable Tommy Henrich to point the way.

The League of Composers yesterday announced details of the musical program to be given at the dinner honoring Serge Koussevitzky in the Waldorf-Astoria next Tuesday. It will include excerpts from Marc Blitzstein's forthcoming opera, "The Little Foxes."

Surfcasters who, in telling of how they "put it out," speak in an off-hand manner of 400 and 450 foot casts, will have an opportunity to prove their ability at the annual contest to be held by the New York Casting Club on Sunday, May 15.

BUFFALO, May 3 -- The New York State Medical Society today sent a strongly worded protest against the Administration's health plans to President Truman and took steps to obtain greater influence with the State Legislature in Albany.

Christian missionaries will remain at their posts in China until "thrown out," the Rev. Dr. Robert A. Magill of Lynchburg, Va., declared yesterday at the Synod House of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

CINCINNATI, May 3 -- Belief that higher sales will result from "loading" dealers with merchandise was ridiculed here today by W. A. Blees, vice president of the Avco Manufacturing Corporation and general sales manager of its Crosley division.
Members of Local 1S of the Department Store Employes Union, unaffiliated, authorized their sixty-two-man executive board last night to call a strike against the four Macy stores in New York.

LONDON, May 3 -- Hollywood's Danny Kaye, the most popular comedian in Britain, was severely bruised about the ribs today in a car crash as he returned from a visit to George Bernard Shaw. Tonight he was on stage of the Palladium, gagging about it all.

DETROIT, May 3 -- Following an incipient rebellion by the leadership of its largest local, the international executive board of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, ordered today that a strike start at the River Rouge plant of the Ford Motor Company on Thursday at noon unless the company had complied with union demands that an alleged speed-up be halted.

A spurt in the final hour of trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday pushed prices irregularly higher. Motor, oil, chemical and amusement shares were the features. The volume, largest in a week, was 830,000 shares, compared with 740,000 shares on Monday.

On the Hebrew calendar today marks the first anniversary of the proclamation of the existence of the young state of Israel. For that newest of all nations this has been a year of impressive achievement. Free elections have been held. A stable and representative Government has been established.

Independent nominating petitions for Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. for Representative in Congress from the Twentieth District on Manhattan's West Side were filed yesterday with the Board of Elections. They insured for him a second place on the ballot in the special election on May 17, under the label of the Four Freedoms party, in addition to the regular nomination of the Liberal party, which had been given to him by its executive committee.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The Atomic Energy Commission today announced the first step in a broad labor relations policy based on recommendations made recently by President Truman's special commission headed by William H. Davis of New York.

IN his "Christ Stopped at Eboli" Carlo Levi wrote a distinguished book about the miserable lot of the peasants and villagers of Lucania, that desolate and dreary province at the arch of the Italian boot. In "God's Thumb Down"* Oscar DeLiso has written a hysterically violent first novel about the same subject. Christ with His message of love and brotherhood never got to the village of Mr. Levi's book.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Unexpectedly calling two agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation as witnesses for the defense, Archibald Palmer, lawyer for Judith Coplon, strove today to trip them and confuse their testimony regarding the 27-year-old woman who is accused of stealing national security secrets from the Department of Justice.

TOKYO, May 3. -- The Japanese coal miners union today launched a series of regional strikes that affected more than 400,000 miners and were calculated to put a serious brake on vital coal production, which the Allies have ordered increased.

MOSCOW, May 3 -- The Soviet satirical weekly Krokodil today presents to readers a description of Coney Island where it says mechanized gambling and mechanized horrors have been mobilized as the chief attractions for millions of Americans.
The city moved ahead yesterday in its program to regulate waterfront public loaders.

Morton Alexander and Vic Elmaleh of the City A. C. provided the first major upset of the National A. A. U. four-wall handball competition at the New York A. C. by turning back Joe Platak and Robert Quinn, Lake Shore A. C. of Chicago, the 1944 winners, in the opening round of the doubles, last night. The score was 21 -- 20, 21 -- 15.

Two new films arrive in Broadway theatres this morning. At Loew's State, the attraction is "The Barkleys of Broadway," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer musical in Technicolor starring Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers, reunited as a screen team after a ten-year separation.

ST. LOUIS, May 3 (AP) -- Federal Judge George H More took under submission today a request by the trustee of the Missouri Pacific Railroad for an order to assure continued control of a subsidiary, the Gulf Coast Lines.

The closing of the Nuremberg trials emphasizes the need of making the great principles established there effective for the future. Such a project might do much to eliminate the doubt and boredom occasioned by the trials' legal complexity, incongruities and length.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., May 3 -- At least 2,897 customers of the bankrupt cigarette mail-order houses operated from Wilmington, Del., whose owner faces two mail fraud charges, began to receive word today that their orders would be filled or their money returned.

The ideas that motivate Arthur Mendel and his Cantata Singers seem sound in principle. Last night they performed the Bach Mass in B minor using soloists, small chorus and chamber orchestra, all matching the size specified by the composer for performance of his choral works in Leipzig two centuries ago. The Mass was performed without cuts, and it was presented at the Church of the Heavenly Rest on upper Fifth Avenue.
MOSCOW, May 3 -- The Soviet Government is launching its fourth post-war internal loan drive, with 20,000,000,000 rubles again the target. The Moscow radio announced the campaign today.
ALBANY, May 3 -- Dr. Francis T. Spaulding, State Commissioner of Education, said tonight that one of the most critical problems facing school districts was what to do about school building needs.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 3 -- There almost was something symbolic about it. When the plane left La Guardia this morning for a visit to the Blue Grass country, it passed directly over the Polo Grounds. Then it took a beeline passage across the country, swooped low over the ivory tower in Cincinnati where Albert Benjamin Chandler does his high-powered thinking, and eventually went on to Louisville, the hoss capital of the land this week.

Talent raids upon the National Broadcasting Company by rival radio networks during the last year have been without detrimental effect upon NBC, Gen. David Sarnoff, chairman of the board of the Radio Corporation of America, parent company, told 500 stockholders at their annual meeting in Radio City yesterday.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 3 -- In much the same way that Citation had done the job a year ago, Fred W. Hooper's Olympia, favorite for Saturday's Kentucky Derby, won the $12,625 Derby Trial at blazing hot Churchill Downs today.

Overlooked by most of the 21,005 who gathered at Jamaica yesterday in search of a winner, William Goadby Loew's Khaki came out of the pack in the homestretch to win the featured North Hills Purse by two lengths over sloppy going.

You can take it from Mr. Alex Levine, liquor store proprietor in the Grand Central zone, or Monsieur Raymond Baudouin, Secretaire General de l'Acadamie du Vin de France, there is no lack of appreciation of good French wines among the American public -- providing the price is right.

HANOVER, N. H., May 3 -- Robert Moses, a Republican and key figure in New York City park and bridge administration and in city planning, said in a lecture at Dartmouth College tonight that he hoped Mayor O'Dwyer would remain in office. In this connection, Mr. Moses said:

As basic investment yields keep receding in response to the current official relaxation of credit restrictions, institutional investors are again investing eyes in the direction of new high-dividend offerings of choice public utility preferred stock.

BORDEAUX, France, April 29 -- Bordeaux seeks to become more industrialized. Its chamber of commerce has urged the Government to place on the banks of the Gironde River some of the new industries to be established with the aid of the Marshall Plan as part of a French program of productive investment.

A substantial increase in complaints charging discrimination in employment were filed with the State Commission Against Discrimination for the first quarter of 1949, the commission reported yesterday. The commission also reported an increased demand for its educational services.

SEATTLE, May 3 -- The world outlook for peace with freedom and justice is not dark, Wilhelm Munthe deMorgenstierne, Ambassador from Norway, declared here today at a University of Washington symposium on world affairs.
SHANGHAI May 3 -- Maj. Gen. Fong Ting-ming laid down a magnifying glass on the map table in his divisional headquarters today.

BAD NAUHEIM, Germany, May 3 -- A huge system of cultural exchange between the United States and Germany to triple the current program is planned for the fiscal year 1949-50, it was learned here today.

Three New York teachers, who since last September have visited schools in thirty-nine states on NEW YORK TIMES fellowships, reported at Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, yesterday on their nation-wide survey of the teaching of current affairs.

A lack of imagination in American cookery has led to its being scornfully described as "a pie-and-potatoes cuisine." But if the pie is good then the words are ill chosen to express criticism. All appetites applaud pastry that's crisp and yet tender, flaky. delicately browned.
WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The North Atlantic treaty would fix for this country as well as its eleven other members a common defensive frontier "in the heart of Europe," Gen. Omar N. Bradley said today.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Because Americans have been wearing out more paper currency than the Federal Government has been issuing, the Bureau of Engraving and Printing is working overtime to meet replacement demands.

Financial records of the city's major ticket brokers were subpoenaed yesterday by Investigation Commissioner John M. Murtagh. This action marked the beginning of an investigation into exorbitant ticket prices for Broadway hit shows.

The Triborough Bridge Tunnel Authority put the financing of the Brooklyn-Battery tunnel on a permanent basis yesterday by selling $141,500,000 of bonds to investment bankers and certain institutional investors after weeks of negotiation with a nation-wide syndicate of underwriting houses headed by Dillon, Read Co., Inc.

Joseph M. Schenck, executive head of production and co-founder of Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, announced yesterday that he had submitted his resignation to the producing company. Reached by telephone in Miami, Fla., Mr. Schenck said he had asked the company to relieve him of his contract as he desired to develop further his already extensive holdings in theatre circuits.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- As an aftermath of the 1948 West Coast maritime strike and to assure against further violation of the Taft-Hartley Act, the National Labor Relations Board today directed two maritime unions to cease the practice of picketing to aid a secondary boycott.

The concern of Capt. William J. Pedrick, executive head of the Fifth Avenue Association, for the future of the businesses he represents is understandable. Given sufficient time, what with the transportation problem of traveling into the heart of New York, many Fifth Avenue stores, as well as others in Manhattan, will be replaced by retail outlets in uptown, Long Island and other suburban communities.

Striking a distinctly optimistic note. Secretary of State Acheson declared yesterday that the forces of freedom and democracy are entitled to draw encouragement from the recent trend of events in Western Europe. He limited this optimism to Western Europe advisedly, for events in China cast new shadows over the international scene.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 3 -- Labor's share of the total national income declined last year in the United States, Canada, Belgium and New-Zealand in comparison with 1938 levels, statistical experts of the United Nations reported today.

By employing new devices in transmission the State Department's "Voice of America" broadcasts have partly overcome the intensive efforts of the Soviet to jam the signals beamed into Russia, it was announced yesterday by George V. Allen, Assistant Secretary of State for Public Affairs.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., May 3 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, expressed confidence here today that the Wood bill, approved by the House as a substitute for the Taft-Hartley Law, would be killed in the Senate.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., May 3 (AP) Plans to transfer New York State headquarters of the Atlantic Refining Company from Philadelphia to Syracuse were announced today. The transfer, to become effective Monday, was announced at a meeting of district managers.

The start of permanent television coverage of the United Nations sessions yesterday was termed by Dr. Herbert V. Evatt, president of the General Assembly, "a very important occasion in the history of the United Nations."

LAKE SUCCESS, May 3 -- Over vigorous British and United States protests, the Social Committee of the General Assembly voted tonight to limit the liberties laid down in a future United Nations convention on "freedom of information" by a dozen different restrictions.
CINCINNATI, May 3 -- Leo Durocher, who seemingly has been wearing the carpets of baseball's high executives almost threadbare these many years, is in the clear again.

Mayor O'Dwyer announced at City Hall yesterday that the city would associate itself with an attempt by fruit and vegetable trucking union leaders to obtain a reversal of the Interstate Commerce Commission ruling requiring receivers of fruit and vegetables by barge to pay to unload the cars on New York City piers.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., May 3 -- Reports on further progress in the successful use of a hormone from the adrenal gland in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis and rheumatic fever, the two major crippling diseases of mankind, were presented here today at the annual meeting of the American Association of Physicians, medical honor society, the membership of which was extended today from 225 to 250.

Negotiations between the National Maritime Union, CIO, and the Committee for the Companies and Agents -- Atlantic and Gulf Coasts -- which represents thirty-three steamship operators, continued yesterday afternoon in the offices of the American Merchant Marine Institute, 11 Broadway.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Following is a comparison of important provisions of the Wood labor bill approved by the House today and three other labor measures, including the Sims bill offered by the House leadership atd defeated. The other two are the old Wagner Act of 1935 and the Taft-Hartley. Act now on the books.

Two museum exhibitions open to the public today -- the fifteenth biennial international water-color exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum and recently acquired paintings and sculpture at the Museum of Modern Art.

PARIS, May 3 -- Economic relations between France and Switzerland were broken off today when the French Government suspended trading in Swiss francs on the Paris free market in retaliation for the freezing by the Swiss National Bank of French funds in Switzerland.

A plan for a union of all Mizrachi women's movements throughout the world was announced yesterday by Mrs. Sarah Herzog, president of the Mizrachi Women's Organization of Israel and wife of the chief rabbi of Israel.

FRANKFORT, Germany, May 3 -- Several members of the United States Military Government decartelization branch today accused their superiors of blocking efforts to break up German trusts. They criticized Gem Lucius D. Clay, Military Governor, for defending high advisers who "misled" him. Their names are withheld at their request.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 3 -- Ginger Rogers will play the leading role in "The Story of Molly X," formerly titled "Tehachepi," a photoplay by Crane Wilbur about the California State Women's Penitentiary, Universal-International announced today. Under the terms of the studio's deal with Miss Rogers, she will make the picture in the summer after she completes "The Perfect Strangers" at Warner Brothers. Aaron Rosenberg will produce "The Story of Molly X."

ALBANY, May 3 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, who will sail from New York City Thursday for a six-week visit to Europe, said today he did not intend to discuss either American or European politics while abroad.

Fairfield Osborn, president of the New York Zoological Society, said last night that the number of people that the earth, or any given country, can support depended in a large degree upon the extent to which existing technical knowledge could be put into practice.

Many dinners were given last night at the formal opening for this season of the St. Regis Roof. Brig. Gen. John Williams Morgan, USA, and Mrs. Morgan gave a dinner party there for Judge and Mrs. Jacob Gould Schurman, the Rev. and Mrs. Gilbert S. B. Darlington, and Mr. and Mrs. J. Fearon Brown.

HONG KONG, May 3 -- Newspaper headlines advising foreign nationals to evacuate Kwangtung and Kwangsi Provinces in South China brought the civil war alarmingly close today to this British Crown Colony.
