WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The National Labor Relations Board today refused a motion to consolidate a sheaf of Taft-Hartley complaints against the International Typographical Union, American Federation of Labor, but promised to bring all cases to a conclusion at the earliest possible moment.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 3 (AP) -- Gov. James E. Folsom outlined a broad program today to improve the living conditions of Negroes in Alabama.

Lack of advance orders will cut deeply into cotton textile exports in the second quarter, it was predicted yesterday by New York exporters. Record shipments in the first quarter, they said, cannot be sustained in the face of curtailed buying by most of the leading world markets for American goods.
Twenty-seven persons were fined yesterday in Municipal Term Court as a result of the spring clean-up drive that the Departments of Health and Sanitation started on Monday.

Israel, marking its first anniversary as an independent state, will probably become a member of the sterling bloc in international trade, Dr. Werner Feilchenfeld, president in 1940 of the Export Union of Palestine and secretary of the Chamber of Industry and Commerce in Berlin before the Nazi regime, said here yesterday.

Mrs. Middleton Rose will give a luncheon tomorrow in the Vanity Fair Room of the Sherry-Netherland for leaders of various committees actively interested in final plans for the Spring Frolic and Tea Dance to be given May 12 in the main ballroom of the Plaza under the auspices of the Humane Society of New York.

Although he started his teaching career fifty-one years ago as a "traditionalist," Dr. Stephen F. Bayne, deputy superintendent of schools, is preparing to retire with a national reputation for having changed many concepts in the field of elementary education.

LONDON, May 3 -- The Foreign Ministers of nine nations and the Belgian Ambassador representing Premier Paul-Henri Spaak assembled in St. James's Palace here this morning to begin discussions of the proposed Council of Europe. By the day's end they were reported to have cleared the ground for the signing tomorrow of a Statute of Europe, thus creating a "parliament" of the democratic European nations.

TRENTON, N. J., May 3 (AP) -- Walter E. Edge, a former Republican Governor of New Jersey, said today in an address at his party's state convention that Frank Hague, former Mayor of Jersey City, would become in effect Governor of New Jersey if the Democratic party won the November election.

Current prices of cars are comparatively low, A. vanderZee, vice president in charge of sales of the Chrysler Corporation, said last night at the annual dinner of the Automobile Merchants Association of New York. A thousand members attended the dinner, which was held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, with Charles Schnurmacher, president of the organization, presiding.
Eleven years ago today the S. S. Lafayette burned at Havre, France, in the greatest marine disaster of the year.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 3 -- A last-gasp appeal for help was made to the United States Government today by the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund. Officials said that its world-wide operations would come to a halt within a few months unless this country took the lead in contributing additional funds.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Maj. Gen. Claire L. Chennault urged Congress today to authorize a "minimum program," of $700,000,000 a year behind a holding action against Chinese Communist forces and to maintain a beachhead in the remaining free areas for the resurgence of Chinese nationalism.
SHANGHAI, May, 3 -- Telephone communications with Hangchow were cut today as Nationalist troops Were reported to have completed the evacuation of that seaport.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Newspapers today won virtually exclusive use of four radio channels for news transmission in a sweeping reallocation by the Federal Communications Commission of the channels used by this country's 200,000 mobile units.
BERLIN, May 3 -- Mainly at United States insistence, occupation costs to be charged to Western Germany for the year ending March 31, 1950, have been substantially reduced for the bizonal area.
A novel no-strike formula for essential industries, painless to the general public but painful to the parties involved, is suggested in this month's issue of The Harvard Business Review.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) -- The head of a Czechoslovak official delegation announced today that financial negotiations with the United States had been suspended. He said he retained hope for United States trade credits but knew no substance for the hope.

Dr. Ordway Tead, chairman of the Board of Higher-Education, declared last night that any comment at this time on the qualifications of any candidate for the presidency of Queens College would be "premature." The board is expected to discuss the matter at its annual meeting, scheduled for May 16.
WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) -- Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce, today asked Congress for a net increase of $10,165,000 over the $316,000,000 voted to his department by the House.
TEL AVIV, Israel, May 3 -- All Israel was festive tonight on the eve of the first birthday of the state.

A Senate committee remarked, in discussing the problem of extending educational opportunity, that "the facts are now legion, the arguments patent." Senate debate on the bill for $300,000,000 in federal aid to education, and the attempts at amendment, clearly illustrate, however, that no formula for such aid will ever be reached that pleases everybody.

The curtain at the Music Box is advertised to rise at 8 o'clock this evening on the premiere of "Mrs. Gibbons' Boys." The product of a pair of new Broadway playwrights, Will Glickman and Joseph Stein, the collaboration is a comedy possessing all the attributes of a farce. Entertainment of that type is regarded as George Abbott's forte, which explains why he became attached to the script as producer-director.

BERLIN, May 3 -- The Soviet Union will go to "almost any lengths" to obtain a united Germany at the proposed meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers, it was predicted here today. Both United States and British sources, whose task it is to study fluctuations in Soviet foreign policy, believe that the West will be faced with a drastic change in Russian tactics in Germany at the proposed meeting.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Senate Democrats closed ranks today to defeat, 65 to 16, a proposal to withhold Federal funds for education from states having separate schools for Negroes. The vote, in which seventeen Republicans joined the unanimous Democrats, was on an amendment to a bill authorizing $300,000,000 annually in grants to states for public education.

Consolidated earnings of General Public Utilities Corporation and its subsidiaries for the first three months of this year showed a satisfactory increase, A. F. Tegen, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting here yesterday. Net income amounted to 73 cents a common share, he said, compared with 55 cents in the first quarter of 1948.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The North Atlantic treaty would allay the fear of insecurity against armed attack and promote the economic recovery of the free nations of Europe. Dean Acheson. Secretary of State, declared today.

The ruling group in Tammany Hall expressed pleasure yesterday over the success of Tammany's fund-raising dinner Monday night in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, but maintained a discreet silence over Mayor O'Dwyer's absence. The Mayor chose instead to address a meeting of 150 members of the Fair Deal Democrats, a group out to best Tammany.

CHICAGO, May 3 (AP) -- Clyde Vollmer, rookie outfielder, led the Senators today on a home run binge that defeated the White Sox, 14 to 12, before 4,507 fans. Vollmer collected two of the Senators' seven round-trippers.

COATESVILLE, Pa., May 3 (AP) -- The Lukens Steel Company today reported net income of $2,271,705 for the first two quarters of its 1949 fiscal year. The quarters ended on April 16. This compares with $759,744 for a similar period a year ago.
LONDON, May 3 -- The last day of the account in the stock markets here today passed with quiet conditions general in most sections.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- For the second time in two days President Truman today told an agricultural group that the Administration's farm program was part of an effort to assure a fair share of national income to all elements of the population.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., May 3 -- Former Mayor Frank Hague was booed tonight when he entered this city's second ward, in which he was born, during a political parade in connection with the municipal elections to be held next Tuesday.

Schick, Inc., Stamford, Conn., maker of electric shavers, to Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn, Inc., for all advertising. Development of summer and fall advertising and sales promotion plans will start immediately.

Plastics, which have been associated for the most part with unbreakable dishes or easy-to-clean kitchen gadgets, are shown as a new medium for artist-craftsmen in the exhibit that opens today at America House. 485 Madison Avenue, and closes May 25.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 3 -- Europe's exports of goods and services in 1948 were $5,600,000,000 below the value of its imports, the International Monetary Fund reported here today. In its monthly bulletin the fund announced that the 1947 deficit in Europe's international payments account had been reduced by $2,000,000,000 last year.

The Commerce and Industry Association and the City's Commerce Department announced yesterday that they would be joint hosts to 200 members of Congress and their families on a three-day tour of the metropolitan area beginning on Friday.

WESTBURY, L. I., May 3 -- The Cherry Valley Club upset the Creek Club, 11 -- 4, in one of the opening round golf matches of the Long Island section, Series 1, of the Metropolitan interclub team matches at the Meadow Brook Club today.

AMMAN, Jordan, May 3 -- The resignation of the Jordanian Cabinet was officially announced here today and it was disclosed that the new Cabinet, which is expected to be formed under the same Premier, Tewfik Abul Huda, would include Palestinian members.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay will retire on May 15 as United States Military Governor in Germany and Commander of United States Forces in Europe. President Truman made this announcement this evening, praising the veteran of the shooting war and the "cold war" unstintingly.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- A compromise was suggested today as a Senate subcommittee completed hearings on a proposed constitutional amendment to change the system of electing the President and Vice President.

To pep up rooms this time of year ready-made slipcovers for studio couches are to be found in clear colors and well-tailored styles that at last rival the more expensive custom-made types. Those now in stores include crisp combinations of prints and plain fabrics, dark-colored grounds with bright patterns and two-piece slipcovers like those popular for full-fledged beds.
CINCINNATI, May 3 -- The text of Baseball Commissioner A. B. Chandler's statement reinstating Manager Leo Durocher of the New York Giants follows:

An organization to foster Italian-American business relations has just been formed in Rome under the auspices of leading manufacturers, bankers and foreign traders in Italy, according to word received here yesterday.

RYE, N. Y., May 3 -- The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association interclub matches, Westchester Division, began on nine fronts in the county today, with inaugural tests in the first cup series taking place over the Westchester Country Club's south course.

The Screen Publicists Guild and the Screen Office and Professional Employes Guild have endorsed a "Don't Go to the Movies" campaign to be launched immediately against Loew Theatres, with other theatres to be targets of this strategy in subsequent weeks, it was announced by the CIO unions.

Mayor O'Dwyer's surprise appointment of a new Bronx member to the Board of Education to replace Anthony Campagna came as a severe jolt to school officials, it was acknowledged yesterday at the board's headquarters, 110 Livingston Street, Brooklyn.

NEW ORLEANS, May 3 (UP) -- A "deeply shocked" priest charged today that 150 displaced persons resettled on Louisiana sugar cane plantations were so ill-paid their babies "are crying for food and milk."

John D. Rockefeller 3d general chairman of the 1949 campaign of the Greater New York Fund drive for $8,000,000, yesterday urged members of the insurance group of the finance and insurance division of the campaign to support the drive to the utmost.

Voluntary restrictions on the use of grains by brewers during the Government's conservation program played a large part in checking the spread of communism in European nations, Senator Clinton P. Anderson, former Secretary of Agriculture, declared yesterday.
SOUTHERN PINES, S. C., May 3 (AP) -- A 4-under-par 68 today moved Johnny Palmer, Badin pro, into the Carolinas open golf tournament lead at the midpoint of the 72-hole competition.

LONDON, May 3 -- A bill was introduced in the British Parliament today recognizing the Irish Republic's full independence from the British Commonwealth but at the same time declaring that the republic would not become a foreign country to Britain.

Visiting buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,304 compared with 1,802 last week and 1,222 in the similar week of last year, according to lists appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 535 arrivals yesterday against 711 last Tuesday.

Price reductions ranging from 5 to 12 per cent on a wide variety of industrial items are coming in so fast that purchasing agents for manufacturing plants in the New York area are having trouble keeping track of the offers, spokesmen revealed here yesterday.

Some sort of celebration was in order, following Manager Leo Durocher's reinstatement by Baseball Commissioner A. B. Chandler, so the Giants made merry in appropriate fashion last night at the Polo Grounds. Cheered by the news that their pilot would be back with them today, the Giants, in the season's initial after-dark contest here, achieved a 5-3 victory over the Pirates.
OLEAN, N. Y., May 3 (AP) -- A process for making gasoline from natural gas, coal or shale was described today as capable of adding 25 per cent to this country's motor fuel supply.

Twenty-one United States amateur golfers have been certified for the British amateur championships near Dublin late this month, the U. S. G. A. said yesterday. The tournament will mark the first time that the title will be decided on Irish soil.

Directors of the Dow Chemical Company declared a dividend of 40 cents on common, payable July 15. The organization previously paid 25 cents in the two previous quarters. The company is on a May 31 fiscal year.

Tariff wars and blockades are not new in Yugoslav history. Forty-four years ago the Austrian monarchy waged a tariff war against Serbia. In spite of immense economic repercussions, Serb leaders rightly rejected the fallacy of diverting the country's foreign trade to countries in Eastern Europe which had practically the same economic structure as Serbia and were, therefore, in no position to supply manufactured goods or absorb Serb exports.
A further complication in the affairs of Sailors Snug Harbor developed yesterday when Mayor O'Dwyer declared flatly that he did not intend to serve as one of its trustees.

CHICAGO, May 3 -- A system of compulsory national health insurance, such as that proposed by the Federal Security Agency, is the best apparent insurance against socialization of medicine, John L. Thurston, assistant administrator of the FSA, asserted here tonight before the Tri-State Hospital Assembly.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned strong and active in the late trading yesterday and final prices showed gains of 21 to 43 points in the old-crop months, while new-crop months were 7 points higher to 2 points lower.

Most of the new crystal pieces that Steuben Glass is bringing out today are small but useful and priced at $25 or less. Originally planned for fall distribution, they have been put into production in time to be given for spring weddings. They are available at 718 Fifth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Representatives of the Congress of Industrial Organizations bluntly told Congress today they wanted the poll tax outlawed to break up a coalition of Southern Democrats and Northern Republicans standing in the way of social progress.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Company firmness and open dealings and cooperation between management and labor leadership were listed as factors in twelve years of unbroken peaceful relations in the Sharon Steel Corporation in a case study made public here today by the National Planning Association.
CAMDEN, N. J., May 4 (AP) -- Sky Miracle, 3-year-old colt from Mrs. Dodge Sloane's Brookmeade Stable, ran six furlongs in 1:10 3-5 today to win the featured Meadowview Purse at Garden State.
Macy's informed its 7,500 unionized employes in this city yesterday that any strike on their part would mean "great losses in employes' wages and in volume of business."

Thomas A. Younglove testified at the Communist trial yesterday that Communist leaders in St. Louis taught party members the need to control railroad workers and to use "violent action" rather than the ballot box to make a successful revolution.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 4 -- Horse sense is a well-advertised commodity but it rarely is in evidence at a race track. Instead of sleeping until a reasonable hour, the colts awaken at the crack of dawn and promptly go to work. That means an early arising for grooms, stable hands, jockeys, trainers and -- once in a while -- newspaper men.
LONDON, May 4 -- Opening of the new account failed to produce any marked increase in business in the stock market here today.
Getting fine cooperation from the Reds, the Dodgers yesterday moved ck over the .500 mark in the National League race, with a 5-1 victory at Ebbets Field.

CLEVELAND, May 4 (AP) -- Two home runs by Joe Gordon, one of them coupled with two other circuit blows in the third inning, enabled the world champion Indians to score a 4-to-3 victory over the Athletics today.

The discussion continues on the question, "Should Communists be allowed to teach in our universities?" The fact that three Columbia professors said "yes," and one said "no," in the answers to the poll carried on by The Columbia Daily Spectator (NEW YORK TIMES, April 29) is interesting.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 4 -- Four Latin American delegations formally asked the United Nations General Assembly today to lift the ban on the appointment of ambassadors and ministers to the Franco Government in Spain.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 4 -- Norman W. Shepard, since 1936 athletic director and basketball coach at Davidson College, tonight was named basketball coach at Harvard University.
Douglas Williamson has been appointed manager of sales promotion of American Hard Rubber Company.

Eleven years ago today a German police chief prohibited swing dancing as a public menace, de nouncing it as "foreign to German character." Proprietors of cafes and dance halls were ordered to expel swing dancing couples.

ALBANY, May 4 -- Governor Dewey appointed Maj. Gen. Karl F. Hausauer of Buffalo, commanding general of the New York National Guard, as his Chief of Staff today, then directed him to disband, as of June 1, the wartime New York Guard.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- A Protestant Church complacent by having catered to upper income groups and having permitted "class stratification and racial segregation" is failing the communities it purports to serve, Mrs. Eugene Meyer, wife of the chairman of the board of the Washington Post and a civic leader and sociologist, charged here today.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., May 4 -- A young Air Force lieutenant saved the life of his radar observer passenger here today after his F-82 twin Mustang fighter plane crashed into a building. He beat holes in the plexiglas canopy, stripped the jammed cover off the burning cockpit with his hands and pulled the man to safety.

The need for teeth straightening and other orthodontic treatment among school-age children in the United States is so great that it forecloses the possibility of a country-wide corrective program even if economic barriers were removed by a Federal subsidy, members of the American Association of Orthodontists were told yesterday.

The out-of-doors is creeping not only into the college curriculum but seems to be finding a place in interscholastic sports. This week-end will find six colleges competing in varied woodcraft events at Dartmouth.

PARIS, May 4 -- Straw, wicker caning is used on summer frocks by Jean Desses. A flared gown with handkerchief point hemline is in black tussor, but the skirt is veiled in natural caning. A wide band of shiny black and natural straw borders the many-pointed hemline of a natural tussor frock.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The Civil Service Commission asked Congress today to raise the salaries of most Federal employes and authorize increases up to $6,000 a year for some high officials. The proposal was made in a bill submitted to Speaker Sam Rayburn, Democrat, of Texas, to revise and simplify the pay scale for more than 1,500,000 Government workers.

Thirty-one major ticket brokers, whose financial records were subpoenaed Tuesday by Commissioner of Investigation John M. Murtagh, will appear in his office it 50 Pine Street at 10 A. M. today, the Commissioner announced yesterday. The investigation, ordered by Mayor O'Dwyer, is aimed at exorbitant ticket prices reportedly being paid for hit shows on Broadway.
The question whether the Communist party should be outlawed was debated last night in the "What's On Your Mind?" forum over WQXR.

LONDON, May 4 -- British diplomatic quarters were pleased today by the announcement that the blockade of Berlin would be lifted, but were not overly optimistic about the outcome of the ensuing meeting of Big Four Foreign Ministers.

Support of the State Department's nonintervention policy in China and opposition to any further military aid to that nation was expressed yesterday by Protentant mission board executives in letters to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee and the House Foreign Affairs Committee.

Shipments of major canned fruits and vegetables to retail outlets continue to be larger than last year, it was learned here yesterday. It was estimated that these shipments are about 15 per cent higher for the year to date compared with the corresponding period last year.

DUBLIN, May 4 -- The clause in the Ireland bill, introduced in the British Parliament, making the unification of Ireland dependent upon the consent of Northern Ireland's Parliament evoked bitter and bewildered feelings here today on all sides.

Only three days remain to see the loan exhibition of paintings and drawings by Seurat. Current at the Knoedler Galleries for the benefit of the Home for the Destitute Blind since April 20, the show will close on Saturday evening. Admission is 60 cents.
A "pronounced drop" in the general death rate in New York for the first four months of this year, compared with the same period in 1948, was reported yesterday by the Department of Health.

The Federal Reserve Board was urged yesterday to eliminate all controls over installment credit. The proposal, made by the American Bankers Association, was contained in a letter from Evans Woollen Jr., the association's president, to R. M. Evans, governor of the Federal Reserve Board.

Charles R. Denny, executive vice president of NBC, threw some light yesterday on the possible future of theatre television. In a letter addressed to Gael Sullivan, executive director of Theatre Owners of America, Inc., Mr. Denny said of three types of NBC television programs potentially available for theatre showing, only programs which NBC might build on order from theatres would be available to them on an exclusive basis.

WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission today set May 24 to start a hearing on proposals by Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., Brooklyn Union Gas Company and Kings County Lighting Company to build natural gas pipeline facilities in the New York metropolitan area.

" Canadian Pacific," which is being released by Twentieth Century-Fox, has been booked as the initial film offering when the Palace starts its combined vaudeville and film policy on Thursday, May 19, it became known yesterday. An adventure drama dealing with the building of that railroad, the picture stars Randolph Scott and Jane Wyatt.

Prices on the New York Stock Exchange advanced fractions to 2 points yesterday in the broadest and most active trading in nearly two weeks. Opposition in Congress to the Administration's labor measure and the announcement of the agreement to lift the Berlin blockade were considered important factors in the rise.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was fairly active yesterday and final prices were 8 to 22 points net lower.
DETROIT, May 4 (AP) -- Righthander Virgil Trucks of the Tigers held the hard-hitting Red Sox to three hits as he beat them, 5 -- 1, today for his fourth straight triumph of the season.

WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission took under advisement today proposed consolidation of the Long Island Lighting Company with two subsidiaries, the Queens Borough Gas and Electric Company and the Nassau Suffolk Lighting Company.

District Attorney Miles F. McDonald of Kings County took exception yesterday to remarks made on Monday by Judge Louis Goldstein in criticizing the Brooklyn prosecutor's handling of a first-degree murder indictment.

Dr. Walter C. Langsam, president of Wagner College on Staten Island, withdrew his name yesterday from consideration for the presidency of Queens College. He made public a letter to Ordway Tead, chairman of the Board of Higher Education, declaring that he was grateful for the recognition but was very happy in his post at Wagner College and would like to remain there.

ST. LOUIS, May 4 -- Vic Raschi spotted the Browns three runs at Sportsman's Park today as the hapless crew of Zach Taylor scored in one inning as many runs as the Yankee right-hander had yielded in all three of his previous starts.

Homemakers may have the advice and guidance of their decorators in choosing anything from a chaise longue to silver flatware in the new showroom at 18 East Fiftieth Street that John Gerald opened yesterday as a service for decorators.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 4 -- With all under-silks preliminaries written into the records, it appears likely that at least a dozen colts will answer the bugle for the seventy-fifth Kentucky Derby on Saturday. The Churchill Downs management regards this as a perfectly charming state of affairs.

Great poverty and unrest among peoples in Southeast Asia and the Pacific islands require close cooperation between the United States and Australia to bring about peace, justice and better living standards in those areas, Dr. Herbert V. Evatt, Deputy Prime Minister of Australia, declared last night. He insisted that this policy should be carried out under the charter of the United Nations.

Mrs. Chaim Weizmann, wife of the President of Israel, said yesterday there was a possibility that "very soon not a single Jew will be allowed to leave Eastern European countries." Therefore, she said, immigration into Israel must go on at top speed.
BOSTON, May 4 (AP) -- The Braves scored all their runs in the opening inning tonight and then fended off two rallies by the Cubs to win, 4 -- 3, before 19,238 fans.

CHICAGO, May 4 -- Grain markets made a strong start and a tame finish on the Board of Trade today with trading largely professional in character. There was a lack of selling pressure early and support was lacking later.
Flying Missel scored a convincing victory in the Broad Channel, the mile-and-a-sixteenth race that served as the main attraction at Jamaica yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The office of Louis Johnson, Secretary of Defense, restated for the National Military Establishment today the Congressional warning against the release of secret military information to the press.
URBANA, Ill., May 4 (AP) -- Companies licensed to manufacture a new ammoniated dentifrice developed by the University of Illinois scientists were identified today by the university's Foundation.

The steamship conference system has little or nothing to fear from investigation by the Maritime Commission or any other Government agency; it has been under scrutiny before, but to date no better industry-stabilizing system has been suggested, according to a survey of the various groups yesterday.

A late fall opening of a new play, "Mother Hildebrand," starring Grace George, was announced yesterday by Guthrie McClintic, who plans to direct as well as sponsor it. Miss George's last New York appearance eight years ago, coincidentally, was in another McClintic production called "Spring Again," in which she co-starred with the late Sir Aubrey Smith.

BUFFALO, May 4 Recent research work on a host of medical problems, ranging from the control of pain to the proper use of newly discovered drugs, was discussed here today as scientific sessions in connection with the annual meeting of the New York State Medical Society began.

A bid for $51,000 for the copy of Lincoln's Gettysburg address that was auctioned on April 27 at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street, was reported erroneously by the galleries as having come from Lafayette College of Easton, Pa. The document went to Oscar B. Cintas of Havana and New York for $54,000.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., May 4 -- Five members of a family died today in an early morning two-alarm fire, believed to be of incendiary origin, which swept through the three-story brick building in which the victims lived. Two other persons were treated for burns at the Medical Center here, and a fireman who fell from a ladder is under treatment for a fracture of the spine.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 4 -- Foreign banks must become national corporations if a bill now in the Senate committees here becomes a law. The measure affects two important American banks, the National City Bank of New York and the First National Bank of Boston, the first operating in Brazil for several years, as well as British and Portuguese banks.

Coudert Brothers, one of this city's oldest law firms which has occupied offices for more than twenty-five years at 2 Rector Street, have leased a floor in the building under construction by Uris Brothers at 488 Madison Avenue, through Douglas Gibbons Co., brokers, according to Cross Brown Company, renting agents for the property.

" Napoleon, For and Against," a critical study by Pieter Geyl, Professor of Modern History at the University of Utrecht, Holland, will be brought out by the Yale University Press on May 18. The work was conceived in Buchenwald, planned in a concentration camp in Holland and written after the liberation.

Take a tip from the sun and gather your cottons in tints from the palest yellow to a glowing golden orange, Arnold Constable advised yesterday in a showing of bright summer fashions at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

ALBANY, May 4 -- Governor Dewey, clearing his desk for a European vacation, announced several hundred appointments today, including 132 members of a state-wide committee to assist in the drive to bring down the costs of housing.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The House killed the Wood labor bill today in a hairline reversal that gave to the Democratic leadership and the labor chieftains little more than a chance to fight another day. The vote was 212 to 209.

Dr. John R. Nichols, newly appointed Commissioner of the Bureau of Indian Affairs of the Department of the Interior, told the twelfth annual meeting of the Association on American Indian Affairs, Inc., yesterday that the time would soon arrive when Indian peoples would be dealt with as other Americans and that all special tribal designations and treaty restrictions would be set aside.

The winning run was scored on a balk and Adam Rakowski's long hitting streak came to an end at Baker Field yesterday as Columbia defeated Yale in an Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League game, 4 to 2.

Dwellers in public housing need not be provided with community facilities so extensive that these tenants will exist apart in a kind of modern city-state, James H. England, executive director of the New York City Housing Authority, said yesterday at a community conference on public housing at the Henry Hudson Hotel, 361 West Fifty-seventh Street.
TURIN, Italy, May 4 -- Italy's national championship soccer team perished in the crash of a three-engine plane during a rainstorm here tonight.

WEST POINT, N. Y., May 4 -- Army pounded five hurlers for thirteen hits in defeating Fordham, 13 to 2, in a seven-inning game at Doubleday Field today. The cadets wrapped up the game with two big rallies, getting five runs on six hits in the third and five more on two blows in the sixth.

The validity of the contracts signed by some 10,000 players in organized baseball in this country, Canada, Mexico, Cuba and Puerto Rico was questioned in the United States Court of Appeals yesterday in an action brought by Max Lanier and Fred Martin, suspended Cardinal pitchers.

An all-male jury in General Sessions took ninety minutes to convict Mrs. Geraldine Vetter yesterday of second degree assault in the burning of her 9-year-old son's right hand. Remanded to the Women's House of Detention to await sentence May 25, the defendant faces a possible penalty up to five years' imprisonment.

A discount of 5 cents a yard will be granted by the American Woolen Company to wool jobbers, it was learned yesterday. The discount, according to company officials, reinstates a company policy that was in force prior to World War II.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 4 -- Borba published today an item that may have tremendous implications in view of speculation aroused concerning the eventual attitude of Mao Tze-tung, Chinese Communist leader.

The United Office and Professional Workers of America, CIO, which finished second to an American Federation of Labor union in balloting among 14,500 Prudential insurance agents a month ago, reversed the outcome in voting yesterday among 5,500 agents of the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company.

Rafael Seppala, Finnish Consul General, presented to the New York Public Library yesterday thirty-two volumes of "Suomen Kansan Vanhat Runot" -- Old Finnish Folklore, a complete collection -- at a ceremony reopening the Finnish National Travel Office at Finland House, 41 East Fiftieth Street.
BERLIN, May 4 -- The boys who held Berlin for the West during 320 days of the Russian blockade were "jumping up and down for joy" tonight.

David S. Meister has purchased the new one-story taxpayer building at 1443 to 1447 Queen Anne Road in the West Englewood section of Teaneck, N. J., from the M. A. Construction Company. The property, containing three stres, is on a plot 40 by 100 feet.

Last night was "American Composers' Night" for the Ballet Theatre at the Metropolitan Opera House, with Morton Gould playing the piano part of his "Interplay," Aaron Copland conducting his "Billy the Kid" and William Schuman and Leonard Bernstein represented, though not present, by "Undertow" and "Fancy Free," respectively.

The Mexican peso continued soft yesterday and closed at 12.57 cents against 13.81 on Tuesday. On Friday the price was 13.95 cents a peso, compared with the week-end carry-over price of 14.08 on Friday. Brokers said there was no apparent explanation of the softness other than the current seasonal decline in Mexican exports, with the resultant shortage of dollars.

Advances that are being made by young and vigorous governments are not confined to the political field. It is natural that political changes such as, for example, India's incorporation of formerly great Princely States or the development of a new Commonwealth formula should attract attention.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Net operating earnings of the national banks in the United States and possessions aggregated $716,000,000 in 1948, an increase of $72,000,000 over 1947, Preston Delano, Comtroller of the currency, announced today.
WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- The city of Memphis, Tenn., today was awarded the grand prize in the national fire prevention contest held by the United States Chamber of Commerce in 1948.

A one-family dwelling at 807 Caffrey Street, near Jarvis Lane, Far Rockaway, Queens, was sold by the estate of Sidney Fast to Joseph Wiener through the Lewis H. May Company, broker. The plot is 40 by 100 feet.

Plymex, Inc., Jesse Weisman, president, bought the five-story store and apartment building on a lot 20 by 65 feet at 337 Lexington Avenue from Berkley Associates, Inc., in a deal reported yesterday by James Felt Co., the brokers, who also arranged a lease of the building for ten years to Plymouth Cleaners Dyers.

ALLAIRE, N. J., May 4 -- Ninety per cent of the 100 emotionally disturbed children who have been living at the two-year-old Arthur Brisbane Child Treatment Center here have shown marked improvement as the result of their stay, it was reported today, by Dr. Georges Lussier, director of the center.

A resolution calling for steps to liquidate some of the large outstandings owing to American exporters by Brazil in the event of a United States loan or other financial assistance to that country was adopted yesterday at the meeting of the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau in the Statler Hotel.

WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- Federal officials dismissed today one complaint involving treatment given a group of displaced persons in this country and undertook an investigation of a second case. Arthur J. Hazes, executive director of the Displaced Persons Commission, said the agency had received full reports on the situation at a Latvian DP colony near Senatobia, Miss., and added that "as far as we are concerned the charges are unfounded."

Governor Dewey urged last night the admission of Israel to the United Nations. He spoke at a United Jewish Appeal dinner held to celebrate the first anniversary of the new state and to pay honor to Dr. Chaim Weizmann, its President. Two thousand persons were present.

The Giants celebrated Manager Leo Durocher's return to the helm by making it two straight over the Pirates yesterday at the Polo Grounds before 9,874 spectators. Paying tribute to their reinstated leader in characteristic fashion, they put on a display of long-ball hitting that scuttled the Buccaneers, 11 to 4.

CHAPPAQUA, N. Y., May 4 -- Of the 165,000 new businesses founded in New York State since the end of the war some that are under the guidance of the State Commerce Department and Woman's Council are emerging as success stories.

Quadruplets were born between 4:30 and 5:10 P. M. yesterday at Lebanon Hospital to Mrs. Ethel Collins of 3410 Kingsbridge Avenue, the Bronx. The four infants, two boys and two girls, weighed a total of 17 pounds 14 ounces at birth.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., May 4 -- The Legislature was accused today of ignoring the essentials of a sound, long-range highway building and reconstruction program for the state. This alleged neglect was emphasized in a summary offered by Judge Truman H. Preston at a meeting of the board of directors, New York State Automobile Association, here.

TRENTON, N. J., May 4 -- The State Motor Vehicle Department is featuring "the accident of the month" in a new kind of campaign to try to cut down the number of crashes and fatalities on New Jersey highways.

ANNECY, France, May 4 -- By the end of the Annecy Trade Conference, seven European countries, Australia and Brazil will have modernized and simplified their customs tariffs as a result of an international attack on the problems of trade barriers.

Jose Basora, Puerto Rico middleweight, won a ten-round decision from Henry Brimm of Buffalo last night in the feature bout at the Manhattan Center. The show marked the last of the current indoor season for the sponsoring Tournament of Champions.

LONDON, May 4 -- Nine Foreign Ministers and the Belgian Ambassador reached full agreement here today on a Statute of the Council of Europe, which will now carry into effect the long-cherished ideal of a democratic European Parliament.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- House members who voted approval of the Wood Labor Bill last night and then helped to send it back to committee apeared in agreement today that the action would force a compromise on sounder legislation.

Saying that "we have started to break of the Liberal party," which is supporting Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., Municipal Court Justice Benjamin Shalleck, Democratic candidate for Representative in the Twentieth Congressional District, announced yesterday that he had received endorsements from twelve labor organizations.

An independent six-man committee representing stockholders of the Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation won a "compromise" battle with the management of the 89 - year - old marine engineering and construction company yesterday.
SEOUL, Korea, May 4 -- The largest newspaper in South Korea, Seoul Shin Mun, was temporarily closed today on the order of D. S. Kim, Director of Public Information.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson announced today that the United States and Britain would move shortly against Bulgaria, Hungary and Rumania on charges of violating the human rights clauses of their peace treaties by religious and political persecutions, suppression of freedom of speech and assembly, and ruthless measures against political opposition. Action is imminent, he declared.

In comment upon Miss Gildersleeve's letter regarding the United Nations and the assassination of Count Bernadotte, it is well known that the Israeli Government has made every effort to apprehend the slayers, and that a report is to be submitted to the U. N. As for the actual murderers of the Count, there is no evidence whatsoever that they were Israelis, and we may never know their identity.

If there were any continuity in the theatrical arts, "Mrs. Gibbons' Boys" would be named Bruno and Sidney in honor of the ill-advised comedy that opened on Tuesday evening. For the invitation to hilarity by Will Glickman and Joseph Stein, temporarily installed at the Music Box last evening, is another damp whiz-bang.

PARIS, May 4 -- In a speech described as having an official character, Jefferson Caffery, retiring United States Ambassador to France, sounded today a note of caution regarding the hopes raised by prospects of a four-power conference on Germany.

The nation's stocks of major oil products changed little last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Gasoline supplies rose 38,000 barrels to 124,787,000. Light fuel oil stocks increased 184,000 barrels to 49,959,000, but heavy fuel oil supplies fell 33,000 barrels to 60,174,000.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, May 4 -- As the Palestine peace negotiations here, under United Nations auspices, proceed quietly, it has become known that France has great hopes of attaining recognition as the protector of Christian interests in Jerusalem -- a subject that Pope Pius has spoken of with increasing directness.

" AM I my brother's keeper?" Cain asked. The answer, Dr. Frederic Wertham suggests in "The Show of Violence,"* a challenging and informing study of modern murder, is "Yes." And after you read the rather dramatically presented trials and preliminary tribulations of some celebrated contemporary killers in his book, you may agree that society as a whole has a considerable responsibility for individual crimes, even in a time of flagrant carnage.

A three-man ornithological expedition to the "treasure house of migratory water fowl" in the Arctic region 200 miles south of the north magnetic pole will get under way May 17, it was announced yesterday. This area has never been explored scientifically.

Cyrille Carreau, Inc., acted as sales agent for the Pinchot Estates with Brener Lewis, Inc., as associate brokers in the recent sale of the five-story tenements at 200-210 West 105th Street, southwest corner of Amsterdam Avenue, to Harry Geisinger.

NEWPORT, R. I., May 4 -- Industrialists, historians and professors, newspaper men, soldiers, sailors and airmen commenced at the United States Naval War College today a six-day series of roundtable discussions on the "future strategy of the United States."

FORT WAYNE, Ind., May 4 (AP) -- Stockholders of the Farnsworth Television and Radio Corporation approved today a plan for sale of its properties, assets and business to the International Telephone and Telegraph Company.

As one of the first New York citizens to owe perhaps life itself to the civilian blood program of the five local chapters of the American Red Cross, 13-month-old Mary Rose Tryborn yesterday joined in a "birthday party" here marking the first anniversary of the program.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- A determined late-hour effort to take away from the military command selection of the members of courts-martial began today as the House prepared to start debate tomorrow on a bill setting up a new uniform code of military justice.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- An attractive young brunette with the name of a Greek poetess appeared today as the principal witness against Judith Coplon, who is now on trial for espionage and who was arrested March 4 in company with Valentin Gubitchev, Russian engineer.

PHALANX, N. J., May 4 -- The chant of an auctioneer rose shrill against the eaves of a rambling old communal dwelling here today. To the lone bidder among a score of prospective buyers went the last remnants of the North American Phalanx, started here in 1843 as probably the first major experiment at communal colonizing in the United States.
CHICAGO, May 4 (AP) -- The Senators hit three homers, two in the ninth inning to snare a 8-7 decision over the White Sox today and sweep a two-game series.

A summons was served yesterday on Leo Durocher directing him to appear before a magistrate in Upper Manhattan Court next Monday to answer the assault charge filed against him by Fred Boysen. However, this expected development was just a passing incident in what proved a big day in the stormy career of the Giant manager.

Increased revenues to the city from salvage returns on discarded and outmoded equipment and waste matter, as well as greater savings in city purchases in the open market, were announced yesterday by John Splain, Commissioner of Purchase.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., May 4 -- The concentration from bacteria of two substances that have been found highly effective in clearing up chronic and refractory infections in various parts of the body of human patients was reported before the Association of American Physicians, which ended its annual meting here today.

In the rare role of peacemaker, City Councilman Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, put the damper yesterday on rank-and-file moves to "jump the gun" on starting time for the union's threatened strike against the Third Avenue Transit Corporation.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The shape of new labor legislation, if any, at this session of Congress will now be determined by the ability and good faith with which the House Committee on Education and Labor sets out to redeem its promise to write a bill the majority can support.

Dollar volume of Crosley Distributing Corporation for the first four months of the 1949 fiscal year more than doubled compared with the like period last year, Bert Cole, vice president and general manager, revealed yesterday. The organization is the local factory branch of Avco Corporation's Crosley division, which produces appliances, radio and television.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- John Foster Dulles urged the Senate today to ratify the North Atlantic treaty and also to issue warnings that this country's concern with Europe's safety certainly would not leave the Soviet Union a free hand elsewhere in the world.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 4 -- Borba, official newspaper of the Yugoslav Communist party, asserted today that Austria was supplying Hungary with cotton received under the Marshall Plan in exchange for rye and sunflower seed oil and was negotiating similar arrangements with Poland and Rumania.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Declaring that the fiscal year 1951 would be critical in Federal fiscal affairs and fraught with grave public consequences, Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat, of Virginia, listed today three courses of action open to the country -- reduced public spending, increased taxes, or large-scale deficit financing.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Yugoslavia has informed the United States Government that she is approaching the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development for a loan, and has asked the United States through its representative on the bank to take a friendly attitude, Secretary of State Dean Acheson said today. The Yugoslavs are not seeking a loan from the United States Export-Import Bank.

CINCINNATI, May 4 -- Careful, sensible pricing by manufacturers will bring about a healthy condition in the present adjustment period but careless analysis and poor judgment can prove disastrous, Charles G. Pyle, managing director of the National Electrical Wholesalers Association, declared here today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 4 -- Arthur B. Krim, president of Eagle-Lion Films, Inc., since 1946, today announced his resignation from the post because of "irreconcilable differences which have arisen between management and ownership."

AMMAN, Jordan, May 4 -- Further difficulty appeared here today in the matter of the accuracy of maps defining the application of the Rhodes armistice agreement between Israel and Jordan to the railway line from Haifa to Tel Aviv.

The Vitex Laboratories of New Jersey is pioneering in the introduction of a non-fat or low-fat (skim) milk fortified not only with Vitamin D but also Vitamin A. Though a technicality in this city's Sanitary Code prevents its sale here, it is being offered in the Midwest and in Philadelphia and other Pennsylvania cities.

An investigation by the City Council of an alleged breakdown in the inspection services of city departments, which has permitted continued rat infestation and health and fire hazards in old-law tenements, was demanded yesterday by Desmond FitzGerald, chairman of the Committee of Five Million, and Gabriel L. Kaplan, its counsel.

In the special election to be held May 17 in the Twentieth Congressional District we support Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., candidate of the Liberal party, the Four Freedoms party, and numerous anti-organization Democrats, for a seat in the House of Representatives to succeed the late Sol Bloom.

Undaunted by the failure of John L. Lewis' effort to enroll New York taxicab drivers under the banner of the United Mine Workers, twenty-eight locals of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, AFL, set up a joint committee yesterday to organize taxi drivers, warehouse employes and all other workers within the technical jurisdiction of their union.

With net sales and production of automotive units sharply higher, net earnings of the Packard Motor Car Company for the first quarter of 1949 rose to $3,911,033 from $1,304,727 in the similar period of last year, George T. Christopher, president and general manager, reported yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 4 -- Members of Local 10 of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, CIO, rejected overwhelmingly today a proposal by their officers to drop 1,000 from the union's rolls for four months to spread a reduced work load among senior members.
Two individuals and two institutions received $1,000 awards yesterday for "opening new areas of knowledge" in recent years.
A new art competition open to all American and French painters and offering $28,000 in prizes was announced yesterday by Daniel J. Wildenstein of the Wildenstein Gallery, 19 East Sixty-fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The Virginia Electric and Power Company, Richmond, Va., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering $20,000,000 of first and refunding - mortgage bonds, Series G, due on June 1, 1979, that are to be sold at competitive bidding.

MONTREAL, May 4 (Canadian Press) -- Net returns from railway operations of the Canadian Pacific Railway in 1948 caused "gravel anxiety" to the company's directors "and must be viewed by shareholders with equal concern," W. A. Mather, president, said today at the sixty-eighth annual meeting of shareholders. He said net earnings -- $18,400,000 -- "fell below those of any year since 1905."

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Congress was told today that reports sent home by missionaries in foreign lands have convinced Methodist women further of the need of abolishing the poll tax and enacting other civil rights legislation.

MELBOURNE, May 4 -- Seven thousand tons of Indian coal that arrived seventy days ago in the Canadian freighter Halingonian Duke cannot be unloaded because the seamen's union has boycotted the ship and barred members of the Waterside Workers Federation from handling the cargo that has cost the people of Victoria $144,000.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., May 4 -- After having abandoned the junior high school system in 1940, this sprawling city of 65,000 residents will return to it on Sept. 1, school officials said today. The change will cost $160,000, but the Board of Education anticipates savings in teacher personnel and classroom additions.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 4 (AP) -- Hopes for a 130-mile $210,000,000 belt line to carry coal and iron ore more cheaply between Lake Erie and the Ohio River went glimmering today.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 4 -- The Ad Hoc Political Committee of the General Assembly, by a vote of 36 to 6, with eleven abstentions, today adopted a resolution inviting a representative of the Israeli Government to state its position on the status of Jerusalem and other questions preparatory to a vote on Israel's application for United Nations membership.
TEL AVIV, Israel, May 4 (UP) -- Israeli troops managed to hold a parade today on the first anniversary of the establishment of Israel as a state, after surging crowds earlier had blocked their route.

With newspapers topping all other media with a 35 per cent gain, national advertising reached an all-time high during March, it was reported yesterday by Printers' Ink. The general index is 6 per cent higher than in February, and 10 per cent above the mark for the like month of 1948, it was noted.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 4 -- The move to postpone final decision on the disposition of the former Italian colonies in Africa gained strong momentum today in the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly.

The Russell Sage Foundation is planning a radical change in its methods of operation, in keeping with its reduced income and changes in the social fabric that have taken place in the forty-two years it has been in existence.

Dr. Herbert V. Evatt, president of the United Nations General Assembly, said last night that the settlement of the Berlin blockade question was an occasion for celebration by all persons interested in world peace and particularly by those interested in the future of the United Nations.
WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Although the timing was in doubt, the eventual wind-up of the Berlin airlift was the subject of exploratory conversations here tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Three Republican members of the Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee "crashed" into the controversy over labor legislation today by unexpectedly introducing a substitute for the Administration bill.

A springtime fete that has elicited the interest and cooperation of many members of society is the May Ball to be held the night of May 19 in the main ballroom of the Plaza as a benefit for the New York Botanical Garden. Mrs. Sheldon E. Prentice is chairman of the executive committee for the fete.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The Senate turned aside additional efforts to change the bipartisan aid-to-education bill today, but hardest fight was still to come on the issue of providing services to parochial school pupils.

Ceremonies at Barnard College yesterday marked the opening of a new two-story wing to Barnard Hall, 117th Street and Broadway. Two hundred and fifty students, faculty and representatives of the Alumnae Association watched while Dean Millicent Carey McIntosh presented the key to the building to Mary Jean Huntington, president of the Undergraduate Association.

WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board today blamed an effort to take off with ice on the wings for a Seattle air crash last January in which eleven Yale University students and three crew members were killed.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 4 -- Without warning, eight members of the Social Committee of the General Assembly today demanded that all work be suspended on a future convention on freedom of information until September.
WASHINGTON, May 4 -- A three-point program aimed at curtailing Government spending was mapped today by the Senate Republican Policy Committee.

PITTSBURGH, May 4 -- Top policy officials of the United Steelworkers, CIO, drew up a collective bargaining program here today that was reported unofficially to take the form of a "package" containing demands for wages, pensions and social insurance.

The number of landlords obtaining rent-rise application forms increased here yesterday, with the six area rent offices handing out or mailing 7,845 sets. Thirty-three applications for rent increases were filed by landlords who were among the 5,000 who had obtained the blanks on Tuesday.

Coffee futures were quiet and easy in yesterday's trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Scattered long liquidation and trade hedge-selling toward the close eased prices for contract "D" 5 to 21 points. Trade covering absorbed the selling.
The Deputy Mayor of Orleans, France, said to the Mayor of Wichita, Kan.: "If I had a cow right here I could show you I can milk one."

GRAFENWOEHR, Germany, May 4 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay received an impressive farewell salute from his command today in a giant army and air force review at this former Wehrmacht training center. Then in an unusually frank interview he commented on the German scene, stressing publicly for the first time his belief that the impending agreement with Russia could be only temporary.

DETROIT, May 4 -- With no progress reported, negotiations to avert a strike at the Rouge and Lincoln plants of the Ford Motor Company were halted for an overnight recess late tonight pending a final session at 9 A. M. at the union's request.

Nat Holman, City College basketball coach, yesterday at Toots Shor's Restaurant told the press of the rising popularity of sports, especially the court game, in Israel. Just returned from a three-week coaching trip to Israel, Holman described the lack of equipment and first-rate instruction there but also told of the vast interest in all sports.

CHICAGO, May 4 -- Three advertising agency executives today praised newspapers' grocery store inventory research as highly valuable marketing tools, and called for improvements, particularly through more "intimate" data on consumers and specific details on competitive promotions.
Western diplomats are reacting to the lifting of the Berlin blockade very much as Paul Makushak, the Brooklyn broom-closet hermit, reacted to his freedom last month.

As a result of a successful last-ditch parliamentary maneuver the Administration has succeeded in achieving at least a temporary stalemate in the bitter contest over labor legislation. On Tuesday the House first rejected a compromise bill offered by the majority leadership, then voted, 217 to 203, in favor of the rival Wood bill, sponsored by a coalition of Republicans and Southern Democrats.

The nominating committee of the Propeller Club of the Port of New York has recommended the election of L. S. Sparrell of the Bethlehem Steel Company as president of the club, succeeding Harmon Lewis. The election will take place at the organization's annual meeting on June 1, Julius C. Manzi; secretary, said yesterday.

Increased sales volume as a result of price cuts was revealed here yesterday by hardware wholesalers, who said that small reductions in a variety of lines have released orders for future delivery from large industrial companies and railroads.

Calvin Bullock, 54-year-old investment management concern, will put into effect today a new plan for distributing shares of mutual investment companies to permit persons of "moderate means" to buy on the installment plan a diversified stake in prime securities at no extra cost over that incurred in the outright purchase of the shares of such funds.
PHILADELPHIA, May 4 (AP) -- John Lengyel, 29 years old, apparently was a wonder at guessing sports results before they happened.
Underwriting syndicates will offer to investors today three new issues of public utility bonds and preferred stock totaling $27,000,000.

CANTON, China, May 4 (UP) -- The Nationalist Government, faced with steady Communist victories and torn with internal bickering, sought today to set up an "Emergency Action Committee" under Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek to resist the Communist advance.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 4 -- "Stop, You're Killing Me," a comedy mystery which Harry Kurnitz and Martin Gable are writing from a screen story by Kurnitz, has been scheduled as Danny Kaye's next picture at Warner Brothers, the studio announced today.
WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- The Tennessee Gas Transmission Company sought today to show that it had a sufficient supply of gas to serve an expanded Eastern market.

Maj. Gen. Julius Ochs Adler, commanding officer of the Seventy-seventh Infantry Division, ORC, will be host at a "muster" rally of past, present and potential members of the division and their guests at 7:30 P. M. on May 18 at the 165th Regiment Armory, Lexington Avenue and Twenty-fifth Street.

MOSCOW, May 4 -- The United States press was characterized as the obedient tool of millionaire warmongers, filled with "lies, slander and shameless advertising of the American way of life" in a Soviet press article marking the celebration of the Day of the Bolshevist Press -- the anniversary of the founding of Pravda in Leningrad [then St. Petersburg] in 1912.

In your issue of May 3 Dr. Alexander Lesser, writing for the Association on American Indian Affairs, holds that the effort in Congress to give Federal sanction to the present exclusion of Arizona and New Mexico Indians from social security benefits to the aged, blind, and dependent children, does not imply racial discrimination.
PHILADELPHIA, May 4 (AP) -- The Phillies ran their winning streak to five games and Ken Heintzelman chalked up his fourth successive pitching triumph with a 7-5 decision over the Cardinals tonight.

NEWARK, N. J., May 4 -- The signing of the Atlantic pact will be the prelude to a Mediterranean pact that will imperil the independence of Israel, Henry Wallace said tonight at a "Peace Rally" held by the Progressive party of New Jersey in the Mosque Theatre here.

The Commonwealth of Massachusetts announced yesterday that it would receive bids on May 16 on issues of bonds totaling $23,800,000. The obligations will be dated March 1, April 1, May 1 and June 1, 1949, and will mature in the years from 1950 to 1979.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Twelve of the Nazi SS troopers convicted in the Malmedy massacre of United States soldiers during the Battle of the Bulge were sentenced to death on "unreliable" evidence, a Senate Armed Services subcommittee investigating American military justice in Germany was told today by a former colonel who reviewed the trials.
SHANGHAI, May 4 -- Although the loss of Hangchow has cut Shanghai's last land communication with the rest of China, no Communist drive toward this city seems under way yet.

BERLIN, May 4 -- The battle for Berlin is over. The battle for Germany is about to begin. As the long, bitter struggle for this city moved swiftly toward a triumphant conclusion for the United States, Britain and France tonight, the people of Berlin, half in relief and half in apprehension, greeted the news that an accord had been reached by the Big Four on lifting of the Berlin blockade.

Keith Lorenz, a New York lawyer, was moved up yesterday by Governor Dewey to the chairmanship of the State Labor Relations Board. Mr. Lorenz said in an interview that his first aims would be to speed up the work of the board and to obtain a clearer definition of the relations between it and the National Labor Relations Board.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 4 -- The United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union have agreed that the Soviet blockade of Berlin, together with counter-measures imposed by the Western powers, is to be raised and that the Council of Foreign Ministers shall take up "questions relating to Germany and the problems arising out of the situation in Berlin, including also questions of currency in Berlin," it was announced today.

Jack Toomey's wildness on the mound proved the undoing of the Manhattan College baseball team yesterday as the Jaspers dropped a 6-1 decision to Brooklyn College in a Metropolitan Conference game at Van Cortlandt Stadium. For the Kelly Greens, it was their sixth loss in seven league outings, while the Kingsmen raised their league mark to 3 -- 3.

Brewers' dried yeast, formerly a waste product of the industry, has been found effective for increasing nutritional values of white bread, candies and other confections, it was disclosed here yesterday.
When Mayor O'Dwyer proclaimed this and next week as "Spring Clean-up Weeks" it seems as though the proposed "clean-up" is to be confined to the outdoors -- to the vacant lots in particular.

In a dramatic vindication of the policy they have pursued, the Western Powers are now able to announce that Soviet Russia has agreed to lift the Berlin blockade, imposed more than ten months ago. As a result, the Western counter-blockade will likewise be lifted, and "after an interval" following the restoration of more normal conditions the Council of Foreign Ministers will meet to discuss the German problem.

VIENNA, May 4 -- In a shakeup of the Soviet military command here paralleling the recent shuffling of top political posts in Russia, Gen. Vladimir Kurasov has been replaced by Col. Gem V. P. Sviridov. The first intimation of it was his farewell visits today to the British High Commissioner in Austria and President Karl Renner of Austria.
PHILADELPHIA, May 4 -- Jim Smith walloped a 350-foot homer in the ninth inning today to give the Penn baseball team a 2-1 victory over Brown at River Field.

Constantine (Gus) Lewis of the Chicago Town Club, defending titleholder, easily disposed of John Miller of the home club, 21 -- 5, 21 -- 5, in the third round of the men's National A. A. U. four-wall softball handball championship at the New York A. C. last night.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety- four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended April 27, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:

Fortune Gallo's San Carlo Opera Company opened its twelfth annual season at the Center Theatre last night with a performance of Verdi's "Aida." The presentation was both smooth and animated, arousing the enthusiastic approval of the large audience in attendance.

WHITMAN, Mass., May 4 -- Francis Cardinal Spellman began observance of his sixtieth birthday today by celebrating mass in the chapel he had dedicated to the memory of his mother, Mrs. Mary Conway Spellman, in the Church of the Holy Ghost.

The first anniversary of the establishment of Israel as a nation was celebrated with demonstrations yesterday at Madison Square Park and Carnegie Hall and by a dinner at which Governor Dewey urged the admission of Israel to the United Nations.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 4 -- Turkish and United States officials were present today at ceremonies marking the unloading of the first consignment of Marshall Plan goods for Turkey.

Albert B. Ashforth, Inc., has been appointed renting and managing agent for the eighteen-story Crowell-Collier office building under construction at the northwest corner of Fifth Avenue and Fifty-first Street. The firm will act as renting agent for the Crowell-Collier Publishing Company and as managing agent for the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

BUENOS AIRES, May 5 -- As President Juan Peron signed papers today formally completing last year's purchase of the British railways, his Government published a decree nationalizing four mixed-company airlines. Nationalization, in effect, will end the role of private enterprise in domestic air transport.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Paul G. Hoffman let it be known today that he had no intention of resigning as Economic Cooperation Administrator any time in the foreseeable future but would continue in that position at least until the Marshall Plan was an assured success.

Consolidated net earnings of the Chrysler Corporation for the first quarter of 1949 amounted to $18,707,951, equal to $2.15 a capital share, compared with $14,921,644, or $1.71 a share, in the similar period of last year, K. T. Keller, president, reported yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, May 5 (AP) -- Red Embree cracked, as did also the Browns' defense, in the eighth inning tonight and the Senators pushed across three runs to hand last-place St. Louis its sixth straight defeat, 5 to 3. Clyde Vollmer slammed his fifth homer with one on and singled across another run for Washington.

At least six months of experience with the new exchange rate for the yen will be necessary before judgment as to the accuracy of the rate can be formed, international-exchange experts advised foreign traders and others here yesterday.

The city's price-controlled parking lot on the site of the old Tombs and Criminal Courts Building is unable to pay its way and the operators, who assert they are losing $5,000 a month, face eviction within a week, it was learned yesterday.

Steps are now being taken by manufacturers and wholesalers to organize sales drives based on the new Federal Housing Administration loan provisions which require no down payment for household, commercial and industrial modernization projects up to $2,500 each. As many as two projects with a top limit of $5,000 per borrower are allowed on this basis.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 5 -- The Western powers have already informed the Soviet Union that they hope the impending Council of Foreign Ministers, which will convene in Paris on May 23, will end around June 15, a month before the date on which the proposed Western German Government is to be in operation, it was learned tonight.

General Electric Company yesterday reduced list prices of two six-cubic-foot capacity refrigerators $17 and $15, respectively. The first unit was cut from $216 to $199 and the second from $224 to $209.

In spite of the thermometer, the Ballet Theatre danced last night before an audience that filled the Metropolitan Opera House to overflowing. Its program consisted of four works, all tried and true: "Petruchka," "Pillar of Fire," the "Black Swan" pas de deux and "Fancy Free."

Federal Judge Samuel H. Kaufman declared yesterday that he was "very doubtful with the present state of the record" that he would approve the petition filed by the holders of $16,000 of the Third Avenue Transit Corporation's $14,830,550 of refunding bonds for reorganization of the firm under the bankruptcy laws.

SHANGHAI, May 5 (AP) -- The Government's Official Central News Agency reported today that Communists had signed a mutual defense pact with the Russian-sponsored North Korean regime and had pledged aid to Burmese Communists in "the joint struggle against American and British imperialism."

The same type of chair that nineteenth-century housewives bought from Yankee peddlers is now offered to local homemakers at Macy's. The famous Hitchcock chair, with its typical gold-stenciled fruit or basket designs on soft black, are now being produced in Riverton, Conn., at the site of the original plant of Lambert Hitchcock at Hitchcocks-ville.

About 200 members of Congress will tour New York Harbor tomorrow afternoon on a four-hour cruise arranged by the Port of New York Authority, the New York City Department of Commerce and the Commerce and Industry Association of New York.

LONDON, May 6--The British Government is moving swiftly to reinforce the defenses of Hong Kong in face of a potential threat from the Chinese Communist forces, A. V. Alexander, Minister of Defense, announced today in the House of Commons.

The hopes of Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. for the backing of all major labor organizations in his campaign for election as Representative from the Twentieth Congressional District of Manhattan received a setback last night when the official endorsement of the American Federation of Labor was denied to him.
KARACHI, Pakistan, April 24 -Pakistan, according to business analysts here, is near the crossroads of her economic future. The record, they say, is good, but the outlook is mixed.

LONDON, May 5 -- The United States Government is going quietly ahead with plans to set up military supply missions in each of the countries that may receive arms under the military arms program now before Congress, it is learned here.

Several York County, Pa., bedroom furniture manufacturers are guaranteeing prices for an indefinite period, wholesale salesmen reported yesterday. Dealers are assured of inventory rebates in the event of price declines, they said. The concerns involved are in the medium to high price brackets, with three-piece suites retailing from $300 to $600.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., May 5 -- The campaign to upset the Hague machine took over the downtown section of this city tonight. Thirty thousand persons in Journal Square, once the sacrosanct precinct of the Hague forces whenever a parade or rally was held, cheered loudly the speeches of an opposition slate that seeks to end the thirty-two year political domination of Hudson County by Frank Hague and his appointed successors.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 5 -- An advance guard of scientists and technicians, drawn from every part of the world, is quietly preparing the first assault in a global campaign against want proposed by President Truman in the now-famous Point 4 of his inaugural address of Jan. 20.

Yesterday Dr. Robert C. Clothier announced that Rutgers University, of which he is president, will establish an Institute of Microbiology at a cost of $1,000,000. The Institute will stand apart not only because it will be the first and most comprehensive of its kind but because it will serve as a monument to Dr. Selman A. Waksman, the discoverer of streptomycin, who will be its director.

News that the old "Phalanstery" at Phalanx, N. J., has been sold for $500 at a court auction stirs up a lot of historic memories. The strange word comes from the gentle socialism that Charles Fourier was preaching more than a century ago. In this new country, where land was to be had almost for the asking and opportunities for individual advancement grew on every bush, the movement strangely caught on.

Principal producers of cellulose acetate filament yarn have been quoting below their published list prices, it was pointed out in the trade yesterday. Such quotations were made on low twist numbers on cones and beams and were the forerunner of price reductions announced by American Viscose Corporation on standard and low twist numbers.
SHANGHAI, Friday, May 6 (AP) -- Several thousand Communist troops today opened attacks northwest and southwest of Shanghai. This may mean the move against this great city has begun.

With the sales of three more dwellings in the Daylight Homes development of 110 one-family houses for veterans in the Lido Canals section of Long Beach, L. I., Stewart A. and Howard A. Burkland, builders, reported yesterday that only two remain to be sold.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 5 -- Princeton University undergraduates will welcome 1,300 young women guests to their Prospect Street eating clubs tomorrow, ushering in three days of spring house parties, the biggest social attraction of the year on the campus.

The twentieth annual report of the Allied Stores Corporation disclosed yesterday that sales of $419,227,618 for the fiscal year ended on Jan. 31, were the largest on record and 6.9 per cent greater than the $392,199,076 volume of the previous fiscal year.

The announcement that Gen. Lucius D. Clay will retire as head of the United States Military Government in Germany and as commander of the American military forces in Europe prompts me to call attention to the career of this remarkable soldier and to the extraordinary service he has rendered to his country.

BUFFALO, Way 5 -- A new medical technique for relieving pain and muscle spasm following a poliomyelitis attack was described here today during the annual meeting of the New York State Medical Society.

The motorship Peter Maersk, latest addition to the Moller Steamship Company's fleet of Danish-flag cargo-passenger ships, operating between United States ports and the Far East, is now in New York on her maiden voyage. The new vessel is scheduled to leave here on Tuesday, company officials said yesterday.

Dr. Leonard A. Scheele, Surgeon-General of the United States Public Health Service, warned last night against arousing false hopes by overemphasizing advances thus far made in cancer research. Contending that cancer research must rather strive to improve our knowledge of cancer, he cautioned that "the penalty of exaggeration is disillusionment."

The New York Central Railroad and the Chicago Great Western Railway borrowed $17,745,000 yesterday on new issues of trust certificates intended to finance the purchase of new equipment. The issues were sold at competitive bidding as follows:

The thirtieth anniversary of the first flight across the Atlantic will be marked with ceremonies here Sunday. The Navy's Truculent Turtle, the P2V2, Lockheed Neptune, the world's long distance champion, will take off from Floyd Bennett Field, near the point from which, on May 8, 1919, three lumbering Navy-Curtiss flying boats started their record venture to Plymouth, England, via the Azores and Lisbon.

Mike Jacobs, veteran boxing promoter who has been the kingpin in the fight game for a dozen years and the guiding light of the Twentieth Century Sporting Club, is about to give up his throne. This was indicated yesterday when it was announced by Brig. Gen. John Reed Kilpatrick, president of Madison Square Garden, that Jacobs' club would relinquish its promotional rights at the Garden to a new corporation.

Brushing aside a psychiatrist's report that Robert Brown, slayer of a manager at the Greystone Hotel last Sept. 7, was insane, General Sessions Judge Saul S. Streit yesterday sentenced the defendant to forty-five years to life in state prison.

If there could be a free interchange of news between the people of Russia and the United States, problems that now beset the two countries would "in large measure" disappear, Arthur Hays Sulzberger, president and publisher of THE NEW YORK TIMES, declared last night.

James G. Blaine, retiring chief of the Economic Cooperation Administration mission in Belgium and Luxembourg, dashed cold water yesterday on hopes in some quarters that the end of the Berlin blockade may lead to a general peace settlement.
