CLEVELAND, May 5 (AP) -- With Bob Feller going all the way for his first victory of the season, the Cleveland Indian sluggers crushed the Boston Red Sox, 7 to 3, today.

On the steps of St. Patrick's Cathedral from 10 A. M. to 6 P. M. on May 18 the Outdoor Cleanliness Association will conduct its sixteenth annual flower mart to raise funds for advancing its civic projects to "clean up, fix up, light up, paint up and plant up" toward a cleaner and more attractive city.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on April 30, 1949, totaled 785,444 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 16,108, or 2.1 per cent more than in the preceding week, 105,671, or 11.9 per cent fewer than in the corresponding week of last year, and 97,130, or 11 per cent fewer than in the corresponding week of 1947.

LONDON, May 5 -- The British Government has decided to drop war crimes charges against Field Marshal Karl von Rundstedt and Col. Gen. Adolf Strauss, aged German war chiefs, and to release them because they are unfit to stand trial, it was announced tonight in the House of Lords.

Alexander Stevens, alias J. V. Peters, alleged Communist underground chief, has been authorized by the United States Commissioner of Immigration to depart from this country voluntarily, Edward J. Shaughnessy, District Immigration Director, announced yesterday.

ROME, May 5 -- A large majority of the Italians heaved a sigh of relief when the agreement on lifting the blockade of Berlin was announced today. The Communists and their allies did not share the general feeling of pleasure because any step toward the elimination of the Berlin sore spot so soon after the conclusion of the North Atlantic treaty runs counter to their thesis that the treaty is "a war pact."

Egypt is expecting its largest tourist season since the war, with 10,000 Americans spending an estimated $3,000,000 between November and April, Joseph Renson, director and general manager of the Egyptian Hotels, Ltd., said here yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 5 -- Czechoslovakia will ask Dr. Herbert V. Evatt, president of the United Nations General Assembly, to urge the United States to allow a representative of the Greek rebel Government to come to Lake Success, it was learned today.

Rabbi Philip S. Bernstein of Rochester, former adviser on Jewish Affairs to the United States Army in Germany, warned last night against becoming too sanguine about the political future of the State of Israel.

Not since the days of the Gibson Girl has the shirtwaist and skirt promised to reach the fashion importance that it does this summer. It will be donned by the busy commuter for town and the leisurely vacationer in the country.
WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) -- United States foreign trade reached the highest point of the year in March, the Department of Commerce reported today.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The feeder airlines -- smaller certificated companies that operate in local regions or areas -- were described to a Senate Commerce subcommittee today as doing a better job than the major trunk lines could do in local service.

A woman was the central character in a post-war type of success story unfolded yesterday when Helene Hoffman was appointed a $17,000-a-year new car sales manager of Ralph Norgan, Inc., 1842 Broadway, Ford dealer. She is described by the company as "the first, and thus far the only woman to attain such an executive position in the automobile industry in New York City."

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 5 (UP) -- Hitting his iron shots dead to the pin, Cary Middlecoff, the golfing dentist from Memphis, took a two-stroke lead in the first round of the $10,000 Greenbrier invitation tournament today with a four under par 33, 33 -- 66.

The American Public Health Association called yesterday for a national conference on public health problems, to be sponsored by major professional organizations, but to include ample representation of the general public.

A bill to set up a new uniform code of military justice was passed by a House voice vote yesterday and sent to the Senate. It is a good bill, as far as it goes, but it doesn't go far enough. What it does to provide like procedures in the various service arms is an essential part of unification and should be supported and approved.

Failure to curb child mortality in highway accidents was attributed in part yesterday by Maj. Gen. Philip B. Fleming, Federal Works Administrator, to the apathetic attitudes of women's groups and residents of rural areas. He spoke at a luncheon of the commercial vehicle section of the Greater New York Safety Council at Rosoffs Restaurant, 147 West Forty-third Street.

" Patterns of Anti-Democratic Thought," by David Spitz, a summing up of the antidemocratic thinking of the homemade American variety rather than attacks from foreign "isms," will be published by Macmillan May 17. Mr. Spitz, a political scientist teaching at Ohio State University, presents his arguments against the thinking of such writers as James Burnham, Lawrence Dennis, Ralph Adams Cram, George Santayana and Irving Babbitt.

In reply to the demand of Desmond FitzGerald, chairman of the Committee of Five Million, and Gabrial L. Kaplan, its counsel, for a City Council investigation of an alleged breakdown of inspection of rat infested old law tenements, Mayor O'Dwyer declared yesterday that New York in the last three years had led the nation in new housing and slum clearance.

After being questioned for two hours by the special Federal grand jury investigating subversive activities, Representative Richard M. Nixon, Republican of California, said yesterday he would recommend to his colleagues on the House Committee on Un-American Activities that they "stay out of" any current espionage case being considered by a grand jury.

City College celebrated the 102d anniversary of its chartering and the thirtieth anniversary of the establishment of its Schools of Technology and Business in Charter Day ceremonies yesterday in the college's Great Hall, Convent Avenue and 139th Street.

An application filed with Surrogate William T. Collins for letters of administration on the estate of Mrs. Bertha M. Gillespie Voss, widow of Frederick G. Voss, wealthy insurance broker, who was found dead in her apartment at 118 West Ninety-first Street, disclosed that she had removed her will from a safe deposit box of the Guaranty Trust Company "for the purpose of revoking" it.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 5 -- Following are excerpts from statements by Dr. Charles Malik, representative of Lebanon, and Aubrey S. Eban, Israeli representative, before the Ad Hoc Political Committee on Israel's application for membership in the United Nations:
Eleven years ago today in Rome the Vatican closed churches and museums in protest against Adolf Hitler visiting the city.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Marked by bickering and wrangling, play acting by Archibald Palmer, the defense lawyer, and more stern admonitions by Judge Albert L. Reeves, the espionage trial of Judith Coplon plodded along again today.

Major appliance manufacturers were urged yesterday to cooperate in eliminating a new wave of "phony" trade-in discounts. The request was in the form of a "memo" that is being sent out by the National Better Business Bureau, Inc., to all known manufacturers of radio and television receivers, refrigerators, vacuum cleaners, gas and electric ranges, washing machines and sewing machines.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The International Association of Machinists has resorted to the Taft-Hartley Law in its long feud with the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners, AFL, over jurisdiction. As a result, the general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board has applied for an injunction for the first time in an inter-union dispute.
CAIRO, May 5 (AP) -- Hamid Gouda, 65-year-old president of the Chamber of Deputies, escaped with his life tonight when three hand grenades were hurled at his car.

Those scribbling out the weekend market list might note on it pineapples, ducklings, peas, strawberries, new beets, bacon and porgies. Though ill-assorted perhaps, these foods all share one welcome point in common: they are lower in price today than they were last Friday.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that the Oklahoma Gas and Electric Company, Oklahoma City, had filed a registration statement covering $10,000,000 of first mortgage bonds, series due June 1, 1979, to be sold at competitive bidding.

Opening wide their nets, New York art galleries catch this week a widely diversified haul. At Durlacher a group of contemporary British and American drawings line the walls, while the center of the gallery is occupied by plastic domed tanks containing a display unusual enough to startle the most jaded gallery goer.

While landlords obtained 7,460 blanks for rent-rise applications yesterday and telephoned requests for 1,200 more, only thirty-five petitions for increases under the Housing Expediter's "fair net operating income" formula were filed.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 5 -- There was one addition to the Kentucky Derby field, one withdrawal and one outstanding workout for Saturday's big run as this theatre of turf operations continued to sizzle in 90-degree-plus weather today. A count of noses in Churchill Downs barns turned fourteen apparently definite startters, which would mean a gross value of $119,650 and a net to the winner of $91,600.

CHICAGO, May 5 -- In a move designed to check the mad dash of the Yankees, the trick fence that created an artificial home-run arrangement was removed from Comiskey Park this morning, but the greatest getaway pace a Yankee club has ever generated continued unchecked.

In a cash transaction reported yesterday, David A. Schulte purchased the five-story building occupied for more than twenty-five years by M. H. Harris, optician, at 9 East Forty-second Street. It is assessed for $435,000 and was bought from Harvey L. Schwamm, president of the National Bronx Bank, through Henry Shapiro Co,. brokers.

Net profit of the Burroughs Adding Machine Company for the quarter ended with March amounted to $2,746,323, equal to 55 cents a share, compared with $2,521,822, or 50 cents a share, in the initial three months of 1948, John S. Coleman, president, reported to stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday in Detroit.

The six-story apartment building with eighty-four suites and nine stores at 272 South Broadway, Yonkers, N. Y., has been purchased for cash by a client of Abraham Sobil from the Park Hill Gardens Corporation through the Sonnenblick-Goldman Corporation, broker, who also arranged a first mortgage loan of $275,000 on the property with a frontage of 216 by 187 feet.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- John L. Lewis and Southern coal operators moved today toward an agreement on the time and place of a joint wage conference to write an agreement replacing the one expiring on June 30.

DETROIT, Mich., May 5 -- The United Automobile Workers, CIO, throttled the gigantic River Rouge plant with a strike today to start a creeping paralysis that will bring the whole manufacturing system of the Ford Motor Company to a halt in a few days.
PASADENA, Calif., May 5 (AP) -- Palomar Observatory's 200-inch telescope may be able to see six hundred million trillion miles farther into space than anybody expected.

PARIS, May 5--Carven's opening took the spectators to Africa, with mannikins stepping forth from a thatched hut. Mme. Carven brought back from a recent voyage a fund of ideas, novelties and fascinating printed cottons to harmonize with sun-bronzed skins.

The addition of three more steamship operators to the eight who have signified approval of the city's plan to designate public loaders on city-owned piers which the companies lease was announced yesterday by Investigation Commissioner John M. Murtagh.

Gen. George C. Marshall has accepted the post of Chairman of the Board of Trustees of New York International House, it was announced yesterday by David Rockefeller, chairman of the organization's executive committee. General Marshall assumed a position held by Henry L. Stimson, former Secretary of State and of War, for twelve years before he resigned last year.

Today's events: Three - Choir Festival, Music of the Americas, Otto Luening, Lazare Saminsky, conductors, Kathryn Oakes and Barbara Stevenson, sopranos, Shirley Wikler, contralto, Robert Goss, baritone, George Perle, William Harms, piano, Robert Baker, organ, Esther Glazer, violin, choirs of Barnard College and Temple Emanu-El, at Temple Emanu-El, 2:30 o'clock; second concert, 5 P. M., with the temple choir. Vivian Bauer, contralto, Dr. Baker and Miss Oakes.

Father Knickerbocker, in the person of James J. O'Brien, scholarly secretary of the Department of Public Works, took off yesterday afternoon from La Guardia Airport, Queens, on an eighteen-day flight around the world as the "good-will world trade emissary of the City of New York."

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- President Truman chided his Congressional leaders today for failure to make progress or a bill that would pave the way for reorganizing the Federal Government as recommended by the commission headed by former President Herbert Hoover.

Manager Bucky Walters had high hopes that his Reds were going to win their fifth game in two seasons from the Dodgers when first Hank Sauer and then Red Stallcup hit home runs at Ebbets Field yesterday.

Yesterday's critical evaluations of "Mrs. Gibbons' Boys," which opened Wednesay night at the Music Box, weren't what George Abbott, producer-director, had bargained for. This also applied to the authors, Will Glickman and Joseph Stein, a new collaborating team.

Msgr. Francis J. Murphy, secretary to Cardinal Spellman, issued a statement last night on the subject of the Cardinal's conversation last month with President Chaim Weizmann of Israel, who mentioned that matter in an interview yesterday as he was leaving for Europe.

Ed Argow, a junior in the School of Commerce, opened the eighth inning with a towering home run over the left field fence to give the City College baseball team a 3-2 victory over Brooklyn College in a Metropolitan Collegiate Conference contest at Macombs Dam Park yesterday.
Harness racing will start its tenth season tonight at Roosevelt Raceway, Westbury, L. I., with the Goshen, a Class 15 pace, featuring the program. The eight-race card will begin at 8:40 P.M.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Following is the vote by which the Senate tonight passed and sent to the House the $300,000,000 Federal Aid-to-Education Bill:

In at least one respect New York should look toward its sister state of New Jersey with admiration and envy. The New Jersey State Department of Agencies and Institutions, realizing that there was a long-felt need for a center where emotionally disturbed children could be treated, established the Arthur Brisbane Child Treatment Center at Allaire two years ago as an experimental project.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- A plan to put national defense expenditures on a firm budgetary and fiscal management basis leading to a possible saving of $1,500,000,000 a year was laid before Congress today.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, May 5 -- In terms of historical timing, the present appears to be a peculiarly propitious moment for the three-power United Nations Conciliation Commission to attempt to push through the mutual concessions by Arabs and Israelis necessary to the conclusion of a permanent Palestine settlement.
Three children from Brooklyn's Williamsburg Settlement officially informed Bernard M. Baruch yesterday that he will be the recipient of the settlement's 1949 Gold Medal Award.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- President Truman declared today that the House vote recommitting the Wood labor bill was a victory for the Administration. He said he thought his party loyalty test for granting patronage privileges was working.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Spokesmen for 2,000,000 coal miners from twelve nations decided today to boycott a conference called for next month in Milan, Italy, for the purpose of forming an international miners affiliate of the Communist-dominated World Federation of Trade Unions.

On Johnny Mize's tenth-inning home run and a stout bit of pinch pitching by Henry Behrman, the Giants beat the Pirates, 3 -- 2, yesterday for a clean sweep of their three-game series. The tense struggle was witnessed by a gathering of 8,422 spectators at the Polo Grounds.

Formal announcement of the agreement between Soviet Russia and the West to lift the Berlin blockade is welcomed everywhere with relief. This feeling is justified not only because the agreement eliminates the most dangerous point of friction in the "cod war" but also because it confirms what has been the basic assumption of recent Western policy.

MOSCOW, May 5 -- Special radio broadcasts brought the news to the Russian people today of the decision to lift the Berlin restrictions and convene the Council of Foreign Ministers -- news that was welcomed by Soviet citizens as tangible evidence that international tension had eased.

" Flamingo Road," which opens at the Strand, is this morning's lone film newcomer. The Warner Brothers drama, starring Joan Crawford and Zachary Scott and dealing with political intrigue, was directed by Michael Curtiz and produced by Jerry Wald from the play by Sally and Robert Wilder.

GENEVA, Friday, May 6 -- A 16 per cent rise in production and a 25 per cent reduction in the overseas deficit brought Europe a substantial distance along the road to economic restoration in 1948, the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe reported today in its annual survey of the European economy.

Joseph E. O'Grady, director of the City Labor Relations Division, moved in last night in an effort to prevent a strike that would shut off service on the lines of the Third Avenue Transit Corporation and deprive 1,800,000 riders in Manhattan, the Bronx and Westchester of their normal transportation.

A 79-year-old Harlem landlord and attorney, who was said to own more than a dozen tenements in Harlem, was fined $500 yesterday and received a suspended ninety-day sentence for failure to correct sanitary violations on one of his properties.

The growing volubility of stockholders at annual meetings was reemphasized yesterday when nine of the 150 attending the annual meeting of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company held the floor the better part of the hour-and-a-half session. The meeting was held in the seventh-floor auditorium of the utility's main office at 176 Remsen Street, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Department store sales in the week ended April 30 were 4 per cent below sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like period of 1948:

Prices on the New York Stock Exchange closed mixed yesterday, following the rally of the previous session which ran into some profit-taking. Trading volume dropped to 920,000 shares from 1,180,000 on Wednesday, although several thousand-share blocks changed hands in the first hour.

The election of Thomas N. Lacy of Detroit, president of the Michigan Bell Telephone Company, as president of the Telephone Pioneers of America for the year beginning July 1 was announced yesterday. He will succeed Carl Whitmore, president of the New York Telephone Company.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- During the week ended May 4, member bank reserve balances increased $53,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

BERLIN, May 5 -- Lifting of the Berlin blockade and resumption of Big Four talks on Germany will open the way to "early establishment" of a unified Germany, Gen. Sir Brian Robertson, British Military Governor, asserted today.

DETROIT, May 5 (AP) -- Left-hander Ted Gray, aided by the relief pitching of Paul (Dizzy) Trout and a two-run homer by Catcher Aaron Robinson, led the Detroit Tigers to a 6-5 triumph over the Philadelphia Athletics today.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 5 -- William K. Divers, chairman of the Home Loan Bank Board, Washington, reported here tonight that the 211 New Jersey member savings and loan associations of the Federal Home Loan Bank System increased their combined resources by 60 per cent in the three full post-war years.

But Why Not supplied a fair share of "getaway day" money to her sympathizers at Jamaica yesterday. Given only a middle chance of finishing ahead of such well-thought-of opponents as Conniver, Mother and Paddleduck in the Firenze Handicap, the 5-year-old daughter of Blue Larkspur surprised the greater part of the crowd of 23,348 by stepping home first in the $28,350 test for fillies and mares.

Along with many other New Yorkers I have been greatly concerned with the serious congestion in midtown Manhattan, especially during the early morning and late afternoon rush to and from offices and business establishments. The two residential areas which have increased most rapidly in metropolitan New York in the last few years are Long Island and adjacent suburban towns in New Jersey.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., May 5 -- The nineteenth annual festival of American music of the Eastman School of Music, of which Dr. Howard Hanson is the director, began tonight before an overflow audience in Kilbourn Hall.

DETROIT, May 5 -- A delicate operation, called a segmental resection, by which the diseased portion of a tubercular lung is removed without destroying the function of the organ was described today to the National Tuberculosis Association by Dr. J. Maxwell Chamberlain, associate visiting surgeon of Bellevue Hospital, New York.

PHILADELPHIA, May 5 (AP) - Ron Northey's first home run of the season in the ninth inning gave the Cardinals a 3-2 decision over the Phillies in the final game of their series today. Philadelphia's winning streak was snapped at five games.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The resignation of W. John Kenney as Under-Secretary of the Navy was announced today by President Truman.

Persons from thirteen nations behind the Iron Curtain, including Russia itself, last night adopted a resolution in Carnegie Hall, pledging their support for a fight against communism and promising to adjourn their differences until the Communist menace in Europe had been ended.
Thomas Mann, German-born novelist, expressed the opinion here yesterday that Russian agreement to lift the Berlin blockade was part of a long-range bid for peace, not an isolated act.

Dr. Herbert V. Evatt and Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt shared the speaker's platform at the Radio Executives Club luncheon yesterday to stress the importance of United States citizens giving full support to the United Nations.
Safeguarding the quality of New York City's milk supply at its source on 43,297 dairy farms is entrusted to the Health Department's corps of country inspectors
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday and final prices were 6 to 18 points net higher than on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Reiterating his thesis, expressed earlier in the week, that it did not matter what prices were so long as everybody shared ntaional wealth fairly, President Truman added today that provision would be made for fixed-income groups under such a system.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Legislation to give the Federal Reserve Board a two-year extension of its authority to control installment credit and to continue indefinitely its present temporary powers over required bank reserves was introduced in the Senate today by Senator Burnet R. Maybank, Democrat, of South Carolina.

A bit of Mexico landed right in the heart of teeming New York City, yesterday noon. The collection of a young Mexican designer, Ramon Valdiosera, was colorfully presented in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. To add to its authenticity six beautiful girls were brought here from Mexico by the Mexican Government Tourist Commission, under whose sponsorship the showing was held.
The city of Tulsa, Okla., announced yesterday that it would receive bids on June 7 on bond issues totaling $6,430,000.

With a declaration that "American churches cannot properly stand apart" from the problem of civil rights for minorities, the Committee on Christian Relations of the Presbyterian Church of the United States (South) releases a report on States' Rights and Human Rights" which constitutes an important chapter in race relations.

BONN, Germany, May 5 -- Under the stimulus of developments in the German problem, members of the Parliamentary Council's Steering Committee tonight rushed to completion the fourth and final reading of the draft of a Western German constitution.

Papers' April Gain 3.11% Advertising in the eight major New York daily newspapers during April totaled 13,634,545 lines, a gain of 3.11 per cent, an analysis of Media Records showed yesterday. Categories recording gains were: Automotive, up 56.29 per cent, and retail, 7.33 per cent. Those with losses were: General, down 8.73 per cent; financial, 7.11 per cent, and classified, 6.20 per cent.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The House Judiciary Committee gave final approval today to a displaced persons bill that would permit 339,000 persons, who fled their homelands to escape either Nazi or Communist oppression, to find a permanent haven in this country.

A radio address by President Truman on Monday, May 16, will be the feature of an hour-long broadcast stressing the importance of the forthcoming "Opportunity" bond drive of the United States Treasury.

FRANKFORT, Germany, May 5 -- The completeness of the Allied economic victory in Germany was indicated today when the Frankfort representative of the Soviet zone's Economic Commission expressed a readiness to accept a new post-blockade trade agreement with the Western areas on the basis of the Western currency.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 5 -- Joseph Mankiewicz was amed today by the Screen Directors Guild as the recipient of the Guild's quarterly award for the excellence of his work as director of "A Letter to Three Wives," a Twentieth Century-Fix film.

With the advance guard of the weakfish arriving in Peconic Bay, mackerel schools showing not too far off the Long Island shore, and the trout streams within a 150-mile radius of the city reported to be in excellent condition for fly fishing, this week-end offers a real variety of fishing for the first time this season.

American business men and trade organizations must overcome their apathetic attitudes toward members of the armed forces, Frank L. Weil, chairman of the President's Committee on Religion and Welfare in the Armed Forces declared yesterday. He addressed the closing session of the seventy-third annual convention of the United States Brewers Foundation in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- President Truman welcomed today the opportunity to renew the search for peace at the point that it had reached ten months ago, before Russia's blockade of the West at Berlin. Making his first comment on the outcome of the negotiations with Russia in New York, the Chief Executive, at his weekly news conference, was cautious and terse, but obviously gratified and relieved by the salutary turn in events.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 5 -- Poland demanded here today that the United Nations General Assembly broaden its two-year policy of diplomatic sanctions against the Franco Government to include a new recommendation to the fifty-eight member countries to cease all export of arms and strategic materials to Spain.

The sea-going career of Capt. Charles W. Whidden, which extends over forty-eight years, will come to an end on June 1, when he will retire as commodore and senior master of the United Fruit Company's "Great White Fleet," it was announced yesterday at an informal ceremony at Pier 3, North River.

The scarcity of freight offerings during the second and third quarters of 1948, caused by the shifting of foreign trade from normal commercial to Marshall Plan channels, and increased operating expenses, were responsible for the reduction of net profits of the United States Lines from $10,145,572 for 1947 to $3,421,996 at the end of 1948, John M. Franklin, president, declared yesterday.

One sure way to court socialism and communism is to do nothing to aid low cost housing, Herman T. Etichman, State Housing Commissioner, said yesterday afternoon at the cornerstone laying ceremonies at the Lillian Wald Houses, Avenue D and East Fifth street.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES of April 26 you report Dr. Weizmann's denial of "aggressive aims" in Palestine. Perhaps your readers will be interested to know how these denials of aggression square with facts.

Vice President Alben W. Barkley will receive the first Four Freedoms Award and speak at a dinner in his honor next Friday night in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, it was announced yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora, chairman of the Franklin D. Roosevelt Four Freedoms Award Committee.

HEWLETT, L. I., May 5 -- Long Island's amateur golf champion, John Humm, and his partner, Ed Neu of Rockville, combined for a 73 over the Seawane Harbor course to win the qualifying medal in the second William D. Richardson memorial tourney sponsored by the Long Island Golf Association today.

ALBANY, May 5 (AP) -- The State Public Service Commission approved today a plan for reorganization of the International Railway Company which operates interurban lines and buses and trolleys in Buffalo and Niagara Falls.

LONDON, May 5(AP) -- Mel Patton's 9.3-second 100-yard dash was approved by the International Amateur Athletic Federation today as the official world record. The University of Southern California star achieved his remarkable time a year ago at Fresno, Calif.

Business loans made by banks in this area continued their downward trend last week, declining $72,000,000, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York disclosed yesterday. According to the figures covering the reporting New York City member banks during the week ended on Wednesday, the reduction is the tenth in as many weeks, and brings the total of such borrowings outstanding to $5,017,000,000, the lowest point since Oct. 22, 1947.

Mrs. Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit, India's Ambassador to the United States, arrived at La Guardia Airport yesterday aboard a Pan American airplane from London. She was accompanied by her daughter, Rita, 19 years old. Mrs. Pandit is a sister of Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India.

PITTSBURGH, May 5 -- Nearly all the rise in business in the Pittsburgh district reported in the first three weeks of April was canceled in the final week of the month, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. Most of the setback resulted from a less-than-seasonal gain in retail sales.
LONDON, May 5 -- Although announcement of the lifting of the Berlin blockade was well received in stock markets today there was no noticeable enthusiasm to undertake fresh commitments.

Coffee futures were easier in quiet trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Scattered long liquidation and trade selling was absorbed on a scale down by trade interests. Final prices for contract "D" were 30 to 15 points lower. Contract "S" also declined in light trading. At the close prices were 7 to 20 points lower with the exception of the spot month, which closed nominally 15 points higher.

VIENNA, May 5 -- The Allied Council for Austria, and more particularly its United States element, finds itself in a dilemma: shall it permit a fourth party to participate in the forthcoming Austrian general elections and thereby allow Nazi voters to achieve open representation, or shall it ban a fourth party and thereby do violence to Austria's Constitution and tradition?

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The Senate passed without change tonight a bipartisan bill authorizing $300,000,000 of annual grants to states to help raise their standards of public education. The vote was 58 to 15.

New York is one of the noisiest cities and Lexington Avenue one of the noisiest streets in the world. Traffic density creates the noise and tall buildings channel it, but the thundering Lexington Avenue bus is the loudest culprit.

A faculty representative on the five-member committee that is seeking a new president for Queens College has protested sharply to Henry E. Schultz, committee chairman, against his exclusion from the committee's deliberations, it was learned yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, May 5 -- After three days of deliberation the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, agreed today on demands covering more than 1,000,000 workers. The union refused, however, to say how much of an hourly increase it wanted.

The Tide Water Associated Oil Company in the first quarter of this year had consolidated net earnings of $9,020,206 after charges and taxes, equal to $1.38 a common share, William F. Humphrey, president, told stockholders at their annual meeting here yesterday.

Governor Dewey, affable but evasive on all matters of politics, sailed for Europe at noon yesterday aboard the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary. He was accompanied by his wife and Paul E. Lockwood, his secretary.

Premier Joseph Stalin of the Soviet Union sent word to American Communists in October, 1946, that war might come any time, and if so they should be ready to go underground, according to yesterday's testimony at the Communist trial.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES for May 2 it was heartening to read of the report of the Community Service Society to the City Planning Commission, strengthening and developing the relation of neighborhood planning to the city of New York as a whole.

LONDON, May 5--Announcing to a cheering House of Commons the imminent lifting of the Berlin blockade, Foreign Secretary Bevin said today that the British Government would approach the ensuing meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers "in the same spirit of firmness and reasonableness" with which it had met the Soviet challenge in Berlin.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Assuring small business men that they would get their share of national defense contracts, Louis Johnson, Secretary of Defense, said tonight that "questionable brokers" who contend they can sell "influence at the right spots," would be driven out of the National Military Establishment.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The National Labor Relations Board unanimously found a New York department store union guilty today of conducting a strike to nullify the board's certification of another union.

Offers of gifts and other services for the Collins quadruplets began to pour in yesterday. These new first citizens of the Bronx, with their mother, were doing fine at the end of their first full day at Lebanon Hospital.

The trustees of the Long Island Rail Road said yesterday in their first report that they are planning to establish a few additional trains in territory where very rapid residential development has resulted in a necessity for greater service. They said it may be necessary to reduce service on certain lines later, because of lack of money, but added that this would not be done unless its necessity is definitely indicated.

PARIS, May 5 -- It is understood in informed circles here that the Western powers are considering fixing a time limit for the four-power conference on Germany that will open in Paris May 23, so that it will not drag on if the early stages do not reveal hope of a substantial achievement.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Henry A. Wallace asserted today that Senate ratification of the North Atlantic treaty would be a sign that the United States intended to make aggressive war on the Soviet Union.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 5 -- Israel's intention to cooperate fully in the establishment of some type of international regime for Jerusalem and a guarantee of the nation's contribution to a solution of the Arab refugee problem were declared today before the Ad Hoc Political Committee by Aubrey S. Eban, Israeli representative to the United Nations.

Ever since Hendrik Hudson and the hardy Dutch traders who followed him, New York has been a city of the sea, and a sailors' town. It is probable that few Manhattanites realize how closely their daily lives are linked to the sea and the men thereof.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 5 -- A Netherlands move to postpone all work on a United Nations convention on freedom of information until September, gained support tonight from a dozen members of the General Assembly's Social Committee.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Dr. Leonard A. Scheele, Surgeon General of the Public Health Service, today announced that the major manufacturers of fluorescent lights stated they would cease using beryllium phosphor after June 30. These lights release mercury dust or vapor when broken. It has now been agreed by the manufacturers that a phosphor other than beryllium will be used.

The 150th anniversary of the historic St. Mark's Church In-the-Bouwerie will be celebrated Sunday with the opening of a campaign for $225,000 to be used to maintain and restore one of the city's few remaining eighteenth century landmarks.

The Bankers Trust Company, Awbrey N. Shaw and Henry A. Mulcahy, as executors of the estate of Robert Alfred Shaw, have sold the five-story apartment house at 170 East Seventeenth Street, Brooklyn, to an investing client of John J. Reynolds, Inc., broker in the transaction.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 5 -- The Ecumenical Patriarch of Constantinople, Athanagoras, said today he had received letters from high-ranking Orthodox prelates in all countries behind the Iron Curtain except Yugoslavia indicating the acceptance of his position. The letters were in the form of fraternal greetings on the Orthodox Easter.

Dr. James. T. Shotwell, historian and a leading American authority on international relations, was elected president of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace at the annual meeting of that organization yesterday at its offices, 522 Fifth Avenue.

LONDON, May 5 -- Representatives of ten European countries laid the foundations in London today for an organization that, in the opinion of Foreign Minister Robert Schuman of France, may ultimately develop into a European state.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., May 5 -- A $1,000,000 Institute of Microbiology for continued research in the field which produced the discovery of streptomycin will rise here through Dr. Selman A. Waksman's contribution to Rutgers University of his royalties on the drug.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., May 5 -- An 18-year-old freshman lost both hands and two other classmates of the same age received burns today in an explosion resulting from an unauthorized chemical experiment in a University Heights laboratory at Rutgers University.
FRANKFORT, Germany, May 5 -- Bavarian state government leaders quashed today fears that a separatist movement might disrupt plans for the Western German government.
North Hempstead, L. I., Union Free School District No. 7 an nounced yesterday that it would receive bids on May 17 on $2,470,000 of bonds dated June 1, 1949 and due on June 1, 1950 to 1977.
WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -- Pan-American Airways told the Navy today that anti-aircraft fire from a carrier task force burst in the general vicinity of one of its big planes near New York on April 15.

After a brief ownership the eighteen - story and penthouse apartment and store building at 200 West Fifteenth Street in the Chelsea section, has been resold by Frederick Brown, the operator, to an investing syndicate in a deal negotiated by Abbott Adams, Inc., brokers.
Recommendations for the peaceful settlement of the latest strike threat on the lines of the Third Avenue Transit Corporation will be made today to both sides by the City Labor Relations Division.

Plans for the establishment of a national, interdenominational Protestant newspaper at an estimated initial cost of more than $1,500,000, will be discussed at a three-day meeting of 200 church leaders in Kansas City, Mo., beginning Tuesday, it became known yesterday.
The New York Little Symphony, under Joseph Barone, presented an all-Mozart program last night at Times Hall. Adi Bernard, pianist, and Kensley Rosen, violinist, were the soloists.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- New Russian protests that Valentin Gubitchev is a Soviet diplomat and thus immune from arrest or trial have been rejected, the State Department revealed today. This Government has notified Moscow that Mr. Gubitchev enjoys no diplomatic status as he is regarded as merely an engineer employed by the United Nations, whose staff is pledged not to receive instructions from any authority other than that organization.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The Air Force announced today an expanded program for reserve force training that will triple the number of flying reservists under instruction and earning either active or inactive duty pay.

A KLM Royal Dutch Airlines plane arrived at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, at 1:08 P. M. yesterday with the largest air shipment of animals ever made, according to Henry Trefflich, bird and animal importer, 228 Fulton Street.
HANOVER, N. H., May 6 -- Dartmouth's baseball team eked out a 2-1 victory over Columbia at Memorial Field before a capacity crowd today.

LONDON, May 6 (Reuters) -- British trades union leaders found themselves today in an uncomfortable dilemma caused by the world-wide strike of Canadian seamen, which involves a dispute between two trades unions operating in Canada.

The Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company has sold the three-story six-family building at 881 St. John's Place, Brooklyn, to Frank Bruno and Edward Burton. Morris Goldman was the broker in the transaction. Title was insured by the City Title Insurance Company.

Mrs. R. M. Torgerson of Cherry Valley led her team to victory, 8 1/2 to 6 1/2, over the Meadow Brook five as the second day of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's interclub matches were completed yesterday.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, May 6 -- M. N. Hawari, a member of the so-called Congress of Arab Refugees, one of many Arab groups now gathering around the United Nations Palestine Conciliation Commission in Lausanne, said today that Arab refugees in Palestine and surrounding areas would rise in violent rebellion unless the Israeli Government soon permitted them to return home.

LONDON, May 6 -- A general lack of support was responsible for a quiet wind-up to the stock market here today. Apart from oils, which were unsettled by the Far Eastern situation, all sections generally stood up well.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The President's Emergency Board today recommended a forty-hour work week for 60,000 employes of the Railway Express Agency, Inc., instead of their current forty-four hours, and that present earnings be maintained, along with a wage increase of seven cents an hour.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, May 6 -- The pending resolution citing alleged violations of workers' rights in Peru and Venezuela was finally adopted last night by the regional conference here of the International Labor Organization by a vote of 40 to 0, with three government and two employer delegates abstaining.

It all started when the wife of an executive for a wholesale liquor distributing concern had wondered aloud how it was that a young cashier, earning $60 a week, could be wearing a smartly tailored suit that she, herself, was unable to afford.
WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -- Three former United States Army officers denied under oath today that German Storm Troopers, imprisoned for the Malmedy massacre, had been mistreated or tortured.

" Life in Bloom," a new color film from Russia, will be presented today at the Stanley Theatre. Written and produced by Alexander Dovzhenko, leading Soviet director, the picture deals with the life of the scientist, Ivan Michurin, played by Grigori Belov.

Rehabilitation and expansion of New York's public libraries, held back for years by the war and shortages of materials, are beginning to reach the stage for contract letting, a survey showed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 6--No criticism of Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor in Germany, was intended in the recent report on decartelization of German industry, Garland S. Ferguson, chairman of the committee that submitted the report, stated "emphatically" today.

ALBANY, May 6 -- The Public Service Commission was accused today of acting illegally in ordering the Consolidated Edison Company to cut its rates by $21,500,000 a year. Before the Appellate Division, Third Department, Jacob H. Goetz, company counsel, contended during argument on the Consolidated Edison's action to vacate the ruling that the commission was not authorized to fix temporary rates at the end of its hearings.

Navy came in the leading color yesterday at the opening of Belmont Park where navy and black costumes worn with white or light-colored hats proved the fashion of the day. Owing to the warm temperature there were few furs, but sable and marten scarfs were the favorites among them.

ALBANY, May 6 -- The State Banking Department announced today it had issued to the General Public Loan Corporation, 122 East Forty-second Street, New York, a license to transact business as a licensed lender at 50 East Forty-second Street, and 403 Main Street, Buffalo.

Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday the city's rejection of the revised plan submitted on April 27 by the Port of New York Authority offering to lease, operate and develop the municipal piers under a program calling for expenditure of $88,901,963 over an initial period of eight years.

Net earnings of the Mid-Continent Petroleum Corporation and its subsidiary for the first quarter of this year declined to $3,357,832 after all deductions from $7,007,163 earned in the initial three months of 1948, according to the report issued yesterday.
BERLIN, May 6 -- Trains will leave Helmstedt in the British zone for the Western sectors of Berlin at midnight of May 11, Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor, announced today.

GENEVA, May 6 -- National economic planning is driving Europe toward increased autarchy and less efficient use of its resources, according to the economic survey of Europe in 1948 issued by the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -- Senator Styles Bridges, Republican, of New Hampshire, demanded today that the State Department name all officials responsible for the present policy of the United States in China and Germany. He said he wanted to get the background of the "tragic situation we find today in China."

Announcing that they could "see no reason why our term should be further extended," members of the holdover March grand jury that indicted John G. Broady and two others on charges of contriving a bizarre wiretapping plot against city officials, were discharged yesterday by General Sessions Judge Owen W. Bohan.

A "laboratory of crime" was discovered yesterday by the police in a four-room apartment at 350 1/2 West Twenty-fourth Street. The apartment was leased by Allan Coulter, 23 years old, of 300 West Twenty-third Street, one of four men arrested late Wednesday night with a "walkie-talkie" device, after an alleged attempt to break into the safes of the New York Giants Baseball Club and the Personal Finance Company at 100 West Forty-second Street.

LONDON, May 6 -- Four-power Austrian treaty negotiations, which have long been deadlocked here, slowed to a virtual halt today. Samuel Reber, the United States delegate, proposed formally that the talks be suspended until June 25 to allow each delegate to report to his Government.

The current report of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe, made public this week, offers some encouraging figures on European recovery and at the same time courageously points out some of the serious remaining economic problems. During 1948 Europe achieved a 16 per cent rise in production and a 25 per cent reduction in her overseas deficit.
Details of three cargo-passenger vessels now under construction in Japan for the De La Rama Steamship Company were received here yesterday by the line.
Atherton G. Fryer has been appointed director of sales research for Lamont, Corliss Co., distributor of Nestle's chocolate and Pond's creams and cosmetics.

Vera Caspary, author of "Laura," "Bedelia" and a number of other novels, has signed a contract with Little, Brown for the publication of her new book. "The Death Wish," a novel of suspense, is tentatively scheduled for publication next year.

The problem of military economy, which is in turn a derivative of the military philosophy and strategic concept that determine the nature and policies of our military establishment, is a problem that cannot be solved solely by the Secretary of Defense or the Executive Department of the Government.
LAKE SUCCESS, May 6 -- Dr. Herbert V. Evatt, President of the United Nations General Assembly, plans to announce the Big Four agreement on Berlin to the Assembly before it ends its spring session.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- A Senate vote against ratification of the North Atlantic treaty would be "helping to send the young men of our country into certain war" with the Soviet Union within a year, James W. Gerard asserted today.

PARIS, May 6 -- The French Foreign Office denied today that the Western powers had agreed on any fixed time limit for their forthcoming conference with the Soviet Union on Germany and officials here indicated that French did not favor such a limit.

Shipments of steel products of all grades, including alloy and stainless materials, reached a record total of 6,305,681 net tons in March, which was also the month of peak ingot output, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

Count Maurice Maeterlinck often insisted that he was not entirely at home in the practical world. He had no great respect for technical achievements and no sympathy for a civilization of gadgets. During much of his life he disclaimed any great interest in politics or much knowledge of it.

The current local out-of-season heat wave blazed yesterday through its third day and sent the mercury here to 92.3 degrees at 3:55 P. M., a record for the date. It also was the hottest day of the year, with the average temperature for the day twenty-three degrees above the normal 57.

DAYTON, Ohio, May 6 -- Rightwing forces in the United Electrical Workers, CIO, will make their first serious and concentrated effort to unseat the leftist national leadership of their union at a conference opening here tomorrow.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 6 -- Seven countries joined today in submitting a joint resolution urging the admission of Israel into the United Nations as a peace-loving state, able and willing to carry out all obligations of the Charter.

There will be no successor to Gen. Lucius Clay in Germany. It would be difficult under any circumstances to find another man with his special qualifications, developed under the terrific pressures centering in postwar Germany, but now it will not be necessary, for the post he occupies will be abolished and he will be replaced by two men, a civilian High Commissioner and a general in command of a reduced occupying force.

The contest between Municipal Court Justice Benjamin Shalleck, Democratic candidate for Representative in the Twentieth Congressional District and Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., his Liberal and Four Freedoms party opponent, reached the intensive fighting stage yesterday.

The United Negro College Fund, Inc., has opened its sixth annual drive for a "marginal" sum of $1,400,000 intended for distribution among thirty-one member colleges, all except one in the South. There is no doubting that this is a good cause, yet the public must ask by now why is the goal so low since that amount of money could command little respect on the building market or in the paying of academic salaries.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (UP) -- The Mayors of New York and Baltimore endorsed the Administration's long-range housing bill today but three real estate spokesmen opposed its public housing and slum clearance provisions.

Perhaps "Tante Marie's French Kitchen, published this week by the Oxford University Press, isn't explicit and extensive enough for the June bride who hardly knows a double boiler from a fry pan. But for her whose wedding was some Junes ago and whose enthusiasm for cooking has grown with her knowledge of it, we can think of few pleasanter presents.
The '49-ers, Hunter College's senior class, struck gold yesterday when they won the college's thirty-third annual inter-class song competition, Sing.

Mrs. Claire M. Senie was elected president of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs, comprising 200 clubs with nearly 250,000 members, at its 139th convention yesterday in the Astor Hotel. She succeeds Mrs. LeRoy Sherman Edwards of 420 Clinton Avenue, Brooklyn, for a two-year term.
GREENWICH, Conn., May 6--Everything in the Audubon Nature Center, 400-acre wildlife sanctuary near here, is protected except the mosquitos.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The Voice of America and the British Broadcasting Corporation will combine their forces daily, beginning tomorrow, by utilizing a maximum of sixty-one radio transmitters in an effort to break through the Soviet jamming of their stations and reach the Russian people with news through two new special programs, it was announced today.

Dr. Robert M. Burns, chemical director of the Bell Telephone Laboratories, was elected last night chairman of the New York section of the American Chemical Society, at the annual meeting of the section in the Statler Hotel.

BUENOS AIRES, May 6 -- The Peron Government is faced with the urgent necessity of raising at least $10,000,000 to enable the Army to get a start on the long dreamed of steel mill in Santa Fe Province and is about to ask for an Export-Import Bank loan, possibly through a private Argentine company, it was confirmed today.

John M. Murtagh, Commissioner of Investigation, announced yesterday that four more steamship lines have compiled with the city plan of assuming responsibility for loading operations at city piers and designated public loaders.

On Jan. 30, 1948, Samuel Sharp, 46 years old, of 1539 Rosedale Avenue, the Bronx, was sentenced by Bronx County Judge Harry Stackell to serve from 5 to 10 years in a state prison for swindling forty persons, mostly veterans, out of $15,000 in deposits on automobiles Sharp was to procure from the War Assets Administration.
The latest report from Maine indicates that the waters of that state are now open, including the northern lakes which are almost clear of ice.

Your correspondent Charles H. Adams noted a mention of General Coxey in THE TIMES; that reminded him of greenbacks. He asked whether we have "* * * not followed rather closely the financial school of Coxey, Townsend and Bryan?" We have, though apparently only a few know it.

The Mayor of the City of New York is a very busy man, but we wonder whether he can afford to be too busy to ignore the courtesies that certain situations require. We are thinking not only of Mr. O'Dwyer's failure to reappoint Anthony Campagna to the Board of Education.

CHICAGO, May 6 -- Hopes that the reorganization of the Tucker Corporation might result in the production of motor cars at an early date appeared doomed today when the reorganization trustees obtained court approval of the sale of several inventory items necessary for automobile output.
A family of egiht Dempseys_a father, mother and six children -- have no place to sleep.

Representative Harold H. Velde, a member of the House Committee on Un-American Activities and a wartime FBI agent, testified for an hour and a half yesterday before the special Federal grand jury investigating subversive activities.

HELSINKI, Finland, May 6 -- Finland, defeated in the war, emerged from otherwise disastrous consequences with at least one gain -- a working shipbuilding industry. Until a few years ago Finnish yards had not built many ships of consequence, but the 1946 Paris treaty imposed upon the Finns the obligation to construct $60,000,000 worth of vessels of all kinds for the Russians.

GENEVA, May 6 -- Eight Western European countries and Czechoslovakia, Austria and the German bizonal area have agreed to extend multilateral agreements assuring free transit of commercial trucks until the end of 1950.

Four leaders of religious, state and civic affairs joined yesterday in emphasizing the far-reaching benefits of the current campaign of the Greater New York Fund by signing a document testifying to the value of the voluntary services rendered by its 423 agencies in the field of hospitalization, health and social welfare.

Pan American Airways and Northwest Airlines, the only two American-flag airlines operating into China, indicated here yesterday that in the event Shanghai fell to the Communist forces they would continue regular operations into and out of China's largest city until "invited to leave."

WESTBURY, L. I., May 6 -- Before 23,371 persons, the largest opening night crowd in the history of the track, the tenth season of harness racing started at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. Despite the threat of rain an hour before the first race, all seating space was packed by post time.

LONDON, May 6 -- A list of eight foreign correspondents who have been barred from entry into Czechoslovakia has been issued by the Ministry of Information in Prague, the Information Service of "Free Czechoslovakia" has reported in London.

DETROIT, May 6 -- The Ford Motor Company discharged thirteen Rouge plant employes today for leaving their jobs a week ago to lead a wildcat strike that was in protest against the international leaders of their own union, the United Automobile Workers, CIO.

DETROIT, May 6 (AP) -- Rookie left-hander Bob Shantz, only last Monday farmed out by the Athletics, held the Tigers to one run and two hits in a ten-inning relief performance to give Philadelphia a 5 -- 4 victory in thirteen innings today.

Share prices slipped a bit yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, as traders studied labor developments for some indication of the business picture for the remainder of the year. Trading inactivity resulted in sales of only 780,000 shares, the smallest since Monday and 140,000 shares less than Thursday's transfers.

LINDEN, N. J., May 6 -- Brownie, a dog who has maintained nearly a year's vigil for its master at the docks of the Bayway refinery of the Standard Oil Company here, had a new "home" -- a brand new doghouse -- today, but he didn't particularly like it.

BALTIMORE, May 6 -- It is the consuming public which is the most to blame for the inadequacy of the houses being built today, Charles M. Goodman, Washington architect, said here today at the opening session of the Second Annual Symposium of the Contemporary Arts, under the auspices of the Baltimore Museum of Art.

ST. LOUIS, May 6 (AP) -- The Washington Senators went on another batting rampage tonight and handed the St. Louis Browns their seventh straight defeat, 8 to 7. A two-run triple by Al Evans in the eighth inning was the pay-off wallop.
Recently General Bradley, Chief of Staff of the Army, delivered the principal address before a dinner of the Jewish War Veterans. The subject related to our international role and the threat of war.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today that it will offer Government-owned grains at market prices, providing that those prices are not less than what the grain cost. This sales-price policy was announced in view of the fact that a large portion of the current supply of wheat is now in the hands of the Government under its farm-price-support program.

Anxious to increase its supply of dollars for the purchase of American goods, Iceland is moving to expand its exports of various fish products to the United States, according to Hannes Kjartansson. Icelandic Consul here. The tiny country, about the size of Ohio and with a population of 138,000, is also seeking to increase its tourist traffic with the United States.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 6 (AP) -- A six-under-par 64 carded beneath a blazing sun sent Dr. Cary Middlecoff six strokes ahead of the field today at the half-way mark of the $10,000 Greenbrier open tourney.

Sterling W. Mudge, training director, Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, yesterday called on all employe training executives to make it absolutely clear to management that advances in training methods and techniques result in lowered operating expenses.

The principles of neighborhood development set forth in the Community Service Society's report for the guidance of the City Planning Commission in its re-zoning program are the outgrowth of long study of the headaches and problems of family life under the modern tempo of the big city.

Mayor O'Dwyer has asked the heads of all city departments to send him reports of progress made during the three and a half years of his administration for the purpose of combining them into one report to be made public later, it was learned yesterday. Among city employes, the Mayor's request has been taken as another indication that, despite repeated private expressions of reluctance, he intends to run for re-election.

Federal aid to education passed the Senate in April, 1948, by a vote of 58 to 22. Now it has passed again, with an even better margin of 58 to 15. This vote does not tell the full story of the strength the $300,000,000 aid measure had behind it, however, for thirteen other Senators not voting had announced their support, and four others were in favor of the bill, but paired.

Temple Emanu-El opened its annual Three Choir Festival yesterday afternoon with a program of choir musie and vocal and instrumental solos in its assembly hall. Later in the day a second offering was presented as part of the evening service in the temple proper.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 6 -- B. G. de Sylva announced today that Columbia will distribute his independent production, "The Great Vampire," a life story of Theda Bara, silent film star, in which Betty Hutton will play Miss Bara De Sylva and Jack McGowan are writing the scenario, scheduled for the cameras next fall.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Registration statements covering $75,000,000 of bonds, $1,600,000 of debentures and 1,505,300 shares of common stock were filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by three companies.

A campaign was started in Harlem yesterday to make the streets safer for pedestrians and motorists. Better street lighting and tighter enforcement of traffic regulations were listed as immediate community needs.

A combination variety, music and quiz program will be the summer replacement for the Jo Stafford Show on WJZ-ABC Thursday nights at 9:30, beginning May 12. The new show, entitled "Name the Movie" will enlist the services of Clark Dennis, tenor; Singer Peggy

BOSTON, May 6 (AP) -- Lefty Warren Spahn pitched a four-hitter tonight in leading the National League's first-place Braves to a 6-1 triumph over the Reds. A crowd of 22,332 saw Spahn twirl shut-out ball until Hank Sauer belted his third home run of the season with one out in the ninth inning.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 6 -- The Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee of the General Assembly agreed today to shelve until September all further work on a future United Nations convention on freedom of information.

HEWLETT, L. I., May 6 -- The Brooklyn Public Links team of Jim Oleska and John Mikrut of Shore View, winners last year, played the best golf of the day as they captured their opening-round match in the second annual William D. Richardson Memorial Tourney over the Seawane Harbor Club course today.

Warm weather has stimulated dress orders to the point where large producers are having difficulty in making nearby deliveries, it was learned yesterday. Business in the last three days, manufacturers said, has indicated immediate need for garments in many of the large metropolitan areas where summer stocks normally are peaked in June and July.

The defense of the diversion of Social Security funds, by George Buchanan Robinson in your letters columns, wherein he tries to prove that we will not get taxed twice for social security, falls absolutely flat. Ex-President Hoover was correct, together with hundreds of other experts who claim that we paid the social security tax once when we had it deducted from our pay envelope and again when we will be income-taxed to service the debt.

Montia Kennedy pitched a six-hit shutout and Johnny Mize hit for the circuit again as the Giants rolled merrily to their fourth straight victory at the Polo Grounds yesterday. It was at the expense of the Cardinals, by a 3-0 score.

SHREWSBURY, N. J., May 6 -- The only United States post office in the country that is situated in the middle of a street is now one of the busiest for its size in the nation. Shrewsbury's tiny, ivy-covered stone post office building, built on an "island" in Sycamore Avenue, this historic borough's main thoroughfare, presents a unique picture to thousands of out-of-town motorists passing on State Highway 35.

Lumber production for the week ended April 30 was 11 per cent above the comparable week last year, according to reports wired yesterday to THE NEW YORK TIMES by trade associations. Shipments were up 3.3 per cent with orders, 4.4 per cent below last year.
BATAVIA, May 6 (AP) -- An informed source said today that the negotiators were reported deadlocked on a definition of the capital area.

BONN, Germany, May 6--German political leaders tonight approved the draft constitution for a West German government on its second reading. The only remaining formality is the third reading set for Sunday.

Frank J. Forster, 31-year-old former civilian disbursing officer on the Army transport Private Francis X. McGraw, pleaded guilty in Federal Court yesterday to an indictment charging embezzlement of $64,571 of the funds entrusted to him.

ASBESTOS, Que., May 6 (UP) -- A motorized convoy of 150 provincial policemen armed with shotguns and tear gas bombs, today broke through barricades thrown up by 4,000 strikers around this entire town, biggest asbestos production center in the world.
SHANGHAI, May 6 -- The Nationalists today appeared to be hastening their previously reported plan to fall back and make their stand on the perimeter of this city.

NEWARK, N. J., May 6 -- Responding today to a reception at which he received a plaque from the New Jersey Advertising Club as "New Jersey's Outstanding Citizen for 1948," Dr. Selman A. Waksman, discoverer of streptomycin, urged "generous and uninterrupted support for scientific research in the United States."

The twenty-second annual celebration of Mary's Day by Roman Catholics, instituted in 1928 in Brooklyn by Mrs. Philip A. Brennan, with the aid of the International Federation of Catholic Alumnae, will take place today, honoring Mary, the Mother of Jesus, as the spiritual mother of mankind.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat, of Virginia, carried his fight for economy in the Federal government to the floor of the Senate today. He warned his colleagues that the fiscal integrity of the Government and the financial ability of the free enterprise system were at stake.

PHILADELPHIA, May 6 (AP) -- The Phillies knocked Elmer Riddle out of the box within three innings with four runs and then held on to defeat the Pirates, 4 -- 3, tonight. Ralph Kiner accounted for two Pittsburgh runs with a fourth-inning homer.

LONDON, May 6 (UP) -- The Moscow radio broadcast today a five-point code for Russian newspaper men as laid down by L. F. Ilyichev, chief of the Communist party Central Committee's Propaganda and Agitation Department.

Manufacturers of women's apparel "franchise lines" were criticized sharply at a meeting of the Association of Buying Offices yesterday in the Statler Hotel for failure to revise their operations in the face of changing business conditions.
Eleven years ago today Lawrin, owned by Herbert f. Woolf of Kansas City, won the Sixty fourth Kentucky Derby before 60,000 persons. It was the first of three Derby victories for Eddie Arcaro.

Retail sales declined during the week despite favorable shopping weather in comparison with bad weather last year. Department store sales were estimated to be about 7 per cent below the corresponding week last year. Sales last week were 9 per cent below last year.
Rocky Castellani, 162, Luzerne, Pa., easily outpointed Tony De Micco, 165 1/4, Brooklyn, in the feature bout of ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The Harry Diamond Ordnance Laboratory was formally dedicated at the National Bureau of Standards today to the memory of one of the nation's foremost scientists and inventors whose contributions to navigational landing aids saved the lives of untold American airmen in World War II.
The cotton futures market opened 2 to 3 points higher on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday but final prices were 3 points higher to 11 points lower.
WASHINGTON, May 6 (UP) -- The Senate Executive Expenditures Committee approved today a bill to set up a new General Services Agency with centralized authority to buy all Government equipment.

More than 100 leading figures in ten fields of Soviet scholarship and culture have been listed as having been removed from their posts, demoted or reprimanded as the result of the campaign against "cosmopolitanism," a survey of the Soviet press reveals.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The United States favors giving Japan increasing direction of her own affairs in the international field as well as that held in the domestic field in order to facilitate the development of responsible government, the State Department announced today.

SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, May 7 (UP) -- President Syngman Rhee said today that the South Korean Government wants to know whether the United States would regard an invasion across the 38th Parallel by the Soviet-dominated North Korean republic as "tantamount to an attack on the American people."

BERLIN, May 6 -- Anti-Russian sentiment has grown so strong in the Socialist Unity (Communist) party in the Eastern zone of Germany that the situation has drawn an official rebuke from the party's executives.

" New York Welcomes Congress" was the slogan that greeted 149 members of both Houses and their families as they arrived in Pennsylvania Station at 5:30 last evening for a three-day tour of the city given by the city Commerce Department and the Commerce and Industry Association.

Names of race horses still remind us -- so Hezekiah Cobb, resting a while from his fox-hunting, bids us note -- that the events which make up history for the people who aren't horseplayers cast shadows -- sometimes long shadows -- across the tracks right now so busy inviting cash customers.

" Bronx Collins Day," by proclamation of Borough President James J. Lyons, was celebrated in the Bronx yesterday, along with the announcement that two of the Collins quadruplets have gained weight while the two others have held theirs.

Barrie Stavis' recently published novel, "Home Sweet Home," dealing with the search for a city apartment by a former GI, may be converted into a Broadway musical. Mr. Stavis, whose "Lamp at Midnight" gave New Stages, Inc., its start two years ago, has been holding exploratory talks about the stage transition with Lina Abarbanell, who is with the Dwight Deere Wiman office. If the deal materializes, Broadway may well see the project in the fall.

Coffee futures rallied sharply on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Demand for the near-by delivery positions by trade interests and some small new buying advanced prices in contract "S" 21 to 47 points. Selling was on a scale up for profit-taking.

Despite the many newer advertising mediums, the newspaper, with its printed word, is still the backbone not only of automobile advertising but of all products, it was declared yesterday by Joseph W. Frazer, vice chairman of the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation.

BATAVIA, Java, May 6 (UP) -- Dutch and Indonesian delegates to a United Nations-sponsored peace conference reached an informal cease-fire agreement today under which the exiled Republican Government would return to Jogjakarta, reliable sources said.

Rocky Graziano, the New York boxer who formerly held the world middleweight championship, was reinstated by the New York State Athletic Commission yesterday, ending a suspension in this state that had been in effect since Feb. 7, 1947.

Police emergency trucks were kept briefly busy yesterday afternoon going to the rescue of 2-year-old boys who got their heads wedged in iron fences. Within two hours, two youngsters had been so trapped.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Legislation designed to make more effective the unification of the country's military forces -- and to cut perhaps 10 per cent from their cost -- was approved tentatively today by the Senate Committee on the Armed Services.
LAUSANNE, Switzerland, May 6 -- The Palestine peace negotiations taking place here are now in the form of a chess game, with both sides maneuvering for position.

Your editorial of April 28, "The Larger Commonwealth" declares that the accord (by which India remains in the Commonwealth) "owes something also to developments in China"; and it also says that "the great sub-continent is certainly threatened by advance of Soviet Power."

DAMASCUS, Syria, May 6 -- Syrian newspapers started again today to attack the proposed concession for a way leave across Syria for a pipeline from the United States oil concession in Saudi Arabia to the Mediterranean coast in Lebanon.

ST. LOUIS, May 6 (AP) -- The St. Louis Post-Dispatch and Chicago Daily News today listed additional Illinois newspaper men who they said received state salaries during the administration or former Republican Governor Dwight H. Green.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 6 -- Ray Atherton of the United States delegation to the United Nations denied today assertions that the United States had a military alliance with Spain, that it had given Spain military assistance, that the United States maintained air bases on Spanish territory, and, finally, that the United States had made overtures toward bringing Spain into the United Nations, the European Recovery Program or the North Atlantic pact.

More than thirty-five houses in the Silbert Town project at Hempstead, L. I., were sold to non-veterans during the past week, Leon M. Silberstein, president of the development company, reported yesterday. A model home has been opened for inspection at Harvard Street and Harriet Avenue.

The Esso-Atlas Sky Merchant, a Douglas DC-4 that flew around the world last January with business men who surveyed foreign markets, will leave La Guardia Airport today on another business flight to North Africa and Europe.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.6 per cent in the week ended May 3, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index was 155.2 per cent of the 1926 average, 1.8 per cent lower than four weeks ago and 4.2 per cent lower than the comparable week in 1948.

Manhattan College upset St. John's University, 2 -- 0, yesterday at Dexter Park to push the Redmen out of first place in the metropolitan collegiate baseball conference. City College, idle yesterday, moved into the lead with a 7-2-record. St. John's is second with a 6-2 mark.
WASHINGTON, May 6 (UP) -- The way was opened today for the Senate Banking Committee to study the "spread" between the prices farmers get and what consumers have to pay.
Five new exhibitions of paintings, ranging in style from naturalism to non-objectivity, make serious attempts to reduce the chaos of appearances to formal visual terms.

The kitchen will be the most important room in the house of the immediate future, Harvey Wiley Corbett, noted architect for such large developements as the Amsterdam Housing Project, declared at a meeting yesterday of the Home Fashions League in the Roosevelt Hotel.

SEOUL, Korea, May 6 -- It was revealed today by the Government Information Department that 414 South Korean soldiers and four officers had deserted to the Communists. The information office said that elements of two battalions had been led into Soviet-controlled North Korea by the deserting officers.

A penniless war veteran seeking enough money to get to his home in Amsterdam, N. Y., was seized by the police last night and accused of having broken into the home of Mrs. John N. Willys, widow of the automobile manufacturer, at 4643 Waldo Avenue, the Bronx.

BONN, May 6 -- Swift disposal of amendments to various articles of the draft of a Western German constitution brought the Parliamentary Council here tonight to the threshold of adjournment. Although a final plenary session has been postponed until Sunday in deference to the Bavarian delegation the probability now is that the document will be ready for submission to the military governors of the three Western zones at Frankfort on Monday.

The prospect at the present time is that fourth-round demands will be presented soon on behalf of some 3,000,000 workers in the steel, coal, automobile and electrical manufacturing industries. In a number of respects this drive will be conducted in a strikingly different economic climate than that which prevailed at the time of rounds two and three, in 1947 and 1948.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -- The 1948 cotton crop was estimated today at 14,868,000 bales of 500-pounds gross weight in a final report by the Agricultural Department. This compares with 11,857,000 bales produced in 1947 and with a 10-year average of 12,014,1000 bales.
OTTAWA, May 5 (Canadian Press) -- Two changes in regulations governing trading in Canadian securities by non-residents have been announced by the Canadian Exchange Control Board.

The Canadian dollar took the "play" away from the pound sterling so far as foreign exchange transactions in the markets here were concerned yesterday. The Canadian currency reached its highest level since Feb. 24, 1947, in the trading.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 6 -- Can Olympia go the Kentucky Derby route?

Women are failing to meet their responsibilities to maintain the American home and American public school education at their traditional best, it was agreed yesterday by three leading women of New York who addressed the third and final luncheon forum in a series "for women by women" at the New School for Social Research.

PHILADELPHIA, May 6 -- The Philadelphia Association of Linen Suppliers, thirteen companies and twenty-one individuals, were indicted today by the Federal Grand Jury on charges of violating the Sherman Anti-Trust Act.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 6 (AP) -- Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister Gromyko in the course of his forty-minute blast on United States-Spanish relations said Americans were trying to take over mercury and uranium mines in Spain "in line with their desire to take over all raw materials in the world connected with the production of atomic energy."
ELMONT, L. I., May 6 -- Many members of society were entertained today at luncheon parties at the opening of Belmont Park.
Publication of the 1949 edition of the Record of the American Bureau of Shipping was announced yesterday by the bureau.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican, of Ohio, gave the advice, "fight it out in the states," to Catholic clergymen questioning him on Federal aid to parochial schools at the annual meeting of the American Council on Education.

BERLIN, May 6 -- The United States delegation to the Council of Foreign Ministers may seek a solution to the Berlin currency problem by proposing the introduction of a separate currency for the city, it is indicated by reliable United States sources.
INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 6 (AP) -- Wind-fanned flames swept through Hollywood Park's big racing plant today, and officials put the loss at upwards of $6,000,000.
