Anxious to halt Fordham's losing streak at four games, Coach Jack Coffey made four changes in his line-up before sending the Rams into Fordham Field against Lafayette yesterday. The revisions proved helpful as the Bronx team pounded a trio of hurlers to triumph by 8 -- 3.
Amander O. Hayes, 64 years old, a police captain who retired in 1933, was killed at 3:50 P. M. yesterday when he jumped from the Queensborough Bridge into the East River.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 6 -- The 479 state-chartered savings and loan and building and loan associations in New Jersey recorded a $200,000,000 growth in the last five years, Jerome B. McKenna, deputy commissioner of banking and insurance for New Jersey, reported today at the fortieth annual convention of the New Jersey Savings and Loan League in the Haddon Hall Hotel.

The finest flowers from greenhouse and garden have been cut in anticipation of Mother's Day tomorrow. Spicy carnations, fragrant lilacs and lily-of-the-valley, roses and orchids are only part of the display that rivals Easter in the florist shops.

MEXICO CITY, May 6 -- Although foreign-exchange trading was heavier today than it had been previous to yesterday's Cinco de Mayo holiday, the closing of all banks to dollar selling virtually balanced dollar buying and the downward trend of the Mexican peso that had business circles alarmed during the first half of the week was definitely checked.

Landlords stepped up the rate of applications for "fair net operating income" rent rises yesterday, filing 153 in the city. At the same time, area rent offices in the various boroughs distributed a total of 9,804 application blanks.

Thomas A. Younglove testified at the Communist trial yesterday the party's "educational" system taught violent revolution was necessary because the Government would use the atomic bomb against labor to save capitalism.
Television broadcasters were faced last night with the possibility that they would not be able to use the music controlled by the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers after June 1.

Rippey drove home a lesson to the 20,695 fans who attended the opening of Belmont Park yesterday. The lesson, let it be known, was not difficult to absorb, for the 6-year-old son of Pompey had a goodly number of players as his well-wishers as he stepped to victory in the $23,850 Toboggan Handicap.

A boycott of New Jersey railroad produce terminals where 60 per cent of the vegetables destined for city retail markets are brought, was threatened yesterday by Joseph G. Papa, president of Local 202, Commission Drivers and Chauffeurs Union, AFL.

Despite an increase in operating revenues to $17,657,290 in the March quarter this year from $13,644,973 in the initial three months of 1948, United Airlines lost $3,070,228 in operations against $3,361,546 in the same period last year, according to the report issued yesterday.

Completely reversing itself for the third time since 1946 on the desirability of the Office of Price Administration and price ceilings, the majority of the American public again believes free competition will do more to keep prices down than OPA.

Protestant churches are in need of adjusting themselves to rapidly changing environments in the suburbs, it was emphasized yesterday at a conference on suburban church problems at the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street.
WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -- The Senate today passed legislation setting standards for applying marketing quotas and acreage allotments to the corn, wheat, cotton, rice and tobacco crops of 1950.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The Communications Workers of America, a union in the telephone industry, announced today its membership had voted to affiliate with the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

Advertising in eight major New York newspapers during the first four months of 1949 totaled 50,255,481 lines, a gain of 4.41 per cent over the like period last year, an analysis of Media Records showed yesterday. Categories recording increases were: Automotive, 59.20 per cent; retail, 4.12 per cent, and general, 3.29 per cent.

Because of the loss on Thursday of the largest post-war order for lead sought by the United States Army engineers for Japan, American custom smelters reduced prices to 14 cents a pound yesterday. The large export order, awaiting official confirmation at the close of business yesterday, brought a quotation of 14 1/4 cents a pound, delivered in Japan from the British zone of Germany and was offered by the Continental Ore Company, 500 Fifth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Total employment should rise substantially this quarter, even though the outlook for manufacturing is not yet clear, Robert C. Goodwin, director of the Bureau of Employment Security, asserted today.

BUFFALO, May 6 -- Medical experience with brain surgery in the treatment of persons "hopelessly" insane is not broad enough yet to provide any definite conclusions about operational techniques or the selection of patients. This was brought out today in the scientific program of the New York State Medical Society's meeting here.

SYRACUSE, May 6 -- Organization of the New York State Association for Supervision and Curriculum Development, a new educational group, was perfected here today at the final session of the annual Conference on Supervision for EIementary Education.

PARIS, May 6 -- A general overhauling of French operations in Indo-China was forecast here today as Gen. Georges Revers, Chief of Staff, continued consultations with responsible Cabinet Ministers prior to his forthcoming departure for Saigon.

One hundred and ten thousand workers in this state have used up all of the twenty-six weeks of unemployment insurance benefits to which they are legally entitled in the present "benefit year," it became known yesterday.

Power granted provisionally last year to the Columbia University Student Council to make the final decision regarding what persons are to be allowed to speak before campus groups has been returned to the Committee on Student Organizations, Albert C. Jacobs, Columbia provost, announced yesterday.

A Board of Education reading committee has recommended that Charles Dickens' novel, "Oliver Twist," be retained on the list of books approved for the city's public school libraries, it became known yesterday.
An eight-month nation-wide missionary crusade, started last October by the Foreign Missions Conference of North America, will end at a mass meeting at 8 P. M., Tuesday, at Madison Square Garden.

American industrial manufacturers last year passed a fantastic production and earnings milestone. The gradual adjustments in output, demand and prices in the last six months from the sharp financial distortions of and following the war, will be reflected in substantially lower earnings for 1949. The extent of the decline will depend on the international situation, Government expenditures and policies affecting taxes, employment and world trade.

AS long as June rhymes with moon, it will be the month of honeymoons. This is fortunate for the resort hotel industry; American vacationists have not yet fully broken out of the chains of July-August holidays, and the parade of honeymoon vacations in June fills hotels, lodges, ranches and camps with a four-week spell of pre-season business before the summer crowd of non-honeymoon vacationists arrive.
Three men accused of operating a loan-shark racket along the Brooklyn waterfront were seized yesterday by detectives dressed as longshoremen who had mingled with dock workers for two months.

DR. WEBBER has skillfully transposed her adult knowledge of plants to the level of the young botanist. Beginning with illustrations and explanations of why we need plants, she tells of their origins and their growth to maturity.

MEXICO CITY -- With more time than money available for our proposed trip here from New York, we perked up our ears when a friend visited us with the triumphant announcement that she had just come from Mexico by bus for a fare of less than $40.

The Russian Government last Thursday made a striking peace gesture. But by the end of the week there was increasing doubt as to whether the gesture was a genuine move toward a general settlement with the West or only another gambit in the great international duel that has come to be called the "cold war."

Dr. Syngman Rhee, the President of Korea, wants to know: "In case of an attack by an outside power, would the Republic of South Korea be able to count on all-out American military aid?" That is a fair question and deserves an answer free from double talk. The United States has already announced that it proposes to withdraw its armed forces from Korea in the near future.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., -- Reminders of Abraham Lincoln are everywhere in this capital of the Prairie State where one shrine alone, the Lincoln Tomb, drew 306,522 visitors last year.
Eleven years ago today, the Greater New York Fund ended its first week as New York's only united appeal for the city's voluntary health and social service agencies and hospitals.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., May 7 -- Instead of hopeful wishing for a breeze out on Long Island Sound, skippers of the summer yachts found a northerly of from 12 to 15 knots said puffs upward, and all but three decided not to risk newly installed rigging for the opening tune-up regatta at the Larchmont Yacht Club today.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., May 7 -- Discovery of a new stable isotope of platinum, of mass 190, the lightest and rarest yet found, has been reported by associate Professor Henry E. Duckworth of the Physics Department at Wesleyan University.
WASHINGTON, May 7 (UP) -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations and the American Federation of Labor today branded as unacceptable Senator Robert A. Taft's new labor bill proposals.

BUENOS AIRES -- Argentina's best known resort, Bariloche, is getting ready for its winter season, which is mainly devoted to skiing. At a time when most persons in the United States will be wondering how to escape from summer's scorching pavements and steamy landscapes, down here near the Chilean border snow will be pretty much taken for granted.

At the base of the brain in the middle of the head of any mammal, including man, lies the pituitary body, properly called the "master gland" because it influences all the other ductless glands and hence the production of hormones. This pituitary body controls growth.

A RECORD year for vacation driving, with at least 24,000,000 cars headed for summer recreation areas, is the forecast currently being advanced on the basis of inquiries already received by various automobile organizations. It is expected that there will be more holiday motorists than in 1948 and that the total mileage they will run up will exceed that for the corresponding period last year.

CAMERA-SHY generals, silent footage and the British law were just a few of the many problems that plagued the editors of "The March of Time" as they edited endless reels of film to put together the twenty-six installments that make up the visual adaptation of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's best-selling "Crusade in Europe."

Fairfield Osborn, whose book, "Our Plundered Planet," made it plain that society will rue its spendthrift policy of living on its capital, participated the other day in a round-table discussion of our renewable resources arranged by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.
PARIS -- France, having regained its place last year as the No. 1 tourist attraction of the world, intends to see to it that it retains this rank in 1949.
New York City will elect this fall a Mayor and the other seven officials who constitute its governing body, known as the Board of Estimate, as well as members of its City Council.

VANCOUVER, B. C. -- While the population of Canada as a whole has increased 11 per cent since 1940, that of Canada's westernmost province has soared an astronomical 32 per cent. British Columbians regard this as a fair measure of the wonders of their realm.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 7 -- Immediate convocation of an international conference to map "programs of action" for overcoming the world housing shortage was proposed today by Anatole A. Solow, housing and city planning specialist of the Organization of American States.
BAD NAUHEIM, Germany, May 7 -- Quietly working behind solid office desks here is a group of American men and women who hold the key to a decent, democratic Germany.

THE Ballet Theatre closes its very successful season at the Metropolitan Opera House with two performances today. The final bill will include not only all the stars, but will have Harold Lang in as a guest dancing the idiot boy in "La Fille Mal Gardee" for the first time. Otherwise the week runs largely to folk affairs. The complete schedule follows:

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The White House, which is the center both physically and symbolically of governmental Washington, stands today an empty, shored-up mass of masonry, while a political and architectural controversy swirls around it.

SIR THOMAS BEECHAM was 70 on April 29, and Victor took the occasion of the birthday to make a splash with the British conductor's recordings. No less than seven albums, two of them devoted to a performance of Gounod's Faust, were released simultaneously to signalize the event.

IN the article "Americans in Paris" (March 27) there is called to the readers' attention the fact that the Bard Review, published tit Venice, Fla., an issue of which will be published in Paris this spring, is "not to be confused with the Bard Review published by Bard College."

" Fixation disk" is the technical name given by Prof. Walter Miles, Yale psychologist, to a tiny area at the rear of the retina. It is the inner nervous lining of the eyeball and a kind of "index finger" for the eye.

SUMMER-FLOWERING bulbs give a large return in proportion to the labor and time involved in planting them. Last spring we used several different kinds to provide temporary foliage and color in a perennial border that was not yet completely planted.

The only two avenues along which a depression is likely to develop is the eventuality that Russia will end the "cold war" and the possibility that this country will "talk ourselves" into a depression. That is the opinion of leading United States purchasing agents who have just concludeed a five-week seminar in purchasing management at the Columbia University School of Business.

THE accumulation of random meditations and reflective oddments about the Ballet Theatre, to which this column shamelessly devoted itself last week, was so little reduced by that exercise that a second installment is herewith appended, again in the spirit of complete self-indulgence. Apropos of nothing in particular and more or less everything in general, then --

EATING, we're told, is fairly universal, which may be why food imports arrive from almost every part of the globe. If the whole world eats, then it would seem each country wants us to eat in its own language; this is interesting on occasion, even if the cost comes high.

ON one of Moscow's typically cold and gloomy days in March, 1938, two of the former top leaders of the Russian Communist party -- Nikolai Bukharin and Genrikh Yagoda -- and nineteen lesser functionaries went on trial for their lives in a small hall of the former Nobles' Club, renamed the House of Trade Unions.

Although elsewhere in the country there will be earlier local events, the greatest speed boat racing year in history will have its first major kick-off on Sunday, June 12, with the always exciting, usually dangerous 136-mile Hudson River marathon from Albany to Manhattan.
Producer and Star of "Man and Superman," returning to the City Center, May 16.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., May 7 (AP) -- Dr. James Jackson of the Indiana State Board of Health today examined 300 patients in the Allen County Infirmary, where twenty-nine elderly persons have died in the last thirty-four days.

BOSTON -- Convinced that New England hospitality is more than just having "the latchstring out," resort operators of this region have dedicated themselves to a program of "scrambled eggs and curtsying" in 1949.

RICHMOND, Va., May 7 -- The Upper South let its attention wander this week over subjects as far apart as the Berlin blockade and the private life of Ingrid Bergman. Only the course of labor legislation in Congress held constant interest.

LIKE fighting men arguing the wartime virtues of ship versus plane, legions of travel experts and travelers are engrossed in debating the comparative qualities of the two types of ocean transport for peacetime use. Will the tourist carriers of tomorrow ply the oceans or fly the air lanes?

BERLIN, May 7 -- British Foreign Secretary Bevin, arriving in Berlin today to thank the men and women of the airlift for their part in breaking the Soviet blockade of the city, declared he thought there was a "better chance for peace now" than at any time since 1945.

Newspapers have become conscious, with the growth of advertising, of a responsibility to the public and a realization of advertising's effects upon morals, manners and customs, H. H. Kynett, president of Aitkin-Kynett Company of Philadelphia and vice president of the Audit Bureau of Circulation, said yesterday.

COUNT CARLO SFORZA was appointed Italy's Minister of Foreign Affairs in 1947. A few days after he took office an angry crowd surrounded his car. Sforza cried out, "I know you want bread. I work sixteen hours a day so you'll get it." Someone in the crowd answered bitterly, "

PARIS, May 7 -- An international committee of experts attempting to analyze the basic concepts of democracy concluded its labors here today on a note of optimism. Its members agreed that the seeds of conflict could be removed from ideological differences.

MR. PUTNAM has already celebrated the natural -- and some unnatural -- wonders of Death Valley in two previous books of non-fiction. He has now fashioned a novel about Death Valley with the beauty and malignancy of the place among its major protagonists.

A new step in preventive medicine, titled "Operation Moving," has been completed at the Peabody Home for elderly women at 1000 Pelham Parkway, the Bronx, it was announced yesterday. And the home's fifty residents, from 65 to 96 years old, now can settle down to celebrating its seventy-fifth anniversary next Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- President Truman urged members of Congress today to do what they thought was right on the basis of facts at hand. He spoke informally at a luncheon in the Carlton Hotel following a ceremony in the rose garden at the White House in which he presented the annual Collier's Magazine Congressional awards for distinguished service to Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, Republican, of Michigan, and Speaker Sam Rayburn, Democrat, of Texas.
CAMDEN, N. J., May 7 (AP) -- King Ranch's Ocean Brief won the $15,000 added Colonial Handicap today at Garden State race track, leading Irisen across the finish line by five lengths.

The Belfast Celtic soccer team, the first to ever carry the Irish colors in an invasion of the United States, will open its ten-game tour today at Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island. A picked eleven from the American League clubs of Brookhattan, Hispano and Hakoah will provide the opposition.

DERBY, Conn., May 7 -- Facing a gallant opponent which made a fight of it from start to finish, Yale's varsity crew was forced to pass up its new low cadence beat of 32 today as it defeated Wisconsin by four feet in the headline event of the annual Derby Day regatta on the Housatonic.
Dr. Raymond Dart's discovery in South Africa of a primitive bone-and-horn culture apparently developed thousands of years before its time is puzzling anthropologists.

ANNAPOLIS, Md. -- This "ancient city" on the banks of the Severn River near Chesapeake Bay will celebrate its 300th birthday May 22 to 27. Known the country over as the seat of the United States Naval Academy, and throughout the state at least as Maryland's capital, Annapolis will endeavor that week to show visitors that, like Anne Arundel County in which it is located, the town has other worth-while attractions.

BUENOS AIRES, May 7 -- As he rounds out the first half of his six-year term President Juan D. Peron faces challenges on both the economic and political fronts. His party lost votes in the last provincial elections, but he still is unquestionably the leader of a majority of the Argentines.

HERE is a book about dogs written by a man who obviously loves and understands them, and who has also a sense of fun. It could better have been entitled "Mr. Willis and Mr. Wallis," for it is their story -- two utterly different but completely devoted pets who live near Epping Forest, England.

FRANKFORT, Germany, May 7 -- The Congressional investigation of the Malmedy war-crimes trials appears to have excited more interest in the United States than in Germany. This reflects certain aspects of the German reaction to the whole program of war crimes trials, best illustrated by those held at Nuremberg.

HARRY M. WARNER, president of Warner Brothers. last week took public issue with the Federal Communications Commission because the commission has not granted Warners' application for a television transmission license. His studio, Warner said, is shelving its ambitious plans to enter the field of television film production, which might have involved an expenditure of $50,000,000, as a consequence of the FCC attitude.

THERE are purists who will assure you that the premium for a grand slam -- 1,500 points, when vulnerable -still is not high enough. For one brief span of years, in fact, this school of thought succeeded in getting the vulnerable bonus increased to 2,250.

GEORGE SEATON, writer-director, boarded a plane for Germany last Wednesday accompanied by a twelve-man camera crew but minus a script for "Quartered City," the Berlin airlift film he will make for Twentieth Century-Fox.
TOKYO, May 7 -- Japan marked the second anniversary of its postwar Constitution on Monday with little fanfare but with mixed feelings.
United States foreign trade thus far this year is running almost neck-and-neck with dollar volume for 1948, according to analysis here yesterday.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 7 -- A bases-loaded pinch single in the last of the ninth by Sophomore Ed Foynes gave the Harvard baseball team a 7-6 victory over Columbia today and enabled the Crimson to remain tied with Penn for second place in the Eastern League standings. The triumph was the third in a row for Harvard and the third in four league contests.

Whenever proposals are made for the expansion of Federal Social Security benefits on the so-called trust fund basis of financing such plans, proponents take exception to plain talk on the fiscal methods employed in their administration.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 7 -- By a 32-to-6 vote, the Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee of the United Nations General Assembly took the first step today to pave the way for the United States and Britain to sign a proposed international convention on news-gathering.

A TAKE-YOUR-OWN-TENT vacation satisfies the wanderlust for mountains, shore, stream or lake, and brings with it an intimate glimpse of some of America's most beautiful, unspoiled scenery and a real sense of adventure.

ON April 19, 1943, in all free countries Jews celebrated the first day of Passover. On that very day, however, in the walled slum area that, for the past thirty months, had been known as the Warsaw ghetto, Nazi death battalions made their awesome entry.

AMONG the many qualities ascribed to modern art by friend and foe, elegance is one that is rarely mentioned and, indeed, rarely present. Surprisingly, then, it twice appears this week, both times in the work of artists who are part and parcel of the modern movement.

JANE WYMAN, now London bound on the high seas, was talking about how it feels to be an "Oscar" winner the other afternoon. To be perfectly frank about it, she feels just the same now as she did before winning Hollywood's special pat on the back for her performance in "Johnny Belinda" and she hasn't noticed that people treat her any differently either. She is happy about that.

THE new Polaroid Land Camera, which delivers a print one minute after the exposure, goes on sale in New York City on Wednesday. Equipped with a 135mm three-element anastigmat lens, the camera will sell for $89.75.

MEXICO CITY -- Cheaper travel costs down here -- resulting from devaluation of the peso's dollar-exchange rate -- gave a tremendous boost to the winter and early-spring tourist seasons. And travel officials also credit the economic factor for the substantial advance bookings by Americans who plan to visit the capital and other Mexican towns and resorts this summer, taking advantage of the high altitudes of this mountainous country to avoid the hot weather.

Mental health needs of public school children throughout the United States are being neglected to an appalling degree, according to a survey sponsored by the Association of Psychologists in the New York public schools.

Gerald W. Johnson in his "Landmark on the Road to Religious Freedom" gives reason to doubt that he really understands the deep religious motivation of the free men of colonial Maryland who, although determined to respect each others' conscientious convictions about God, had no idea, in the words of Mr. Johnson, of "repudiating all official concern with religion."
In stating that "The Real Traffic Problem" cannot be legislated or engineered out of existence, William Laas indicates that people in cities must be sold on an alternative means of travel.

THIS new book by Dr. Fredric Wertham is a study in the causes and prevention of murder. It is Dr. Wertham's thesis that murder can be prevented, that society can be protected from the murderer and the murderer from himself.

The Art Education Project of the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street, will have as its lecturer on Tuesday at 6 P. M. George Binet, who will speak on "Fine Arts as a Profession."

ST. LOUIS, May 7 -- With Eddie Robinson supplying the power, the Washington Senators won their fifth straight game, defeating the St. Louis Browns, 6 to 4, today. It was the eighth loss in a row for St. Louis.
WEST POINT, N. Y., May 7 -- Jim Scholtz, Army weight man, and John Zegger, Columbia sprinter, shared individual honors in a dual meet which Army won 101 to 25, on North Athletic Field today.

I was interested in reading Takayuki Asakawa's letter in THE TIMES Magazine asking for an American friend to correspond with. Thousands of Japanese as well as men and women throughout Western Europe are turning to individual Americans, looking for details about everyday living from "non-official" people they can trust.
HOUSTON -- Better roads, new hotels, more accommodations and a return to pre-war service will come as a pleasant surprise to the summer tourist in Texas this year.

AS a member of the new Senate Subcommittee on Health, I have just finished my homework -- boning up on ten volumes of testimony gathered by two earlier subcommittees on this question: How can we best bring adequate medical care within the reach of all our people?

WINNIPEG, Man. -- With vacationists already beginning to arrive in the prairie provinces of Western Canada, it is expected that the big annual influx of tourists may get under way this year at least a month ahead of the 1948 season.

CLEVELAND, May 7 (AP) -- Ken Keltner's high bounder drove in Dale Mitchell with the winning run in the twelfth inning today as the Cleveland Indians eked out a 4-to-3 victory over Joe McCarthy's Boston Red Sox.

NOT everyone wants to plant an extensive vegetable garden. If time or space is limited, three vegetables that are comparatively easy to grow, and particularly delicious when fresh, are tomatoes, corn and beans. And, now that danger of frost is past, they may be started in the garden.

CHICAGO, May 7 (AP) -- Grains slumped toward the close of the session on the Board of Trade today, giving up gains made in early dealings. Some of the selling represented evening-up operations by local traders prior to the week-end.
DAYTON, Ohio, May 7 -- James Carey, secretary of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, predicted today the complete rout of the leftist national leadership of the United Electrical Workers, CIO.

It will be no easy matter to drive rockets with atomic energy, Howard S. Seifert, chief of the Jet Propulsion Laboratory at the California Institute of Technology, writes in Physics Today. The heat at which rockets would operate with nuclear energy would be so high that they could not withstand it.

" Your ship to the south, sir," sang out a youngster of nineteen, and with the words a lean gray-haired man pulled on a topcoat, stepped from the pilot boat New Jersey into a small launch off Ambrose Channel and in ten minutes was directing a cargo ship safely through the shoaling entrance to New York Harbor.

THE cost of transportation, a major item in summer vacations that cover much territory, as most tours do, has gone up, rather than down, since last summer. As a result, even though there has been a modest retrenchment in some food and hotel rates, travel costs this summer will run about the same as last year.

NEVER before has the serious amateur been confronted with so great an array of tools for color photography as he is today. The question of making the best use of these tools is the concern of every color worker.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Seldom has the indissoluble, organic link between politics and economics been so clearly and perhaps so dramatically revealed as this week when the House of Representatives executed some surprising but not illogical gyrations on labor relations legislation.
TORONTO -- American visitors to Ontario this summer will benefit from stricter supervision of all restaurants and resort and camp accommodations.

MR. HAIG-BROWN has written a moving and exciting novel about the majestic vastness of the Pacific Northwest and a man whose spirit was wholly given to it. Colin Ensley, son of a British Columbian woodsman, grows to manhood under the guidance of a sister and mother he loves, a father with whom he is never at ease and a young school teacher who perceives his capabilities and conflicts and is herself in love with him.

CUYAMA VALLEY, Calif., May 7 -- Crossed-finger hopes that California may have turned up another major oil field, possibly comparable to the 80,000,000-barrel Elwood find, rose this week when the Richfield Oil Corporation brought in a 5,088-barrel-a-day gusher.
They asked the young man if he knew what day May 8 was. He said he believed that he was supposed to say something about Mother's Day but that he really had something else on his mind.

The events of the last five months have produced speculation concerning the possible effects of the paradox of the nationalization of communism and its international repercussions. Communism, which started as an international movement, has now become identified with particular national sovereignties, the U.S.S.R. and the Tito regime being, of course, the outstanding examples today.

ATLANTA, May 7 -- The first Southern regional conference of the Urban League today went on record as supporting proposals for expansion of the organization's social and economic welfare program in Southern communities.

Richard Neuberger in "Timber Graveyard" performs a public service in calling attention to the ravaging of our forest resources by greedy lumber men. A similar process is going on in public grazing lands of the Rocky Mountain area east of Oregon and Washington.

THE problem of raising the standards of today's amateur photographer is no different than in previous decades, according to Edward Steichen, head of the Museum of Modern Art's photography department. It has merely been multiplied, he says, and as a result has become more impressive, because more persons use cameras today than ever before.

THE new First Deputy Minister of the Armed Forces of the U.S.S.R., Vassily D. Sokolovsky, until a few weeks ago the grim-faced, steel-jawed Soviet Commander in Chief and chief non-cooperator in Germany, is a great reader.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The State Department will be confronted with an embarrassing question when the Chinese Communists seek, as they are likely to, diplomatic recognition from the powers. That point has not yet been reached, but it is bound to come in time.
WASHINGTON, May 7 -- At least 500,000 landlords already have taken the first steps toward seeking higher rent returns under the new control act, the Federal Housing Expediter's Office reported today.
LONDON, May 7 -- Bobby Locke of South Africa today was installed as the favorite to capture the British open golf championship starting on July 4.

SEOUL, Korea, May 7 -- United States Ambassador John J. Muccio conferred today with President Syngman Rhee and said he believed that economic aid, coupled with the assured ability of the Korean security forces to maintain order, would obviate armed clashes here.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 7 -- A long-term program of American capital investment abroad, aimed at raising productive capacity throughout the world and restoring international currency convertibility, is the "only feasible alternative" for ensuring stability in this country's commercial relations with the outside world, the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe reported last week.

SHANGHAI, May 7 -- Apparently mindful of the 1927 Communist-led labor insurrection, Shanghai police in the past three days have rushed seventeen men accused of various crimes to busy street corners and shot them publicly.

IN late April and early May spring came, bringing the sun and hope to Berlin. The ugly, broken city, in whose ruins fierce resistance to tyranny flamed in the long, cold nights of winter, dared to take a deep breath and to ask "Is it true; is there going to be a real settlement on Germany?"

Help for the totally deaf in the form of a non-auditory system for transmitting speech and other sounds as signals through electrical stimulation of the skin was reported yesterday at the closing session of the meeting of the Acoustical Society of America at the Statler Hotel.

Price reductions ranging from 4 to 10 per cent announced last week by Thomasville Chair Company and Kling Factories soon will be followed by similar cuts by a number of leading medium price quality bedroom furniture manufacturers. This was the consensus of retailers just returned from the Jamestown market and Southern factory tours to inspect pre-market samples of new merchandise.

DUBLIN. EIGHTEEN months ago the Abbey Theatre left the discerning critic nothing to desire except an atomic bomb. Slovenly acting, production and make-up in monotonously repeated repertory successes or occasional Gaelic translations reflected its management's muddled attempts to build up a bilingual company without reasonable assessment of the means available to create Gaelic drama or proper appreciation of the artistic tradition which was being sacrificed to this end.

With the volume of new domestic orders for aluminum products declining in general, many members of the aluminum producing and fabricating industry are hopefully looking to Washington for a relaxation of export quotas to permit greater shipments to markets, where demand is increasing.

HEWLETT, L. I., May 7 -- Despite the strong breeze that whipped over the sand dunes of the Seawane Harbor Club course, John Humm, Long Island amateur champion, and his partner, Ed Neu of Rockville, turned in a sub-par performance in the semi-final round of the William D. Richardson Memorial tournament today.

THE Reporter at Large department of the New Yorker magazine has been from the very beginning a special sort of entertainment: one which declined the invitation to be influenced, in either subject or style, by the witty and sometimes brilliant mannerisms that surround it on all sides.

SUAVE and well written as one would expect, Miss Allingham's latest production is a double feature -- "Deadly Duo." Both mysteries pose a very pretty girl with a tender love affair against a background of sudden death in an English setting.

EUROPE, this summer, will offer the music-lover the richest fare since the war. So many festivals have been lined up that a tourist reaching Prague next Saturday could start a musical feast that could continue almost unbrokenly until he left Venice late in September. If he had the money to take them all in, his musical odyssey would take him to Czechoslovakia, France, Holland, Austria, Scotland and Italy.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 7 -- Paced by its two brawny Olympians, Jim Fuchs and Vic Frank, Yale's track and field squad ran to fourteen straight its three-year string of dual meet victories by defeating Princeton, 82 to 58, in the forty-fourth meeting between the Eastern Intercollegiate League rivals today.

Fourteen distinctive gardens in East Side residential districts will be opened to the public on Tuesday and on May 17 under the auspices of the City Gardens Club. The places will be shown from 2:30 to 6 P. M. each day and there will be no postponement in the event of inclement weather.
A newcomer to the ranks of independent film makers. Mr. Kramer is the producer of "Champion" and the forthcoming "Home of the Brace."

One thousand teachers and administrative officials of the New York public school system attended a testimonial luncheon yesterday for Dr. Stephen F. Bayne, Deputy Superintendent of Schools, who will retire on Sept. 1 after fifty-one years as an educator.

PANAMA -- There has been such an increase in travel from the United States to Central America this spring that some hotels are booked full and advance reservations will be necessary at many others during the summer months, especially in Guatemala and Panama.

The Cardinals, who seem to have fallen a long way from their onetime lordly estate, dropped a couple of more notches yesterday as Clint Hartung spun a glittering three-hitter while his Giant colleagues mauled Eddie Dyer's Redbirds at the Polo Grounds, 9 to 1.

OMAHA, Neb., May 7 -- How to cope with a coming flood -- in this case a flood of wheat -- was receiving top attention this week in the Middle West. A deluge of winter wheat is expected to overflow available storage space, snarl transportation and depress prices.

HOWEVER one might feel about the textural attractions of real fabric during the more formal seasons when windows stay closed and housekeeping chores are done on schedule, there is a great deal to be said for a summertime switch to carefree plastics.

A mass invasion of the Twentieth Congressional District by canvassers and workers from outside in preparation for the special election on May 17 to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Sol Bloom is scheduled for this week, it was learned yesterday.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 7 (AP) -- Dean Noll of Manhattan and Jim McKenna of Villanova ran a quarter-mile dead heat today, but Noll's teammates found the going much easier as they won a triangular track meet in Thompson Stadium.
Mary Roche's "Stones for Glass Houses," telling what architects' wives think about their homes is interesting and witty; however, it is not very flattering or fair to the modern home.

WHENEVER fighting stops in China, Marxism will have to make its peace with the Chinese tradition symbolized by the hoary figure of Confucius. While Marx and Confucius are unlikely to become brothers in the new China, still neither is likely to extirpate the influence of the other.

HONOLULU, Hawaii, May 7 -- Stranded and jobless in this mid-Pacific area, several thousand former civilian employes of the United States Navy, the majority of whom were recruited from the United States mainland during the war years, are awaiting transportation home and Navy authorities are wrestling with the problem of helping them on their way.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 7 (AP) -- Bobby Locke came in with a 7-under-par 63 here today to pull within one stroke of Dr. Cary Middlecoff after 54 holes of play in the $10,000 Greenbrier open golf tournament.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. -- Those Florida West Coast residents who derive their income from the tourist trade, and that means most of the population, are taking much-needed rests following one of their busiest winter seasons.

A resolution urging immediate ratification of the North Atlantic Treaty and recommending that the Government take prompt action to "implement the obligations" assumed by the United States under the pact will be submitted on Tuesday at the annual meeting of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, it was announced yesterday.

OAK RIDGE, Tenn. -- This strategic center in the development of atomic energy and the cradle of atomic research is today open to the public after years of an existence shrouded in the deepest secrecy as the nation's most closely guarded wartime project.

MARSHWOOD was a house with a past and a personality. An anachronism in the Nineteen Twenties, it was a reminder of the Gilded Age, when one could speak casually of the Yellow Room, the rose gardens and servants' quarters.
PLYMOUTH, Mass. -- Visitors returning this year to the home of the Pilgrims will find plans well advanced for the restoration of the town's first settlement as it was in 1623.

PHILADELPHIA, May 7 (AP) -- A letter to Attorney General Tom C. Clark demanding that he retract his listing of the National Blue Star Mothers of America as "subversive" was made public today by Catherine V. Brown, organizer of the Blue Star Mothers.

Creation of a Transit Authority to solve the city's transportation problems was urged yesterday by the executive board of the Queens Transit Committee, an organization representing nine civic organizations and cooperating with the Chamber of Commerce of the Borough of Queens.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Dr. Philip C. Jessup and Charles E. Bohlen will fly to Paris late next week for an exchange of views with the French and British prior to the meeting of Big Four Foreign Ministers on German questions on May 23, it was announced today.

Seven years ago the Rescue Mission Society of 5 Doyers Street, in Chinatown, a society that feeds and houses underprivileged men, purchased a plot of ground fifty feet by ninety feet directly across the street from the society's headquarters.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- A logjam affecting 15,000 Federal paychecks was finally broken on Friday when the President approved a Congressional resolution allowing about a dozen agencies to pay their employes even though the official appropriation was lacking.

Manhattan extended its winning streak to two games yesterday afternoon by defeating Pratt Institute 16 -- 6, in a non-league encounter at Van Cortlandt Stadium. It was the first time since 1947 that a Manhattan nine was able to put together two victories in a row.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, May 7 -- The Military High Court dismissed today the appeals of Juliu Maniu and Ion Mihalache, Peasant party leaders, against sentences of life imprisonment for treason on Nov. 11, 1947.
Mothers should make their influence felt in politics in order to promote good-will in international relations, rabbis declared in Mother's Day sermons here yesterday.

In Mother's Day promotions here last week retailers stressed nylon slips and gowns, cotton and nylon blouses, handbags, cotton sunback dresses and leather topped mahogany tables, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the Retail News Bureau, Inc.

PARIS, May 7 -- The Jordanian Government is displaying signs of nervousness and weakness and the Syrian Government also is apprehensive because of fear of the Iraqi Army now stationed at Mafrak, according to reports received here. There is said to be a possibility of internal disorder in Jordan.

DETROIT, May 7 -- Henry Ford 2d, president of the Ford Motor Company, told all of his workers today that the company was willing to resume talks to end the three-day strike at the River Rouge and Lincoln plants at any time but would never relinquish management's contractual prerogative of establishing production standards.

SINCE 1941, when the Aquarium was closed to allow for the building of the BatteryBrooklyn tunnel, there has been a question of what. to do with the structure, known as Fort Clinton, which was built as a part of the defenses of New York just before the War of 1812.

IN contrast to the summer of 1948 there is one difficulty photographers will not have to contend with during the coming summer vacation season -- shortages. There will be an adequate supply of practically all types of cameras, accessories and materials, including color film.

LOS ANGELES -- Quite recovered from the winter's embarrassing "deep freeze" and in a festive centennial mood, Southern California is swinging into spring with the greatest plenitude of tourist facilities and intereests since the war.

IF I cavil at a book by Nicholas Blake, it is because, ever since his "Shell of Death," I have come to expect nothing short of perfection from him. And "Head of a Traveler," in which Nigel Strangeways uses his (and his creator's) perceptive understanding of poetry to unravel the puzzle of the beheaded corpse, does fall short of that perfection in two respects.

Making his first start for Fordham, Jim Daly, right-handed sophomore from the Bronx, pitched a two-hitter yesterday to blank Villanova, 1 -- 0, for the Rams' second victory in two days at Fordham Field.

The forthcoming combined exercises of the fleets of the Western European Union -- now scheduled for mid-June off the British coast -- will be the first tangible military evidence of the type of collaboration that can be expected from the Atlantic pact.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 7 -- This was no ordinary Kentucky Derby, there had to be something extra special about it, because this was the Diamond Jubilee of the Run for the Roses, now the premier event of the American turf. The winner automatically took a place with Aristides, Manuel and Black Gold in the fascinating chronology of this fascinating race.

OF the making of pioneer stories there is no end, but one as evocative as this is always welcome. It is especially interesting, as it deals with the opening up of Kentucky, a phase rarely dealt with in our many excellent narratives of early America.

FRANKFORT, Germany, May 7 -- The impending departure of Gen. Lucius D. Clay has inspired editorials in the German press that display a profound respect for his ability and achievements in Germany. This is mixed with a rather cool appraisal of him personally.

MOSCOW, May 7 -- While the Soviet press has given no reason to believe Russia's basic position on Germany has undergone any change, there is hope here that the lifting of the Berlin restrictions will affect the psychological atmosphere under which the Big Four Council of Foreign Ministers is to convene in Paris on May 23.

BERLIN, May 7 (AP) -- The invitation to the meeting at Brunswick was signed by Otto Nuschke, Herman Kastner and Otto Grotewohl, leaders respectively of the Soviet-zone Christian Democratic party, the Soviet-zone Liberal Democratic party and the Socialist Unity (Communist) party.

THE American theatre is already decentralized. A national theatre already exists. Although it does not conform to Broadway specifications, it fulfills the needs of individual communities more nearly than the regular commercial theatre is now able to do. These general conclusions

PRACTICALLY all recent Alaskan books have been about the new Alaska -- the Alaska of paved cities such as Anchorage (20,000 inhabitants), the Alaska of atomic" airfields and a streamlined diesel train clattering to Fairbanks, the Alaska which may be on the threshold of statehood.
PHILADELPHIA, May 7 (AP) -Hal Gregg, pitching nine full innings in relief, held the Phillies to seven hits today as the Pirates clubbed five hurlers for a 14-hit 16-4 victory.

CHICAGO -- The Chicago Railroad Fair, which last summer attracted 2,500,813 visitors, will begin a repeat performance on June 25. This year's improved and expanded version will run 100 days, compared to last year's stand of seventy-six days. The closing date for the exhibition is Oct. 2.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 7 -- The United Nations Commission for Indonesia sent official word today that the Netherlands and the Republic of Indonesia had agreed to call off five months of fighting in the jungles of the East Indies.

BONN, Germany, May 7 (Reuters) -- The Constitution for the West German Federal Republic, which received its second reading here last night, has been so framed that it can easily be applied to all Germany if the forthcoming four-power conference results in agreement.

AFTER your battered desk has been cleared and the staff has loaded you with gifts, and farewells are said -- what then? You have retired. Will retirement be a smooth road into the future or will it be filled with ruts?

The expected appointment of John J. McCloy, president of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, as United States High Commissioner in Germany has aroused considerable speculation in financial circles over the naming of his successor.

COLUMBIA, Mo., May 7 (AP) -- The American press "is a free press in the best sense of the word," in the opinion of John S. Knight, publisher of newspapers in Chicago, Detroit, Akron, Ohio, and Miami, Fla.

Ponder won the seventy-fifth Kentucky Derby by three lengths from Capot, with Palestinian third, before 100,000 spectators at Churchill Downs yesterday. Netting $91,600 of the $119,650 purse, the 16-1 shot was the fourth victor for Calumet Farm and the fifth for Trainer Ben Jones in the Louisville classic.

HOW to adapt the dance to the limitations of the television camera ranks among the more perplexing artistic problems in video, and at this juncture it remains largely unsolved. Inherently, the dance form and television are not susceptible to easy fusion.
LOS ANGELES, May 7 (AP) -- Sprinter Pell-Mel Patton University of Southern California went on a world-record-breaking spree today.

BERLIN, May 7 -- A "spot check" of the United States zone of Germany, conducted at the request of Gen. Lucius D. Clay, has ended with the Military Government satisfied that public offices are clear of Nazis barred by law from holding official positions.

There is a surface appearance of leisure in most Wall Street dining rooms these days. The unhurried atmosphere at the brokers' tables reflects the inactivity in the securities trading business. The theme of most luncheon conversations is how to rouse the market from its apathy.

GUY McCRONE'S successful earlier novel, "Red Plush," was, according to some reviewers, "a kind of 'Forsyte Saga' with a Scottish tinge." "Aunt Bel," the new volume in his series, is comparable to one of those later works of Galsworthy like "The White Monkey" or "The Silver Spoon," still in the "Saga" yet not approaching its first three parts in significance.
Columbia, Shrewsbury (Mass.) High School and La Salle College of Philadelphia each won a race yesterday in two-boat events held on the Harlem River.

An unemployed 26-year-old waiter from Amsterdam, N. Y., charged with stealing $100,000 from the home of Mrs. John N. Willys, widow of the automobile manufacturer, at 4643 Waldo Avenue, the Bronx, was arraigned yesterday on a charge of burglary in Bronx Magistrate's Court.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn. -- For the first time since the beginning of the war, this year there will be enough lodgings and other essential facilities for persons desiring to spend a summer vacation in the Tennessee Valley, according to travel bureaus in the valley. And prices will be reasonable, they add.

IT may well go down in history that 1949 was the year the automobile trailer entered a new stage in its evolution, for on the market this year are a collapsible two-story model and a luxury coach which boasts an astradome, a folding sun deck and a television set.

AT a party I gave shortly after V-J Day the hired bartender glanced rather superciliously at the Ersatz liquor on the bar and made a point of asking each guest with explicit courtesy whether he wished his highball with bourbon or scotch-type whisky.

THE second volume of "The Jewish People -- Past and Present" has appeared. The third volume is to be published early in 1950. With two-thirds of European Jewry annihilated, and the institutions that gave rise to its creative forces no longer in existence, the responsibility for carrying on has clearly become the duty and privilege of America.

What makes careers? Is it the way men blueprint their lives? Or is it the way life bluepencils their fans ? John W. Haussermann should know something about this. He's been a trial lawyer, a county- beat politician, a combat soldier, judge, city counsel, international lawyer, mining industrialist and banker.

THE Somerset Maugham Award has gone this year to a poet. He is Hamish Henderson, a Scotsman who served in Africa with the Highland Division, and his book is called "Elegies for the Dead in Cyrenaica." The award is given to a writer under 30 years of age, and the two earlier recipients were Miss A. L. Barker (for her short stories) and P. H. Newby for his novels.

The challenging article by Warren R. Austin entitled "A Warning on World Government" in the May number of Harper's Magazine should be widely read. Former Senator Austin is the United States representative at the seat of the United Nations. He has great ability and profound knowledge of the problems of collective security and world peace.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 7 -- The newspaper Politika accused Soviet scientists today of rewriting the history of scientifc discovery and invention in the interest of "narrow nationalistic motives" and charged them with falsely claiming some of the greatest discoveries and inventions in modern times.

A broad training program to develop better personnel throughout the building supply industry is now being pushed by the Johns-Manville Sales Corporation and City College of New York School of Business. W. R. Wilkinson, vice president of Johns-Manville, and Dr. Robert A. Love, director of the evening and extension division of C. C. N. Y., disclosed the program jointly yesterday.

ALBANY -- Many resort operators in the Adirondacks, Finger Lakes and other vacation areas of New York State have reduced their rates by as much as 10 and 20 per cent for the spring and summer season, according to a survey made by the Travel Bureau of the State Department of Commerce.
IN reply to Mr. Maynard's letter in last week's TIMES pertaining to "Opportunities for Composers," let me add this comment.

BOSTON, May 7 -- Should the work of the Commission on the Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government, headed by Herbert Hoover, die in the dusty pigeonholes of Washington, America as now known may well die with it, Dr. Robert L. Johnson, president of Temple University, warned today.

WHEN a new baby arrives in the family it is natural for an older child to feel unloved and left out. The phrase, "His nose is out of joint," has long been used to laugh off a child's jealousy, as Lawrence K. Frank points out in a foreword to a book of pictures and text, "David's Bad Day," by Else McKean, to be published May 15 by Shady Hill Press.
RANGOON, Burma, May 7 (AP) -- A Government spokesman said today Burma had doubled the guard on the China-Burma border to stop any attempts of Burmese and Chinese Communists from joining forces.
Mayor O'Dwyer appealed for Federal aid in slum clearance and low-cost housing construction yesterday when he welcomed sixty-nine members of Congress and their families at City Hall.

This is a comment on the article "How Beethoven Fares in Colleges," by Benjamin Grossbayne in THE TIMES of April 24. We regret that not all institutions of higher education in America had an opportunity to participate in the investigation which Mr. Grossbayne carried on in "ascertaining what American colleges are doing with Beethoven."

Unless our Government shows some heart as well as head, the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund will be forced to close down its work on behalf of the world's needy youngsters. For the Children's Fund, facing a financial and a moral crisis, is battling for its life -- and therefore for the health and lives of the children it has been reaching.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 7 -- The slot machine was a much discussed gadget this week as California, sometimes thought of as tolerant of gambling, took steps which many persons feared and many others hoped would lead to driving the "one-armed bandits" from the state.

ANKARA, Turkey, May 7 -- "If by some magic geographical reshuffle Turkey were adjacent to California and open to United States exploitation it would become as rich, or possibly richer, than any state in the union within a decade," it was said here today by a well-known economist.

A new two-door sedan in the low price bracket has gone into country-wide delivery, according to an announcement yesterday by the Dodge division, Chrysler Corporation. The car is an addition to the Wayfarer series and is scheduled to sell in this city for $1,864, exclusive of sales tax. It is on display at Bishop, McCormick and Bishop, 1709 Broadway, and other showrooms in the metropolitan area.

SINCE midsummer of 1945 this ancient city has been busy covering up the scars of war and uncovering the unexploded bombs of war. Though few Londoners are aware of the fact, bomb-disposal squads go out each day, as they did during London's wartime ordeal, to dig up the "duds" left behind by the Luftwaffe raiders in the blitzes.

OF all the dreams of the world, the greatest -- and seemingly the most fugitive -- is to have man live beside his fellow man in permanent peace and respect. Not twenty miles from Lake Success, where faltering steps toward this dream are taken by the Governments of the world, the dream is everyday practice --"one world" exists under one roof.

JUNEAU, Alaska -- According to Alaska's pre-season tourist barometer -- the stack of inquiring letters from all parts of the world -- the territory expects in 1949 the greatest influx of tourists in its eighty-one-year- old history.

DETROIT, May 7 (UP) -- Some 135,750 were idle throughout the auto industry in strikes and layoffs. About 47,000 of the idle at companies other than Ford were expected to return to work Monday but the spreading paralysis of the Ford strike soon would offset that number.

Adjustment of exchange rates to speed foreign-trade transactions will be high on the agenda of the board of the International Monetary Fund at its annual meeting in Washington in September, according to word in financial circles here last week.

PARIS -- The American tourist in Western Europe this summer will find that his trip in some ways will be easier than it was before the war. Now, as in the trusting days before World War I, it has once again become possible to travel from country to country without that irritating formality, the visa.

CHICAGO, May 7 -- Bob Porterfield had his initial effort of the Yankees' 1949 campaign at Comiskey Park today and got through the experience in a highly satisfactory manner. The rugged Virginian, who hurt his arm in a Brooklyn exhibition struggle three weeks ago, just missed a shutout as the Yanks maltreated two of the three hurlers Jack Onslow tossed into the fray and defeated the White Sox, 8 to 1, before 11,520 onlookers.

China, before Chiang Kai-shek's march to power in 1927, was a badly divided and disorganized country. The atmosphere had been one of political anarchy. Quarreling war lords had held power in various sections of the country, led their own armies, levied their own taxes.

THE decision of Street Smith to discontinue the publication of pulp thrillers and comic magazines may mark the end of another era in the history of sensational literature. However, though a waning interest in pulp adventure tales may be the trend at the moment, it seems unlikely that the demand for swiftly paced, stereotyped, inexpensive stories will ever die out permanently.

Edward Lasker's article, "Chess Men -- and Chess Mentality," made a shrewd point about self-confidence as an attribute of chess masters. How true! One afternoon before the war the writer was sitting in the Cafe Regence, famous center of Parisian chess, when there was a great commotion, as a stalwart, vigorous, ruddy man came in.

Servel, Inc., manufacturer of gas refrigerators in Evansville, Ind., has just finished distributing to its 12,000 dealers and distributors throughout the country booklets telling them how to find good salesmen.

MIAMI -- The Gold Coast that is Florida's eastern shoreline -- its name comes not only from the golden sun and the golden sand, but also from the gold that the tourist business pours into the area during the winter -- is preparing to do a brisk trade on the same strand this summer.
PRINCETON, N. J., May 7 -- An "open house," in which several of the historic and beautiful homes and gardens here may be visited by the public, will be held next Saturday afternoon.

For the first time since before the war, the University of Michigan will sponsor from June 13 to 18 an "alumni university." The program will include four daily lecture periods and recommend reading to bring alumni up to date on contemporary American problems.

HARRISON, N. Y., May 7 -- A New York State Department of Commerce campaign to promote the public's interest in aviation bore fruit today when a department-sponsored airshow drew 15,000 persons to the Westchester County Airport here.

About eleven million older persons in this country face years of non-productivity and slow death because of their degenerative diseases. The prospect does not discourage Dr. Clive M. McCay, Professor of Nutrition at Cornell University, who showed years ago that underfeeding was one way of living long.

BOSTON -- New England's summer-resort operators are as price conscious this season as their guests, and throughout all the six states, where tourism is one of the top-ranking industries, the goal seems to be to hold vacation costs to last year's price range. This means families may enjoy vacations at rates ranging upward from $35 a week per person.

JOHN STRACHEY once rightly described the Nineteen Thirties as the golden age of English detection -- a period in which the comedy of manners and the strict puzzle successfully fused to produce a new and suavely literate form of entertainment.

The Transport Workers Union, CIO, rejected yesterday a city mediator's formula for settlement of Local 100's dispute with the Third Avenue Transit Corporation and it appeared that only the direct intervention of Mayor O'Dwyer could halt the strike called for 4 A. M. tomorrow.

Former associates prominent in the fields of politics, business and civic affairs were among the 1,000 persons who attended a solemn high mass of requiem yesterday for Capt. William J. Pedrick, Collector of Internal Revenue for the Second New York District, held in the Church of St. Jean Baptiste, Lexington Avenue and Seventy-sixth Street.

With some 900,000 barrels a day of shut-in crude oil production in this country, there is a belief in a section of the petroleum industry that the Economic Cooperation Administration may be moving too fast in its efforts to expand oil operations abroad with the purpose of making Europe independent of the oil resources of the Western Hemisphere.

CHICAGO, May 7 -- In an address accepting the gold medal award of the American Institute of Chemists, Inc., Dr. Warren K. Lewis, emeritus Professor of Chemical Engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said tonight that "society needs professional leadership of the highest calibre in the attack on the complex human problems of the economic order."

THE hand that Reinhold Niebuhr gives in greeting is as bony and strong as a farmer's, and goes with his powerful frame, his vigorous head. Dr. Niebuhr, at 56, has just published his twelfth book, "Faith and History."

THE amateur photographers are coming out of their darkrooms by the thousands, attracted by the warm soft lighting of the spring and summer sunshine. In the next few months they will be seen in town and country, on Times Square and in the remote mountains, shooting like mad and stacking up negatives to be printed with tender care through the autumn and winter nights.

THE purple and white blooms of lilacs are decorating the countryside and lawns across the land. From Tennessee to Maines, spring travelers may follow a leisurely progress through a lilac world. Such fine collections as those in Rochester, N. Y., and at the Arnold Arboretum in Boston, Mass., open up new vistas of delight and wonder at the adaptable shrub so universally known.

Officials of the American Jewish Committee, reporting yesterday at the opening session of the spring meeting of its executive body, asserted that only permanent peace between the Arab nations and Israel could assure the solution of Israel's pressing economic and rehabilitation problems.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, May 7 -- Westerners, many of them directly dependent upon the mining industry for wages and sales, are more than a little worried by this week's sharp slump in the prices of metals. Production of non-ferrous metals in such major districts as Butte, Bingham, Leadville and Coeur d'Alene has not yet been affected by the sag in refinery prices for copper, lead and zinc. Marginal mines, however, are already hard hit.

By offering customers their choice of f.o.b. or delivered prices, industrial companies need fear no anti-trust proceedings. This was the formula advanced last week by Lynn C. Paulson, assistant chief trial counsel of the Federal Trade Commission in Washington.

A STUDENT of warfare, interested in what made the Red Army "tick," will find little information of value in this volume, which is more the story of Polish-born Fred Virski's travels and escapades as a deserter in time of war within the Soviet Union than it is a story of life in the Russian Army.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 7 -- Princeton's varsity lightweights defeated Harvard and Yale in the twenty-fourth annual Goldthwait Cup race and the Tigers swept three sprint races with Rutgers today, to the great delight of a gala house party week-end gathering on the shores of Lake Carnegie.

IN a prefatory chapter to this, his second novel, Mr. Gresham retells the story of the blind men who sought to know the truth of the elephant. Each touched a part of the animal and then generalized from that one experience. While the sightless men disputed, the elephant departed.

Conflicting influences brought alternating periods of strength and uncertainty to financial markets last week. Favorable factors, such as the easing of tension with Russia over the lifting of the Berlin blockade and resistance to attempts to erase the Taft-Hartley Law from the statute books, were offset by ominous signs of labor difficulties.

TORONTO, May 7 (AP) -- Al Porto, 21-year-old lefthander of the Toronto Maple Leafs, turned in the first no-hit, no-run game of the International League season today as he blanked the Newark Bears, 5 -- 0, in the second game of a double-header.

The Bar Kochba award, given to the outstanding Jewish athlete of the year, was presented to Henry Wittenberg, Olympic heavyweight wrestling champion, last night at the fourth annual national "Sports on Parade" staged by the States Maccabi Association in the St. Nicholas Arena.

The Voice of America and the British Broadcasting Corporation succeeded yesterday in getting 25 per cent of their news programs through to the Russian people despite Soviet jamming of their short-wave broadcasts.

PETUNIAS set out as plants in May will bloom over a longer period and produce more flowers per plant than any other annual. And, in spite of the bewildering assortment listed in the seed catalogues, there is a specific type of petunia for any kind of planting desired.

CHICAGO -- Practically everyone connected with the business of making the Midwest's vacation resources accessible and attractive to tourists is convinced that a full-fledged buyer's market is in prospect for the first time since the war.

Soviet middle school graduates "in the mass' have enough knowledge for college but 20 per cent of those who take the entrance examinations flunk them annually, S. B. Kaftanov, Soviet Minister of Higher Education, reports in Komsomolskaya Pravda, Moscow organ of the Soviet Young Communist League.

Public Law 31, Eighty-first Congress, entitled "Housing and Rent Act of 1949," was passed last March 29. It includes these words: "* * * the Housing Expediter and the local boards shall observe the principle of maintaining maximum rents * * * at levels which will yield to landlords a fair net operating income * * *."

THIS summer the vacationing American will have his choice of the widest variety of tried and tested passenger planes since the first flight of the Wright brothers. The familiar pattern of two or three different types of commercial airliners has been changed. This year there will be no fewer than seven different types of commercial aircraft in regular service.

I FEEL it imperative to offset the erroneous impression inadvertently created by your drama critic that central staging is a dramatic form limited to a comparatively small audience for full and complete appreciation. In 1940, at Long Beach, I directed five plays for the "Ringside Theatre" before audiences that numbered over one thousand. These plays with professional Equity casts were, "Margin for Error," "Morning Star," "Pins and Needles," "Sailor Beware," and "Kiss the Boys Goodbye."

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The House Ways and Means Committee was defended by ranking members representing both parties today for adopting a secrecy rule in its current deliberations on expansion and liberalization of the Social Security program.

Mass-consumed cotton apparel items today average 19.5 per cent less at the retail level than they did a year ago, according to a survey made by the Cotton-Textile Institute. The price declines on fourteen of these items, it was said, ranged from 11 to 33 per cent, indicating that the sharp price decreases in primary markets have been carried forward gradually to the consumer.

HAVANA -- The Cuban Government has just ordered a 10 per cent reduction in hotel and boarding house rates as part of an anti-inflation campaign. This action, coupled with the regular seasonal lowering of lodging prices, is assisting efforts of Cuban travel officials to develop a summer tourist season to rival that of the winter months.

Retail stores are buying summer merchandise cautiously with relatively short-term commitments, it was reported here last week. They are finding merchandise plentiful and as a result find they can argue prices with manufacturers in many cases. Orders are being placed with maximum delivery dates of between six and eight weeks.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The third round in the battle between President Truman and a majority of Congress has begun with shadow-boxing. If history repeats itself this will be followed by sparring and then by an exchange of real blows. But if the President gets even a doubtful draw at this session of the Eighty-first Congress that will surprise the ringside experts, most of whom look for a decision the other way.

THE chances are good that the Metropolitan Opera's 1949-50 season will run to eighteen weeks, two more than the one recently completed. The opening date, which has been penciled in for Nov. 21, is a week earlier than last year, which means seventeen weeks for sure. The matter will be settled when the negotiations with the unions have been completed, and the report is that the settlement is "pretty near."

Following closely the scope and content of part one of the Joseph Brummer collection of art auctioned last month, part two, on the block this week in four sessions from Wednesday through Saturday, will again offer valuable and rare Romanesque, Gothic and Renaissance art objects and Egyptian, Greek, Roman and pre-Columbian antiquities.

EVERY extraordinary person has a certain mission which he is called upon to fulfill. After he has accomplished it he is no longer needed on earth in this form, and Providence makes use of him for something else. But inasmuch as everything here on earth is affected by the operation of natural forces, the daemons engage in efforts to trip him up until they have him down.

Each October, when National Employ the Physically Handicapped Week is held, civic leaders urge that the campaign to employ disabled persons should not be limited to one week a year but should be carried on continuously. In New York's 3,000-bed Bellevue Hospital that suggestion is being followed by a small group of business and professional men known as the "Just One Break" committee.

The rise in the national birth rate and the wartime limitation on building construction has placed such a heavy burden on the average community's ability to build new schools that state assistance is now needed to alleviate the emergency. This is the conclusion of Dr. Wallace H. Strevell, whose monograph on "State Aid for Central School Building" has just been released by Teachers College of Columbia University.

IN this tightly plotted short novel, Mr. Maltz achieves an effect all too rare in current fiction -- an affirmation of faith in man's courage, in man's will to put things right in a badly off-center world. Set in that gloomy trap for the unwary writer (an old man's home), the story he tells is always engrossing -- and, at times, inspiring, in the best sense of that misused word.

SANTA FE, N. M. -- Expansion of old facilities and construction of new ones indicate a banner tourist year for New Mexico, where the business of entertaining out-of-state guests since the war has grossed $125,000,000 annually. Rates will be about the same as they were last year; only a few accommodations show slight increases.

GENEVA, May 7 -- Startling contrasts between ostensible economic progress in Eastern Europe, expressed in terms of percentage completion of plans, and the actual growth of real capital in Eastern European industry, are revealed in data published by the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe in its annual survey of Europe's economy.

NOW that spring has come around again, young readers of 9 to 11 will especially welcome Marion Renick's newest book dealing with an American sport. This time it's softball. The Dooleys are a numerous family, and they are all softball fans. This includes Mrs. Dooley who arranges the household schedule to suit game and practice time.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 7 -- An invitation to United States capital to come to Brazil to develop industry and agriculture is in the program of President Eurico Gaspar Dutra. He may broach this subject to President Truman who originated the plan of helping undeveloped world areas and then place the matter in the hands of experts who will accompany him in his talks with American representatives.

THE best pictures are made by those photographers who feel some excitement about life and use the camera to share their enthusiasm with others. The camera in such hands is a medium for communicating vital experience; because the photographer is moved strongly by what he sees, he wants to tell people about it, and so makes a picture.
DETROIT, May 7 (AP) -- Righthander Freddie Hutchinson and rookie outfielder Johnny Groth combined their talents today to give the Detroit Tigers a 4-2 decision over the Philadelphia Athletics.

WHEN a narrative is too long to be a short story and too short to be a novel, we have a literary compromise called either a novelette or that fancy thing, a novella. It is an uneasy form and seldom comes off satisfactorily. "The Good Family" is no exception.

TWO of the ablest expounders of modern physical science, especially of relativity and the quantum theory, were the late A. S. Eddington and Sir James Jeans. Both were devout men and both were convinced that when we behold a tree or a lake glittering in the sunshine, we respond to something "out there," something that is not the tree and the lake as interpreted by our retinas and brains.
ATLANTA, Ga., May 7 -- People in the Southeast concerned themselves this week with a broad variety of subjects -- international, national and local affairs all getting a generous share of attention.
The Police Athletic League's "typical boy and girl," after a tour of Police Headquarters yesterday morning, both agreed that "criminals couldn't get very far in New York."

MRS. PRESCOTT, the daughter of the late Albert Henry Wiggin, has written an affectionate biography of her father, "the man who built the Chase Bank," and one of the dominant financial figures in the New York City of the Nineteen Twenties.

ALL fifteen of these short stories by Herman Melville were written in the crucial (and perhaps heart-breaking) years between 1853-56 -- the years just after "Moby Dick" and the disastrous "Pierre," and just before "The Confidence Man" and (except for the poems) the long years of silence.

ROME, May 7 -- The first important test since the general election of April 18, 1948 will be held tomorrow in Sardinia where 800,000 voters are called to the polls to elect sixty Councilors for the island's first regional Parliament.
LUBBOCK, Tex., May 7 (AP) -- Floodwaters rose into 350 Lubbock homes and resulted in one death today, increasing the Texas toll from violent weather to five dead and thirty-six injured in two days.

OUT of the intolerable wreckage of World War I emerged four words uttered by a woman about to die. On the night in Brussels when she faced the firing squad Edith Cavell said quietly that "patriotism is not enough."
TRENTON, N. J., May 7 (AP) -- Fare increases requested by the Pennsylvania and Erie Railroads were suspended today by the Board of Public Utility Commissioners.

The thirteenth annual Three Choir Festival under the auspices of Congregation Emanu-El closed yesterday. Following the custom of other years, the third and final program was integrated with the regular morning service for the sabbath at Temple Emanu-El. Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street.

Cotton textile production, off 20 per cent so far this year, will undergo further curtailment in the next sixty days, it was pointed out last week. Total output for the year, textile men predicted, will fall to the lowest level since 1939, unless the market takes a marked turn for the better in the third and fourth quarters.

Jokes circulating in Europe today include a few that are simply "a laugh for a laugh's sake," but most of them serve as ideological and political weapons. Many are recognizable as merely new versions of old standbys. Here is a selection forwarded by Times correspondents.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 7 (AP) -- An "outside chance" that Ponder might sneak into the place or show end of the pay-off was the only reason the horse was entered in the Kentucky Derby today.

When 'teen-agers wrecked the dining room of the Manhattanville Neighborhood Center at 514 West 126th Street, directors of the institution decided it was time to revise their technique in dealing with street gangs.

THE short biography, like the short story, is one of the most challenging forms confronting an author. A few deft strokes must outline a vivid as well as balanced portrait of his subject. Wealth of detail must be sacrificed to the barest essentials.
