WASHINGTON, May 7 -- There's a new definition of the Truman Doctrine coming to light in Washington. In broad concept it works like this: If thy neighbor smite thee, turn the other cheek. If he smite thee there also, then you lower the boom on him.
A new technique for detecting cancer of the cervix in women has been developed by two professors at Yale and New York Universities, it was announced yesterday.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn. -- A state-wide series of celebrations will mark Minnesota's Territorial Centennial this summer. Leading events will include the Minneapolis Aquatennial, a city-wide sports festival, and the presentation of a series of five historic pageants to be held at various of the state's parks.

WITH an eye for what's timely, George Bagby lights a fuse to the bitter cold war between landlord and tenants in a down-at-heel apartment house. The renting agent -- a detestable, gouging woman -- winds up at the bottom of the elevator shaft.

HONOLULU -- Mainland vacationers considering a spring or summer trip to Hawaii can be assured of ample accommodations from May through August. This month and next will be "between seasons" in these islands, where there are no seasons so far as climate is concerned.

NEWARK, N. J. May 7 -- An eleventh-hour attempt to introduce a racial issue in the campaign for election next Tuesday of five city commissioners was partly checked today by action of Postmaster John A. Rielly, who impounded 1,200 postcards regarded as racially slanderous.

EVEN mice have their housing problems today, according to this merry picture book. Whisker and Frisker were snugly ensconced in an old red sock until a kitten in search of a cap evicted them. Then their peregrinations from pocketbook to muff to dolls' house were fraught with disappointment and interruptions, but eventually the mice solved their problem with great firmness and ingenuity.

HALIFAX, N. S. -- The Halifax Bicentenary celebration, extending over two and a half months from June 21 to Labor Day, will highlight Nova Scotia's vacation season with an elaborate program of events for which the city fathers have been planning for more than two years.

THE Berlin blockade will be lifted this week and the common idea is that thereby the "cold war" with Russia has moderated. Whether this is only a "defrosting of the refrigerator" remains to be seen, as the expression goes. Businesswise, of course, the seeing part is immensely important because some $23 billions in rearmament, European relief and Atlantic Pact expenditures are tied in with the issue.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, May 7 -- It is becoming increasingly likely that as part of the overall Palestine peace settlement, Jerusalem, instead of being placed under an international regime as originally desired by the United Nations, will be partitioned between Israel and Jordan, with safeguards being established for sacred religious shrines.

THE vacation season, which always seems to take such a long time arriving, and then suddenly sneaks up before any plans are made, is already here. For the first time in four years, the resort and travel industry is being modest in its spring predictions and use of superlatives, meanwhile making earnest plans to be more careful with, and considerate of, its customers.

THE summer cruise season, already marked by heavy advance bookings for July and August, probably will find many unhappy vacationists left at the pier to watch crowded ships pulling out for romantic sails to Caribbean and South American ports.

Showing tremendous all-around strength that enabled it to take places in nine of the twelve open events, the Bishop Loughlin track team won the third annual Brooklyn College interscholastic meet yesterday with 35 2-3 points.
TOWSON, Md., May 7 (AP) -- Dr. Otto F. Kraushaar was inaugurated today as the sixth president of Goucher College in ceremonies held on the institution's new campus just north of Baltimore.

KARACHI, Pakistan, April 22 -- The former colonial countries of Asia, meaning principally India and Pakistan, are tired of going to the United States and Britain as suppliants for aid in combatting the common enemy, communism. They feel that the West needs them in this battle perhaps more than they need the West, unless the latter is willing to let all Asia go to the Communists.

ATHENS, Ohio, May 7 -- Dr. Irma E. Voigt, the first and only dean of women in the 145-year history of Ohio University, will end her thirty-six years of service to the university on June 30. John C. Baker, president, has accepted her resignation with regret.

HAMILTON, Bermuda -- After an Easter season unequaled since before the war -- and in only two pre-war years were the March, 1949, travel figures exceeded -- Bermuda is anticipating equally good summer business.

JERSEY CITY, May 7 -- The Frank Hague Democratic organization, which has shown its political strength in national and state conventions for three decades, faces its greatest test at the municipal election here on Tuesday.

Preliminary plans for the Welfare Center Building to be incorporated in the Brooklyn Civic Center were announced yesterday by Mayor O'Dwyer and Borough President John Cashmore. The structure will be erected at an estimated cost of $1,400,000.

BEIRUT, Iraq, May 7 -- Troops of King Abdullah's Arab Legion fired over the heads of Palestinian Arab demonstrators in Nablus, Palestine, today, according to reports reaching here. Stones were hurled at the Government House in Nablus in a demonstration of protest against Jordan's cession to Israel of a strip of rich farm land in the Tulkarm-Jenin area under the terms of the armistice agreement signed at Rhodes.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 7 (UP) -- Mrs. Ronald Balcom of New York and Palm Beach reported tonight that $250,000 worth of jewelry had been stolen from her suite at the Greenbrier Hotel.
BALTIMORE, May 7 (AP) -- Brookmeade Stabie's Chains won the $25,000 added Dixie Handicap at Pimlico today.

FOR THIS WEEK: Disbud peonies, pinching off the small side buds and leaving only the large center one. Ants on peony buds do no harm. . . . Scatter bonemeal or 5-10-5 fertilizer around narcissus. . . . Spray roses, ornamental crabapples and any flower seed lings touched by aphids with nicotine sulfate. . . .
TEL AVIV, May 7 -- Israel is facing the toughest battle of its young life. This time it is on the economic battlefield.
President Truman yesterday proclaimed May 23 as National Maritime Day.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 7 -- An Arab campaign to postpone a decision on Israel's application for membership in the United Nations suffered a setback today by the decision of the General Assembly's Ad Hoc Committee to apply the closure rule and bar any new speakers.

Following President Truman's inaugural address, comments and suggestions have been echoed from all corners of the world. The issue is, of course, the fourth point, which sets out in broad outline the economic foreign policy of the United States in connection with the industrially backward areas of the world.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- While rent control officials would not venture even a guess, best outside sources believe somewhat less than half the tenants in the 14,000,000 dwellings presently controlled stand to have their rents eventually increased as a result of this week's formula for "fair rent" adjustments.

PARIS, May 7 -- Dr. Philip C. Jessup is expected in Paris next week to discuss with Foreign Minister Robert Schuman and his aides Western policy for the forthcoming four-power Foreign Ministers conference on Germany. It is understood that he will later visit London and that the French and British experts will also survey the outlook together.

WEST POINT, N. Y., May 7 -- Princeton virtually eliminated Army from the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League race today when the Tiger nine stopped the cadets, 6 to 2, at Doubleday Field. The setback was Army's third straight League loss and evened the Tigers mark at three and three.

PORTRAITS of persons who were notables in the era when John I (1347-1433) was King of Portugal, from 1385 until his death, are to appear on stamps in preparation. Several of the men honored are new to philately's expanding gallery.

IT is refreshing to read a sports story like this one which is not overcrowded with slang. Its likable hero is lanky and awkward Paul Smith, who enters junior high school with little confidence in himself. By the time he earns the nickname of "Stretch" he is a player on the basketball team.

SPOKANE, Wash. -- Vacations will be cheaper this summer in the Pacific Northwest. Inns, hotels and restaurants all report moderate reductions in rates, with further decreases tentatively promised. The tourist dollar is becoming tighter, and the Northwest seems willing to cut tariffs in order to bid for its share.

The importance of the North Atlantic pact was emphasized last night by speakers attending the fifty-second annual dinner of the Irish American Historical Society, in the Biltmore Hotel, at which Mrs. Anne O'Hare McCormick of THE NEW YORK TIMES editorial board received the society's gold medal.
FRANKFORT, Germany, May 7 (UP) -- At least eight members of Gen. Lucius D. Clay's "brain trust" said today they hoped to resign when the United States Military Governor retires about June 1.
LONDON, May 7 (Reuters) -- Manchester United today won a three-way battle for runner-up honors to Portsmouth in the English Soccer League.

About 15,600,000 working men and women belong to labor unions. They and their dependents total perhaps 50,000,000 -- one in every three Americans. Their relations with management are regulated by the controversial Taft-Hartley Act. Their wages -- both as purchasing power and as a part of the cost of production -- are a vital element in the national economy.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, May 7 -- Both Norway and Denmark have solved the problem of nation-wide medical insurance with a maximum of coverage and a minimum of red tape.
Not because the Dodgers routed the Cubs, 10 -- 4, did yesterday's game provide a human interest yarn for many fans among the 14,404 at Ebbets Field.

LAST week, on Mayor O'Dwyer's order, Investigation Commissioner John M. Murtagh began the latest of the city's drives against theatre ticket gougers. Although sensible people on Broadway recognize that a move was bound to come in a season that produced such tremendous hits as "Death of a Salesman," "South Pacific" and "Kiss Me, Kate," they cannot help wondering what in the end will be achieved.

BORDEAUX, France, April 30 -A two-year task of clearing Bordeaux harbor of ships sunk there by the Germans to bottle up the port has now been finished although the newly dredged channel still lacks several feet of the prewar depth at several points.

DELAND, Fla., May 7 (UP) -- Frederick O. Hammer, 41 years old, posted bond of $21,000 and was freed tonight after being charged with beating his wealthy wife with his fists. He denied his tripped and fell while boarding their yacht.

SANTIAGO, Chile -- South America is a vacation land of paradox. For 130 Argentine pesos -- less than $20 over most hotel desks, though not at banks, where it would come to about $27 -- you can make the most celebrated air crossing in the Western World.

TO the current issue of "The Scriptwriter," organ of the Radio Writers Guild, Hester Sondergaard, the actress, has contributed an article in which she strongly argues that some writers are not doing all they might to help radio.

WASHINGTON -- In the varied vacation area beyond the Potomac, where the Atlantic in the east and the Appalachians in the west provide beaches and highlands, this is a year for celebrations, festivals and sports events.

NASSAU, Bahamas -- This conservative little British resort 180 miles from Miami is about to eliminate "off season" from its vocabulary. The principal reason is that William E. Butlin, Britain's "package holiday" king, has announced that his Fort Montagu Beach Hotel here will never again close at the end of the winter season.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Col. -- It looks like happy vacationing this summer for some four million travelers who will cross the Great Plains to enjoy the superlative weather, majestic terrain and endless scope of activities in the Rocky Mountains.
" LORD JOHNNIE" is like a poor relation of an old and illustrious family -- a family that includes Le Sage and Fielding.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The Office of Vocational Rehabilitation said today that 1,064 deaf men and women and 3,436 who were hard of hearing were trained and placed in jobs through State-Federal Funds in the fiscal year 1948. This was a 10 per cent increase for the deaf and a 42 per cent increase for the hard of hearing over the previous fiscal year.

OTTAWA -- More Americans went to Canada on vacation last year than to any other place outside their own country. They traveled easily, they traveled lightly and most of them were fully satisfied, judging by the minimum of complaints received by the Canadian Government Travel Bureau in Ottawa.

Some remarkable doings at the Bronx Zoo yesterday nullified many popular ideas about the respective virtues of city and country life. From what was seen in in Farm-in-the-Zoo, it appears that city life can provide just as hardy a breed of men and animals as that of the highly touted country life. Perhaps hardier.
A scholarship to enable an American student of theatre to study for two years at London's Old Vic playhouse has been established by the Transatlantic Foundation, it was announced yesterday.
OTTAWA, May 7 (AP) -- The world wheat production picture is discouraging.

TO the current issue of "The Scriptwriter," organ of the Radio Writers Guild, Hester Sondergaard, the actress, has contributed an article in which she strongly argues that some writers are not doing all they might to help radio.

WASHINGTON -- In the varied vacation area beyond the Potomac, where the Atlantic in the east and the Appalachians in the west provide beaches and highlands, this is a year for celebrations, festivals and sports events.

NASSAU, Bahamas -- This conservative little British resort 180 miles from Miami is about to eliminate "off season" from its vocabulary. The principal reason is that William E. Butlin, Britain's "package holiday" king, has announced that his Fort Montagu Beach Hotel here will never again close at the end of the winter season.

LONDON -- Visitors to London this year will find the city at its best since those now almost forgotten days of before the war. Use of paint, the installation of flower boxes outside Government department windows and shops, the replanting with bulbs and annuals of the Thames Embankment gardens, the return to colorful ceremonial of pro-war, have helped to restore much of the old London atmosphere.

THE South Pacific is divided into two parts. To the east lies Polynesia, peopled by a fair Malaysian race occupying the islands of Tahiti, Samoa, Rarotonga and Tonga. No one has yet caught the full wonder of this area, and when I sought to write about the South Pacific I avoided all mention of Polynesia, because what I saw there was far too incredible to be the subject of fiction.

THE islands of the Caribbean, once primarily winter resorts, have become a year-round proposition for vacationists who crave a few weeks of loafing, fun and sun-tan. Late word from the isles of flying fish and waving palms is that there will be no relaxing of tourist hospitality during the summer. Hotels will remain open and all facilities for the amusement and comfort of visitors will be in operation.

DISINFLATION, recession -- pick your own name for it -- has been bringing not only lower prices, which are welcome, but unemployment, which is not. Few would greatly mind a little dip in the business cycle, but the slide downhill might go too fast or too far.

TOKYO, May 7 -- Under a general directive from Washington, the occupation is attempting as rapidly as possible to remove price and other controls from the Japanese economy. More than 400 key items in the price structure are under study and a steady stream of decontrol orders seems to be indicated.

Some months ago we ran a series of columns on the bait-fly-spinning controversy, and the arguments for and against the establishment of certain portions of state-controlled trout streams as "fly fishing only" waters.

Brooklyn College gave New York University's defending Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference champions a bad time at Ohio Field yesterday, not only winning, 8 -- 5, but making it particularly noteworthy because this was the first time since 1942 that the Kingsmen had beaten the Violets on the diamond.

AT the dinner to be tendered Serge Koussevitzky by the League of Composers Tuesday night at the Waldorf-Astoria, music will be heard by composers whom the Koussevitzky Foundation has variously commissioned. Greetings will come from creative musicians of most of the Western nations whose compositions Koussevitzky has signally advanced in his twenty-five years' service as conductor of the Boston Symphony Orchestra.

THE CBS television network will offer two new shows today in the 7-to-8-P. M. time being vacated by Studio One. The dramatic program, under the sponsorship of Westinghouse Electric Company this week switches to Wednesday nights at 10 o'clock.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) -- A Miami newspaper man, Paul Crouch, who says he quit the Communist party after having been active in it for nearly twenty years, has been subpoenaed by the House Un-American Activities Committee for May 24.

Some of the recommendations of the Hoover Commission are taking shape in legislation and are making progress in Congress. The Commission has done its work and done it well. The Congress still has much work to do to carry out the recommendations. There is a third party to the economy clean-up in government that also has its work cut out for it. That party is the public.

PHILADELPHIA, May 7 -- Women's apparel stores here did slightly better last week than a year ago. Pennsylvania Railroad carloadings totaled 122,085 as against 142,286 a year ago, a decrease of 14.2 per cent, and for 1949 to date they totaled 1,874,570 it compare with 2,042,756 last year, a decrease of 8.6 per cent.

Edward Molisani, a vice president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union and manager of the Italian Cloak Makers Union, Local 48, was honored yesterday by the Italian Government for raising more than $1,000,000 last year for relief work in Italy.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 7 -- Welfare agencies in San Francisco this weekend were taking care of most of the unemployed, penniless men who arrived here from Honolulu Wednesday on the Breckenridge, while they awaited reports from Hawaii as to the future policy of territorial officials and the Navy.
WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Opposition by the Administration to any further flat-rate increases in the pay of classified Federal employes and postal workers was made known today.

MERRY BATES' mother wanted her to become a teacher, and Bradmont State Teachers College offered her a scholarship. Merry, with no interest in teaching and with a boy friend at the university, yielded to please her mother, agreeing to try the normal school for one year.

OTTAWA, May 7 -- Campaigning in the Canadian general election, to be held June 27, will begin next week when Prime Minister Louis St. Laurent and George Drew, Progressive Conservative leader, are scheduled to make speaking tours throughout Eastern Canada.

THE City Gardens Club annual Spring Showing of New York City gardens and penthouse terraces will start on Tuesday, from 2:30 to 6 P. M. Among the eight gardens to be visited on that day are the Albert D. Lasker house at Beekman Place, with a terrace overlooking the East River, the apartment of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Delaney with a flower room and the tulip garden of Mrs. Philip Littell.
BOSTON, May 7 -- As New England Legislatures prepared to swing into the home stretch of their current sessions there was mixed reaction this week to some of the things that were being accomplished.

HERE is an important addition to the melancholy literature about the lost peoples of central and eastern Europe. In "Prowling Russia's Forbidden Zone," Werner Knop has produced the first sizable report on the lives and thoughts of the 17,500,000 Germans in the Soviet zone of occupation.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 7 -- All the honors went to Harvard again today as the Crimson swept to victory in varsity, junior varsity and freshman crew races on the Charles for the third successive week in the Adams Cup regatta.

Vic Herschkowitz, Brooklyn mail-carrier, routed Walter Plekan, Buffalo A. C., 21 -- 18, 16 -- 21, 21 -- 12, in the final of the national A. A. U. four-wall handball singles yesterday at the New York Athletic Club.

Cool air from the Northwest ended the season's first heat wave yesterday and temperatures in the city did not exceed the seventies. The high for the day was 79 at 12.35 P. M. This was eight degrees shy of the record for the date, set in 1939. Gusts of wind varied from 15 to 30 miles an hour.
Retail sales expanded seasonally here last week, but dollar volume continued to run below the comparable period of last year. Department store sales were estimated at about 7 per cent below 1948.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Supporters of President Truman's civil-rights proposals took new heart this week at legislative developments that pointed to another and more direct test on the program during this session of Congress.

KINGSTON -- Because the Catskill Mountains are so close to New York they are sometimes overlooked by holidayers in search of greener pastures. Yet to a first-time visitor from afar the Catskills are most impressive, especially the northerly side of the range where narrow valleys cut deep into the mountains and cold, fresh streams tempt the camper, the fisherman and hardy swimmers.

Blue Lancer had little trouble winning the $18,100 Swift Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday. The colt, owned by Daniel Hess, crossed the wire a full length ahead of Curandero of the King Ranch after a tense duel in the closing stages of the seven-furlong dash for 3-year-olds.
PHILADELPHIA, May 7 -- Finishing strong, relief hurler Ken Parker struck out the side in the ninth as Penn downed the Yale nine, 11 -- 7, at River Field today.

With 150 regular and reserve officers of the armed forces and 115 industrialists, educators and other civilians attending, the second annual Economic Mobilization Course for Reserve Officers will be held here tomorrow to May 20, it was announced yesterday.

ITHACA, N. Y., May 7 -- The cornerstone of Statler Hall, the first college building designed expressly for instruction in hotel administration, was laid today at a brief ceremony at noon at Cornell University.

DESPITE disheartening difficulties the Brooklyn Museum's fifteenth international biennial water-color exhibition is a very lively and provocative event. Swiss and Dutch representation had to be abandoned as inadequate:

HARRISBURG, Pa. -- Pennsylvania's tourist industry should reap extra dividends from the state's conservation program this summer with the opening of five new state parks, ranging from three to five thousand acres apiece.

CAMP prices, soaring since the war, are leveling off as more than 10,000 children's camps across the nation prepare for the biggest season since 1941. Enrollment fees charged by top-bracket establishments last season set a record of more than $600, but indications are that this year a youngster can have a summer away from home for as little as $200 on the average.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 4 to 10 points net yesterday. It opened unchanged to 4 points up, and then eased on week-end liquidation and further selling of the May delivery by spot interests.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 7 -- A resolution that would allow members of the United Nations to send Ambassadors and Ministers to Spain was approved today in the Political Committee of the General Assembly by a vote of 25 to 16 with sixteen abstentions.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- President Truman could do a lot of celebrating tomorrow. The day will have a threefold significance, but he will probably spend it quietly with his family. Although it will be Sunday, he will get in a lick of work, too.

PHOENIX, Ariz. -- With the completion of added tourist facilities, the cool plateau country of northern Arizona expects to play host to a record number of vacationists this summer, and a stepped-up program of Western-style entertainment is being readied for the visitors.

LIFE on the Hudson River will be gay again this summer. For a time things looked pretty dark, for the Hudson River Day Line went out of business last winter and announced that its white excursion steamers would no longer run from the foot of Forty-second Street up the river Henry Hudson charted a long time ago.

HARD on the heels of Prof. C. M. Bowra's English publication, "Second Book of Russian Verse," has come this American anthology, "A Treasury of Russian Verse," excellently edited and introduced by Dr. Avrahm Yarmolinsky.

THIS is an excellent short life of Beaumarchais by a French scholar and man of letters now established in a professorship at Leland Stanford University and known already to American readers for his work on modern French literature.

KINGS POINT, L. I., May 7 -- City College strengthened its hold on first place in the metropolitan collegiate baseball conference by defeating the United States Merchant Marine Academy, 4 -- 3, in 10 innings today. It was the eighth league victory for the Beavers against two losses.

BOSTON, May 7 (AP) -- Big Bill Voiselle, Boston Braves' right-hander, gave only two hits today but both of them were in the eighth inning after he had walked two batters, and the Cincinnati Reds whipped the National League champions, 4 -- 2. The loss dropped the Tribe into a tie for first place with the New York Giants, who defeated St. Louis, 9 -1.

When rats are fed on a diet low in potassium, heart fibers are damaged. If there is a deficiency of choline or vitamin B-6, arterial and heart injury also results. There is considerable evidence that nutritional deficiencies may have bad effects on the heart. This raises the question of vitamin E, said to be important in enabling the heart muscle to do its work.

WASHINGTON -- The national parks continue each year to become more popular with the people -- to whom they belong and for whom they are maintained. The national parks operate on a twelve-month calendar ending Oct. 30, and in the park year ended last October the total number of visitors was nearly 30,000,000, a new attendance record. The former high mark was reached in the previous year, when attendance topped 25,000,000.

Healthy criticism of the packaging industry aimed at spurring improvements held to be essential for successful adjustment to greater competition will highlight the eighteenth national Packaging Conference and Exposition opening Tuesday in Atlantic City under sponsorship of the American Management Association, it was learned last week.

BERLIN, May 7 -- The meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers, which opens in Paris two weeks from Monday, ushers in a climactic period in the post-war struggle for Germany, the principal focus of political warfare in Europe between Soviet Union and the democratic West.
DR. MEIKLEJOHN'S article in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine of March 27 on the problem, "Should Communists Be Allowed to Teach?", so obviously avoids the central issue that it perhaps needs no reply.

SANTA CRUZ, Calif., May 7 (UP) -- A seedling of a giant redwood, the world's largest, tallest and oldest living thing, was planted today in honor of Gen. George C. Marshall, who received the first annual "Fellowship of Man" award.

THE joys and calamities involved in building a dream house and the adventures of a sophisticate in a primitive Mexican village are subjects that may have been somewhat overworked of late, yet Elsa Larralde manages to combine the two in a warmly entertaining book.

MOSCOW, May 7 -- Sergei A. Gerassimov, Soviet film producer, just back from New York where he was a delegate to the peace congress at the Waldorf-Astoria, summarized his impressions of America in an account published today. His chief comment was that the unclothed woman, "like a national trademark, has become the symbol of American commerce."

This nation's treatment of criminals was attacked yesterday by some of the country's leading authorities in criminology. They called for a changed philosophy in the criminal laws and for extensive psychiatric help for prison offenders.

LONDON, May 7 (Reuters) -- Cambridge University batsmen J. G. Dewes and G. H. Doggart set an English cricket record today, hitting 429 runs off Essex bowling in an unbroken second-wicket stand. They need only another 27 runs to top the world mark for the second wicket -- 455, scored by Indian batsmen B. Ninbalkar and K. V. Bhandarkar.
BESET by mounting operating costs and a disturbing decline in passenger travel, the railroads are looking hopefully to the vacation season to start an upward trend in revenue again.

Many newspaper readers and radio listeners in this country and the world over may have been surprised by the apparent coolness and skepticism in high quarters over the settlement of the Berlin blockade. The blockade was clamped down by the Russians for the obvious purpose of getting control of Berlin and so driving the Western allies out.

Prominent women, headed by Mrs. Leonard B. Smith, are serving on the committee of sponsors for the American premiere of the French motion picture, "Devil in the Flesh," tonight at the Paris Theatre for the benefit of five French relief societies.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The American merchant marine, with less than half the passenger-carrying capacity it had in 1939, faces serious problems in the general upbuilding of competitive fleets, it was shown in an authoritative survey made public here today.

Strains of "Hail! Hail!" and "Muffin Man," played by a band of forty youngsters from Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church, 457 West Fifty-first Street, routed tenants in the West Fifties yesterday from any disposition to Sunday afternoon drowsiness.

ST. LOUIS, May 8 (AP) -- The Boston Red Sex swept a double-header from the St. Louis Browns today, 10 to 6 and 4 to 3, as the Browns suffered their tenth straight defeat. The first game went 13 innings and the second was called at the end of the eighth on account of darkness.

In a final burst of speed to keep abreast with rapidly moving events, the Parliamentary Council at Bonn has at last completed the draft of a provisional Constitution which establishes a Federal Republic of Germany resting on the self-governing authority of the German people and dedicated to the service of world peace in a united Europe.

DETROIT, May 8 -- Offers by city officials of Detroit and Dearborn to assist in mediating the strike against the Ford Motor Company at the River Rouge and Lincoln plants by the United Automobile Workers, CIO, were firmly rejected today by the automobile manufacturer.

The most complete exhibition of Vincent Van Gogh's work ever held in this country will open in October at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, it was announced yesterday. The Art Institute of Chicago, a co-sponsor of the show with the Metropolitan, will receive the paintings and drawings in midwinter for an exhibition there when the New York show ends.

TEL AVIV, May 8 -- The possibility of closing the gates of Israel to unlimited immigration was indicated today by Dr. Israel Goldstein, treasurer of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, in a report to the Zionist General Council, which is meeting in Jerusalem.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 8 -- Officials of the United Nations spent most of this balmy summer Sunday over their desks drafting night and day work schedules for the final week of the General Assembly's third session, which is scheduled to wind up next Saturday.

WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) -- The Michigan School for the Deaf at Flint has been selected for an intensive program designed to enable illiterate or unschooled deaf men and women to become self-supporting.

Five hundred refugees -- men, women and children who suffered in concentration camps in the Nazi regime -- assembled yesterday afternoon in the Marseilles Hotel for ceremonies in tribute to the sixty-fifth birthday of President Truman and in Celebration of the fourth anniversary of V-E Day.
CHICAGO, May 8 (UP) -- Thousands of auto industry workers idle in stoppages other than the Ford strike were scheduled today to return to their jobs within the next two days.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Congress appears this week to be in the position of a distance runner, who, having turned back the spurts of several challengers, is giving himself a "breather" for the tough racing of the last laps that are nearing.

MOSCOW, May 8 (AP) -- Izvestia, the Soviet Government newspaper, observed the fourth anniversary of the Allied victory over Germany today with an editorial declaring that Russia was "not forgetting the danger of a new war being prepared by American imperialists."

Competition among religious groups for prestige, money and membership -- "just like a lot of athletic clubs" -- was assailed yesterday by the Rev. Dr. W. A. Visser 't Hooft, general secretary of the World Council of Churches.

CHICAGO, May 8 -- American business, labor and Government were warned tonight against a return to an economy of scarcity. The warning came from Sidney R. Rabb, president of the Super Market Institute, who addressed the annual dinner of the institute's twelfth annual convention in the Stevens Hotel.
United States shipping companies are making a strong and successful bid for Indian trade with more than 130 sailings now scheduled yearly, according to the American Merchant Marine Institute.

NEW ORLEANS, May 8 -- The hard-driving directors of the International House, this port's remarkable shipping and trade promotion organization which has received world-wide attention, are embarking on another phase of their program.

Motherhood is woman's "chief role and most glorious career," the Rev. John M. Flemming declared yesterday in a Mother's Day sermon at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral. Father Flemming is assistant secretary to Cardinal Spellman and a member of the cathedral staff.

An agreement yesterday between the Third Avenue Transit Corporation and the Transport Workers Union, CIO, averted a strike of 4,000 bus drivers set for 4 A. M. today. However, a snag apparently developed over one of the terms of the settlement.
Three hundred members of the Knights Templar of the metropolitan district marched yesterday in a colorful procession to their twenty-second annual service in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 8 -- The Diamond Jubilee celebration of the Kentucky Derby provided a spectacular race. The evidence is not in as yet as to whether it also provided a spectacular horse. Ponder won it in the same approximate fashion as his pappy, Pensive, had won it five years previously, charging up from behind in the homestretch.

Storage cabinets, an important phase of kitchen planning, are the subject of two new booklets. One, prepared by the University of Illinois, gives concise information on buying the units so as to have all the space needed. In the other, the United States Department of Agriculture presents diagrams and directions for those ambitious home carpenters who wish to construct the cabinets themselves.

At 2:10 P. M. yesterday two iron men of the wooden airplane Navy-Curtiss 4 began at Floyd Bennett Naval Air Station to retrace the first flight ever made across the Atlantic, on which they set out thirty years and eight minutes before.
Ten new films, including importations from France, Spain and Italy are slated to open in midtown theatres this week. The programs follow:

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Initial claims for unemployment insurance benefits fell off for the week ending April 30, although the total number of claims rose for the third straight week, the Federal Security Agency's Bureau of Employment Security reported today.

BERLIN, May 8 -- British Foreign Secretary Bevin declared today that there was much to be done in Germany before the occupation troops could be withdrawn and that the question of Germany's frontier with Poland was still open.

Acting with breath-taking celerity, Mayor O'Dwyer and the Board of Estimate have rejected the revised Port Authority plan for rehabilitation of the city's waterfront, which would have provided about $90,000,000 for modernization, over an eight-year period, and have again endorsed the $55,000,000 ten-year plan of the Department of Marine and Aviation.
LOUISIANA, Mo., May 8 -- Private industry was told in effect today by Secretary of the Interior J. A. Krug to take over the development of commercial-scale synthetic fuel plants.

NEWTOWN, Pa., May 8 -- Mrs. Emily Abel Balzer, daughter of Mrs. Charles Tutenberg of Hartsdale, N. Y., and Santa Barbara, Calif., and known on the stage as Emily Lawrence, was married here today to Theodore Newton, son of Mrs. C. Bertram Newton of Elizabeth, N. J., and the late Mr. Newton, by Justice of the Peace Andrew H. Dillman in his home.

The appointment of James T. Turbayne as assistant general manager in the United States for the British Travel Association was announced yesterday by Sir Harold Boulton, chief representative of the organization in North America.

CHICAGO, May 8 -- Prices of corn futures on the Board of Trade here held within relatively narrow price limits last week, with trade largely professional in character. Small receipts from the country caused numerous small upturns. However, these were not maintained, although current spot prices and that for May are well below the Government loan level, and reports indicate that the movement into the loan is increasing.

DAYTON, Ohio, May 8 -- Right-wing forces in the United Electrical Workers, CIO, making their most determined bid in ten years to overthrow the leftist leadership of their national union, named a three-man slate today to run for the organization's top offices.

There is reason for much gratification over the fact that a compromise has been worked out between the Dutch and the Indonesian Republican leaders. There is reason to congratulate each of the parties to the discussion. The Republicans have obtained what was of most importance to them, the reconstitution of their Government at Jogjakarta.

JERUSALEM, May 8 -- The Zionist General Council, which is the supreme Zionist body when the Zionist Congress is not in session, is expected to request Rabbi Abba Hillel Silver, former chairman of the American section of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, and Dr. Emanuel Neumann, president of the Zionist Organization of America, to withdraw their resignations from the Agency.

Announcement of four $5,000 fellowships for newspaper workers for foreign study was made yesterday by the Reid Foundation, established by the late Ogden Reid, editor of The New York Herald Tribune. Lithgow Osborne, president of the American-Scandinavian Foundation, announced winners of fifteen fellowships totaling $23,200 awarded to residents of the United States for study in Scandinavian countries.

Elbert Curtis, Mayor of Simsbury, Conn., may be explaining for some time exactly how he happened to miss the first Simsbury Special to leave Grand Central in twenty-five years. Most of his 228 constituents who started for home last evening felt he should never have gone to Brooklyn alone, though they admitted there was no other way he could have seen the Dodgers.

The demand for low price summer dresses rose sharply in the wholesale apparel market here last week, with buying activity centered on daytime cottons, bembergs and linens, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

CHICAGO, May 8 -- Upturns in lard futures on the Board of Trade were not maintained last week. Although 3,000,000 to 4,000,000 pounds were reported to have been sold to England, the quantity taken was disappointing and packers were sellers following the acceptances.

WASHINGTON, May 8 (UP) -The nation's labor force seems to be stabilizing after the hectic postwar round of job changing although factory layoffs are at a ten-year high, the Labor Department reported today.
Eleven years ago today Max Schmeling arrived in New York for his second match with Joe Louis in Yankee Stadium, his eighth trip to the ring in quest of the heavyweight championship.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 8 (AP) -- A brilliant 66 that brought him a 72-hole total of 265 gave Dr. Cary Middlecoff a two-stroke victory over Bobby Locke today in the $10,000 Greenbrier open golf tournament.
NEWPORT, R. I., May 8 -- The Rev. Theodore Lewis of Dublin, Ireland, was formally installed today as Rabbi of the Congregation Jeshuat Israel here in the historic 186-year-old synagogue.
BONN, Germany, iViay 8 (UP)The Constitution for Western Germany was adopted on the fourth anniversary of V-E Day, as nonCommunist assemblymen had determined it should be.

TRENTON, N. J., May 8 -- Ch. Smilestone's Bric-a-Brac, a black miniature poodle owned by Mrs. Peter Frelinghuysen of Morristown, N. J., took chief honors today in the twentieth annual event of the Trenton Kennel Club, traditionally one of the earliest outdoor competitions of the northeastern area.

GENEVA, May 8 -- More than one-third of Europe's total dollar deficit in 1947 and 1948 arose with countries other than the United States, according to data published by United Nations Economic Commission for Europe.
PHILADELPHIA, May 8 (AP) -The Executive Board of the United Lutheran Church in America today drafted plans for widespread evangelical work in countries behind the Iron Curtain.

PITTSBURGH, May 8 -- The steel ingot rate for the country continued its slow downward trend last week, losing one-half point to 97.5 per cent of rated capacity. This decline placed the rate 4 1/2 points below the high mark of 102 per cent reached several weeks ago.
Instead of white sauce, condensed cream of chicken soup is used as a basis for this souffle:
Mother's Day was commemorated throughout the metropolitan area yesterday in appropriately sunny and pleasant weather.
DETROIT, May 8 (AP) -- Kaiser-Frazer Corporation, which built 5,356 vehicles in April, plans to assemble more than 9,000 this month.

If America's national future is to be a prosperous one religion in the home must be restored to the position it held when our nation was founded, the Rev. Albert L. Neibacher, pastor of St. Luke's Evangelical Lutheran Church, 308 West Forty-sixth Street, declared in his sermon yesterday.

VIENNA, May 8 -- If Austria is to stand on her own feet when Marshall Plan aid ceases in 1952 she must increase her productive capacity 40 per cent over the present level and her exports by 130 per cent, according to the Austrian Institute for Economic Research.

PRAGUE, May 8 -- In recent years the Czechs have learned about such matters as Socialist science, Socialist art and Socialist competition. Today Czech youth was introduced to a new aspect of the Socialist world -- Socialist races.

Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation will open a heavy spring campaign this week on its portable radio line, it was announced over the week-end by Charles Robbins, vice president in charge of sales. Introduction of a new low-priced three-way portable will be featured.

WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) -The Census Bureau will test its plans this month for the 1950 census. Several spots across the country will be the scenes of tests for questions and procedures to be used next year in the check on population and agriculture.
PHILADELPHIA, May 8 (AP) -Bill Nicholson drove in five runs with a single and his fourth home run of the season today as the Phillies won the second game of a double-header with the Reds, 8 to 1.

On the United Nations site at First Avenue and Forty-seventh Street, where construction of a building for the delegation offices and specialized agencies of the United Nations is contemplated, five men can be found who are pessimistic about the future of the world organization.

Following the lead of the international General Electric Company, several other large companies are planning soon to start advertising campaigns abroad in cooperation with the Advertising Council's program for "selling" the American way of life to the people of other countries, it was learned over the week-end.

HONOLULU, May 8 -- Hawaii, its postwar economy kept off balance by military readjustments in the Pacific and by a succession of crippling strikes, was beginning today to feel serious effects from the latest severing of the territory's vital sea trade lifeline.

The 150th anniversary of the consecration of the edifice of St. Mark's Church in-the-Bouwerie, Tenth Street and Second Avenue, was celebrated yesterday afternoon. The exact date of the consecration was May 9, 1799. The anniversary sermon was preached by Bishop Charles K. Gilbert of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York.

It is reassuring to know that the latest in the long series of strike threats by Michael J. Quill's Transport Workers Union has been headed off, at least temporarily, through the efforts of the City Division of Labor Relations. The buses and trolleys will continue to run on the routes of the Third Avenue Transit Corporation and 1,800,000 New Yorkers will not have to scramble this morning for new modes of transportation.

GENEVA, May 8 -- King Leopold of the Belgians expressed the wish tonight that the next National Parliament would soon solve the "royal question," enabling him to return to Brussels and regularizing the country's "constitutional position."

Mayor O'Dwyer has steadily demonstrated a capacity for self-reversal that has almost always gotten him out of tight spots. Unfortunately for the cause of education, his recent prestidigitation in the Queens College presidency matter has been snagged by the politician-friend he appointed to the Board of Higher Education in 1947.
WASHINGTON, May 8 (UP) -Senator J. Howard McGrath of Rhode Island, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said today that "a Dixiecrat has no future in the Democratic party."

" Concerto for Fun," a one-man show opening tonight at the Mansfield, will introduce Henry L. Scott to Broadway. A skilled pianist-satirist, Mr. Scott reports that it took him ten years to test material for this event. How did he do that?

BONN, Germany, May 8 -- With all sixty-five delegates present and hundreds of spectators jamming every available corner of the chamber, the Parliamentary Council adopted tonight the draft of a new Western German Constitution that had taken more than eight months in creation.

LONDON, May 8 -- The behavior of the stock markets here last week would seem to indicate some return of confidence in the business position and outlook. However, their behavior can be deceptive at times, and this may be one of those times.

ABOARD THE CARRIER FRANKLIN D. ROOSEVELT, May 8 (UP) -- Admiral W. H. P. Blandy, Atlantic Fleet commander, today urged trading of officers among the armed forces as a means of promoting unification and more intelligent war planning.

Dr. William Haber, former adviser on Jewish affairs to Gen. Lucius D. Clay, emphasized yesterday the "crucial importance" of supporting democratic elements in Germany "if we are to avoid the revival of a Germany bent once more on world aggression."
Of the 500 known Stradivari violins remaining in the world today, about 300 have "passed through the hands" of Simone F. Sacconi for repairs, the master violin-maker estimates.

WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) -After five perilous hours on a jagged rock in turbulent waters of the Potomac River, two Georgetown University students were rescued last night by means of an improvised breeches buoy.

CHICAGO, May 8 (AP) -- At least seventy cities in twenty-six states have industrial foundations to give manufacturing enterprises financial aid, the American Society of Planning Officials reported today. The idea is to bring new payrolls into the community and bolster those already established.

The Big Show--Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus--finished last night its annual spring run in Madison Square Garden and headed for Boston. Left behind was Roland Butler, the man of adjectives, to supply the vital statistics.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., May 8 -The seriousness of the challenge to the Hague dynasty contained in the opposition to the organization ticket in Tuesday's mayoralty election, was confirmed today by former Mayor Frank Hague himself.
In the absence of untoward developments the blockade and counter-blockade in Berlin will be officially terminated at the end of this week.
BONN, Germany, May 8 -- The text of Western Germany's draft Constitution as translated officially by the Military Government:

AMSTERDAM, May 8 -- The Dutch Reconstruction Bank in its annual report issued last week said it was not over-optimistic regarding industrialization of the Netherlands because of a lack of risk-bearing capital protection of several "hothouse" industries under foreign exchange control and too great stress on consumer goods in which industrial development was highly unbalanced.
LONDON, May 8 -- More socialism in Britain's nationalized health service was demanded today by the annual conference of the Socialist Medical Association, a small organization of Socialist doctors.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Representative Wright Patman, Democrat, of Texas, today accused the McGraw-Hill Publishing Company of aiding the U. S. S. R. by "passing on pure propaganda about Russian accomplishments" in a paid national advertisement.
CANTON, China, May 8 (AP) -Acting President Li's arrival in this provisional capital apparently answers the two-week-old question of who is going to run Nationalist China.

Two studies of Italian history, culture, politics and life will be published this week. Dutton is issuing today "Italy and Italians," by Count Carlo Sforza, Foreign Minister of Italy and author of "Contemporary Italy." Oxford University Press will issue on Thursday "The Genius of Italy," a series of seventeen essays by Leonardo Olschki.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- William L. Clayton, former Under-Secretary of State, urged today that the United States join the International Trade Organization because world peace and prosperity depend on world trade.

MOSCOW, May 8 -- A new Soviet play, "The House on the Lane," whose premiere was held in the Lenin Komsomol Theatre last night, attracted a number of Moscow's diplomats. The production aroused unusual attention because of the announcement that it had been based in part on revelations of Annabelle Bucar's book, "The Truth About American Diplomats," which is a current best seller.

CHICAGO, May 8 -- Resolutions calling for an end to discrimination against Negroes and opposing pending legislation for Federal aid to education were adopted today by the national congress of the National Federation of Catholic College Students.

PARIS, May 8 -- A two-week motor trip through the West of France was revealed, more vividly than statistics could do, both the fact and the feeling of recovery in a country cruelly scarred by war, and fearing nothing so much as another invasion.

BOSTON, May 8 (AP) -- The Pirates knocked the Braves into third place today by twice defeating the National League champions, 8-3 and 11-8, before a disappointed throng of 27,211. The double victory boosted Pittsburgh from the league cellar to sixth place.

CLEVELAND, May 8 (AP) -- Washington's high-stepping Senators ran their winning streak to seven straight today in handing the world champion Indians a double loss, 7 -- 3 and 2 -- 0, before 49,734 fans.
Discussion of the North Atlantic Pact since its text was made public has given little attention to one practical and important point, its relation to our future security against atomic attack.

Soviet radio jamming stations apparently improved the effectiveness of their technique yesterday in preventing the programs of the Voice of America and the British Broadcasting Corporation from reaching the Russian people, according to officials of the State Department.

Louis J. Lefkowitz, chairman of the law committee of the New York County Republican Committee, announced yesterday that he would apply today to Supreme Court Justice Ernest E. L. Hammer for an order requiring Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. to show cause why his name should not be removed from the registry of voters in the seventh election district of the Fifth Assembly District.

Although inventories are receding to more normal levels, consumer resistance to high prices continues to hold the lid down on sales, according to a survey of members of the New York Credit Men's Association, the Chicago Association of Credit Men and the Los Angeles Credit Managers' Association.

OMAHA, Neb., May 8 -- Fifty-one weeks after his death in Berlin a dream of Msgr. Edward J. Flanagan came true today. Dedication exercises marked the completion of a $10,000,000 building program at Boys Town, the all-modern "city of little men."

CHICAGO, May 8 -- While prices have continued their downward trend, there are no severe breaks, except for some "obviously overpriced items," a report of the business survey committee of the Purchasing Agents Association of Chicago revealed today.

Christianity offers a valuable and too often neglected source for enriching home life and combating paganism here and abroad, the Rev. Dr. John Harold McCombe, associate minister of Christ Church, Methodist, at Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street, declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls during the period April 30 to May 6 are given in the appended tabulation:

A Green Cross campaign for $750,000 to promote safety in everyday life was announced yesterday by William A. Irvin, chairman of the National Safety Council. New York's quota is $250,000. Advance subscriptions of $169,235 have been received.

One of the deep-rooted instincts of man is to throw nothing away. Lest this be disputed by a reminder that the Department of Sanitation has large trucks which do nothing but carry off objects which have been thrown away, the original statement bears repetition.

TOKYO, May 8--Occupation offices estimate that at least 40 per cent of the present United States civilian officials in Japan will be replaced before the end of the year by Army officers, principally those relieved of European duties.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 8 -- To a foreign visitor, opinion seems to be unanimous in Amman, Damascus and Beirut that the Arab nations have a moral obligation to fight again in Palestine as soon as they are able to. Government officials, businessmen, small shopkeepers, foreign workers, diplomatic and consular officials, journalists, taxi drivers and waiters all agree to an extent that seems to make discussion of the details of the Palestine situation almost pointless.

WASHINGTON, May 8 (UP) -Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat, of Nevada, chairman of the Judiciary Committee, said today that the Navy needed a corps of lawyers who could qualify at a bar "outside of an officers' club."
Mordecai Peter (Three Finger) Brown and Charles A. (Kid) Nichols, two great pitchers of the past, joined fifty-six other baseball immortals yesterday in the game's Hall of Fame at Cooperstown, N. Y.

The fifth annual George Gershwin Memorial Concert, sponsored by the B'nai B'rith Victory Lodge, was given Saturday night at Carnegie Hall. Proceeds of the event will go to the Gershwin Memorial Fund, which organization's $1,000 prize-winning composition for this year, Ned Rorem's "Overture in C," received its world premiere in the course of the evening.

The comments in the column Topics of The Times of May 2 relative to the improper use of DDT and other of the new and powerful organic insecticides were of great interest to the many private and government shade tree and mosquito-control people who have been troubled by the avalanche of conflicting claims and recommendations dealing with the post-war spraying materials.

Prices of cotton in the domestic market last week were features by renewed firmness in spots and nearby deliveries. The more distant months showed relatively little change. At the week's end active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were 44 points higher to off 25 points lower on the week, compared with advances of 4 to 47 points at the end of the previous week.

While the 20 per cent excise tax on luggage was cited as having a harmful effect on consumer demand for luggage, an active travel season ahead is expected to reduce retail inventories before new lines are shown during the latter part of the summer, it was reported over the week-end.

Twenty-five thousand persons gathered yesterday on the Bronx campus of Fordham University in the second annual combined observance of World Sodality Day under auspices of the New York Roman Catholic Archdiocesan union of sodalities of the Blessed Virgin Mary.

Every stitch can be nylon for the girl of 1949 whose grandmother was pure silk from head to toe. Item by item of a woman's wardrobe has been tried out in nylon recently. The synthetic yarn, made of water, coal and air, has been knitted or woven into a variety of fabric types to suit different kinds of clothing.

Harry J. Wines has been appointed sales manager of the automatic heating division in the air-conditioning department of General Electric Company. Bloomfield, N. J. He was formerly vice president in the sales division of the Zenith Radio Corporation.

Concerned over recurrent strike threats on the city's privately owned bus and trolley lines, Mayor O'Dwyer is planning to recommend appointment of a permanent impartial chairman to supervise labor relations on the private transit facilities, it became known last night.

When the war was over many of the men and women who had been serving as volunteers left our hospitals and welfare agencies. To them the emergency was over. But the war is not over for our blind and disabled veterans, nor for one of our most valuable volunteer groups, the Manhattan Motor Transport Unit of the American Women's Voluntary Services.

PHILADELPHIA, May 8 (AP) -Striking Philco Corporation workers voted tonight to end their week-old walkout and go back to work at 7 A. M. tomorrow at twenty-one plants and warehouses in the Philadelphia area.

The Belfast Celtics, the first of four European soccer contingents scheduled to appear here this season, made their American debut yesterday and ran into quite a surprise as they were held to a 2-all tie before 15,000 spectators at Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island.

The Air Force Reserve Training Center at Mitchel Field, L. I., will be discontinued soon and its personnel will be moved to the Navy's Floyd Bennett Field in Brooklyn for continued reserve activity, it was learned yesterday.

CAPETOWN, May 8 -- In daily conferences last week, South Africa's case for the sale of processed or semi-processed gold at premium prices was put before Camille Gutt, managing director of the International Monetary Fund, who was preparing today to return to the United States.

The Acoustical Society of America got around to our ears the other day -specifically to the erosive effect of noise. What with subway trains that make conversation impossible, raucous horn-blowing, motor-trucks that roar through the streets, airplane propellers that assault the ear, pneumatic riveters that are tireless in performing their noisy function, it is about time that science took notice of noise.

Alexander Stevens, who had been described before the House Committee on Un-American Activities as a master of international Communist intrigue, flew out of this country yesterday, leaving behind him two new mysteries.

Paramount Pictures, Inc., in the fiscal year ended on Jan. 1, last, had earnings of $24,357,102 after taxes and all charges, compared with $31,440,477 earned in the preceding fiscal year, Barney Balaban, president, reported in the annual statement to be released today.

Thor Johnson, 36-year-old conductor of the Cincinnati Symphony, has been chosen for the $1,000 Alice M. Ditson Award that Columbia University has conferred annually since 1945 on an American conductor who has rendered distinguished services in the field of American music.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 8 -F. Hugh Herbert's million-dollar suit, filed in December against Columbia for alleged interference with his sale of screen sequel rights to his play, "Kiss and Tell," which Columbia filmed in 1945, has been settled out of court, the author has disclosed, and he has concluded arrangements with Nasser Brothers to produce a sequel under the title, "A Kiss for Corliss," this summer at the general service studios.

SHANGHAI, May 8 -- Kashing, rail town sixty-five miles southwest of this city, which had been the focus of a three-pronged Communist attack for several days, fell yesterday, according to local press reports and Communist claims.

BUENOS AIRES, May 8 -- The dropping of Dr. Juan Bramuglia as Foreign Minister at the behest of Senora Eva Peron and a group of nationalist ministers was urged upon President Peron so strongly late last month that, according to one informed source, the change was imminent.

Present-day parents have relinquished too many of their duties to other organizations, Msgr. George Murdock, Roman Catholic chaplain at West Point, declared yesterday at the eighteenth annual communion breakfast of the Holy Name Society of the Department of Sanitation, held in the Astor Hotel.
Edwin J. Becker, a prolific young writer, earned $20,000 selling short stories and novels while in Bordentown Prison, N. J., for writing bad checks.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- President Truman began the observance of his sixty-fifth birthday today by going to church. Afterward he told his pastor he owed his good health to the hard work that had always kept him out of mischief.

PARIS, May 9 -- In a collection of spectacular simplicity, Balmain designs one-sided jackets for autumn. One side of the front of a black wool bolero is a long scarf passing under the belt of a black wool frock. Flaps of pockets, one on the bolero side and one on the scarf end, are of black faille.

ZURICH, Switzerland, May 8 -Negotiations scheduled to begin in Washington on Tuesday between representatives of the United States, Britain and France on one side and Switzerland on the other will aim at breaking the deadlock that until now has obstructed execution of the Washington agreement of May 25, 1946, concerning liquidation of German assets in Switzerland.

Thomas Dato, 9 years old, of 123 Waverly Avenue, Brooklyn, drowned yesterday in Prospect Park Lake, Brooklyn, while trying to swim ashore from a rowboat that went adrift with four children aboard at.7:15 P. M. Annie Dunn, 14, of 437 Myrtle Avenue, Brooklyn, was taken to the Kings County Hospital suffering from exposure after swimming twenty feet to the lake's edge.

Unlike the Redbirds of a few years ago, who won ball games with fancy flying along the base-paths, the current crop of Cardinals virtually ran themselves out of their contest with the Dodgers at Ebbets Field yesterday.

HEWLETT, L. I., May 8 -- Jim Oleska and John Mikrut solved the difficulties of the Seawane Harbor Club links for the second year in succession today to win the thirty-six-hole final of the William D. Richardson Memorial tourney. They turned back John Humm, Long Island amateur golf champion, and Ed Neu of Rockville by 7 and 6.

Well pleased with their three-day sightseeing and educational visit to New York, 200 members of a Congressional touring party inspected the United States Military Academy at West Point yesterday before returning to Washington last night.

First steel deliveries have arrived at Ashtabula, Ohio, for construction of a $10,000,000 new metallic sodium plant, expected to produce 36,000,000 pounds a year for gasoline, steel and chemical plant consumers, J. K. Moffett, vice president, and Paul J. LeMarche, engineer of the National Distillers Chemical Corporation, 120 Broadway, disclosed here over the weekend. Sodium metal and chlorine will be the first products of the chemical company's plants, they said.

Besides being comfortable for lounging, most of the new outdoor furniture this year caters to the lazy by being either practically waterproof so it does not have to be moved to shelter during storms or extremely light weight so it can be moved in a jiffy.

MOSCOW, May 8 (UP) -- David Zaslavsky, Soviet journalist and political analyst, today accused American newspapermen, especially foreign correspondents, of being trained intelligence agents, spies, diversionists and devoted servants of capitalism.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., May 8 -The second and final of the tune-up regattas of the Larchmont Yacht Club today became a dress rehearsal in earnest for the summer's long competition.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., May 8 -- The Rev. Dr. Robert E. Terwilliger of the faculty of the General Theological Seminary and assistant rector at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, New York, has been elected rector of Christ Episcopal Church in this city, the congregation was informed today.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, May 8 -- The Israeli Government has submitted the draft of a preamble to a peace treaty to the United Nations Palestine Conciliation Commission for transmission to the Arab states, it was learned here tonight.

A community service was conducted yesterday afternoon at Holy Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church (in the parish of St. James), 316 East Eighty-eight Street, which was attended by 500 members of all faiths. The service was the opening of a month-long commemoration of the fiftieth anniversary of the consecration of the church.

A series of changes in Federal law to enable larger numbers of displaced persons from Europe to settle in the United States is recommended in a report made public yesterday by the New York State Commission on Displaced Persons. State Industrial Commissioner Edward Corsi is chairman of the commission.

Foreign exchange traders' attention last week veered sharply to the spectacular rise in the Canadian free dollar which climbed to 95.38 cents, highest since Feb. 24, 1947, thus displacing the pound sterling as the focal point of interest. Friday's close on Canadian was 95.32 cents, a gain of 1-1/16 cents over the preceding week.

Theodore Granik, whose "American Forum of the Air" made its radio debut more than twenty years ago, has come up with a new half hour show, "American Television Forum," which will have its premiere over NBC-TV at 3 P. M. on Sunday, May 22.
Perhaps this sort of thing can't go on much longer, but for the moment no one is checking those astonishing Giants.

ALBANY, May 8 -- Two all-day hearings will be held later this month on the location of two projected medical education centers to be established by the State University of New York, it was announced today.

DETROIT, May 8 -- Before a banner crowd of 52,891 today the Yankees put on their most explosive outburst of the campaign, raking three of Red Robert Rolfe's pitchers for 17 blows. They chased Virgil Trucks to the showers with his first defeat of the season after four straight victories.

Rainbow Shops, a chain selling women's specialties, leased the entire property measuring 45 by 150 feet at the southwest corner of Kings Highway and East Sixteenth Street, adjoining the BMT Brighton Beach station, in Brooklyn, from the Remsenburg Realty Corporation.
As spring advances the metropolitan art season shows no signs of weakening, either in the quality or the variety of exhibitions being held.

CHICAGO, May 8 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Athletics rallied for three runs in the eighth inning today to win the second game of a double-header, 3 -- 2, from the Chicago White Sox after losing the opener, 11 -- 3, before 23,158 fans.

Plans for altering the five-story dwelling at 107 East Seventy-third Street, near Park Avenue, into an apartment building with a professional office have been announced in connection with the sale of the property by Mrs. Dorothy Q. Pardee Clark to Dr. Benjamin Silbershire.

LONDON, May 8 -- Countess Clare Cowley, widow of the third Earl of Cowley, died early today in a fire at her home, Seagry House, near Chippenham in Wiltshire. Lady Cowley, who was 70 years old, was the stepmother of the present Earl of Cowley who lives at Wellesley Ranch in Carson City, Nev.

Theodore Granik, whose "American Forum of the Air" made its radio debut more than twenty years ago, has come up with a new half hour show, "American Television Forum," which will have its premiere over NBC-TV at 3 P. M. on Sunday, May 22.
Perhaps this sort of thing can't go on much longer, but for the moment no one is checking those astonishing Giants.

ALBANY, May 8 -- Two all-day hearings will be held later this month on the location of two projected medical education centers to be established by the State University of New York, it was announced today.

DETROIT, May 8 -- Before a banner crowd of 52,891 today the Yankees put on their most explosive outburst of the campaign, raking three of Red Robert Rolfe's pitchers for 17 blows. They chased Virgil Trucks to the showers with his first defeat of the season after four straight victories.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Federal grants-in-aid to the states have expanded to proportions that threaten local self-government with extinction, Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey told a joint Senate and House group today. He urged that Congress adopt no more such programs until this system of financing services to the people is studied and investigated.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 9 -- The liquor industry was cautioned today to be "mindful of statutory and regulatory provisions and be guided accordingly" as merchandising became "more and more competitive" with early availability of greatly increased supplies of "aged whisky, as well as Scotch and other liquors."

CHICAGO, May 10 -- The "consistent and widespread use" of newspaper advertising by retail grocery organizations was described here today as "a strong testimonial to the power of newspaper advertising to stimulate sales" by Allen B. Sikes, service manager of the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 9 -- A state-supported out-patient clinic for alcoholics was opened here today when the Connecticut Commission on Alcoholism transferred its headquarters and established the clinic at 412 Orange Street.

Pretty girls and pretty dresses made a pleasing showing yesterday at the St. Regis, at the summer opening of the Viennese roof. The atmosphere was bright, the pink tablecloths flattering, the luncheon guests' spring hats gay with flowers.
A pair of young European-born musicians gave a joint debut recital at Times Hall last night, and a very acceptable event they made of it.

Persons who have trouble sleeping will find their problems -- and possible solutions -- more clearly defined in the newly remodeled Sleep Shop that Lewis Conger opened yesterday. Numerous gadgets, aids and pieces of equipment designed to overcome different difficulties are assembled under signs that not only describe a particular problem but also suggest remedies.

DETROIT, May 9 -- Negotiations between the Ford Motor Company and the striking United Automobile Workers, CIO, will be resumed tomorrow at 2 P. M. at the request of Walter P. Reuther, union president.

Consumers of lead in recent months have bought more than they needed, bidding up the price "beyond all sense," Clinton H. Crane, chairman of the board of the St. Joseph Lead Company, declared at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday.

The Board of Education's plans for reorganizing the Youthbuilders program were sharply criticized last evening by Newbold Morris, chairman of the board of directors of Youthbuilders, Inc., 120 East Sixteenth Street.

While New York sleeps, the quietest place in town is in the home of a happy Bronx family of 2,000. Love-sick couples stroll demurely by the pond. Old-timers lie about comfortably. Sleepy-eyed youngsters cuddle near contented mamas.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., May 9 -- Frank Hague, a symbol of political bossism for many Americans, is facing in tomorrow's City Commission elections the most serious threat in thirty-two years to his continued domination of Jersey City and the Democratic party in the state of New Jersey.

BALTIMORE, 9 (AP) -- Palestinian and Old Rockport, a couple of speedsters who missed the jackpot in the Kentucky Derby, arrived here today for Pimlico's Preakness -- second stop on the goldand-glory trail for three-year-olds.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 9 -- The Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee of the United Nations General Assembly approved today a "compromise" formula for a proposed news-gathering convention that calls on correspondents to uphold a high code of journalistic ethics but does not attempt to enforce this code as law.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Wartime correspondence between Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and the Russian High Command was made public by the State Department today to prove that his order halting the Western Allies' advance into Czechoslovakia at the Pilsen line had been issued at the urgent request of Soviet military authorities.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -- Six authorities on women's dress today got the assignment to give a "new look" to uniforms for women in the Army and Air Force. They will consider styling as well as materials to be used in uniforms.

Dr. Alvin S. Johnson, president emeritus of the New School for Social Research, said yesterday that opening of the projected Shipherd College depended on the raising of $250,000, the amount needed to renovate and equip six buildings at Madison Barracks, an abandoned Army post near Sackets Harbor, N. Y.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- When Senator Arthur V. Watkins of Utah walked out of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee this morning saying he had been insulted by Chairman Tom Connally he added one more incident to Senator Connally's picturesque career as a senior presiding officer.

Service improved yesterday on the Kingsbridge division of the Third Avenue Transit Corporation after settlement of a dispute that threatened to tie up all the company's seventy-six bus and trolley routes in the Bronx, Manhattan and Westchester.

Walter Schnyder of La Salle iilitary _cademy scored a 6-3, 6-4 victory over Alan Willner of Loughlin to lead the way into the quarter-final round of the Athletic Association of Private Schools tennis tournament, which started at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills yesterday.

The Maritime Commission hearing on a complaint filed against two North Atlantic steamship conferences by the Isbrandtsen Company, Inc., got under way yesterday amid indications that the dispute might eventually reach the United States Supreme Court for settlement.

TEHERAN, Iran, May 9 -- Iran's Constituent Assembly held a final meeting today after having changed the Constitution to give the Shah the power to dissolve Parliament when he deemed it necessary. This enables him to break the deadlocks in Parliament that have blocked legislation repeatedly, but the new provisions also contain a safeguard against any abuse of power.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (UP) -- The House today passed, 222 to 51, a bill calling for a census of housing next year as part of the regular population count which comes every ten years. The regular census is expected to cost $70,000,000. The bill sent to the Senate today would add $15,000,000 to find out what kind of living quarters Americans have.

FRANKFORT, Germany, May 9 (UP) -- A series of official changes was made today in the text issued yesterday [and published in THE NEW YORK TIMES Monday] of the Constitution for Western Germany approved by the Bonn Parliamentary Assembly.

TRENTON, May 9 -- The medallion of the New Jersey Agricultural Society was presented tonight to Harry B. Weiss of Highland Park, State Director of Plant Industry, for his achievements in farm research, insect pest control and betterment of rural living. Mr. Weiss is credited with discovering the invasion of the Japanese beetle in this country and with organizing effective control methods.
Tammany Hall announced yesterday that it would not press its objections to the petitions nominating Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. for Congress on the independent Four Freedoms party ticket.

The one-story taxpayer on a plot 100 by 100 feet at 231-11 to 231-19 Merrick Road in Laurelton, Queens, has been sold by Laurelton Stores, Inc., to the Dorob Realty Corporation. The property is assessed at $55,000 and was sold subject to a mortgage of $53,958.

It's SRO every night over at the Majestic Theatre, where the musical, "South Pacific," is packing them in, but a self-admitted ticket speculator turned up yesterday in Municipal Term Court with eighteen choice locations in the orchestra.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 9 -- Racial relations in the Union of South Africa have deteriorated to such an extent that "a serious conflagration is to be feared," M. C. Setalvad, chairman of India's delegation to the United Nations, told the Political Committee of the General Assembly this morning.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that five companies had filed registration statements covering $3,679,464 of debentures, $2,750,000 of bonds and 415,000 shares of preferred and 178,137 shares of common stock.
Two large projects to provide housing for a total of 267 families were among plans filed yesterday with the Queens office of the Department of Housing and Buildings.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Senate hearings on measures to establish a uniform code of military justice closed today with the assurance that full committee consideration would be given to the proposal to strip commanding officers of the right to name members of courts-martial.

A bitter fight for the presidency of the Board of Education is expected today when the nine members hold their annual election meeting in the school headquarters building at 110 Livingston Street, Brooklyn.

PARIS, May 9 (AP) -- Trading on the Paris Bourse (stock exchange) was halted today by a strike of 7,000 Bourse workers belonging to both non-communist and communist unions. Seeking a 22-per-cent wage increase, they struck for an indefinite period.

MOBILE, Ala., May 9 -- Ready for her new service between New York and Mediterranean ports, the refurbished liner La Guardia sailed early this afternoon from the yard of the Alabama Dry Dock and Shipbuilding Company.

Tomlinson's new "American Informal" furniture, which Hathaway's, 51 West Forty-fifth Street, is showing in three newly decorated rooms, should appeal to those who want pieces planned for today's rooms but coupled with some of the mellowness of traditional styles.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -- The Supreme Court in effect invited today a test of the power of Federal courts to review the cases of American civilians convicted by United States military courts abroad.

CLEVELAND, May 9 -- Through the combined use of new lights brilliant enough to penetrate 1,000 feet of fog and radio and radar landing aids, Cleveland Municipal Airport is expected to make the closest possible approach to all-weather flight operations.
