LAKE SUCCESS, May 9 -- Australia and India proposed today that, in light of the agreement reached in Batavia, Java, on Saturday between the Netherlands and the Republic of Indonesia, the United Nations General Assembly should defer discussion of the Indonesian question until the September session.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (UP) -- Harry Sacher, one of the defense attorneys in the New York trial of eleven Communist party officials, was dropped today from his $6,000-a-year post as general counsel of the United Shoe Workers, CIO.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday and final prices were 8 to 12 points net higher than on Saturday.

Industrial concerns expect to reduce their employment of engineers 26 per cent this year, while Government agencies count on an 8 per cent cutback in their engineering employment, the General Survey Committee of Engineers Joint Council reported yesterday. This would mean a general drop of 23 per cent in the employment of engineering graduates, the council said.

Yesterday at Ebbets Field the Cardinals and Dodgers gave another one of those imitations of the annual game between the New York and Brooklyn baseball writers and, before the affair had ended in a 14-5 victory for the Redbirds, most of the 13,042 cash customers were calling the Brooks bums and not kidding.

Harvard, the lone undefeated varsity eight-oared crew in the East, has been seeded first for the trial heats in the championship sprint regatta of the Eastern Association of Rowing Colleges, to be held Saturday over a 2,000-meter course on Lake Onondaga at Syracuse. The Crimson junior varsity and freshman crews, also unbeaten, likewise were rated No. 1.

CHICAGO, May 9 -- Stuart S. Ball was elected president of Montgomery Ward Co., at a meeting of the company's executive committee today. Art attorney, Mr. Ball has been secretary of the company since 1934 and was given the additional title of vice president three weeks ago.

Dorothy Cox, designer, has been making for years the smart casual clothes that bear the McMullen label. At a still-life fashion show yesterday in Lord Taylor's Sport Shop, Miss Cox talked with the customers who came to see the country evening clothes made of stripes and plaids, and the modish town ensembles of linen and cotton.

TULSA, Okla., May 9 (AP) -- Scientific developments for making liquid fuels from natural gas and deriving gas from coal are mastering the day when "interfuel competition" will cease, the American Institute of Chemical Engineers was told today.
A bill to curb new "rackets" in door-to-door selling will be introduced today in the City Council by Ira J. Palestin, Liberal, of the Bronx, it was learned yesterday.

Lower Level Democracy While the elections last fall received a good deal of publicity, they must not be regarded as the ultimate expression of a working democracy. In fact, they were only the expression of democracy along higher levels, and while important they were a little remote.

MOSCOW, May 9 -- Marshal Vassily D. Sokolovsky, Deputy Defense Minister and Soviet Commander in Germany until recently, placed the blame today for the failure of the Allies to discuss a German peace treaty upon the United States and Britain, and declared that the present international atmosphere was characterized by an "artificial tenseness" created by the machinations of the Western powers.

MADISON, Wis., May 9 (UP) -- John K. Gill, 44 years old, a bank president's son, who walked away from his desk when auditors began a routine check March 21, surrendered to the Federal Bureau of Investigation today on charges of making false entries totaling $175,000.

Robert Walker will return to films shortly in a co-starring role with Deborah Kerr and Peter Lawford in Metro - Goldwyn - Mayer's "Please Believe Me," in which he will portray a young, Texas attorney. The script by Nathaniel Curtis is described as dealing with an English girl who believes she has "inherited a fabulous land empire from an American G.I. she met during the war."

BERLIN, May 9 (AP) -- This is the text of an order issued tonight by Gen. Vassily I. Chuikov, Soviet commander in Germany, on the lifting of the Berlin blockade at 12:01 A. M., Thursday (6:01 P. M., Wednesday, Eastern daylight time):
Robert Anderson, director of the prize-winning Canadian film, "Drug Addict," has arrived in New York, "amazed to learn," he said yesterday, that his film had become a cinema cause celebre.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -- The National Grange today protested to Congress that proposed increases in postal rates were "unrealistic" and would injure both rural mail users and newspapers.

BUENOS AIRES, May 9 -- The Peronista party, which can still be depended upon to win any election but which slipped last month in two provincial contests, suffered a loss yesterday that gave to this trend a certain amount of significance.

The "immeasurable amount of work and help" rendered by volunteers at the Hospital for Special Surgery, 321 East Forty-second Street, was lauded yesterday at award presentation ceremonies at the hospital.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The Council of Economic Advisers, it was learned tonight, suggested to President Truman last month that he might consider scaling down his request for a $4,000,000,000 tax increase, but not at the expense of a budget deficit.
As a focal point for community mobilization in the rehabilitation of alcoholics, New York urgently needs to establish "ambulatory" alcoholic clinics, Dr. Giorgio Lolli declared last night.

Fred Boysen, the baseball fan who charged that Leo Durocher, manager of the New York Giants, kicked him after a Giant-Dodger game at the Polo Grounds on April 28, fell into the toils of the law himself yesterday after withdrawing his charge and apologizing to Mr. Durocher in Upper Manhattan Court.
BERLIN, May 9 -- Gen. Vassily Ivanovich Chuikov, Soviet Military Governor and Commander in Chief in Germany, tonight issued orders for lifting the blockade of Berlin.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 9 -- Some members of the United States and British delegations are seeking to persuade Denmark and Norway to abstain from voting when a Latin American resolution to allow Ambassadors and Ministers to return to Madrid comes before the United Nations General Assembly, it was learned today.

Alexander Stevens, alias J. Peters, Communist underground leader who "deported himself" Sunday, said in a message made public yesterday that he left the United States voluntarily to eliminate "confusion and hysteria." Mr. Stevens, who left by plane for Budapest, was under a deportation order as an alien Communist.

RYE, N. Y., May 9 -- Serving notice that she intends to resume her last year's sway over Westchester women's golf, diminutive Mrs. John H. Bartol of the Greenwich Country Club won top honors in the opening one-day tournament of the Westchester and Fairfield Women's Golf Association today.

With Fay Bainter as its star, "Gayden," a new play by the husband and wife team of Mignon and Robert McLaughlin, will bow in at the Plymouth Theatre tonight under the auspices of Gant Gaither. The curtain is scheduled to go up at 8:20 o'clock.

WINNIPEG, May 9 (Canadian Press) -- The action of the United States in declaring flax a surplus commodity, thereby closing that market to Canadian producers, is considered one of the factors underlying the Canadian Wheat Board's action today setting an export price of $3.80 a bushel for flax -- 20 cents below the price the board pays producers.

Almost every household will find use at one time or another for "Special Diet Recipes," just released by the department of nutrition and service of the Gerber Products Company. In no way does this forty-four-page booklet prescribe for any ills; it merely tells how to cook and present what lithe doctor orders.

PHILADELPHIA, May 9 -- A Federal District Judge, James P. McGranery, refused today to permit Representative Earl Chudoff, Democrat, of Pennsylvania, to enter a plea for a client. He told Mr. Chudoff that a member of Congress as an employe of the Government was not permitted to represent a man accused of violating Federal laws.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (UP) -- John Edgar Hoover will celebrate his twenty-fifth anniversary tomorrow as head of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 9 -- New and wholly unexpected demands by Syrian Premier Husni Zayim seriously menace the Trans-Arabian pipeline built by United States interests as a Mediterranean outlet for the great Arabian American Company oil fields in Saudi Arabia, it is learned from Damascus on apparently reliable authority.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's message to Congress on government reorganization:

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- An implied desire to see the defeat of Senator Harry F. Byrd, Virginia Democrat, and others who oppose the Administration's program was attributed to President Truman today by Gilbert Harrison, national chairman of the American Veterans Committee.

The Amton Construction Company has purchased three parcels of land at the railroad station in Albertson, L. I., for improvement with a warehouse and office building for its own occupancy. James Sherrard, Rocco Abbondondolo and M. Florczak were the sellers.

NEWARK, N. J., May 9 -- Prof. Eugene G. Rochow, chemist of Harvard University who helped found a new industry upon sand, received the biennial Leo Hendrik Baekeland award here tonight. In accepting, he gave some drastic views about the future of humanity.

Two Brooklyn high school students charged with a series of robberies that netted them $1,500 in two weeks pleaded in court yesterday that they were working their way through college, if a little in advance of actual matriculation.
BALTIMORE, May 9 (AP) -- The Commercial Credit Company today reported a gain in its net income for the first quarter of 1949 and announced that its net worth has topped the $100,000,000 mark.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- President Truman called upon Congress today to give him authority quickly to start overhauling Federal operations in line with the first major recommendation of the Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government.
SHANGHAI, May 9 -- The National Government's official Central News Agency today said Communists had launched drives west toward Nanchang in Kiangsi Province and south into Fukien Province.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -- Judith Coplon's attorney proposed today that the jury trying her on espionage charges be taken on a tour of New York.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 9 -- Universal-International has borrowed Maureen O'Hara from Twentieth Century-Fox for the leading feminine role in "Bagdad," with Paul Christian and Vincent Price, U-I announced today. Miss O'Hara will take over the role previously intended for Yvonne de Carlo, who is recovering from an illness and will probably not be well enough to start work by June 1, when "Bagdad" is scheduled for the cameras.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities plans to ask Paul Crouch, Miami newspaper employe, what he knows about the disappearance of Juliet Stuart Poyntz, former high Communist, in 1937.

Additional orders for many types of Japanese goods may be delayed until July in order to appraise effects of the stabilization of the yen at the rate of 360 to the dollar, it was indicated in import circles here yesterday.

Eliahu Elath, Israeli Ambassador to the United States, said last night that Israel wanted peace with the Arabs and would make every effort to obtain closer relations and cooperation with all the peoples in the Middle East.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J. May 9 -- Because of decreasing student enrollment and curtailed income, Rutgers University will not reappoint thirty-two instructors at the end of the present term and may release sixty-two others, Dr. Robert C. Clothier, the president, announced today.

SHANGHAI, May 9 -- During the past few weeks a medieval frame of mind has taken hold of the inhabitants of this city. With a siege in the offing and possible subsequent disorder, the people are thinking of their homes as potential fortresses.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 9 -- The Yugoslav news agency Tanyug announced today that serious incidents had occurred on May 6 along the Albanian and Hungarian frontiers.

Rain or shine a Brooklyn savings and loan association will be prepared for the opening of' its branch office on Thursday. The South Brooklyn Savings and Loan Association, it was announced yesterday, has taken out rain insurance in what is described as the first instance of its kind among banking institutions.

Only the most naive optimist would believe that the Nationalist Government of China will ever return to national power. Whether we like it or not, the Communist regime is the de facto government, and sooner or later it must become the de jure government if the Western Powers wish to continue diplomatic relations with that country.

Custom smelters reduced copper yesterday to 18 cents per pound, a drop of 1/2 cent from the 18 1/2-cent level which prevailed last week. They also dropped zinc 1/2 cent to a new 12-cent level, St. Louis. The cuts marked new lows since their post-war highs.

Four French Rover Scouts who have come to the United States to paddle down the Mississippi as Marquette and Joliet did in 1673 were welcomed officially yesterday at Boy Scouts of America headquarters.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, May 9 -- Israel's initiative in submitting a draft agreement between Israel and Arab states that might form the preamble to a peace treaty seemed today to have failed to speed up appreciably the pace of discussions looking toward a Palestine settlement.

A suit filed in Federal Court yesterday by a group of landlords challenged the Housing and Rent Act of 1949 on Constitutional grounds and asked that Tighe E. Woods, the Housing Expediter, be restrained from enforcing the "fair net operating return" formula he announced last week.

The New Jersey Machine Corporation has purchased 15,000 square feet of vacant land at the southwest corner of Clinton and Sixteenth Streets in Hoboken, N. J., from Webb Knapp, Inc. J. I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -The Department of Commerce said today it is lifting export control quota restrictions from many iron and steel mill products because of improved domestic supplies.

The majority of thirty regional variety chain-store operators meeting yesterday in the Statler Hotel expressed intentions of expanding inventories to build up sales to meet consumer demand. Representing more than 600 stores throughout the nation, the retailers are here for a meeting of the Limited Price Variety Stores Association, Inc.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- An examiner for the Interstate Commerce Commission today recommended to that body that it deny $148,000 in reparation which the Reconstruction Finance Corporation asked the ICC to levy against the railroads on shipments of tin ore and tin concentrates made in the war period from New York and other Eastern points to Texas City, Texas.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., May 9 -Premieres of chamber operas marked tonight's offering in the Eastman School's Festival of American Music. The works were "Don't We All," by Burrill Phillips of the Eastman faculty, with libretto by Alberta Phillips, and "In the Name of Culture," by Alberto Bimboni of the Julliard School opera department, with libretto by Norman Frizelle Stolzenbach, lecturer in English at the University of Toledo.

BOSTON, May 9 (AP) -- Right-hander Vern Bickford, who was unable to finish the first inning yesterday, tonight pitched the Braves into second place in the National League with a three-hit job, leading Boston to a 4-1 triumph over the Pirates.

If no commercial manager has put on William Saroyan's "Don't Go Away Mad," it is easy to understand why. It is a weak and groping play without much of the Saroyan spirit. The Abbe Practical Workshop played it last evening before an invited audience at the Master Institute Theatre.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., May 9 -- Delegates to the annual convention of the American Federation of Hosiery Workers here today were asked by their president, Alexander McKeown, to relax certain restrictive union rules to enable unionized Northern mills to compete more favorably with non-union Southern plants.
DETROIT, May 9 -- A home-run blast from the bat of Dick Wakefield brought disappointment to Vic Raschi and the Yankees today before 11,733 fans at Briggs Stadium.

There is no need to speak at length of the opera, or "music-play," "A Drumlin Legend," music by Ernst Bacon, text by Helena Carus, commissioned by the Alice M. Ditson Fund, given one of five performances last night by the Columbia Theatre Association in the Brander Matthews Theatre.

William H. Weintraub Co., advertising agency, in an expansion move, has leased the entire seventeenth floor of the office building under construction at 488 Madison Avenue. Brown, Harris, Stevens, Inc., were the brokers. The advertising firm, which has been occupying portions of three floors at 30 Rockefeller Plaza, expects to be in its new quarters on Jan. 1.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- A law professor with considerable experience in criminal prosecutions and a noted physicist were nominated by President Truman today to fill vacancies in the United States Atomic Energy Commission. They are, respectively, Gordon Dean of Vista, Calif., and Dr. Henry De Wolf Smyth of Princeton, N. J.

FORT CHURCHILL, Canada, May 8 -- Here on wind-swept barren lands, along Hudson Bay, Canadian, British and United States soldiers and scientists have completed a crowded winter's research into the problem of waging war in the Arctic.

Irving Hudes and Harry Harden of New York City have purchased Idlewood, a forty-acre resort hotel property on Route 22, one mile south of Katonah, N. Y., from the Westchester Pines Realty Company. Joseph P. Day, Inc.; was the broker.

Saving lives at the risk of their own was "just another chore" to Michael Evans, 13 years old, of 1662 York Avenue, and Charles Montalbano, 12, of 774 Forty-third Street, Brooklyn. Both were shy yesterday when asked about contests with death that won for them the School Safety Patrol Honor Medals, highest national awards of the American Automobile Association.

On the eve of the anniversary of the independence of the Kingdom of Rumania, General Nicolae Radescu, the last constitutional Premier of that country, announced yesterday the formation here of a Rumanian National Committee.

Jackie Robinson, the Brooklyn Dodgers' popular second baseman, has a new fan. He is Aduaye A. Emeni, 21-year-old crown prince of Kwale, a Warri province in Nigeria, which is a little smaller than Pennsylvania and has a million subjects.

More than 750,000 new members have been added to the rolls of the Methodist Church during the last decade, Bishop Ivan Lee Holt of St. Louis, president of the denomination's Council of Bishops, said yesterday in a statement issued here by the church's Commission on Public Information.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Labor spokesmen today sounded what they declared was "the death knell of independent unionism in the telephone industry" when the Congress of Industrial Organizations formally presented a charter of affiliation to the Communication Workers of America. CWA members had voted 2 to 1 for affiliation.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- President Truman a few days ago told a press conference that Democrats in Congress who fail to support legislation which carries out the party platform of 1948 might be denied all federal patronage, and he added that the Lesinski bill to repeal the Taft-Hartley Act was an example of such legislation. The plain implication was that his view of what redeems a platform pledge, not theirs, would be the official test.
Football coaches and officials, sports writers and athletic directors will be asked to help select the site of a proposed national football shrine and hall of fame.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 9 -- Britain and Italy have agreed on a plan to award Italy a United Nations trusteeship over her pre-war African territory of Somaliland, beginning immediately, and over Tripolitania, in 1951, it was disclosed here today.

My Emma of the Belair Stud found the Water Blossom Classified Handicap exactly to her liking at Belmont Park yesterday. Next to the outside choice in the field of five fillies in the mile race that featured the card, My Emma stepped home to victory by a margin of more than three lengths, to the surprise of most of the crowd of 22,901.

Under the present world situation the possibility of the United States maintaining peace is in direct relation to our ability to win a war if it is thrust upon us, Maj. Gen. A. W. Vanaman, commandant of the Industrial College of the Armed Forces, said yesterday.

When the Communists reverted in 1945 to their pre-war policy of violent revolution, they expected the time soon would be ripe to overthrow the United States Government, a new surprise witness testified yesterday at the Communist trial.

Ten unions of the Congress of Industrial Organizations and the state and city CIO councils announced yesterday that "any move to break" the thirty-nine-day brewery strike would be met with the full strength of the CIO.

With prices averaging 10 per cent lower and extending in some cases to 20 per cent under last year, good spot orders and improved advance purchasing were reported yesterday at the fall National Market Week of the Boys' Industry at the New Yorker Hotel.

District Attorneys in the five counties have joined with city police, state and Federal authorities in a drive to wipe out the traditional loan shark racket on the city waterfront, it was learned yesterday. The many-pronged drive was disclosed when a longshoreman-victim was held in $50,000 bail in Brooklyn as a material witness after he had sought to withdraw his complaint against three alleged usurers.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 9 -- M. S. Szymczak, member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve Bank, said today this nation was witnessing in its international, as well as its domestic economy, a readjustment from deficit to surplus conditions.

Eleven years ago today in London centuries-old tradition was broken when United States Ambassador Joseph P. Kennedy announced he would make his first royal court appearance in white tie and tails instead of the customary silk stockings and knee breeches.

ST. LOUIS, May 9 -- A greater role in top management for credit executives of retail establishments was urged here today by Lindley S. Crowder, general manager-treasurer of the National Retail Credit Association, St. Louis. He spoke at the opening sessions of the sixteenth annual convention of the Credit Management division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association in the Statler Hotel.

Extensive radio coverage of the lifting of the Berlin blockade at 12:01 A. M., Berlin time, on Thursday, is being planned by all the major networks. On short notice, correspondents are being flown from New York to Germany to cover the event from both Berlin and Frankfort, and special interviews are being set up with important personages involved in the operation.

Rebounding from a two-game losing streak and a prolonged batting slump, New York University trimmed the midshipmen from Kings Point, 7 -- 3, at Ohio Field yesterday. This victory was the Violets sixth Metropolitan Intercollegiate Baseball Conference decision as against three losses.

Mitchell Parish may not be the only Phi Beta Kappa man in Tin Pan Alley, but he is probably the only lyricist to get the scholastic equivalent of the Hit Parade at the age of 48. Mr. Parish, now a junior at Washington Square College of New York University, won his key yesterday after accumulating thirty As and three Bs.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores last week dropped 7 per cent below the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The decline for the four weeks ended last Saturday was also 7 per cent.

LONDON, May 9 -- The Government's bill to nationalize the iron and steel industry passed its final stage in the House of Commons tonight. It will go to the House of Lords "unwept, unhonored and undiscussed," Oliver Lyttelton asserted.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -- Top ranking Administration officials reported tonight that President Truman had about decided to veto a Federal pay resolution because it contained a provision denying salaries to two Reclamation Bureau officials.

At least 10 to 12 per cent of all children up to eighteen years of age are victims of broken homes in this nation and "through absolutely no fault of their own" find themselves deprived of a normal home life, Dr. Kenneth D. Johnson, dean-elect of the New York School of Social Work, declared last night.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 9 -- Five teams finished in a tie four for first position with scores of 65 in the weekly amateur-pro event of the Long Island P. G. A. at the Cherry Valley Club today.
WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The Administration and the Senate's bipartisan foreign policy leaders joined today in an effort to push ratification of the North Atlantic treaty forward with all possible speed.

New York and Queens rank first and second respectively in average family income among the nation's 200 largest counties, according to Sales Management magazine's twentieth annual survey of buying power, released yesterday.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 9 -- Five teams finished in a tie four for first position with scores of 65 in the weekly amateur-pro event of the Long Island P. G. A. at the Cherry Valley Club today.
WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The Administration and the Senate's bipartisan foreign policy leaders joined today in an effort to push ratification of the North Atlantic treaty forward with all possible speed.

New York and Queens rank first and second respectively in average family income among the nation's 200 largest counties, according to Sales Management magazine's twentieth annual survey of buying power, released yesterday.
ST. PAUL, Minn., May 9 (AP) -- The State Executive Council authorized today the sale of $84,000,000 in tax-free bonds to pay bonuses to veterans of World War II.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The experimental "air coach" services could demoralize, through uncontrolled expansion, the whole aviation passenger system, W. A. Patterson, president of United Air Lines, Inc., asserted today.

LONDON, May 9 -- Brig. John Bagot Glubb Pasha, British commander of the Jordanian Arab Legion, asserted today that some Palestine Arab refugees who had attempted to return to their homes in Israel had been shot and others had been sent back to Arab territory.

The design of a bronze plaque, 18 by 24 inches, to be erected in memory of Babe Ruth, was approved yesterday by the City Art Commission for erection on the bleachers of the playground at Macombs Dam Park, East 162d Street and Jerome Avenue, the Bronx. At its regular monthly meeting at City Hall the commission sanctioned the marker as a gift of the Bronx County Democratic Committee.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 9 -- The Ad Hoc Political Committee of the General Assembly approved today a resolution calling for the admission of Israel to the United Nations. The vote was 33 to 11, and thus apparently assured the necessary two-thirds majority for the application when the General Assembly takes it up later in the week.
The tribute to General Clay by his wartime chief, Judge Patterson, carried in your columns on May 6, is timely and richly deserved. A word from another source might be added.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -- The State Department issued the following release today on the fourth anniversary of the liberation of Prague, Czechoslovakia, during World War II.
GENEVA, May 9 -- European governments were told by two authorities today that if they wanted higher standards of living for their people they must abandon economic nationalism and loosen up trade.

Dr. Ralph Bunche, retiring as Acting United Nations Mediator for Palestine, was honored last night with an award for distinguished service by the American Association for the United Nations at a dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel attended by 1,000 guests.

A painters' union official and the president of a contracting company in which the labor man was a secret partner were indicted yesterday for allegedly cheating the city out of $91,809 in the redecorating of city-owned buildings.

NAGS HEAD, N. C., May 9 -- Usually our arrival on the outer banks is the signal for the weather man to send along a southwest blow that ships up the surf and drives every channel bass from the inshore sloughs to the quiet of deeper water off-shore.

Dissension over the One World Award, to be presented tomorrow night at a dinner at the Plaza Hotel, was discovered yesterday. Several persons formerly associated with the award committee said they had resigned and charged that the affair had taken on "promotional characteristics" out of keeping with the original spirit of the movement.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (UP) -- The Senate Judiciary Committee today voted to pay $20,000 to the families of five children and a minister's wife who were killed by a Japanese balloon-bomb in Oregon during the second World War.

Proof sheets of sixteen ads supporting the free chest X-ray campaign against tuberculosis will be distributed next month by the Advertising Council to all daily and weekly newspapers, it was learned yesterday. This year's drive, second to receive Council support, is expected to be marked by considerably greater participation of newspapers and other media, it was said.

In an effort to make furniture for export that would appeal specifically to the American trade, a Swedish manufacturer has enlisted the talents of an American designer. Two bedroom groups and a series of occasional living room pieces designed by Erno Fabry of New York, and made by Bodafors of Stockholm were introduced yesterday at the decorator's showroom of Swedish Modern, Inc., 675 Fifth Avenue.

When economy shrinks the meat on tables in homes for the aged, cottage cheese patties fried in bacon fat or a casserole of miniature meatballs and left-over vegetables will be relished as substitutes, dietitians from institutions affiliated with the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies reported yesterday.

LONDON, May 9 -- In reply to widely expressed fears that Canada might be losing her British market, the British Government announced today that additional purchases would be made from the Dominion this year.

Coffee futures were strong and active in yesterday's trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Demand from trade houses plus some short-covering advanced prices in contract "S" 30 to 40 points above Friday's close. Firmness in the spot market added strength to futures prices.
I do not wish to consider in this letter the merits and faults of the Taft-Hartley Act, but to study Mr. Truman's method of achieving its repeal.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 9 -- A decision by the Maritime Commission on the future of the liners Monterey and Mariposa of the Matson Navigation Company is probable in June, Commissioner David J. Coddaire said here tody.

Competition for the purchase of $18,000,000 of new public utility bond issues and of a new issue of utility common stock priced at $2,691,372 produced twenty-two bids from investment banking groups yesterday. The awards were as follows:

PRAGUE, May 9 -- The Hungarian Government has decided to allow the relatives of Jews now in Israel to emigrate, it was reliably learned today, but it has not yet defined the word "relatives." An agreement, including the defini-between the Hungarian Governtion, is expected to be concluded ment and Israeli representatives in Budapest next week.

After two weeks of hearings on the North Atlantic Pact, Senator Connally is trying to speed up proceedings in an effort to get the Treaty before the whole Senate for earliest possible approval. In this effort he displays a better understanding of both the international situation and the national interest than his colleague Senator Lucas, the Democratic majority leader, who would shelve the Treaty for the present in order to debate the Administration's labor bill.

Mayor O'Dwyer and Borough President John Cashmore were among 850 persons who attended an interfaith dinner last night that opened the thirty-fifth annual Brooklyn Week for the Blind. The meeting sponsored by Catholic, Protestant and Jewish groups, took place in the St. George Hotel, Brooklyn.

On the Senate's calendar this week is a measure which has been accurately described as "the indispensable other half of the Marshall Plan." This is the bill which would extend the Hull Reciprocal Trade Agreements program for another two years.

Matching their best streak of 1948, the Giants made it seven in a row last night at the Polo Grounds, conquering the Cubs, 7 -- 2, before 22,445 fans. How long this string of uninterrupted successes will go, Leo Durocher does not know, but right now the suddenly popular pilot is treading on clouds.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 9 -- A decision by the Maritime Commission on the future of the liners Monterey and Mariposa of the Matson Navigation Company is probable in June, Commissioner David J. Coddaire said here tody.

Competition for the purchase of $18,000,000 of new public utility bond issues and of a new issue of utility common stock priced at $2,691,372 produced twenty-two bids from investment banking groups yesterday. The awards were as follows:

PRAGUE, May 9 -- The Hungarian Government has decided to allow the relatives of Jews now in Israel to emigrate, it was reliably learned today, but it has not yet defined the word "relatives." An agreement, including the defini-between the Hungarian Governtion, is expected to be concluded ment and Israeli representatives in Budapest next week.

After two weeks of hearings on the North Atlantic Pact, Senator Connally is trying to speed up proceedings in an effort to get the Treaty before the whole Senate for earliest possible approval. In this effort he displays a better understanding of both the international situation and the national interest than his colleague Senator Lucas, the Democratic majority leader, who would shelve the Treaty for the present in order to debate the Administration's labor bill.

Mayor O'Dwyer and Borough President John Cashmore were among 850 persons who attended an interfaith dinner last night that opened the thirty-fifth annual Brooklyn Week for the Blind. The meeting sponsored by Catholic, Protestant and Jewish groups, took place in the St. George Hotel, Brooklyn.

An agreeable excursion into "American Theatre Highlights," as she calls her one-woman show, was offered by Dorothy Sands last night at Times Hall for the benefit of Radcliffe College's seventieth anniversary fund drive. That Miss Sands is an alumna of Radcliffe is only a small fraction of the reason for the warmly enthusiastic reception she received.

OSLO, Norway, May 10 (UP) -- A dispute over the definition of amateurism between American and European delegates at the International Ski Federation Congress today threatened to remove skiing from the 1952 Winter Olypmics program.

The Right Rev. Charles Kendall Gilbert, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, formally notified the 167th diocesan convention yesterday of his intention to retire on Aug. 6, 1950, his seventy-second birthday.
ROME, May 10 -- British Princess Margaret, dressed severely in black, was received by Pope Pius XII in a private audience in his personal library today.

ST. LOUIS, May 10 (AP) -- The lowly Browns could muster only three hits today, but one was a ninth-inning home run by Jerry Priddy for a 2-1 verdict over the Red Sox that snapped the St. Louis losing streak at ten games. Only 1,663 fans were on hand for the pitchers' duel.

New York City now has its fourth Commissioner of Commerce in three and a half years, but he has had the foresight to warn the Mayor in his letter of acceptance that he will serve in this dollar-a-year post as head of the Commerce Department only until a "worthwhile pattern for the office has been established."
TEHERAN, Iran, May 10 -- The Russians have occupied three Iranian border posts, a military source here said today.

CHICAGO, May 10 (AP) -- The Athletics blended three scattered singles with eleven bases on balls to defeat the White Sex, 5 -- 0, before 9,361 persons tonight in the first Comiskey Park night game of the season. Joe Coleman pitched the distance, allowing five hits, to gain his second victory against three losses.
Eleven years ago today, Congress passed the New Deal's Aid to Business bill to provide 5,000,000 jobs in the next year. President Roosevelt's spendinglending program approximated $5,330,000,000.

Everybody has gone to a lot of trouble to make "Gayden" as horrifying as a modern "Ghosts." Mignon and Robert McLaughlin have written the story of a "constitutional psychopath" and his indulgent mother with what is probably scientific accuracy.

SHANGHAI, May 10 -- According to the Nationalists' official Central News Agency, the Communists have opened their long-awaited drive on Hankow and the railroad leading to Canton. At the same time, it appeared the Communists were preparing the final assaults on Tsingtao and Shanghai.

The General Outdoor Advertising Company, Inc., of 60 East Forty-second Street, and the Pittsburgh Outdoor Advertising Company, which it controls, were charged with violation of the Sherman and Clayton anti-trust acts in a suit for $750,000 in damages filed in Federal Court yesterday by three Pittsburgh outdoor advertising companies.

May is a splendid month in many respects. It is the blossom-laden bridge from spring to summer, the garland-wound gateway to June. Indeed, it vies with June as a prime topic among poets, who have sung of May as "the sweetest" month, "the dauntless youth of the year," the "bounteous May."

LONDON, May 10 -- Maj. Julian Kajdy, an assistant military attache at the Polish Embassy here, was described today as a "foreign agent -- in common parlance a spy" who had paid agents to obtain secret information on American air strength, including atomic weapons in the British Isles.
BUFFALO, May 10 (AP) -- Compulsory health insurance will not solve the problem of dental care, the president-elect of the American Dental Association said today.

Sedate Grand Central Terminal resounded with unusual sounds at about 1:30 P. M. yesterday. They were the voices of two announcers, Martin Stern, director of the Swim for Health Association, and Mary Kelley, director of the Millinery Fashion Bureau, describing a vacation fashion show in progress on the east balcony of the terminal.

CLEVELAND, May 10 (AP) -- A first-inning single was the only hit the Indians got today as Mickey Haefner hurled Washington to a 1-0 victory, the Senators' eighth straight. It was the first one-hitter of the major league baseball season.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 10 -- Alan H. Temple, vice president of the National City Bank of New York, said today that the next twelve months would answer the question whether this nation would pass from an inflationary boom to a stable situation on a lower price level without an intervening collapse or depression.

Import controls imposed by the Union of South Africa as a result of drains upon its gold reserves will be maintained "only as long as absolutely necessary," Eric H. Louw, Minister of Economic Affairs of the Union, declared yesterday at the luncheon meeting of the Export Managers Club at the Statler Hotel.

The Urban League of Greater New York, a social service organization concerned with improving the living conditions of Negroes and Puerto Ricans, found 1,856 jobs for persons who applied for work last year, Edward S. Lewis, its executive director, reported yesterday. The applications totaled 8,016.

High hopes held by Henry L. Scott, pianist-comedian, for his one-man show, "Concerto for Fun," were blown to smithereens when he read yesterday's criticisms. Consequently, he called off the scheduled two-week visit at the Mansfield after only one performance on Monday night.

The appointment of Thomas J. Watson Jr., vice president of International Business Machines Corporation, as chairman of the 1949 campaign of the United Hospital Fund was announced yesterday by Roy E. Larsen, president of the fund and of Time and Life, Inc. The campaign will open in October.

LONDON, May 10 -- The announcement by Harold Wilson, president of the Board of Trade, that exports declined in April, unsettled the stock market here today. Most sections were "patchy" and price movements were irregular.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was steady all day yesterday and final prices were 4 points higher to 14 points net lower.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., May 10 (AP) -- Gov. Frank Carlson of Kansas said today that since executive and judicial departments of the Government seemingly were against states' rights. "we are thankful that we still have a Congress close to our people."

New York University's superiority in the field events carried the Violets to their eighth straight triumph in the Metropolitan Intercollegiate outdoor track and field championships in a surprisingly close battle with Manhattan at Randalls Island Stadium yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 10 -- The special Political Committee of the United Nations General Assembly approved late tonight a Bolivian resolution directing the Economic and Social Council and the Secretary General to investigate conditions of life and work among millions of aboriginal inhabitants of Central and South America. The final vote, which came shortly before midnight, was twenty-eight in favor and none against, with nine nations abstaining.

NAGS HEAD, N. C., May 10 -- While the sea recovered from the tumult of yesterday's wind, we were pushed around and about Kitty Hawk Bay in an ancient but water-tight rowboat. Although conditions did not satisfy our guide, two of us managed to take what would have been a black bass limit had we kept them.

The new Ellerman Bucknall cargo-passenger vessel City of Liverpool will leave New York May 27 on her maiden voyage to the Far East, it was announced yesterday by Norton, Lilly Co., 26 Beaver Street, agents here for the owners. The ship will call at Manila, Hongkong, Shanghai and Singapore.

BONN, May 10 -- On a secret ballot at the last plenary session of the Parliamentary Council here, Bonn was chosen tonight as the future capital of the new Western German State. The vote was 33 for Bonn and 29 for Frankfort. Two Communists abstained and one vote was invalid.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Consumer income, or income received by individuals as distinguished from that of corporations, dropped to an annual rate of $214,300,000,000 in March, the third successive decline since the beginning of the year.

Mabs of Hollywood and Franklin Simon gave a party last evening at the Pierre Hotel to start off the bathing suit season. Mabs, who made the first lastex swim suit, is now the name connected with a large organization that creates hundreds of bathing costumes for the girls in search of a form-fitting suit.

PHILADELPHIA, May 10 (AP) -- M. W. Clement, president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, said today the nation's largest railroad would finish 1949 "just as good or better" than 1948 "if we get economic justice from the Interstate Commerce Commission."

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Pensions of $72 a month for low-income veterans of both world wars at the age of 65 were voted today by a House Committee, and passage of the new, watered-down bill was widely expected in the House itself.
BALTIMORE, May 10 (AP) -- As it poured rain at Pimlico this morning, stable talk turned to what a wet track on Saturday would do to the dope on the $75,000 added Preakness Stakes.

CINCINNATI, May 10 (AP) -- Officials of the Mexican Baseball League met with Baseball Commissioner Albert B. Chandler today in their quest for a stronger agreement governing recognition of reserve clauses and player contracts. Whether anything definite was accomplished was not announced.
The Appellate Division ruled unanimously yesterday that two sections of the Alcoholic Beverage Control Law respecting mandatory price-fixing were invalid.

The parrot who cried "Help!" too often wound up like the little boy in the fable: no one paid him any heed yesterday and so his master, owner of a coin and stamp business at 1480 Broadway, in Times Square, was robbed of $744 in cash and an undetermined amount of coins and stamps.

CHICAGO, May 10 -- Secretary of Labor Maurice J. Tobin today told members of the Super Market Institute, Inc., enactment of a 75-cents-an-hour minimum wage law would protect them from unfair competitors who pay inadequate wages. The institute, attended by 5,000 leaders in the food industry, is holding its annual convention.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- A warning to this country's European associates in the North Atlantic treaty against any assumption that American military aid could give them any absolute guarantee of safety from invasion was issued today by Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 10 -- Mayors, supervisors and other officials of fifteen Westchester County communities met in the County Office Building here today and organized a committee to draft strategy for fighting the New York Central Railroad's application for commutation rate increases of 31 to 46 per cent.

Labor and management resumed negotiations yesterday in an effort to end the strike, now in its sixth day, at the River Rouge and Lincoln plants of the Ford Motor Company. The stoppage, the first authorized walk-out of Ford employes since 1941, already involves 65,000 workers, and if it continues many days longer can affect a total of some 106,000.

The Commonwealth and Southern Corporation, whose plan of dissolution is awaiting decision by the District Court in Wilmington, Del., announced yesterday in its annual report that net income in 1948 amounted to $18,450,081, compared with $16,995,837 in 1947.
The Majoro Corporation of the Majestic Theatre, was ordered yesterday to produce records of all its ticket business since "South Pacific," the hit musical, opened there on April 7.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 10 -- Prospects for a particularly close United Nations General Assembly vote on a four-power resolution to allow ambassadors and ministers to return to Madrid were evident today as leaders of both sides engaged in final energetic electioneering.

American Communists reorganized their party leadership schools after the war to teach that the streets of America would have to run red with blood" as did the streets of Russia in 1917, according to yesterday's testimony at the Communist trial.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- Railroads serving New York Boston and Portland, Me., today asked Interstate Commerce Commission authority to equalize freight rates on grain from Great Lakes points to all ports from Baltimore north to Portland.
LONDON, May 10 -- While Annie was getting her gun at the London Coliseum, Fanny was getting her fun out in the Provinces.
GENEVA, May 10 -- Eastern Europe should export more goods to Western European countries, Dr. Amazasp A. Arutiunian, Russian delegate, told the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe today.

BERLIN, May 10 -- The Soviet Military Administration will push adoption by the Communist-dominated People's Congress of the constitution for an Eastern German state. It hopes to have the organization of this state as far advanced as that of the Western-sponsored German Federal Republic when the Council of Foreign Ministers meets May 23 in Paris.

Richard Skinner and Evelyn Freyman announced yesterday the engagement of Basil Rathbone in "The Heiress" for the week of Aug. 9 at their summer playhouse in Olney, Md. The theatre's season will get under way on May 31 with Tallulah Bankhead in "Private Lives," featuring Donald Cook.

CHICAGO, May 10 -- The historic Apollo Theatre on Randolph and Clark Streets in the Loop, closed its doors tonight to make way for razing of the building. A bus station will be erected on the site. Most of the building's other tenants already have moved.

TRENTON, N. J., May 10 -- Argument in the appeals of six Trenton Negroes, convicted and sentenced to death for the murder of a Trenton storekeeper, will be heard by the New Jersey Supreme Court Monday.

ROANOKE, Va., May 10 (UP) -- Police tonight lodged a murder charge against Lee Scott, 16 years old, accused of murdering Dana Marie Weaver, 16, in the parish house of Christ Episcopal Church on Sunday.

Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation affirmed yesterday in what it described as "the most far-reaching statement of sales policy ever made by a major distributor" a five-point program designed to aid theatre owners to "win back and retain the large audience not now attending motion-picture theatres."

NEWARK, N. J., May 10 -- Mayor Vincent J. Murphy, secretary of the New Jersey Federation of Labor, was defeated today for reelection to the five-man city commission. He finished in sixth place among a field of thirty candidates, including all incumbents, who contested for the five seats.

Matthew S. Crinkley, vice president of the Isbrandtsen Company, Inc., told a Maritime Commission trial examiner yesterday that 90 per cent of the shippers disliked the contract rate systems of North Atlantic conferences.

Federal Judge Simon H. Rifkind ruled yesterday that Valentin A. Gubitchev, Soviet engineer under indictment on an espionage charge, did not have diplomatic immunity and that he was subject to the jurisdiction of the Federal court.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- In a move to whip up public interest in the Administration's fair employment practices program, public hearings in the House began today and will be continued at least three weeks.

VIENNA, May 10 -- The Austrian Cabinet today accepted a new wage, price agreement raising wages and prices, dropping subsidies and increasing gas and electricity rates and railroad and streetcar fares.
Four candidates have been nominated for the presidency of Local 6 of the International Typographical Union, AFL, which will conduct its biennial elections next Wednesday, it was made known yesterday.

Sales and earnings of the May Department Stores Company and its subsidiaries in the fiscal year ended on last Jan. 31, were the largest in its thirty-nine-year history, according to the report released today.
The Lehigh Valley Railroad Company announced yesterday it has received more than the required 75 per cent of assents necessary to justify its proposed Mahaffie Act readjustment plan.

Earnings of the Gulf Oil Corporation and its subsidiaries in the quarter ended on March 31 were $26,973,000 after taxes and all charges, in contrast to $38,517,000 earned in the initial three months of last year, according to the report issued yesterday.

DETROIT, May 10 -- In an effort to win the rubber game of his first series against his old club, Red Robert Rolfe today sent Hal Newhouser against the Yankees, but the Tigers' ace was just another pitcher to the Bombers.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- A former Polish general testified today that Moscow-directed agents expected to "break up the United States" into a series of small separate nations of Negroes, Germans and other racial entities.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Senator Elbert D. Thomas, chairman of the Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee, indicated today at a press conference that the new labor relations bill introduced last week by Republican Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio might be the basis for compromise on pending labor legislation.

The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's interclub team matches were somewhat marred by the heavy rain of the early morning hours and after much telephoning by the sectional team captains, it was decided in two districts that the matches would go on.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 10 -- The cease-fire agreement reached by the Netherlands and the Republic of Indonesia resulted today in a postponement until September of debate in the United Nations General Assembly on the struggle in the East Indies.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 10 -- An optimistic outlook for this nation's huge $6,500,000,000 packaging industry both as to the supply of packaging materials and the demand for finished products was presented here today at the eighteenth National Packaging Expositionand Conference in Convention Hall.

A new approach to improving intergroup relations in American industry will be started today in a project sponsored jointly by the General Cable Corporation of Perth Amboy, N. J., and the National Conference of Christians and Jews.

DETROIT, May 10 -- Still in a deadlock and with no progress reported, negotiators for the Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers, CIO, declared an overnight recess today in their fresh efforts to halt a six-day strike that has closed the Rouge and Lincoln plants and is bringing the company's nationwide network of operations to a standstill.

Harold Springer, a former officer of the Continental Bank and Trust Company, since merged, has been appointed a trust officer of the Colonial Trust Company, it was announced yesterday by Arthur S. Kleeman, president.

CHICAGO, May 10 (AP) -- Leo Crowley, board chairman of the Milwaukee Road, declared today "some relief in operating costs must be given if the railroad industry is to survive under the free enterprise system."

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The withholding of full diplomatic representation from the Franco regime in Spain broke out as an angry issue on the Senate floor today. Debate was largely in bitter condemnation of American policy and abstention by the United States from voting on the question Saturday at the United Nations.

Coffee futures were slightly lower in moderately active trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Commission-house selling was absorbed by trade interests. The undertone was steady with final prices at about the best levels of the day. Contract "S" closed unchanged to 10 points lower. Contract "D" eased 5 to 13 points in quiet trading.

The Manufacturers Trust Company has come to the aid of 659 employes of the Office of the Housing Expediter, who have not received their salaries during the last six weeks, it was made known yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 10 -- A subcommittee of the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly today approved in principle a new British proposal under which Libya would become independent in ten years, with Britain meanwhile retaining the administration of Cyrenaica and France that of Fezzan. The vote was 8 to 5, with three abstentions.
Need a baby sitter? Call UNiversity 4-3200, Extension 2268, and ask for Lou Little.

Councilman Edward Rager, Manhattan Republican, charged yesterday at a public hearing before the City Council's finance committee that the executive budget was "inflated" by illegal inclusion of 23,000 provisional city employes. He said that many of the employes had been appointed through district political clubs and were "drones."
BERLIN, May 10 -- The question of powers to be wielded by a United States high commissioner to Germany is holding up this appointment, it was reported here today.

Large hollow wooden blocks that children like to combine in imaginative ways just for fun are the basis for inexpensive new nursery furniture at Creative Playthings, 867 Madison Avenue. They were designed by Frank Caplan and Martha New. The first of the units was selected for the children's playroom in the modern house by Marcel Breuer on exhibit in the garden of the Museum of Modern Art.

Whether the proper differential exists between the wages of licensed and unlicensed engine department personnel was the chief topic of negotiations yesterday between representatives of the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, CIO, and the Committee for the Companies and Agents -- Atlantic and Gulf Coasts.

BUFFALO, N. Y., May 10 (AP) -- Jersey City regained first place in the International League race by defeating the Bisons, 9 -- 5, tonight before 2,984 chilled fans. The setback ended Buffalo's winning streak at seven straight.

Purchase of Station WOV by the Victory Broadcasting Corporation was approved in Washington yesterday by the Federal Communications Commission, according to Associated Press. The price was reported in excess of $200,000.

An unusual collection of French illustrated books and bookbinding will go on exhibit at the Cultural Division of the French Embassy, 934 Fifth Avenue, on Thursday and continue through June 5. Among the noted French artists who have illustrated the rare editions on display are Matisse, Picasso, Rouault, Utrillo, Derain, Vlaminck, Dufy and Laurencin. The books, ranging from Euripides to Albert Camus, include works of English, German, American, Russian as well as French authors.

Several years ago subway and bus riders around New York began to notice posters on democracy and tolerance as they gazed at the advertising borders above the windows of trains and buses. The posters attracted attention because they were well-drawn and sharply phrased.

Two Jamaica, Queens, radio patrolmen found $12,208 in bills yesterday morning when they stopped their department car to clean a dirty windshield during a heavy rain. The money was tied up in a knotted rag lying in a gutter.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The Chief Rabbi of the new state of Israel sat here today, reading the Hebrew script of his Bible and talking of great prophecies. What he read he uttered in English, his voice edged with the true accent of an Irishman. Then, with a Missouri twang, the words of the 126th Psalm were echoed right back to him by President Truman.

Receiving the five votes necessary to win, Maximilian Moss, Brooklyn attorney, was elected president of the Board of Education yesterday. Four members refused to cast their ballots in what was described as the most bitterly contested board election -- behind the scenes -- in twenty-five years.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Employment in the eleven naval shipyards in the United States and Hawaii will be reduced nearly 10,000 persons in the fiscal year beginning July 1, the Navy announced today.

Vince Foster, hard-hitting Omaha welterweight, and Charley Fusari of Irvington, N. J., continued their boxing drills yesterday in preparation for their scheduled ten-round tussle at Madison Square Garden Friday night.

DUBLIN, May 10 -- Party divisions were obliterated in a surge of national resentment when a crowded Dail [Parliament] adopted unanimously tonight a resolution protesting against the British Government's Ireland bill.

Sixty-five thousand unionized dressmakers in this city were ordered last night to stop work for four hours tomorrow and join in a public protest against the murder of William Lurye, a special organizer for the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, AFL.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- Capt. Eddie Rickenbacker, president of Eastern Air Lines, urged the Civil Aeronautics Board today to authorize through one-carrier plane service from Florida to California.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- Postmaster General Jesse M. Donaldson today challenged complaints by publishers that proposed higher rates on second-class mail would drive them out of business.

Three New York school teachers who, as NEW YORK TIMES fellows, recently made a nation-wide survey of current affairs teaching, continued their report yesterday afternoon to an audience of 500 teachers in Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The bipartisan economy drive gained momentum today, along with a significant recruit from the "liberal" wing of the Democratic party, in the wake of yesterday's disclosure that the President's Council of Economic Advisers was concerned over the possible impact on the declining economy if there should be a sharp tax increase.

BERLIN, May 10 -- The Western occupying powers will probably order the Bonn Parliamentary Council to dissolve the eighteen-man committee named to act as an interim government for Western Germany until a formally elected regime is established, it was indicated today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 10 -- John Huston, film director who has been designated as the recipient of the 1949 award of the One World Committee, to be presented in New York tomorrow night, said today when informed of dissension that has arisen in connection with the award:
BUFFALO, May 10 (AP) -- The Frontier Oil Refining Corporation announced today that it had formed two new companies to separate its production and refining activities.

Underwriting Inventory According to reports in underwriting circles, today's marketing of new issues of AA-rated and A-rated public utility bonds at yields of 2.81 per cent and 2.90 per cent, respectively, has touched off lively indications of institutional investment interest, vindicating the continued venturesome bidding of banking syndicates.

GREELEY, Col., May 10 -- The vast Colorado-Big Thompson irrigation and power project is half-finished but has already caused twice the headaches anticipated. "Big T" has come to mean big trouble because of angry debates it started in this and bordering states that may soon explode in Congress.

A shipload of assorted cargo, including furs, pig bristles, tung oil and other products, left Tientsin, China early last week for the United States, according to advices received here yesterday by interests engaged in financing foreign trade.
Tammany charged yesterday that the campaign of Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. for Congress in the Twentieth District was just a plot by a lot of ex-New Dealers to block the Truman program.

ROME, May 10 -- The regional election held on the island of Sardinia on Sunday marked a severe setback for Premier Alcide de Gasperi's Christian Democratic party and a considerable, though less startling, advance for the extreme left-wing parties.
LONDON, May 10 (UP) -- Protestant churchmen today described Princess Margaret's visit to Pope Pius as a "direct evasion of the Bill of Rights, Britain's basic act of Constitution."

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 10 -- Brig. Gen. R. H. R. Parmentier, deputy director of the United Nations Palestine refugee relief, has arrived in Beirut to take action on a scandal that has broken out over inferior flour delivered to the refugees.
CHICAGO, May 10 (AP) -- Promoter Joe Louis today estimated that the June 22 bout between Ezzard Charles and Jersey Joe Walcott for his vacated heavyweight crown will gross about $300,000.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The National Security Council, it was learned today, has created the Interdepartmental Committee on Internal Security (ICIS) to develop a policy against subversive activity within the United States.

A detailed protest against the tentative decision of the Civil Aeronautics Board not to grant Willis Air Service, Inc., a five-year certificate of public convenience and necessity was made yesterday by the all-freight airline, which has been operating between the New York area and Florida for more than three and a half years.

The Palestine Economic Corporation will offer to investors today without underwriting 600,000 shares of common stock at $28 a share to raise funds to expand the corporation's established enterprises and to organize new businesses to help meet the needs of Israel's growing population.

The convention on genocide that was approved by fifty-five nations in Paris last December still awaits action by this Government. This is amazing in view of the bold and inspiring leadership by our delegation in U. N. meetings to write this crime into international law.
Word of Honor of the Phantom Farm just about ran away and hid from four others in the Don Bingo Classified Handicap that occupied the feature spot at Belmont Park yesterday.

Inviting in their array of fresh bright colors, the summer collection of Joyce shoes, seen yesterday at B. Altman Co., remained true to their California designer's original concept that shoes should be light in weight and, above all, comfortable. Typical of this, the newest addition of the shoe family was fashioned of pliable natural glove pigskin in a wedge tie with a forked tongue that fits the foot like a glove.

Louis Cooper has purchased the one - story taxpayer building at 83-89 Rockaway Avenue, Valley Stream, L. I., from David Selvin. Sale was subject to a first mortgage of $50,500. Lane Realty and S. M. Siegel were the brokers.

ST. LOUIS, May 10 -- A "middle of the road policy," neither too conservative nor too optimistic, should be followed by credit executives in planning for the future, it was declared here today by Sidney R. Baer, vice-president-treasurer, Stix, Baer Fuller, St. Louis.

CAMDEN, N. J., May 10 -- George W. Frost, former Camden Police Chief, was cleared today of charges of misconduct in office. Superior Court Judge Donald M. Waesche granted a judgment of acquittal on all four counts in an indictment, including a charge of failure to suppress gambling.

SHAWNEE - ON - DELAWARE, May 10 -- Rayon fabrics will be used in 23 to 28 per cent of all men's suits sold this summer, according to Joseph A. Golden, head of the men's wear division, Burlington Mills. Speaking today at the National Textile Seminar in the Shawnee Inn, Mr. Golden predicted that by 1950, rayons will account for upward of 35 per cent of the total summer suit volume.

The 1949 Greenwich Village Fresh Air Fund Arts Festival moved into the last stages of preparation yesterday as artists and craftsmen, Village organizations and their friends made ready for tomorrow's opening in Artists Row, the famous line of brick houses on Washington Square South that has been condemned to be torn down.

CHICAGO, May 10 -- Chancellor Robert Maynard Hutchins of the University of Chicago and Mrs. Vesta Sutton Orlick were married today in a candlelight ceremony by the Rev. William J. Hutchins, father of the bridegroom, in the home of Mrs. William Sutton, the bride's mother. The bridal couple left immediately on a trip to the South.
The Third Avenue Transit Corporation criticized the Public Service Commission yesterday for a policy of "too little, too late" in dealing with applications for fare increases.
SEOUL, Korea, May 10 -- South Korea today celebrated the first anniversary of the United Nations-sponsored elections that led to the establishment of the Korean Republic.

Serge Koussevitzky, who recently completed his twenty-fifth and final season with the Boston Symphony Orchestra, called last night for the establishment of a Department of Fine Arts. His plea for Government support of the arts came during his speech at the dinner in his honor at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel that was organized by the League of Composers.

American aid to Belgium under the Marshall Plan is helping that country to solve its monetary problems, but a vital step before 1952 is the establishment of a "proper" international monetary organization to move for the stability of European currencies and their free convertibility.

Time, money and an immense amount of genuinely devoted and inspired labor would be wasted if the excellent reports of the Hoover Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government should wind up as mere reports. There is a danger of this happening.

The National Association of Women Artists will open their 1949 annual exhibition of oils, sculpture, water-colors, miniatures and work in graphic media tomorrow evening in the galleries of the National Academy, Fifth Avenue at Eighty-ninth Street. Some 350 entries have been assembled, installed throughout the available gallery space -- 142 oil paintings, approximately 100 water-colors, fifty pieces of sculpture, nearly seventy prints and a generous dozen miniatures.

The present level of rayon textile prices offers values which manufacturers and retailers cannot afford to overlook, it was pointed out yesterday by Herman Chopak, president of the textile converting company bearing his name. With production curtailed and inventories down, the trade will see a general stiffening of prices, he predicted with a squeeze on desirable goods.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Salaries of executives of airlines partly dependent on Federal mail subsidies were under Senate scrutiny today.
CAMDEN, N. J., May 10 (AP) -- The largest daily double pay-off in New Jersey racing history -- $3,015.40 for $2 -- turned up today at Garden State Park.

A settlement in the Federal Trade Commission's action against a major segment of the paper industry -- one of the largest such cases in number of respondents -- appeared yesterday to be a strong possibility.

Thirty-eight thousand mentally deficient babies were born in the United States last year, it was reported yesterday by the Association for the Help of Retarded Children, Inc., as it announced the opening of offices at 1133 Broadway.

PARIS, May 10 -- Outsize collars, pocket flaps and peplums inspired by the gracefully curving point of the calla lily, jagged necklines in sharp, uneven points like a broken egg shell are a part of Schiaparelli's interesting contribution to midseason showings.
Frank Hague, one of the last of the old-time political bosses, ruled Jersey City for thirty-two years almost as a feudal lord ran his fiefdom.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., May 10 (AP) -- Donald P. Hess, president of American Bosch Corporation, said tonight that Joseph E. Ridder, publisher and industrialist, probably would be made chairman of the board at a stockholders' meeting in New York on May 26.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 10 -- Eric H. Louw, South African delegate to the United Nations, quit the council table of the Political Committee this morning in protest against the decision to discuss the Indian problem in South Africa prior to debating the General Assembly's competence to enter the case.
WORCESTER, England, May 10 (Reuters) -- The New Zealand cricket team gained the first victory of its English tour today when they beat Worcestershire by 150 runs.
The two centers of gravity between which our nation is now balancing with regard to China may soon coalesce to threaten us with a force which we may not be able to resist.

Brooklyn's week for the blind started off in full swing yesterday when Martin's of Brooklyn gave the first of three fashion presentations at the St. George Hotel. While there is no admission to the fashion shows, proceeds from the sale of articles made by the blind and flowers will benefit the Brooklyn organization for the blind.

An appeal was made yesterday to manufacturers to contribute any type of merchandise to the bazaar being held by the Women's Division of the Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society at the Hotel Bradford, 210 West Seventieth Street.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (UP) -- The National Labor Relations Board killed a labor-management wage contract today because, it said, the union security provisions went farther than allowed by the Taft-Hartley Act.
The State of California announced yesterday that it would receive bids on $30,000,000 of veterans' welfare bonds on June 21. The obligations are to bear interest of 2 1/4 per cent.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,452 against 1,304 last week and 1,121 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 734 arrivals yesterday, compared with 535 last Tuesday.

Not since pre-war days have stores been so abundantly stocked with molds for jellied salads or, as they sometimes are called, aspics. They come in wide and interesting variety -- shaped like stars, rings, diamonds and, for a jellied tuna salad perhaps, in the form of a fish. Where to find them?

SOUTHAMPTON, England, May 10 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, who as an unknown young law graduate toured England twenty-four years ago in a second-hand automobile, returned tonight as the most famous passenger aboard the luxury liner Queen Mary.

A long list of representative issues again touched new lows for the year yesterday as the stock market slid off for the fifth consecutive session in a virtual duplication of the Monday pattern. Pressure against the steels was particularly upsetting to market followers and invited a continuation of the highly cautious trading exhibited in the last several sessions.

It is encouraging to learn from public officials that New York's libraries, which suffered much throughout the depression and war years in depleted book stocks, deteriorating buildings and inadequate personnel, at last are at the point of being refurbished, expanded and restocked.

ST. LOUIS. May 10 (AP) -- Discussing the use of premium gasoline in automobiles, Julian J. Frey, general sales manager of the Ethyl Corporation, said today that the chances were about fifty-fifty that the car owner should use it if he wished for the best knock-free performance.
ROCHESTER, N. Y., May 10 (AP) -- Resignations of three members of the staff of The Danville, Ill., Commercial-News were accepted today, headquarters of the Gannett newspapers here announced.
BERLIN, May 10 -- Both the Russians and the Western powers moved today to free this besieged city from restrictions that have throttled it for nearly a year.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., May 10 -- The General Federation of Women's Clubs has played a part in preventing the "cold war" from becoming a shooting one, Mrs. J. L. Blair Buck, federation president, said tonight.
An article in THE TIMES of May 8 relates a story of Mayor O'Dwyer's appeal to sixty-nine visiting members of Congress for support of the currently proposed Housing Act of 1949.

Immediate ratification of the North Atlantic pact was urged last night in a resolution adopted by the Association of the Bar of the City of New York at its annual meeting. Three hundred members attended the session at the association's hall at 42 West Forty-fourth Street.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- The defense sought in vain today to find out what put the FBI on the trail of Judith Coplon and Valentine A. Gubitchev as spy suspects.

Judges of the juvenile courts throughout the country should be selected on the basis of their understanding of and affection for children, as is done in England, rather than by political appointments, it was urged yesterday by Mrs. Dermot Morrah, Justice of the Peace in the London juvenile courts and one of England's outstanding social workers.

Nationalization of the nation's railroads is inevitable in less than ten years unless subsidizing of the roads' competition is ended, William White, president of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad, told the annual meeting of stockholders here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- J. Edgar Hoover today rounded out twenty-five years as head of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and Congress paid tribute to his long service by proposing a school to help in his fight against juvenile delinquency.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 10 -- The university press, like the scholar, has left the cloister during a decade of achievement just ended to become an effective barometer of the nation's efforts toward peace and stability.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 10 -- A United Nations convention that would lay down for the first time in history an international law protecting the rights of correspondents and news agencies was approved here tonight by the Social Committee of the General Assembly.

It is no secret that energetic children can devise rainy-day diversions that sometimes distract adults. In the case of Mark Armstrong, who is not yet 3 years old, quite a few people in Brooklyn and, eventually the police, became involved yesterday in his childish pastime.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 10 -- Production of "Annie Get Your Gun" was halted today at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer because Judy Garland, star of the film, walked out at lunch time and did not return. A studio statement declared: "Miss Garland refused to report on the set of "Annie Get Your Gun" after lunch today and has been suspended from salary by the studio.

The Newspaper Guild of New York, CIO, announced yesterday that it had reached an oral agreement with T. O. Thackrey, editor and publisher of The Compass, new Manhattan daily newspaper, which will give its members a thirty-five-hour week and a $120 minimum for journeymen editorial workers.
Russian jam sessions on frequencies used by the Voice of America and British Broadcasting Corporation in Iron Curtain broadcasts combine a weird medley of sounds that drown out the speaker's voice.

LONDON, May 10 -- Foreign Ministers' deputies who have been discussing an Austrian peace treaty here for the last three months agreed this morning to suspend their discussions and to resume them "not later than June 25."

A means of penetrating the Iron Curtain which will not be impeded by jammed radio wavelenghts exists and should be used by United States information agencies. I believe that the American story told in sketch strips -- comic strip technique but decidedly not comic strips -- would be handed from person to person in country after country.

ST. LOUIS, May 10 -- Jack Dempsey, former heavyweight champion, announced today that he will be the sole promoter of Willie Pep's next title defense of the featherweight championship, possibly a return engagement with Sandy Saddler of New York.

PARIS, May 10 -- There are mounting indications that the dual machinery of Soviet foreign policy is seeking to prepare the ground-work for some form of over all settlement in all Western Europe with the United States, Britain and France.

A campaign for $200,000 was started last night at a dinner at the Rabbi Jacob Joseph School, 155 Henry Street, founded in 1900 as the first Yeshiva Day School in this country. The money is to be used to equip the new Joseph Golding High School, which was purchased in December to house the Rabbi Jacob Joseph School's high school department.

A new novel by John O'Hara, his first in nine years, has been scheduled for summer publication by Random House. "Rage to Live" is a story about a rich Pennsylvania family. It will be issued on Aug. 16, the fifteenth anniversary of the publication of his first book, "Appointment in Samarra."
The Giants' gay capers at the top of the National League flag race suffered a slight letdown yesterday but it wasn't anything the opposition had to offer that checked the rampant Polo Grounders.

Frank Hague's thirty-two-year reign as boss of Jersey City was broken last night when a record turn-out of voters decided to replace the present City Administration with a new one pledged to wipe out boss rule.

The shortest possible commitments in the purchase of men's and boy's clothing for fall will be the safest, W. R. Granger, divisional merchandise manager of Woodward Lathrop, Washington department store, told retailers yesterday. As chairman of the men's and boys' wear group of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, he presided at their luncheon meeting in the Statler Hotel.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 10 -- Dr. George P. Berry, associate dean of the School of Medicine and Dentistry at the University of Rochester, has been appointed dean of the Harvard Medical School, Dr. James B. Conant, president of Harvard, said tonight. The appointment is effective July 1.

In Asia, where the United States should be helping China resist communism, lies the Christian hope of the future of American democracy, Representative Walter H. Judd, Republican, of Minnesota, told a Protestant mission audience of 16,000 persons in Madison Square Garden last night.
In a letter Thomas Jefferson wrote to William Ludlow at the age of 81, he had this to say among other things:
