JACKSON, Miss., May 10 (UP) -- States' Rights Democrats, girding for elections in 1950, approved a platform today that would amend the Constitution to let the states control virtually everything except national defense. They declared for delegation to the states of police powers and all control civil-rights laws, education, election rules and wages and hours.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- Mrs. Lou Gehrig, widow of the former Yankee baseball star, pleaded with Congress today to help find a cure of the disease that killed her husband.
On the eve of the annual award dinner of the One World Award Committee, a controversy continued to grow yesterday about the management of the organization, dedicated to world peace and unity.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 10 -- Use of electric shock therapy as part of the treatment of 100 schizophrenic patients at the Westchester Division here of the New York Hospital produced results twice as successful as under earlier systems of treatment, the hospital said today in its annual report for 1948.

"Streets of Laredo," which arrives at the Paramount, is this morning's lone film newcomer. The Western, which was produced by Paramount and filmed in Technicolor, features William Holden, Macdonald Carey, William Bendix and Mona Freeman. Leslie Fenton directed and Robert Fellows produced from a screen play by Charles Marquis Warren and Lynn Root.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Robert A. Lovett, former Under-Secretary of State, has declined to accept the position of President of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- Farmers are getting a good start on the new crop season which already promises to produce a near-record wheat yield. The Department of Agriculture gave that summary today in a report which estimated the favorably progressing winter wheat crop at 1,021,476,000 bushels.
Gen. James Doolittle is quoted in your columns as saying substantially that this country "must be prepared physically, mentally, morally" to drop atomic bombs on Russian centers of industry.

Earnings of M. Lowenstein Sons, Inc., textile manufacturers, declined to $1,294,640, or $1.26 a common share, after taxes and preferred dividends in the first quarter of this year, from $4,629,511, or $4.54 a common share, in the 1948 period, Leon Lowenstein, board chairman, reported to stockholders at the annual meeting here yesterday.
LONDON, May 10 (AP) -- Frank Stranahan, who won the British amateur golf championship last year, and his predecessor, Willie Turnesa, may meet in the final round of the 1949 tournament.

IN the same graceful, effortless and unobtrusive way he played ball, Charlie Gehringer has eased himself into the Hall of Fame at Cooperstown. There was no fuss to it. That never was Charlie's way. He didn't even get elected on the original ballot by the baseball writers but was the first and only man ever chosen by a run-off poll.

Samuel Lemkin, union official and secret partner in a painting contracting concern, who was indicted on Monday on charges of cheating the city on redecorating jobs, resigned all his union connections yesterday.

PARIS, May 11 -- In a meeting at which Foreign Minister Robert Schuman reviewed the principal problems of foreign policy, the French Cabinet today approved and asked for early ratification of four measures.

This week Koreans have celebrated the first anniversary of the election out of which the Republic of Korea was formed. That was the ballot, under United Nations supervision, that was subsequently certified to have been fair and free. It made possible the formation and recognition of a Government entitled to a respected place in the family of nations.

Nell K. won filly-of-the-day honors at Belmont Park yesterday by leading a field of seventeen to the wire in the $19,150 Acorn Stakes. She was the $12.90-for-$2 third choice in the nineteenth running of the mil jaunt for 3-year-old fillies.

The United Nations General Assembly approved today, after prolonged and ineffectual debate, an amended Polish resolution deferring indefinitely consideration of proposals to make Russian and Chinese additional working languages of the world body.

A Lockheed P2V-2 Neptune patrol bomber, a 60,000-pound, twin-engined naval plane which holds the world's non-stop distance record and is capable of carrying the atomic bomb, is being prepared for experimental landings on a carrier's deck.

William Z. Foster, national chairman of the Communist party, called for the strengthening of party leadership last July in case of war between Soviet Russia and the United States, according to yesterday's testimony at the Communist trial.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The lifting of the Berlin blockade does not alone solve the German problem, Secretary of State Dean Acheson asserted today. He added that whether a solution could be reached at the meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers in Paris would depend on the Soviet stand.

The seven-game winning streak of the Giants ended yesterday. Getting only six hits off Howie Fox, they bowed to the Reds, 4 -- 2, before a chilled gathering of 5,260 at the Polo Grounds. It was the league-leading New Yorkers' first loss to a Western adversary.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended May 4:

Their ninth-inning rally falling short, the Dodgers dropped a 5-3 decision to the Pirates last night at Ebbets Field as Rex Barney again failed to go the route. It will be recalled that Billy Meyer's Corsairs gave the Brooks a lot of trouble last year and this first meeting of the current campaign went according to the old script, except that a rookie southpaw, Bill Werle, chilled the home side this time.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., May 11 -- The Rev. Brother William B. Cornelia, who founded Iona College here, will observe the fiftieth anniversary of his investiture as a religious Brother tomorrow. In the evening he will be the guest of 600 students, alumni, faculty members and trustees at a testimonial dinner.

The United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, CIO, has asked the General Motors Corporation to put a new "floor" under the sliding pay scale it set up in its unique wage agreements with the electrical union and the United Automobile Workers, CIO, a year ago.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 11 -- Dr. Morse A. Cartwright of Teachers College, Columbia University, was elected president today of the American Association for Adult Education at the closing session of the annual meeting here.

Harold Volk, president of Volk Brothers, Dallas, has been elected president of Shoes Associated, a group of eleven leading shoe stores throughout the country, it was made known here yesterday. During October, it was added, inspection tours for the interchange of ideas will be made to these member stores: Imperial Shoe Stores, New Orleans; Krupp Tuffly, Houston, and Volk Brothers, Dallas.

A two-story and two four-story store and apartment buildings at 782 Ninth Avenue, northeast corner of West Fifty-second Street, were sold by Bernard Realty Corporation to Arthur Meyer for investment in a deal reported yesterday by Samuel Gaumont, the broker.

Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer upheld yesterday the right of Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., to vote in the special election next Tuesday in the Twentieth Congressional District, in which he is the Liberal and Four Freedoms party candidate for Representative.

Price cuts on acetate filament yarn, averaging from 1 to 4 cents a pound, are not likely to stimulate purchases by weaving mills, according to textile men. In pricing their rayon goods, mill men said yesterday, they have anticipated reductions in yarn costs up to 10 cents a pound and were critical, therefore, of the "token" cuts made by rayon producers.

Domestic steel mills turned out 7,783,807 net tons of raw steel in April on operations averaging 98.4 per cent of ingot capacity, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. It was the first month this year that mill schedules were under 100 per cent, but the month's output represented a record yield for April.

Four new films will open in midtown theatres today. At the Victoria, the attraction is "Home of the Brave," and anti-Negro prejudice drama produced by Stanley Kramer and directed by Mark Robson from a screen play by Carl Foreman, and the play by Arthur Laurents.

LOS ANGELES, May 11 -- "Marie Antoinette in Pennsylvania,'' a new musical comedy with an eye on Broadway and considerable promise therefor, opened here last night under the auspices of Eugenie Leontovich at her tiny 121-seat Stage Theatre.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, May 11 -- Bonn will be ready to assume its status as capital of the Ger man Federal Republic sometime in August, Dr. Hermann Wandersleb, chief of the North Rhine-Westphalia chancellery here, said today.

HELMSTEDT, Germany, May 11 -- The Autobahn between Berlin and this British zone town is open again. If there had ever been anything wrong with the bridge over the River Elbe at Magdeburg, one could not tell it in crossing it after the blockade of Berlin was lifted this morning.
Eleven years ago today negotiations continued between the city and the transit companies for the purchase of the IRT and BMT subways by the city to unify New York's underground transportation.

Reflecting increased sales, net earnings of the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., and its subsidiaries rose to $12,762,467 in the first three months of this year from $10,415,705 in the corresponding quarter of 1948, Robert C. Stanley, chairman of the board, reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- In the face of President Truman's program for a $4,000,000,000 tax increase this year, Representative Robert L. Doughton, Democrat, of North Carolina, said after a White House visit today that he hoped there would be no increase at all.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Thomas B. McCabe, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, today urged Congress to extend the Board's authority over bank reserves and consumer installment credit. He said such action was needed if the Board was to have sufficient residual power to deal flexibly with deflationary as well as inflationary trends.
CAMDEN, N. J., May 11 (AP) -- E. B. Ryan's Touch Control, 4-year-old son of Okapi-Sun Monia, won the featured Haddonfield Purse in a driving finish at Garden State today.

Two faculty members of New York University's School of Education will be honored by alumni today on completion of twenty-five years' service. Associate Dean Ralph E. Pickett and Dr. Paul S. Lomax will receive plaques commemorating their achievement.
LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., May 11 -- Cloudy skies and cool breezes greeted the Women's Long Island Golf Association for their first one-day event of the season over the Piping Rock Club course today.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., May 11 -- The American Federation of Hosiery Workers voted today to return to the American Federation of Labor which it left fourteen years ago. The 200 delegates representing 50,000 members at the annual convention unanimously approved a resolution introduced by the union's executive board.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 11 -- Bobby Wolcott, veteran Tiger hurler, survived a rocky ninth inning as Princeton beat Cornell, 4 -- 3, for its fourth Eastern Intercollegiate League victory on University Field today.
LONDON, May 11 -- Emphasis on difficulties in export markets reduced business to minimum in the stock market here today. Except for isolated features little of interest was seen.

Sharp criticism of some of the public relations methods of the armed services was made here yesterday by John Reagan (Tex) McCrary, former New York newspaper editor and an Air Force public relations officer in World War II.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The outlook today for an executive board meeting of the Congress of Industrial Organizations next week was for a series of clashes between the political forces of the Right and the Left.

The "new" Truman farm program is in fact "old stuff." For the past sixteen years the Socialist schemers in the Department of Agriculture have been planning the complete regimentation of the American farmer and the socialization of the country as a whole.

Candy comes in a novel style in the Petit-Pies that Barton's Bonbonniere introduces today. The wedge - shaped chocolate - covered confections are arranged in round "pies" that are packed, four to one pound, in a flat box. It is the deliciousness of the pieces, though, as much as their unusual presentation that makes them so attractive.

Because Charles F. Maurice is only a volunteer in the Hospital for Special Surgery, at 321 East Forty-second Street, he has always tried to work harder than the doctors and nurses, whom he has assisted in the operating room since 1943.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Increasing purchasing power in the South is the principal reason for the growth of industry in that region, according to a study made public here today, and not the "cheap labor" that was once considered the region's prime asset. Income payments in the South were found to have risen 187 per cent since 1940, while those in the country as a whole rose only 150 per cent.

The consolation obtained by some Soviet Jews from their religion has been singled out for contemptuous treatment in connection with the campaign against "cosmopolitanism" in the Soviet Union, Russian newspapers received here disclosed.

Reporting on operations of the International Paper Company for the first quarter of this year, John H. Hinman, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday that the net profit was $13,814,831, equal to $3.82 a common share.

The Central Location Index that has found 50,000 persons in postwar Europe for relatives all over the world suspended operations yesterday. Its functions will now revert to the member agencies of the Index.

The United States Maritime Commission announced yesterday that it had invited fifteen shipyards to bid on the construction of a prototype merchant ship, which will be the basic model for large-scale shipbuilding in any future national emergency.

North Dakota sold yesterday $27,000,000 of tax-exempt veterans' bonus bonds due July 15, 1950 to 1958, to a banking syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., at an interest cost of 1.3397 per cent. The syndicate bid 100.318 on an interest basis of 1.40 per cent.

Contrary to the expectations of many persons, children of both sexes who have viewed a recently produced 16-mm film on sex education have responded with "a dignified, calm and casual attitude," Dr. Ruth Bochner, child psychologist who has screened the film for high school students in New Rochelle, declared yesterday.

Peck Peck, owners of forty-eight women's specialty shops in forty cities throughout the country, have leased the fifth and sixth floors of the Lumber Mutual Building at 260 Fourth Avenue. Cushman Wakefield, Inc., agents of the building, were the brokers in the transaction.

Southpaw Dick Weber, who has yet to be defeated in college baseball, hurled Rutgers to its first victory over Columbia on the Lions' diamond in thirty-seven years yesterday when he stopped the Lions, 4 -- 1, at Baker Field. The Scarlet junior registered the fourteenth consecutive triumph of his career and his seventh in the current campaign.
Over the Wykagyl Country Club course at New Rochelle today, sixteen top-flight golf professionals will start the eighth annual Goodall round-robin tourney that ends on Sunday.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- President Truman and organized labor are determined to press for the passage of the Administration labor relations bill with some amendments that will not cripple the national policy of encouraging free collective bargaining.

Both the Metropolitan Fair Rent Committee and one of its affiliates, the Real Estate Board of New York, registered dissatisfaction yesterday with the Housing Expediter's "fair net operating" income formula. William E. Russell, chairman, said the committee was prepared to institute a court action to nullify the 1949 Federal rent law that gave rise to the formula.

TOKYO, May 11 -- In his most eloquent speech since Japan's surrender, Premier Shigeru Yoshida tonight made a plea before the Tokyo Correspondence Club for world understanding that his nation today was not the Japan of ten years ago.

The Organization for European Economic Cooperation was urged yesterday to speed up plans for integration of the European economy by the United States Council of the International Chamber of Commerce, in a report issued here.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed steady, 1 point higher to 10 points lower.
Rex Stout, author and president the Friends of Democracy, expressed the belief last night that Germans would join with the Soviet Union to fight the United States if there should be war in Europe.

KANSAS CITY, May 11 (AP) -- Too many persons who are appointed to Federal office talk too much and listen too little, one of them said today. He was James K. Vardaman, a member of the Federal Reserve Board, who came here from Washington to talk to the Missouri Bankers Association.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- A new Argentine economic program designed to remove a number of trade restrictions and promote commerce with this country was officially laid before the State Department today.
WASHINGTON, May 11 (UP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board said today that fears concerning explosion of photographic flash bulbs carried in aircraft were groundless.
PARIS, May 11 -- Low, wide, softly cuffed necklines grace Robert Piguet's midsummer afternoon gowns in white ottoman, palest rose tussor, natural shantung, black or navy taffeta.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- British airwomen may fare better in their mess halls hereafter because of the first post-war interchange of information between the top women of the United States and United Kingdom Air Forces. Also, WAF's here may have a chance to learn more trades.

ST. LOUIS, May 11 -- Establishment by department stores of production goal programs was urged here today by Wayne C. Stokes, manager, credit and collection department, Marshall Field Co., Chicago. He spoke at the sixteenth annual convention of the credit management division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

SHANGHAI, May 11 -- Chinese and Russian negotiators in Urumchi have agreed to extend the Sino-Soviet airline concession in Sinkiang Province another five years, it was reported today by the official Central News Agency.

Henry Steele Commager, author, anthologist and Professor of History at Columbia University, has signed a contract with Bobbs-Merrill for a two-volume work on the Civil War as seen by participants. The work is scheduled for publication in 1950. Mr. Commager's recent book was "St. Nicholas Anthology," published last year.

Frank Roane, baritone, who won the second annual Concert Award of the American Theatre Wing Professional Training Program, will be presented in the debut recital constituting the award, Sunday, May 22, at 3 P. M., in Times Hall.

THOMAS MANN'S "The Magic Mountain" will probably always be held as a measuring stick against any novelist who writes about the still world of a tuberculosis sanitarium as inevitably as Tolstoy's "War and Peace" is used as a stick to beat any novelist who threatens to write a great war novel. (The "Peace" part of the title, ironically enough, is generally overlooked, come to think of it.)

SHANGHAI, May 11 -- It was reported tonight that the Nationalist Government is considering a withdrawal from the Hankow-Yangtze line because of Communist advances toward Changsha, which is on the rail route south from Hankow.

MINEOLA, L. I., May 11 -- A newly developed type of radar equipment aided the all-weather operation of the Berlin airlift, Dr. H. R. Skifter declared here today. He is president of the Airborne Instrument Laboratory, Inc., maker of the apparatus.

A man who has identified himself as Gerhart Eisler, native of Germany, is fleeing from the United States aboard the Gdynia-America liner Batory, it became known yesterday. The fugitive is believed to be the former Comintern agent named by the House Un-American Activities Committee as America's No. 1 Communist, jumping $23,500 bail to escape serving a year in jail and other penalties, but his identity has not yet been definitely established.

HELMSTEDT, Germany, Thursday, May 12 -- A smiling Russian captain motioned the vehicles of a British military convoy past the highway checkpoint here last night after only a cursory perusal of documents and waved them on to Berlin.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Child research was advocated as a means of lessening "stresses and strains on civilization" by J. Donald Kingsley, Assistant Federal Security Administrator, as hearings opened today on the National Child Research Bill.

Eighty-eight per cent of 2,000 industrial concerns throughout the nation are not contemplating "plant expansion now or in the discernible future," according to Herbert I. Segal, president of the Asset Realization Company of Newark, N. J.
An appeal for registered nurses to fill 2,000 vacancies in the city's thirty municipal hospitals was made yesterday by Dr. Marcus D. Kogel, Hospitals Commissioner.

With negotiations still in progress, one of the greatest monopolies in the boxing promotion field will result if the newly allied Madison Square Garden Corporation and International Boxing Club succeed in absorbing the Tournament of Champions, Inc., it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- Bogdan Raditsa, a former Yugoslav Embassy official here, said today that Communist agents were making "regular visits" to the United States under the protection of diplomatic immunity to help prepare for "world revolution."
CLEVELAND, May 11 -- The Yankee invasion of the West ended on a sour note tonight in the frigid atmosphere of expansive Municipal Stadium.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- A large audience assembled to celebrate the first anniversary of the birth of Israel tonight hailed the news that the new Jewish state had been admitted to the United Nations.

LONDON, May 11 -- Governor Thomas E. Dewey of New York today advised the Western powers that in preparing to enter negotiations with the Soviet Union on the problem of Germany they should be "wary of bear traps." The former Republican candidate for President, speaking at a press conference in London, said:

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The division of public utilities of the Securities and Exchange Commission recommended today that the SEC reject a plan of the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation, Syracuse, N. Y., which provides, in part, for the merger of certain of the company's subsidiaries and a split of the new operating company's stock.
The board of directors of Youthbuilders, Inc., asked the City Council yesterday to delete or transfer budgeted funds allotted to the Youthbuilder program in the city's public schools.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, May 111 -- Anti - Leopoldist newspapers, commenting on the interview with the exiled Belgian King published in THE NEW YORK TIMES, said today former King Leopold had retracted his promise to stay outside party politics and the coming election campaign.

Foreign Minister Moshe Sharett, standing at the rostrum of the General Assembly as the first Israeli delegate to the United Nations, gave his country's promise last night to work for peace with its Arab neighbors and for friendship with the United States and the Soviet Union.

The smashing defeat of Frank Hague in Jersey City marks the almost miraculous end of a thirty-two-year era in politics. In thirty-six years the boss had never lost an election. His ability to "deliver" the vote in Hudson County had become a fabulous byword in national and state elections.

BUFFALO, N. Y., May 11 -- Dean Walter Henry Wright of the New York University College of Dentistry told members of the New York State Dental Society today that their major problem was in the field of "prevention." Two thousand dentists are here for the eighty-first annual meeting.

CHICAGO, May 11 -- The grain markets on the Board of Trade showed a strong undertone the greater part of today. May wheat acted tight and advanced 1 7/8 cents a bushel at one time in sympathy with Minneapolis, where the current delivery was up 4 1/2 cents at the extreme and closed with a net gain of 4 1/4 cents.
WASHINGTON, May 11 (UP) -- John L. Lewis actually is not a gruff old man, but a lovable character who gets along fine with children.

The enthusiasm of youth sat lightly on the shoulders of old people yesterday. They were buoyant, their eyes sparkled and they were intent on talk of handicrafts as the Third Annual Hobby Show for Older Persons opened in the American Museum of Natural History, Seventy-seventh Street and Central Park West.

The political coalition that dethroned Frank Hague as boss of Jersey City has decided to seek a court order barring the outgoing city administration from destroying or altering official records before it leaves office next Tuesday.

Eight plastering contractors and their association, the Brooklyn Plastering Contractors Association, Inc., of 100 Flatbush Avenue, pleaded guilty yesterday before Judge Louis Goldstein in Kings County Court to a misdemeanor charge of violating the General Business Law.

More than half the Jewish displaced persons admitted to this country since Oct. 30 entered under the auspices of the Hebrew Sheltering and Immigrant Aid Society, it was announced yesterday. Of 6,169 Jewish DP arrivals, HIAS reported handling 3,503 cases.

After many months of experience with its social welfare program of services for children and youth in New York's areas of greatest need, the New York City Youth Board announced yesterday its plans for attacking the juvenile delinquency problem on a broad front in the fiscal year 1949-50.

Raymond Fernandez and Mrs. Martha Beck, who are now in the Nassau County Jail at Mineola, L. I., will be tried in Bronx County on the first-degree murder indictment against them growing out of the slaying of Mrs. Janet Fry, 60 years old, a widow, in Valley Stream, L. I., last Jan. 4.

For the first time in ten months the noise of rail and motor traffic was heard last night on the long-silent highways leading into Berlin. But this almost-forgotten sound did not drown out the familiar drone of the loaded planes flying on the usual three-minute schedule into the three airfields in the Western sectors.

The Dessoff Choirs, under Paul Boepple, presented a program of baroque music, ranging from Palestrina to Bach, last night at Town Hall. All of the offerings on the carefully chosen schedule were masterpieces of choral writing and the chorus reached new heights in its delivery of them.

MOSCOW, May 11 -- The authoritative foreign affairs journal, the New Times, suggested today that the Paris Council of Foreign Ministers meeting might become a "turning point" in the post-war deadlock of great powers.

CHICAGO, May 11 -- Donald B. Lourie, president of Quaker Oats Company, today labeled Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan's plan of guaranteed income for farmers "a sugar-coated socialistic pill." He spoke at the annual convention of the Super Market Institute, Inc.

Dissension among the higher echelons of the American motion-picture industry appeared yesterday to be leading toward a major crisis when some details leaked out concerning secret trade proposals discussed at the Joint Anglo-American Film Council meeting last month in Washington.

BERLIN, Thursday, May 12 -- Just as the morning sun rose over the jagged skyline of this broken but defiant city a Soviet zone locomotive chugged wearily into the Charlottenburg Station in the British sector hauling the first train to reach Berlin from the West in 328 days.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson declared today that the question of restoring full diplomatic relations with Spain turned primarily upon the attitude of Western European countries that were still opposed to bringing her back into their international family for military and economic cooperation.

The proposal to designate an impartial chairman for the private transit industry will be discussed by Mayor O'Dwyer today with spokesmen for the city's privately operated bus and street-car lines and union leaders representing their employes.

The downward spiral in the stock market was arrested yesterday as the steel issues reversed the recent trend and lent steadiness to most major sections. The recovery was selective, however, and was accompanied by only fractional gains and a slight increase in business.

In the first seventeen days of the 1949 campaign the Greater New York Fund has received 33 1/2 per cent in cash gifts toward its $8,000,000 goal, or almost 50 per cent of the total contributions last year, John D. Rockefeller 3d, citywide campaign chairman, announced yesterday at the first report luncheon at the Roosevelt Hotel.

Traditional furniture made by modern assembly-line methods so that the pieces can be offered in a medium-price range was shown yesterday at the Ambassador Hotel by two North Carolina companies, Henredon of Morganton and Heritage of High Point and Mocksville.

Martin L. Straus II, chairman and founder of Eversharp, Inc., announced last night withdrawal of his name from a management slate for re-election as a director. He charged that the proxy statement sent to stockholders by the proxy committee contained false and misleading statements and that therefore he could not be a candidate for re-election on that slate.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The Keller Motors Corporation, Huntsville, Ala., which expects to produce an automobile to sell in the "lowest possible price field," filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 5,000,000 shares of 3 cents par value common stock.

John Huston, the motion picture director, received last night the One World Award, which will take him on a global tour during which he intends to make a documentary film that he hopes will further the cause of peace.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- In a sharply critical and semi-offical study of the Government's relations with the mining industry, a consultant to the National Security Resources Board contended today that drastic manpower controls, assigning "every usable person to the job where he or she is most needed," would be necessary in the event of another war.

The contents of yesterday's critical notices on "Gayden" were of a sort to convince Gant Gaither, producer of the Mignon and Robert McLaughlin play, to retire the attraction after Saturday night's performance, the seventh. The production made its local debut at the Plymouth Theatre on Tuesday evening and brought back to Broadway and the legitimate stage Fay Bainter, who in the last decade confined most of her playing activities to the films.

The controversy between the Port of New York Authority and the airlines over the use of New York International Airport at Idlewild moved a step closer to settlement yesterday in the chambers of Justice Thomas J. Cuff of the Supreme Court in Jamaica.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- Following is the text, as edited and transcribed by the State Department, of Secretary Dean Acheson's extemporaneous answer today to questions on United States policy toward Spain:

As a result of my early training, as well as mature inclination, I have always given dutiful consideration to the editorial pages of THE NEW YORK TIMES. Having grown up in a little town in what was then known as "Oklahoma Territory," this source of information and culture always reached us about four or five days late -- but we were persistent.
DETROIT, May 11 (AP) -- The Senators achieved the ninth straight victory of their Western trip as they pummeled the Tigers, 11 to 1, today.
ELECTRA, Tex., May 11 (AP) -- It looks as if everybody in Electra will turn out to meet the Fort Worth and Denver Railroad's Zephyr on Friday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., May 11 -- Record-breaking attendance despite unfavorable weather at the eighteenth National Packaging Exposition now under way here in Convention Hall was attributed by industry leaders to a strong desire to lower production costs and increase sales through improved packaging, packing and shipping of both industrial and consumer goods.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The United States was reported today to have under consideration a plan under which all occupation troops in Germany would be withdrawn into restricted areas at the North German ports.

It is not every day a Russian publication makes a statement about the United States that we in this country are able to endorse even in part. It was with considerable interest, therefore, that the dispatch from our Moscow correspondent, Harrison E. Salisbury, was received the other day in which he reported on what the Soviet weekly, Krokodil, had to say about a thriving American resort known as Coney Island.

A quick, safe and relatively effective therapy for functional mental illness was described before a staff conference at Creedmoor State Hospital in Queens yesterday afternoon with medical evidence, gathered during a three-year trial period, that it can "markedly reduce" the number of mental patients requiring hospitalization.

An ex-GI and a Coast Guardsman plunged into the East River off Pier 11 near Old slip a little after 7 o'clock last night to rescue Eileen Kellar, 19 years old, of 331 East Ninety-second Street who had jumped into the water. She was taken to Bellevue Hospital for observation and treatment.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., May 11 -- Compulsory health insurance was branded as "another step in the creation of a Socialist state" in a resolution presented today by the Woman's Club of Orange to delegates of the New Jersey State Federation of Women's Clubs in convention here.

Liquor retailers who made sales here yesterday at prices below fair trade minimums were in violation of the law, according to the State Liquor Authority. Despite the fact that this mandatory law was declared unconstitutional Tuesday by the Appellate Division of the New York State Supreme Court, the Authority says the law is still in force because they have not yet received official notification of the decision.

The annual 500-mile Indianapolis Speedway race on Monday, May 30, will be covered by Mutual in four separate broadcasting periods. From 11:45 A. M. to 12:15 P. M., Bill Slater and Gene Kelly will describe the start of the thirty-three-car race around the two-and-a-half-mile brick-paved oval.
Two large group shows opening this week find younger painters and sculptors staking their claims to individual artistic identity.

Vladimir Drozdoff, who gave a recital last night in Times Hall, is a pianist of the older school and the grander manner. Playing, among other works, a Glazunoff Prelude and Fugue, compositions of Chopin, his own "Sonata Elegia" and two movements, by request, from another sonata by himself, he sometimes forced more tone than his piano could conveniently bear, and was not always precise in his treatment of his text.

BOSTON, May 11 (AP) -- A 31-year-old Coast Guard lieutenant -- officer of the watch aboard the cutter Eastwind the night thirteen of her crew were killed in a collision with a tanker off New Jersey -- was convicted today by a court martial on two of four charges.

The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation has started an examination of several large New York banks -- the first such checkup in this area since the agency was established in 1933 -- it was learned yesterday. A representative sampling of banks will be made, it is understood, including state and national institutions, non-members of the Federal Reserve, as well as members.

DETROIT, May 11 -- The name and prestige of Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, were injected by indirection today into the strike against the Ford Motor Company by the United Automobile Workers, a CIO affiliate.

LONDON, May 11 -- Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin said today that the British Government desired that the embargo on shipment of British arms to Arab states be lifted "as soon as peace and tranquillity are reasonably well established."

SHAWNEE ON DELAWARE, Pa., May 11 -- Textile men heard a management official assert that 100 per cent cooperation with a union had been the salvation of the clothing industry in Rochester. The occasion was the labor-management forum of the Philadelphia Textile Institute's national seminar.

The administration of the Zionist Organization of America and the Committee for Progressive Zionism, which have been opposed to each other on matters of policy, announced jointly yesterday that "considerable progress" has been made toward agreement as the result of several joint conferences.

Two leaders of Jewish groups in this country which have played a leading part in agitating for the admission of Israel to the United Nations issued statements last night hailing her entrance into the world body.

WASHINGTON, May, 11 -- The Communist party of the United States, through a statement filed by its general secretary, Eugene Dennis, likened the North Atlantic treaty today to "Hitler's Axis," and demanded that the Senate withhold any action toward its ratification until after the Big Four Foreign Ministers' conference.
ST. LOUIS, May 11 (AP) -- Jack Graham doubled twice, batting in two runs and scoring twice, to lead the Browns to a 5-to-4 victory over the Athletics tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- A House subcommittee is holding long daily sessions to determine whether the cause of international aviation would be advanced by a bill subjecting international freight rates of United States overseas airlines to the control of the Civil Aeronautics Board.

GENEVA, May 11 -- A gloomy picture of an unhealthy European economy suffering from underproduction in the West and underdevelopment in the East was drawn today by Eastern European delegates before the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe.

STONINGTON, Conn., May 11 (AP) -- Four persons were killed late today when an automobile in which they were riding was struck by an east bound New Haven Railroad train, the Yankee Clipper, at Burdick's Lane crossing, 100 yards from the Rhode Isand-Connecticut line.

BERLIN, May 11 -- Two leaders of the Bonn Parliamentary Council turned down today the latest proposal from Russian zone Communists for a meeting to prepare a joint memorandum to the forth-coming meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers.

Mayor O'Dwyer declared yesterday that he would not sign local legislation to increase taxicab fares without first obtaining from taxicab fleet operators "assurances and guarantees" that they would grant improved wages and working conditions to their employes.
WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today authorized the absorption of the Kansas City, St. Louis Chicago Railroad into the Gulf, Mobile Ohio Railroad Company system.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- Reports of an abrupt break-up of a Republican parley on finances were met with a denial today by the GOP chairman, Representative Hugh Scott, that any hard feelings were involved.

Plans for 107 one-family homes containing four and one-half rooms were announced yesterday in connection with the purchase from Salisbury Manor, Inc., by Clearmeadow Homes, Inc., of twenty-five acres of land on both sides of Fifth and Sixth Streets, between Front Street and Prospect Avenue, in Eastmeadow.

Coffee futures turned strong on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Demand by local trade houses and short covering advanced prices for contract "S" 20 to 35 points. The near-by delivery positions were the strongest feature. New high levels were established in several positions, with the spot May selling at a high record for coffee futures.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The House, reviving a 1948 campaign issue that is regarded by some as the main factor in the Republicans' loss of the farm vote, passed today a bill giving the Government broad authority to acquire storage facilities for crops.

Voice of America officials cited yesterday the text of a broadcast from Moscow made in English on Tuesday evening and beamed at North America, as evidence that British Broadcasting Corporation and Voice broadcasts to Russia were getting through despite intensive Soviet jamming of the frequencies used by the two.

TEHERAN, Iran, May 11 -- The seven-year plan for the economic development of the entire country fat a cost of $656,000,000 entered the stage of real organizational work today following confirmation last night by the Shah, Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, of the personnel of the seven-man board of directors.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- What the deficit from passenger services of Class I steam railways does to net operating railway income was indicated today by the Interstate Commerce Commission. Net railway operating income from freight service in 1948 was reported at $1,561,200,000 and the deficit in net railway operating income from passenger service was set at $559,900,000, these were the highest figures ever reached in rail history, the ICC said.
The Community Service Society reported yesterday that its family counseling and health programs had aided 27,426 families in the fiscal year 1947-48, a year marked by its 100th anniversary.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson welcomed today the signing by the western European governments of the Statute for the Council of Europe as a "step forward toward the political integration of the free nations of Europe."
MOSCOW, May 11 (UP) -- The magazine Bolshevik denounced today two Russian historians as "homeless cosmopolitans" guilty of "national nihilism" and "fawning before foreign things."
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Latest proposals by the Air Force to conform to armed service policy on racial equality were approved today by Louis Johnson, Secretary of Defense.

A thousand persons attended a testimonial dinner last night at the Astor Hotel in honor of Harvey Rosen, former secretary of the New York Fire Department. The dinner was sponsored by the National Committee for Labor Israel as a testimonial to Mr. Rosen, who had given considerable aid as a public official to Histadrut, Israel's labor federation.

BOSTON, May 11 (AP) -- Lefty Warren Spahn gained his fourth victory of the season, plus his second shutout, for the Braves by blanking the Cardinals, 7 -- 0, with a three-hit performance tonight before a crowd of 14,419. The tribe clinched matters with a five-run uprising in the first inning.

A decline of 1,387,000 barrels in the week ended May 7, put the nation's stocks of gasoline at 123,400,000 barrels, the American Petroleum Institute announced yesterday. Light fuel oil stocks increased 1,414,000 barrels to 51,373,000, and stocks of heavy fuel oil rose by 850,000 barrels to a total of 61,024,000.

Edward G. Budd Jr., president of the Budd Company, told stockholders at their annual meeting yesterday in Philadelphia that he expects to "have a good year with larger sales and profits than in 1948," barring labor troubles or a business collapse.

The fatal stabbing of a special organizer for the International Ladies Garment Workers Union provides shocking new support for long-standing union charges that gangster elements have again obtained a foothold in the New York garment industry. These charges were first made last September when thugs invaded the headquarters of the union's Dress Joint Board in West Fortieth Street and beat three organizers with chairs and brass knuckles.

The Cliffs, forty-three-acre estate held by the Beekman family for more than a century, has been purchased by Clendenin J. Ryan from the Beekman Family Association, it was announced yesterday by Douglas L. Elliman Co., the brokers in the sale.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 11 -- The Government of the United States will "welcome the opportunity to negotiate bilateral agreements" with underdeveloped countries throughout the world to remove sources of fear deterring private capitalists from investing their funds in development projects in such regions.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 11 -- India announced tonight that she would press for changes in the United Nations' news-gathering convention when the newly drafted press pact comes up before the General Assembly, probably tomorrow.

CHICAGO, May 11 (AP) -- The White Sox scored in every inning today to blast Boston, 12 -- 8, while climbing back to a .500 percentage in the American League with their eleventh victory in twenty-two games.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The new veterans pension bill was further watered down in committee today -- to such an extent that its author, Representative John E. Rankin, Democrat, of Mississippi, voted, though in vain, against reporting it to the House.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (UP) -- Jesse M. Donaldson, Postmaster General, agreed today to a "compromise" increase in second and third class mail rates if it came from Congress and not magazine and newspaper publishers.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- New York grain exporters urged today that railway freight rates on grain from Great Lakes points be equalized to all North Atlantic ports. They told an Interstate Commerce Commission examiner that a differential of one-half cent on each 100 pounds in favor of Philadelphia and Baltimore causes grain to flow to those ports.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., May 11 -- A new class for flower arrangements that emphasized the relationship between flowers and room settings won enthusiastic praise from local garden club members at the spring flower show held here today by the Matinecock Garden Club of Glen Cove.

BERLIN, Thursday, May 12 -- The first western passenger train since last year arrived in Berlin at 5:11 A. M. today (11:11 P. M. Wednesday, Eastern Daylight Time) -- hauled by a Soviet zone locomotive.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Every time a cosmic truth about the scope of the North Atlantic Pact is uttered in the hearings before the Committee on Foreign Relations, some earnest friends of the proposed alliance wring their hands and prophesy that the statement will deeply discourage the European parties to the contract.

A reward of $25,000 was offered yesterday by the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, AFL, for information leading to the arrest and conviction of the murders of William Lurye, a special organizer for the union.
Is it necessary to the cause of democracy to have sound trucks blaring through residential areas of this city during the evenings of an election campaign?

Samuel Rubel, immigrant youth who started his fabulous career as a peddler of coal and became head of the Rubel Corporation, the Ebling Brewery and other corporations, left an estate of $8,000,000 when he died at Sunset Hall, his country estate in Ridgefield, Conn., on April 29, last.

The United States liner America and the British-flag Cunard White Star liner Queen Elizabeth, largest vessels in their respective merchant marines, arrived here yesterday within a few hours of each other carrying a combined passenger complement of 2,684.
LONDON, May 11 -- Only twelve members of the British House of Commons voted tonight against the bill that caused such a fit of Irish temper in the Dublin Parliament last night.

The F. W. Woolworth Company has scheduled a special series of ads in 325 newspapers of 216 store cities, it was announced yesterday. The company, already a user of newspaper advertising in connection with store openings, will use the campaign as a test designed to gain experience in the advertising of branded merchandise, a spokesman said.
WEST POINT, N. Y., May 11 -- Army recorded its initial victory in the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League today by routing Yale, 13 to 4, at Doubleday Field.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 11 -- An Indian resolution to create a commission for the study of the treatment of Indians in South Africa and to submit a report, along with recommendations for a solution, to the next General Assembly was passed by the United Nations Political Committee today.

BERLIN, May 11 -- The light of freedom kindled by the people of blockaded Berlin may inspire all Germany to fight against the rise of any dictatorial power in the future, Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor, said in an interview today.

A three-point program for manpower control in wartime economic mobilization was suggested yesterday by Col. George A. Harvey of the Army in a lecture to business executives and reserve officers attending a course in economic mobilization being given by the Armed Forces Industrial College at 30 Rockefeller Plaza.
WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- Judith Coplon lost a new bid for freedom today in the midst of her thirteen-day-old espionage trial.

National Airlines yesterday signed an agreement with Pan American Airways and Panagra (Pan American Grace Airways) to make effective the plan for interchange of equipment and to give PAA a 30 per cent stock interest in National.

Latent resentment among British natural rubber producers over the growth and maintenance of a synthetic rubber industry in the United States has cropped up again in London. At the annual meeting of the United Sua Betong Rubber Estates, Ltd., Sir John Hay, chairman of the company, told shareholders that there was general suspicion among natural rubber growers that the synthetic industry was being used to keep prices for natural rubber to a relatively low level.

The Home Line, which will operate the famous old liners Matsonia and Kungsholm, now renamed the Atlantic and the Italia, between the Mediterranean and New York, has completed arrangements with the Cunard White Star Line for use of Pier 54, North River as a terminal, it was announced yesterday by the Cosmopolitan Shipping Company, agents for the Home Line.
Dr. Sydney Norton Baruch, consultant engineer for the Air Force, demonstrated yesterday here a mechanical crib, "Night Nurse," that he has invented for rocking and crooning babies to sleep.

Maximilian Moss, a lawyer and an able man, with the further qualification of being a close friend for many years of Mayor O'Dwyer, has been elected president of the Board of Education. He succeeds Andrew G. Clauson Jr., also an able man, who has served as president since May, 1946.

VIENNA, May 11 -- The Austrian Parliament today unanimously adopted a resolution calling on the great powers, in connection with lifting of the Berlin blockade and resumption of attempts to achieve world peace, to grant a peace treaty to Austria.
The General Assembly admitted Israel to membership in the United Nations at 7:28 last night by a vote of 37 to 12, with nine abstentions.

A 66-year-old mail clerk with forty-two years' service in the Post Office was sentenced to a year and a day in prison in Federal Court yesterday for stealing $4,500 from letters in the last ten years.
WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican, of Ohio, called on the State Department today to "shake loose from its Communist-front philosophy" and grant full recognition to Spain.

Three letters from as many shippers complaining that they were unable to use Isbrandtsen Steamship Company, Inc., vessels because of conference restrictions, were introduced into a Maritime Commission hearing yesterday morning.

NAGS HEAD, N. C., May 11 -- It is difficult to know just what form of fishing to pick on a bright day down here, for you can go after black bass on Currituck, get a boat and go outside the mouth of the inlet for blues and channel bass, or run the beach hoping for some surf casting on blues or bass.

Israel, the fifty-ninth and latest member of the United Nations, is planning to cast her vote against the four-power resolution that would permit sending Ambassadors and Ministers to Madrid, it was learned yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 11 -- Michael Wilding, English actor who is row in Hollywood on a visit, has been signed by Warner Brothers to return to London for the leading role opposite Jane Wyman in "Stage Fright." Wilding, who arrived here Saturday, will go back to England next week to prepare for the picture, which Alfred Hitchcock will direct for Warners starting about June 1.
City College's six-game winning streak in the Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference came to an end yesterday and the Beavers dropped into a tie for the loop leadership with St. John's.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The second day of hearings in the House on the Administration's fair employment practice bill produced recurrent appeals today for a bipartisan effort to push it through to passage.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- David E. Lilienthal, chairman of the United States Atomic Energy Commission, said after a White House visit today that the commission would make power from atomic energy a reality in about four and a half years but not cheaply enough to compete with electric power.
PHILADELPHIA, May 11 (AP) -- The Chicago Cubs came from behind tonight to defeat the Phillies, 4 -- 2, and hand Ken Heintzelman his first loss in five decisions this season.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The Republican drive in the Senate for cutbacks in governmental spending suffered an abrupt and decisive setback today. In three voting tests, the Senate rejected a second attempt to reduce departmental and agency funds for the coming fiscal year at least 5 per cent.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 11 -- Disputes arising under the Draft International Covenant on Human Rights will be referred to specially constituted fact-finding panels empowered to decide on the merits of the case and make recommendations to states party to the treaty, according to a United States proposal to be laid before the current session of the Human Rights Commission of the United Nations Economic and Social Council.

LONDON, May 12 -- Reports that the United States Government is considering a plan to regroup all occupation forces in Germany into restricted areas around the north German ports and in France met with noticeable reserve in British official circles here today.

Net income of the Cities Service Company for the quarter ended on March 31 was $6,849,991, equal to $1.85 a share, compared with $6,228,819, or $1.68 a share, in the comparable 1948 period, the company reported yesterday.

Prevalence of Indians The schoolroom would be a somber place if there were no Indians. If there were no Indians, the schoolroom would have no more than the unrelieved tedium of blackboards and, in the afternoon, the printed page which jumps and shimmers just this side of sleep.

Action by the Board of Estimate cleared yesterday the way for ultimate development of the north shore of Jamaica Bay as a vast park region, as favored by Park Commissioner Robert Moses, and ended any possibility that these lands might some time be developed for industrial and seaport purposes.
Engineering details of the new superliner to be built for the United States Lines will remain secret indefinitely as far as William Francis Gibbs is concerned.

Six weeks ago the House of Representatives rejected a bill (offered by Mr. Rankin of Mississippi) which in its original form proposed to pay a pension of $90 a month for the rest of his life to every veteran of either World War upon his reaching the age of 65.
Richard (Pancho) Gonzales, national tennis champion from Los Angeles, will arrive in New York Monday and leave the same day for Paris aboard a Pan American airliner.
New York's first commercial helicopter base will be opened at Pier 41, East River, near Gouverneur Street, next Wednesday by the Metropolitan Aviation Corporation, it was announced here yesterday.

HOBOKEN, N. J., May 12 (AP) -- John L. McCaffrey, president of the International Harvester Company, today told the annual stockholders meeting the company's production and sales had reached the highest levels in its history.
LIMA, Peru, May 12 (UP) -- Discovery of a large "terrorist arsenal," allegedly belonging to the outlawed Apra party, was reported by the police today.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The President at his press conference today bid for a reputation which it is doubtful contemporary opinion or history will accord him. He said he had always been for "rigid economy" and pointed to his budget for fiscal 1949 as an example.
CHAPEL HILL, N. C., May 12 (UP) -- Hans Freistadt admitted today that he was a Communist Party member but said, "I consider myself a loyal citizen of this country."

The airy, translucent draperies that Ben Rose showed yesterday at the Berkshire Hotel should prove welcome to homemakers seeking summer decorating ideas. Four of this designer's well-known linear motifs have been used on white Celanese ninon.
Helen Keller, blind author and lecturer, received yesterday a citation of merit from the Palestine Lighthouse at a luncheon in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
Eleven years ago today, Mexico severed diplomatic relations with Great Britain following the British protest of the expropriation of British - owned oil property.

OCEANPORT, N. J., May 12 -- From a $1-a-day race-track laborer to one of the East's leading turf figures -- this has been the rise in the thoroughbred racing world of Edward J. Brennan, who yesterday observed his thirtieth anniversary as a racing official.

Charging that Washington is "dragging its feet" in the release from export control of goods in plentiful supply here, the Overseas Automotive Club yesterday went on record in favor of action by the Office of International Trade in expanding its recent list of 500 items to 2,500 or 3,000 which would not require an export license.

St. John's University routed Kings Point yesterday at Dexter Park, 17 to 2, to take first place undisputed in the Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference as City College, which shared the lead, was idle.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 12 -- Indications abound that some Latin-American supporters of the four-power resolution to permit the sending of ambassadors and ministers to Madrid will feel themselves free to send them anyway should their resolution fail to receive the requisite two-thirds majority in the General Assembly of the United Nations.

DETROIT, May 12 (AP) -- The Washington Senators' nine-game winning streak ended here today as right-hander Virgil Trucks and Second Baseman Don Kolloway of the Detroit Tigers played leading roles in a 2-1 Tiger victory.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Despite the willingness of some labor leaders to make concessions beyond the Administration labor relations bill, President Truman took a firm stand today against compromise.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Statutory responsibility for strategic planning of the nation's defense would be placed on the Joint Chiefs of Staff under the terms of the unification bill reported to the Senate today by its Armed Services Committee.
On May 5 Senator McMahon challenged Henry Wallace to produce documentation in support of Mr. Wallace's charges of aggressive attitude toward Russia in the negotiation of the proposed Atlantic Treaty.

Four six-meter yachts from this country are to be shipped abroad to race for the British-American Cup and the Scandinavian Gold Cup. It will be a quartet from the Seawanhaka Corinthian Club in Oyster Bay, L. I.

DENVER, May 12 (AP) -- A special three-judge court ruled today that the Colorado Southern Railway Company does not owe income taxes, or excess-profit taxes, for 1942 and 1943. The ruling rejected a United States Government claim for $3,001,061.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 12 -- Levi Jackson, the Negro captain of Yale's football team, became a member today of one of the campus' six elect secret societies of carefully winnowed membership. He was one of ninety undergraduates "tapped" for the honor among a junior class of about 1,400 and was the first member of his race chosen for one of the societies.

The hearings before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee have already demonstrated that the North Atlantic Treaty commands the support of a great variety of representatives of American public opinion, ranging from conservative Republicans to Socialists. In fact, the only outright opposition to the Treaty appears to be confined to a strange medley of die-hard isolationists, well-meaning but politically innocent pacifists, and the pro-Soviet factions of the Communists and their fellow-travelers.

On her week-end shopping tour the housewife will find that a few fresh foods in just about every category are lower in price than they were last Friday. The consumers' service division of the New York City Department of Markets has found in its survey of retail groceries that tariffs are down on eggs, several meat cuts, strawberries, ducks, broilers and fryers, and a number of vegetables.

FRANKFORT, Germany, May 12 -- The United States, Britain and France through their military governors approved tonight the draft constitution for the West German state adopted by the Bonn Parliamentary Council.

New York improved its lead as the state with the largest number of industrial establishments, according to the preliminary industry report of the 1947 Census of Manufactures, released today. It reported 47,701 establishments in New York, employing 1,777,000 persons, with $5,278,000,000 total salaries and wages for the year.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., May 12 -- The Eastman School's nineteenth annual festival of American music ended on a highly dramatic note tonight with a performance of Dr. Howard Hanson's "The Lament for Beowulf," presented with the composer conducting the Eastman Senior School Symphony Orchestra and chorus.

STAMFORD, Conn., May 12 -Twelve years ago the Stamford Museum began in a single room of a bank building in the heart of the city's business district. The institution, now housed in twelve rooms set in eight acres of Courtland Park off the Boston Post Road, has developed an appeal to all ages, all socal groups and every intellectual level in this community.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- After applauding two speeches calling for economy, the House voted without opposition today to give its members more money for clerk hire and communications expenses.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- Railroads serving Philadelphia and Baltimore opposed today proposals to take from them a differential under other North Atlantic ports in the movement of export grain from Great Lakes points.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Alfred J. Marrow, director of research of the Harwood Manufacturing Company, a New York textile concern, urged approval today of the $7,500,000 national child research bill as a first step in making productive those persons who cannot hold jobs.

Today's events: Symphony concert, conducted by Wheeler Beckett, Centenary Singers, Carnegie Hall, 3:30 o'clock; Consuelo Cloos, mezzo-soprano, Times Hall, 8:30; Festival of Contemporary Music, chamber music concert, Frederick Fennell, conductor.
SHANGHAI, Friday, May 13 (AP) -- Airline pilots today reported that they had seen small arms fire a scant ten miles from Shanghai's main airport.

The request by the State Liquor Authority for a stay of execution against the ruling invalidating mandatory fair trade was denied last night. The refusal was made by Presiding Justice David W. Peck of the Appellate Division, which had ruled two sections of the law unconstitutional last Tuesday.

The property at 46-54 Broad Street, northwest corner of Caldwell Place, in Elizabeth, N. J., has been leased by a New York group for seventy-five years, on a net basis, for improvement with a two-story store and office building.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- A House subcommittee virtually ordered today the appearance of leaders of five major railroad unions at a public hearing next Tuesday to answer the charge that they bar Negroes, Mexican-Americans and Japanese-Americans from membership.

A real estate transaction which appeared at first to be a routine court auction proceeding turned out yesterday to be a purchase in which sentiment and nostalgic associations were factors almost as important as the investment motive.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 12 -- The nuclear power plant for propelling ships is surely on the way but engineering difficulties make its practical realization a good many years distant, Dr. Lee A. DuBridge, president of the California Institute of Technology, asserted here tonight.

Jose Ferrer, star of "The Silver Whistle," is compelled to leave the Theatre Guild's only hit of the season on May 28. He said so yesterday. No replacement being on hand, it looks as if the Robert McEnroe play will have to close its engagement at the Biltmore on that date.

The United States Office of Education should be reorganized as an independent office whose policies are determined by a Federal Board of Education serving without salary, Dr. John W. Studebaker, former United States Commissioner of Education, said here yesterday.
Those who feel the need to follow the byways of contemporary painting as well as the high road are recommended to visit three exhibitions that show genuine sensibilities at work.

DETROIT, May 12 -- On the basis of figures computed privately by insurance firms at the request of Walter P. Reuther, head of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, it was learned tonight that the three major demands of the union in its 1949 bargaining program would be equivalent to a wage increase of nearly 50 cents an hour, or almost $4 a day.

A bit alarmed over signs that his pennant-favorites were on the verge of going into a severe tailspin, Manager Barney Shotton shuffled Brooklyn's line-up yesterday. The Dodgers responded with an 11-to-6 triumph over the Pirates, before 7,455 paying spectators.

LONDON, May 12 -- The first television apparatus to be permanently installed in a hospital for educational purposes was used yesterday at Guy's Hospital here. Medical students watched an appendectomy on a television screen and listened to the surgeon's observations from the operating theatre.

PARIS, May 1 -- A French official spokesman emphatically denied tonight that the French Government had been informed of a suggestion attributed to George F. Kennan, head of the United States State Department's policy planning division, to propose a reduction of the forces of occupation in Germany or the withdrawal of French forces from the French zone of occupation.

A gala dinner and dance entitled Bal des Oiseaux was given last night in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria as a benefit for the Hospitalized Veterans Music Service, a subsidiary of the Musicians Emergency Fund. The fete served as a pre-opening of the roof for the late spring and summer season.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The Senate's foreign policy leaders said today that Spain was not wanted in the North Atlantic treaty's defensive alliance and indicated that there was no foreseeable possibility of her admission.

Elegance and easy upkeep in decorative fabrics are no longer incompatible. Rich velvets and heavy lustrous damasks of nylon, sheer white curtaining of Fiberglas, and pin-money cottons, some iridescent, others combined with metallics, were shown yesterday at the home furnishings luncheon of The Fashion Group held at the Biltmore Hotel.

Twelve-year-old Barbara Nikoli a Greek orphan, who lost the sight of one eye when her face was mutilated by an exploding mortar shell, remained cheerful yesterday at the prospect of further operations to save her sight and improve her facial appearance.

A program of Jewish liturgical music was presented last night in St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University as the first of four concerts of the Festival of Contemporary American Music. The elaborate list of offerings, consisting of works by thirteen composers, was performed by Cantor David J. Putterman and the Park Avenue Synagogue Choir, with Max Helfman conducting and Isidor Celler presiding at the organ.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., May 12 -Kap, a 3-year-old boxer dog, was home tonight after the most eventful day of his life, which included some law-breaking, commuting to New York, and an escort home in a private car as the guest of a railroad inspector.

Mrs. John B. Trevor Jr. is president of the recently formed junior board of managers of the New York City Mission Society that has been holding frequent meetings to further plans for the organization's annual benefit sale, luncheon and tea dance in the autumn at the Ambassador.

Boston, Mass., announced yesterday that it would receive bids on June 1 on $11,250,000 of various bonds. The sale will be in two lots; the first, consisting of $8,750,000, will be due on June 1, 1950 to 1979. A second lot, comprising $2,500,000 of bonds, will be due on June 1, 1994.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- An acknowledged Communist turned up today with an Atomic Energy Commission scholarship for advanced study in nuclear physics at Government expense. The fellowship is for $1,600.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- President Truman brushed aside today the signals recently raised in Congress and declared that he was still firm in his stand for a $4,000,000,000 tax increase, and his economic and social programs as well.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- President Truman said today that in his opinion the lifting of the Berlin blockade was an encouraging note in the world situation.

PARIS, May 12 -- Dr. Chaim Weizmann, President of Israel, commenting on the admission of his country to the United Nations, declared in Paris today that "the people of the Book" would be worthy of the trust of the nations.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- A modest little conference on what many of its members regard as the basis of the nation's health and prosperity got under way here today with the warning that because of continuing large-scale spoilage of natural resources, the "virile life of the nation is already in jeopardy."
A series of dinners and functions last night throughout New York on behalf of the United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York resulted in contributions of more than $3,250,000 for the appeal.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 12 -- Exiles from three Baltic States appealed to the United Nations today to investigate what they called the "illegal Soviet Russian occupation" of their homelands. The appeal renews a similar plea sent to the United Nations in October, 1948.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., May 12 -- It might just be a sign of the times, but the lowly wash cloth and soap are being "glamorized" here at the eighteenth national packaging exposition and conference in Convention Hall.

The voluntary hospitals in New York are on trial today not only in the raising of money to defray the costs of patients who cannot afford care, but to prove they can do a better job in managing hospitals than can government, Dr. Eli Ginzberg, director of the New York State Hospital Survey, declared last night.

Reserve Requirements The State Banking Board has approved a reduction in reserve requirements against demand deposits of non - member banks in Manhattan from 26 to 24 per cent and against time deposits of all non-member banks in the state from 7 1/2 to 7 per cent, it has been announced by Elliott V. Bell, Superintendent of Banks.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- President Truman was reported to have told a meeting of the Committee for Economic Development today that the two primary purposes of his Administration were peace in the world and economic stability at home.

The stock market gained more ground yesterday although the new advance generated no increase in volume. Gains of around a point were more plentiful than in recent sessions but the composite price rose only 0.38 point. The steels again gave the list a basis for an advance, and the television stocks also were active.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- In the usual Soviet Embassy a first secretary heads up the spy organization, the Senate Judiciary Subcommittee was told today.
The first over-the-jumps stake of the New York racing season was the main item of business at Belmont Park yesterday, and players of favorites continued to be taken over the jumps in it.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- During the week ended May 11, member bank reserve balances decreased $909,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Plans for a 2,000-apartment non-profit housing development to be built in Queens under the joint sponsorship of Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, AFL, and employer-members of groups affiliated with the Joint Industry Board of the electrical industry here, were announced yesterday by Herman T. Stichman, State Housing Commissioner.

PARIS, May 12 -- A marked change in the European trading system to permit commerce to move more freely, stimulate greater competition and consequently foster an easing of the now high European price levels has been proposed by United States officials. It has provoked intense discussion among experts here of the European Marshall Plan council, the directing body of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- Americans for Democratic Action protested today that a group of Senators had a "secret session" with a Spanish banker Tuesday to work out a "large United States loan to Franco for the purchase of cotton in the United States.

In response to numerous protests, the Interstate Commerce Commission has decided to reopen and review the situation leading up to its recent decision to impose unloading charges on produce brought into this city. It has been estimated that this would mean a price increase of $3,000,000 to New York consumers of vegetables and fruits.

The congregation of the Free Synagogue, 40 West Sixty-eighth Street, voted last night at a special meeting to change the name of the synagogue to the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue. The Free Synagogue was founded by the late Dr. Wise forty-two years ago and was served by him as rabbi up to the time he died on April 19.
An adverse wind and tide seem to be carrying the Giants in the wrong direction and yesterday not even their surprise pitcher of the spring campaign, Clint Hartung, could do anything about it.

Gerhart Eisler, internationally known Communist leader, is enjoying first-class accommodations on the Polish luxury liner Batory on which he is crossing the Atlantic after starting a journey to Germany by way of Gdynia, Poland, by stealing aboard the ship.

CHICAGO, May 12 (AP) -- Vern Stephens assured a successful finish to Boston's first Western trip by hitting his eighth home run with two out in the eleventh inning to give the Red Sox a 2-1 victory over the Chicago White Sox today.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The United States today ended, in effect, reparations from Japan to ease the load on the United States taxpayer of contributing heavily to Japan's support and to give her a greater opportunity to get on her own economic feet.

Federal Judge Harold R. Medina charged defense counsel at the Communist trial yesterday with trying to take over the court room, with judge-baiting efforts to provoke him to anger and with persistent misquotation of testimony.

Beatrice I. Herman of the Goodwins Department Store family has purchased the custom-built ranch-style residence nearing completion at 26 Deering Lane in the Rolling Park community at Hewlett Harbor, L. I., from Harry Sokolov Sons, builders.
Activity increased on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday and final prices for cotton futures were 20 points lower to 3 points higher than on Wednesday.
Thirty-six years ago, actors crowded the sidewalk near Seventh Avenue and Forty-seventh Street, with a yearning in their eyes to play Martin Beck's brand-new Palace Theatre.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 12 -- Frank F. Allen of Asbury Park, president of the New Jersey Bankers Association, expressed today optimism in the nation's economic outlook and denounced "alarmists" who are crying depression.
LONDON, May 12 -- Quiet conditions ruled in the stock market here again today, except for a few flurries of activity.

Three midtown theatres will present new films today. At the Roxy the attraction is "The Forbidden Street," Twentieth Century-Fox's adaptation of the Margery Sharp novel, "Brittania Mews," starring Dana Andrews and Maureen O'Hara.

A martyr's burial was given yesterday to William Lurye, slain organizer for the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, AFL, as 65,000 of his fellow unionists quit work for four hours in a public protest against his murder.
Starting a series of special events, the Seventy-seventh Infantry Division conducted a colorful flag ceremony yesterday at the base of the Statue of Liberty on Bedloes Island.

About 25 per cent of next year's total orange crop in Florida will be used to produce concentrated frozen orange juice, Dr. J. L. Heid, research director for the Florida Citrus Canners Cooperative, predicted yesterday at the quarterly meeting of the National Wholesale Frozen Food Distributors, Inc., in the Statler Hotel.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- A group of holders of preferred stock filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a plan urging the immediate dissolution of the International Hydro-Electric System, Boston.

ALBANY, May 12 -- A request that hotels be permitted to increase telephone charges to patrons if the Public Service Commission granted to the New York Telephone Company a temporary rate increase of 10 per cent, was made today by the New York State Hotels Association and the Hotel Association of New York City.

BERLIN, May 12 -- Political leaders in Western Germany, spurred by the defeat of the Soviet Union and German communism over the blockade issue, demanded German unity under a free regime today as the blockade of Berlin -- a month ago a terrifying reality -- passed into history.

The special Congressional election to be held next Tuesday has brought Manhattan's West Side to a state bordering on bedlam. Each night upper Broadway floats in a sea of oratory. Each afternoon mothers pushing baby carriages on the borders of Riverside Park discuss the decibel content of their living rooms the night before, as the product of an army of sound trucks floats in even through closed windows.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The Truman Administration's multibillion-dollar public housing and slum clearance bill was approved without substantial change today by the House Banking and Currency Committee by a straight party vote of 14 to 7.

Dr. Abraham Flexner, whose thunderings against Columbia and other large universities rocked American halls of learning two decades ago, was found last night to be one of the most enthusiastic students in a fine arts course at Columbia University.

Business loans made by banks in this area dropped $42,000,000 last week to $4,975,000,000, another new low for the year, the smallest volume outstanding since Oct. 22, 1947. According to the figures issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, covering the week ended on Wednesday, this was the eleventh consecutive weekly decline in borrowings from the reporting New York City member banks.

The famous Collins quadruplets played a secondary role yesterday in the second Bronx Collins Day. For Borough President James J. Lyons proclaimed "Stephen Collins Day" in honor of their 2-year-old brother so that the child would not suffer from the effects of public partiality.

The more than 500 children and adults served by the Prescott Neighborhood House, 247 East Fifty-third Street, are faced with its closing and the loss of the social services it has supplied during the last thirty years unless $25,000 can be raised to continue its work in the east midtown section of Manhattan.
The Rachmaninoff Fund, founded in memory of the noted pianist to provide career opportunities for young musicians, has been abandoned.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The International Association of Machinists won its first Taft-Hartley Law action today against the Brotherhood of Carpenters, AFL.
