The National Labor Relations Board ruled that the carpenters' union did not have jurisdiction over the installation of generators at a southern California power plant.

The State Banking Board has added securities of a value of $527,888,000 to the legal list, it was announced yesterday by Elliott V. Bell, Superintendent of Banks. Two of the securities have been added on a when-issued basis.

A detailed report of the United States participation in the United Nations for 1948 was transmitted to Congress yesterday with accompanying letters from the President and the Secretary of State. It is an impressive record; Mr. Truman notes that the nature of our participation and the many different ways in which it is manifested will come as a surprise to many members.

Deputy Hospital Commissioner George H. Bruns, questioned by the District Attorney in connection with the case of two men indicted Monday for allegedly defrauding the city on painting contracts, resigned Tuesday, it was learned yesterday.
The approaching visit to this country of President Eurico Gaspar Dutra of Brazil will serve to focus renewed attention upon our great and friendly neighbor to the south.
The all-purpose cotton dress suitable to every age and named the "Dilly' by its designer, Nelly morning by McCreery's at a press breakfast in the store's Big Top restaurant.
RANGOON, Burma, May 12 (AP) -- Burmese army units have made a forty-mile advance through rebel territory in central Burma, pro-Government sources said today.

While the critical shortages of World War II were in machine tools and labor, if this country should enter another war its primary shortage would be in manpower, Col. George A. Harvey said yesterday. He made his statement to business executives and reserve officers attending an economic mobilization course given at 30 Rockefeller Plaza by Army, Navy, and Air Force officers of the Industrial College in Washington.
Dr. Richard B. Morris, Professor of History at City College, has been named Professor of History at Columbia University, Albert C. Jacobs, Columbia provost, announced yesterday.

FOR two years, from 1945 until 1947, Robert Shaplen was a correspondent in the Far East for Newsweek magazine. Scurrying across the map from Manchuria to India, never staying long in one place, hurrying fast on the trail of change and violence and melodrama as a reporter must, he formed in his own mind a series of vivid impressions of Asia in a revolutionary ferment.

The Bankers Trust Company, under arrangements with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, will act as agent for stockholders wishing to purchase or sell rights in connection with A. T. T.'s recently authorized $395,000,000 of ten-year 3 1/8 per cent convertible debentures issue.

LONDON, Friday, May 13 -- With only a handful of results remaining to be declared, it was evident early today that the Conservatives had made heavy gains from the Laborites in yesterday's municipal elections throughout England and Wales.

Mayor O'Dwyer was guest of honor yesterday at a tea in the home of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel A. Lewisohn, 115 East Seventy-third Street. The event, according to custom, precedes the opening of the Lewisohn Stadium Concert season, which this year starts June 20.
AMSTERDAM, N. Y., May 12 (AP) -- A couple of former Amsterdam Rugmakers returned today with the Yankees, who beat their Canadian-American League farm, 9 to 2.

On the ground that sending ex-Communist leader, George Hewitt back to face a perjury charge in the State of Washington might lead "to slaughter," Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy in the Bronx refused yesterday to extradite the former Communist national committeeman.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 12 -- In a major policy statement on methods of financing President Truman's proposed "bold new program" of American technical assistance to underdeveloped countries, the United States Council of the International Chamber of Commerce said today that "financial expedients" and other artificial measures will never take the place of a favorable "climate" in attracting foreign private investors to economically backward areas.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 12 -- Mike Turnesa, Knollwood pro, posted a five under par best-ball score of 31, 34 -- 65 today with each of two amateurs from his club, James Raymond and Dr. G. Everett Gaillard, for top position in the opening one-day tournament of the Westchester County Golf Association.

The one-story taxpayer building at 1289-1293 Broadway, Brooklyn, has been purchased by Frederick Brown from the Bank of the Manhattan Company, Paul G. A. Bohack and Henry C. Bohack Jr. as trustees of the estate of H. C. Bohack.

TEL AVIV, May 12 -- The former German farming village of Sarona, which has now been engulfed by Tel Aviv, has taken on a new appearance since Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion and his provisional Government of Israel Hebraized the village's name to "Hakirya" and established their governmental seat there.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- Following is the text of a statement by Maj. Gen. Frank R. McCoy, United States representative on the Far Eastern Commission, concerning Japanese reparations and the level of industry:

Although sales of the paint industry are slightly lower than last year, there is no cause for alarm, it was said last night by Paul S. Kennedy, retiring president of the New York Paint Varnish and Lacquer Association. He spoke at the annual dinner meeting of the organization in the Biltmore Hotel.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., May 12 -- The Atomic Energy Commission has approved the experimental use of radioactive gallium in a few selected cases of human bone cancer at the United States Naval Hospital in Bethesda, it was announced here tonight.

CHICAGO, May 12 -- Wheat made a firm stand and a tame finish with May closing unchanged to 1/8 cent off and deferred months down 3/8 to 3/4 cents a bushel on the Board of Trade today. Corn, however, showed a firm undertone and was 1/4 cent up to 1/8 cent down. Oats were 7/8 cent higher to 3/8 cent lower than on Wednesday, May showing the strength.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- President Truman regretfully signed today a temporary pay resolution, explaining he had no alternative because the pay of thousands of Federal employes was being held up, but he strongly protested a rider depriving two Interior Department officials of their salaries.

CAMBRIDGE, England, May 12 (UP) -- Dr. E. W. Barnes, Bishop of Birmingham, said today that in the present economic state of the world large families were a "form of selfishness." He warned that over - population and starvation were more to be feared at the moment than racialism and war.

ST. LOUIS, May 12 (AP) -- The Browns fired a home run barrage against Lefty Lou Brissie in the early innings tonight and went on to a 9-to-3 victory and a sweep of the two-game series against the athletics.

A twenty-four-hour guard was placed on an incinerator in the basement of Jersey City's City Hall yesterday to prevent any destruction of records or files. A similar guard was posted at entrances and exits of the building to prevent removal of public documents.

The Board of Estimate authorized yesterday the issuance of $640,000 in budget notes, redeemable in the 1950-51 budget, to cover staff salaries and other expenses of the Temporary City Housing Rent Commission from May 1, 1949, to April 30, 1950.

This week John Edgar Hoover marked his twenty-fifth anniversary as Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. When he took over the post in 1924 the bureau was a small agency of "brief-case investigators" with an extremely limited and peaceable jurisdiction.

Frank Stanton, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, has signed a new contract with the network under which $100,000 will be paid to him a year and such additional compensation as the chain's board of directors may award him, CBS disclosed yesterday.

MOSCOW, May 12 -- Sergei Ivanovich Vavilov, president of the Academy of Science, and a group of other distinguished Soviet philosophers declared in a series of articles publishsed today by the Moscow press that dialectical materialism holds the key to understanding of atomic physics.

HAVANA, May 12 -- The creation of the new special investigation service of the Cuban Army is being viewed by the Cuban public with some alarm. Protests from various representatives have caused the House to schedule the matter for debate next Monday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 12 -- Greer Garson will play the leading role in "Europa," which Gottfried Reinhardt will produce this summer at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, the studio announced today. Ladislas Fodor and Jerry Davis, have written the scenario from a screen story by Fodor about a contemporary romance between a titled European lady and an American college professor, with the background of a mythical country.

LONDON, May 12 -- By an almost unanimous vote the House of Commons approved the North Atlantic pact tonight after both Foreign Secretary Bevin and Winston Churchill had declared that it would be a deterrent to Soviet aggressiveness and a contribution to peace. The vote was 333 to 6.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., May 12 -- Johnny Palmer of Badin, N. C., who finished in last place a year ago, enjoyed the lead when the statistics were tabulated tonight at the conclusion of the initial round of the Goodall round-robin tournament over the rolling Wykagyl Country Club links.

LEXINGTON, Ky., May 12 -- Roman Catholics were urged to accept leadership in eliminating the segregated school system at the concluding session here today of a three-day convention of the Catholic Committee of the South.
ESSEX FELLS, N. J., May 12 -- The Women's New Jersey Golf Association opened its season with a record turnout of more than ninety players at the Essex Fells Country Club course today.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- President Truman disclaimed any intention today of attempting a purge of his opponents in Congress. He declared that to be a task for the voters.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- Following are the texts of a letter from President Truman to Congress, accompanying a report on United States participation in the United Nations during 1948, and a letter from Secretary of State Acheson to the President on the same subject:

A teacher who has been in the New York public school system for twenty-three years announced her resignation yesterday, charging that a Roman Catholic "religious group" was seeking to control education policy and that fear was rampant in the schools.
PHILADELPHIA, May 12 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Phillies squared matters with the Chicago Cubs today, coming through with a 4-3 victory as Hank Borowy whipped his old team-mates at the first asking.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Allan Sproul, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, asked Congress today to give the Federal Reserve Board permanent power to control consumer installment credit. He hedged, however, on supporting a proposal to extend the board's power to control reserve requirements of banks.

Municipal Court Justice Benjamin Shalleck, Democratic nominee in the Twentieth Congressional District, received yesterday a letter from Senator J. Howard McGrath, Democratic National Chairman, endorsing his candidacy and assuring him of the whole-hearted support of the Democratic National Committee.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Calling today on President Truman to present her credentials as the first woman Ambassador to the United States, Mrs. Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit of India said afterward that she had had a most interesting visit.

Earnings for the first quarter ended on April 2 are estimated by Paramount Pictures, Inc. at $5,675,000 after taxes and all charges, according to the report issued yesterday. For the corresponding three months of 1948 estimated earnings were $7,760,000.

The small fry of the community gave impetus yesterday to the opening of the Greenwich Village Fresh Air Fund Arts Festival, the annual fund-raising event cooperated in by Village organizations and individuals to send youngsters to camp.

When Ohrbach's doors opened to the public at noon yesterday, customers found their way quickly to the newly opened Sun Shop on the third, and to the freshly redecorated bathing suit department on the main floor.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on May 7 were 768,337 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 17,107 cars, or 2.2 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 111,950 cars or 12.7 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week of last year, and 115,905 cars, or 13.1 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week of 1947.

MOSCOW, May 12 (UP) -- All Moscow newspapers today carried a Tass agency dispatch from Berlin saying that the Western Allies had issued orders to lift the Berlin blockade. There was no accompanying comment.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, May 12 -- Israeli and Arab delegations signed an agreement today establishing the procedure for discussions of a political settlement in Palestine with the United Nations Conciliation Commission.

" The Violent Men," by Cornelia Meigs, Professor of English at Bryn Mawr, will be published May 24 by Macmillan. It is an account of the men who confronted one another during the meetings of the Continental Congress, 1774-1786, arguing bitterly over whether to break away from England, or to compromise and conciliate.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- Federal Judge Albert L. Reeves sternly rebuked counsel today for "childish" antics in the espionage trial of Judith Coplon, 27 years old, a former analyst for the Justice Department.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission disclosed today that it had approved rate schedules for new natural gas service by the Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation from the Big Inch line to companies in New Jersey, New York, Pennsylvania, Missouri, Indiana and Ohio.
WASHINGTON, May 12 (UP) -- The House passed by voice vote today a bill calling for a reorganization of the State Department. The Senate previously had passed a slightly different version.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 12 -- William J. Neely, Hastings-on-Hudson civic leader, village clerk, treasurer and tax assessor, was taken into custody at his Hastings office today and arraigned here later in county court on a charge of misappropriating village funds.

Celanese Corporation of America has issued new prices for acetate rayon yarn, it was announced yesterday. Reductions are in line with those made by Tennessee Eastman Corporation and American Viscose Corporation, and range from 2 cents a pound on 150 denier to 6 cents on 55 denier numbers.

Behind the superb twirling of Arnie Portorcarrero, who struck out sixteen rivals and gave up only three hits, the pace-setting George Washington High nine crushed Machine and Metal Trades, 13 -- 1, in the Manhattan P.S.A.L. yesterday at Washington Field. The victory was the sixth for the winners.

Vince Foster will make his bid for recognition as a leading contender for the welterweight championship when he opposes Charley Fusari of Irvington, N. J., in the main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight. The fight has aroused considerable interest among boxing fans, and the promoters expect a crowd of 17,000 fans and a gate of $90,000.
The Consolidated Edison Company of New York has offered to the city a 10-year contract for the supply of electric power to the municipal transit lines at a rate increase of 45 to 50 per cent.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder called the country's economic position "exceptionally strong" in an address today at the annual conference of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks.
Mayor O'Dwyer made public yesterday details of a plan to curtail strike threats on the city's private transit lines by the setting up of an impartial chairman for the industry.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- President Truman today pledged continued support of the United Nations by the United States "in all respects." The pledge was in a letter to Congress transmitting a report on the activities of the United Nations and the participation of the United States in 1948.

LAKE SUCCESS, Friday, May 13 -- The Political Committee of the United Nations General Assembly adjourned at 12:35 this morning and will reconvene at 10:30 A. M. to vote on an Anglo-Italian plan for the disposition of the former Italian colonies.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- C. R. Smith, president of American Airlines, Inc., told a Senate Commerce subcommittee today that his hard-pressed industry would benefit more in the long run from businesslike management than from overgenerous governmental assistance.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 12 -- The Israeli flag, a Star of David on blue and white, was raised this morning to symbolize the new state's admission to the United Nations, shortly after mounting Arab indignation had exploded in a formal protest here over egg-pelting outbursts in Manhattan.

FRANKFORT, Germany, May 12 (UP) -- A clause in the Western German constitution, approved tonight by the Allied commanders in chief, reserves to the German federal government the right to manufacture "weapons designed for warfare."

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, May 12 -- A political storm is brewing in the Netherlands as a result of the recent agreement with the Republic of Indonesia concluded in Batavia. Debate in the States-General scheduled today was postponed until next week pending further word on the resignation of the High Commissioner, Louis J. M. Beel, who opposed the line taken for the settlement.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 12 -- Poland accused the Western occupying powers today of using the International Refugee Organization as a "mass emigration syndicate" for furnishing cheap labor for Marshall Plan nations and overseas countries.

CHICAGO, May 12 -- The 5,500 specialists attending the annual convention of the Super Market Institute, Inc., were told today that a survey of customer reaction to self-service meats in the Philadelphia trading area brought "disturbing answers" and demonstrated that "an alarming percentage actually disliked self-service meats."

It was a great moment for both Israel and for the United Nations when the General Assembly voted by a large majority to admit the new state as the fifty-ninth member of the world organization. For Israel, which has waged a long and agonizing struggle for statehood, this moment marked the triumph of its fight for world recognition.

PENSIVE won the Kentucky Derby in 1944 and a half decade later it was won by his son, Ponder. Advice is hereby given to mortgage the old family homestead some five years or so from now and bet the wad on Ponder's son. He will be a long shot without a chance of winning just as his pappy and his grandpappy were.

Coffee futures moved off in light trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Scattered long liquidation and trade hedge-selling was absorbed by some new buying and support from producer interests. Final prices for contract "S" were 15 to 30 points lower.

TOKYO, May 12 -- For the first time since Japan's surrender her stock markets will resume formal business Monday. They were closed Aug. 1, 1945, attempted to reopen in September of that year but were forbidden by Gen. Douglas MacArthur's Sept. 25 directive.

Senator Brien McMahon named yesterday about two dozen persons who know the size of the country's atomic bomb stockpile and once more called for serious consideration of the value of making this information available to the public.

ANNECY, France, May 12 -- The next phase of Marshall Plan operations should be the establishment of a trading system that will reduce barriers to international commerce and provide for better economic specialization in Europe, W. Averell Harriman, special Ambassador for the Economic Cooperation Administrator, said here tonight.
One of the reasons we have made such slight progress toward better housing for the general public is that there has been so little clear thinking and analysis of this vital problem.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Department storea sales in the week ended May 7 were 1 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reservea Board reported tonight. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1948:

SAN FRANCISCO, May 12 -- Comdr. E. O. Rigsbee Jr., 41 years old, who took command of the aircraft carrier Antietam ten days ago, was found shot to death today in his cabin on the ship at Hunter's Point Naval Yard. The vessel is being prepared for decommissioning.

The testimony of Matthew S. Crinkley, vice president of the Isbrandtsen Steamship Company, Inc., of 26 Broadway, at a Maritime Commission hearing into steamship conference rate practices, ended yesterday with the witness describing his own company's rate contracts as "entirely legal."

Rayon yarn and staple shipments by domestic producers, totaling 55,900,000 pounds in April, were 39 per cent below shipments in April, 1948, according to the Textile Economics Bureau, Inc. Filament yarn shipments amounting to 48,900,000 pounds were 28 per cent under those of the corresponding month last year, and staple deliveries totaling 7,000,000 pounds were down 69 per cent.

AUBURN, N. Y., May 13 (AP) -- Three more union stewards were suspended today at the International Harvester Company plant here as a one-day walkout of the Farm Equipment Workers, CIO, ended. The strike of about 1,100 workers was staged in protest against the company's earlier suspension of three other union officials.

BERLIN, May 13 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay, retiring United States Military Governor, declared today that he "assumed" a united Germany arising out of the coming meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers in Paris would "be given membership in the Organization of European Economic Cooperation."

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The Senate was forced to recess early tonight out of sheer confusion. In the debate over a bill to impose a 2 per cent sales tax in the District of Columbia, it became apparent that the Senators could not even agree on the immediate question before them, and Senator Scott W. Lucas of Illinois, majority leader, obtained a breathing spell until Monday.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat, of Nevada, saaid today that he might move to cut off student aid funds from the Atomic Energy Commission unless it barred Communiste from its science study program.

Officials of area offices of the Veterans Administration said yesterday that discharge notices had been given this week to more than 800 employes, many of them career workers with years of Government service It was noted that employe morale had been impaired as result.
The Women's Army Corps is seven years old today -- and still going strong.
Leo Durocher, up to his neck in trouble just a few weeks ago, had reason to feel comfortably secure and very happy last night.

The Embassy Newsreel Theatre in the Airlines Terminal Building, Park Avenue and Forty-second Street, will become a first-run outlet for British and foreign-language pictures on May 25. The switch in policy, announced yesterday by W. French Githens, president of Newsreel Theatres, Inc., is a further reflection of the declining attendance at newsreel theatres, several of which have been converted to feature-run houses in recent months.

PARIS, May 13 -- Indo-Chinese supporters of former Emperor Bao Dai said today he could rally to his new Viet Nam state not only leaders of the French zone, but many now fighting the French, if the Paris Government applied the recent agreement with him under Parliamentary approval.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- There were strong indications today that Congress might permit the Federal Reserve Board's authority to control consumer installment credit and its temporary mandate over bank reserves to lapse on June 30.

The Pacific Gas and Electric Company and its subsidiaries had a net income of $25,447,010, in the twelve months ended on March 31, according to the report issued yesterday by J. B. Black, president. This is equivalent to $2.16 each on 7,540,296 shares of common stock outstanding and compares with a net income of $24,535,138, or $2.40 a share on 6,717,399 common shares in the twelve months to March 31, 1948.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Bank irregularities reported to the Federal Bureau of Investigation in 1948 involved a total of $3,000,000, most of which was stolen as the result of "gambling, drink and women," Lee R. Pennington, FBI inspector, said today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 13 -- Robert Buckner's next production at Universal-International will be "Hot Water," a film which Buckner has written from a screen comedy by Herbert Clyde Lewis purchased by the studio in 1947 under the title "Patent Applied For."

Margaret Truman, daughter of President Truman, and James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, AFL, were among a large group of well-wishers that bade farewell yesterday to the 110 members of the Philadelphia Orchestra, who sailed for England yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Parthia.
The harbor boomed a raucous welcome yesterday to the new passenger liner La Guardia.

The flight of Gerhart Eisler, former Comintern agent, from the United States on the eve of a Supreme Court decision on his conviction for contempt of Congress threatened last night to embroil this country in a diplomatic incident with Communist-dominated Poland.

In a little black straw bonnet topped with posies that was anchored with a bow tied under her chin, Grandma Moses, passing through New York on her way to Washington, stopped here long enough yesterday to give the press an interview.

TOKYO, May 13 -- Japan's best news since the surrender came today in the statement by Maj. Gen. Frank R. McCoy, retired, United States member and chairman of the Far Eastern Commission, that the United States had decided to halt reparations removals.

NEW HAVEN. Conn., May 13 -- Dr. V. O. Key Jr., chairman of the Political Science Department of Johns Hopkins University since 1947, has been appointed Alfred Cowles Professor of Government at Yale University.
A fair for children and their parents will open a week's stand Monday afternoon in Grand Central Palace, 480 Lexington Avenue, it was announced yesterday.

A sudden rebound in the copper issues helped yesterday to maintain the stock market on an even keel. Aside from the recovery in the red-metal section, few changes developed to distinguish the session from the previous day. Gains in the metals ranged to a point and beyond, with fractional changes elsewhere and the composite rate was raised only 0.05 point on the day.

With one more round to go, the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's interclub team matches in both the Long Island and New Jersey districts are so close that everything hinges on play next Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Two pro-Truman Democrats from the States' Rights state of Mississippi went to the White House today for a showdown on the patronage that has not been coming their way.
CINCINNATI, May 13 (AP) -- Baseball Commissioner A. B. Chandler today gave Artie Wilson, Negro shortstop, to Newark in the International League. Newark is a farm club of the New York Yankees.

There must be something to the old saw to the effect that "East, West, home's best" for when we arrived back from the Outer Banks the reports on local and northern fishing were excellent, off-shore in-shore and on the rivers.

Elimination of frontier formalities in Europe for American drivers and cars through a treaty formulated by the United Nations was forecast yesterday by Robert J. Schmunk, president of the American Automobile Association. International conferences will take place this summer with a view to obtaining recognition of license plates and driving credentials issued by any state in this country, he added.

Dade County, Fla., announced yesterday that it would accept bids on June 7 on $6,420,000 of various bonds, dated July 1, 1946, and Jan. 1, 1949. They will be due 1950 to 1959, with bidders to name the rate.

In a move stressing the close co-operation between the Bureau of Advertising, ANPA, and the American Association of Newspaper Representatives, details of the bureau's extensive collection of market and media data were explained at a special session of the AANR's New York chapter, it was announced yesterday.

Roy Hudson, former member of the American Politburo of the Communist party, told Cleveland Communists in 1945 they had to support the Soviet Union in Europe, according to yesterday's testimony at the Communist trial.

A stalwart pitching performance by Larry Jansen and heavy hitting by his teammates put the Giants back on the winning road last night. In routing the Phillies, 9 -- 1, before 21,765 chilled spectators at the Polo Grounds, the Giants looked like anything but a club that had just dropped two in a row to the Reds.

NEW ORLEANS, May 13 -- A group of more than 600 Lithuanians and Latvians who are destined to become sharecroppers in Mississippi were aboard a displaced persons ship that arrived in New Orleans today. They were among 844 persons aboard the Army transport General Omar Bundy.
Mayor O'Dwyer issued yesterday from City Hall a proclamation designating next Wednesday as "Seventy-seventh Division Day" in honor of the city's own Organized Reserve Corps unit.

As the campaign for election of a Representative in the Twentieth Congressional District neared its close, Municipal Court Justice Benjamin Shalleck, Democratic candidate, predicted yesterday that he would be a sure winner at the special election next Tuesday and that the result would not be close.

Sales of leading mail-order and chain-store companies declined 4.6 per cent in April, compared with the corresponding month in 1948, according to a compilation covering forty-four companies made by THE NEW YORK TIMES. In March a decline of 9.8 per cent was shown.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- A railroad statistician today told the Interstate Commerce Commission that, in the light of developments, estimates made in March that freight and passenger traffic would be below last year must be revised.

CAMDEN, N. J., May 13 -- The last charges against Camden city and police officials which grew out of an investigation more than a year ago by former Attorney General Walter Van Riper into gambling and alleged police laxity in this city were nolle prossed today.
Investment buying featured realty transactions in Manhattan and the Bronx reported yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 13 -- Nearly four cents out of every dollar spent for the National Military Establishment, or about one cent of every dollar paid in Federal taxes, are now spent for research and development to provide more effective weapons, equipment, medicines and utilization of human resources, Dr. Karl T. Compton, chairman of the Research and Development Board, today told the Executives Club.
Raymond F. Littley has been appointed sales manager of the automotive division of the Budd Company, with headquarters in Detroit.

Eleven years ago today the past met with the present in the Near East when King Solomon's long vanished seaport, where he built and operated ships and smelted copper, was rediscovered under the sands, half a mile from the present shore-line of the Red Sea near Aqaba, recent point of friction between Israeli and Trans-Jordan forces.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 13 -- The Political Committee of the United Nations General Assembly approved today a resolution based on the Anglo-Italian agreement for the disposition of the former Italian colonies. Under it, British administration of Cyrenaica and French administration of the Fezzan would continue until all of Libya became independent in 1959, and Italy would take over the administration of Tripolitania in 1951 for the remainder of the period of trustee-ship.

In doubt earlier this week about continuing beyond next Monday night's performance, "The Traitor" has decided to stick around indefinitely or as long as box-office receipts warrant. An upturn in business that became noticeable on Thursday encouraged the management to keep the attraction going, according to Jean Dalrymple, who represents Jed Harris, producer of the Herman Wouk melodrama.
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Amid Congressional talk of budget cutting, a Yale law professor said today that financial caution about developing regions of the country was not prudence but miserliness.
PITTSBURGH, May 14 (AP) -- The Pirates got three home runs tonight to give them a 3-2 victory over the Cardinals.

The Graham-Paige Motors Corporation will sell 200,000 shares of common stock of the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation this year, thus reducing its holdings of the latter company's stock to 600,000 shares, according to the Graham-Paige proxy statement, issued yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The first step toward unifying the medical services of the National Military Establishment occurred today with the setting up of a Medical Services Division in the Office of Secretary of Defense. The order was issued by Secretary Louis Johnson.

CHICAGO, May 13 -- The City of Chicago will not attempt to market a new bond issue until it has made a reappraisal of need and until all court proceedings involving the legality of a 1945 judgment refunding issue are finished, spokesmen in the City Controller's office said today.

In view of the large number of people governed, the cost of maintaining their local government, and the fact that the city government changes hands no oftener than once in four years it does not seem premature, in mid-May, to turn over some thoughts preliminary to November.

Coffee futures rallied after early small declines on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Trade buying and short-covering advanced prices in contract "S" 30 to 20 points. Long liquidation and profit-taking on a scale up provided the contracts, continued firmness in the spot coffees added strength to the futures market.

Mrs. Teresa Eberhardt has the typically Austrian appetite for veal. And the way in which she prepares it would develop a similar enthusiasm in those who argue all meat of that sort is flat, tasteless.
WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- Fur names such as "mink-dyed muskrat" and "sable-blended muskrat" were defended before a House subcommittee today as having helped to "glamorize" the American woman.

PARIS, May 13 (AP) -- France and Sweden took commanding leads over their second-round opponents today as tennis teams of six nations opened bids for quarter-final berths in the European zone Davis Cup eliminations. Two others were forced to the Sidelines by rain.

BALTIMORE, May 13 -- The business of sorting out the top 3-year-olds continues tomorrow at Pimlico, where the names of ten colts went into the entry box this morning for the seventy-third running of the Preakness Stakes.

Your editorial of May 13, "Arms and the Pact," goes to the root of the major problem inherent in the twofold Atlantic Security Program. It raises the one outstanding issue which must be clarified and understood here and abroad before a final commitment is undertaken.

Anne Powers, author of two historical novels, "Ride East! Ride West!" and "The Gallant Years" has a third novel coming from Bobbs-Merrill on May 23. "No Wall So High" is a story about a merchant adventurer in Eliza bethan England.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 13 -- The National Packaging Exposition in Convention Hall ended here today with industry spokesmen encouraged by increased attendance at the show. They foresaw increased emphasis on effective packaging, packing and shipping throughout American industry and predicted a continuing high level of sales in spite of increased competition.
Four of the new current art exhibitions demonstrate that contemporary painters have found more than one way to express their messages.

ST. LOUIS, May 13 (AP) -- Don Kolloway banged out four hits, including three doubles, to lead the Detroit Tigers to an easy 7-to-2 victory over the St. Louis Browns tonight. Young Ted Gray scattered seven hits to chalk up his third victory.

PHILADELPHIA, May 13 -- The Philco Corporation reported yesterday net income of $915,000 on $53,006,000 in sales during the first quarter of this year, compared with a profit of S2,144,000 on $58,661,000 in sales in the 1948 period.

President Truman declared last night that there is no more zealous or more eloquent advocate of the Four Freedoms than Vice President Alben W. Barkley. In a message to the Four Freedoms Award Committee, read at its dinner at the Warldorf-Astoria Hotel, the President heartily congratulated Mr. Barkley, who received the committee's first award for making the most distinguished contribution in the field of public service.

Alexander Smith Sons Carpet Company will "in a very short time," end temporary discounts ranging from 10 to 20 per cent on a limited number of carpet patterns, W. C. Hammel, vice president in charge of sales, disclosed yesterday.

BUFFALO, N. Y., May 13 (AP) -- The president of the New York State Dental Society said today the Federal Administration's advocacy of compulsory health insurance "shows a dangerous willingness to experiment with the health of the people for the sake of political advantage."

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Ely Culbertson, many times world bridge champion, revealed today that he had met his match at the bridge table in Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and Chief Justice Fred M. Vinson of the United States.

Sales of copper, lead and zinc by custom smelters continued to improve yesterday, with a noticeable increase in demand for refined copper at 18 cents a pound reported by several vendors. Improved demand was interpreted by refiners as a definite indication of a return of buying interest because sales of refined copper exceeded the custom ore and scrap intake of some smelters for the first time since March.

VIENNA, May 13 -- Apparently to support the Communist Information Bureau contention that acceptance of the European Recovery Program brings ruin on the participating country, the Russians charged at today's meeting of the Allied Council that unemployment was greatly on the increase in Austria and that the Austrian Government was not taking proper steps to end it.

A request for permission to appeal the decision against mandatory fair trade will be made to the Court of Appeals in Albany on Monday. This was disclosed yesterday by the State Liquor Authority after a closed meeting with about fifty representatives of all levels of the industry.

This summer's brides have definite ideas on what they want, according to the bridal consultants in stores about town. Hints on what they'll be wearing in June indicate that traditional satin still holds forth, regardless of weather, as the top fabric. Designers have brought forth what they call summer satin, giving this lovely fabric a new lightness by combining it with tulle or net.

Although domestic consumption of cotton is currently running considerably below last year's rate, the difference is more than made up by increased exports in the 1948-49 season. The New York Cotton Exchange Service Bureau estimates consumption in April at 615,000 bales, compared with 830,000 bales in the same month last year.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., May 13 -- With ninety-seven entrants from as far West as the states of Washington and Oregon and as far south as Texas and Florida, the fortieth annual amateur championships of America Trapshooting tournament started at Travers Island today. The event will continue tomorrow and ends Sunday.

LONDON, May 13 -- On the heels of the sweeping Conservative gains in local elections throughout England and Wales, Conservative party leaders predicted tonight that if the present trend were maintained their party would be returned to power in the next general election with a majority of approximately seventy seats.
DETROIT, May 13 -- The United Automobile Workers, CIO, made a new offer late today to settle its strike, now in its ninth day, against the Ford Motor Company.

Charley Fusari enjoyed a brief workout at the expense of Vince Foster, the widely heralded welterweight threat from Omaha, in the main bout, scheduled for ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night.
Hark! The Herald Tribune sings With Lewis Gannett's "Books and Things." Now let tribune heralds yell -- Gannett's book, "Cream Hill"* is swell.

CHICAGO, May 13 (AP) -- Gus Zernial's seventh-inning double, his fourth hit in five times at bat, scored Gordon Goldsberry with what proved the winning run in Chicago's 11-10 victory over Cleveland before 36,914 persons tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- Shipping interests in Philadelphia and Baltimore insisted today that their ports would be "severely injured" by lower freight rates on grain from Buffalo to New York, Boston and Portland.
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Francis Patrick Matthews of Omaha, prominent Roman Catholic layman, lawyer and business man, was nominated today by President Truman to be Secretary of the Navy.

The United Nations General Assembly approved at 2:30 o'clock this morning a news-gathering convention that attempts, for the first time in history, to lay down international laws to safeguard the free flow of information.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Cyrus S. Ching, director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, told the principals in the Ford Motor Company strike today he would have to intervene if they did not report significant progress toward settlement in a reasonable time.

GENEVA, May 13 -- Eastern and Western European delegates to the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe hurled charges of discrimination at each other today in debate on what was wrong with East-West trade.

An explosion and fire in a sixteen-ton trailer truck loaded in contravention of regulations with highly inflammable and volatile carbon disulphide almost knocked out a 300-foot section of the Holland Tunnel under the Hudson River just before 8:48 A. M. yesterday.

"To complain is a very human attribute," Sanitation Commissioner William J. Powell commented yesterday in releasing a report showing that his agency had received 16,905 complaints from the public in the last six months.

Establishment of what is said to be the first privately owned Canadian-flag shipping line to operate a regular cargo service between eastern Canada and the United Kingdom was announced by John B. Goulandris, president of the new enterprise, in a statement released here yesterday.
SANTA BARBARA, Calif., May 13 (AP) -- Former Gov. Dwight Green of Illinois denied today that newspaper men of his state were hired as state employes to further his political interests.

The case of young Hans Freistadt, an Austrian who became first an American citizen and later a Communist, has aroused Congressional ire and made the Atomic Energy Commission again the target of attack.

A three-team photo finish shapes up among Yale's defending squad, Army's indoor champions and Cornell's rising forces in the fifteenth annual outdoor track and field championships of the Heptagonal Games Association at Franklin Field, Philadelphia, today. Also competing in the "Ivy League's" title carnival will be Pennsylvania, Princeton, Harvard, Navy, Columbia, Dartmouth and Brown.
MOSCOW, May 13 -- The Soviet press reports that two embezzlers who had been able to carry out their depredations over a period of five years have been brought to book.

The Maritime Commission hearing into steamship conference rate practices was adjourned abruptly at 5:30 P. M. yesterday. A heated exchange between counsel for both sides preceded the adjournment. The hearing will resume on May 24. C. W. Robinson, commission trial examiner presided.
One hundred and fifty Port of New York Authority employes were hacking away last night to clear the Holland Tunnel of wreckage with equipment ranging from sledge hammers to bulldozers.
The International Ladies Garment Workers Union, AFL, announced yesterday the establishment of a $50,000 trust fund for the support of the widow and four young sons of William Lurye, slain organizer.

PARIS, May 13 -- The preliminary talks on German issues that are expected to arise in the forthcoming four-power conference will begin tomorrow among the representatives of the three Western powers at the French Foreign Office.

We desire to urge that the decision by the Paris Conference on the Peace Treaty that Italy must renounce all title to her former colonies should be upheld. These territories were used by Italy as bases for aggression against her neighbors.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange became fairly steady in the late trading yesterday and closed 4 to 14 points net higher.

One of the largest building loans of recent years involving financing of a single privately-owned property has been arranged by John J. Reynolds, Inc., New York brokers, for the Joseph P. Kennedy interests covering the Merchandise Mart in Chicago.

Hospitalized injured and scores of eyewitnesses graphically described the damage and disorder that resulted yesterday from the chemical fire and explosion in the Holland Tunnel. Their stories re-created scenes of near panic in the gas-filled and debris-littered section of the tunnel, embracing an area of about 200 feet and about half a mile from the New Jersey entrance.
HONG KONG, May 13 (AP) -- Shanghai today is a city ruled by guns.

Retail sales declined during the week, according to estimates made here yesterday. Department store sales here were believed to be about 8 per cent below the corresponding week last year. Sales last week were 6 per cent below last year.
LONDON, May 13 (AP) -- The Royal Society, an organization of British scientists, announced today it had elected two Americans to membership.

Reports from police, fire, hospital and Port Authority officials erL both sides of the Hudson River indicated late yeserday that at least sixty-six persons suffered injuries as a result of the Holland Tunnel blast.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Average primary market prices advanced 0.5 per cent in the week ended May 10, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index was 155.9 per cent of the 1926 average, 1.1 per cent below four weeks ago and 4.8 per cent lower than the comparable week in 1948.

MOSCOW, May 13 -- Pravda described the Bonn Constitution today as a barricade on the road of the forthcoming negotiations of the Big Four Foreign Ministers at Paris and suggested that the haste with which final German approval had been obtained for the Bonn document appeared as an attempt to confront the conference with a fair accompli.

PRAGUE, May 13 -- Delegates to the Czechoslovak trades union congress have announced plans to extend "Socialist competition" -- the principal means by which the Communists claim to be making labor more productive than in capitalist countries.

After a meeting yesterday of the World Trade Committee for the celebration that begins May 23, the City Commerce Department emphasized its functions in relation to the city as a business and tourist center.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Statements of praise to the Women's Army Corps in its seventh anniversary were issued today by Secretary of Defense Louis Johnson, former Secretary of the Army Kenneth C. Royall, and Gen. Omar N. Bradley, Chief of Staff.

Two compromise plans regarding the four-nation resolution to send Ambassadors and Ministers to Spain are being considered for introduction in the United Nations General Assembly today, should the proposal by Brazil, Colombia, Peru and Bolivia be judged in danger of defeat, it was learned last night.

BOSTON, May 13 -- Although the Braves belted fifteen of their eighteen hits in nine innings and the Dodgers only seven, the National League champions had to go ten frames to squeeze out a 6-5 victory under the Braves Field lights tonight.

FRANKFORT, Germany, May 13 -- The Russians have promised the United States Military Government that they will resume immediately reciprocal shipments of wheat, timber and similar commodities to eighteen member nations of the Interallied Reparation Agency in fulfillment of the Paris Reparation Treaty and the Potsdam Agreement.
PARIS, May 13 -- Peplums play an important part in the Maggy Rouff-Mendel collection of white, the palest pastels and an occasional scarlet.

SYRACUE, N. Y., May 13 -- Only regatta of the year that brings all heavyweight eights of the East together, the fourth annual sprint championships of the Eastern Association of Rowing Colleges will be held tomorrow over a 2,000meter course on Lake Onondaga with a record entry.

Leigh Mitchell Hodges, in THE TIMES of May 9, reminds us of the article by Jacob Riis (The Outlook, 1907) which resulted in our use of the Danish Christmas seal. Mr. Hodges modestly omits his own crucial part in it. When Emily Bissell, the Maryland Red Cross worker who had the first seal printed here, went to The North American, Philadelphia newspaper, for publicity on her seal, the Sunday editor turned her down.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The time for the coming bituminous coal wage conference between the Southern Coal Producers Association and the United Mine Workers of America was fixed today as May 25. The place will be Bluefield, W. Va., marking the first time such a meeting has been held in the Southern coal mining area.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., May 13 -- After three rounds of play had been completed today, the visitor from South Africa, Bobby Locke, had a total of 36 points in the Goodall round-robin golf tournament at the Wykagyl Country Club course and was nine points ahead of his nearest competitors in the field of sixteen.

BERLIN, May 13 -- Soviet authorities demanded today that the Western occupying powers order the reinstatement of the 1948 trade pact between Eastern and Western Germany. They accompanied their demand with the warning that the agreement to end the blockade of Berlin could not be fulfilled by the Russians alone.

A rise in automobile liability insurance rates for private passenger car owners was forecast yesterday at an all-day hearing of the State Insurance Department called to e~lore auto rating practices in general.

The fiftieth anniversary of the First World Peace Conference at The Hague in the Netherlands will be celebrated on Wednesday in this and other countries by thousands of children with songs, speeches, plays, dances and exhibits of art under church auspices.
LONDON, May 13 -- The stock markets here today were unresponsive to Conservative victories yesterday in borough elections, but despite the scarcity of business, the general undertone was firm.

SHANGHAI, May 13 -- The rumble of distant artillery penetrated even to the heart of the financial district today as the Communists made a dash toward the mouth of the Whangpoo River in an effort to seal off the city from the sea.

GOSEBURG, Germany, May 13 (UP) -- The ministers-president of the Western German states rejected today a proposal by the Bonn Constituent Assembly that an executive committee by formed to act as a government unitl the separate regime for Western Germany finally was established.

Social and group work agencies are not getting sufficient financial support for their community programs because they don't know "how to sell their story so people will buy it." Mrs. Anna Arnold Hedgeman, assistant to the Federal Security Administrator, Oscar R. Ewing declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- A group of young Americans who a fortnight ago were flying passengers between Newark Airport and Miami today are operating a new small airline between Switzerland and Israel.
WASHINGTON, MAY 13 -- Registration statements covering more than $30,000,000 in new financing were filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by three companies.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, today demanded lie detector tests for a former Army officer and two aides who have been accused of brutality toward German prisoners held for the Malmedy massacre trials.
WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission blocked today proposed commutation fare increases on the Pennsylvania Railroad between New York City and many points in New Jersey.

CHICAGO, May 13 -- Reports of drought from parts of the American and Canadian spring-wheat territory and announcement of the Government program under which farmers would be permitted to reseal grain held on farms for loans and receive storage charges for so doing dominated the action of the grain markets on the Board of Trade today.
For the first time in its history the New York Fire Department used four rescue squad trucks at one time, when the local firefighters responded to the explosion and fire in the Holland Tunnel.

Through its action favoring Park Commissioner Moses' plans for Jamaica Bay, the Board of Estimate appears to have ended for all time the remote possibility that the north shore of this waterway might be developed for industrial purposes. Rather, the board has gone along with Mr. Moses' sensible reasoning that this part of Jamaica Bay literally cries out for park development.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- A bill that would increase the pay of the armed services by $360,000,000 during the fiscal year 1950, which begins July 1, was approved unanimously by the House Armed Services Committee today. It will be formally reported when the House convenes on Monday.
WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- Sweeping changes in pay scales are proposed in the measure approved unanimously today by the House Armed Services Committee.

Today's events: "Madama Butterfly" at 3 P. M. and "Aida" at 8:20, San Carlo Opera Company, Center Theatre; Peggy Cowan, soprano, and Leslie Faber, bass, Carl Fischer Hall, 5:30; First Piano Quartet, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Fraternal Mandolin Symphony Orchestra, Thomas Sokoloff, conductor, Norman Atkins, baritone, Town Hall, 8:30; Contemporary American Music Festival, McMillin Theatre, Columbia University, 8:30.

BUENOS AIRES, May 13 -- The Government formally acquired today the Dodero shipping interests, which have held a virtual monopoly of Rio de la Plata transportation as well as maintaining European services.
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Hamilton Fish, a leader among pre-war Congressional isolationists as a Representative from New York, came out today for ratification of the North Atlantic treaty.

"Coaches drawn by four horses have returned to London streets," so a dispatch from that metropolis tells us -- and they have returned to promote the tourist trade, like the coach that points up the period picture in our American Williamsburg, restored.
WASHINGTON, May 12 (UP) -- A Senate investigation was ordered today into White House handling of an Army promotion list.
WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- The Treasury today offered one-year 1 1/4 per cent certificates in exchange for all of $5,315,135,000 in bonds and certificates falling due next month.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., May 13 -- The emotional development of a baby is the "trailbreaker" for every other development bodily or mental, Dr. Rene Spitz, world-famed psychiatrist, declared today.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 13 -- Following is the text of the resolution on the former Italian colonies, with the paragraph-by-paragraph vote, approved today by the Political Committee of the United Nations General Assembly:
WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- Senator Harry P. Cain, Republican, of Washington, today accused Charlie Chaplin, film comedian, of creating an incident that he said "skirts perilously close to treason."

Half of the long-distance telephone circuits to the West and South were knocked out of commission by the explosion and fire in the Holland Tunnel yesterday. Delays of several hours were experienced by many persons seeking to place calls although in the course of the day it was reported that there was considerable improvement. Service still was spotty, however.
The Traffic Division of the Police Department will open an investigation today that may lead to the re-routing of traffic from Convent Avenue between 135th and 140th Streets.
TEHERAN, Iran, May 13 -- The rugged tribes of Iran, once a constant worry to the central government, are now being incorporated into the country's defense plans as valuable auxiliaries of the Army.

PARIS, May 13 -- Financial experts of the European Marshall Plan Council said today they hoped by the end of this month to devise a plan for freer European trade that would meet the desires of the United States and win the adherence of the British.

ALBANY, May 13 -- Another major step in the program to reduce overcrowding in the state's mental hospitals was taken today with the award of contracts totaling $8,109,770 for construction of a 960-bed, medical-surgical building at the Hudson River State Hospital, Poughkeepsie.
CAMDEN, N. J., May 13 (AP) -Brookmeade Stable's Floating was an easy winner of the top event at Garden State Park today.

Although there will be little outward sign of festivity at the Majestic Theatre tomorrow night, one of the waning theatre season's more colorful events is expected to take place when the fabulously successful musical, "South Pacific," gives its special performance for people in show business.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (UP) -- Trade between the United States and Russia climbed in March, but there was another cut in Russian shipments of steel - hardening chrome and manganese for the third consecutive month.

BOMBAY, India, May 13 -- Sir Benegal Rama Rau, former Indian Ambassador to the United States said here last night that the gravest consequence of Marshall Plan aid to Western Europe and the North Atlantic pact was that "Communism has been let loose in the countries of Southeast Asia."

CINCINNATI, May 13 (AP) -- Cincinnati's rising Reds clubbed four Chicago pitchers for thirteen hits tonight as they trounced the Cubs, 7 -- 0, and moved into third place in the National League. Bud Lively spaced ten hits for his third victory in four outings.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 13 -- The New Jersey Bankers Association went on record today in opposition to the Maybank bill (Senate Bill 1175), which proposes permanent authorization of the temporary power now held by the board of governors of the Federal Reserve Board to increase bank reserve requirements at will.

A new musical film series, "Paradise Island" -- prepared expressly for television -- will have its premiere showing on WNBT on Tuesday from 10 to 10:15 P. M. The twenty-six week series of fifteen-minute films will feature Danny O'Neill and Anne Sterling, singers, with guest stars.

The Holland America liner Nieuw Amsterdam arrived here yesterday from Rotterdam with 882 passengers, among them Vice Admiral Alan G. Kirk, newly appointed United States Ambassador to Russia, and Mrs. Kirk.

For more than three-quarters of a century the State Charities Aid Association has quietly gone about its service to the public. For fifty years its Child Placing and Adoption Committee has been at work. This is one of the largest and oldest of the city's child adoption agencies, and has placed more than 7,000 children in adoptive homes, accepting these children without regard for race, color or creed.

Communism is a world-wide conspiracy that recognizes no political or geographical boundaries and preparation for a third World War is a basic communistic line today, Col. W. R. Godard told business executives and reserve officers yesterday at an Economic Mobilization Course at 30 Rockefeller Plaza.

The lame-duck Jersey City Administration, dominated by former Mayor Frank Hague, cut the work hours of policemen and firemen yesterday and ordered a referendum this fall on a proposition to raise police and fire salaries $500 a year.

Thomas J. Watson, president of International Business Machines Corporation and Dr. William Y. Elliott, Professor of Government at Harvard University, urged support here yesterday for United States economic and military expenditures on Europe.

Fifteen weeks of patient shadowing by detectives resulted yesterday in thwarting an insurance fraud in which a twice-convicted arsonist was alleged to have faked a $2,000 burglary of a Bronx apartment.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (UP) -- Britain and the United States have agreed to buy about 850,000 tons of raw sugar from Cuba at a maximum price of 4 cents a pound, it was announced today. The announcement was made jointly by the United States Department of Agriculture, the British Food Ministry and the Cuban Sugar Stabilization Institute.

The Hebrew Free Burial Society for the Poor of the City of Brooklyn has sold the two-story building at 101 Varet Street, Brooklyn, containing a store, shop and garage, to Jacob Shapiro. The property, on a plot 25 by 100 feet, was acquired subject to a mortgage of $3,925.

The Consolidated Fur Dressing and Dyeing Corporation has purchased the fur factory at 145-68 228th Street, Springfield Gardens, Queens, from the Northern Pierine Realty Corporation. The building is on a plot 200 by 585 feet. Included in the sale was a vacant plot, 200 by 585 feet, on the westerly side of 227th Street.

Ridden confidently by William Boland, 17-year-old triple-bug apprentice, the King Ranch's Safe Arrival captured the Ballot Purse, a mile-and-a-sixteenth contest, before 20,672 persons at Belmont Park yesterday. Despite the fact that a comparative unknown was up.

THE huge and complex mechanism pictured here is a B-36, the world's largest and most far-ranging land-based bomber. It is the target of two-pronged criticism. The Navy argues that carrier-based bombers are the nation's first line of defense.

PARIS, May 14 -- According to estimates by experts who have been giving careful attention to the subject, the membership of the French Communist party has fallen off approximately 30 per cent during the past three years.

The first session of the Eighty-first Congress has been under way for nineteen weeks and is to last eleven more. This is how the important items in President Truman's program have progressed so far, and the outlook for the future.

A BRIDGE player develops countless habits in play. Certain patterns suggest specific treatment, and the player proceeds along the habitual lines without conscious thought. That this is so is fortunate. Otherwise the play of every bridge hand would take practically forever.

EVEN the visitors who always assert they would hate to live here admit that New York has its points. One, at least to the epicure, is its fragrant, flavorsome bakeries, where bakers of many origins turn out Polish babka, Italian panettone, Scotch shortbread, French brioche.

Perhaps one of the nicest questions to be posed at the coming Paris meeting of the Big Four Foreign Ministers will be whether the Marshall Plan benefits would be extended to a united Germany. In other words, would the aid of the ERP now being given to West Germany be given also to East Germany if an agreement is reached on unification?

TEHERAN, Iran, May 14 -- Negotiations between the Iranian Government and the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company for revision of the company's concession to give Iran a larger share of profits have broken down temporarily.

A FOLDBOAT trip down the Rio Grande River in the Big Bend country of southwest Texas is an adventure that provides many of the challenges of frontier exploration. It is not a holiday to be recommended to the average city-born-and-bred tourist.

Edward Crankshaw in "Is a Settlement With Russia Possible?" declares, "All great peoples have their dreams." Ours he describes as "The American dream of bringing the joys of mass-production and the drugstore to every African village."
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 14 -- It was announcd today that the Hungarian Government has prohibited the transshipment of Czechoslovak exports to Yugoslavia across Hungarian territory.

ST. LOUIS, May 14 (AP) -- With Roy Sievers slamming the ball and Al Papai doing the mound work, the St. Louis Browns moved back into the victory column today with a 8-3 triumph over the Detroit Tigers.

BALTIMORE, May 14 -- A rip-roaring run in the rain resulted in a head decision for Greentree Stable's Capot over Isidor Bieber's Palestinian in the $110,870 Preakness Stakes at Pimlico today, with both colts smashing the track record for a mile and three-sixteenths.
That was a magnificent layout of Elephant Hunt photographs from the Bronx Zoo's current exhibition in THE TIMES Magazine. I would like to add a footnote about the photographer.

CHICAGO, May 14 -- The Chicago Daily News today published a dispatch from Albany, N. Y., stating that "three veteran newspaper reporters covering Capitol news (there) have been drawing pay for part-time state-appointed jobs from four to fourteen years."

The world's largest corporate enterprise, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, has reached the peak of its post-war expansion program, the accomplishment of which required about $2,750,000 of new capital each business day since the end of the war.

IRIS, peonies and other late spring - flowering perennials will be featured on the two-day program, sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES, in Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, New York City, on May 24 and 25. Sessions will be held at 2:30 P. M. each afternoon, and at 8 P. M. on May 24.

THIS book is too short. I wouldn't know just how much longer it ought to be, but I feel that the author surely must have limited or cut certain of these sketches of American heroes of husbandry to a point where he himself bled inwardly; and there are points where even the reader suffers mildly, wanting more.

THE veil of secrecy which surrounded the deliberations of the Joint Anglo-American Film Council in Washington last month was ripped asunder the other day with the result that dissension has arisen among the top brass of the American industry.

PHILADELPHIA, May 14 -- Sales reported last week by women's apparel stores in Philadelphia showed a gain of 12 per cent above a year ago, and for the four weeks ending May 7 were 13 per cent larger than in the corresponding 1948 period.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The American Association of University Women today announced the award of $40,750 in fellowships to twenty-seven women whose research projects were judged as valuable in extending human knowledge.

SHANGHAI, May 14 -- The growing battle for Asia's greatest city continued tonight. The action was primarily a battle for Shanghai's outlet to the sea at Woosung. On the other sides of the city the Nationalists were withdrawing to their final defense line in the out-skirts, needing fewer men to hold.

Only two of the compositions offered on the program of the sixth concert of the Festival of Contemporary Music last night in the McMillin Theatre -- a concert given in collaboration with the National Institute of Arts and Letters -- invite remarks.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., May 14 -- A pension plan financed by employer contributions of 15 cents for every dozen pairs of hosiery manufactured was proposed by the American Federation of Hosiery Workers yesterday as a demand in this year's contract negotiations.
TOKYO, May 14 -- Japan wants permission to "borrow" plants, once designated for reparations, until the peace conference settles their fate.

AS any reader of the Bobbsey Twins will recall, if one throws together the correct proportion of bouncy, attractive young people, parental interference, spunk and plain high spirits, the result will be a happy little concoction to while away a rainy afternoon in granny's attic.

The General Assembly's approval of the first United Nations news-gathering convention was hailed yesterday by Erwin D. Canham, United States delegate, as the creation of safeguards for correspondents and news agencies against possible future attempts to restrict the freedom of the press.

GENEVA, May 14 -- Genial quips and soft words characterized the Eastern European speeches in the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe today on the usually explosive question of Western discrimination against trade with Communist countries.

TECHNICALLY, Lanny Budd's long and perilous labors are not yet over. Not until July will Viking publish "O Shepherd, Speak!," tenth and ultimate volume of Upton Sinclair's feverish epic, in which Lanny considers the Battle of the Bulge, the Yalta Conference, the atom bomb and finally the post-war world.
THIS is more than just another animal story for young children. Hodie, a French poodle, emerges from it as the friendliest, happiest dog that ever won his way into a youngster's heart.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 14 -- A section of a grandstand collapsed beneath the weight of fans at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway today, causing serious injury to one Indianapolis man and cuts and bruises to twenty-eight others.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 14 -- The International Red Cross, which is responsible for the feeding and care of refugees in Palestine, is urging United Nations Palestine relief headquarters here to recognize a large part of the resident population in parts of Palestine held by the Arab Legion as resident refugees.

BUENOS AIRES, May 14 -- President and Senora Peron put on a full scale show this morning at a railroad station ceremony marking the Government's acquisition of the small Buenos Aires Central Line, the last foreign-held route in the country.

An altar cloth or antependium embroidered by King Gustaf V of Sweden will be presented on his behalf by a representative of the Swedish Consulate to Bethlehem Lutheran Church of Brooklyn. Third Avenue and Pacific Street, as a seventy-fifth anniversary gift at 4 P. M. today, it was announced yesterday.

DALLAS, May 14 -- Hot, dry weather stimulated department store sales of late spring and summer apparel, particularly sportswear, shoes, sporting goods and other seasonal lines. The farm outlook remained relatively bright despite reports from Northwest Texas and the Panhandle South Plains area that 300,000 to 500,000 acres of cotton would have to be replanted as the result of excessive rain, hail and storms.

Despite the sharp criticism leveled at what is considered needless delay in establishing minimum export packaging standards as a bar to huge cargo claims losses, completion of an international survey on loss causes will be awaited before further steps are taken in a recently started improvement program, it was learned yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, May 14 (AP) -- The CIO United Steelworkers formally asked today for a fourth-round pay increase for 706,000 workers. The demand for an unspecified wage increase, plus social benefits including pensions, was made in letters to 835 steel companies.

Ports on the Gulf of Mexico, which have admittedly taken considerable business away from New York and other Atlantic gateways by an energetic and sustained drive for business, are now engaged in a program of port improvements to provide facilities for an expected increase in traffic.

Cutbacks in production have become general in most metal lines, from output of mines to production of finished products, it was revealed in a canvass of metal-working companies here last week. For the first time since 1939 zinc mining output was reduced to a point 25 per cent below peak rates, while leading gray iron foundries reported cut-backs adding up to as much as 25 per cent compared with operating rates in January.

Formation of a Management Control of Records as the first step in a plan for systematic disposal of many tons of useless old city documents will soon be recommended to Mayor O'Dwyer by his Municipal Archives Committee, it was learned yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 14 -- Mr and Mrs. Robert Lee Henry's aged chestnut gelding, Ace, in the working hunter division, and Mrs. Nat Krupnick's aged chestnut mare, the prominent jumper, Liberty Belle, took leads in their respective groups as the two-day New York Military Academy-Secor Farms horse show got under way at the grounds of Secor Farms Riding Club, Hillair Circle, today.

ALL lovers of French eighteenth century art know, even if only second-hand or by hear-say, how much later generations owe to the passion and industry of the Goncourt brothers. The unflagging enthusiasm and strange genius of that unique literary team revived interest in the art of the eighteenth century when, with the exception of a very few private collectors, its productions were both scorned and rejected.

THE sun shone brightly upon the little square of St. Christoph, a fashionable Austrian resort. From her hotel balcony Viktoria Lorien Enzenfeld watched the villagers gathering for a parade. She saw, too, an attractive stranger sitting below on the terrace.

IN "American Freedom and Catholic Power" Paul Blanshard, a free-lance journalist and head of New York City's Department of Investigation under Mayor Fiorello La Guardia, expands into a full-length book several articles he wrote for The Nation some months ago.

Today marks the halfway point in negotiations between three Congress of Industrial Organizations maritime unions and a committee representing thirty-eight Atlantic and Gulf Coast steamship operators. Contract talks commenced on April 15 for new agreements to replace those expiring on June 15.

Thirty-seven per cent of 1,828 tuberculosis patients left hospitals and sanatoriums in and around New York prematurely and against medical advice in 1947, according to a report of a survey made public yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The State Department announced today that President Truman would submit the military assistance program for Western Europe to Congress soon and would recommend a six-point program designed to assist the members of the North Atlantic pact and other free nations in rebuilding their defenses.

THE week just past has seen tulips in the height of their beauty throughout much of the New York area. Now that the season is almost at an end, this is a good opportunity to review the list of varieties which will afford the most satisfaction if planted this coming fall.

A RECENT letter suggested (facetiously?) an investigation into the reasons why producers buy bad plays, why people invest in them, why directors take on the chores of staging them, and finally why "respectable actors" act in them.

ARENA theatre, or central stage, technique -- which finds the actors performing without the conventional scenery and with the audience on all four sides -- will be used tonight on television when Shakespeare's "Romeo and Juliet" is presented from 9 to 10 o'clock over NBC-TV.

Johnny Meagher, lanky right-hander, pitched Manhattan College to a 12-4 victory over C. C. N. Y. yesterday. The upset at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx was a serious blow to the second-place Beavers' Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference hopes.

DURING the last few years many economists have been wondering if scholarship in their reasonably well-rooted discipline has entered upon a serious decline. Students are now obliged to become familiar with a formidable array of techniques, and the question is whether they learn to handle this conceptual and statistical apparatus at the expense of a knowledge of the history of economic ideas.

Apropos of nothing at all except the middle of May, this is a delightful time of year for a birthday. Some people have their birthdays on Christmas or the Fourth of July, but the really fortunate ones have theirs in mid-May, when the world is sweet and the leaves are new and the birds are full of song. No one could ask for more on an anniversary.

SALT LAKE CITY, May 14 -- A flare-up in the long-lived animosity between the United States Forest Service and Western stockmen is arousing new interest in the Mountain States. This spring rangers, seeking to check overgrazing and resultant erosion on Government lands, have been increasingly cautious in issuing permits for running cattle and sheep in upland preserves.
The second annual Jewish Youth Week will open here today with a city-wide program at the Ninety-second Street Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association, it was announced yesterday.

Africa and the Middle East are the present-day magnets for American capital seeking investment outside the United States, bankers concerned with foreign investments said last week. Other areas which once drew surplus monies in volume from the United States have lost much of their appeal because of international developments and because of excessive restrictions on the transfer of currency and general operations, it was added.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 14 -- Bank deposits in Minnesota and the Dakotas fell off as farmers dug into their pockets to put in the spring crop and prepare for another good growing season, report to the State Banking Commissioners showed this week.

Early last week attention was drawn to the deplorable conditions that too frequently exist in public homes, when it was learned that thirty aged residents of a county home in Indiana had died within thirty-nine days, apparently from malnutrition.

"CRUSADE IN EUROPE," the March of Time film version of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's book, holds every promise of being important television for a number of reasons. Not the least of these, be sure, is that the home viewer finally has a chance to see a fresh and arresting film especially edited for the needs of television.
INDEPENDENCE, Mo., May 14 -- A painters' union in the American Federation of Labor today protested, to President Truman, the hiring of a nonunion man to paint the "summer White House" here.

A new playground was opened yesterday by the Police Athletic League at 421-425 West Forty-seventh Street on property adjoining St. Albert's Roman Catholic Church. The Rev. Cyril C. Roosens, pastor of St. Albert's, and James B. Nolan, Sixth Deputy Police Commissioner, participated in the dedication exercises.

The greatest single fault of the German education system, from the American viewpoint, has always been its authoritarian pattern. Highly centralized, the system took its orders only from above. More important, the school system was always kept isolated from the people themselves.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., May 14 -- Ben Higginson of Newburgh, who won his first championship in the same tournament back in 1912, proved that he has lost none of his skill today when he captured the 200-target singles crown at the New York Athletic Club's Travers Island.

Tightening competitive conditions are leading many well-known manufacturers to redesign their products, Francesco Collura. New York industrial designer, of 444 Madison Avenue, disclosed yesterday. He emphasized that these companies are learning they can reduce production costs by simplifying designs.

Vaudeville was supposed to have died some years ago -- but it didn't. It managed to earn its coffee and cakes from night clubs, radio, even carnivals and circuses. Then some of it got on a bacon-and-eggs standard through television. Now, this week, it's coming back to the Palace.
BERLIN, May 14 -- "Let us put Germany, so to speak, in the saddle! You will see that she can ride."

The hottest frontier of the cold war -- the blockade of Berlin -- was eliminated last week, but there were few signs that a broad settlement between Russia and the West is likely in the near future. The propaganda war went on; it was waged with undiluted acid.

With one exception, local upholstered furniture factories are working thirty-five hours weekly, the normal work week without overtime, a spokesman for the city's seventy major living room furniture producers disclosed yesterday. He said overtime operations were the rule in the first quarter, but sharp declines in April retail orders have forced all but one large operator, to curtail production.

JANE COWL, who wears with easy grace the theatre's "distinguished lady" mantle, has finally succumbed to the blandishments of Hollywood.
