At least she has broken her thirty-two years of resistance to movie offers long enough to play a prominent character role as a distinguished lawyer and mother of Robert Montgomery in the high comedy "Come Be My Love."

A "plug-in" television system which can be moved from job to job in any factory has been developed for industrial uses by Remington Rand, Inc. Called Vericon, it differs from ordinary television in that impulses are delivered over a coaxial cable to a master viewer, instead of through the air.

Retail promotions here last week centered mainly on summer apparel and accessories, with emphasis on bemberg sheer print dresses, cotton dresses, summer suits, straw handbags, gloves and raincoats, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the Retail News Bureau, Inc.

The writer of Topics of The Times of May 3 has my deepest sympathy. Poor man, he never knew the delights of New Year's Day in this city in the closing decades of the last century. At that period gentlemen, old and young, dressed in their finest, spent New Year's Day, from mid-morning often till late in the evening, calling on all their lady friends.

Just picked up THE TIMES Magazine for March 6, 1949, and regret very much having missed one article until now. The article was, "It's a Woman's World in Alaska," by Richard L. Neuberger. I want to ask him -- and now -- why don't the Alaska males and the United States females get together? Such shortage of males in the United States and a shortage of females in Alaska!

Every session of the United Nations General Assembly has ended with a rush of last-minute business. There have been night meetings of committees and the full Assembly in efforts to complete the agenda. Some of the Assembly's most important votes have been taken during the final rush -- for example, the Palestine partition resolution, which passed on the last day of the 1947 session.
Has post-war competition evolved a revolutionary new type of factory for American industry?
PITTSBURGH (AP) -- A drop in steel production might make perfumes and dyes scarcer or higher in price.

A native preacher from the Solomon Islands, who aided in the rescue of 500 allied soldiers during the war, will come to New York, May 24, on the S. S. Mauritania to renew friendships with the former service men.

PARIS, May 14 -- Deputies for the Foreign Ministers of Britain, France and the United States held today the first of a series of meetings designed to harmonize the views of these powers regarding Germany before they meet with the Soviet Union in the four-power Foreign Ministers' conference in Paris on May 23.

I was pleased to read that efforts are being made to reduce speculation in theatre tickets. It was reported that people who brag about getting tickets to a hit at the last minute hindered any attempt at correcting this activity.

DUBLIN, May 14 -- Politically this has been a tense week in the capital of the Irish Republic. Within three weeks the atmosphere of friendliness between Dublin and London in which the republic was inaugurated has changed into one of estrangement.

Arthur Miller's "Death of a Salesman," which has received the Pulitzer Prize, the Drama Critics Circle award and the Antoinette Perry award, is being published this week in book form. It is the first play to become a Book-of-the-Month Club selection.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The United Mine Workers Welfare and Retirement Fund reported today it had spent $106,840,139 in benefits for soft coal miners and their families since payments began two years ago.

Price trends on industrial materials, except soap, tallow and steel, appear headed downward for the short term, but the long-term indications are that the end of the inflationary cycle has not been reached, according to an economic survey made by a New York purchasing agency.

PSYCHOANALYSIS may be likened to the latest act in the drama of scientific development that began some 400 years ago with the dawn of the modern era. Man discovered the world about him, explored the earth, the physical and chemical forces at play in the universe and penetrated the mysteries of living organisms, including his own body.

There remains on the list of matters of which the Security Council is seized the item of Hyderabad. Nothing has been done for some months concerning this item, though the situation should command the attention of those who are interested in maintaining the prestige and authority of the United Nations.

Rayon goods suppliers once again are faced with the problem of widespread disregard of design ownership, it was pointed out yesterday. Attempts at self-regulation by converters through utilization of a design protection agreement have been temporarily abandoned, according to an announcement of the Textile Distributors Institute, and the industry anticipates an increase in "sharp" competitive practices.

Week-end liquor prices offered no inducements to bargain hunters. Old price levels were being maintained pending final outcome of the State Liquor Authority's application to the Court of Appeals in Albany tomorrow for permission to appeal last week's decision by the Appellate Division invalidating mandatory fair trade.

THE 130 photographs picked in the sixth annual "News Pictures of the Year" competition, jointly sponsored by the University of Missouri School of Journalism and the Encyclopaedia Britannica Book of the Year, are reproduced in "The Great Pictures 1949" (New York: Greenberg, publisher. $3.50).

LONDON, May 14 (AP) -- France and Sweden advanced to the quarter-final round of European zone Davis competition today by scoring decisive doubles victories over Denmark and Norway respectively. They joined Yugoslavia and Switzerland, already in the round of eight.
Dr. John J. Theobald, Dean of Administration at City College, is the latest candidate for the presidency of Queens College, it was learned last night.

The circus has left town, but this week, at the American Museum of Natural History, another show that is as thrilling in its way, has opened for an eleven-day run. It is the annual Hobby Show for Older Persons organized by the Welfare Council.

MAKING a home takes time, thought and usually a good deal of money. You can do without the money -- or cut it from a good deal to a very little -- if you are able and willing to substitute the only alternatives that we know of: creative imagination and elbow grease. It was the substitute formula that produced the interiors shown here, from the Connecticut home of Commander and Mrs. Clinton Heath.

MR. TRUMAN has made clear that he proposes to continue the New Deal. That policy, which some critics thought an aberration, which others hoped was merely a temporary concession to the depression, is now seen to be a permanent feature of American political history.

MELBOURNE, Australia, May 15 -- There have lately been trickling back to Australia excerpts from an agency dispatch published in United States newspapers declaring that Australia was virtually defenseless and that, in the event of another armed conflict in the Pacific, the United States forces would have to bear the main burden.

"Legislators" refused to go home after considering a record number of important national bills at the final session yesterday of the fifth annual model Congress conducted by the Hunter College Political Science Department and Club.

Five records were set yesterday as Boys High won its own track and field carnival at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island. The 1,200 contestants from some sixty schools vied for both open and novice honors.

With all four candidates for Representative in the Twentieth Congressional District increasing their efforts in preparation for the special election next Tuesday to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Sol Bloom, the result last night appeared to be in doubt.
TRIPOLI, Libya, May 14 (AP) -- Police today dispersed groups of Arabs demonstrating against the United Nations action regarding distribution of Italy's pre-war colonies.
Two thousand persons attended the fiftieth anniversary dinner of the National Jewish Hospital at Denver last night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
Nine New York State "good-will ambassadors" will be sent to Europe to spend the summer in promoting closer understanding between communities here and abroad, it was learned yesterday.

IN 1935 the United States consumed 450,000 tons of rubber. Almost every ton of it came from trees in far-away plantations. In 1945 we used twice this amount of rubber. Almost 90 per cent of it came from reactor tanks scattered around our own country.

GUANAJUATO, Mexico -- The average Guanajuatense feels the same grandee-like pride in his home town as the proper Bostonian or the resident of Charleston. To the outsider this seems, even after a short stay, a perfectly reasonable attitude.

WE are still safe from regimentation. When two professional writing men can go from New York to the hills of Connecticut, live there, and write books as different as these about their experiences -- while this can happen, individualism still flourishes.

LONDON, May 14 -- Not the least important of the questions posed for the West by the Communist victory in China is the impact that the sweep of the Communist armies toward Canton, Burma, Thailand and Indo-China will have on the 674,000,000 persons who inhabit the non-Russian countries of Asia.

Roy Jacobs and Richard Kline of Barnard advanced to the singles semi-finals of the Eastern interscholastic lawn tennis championships for private day and boarding schools at the Boulevard Gardens courts. Woodside, yesterday. The tournament is sponsored by St. John's University.

American colleges and universities have shown a distinct trend in recent years toward supplementing classroom study with field work. This educational practice, once limited to graduate work and a few undergraduate specialized fields, is now becoming an important and valuable part of the liberal-arts curriculum.

Romanesque, Gothic and Renaissance objects of art, from the collection of the late Joseph Brummer, internationally known art dealer of this city, were sold for $105,845 yesterday at the final session of a four-day sale in the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.

INNES enthusiasts will be glad to know that his new book is one of his best, a fine suspense novel with the kind of penetrating and humorous observations on the frailty of human nature that one has come to expect of him.

JOHN ALDEN KNIGHT is one of our few really top-flight writers on hunting and fishing. He is an excellent observer blessed with a mind both analytical and experimental, and is a notably clear, concise writer. All these qualities are evident in "Black Bass."

How weak is Edward Crankshaw's dialectical point ("Is a Settlement With Russia Possible?") in rejecting "the absurd generalization that dictatorships must expand unceasingly or perish." His own example of Franco proves it.

SO that my name may not have been taken completely in vain, may I be permitted a few words apropos the American composer George Maynard's letter, published in THE TIMES on May 1, in which he pleaded the cause of the unplayed, unsung and, alas, even "unanswered" American composer.

LITTLETON, Col. AS editor of a country weekly newspaper, my job, it is generally assumed, is to write about my own community, to tell people what goes on in and around the town of Littleton. I am supposed to let the big daily papers, and others who know about such things, cover the problems of the world; I am supposed to stick to Main Street.

The Roscoe B. Jackson Memorial Laboratory which was destroyed by the fire that swept Bar Harbor two years ago is being rapidly rebuilt, thanks to the financial assistance that it has received from philanthropic well-wishers who realized what the loss of thousands of inbred mice meant to scientists who specialized in cancer research.

AT his news conference last week President Truman once more repeated his request for $4 billion more in taxes and for the stand-by wage and price controls for which he asked last January to combat inflation.

Two divisions of Soviet troops in the Ukraine and two in the Caucasus area are aiding local police forces in intermittent but bloody warfare against anti-Communist guerrillas in those regions, according to information seeping out of Russia.

MERLE COLBY, a man of intense if muddled good-will, has written a problem novel. The scene is Washington, the time a future distant. The theme of the book -- no, that ought to be written with capital letters. The Theme of the Book is: "Science: Shall She Be Free?"

They call New Jersey many things. To its Chamber of Commerce enthusiasts it is the "Garden State"; to its critics it is sometimes the "Mosquito State." But to cruising and vacationing yachtsmen New Jersey is getting pretty close to becoming a paradise afloat.

BONNIE BESS, the weathervane horse, was subject not only to the four winds of heaven but also to the winds of fate. For a hundred years she had foretold the weather from her perch on a comfortable barn, but when the farmer moved away Bess was left alone and forlorn.

ALTHOUGH Mr. Anthony Powell maintains that the name of John Aubrey is "now widely known," that "in English literary history * * * he is one of the most arresting figures of the seventeenth century," this antiquary's fame has surely not spread so far as that of his contemporaries, Samuel Pepys and John Evelyn -- than whom Aubrey was no less interesting and certainly as versatile a character.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., May 14 -- Increased unemployment during the last few weeks in various fields, and proposals to increase taxes from both national and local levels are giving labor and management in the Deep South considerable concern.

The tenth in the spring series of art lectures sponsored by the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street, will be held on Tuesday at 6 P. M. The topic wil be "Art Expression: a Human Need," the speaker, Shirley Silbert of the New York Society of Craftsmen.

IN his new novel Charles Bonner has attempted to establish the necessity of what he would call the "romantic" perspective in contemporary society. To work out this theme he has chosen various characters whose viewpoints range from unrealistic fantasy to complete prag matism, and set them in motion around his protagonist, a young man named Eliot Kent.

THERE'S something stupendous about Frank Yerby's new novel of Pride Dawson, a prize robber baron who got his start in New York in the Eighteen Seventies. In fact, everything runs to excesses -- poverty and wealth, goodness and badness,

The same week that put the spotlight on our German policy with the lifting of the Berlin blockade brought our Japanese policy into sharp focus with the announcement that reparations would be suspended. The two policies, German and Japanese, are not merely similar; they are facets of an attempted solution of the same problem. What do we propose to do with our former enemies?

The United States will not ask for any allocation of German scrap metal for the third quarter of this year when the Organization for European Economic Cooperation meets on May 24 in Paris to establish quotas for nations eligible for a share of the material.

THE premiere radio performances of three major musical works will be heard on the air this week. Two of the works -- Randall Thompson's Third Symphony and Paul Hindemith's Concerto for woodwind, harp and orchestra -- will be offered by the CBS Symphony Orchestra at 3 P. M. today.

IT is hard to take "Trends in Literature" very seriously. Mr. Shipley has an impressive number of books to his credit as author or editor -- "Dictionary of World Literature," "Encyclopedia of Literature," "The Quest for Literature," among others.

Further evidence that aureomycin, the golden-colored antibiotic, is effective in combating virus pneumonia, against which penicillin and the sulfa drugs are useless, is presented in the American Journal of Medicine by Drs. Yale Kneeland Jr., Harry M. Rose and Count Dillon Gibson, all of the College of Physicians and Surgeons (Columbia).

SAN JUAN, P. R., May 14 (UP) -- Asserting that "the press can improve the state, but the state cannot improve the press," Gov. Luis Munoz Marin announced today that he would veto a bill creating the Press Institute of Puerto Rico to regulate the practice of professional journalism.

With both opposing pitchers going the full route, the pace-setting St. John's University baseball team edged out a fighting Fordham unit, 2 -- 1, in thirteen innings of tense and exciting play in the Metropolitan Baseball Conference yesterday at Dexter Park, Woodhaven, Queens.

BERLIN, May 14 -- The Soviet Union's diplomatic campaign to achieve German unity on a "democratic" basis at the forthcoming Paris meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers will open in Germany tomorrow when voting begins to select delegates to the "all-German People's Congress."

ATLANTA, May 14 -- Southerners who have been vigorously opposing proposed Federal civil-rights laws pointed to the action of a Georgia grand jury this week in support of their argument that sentiment in this section is mounting against Ku Kluxism and that efforts are being intensified toward local solutions of racial persecution problems.

SOME months ago Nora Kaye married and left the ballet for good. Some weeks ago, when the Ballet Theatre reopened, she was back in the fold. So much for ballerinas who retire in their youth and at the height of their powers.

HORSE RACING Greentree's Capot won the $110,870 Preakness Stakes by a head from Palestinian yesterday, with Noble Impulse third and Ponder, the Kentucky Derby victor, fifth. Lowering Pimlico's record for one mile and three-sixteenths to 1:56 under a strong ride by Ted Atkinson, Capot paid 5 to 2 and earned $79,985. Loser Weeper took the Metropolitan Handicap at Belmont Park.

BOSTON, May 14 -- A $585,000 health center to provide free diagnostic care for 15,000 workers in Boston and eastern Massachusetts was opened today by the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, AFL. At a banquet marking the opening, David Dubinsky, president of ILGWU, pointed out that the center was the ninth of its kind sponsored by the union.

Your editorial of May 4 in favor of the bill for federal aid to education asserted that the case for such aid "rests on a simple and obvious set of facts. * * * If there were no state lines, no one could sensibly argue that a child in Tennessee should be permitted to receive educational opportunity inferior to that received by a child in New York or California."

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 14 -- Delegations of various groups in Palestine are reported here to have gone to Damascus and offered to Premier Husni Zayim an aid force of 20,000 Palestinians if conflict should break out on the Israeli-Syrian frontier with Israel.

Flying squads of union men, members of Local 202, International Brotherhood of Teamsters, AFL, will blockade ferry, tunnel and bridge approaches to New York beginning at 8 o'clock tonight in an attempt to cut off produce shipments from New Jersey, i was announced yesterday.

INTERSTATE bus transportation, with fares averaging one and a half to two cents a mile, or approximately half of those on railroads, continues to be the vacationer's most economical means of transportation. And the opening of hundreds of miles of new through routes will give this summer's bus travelers more rapid service on regular runs than ever before, as time-consuming change-overs are eliminated.

PARIS, May 14 -- For three days now, movers, electricians and telephone linemen have been busy putting the Palais Rose, one of the gaudiest mansions in Paris, in shape for the meeting of the Big Four Foreign Ministers on May 23.

Cottons are becoming ever more an American fashion. Small wonder. They are lovely in quality and design. In their use they range from covert type, frequently used for workmen's clothes, out of which Brigance has made some unusual designs to the striped chambray which Ceil Chapman has so cleverly had stitched in shell pattern to give it an unusual appearance.

IN comparison to its creative situation after the First World War, German music on the whole appears to be rather on the conservative side today. The young generation of composers in particular seems to be somewhat skeptical about new methods of musical thinking.

When he received the Leo Hendrik Baekeland award from the North Jersey Section of the American Chemical Society, Prof. Eugene G. Rochow of Harvard enlivened the occasion by telling his hearers how wonderful it would be if chemistry were exploited to the full.

When Prof. Eugene G. Rochow received the biennial Leo Hendrik Baekeland Award of the New Jersey Section of the Americal Chemical Society last week, he took the opportunity to do some speculating about the future in the vein of H. G. Wells. As a chemist he naturally confined himself to his own field.

Indians now residing on eight reservations in New York State long have enjoyed full benefits of educational and social security measures, tribal leaders and welfare and educational officials disclosed last week. However, some tribal spokesmen, who are fearful of encroachments on Indian rights, expressed yesterday a complete distrust of pending Federal legislation that is designed to grant to New York State courts extended jurisdiction over Indian civil actions.

The average annual income of sales executives in New York City -- those in managerial positions with salesmen under their supervision and a voice in direction of sales policies -- was $20,575 in 1948, according to a survey of 1,800 members of the Sales Executive Club of New York.

WITH "Lost Boundaries" currently in the cutting and scoring stages here, Louis de Rochemont's independent RD-DR Corporation will return to the same Portsmouth, N. H., scene of operations sometime in July to start work on "Smutty Nose," the second film under that company's banner.

NO one was noticeably astonished when "Death of a Salesman" made a clean sweep of all the prizes during the early spring. By common consent Arthur Miller's threnody on the last day of an aging drummer is the finest play of a season that has included also one of Maxwell Anderson's finest dramas, "Anne of the Thousand Days."
PRINCETON, N. J., May 14 -- Georgetown's varsity baseball team pounded out fourteen hits and capitalized on six Princeton errors to down the Tigers, 6 -- 1, on University Field today.

For the second time in its history, the United Nations General Assembly asked the Union of South Africa yesterday to get together with India and try to settle their bitter quarrel over the treatment of Asiatic and Negro minorities by the Pretoria Government.

SANDRA MICHAEL is a neat and pert housewife who wears slacks and is convinced that the daytime radio listener can absorb something more than emotional be-bop. The ranking dissenter among authors of morning serials, she has no hesitation in injecting in her plots such meaty matters as war, peace, liberalism, and academic freedom.

WEBSTER'S New Collegiate Dictionary is a revision of the Fifth Edition of Webster's Collegiate Dictionary. An increase in page size has made possible the inclusion of 125,000 entries as against 110,000 in the Fifth Edition, as well as 2,300 illustrations as compared to 1,800 in the older book.

Vice President Alben W. Barkley and Senator Irving M. Ives paid tribute to Israel last night at a Madison Square Garden celebration of the first anniversary of that state. They called upon the United States to help the new nation in the interests of democracy and peace.

MALVERN, Pa., May 14 -- Mister Mars, 8-year-old brown gelding owned by Miss Betty Bosley, won a leg on the Radnor Hunt Cup in the feature timber race at the nineteenth annual spring meeting of the Radnor Hunt Club.

J. GOLDSBOROUGH BRUFF failed to graduate from West Point, for reasons not clear to his biographers. But he used his two years of military training there to good advantage twenty years later when he marshaled a group of other well-breds to form the "Washington City and California Mining Association" and departed from the capital for the gold fields on April 2, 1849.

CHICAGO, May 14 (AP) -- Trends in grains were mixed today on the Board of Trade. The near-by months tended lower, but December contracts showed a firm tone from the start. Lard, which was inclined to lag yesterday, had a good rally.
RICHMOND, Va., May 14 -- The political organization led by United States Senator Harry F. Byrd is facing its severest test in twenty years. The test will Come in the gubernatorial primary on Aug. 2.
VIENNA, May 14 -- The Hungarian people will go to the polls tomorrow to cast a vote, the result of which is absolutely pre-ordained and the purpose of which would seem to be a mystery.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- American Federation of Labor unions won more collective bargaining elections than the Congress of Industrial Organizations in the first quarter of 1949, but apparently the CIO won bigger ones.

A TOTAL of 247,175 passports, the greatest number ever issued or renewed during the space of a year, was processed by the State Department in the twelve-month period ended March 31, according to the department's first annual compilation since before the war.
A BRIGHT-EYED little man with an iridescent duck feather in his hatband stopped me the other day and said in a hoarse whisper, "Tell me, what shall I do? I am free, at last!"

THE polyglot population of this colorful, teeming city in the heart of French Morocco has settled back to normal existence after experiencing an uncommon period of excitement. This was occasioned by the filming of scenes here, with Tyrone Power and Orson Welles, for the Twentieth Century-Fox picturization of Thomas Costain's sprawling, historical adventure, "The Black Rose," and the simultaneous visit of the Sultan of Morocco, Sidi Mohammed, on his annual inspection tour.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., May 14 -- Proposals for "socialized medicine" aren't "one, two, three with what the Bureau of Reclamation and the Army Engineers are doing to take this country down the road to socialism," former Gov. Leslie A. Miller of Wyoming declared today.

TWO artists at the Betty Parsons Gallery illustrate one of the paradoxes of modern art -- that things are not what they seem. For the representational painter William Congdon sees by the light of his inner imaginative eye, while Adeline Kent, the abstract sculptor, creates her impersonal shapes from the world of visible organic forms.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The all-American mystery of who floored the GOP elephant at the last election was cleared up for the 680 guests at the Women's National Press Club annual dinner tonight when a spotlight settled on President Truman.

Arriving at New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, from Venezuela Friday night with the expectation of obtaining plastic surgery for a shattered jaw, Alessandro de la Cruz, a cabinet maker in Caracas for two years, was held by the immigration authorities at Ellis Island for a hearing tmorrow.

THE literature of France is never dead: whilst the critics cry that it is, the titles still come boiling from Publishers' Row. Take Jean Cocteau. Other passengers on the New York-Paris plane slept, but he improved each flying hour by writing a "Lettre aux Americains," which, of course, was promptly published upon his coming to French earth.

OMAHA., May 14 -- Synthetic fuel was a lively topic in the Middle West this week as Secretary of the Interior Julius A. Krug dedicated two new Government plants for extracting oil from coal at Louisiana, Mo.

THE only trouble with this story is that, having read it, 8-to-12-year-old boys and girls will want to leave home immediately to settle on a Texas ranch. Judy and Glenn Bartlett couldn't remember when the Box B had been one of the most important ranches in Texas.

The Physicians Forum, a national organization of physicians, announced yesterday its support of an independent slate of candidates for the annual election of officers of the New York County Medical Society, largest county group in the nation.

THE middle of May finds the season pretty well over, though there are still a few events of interest on the calendar. This week seems to run chiefly to ethnological matters, but with next Sunday's concert by Virginia Johnson we shall get into the modern dance again.

BOSTON, May 14 -- It has been rumored in the past that there is balm in Gilead, but the Dodgers are certain that there is none in Boston after loving their second straight extra-inning game to the Braves under the lights.

MOSCOW, May 14 -- The Soviet Union is not prepared to accept unquestionably any program for a German settlement agreed upon unilaterally by the three Western powers merely for the sake of achieving a general solution of the German question, it was stated today by the international observer of the newspaper Izvestia.

PARIS, May 14 -- Considerable relief is felt by circles of the politically moderate Third Force over Secretary of State Dean Acheson's declaration on Spain in which he publicly insisted upon the liberalization of the Franco regime and the restoration of civil rights.

IT is rare, indeed, that this corner has occasion within one week to hail the boldness and candor of two exceptional films. Yet that was our privilege this past week, and the thrill which this coincidence inspired has led us to wild and hopeful wondering whether maybe the millennium has set in, whether maybe the screen is maturing, instead of drifting toward gibbering idiocy.
The Holland Tunnel, completed in 1927 after seven years of construction, is built on a shell-within-a-shell plan. The outer rim is 1 5/8 inches of cast iron lined with 16 inches of concrete.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 14 -- Yale took advantage of Brown errors to gain its second astern Intercollegiate League victory by a score of 4 -- 2 today. The Elis have been set back in three circuit contests.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 14 (AP) -- The biggest pre-race crowd in Indianapolis Motor Speedway history -- variously estimated at 40,000 to 90,000 -- saw all this today:

MORE space will become available for travelers to Mediterranean ports with the maiden voyage of the liner La Guardia from New York to Naples and Genoa on May 27. The La Guardia, named for the late Mayor of New York, was formerly the General W. P. Richardson, a P-2 class type ship.

FOR those still unsated by current tales of high adventure and derring-do, this novel of the French and Indian War is sure to please. "With bow and arrow through the frontiers of colonial Pennsylvania" might well be its subtitle.

For the first time in eight years, machinery manufacturers are obtaining inventories of electric motors on consignment without investment of their own capital. In a canvass of equipment manufacturers here last week, purchasing executives said this trend now promises to insure sizeable reductions in the "cost of buying" by eliminating much of the costly "shopping for shipments" of postwar years.

NORFOLK, Va., May 14 -- Community efforts toward the elimination of racial barriers in the field of cultural opportunity have made progress here as a result of a current exhibit at the Norfolk Musuem of Arts and Sciences.

The eastbound tube of the Holland Tunnel, cleared in its damaged section by crews working through the night, is expected to be restored to service by late today or tomorrow, the Port of New York Authority said yesterday.

ANNUALLY, beginning in 1944, Irving Marsh and Edward Ehre have turned out a collection of the "best sports stories" of the year. "Best Sports Stories -- 1949" contains forty articles -- accounts of games, races and matches, personality pieces about sports figures and bits of sports history -- taken from newspapers and magazines in 1948.
DO children brought up under a permissive regime (having some "say" of their own) get along better when grown up?

BEAR MOUNTAIN -- Although the new 250-foot pool will not be ready for swimmers until Memorial Day, Palisades Interstate Park formally opened its summer season last week-end. Twelve thousand people were clocked in a week ago Saturday and the next day the crowd jumped to 35,000.
The Giant steamroller, on the move again, flattened the Phillies at the Polo Grounds yesterday for the second time inside of twenty-four hours.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The White House said today President Truman meant no criticism of House Democratic leaders in his letter to A. F. Whitney, president of the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen, in which he said he "never believed in any compromise on the labor program other than the amended Wagner Act."

The Treasury's decision on Friday to maintain the pattern of its bank-eligible security offerings aroused considerable disappointment in banking circles. The announcement that it would offer one-year, 1 1/4 per cent certificates in exchange for all $5,315,135,000 of its bonds and certificates falling due next month effectively blasted the prevailing expectation that a 1 5/8 per cent five-year note would be provided.

ONE section of American writing, finding its full expression in the Henry James-Edith Wharton school, has always been cosmopolitan in tone and international in theme. But by force of circumstance, including the landing craft and jeeps of World War II, it would now be hard to find any section of modern American writing that is not international.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The resignation of Gen. Lucius D. Clay as United States Military Governor in Germany, which formally takes place tomorrow, and his replacement by a High Commissioner will mean in real effect the turning over of the administration of Germany to civilian hands, with all that implies.

Financial markets remained in a stalemate last week as Federal legislation pertaining to labor laws and taxes lagged and business uncertainties continued. Mixed price trends were the rule on the New York Stock Exchange, where trading was at a slow pace.

THE last hundred years have seen new and more terrifying forms of authority. A new technique of seizing power, and wider opportunities of exercising it, have made many old terms obsolete, and presented political scientists with a new problem:

Officials representing three of France's most important industrial concerns arrived yesterday at Idlewild for a month's study of public relations and personnel administration techniques now employed by American industry.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., May 14 -- New York University's hopes for a seventh successive Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference championship suffered a severe jolt this afternoon when Arnold Wilschek tossed up a neat three-hitter as Hofstra blanked the Violets, 3 to 0.
CHICAGO, May 14 -- Purchase of Ed Klieman, 31-year-old right-handed pitcher, from the New York Yankees was announced today by the Chicago White Sox. The price was not disclosed.
John H. McCann has been appointed personnel director of the Taunton, Mass., plant of Swank, Inc., manufacturers of men's jewelry, leather and other accessories.

Under continuous and unrelenting pressure for more and more revenue there is a strong tendency on the part of taxing authorities to broaden the bases of taxes. This tendency is notably pertinent to the concept of income for income-tax purposes.
DUBLIN -- Ireland is an ideal country for a cycling trip. Untouched by two world wars, it possesses infinitely varied scenery and its people are traditionally friendly to Americans.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Prospects of a continued decline in the country's economy that would reduce Federal revenues $2,000,000,000 below President Truman's January budget estimate for the next fiscal year were reported today by Congress' professional staff of fiscal experts.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., May 14 -- Four classes were represented today in the first of the dual opening regattas at the Larchmont Yacht Club. The leaders were W. H. Stanley's International, Bumble Bee; Glen Macnary's Atlantic, Ann; Skip Etchells' Star, Shillalah, and Richard Becker's 210, Pride.

FOR the casual newspaper reader to understand such everyday events in the Middle East as the recent army coup in Syria and the Soviet Union's renewed propaganda attack on Iran it is almost indispensable to have some knowledge of the complex and tragic history of the Arab states and their near neighbors.

PHILADELPHIA, May 14 -- Hitting the jackpot with a rousing series of performances, Army's inspired squad made a complete runaway of an expectedly close battle for team honors with Yale and Cornell in the fifteenth annual outdoor track and field championships of the Heptagonal Association today.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., May 14 -- Although the administration of Mayor Frank Hague Eggers won't come to an end until next Tuesday noon, many job holders at the City Hall moved out of their offices today. A funereal atmosphere pervaded the high-ceilinged rooms which has been the focal point of the Hague machine since 1913.

GENEVA, May 14 -- One of the difficulties of an economic program on the massive scale of the Marshall Plan is that you never know what really has happened in one period until you are well along in the next.

THROUGHOUT New York State a vigorous campaign is being waged this month to curb the increasing number of highway accidents. Thomas W. Ryan, director of safety for the state, has urged all motorists to check their cars and if any defects are found, to remedy them immediately.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 14 -- Residents of the Pacific Northwest are showing increasing interest in what a Columbia Valley Administration, as proposed by bills put before Congress with President Truman's blessing, will do for or do to them and the 220,000-square-mile Columbia River basin.

JUDITH ANDERSON brought to a close last night her engagement in "Medea" at the New York City Center and tomorrow night Maurice Evans keeps the playshop alight with a fortnight's return visit in "Man and Superman."

Elimination of racial barriers in this nation's naturalization process was advocated yesterday by Edward J. Shaughnessy, director of the New York District of the Immigration and Naturalization Service.

The Convention on the International Transmission of News and Right of Correction approved yesterday, after midnight and long travail, by the United Nations General Assembly cannot be regarded as a perfect document. But it represents progress in codifying safeguards to the free flow of information, and the test of experience can be counted on to supply the initiative for correction.
Loser Weeper had enough left at the finish to win the Metropolitan Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday.

Fourteen Methodist Bishops have signed a statement in support of the North Atlantic pact because "it will help to advance and protect the ideals for which our nation poured out life and treasure in two world conflicts," the Methodist information office announced here yesterday.

Lawyers for the American Committee for the Protection of Foreign Born scurried around yesterday, seeking to initiate a legal process to free Brunhilde Eisler, wife of the international Communist leader seized in England on a flight to Germany.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- At a current cost of more than $1,732,000,000 yearly, the Veterans Administration is paying nearly 3,000,000 veterans or dependents pensions (payments for non-service-connected disabilities) or compensation (payment for disabilities incurred in active service.)
THE Russian commandant looked sternly at the dark - eyed American girl. "Cats have whiskers and meow," he said. "You are pretty and speak English."

SOONER or later almost every small - property gardener wishes he had a small tractor. Before buying, however, certain factors might be considered. It must be decided, for example, how much land should be in cultivation to justify the purchase of a tractor.

CHICAGO, May 14 -- Construction permits for all types of building in the Chicago area in April continued an upward trend, reaching the highest dollar total since last July. Permits for housing units also increased and showed the highest number since September, 1947.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 14 -- A revolutionary light plane that lands and takes off in an area no larger than a tennis court, flies safely at a speed as low as twenty-seven miles an hour and makes about as much noise as an automobile was announced here today.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., May l4 -- Continuing his fine iron play and superb putting, Bobby Locke, the talented golfing visitor from Johannesburg, South Africa, kept the tabulators and his fellow competitors busy as he played the Wykagyl Country Club course in 68 today.

WHENEVER President Truman attends a public ceremony, his arrival is heralded not, as many might expect, by a popular waltz honoring his native Missouri, but by a stately tune first composed for a Scotsman.

WOOSUNG, China, May 14 -- West of this town, whose forts guard the sea approaches to Shanghai, a Nationalist fieldpiece let fly today. Startled at the explosion, a flock of swallows darted briefly to one side and then resumed its course.

The Girl Scout Council of Greater New York, Inc., will spend $200,000 on expanding its camping facilities to accommodate 11,649 Girl Scouts annually, doubling the present capacity. Mrs. Howard Phipps, president of the Council and chairman of the 1949 contributors' campaign made the announcement at a meeting of 100 voluntary Scout workers of the boroughs of Manhattan and the Bronx, in Council headquarters, 133 East Sixty-second Street.

Controversy over discharge notices to 800 Veterans Administration employes in the metropolitan area widened yesterday when disabled veteran workers complained that non-veterans were being retained after the cuts.

A few months ago this department published the news that the 200-inch telescope of Palomar had to be re-polished to correct infinitesimal distortions in the images of stars. The test pictures so far taken look better to laymen than they do to astrophysicists.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- What began as an economy ripple in the Senate some time ago seems now to be growing into a good-sized wave. The movement, which has acquired a deeply bi-partisan complexion, is feeding on increasing recognition of a long-apparent fact: Only by bold action in slashing appropriations can Congress hope to avert a deficit in the 1949-50 fiscal year without raising taxes.

FIFTEEN separate "expeditions" by horseback and canoe into the grandeur and solitude of the last remaining wilderness areas of the United States are offered this summer at reasonable cost to a maximum of 290 hardy vacationers by the American Forestry Association.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., May 14 -- The failure of parents to help children psychologically is preventing many children from becoming gifted, exceptional and "truly social," it was charged today by Dr. Margaret Ribble, New York psychiatrist.

Local and national leaders of the Brotherhood of Railway and Steamship Clerks, AFL, have decided to accept the recommendations of a special three-man Presidential fact-finding board in their dispute with the Railway Express Agency, it was learned yesterday.
CAMDEN, N. J., May 14 (AP) -- King Ranch's Ocean Brief set a new record for six furlongs at Garden State Park today in winning the $15,000-added Camden Handicap.

NO institution growing out of the American ideal of universal education is more significant than the American college; none is more important in furthering that ideal. Yet surprisingly enough no social scientist has yet published a realistic study of one of these typical American institutions.
THIS book of poems, Stephen Spender's fourth to be published in America, exhibits, as his poetry consistently has, the genuine feelings of a sensitive poet reacting to the horrors of our time.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday, and final prices were 12 to 21 points net lower.

IN the rush of seed planting during May, it is easy to forget some of the old favorites among the flowers. In spite of the tempting descriptions of new varieties, marigolds, zinnias and many other annuals have proved too dependable in color and for cutting to omit.

Thomas Joseph Kelly, holder of the Congressional 1Vfedal of Honor, and Miss Wilma Ann Grassman, !both of Brooklyn, after playing the ;roles of bridegroom and bride at !three annual fashion shows for the I Brooklyrt. Apostolate for the Deaf land Hard of Hearing, will have a 'real marriage ceremony on June 11, it was announced yesterday.

As a long-time student of international affairs, I congratulate you on Nathaniel Peffer's "Asia -- Spiritual Challenge to Us." Mr. Peffer has put his finger on the salient factor of our bankrupt foreign policy not only in the Far East but also in Europe.

READING in Friday's NEW YORK TIMES that the Sunday Book Review Section of May 1 would contain an article by Gerald W. Johnson on "American Writing, American Life" dealing with the ways the American novel represents the American character to the outside world, I urged my pupils (in a seventh term high school American literature course) to read it for the May 2 class.

Plans intended to foster private barter trade through a central registration and marketing organization in this city and London, designed to by-pass the "dollar shortage," were outlined here yesterday by Eigil LaFontaine, international president of the World Association of I. T. (Industry and Trade) Information, with headquarters at Geneva, Switzerland.

LONDON, May 14 -- With most of the returns in from the municipal elections held in England and Wales this week, it was evident that the Conservative party had scored a victory over Labor. Initial gains made by the Conservatives in smaller urban and rural constituencies were confirmed by the latest results in the London borough council elections.

Courses leading to a Doctor of Philosophy degree in basic medical sciences are now being offered for the first time by the University of Mississippi. Major fields of concentration have been established in anatomy, biochemistry, physiology, pathology, bacteriology and pharmacology.

WHETHER they stay in the city or go to the country, Americans will have the opportunity of hearing a good deal of music this summer. The special music festival at Aspen, Col., celebrating the bicentennial of the birth of Goethe, seems about the only new major series.
Hop a plane to Mexico City, visit glamorous Acapulco, see the buried city of Cuernavaca, Tasco Guadalupe, the Pyramid of the Sun and Moon -- and do it without spending one cent.
MAY is an active month for the garden clubs in the New York area. Many hold spring flower shows and plant sales, several of which are scheduled for this week.

Dr. Emanuel Neumann, president of the Zionist Organization of America, expressed regret last night that he could not withdraw his resignation from the Jewish Agency for Palestine because "there has been no clarification of the issue involving the administrative autonomy of our organization" and of Zionist bodies here and abroad.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 14 -- Harvard, Yale and Princeton surrendered to Cornell today the private monopoly they have held on the Joseph Wright Trophy, emblematic of lightweight rowing supremacy, in the fourth annual 150-pound regatta, sponsored by the Eastern Association of Rowing Colleges, on Lake Carnegie.
BERLIN, May 14 -- British authorities accused the Russians today of imposing new travel and transport restrictions between Eastern and Western Germany.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 14 -- Announcement that Prof. Joseph Reese Strayer, chairman of Princeton University's Department of History, would become the first holder of the newly created Dayton-Stockton professorship in history was made today by Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of the university.

PRAGUE, May 14 -- After a renewed press campaign against the Vatican in recent days, the chairman of the Czechoslovak People's Party, Minister of Transport Alois Petr, told his party's presidium yesterday that delays in the church-state negotiations since the deadlock of last February were "causing disquiet in broad sections of the Catholic public."

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- With more than 21,000 displaced persons settled in American homes, the first "bad DP" has yet to get off the boat. That is the record of nearly a year's operation of the twentieth century version of the tradition of America as a refuge for the persecuted.

In three sales this week the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street, will offer Americana and other books on Monday and Tuesday, English furniture and decorations on Wednesday and Thursday, and French provincial cabinetwork on Friday and Saturday.

IDWAL JONES' new book may seem too local and too special in its subject to interest readers who are neither Californians nor students of American wines. Actually "Vines in the Sun" is one more of an increasing number of books to which general readers may turn if they really wish to free their imaginations of those garish images which still spell California to most people east of the Rockies.

Making metal sandwiches has grown since the war into a ten to twelve million dollar a year industry. Prized by many users because they retain the desired properties of each of the metals used, these sandwiches are made by pressing two or more metals together.

BERLIN, May 14 -- Increased freedom to administer the Western sectors of Berlin was granted to the Magistrat, or City Council, by the occupying powers today in a "little occupation statute" that retained for the Western Allies all the major controls.

THE camera with the built-in darkroom -- the $89.75 Polaroid Land Camera which produces a 3 1/4x4 1/4-inch deckle-edge print one minute after taking a picture -- was made available to New York amateurs last week. No longer a laboratory curiosity, it produced consistently well-exposed pictures when the writer ran a few rolls through it to see how it holds up in ordinary use.

It was doubly interesting to read Roger McHugh's properly warm appreciation of the renaissance in the Abbey Theatre under Miss Ria Mooney's producing genius, since he has been in the past one of Dublin's most unsparing critics of the Abbey plays and players.

CINCINNATI, May 14 (AP) -- The Chicago Cubs, aided by a pair of homers and five walks, paraded seven runners across the plate in the fourth inning today and went on to bury the Cincinnati Reds under a 13-1 score, giving Dutch Leonard his first victory of the season.

The laying of the cornerstone of the new $5,000,000 Alfred E. Smith Memorial Building at St. Vincent's Hospital, Seventh Avenue and Twelfth Street, will take place May 23, at 4 P. M., with Cardinal Spellman officiating, it was announced yesterday.

LIKE many another girl with a popular older sister to live up to, Kate Vale dreaded entering Valerie's old college as a freshman in the coming fall. She dreaded the boring summer ahead. felt tired even of making the effort to be herself.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, May 14 -- Campaigning for tomorrow's first municipal elections since 1945 was in full swing today. Under the slogan. "Every Vote for the Fatherland Front Is a Vote for Peace," groups of workers, youths, intellectuals, peasants and women marched or drove singing through the streets of Sofia and other towns and villages.

Employing five pitchers in a game which saw both teams unable to produce lusty stickwork, Navy's nine broke out of a three-game losing streak yesterday by halting Andy Coakley's Columbia outfit, 8 to 6, in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game at Baker Field.

William S. White's article on Senator Taft, "How to Win Influence, If Not Friends," was one of the best presentations of its type I have read -- penetrating, discerning and unbiased. Name another man high in public life, if you can, who has been so unswervingly true to his principles and so oblivious of the vote-getting or vote-losing consequences of his actions as Mr. Taft has been.

DETROIT, May 14 -- The United Automobile Workers, CIO, appealed to the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service tonight to intervene in the ten-day strike against the Ford Motor Company. The union charged that a week of negotiations had brought the dispute no nearer a settlement than the day the walk-out began.

Manufacturers of branded lines of women's apparel reported good initial success last week on fall coats and suits which have been shown on the road. The outstanding producers in the field said that the first orders coming in were larger in number of units than they were a year ago, and that there is a marked tendency by retailers to buy farther ahead.

THIS is "the first authorized American translation" of Andre Gide's well-known "book" on Oscar Wilde issued by the Mercure de France publishing house in Paris in 1910. The quotation marks are necessary, for it is not clear from the publisher's words on the jacket whether or not the volume has been previously available in English translation in the United States, and certainly only by courtesy can this slim work be called a "book."

THE report which seeped out of spring training, a report vehemently denied, indicated that the Boston Braves did not hold the fatherly Billy Southworth in the filial esteem to which he'd been accustomed. More recently there was a minor rebellion on the Chicago White Sox, the chief contestants being Catcher Joe Tipton and Manager Jack Onslow.

Robert R. Young, boss of the Alleghany Corporation which numbers among its principal investment offsprings the Chesapeake Ohio and other railroads, and long the antagonist of Wall Street procedure, is ready to join forces with those opponents to promote investor interest in American industry.

It is to be hoped that the Byrd-Bridges bill requiring consideration of Federal appropriations in one omnibus bill, instead of piecemeal as at present, reported in your issue of May 5 as approved by the Senate Republican Policy Committee, attracts attention and popular support.

IN Hollywood there is no point in having a secret unless people know about it, and so Republic Studio recently let it be noised around that a production called "Fathoms Deep" was a most mysterious operation having to do with communism.

A panel of six junior high school students agreed yesterday in a Youth Forum discussion that courts should take some action against parents if their children proved delinquent because of neglect in the home. The forum, broadcast over Station WQXR and sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES, was held in Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

In sermons on "I Am An American Day," observed today, rabbis here yesterday urged that we strive to extend the blessings of freedom and democracy to less fortunate peoples of the world. They also expressed gratitude for the admission of Israel into the United Nations.

ROME, May 14 -- Thirteen young men were hospitalized as a result of injuries received in a fight between pro-Fascist and anti-Fascist students at the University of Rome this morning. Motorized police were called by the Rector of the University and quelled the riot after making two arrests.

There is a touch of paradox in the fact that the United States program for the expenditure of $1,450,000,000 for arms aid abroad should be set forth in a State Department "peace paper." Yet this program is designed directly for keeping the peace by making the strength of free nations a deterrent to aggression.

A fire and explosion injured five persons in the sub-basement of the five-story building occupied by the Vesey Hardware Corporation at 26 Vesey Street at 3 P. M. yesterday and reportedly caused damage of $50,000.

Many of "the old grads" who had not strayed too far from Pratt Institute during the last fifty years and more returned yesterday with their fellow alumni and alumnae to the sixty-second annual reunion on the campus at 255 Hyerson Street, Brooklyn.

THERE are two contrasting ideas of religious expression. According to the first and more familiar of them, beliefs and the mysticism based on them continue from age to age, essentially the same in form and content, which is broadly the tradition of the churches and especially of those churches regarded as conservative.

LAKE TAHOE, Calif. -- Even after his hilarious European rambles reported in "Innocents Abroad," travel-minded Mark Twain remembered cloud-rimmed Lake Tahoe as "a noble sheet of blue water walled by snowclad peaks -- surely the fairest picture the whole earth affords."

A RECENT news dispatch from Shanghai quoted a foreign resident of that encircled city as declaring: "God help the Communists when they get this place on their hands." This remark could be used to describe the prospects for Communist rule not only of Shanghai but of the rest of China as well.

MISS MONICA STIRLING is obviously well acquainted with Italy, which she uses as the background for her novel "Lovers Aren't Company." As a matter of fact, the background is more real than her story, which is the thoroughly usual drama of the still-young woman, her handsome lover and her jealous child.

ALBANY, May 14 -- The two public agencies of which three Albany newspaper men are members were described at the Capitol today as autonomous bodies, the members of which are paid on a per-meeting basis by the agencies and not by the state.

STAMP collectors, first in Sweden, later in England, and more recently in New York, have been hoaxed by "news" that Sweden had scheduled a series of stamps with portraits of members of Sweden's present Cabinet.

A CORRUPTED French phrase that has been responsible for more nostalgia than any other term in the lexicon of show business will have a full-dress revival here on Thursday. The occasion will be the return of vaudeville to the Palace Theatre after an absence of fourteen years.

Efforts to hasten formulation of an integrated economic program for Europe, leveling of trade barriers and convertibility of European currencies have now taken the No. 1 spot on the agenda of leading foreign trade interests here.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- A nation that has boasted of its business management, efficiency, thrifty habits and vision has been living too long off its capital resources, in the opinion of leading conservationists who viewed the problem from a dozen different angles here this week.
LONDON, May 14 -- Gerhart Eisler, German-born Communist fugitive from the United States, was arrested tonight after a struggle aboard the Polish liner Batory, on which he had fled as a stowaway.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The Research and Policy Committee of the Committee for Economic Development called today for a $2,100,000,000 reduction in Federal spending as the only sure way to avoid "damaging consequences" to the country's economy.
WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -- Following is a partial text of the State Department "Peace Paper" outlining Administration plans for providing arms to the Atlantic Pact nations:

Summer dresses were in strong demand in the wholesale apparel market here last week with heaviest activity centered on cottons, retailed from $8.95 to $14, medium price hembergs, chiffons, spun linens, pure silk prints, black sheers and low-end nylon cords, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buying office.

CHICAGO, May 14 (AP) -- Renegotiation of war contracts has won its spurs as a wartime profit control method. This is the conclusion reached in a new study made by Richards C. Osborn, University of Illinois economist. It is a detailed examination of a control device untried until 1942.

THE customary brickbats, whenever the year's Pulitzer awards in literature are announced, have been fewer this time, I think, than in many years. More often than not there is ground for honest and intelligent division of opinion as to the year's best novel, play, biography, history or poetry; the book in any of these fields so outstanding as to admit of no reasonable alternative is rare indeed.
In the parlance of Wall Street, Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane will "give up" a tri-linguist to the State Department this week.
HANOVER, N. M., May 14 -- Dartmouth's baseball team made it five straight in Eastern League competition today as it downed Harvard, 5 -- 2, at Memorial Field.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Although President Truman voiced strong opposition this week to a compromise in the Administration's labor bill, there remains the large possibility that any measure passed during this session will be a compromise.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 14 -- The memory of Edward Jenner, discoverer of vaccination, is being honored by an exhibition on display in the Medical Library of the Yale University School of Medicine.

PHILADELPHIA, May 14 -- Connie Mack's unpredictable Athletics plowed a furrow in left center field at Shibe Park today with an amazing succession of two-base hits. When they tired of this their aim was directed at the left-field seats. When the demonstration had run its course the Yankees were plowed under by a score of 8 to 5.

SEVEN years ago a frosty mannered martinet with the rank of admiral and the name of Ernest J. King -- known in the Navy as "Old Eagle-Eye Ernie" or as "God A'mighty and the Twelve Apostles" -- became boss of the toughest naval war this country had ever undertaken.

THE recent decisions of the Columbia and RCA Victor recording companies to go their separate ways in disk design and turntable speed have put the other people who manufacture phonographs on the spot. The following is intended to give a general idea of what you may find if you look for a new machine able to play all the different types.

The trial of eleven Communist leaders ended its seventeenth week on Friday, with the prosecution nearing completion of its effort to prove that the Communists had conspired to teach and advocate overthrow of the Government by force and violence.

TO little Juan the traditional spring return of the swallows to Capistrano was more than a legend. He lived near the California mission and daily listened to old Julian, the mission gardener, as the latter spoke of the birds.

This seems to be the era of light tackle fishing for the salt water anglers of coastal and bay areas, for the angler who is more interested in the sport of fishing than the volume of the catch has found that light tackle provides greater enjoyment as a result of placing the premium on skill rather than strength.

PARIS, May 14 -- In an effort to obtain inclusion of the Austrian problem on the agenda of the four-power Foreign Ministers' conference Dr. Karl Gruber, Austrian Foreign Minister, today conferred with Dr. Philip C. Jessup, United States Ambassador at Large, and afterward with Sir Ivone Kirkpatrick, the British deputy.
LAST week America's only all-freight airline operating in international trade celebrated its second anniversary by hauling a mixed cargo of merchandise across the Atlantic.

POTTSTOWN, Pa., May 14 -- Tallying five runs in the first inning, the Lawrenceville School baseball team went on to crush the Hill School, its traditional rival, by 12 -- 1 today. Jim Smith, the loser's starting pitcher, gave up five singles and two walks in the opening frame.
In the midst of purchasing for fall sales, executives of large variety and general merchandise chains disclosed last week that they are expecting to sell more items than they did last fall.
WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -- Stephen Raushenbush, United Nations economic consultant, proposed today that Congress set up a new lending agency, the National Resources Corporation.
Turpentine and resin are obtained from the sap that exudes from a Southern pine tree when its bark is cut or injured. The natural, sticky mixture of turpentine and resin is called "oleo-resin."

AMATEUR art is spreading like a pleasant epidemic in America. It is safe to say that the easel will take its place with the maple in the summer landscape and that the Sunday painter, like the Sunday driver, is a permanent part of our national life.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -- Senate and House conferees were in agreement today on provisions of the first deficiency appropriation bill. They are expected to report the measure Monday to both chambers for final passage.

Warmer weather spurred the call for summer merchandise here last week, particularly women's apparel and accessories. Dollar volume of sales, however, again fell below last year. Department store sales were estimated at about 8 per cent under the comparative 1948 week.

LONDON, May 14 -- The 24-year-old London girl victim of cancer of the brain, for whose treatment radioactive phosphorous isotopes had been flown over from the United States, died today. She was Iris Muriel Davis, a graduate of Barnard College and the only child of Jack Davis, who operates newsreel theatres in London and New York.
PITTSBURGH, May 14 (AP) -- Joe Garagiola, center of a feud between the Pirates and Cardinals, today answered the boos of Pittsburgh fans by leading St. Louis to a 4-to-3 victory at Forbes Field.

SYRACUSE, May 14 -- Invincible Harvard maintained its supremacy over the East today as it scored the first sweep registered in a championship sprint regatta of the Eastern Association of Rowing Colleges.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 13 -- Col. Gen. Alexander Rankovitch, Minister of Interior and head of the Yugoslav Security Police, pledged his organization last night to merciless extermination of any Yugoslavs who would betray their country to the Cominform or to any group of the Right that was seeking to overthrow Premier Marshal Tito's regime.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- President Truman's good luck charm worked again today.

The United Nations General Assembly adjourned at 6:20 o'clock last night without reaching the two hardest-fought items on the agenda of this session, the question of relations with Spain and the disposition of the former Italian colonies in Africa.

SMALL - FLOWERED dahlias produce a profusion of bloom over a long season. They are gay and charming for cutting, as well as useful to fill bare spaces in the perennial garden, or as accent plants among the annuals.

The Council on Foreign Relations, 58 East Sixty-eighth Street, is offering two resident fellowships for American foreign correspondents to help them increase their competence in reporting and interpreting events abroad, it was announced yesterday.

SCULPTURE, the much neglected orphan of the arts, is having a hearing in Philadelphia. Beginning today, the third "Sculpture International," organized by the Fairmount Park Association, will be on view at the Philadelphia Museum through Sept. 11. Some 250 pieces, the work of artists from more than a dozen nations, have been assembled.

GERALD W. JOHNSON'S argument that American writing is misrepresenting us to the world is based on a view of the creative life all too common among certain of our critics. Subjects for novelists, surely, cannot be assigned as if they were so many "ads" to be written to "sell" us in the world market.
Every day on his way to and from work John Woolley is driven along the West Side Highway. He passes close by the bows of ships that a man might take for a visit to Paris, or Istanbul, say, or Rio.
RICHMOND, May 14 -- Three bills before Congress held top interest this week in the Upper South.

Eminent men of Soviet Russia have shown us how to deal with errors of judgment and execution which are all too common. Full confession is called for in such instances. The precedent having become well established by this time, it should surprise no one to find a confession here of an error that appeared in this column recently in comment on the difficulties of Russian grammar.
SOME gardeners have been fascinated this year by the idea of pelleted seeds. This innovation consists of surrounding seeds with protective or stimulative materials.

TICKET brokers, usually reluctant to stray south of the Empire Theatre, may as well learn the way to 50 Pine Street. For during the next few weeks they will be visiting that old building in the financial district to explain to Investigation Commissioner John M. Murtagh why their ledgers sometimes look as though they had been prepared by William Saroyan.

MUCH correspondence continues to reach this department in connection with the article on the decline in the standards and numbers of players of stringed instruments, broached here some weeks ago. Various steps necessary to meet this situation, which threatens the future of our orchestras, have been suggested.

CHICAGO, May 14 -- A study of 637 brand names made at the behest of a group of leading American manufacturers by William J. Archer Jr. of Robert N. McMurray Co., management consultants and market analysts in Chicago, has produced these findings:

WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -- Twenty thousand boys and girls who daily watch over the safety of the country's school children paraded down Constitution Avenue today. They were members of school safety patrols in all forty-eight states and the District of Columbia.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Senator Bourke B. Hickenlooper, Republican, of Iowa, charged today that another Communist has received a scholarship of the Atomic Energy Commission -- and that the commission let him have it after its own investigation showed his background.
What motivated the author of "Asia: Spiritual Challenge to Us" when he insisted that "China has to be written off"? Do you never subject manuscripts to editorial criticism? * * *
ITHACA, N. Y., May 14 -- Cornell defeated Army, 3 -- 2, in the tenth inning of their Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League game today with the help of Army's sixth and last error.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 15 -- The Trans-Arabian Pipeline Company appears to have succeeded in inducing Syrian Premier Husni Zayim to permit its Tapline to be brought to Sidon in southern Lebanon and to abandon the effort to have it terminate at the north Syrian port of Latakia.

The second part of the third session of the General Assembly of the United Nations is drawing to its close. It convened on April 5 to take up matters that were not completed in the meetings of Sept. 21-Dec. 12 in Paris as well as new business. It has been, on the whole, a fruitful session, largely constructive in its character, and has reflected the purposes for which the Assembly was created.

PARIS, May 15 -- Foreign currencies are flowing into the French Treasury for the first time since the liberation, according to a high financial official here. They come from tourists and the repatriation of certain funds and are currencies that, up to recently, passed almost entirely to the black market.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Net current operating earnings of the nation's 13,419 federally-insured commercial banks reached $1,240,000,000, a new record high, in 1948. These earnings were 11.2 per cent greater than those for 1947, the previous record year.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., May 15 -- An accelerated construction program cutting four months from the building time of the new super-liner for the United States Lines will enable the ship to go into service in time for the 1952 summer tourist season, an official of the Newport News Shipbuilding and Drydock Company, the builder, disclosed today.

Fire caused apparently by an overheated lamp destroyed a small "dwelling" near the Central Nurses' residence on East Road, Welfare Island, shortly before 8 o'clock last night, it was reported by fire headquarters.

CHICAGO, May 15--The Oriental Institute of the University of Chicago, the largest institute in the world for the study of Oriental antiquity, celebrated today its thirtieth birthday with a display of two recently acquired treasures.

An 8-year-old boy, whose mother said he couldn't read, appeared recently at the Testing and Advisement Center of New York University, 51 West Fourth Street. On a subsequent visit, he faced a guidance counselor resolutely, looked down at a piece of paper and read easily what the man had written.
Ouster of the Rev. Dr. John Howard Melish from his pulpit at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity in Brooklyn Heights was denounced as an injustice by yesterday's preacher there.

Orders and reorders for popular price dresses last week were "a little short of phenomenal," according to reports on the wholesale apparel market here prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, May 15 -- Whatever answer the Nationalist Government of Premier Daniel F. Malan may make to yesterday's decision of the United Nations to invite South Africa, India and Pakistan to endeavor to settle their differences at a round-table conference, it is believed here that the regime will have the support of virtually the entire white population, regardless of party.

Ralph Wright, Assistant Secretary of Labor, predicted yesterday the repeal of the Taft-Hartley Act and the passage of a labor law containing the essential provisions advocated by President Truman and administration leaders.

To help raise educational standards throughout the nation, a number of men and women prominent in various aspects of American life have formed a National Citizens Commission for the Public Schools, it was announced yesterday.

Cornelia Phillips Spencer, pioneer for higher education for women in the South, is the subject of a biography to be published by the University of North Carolina Press under the title "The Woman Who Rang the Bell." Mrs. Spencer was a friend and confidante of Southern statesmen in the Civil War period and was a leader in education during reconstruction.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 15 -- Borba, official newspaper of the Yugoslav Communist party, asserted today that the current trial in Tirana of five top-ranking Albanian Communist leaders accused of collusion with Yugoslavs is being held in camera because Albanian authorities are using "Budapest and Albanian" methods on the defendants.

David Mannes, the conductor-composer-violinist, decided yesterday that he had become "just a fiddler on the loose." At that moment the 83-year-old musician was wearing an engineer's cap and jacket and had just stepped from a locomotive cab in which he had ridden from Grand Central Terminal to Westport, Conn.

Ignoring the protests of economy-minded members of Congress -- and even the friendly warnings of his own economic advisers -- President Truman told newsmen last week that, business recession or no business recession, he would neither withdraw nor modify his demand of last January for $4,000,000,000 in new taxes for fiscal 1950.

PITTSBURGH, May 15 -- The steel ingot rate for the country last week fell off 1 1/2 points to 96 per cent of rated capacity. According to opinion here March was the high point for some time to come. There is no longer any doubt in steel circles that the steel-making rate is in a downward trend.

Manufacturers of women's apparel are making important sales gains on summer suits of rayon and rayon-cotton mixtures, it was reported last week. Going into peak production on the lightweight items, producers find themselves behind schedule as the result of the early warm weather, which has stimulated consumer purchases.

Plan for the erection of a taxpayer abutting the large municipal parking area in Garden City, L. I., have been announced in connection with the leasing for a long term of a plot 120 by 200 feet on the east side of Franklin Avenue, between Ninth and Tenth Streets. The property was leased by Charles P. Ryan, David Cohen and I. George Berkmar from the Garden City Company.

Political and economic freedom for mechanical department employes of newspapers is as necessary to a free press as freedom for publishers and reporters to print truth as they see it, Magistrate William E. Ringel said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (UP) -- Representative Brooks Hays, Democrat, of Arkansas, announced today the opening of a drive for a civil rights program designed as a meeting ground for President Truman and his Southern Democratic foes.

BERLIN, May 15 -- About 52 per cent of the 14,000,000 eligible voters in the Soviet zone of occupation in Germany and in the Soviet sector of Berlin cast their ballots today to elect the third People's Congress and, according to the Russians, to register their desire for German unity, a peace treaty and wthdrawal of the occupation forces.

L. V. Dougherty, formerly Western sales manager of Textron, Inc., has been appointed vice president in charge of sales and advertising of American Lady Corset Company, with headquarters at 148 Madison Avenue.
The cast of a hit play applauded the audience last night.

BOSTON, May 15 -- Customs inspectors today searched the baggage of 829 displaced persons arriving from Bremerhaven, Germany, aboard the United States Army transport General Leroy Eltinge and seized undeclared jewelry, silverware and merchandise valued by the officials at "thousands of dollars."

Pound sterling stepped back into the orbit as the top interest in the foreign exchanges which it had yielded in the brief interval of the preceding week when the sharp rise of the Canadian free dollar took the spotlight.

LONDON, May 15 (AP) -- The Ministry of Supply announced today a reduction in selling prices for copper, lead and zinc because of recent falls in American market prices. Another consideration, the statement said, was criticism by manufacturers of the effects Britain's higher prices were having on British trade and exports.

WEIGHT-lifting is a sport whose greatest curse is its own terminology. Such irritating-to-the-ears terms as clean and jerk, snatch and press provoke snickers instead of admiration and that's unfortunate because the army of bar bell enthusiasts in this country is growing by the proverbial leaps and bounds. Skill and strength also are growing with it. In 1932 the United States took one third place in the Olympics.

PARIS, May 15 -- A tramp's carry-all swung on the end of a stick, ragged hemlines give a carefree, vagabond air to Jacques Heim's beach costumes, either all-black or in brightest balloon colors mixed.
The number of art exhibitions this week shows that the season is prolonging its activities well into the late spring.

MIAMI, Fla., May 15 (UP) -- Police broadcast a state-wide alarm today for Count Ossip De Perelma, 72 years old, a Russian-born artist, reported missing with $23,000 by his bride of one month. His wife, the former Lydia Francoise Simpson, offered a $10,000 reward for information leading to his whereabouts.
CLEVELAND, May 15 (AP) -- The "whole business picture," said the Cleveland Trust Company today, "is characterized by a relatively cautious attitude on the part of consumers."
The city's tenth annual observance of "I Am an American Day" was held yesterday afternoon on the Mall in Central Park.

ATHENS, May 15 -- Reports from Florina said that Communist attacks launched from the Presba area against the outskirts of the town had been driven off. Among the attackers were said to be two infantry companies composed of young persons averaging 15 or 16 years who had been forcibly recruited recently.

Prices of cotton in the domestic market moved irregularly last week and at the close of trading or Saturday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net losses of 6 to 17 points, compared with advances of 44 to declines of 25 points in the previous week.
ALBANY, May 15 -- The State Tax Commission said today that 80 per cent of the New York State personal income tax was paid by 19 per cent of the taxpayers.
