OYSTER BAY, L. I., May 15 -- A well - dressed, well - mannered woman, 50 years old, has been taken from the historic Matinecock Inn where she has been staying here and lodged in the county jail at Mineola, the police reported today.
The edifice of the Fifth Church of Christ, Scientist, at 9 East Forty-third Street was dedicated at three identical services yesterday at 11 A. M. and 3 and 8 P. M. Altogether 5,000 persons attended.

TRIPOLI, Libya, May 15, (AP) -- Shooting and stabbing incidents today marked Arab demonstrations against United Nations plans for Italy's prewar African colonies, including Libya. Some Arab leaders threatened non - cooperation with the British administration.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., May 15 -- Corny Shields, who had finished third with his international sloop Aileen in the initial Sparkman Trophy race yesterday, finished first today in the second contest at the Larchmont Yacht Club.

Another group has just been formed with the avowed purpose of instituting much-desired reforms in the theatre. Named the Committee of Theatrical Producers, it was organized by seventeen of the leading Broadway producers.

CHICAGO, May 15 -- Outside interest in corn increased somewhat last week on the Board of Trade here, especially in the December, which represents the new crop. Part of the buying was based on the belief that the price for the December was materially too low as compared with the prospective Government loan on this year's harvest, which will be at 90 per cent of parity, the same as in 1948.

PHILADELPHIA, May 15 -- Yankee pitching collapsed today as the Athletics nudged the league-leaders out of both ends of a double-header and into their fourth straight defeat before a gathering of 35,004.
New York produce teamsters undertook yesterday a boycott of New Jersey railroad terminals, which had the immediate effect of winning back for them most of 1,200 jobs they had lost in recent months.

The Children's Aid Society served 62,757 boys and girls last year in its clubs, kindergartens and playgrounds, and gave vocational, educational, and employment counseling to 8,902, according to the ninety-sixth annual report, made public yesterday.

CINCINNATI, May 15 (AP) -- Cincinnati and Chicago divided a twin bill today, the Reds taking the ten-inning opener, 6 -- 5, and the Cubs the second game, 8 -- 5, giving Calvin McLish his first victory of the season. The split enabled the Reds to retain third place in the National League.

Senator Paul H. Douglas, Democrat, of Illinois, demanded here last night the creation of a joint Congressional committee that would function throughout the year in the investigation of discrimination and propose civil rights legislation when needed.

CHICAGO, May 15 -- Many states have made encouraging progress in improving their school systems, but there is much yet to be done, according to a 256-page report, "The Forty-eight State School Systems," just published by the Council of State Governments.

The establishment of regular passenger service between New York and Israel was announced here yesterday by the Greek Line. The Panamanian-flag liner Neptunia, for which the Greek Line will act as agents, will sail at midnight, May 21, for the first of six voyages scheduled for this year, either to Haifa direct or with intermediate calls at Mediterranean ports.

ST. LOUIS, May 15 (AP) -- Rallying behind the steady pitching of Ned Garver, the St. Louis Browns steam-rollered the Detroit Tigers, 12 to 4, in the second game of today's doubleheader to gain an even break for the day.

CHICAGO, May 15 -- Higher prices for hogs and a continuation of a moderate export business in lard resulted in somewhat higher prices for lard on the Board of Trade last week. Aggregate trade was not large, and warehouse interests were sellers on minor upturns, results in the market holding within comparatively narrow limits.

It is a welcome circumstance that the current plenitude of bacon coincides with the ready availability of such spring vegetables as asparagus, new potatoes, spinach, onions and snap beans. For the sweet smoky taste of a meat that nutritionists say is no meat at all, but actually a fat, provides a remarkably appetizing accent for these foods.

Twenty-five thousand Brooklyn and Long Island Catholics joined yesterday in a mass prayer for the liberation of Cardinal Mindszenty, Hungarian prelate, and other Catholic and Protestant clergymen imprisoned by Soviet satellite countries.

In the procession, made up of all ages, was a mirror of every stage of the process of making Americans out of folk who -- certainly by no fault of their own -- did not begin that way. Plodding along gravely and patiently were elderly women who would not have seemed out of place if they had been following, instead of Fifth Avenue, a road through fields or towns long left behind them.

The number of patients cared for last year by the New York State Department of Mental Hygiene reached a record high of 112,500, it was disclosed yesterday by Dr. Frederick MacCurdy, State Commissioner of Mental Hygiene.

The Sunday afternoon offering by the San Carlo Opera Company was Puccini's "La Boheme." The Center Theatre showing was notable for the high spirits with which the cast went about its business, for some excellent singing and for the operatic debut of Elaine Malbin, 18-year-old soprano.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Bipartisan sentiment among Congressmen for economy and the avoidance of either a deficit or a tax increase grew today as Congress faced a week of moderate floor activity but several important committee sessions.
Four new films, including arrivals from Great Britain and Italy, are slated to open in midtown theatres this week. The programs follow:
WASHINGTON, May 15 -- President Truman will go on the radio tomorrow night to open the Treasury Department's six-week "opportunity" drive to sell $1,040,000,000 worth of Savings Bonds.

AMSTERDAM, May 15 -- The urgent necessity of Dutch industrialization was emphasized last week by the Minister of Economic Affairs, Dr. R. M. Jan van den Brink in a broadcast. He stressed the heavy increase in Dutch population resulting in 40,000 young men and women annually entering the labor market, which figure, he said, will increase in the coming years.

The Air Force is going to do something about the charge that present fighter aircraft are three to five years behind the development of our big, long-ranging bombers, like the B-36, and are perhaps incapable of intercepting bombers of comparable performance developed in other countries.
CHICAGO, May 15 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox shut out the world champion Cleveland Indians twice today, 10 -- 0 and 2 -- 0, before a record crowd of 53,325 at Comiskey Park.

The New Jersey to New York tube of the Holland Tunnel was reopened to traffic at 5:09 P. M. yesterday after having been closed fifty-six hours by the disastrous series of explosions and fires that battered a 300-foot section Friday morning.
WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The effect of modern chemical wizardry on this nation's bread and milk has become a matter of voluminous Government record.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -- Joe Dobson posted his first victory of the American League season here today as he limited Washington to four hits while the Boston Red Sox registered a 3-0 triumph before a crowd of 25,748.

Henry G. Hotchkiss, president of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, 122 East Twenty-second Street, announced yesterday appointment of a committee from the affiliated foster boarding home agencies to help find critically needed foster homes for Protestant children.

The $727,000,000 Electric Power and Light Corporation, a sub-holding company in the Electric Bond and Share Company system, reported yesterday that net income for 1948 was $14,784,511, compared with $12,724,085 in 1947.

MADRID, May 15 -- Bomb explosions damaged the Bolivian, Brazilian and Peruvian Consulates in Barcelona early this morning. The embassies of the three countries in Madrid immediately filed protests with the Foreign Office.

BANGKOK, Thailand, May 6 -- An Iron Curtain in miniature surrounds two acres of lease government land in this city. The plot has a population of about sixty Russians who have set up one of the mysteries of the Orient in Siam.

Branding driver-license eye examinations "woefully inadequate" and "almost farcical," Dr. Theodore H. Conklin, chairman of the board of directors of the New York State Optometric Association, called yesterday for elimination of the present tests, given by the state to applicants for operators' licenses.

UNION, N. J., May 15 -- Rent increases for residents of Stuyvesant Town, a huge garden apartment development here, which were announced several months ago, have been upheld in a ruling by Superior Court Judge Alfred A. Stein.
The old administration building of Luna Park, closed for five years, was destroyed yesterday at 5 P. M. by a fire that attracted many of the reported 550,000 persons visiting Coney Island.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -- Special ceremonies for the opening of the nation-wide campaign to sell bonds will be held tomorrow in Independence, Mo., President Truman's home town, with four networks broadcasting the proceedings.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The cost of the first year's implementation of Point Four of President Truman's State of the Union message last January -- the "bold new program" to develop the world's backward areas -- has been reduced to about $30,000,000 over funds already budgeted, it was learned tonight.

Plans to make Chicago a television center were revealed yesterday by Niles Trammell, NBC president. Mr. Trammell announced the start of construction of a new television studio in Chicago as the first step by the network in expanding television facilities there.
Improved management-labor relations are a factor in the bright prospects for shipping in Gulf ports, according to an informal survey of the industry there.

TOKYO, May 15 -- Japan has suddenly emerged as an automobile exporting nation. Contracts already are on the books for 6,000 Nissan and Toyopet cars and trucks, most of which will go to Formosa. Nissan makes standardized vehicles and Toyo makes midget sedans and delivery trucks.
CANBERRA, Australia, May 15 (AP) -- Prime Minister Joseph B. Chifley said today plans for a Pacific pact were under way, "parallel with corresponding planning for the North Atlantic."

Israel's immediate need of $800,000,000 to meet its immigration requirements for the coming year can be relieved to a major extent by the combined efforts of all Zionist bodies in this country, the United Jewish Appeal and individual givers, Daniel Frisch, vice president of the Zionist Organization of America, asserted yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, May 15 (AP) -- A two-run rally in the ninth inning gave the St. Louis Cardinals a 4-3 edge over the Pittsburgh Pirates in a single contest today. Red Schoendienst singled Chuck Diering home with the winning run after two were out.
Thirteen-year-old Javier Najera Torres, Mexican "good-will ambassador" to the United States, was received yesterday by Cardinal Spellman on the grounds of St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Mrs. Fanny Blankers-Koen, Holland housewife who captured three individual track titles in the Olympic games, arrived at Idlewild Airport yesterday aboard a Royal Dutch Airline plane from Amsterdam. She is stopping here enroute to an appearance in the Coliseum Relays in Los Angeles next Friday.

Recent extensive changes in the Soviet Government, involving shifts of some high-ranking military personnel, have not altered the Basic structure of the Russian armed forces, according to the best analyses available in this country.
AMARILLO, Tex., May 15 (UP) -- A tornado slashed through a thirty-square-block area in Amarillo's south side tonight, killing at least five persons and seriously injuring at least eighty-two.

Planning expansion to meet new developments in mass communication, Columbia University's School of Journalism hopes eventually to establish "a graduate school of radio, television, facsimile and the new arts and instrumentalities of communication."

The Oak Ridge, Tenn., atomic energy plant will begin receiving 60,000,000 cubic feet of natural gas a day early in November, it was announced yesterday by the East Tennessee Natural Gas Company, which has completed financing for a 172-mile pipeline that will carry the fuel from Greenbrier, Tenn. Construction will begin immediately.

LONDON, May 15 -- Polish authorities in London charged British police today with the "forcible abduction" of Gerhart Eisler, German Communist fugitive from the United States, who was bodily removed from the Polish liner Batory at Southampton yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 15 -- The bomb explosions in the Bolivian, Brazilian and Peruvian consulates in Barcelona early this morning were the central topic of conversation today among the Latin-American delegations to the United Nations. The bombings are generally viewed here as a protest of anarchist underground elements over the part taken by the three countries in presenting the Spanish resolution.

BERLIN, May 15 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Commander in Chief of the European Command and Military Governor in Germany, left Tempelhof airfield at 6 P. M. today on the first leg of a flight that will take him to Washington and retirement from the Army.

CHICAGO, May 15 -- State tobacco taxes yielded last year a reccord $374,000,000 in revenues, the Federation of Tax Administrators said today. The gain was attributed to increased consumption of cigarettes, cigars and other tobacco products, and new and increased taxes on these items.

PARIS, May 15 -- In drafting a new trade credit agreement, experts of the European Marshall Plan Organization emphasize that trade within Europe has been greater than was expected when the present agreement was made last autumn, and that the direction of this trade has changed.

CAMBRIDGE, Ohio, May 15 -- Mrs. Wendell L. Willkie, widow of the 1940 Republican nominee for President, was recovering tonight in St. Francis Hospital here from injuries received in an automobile accident today in which her son, Philip, 29 years old, was less seriously injured.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 15 -- Herbert H. Lehman, former Governor of New York and honorary national chairman of the United Jewish Appeal, has concluded, after his first week in Israel, that the new state's achievements were greater than he expected.

Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State Chairman, announced yesterday that he had filed with Wayne Coy, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, a formal complaint against the Columbia Broadcasting System for its refusal to provide the Democratic party of New York State with equal time and facilities to answer an address made over the state CBS network by Governor Dewey on May 2.

PHILADELPHIA, May 15 -- Formation of the Board of Directors of the Citizens Committee for Reorganization of the Executive Branch of the Government was announced here today by Dr. Robert L. Johnson, national chairman of the committee and president of Temple University.

The First Piano Quartet, a group of four pianists and four concert grands, gave its first New York concert Saturday night in a well-filled Carnegie Hall. The team, Adam Garner, Vladimir Padwa, Frank Mittler and Edward Edson, has been widely heard on the radio during the last eight years.

ALAN VILLIERS, the literary Australian sailor who has written nine books about his own seafaring adventures, has written a good one about the nautical adventures of others in "The Coral Sea."* Until the great victory of 1942, when naval flyers from the Lexington and Yorktown won the first American victory in the Pacific War, few people had ever heard of that large and treacherous expanse of reef-crowded water.

DETROIT, May 15 -- Henry Ford 2d, president of the Ford Motor Company, told the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service today that the stoppage by the United Automobile Workers, CIO, was "a political strike" that was being prolonged "by a small group of embarrassed union leaders" seeking a face-saving settlement.

GILGIT, April 28 -- This dateline omits, advisedly, to say what country Gilgit is in. No one seems to know, even in Gilgit, which is often called "The Rooftop of the World," near where Afghanistan, China, India, Pakistan and the Soviet Union meet.

Your leading editorial of May 10, entitled "To Expand World Trade," expresses a point of view with which we might take issue. However, we prefer to confine ourselves to calling to your attention two errors in the editorial of a rather fundamental nature, and one moot point.

TEHERAN, Iran, May 15 -- Iran has formally demanded payment from the Soviet Union of more than twelve tons of gold, nearly $9,000,000 in United States currency and about $11,000,000 in Iranian rials owed since World War II, Foreign Minister Ali Afghar Hekmet announced today.

Beginnings of "a more cooperative attitude toward business" by the Federal Trade Commission, beyond encouraging trade practice agreements, was seen by advertising observers here last week as a possible result of the Hoover Commission report.

Our preoccupation with problems of world-wide scope and our attention to great dramatic crises such as those in Germany and China may cause us to overlook some smaller situations in which something can and should be done. There are sore spots in our whole Asiatic relationship that need attention.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Senator Ralph E. Flanders, Republican, of Vermont, said today that the Japanese wartime balloon trick could be used to get messages of friendship over the Iron Curtain to the Russian people.

Miss Frances Taussig, executive director of the Jewish Family Service of New York and a nationally recognized leader in the field of social work, will retire sometime this year, it was announced yesterday by Ralph K. Guinzburg the agency's president.

KEARNY, N. J., May 15 -- Back from a flying trip to Toronto, where they gained their first victory, 5 to 0 over Ulster United, the Belfast Celtics defeated a picked eleven of New Jersey soccer stars in the third match of their tour before a crowd of 8,500 fans on the grounds of the Kearny High School today.

Eleven years ago today the first air drill ever held in the Western Hemisphere -- a dramatic blackout in Farmingdale, L. I. -- was staged. At the same time New York business men and their employes were championing the cause of the first annual appeal of the Greater New York Fund in behalf of the city's voluntary hospitals, health and social service agencies.
WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls during the period May 7 to 13 are given in the appended tabulation:

Peace can be achieved if the United States and the Soviet Union work together for it, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko said yesterday as he departed for Paris and Moscow from Idlewild Airport.

Excess distributors' inventories of industrial supplies, tools and machinery are being worked off by the cooperation of manufacturers, distributors revealed over the week-end. Excess items are being accepted by some manufacturers in return for larger orders for faster moving items, while other companies are filling new factory orders from distributors' excess stocks.

Concern recently expressed by local shipping men over the future of the Port of New York was justified last week by Customs figures that showed greatly reduced collections. Harry M. Durning, Collector of the Port, said Customs totals for the month of April had continued the downward trend of the last several months.

Two more trolley lines in Brooklyn disappeared yesterday when buses replaced street cars on the Eighth Avenue and Bay Ridge lines. On Eighth Avenue the fleet of eight street cars was replaced by fourteen buses, cutting the headway from a six to a five-minute interval.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, May 15 (UP) -- Government officials said tonight that more than 90 per cent of the Hungarian electorate voted today in the one-ticket national parliamentary election.

CHICAGO, May 15 -- A dry weather scare embracing an area in the American and Canadian Northwest with an estimated 25,000,000 acres in winter and spring wheat became the main influence in the wheat market here last week and sent the new crop deliveries up sharply, July rallying 5 5/8 cents a bushel from the low before the upturn was checked by a forecast for showers in the Dakotas and Minnesota.
GENEVA, May 15 -- The Economic Cooperation Administration is gravely concerned about what it suspects are efforts to re-establish the European coke cartel.

Max E. Youngstein, vice president in charge of advertising, publicity and exploitation at Eagle Lion Films for the last two and a half years, has been appointed director of national advertising, publicity and exploitation for Paramount Pictures, it was announced by Barney Balaban, president.

LONDON, May 15 -- Capital investment in Israel this year -- that is, the provision of new facilities for production and employment -- will be at a rate relatively higher than that of any other nation in history, David Horowitz, Israeli Under-Secretary of Finance, said in London today.

MOSCOW, May 15 (U.P.) -- The Government newspaper Izvestia complained today against a Soviet biologist who had held that man had started on the downward path when he began to walk on his two legs. The scientist, the paper said, is "an ignoramus."

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., May 15 -- With a concluding round of 66, Bobby Locke of Johannesburg, South Africa, left his pursuers far in his wake as he won the Goodall round-robin golf tournament over the Wykagyl Country Club by a convincing margin of 33 points.

PARIS, May 15 -- In connection with the survey of prospective Western policy at the forthcoming conference of the Big Four Foreign Ministers on Germany, which the deputies for the Western Foreign Ministers will resume tomorrow, observers in closest touch with the issues under discussion emphasized today the belief here that the Soviet Union was eager to expand trade between Eastern and Western Europe.

A special committee appointed by the Greater New York Retail Furriers Association, Inc., to study fur advertising ethics in New York and other cities, has found that a "deplorable situation" exists as to value claims and a continuous monthly-by-month offer, by some stores, of reductions for regular fur prices running as high as 50 per cent.
The hoped-for spring upturn in employment has not yet made itself felt in most sections of the country and many business men expect no real pickup in industrial activity until fall.
MOSCOW, May 15 -- Soviet dispatches from Berlin emphasized today what was termed a growing movement in both the Eastern and Western occupation zones for the unification of Germany.

FORT WORTH, Tex., May 15 (AP) -- Fire destroyed the main stands of the Fort Worth Texas League ball park today causing damage which officials estimated at $1,000,000. But fifteen hours later, a baseball game was going on in the scene of the two-hour holocaust.

The latest ideas on what is good for children psychologically, combined with some of the newest thoughts in interior decoration, have resulted in a cheerful remodeling of Woodycrest, a home for boys and girls from 8 to 18 year old at 936 Woodycrest Avenue, the Bronx.

LONDON, May 15 -- Actual lifting of the Berlin blockade last week proved to have been well discounted by the stock markets here, although there was keen disappointment that investors did not celebrate this highly important political event by coming in to buy.

Extensive long-term educational programs to increase dental care and better grooming are beginning to pay off for the drug and toiletries trade and sponsoring manufacturers, a top executive for a national drug products concern declared last week.

The City Planners, who have been working overtime since the end of the war once more made men and material available for construction and expansion, are now attacking one of the most vexing of New York's traffic problems, that of the bottlenecks now existing at the Manhattan plazas of the Williamsburg, Queensboro and Brooklyn Bridges.

Net income of the Anaconda Copper Mining Company and its subsidiaries for the first three months of this year was $14,005,005 before depletion, equal to $1.61 a share on 8,674,332 shares of capital stock, according to the preliminary report issued yesterday for release today.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 15 (AP) -- Johnny Parsons, a thin, nervous young man from Van Nuys, Calif., today moved up among the favorites for the 500-mile auto race May 30.

FRANKFORT, Germany, May 15 -- The new Constitution for Western Germany will be placed this week before the Parliaments of the eleven participating states in an effort to obtain its ratification before the Council of Foreign Ministers meets in Paris.

Probably the most important sessions of the Foreign Ministers' Conference are the preliminary meetings being held in Paris now by the representatives of the three Western Powers. Harold Callender reports that these talks consist, to a large extent, of guessing what the Russian Foreign Minister will propose and how the Western Ministers will reply.

A vital religious faith cannot exist if religious practices are kept apart from other activities, Dr. Arthur C. Lichtenberger of the faculty of General Theological Seminary said last night at a service at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

LONDON, May 15 (AP) -- Italy swept into the quarter-finals of the European Zone Davis Cup tennis eliminations today by taking the final two singles matches from South Africa. This gave the Italians a 4-1 edge.

Benjamin Gassman, Liberal party law committee chairman, charged yesterday that Tammany was planing to "steal" tomorrow's special election in the Twentieth Congressional District and elect Municipal Court Justice Benjamin Shalleck, Democratic candidate for Representative, by the use of "floaters."
RUTLAND, Vt., May 15 -- Rutland Junior College students, their alma mater in financial difficulties, have embarked on an ingenious campaign to raise money to pay their teachers' salaries.

BOSTON, May 15 -- Boston weather was no colder than Dodger hearts today as the Brooks took their third straight licking from the Braves, this time by a shut-out, their second this season, and both by Boston pitchers.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 15 -- Miss Jean M. Cochrane of Westport, Conn., took home two championship ribbons from the combined New York Military Academy-Secor Farms Horse Show at the conclusion of the two-day event staged at the outdoor ring and hunter course of the Secor Farms Riding Club here today.
ROME, May 15 (AP) -- Italian officials have started an investigation to determine how a renaissance Italian painting had reached the United States.

YONKERS, N. Y., May 15 -- Victor Dyrgall of the Millrose A.A., king of the nation's roadrunners for the last couple of years, today impressively added the National A.A.U. marathon crown to his large collection of distance titles.

PARIS, May 15 -- A statement made by former Premier Georges Bidault in a speech at Cherbourg late last night -- which looked like an offer of support by the Popular Republican party to Charles de Gaulle -- caused a sensation today in French political circles. M. Bidault, when reached at Coutances, modified the statement late today, and his party headquarters denied that any advances had been made to the de Gaullist movement.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 15 -- Award of the first three fellowships for advanced study at the Guggenheim Jet Propulsion Center at Princeton University was announced here jointly today by Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of the university, and Harry F. Guggenheim, president of the Daniel and Florence Guggenheim Foundation.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 15 -- Leo Genn, British film actor, who has been on the American screen in "Mourning Becomes Electra" and "The Snake Pit," has been signed by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer in London to play Gaius Petronius in "Quo Vadis," the studio here announced.

In preparation for the coming struggle over Germany at the Four-Power meeting scheduled to start next Monday, representatives of the United States, Britain and France are already meeting in Paris to map out a common program which would extend their solidarity regarding Western Germany to the problem of Germany as a whole.

The fifth annual Festival of Contemporary American Music, sponsored by the Alice M. Ditson Fund of Columbia University, closed yesterday afternoon with a concert given in collaboration with the Columia Broadcasting System at the McMillin Academic Theatre.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., May 15 -- For the second time since the tournament started three days ago, M. D. Clark, a mink rancher from Woodbury, Conn., found himself engaged in a shoot-off for top honors as the fortieth annual amateur trapshooting championships of America came to a close at the New York Athletic Club's Travers Island today.
FRESNO, Calif., May 15 (AP) -- One more performance, better than the world record, has been added to the impressive, if only 22-year-old, history of the West Coast relays.

Pennant contenders for years have been advised to "fatten up on the Phillies" and the Giants concluded a week-end feast yesterday at the Polo Grounds. Annexing their third straight for a clean sweep of the set, Leo Durocher's lads bagged a workmanlike, 7-3 victory behind Montia Kennedy's 7-hit pitching and remained in a first-place tie with the Braves.

ZURICH, May 15 -- Trade between France and Switzerland has been virtually at a standstill since May 1, when the French-Swiss trade agreement of July 29, 1947, originally written for fifteen months but prolonged four times to gain time for bargaining, and the French-Swiss payments agreement of Nov. 16, 1945, both expired as the result of failure of all efforts to arrive at an agreement on a new basis.

It is disturbing to find the issue of communism again a major point of conflict within the National Maritime Union, CIO. All candidates identified with the Communist faction in the union were swept out of office in its national elections last summer. Philip Murray and other national officers of the CIO congratulated Joseph Curran and his associates on having eliminated the danger of Communist sabotage among the personnel of the American merchant marine.

LONDON, May 15 (AP) -- The text of a statement issued by the Polish Embassy today, and also the text of a statement said by the Embassy to have been written by Gerhart Eisler aboard the Polish liner Batory:

"Me, the Sleeper," a play about the tortured mind of a war veteran, was presented over the weekend at the Master Institute Theatre as the sixth offering in the Invitational Series of the Expermental Theatre.
SHANGHAI, May 15 -- The Communists tightened their ring around the land side of this city today, pushing into the western outskirts.

With the lifting of the blockade of Berlin, it is urgent, as you pointed out in your editorial on May 6, that the United States elaborate a positive program for Germany. I should like to supplement the suggestions you made regarding such a program.

The headline "U. N. Unit Supports Easing Franco Ban" on the front page of your edition of May 8 was hard to take. But still harder was the realization that our own United States delegation refused to vote against permitting "member states full freedom of action as regards their diplomatic relations with Spain."

Barnard College has awarded the Public Service Fellowship to Mrs. Sabra Follett Meservey of 50 Morningside Drive, it was announced yesterday. The fellowship was established in 1934 by the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform and is for a woman college graduate showing promise of usefulness in public service.
OSLO, May 15 (AP) -- Col. N. R. Oestgaard of Norway was elected president of the International Ski Federation at the final session of the group's meeting last night.
WASHINGTON, May 15 (UP) -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson will advise Congress this week that there is no place in the Atlantic security pact for Spain or for Western Germany.

Imagine flying to Mexico City and soaking up the sun on the famous beach at Acapulco. Or picture yourself cruising leisurely to Bermuda. These and twenty-eight other vacation trips for two are offered to you by the Greater New York Fund.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The House Rules Committee approved today for floor action a resolution calling for a joint Congressional investigation into lobbying activities and the effectiveness of the lobbyist registration and reporting act.

The economy has swung pretty much from sellers' market to buyers'. Following a perfectly normal reaction, business men and lawmakers are seeking to take corrective action. Responding to the logic of the pocketbook, the first step is for them to "pull in their horns," cut down on the spending. But it is a fair question to ask, Are they doing the thing that creates recession?
The first concrete plan to fill the vacancies for public health nurses on the city payroll has just been presented to the Budget Director by the Department of Health, it was learned yesterday.

Henry A. Wallace declared last night at a rally in Madison Square Garden that if the American representatives at the Foreign Ministers' Conference in Paris next week resolved to plan for peace and not for failure they could lay a solid foundation against war.

LONDON, May 16 -- One of the largest audiences ever assembled in the Grand Committee Room of the House of Commons heard there tonight an off the record speech by Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York. Upon the members of Parliament of all parties the former Republican Presidential candidate obviously made a great impression in his replies to questions on the role of the United States in world affairs.

In an article appearing in Science Dr. Detlev W. Bronk of Johns Hopkins once more discusses the motives that prompt scientists to undertake research. Like most of those who have written on the subject, he takes the stand that the theoretical scientist is an independent agent who thinks and acts as he pleases.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- For the American people and their Government there should be a simple test of the projected international compact on the gathering and correction of news reporting which the General Assembly of the United Nations has approved and the delegate of the United States has recommended.

There are at least four Air Force fighter planes and an equal number under development for the Navy that may be able to meet demands for something to intercept the B-36 bomber at altitudes above 40,000 feet, it was declared here yesterday.

Because of the chief prosecution witness' fear of intimidation the Bridge Plaza Magistrate's Court in Brooklyn was cleared of all spectators at a hearing yesterday of three men accused of usury along the Brooklyn waterfront.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 16 -- The Zionist General Council closed an eleven-day session today without having settled two outstanding issues: First, the future of the Zionist organization now that the goal has been reached and the Israeli state created, and second the relationship between the state and the Zionist movement.

The meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers in Paris next Monday will be by all odds the most fateful gathering of this decisive body since the end of the war. By comparison, all previous meetings have been preliminary sparring matches, revealing enough to shatter Western illusions about Russian policies and ambitions, but serving Russia merely to test Western, and in particular American, determination and endurance to the point of the showdown in Berlin.
TORONTO, May 16 (AP) -- The Jersey City Little Giants combined two hits, a passed ball and a sacrifice for a run in the top half of the eleventh inning to beat the Maple Leafs, 7 -- 6, tonight.

Arise got up just in time to score an unexpected victory in the Stromboli Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. The definite outsider in the field of six 3-year-olds, which included the George D. Widener entry of Reveille and Marabout, Arise made a splendid bid in the stretch to take the six-furlong event by a neck from William Helis' Danherst.

An upstate local of the International Hod Carriers, Building and Common Laborers of America, AFL, charged in suits on file in Federal Court yesterday that its members employed on the Delaware water project had been forced to work at low wages and under dangerous conditions as the result of agreements that four construction companies reached with one of its international vice presidents.
Horace Greeley notwithstanding, a covered wagon came East to City Hall yesterday.

Prior to departing on their first tour of the hinterlands this season the Giants yesterday lopped off two players from their roster, dispatching Lucky Jack Lohrke and Andy Tomasic to the Jersey City club in the International League. Both are subject to twenty-four-hour recall.

FRANKFORT, Germany, May 16 -- Maj. Gen. George P. Hays, deputy United States Military Governor, cleared up for the record today the East-West sore point on the matter of Russian insistence upon using Soviet zone locomotives and crews to haul Western military traffic through the Soviet zone. He said that the Russians were legally justified.

TRENTON, N. J., May 16 -- New Jersey's highest court listened for four hours today to a recital of the facts and the law governing the conviction here last August of six Negroes in the slaying of William Horner.
BALTIMORE, May 16 (AP) -- Dramamine, the drug that conquered seasickness, may be useful against morning sickness.

On the subject of atomic research, widespread and dangerous confusion in public thinking is revealed by the article in today's TIMES dealing with the Communist who received a fellowship for study in this field at Government expense.

A Polish attempt to label refugee camps in Western Germany and Europe as crime-ridden slave markets where cheap labor can be recruited by capitalistic societies was overwhelmingly defeated by the United Nations General Assembly early this morning.

The President inaugurated in a brief radio address last night the third postwar drive to increase public ownership of the federal debt. The campaign, which gets under way today, has as its objective the sale over the next six weeks of $1,040,000,000 in "E" bonds, which return the purchaser $25 at the end of ten years for every $18.75 invested.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Opening the Opportunity Savings Bond Drive to encourage a public investment of $1,040,000,000 in the Treasury's offering, President Truman declared tonight that every family should buy a bond to insure its future.

Television listeners will hear little or no music controlled by the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers after today on programs which are kinescoped for delayed showings on stations not connected by coaxial cable.

A widespread air and sea search was under way yesterday for the crew of a small motor schooner after the vessel reportedly sank about 360 miles south of Greenland, according to Coast Guard headquarters here.

Reacting to the Treasury's announcement over the week-end that it planned no more than a new 1 1/4 per cent certificate in exchange for its bonds and other securities due next month, the Government securities market was fairly active yesterday and most issues closed higher.
LITCHFIELD, Ill., May 16 -- Two chiefs of police plodded up and down on opposite sides of Litchfield's main street today, glowering at each other.

WARSAW, May 16 -- The Polish Government sent to British Ambassador Sir Donald Gainer a vigorous protest note over the "invasion of the Polish motorship Batory by British officials and the forcible removal of Gerhart Eisler."
The seventy-fifth anniversary of the opening of Mount Sinai Hospital's Out-Patient Department was celebrated yesterday in the children's clinic.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 16 -- Economic experts of the United Nations prepared today to issue an order to commissions of the world organization working in the field of economic development to stop dealing in generalities and get down to the practical business of drafting workable blueprints for economic advance in the world's underdeveloped countries.

Homemakers choosing new dinnerware and table accessories these days will have to be definite in their likes and dislikes and bold in their choices, judging by new patterns now in the stores. The results are apt to be brighter, more cheerful tables.

Active trading in coffee futures continued on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Strong demand from trade interests and some short covering advanced prices in Contract "D" 40 to 75 points above Friday's close. Selling was on a scale up, principally on profit-taking.
WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP) -- A "disagreement" between President Truman and House Speaker Sam Rayburn sent a veteran Democratic leader to the White House today to "smooth" things over.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP) -- Major Gen. Lewis A. Pick, chief of Army Engineers, said today that on paper the national flood control program now included nearly 1,000 projects with an estimated cost of $7,503,000,000. He called it "probably the largest single construction program in the entire world."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 16 -- At a stormy meeting of the New Haven County Bar Association tonight, the members voted overwhelmingly to reject two resolutions opposing the appointment by Gov. Chester Bowles, a Democrat, of Senator Raymond E. Baldwin, a Republican, to the State Supreme Court of Errors a few days ago.

The first of a series of surveys on civil rights and group relations in the United States was made public yesterday by the American Jewish Congress and the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. They declared that, despite recent progress, discrimination still was the most important obstacle to democracy.
The New York campaign of the 1949 appeal for funds of the American Red Cross has reached nearly 90 per cent of its quota, Brig. Gen. E. F. Jeffe, chairman of the local drive, reported yesterday.

ROME, May 16 -- The Italian Government is contemplating a direct appeal to the New York Metropolitan Museum of Art for restitution of the painting of St. Sebastian, attributed to Andrea Del Castagno, which is now on exhibition there.

The desperate plight of the Palestinian refugees lies upon the conscience of all who know that many hundred thousands of them are helpless and starving in the desert. They are not allowed to return to their homes. Only about half of the $16,000,000 contribution of the United States has thus far been placed at the disposal of the United Nations Relief Committee.
LONDON, May 16 -- After small week-end orders had been dealt with in the stock market here today, trading was quiet and buying at a minimum.

HONGKONG, May 16 (Reuters) -- Big Hong Kong interests, confident in the future of the colony, have bought heavily on the Hong Kong Stock Market in the last two weeks and so averted a slump which might have followed the record sales made during that time, a leading Hong Kong stockbroker said today.
SHANGHAI, May 16 -- A new Communist spearhead is sweeping between Shanghai and the coast in an apparent effort to encircle Nationalist armies here.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- David E. Lilienthal, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, firmly defended today the system by which students are selected by a non-political, private organization for fellowships or other aid from Federal funds.
LAREDO, Tex., May 16 (AP) -An American team from Lowry Air Force Base, Denver, today won Laredo's international pistol shoot in competition with Canadian and Mexican teams.

" May Wine Time Is Here," say the signs in restaurants and wine shops. But it's probably only to those of German background that this news brings back nostalgic memories. For it was along the Rhine in the wine-producing vineyards between Mainz and Cologne that this spring beverage originated.
Welfare Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard was made an honorary lifetime member of the Hudson Guild at a ceremony in the community center at 436 West Twenty-seventh Street yesterday afternoon.

PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., May 16 -- A residential neighborhood of tomorrow that sets a new pace in modern architecture and cooperative ownership is rising from ninety-seven acres of wooded hillside and rolling meadow in Central Westchester.

Voters of the Twentieth Congressional District will go to the polls today to determine whether Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. will receive encouragement or a check in his ambition to follow his father in a political career.

The Willard Gibbs Medal, on of the highest honors in chemistry, will be awarded Friday night to Prof. Peter J. W. Debye, head of the Department of Chemistry at Cornell University. The presentation will be made by Prof. Linus Pauling, president of the American Chemical Society, at a dinner of the organization's Chicago section at the Furniture Club of America in Chicago.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 16 -- A crisis has broken out on the campus of the American University in Beirut with regard to the students' traditional role, which has been famous throughout the Arab world as the bearer of the idea of Pan Arabism.
WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The House today passed a bill to cancel the overtime rights of Federal lighthouse keepers, and to pay a flat bonus to them instead.
BRISTOL, England, May 16 (Reuters) -- A general stoppage by about 1,200 men held up today the unloading of seven ships at Avonmouth, ten miles from Bristol.

CHICAGO, May 16 -- The Administration's proposed program of compulsory Government insurance would deprive industry of a needed source of loan capital, the private insurance company, W. G. Caples, director of industrial relations for the Inland Steel Company, said today.
BERLIN, May 16 -- Outcome of voting in the Soviet zone and Soviet sector of Berlin will not be known until tomorrow, ADN, Soviet-licensed news service, reported in a terse paragraph late tonight.

WASHINGTON, May l6 -- The batle between right and left wing forces in the Congress of Industrial Organizations may lead toward revocation of charter of left-wing unions, it was reported here today in authoritative CIO circles.

Mrs. Hugh S. Walker, vice chairman of the benefit "Salute to Summer'' party to be given next Tuesday at the Plaza, gave a tea yesterday in her home at 116 East Sixty-third Street for members of the junior committee recently organized by Mrs. Lewis A. Coffin Jr.

TOKYO, May 16 -- Within the next ten days, the Japanese Government is expected to issue an order to the banks that will ease trade and industrial credit materially. The move, which has received occupation approval, will end a rule that bankers must make available 35 per cent of any increase in deposits for Government financing.

Asserting that world peace depended upon world education, Attorney General Tom C. Clark proposed last night that a world university be established to bring the youth of many nations together for education in brotherhood.
BILOXI, Miss., May 16 (UP) -Harry M. Davis, 38 years old, science editor of Newsweek magazine, was drowned in the Gulf of Mexico tonight.

Awards to twelve groups and individuals for "outstanding contributions to the progress of education" in 1948 were announced yesterday by the Education Writers Association at a luncheon in Columbia University's John Jay Hall.

William Church Osborn, honorary president of the board of trustees of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, was honored by the institution yesterday on the forty-fifth anniversary of his election to the board.
KINGS POINT, L. I., May 16 -- New York University unleashed an eighteen-hit attack to defeat the United States Merchant Marine Academy, 21 -- 2, today on Roosevelt Field.
WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP) -- The House of Representatives passed today a bill to prevent railroads in reorganization from avoiding state controls.

GENEVA, May 16 -- Eastern Europe's economic difficulties and its slow pace of economic development are the direct result of Soviet efforts to divert the resources of the whole region to its own uses, Paul R. Porter, United States delegate, charged in the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe today.

Dr. John J. Theobald, dean of administration at City College and a strong foe of left-wing campus activity, was elected last night by the Board of Higher Education to the presidency of Queens College. His election brought to an end a controversy in which Mayor O'Dwyer at one time took a hand.

A new "pilot project." designed to promote closer school and community ties and to stimulate "local initiative in the operation of the schools," has been started in an East Bronx area by the Board of Education, the Public Education Association and the Metropolitan School Study Council, it was announced yesterday.

CONGERS, N. Y., May 16 -- In the Gay Nineties and shortly after the turn of the century a horse-drawn hansom made better time in New York City than present-day midtown taxicabs, according to William P. O'Brien, 76-year-old Rockland County Court crier, who was one of New York's best known cab drivers until he retired in 1909.

Following are extracts from speeches on the question of the Franco regime in Spain delivered yesterday in the United Nations General Assembly by Dr. Juliusz Katz-Suchy and Hector McNeil, the Polish and British representatives:

A witness at the Communist trial testified yesterday that party leaders secretly tried to use newspaper men, writers and other "professionals" to exploit labor grievances for a revolution to be aided by the Soviet Union.

CHICAGO, May 16 -- Grain markets fluctuated in a nervous manner on the Board of Trade here today with short covering in May wheat and soybeans giving the two deliveries independent strength. Wheat was up 2 1/8 cents a bushel at one time and at a new high since Jan. 8 and the May soybeans advanced 4 cents from the early low to a new high since Jan. 29.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- David A. Morse, director of the International Labor Office, called on President Truman today and informed him of plans for implementing "Point 4" of the President's inaugural address.

The bill now before the House to increase and adjust pay scales in the armed forces is a sound measure and should be adopted. The unanimous approval of the House Armed Services Committee came after careful study and should carry weight.
John M. Murtagh, Commissioner of Investigation, said yesterday that his staff was looking into the letting of city contracts, but he would not make public any details of the industry.

Net income of the Cincinnati Gas Electric Company and its subsidiaries for the twelve months ended with last March increased to $8,663,764, equal to $3.38 a common share, from $7,328,742, or $2.78 a common share, in the twelve months to March 31, 1948, the report disclosed yesterday.

One of the theatre's unique projects, the stage adaptation of James Joyce's "Finnegans Wake," is in the making, it was learned yesterday. Edwin R. Armstrong, better known in theatrical publicity circles as Ned, confirmed the report that he would serve as sponsor of the unusual undertaking.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The New York State Electric and Gas Corporation, Ithaca, N. Y., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 40,000 shares of cumulative preferred stock of $100 par value to be sold at competitive bidding.
Members of the National Association of State Racing Commissioners voted unanimous opposition yesterday to proposals that off-course betting on horse racing be legalized.

The hope that private enterprise soon would take on a larger share of the production of homes for families of moderate income was expressed by Deputy Mayor John J. Bennett yesterday as the New York City Housing Authority conducted cornerstone ceremonies for one public housing project, broke ground for the construction of another, and began to accept applications for apartments in a third.
Trading in cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday and final prices were 12 points higher to 4 points lower.

The United Nations General Assembly defeated yesterday a resolution that would nave permitted the return of Ambassadors and Ministers to Spain while the Franco regime was in power. The vote was 26 for the proposal and 15 against with sixteen abstentions.
The tears shed yesterday in Kings County Court by ten of Donato Mangelli's eleven children saved their father from a prison term on a charge of criminally receiving stolen property.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- A hero's return was being prepared today for Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States commander and Military Governor in Germany, and President Truman asked the Senate to approve his promotion to full general before retirement.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (UP) -- Congress completed action today on a compromise $524,700,000 deficiency appropriation bill carrying $2,500,000 to start work on the Tennessee Valley Authority's proposed steam plant at New Johnsonville, Tenn.

The Carnegie Cup regatta at Princeton and the Dad Vail eeting at Poughkeepsie for the smaller powers, the two rowing events scheduled for this week in the East, occupied chief attention at the weekly crew luncheon at the New York A. C. yesterday.

ALBANY, May 16 -- The State Board of Law Examiners announced today that 665 of the 1,393 applicants for admission to the bar passed the examination held March 2 and 3. Five hundred sixty seven of these who passed are residents of the first and second judicial departments, which comprise New York, Bronx, Kings, Queens, Richmond, Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester, Rockland, Putnam, Orange and Dutchess counties.
NEW SUFFOLK, L. I., May 16 -- This little sport fishing port is increasing in popularity with anglers, and after a day's weak-fishing out of here it is not difficult to understand.

Those with any stake in the prosperity of Long Island should take the initiative in obtaining legislation to release the Long Island Rail Road for a while from its taxes, it was suggested yesterday by David E. Smucker, trustee of the bankrupt carrier and its chief operating officer.

Held in London to face charges in extradition proceedings, Gerhart Eisler charges that the British authorities who removed him from a Polish ship "have brutally violated the old British tradition of asylum for political emigres fighting for freedom and progress." Elsewhere in his statement Mr. Eisler says again: "I am a political refugee."

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 16 -- The building trades department of the American Federation of Labor, representing 1,750,000 organized construction workers, decided tonight to scrap the arbitration machinery set up to settle jurisdictional disputes in the building industy and to substitute a new arbitration authority in which employers would have no direct representation.

CHICAGO, May 16 -- The Rev. Arthur W. Terminiello was arrested after speaking at a tumultuous meeting here Feb. 7, 1946, sponsored by the Christian Veterans of America. Other speakers at the meeting were Gerald L. K. Smith, head of the America First party, and Fred Kister, head of the Christian Veterans.

The Children's Aid Society releases its annual report, the ninety-sixth, at the same time that hearings on the National Child Research Bill are being held in Washington. The report, entitled "The New Crop" and issued in observance of Children's Aid Society Week, points out the agency's efforts during the past year in fortifying the environment, the health and the homes of more than 45,000 New York City children regardless of race, color or creed.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., May 16 -As final preparations were being made for the induction of John V. Kenny and his colleagues into the City Commission tomorrow, ending the Hague-Eggers regime in this city, former Mayor Frank Hague served official notice that his organization would continue to function politically.

BALDWIN, L. I., May 16 -- Pete Brown of the Wheatley Hills club and Henry Ciuci, Fresh Meadow, clipped eight strokes from par with 31, 32 -- 63 to win the weekly amateur-pro tournament of the Long Island P. G. A., at the Willow Brook club today.

BERLIN, May 16 -- Before leaving for the United States on Sunday, Gen. Lucius D. Clay, retiring United States Military Governor, gave the approval of the United States Military Government to increases in social security benefits in the bizonal United States-British area that, it has been estimated, will cost an additional 1,000,000,000 marks annually.

HAVANA, May 16 (UP) -- Representatives of four airlines operating from Havana's International Airport demanded from Cuban authorities today protection of their equipment and flight communications in case of a strike by members of the Air Workers Union.
CAMDEN, N. J., May 16 (AP) -Normrich, carrying the silks of F. St. Charles, took the lead at the head of the stretch and went on to win the featured Glassboro Purse at Garden State Park today.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The National Labor Relations Board declared unanimously today that, contrary to the views of Robert N. Denham, its general counsel, the board has discretion in asserting jurisdiction over unfair labor practice cases.

DETROIT, May 16 -- With Federal intervention impending in the walkout against the Ford Motor Company, Thomas Thompson, president of Local 600 of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, asserted today that the union was striking to establish a precedent for the "entire industry."

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., May 16 -From early morning until late at night, 35 foursomes composed of two men amateurs, one woman amateur and a top professional teed up at the Piping Rock Club course today in a match the proceeds of which went to the North Country Community Hospital at Glen Cove.

Fruits and vegetables moved through the port yesterday in normal quantities after a teamsters' boycott had won back 1,200 jobs but added freight handling costs had brought a round of protests from trade and consumer groups.

Plans for an official welcome to General Clay at City Hall on Thursday were announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, chairman of the Mayor's Reception Committee, after a conference with representatives of the armed services and the municipal departments concerned.

TRENTON, N. J., May 16 -- Top New Jersey officials, as state trustees of a $50,000,000 employes disability fund, admitted before an investigating commission today that they had no knowledge of the profit made by a New York broker in selling them $3,405,000 of New York State housing bonds.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- A reduction of 30 per cent in Western Europe's total gold and dollar deficit in the year ending June 30, compared with the preceding year, was forecast today in a report to Congress by the Economic Cooperation Administration covering the final quarter of last year.
The Bell unit of the Newspaper Guild of New York, CIO, went out on strike last night against the four syndicate affiliates of the North American Newspaper Alliance, Inc., a Delaware corporation.

The Board of Estimate's final approval of the construction of three pedestrian ramp-overpasses, one each at 103d, 111th and 120th Streets on the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive, brings nearer the day when that great artery will be entirely free from traffic lights. As it is, these lights will disappear from the segment of the drive from Ninety-sixth Street to 125th Street as soon as the new overpasses are finished.
Brooklyn, Bronx and Queens spokesman made determined bids yesterday for the state medical school projected for this area.

MOSCOW, May 16 -- A comparative evaluation of the role played by Soviet forces and those of the West in the defeat of Germany is provided by a historical textbook now in use in the Soviet secondary schools. The text is a three-volume history of the U.S.S.R. prepared by the Institute of History of the Academy of Sciences. Twenty-five pages are devoted to the story of Germany's defeat.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., May 16 -- Henry H. Heimann, of New York City, executive manager of the National Association of Credit Men, said today credit of the world rests upon fulfillment of promises and it is the duty of credit executives to insist that promises be made good so that faith in mankind will not suffer.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 16 -Resuming a golf partnership which terminated in 1942 when the amateur club-swinger entered the Navy, Pat Circelli, pro at Gedney, and Phil Santora, now of Westchester Hills, teamed to win top honors in the one-day pro-amateur tournament staged by the Westchester P. G. A. at the Westchester Hills Golf Club this afternoon. A field of 47 pairs competed.
BERLIN, Tuesday, May 17 -- First scattered returns today from Eastern Berlin in the Soviet zone elections showed more votes against the Communists than for them.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today began listening to a week-long argument on whether or not to grant the railroads additional increased freight rates amounting to $550,000,000 a year.

A new English translation of the autobiography of Johann Wolfgang von Goethe will be brought out by the Public Affairs Press of Washington to commemorate his bicentennial. "Goethe's Autobiography: Poetry and Truth from My Own Life," has been translated by R. O. Moon and is based on the ten-volume edition that was published in Berlin in 1889.
WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The Department of Agriculture today conferred upon employes five distinguished service awards, and fifty-three awards for superior service.

Fresh from a visit to America, Maurice Evans has brought back to New York his impish production of Bernard Shaw's "Man and Superman." Since it delighted the town last season, when it was fresh and expensive, it ought to delight the town again at the City Center, which charges the prices of tomorrow.

LEICESTER, England, May 16 (Reuters) -The New Zealand cricket tourists dismissed Leicestershire today for 119 runs in three and a quarter hours. The County was forced to follow on 317 runs behind and by close of play had scored 123 for the loss of one wicket in the second innings.

The proposition that high Government spending must continue in order to prevent a depression was attacked yesterday by Senator Kenneth S. Wherry. Republican, of Nebraska, as part of an Administration philosophy threatening further steps toward national socialism.

St. John's took a firmer hold on first place in the Metropolitan Conference yesterday as the Redmen, behind Jack Gordon's neat six-hitter, defeated Manhattan, 8 -- 2, at Van Cortlandt Park. The victory partially atoned for the 2-0 defeat Frank McGuire's team had suffered at the hands of Manhattan ten days ago.
Two rent gougers received workhouse sentences when they appeared yesterday in Special Sessions. Six other persons were fined a total of $2,350 for excessive rentals.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The Supreme Court ruled today that the Federal Government could sue Texas and Louisiana in an effort to establish the paramount rights of the United States to the vast oil deposits beneath coastal waters of the Gulf of Mexico.

VIRGINIA BEACH, May 16 -- Assurance that the Economic Cooperation Administration is well aware of the problems of the tanning industry as an export and an import group, was given here today by Theodore L. Sweet, chief, industry division, Combined Materials Branch of the ECA.

Edith Noble Warner in a letter to THE TIMES complains that while much publicity is given to cleaning up Harlem, other sections of Manhattan appear to be overlooked. The truth is that the Sanitation Department has never regarded street conditions in Harlem as any better or worse that any other congested area in the city.

" One Woman's Story," a British-made adaptation of the H. G. Wells novel, "The Passionate Friends," starring Ann Todd, Claude Rains and Trevor Howard, will have its local premiere tonight at the Rivoli Theatre. The romantic drama was directed by David Lean and produced by Ronald Neame from a screen play by Eric Ambler.
Construction of a two-acre recreational center, including a big skating rink, in Central Park is expected to begin in the early fall, the Park Department announced yesterday.

SEATTLE, May 16 (AP) -- After less than two months in professional baseball, Sammy White, sensational young Pacific Coast League rookie catcher, was sold today by the Seattle Rainiers to the Red Sox for delivery in 1950.
LONDON, May 16 (UP) -Czechoslovakia eliminated England and Hungary defeated Belgium today to join five other nations already in the quarter-finals of European Zone Davis Cup tennis.
Some of the famous art treasures of the Prado Museum in Madrid may be on exhibition next winter at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

CLEVELAND, May 16 -- The American Federation of Labor's -- world-wide offensive against communism received new impetus today when the AFL executive council unanimously approved joint participation with the Congress of Industrial Organizations in a new world labor body.

Members of the United Nations General Assembly will take up the question of the former Italian colonies a meeting opening at 11 A. M. today with the hope that they can reach a vote by nightfall and end their spring session.

Vanity Fair Pearls, Inc., has leased the building at 155-01 South Road, Jamaica, Queens, for use in the manufacture of simulated pearls and kindred objects. The company, headed by Louis Rabinowitz, formerly president of the Valjean Pearl Corporation, has its showrooms at 377 Fifth Avenue, where its sales representative is the House of Hordan.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- A former highly-placed Communist party functionary in this country insisted today before a Senate Judiciary Sub-committee that Gerhart Eisler's flight from the United States was dictated by Moscow.

Although volume prices are down an average of 20 per cent on stationery products, most classifications of the business expect harder selling to bring a 20 to 25 per cent volume increase over last year, according to views expressed yesterday by representative officials at the New York Stationery Show.

PRAGUE, May 16 -- A secret Czechoslovak state court today announced it had sentenced Gen. Karel Kutlvasr, leader of the Prague uprising of May, 1945, to life imprisonment and three others to death on charges of plotting to overthrow the Government.
WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP) -- The nation's output of goods and services took its biggest post-war dive in the first quarter of 1949.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The youthful president of Seaboard and Western Airlines, Inc., a post-war irregular transatlantic air freight service, flatly charged before a Senate committee today that the three certificated airlines with whom his company competes were trying to "crush" Seaboard because it was too efficient.

TEHERAN, Iran, May 16 -- United States official circles in Teheran are alarmed by reliable reports that Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi is preparing to hand the control of the Iranian gendarmerie back to the War Ministry.

An issue of $23,800,000 of various purpose bonds, issued by the State of Massachusetts, was awarded yesterday to the First National Bank of Chicago and associates for 100.158, an interest cost of 1.6357 per cent. The group will reoffer the issue, which is dated April, May and June 1, 1949, at prices to yield from 0.65 for 1.60s, due on Dec. 1, 1949, to 1.85 per cent for 1 3/4s, due on Jan. 1, 1979.

LONDON, May 16 -- While Communist pickets circled slowly past the entrance, a magistrate in Bow Street Police Court here ordered today that Gerhart Eisler, German Communist fugitive from the United States, be held for a hearing on the request of the American authorities for his extradition to the United States.

JOE McCARTHY always was a slippery man to pin down for an opinion as to the potentialities of his ball club. In spring training he'd say, "It's too early to tell yet. I haven't seen enough ball clubs. Wait until the season starts." Once the campaign began he'd wriggle some more. "I'd have to see every team first," he'd remark cryptically.

The question of increased dividends on the common stock of the Consolidated Edison Company, an issue of prime interest to the 500 stockholders attending the utility's annual meeting yesterday, was placed squarely in the lap of the Public Service Commission.

Two big triples proved the difference yesterday. Marty Silverman of Brooklyn College defeated Ron Schoek, Fordham southpaw, 12 -- 0, in a pitching thriller at the Kingsmen's field. Backed by gilt-edged defensive play which reeled off three double plays, Silverman struck out five and scattered six hits to notch his third Metropolitan Conference victory and the first shutout for the Kingsmen.

Almost never seem to see an umbrella swinging from a gentleman's arm these days; used to be such a dashing sight, remarked the man in the old-fashioned hat in the tiny entrance that had become a sanctuary from the torrential beating of a spring shower.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 16 -- Edward Small, independent film producer and financier, has made "several" formal offers for the purchase of Eagle-Lion Films, it was learned today, and further discussions of the prospective deal will now be transferred to New York for action by Robert Young, controlling owner of Pathe Industries, the parent company.

A revision of American tariff laws would be of immeasurable value to Belgium and all other European countries, Baron de Vaxelaire, head of Belgium's largest chain of department and variety stores, declared here yesterday.

American industry was basically unprepared to fight the type of war this country was forced to wage in World War II, Col. G. A. Harvey yesterday told industrial executives and reserve officers attending an economic mobilization course at 30 Rockefeller Plaza. Colonel Harvey offered a plan for future economic mobilization to meet the difficulties that he said arose when the country went on a big buying spree in 1942.

General Electric Company yesterday announced list price reductions ranging from .$9.25 to $19.25 on all nine units comprising its household refrigerator line. The reductions, effective today, follow list price cuts from $5 to $23 on thirteen household refrigerators announced over the week-end by Frigidaire division, General Motors Corporation.
The Port of New York Authority moved yesterday to obtain stiffer penalties for violation of its regulations governing the transport of explosives and other hazardous cargoes.

An over-all improvement in the promptness of payments of export drafts by Latin-American countries occurred in April, partly reflecting increasing efficiency in operation of the exchange control systems in some of the countries, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The Administration was called on today by Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg to clarify what obligation the United States would have to help put down "internal disorders" occurring the countries that signed the North Atlantic treaty.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- India's new Ambassador to the United States, Mrs. Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit, who has just completed a two-year tour of duty in Moscow, today told her first press conference here that her aim is to steer completely clear of alignments with power blocs.

The most important trend in social work today is the tendency of social agencies to merge, Dr. Eduard C. Lindeman, a leader in social work education, declared yesterday. He warned, however, that mergers should not be made "merely to save money but for more efficient service to the community."

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Department of Justice officials awaiting the extradition from England of Gerhart Eisler said today that the German Communist would be charged as a fugitive and with violation of his bail if and when he was returned to the jurisdiction of United States Courts.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Officials of the Export-Import Bank told the Senate's special investigating subcommittee today that they knew nothing of a reputed $100,000 cash "kickback" on marine insurance covering shipments to Poland under a $40,000,000 United States loan.
WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP) -- Lou Stringer's blunder as a pinch runner and Washington's quick capitalization on it presented the Senators a 3-2 decision over the Red Sox today.

The special Federal grand jury investigating subversive activities has issued subpoenas calling for the appearance of Mrs. Gerhart Eisler and two officials of the Gdynia America Line for questioning tomorrow morning.

ST. LOUIS, May 16 -- Congressional passage of a kill that would provide Federal funds to improve local public health programs was demanded here today by Mrs. L. W. Hughes of Arlington, Tenn., president of the National Congress of Parents and Teachers.

If President Truman's compulsory health insurance program is approved, the Federal Government will undertake to increase the number of persons receiving training as practical nurses from 2,000 to 10,000 a year and eventually to 30,000, according to Oscar R. Ewing, Federal Security Administrator. Measures will be taken also to increase the number of physicians, dentists and other professional experts needed, he said.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The plight of thousands of recent political refugees from Russian satellite countries unable to qualify for aid as displaced persons was brought to the attention of this Government today by a group of former political leaders of Eastern Europe, including Russia.

AMARILLO, Tex., May 16 (AP) -- Damage was estimated at more than $3,000,000 today in the wake of a tornado that last night killed four persons here and then skipped eighty miles north to flatten some of Texas' richest wheat land. Eighty-three persons were injured and 350 homes -- ninety of them owned by veterans -- demolished by the tornado, which wrecked thirty-five blocks here.

PARIS, May 16 -- Possibly as a result of last minute efforts by the British Government of Cyprus to reduce the strength of local communism, yesterday's municipal elections in the Crown Colony swung in favor of the right-wing candidates.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP) -- The latest in a long series of Federal Bureau of Investigation agents who shadowed Judith Coplon acknowledged today that he, too, never saw her pass any papers to Valentine A. Gubitchev, her alleged Russian sweetheart.
LONDON, May 16 (AP) -- Women from the United States aim to dress in comfort for Thursday's presentation at court.

Charles M. Lincoln, retired newspaper executive, was re-elected honorary president of the Society of the Silurians, Inc., by unanimous vote at its fifty-first semi-annual dinner last night at the New York Athletic Club.

Emphasizing that one out of every five children who are graduated from grade school next month would be suffering from defective vision, Dr. Walter J. Wittmann called yesterday for "adequate" visual hygiene in all schools of New York State.
WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The Government can be called upon to pay damages in the injury or death of a soldier in addition to sums paid as military or veterans' benefits, the Supreme Court decided today.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- After brief debate the Senate, by a unanimous voice vote, passed and sent to conference today the legislation to give the President authority to make reorganizations within the Executive Branch in the interest of economy and greater efficiency.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 16 -- Although Israel has announced her intention of favoring an independent Arab state in Palestine under terms of the partition resolution of 1947, an unofficial suggestion has been put forward that an international trusteeship might be more acceptable.

The action of the Supreme Court yesterday in denying a stay against the reorganization plan sets in motion the final phase of compliance by Electric Power and Light with a seven-year-old dissolution order issued against the utility by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The airy, open quality of Greek sandals made 2,000 years ago, has found its way into present-day shoe fashions in a streamlined, sophisticated manner. The Greeks made thong sandals to tread the hot, stony roads of Mediterranean countries.

Fresh life was injected into the stock market yesterday by a burst of buying in a selected list of public utility issues, and scattered strength in the industrials enabled the list to make new gains. Outstanding advances were registered by issues of Electric Power Light after the Supreme Court of the United States refused to halt the reorganization plan.

The first issue of The Daily Compass, New York's new daily newspaper, appeared yesterday. It is a morning tabloid, costs 10 cents and will be printed six days a week. Yesterday's paper had thirty-two pages.

The first large variety trade show to be held in New York since the war opened yesterday at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory with an unexpected attendance of more than 2,000 buyers from department and variety stores as well as buying offices.

C. C. Carr will retire on June 1 as director of public relations and advertising for the Aluminum Company of America and will be succeeded by his assistant, Arthur P. Hall, the company announced yesterday. Mr. Carr, formerly publisher of the Sullivan, Ind., Times, has been with Alcoa for the last fifteen years.
WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP) -- The Supreme Court by a vote of 4 to 2 refused today to halt a reorganization plan for the Electric Power and Light Corporation.

Public School 174, Dieterle Crescent and Sixty-fifth Drive, Rego Park, Queens, which was built at a cost of $1,575,070, was formally dedicated yesterday. In a "community salute" to the new school, Nathaniel Schneider, chairman of the local school board, presented a steel engraving of Abraham Lincoln to the institution.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The right of free speech must be maintained even where the speaker's words stir people to anger and unrest, the Supreme Court held today by five to four, narrowest division possible in the tribunal.

Four model residences of modified Colonial styles, each with at least half an acre of land, have been completed for inspection in the Northacaes project comprising sixty-four acres on North Street, in White Plains, N. Y., Sam Minskoff Sons, builders, reported yesterday.

TOO many anthologies have no excuse for being other than their editors' understandable desire to earn an honest penny. A few are treasure houses stored with literary loot from many an unknown kingdom (unknown to most readers, anyway). "The Spell of the Pacific"* is one of these, a magnificent collection of wonderfully various and interesting selections covering 400 years and much of the world's largest ocean.

The Celanese Corporation of America had a net ncome of $6,047,624 in the first three months of this year after taxes and all charges, compared with $9,743,930 earned in the initial quarter a year ago, according to the report released today.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 17 -- Princeton University has received a three-year grant of $30,000 from the Rockefeller Foundation for the establishment next fall of a series of seminars that will bring leading creative writers from this country and abroad in contact with Princeton students in the discussion of modern literary criticism, Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of the university, announced today.
