LAKE SUCCESS, May 17 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, speaking for the United States, told the United Nations Human Rights Commission today that this country would strongly oppose any detailed listing of curbs to be imposed on rights and fredoms guaranteed in the proposed covenant on human rights.

WFDR, the International Ladies Garment Workers Union's new FM radio station in New York, begins broadcasting on a test basis at 2 o'clock this afternoon. The station will be on the air from that hour to 11 P. M. daily on Channel 282, located at 104.3 on the FM dial.

ATHENS, May 17 -- The Army General Staff today reported successes in several parts of Greece. Four rebels were killed and twenty-nine captured. Forty members of a Communist auxiliary clandestine organization, Autoamyna, Were apprehended in Rumeli, central Greece, now a main area of operations.

TOKYO, May 17 -- Some chance remarks by Premier Shigeru Yoshida during the course of a long conversation this afternoon have cast an entirely new light on what is being done to modify the purge that has taken 176,000 persons out of political and business life.

PARIS, May 17 -- Although strictest secrecy is being maintained in the Western powers' tactical negotiations prior to the Council of Foreign Ministers' conference, the impression gathered is that a spirit of unanimity prevails on the ways of approaching the specific problems likely to be raised by Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky.

Dun Bradstreet, credit ratings, which plans a twelve-story office building in the blockfront on the east side of Church Street, from Park Place to Barclay Street, has added 26-28 Park Place to the site, which runs all the way back to the Woolworth Building, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Builders were disturbed today over a decision of American Federation of Labor unions to set up new machinery for settling jurisdictional disputes without employer participation.

Since the United States Atomic Energy Commission is spending money for atomic energy scholarships, the Government has "not only every right but every duty to safeguard itself from any elements that might threaten national security," Robert E. Sherwood said last night.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- A bill to avert a Federal deficit in the fiscal year beginning July 1 by a speed-up of corporation tax payments was introduced in the House today with Democratic leaders evidencing considerable interest and Republican chiefs denouncing it as a "fraud."

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- House Republican leaders have decided to wage a no-compromise fight against the Administration's Multi-billion-dollar public housing and slum clearance bill when it comes to the floor, probably next week.

FRANKFORT, Germany, May l7 -- Signs of continued French hesitancy in the program for the German Federal Republic were reported today by Western Allied officials. The officials cited today's three-power meeting as an example.
Five hundred New York University students watched the rescue yesterday of three workmen buried up to their armpits by a cave-in of a trench on South Field, near the campus gymnasium in the Bronx.

Demonstration of therapy for cerebral palsied children, discussion of comics, radio and television by eight youngsters, movies explaining the needs of young children and the meaning of their play, were features of yesterday's session of Our Children's World '49 exhibition at Grand Central Palace.

SEOUL, Korea, May 17 -- Immediate negotiations for establishment of a mutual assistance pact between non-Communist Asiatic countries and the United States against Soviet aggression were advocated here today by President Syngman Rhee.

The Rev. Joseph A. Assmuth, noted entomologist and Professor of Biology at Fordham University, will leave for Cologne, Germany, aboard the Caronia tomorrow to attend the centenary celebration of the opening of the first Kopling house in that city.

Coffee futures prices were lower in moderately active trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. After early steadiness on producer buying, prices drifted lower on scattered selling and absence of early support. Prices rallied somewhat late in the day. Final prices for contract

With a Treasury deficit in sight, there has suddenly emerged from a group of Democratic members of the House Ways and Means Committee what purports to be a "painless" method of avoiding the politically disagreeable alternatives of cutting expenditures or raising taxes.

A $7,755,000 plan for improving and rearranging the Manhattan approaches to the Queensboro Bridge, prepared by Parsons, Brinckerhoff, Hogan Macdonald, engineers, was forwarded to members of the Board of Estimate yesterday by Frederick H. Zurmuhlen, Commissioner of Public Works.

Plans for continuing the old Mills Hotel at 160 Bleecker Street as a rooming house were announced yesterday following sale of the 1,535-room structure by the Mills estate to a syndicate headed by Philip Edwards. The building was opened in 1897 and was the first of three in the well-known chain started to provide rooms for single men of moderate means.
PITTSBURGH, May 17 -- Smacked for a homer by his mound adversary, Clint Hartung, quite early in the fray, Bob Chesnes retaliated with interest tonight and he did it when it produced the most damage.

ALBANY, May 17 -- Hearings on a request by the New York Telephone Company for a temporary 10 per cent increase in local service charges and intra-state tolls calculated to add $30,800,000 a year to the company's gross income were concluded today by the Public Service Commission.

NEWARK, N. J., May 17 -- With two new members replacing former Mayor Vincent J. Murphy and Commissioner John A. Brady, who were defeated in the election last Tuesday, the five newly elected City Commissioners took their oaths of office today in the City Hall and named Ralph A. Villani as Mayor.

FORT BRAGG, N. C., May 17 (UP) -- Some 1,400 paratroopers bailed out of Air Force "Flying Boxcars" to "recapture" their sprawling post in Army maneuvers today. A captain fell to his death and twenty-six other soldiers were injured.

A housemaid who is said to have robbed two employers of jewelry and furs worth $55,000 was charged with grand larceny last night at the West Sixty-eighth Street Station after twelve hours of questioning.

ROME, May 17 -- The painting of St. Sebastian by Andrea Del Castagno, which the Italian Department of Fine Arts believes to have been smuggled out of Italy, belonged to the collection of a Florentine family, the Giornale d' Italia said today.
For the next nine or ten years, Leon Glass, whose past includes arrests for impersonating Army officers, a Secret Service agent, bigamy and forgery, will find his activities curtailed.
WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The executive board of the Congress of Industrial Organizations struck its Communist minority a stinging blow of censure today.

A vacancy in the post of examiner for the Board of Education, paying $12,000 annually, was announced yesterday by the Municipal Service Commission. The period from June 7 to 22 was set for filing applications, which may be done by mail.

LONDON, May 17 -- Little activity was seen in the stock market here today and it is considered probable that slack conditions will rule during the new account opening tomorrow which will last three weeks.

Evidence that there was little wrong with the Yankees a well-pitched game would not cure was given to the season's largest crowd -- 73,150 -- as the Bombers downed the world champion Indians, 4 -- 3, last night at the Stadium. Lefty Ed Lopat, in his first outing since May 3, went all the way in a commendable seven-hit exhibition for his fourth victory.

The stock market was unable yesterday to extend the recovery and, although public utilities remained the major medium of trading, prices for these issues faltered on moderate profit-taking. Heavy industrial shares were marked down and the oils softened on the outlook for 1949 earnings as pictured by one producer.

The Port of New York Authority, in view of the absence from the city of two of the three airline presidents whom it had invited to confer with it today over the long-drawn-out dispute over use of New York International Airport at Idlewild, has proposed that the meeting be held the week of June 30.

Miss Ethel Dammrich, who resigned from the public school system last week after twenty-three years as a teacher here because of alleged influence on school policy by a Roman Catholic newspaper, said yesterday that her resignation would stand.

Lieut. Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, commanding general of the First Army and former Ambassador to the Soviet Union, will be the principal speaker tonight at a muster for the city's Seventy-seventh Division, Organized Reserve Corps.

The United Nations General Assembly early today rejected a resolution based on an Anglo-Italian agreement for the disposition of the former Italian colonies in Africa. The vote was 37 against to 14 in favor.

CHICAGO, May 17 -- Government suits involving about $30,000,000 in claims against 199 defendants for violations of the former Price Control Act are affected by a Federal Court of Appeals decision upholding Judge William J. Campbell of Federal District Court in dismissing a similar suit.

BOSTON, May 17 (AP) -- The stumbling Red Sox opened a lengthy home stand today by shading the revitalized White Sox, 4 -- 3, thanks to a two-run homer belted by Vern Stephens in the eighth inning. It was Stephens' ninth of the season, a line drive into the screen atop the wall in left.

LOU BOUDREAU was sprawled out on an easy chair in his hotel suite, whiling away the hours before last night's game with the Yankees, a clash which opened the first Eastern swing for the slightly staggering Indians. Herold (Muddy) Ruel, his coach, walked silently across the room, stepped out onto the terrace and peered down twenty-six stories to the street below.

MIDDLETOWN, N. J., May 17 -- Rainbow Inn, once popular pre-Revolutionary stagecoach stop at the junction of the old Burlington and Minisink Indian trails in Middletown Township, is being transformed into a modern dwelling with the antiquity of the famous landmark preserved.
Letters from our readers often contain information that is of general interest. Here are some of the suggestions, comments and inquiries that have been received recently:

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 17 -- Preparatory work on the Syrian section of the long-delayed $200,000,000 Trans-Arabian pipline will begin immediately, although actual construction of that part cannot begin for months.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, May 17 -- A new Communist drive to introduce "unified cooperatives" into the villages is meeting active resistance from some Czechoslovak peasants, the latest issue of the Communist review Fonkcionar reports.

The all-day conference of the Brooklyn Real Estate Board tomorrow at the Hotel St. George will be opened with a discussion on business and residential rent control by Frank A. Barrera, of counsel to the board. John W. Lake, president of the board, will preside at the luncheon session, at which the speakers will be Supreme Court Justice George J. Beldock and Charles F. Noyes.

The City Council approved yesterday the 1949-1950 expense budget of $1,197,434,284 in spite of vigorous attempts by four minority members to have it returned to the Board of Estimate to be shorn of some of the appropriations for jobs they considered useless political patronage.

LONDON, May 17 (AP) -- The quarter-final bracket for the European Zone Davis Cup eliminations was completed today when Chile's tennis team defeated Egypt, three matches to two, at Birmingham, England.

Stressing the value of "the family pattern" in the nation's social progress, Dr. Eduard C. Lindeman of the New York School of Social Work, Columbia University, declared yesterday that day nurseries provide an important contribution to this pattern.

For the fifty-second year the Clara De Hirsch Residence Club for young women will give tonight its annual founders day dinner at the club, 225 East Sixty-third Street. But this time it will also honor the retiring president of its board of directors, Mrs. Angelika Wertheim Frink, for whom the dinner will be a testimonial.

Brazil will tighten import controls to the degree necessary to enable payment of dollar indebtedness to American exporters, the Brazilian Finance Minister Pedro Luiz Correa e Castro declared yesterday in a statement released here by the Brazilian Government Trade Bureau.
OKLAHOMA CITY, May 17 (UP) -- Police today were investigating the report by a New York jewelry salesman of a $100,000 armed robbery.

Those who have been anxious to try the shad fishing on the Connecticut River may depart any day now, for the reports indicate the fishing to be excellent, with catches of from 25 to 100 shad per day in the Enfield area.

The employes of the Port of New York Authority were commended yesterday for the courage and calmness with which they met the test of the explosions and fires that ravaged a section of the Holland Tunnel last Friday.
ST. LOUIS, May 17 (AP) -- Singles by Eddie Waitkus, Del Ennis and Andy Seminick in the twelfth inning pushed over the run with which the Phillies beat the Cardinals tonight, 5 to 4.

Newspaper advertising proof sheets for the first of a series of retail campaigns in cooperation with the Advertising Council's economic understanding program will be prepared by Lester Harrison, Inc., it was announced yesterday. The volunteer agency will work with the council's retail advertising committee in devising the special material for the retail phase of the campaign.

LONDON, May 17 -- A statement from Dana Wilgress, Canadian High Commissioner, declaring the action of Canadian crews striking in ports abroad illegal was issued in Bristol tonight. Two Canadian ships are immobilized at Avonmouth, Bristol; the Montreal City and the Gulfside.

RICHMOND, Va., May 17 (AP) -- President Ernest E. Norris told stockholders of the Southern Railway Company today the Southern was doing all "humanly and financially" possible to enhance the efficiency and economy of its operations.
CLEVELAND, May 17 -- The American Federation of Labor asserted today that the Democratic Eighty-first Congress had offered labor "scarcely any greater comfort" than its Republican predecessor.

BERLIN, May 17 -- The Communist party and Soviet policy in Germany have suffered a startling election setback in the heavily policed Soviet zone of occupation and the Soviet sector of Berlin less than a week before the Council of Foreign Ministers reopens discussion of the German problem

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- A proposed cut of $371,140 in the 1950 appropriation for the Securities and Exchange Commission would seriously "impair" its ability to protect American investors, Edmond M. Hanrahan, chairman of the agency, warned Congress today.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -- Held to five hits, the Tigers capitalized on the wildness of Walter Masterson and Forrest Thompson to score four runs in the last two innings and defeat Washington, 4 -- 2, tonight. Johnny Lipon's single with the bases loaded in the ninth gave the Tigers their margin of victory.

Caught in the middle of a price "tug-of-war" between railroads and steel mills, railroad car builders are without any new orders for freight cars, David A. Crawford, president of Pullman, Inc., told stockholders at the company's annual meeting in Wilmington, Del., yesterday.

More and more often we read in the newspapers about some child who has found a gun and shot a playmate, usually fatally. Yet no consideration is given to the fact that from the age of about three years most children are given toy pistols and are allowed to shoot them at other children, parents, nursemaids, etc.

PHILADELPHIA, May 17 (AP) -- Rookie southpaw Alex Kellner won his third relief pitching victory in four games when he hurled the Athletics to a 9-2 triumph over the St. Louis Browns tonight. Hank Majeski supplied the batting punch, driving in five runs.

Commissioner of Investigation John M. Murtagh's effort to discover whether ticket scalping was preventing an equitable distribution of seats to the hit musical "South Pacific" was delayed yesterday when the box office treasurer of the Majestic Theatre had failed to make a requested appearance at the commissioner's office.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 17 -- Universal - International filed a countersuit today in Federal Court against Marston Production, the Nat Goldstone-Tony Martin company, asking $325,439.25 damages and a decree of foreclosure on "Casbah," a film produced by Marston and released in March of 1948 by U-I.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., May 17 -- The state Democratic chairman, Paul E. Fitzpatrick of Buffalo, told the women's division of the Democratic State Committee today that he intended to take "the appalling conditions which exist in this, the richest state of the union, to the "political battlegrounds" in the municipal and state-wide campaigns."

A team of four American contract bridge stars, composed of George N. Rapee, Samuel M. Stayman and Peter Leventritt of New York and John Crawford of Philadelphia, departed for England by Pan American Airlines yesterday afternoon to play matches against four English teams.

From a distance Shanghai looks like a city waiting to be conquered. As the Communist armies draw nearer, the population and the countless thousands of refugees encamped around the town seem to have sunk into a mood of dull resignation. The West appears equally fatalistic as it watches the open door slowly closing.

Maximilian Moss, newly elected president of the Board of Education, said yesterday that he favored prompt action to support Board of Regents rules barring members of subversive organizations from public school jobs.
Art as an experience shared by parents and their children was demonstrated yesterday at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, where the creative work of both was placed on exhibition.

Reflecting larger film rentals and theatre receipts, the consolidated net earnings of Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation and its subsidiaries increased to $3,017,736 in the thirteen weeks ended on March 26 from $2,926,842 in the first quarter of 1948, Spyros P. Skouras, president, reported at the annual meeting of stockholders held here yesterday.

LONDON, May l7 -- The Foreign Office, in pursuit of its retaliatory policy against countries of the Soviet bloc that have expelled British diplomats, announced tonight that it had demanded the recall of a member of the Czechoslovak Embassy staff in London.

Two million American citizens in Puerto Rico have been living for years under economic conditions far worse than the temporary plight of war-torn Europe, Dr. Antonio Fernos-Isern declared here yesterday.

CINCINNATI, May 17 (AP) -- Scoring the deciding run in the eighth inning, the Reds opened their first home stand against the East tonight by defeating Warren Spahn and the Boston Braves, 5 -- 4, before 21,911 fans. The defeat held Boston in a first-place tie with the Giants, who were beaten in Pittsburgh.

JERUSALEM, May 17 -- Despite seemingly insurmountable odds including a war and a massacre, the Hebrew University-Hadassah Medical School was opened here today in temporary quarters that not long ago were in no man's land.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday drifted lower and closed unchanged to down 15 points net, with the July contract showing the effects of increased spot cotton offerings in the South.

Mangohick ran a better than fair six furlongs at Belmont Park yesterday. Competing in the Roslyn Classified Handicap on the main course, the 5-year-old son of Sun Beau spun off the impressive figures of 1:10 4-5 to take first money in the feature.

Two new champions were crowned yesterday, in New Jersey and Long Island, when the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's interclub team matches were concluded. The Westchester section, however, still has another day of play before the winner is assured.

VIENNA, May 17 -- The Austrian Government and Vienna police and the United States garrison in the capital were kept in a state of alert today when 20,000 Communist-led workers marched along the Ringstrasse to City Hall shouting, "The people have sacrificed enough.
GENEVA, May 17 -- Eastern European countries unanimously rejected today United States charges that their economies were being dominated and distorted by the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, May 17 -- A $20,000 bond under which Gerhart Eisler had been held in this country was forfeited, and a bench warrant was issued for the arrest of the Communist today.

Charging that the American Medical Association was not a competent authority to pass on cosmetics, S. L. Mayham, executive vice president of the Toilet Goods Association, urged member manufacturers to resist efforts of the AMA to impose a seal of approval on products of the industry.

Eleven years ago today charges that free speech and other civil liberties had been suppressed in the Jersey City domain of Mayor Frank Hague resulted in orders for a thorough investigation by the Department of Justice.
KEY WEST, Fla., May 17 (AP) -- President Eurico Gaspar Dutra of Brazil arrived by air today for a state visit with President Truman.
ROCHESTER, N. Y., May 17 (AP) -- Eastman Kodak Company announced today that first-quarter earnings were $11,728,892, compared with $12,903,244 in the first quarter of 1948.

Proponents of compulsory health insurance, including public officials, have set a new low in propagandizing "their wilful misrepresentation of the voluntary health plans," Dr. Paul R. Hawley, national chief executive of the Blue Cross and Blue Shield Plans, declared yesterday.
Members of the National Association of Paper Box Manufacturers were told yesterday that only 14.5 per cent of concerns i. their industry expect an increase in business this year.

Minimum construction specifications for houses accommodating one to four families are contained in a new manual being distributed by the Century Federal Savings Association to its 50,000 customers and others planning to build homes in or near New York City.

MOSCOW, April 12 -- You don't need a market research analyst or a public opinion specialist to find out what books have hit the best seller list in Moscow this spring. All you need is a list of the latest winners of Stalin Prizes.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -- Objections by two members yesterday blocked action by the House on a bill to prevent railroads in reorganization from avoiding state controls. The Associated Press erroneously reported passage of the bill.

Philip Sporn, president of the American Gas and Electric Company, told stockholders at the annual meeting here yesterday that the company's earnings in 1949 would exceed those of last year, despite the fact that the "business cycle has turned downward."

GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 17 -- The Canons of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island were amended here today to provide severe penalties in disputes involving the refusal of either a rector or vestry to obey decisions of their Bishop relative to the dissolution of pastoral relationships.
Joe DiMaggio, the New York Yankees' $90,000 bench warmer, will don a uniform for the first time this season "some time next week," the club announced last night.

MOSCOW, May 17 -- The excellently printed Journal Mode, issued by the Ministry of Light Industry, introduces new Soviet fashions for the spring and summer of 1949 with a forty-six-page edition filled with photographs of new styles, many of them in two and four colors.
WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -- The Senate Labor Committee approved legislation today to outlaw so-called "overtime on overtime" pay claims in industry generally, on a retroactive basis.

The Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America expressed approval yesterday of the closed or union shop if arrived at by collective bargaining, but only if the agreements assured the democratic character of the union and the rights of the individual member.

A letter by Robert A. Willett in THE TIMES of May 10 stresses the principle that members of Congress are accountable to the nation according to the measure of their devotion to leadership by the President.

The great cloud of billowing gray smoke, the series of explosions, the burning mass of trucks and trailers, the chunks of concrete strewn along the roadway -- all in the blackness of the Holland Tunnel at the point where the tube plunges under the waters of the Hudson River -- could have been evidence of a major catastrophe.

CHICAGO, May 17 -- That three-game losing streak the Dodgers had built in Boston was shattered at Wrigley Field today by a six-run explosion of Brooklyn bats in the eleventh inning for an 8-5 triumph over the Cubs.
Fordham shelled a trio of Hofstra hurlers for twelve hits and as many runs for a 12-1 Metropolitan Conference triumph at Fordham Field yesterday.

FRIDAY night was the birthday party and Saturday was the day when the modern houses in our town were open to public inspection for the benefit of the public library. Both circumstances were distracting. At the party a courtly gentleman presented my wife with an entirely unexpected bottle of Mary Chess' Tuberose and the cook presented her with an entirely unexpected cake most splendidly decorated with leaves and flowers and a discreet handful of candles.

Liquor retailers here have "practically stopped buying supplies," according to reports received yesterday from wholesalers in this area. Despite the fact that liquor purchases have been on a fairly consistent "hand-to-mouth" basis during the past several months and warmer weather is always expected to depress sales, they are far below "normal," suppliers say.

ROME, May 17 -- Battles between hundreds of Communist and non-Communist workers in the Emilia region ended this evening with one dead and thirty wounded near the village of Molinella. Police were attacked with firearms by Communist workers but rapidly reestablished order.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The Senate changed its mind today about ordering a reduction of 5 per cent or more in the operating costs of the Department of Labor and the Federal Security Agency. The saving, voted on April 28, would have been an estimated minimum of $15,000,000.
ALBANY, May 17 -- The Public Service Commission said today that the "on-time" performance of New York Central trains in this state had improved greatly since 1947.

The First Boston Corporation and Harris, Hall Co., Inc., head a nationwide investment banking syndicate that will offer today $25,800,000 of common stock of the Southern California Edison Company. This is one of the largest new-money offerings by a utility in recent years.

MADRID, May 17 (UP) -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco plans to make a speech of about ninety minutes tomorrow at a new session of Parliament deploring the refusal of the United Nations to end its boycott of his regime, well-informed sources said tonight.

NEW DELHI, India, May 17 -- The Indian Constituent Assembly approved today India's decision to continue as a full member of the British Commonwealth of Nations when she becomes a republic. Ratification of the decision of the recent Prime Ministers' conference in London came after two days of heated debate during which several non-Congress party and independent members bitterly opposed India's remaining within the Commonwealth.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Representatives of two railroad brotherhoods admitted today that their unions had accepted only whites as members for more than half a century but insisted that the unions had taken no stand for or against fair employment practice legislation.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, May 17 -- Palestine Arab representatives, supported by the Arab states, have proposed a mixed commission to establish the status of Arab properties and communities in Palestine, it was learned here today.
George D. Widener, president of Belmont Park, said yesterday that he was opposed to night horse racing and that no stakes race was worth more than $50,000.

Action just taken by Egypt with respect to import licenses will tend materially to narrow the scope of "cheap" sterling in three-cornered re-export transactions involving transshipment of merchandise in foreign trade, according to interpretations here yesterday.

The Roman Catholic Church of St. Joseph, 421 East Eighty-sixth Street, in the Yorkville section of the upper East Side, has purchased the adjoining nine-family building at 419 East Eighty-sixth Street from Beatrice Albert for altering into a convent, it was announced yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 17 -- Contrary to charges made recently by a group of United Nations economic experts, the International Monetary Fund is now receiving the wholehearted cooperation of its member governments in its drive to prevent competitive import restrictions and currency devaluations in the event of a major recession, Gordon P. Williams of the fund, told the United Nations today.
WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -- Independent retailers' sales in April registered a 5 per cent gain over March and 1 per cent over April, 1948, the Commerce Department reported today.
Mayor O'Dwyer, a former policeman, declared last night that the Police Department should be an autonomous agency independent of City Hall and all outside agencies.

The relinquishing of Pier C. Jersey City, by American Export Lines after using it for five years, has increased rather than lessened the steamship company's efficiency of cargo-handling operations, officials asserted yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Further argument by scientists was brought before the joint Atomic Energy Committee of Congress today against the proposal to subject to loyalty checks all applicants for Federal fellowships under the Atomic Energy Act. Witnesses repeatedly referred to such requirements as "political means tests."

The causes of defective vision among school children will be studied by a special school survey committee of the New York State Optometric Association, it was announced yesterday at the closing session of the fifty-fourth annual meeting of the association at the New Yorker Hotel.

The four-story eight-family apartment building at 156 Garfield Place, Brooklyn, was sold by John Nelson and Anna Fryland purchased to Nancy Schroeder in a deal arranged by L. L. Yearsley, broker. The Title Guarantee and Trust Company insured title to the property, which is 27 by 100 feet.

The International Society for Contemporary Music gave its third concert of the season last night at the Museum of Modern Art. It had the homogeneity of style and idiom which usually marks these performances, as well as an unusual number of score-followers who rustled their pages in unison.

Apathy among voters in the United States must be fought and beaten, Ed P. Phillips, past president of the Richmond (Va.) Citizens Association, asserted yesterday at a luncheon-meeting of the Fourth National Conference on Citizenship at the Commodore Hotel.

The Academy Award for Distinguished Service in Public Education was given to Dr. Stephen F. Bayne, deputy superintendent of schools, at the thirty-eighth annual meeting of the New York Academy of Public Education, at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night.

Francis Hackett, distinguished author, believes that the successful Maxwell Anderson play, "Anne of the Thousand Days," which deals with Henry VIII and his ill-fated second wife, Anne Boleyn, has been plagiarized from two books he wrote on the historical characters, "Henry the Eighth -- A Personal History" and "Queen Anne Boleyn," plus his own dramatization of the latter, it became known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- General Lucius Dubignon Clay gave Washington a demonstration today of when and how to retire. His timing was perfect. His manner was grave and modest. His break was clean. And Washington responded warmly to this unusual combination.

BURBANK, Calif., May 17 -- Testing of the XF-90, the heavy new penetration fighter powered by two turbo-jet engines, was announced today by the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, manufacturer of the Air Force's latest attack plane.

Numerous small bowls, just large enough to serve as individual ashtrays and decorative enough to enliven a table top are among the ceramics by Jarl Hesselbarth which Bonniers, 605 Madison Avenue, brought out yesterday. Mr. Hesselbarth, a 27-year-old Norwegian artist who has been elected a life member of the National Sculptors Academy of Norway, settled in New York about a year ago.

DETROIT, May 17 -- A company offer to quarantine the focal points of the Ford strike to permit a resumption of work by about 95 per cent of the 102,000 who are idle met a prompt rejection today by the United Automobile Workers, CIO.
Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. turned on the charm last night to evoke frenzied ovations from supporters as he acknowledged gratitude to them in a tour of the district that had elected him to Congress.

A consent agreement to a judgment dissolving a Queens cemetery corporation that State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein had accused of being "a pseudo real estate firm retailing graves at excessive prices" was filed yesterday in Supreme Court.
Lamb sold on the New York wholesale markets yesterday from 58 to 66 cents a pound, the highest prices of the common types of dressed meats.

Ranch mink of the Great Lakes Mink Association advanced 15 per cent over April, returning prices to the February level, at the sale held yesterday by the New York Auction Company. Ninety-nine per cent of the 45,000 skins were sold. Top was $42 for males in standard pelts of the Kobuck type.

CAIRO, May 17 -- Twenty thousand Arabs took part in a demonstration today on the streets of Tripoli against the plan to transfer Tripolitania to an Italian trusteeship in 1951. According to a correspondent of Al Ahram, Cairo's leading newspaper, the crowd, carrying pictures of Premier Stalin, demonstrated for the Soveit Union and against the British, Americans and Italians.
The Health Department's new plan to fill the vacancies for public health nurses on the city payroll was endorsed yesterday by leaders in the fields of medicine, nursing and public health.

The victory of Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. yesterday in his race for Congress was hailed by his supporters as dooming the present leadership of Tammany Hall, while Hugo E. Rogers, leader of Tammany, who had opposed the Roosevelt candidacy, warned against the threat of minority parties to the two-party system.

A news dispatch the other day brought home with startling vividness the often forgotten fact that, despite the myriad ships plowing the waters of our planet, despite the myriad railroads and motors gridironing its terra firma and the myriad planes crisscrossing its skies, there are still big patches of unexplored territory scattered over it, where mystery is still bred and romance still beckons.
WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -- The House passed by voice vote today a bill to stop an estimated $40,000,000 a year avoidance of state cigarette taxes through mail-order shipments from tax-free states.
MUNICH, Germany, May 17 (AP) -- A German woman went on trial today on a charge of having stolen official United States documents for the use of foreign agents.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 17 (AP) -- Merrill Buffington, secretary of the Greyhound corporation, told stockholders today a new supplemen tal pension plan was scheduled to take effect on July 1. The plan, under which employes may pay an additional 1 per cent to be matched by the company, must be approved by all Greyhound operating companies and unions representing workers.

Renewed rumors of devaluation of the pound sterling affected trading in the local market here again yesterday and far forward sterling suffered its worst break in years, going through the spreads of February, 1948. Six months' contracts closed at $3.87 1/2, about 5 cents below that of the preceding week, with ninety days' at $3.93 1/2, a decline of about 3 cents. Spot sterling touched $4.02 13/16, lowest in a month.
JERSEY CITY, N. J., May 17 -- Ten thousand persons filled the City Hall and overflowed into the streets today in a joyous, noisy welcome to the first unbossed city administration since 1917.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The Atomic Energy Commission confirmed tonight that a small quantity of uranium metal, containing about 1.05 ounces of U-235, used in the production of Atomic bombs, was lost in February at the Argonne National Laboratory near Chicago.

The special Federal grand jury investigating espionage questioned Senator Karl E. Mundt, Republican, of South Dakota, and Paul Crouch, former Communist organizer in North Carolina, for several hours yesterday, but according to the foreman, John Gilland Brunini, obtained no new leads from them.

The suggestion that the Long Island Rail Road be freed of tax burdens while it is getting on its feet financially is both bold and naive. David E. Smucker, trustee of the bankrupt carrier and its chief operating officer, must have been speaking with his tongue in cheek, we assume.

The discharge of 2,000 cases of whisky from the holds of the United States Lines freighter American Reporter yesterday marked the first use of a new method of handling that type of cargo, and created considerable interest among liquor importers.
ST. LOUIS, May 17 -- Old-fashioned notions about bringing up children are still held by too many men, the National Congress of Parents and Teachers was told today.
CHICAGO, May 17 (AP) -- Sears, Roebuck Co. announced today it is mailing its biggest midsummer catalog in history to its mail order customers.

ATLANTIC, CITY, May 17 -- More than 2,000 delegates to the fifty-third annual credit congress of the National Association of Credit Men today took part in thirty different industry group meetings for a thorough discussion of their own conditions amid a general feeling that while our economy was adjusting, business prospects were still favorable.

The Port of New York Authority announced yesterday that it will place on the market $54,000,000 of two series of general and refunding serial bonds on June 1. Proceeds from the issue will be invested in short-term Government obligations, and will be applied, together with other funds, to the refunding of the 3 per cent general and refunding bonds due 1976 which are callable beginning Dec. 15, 1950, at 102 per cent.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -- The Chicago Board of Trade said today that railroad freight rates on grain and grain products should be lowered rather than raised. Its position was outlined to the Interstate Commerce Commission by I. M. Herndon, who said he was authorized to speak also for the Boards of Trade in Indianapolis, Louisville and Cincinnati.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -- A New York insurance man told Senate investigators today that his concern paid $93,000 to a freight forwarder as discounts and commissions on marine insurance placed on goods bought by Poland with a United States loan.

In a major revision of policy, the new management of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation decided yesterday to increase production and to diminish development projects at the company's engine division, the Wright Aeronautical Corporation.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, May 17 -- An International Labor Office commission, inquiring into allegations of breaches of international regulations by ships of Panama registry at the request of the Panama Government, went to Antwerp today to interview the crews of the Panama ships Derna and Marilyn.

Supreme Court Justice Charles S. Colden, president of the Queens College Association, chided the Board of Higher Education yesterday for the speed with which it named Dr. John J. Theobald as president of the college.
WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee neared today the end of hearings on the North Atlantic treaty with its early approval clearly foreshadowed.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., May 17 -- The second annual Montclair Antiques Show opened this afternoon at the Montclair Athletic Club with fifty-five dealers from eleven states represented. The majority of the exhibitors feature furnishings suitable for today's suburban homes at prices not too high as antique prices go.

VIRGINIA BEACH, May 17 -- The retail practice of "lumping" all products into the same category and insisting upon price merchandise without regard to current costs of production was decried here today by Irving R. Glass, executive vice president of the Tanners' Council of America, Inc.

An increasing number of violations of the silk and rayon labeling regulations as set down by the Federal Trade Commission have been observed in the textile trades, it was learned yesterday. Fabrics containing only a small percentage of nylon yarn are being sold as all-nylon cloth, according to trade sources, and other abuses of proper labeling have been noted in silk, and designations of crepe and alpaca weaves.

NEWARK, N. J., May 17 -- Officials of the National State Bank and the Merchants and Newark Trust Company announced that stockholders of their respective institutions had been advised by letter today that a consolidation would be voted upon at special meetings of the stockholders June 15.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay, retiring United States Military Governor in Germany, returned to this country today, a military leader who became a hero in time of peace. From the moment that the Air Force transport touched down at the military air transport field at 10:14 A. M., General Clay, a tired man whose face and manner bore the marks of his grueling occupation tasks, received the welcome of his life.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., May 17 -- A proposal to intensify the eleven- year campaign by the League of Women Voters of New York State for a state-wide system of permanent personal registration of voters by considering it for the current agenda was accepted today at the opening of the group's twenty- third convention here.

The sale of the Young Women's Christian Association property at 48 Church Street, White Plains, N. Y., was reported by Edward M. West, Inc., broker. The buyer is a client of Filardi Caruso, attorneys. The property consists of administration and residence buildings and was sold for a reported price of $45,000.

NORTH BERGEN, N. J., May 17 -- Mayor Paul F. Cullum, Democratic leader and chief executive of this township since 1934, was defeated tonight for re-election in a recall instituted by him to get rid of three commissioners who had broken with his administration. However, the community's mandate was not a clear one.

PARIS, May 17 -- A positive and concerted policy of the three Western powers regarding the future of Germany is expected to emerge from the talks here this week of their experts and from the culminating meeting Saturday of their Foreign Ministers preparatory to the Big Four conference opening Monday.

Four hundred volunteer workers who have contributed more than 150 hours of service to voluntary, non-profit hospitals in Manhattan, the Bronx and Richmond were honored yesterday at the ninth annual United Hospital Fund awards meeting in the Pierre Hotel.

Still trying to "find itself," following the Treasury's week-end announcement of a new 1 1/4 per cent certificate offering in exchange for its bonds and other obligations due next month, the government bond market acted sluggishly yesterday.
FORT WORTH, Tex., May 17 (AP) -- The flood from a twelve-inch cloudburst took the lives of six persons here and left 13,200 others homeless as the waters receded tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- In the face of unremitting resistance in Congress, President Truman gave up his fight today to appoint his friend, Mon C. Wallgren, as chairman of the National Security Resources Board.
SHANGHAI, May 17 -- Communist armies today drove ahead in their drive to encircle Shanghai and pinch off its outlet to the sea by squeezing from both sides of the Whangpoo River.

The long debate over Spain in the General Assembly of the United Nations has ended in a somewhat inconclusive result. A majority of the states voting on the question approved a resolution that would have sanctioned the return of Ambassadors and Ministers to Madrid while the Franco regime is still in power.

CHICAGO, May 17 -- Showers ranging from a trace to three-quarter inch of rain which covered the greater part of the North American spring wheat area were largely responsible for a lower range of prices on the Board of Trade here today. Showers fell also in many parts of the Corn Belt, and there were unwanted rains in the Southwest which are expected to delay the start of harvesting in Texas.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Stockholders of the Pere Marquette Railway who dissented from the 1947 proposal for the merger of that carrier with the Chesapeake and Ohio and went to court to obtain a cash settlement under Michigan statutes will be required to accept the same stock settlement as other stockholders under an opinion handed down today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.
Communist leaders formulated plans at secret party meetings to control labor unions for revolutionary purposes, according to yesterday's testimony at the Communist trial.

LONDON, May 17 -- The United States and British Governments have agreed to coordinate their policies toward eventual recognition of the Chinese Communist regime, it is reported here on good authority. There is no plan at present to withdraw recognition from the Nationalist Government, but with the Communist forces in China virtually driving everything before them, the feeling is growing that an effective end of the Nationalist administration is but a matter of time.

Your editorial "An Unhappy School Board," in THE TIMES of May 12, touched on a subject with which the parents of New York City's school children have been concerned for many years -- namely, the method of selecting members of the Board of Education.

NORTH CALDWELL, N. J., May 17 -- Two New Jersey players, Victor Segond of Rockaway River and Harmon Hagenbuckle of Springdale, led a field of fifty-nine in the Metropolitan Golf Association's first one-day tournament of the season today.

Independent voters on Manhattan's West Side yesterday swept Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., third son of the war-time President, into Congress as the successor to the late Sol Bloom as Representative of the Twentieth District.
RENO, Nev., May 17 (AP) -- The Kaiser-Frazer Corporation lost $5,805,298 during the first quarter of 1949, the company reported at its annual stockholders meeting here today.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 17 -- A war on poison ivy along the highways and lanes of Westchester was planned today by the County Recreation Commission.

PARIS, May 17 -- Plans for raising an additional 83,000,000,000 francs to cover the French budgetary deficit were submitted to the Cabinet Council today and will come up before a full-dress Ministers Council tomorrow.

Social scientists throughout the world were called upon last night by Dr. Brock Chisholm, director general of the World Health Organization, to abandon "leisurely learning" and to work to save humanity from "its present state of suicidal insanity."

When Saks Thirty-fourth and McKettrick get together it means attractive and wearable dresses at a reasonable price. A showing entirely of McKettrick Classics took place on the fourth floor of the store yesterday afternoon.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 17 -- The Yugoslav Communist party said today that its demand for equality between smaller Communist states and the Soviet Union was gaining ground in the lower ranks in Communist parties in Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Rumania.

The intention of the Cuban delegation at the conferences at Annecy, France, of the parties to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT), to press for restrictions on textile imports into Cuba, chiefly from the United States, will be opposed by the Textile Export Association of the United States, it was announced yesterday.

" Guaglio," an Italian-made drama dealing with juvenile delinquents, which arrives at the Avenue Playhouse, is this morning's lone film newcomer. Adolfo Celi is starred in the offering, which was directed by Luigi Commencini, who co-authored the script with Suso Cecchi D'Amico.

PITTSBURGH, May 17 -- In a move that caught both steel and coal industry leaders by surprise, John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, made a bid today for separate contract negotiations with the H. C. Frick Coke Company, operator of the "captive" mines of the United States Steel Corporation.

Ninety veteran amputees employed by the Veterans Administration are scheduled to participate tonight in a caravan to Washington to press for legislation that would give a super-preference to amputees and blind veterans in the retention of civil service jobs.
A middle course in the selection of a system of providing medical care for the nation was advocated yesterday by Dr. Henry N. Pratt, director of New York Hospital.

Ninety veteran amputees employed by the Veterans Administration are scheduled to participate tonight in a caravan to Washington to press for legislation that would give a super-preference to amputees and blind veterans in the retention of civil service jobs.
A middle course in the selection of a system of providing medical care for the nation was advocated yesterday by Dr. Henry N. Pratt, director of New York Hospital.
BUENOS AIRES, May 17 -- Ambassador James Bruce arrived here tonight from the United States with prospects for better trade relations with Argentina greatly improved.

During the World Peace Congress in Paris Konni Zilliacus and I learned that the State Department had refused us the right to accompany Henry Wallace on his cross-country tour. Our first reaction was a feeling of betrayal.
For "saving the dignity and the structure of the United Nations" by his success in restoring peace to Palestine, Dr. Ralph J. Bunche received the thanks of Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday at City Hall.

The graduation exercises in the James Memorial Chapel last night, at which 116 students received degress, ended the 113th anniversary program of the Union Theological Seminary, Broadway at 120th Street.

A plan to make public higher education available "within commuting distance" to qualified youths, regardless of race, religion or economic factors, is being outlined by the State University, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -- Following are the texts of General Clay's talks before the House of Representatives and the Senate and the citation by President Truman:

LONDON, May 17 -- At several meetings in London tonight, supporters of the recent left-wing "peace conference" in Paris demanded the release of Gerhart Eisler, Communist fugitive from the United States now held in Brixton prison.

PHILADELPHIA, May 18 -- Business must assume the responsibility of creating and maintaining more jobs because high employment is essential to a healthy, robust economy in this country, Harry A. Bullis, chairman of the board of General Mills, Inc., declared here tonight.

PITTSBURGH, May 18 -- Big Jawn Mize exploded two home runs this warm, sunny afternoon to establish himself as the outstanding circuit clouter among the players active in baseball, but those shots failed to win for the Giants even with Larry Jansen on the mound.

American railroads would retain their competitive standing in relation to truck rivalry if the Interstate Commerce Commission were to approve the pending application for an increase in railroad freight rates, William T. Faricy, president of the Association of American Railroads, said yesterday.

A marked difference of opinion has developed between the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and several commercial banks here over the acceptability of the so-called "model statute" which would authorize deferred posting of checks, it was learned yesterday.
LONDON, May 18 -- Apart from the interest shown in individual issues, there was no appreciable increase in business on the opening of the twenty-one-day account in the stock market here today.
WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Louis Johnson, Secretary of Defense, asked Congress today for authority to spend $623,125,682 on critical housing and public works needs of the three armed services.

"Heliport No. 1," New York's first commercial helicopter base, began operations yesterday with a series of flights made by an "infuriated palm tree," from Pier 41 on the East River, at Gouverneur Street.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The Senate minority conference, made up of all Republican Senators, showed a general determination today to keep trying to cut at least 5 per cent from every departmental and agency appropriation recommendation that reaches the floor at this session.

The stock market moved narrowly yesterday, but there were periods of alternating strength and weakness and the close was slightly lower than on Tuesday. Corporate developments accounted for major price changes in individual issues, with losses most in evidence.

CHICAGO, May 18 -- Bursting out in a rash of base hits, including Duke Snider's sixth and Roy Campanella's seventh home runs, the Dodgers today hammered the Cubs into the rain-soaked turf of Wrigley Field beneath a 14-5 score.

The end of the major league career of Charley Keller was indicated yesterday when the Yankees, in the process of reducing their roster to twenty-five players, announced that the ailing outfielder had been released on option to Newark of the International League.

Coffee futures moved higher in active trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Strong demand by local trade interests, coupled with short-covering, aided the advance. Final prices in contract "D" were 15 to 22 points above the previous levels.

J. Sigfrid Edstrom, president of the International Olympic Committee, here mostly on non-Olympic business, said among other things yesterday that the 1956 Games in Melbourne, Australia, would be held in October.

CHICAGO, May 18 -- May wheat fluctuated in an extremely nervous manner within a range of 3 1/4 cents a bushel on the Board of Trade today, breaking 3 1/2 cents early on scattered liquidation and closing of spreads with July, and then rallying rapidly on short covering to close with net losses of 1/4 to 1/2 cent.

ST. LOUIS, May 18 (AP) -- A double by Granville Hamner and a single by Eddie Waitkus off relief pitcher Ted Wilks broke a 2-2 tie in the eighth and gave the Phils a 3-2 triumph over the Cardinals today.

The City Planning Commission adopted yesterday a master plan for the development of a Manhattan Civic Center in the areas adjacent to Foley Square and City Hall. As adopted the plan varied only slightly from the proposal put forward by the commission nearly a year ago.

Every two and one-half hours, on the average, some one is accidentally killed in New York City. More than half of these deaths are in the home. The causes range from falls and burns to suffocation, poisoning and careless use of firearms.

Al Weill of New York, manager, matchmaker and promoter in boxing for the last thirty-five years, yesterday was named matchmaker for the new organization that Madison Square Garden is setting up. He succeeds Nat Rogers, who worked for Mike Jacobs in the Garden and elsewhere for the past sixteen years.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 18 (AP) -- The San Francisco Superior Court yesterday gave to Insurance Commissioner Wallace K. Downey possession of the California business and affairs of the Rhode Island Insurance Company and the Pioneer-Equitable Insurance Company of Indiana.

I read with interest the letter of my colleague, Prof. Clyde Eagleton, on "Hyderabad as a U. N. Issue," published in your issue of May 15. As Professor Eagleton's letter is an attack on India, I feel compelled to take issue with him.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., May 18 -- Hudson River captured the first cup series championship as play was completed in the Westchester division of the annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association interclub team matches today. Competing against Westchester Country Club players at Sunningdale, the Yonkers club won by 13 1/2 to 1 1/2 to finish in front with 50 1/2 points.

Flora Esmond, one-time vaudeville star, died Oct. 2 last year in a squalid flat. The immediate cause of her death at age 76 or more was malnutrition, and her estate appeared to consist of a lot in Queens worth $400 and a hopeless collection of junk in her quarters at 360 West Fifty-third Street.

Vibrant colors were the choice of Russeks yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel for its showing of summer fashions in which it turned first to a lively carrot tone, then to sunny tints of yellow. A third pleasing choice was a soft pink, flattering to blonde, brunette and redhead.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The United States and the International Refugee Organization are doing what they can in behalf of recent political refugees from Eastern European countries, Secretary of State Dean Acheson declared today.

The two top officials of the United Nations told the last meeting of the third General Assembly yesterday that the world organization had proved its value by easing the East-West crisis and holding out strong hope for a peaceful world.

Voluntary participation in the reserve movement for the armed services is the first step that must be taken to perfect our mobilization preparations, Maj. Gen. Charles W. Ryder, an assistant to the Secretary of the Army, said last night at the "muster" of New York's own reserve unit, the Seventy-seventh Infantry Division.

Ferd, owned by Mrs. Andy Schuttinger and trained by her husband, made his stakes record two for two at Belmont Park yesterday when he won the seventy-third running of the Juvenile for 2-year-olds. As in the Youthful Stakes at Jamaica early in the month, Ferd was the first and E. P. Taylor's $36,000 Navy Chief was the runner-up in a photo finish.

FRANKFORT, Germany, May 18 -- Charles H. Collison, deputy chief of the United States Military Government decartelization branch, has been notified of his dismissal, the head of the branch confirmed today.
Edith Hatch, for seventeen years stylist for Nashua Mills, has joined Spring Mills, Inc., as fashion and style consultant.

Goodman Ace's radio series, "mr. ace and JANE," is being dropped by CBS next week, but it won't be long before he's back on the network with a television show. Starting in August, Mr. Ace will write a five-minute television show featuring Ruth Gilbert, to be known as "Ruthie on the Telephone."

ROME, May 18 -- About 500,000 farmhands in the Po Valley and in the Province of Rome struck today after the Confederation of Landowners had rejected their demands, including a national contract setting minimum wages.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson declared today against any Pacific defense pact along the lines of the North Atlantic treaty, at least for the present, even though "there are serious dangers to world peace existing in the situation in Asia."

Edmund Hunt, who once walked out of the Criminal Courts Building while being held for trial, proved too fleet for his own good when he attempted to run out of a Rockefeller Center bank after failing to cash an allegedly forged check, it was revealed yesterday in Felony Court.

Ewan Clague Commissioner of Labor Statistics for the United States Department of Labor, warned social welfare agencies yesterday that increasing unemployment would impose a greater call upon their facilities in the coming year.
LONDON, Thursday, May 19 -- After a long fight to get the movie "The Snake Pit" through British censorship, this "brilliant and horrible film," as The Evening Standard calls it, will open here today.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) -- The Interstate Oil Compact Commission today urged legislation to bar the Federal Power Commission from taking jurisdiction over the production and gathering of natural gas by independent operators.
VENICE, May 18 (AP) -- The first luxury passenger ship to come from Italian ways since the war will ply the waters of the eastern Mediterranean.

ST. LOUIS, May 18 -- Some writers of comic strips are much more sensitive to the "struggles" of children than many parents are, Dr. Ralph H. Ojemann, Associate Professor of Psychology and Education at the University of Iowa, asserted today.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Pomp and ceremony were mingled with a typical American birthday celebration as Gen. Eurico Gaspar Dutra, Presi dent of Brazil, was welcomed today by President Truman for a ten-day state visit. The bonds of friendship with this country's foremost Latin-American ally in the war were renewed in the most cordial fashion.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., May 18 -- Doorbell ringing, pamphleteering, speechmaking and personal interviews with political leaders and legislators by members of sixty units of the League of Women Voters of New York State paid off in increased state funds for schools and a record turnout at the polls on election day, committee chairmen claimed in reports at the second session of the league's convention, which ends three days of meetings here tomorrow.

The May issue of The American Federationist, monthly organ of the American Federation of Labor, carries an article by Mr. George Meany titled "Why Labor Hates Injunctions." This is of more than ordinary interest in view of the controversy that has recently surrounded the question whether new labor legislation should or should not retain the injunction provision of the Taft-Hartley Act for use in national emergency strikes.

The short interest in listed stocks on the New York Stock Exchange as of the close of business on Friday aggregated 1,628,551 shares, the largest total in sixteen years, it was announced yesterday. On April 14 the short positions amounted to 1,498,493 shares.

Mary Uglianitza, 22-year-old New Jersey factory worker who exchanged jobs and living conditions for a month with a British girl, returned home yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary, overwhelmed by British hospitality but happy to see the Statue of Liberty again.

CAIRO, May 18 -- Voting down the Bevin-Sforza agreement for an Italian trusteeship of Tripolitania in 1951 has had the effect here of somewhat restoring confidence in the United Nations and the Western world. Arab spokesmen, Government officials, journalists and the political community fairly beamed today.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Anthon H. Lund, associate director of the division of trading and exchanges of the Securities and Exchange Commission, was named director of the division today. He succeeds the late Edward H. Cashion.

A 220-pound housemaid, who was referred to by the police as "Madame Queen' because of her "arrogant, queenly grand manner," was held without bail in the Women's House of Detention after she asked for an adjournment in Felony Court so she could engage an attorney.

Trials with a new blood test for cancer on more than 4,000 individuals have shown that it is accurate in 95.4 per cent of the cases, it was reported yesterday at a seminar at the New York Medical College Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals.

Possibly it is unwise for any layman to even question the sacred science of medical men: at least on the subject of alcoholism. Such, for example, as the pronouncements of Dr. Williams of the University of Texas and his confreres as set forth in Science in Review in THE TIMES of May 1.

The 101st annual meeting of the New York East Methodist Conference opened yesterday morning at a holy communion and memorial service at Hanson Place Central Methodist Church at St. Felix Street, Brooklyn. The service was conducted by Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam of the New York Methodist area. Enrolled as delegates were 400 laymen and clergymen.
Eleven years ago today Maria Kramer startled Broadway and began her successful New York realty career with a $7,000,000 cash purchase of the Hotel Lincoln.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The "bold new" program of technical cooperation for underdeveloped areas of the world projected by President Truman under Point Four of his inaugural address will be "modest" in cost, with Europe receiving less assistance than other regions in view of the contribution of the Marshall Plan, Secretary of State Dean Acheson said today.
Poland tried unsuccessfully yesterday to force debate on the Gerhart Eisler case in the United Nations General Assembly.
The report of the Great Northern Paper Company and its wholly owned subsidiaries disclosed yesterday a net profit of $1,352,347 for the quarter ended on March 31.

Price competition in cigarettes at the retail level is increasing here, with leading tobacco and drug chains bringing standard brands down one cent to 20 cents a package or 2 for 39 cents. Still lower levels prevailed in a midtown department store which sold two packages for 35 cents.
The Association of Official Racing Chemists advised the National Association of State Racing Commissioners yesterday that it was opposed to pre-race tests of horses.

SHANGHAI, May 18 -- Communists, fighting to close in from both sides on the mouth of the Whangpoo, this city's last link with the outside world except by air, swept today to the east bank of that narrow river about three miles below Shanghai.

DETROIT, May 18 -- On two occasions during the life of the present contract the United Automobile Workers, CIO, agreed to arbitration of speed-up charges against the Ford Motor Company that involved the same grievances as those that provoked the current strike, it was learned today.

Beginning of a campaign to send 100,000 food packages of the Cooperative for American Remittances to Europe (CARE) to refugees from the Soviet Union and the Soviet satellites was announced yesterday by Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd, U.S.N. (ret.), chairman of the campaign.
BOSTON, May 18 -- The United States Army transport General Howze today landed 944 displaced persons from Bremerhaven, Germany, including a Habsburg princess and her two daughters.
WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The national and Congressional leadership of the Democratic party lost no time today in rolling out the welcome mat for Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr.

Expansion of group-buying activities on several types of footwear is planned by Shoes Associated, Inc., the first and still the only association of its kind in the shoe field, it was reported here yesterday by Miss Marion Palmer, executive vice president.

Providence, R. I., sold bond issues yesterday totaling $3,229,000 to a banking syndicate headed by Drexel Co. at a bid of 101.0599 for interest of 2.40 per cent, an interest cost of 2.33 per cent. The bonds, which will mature from 1951 to 1974, were reoffered at prices to yield 1 per cent to 2.40 per cent.

Persistent Broadway reports were confirmed yesterday by George S. Kaufman, noted playwright-director, that he would marry Leueen MacGrath, a pretty Irish actress, who scored a personal success in the recent production of "Edward, My Son," which marked her debut in this country.

The unexpectedly large margin by which Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. won the Congressional election in the Twentieth District, on Manhattan's West Side, is, first of all, a personal triumph for a young man with marked gifts for a political career. The legacy of his father's name and features was a basic asset to start him on his way, and it should not be underestimated.

Gen. Stasys Rastikis, commander in chief of the Lithuanian Army from 1934 to 1939, was among 884 displaced persons who arrived here yesterday aboard the Army transport Marine Marlin. The vessel docked at Pier 61, North River, at 8:40 A. M.

Underwriting syndicates will put on the market today blocks of public utility, railroad and industrial securities valued at more than $31,000,000. All except $8,000,000 par value of preferred stock of the United Biscuit Company were bought by the bankers at competitive sale.

One by one like stars before sunrise the violets are disappearing, now that May is running its bright course. Poor is the gardener who has not, off somewhere in a corner, a patch of these cheerful flowers.
WEST POINT, May 18 -- An eight-run rally in the second inning enabled Colgate to score a decisive 12-to-2 victory over Army at Doubleday Field today

Carpet dealers will continue to receive adequate supplies of most merchandise for at least sixty days after May 31 if a threatened industry-wide strike halts all production on that date, an industry leader declared yesterday. He said warehouse and dealer inventories of mills which distribute directly will take care of retail demand for all but wide-loom merchandise for at least eight weeks.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed irregular yesterday, 4 points lower to 11 points higher.

The Choristers of the City's Department of Welfare, with Florence Mardirosian conducting, gave its annual concert last night at Town Hall. Anahid Ajemian, violinist, and Maro Ajemian, pianist, were the guest artists. The entire proceeds of the event will be used to provide musical recreation for disabled veterans in hospitals in the metropolitan area.

Because there were 141,426 unlawful pupil absences from New York public schools from Jan. 1, 1948, to March 31, 1949, this city lost $350,000 in state funds, Justice James V. Mulholland of the Domestic Relations Court reported yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 18 -- Warning that fundamental and radical changes are being advocated in our method of government, Russell J. Hopkins of Titusville, Pa., president of the Pennsylvania Bankers Association, said today that "we have a self-propagating bureaucracy which must be checked."
A psychiatrist reported yesterday that so-called hopeless schizophrenics had been rehabilitated by vigorous group exercises.

One large distilling company here is sending all its retail customers in this area new selling contracts drawn under the provisions of the Feld-Crawford Act, it was learned here yesterday. This is the law authorizing producers to set a universal minimum price on their products and enforce its use through civil court action.
City College undergraduates, alumni and faculty members, to the number of 400, did honor last night to Henry Wittenberg, Olympic light-heavyweight wrestling champion.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (UP) -- Robert J. Wirth, an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, testified today at Judith Coplon's espionage trial that the United States had counter-spies planted among Russia's diplomatic representatives.

MOSCOW, May 18 -- The leading editorial in the Soviet foreign affairs journal New Times today strongly called for a return to the Potsdam and Yalta principles as a basis for a solution of the German problem. It asserted that only on "the firm soil of these principles" could the four powers achieve an agreement both in their interests and in the interests of the German people.

LONDON, May 18 -- In a private conference with leading British editors Sir Stafford Cripps, Britain's economic chief and Chancellor of the Exchequer, warned today that Britain might soon face a serious economic crisis unless the nation's production efficiency was increased and prices were cut.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) -- The House of Representatives gave unanimous approval today to continuation of the Federal crop insurance program. It passed by voice vote and sent to the Senate a bill expanding the present limited insurance program and providing for broader experiments with multiple-crop insurance.

THIELLS, N. Y., May 18 -- The elimination of unnecessary red tape in the state Department of Mental Hygiene, as well as in all other state departments, was urged today by Franklin B. Kirkbride, a civic leader who for many years has been active on behalf of the mentally ill in this state.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, said today that his department was studying a proposal by Representative Wilbur Mills, Democrat, of Arkansas, to expedite collection of corporation income taxes.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Not until the thirty-eight pages of Supreme Court opinions in the Terminiello case have been read and reread do limitations appear in a 5-to-4 decision that at first seemed so sweeping. The narrow majority of the Supreme Court did not actually set up the Constitution as a shield for inflammatory public oratory inciting to riot.

BOSTON, May 18 (AP) -- The Red Sox landed on Marino (Chick) Pieretti for three runs in the opening inning today and used their heavy bats in good style to defeat the White Sox, 7 -- 4, before 10,406 fans. It was Boston's second decision in two days over Chicago.
Some of Great Britain's outstanding soccer players arrived here yesterday aboard the Queen Mary of the Cunard White Star Line.

Samuel Seabury, leader of three successful city campaigns that resulted in the election of the late Fiorello H. La Guardia as Mayor, announced yesterday that a fusion movement would be started in an attempt to defeat Mayor O'Dwyer and the other Democratic members of the Board of Estimate and elect a fusion ticket.

Former Secretary of State George C. Marshall said last night that in all his years in high public office he had come to dread "the back-door influences of official Washington" more than anything else.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- President Truman formally designated John J. McCloy today as United States High Commissioner for Germany. At the same time, Mr. McCloy's resignation as president was accepted by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, which elected Eugene R. Black as his successor.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that the Public Service Company of New Hampshire, Manchester, N. H., had filed a registration statement covering $4,000,000 of first mortgage bonds, Series E, due 1979, that are to be sold at competitive bidding.

For the first time in its seventy-year history, Diamond Match Company will launch an extensive national advertising campaign in consumer publications and business papers, it was announced yesterday. The advertising will be placed by the Chicago offices of Diamond and McCann-Erickson, Inc., which has just acquired the account.

The resale by David S. Meister, operator, of the four-story apartment house with stores at 6006-12 Bergenline Avenue, West New York, N. J., was reported yesterday. There are four stores and twenty-four four-room suites in the building, which occupies a plot 62 by 95 feet and was sold subject to a mortgage of $74,000.
PARIS, May 18 -- Progress was made today, after sharp discussions, toward acceptance of the Government's plan for economic and financial reforms to keep the French budget within balance.

RUTLAND, Vt., May 18 (UP) -- Two young veterans, jailed for months like the paupers of medieval England, today faced possible life imprisonment unless they paid court judgments totaling less than $5,000.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson announced at his news conference today that he would reserve freedom of action at the conference of Big Four foreign ministers in Paris on German problems to make clear to the world at any time the policies and positions of the United States on pending issues.
American Communists are taught the need for violent revolution and also for denying this with a pretense of merely "predicting" violence, according to yesterday's evidence at the Communist trial.

The nation's industry is just as much subject to call in the event of war as any individual and "it must be prepared to meet that call," William J. Wade of the Willys-Overland Motors Company of Toledo, Ohio, told executives and reserve officers yesterday at 30 Rockefeller Plaza,

ATLANTIC CITY, May 18 -- While the purchasing power of farmers and factory workers has increased 75 per cent or better over the last ten years, there has been no substantial increase in the real earnings of common stockholders or other investor groups, the fifty-third annual credit congress was told today.
WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) -- A Congressional committee proposed today a "duel" high in the clouds to decide how tough the Air Force's B-36 bomber really is.
Three men distinguished for their work in combating race prejudice agreed last night that education, legislation, and prosperity were needed to eliminate ethnic hatreds and discrimination.

Denim in a feminine interpretation offers the most interesting feature of the Brigance summer fashions on exhibition at Lord Taylor's this week. Men who have worn this fabric for rough and ready work would be surprised to see it appearing in delicate colorings and beach and spectator togs.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Senator Brien McMahon, chairman of the Joint Atomic Energy Committee of Congress, announced tonight that the ounce of uranium oxide, containing enriched U-235, "lost" at the Argonne National Laboratory near Chicago several months ago was not stolen. He added that six-sevenths of it already had been recovered.

A study of a long-range program for American liberalism by Irwin Ross has been set for June 22 publication by Harper. "Strategy for Liberals" presents a case for "mixed economy" -- a blend of capitalist, cooperative and socialist economic elements -- and discusses the political strategy needed to bring it about.
WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The Foreign Relations Committee closed today three weeks and one day of hearings on the North Atlantic treaty and will soon recommend its ratification by the Senate.

Vitamins purchased at the drug store may supplement sensible eating habits, but never can substitute for them. In the current issue of its Nutrition Notes the Community Service Society points out that vitamins are only one essential of an adequate diet, the others being protein and minerals.

OMAHA, May 18 (AP) -- The First Bancredit Corporation of St. Paul, Minn., has filed a civil suit seeking to recover $593,556.84 from eight Nebraskans. The corporation contends it suffered the loss by investing in notes and mortgages, many of which "turned out to be fictitious and forged instruments."

Predicting renewed importance for the neighborhood-house concept of social work in cities, Edward Corsi, New York State Industrial Commissioner, told the forty-eighth annual meeting of the United Neighborhood Houses, Inc., yesterday that to train five able community leaders was better than to send 5,000 youths to camp for two weeks of play.

Shortly after CIO and British and Dutch labor leaders walked out of the World Federation of Trade Unions last January, on the ground that it was a Communist-controlled organ, plans began to take shape to establish a new international association of non-Communist unions.

The toiletries and cosmetics industry was urged yesterday to set up a joint promotional program as a means of increasing its share of the consumer dollar. The recommendation was made by Frazer V. Sinclair, president of the Pope Publishing Company.
GENEVA, May 18 -- France has proposed a new technique for increasing East - West trade under United Nations auspices.

CLEVELAND, May 18 -- The American Federation of Labor's Union Industries Show, which is being sponsored by the AFL's union label trades department to demonstrate skill of the organization's craftsmen and stress labor amity with employers, was formally opened today.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Walter Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, today called for a public housing program that would take up the present slack in employment and make house building "the greatest national industry."
