Moshe Sharett, Foreign Minister of Israel, expressed yesterday the "heartfelt gratitude" of his Government to Dr. Herbert V. Evatt, president of the General Assembly during its third regular session, for his part in furthering the admission of Israel into the United Nations.
Following is a summary of the major decisions taken by the United Nations General Assembly during the spring session at Flushing Meadow:

LONDON, May 18 -- So encouraging are voyage figures and prospects for 1949 that the Cunard Steamship Company has paid off its last outstanding bank loan of 600,000 ($2,400,000), Frederic A. Bates, chairman of the board, announced at the annual general meeting in Liverpool today.

Although the die-hards will refuse to give up their periodic efforts to find good dry fly fishing on the Catskill streams, this week-end will find a large crowd of anglers putting out from New Jersey and Long Island fishing ports in search of the big mackerel which seem to be unusually plentiful.

NORWALK, Conn., May 18 (AP) -- The Norwalk Tire and Rubber Company was hammered today by a barrage of attachment proceedings against its property. Five companies filed attachments today in Norwalk Town Clerk's office amounting to more than $1,500,000.
The sweeping victory of Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. in Tuesday's special election in the Twentieth Congressional District seemed yesterday to be likely to have four important political results.

PHILADELPHIA, May 18 (AP) -- The Browns won a battle of home runs in ending the Athletics' four-game winning streak with an 8-6 victory tonight. Stan Spence, Roy Sievers and Sherman Lollar hit homers for the Browns while Eddie Joost and Mike Guerra connected for the Mackmen.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Okla., May 18 -- Opposition to Federal aid to any church-sponsored school, and endorsement of the Supreme Court's verdict in the Champaign, Ill., case against sectarian teaching in the public schools were expressed today by the Southern Baptist Convention, as it began its five-day annual meeting.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (UP) -- Gustave W. Vogel, 36-year-old freight forwarder of New York City, admitted today that he got $115,000 in marine insurance "kickbacks" on American-financed shipments to Poland.

The New Hampshire law, effective yesterday, which allows savings banks in the state to invest in certain open-end investment companies marks a further advance by the open-end funds along the road of fiduciary investment acceptability.
MADRID, May 18 (UP) -- Following is the text of a telegram that Generalissimo Franco read in Parliament as having come from the Duke of Alba, onetime Spanish Ambassador in London:

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,619 against 1,452 last week and 1,222 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 667 arrivals on Tuesday compared with 734 on Tuesday of last week.

Magistrate Morris Rothenberg, acting national chairman of the United Palestine Appeal, said in a special report issued yesterday that funds raised in this country had made possible last month "very substantial imports" of transit camp equipment for houseless Israeli immigrants.

Convinced that in the future at least 90 per cent of all homes will be of the prefabricated type, Cy Williams and associates, who long have been engaged in residential construction on Long Island, announced yesterday that they had entered this field.

Long-stemmed lilies, rare passion flowers and many spring flowers were displayed yesterday at the sixteenth annual flower mart, sponsored by the Outdoor Cleanliness Association, on the steps of St. Patrick's Cathedral.
New York will embark soon on a wide promotional program to attract trade to the port as a gateway of world commerce, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson hailed today the results of the Sunday voting in the Soviet area of Germany.

RYE, N. Y., May 18 -- Enlarged training programs for salesmen are needed because of the war-born period that allowed salesmanship to become rusty, leaders of the National Society of Sales Training Executives said today at a spring meeting in the Westchester Country Club.

PHILADELPHIA, May 18 -- Will Prior and Walt Armstrong each blasted a two-run homer to lead Princeton in a 6-3 Eastern Intercollegiate League victory over Penn at River Field today. Prior smashed his fourth circuit clout of the campaign in the eighth inning, driving Armstrong home ahead of him and breaking a 3-3 tie.

MADRID, May 18 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco told the world tonight that the European states were "so clumsy, so old and so divided that they are pushing us toward countries of our own strain in the American Continent, in which the United States has achieved the ruling position."

PROVIDENCE, R. I., May 18 (AP) The California Insurance Commissioner's charge that the Rhode Island Insurance Company is insolvent was vehemently denied today by Jesse B. White, president of the company, which is chartered in this state.

It has been several weeks since the Rev. William Francis Murray suggested to a parishioner that in the matter of donations toward a new church labor would be as welcome as currency. Since then, Father Murray said yesterday, sixty parishioners have used their spare time to set a foundation for the church and to erect the shell of a two and a half story building that will serve as rectory.

CAPETOWN, Union of South Africa, May 18 -- In an endeavor eventually to displace New York as the world market for karakul pelts known to furriers as "Southwest African Persian lambskins," the Farmers Cooperative Union of Southwest Africa announced today that it proposed to hold its own auction sales at Windhoek, capital of the territory.

PHILADELPHIA, May 18 -- The Third United States Circuit Court of Appeals ruled five to one today that states cannot extradite chain gang fugitives who suffered "cruel and brutal" treatment by their jailers.

ROSLYN, L. I., May 18 -- The final contract for laying a concrete deck has been let in the construction of the Roslyn viaduct, a 226-foot span across Hempstead Harbor, and work is expected to start on Monday on the last operation of the $3,500,000 project.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) -- Detroit mustered only one hit against four pitchers tonight, but the Senators required a three-run eighth-inning homer by Eddie Robinson to defeat the Tigers, 6 -- 3. Aaron Robinson's single in the fourth didn't figure in Detroit's scoring.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures, to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, May 18 -- Approach of the Communist party congress May 25 and the attendant increase in security precautions have set in motion rumors of large-scale arrests among the Czech police, army and others.

VIENNA, May 18 -- The Austrian Government has begun negotiations with Soviet occupation authorities designed to reopen the Danube to Austrian trade and believes it has reason to hope they will be crowned with success.

Vic Raschi spun an impressive two-hit shut-out and Tommy Henrich clouted two home runs yesterday as the Yankees freely clubbed once-great Bobby Feller to make it two in a row over the world champion Indians before a sweltering crowd of 28,606 at the Stadium.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 18 -- Niven Busch has concluded a deal with RKO for distribution of his independent production, "Daybreak," in which Teresa Wright (Mrs. Busch) and Lew Ayres will play the leading roles. John Sturges will direct the film, which will start June 7 at the Nassour Studio.

Thirty-eight city residents are among the 148 Columbia College students to receive King's Crown awards, presented annually by the college for outstanding participation in extra curricular activities, it was announced yesterday.

WATERTOWN, N. Y., May 18 (AP) -- Sales of the F. W. Woolworth Company for the first four months of this year decreased $53,251 from the comparable 1948 period, A. L. Cornwell, company president, reported today. Sales for the 1949 period totaled $177,050,318, compared with $177,103,570 for the first four months last year, he told the annual stockholders meeting.

BERLIN, May 18 -- The most important road link between Berlin and the Western zones of Germany was effectively closed to German truck traffic today by Soviet authorities who demanded additional documentation for supplies being brought to Berlin.

John M. Murtagh, Commissioner of Investigation, announced yesterday afternoon that he would seek to revoke the license of the Majestic Theatre, where the musical hit, "South Pacific," is playing, because Jack Pearl, the theatre box-office treasurer, would not cooperate in the city's ticket scalping inquiry.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended May 11:

BERLIN, May 18 -- Of all the benefits that lifting of the Russian blockade a week ago brought to Berlin, none is more apparent in the talk of everyday people than their faith that with the support of the Western powers Berlin will continue to be free.

LOS ANGELES, May 18 -- Hale Brothers Stores, Inc., of San Francisco, has bought 27 per cent of the outstanding common stock of the Broadway Department Store, Inc., of Los Angeles, it was announced last night by the concerns.

The American Petroleum Institute estimated yesterday that the daily average gross crude oil production for the week ended on Saturday was 4,899,350 barrels. The figure represents an increase of 2,600 barrels compared with the previous week. For the week ended May 15, 1948, the daily average crude production was 5,422,600 barrels.

PARIS, May 18 -- Reports have been received in Paris that important Communist leaders in Czechoslovakia are privately concerned about the even remote possibility that the forthcoming Council of Foreign Ministers may lead to unification of Germany.
Senator Irving M. Ives urged and predicted last night a half-billion-dollar cut in the Economic Cooperation Administration program for Europe this year.
Young couples furnishing their first houses are advised to buy a few good pieces at a time, choosing those that are flexible enough to keep pace with a growing family.

The city is withholding final payment on a considerable number of the 500 new buses delivered by General Motors until the company makes seventeen modifications in their construction, it was learned yesterday.

CLEVELAND, May 18 -- The waning influence of Communists in the Congress of Industrial Organizations has made the outlook for unity in the American labor movement brighter than it has ever been since the original split fourteen years ago, leaders of the American Federation of Labor said here today.
Senator Irving M. Ives urged and predicted last night a half-billion-dollar cut in the Economic Cooperation Administration program for Europe this year.
Young couples furnishing their first houses are advised to buy a few good pieces at a time, choosing those that are flexible enough to keep pace with a growing family.

The city is withholding final payment on a considerable number of the 500 new buses delivered by General Motors until the company makes seventeen modifications in their construction, it was learned yesterday.

CLEVELAND, May 18 -- The waning influence of Communists in the Congress of Industrial Organizations has made the outlook for unity in the American labor movement brighter than it has ever been since the original split fourteen years ago, leaders of the American Federation of Labor said here today.

Appropriate for American living and in good taste were the summer fashions shown yesterday at Martin's of Brooklyn. Marking the opening of the Sun Shop, the presentation featured a group of beach and resort clothes.

ALBANY, May 18 -- The Public Service Commission indicated today it would approve a plan of the three principal companies in the Niagara Hudson System to issue Class A stock having certain privileges over the proposed common stock if the proposal received the approval of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

THE Yankees have bravely announced that Joe DiMaggio will climb back into uniform next week and test his injured heel. The natural assumption is that the Great Man is on the road to recovery and soon will start terrorizing enemy pitchers. The fervent hope here is that it's true, not for the sake of the Yankees as much as for the sake of DiMadge himself.

How to make a home with cast- offs -- some of them literally salvaged from the trash can -- is demonstrated in a model furnished apartment at Lillian Wald Houses, Houston Street and East River Drive. The work was done at the request of the New York City Housing Authority by junior students in the home-furnishing class, of Pratt Institute School of Home Economics under the direction of Miss Josephine Wasson.

Perhaps some of your readers may be able to furnish information about a most audacious and almost successful attempt to burn New York City on Nov. 25, 1864, by a group of Confederates who had entered the city from Canada.

LONDON, May 18 -- Two more left-wing pro-Soviet members of Parliament, Leslie J. Solley and Konni Zilliacus, were expelled from the British Labor party today. At the same time, on the initiative of Prime Minister Attlee, the parliamentary private secretaries of five Ministers were discharged for having voted against the Labor Government in the House of Commons.

Ninety per cent of the people in Czechoslovakia are anti-Communist, according to Miss Vlasta Adele Vraz, American-born Prague head of American Relief for Czechoslovakia, who was jailed last month for a week and then released.
WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The executive board of the Congress of Industrial Organizations voted two more policy decisions today over the ineffectual resistance of its Communist-minded element.
DETROIT, May 18 (AP) -- More than fifty Great Lakes vessels were targets today as the Seafarers' International Union, AFL, launched a drive to oust Communists from lake shipping crews.

CINCINNATI, May 18 (AP) -- The third-place Reds moved within one game of the National League lead today by trouncing the Braves, 13 -- 9, when Grady Hatton it a grand slam homer in the ninth. Eddie Erautt was the winning pitcher and Nelson Potter the loser for Boston, which still shares first place with the Giants.

The United Nations General Assembly ended its spring session at 6:18 o'clock last evening after having decided to postpone a decision on the disposition of the former Italian colonies in Africa until its fourth regular session, which will convene at Flushing Meadow on Sept. 20.
Accessories that are dramatic in color, shape or texture are favored by Modernage, 16 East Thirty- fourth Street, which showed new ceramics and enamelware yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- When the Senate Foreign Relations Committee completed hearings on the North Atlantic Treaty this afternoon the question thoughtful observers here were asking was whether the lack of excitement over this legislation indicated public acceptance, public indifference, public ignorance or all three.
WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) -- Following are the texts of President Truman's welcoming remarks and the response by Brazil's President Eurico Gaspar Dutra at the National Airport here today:

"Canadian Pacific," a drama about the building and the early history of that railroad, will have its local premiere today at the Palace as the inaugural feature film under the theatre's new vaudeville and film policy. Randolph Scott and Jane Wyatt are starred in the offering, which was filmed in Cinecolor and independently produced by Nat Holt for Twentieth Century-Fox release.

The Committee for the Companies and Agents, Atlantic and Gulf Coasts, which represents twenty-five steamship operators, yesterday rejected all contract proposals of the American Radio Association, CIO, as "unrealistic and exorbitant."

John M. Murtagh, Commissioner of Investigation, who is conducting the city's inquiry into waterfront crime, predicted yesterday that the pier-loader phase of the inquiry would be settled completely by the first of June.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- When the Senate Foreign Relations Committee completed hearings on the North Atlantic Treaty this afternoon the question thoughtful observers here were asking was whether the lack of excitement over this legislation indicated public acceptance, public indifference, public ignorance or all three.

Overriding a "minority report" by Park Commissioner Robert Moses, the City Planning Commission adopted yesterday in City Hall a zoning amendment limiting to thirty feet the height of new buildings within half a mile of the boundaries of private airports.
WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) -- Following are the texts of President Truman's welcoming remarks and the response by Brazil's President Eurico Gaspar Dutra at the National Airport here today:

After more than three decades of guiding subway trains, Hosea Wilson Welch, BMT motorman who reached the retirement age of 70 on May 15, shifted to being a passenger yesterday and decided after the first few minutes that he was going to like the change.

The likelihood of television losing use of the music controlled by the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers materially lessened yesterday. The society extended until June 15 its permission for video stations to use the ASCAP catalogue without immediate payment.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- A $100 contempt fine was levied today on Archibald Palmer, defense lawyer in the Judith Coplon espionage trial, for talking back to Judge Albert L. Reeves and using tactics the court considered time-wasting.
LONDON, Friday, May 20 -- Tass said today the Soviet Union was willing to talk over settlement of the Greek civil war on the basis of the recent peace bid of the Greek guerrilla Government.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 19 -- E. M. Elkin, general tax attorney of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, Pittsburgh, said today there is need for a sensible spending policy that will reduce Federal expenditures to minimum levels of efficiency and some moderation in the tax burden "if we are to enjoy a prosperous democracy."
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- During the week ended May 18, member bank reserve balances increased $138,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, May 19 -- The increase of 15 per cent in pig-iron production realized by the Republic Steel Corporation through the employment of pressure-blowing in several of its blast furnaces here has attracted the interest of seven foreign nations, E. M. V. Richards, the company's vice president in charge of operations, disclosed today.

PITTSBURGH, May 19 (AP) -- Braves hurler Vern Bickford won his own game with a single, scoring Phil Masi from second in the first of the ninth, giving Boston a 3-2 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates today

PARIS, May 19 -- In their first open demonstration since the liberation, supporters of former Marshal Henri-Philippe Petain shouted to a halt today an auction sale of books and souvenirs once belonging to the chief of the Vichy regime.

The right forearm of St. Francis Xavier, whose missionary endeavors earned for him the title "Apostle of the Indies," arrived at La Guardia Airport at 7:27 o'clock last night from Barcelona, Spain, with a group of five Spanish priests and twenty-seven lay Catholic pilgrims.

Back from the Rome meeting of the International Olympic Committee, Avery Brundage yesterday said that efforts to streamline the programs of future Olympic games are continuing although Helsinki in 1952 will stage all of the sports that were held in London in 1948.

Radio Corporation of America will introduce a new ten-inch direct view tube table television set listing at $269.50 in all cities with television transmitting facilities on Monday, H. G. Baker, general manager, RCA-Victor home instrument department, announced yesterday.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 19 -- The Tanjug news agency announced today that Yugoslav frontier guards, stationed along the Danube, had sunk a small Hungarian boat by gunfire on Tuesday last at 10 P. M. for violation of Yugoslav territorial waters.

The artists' and craftsmen's Mecca, Greenwich Village, will be the scene this evening of its second fair in two weeks, the Craftsmen's Equity annual event that opens for week-ends in a dressed-up lot at Eighth Street and Avenue of the Americas.

ROME, May 19 -- Extreme left-wing and right-wing parties, prompted by different reasons, united today in asking for the resignations of Premier Alcide de Gasperi and Count Carlo Sforza, the Foreign Minister, because of what they termed the disastrous result of Italian foreign policy as shown by the United Nations General Assembly's refusal to grant a trusteeship over Tripolitania to Italy.

It has frequently been reported that an atomic bomb contains about twenty-odd pounds of explosive material. On this assumption, it follows that even if we did not have Senator Brien McMahon's word for it the disappearance of one-seventh of an ounce of uranium at the Argonne Laboratory near Chicago is of no military importance to anybody.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended May 14 totaled 771,736 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

United States Attorney John F. X. McGohey rested the Government's case yesterday against the eleven Communist leaders charged with conspiracy to teach and advocate violent overthrow of the Government. Federal Judge Harold R. Medina then held the Government had presented such a strong prima facie case he would hear only limited arguments on defense motions to throw it out.

The United States' aid to Turkey program is proceeding according to expectations, Admiral Mehmet Ali Ulgen, commander-in-chief of the Turkish Navy, said yesterday at La Guardia Airport on his arrival from Istanbul on a month's visit as a guest of the United States Navy.

Senator Brien McMahon, Democrat, of Connecticut, chairman of the Senate-House Joint Committee on Atomic Energy, has renewed his suggestion that the number of atomic bombs in the United States stockpile be made public.

Earnings of the Creole Petroleum Corporation for the first three months of this year are estimated at $32,000,000, or 38 per cent lower than actual earnings for the first quarter of 1948, A. T. Proudfit, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting held here yesterday.

There are many who will lyrically extol the scenic wonders of the Rhine, the Nile and the Amazon. Just say Hudson River to Capt. Frank E. Brown and quick is the answer: "The daddy of them all." And quick is also the quote from Washington Irving's "Rip Van Winkle":

The mild winter and warm spring have done much to improve the wildlife situation in New York, Pennsylvania and most of the New England States, according to reports from conservation groups in these areas.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- John J. McCloy, the newly appointed American High Commissioner of Germany, is a man who can cuss out a general or win over , Senator, or out-talk a diplomat, or knock the chip off a reporter's shoulder faster than a German can say "ve for we and wisy wersy."

First baseman Jim Felton's single to center scored Artie West from second in the tenth inning yesterday to give St. John's a 7 -- 6 triumph over City College in a Metropolitan Collegiate Conference contest at Dexter Park, Woodhaven.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (UP) -- Representative Herman P. Eberharter, Democrat, of Pennsylvania, was accused today of drunkenness, wife-beating and shady business transactions by witnesses seeking to block his appointment as federal judge in the Western District of Pennsylvania.

May I raise a dissenting voice to the universal demand either for less public spending or more taxes. Back in January, 1949, the correct policy was more taxes. But by the spring of 1949 it has become increasingly clear that the problem in 1949 is not going to be one of inflation, but rather that of preventing a small decline from snowballing into a large one.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, May 19 -- A mixture of business and pleasure fills the calendar of Governor Thomas E. Dewey on his two- and-a-half-day visit to the Netherlands, homeland of the finest herds of his favorite Holstein and Frisian cattle.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- House Democratic leaders, scheduling the second round of the veterans' pension fight for next Thursday, gave their tacit support today to a watered-down bill in hopes of stopping a new drive for broad-scale benefits.

Three teen-aged soldiers, accused of assaulting a middle-aged widow and stealing her fur jacket and handbag as she was about to enter her apartment house at Tenth Street and Fifth Avenue, were arraigned yesterday on robbery charges in the youth part of Felony Court.

MOSCOW, May 19 -- The newspaper Soviet Lithuania, published at Vilna, devoted a full page to life in the United States in its issue of May 14 under the title, "In the Country of the Yellow Devil" -- a quotation from Maxim Gorky's famous impressions written after his visit to the United States.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 19 -- Betty Hutton will replace Judy Garland as star of the screen version of "Annie Get Your Gun" at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, the studio announced today. When Metro borrowed Miss Hutton from Paramount for the assignment, the latter studio announced that "Let's Dance," in which Miss Hutton was scheduled to play opposite Fred Astaire, will be postponed until "Annie" is completed.
CHICAGO, May 19 (AP) -- A prediction that 6,000,000 television receivers will be operating by 1951 was made today by the president of the Radio Manufacturers Association.

BUFFALO, N. Y., May 19 -- The Rev. Dr. Clifford Edward Barbour of Knoxville, Tenn., was elected moderator today of the Presbyterian Church in the U. S. A. at the opening session here of the denomination's 161st General Assembly.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 19 -- Dr. Herbert V. Evatt, president of the United Nations General Assembly, announced today that the Assembly's conciliation group had given up its efforts to adjust existing differences between Greece and Yugoslavia.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 19 -- William L. Batt, president of SKE Industries, Inc., Philadelphia, said today that the international trade organization, aimed at restoring world trade, offered the only hope of making certain that the heavy investments of American dollars abroad "shall not have been wasted."

SEOUL, Korea, May 19 -- The Korean Government today asked the United Nations Commission on Korea whether or not it intended to consult with North Korean Communist authorities on unification of Korea. At the same time the Government warned the commission that "it is not the Koreans in the north who are preventing the reunion of northern and southern Korea; it is their Soviet overlords whose orders they obey."

A 33-year-old dealer in used cars was under arrest yesterday in Brooklyn as the alleged operator of a scheme in which he obtained "nearly $1,000,000" in advance payments for new automobiles that he never delivered.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., May 19 -- Warning that an over-all national health bill "may kill the patient," Dr. Gilson Golby Engel of Philadelphia, president of the Pennsylvania Medical Society, said today that a separate bill for each problem was more important to a proper solution.

Life insurance companies throughout the country have completed or in prospect housing projects to provide rental accommodations for 47,000 families through an investment which will reach $475,000,000, the Institute of Life Insurance reported yesterday.

The music of Leon Kirchner, one of the truly promising young composers of the day, was presented last night in the season's final Composers Forum at McMillin Theatre, Columbia University. Represented on the same bill was Ned Rorem, whose compositions also are getting frequent hearings these days, and a first-rate group of performers.

Continuing their downward plunge for the twelfth consecutive week, business loans made by banks in this area dropped $79,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday. The decline brought the total outstanding to $4,896,000,000, the lowest level since Oct. 15, 1947, according to the figures covering the reporting New York City member banks, issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Nineteen million of the Soviet Union's 33,000,000 urban workers maintained vegetable gardens on workers' allotments last year, four times the number with victory gardens in 1942, according to a report published by the Soviet trade union administration, which became available here yesterday.
The Irving Trust Company has been appointed agent for common stock subscription of the South Carolina Electric and Gas Company.

Four thousand students of Abraham Lincoln High School, Ocean Parkway and West Avenue, Brooklyn, expressed their thanks yesterday to Dr. John Dewey, the "father" of progressive education, for "everything that is good in our school."

Joseph M. Price, who died last week, was an ideal municipal reformer, not of the starry-eyed variety, but clear-sighted and minded, practical, positive and persistent even to obstinacy. He would have made a first-class politician had he not been so stern a Roman. He had a mind of his own and was not easily persuaded to change it.

SHANGHAI, May 19 -- The Communists tonight still had not cut the Nationalists' escape route from the city down the Whangpoo but at many points were within rifle range of its shores and the danger was imminent that the Reds might bring up artillery.
State Fair Toy Novelty Co, floor in 123 Mercer St -- Brett, Wyckoff, Potter, Hamilton, Inc, brokers.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The executive board of the Congress of Industrial Organizations put its dissident minority on notice today to honor and obey the CIO constitution and policy or get out.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Charles F. Brannan, Secretary of Agriculture, today told a Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee that unless the United States ratified the International Wheat Agreement this country either would be forced into bilateral agreements that meant rigid home controls or be forced out of the world market.

The first post-war cut on apparel class viscose rayon yarn was announced yesterday by American Viscose Company, the largest producer of rayon. Reductions ranged from 10 cents a pound on 75 denier to 3 cents on 300 denier. The 100 denier yarns were reduced 8 cents a pound and the 150 denier 6 cents.

LONDON, May 19 (AP) -- The question whether Communist Gerhart Eisler is a fugitive from United States justice or a political refugee entitled to asylum is to be decided by Home Secretary James Chuter Ede.

Since there was a meeting of some local political interest that night, it was decreed that the head of the house mind the baby. This was a frank way of putting what long had been suspected, that politics no longer is in the province of men but has become a creature of women.

Formal greetings between Glasgow and New York were exchanged yesterday at City Hall, where Mayor William O'Dwyer greeted members of the Scottish international soccer team, which will open its tour next Sunday against the American Soccer League all-stars at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island.

ST. LOUIS, May 19 -- Pitching masterfully in the pinches Preacher Roe, veteran southpaw, tonight hurled an eight-hit shut-out as the Dodgers continued their Western winning streak by beating the Cardinals, 2 -- 0, under the Sportsman's Park lights.
Orleans Parish, La., announced yesterday that it will receive bids June 3 on $2,500,000 of school bonds dated Dec. 1, 1927, and due on each Dec. 1 from 1949 to 1967.

While several hundred passersby looked on in City Hall Plaza yesterday, Mayor O'Dwyer, members of the Board of Transportation and representatives of Swedish organizations inspected a new fifty-passenger bus to be used in Stockholm.

Pineapple production of the Hawaiian Pineapple Company will reach a new high this year, running 20 per cent over 1948 for the fiscal year ending this month, Henry White, president, said in an interview yesterday at the Drake Hotel.
LOS ANGELES, May 19 -- Wearability and femininity are keynotes of the new fall fashions presented this week by the Affiliated Fashionists of California.

CHARLIE KELLER is a hulking creature of forbidding mien. His features are heavy and swarthy. He looks as though he could strangle a horse with his bare hands. In fact he'd make an ideal bogeyman for scaring little children -- if you were to accept him on appearances only. But that would be a snare and a delusion.

ATLANTA, May 19 (AP) -- Attorney General Eugene Cook said today he would appeal a Federal Court decision in Philadelphia denying extradition of a murderer to Georgia. Mr. Cook said he would argue the case personally in making the appeal to a higher tribunal.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:The letters of Richard A. Sears and Walter Sosnoski follow the same line as that of the "experts" on China, whose influence on our State Department has led to a China policy that has proved disastrous.
Dr. Maurice N. Eisendrath, president of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, called on American Jews last night for greater support of the organization's religious and cultural institutions.
ALBANY, May 19 (AP) -- The Public Service Commission today authorized the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation to issue new preferred and common stocks with par values totaling $5,833,325.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 19 (UP) -- The "heresy" dispute that resulted in the discharge of three Boston College instructors and the silencing of a Jesuit priest recently flared anew tonight when two girl students at Emmanuel College resigned and refused to take their degrees.

As of this moment no deal has been consummated with Herman Shumlin to stage "The Innocents," but reliable sources indicate he may do so. Their assumption is based on the fact that Mr. Shumlin has been conferring with William Archibald regarding his dramatization of "The Innocents," based on Henry James' story, "The Turn of the Screw."

CLEVELAND, May 19 -- Basic steps intended to curb Communist influence in the Canadian Trades and Labor Council and thus prevent the threatened withdrawal of its anti-Communist affiliates were agreed upon here today by representatives of the Canadian group and the executive council of the American Federation of Labor.
Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder told members of the Tax Executives Institute, Inc., last night that he doubted "any great cuts" could be made in President Truman's $42,000,000,000 budget.

Bracha Zefira, contralto from Israel, gave her first New York recital last night at Town Hall. In a program devoted to Hebraic music, the gifted artist was assisted by Robert Cornman, pianist; Gloria Augustini, harpist; a male quartet from the S. Silbermintz Choir, and an ensemble composed of Shulamit Silber, violinist; Frederick Wilkins, flutist; Daniel Oppenheim, clarinetist, and Claus Adam, 'cellist.

A private move seeking agreement on basic standards for advertising of the new ammoniated dentifrices among a group of leading drug products manufacturers is about to be initiated, it was learned yesterday.

Prophetic of the lush autumn colors to come were the fashions of Merrimack's fabrics that company showed yesterday afternoon at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel to an audience composed entirely of stylists and the press. The materials were velveteens, corduroys and rayon wool blends.

WESTFIELD, N. J., May 19 -- Teaming perfectly, Mrs. H. C. Ramsey of Baltusrol and Mrs. Philip Cudone of the Knoll won low gross honors with a best-ball score of 35, 40 -- 75 at the Echo Lake Country Club course today.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., May 19 -- Delegates from sixty units of the League of Women Voters of the state decided on a statewide system of permanent personal registration of voters and improved legislative procedures as objectives for the next two years as they closed their convention today.

Ninety thousand textile workers in the woolen and worsted branches of the industry were advised yesterday by their union not to ask for wage increases on Aug. 1 when their present contracts are reopenable.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The Congressional Joint Committee on Atomic Energy has undertaken an independent investigation of the disappearance of an ounce of U-235 from the Argonne National Laboratory several months ago, it was announced on the floor of the Senate today by Senator Brien McMahon, Democrat, of Connecticut, chairman of the committee.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- A registration statement was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the Sun Oil Company, Philadelphia, and the "Stock Purchase Plan for the Employes of Sun Oil Company and its Subsidiaries," covering 11,000 memberships in the plan.

PHILADELPHIA, May 19 (AP) -- The Federal Circuit Court of Appeals took under advisement today a case that affects damage claims of merchant seamen injured overseas while serving on ships controlled by the United States.

Today's events: Hazel Gruppe, piano, and Francis Flanagan, violin, Carl Fischer Hall, 5:30 o'clock; Memorial to Alexander Pushkin, Russian Operatic Group, Michael Fiveisky, conductor, Maxim Panatleieff, baritone. Vera Briner, soprano, and others, Carl Fischer Hall, 8:30.

Three modern room settings visible through the glass front of the newly remodeled Sachs-Quality store at Thirty-fifth Street and Eighth Avenue are a clue to the new role that the store has assumed along with its restyled exterior.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The Government's purse strings will be tightened to cut off Communists from Federal fellowships or other direct aid, Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney, Democrat, of Wyoming, promised today. Senator O'Mahoney is chairman of the Appropriations subcommittee holding hearings on the fiscal requests of the Atomic Energy Commission.
A blind college youth who aids paraplegics at the Bronx Veterans Administration Hospital viewed optimistically yesterday his own future in the field of rehabilitation.

Eleven years ago today T. Frank Hayes, Lieutenant Governor of Connecticut and Mayor of of Waterbury surrendered to a charge of conspiracy with eleven other state and county officials in a plot to loot Waterbury's city treasury of more than $1,000,000.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday and final prices were 6 points higher to 5 points lower. The market opened unchanged to 1 point lower, and held within a narrow range all day. A spot house was credited with selling about 5,000 bales of the July and October deliveries, mostly the latter.

Pressure was working from two directions yesterday against the present Tammany regime headed by Borough President Hugo E. Rogers as a result of the organization's fiasco in the special election Tuesday in the Twentieth Congressional District.

Dr. Harry D. Gideonse, president of Brooklyn College, issued a formal statement yesterday warning students, in view of a two-hour strike called by the student council for today, that the college would insist upon enforcing its orders and regulations, which forbid unauthorized leaving of classrooms.

FRANKFORT, Germany, May 19 -- Alexander Sacks, former member of the United States Military Government decartelization branch, faces possible dismissal because of testimony he gave to a special Army committee investigating the anti-trust program in Germany.
R. A. Hummel, president of the Lone Star Cement Corporation, has been elected a director of the American and Foreign Power Company, Inc., it was announced yesterday.
With what veteran observers described as "the longest home run hit in the Yankee Stadium" and an even more important two-run single, Larry Doby slugged the Indians out of their slump yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, May 19 (AP) -- Joe Kirkwood Jr. of Los Angeles urged a 16-foot putt into the cup on the eighteenth green today to give him a four-under-par 68 and a tie with Bobby Locke for the first-round lead in the sixth annual Philadelphia Inquirer invitation golf tournament.

Dr. Benjamin Lee Gordon, author of "The Romance of Medicine," an account of the evolution of medicine from primitive times and occult practices, has written another volume of medical history entitled, "Medicine Throughout Antiquity." The book traces the history of medicine from prehistoric times to the end of the Greco-Roman period and contains 157 illustrations and a foreword by Dr. Max Neuberger.

Lee Shubert, operator of the Majestic Theatre, where the musical hit, "South Pacific," is playing, was subpoenaed yesterday afternoon by John M. Murtagh, Commissioner of Investigation, for questioning at 1 P. M. today about the sale and allotment of tickets since the show opened on April 7.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The United States will enter the Big Four conference with new hope for its success but will not agree to a single backward step in the American campaign to restore "the health and strength" of the free world.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- A Senate Commerce subcommittee heard Richard Hillman, a Federal Power Commission economist specializing in utilities, argue today that the airlines had developed as a luxury service that failed to meet public or military requirements.

OKLAHOMA CITY, May 19 -- The Southern Baptist convention today tabled a proposed amendment to its constitution that would have penalized any member of the denomination who affiliated directly or indirectly with the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America.

BERLIN, May 19 -- The Russians reopened the Autobahn between Berlin and the West to German truck traffic for five hours tonight. But they also reaffirmed their determination to bar this traffic from using the broad highway to supply this city, spiking hopes of a speedy accord on the implementation of the agreement that ended the eleven-month blockade.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, May 19 -- At today's meeting of the Inland Transport Committee of the International Labor Organization, United States employers delegate L. W. Horning, vice president of the New York Central Railroad System, and Canadian employers delegate S. M. Gossage, assistant personnel manager for the Canadian Pacific Railway, pleaded for collective bargaining in industry as a means of settling differences between employers and employes rather than forcing a plan or method upon them.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Republicans, to a man, asserted today that President Truman was sidetracking Taft-Hartley repeal in naming Representative Augustine B. Kelley, key Administration figure on a closely divided House Labor Committee, for a five-week foreign assignment.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 19 -- The bid for the medal in the annual Walter J. Travis Memorial tournament staged by the Garden City Golf Club ended in a four-way tie today after the last of the 141 players had reported in at twilight.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- Freddie Hutchinson's hitting and pitching helped give Detroit a 10-to-1 triumph over Washington today. Hutchinson scattered seven hits in getting his second victory and hammered out a triple, a double, a single and batted in three runs.

Eleven additional child day care centers that will accommodate 600 youngsters will be established in local housing projects within the next year with the aid of city funds, Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard of the Welfare Department said yesterday.

Sterling exchange turned firm in a day of quiet trading here yesterday. Despite the fact that demand for the British currency was light and there was an ample supply, "spot" sales were concluded at $1.02 15/16, a price fractionally above that of the preceding day.

Six new exhibitions give free run to a wide variety of art forms. At the Mortimer Levitt Gallery paintings recently loaned to museums by them are on view. Dominating this show are paintings by Everett Spruce which fix nature in her more unruly moods, storm clouds in "Lost Boat," the pitiless heat of the desert subjects, the brute force of "Red Bull."

The Board of Higher Education has emerged from its long ordeal of finding a president for Queens College. In the relative calm which obtains for the moment, at least, other aspects of its problems may be considered. Dr. John J. Theobald, dean of administration at City College, takes over the presidency of a thriving institution.

Three Soviet professors of economics, I. Blyumin, D. Rosenberg and B. M. Shtein, are attacked in the current issue of Bolshevik, journal of the Soviet Communist party, as "cosmopolitans" who have perverted "the history of the Russian economic thought."
WASHINGTON, May 19 (UP) -- The text of Secretary Acheson's statement on the Council of Foreign Ministers meeting in Paris follows:

The Consumers Power Company has cut its 1949 construction budget by $6,500,000 because of a ruling by the Michigan Public Service Commission which granted the utility $3,000,000 less than the $4,800,000 it sought on gas rates.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 19 -- Brazil urged the United Nations today to act on a series of positive inducements to be offered foreign private investors by underdeveloped countries seeking to attract capital under President Truman's "bold new program" of technical assistance and private investment.
Mrs. Patricia Canning Todd of La Jolla, Calif., sixth ranking woman tennis player of the country, left yesterday for England aboard an American Overseas airliner from La Guardia Field.

Review of the movies was necessary at Belmont Park yesterday before the "official" sign flashed to give first money of $6,750 to Rigan Mckinney's Navigate in the twenty-eighth running of the Charles L. Appleton Steeplechase.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (UP) -- The Department of Justice asked today that twenty-two railway labor unions be kept out of the Government's $2,000,000,000 wartime rate-rebate suit against the nation's railroads. The Government is trying to collect what it claims were overpayments to the railroads for hauling freight.

MOSCOW, May 19 -- Archibald Johnston, who renounced the editorship of the British Government's Moscow publication Britansky Soyusnik (British Ally) last month to devote himself to "fighting for peace" conducted a press conference in Moscow's newly-opened Soviet Journalists Club today.

PARIS, May 19 -- A greater effort to "quench the thirst for knowledge among the masses of the people of the world" was out-lined here today by Douglas H. Schneider of New York, newly appointed director of the mass communications department of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.
WASHINGTON, May 19 (2P) -- President Truman congratulated Dr. Gilbert Grosvenor today for "a record of outstanding accomplishment" in his fifty years as editor of the National Geographic Magazine.
SHANGHAI, Friday, May 20 -- Shells from the battlefront fell in Shaighai today for the first time and it appeared that time was drawing short for this major Asian city.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 19 -- President Eurico Gaspar Dutra, who is now paying a state visit to the United States, undoubtedly will take advantage of the opportunity to discuss Brazilian-United States economic problems, officials here believe.

CAMBRIDGE, England, May 19 (Reuters) -- Two New Zealand cricketers -- Vice Capt. Mervyn Wallace and 24-year-old John Reid -- drew within a few runs of hitting a double century each against Cambridge University today.

Parents were told here yesterday that it is their duty, not just for the sake of their children but also as a community service, to avail themselves of existing school services to improve the health and welfare of students.

I want to thank you and Dr. Howard Rusk for the editorial in THE TIMES of May 15 and for his splendid article on the need for an activity program for our aging population. We who have been carrying on the project at the William Hodson Community Center welcome your interest and understanding.

Sure-fire harbingers of summer in the city -- archery ranges, bathing beaches, music groves and swimming pools -- are currently being made available by the New York City Park Department in its greatest and most diversified program of recreation for stay-at-home New Yorkers.

A growing hunger for "yield bonds" on the part of major institutional investors is suggested by the pricing and subsequent marketing experience of the Alabama Gas Company's new mortgage bonds. With all of the company's outstanding bonds of the same mortgage held privately, a pinpoint market rating was out of the question and pricing consequently became a question of hunch.
CINCINNATI, May 19 -- The Giants today finally got around to showing the folks in the hinterlands how they do it at the Polo Grounds.
THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, May 19 (AP) -- The Netherlands Government announced today the appointment of a new Dutch High Commissioner in Indonesia.

LONDON, May 19 -- A new warning to enforce rigid party discipline on dissident Laborites was issued tonight by the parliamentary Labor party. This follows expulsion from the Labor party yesterday of two leftists and the dismissal of five parliamentary private secretaries.

In terms of real purchasing power, advertising costs are 40 per cent below those of 1940, it was pointed out yesterday by Armo Johnson, vice president and director of media and research of J. Walter Thompson Company, advertising agency.

In the opening words of his fine work, "The Dictionary of American History," James Truslow Adams observed that "America has never before been so interested in its history as it is today." That in itself is, in no small degree, a tribute to the powers as a writer and as a historian of James Truslow Adams.

The report of the United Aircraft Corporation for the quarter ended with last March disclosed yesterday a net income of $1,206,831 after taxes and all charges, compared with $3,248,230 in the first three months of last year.

PATERSON, N. J., May 19 -- The Paterson Savings and Trust Company today offered to purchase the interests of the stockholders of the Clifton Trust Company and of the First National Bank of Clifton, N. J., for $700 per share of common stock.

ALBANY, May 19 -- The Court of Appeals upheld unanimously today the right of John M. Murtagh, New York City Investigation Commissioner, to subpoena records of the Dairymen's League Cooperative Association, Inc., involving its relations with independent and chain store customers.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Brazil's sympathetic interest in the efforts of the United States to keep the world "from renewed bloodshed" was expressed to a joint session of Congress today by President Eurico Gaspar Dutra. He received prolonged ovations from the assembly, both on arrival and departure.
An unearned run in the last half of the ninth inning gave Brooklyn College an 8-7 victory over Manhattan in a Metropolitan Conference game at Flatbush yesterday.
LAKE SUCCESS, May 19 -- The Government of India said plainly today that it could never recognize the independence of any of the Princely States within its borders.

" The Lady Gambles," a Universal-International drama starring Barbara Stanwyck, Stephen McNally and Robert Preston, will have its premiere this morning at the Criterion. Michael Gordon directed and Michel Kraike produced from a screen play by Roy Huggins, an adaptation by Halsted Welles and a story by Lewis Meltzer and Oscar Saul. Edith Barrett, John Hoyt and Leif Erickson are among the featured players.
WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- With a rebuke to the Army, a House group refused today to permit President Truman's military aide to wear his controversial medal from Argentina.
The city's Department of Marine and Aviation now has lease contracts with four steamship companies committed to spend approximately $2,500,000 on city pier rehabilitation.

With Federal, State and Municipal officials joining shipping industry executives in one of the largest peacetime observances of National Maritime Day, the first phase of a four-day tribute to the nation's merchant fleet will open here this morning.

A two-pronged organizational drive, marked by the granting of charters to two new affiliates -- the Marine Allied Workers of the Atlantic and Gulf coasts and the Brotherhood of Marine Engineers -- was started yesterday by the Seafarers International Union of North America, AFL.

BOSTON, May 19 (AP) -- Sevellon Brown, editor and publisher of the Providence Journal-Bulletin, and A. Edwin Larsson, editor of the Wellesley Townsman, received plaques tonight from the Boston University chapter of Sigma Delta Chi for outstanding contributions to New England journalism.

If only one extravagance may be permitted in the week-end marketing, then choose those glossy mahogany-hued cherries, coming in the first regular shipments of the season from California. Their price is as high as 79 cents a pound in some stores, the consumers' service division of the City Department of Markets reports, but as low as 39 in others.

CHICAGO, May 19 -- Fairly general evening up was under way in May deliveries of grain on the Board of Trade today, resulting in irregular markets. Wheat closed 1 1/8 cent a bushel lower to unchanged, May showing the weakness.

BOSTON, May 19 -- Gov. Paul A. Dever of Massachusetts interceded with Gov. Ernest W. Gibson of Vermont today in an attempt to aid two war veterans held in a Rutland (Vt.) jail under an old Vermont law that allows a debtor to spend up to a lifetime in prison for failing to pay a civil judgment.
A run-off election for the two top offices of Local 6, International Typographical Union, AFL, will be held on June 8, it was announced yesterday by Laurence H. Victory, president.

Thomas O. Heggen, 29-year-old author of the book, "Mister Roberts," and co-author of the Broadway hit of the same name, was found dead yesterday morning, his head under water in the bathtub of his duplex apartment at 8 East Sixty-second Street.
Sixty-two nurses from St. Luke's Hospital School of Nursing received their diplomas yesterday at exercises in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue and 110th Street.

DUBLIN, May 19 -- James J. O'Brien, secretary of the Department of Public Works of New York City, has caused something of a sensation in Dublin for the past two days as he moved around with notables in his quaint Dutch colonial costume as "Father Knickerbocker."

Kelvinator division of Nash-Kelvinator Corporation yesterday reduced list prices on six of its eight household refrigerators $10 each. C. T. Lawson, vice president in charge of sales for the division, attributed the cut to more efficient production.

Continuing its mastery of second division opposition, Fordham walloped Kings Point, 11 -- 4, yesterday in a Metropolitan Baseball Conference game at Fordham Field. The victory squared the Rams' league mark at 6 -- 6 and their season record at 10 -- 10.
Production plans for the summer season were announced yesterday by playhouses on the Atlantic seaboard.

The call for regeneration of the fusion movement in New York to oppose the re-election of Mayor O'Dwyer that was issued on Wednesday by Samuel Seabury received a formal welcome yesterday from the Republican party.

A high-grade medical care program will never be created under any auspices, public, cooperative or private, in this country except as a group practice plan, David M. Heyman, president of the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York, asserted yesterday.

DETROIT, May 19 -- The United Automobile Workers, CIO, disclosed tonight that it would insist that the Ford Motor Company consider the union's 1949 contract demands, including its all-important pension plan, concurrently with negotiations to settle the current "speed-up" strike.

Robert Villemain and Pete Mead will clash in the ten-round bout that will head the boxing program at Madison Square Garden tonight. These middleweights are expected to attract a crowd of 12,000 fans and a gate of $40,000 to a show which will be the last to be conducted by Mike Jacobs' Twentieth Century Sporting Club.

The 28,000-deadweight ton supertanker Olympic Torch, second of six being built for the Olympic Oil Lines, will be launched this afternoon from the Bethlehem-Sparrows Point, Md., shipyard. The vessel will be sponsored by Mrs. B. Brewster Jennings, wife of the president and chairman of the board of Socony-Vacuum oil Co., Inc.

Manufacture of shoes in the I. Miller and Sons, Inc., plant, Long Island City, Queens, was stopped yesterday when 1,200 production workers refused to cross a picket line set up by fifty striking office employes.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- President Truman took President Eurico Gaspar Dutra of Brazil for a long walk this morning and showed him the spot where a venturesome woman reporter once trapped John Quincy Adams swimming in -- ahem -- the altogether and forced him to give an interview on a controversial issue of the times.

Coffee futures were quiet and easier of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Scattered liquidation in the spot May was absorbed by trade hedge-covering. Final prices for contract "S" were 1 to 10 points lower. Contract "D" was dull, and final levels were 11 to 15 points lower with the exception of the spot May, which closed 24 points higher.

Few who have ridden up the Lower Broadway avenue of heroes to receive a New York welcome deserved that honor so well as General Lucius D. Clay. He stood, in Germany, as a symbol of democratic policy in a time when the slightest sign of weakness or irresolution might have had consequences beyond imagining. Mayor O'Dwyer summed up his soldierly conduct well: it was "courageous without truculence and diplomatic without fear."

Failure within one year of the fair net operating income formula promulgated by National Housing Expediter Tighe E. Woods was predicted by Charles F. Noyes yesterday at the annual real estate conference of the Brooklyn Real Estate Board in the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn.

THE simplest, most fundamental and most often repeated advice aspiring writers encounter is "write about something you know well." They hear it first in sixth-grade English class and usually ignore it in order to write themes about something "interesting," such as invasions of Mars or the habits of vampires. They continue to hear it from professors, critics and venerable authors with thirty books listed after their names in "Who's Who."
LONDON, May 19 -- After an uncertain start, which was attributed to the latest Berlin news, a better tone developed during the afternoon in the stock market here today.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, May 19 -- For his birthday -- he will be 75 on Sunday -- Premier Daniel F. Malan today received a welcome present from the electors of Vereeniging in Transvaal Province in the form of an additional seat in Parliament.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Democrats took the offensive today in the economy battle in the Senate, where Republicans have failed three times in recent days in efforts to cut at least 5 per cent from appropriations recommended for Government operations during the approaching fiscal year.

If wishes could make vaudeville shows, the bill that reopened the Palace yesterday afternoon would have been overflowing with enjoyment. For the house was choked with appreciative people who were determined to see a glorious past reborn in the present and who fervently applauded Pat Rooney's fatherly blessing at the end.
WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture has arranged for price - supporting loans to growers on 1949-crop wheat harvested before the start of the official marketing season, July 1.
Edward J. Krug, 82-year-old practicing attorney, after sixty years before the bar believes it is a greater honor to be trusted than to be loved.

Most of the motifs in the new wallpapers designed by William Justema have been taken from the odds and ends glimpsed in shops and theatres in San Francisco's Chinatown rather than from restrained oriental documents.

An old man sat alone and unnoticed yesterday afternoon in the back-stage shadows of the Palace Theatre. On stage, in the glare of spots and loots, in the shrill blare of trumpets and tympani, vaudeville was attempting another comeback.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 19 -- A discovery that cancer disrupts the thyroid function, assertedly affording first evidence that any generalized metabolic activity in the body is disturbed by the disease, was reported today by a group of researchers at the University of California Medical School.

BOSTON, May 19 (AP) -- Although they rapped nearly twice as many hits as the Red Sox, the White Sox needed the assistance of four Boston errors today to win, 7 -- 6, in ten innings before 8,003 fans. The Chicagoans got 13 hits to Boston's seven.

Attendance at the New York City Center of Music and Drama reached an all-time high during the last year, with a total of 575,637 patrons. The announcement was made at the sixth annual meeting of the theatre's incorporators yesterday in the Hotel Gotham.

Secretary of State Acheson has made it plain that his department is not at present considering a defensive pact for the Pacific along the lines of the Atlantic Pact. Some other governments, notably the Australian and the Philippine, have been considering some type of agreement.

LONDON, May 19 -- Foreign Secretary Bevin announced in the House of Commons today an Anglo-Egyptian agreement for harnessing the waters of the Nile that. he said, would make possible greater development than ever before of Africa's mightiest river.

Two New York detectives burst into the Grant Pharmacy at 799 Park Avenue yesterday afternoon while a holdup was in progress and after firing six shots captured three members of a gang that had been responsible for at least four other holdups in Manhattan within the last two weeks.

Gen. Lucius D. Clay was welcomed to New York as a returning hero yesterday because of the part he played in halting the spread of Communist control in Europe through the firm policies he followed for four years as American Military Governor of Germany and commander of United States occupation troops.

PARIS, May 19 -- After five days of meetings experts of the three Western powers finished today the report they will make to their foreign ministers preparatory to the Big Four conference on Germany that will begin in Paris Monday. They were understood to have attained a large measure of agreement regarding the issues likely to arise, and on all major questions the Western powers expect to be united.

PARIS, May 19 -- A revolt that developed today against the Government program for balancing the budget deficit was regarded in some circles here tonight as threatening a Cabinet crisis in France while the Four-Power foreign ministers' conference was preparing to meet here Monday.

Rehabilitation of the Republican State Committee, was pledged yesterday by Representative William L. Pfeiffer, new Republican State chairman, in a press conference at the headquarters, 41 East Forty-second Street.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, chief delegate of the Philippines on the Far Eastern Commission, protested "in the strongest possible terms" before the commission today the decision of the United States to end reparations from Japan.

A final hearing began in Federal Court yesterday in the Government's attempt to enjoin two associations of United States alkali exporters, Imperial Chemical Industries, Ltd., of Great Britain, and other defendants from continuing an alleged conspiracy to restrain interstate and foreign trade and commerce in alkalis.

Late selling on the stock market yesterday found many vulnerable spots and produced the widest decline of the month. Always susceptible to developments in the field of labor and management, the share list was forced to absorb fairly insistent selling soon after the executive board of the CIO told its members that "immediate wage increases" are needed.

GENEVA, May 19 -- Eastern European countries were urged today by Western delegates to the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe to forget their dogmatism and realize their economic problems were essentially the same as those of the West.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 19 -- Only the restoration of an international gold standard with the help of the International Monetary Fund will permit resumption of free currency convertibility and multilateral trade, Philip Cortney, speaking for the National Association of Manufacturers, told the United Nations today.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Department store sales in the week ended May 14 were 3 per cent less than sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1948:

Oscar R. Ewing, Federal Security Administrator, described President Truman's health insurance plan last night as "no more socialistic than the fire department, which does not require a pauper's oath before it turns on the water."
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- President Truman today accepted the first new flag of the revived United Service Organiations, which will carry on welfare and recreation work among service men.

Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., victor in the Tuesday special election in the Twentieth Congressional District, had several political comments before departing from La Guardia airport last night en route to Israel on a Transworld Airways airplane.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The Senate Agriculture Committee today informally agreed to take up the pork and pork-products phase of Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan's production-subsidy farm plan before going into the whole program.

Helicopters capable of transporting fourteen or fifteen passengers may be produced and licensed for commercial operations within three years, it was said yesterday by David G. Forman, a representative of the Bell Aircraft Corporation.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- A B-50 four-engine bomber has made successful taxi tests on its own attached "airport," the National Military Establishment said today.

Thomas L. Robinson, new youth activities director of the Jersey City Y.M.C.A., has purchased the two-family dwelling at 65 Audubon Avenue, Jersey City, N.J., from Johanne Olsen. J.I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker.
BERLIN, May 20 -- An intensified campaign to confront the Council of Foreign Ministers with a national outcry for German unity was initiated by the Communists today.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- President Eurico Gaspar Dutra of Brazil had praise for the press of the United States as "one of the strongest forces for construction and for order in the modern world" in an address today at a luncheon in his honor by the National Press Club.

Retail sales here this week continued to show declines in comparison with the corresponding week last year. Department store sales were estimated to be down about 15 per cent. Sales last week were 11 per cent below the corresponding week in 1948.
I should like to offer my rebuttal to Herbert Harvey's letter to THE TIMES in defense of the inclusion of Communists in the scholarship program of the Atomic Energy Commission.

PARIS, May 20 -- So cold was the reception accorded today to the Government's fiscal program to meet the deficit in the budget that but for the Big Four Foreign Ministers' conference, opening next week, France might expect a Cabinet crisis.

Technical control of consumer goods production in many Soviet factories is very poor and little effort is made to find out why the goods turned out is of such poor quality, the Soviet State Planning Commission in Moscow says in a report on shoe and clothing production that has just become available here.

HANOVER, Germany, May 20 (AP) -- West German exports for the first quarter of this year totaled $260,000,000, Baron Vollrath von Maltzhan, chairman of the foreign section of the Bizonal Economic Council, said today.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., May 20 -- Harold Sanderson, Canoe Brook professional, and Dr. Stephens G. Lee, defending champions in the New Jersey State pro-amateur match-play championship, tied for the medal today in the fourteenth holding of the tournament over the rugged Plainfield Country Club course.

CLEVELAND, May 20 -- The Executive Council of the American Federation of Labor ordered the Air Line Pilots Association today to stop trying to organize flight engineers in opposition to the Flight Engineers International Association.

Marcel Cerdan, holder of the middleweight championship of the world, arrived in New York yesterday from France. The 160-pound king indicated, a few hours after his arrival, that he would defend his crown against Jake La Motta of the Bronx in a fight scheduled for Detroit on June 15.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 20 -- Charles Brackett, screen writer and producer, was unanimously elected president of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences last night by the Academy's, board of twenty-four governors, who represent the various branches of the film industry.

Frank. H. Brown, Regional Director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, announced yesterday the appointment of Mediation Commissioner Harry Winning to attempt to settle contract disputes here involving three maritime unions and the thirty-eight owners and agents of East and Gulf Coast shipping.
WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -- The Department of Justice notified the Supreme Court today that Gerhart Eisler was a fugitive and asked that his appeal from a contempt-of-Congress conviction be dismissed.

MEDIA, Pa., May 20 (UP) -- Herbert Gunther, former member of the Nazi Brown Shirts, now teaching at Harvard University, received United States citizenship in Delaware County Court today over the objections of the Federal Bureau of Naturalization.

PITTSBURGH, May 20 -- Business in the Pittsburgh district last week dropped to its lowest level since March, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. The bureau's seasonally adjusted index of business stood at 185.5 per cent of the 1935-39 average last week.

Federal Judge Harold R. Medina reserved decision yesterday on defense motions to throw out the Government's case in the trial of eleven Communist leaders on charges of conspiracy to teach and advocate violent overthrow of the Government.

A special elevator, which will enable Col. Elliott White Springs, president of the Springs Cotton Mills, Lancaster, S.C., to move his entire office from a cupola on the top story to the directors' room on the third floor, is one of the features of an office-laboratory building planned by the company, it was announced yesterday.

TOKYO, May 20 -- The Soviet Union's announcement that it would return all Japanese war prisoners to their homeland by November, "95,000 in all," was received here with incredulity and resentment. According to Japanese figures, the Soviet Union still holds 398,743 Japanese and the Chinese Communists retain 60,316 more.

A charge that Mayor O'Dwyer had suppressed reports of fraud in the city administration and had interfered with their investigation was denied vigorously yesterday by the Mayor, Commissioner of Investigation John M. Murtagh and District Attorney Frank S. Hogan.

ATLANTA, May 20 (AP) -- The South's plan for regional education was in effect today as contracts were signed by the Regional Council for Education with the Medical College of Virginia, Louisiana State University, Emory University and Vanderbilt University for medical and dental training.

The news has emerged from Washington that Representative Kelley, key Administration figure on the House Labor Committee, has been detached from duty for a five-weeks' assignment abroad. The word "emerged" is used advisedly. The fact that Mr. Kelley had been appointed a member of the United States delegation to the International Labor Organization conference at Geneva was not announced by the White House.

The presentation of Verdi's "Aida" by Arturo Toscanini and the NBC Symphony Orchestra was adjudged the outstanding musical event of the year in the sixth annual National Radio Poll, conducted by Musical America magazine. Mr. Toscanini also won first place in the Symphony Conductor (Regular) category for his direction of that orchestra, and the special award to the network most faithful to serious music went to the National Broadcasting Company.

GENEVA, May 20 -- The trend of investment in Europe is "inconsistent with the efficient and economical use of resources," Paul R. Porter, United States delegate, said today in the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe.

THE TIMES editorial of May 7 "A Victory for Education" is a superbly reasoned statement of the rights of American citizens to equal educational opportunity. Change one word in the final paragraph of the editorial and you give the core of the Catholic stand on federal aid to all recognized American schools.

If you belong to the high school crowd and like to give parties, then a new booklet, chock-full of ideas for gala occasions, is for you. Packed into twenty-four brightly illustrated pages are suggestions on menus, games to play and appropriate table decorations.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 20 -- In a speech today to his own Elite Guards Division, Marshal Tito said that the struggle for power between East and West would not result in war in the near future but added that "that does not mean that there will never be war."

PITTSBURGH, May 20 (AP) -- Bill Werle, southpaw rookie, pitched the Pirates to a 2-1 victory over the Braves tonight before a crowd of 29,807. His long double in the fourth batted in what proved to be the winning run.

CHICAGO, May 20 -- Price changes in the grain markets were rather rapid on the Board of Trade today as evening-up operations continued in the May deliveries. Trading in the latter will cease at the close tomorrow. When trading started this morning there were uncompleted contracts for about 11,000,000 bushels of May wheat, 7,000,000 bushels of corn, 5,500,000 of oats and 5,000,000 of soybeans.

H. Chamberlain writes you, under date of May 8, advocating mass production of housing by private industry in place of subsidized housing at the general expense of the taxpayers. He said such a plan requires the cooperation of a "small group of industrialists of national stature."

Democrats opposed to the present leadership of Tammany viewed with suspicion yesterday overtures from members of the present dominant group in the Hall to drop Borough President Hugo E. Rogers as leader and name someone else.
LONDON, May 20 (AP) -- Here is the text of the British Foreign Office statement concerning the Soviet proposals on Greece:

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., May 20 -- At the annual meeting today George D. Mead of Glens Falls was elected president, succeeding G. Perry Crawford, to head the Glens Falls group, which consists of the Glens Falls Insurance Company, the Glens Falls Indemnity Company, the Commerce Insurance Company and the Glens Falls Corporation.

Mid-May marks a change of season for gardens and, therefore, of flowers to cut for arrangements. Peonies, iris and the more substantial perennials are gradually displacing the bulbs whose display is almost finished.

In ceremonies marred by a steady rainfall the first phase of this city's observance of National Maritime Day was held yesterday at noon, on the steps of the Custom House. The attendance at the exercises was held down by the inclement weather, but many hundreds listened to the celebration from the windows of nearby office buildings.

The United States Trust Company's pending offering of $18,663,000 of outstanding tax-exempt bonds owned by the late Eugene Higgins, noted before World War I as a sportsman, will bring forth bids from bond houses in all parts of the country, both singly and in syndicates, it was predicted in underwriting circles here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -- An agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation testified today that Valentin A. Gubitchev, 32 years old, Russian espionage suspect, "took a long look over his shoulder" and then broke into a run while being trailed by FBI men in New York.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -- The marine economy of the Great Lakes deserves and needs special treatment because of wartime sacrifices, Harry C. Brockel, traffic director of Milwaukee, told a House committee today.
LOS ANGELES, May 20 -- Fabri interest takes top position in the new Fall openings of California manufacturers.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The first House hearing on compulsory health insurance opened today. The Senate will start its fourth hearing Monday on this subject, which Senator Robert F. Wagner, Democrat, of New York, advanced ten years ago.

PHILADELPHIA, May 20 (UP) -- Blinding rain swept the Whitemarsh Valley Country Club course today after part of a field of 122 teed off, causing a 24-hour postponement of the second round of the Philadelphia Inquirer $15,000 golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The Department of Justice is investigating 833 suspected alien subversives but under existing law might not be able to enforce deportation orders against them, Attorney General Tom Clark declared today.

The Appellate Division, Second Department, has created a Calendar Classification and Control Term in the Brooklyn and Queens Supreme Courts in a move to expedite the handling of negligence cases on the congested calendars of the courts, it was announced yesterday.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 20 -- Communist activity in Jordan has reached a pitch during the last two months that has seriously alarmed the authorities there, a reliable Arab informant reported today from Amman.
An unusual manifestation of interfaith practice was witnessed last evening on the lower East Side.

ST. LOUIS, May 20 -- The two runs which meant victory last night were far from enough for the Dodgers tonight as the Cardinals evened the series by outscoring them, 6 -- 2, before the season's largest crowd at Sportsman's Park -- 22,062 paid.

ROME, May 20 -- The Italian Communist party implicitly admitted today that more than 300,000 members had failed to renew their 1948 membership thus far, in a claim that on April 30 its total membership had reached the 2,000,000 mark.

VIENNA, May 20 -- Unqualified recognition of Austrian sovereignty, the creation of an Austrian army and the immediate evacuation of Austrian territory by the Big Four as soon as the army is created, were demanded by Austria's Foreign Minister today as steps to be taken by the occupation powers if the Foreign Ministers in Paris do not settle their differences on Austria.

The organization and staffing of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (better known as the World Bank) was completed in June, 1946, but it was nearly a year more before the institution made its first loan. The delay was caused by the fact that the Bank had originally been set up along political lines.
CAMBRIDGE, England, May 20 (Reuters) -- Spin-bowler G. Rabone paved the way for the New Zealand cricket tourists' victory over Cambridge University at Cambridge today, by an innings and 56 runs.

CINCINNATI, May 20 -- Although it is still difficult to reconcile the thing with the pre-season estimates of the sad sort of pitching the Giants were dragging into the pennant race, Monte Kennedy did it again today.
