LONG BEACH, Calif., May 20 -- A twelve-square-mile section of the earth's surface that includes part of Long Beach harbor, part of one of the country's richest oil fields, most of the $100,000,000 Terminal Island naval station and shipyard, and major industrial installations, is sinking into the ocean at a rate of as much as two inches a month.

RUTLAND, Vt., May 20 (AP) -- Three Army combat veterans of World War II were in Vermont jails today, with little hope of early release, because they are unable to satisfy court judgments in automobile accident cases.

PHILADELPHIA, May 20 -- Seven breweries, three of them nationally known are charged with conspiracy to fix prices in violation of the Federal anti-trust laws in a $1,050,000 damage suit filed in the United States District Court here today.

The Supreme Court decision in the Terminiello case is of great interest and importance, but not primarily for the reasons popularly ascribed. The case has aroused intense interest largely because of its free-speech aspects; yet on reflection it would seem that the decision alters neither the safeguards of the doctrine of free speech nor the safeguards against abuse of that doctrine.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The State Department announced today that the United States had rejected Russian suggestions looking to a compromise settlement of the Greek situation by taking it out of the United Nations and placing it in the hands of the great powers for negotiation.
LONDON, May 20 -- Britain's trade deficit was more than doubled last month, the Board of Trade stated today. The principal factor was a dive in exports.

Just when the picture begins to look really bright both for the fresh and salt water anglers, along comes the weather man with a collection of isobars, fronts and pressure areas and no one gets a chance to go off fishing.

Production costs are preventing bedding manufacturers from carrying out plans to reduce mattresses before the end of the current quarter, Irving Weisglass, president, Eclipse Sleep Products, Inc., disclosed yesterday. He said cotton linters not only are holding firm but have increased slightly in the last few weeks contrary to bedding industry expectations and ticking costs are stable after a steady downward trend which ended late in March.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 20 -- Dodging under an umbrella between strokes, Dick Remsen Jr. of the Garden City Golf Club managed to elude the elements satisfactorily and at the same time defeat John Nicholson of the Garden City Country Club, 4 and 2, to gain the semi-final round of the Walter J. Travis Memorial Tourney today.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 20 -- Champion Carillon Colin of Puttencove, black standard poodle belonging to the Puttencove Kennels of Manchester, Mass., went to best in show today in the fifteenth and biggest specialty of the Poodle Club of America on the soggy grounds of the Garden City Hotel.
The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary sailed for Cherbourg and Southampton at 1:40 P.M. yesterday leaving three breathless would-be passengers stranded on the pier.

Argument before the City Planning Commission at City Hall yesterday disclosed the intention of Borough President James A. Burke of Queens to bring before the Board of Estimate a proposal for the construction of proposed Junior High School 190 at Booth Street, Sixty-eighth Drive and Yellowstone Boulevard, Forest Hills.
MOSCOW, May 20 (AP) -- The Soviet Repatriation Authority said today that all remaining Japanese war prisoners in Russia would be repatriated to Japan during the period from May to November.

Advertising in newspapers fifty-two cities during April totaled 205,466,027 lines, a gain of 4.2 per cent over the like month last year, it was reported yesterday by Media Records. A gain of 3.5 per cent was recorded for the first four months of this year.
WILMINGTON, Del., May 20 (AP) -- Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman of General Motors Corporation, predicted today that there would be plenty of new cars by the end of this year.
WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -- Washington clustered six of its eight hits in the first three innings tonight to defeat the St. Louis Browns, 5 -- 3, behind the seven-hit pitching of Sid Hudson.

Surveys under Government auspices are being quietly made in trade quarters here to ascertain why the volume of imports from European countries aided by the Economic Cooperation Administration is not larger, it was learned here yesterday.

Paul Makushak, the 32-year-old Brooklyn "hermit" who was released April 26 from a walled-in closet he had occupied for ten years, and his mother, Mrs. Anna Makushak, 58, have been adjudged mentally ill and will be committed to a State institution for treatment, it was learned yesterday.

Irwin J. Golden has been appointed office manager and controller of Jack Braunstein, Inc., resident buying office of 225 West Thirty-fourth Street. He was previously controller for Adler Child's of Dayton and Biers Bros. of Niagara Falls.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Economy efforts took a fourth straight beating in the Senate today as members rejected, in succession, proposals to slash 40 per cent, 10 per cent, or even 5 per cent from the $751,440,000 Army Civil Functions Appropriations Bill.

The end of another week of heaviness in stocks and firmness in bonds brings to underwriting houses in the new capital market an interval of inactivity which is not likely to be terminated until June. Syndicates succeeded during the past week in shortening current inventories of term corporate bonds with no new issues of this type scheduled until after the turn of the month.

EVANSTON, Ill., May 20 (AP) -- The Western Conference today voted that Michigan State College be accepted as a tenth member and that it begin conference competition in the academic year 1950-51, excepting in football. The new member is eligible to participate in conference business affairs immediately.

While average retail grocery sales throughout the state are down in comparison with last year, some stores have managed to maintain volume despite the trend, A.F. Guckenberger, executive secretary of the New York State Food Merchants Association, reported yesterday.
MILLEDGEVILLE, Ga., May 20 (AP) -- Six armed convicts, described as dangerous, overpowered their guards here today and escaped in a blaze of gunfire.

The meaning of Christianity in rural life will be emphasized tomorrow in churches all over the country. The day will be known as Rural Life Sunday for Protestants and Roman Catholics. For the latter it will be the first of three "Rogation Days," when special prayers will be said to appease God's anger at man's transgressions; to ask protection in calamities and blessing of the coming harvest.

On the basis of current wool prices, worsteds for next spring should show a decline of 10 per cent, it was asserted in the trade yesterday. Worsteds for late fall delivery should also reflect the lower quotations on finer grades of imported wool, according to apparel manufacturers.

BUFFALO, May 20 -- The General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A. today asked its sister communion in the South to join with it in seeking a country-wide unity of the various branches of American Presbyterianism.

BERLIN, Saturday, May 21 -- The Western sectors of Berlin, barely over the Russians' eleven months' siege of the city, were faced with a new threat of a railroad blockade when a strike call by the non-Communist Railway Workers Union took effect at midnight.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Registration statements covering more than $30,000,000 of new financing were filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by five companies.

Eleven years ago today France warned that if Germany crossed the Czechoslovakian border it would mean war! And eleven years ago at the same time public-spirited citizens in New York wrote a different kind of history.

LONDON, May 20 -- As warm and appealing as she was in "The Heiress" in New York, Wendy Hiller achieved a new triumph on her return to the London stage tonight, playing the title role in Ronald Gow's dramatization of H.G. Wells' "Ann Veronica."

Federal Judge Samuel H. Kaufman reserved decision yesterday as arguments were completed in the Government's anti-trust case against two associations of United States alkali exporters, Imperial Chemical Industries, Ltd., of Great Britain, and a number of other corporations.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The North Atlantic treaty could and probably would be quickly thrust to the top of the Senate's calendar for ratification if the Big Four Foreign Ministers' Conference in Paris should take any turn where American negotiators believed they urgently needed quick action.

LINCOLN, Neb., May 20 (AP) -- Missouri, the defending champion, and Nebraska warmed up for their expected two-way battle for the Big Seven conference track title by qualifying nineteen and fifteen men, respectively, in preliminaries today.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- President Truman pressed a golden telegraph key in his office today, starting a new generator that made Grand Coulee Dam, 3,000 miles away, the greatest single power producer in the world.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Unemployment insurance benefits paid to workers covered by State agencies in April declined $15,652,000 from the March total, Robert C. Goodwin, director of the Bureau of Employment Security, reported today.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (UP) -- Gordon Gray, Acting Secretary of the Army, extended today the stays of execution for six former Nazi troopers sentenced to death for having taken part in the Malmedy massacre.

The students of the Abraham Lincoln High School of Brooklyn have presented the sixteenth annual Lincoln Award to 90-year-old Professor John Dewey "for distinguished service to the City of New York." In previous years the medallion has been given to such outstanding figures in public life as Samuel Seabury, Lillian Wald, Fiorello La Guardia, Robert Moses, Walter Damrosch, Mary Simkhovitch, Eleanor Roosevelt and Bernard Baruch.
Masters of ersatz materials, some Germans in the Soviet zone are now using floor wax and shoe cream as food, especially for sandwiches and roasting.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was firm yesterday and final prices were 2 to 10 points net higher.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson, with President Truman on hand to wish him luck, departed this afternoon for the Paris conference of Foreign Ministers, which will seek a settlement on Germany to lay the groundwork for a firmer approach to world peace.
LONDON, May 20 -- Week-end influences restricted business in the stock markets here today and a distinctly easier tone developed.

The Economic Mobilization course that 280 Army, Navy and Air Force Reserve officers and civilians have attended at 30 Rockefeller Plaza for the last two weeks closed yesterday on the theme: "May you never have to use the information you have received."

Lee Shubert, accompanied by three associates and carrying six large folders, went to the office of John M. Murtagh, Commissioner of Investigation, yesterday afternoon to explain the sale and allotment of tickets to "South Pacific," the musical now playing to sell-out audiences at the Majestic Theatre.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Two agreements of major importance to railroad labor peace have been signed by all the Class I carriers and the five unions representing practically all train and engine service employes.

Virtually all of the $50,000,000 or more in Argentine overdrafts on banks in the New York Federal Reserve District have been worked off since the Argentine Government clamped down on dollar transfers two years ago, it was learned in international banking circles here yesterday.

SHANGHAI, Saturday, May 21 -- Chinese Nationalist forces prepared yesterday to evacuate Shanghai. Rapid progress was being made toward such a move, although the city itself was still inside the ring of Nationalist outposts. There was no Communist pressure on the thinning Government line.

Pointing out that price declines in rayon yarn and staple have been anticipated in price cuts already granted, textile manufacturers yesterday indicated that they will make no further voluntary mark-downs as a result of the recent viscose yarn reductions.

CLEVELAND, May 20 -- John L. Lewis, who has been in and out of the American Federation of Labor twice before, tried to give the revolving door another turn today, but the AFL executive council unanimously rejected the terms he set for re-affiliation.

The visitor, carrying a bushel basket with lid firmly attached, said he was looking for the Wood, Field and Stream Department, but that as long as he was here in this corner he would rest for a few minutes if there were no objections.

FRANKFORT, Germany, May 20 -- The Bonn Constitution has now been ratified by the required two-thirds majority of the eleven Western German states, but the proposed electoral law for the election of the new government's first legislature was forced to the government level today for decision by the United States, British and French foreign ministers in Paris.

Studies that may point the way to the prevention of coronary thrombosis, one of the most serious forms of heart disease, are reported in the current issue of New York Medicine, the official publication of the Medical Society of the County of New York.

TRENTON, N.J., May 20 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll today set May 31 for return of the New Jersey Legislature in special session to consider low-rent housing legislation and reciprocal measures with New York State to forestall such accidents as the Holland Tunnel explosion of last Friday in which sixty-six persons were injured.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Applicants for Atomic Energy Commission fellowships will be required to sign oaths of allegiance to the Government of the United States, or the fellowship program will be terminated, David E. Lilienthal, chairman of the AEC, assured a Senate Appropriations subcommittee today.

There was no questioning Robert Villemain's superiority over Pete Mead of Grand Rapids in the main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night. The Frenchman, loser of his first two fights in the Garden, made good on his third attempt by earning the unanimous verdict over his American rival.

LONDON, May 20 -- Winston Churchill, in an outspoken attack on the Labor Government tonight, pledged that if the Conservatives won in the coming general election they would immediately repeal the steel nationalization measure. [A bill to nationalize the steel industry is pending in Parliament.]

EVANSTON, Ill., May 20 (AP) -- Minnesota and Indiana, expected to fight it out for the team title, set the qualifying pace today in nine preliminary tests for the forty-ninth Big Nine outdoor track and field meet tomorrow.

A sewing machine so capable it can sew two or four-hole buttons on a dress in a matter of seconds has been finding its way this spring to local stores from Italy, where it is made by one of that country's largest producers of machinery.

George Robertson, a signal man at the elevated West Farms station of the IRT subway in the Bronx, was mildly astonished when he saw a small, purposeful-looking dog traveling south on the north-bound tracks yesterday morning. It was 8:15 A.M., a busy time.

After operating trains since 1885, first by steam and later by electricity, the Staten Island Rapid Transit Railway now wants to discontinue passenger service on its three lines out of St. George, it became known yesterday.
PARIS, May 20 -- Germany, the unbidden guest, the victim or the victor of the meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers opening here Monday, is divided on her own basic problem -- unification.

LONDON, May 20 -- The Britons' rush for candy has been so heavy that C.R.M. Cannon of the National Federation of Wholesale Confectioners appealed to the public today to limit its buying to five ounces weekly for each person.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- A young veteran's description of the manner in which the Civil Aeronautics Board ordered his successful air freight business out of existence today prompted Senator Edwin C. Johnson, Democrat of Colorado, chairman of the Senate Commerce Committee, publicly to accuse the board of "flagrant discrimination."

OKLAHOMA CITY, May 20 -- The Southern Baptist Convention today took the unprecedented step of naming a Northern city, Chicago, as the site of its 1950 convention, and added the Northwestern states of Oregon and Washington to the "SBC area," composed of the District of Columbia and twenty predominantly Southern and Southwestern states with recognized Southern Baptist "constituencies."

ELIZABETH, N.J., May 20 (AP) -- Normal service was restored by mid-evening on the Pennsylvania Railroad tracks near here, after rain-soaked workmen spent all day clearing the wreckage of a derailment.

From his hometown, Saratoga Springs, N.Y., Monty Woolley yesterday confirmed a report that he is seriously considering staging a play for Broadway next season. What the name of the play is, who wrote it and who might be the producer, Mr. Woolley would not say, declaring that the deal is just in the discussion stage.
Antique French provincial furnishings, the first of Elinor Merrell's importations since the war, have just been put on display at her shop at 40 East Fifty-seventh Street.

CROTON-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., May 20 -- Westchester's war on poison ivy was opened today at the county camps for children on Croton Point, but rain suddenly converted the assault into a rout and left the poisonous creeper a temporary winner.

"Paul Gauguin: Letters to His Wife and Friends," edited by Maurice Malingue, arranged to give a picture of the man and the artist, will be issued on Wednesday by the World Publishing Company. The volume includes several hundred letters, many of which had never been published before, that had been written from France, Oceania and Tahiti.

The thirteenth annual report of the Rome Cable Corporation issued yesterday for the fiscal year ended on March 31 shows net earnings of $1,115,960, or $2.78 a common share. This compares with $1,152,579, or $2.83 a share, for the preceding fiscal year, which included copper profit of $115,000.

Stock prices slid moderately lower yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, extending losses for the fourth consecutive day. Attempts to rally the market made slight headway as sales dropped to 740,000 shares from 840,000 on Thursday. Losses ranging from fractions to a point or more were liberally sprinkled throughout the list at the close.

Coffee futures declined in slow trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Scattered trade selling depressed contract "S" 4 to 19 points. Contract "D" also was easier on thin volume. Final prices were 16 to 20 points lower.

Fred W. Hooper's Olympia, leader to the stretch in the Kentucky Derby, and Crispin Oglebay's Noble Impulse, leader to the stretch in the Preakness, are among seven 3-year-olds scheduled to get some exercise at Belmont Park today in the seventy-fourth edition of the Withers Stakes.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Average primary market prices advanced 0.1 per cent in the week ended May 17, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index was 156.0 per cent of the 1926 average, 0.6 per cent below four weeks ago and 4.8 per cent lower than the comparable week in 1948.
Never was the old adage "The Power to tax is the power to destroy" in as great need of being impressed upon the consciousness of the people of this country as at present.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, May 20 -- A circular letter to all Czechoslovak Roman Catholic clergy signed by Archbishop Josef Beran of Prague in the name of the Czechoslovak Bishops has disclosed that the Bishops' conference at Dolni Smokovec in Slovakia was broken up on March 22 by the discovery of concealed microphones in a conference room.

Paul Delbarre, an 18-year-old French youth, arrived here yesterday on the French liner De Grasse, the guest as long as immigration laws will permit, of George R. Miller, of Woodbine, Pa., one of ten former Allied airmen saved by the boy and his family after being shot down during the war.

Today's events: New York Folklore Society concert, McMillin Theatre, Columbia University, 2 P.M.; Bob Wilber Jazz Band, Carl Fischer Concert Hall, 3; Concert and Art Exhibition, High School of Music and Art, 7:45; "Lucia di Lammermoor,"

The score for each meeting of the U.N. General Assembly is so mixed that it can be chalked up as success or failure, depending on which side of the ledger is added up. The session in Paris last autumn left many issues hanging in the air, including the Berlin blockade, but it achieved agreement on the first international convention on human rights in history.

LONDON, May 20 -- The British bridge team led the United States team by 710 points after 32 boards of play in the first session of a match at Crockford's Club here tonight for the Crowninshield Cup, symbolic of the European-American Contract Bridge Team-of-Four supremacy.
Dr. Alexander M. Dushkin, recently appointed director of undergraduate studies at the Hebrew University in Jerusalem, presented yesterday a program of reorganization along American lines.

Peter Harisiades, Greek-American Communist writer, was arrested yesterday and taken to Ellis Island to await deportation to Greece. He was seized at his home, 392 East Fourth Street, Brooklyn, the Immigration and Naturalization Service announced.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 20 -- Joseph L. Snider, Professor of Business Economics, Harvard University, said today that while further deterioration of business is to be expected, "happily, it does not appear likely that we shall have one of our severe depressions."

Again the Community Service Society of New York, 105 East Twenty-second Street, has turned out an annual report telling of a backbreaking job well done. And as usual, in these times, the statistics included in the report tell of a deficit which the organization could not avoid and still do the job required of it.

DETROIT, May 20 -- The Ford Motor Company, flatly rejecting a demand by the United Automobile Workers, CIO, that a new contract be negotiated while the so-called speed-up strike is in progress, met a prompt rejoinder from the union today that unfair labor charges would be filed with the National Labor Relations Board on Monday.

Twenty-six nurses were graduated yesterday from the Harlem Hospital School of Nursing at commencement exercises held at the Mother African Methodist Episcopal Church Zion, 140 West 137th Street. Dr. Morris A. Jacobs, Regional General Medical Superintendent of the Department of Hospitals, presided.

ALBANY, May 20 -- The Board of Regents said today that no purpose would be served by granting requests for public hearings on the merits of the 1949 Feinberg law requiring the removal from teaching and supervisory positions in the public schools of persons belonging to subversive organizations.
CAMDEN, N.J., May 20 (AP) -- Veteran Jockey Johnny Gilbert was the riding star today at Garden State Park, where he booted home three straight winners, including the featured event victor.

Modes of transportation used by "Forty-niners of two centuries" were utilized yesterday to further the efforts of the Treasury Department to sell $127,000,000 worth of Series E Savings Bonds in this state, beginning last Monday and ending on June 30.

DETROIT, May 20 (AP) -- Hudson Motors' spring sales continue to climb, according to A.E. Barit, president of the company. He told a stockholders' meeting today that April deliveries totaled 14,496 units, a 34 per cent increase over April of last year.
The following books of a religious and inspirational nature have been published recently:

PARIS, May 20 -- Diplomatic sources reported tonight that this week's conferences among representatives of the United States, Britain and France had produced an agreement on a united-front policy toward the Soviet Union in the meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers.

PHILADELPHIA, May 20 (AP) -- Ferris Fain's single with one out drove in Eddie Joost with the winning run in the tenth inning as the Athletics advanced within half a game of second place in defeating the Tigers, 2 -- 1, at Shibe Park tonight.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 20 -- The United States told the United Nations today that it was fully prepared to step up highway, school and other public construction to high levels to prevent the spread of unemployment resulting from a contraction of private business activity.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 20 (AP) -- The International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes signed individual contracts today with the ten major movie studios. Roy Brewer, international representative, said that the agreements gave the union "sole jurisdiction over all machine and mechanical work in the industry."

SEOUL, Korea, May 20 -- President Syngman Rhee told his weekly press conference today that he disagreed sharply with Secretary of State Dean Acheson's opinion that discussions leading to Pacific pact were untimely.

DEERFIELD, Mass., May 20 -- To commemorate the 150th anniversary of the founding of Deerfield Academy here, faculty wives and townspeople opened the old houses today and dressed in period costumes to give visiting educators and guests a picture of early American life.

Your editorial "New York's Next Mayor" overlooks the obvious lesson of the La Guardia interlude. The opposition to the Democratic organization was able to win three consecutive elections only because it had a candidate who, far from fitting your prescription of a business man concentrating on efficiency and economy, had made politics his career.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Louis Johnson, Secretary of Defense, created today a new inter-service Civilian Components Policy Board to make and direct policies affecting the relationship of the National Guard and Organized Reserve units to over-all national defense.

William Corcoran Jr., the Brooklyn dealer in used cars who allegedly perpetrated a $1,000,000 swindle against would-be automobile purchasers was depicted yesterday as a "benefactor rather than a malefactor" in the automobile market.
MOSCOW, May 20 -- New evidence of interest in the solution of outstanding European problems on the part of the Soviet Union was seen today in the Soviet statement on the Greek question.

"Big Jack," last of the late Wallace Beery's long series of starring pictures for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, will have its local premiere today at the Gotham. Richard Conte, Marjorie Main, Edward Arnold and Vanessa Brown play the leading featured roles.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., May 20 -Judge William J. Shea of Superior Court today dismissed a motion to invalidate the election of directors of the Norwalk Tire and Rubber Company, Norwalk, Conn. The election took place last Jan. 17 at the annual meeting of stockholders.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 20 -- The increase in the rate of bankruptcies during recent months seems to be leveling off, S. Clarence McGuire, vice president, American Credit Indemnity Company of New York, said here today.
WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -- The armed forces told Congress today that lack of adequate housing for service men's families was jeopardizing national defense efforts seriously.
Courtesy at corners to avoid death at the crossroads was urged yesterday for motorists and pedestrians by the Automobile Club of New York.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, May 20 -- Ernest Vesey, chairman of the Finance Committee of the Assembly, was almost shouted down today when he suggested that the time had come for Bermuda's currency to be linked to the United States dollar.

The New York Library Association began its annual conference yesterday in Syracuse under circumstances more auspicious for this state's public libraries than have ever existed before. A passage in Governor Dewey's radio speech to the people, in early March, is the basis for confidence that the state is ready at last to recognize its obligations to the people in respect to libraries.

Investigation Commissioner John M. Murtagh renewed yesterday his year-long study of milk prices by serving subpoenas on three major milk distributors. His action calling on them to produce books and records from Feb. 1 to May 19 dealing with rebates and discounts followed by a day a State Court of Appeals decision upholding his right to subpoena such records.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 20 -- Dr. Brock Chisholm, director general of the World Health Organization, expressed the hope today that a "greatly increased" global health program for next year would bring the Soviet Union, Byelorussia and the Ukraine back into the United Nations organization.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 20 (UP) -- Acting President Mamerto Urriolagoitia organized a ten-man Cabinet today. Eight of the Ministers are leaders of the Government's Republican Socialist Union party and two are Independents. They will be sworn in Sunday.

College rowing offers its last full program of the season today preparatory to the New London and Poughkeepsie regattas in late June. After today, only the Harvard-Cornell races on Lake Cayuga May 28 remain in the Earl until the Crimson rows Yale on the Thames June 24 and all the other powers meet on the Hudson June 25.

This is the time of year when college students begin to steel their nerves for the traditional horrors of final examinations. For some students at New York University, however, the seasonal battle of wits with professors holds few terrors. The reason? The students prepare their own examinations.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The young men of the country should be relieved from the obligation of registering for selective service unless the funds for the organization are adequate to make it function efficiently, Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, director, told a Senate appropriations subcommittee today.
WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -- Following is the text of the State Department's statement today on the Soviet "peace proposals" for the Greek civil war:

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Not-withstanding the character of a current report by the International Printing Pressmen's Union, the Senate Labor Committee will continue a vigorous investigation of the manner in which the late George L. Berry used the union funds, Senator Wayne L. Morse, Republican, of Oregon, said today.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 20 -- A thorough study and revision of standards for public libraries was demanded at the opening of a three-day conference of the New York Library Association here today.

The National Broadcasting Company has singed an exclusive contract to broadcast and televise the Cotton Bowl football games on Nes Year's Day in Dallas, Tex. The games previously had been reported over the Manual network. The contract marks the beginning of an effort by the NBC to recapture broadcasting rights to major sports contests, the network last season having lost the Rose Bowl football games to CBS.
LONDON, May 20 (UP) -- The castles that Americans built for the Philp family have vanished into thin air. The neighbors jeer, and a cockney waif named Elizabeth remains a pauper.
LONDON, May 20 -- To Soviet proposals for stopping the civil war in Greece, the British Government i replied today that no negotiations could be undertaken "behind the back of the Greek Government."

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Not-withstanding the character of a current report by the International Printing Pressmen's Union, the Senate Labor Committee will continue a vigorous investigation of the manner in which the late George L. Berry used the union funds, Senator Wayne L. Morse, Republican, of Oregon, said today.

CLEVELAND, May 21 -- The International Brotherhood of Teamsters, AFL, has scrapped its three-month-old peace pact with the Retail Clerks International Association, AFL, in the organization of department store workers, Dave Beck, executive vice president of the teamsters, disclosed here today.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were quiet yesterday and final prices were 2 to 13 points net lower.

HAVING made five films for Universal - International in the last twelve months, Stephen McNally was doubly grateful for a short respite here, even though it entailed exploitation in connection with "The Lady Gambles," in which he shares stellar billing with Barbara Stanwyck and Robert Preston.

CHICAGO, May 21 -- Electricity output in Chicago for the week ended May 14 registered the first decline in comparison with year-before figures since August, 1946. Output for the May 14 week was 215,454,000 kilowatt hours, a decrease from the same period last year of 1.5 per cent.

LONDON, May 21 -- A plea was made to the Liberals today to join the Conservatives in an anti-Socialist united front for the next general election. Simultaneously, the Liberals themselves attempted to woo trade unionists away from the Labor party.
The American Theatre Wing, noted for its stage door canteens during the war, will undertake next Wednesday a novel method of raising money to carry on its work for veterans in the hospitals.

BERLIN, Sunday, May 22 -- After twenty-four hours of bloody violence, growing in intensity as the night wore on, the Communist-dominated Free German Trade Union Federation indicated the first signs of surrender in the Berlin railway strike early this morning.

Low-price dress manufacturers are in a jam on deliveries, and cannot promise full summer shipments before June 15 to 20, if then, a canvass of the market disclosed last week. Buyers crowded into showrooms seeking quick shipments.
Howard Taubman's studied treatment of octogenarian Arturo Toscanini and his undimmed passion for the ultimate in musical interpretation is a generous tribute.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 21 -- The election of Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. to Congress from New York had its effect this week on the thinking of many West Coast residents, who could not help considering the victory with another Roosevelt in mind -- James Roosevelt, the eldest son of the late President.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- Twenty-one Americans will be decorated for war services by Sir Oliver Franks, the British Ambassador, at an embassy ceremony on Tuesday. The following are included:

EASTON, Pa., May 21 -- A drive to impress business, industry and the public generally with the role played by independent colleges in the battle for the preservation of human liberties has been initiated by the Greater Lafayette Committee.

THE secular illusion to which Mr. Davies (author of "Down Peacock's Feathers" and other books) addresses himself in the present volume is that of trust in human nature and its ability to abolish evil. He calls this an "obsession of self-confidence." founded on post-Renaissance materialism.

Robert Trumbull's "Fact Invades India's Troubled Land" is not wholly fair to an institution or to a body of men. The Indian princes had their foibles, to be sure, but they wielded power in various ways and did not only evil.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (UP) -- The Interior Department today pinned a silver medal for meritorious service on Thomas P. O'Neill, a minor employe, because, it said, he is "one of the unsung heroes who are the backbone of the Federal service."

In retail promotions here last week retailers featured cotton dresses, plastic raincoats, synthletic and cultured pearls, nylon dresses, organdy dresses and linen hats, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the Retail News Bureau, Inc.

PARIS, May 21 -- By a vote of 391 to 210, the National Assembly tonight passed the Government's bill that changes Cochin China from a French colony to an autonomous territory with the independent status of the other Indo-Chinese states within the French Commonwealth.

The magnitude of the job that lies ahead before the children of this country can be assured a good public school education was pointed up last week in a comprehensive survey issued by the Council of State Governments. The council is composed of state commissions on interstate cooperation, whose members usually are legislators and administrative officers.

WASHINGTON. May 21 -- President Truman's welfare state, the Republican-Southern Democrat coalition in Congress, the North Atlantic pact, and other current subjects were vehicles for satire when the Gridiron Club staged its spring dinner before the President and 500 other guests at the Hotel Statler tonight.

Six senior high school students discussed the topic "Does UNESCO Point the Cultural Path to Peace?" at the Youth Forum yesterday in Times Hail, 240 West Forty-fourth Street. Broadcast over Station WQXR, the forum was sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

LANGLEY AIR BASE, Va., May 21 -- The American aircraft manufacturing industry could go into almost immediate production of supersonic planes capable of combat in the event of a war emergency, according to John Stack, deputy chief of research for the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics.

PARIS, May 21 -- Here, in what will be for the next few weeks the diplomatic capital of the West, there will be many anxious thoughts about what is happening on the other side of the world, where the Chinese Communists are driving toward control of a country that has more people than are represented here by the Foreign Ministers of the four great powers.

WITH the motor boat he had salvaged from an old wreck, young Doug Niles looked forward to a pleasant, profitable summer on a Montana lake. But trouble appeared in the person of Marion Chadwick, a hostile vacationer, and in the form of strange happenings on eerie Dark Island, where mysterious lights glowed at night.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., May 21 -- For the fortieth time in its fifty-year history the Bethlehem Bach Choir today presented in its entirety Johann Sebastian Bach's mighty choral work, the Mass in B Minor, in Packer Memorial Chapel at Lehigh University.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Americans will eat more pork this year than in either of the last two years, the Department of Agriculture predicted today.
BRITISH film production seems to have emerged temporarily from its spell in the doldrums, and, on paper at least, the prospects look fair for a summer of reasonable, if limited, activity.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 21 -- Assailed as fantastic and visionary and defended as "the greatest project ever conceived" for development of California, a nine-year-old but sometime quiescent plan for altering the face of the San Francisco Bay area has just been brought back to public attention.

BROADWAY'S oldest cold war -- the battle of the producers -- seemed to have ended last week when seventeen of the city's major producers held a love feast and vowed to stop nipping at one another and the theatre that feeds them.

A GENERATION has passed since these two essays were first published. "Les Peintres Cubistes" appeared in 1913, at the close of the heoric first five years of Cubism. Written in a poet's evocative and oblique language, it was the first authentic statement of the point of view of Picasso, Braque and the intimate circle which they attracted.

CHATHAM, Mass. -- Cape Cod waters will soon resound with the swish of rod and reel. From Buzzards Bay to Provincetown, disciples of Izaak Walton will swarm over the picturesque peninsula seeking anything from a scrappy mackerel to the mighty tuna.

This week-end is signalizing the opening attack of Operation Speedboat in what by a wide margin is certain to be the most exciting year in the long history of dare-deviltry on American waterways. Two preliminary tune-ups are being held 3,000 miles apart in preparation for the famous Gold Cup Classic, which will be held nearly two months earlier than usual, on July 2 at Detroit.

The coming Foreign Ministers' Conference in Paris may be the turning point of the "cold war." The meeting will either be inconclusive, thus leaving unabated a crisis in the East-West relations which will inevitably result in the much dreaded "hot" war, when the time factor ceases to constitute an advantage; or it may possibly produce the first real agreement between the West and the Kremlin, and result eventually in a mutually profitable modus vivendi.

Gerhart Eisler, who was caught a week ago Saturday in England in an attempt to escape "persecution'' by the United States Government, is that twentieth-century phenomenon -- the professional, international, Communist revolutionary.

BUENOS AIRES -- Ask for a tourist guide in any large Latin - American capital, through one of the international agencies or big hotels, and instead of a sinister mustachioed character in a wilted white linen suit, as likely as not you will draw an attractive young lady trained to solve the traveler's problems.
EVANSTON, Ill., May 21 -- Minnesota's Gophers hurdled their way, literally and figuratively, to their first Western Conference outdoor track title in history today as one new meet record was set.
BERLIN, May 21 (AP) -- Financial difficulties holding up East-West German trade have been settled in four-power talks, Maj. Gen. George P. Hays said today.
AMSTERDAM, May 21 -- A crisis in the Belgian diamond industry is beginning to seriously affect the city of Amsterdam, where more than one-third of the diamond workers are now unemployed.

THE success of dramas at the City Center is due not only to the prevailing low scale of prices but also to the large capacity of the theatre. The City Center seats more than 3,000 persons. The producer can play at a $3 top and take in more money than a Broadway smash hit playing at $4.80 or $6 in a smaller theatre.

A new rechargeable cell which weighs one-third to one-half as much as the familiar cadmium-nickel, ironnickel or lead-acid cell has been invented by Prof. Henri Andre after fifteen years of laboratory research and field tests. Because it is so compact the cell obviously has its uses in hearing aids, portable radios, flashlights, self-propelled wheelchairs, portable electric movie cameras, aircraft and commercial vehicles.
DETROIT, May 21 -- By now it has become apparent even to a casual observer that 1949 is a year of crisis in the skyrocketing carreer of Walter P. Reuther.

CONSTRUCTION of an automobile bridge across the Hudson River connecting Rhinecliff and Kingston is being considered by the New York State Public Works Department. Final plans await Army approval of the site.

RICHMOND, Va., May 21 -- New variations on the old themes of free enterprise and free speech troubled the Upper South this week and brought sharp divisions in opinion. There were two controversies over the construction of dams.

PHILADELPHIA, May 21 -- Joe Kirkwood Jr., shot a course-record-breaking 66 today to take a commanding lead at the half-way mark in the sixth annual Inquirer invitation golf tournament with a 36-hole total of 134.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- A report of the Joint Committee on Labor-Management Relations today praised the policies of the Tennessee Valley Authority and the unions representing its employes.

Re Nathaniel Peffer, author of "Asia: Spiritual Challenge to Us," this country cannot afford to have such an outstanding authority on international relations, with an intimate first-hand knowledge of the Far East, restricted to the realm of theoretical discussion.
SEVENTY-THREE years ago Dostoevsky set down in "The Diary of a Writer" the following passage:

ONE can say it without hesitation, or without those insistent qualifying phrases: books like Lionel Trilling's "Matthew Arnold" are the kind we need. This critical study was first published ten years ago, and now Columbia University Press has reissued it at $5. That Mr. Trilling chose, or felt compelled, to examine Arnold becomes a most fortunate circumstance for the reader.

BERLIN, May 21 -- Nothing is more indicative of the changing political climate in Germany than the interest being shown throughout the country in the meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers, which opens Monday in Paris.
ROLLING north by bus over the famous Alaska Highway to the heart of America's last frontier is a travel adventure that will be open to tourists this summer.

THE Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival at Lee, Mass., bids fair to be especially festive this summer, for the Ballet Theatre will be represented on many of the programs and will in addition give a little midsummer season of its own there to coincide with the Berkshire Music Festival at near-by Tanglewood.

DUBLIN, May 21 (Reuters) -- Sean MacBride, Ireland's Minister for External Affairs, issued a statement today accusing the British Government of "bad faith" in connection with the Ireland Bill, recently passed by the British House of Commons.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 21 -- The metropolitan all-breed outdoor dog show season began today with the forty-third event of the Ladies' Kennel Association of America and the top award in it went to a New York Scottish terrier, Mrs. John G. Winant's Champion Edgerstoune Pepper.

"Perennial Preview" is the title of the flower show, sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES, which will be held in Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, on May 24 and 25. In addition to the flower show, programs will be held in the auditorium at 2:30 and 8 P. M. on Tuesday, and at 2:30 P. M. on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The Congressional economy drive, which only last week seemed to have become fairly well cranked up, is now puttering along in reverse gear without any hope of reaching its destination. It turns out that the road ahead is too rough and the goal too distant.

A preview of Bloomingdale's new branch store within the Fresh Meadows Housing Development in Queens will be afforded to invited guests tomorrow. The store will open for public patronage on Tuesday morning.

A Manhattan team that has been having considerable difficulty against Metropolitan Baseball Conference competition found a suitable target in Fordham yesterday and scored a 3-1 triumph at Fordham Field.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -The Senators continued their mastery of the Browns today with a two-run rally in the ninth that meant a 7-6 victory. It was Washington's fifth triumph in five games with St. Louis.

DAYTON, Ohio, May 21 -- German scientists during World War II developed a television device similar to the human eye for controlling guided missiles or aircraft but never put it to use, the Air Materiel Command at Wright Field disclosed today.

DOROTHY FOSDICK, first and only woman member of the State Department's Policy Planning Staff, is an amiable soul, who is far less impressed with her importance than many men (let alone women) in positions of similar rank.

IT is probably enough to report that Columbia has hastened to make a complete recording of the Rodgers and Hammerstein score from South Pacific, and let nature take care of the rest. Nothing a record reviewer could say would be likely to augment or diminish the public interest in "South Pacific," and there is little that this reviewer would care to say to detract from that interest.

Insufficient stocks, coupled with warm weather, brought many reorders to the wholesale apparel market here last week, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office.

THE first annual art festival of the Queens Botanical Gardens Society is being staged today. Thirty-five or more amateur and professional artists, all from Long Island, are participating in this event and will turn the five - acre gardens in Flushing Meadow Park into a huge outdoor studio.

A 25-year-old man who spent four years in the National Leprosarium at Carville, La., described yesterday the conditions of social ostracism and economic discrimination he has met since his discharge last October.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- Roy E. James, a Republican, who ran against Representative Francis E. Walter, Democrat, of Pennsylvania, last fall, said today that he had been ordered dismissed or transferred from his $8,500-a-year post in the Army Department.

PHILADELPHIA, May 21 (AP) -Shortstop Eddie Joost smashed out four hits to drive in six runs and right-hander Carl Scheib allowed one safety in six innings of relief to lead the Philadelphia Athletics to a 15-7 triumph over the Detroit Tigers today.

YOUR reviewer. Perry Miller, prefaces his review of a novel called "Lonesome Valley" (April 17) with a remark that has my dander up. After stating that a "peculiar curse" has rested on fiction dealing with hill people he goes on to say: "From Charles Egbert Craddock to Elizabeth Roberts and Marjorie Kinnan Rawlings" the stereotype has brought forth a formula that Mr. Perry dubs a "sustained monotony."

WITH every shady spot a boon on hot summer days, the success or failure of planting there is of real importance. In considering the limitations of such areas, the density of shade should have as much influence on choice of plants as do problems of competing tree roots and moisture supplies.

The case of Hyderabad, now before the Security Council, has again brought forward the issue of United Nations competence in a problem that may be judged purely domestic or otherwise. It is the contention of India that the Hyderabad situation is in no sense international and that therefore the Security Council is not properly seized with the case.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 21 Yale inflicted the first Eastern Intercollegiate League defeat of the season on Dartmouth today as Bob Goodyear checked the Indians. 3 -- 2.

Nitrogen mustard, related to the mustard gas of evil military reputation, has the same effect on fruit flies, some bacteria, molds and barley. But what of higher animals?

THIS readable story about a 10-year-old French boy's search for his father in seventeenth-century Quebec gives a valuable picture of life in that early settlement. Philippe's quest takes him into every corner and outpost of "Kebec," where readers will meet settlers and Indians and discover the pleasures and problems of the French-Canadian pioneer.

MOSCOW, May 21 -- The Soviet Union's objective at the next week's meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers in Paris, as outlined by press commentators, is the achievement of a final post-war settlement of the German question.

Children of the parochial schools of the archdiocese and their teachers, members of various religious orders, joined yesterday with several hundred of the clergy in honoring Cardinal Spellman. They attended a solemn pontifical mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral in commemoration of the tenth anniversary of the Cardinal's installation as Archbishop of New York.

ITHICA, N. Y. May 21 -- Pennsylvania defeated Cornell, 3 -- 1, in a tight Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League game before 2,000 here today, with Ed Lukievics besting Ed Winnick on the mound as they gave up six hits apiece.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 21 -- After one of the most unusual rallies in the thirty-nine year history of the event, Joe McBride of Arcola, New Jersey amateur champion, turned back Dick Remsen Jr. of the home club to win the Walter J. Travis Memorial tourney final by 2 and 1 over the Garden City Golf Club course today.

THERE are some of us who are convinced that English literature owes much of its durability to the dividing line that separates the novel from poetry. We shudder to think of what fictional extravagance Keats might have produced if he had not confined himself to metrical form.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -Congress gave evidence this week that it wants a lobby law with plainer language, and perhaps stronger provisions, than the one it put on the statute books less than three years ago.

BRITISH public schools have served as the setting for admirable mystery novels by James Hilton and Nicholas Blake, among others, but the murderous potential of American private schools has been badly neglected. Equally neglected are the atmospheric beauties of Marin County, a stretch of country just north of the Golden Gate, as typical of California as the familiar Hollywood murder locale is atypical.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 21 -- Tuning up for the defense of its Intercollegiate AAAA title next week-end, Yale's powerful track squad overwhelmed Harvard by the record-breaking score of 111 to 29 at DeWitt Cuyler Field today. It was the fifteenth straight dual meet triumph for the Elis over a period of three years.

The growing strategic dependence upon the atomic bomb and the general assumption that if war comes we will use it in widespread attacks upon Russian cities have tended to put the cart before the horse in the formulation of national policies.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- James Forrestal killed himself this morning.

Is it to be staged at sacred Carnoustie or even at hallowed St. Andrews amid the Scottish burrs and thistles? Don't be betraying your ignorance, lad. 'Tis in none of those places.
