WORCESTER, Mass., May 21 -- One hundred years of organized activity by Franco-Americans in New England will be celebrated with a centennial congress in this city next Saturday and Sunday.

Gabriel A. Wechsler, general secretary of the City Fusion party, warned the fusion forces yesterday not to let the weakness of Tammany and Borough President Hugo E. Rogers, its leader, revealed by the election of Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. as Representative, obscure the real issue of the coming city campaign.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- President Truman and President Eurico Gaspar Dutra of Brazil agreed during their conversations here this week on a mutual program for economic development and social progress.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., May 21 -- The Larchmont summer racing season opened in full blast yesterday with the first regatta of the New York Yacht Club. But the blast was not of wind.

Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam of the New York Area of the Methodist Church was commended by the New York East Methodist Conference yesterday afternoon "for his courageous and effective leadership in resisting encroachments on the American principle of separation of church and state."

CHICAGO, May 21 (AP) -- An American watch manufacturer said today that an "inadequate,, obsolete and unrealistic tariff" on watch imports is undermining the American watch industry's ability to meet possible war emergency demands.

PARIS, May 21 -- The arrival by plane today first of Secretary of State Dean Acheson, then of Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky brought the Big Four Foreign Ministers to Paris again for their first conference together in one year and one-half.

FOR eleven days after the death of her father April Haddon and her stepmother play out a grim battle of wills in the family home on Long Island. Violence ends the tension. Circumstantial evidence points to the possibility of the older woman being malevolent and criminal.

WHY doesn't my wistaria bloom better?" is a question frequently asked of horticulturists. As a matter of fact, most plants, if they have proper growing conditions, will flower freely in spite of the supposition that some wistaria are unable to bloom.

LAWRENCEVILLE, N. J., May 21 -- Bringing out the heavy artillery to stage a gallant uphill battle, Lawrenceville's nine defeated the Hill School, 12 -- 8, in a game that provided the highlight of an athletic program staged as part of the annual alumni day exercises today. A turnout of 2,000 graduates, parents and friends was on hand for the festivities.

PRICE reductions on cameras and movie projectors averaging 12 1/2 per cent, with a maximum cut of 17 1/2 per cent, are announced by Eastman Kodak Company. Among the cameras affected are the Flash Bantam, Kodak Tourist in the f/6.3, f/8.8 and Kodet models, Flash Brownie and the Baby Brownie Special. Movie equipment reduced in price includes the Cine-Kodak Magazine 16 camera and Koda-scope projectors Eight-33, Sixteen-10 and Sixteen-20.

Dr. Isidore S. Edelman, medical researcher whose name has been brought into the controversy over loyalty requirements of applicants for Atomic Energy Commission fellowships, was defended yesterday as a loyal citizen of high moral character.

Five sales of art and literary property will be held this week at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street, starting on Monday with an auction of books and another of precious-stone jewelry.

LATE in 1946 twenty-three Germans, all but three of them doctors of medicine, went on trial at Nuremberg for "crimes against humanity." Eight months later fifteen of the twenty-three were found guilty of inhuman medical experiments upon human beings, and seven were hanged.
ITHACA, N. Y., May 21 -- Princeton's well-rounded track and field squad made Cornell hustle to take a 78 1/4 to 61 3/4 decision in a dual meet at Schoellkopf Field today.

THERE is more to Europe than castles, cathedrals and obelisks. There are people. But the interesting trivia which would demonstrate to American tourists that Europe is inhabited and that its peoples have amusing manners and fashions are usually unheralded by the guides and the official guide books.

THE indications are that New York will have a good solid musical season in 1949-50. The managers of the concert halls expected bookings to drop considerably from the level of the last two years. They have dropped a bit, but not as far as anticipated.

The child who exhibits a preference for building blocks, modeling clay or toy soldiers when he should be doing his homework may not actually be neglecting his academic pursuits. Under the new program now in effect in New York State's elementary schools, outside interests are playing an increasingly important role in educating children in the ways and whys of arithmetic.
THEATREGOERS by the thousands will make their annual pilgrimage up the slopes of Mount Tamalpais today.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The Atomic Energy Commission ordered oaths of loyalty and non-Communist affidavits into effect today for all present and future holders of commission fellowships in medical, physical and biological science.

MONTREAL -- The two large Canadian railway systems -- Canadian National and Canadian Pacific -- have increased their first-class fares up to 15 per cent, and in so doing have taken back the gift which Canadian travelers had enjoyed since the Federal Government repealed the 15 per cent travel tax in March of this year.
BANGKOK, Thailand, May 21 (UP) -- Viet Nam President Ho Chi Minh said today that the "third and final" stage of the war against the French in French Indo-China would begin soon.

ROME, May 21 -- The strong-arm methods, which Italian officials said the Communists have been using to establish a labor dictatorship in the organization threatened today to cause a split within the CGIL (Italian General Labor Confederation) and further weaken the hold that the extreme left-wing parties have had until now on the majority of Italian unions.

SHAKESPEARE'S part in the development of the theatre is the central interest in this account of London's sixteenth-century playhouses and the people who made them famous. Written primarily for young readers, the book has many unique features designed to help students visualize the theatrical world of the period.

QUEBEC, May 21 -- The United States advertising picture brought cheer to Canadian newsprint firms this week, when they learned that linage across the border was over 3 per cent ahead of the first quarter last year.

Plans for superimposing a new set of runways over those now in use at Newark Airport and for acquiring an additional 800 acres of land for enlarging the field were announced yesterday by Joseph M. Byrne Jr., vice chairman of the Port of New York Authority.

Sleek, sissy, serviceable -- pay your money and take your choice when it comes to buying your smmer beach costume. Big news are the nylon suits that dry in a jiffy when you come out of the water. They are grand to wear and pretty to look at, and come in lovely colors.
Precision timing aimed at saving as much as three days in delivery time of less-than-carload freight lots in the Midwest will be introduced by the New York Central in Indiana early next month.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Representative Jacob K. Javits, Republican, of New York, reported today on the basis of a questionnaire that seventeen Governors or Mayors throughout the country and its territories favored his bill to provide $50,000,000 of Federal aid for community youth projects designed to curb juvenile delinquency.

J. Anthony Lewis' implication ("Harvard Goes Co-ed, But Incognito") that the Radcliffeite is potentially better off than a Vassar or Smith girl is made totally without regard for the important ingredients of female education.

Savings banks are recasting their traditional approach to the public as a result of studies of public thrift motives now being completed. The studies indicate that because of the great social changes that have occurred during recent years, most persons are no longer primarily interested in saving merely for security reasons.

CAIRO, May 21 -- The failure of most members of the United Nations to make any substantial contribution to the relief of Palestinian Arab refugees has forced the United Nations Relief for Palestine Refugees and its three field agencies here to adopt this week a restricted program to carry through until November 1.

The Greeks had a word for the trouble that is noted by the Economic Commission for Europe, that highly independent agency of the United Nations. The trouble with Europe, says the ECE in its elaborate report on the state of the nations, is the trend to autarchy -- meaning, as the context clearly shows, self-sufficiency.

THE latest two tennis champions to come out with books of instruction for beginning players are Miss Mary K. Browne, U. S. Singles Champion (1912-14), who now coaches at Lake Erie College, and Jack Kramer, who, after winning nearly every amateur title in sight, has taken to playing Bobby Riggs for pay in various climes and on various surfaces.

NOW that New York has existed for twelve days since "Home of the Brave" premiered at the Victoria Theatre, without any disturbance of the peace or even popular demonstration to mar its successful run, it is safe to assume that this picture, which has anti-Negro bias as its theme, is not going to cause a rebellion -- not in this community, at least.

CHICAGO, May 21 (AP) -- Hank Borowy pitched and battled the Phillies to a 5-1 victory over his former Cub mates today before a ledies day turnout of 18,840. It was his third victory of the season and his second over the Cubs.

I find Hubert H. Humphrey's "The Case for National Health Insurance" infuriating. I took the trouble of calling the local Blue Cross Plan and asked what their enrollment is. They reported that there are nearly 4 million enrolled in New York City alone and nationally 34 million and that in all voluntary plans there are more than 55 million people now protected against the catastrophe of sudden hospital expense.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- Senator Paul H. Douglas, Democrat, of Illinois, said today that he favored giving the President restricted power to seize strike-bound or strike-threatened facilities in key industries in national emergency situations.
ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., May 21 -- The major issue in the Southwest this week was telephone rates.

THE tenth edition of "Facts and Figures," a tabular report of the American air transport industry published by the Air Transport Association of America, indicates that the scheduled air lines of the nation are not in as bad shape as generally believed.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 21 -Formal approval for the merger of the Waterfront Employers Association of the Pacific Coast and the Pacific American Shipowners Association was given this week by the memberships of the two organizations.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 21 (AP) -- It's the end of an era -- Hollywood's perennial "most eligible bachelor," James Stewart, is engaged. His fiancee is Mrs. Gloria Hatrick McLean, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar B. Hatrick of Larchmount, N. Y.

RANDOLPH, Vt. -- A sight of rare beauty has suddenly come into the northeastern states, and it should be kept in mind when planning vacation motor trips this summer. Even as far north as the Canadian frontier there is now an opportunity to see the large snowy egrets which last summer turned watercourses and marshes into a fairyland.

THE problem of the Jew in an alien environment is penetratingly examined in Mr. Davis' first novel. It is the story of Daniel Gordon, who was born Daniel Hyman Goldstein and who left the Jewish fur markets of Philadelphia to make a new life for himself among the goyim of a bustling little Carolina town.

Approximately 350 midshipmen and officers of the New York State Maritime College, Fort Schuyler, will leave here June 8 aboard the training ship Empire State on the school's annual summer training cruise, it was announced yesterday by Vice Admiral Herbert F. Leary, USN (ret), president.

In "Los Alamos -- Capital of the Atomic Age" Hanson W. Baldwin refers to "the gigantic convulsions that once tore this region asunder," referring, I assume, to either earthquake or, less likely, volcanic action. * * * There are near-by signs of both these types of action. of course.

The inhabitants may not have realized it, but New York was stormed and taken yesterday by a handful of Army Transportation Corps reservists in maneuvers combining the joint talents of the Army, Navy and Air Forces.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Associates of the Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government, including former Secretary of State Henry L. Stimson, praised Congress today for approving "as far as it goes" a measure making "far-reaching reforms" possible within the State Department.
The vital role of foreign trade in the economic well-being of the United States will be highlighted here beginning tomorrow in a series of observances of "World Trade Week."

DENVER, May 21 -- Two new gigantic Federal projects to lift Colorado River water from the western slope of the Continental Divide and spread it on eastern Colorado land are on the drawing boards of the Bureau of Reclamation here. By comparison the country's first great trans-mountain water diversion project, the Colorado-Big Thompson now under construction, is a pygmy.

PORTLAND, Me. -- Visitors in Maine are usually as astonished to learn that the state contains a sizable desert as they would be to hear of a pine forest in the middle of the Sahara. Yet sixteen miles out of this city, just off U. S. Route 1 near the town of Freeport, the traveler will find 500 acres of shifting sand dunes surrounded by woodlands and rolling green fields.

ANY boy or girl who has ever loved a dog would sympathize deeply with Sandy Ferguson at the disappearance of his new collie even without the realistic treatment here accorded the situation by Mrs. Eames. Sandy's father, who had been skeptical of the value of a highly bred show dog on a working ranch, had come round a bit when Handy, the collie, appointed himself the responsible guardian of Sandy's baby sister.

Britain's "cradle-to-the-grave" health program is in the eleventh month of its operation. It is the subject of much vigorous praise, violent denunciation and cold-eyed analysis. Also, it is receiving the tartly humorous attention of Punch, which inclines to present a Conservative party view of government medicine.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 21 -- The Minneapolis Star and Tribune Company, which publishes the Star, evening newspaper, and the Tribune, morning, will dedicate its new plant with a ten-day program that began tonight when a carrier boy started a seven-day round-the-world newspaper delivery route.

Behind Fred Sanford's effective relief pitching the Yankees beat the White Sox, 4 -- 3, on Johnny Lindell's single with two out in the ninth inning yesterday. Scoring eight runs in the ninth, the Dodgers routed the Cardinals, 15 -- 6. While the Giants were rained out in Cincinnati, the Braves cut New York's National League lead to half a game by downing the Pirates, 8 -- 2.

CHICAGO, May 21 -- An exhibition which shows how science serves the public by assuring the quality of the goods that it buys was presented this week to the Museum of Science and Industry by Sears, Roebuck Co. Gen. R. E. Wood, chairman of the board of Sears, made the presentation to Major Lenox R. Lohr, president of the museum, at a luncheon attended by many of Chicago's business leaders in the museum.
LOS ANGELES, May 21 (AP) -Speed, muscle and glamour, mixed with record-making performances, marked the ninth annual Coliseum Relays.

THERE was a time when a spy could hold up his head and feel that his business was hardly every man's dish. Today the profession has become as debased as a Chinese dollar. An American writer of pro-Soviet tracts is dragged from her bed in Moscow and told that whether she likes it or not she is a first-class capitalist spy.

The biggest post-war luxury cruise has been scheduled for next winter by the Cunard White Star Line in connection with two travel concerns, American Express Company and Thomas Cook Son, it was announced yesterday.

A new approach to family service, with the psychiatrist used not as consultant but as an actual participant in the agency's program, has helped at least 45,000 persons in this city, the Community Service Society reported yesterday.

Ships' whistles at noon yesterday heralded the seventeenth annual observance of National Maritime Day. Virtually all vessels in the harbor, bedecked in the traditional strings of bright-colored signal flags, participated.

A mystery posed by the early morning disappearance of Owen Davis Jr., son of the playwright, from a stranded yacht near Hart Island was solved partly yesterday afternoon after his body was found in Long Island Sound off Kings Point, L. I.

Introduction in Congress late last week by Senator Burnet R. Maybank, chairman of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee, of a resolution to amend the Export-Import Bank Act to guarantee dollar payments to American small business for exports to Western Hemisphere countries, marks another move to alleviate the dollar shortage in foreign trade.

OKLAHOMA CITY, May 21 -- Liberalization of the present Displaced Persons Act, to admit 400,000 persons in four years and to remove "discriminatory clauses," was urged today by the Southern Baptist Convention.

WEST POINT, N. Y., May 21 -- Army's heralded track and field force put on another of its displays of all-around brilliance today in overwhelming Villanova and Fordham in a triangular meet at the North athletic field.

PHILADELPHIA, May 21 -- In the first half of May, retail sales went into a new slump here. Seven of the leading women's wear stores in Philadelphia last week did 9 per cent less dollar volume than a year ago, but their sales during the four-week period showed a gain of 3 per cent compared with the corresponding weeks last year.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 21 -- Business activity in the Ninth Federal Reserve District is slowly closing the gap between the dollar volume of last year's record-breaking figures and the recent lower levels. Bank debits compiled by the bank in Minneapolis on reports from 133 cities showed the January-April total of $10,307,370,000 to be only 4 per cent below the level for the same period last year.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 21 -- Retail activity in the Twelfth District last week continued to fall below last year's level. The only areas in the district which showed gains over a year ago were Seattle and Spokane. While Portland held even, all other areas showed marked decreases.

There has been a great deal of heat on the subject of compulsory health insurance, both from those in favor and those against it, but too little light. Fortunately, a more reasonable attitude seems to be in the offing. The champions are getting tired.
SHANGHAI, May 21 -- Communists last night tried to sneak across the Whangpoo River in a dozen junks and land on the edge of the city's municipal airport at Lunghwa.
BERLIN, May 21 -- Brig Gen. Frank L. Howley, United States Commander in Berlin, said today the Russians had admitted sending "kidnappers" into the United States sector of Berlin.
BRITAIN'S latest literary sensation is Norman Mailer's "The Naked and the Dead," published there earlier this month to the tune of an indignant editorial scream for its suppression.

THIS is a well-turned-out puzzle about a group of upper level (penthouse) New Yorkers whose lives are shattered by the unseemly presence of homicide. John Harland, one of those elegant, highly civilized, erudite men of fiction, who make a career of being connoisseurs of human behavior, solves everything long before you will.

UNLESS we do something to prevent the things that set up friction between parents and children, "we can get mad at even a 15-month-old, and then we have Discipline on our hands," according to Dr. James L. Hymes Jr.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- In two branches of the coordinate, triune Government of the United States this week there were disputes over the fair and proper execution of two clauses in the Constitution. The disputes were academic in the sense that in each instance one viewpoint already had prevailed. But the expressed differences of opinion are important and will reappear, possibly with the positions of the current victors reversed.

A COLLECTION of good evergreens on the property represents an investment which it is wise to protect. Correct planting practice and subsequent care are particularly important for yews, Japanese hollies, rhododendrons, laurels, azaleas, pieris, and the slower-growing arborvitaes and junipers, used in foundation plantings.

"THE EAGLE'S SONG" is American history synopsized in the story of Woodbury, an up-state New York town, from colonial days until after the first World War. The town's history is one of undying conflict between two families.

PARIS, May 21 -- The British delegation to the Council of Foreign Ministers' meeting will reject any Soviet proposals for the complete withdrawal of occupation troops from Germany in the immediate future, an authoritative source said today.

ALTHOUGH the fame of James A. Michener is as a man of literature (he was awarded the Pulitzer Prize for Literature in 1948 for "Tales of the South Pacific," and has now published a new novel, "Fires of Spring"), he has been pushed into still more fame by the musical play "South Pacific."

CHICAGO, May 21 (AP) -- Grains generally moved higher today in a fairly brisk trade. Most interest centered around the May deliveries, in which dealings ended at the close of the market. They advanced on short-covering with soy beans showing the most strength.

The Senate has now refused for the fourth time to make even small reductions in appropriations bills that have come before it. Republicans have led the movement for reduction of these bills by at least 5 per cent, but Senator Douglas, Democrat, of Illinois, had no better luck when he proposed a 40 per cent reduction in the so-called Rivers and Harbors Bill.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 21 -Harvard's baseball team combined heavy hitting with shut-out pitching to beat Army, 10 -0, at Soldiers Field this afternoon. The Crimson which generally can't do anything right for its ace pitcher, Ira Godin, landed on three cadet hurlers for thirteen hits, including a home run and a triple.

CAMDEN, N. J., May 21 (AP) -- Loser Weeper, 6-5 favorite flying the silks of Alfred G. Vanderbilt, raced to a two-and-one-half-length triumph before 27,000 persons today at Garden State Park in the eighth running of the $15,000 added Valley Forge Handicap.

"YOU'RE going to adore school," they told Philippa. And so, of course, she hated it even more than she had expected to. Quiet, shy, grieving over the death of her mother, missing her companionable father, the young American girl felt herself an awkward misfit among the ebullient girls in the Swiss boarding school.

ON May 22, one hundred years ago, the United States Patent Office issued a patent numbered 6,469 and titled "Vessels, Method of Lifting Over Shoals." It was by no means the most outstanding of the 1,076 patents granted in 1849.

THIS is the story, in microscopic detail, of the 27th Division in the Pacific. Federalized in October, 1940, the New York outfit trained in the South, rushed to California embarkation points a few days after Pearl Harbor and began embarkation for Hawaii in February, 1942.

Fortunate the person who has a pair of orioles resident in his trees. Particularly a pair of Baltimore orioles, which are a delight to eye and ear and which, once they have chosen a tall tree for a nesting place, return to that tree year after year. Big elms are their favorites, in this part of the world, but they will on occasion adopt a tall old apple tree which has escaped the pruner's saw.

Merchants who oppose retail price fixing by manufacturer contended here last week that public sentiment is shifting in their favor. They based this belief on decisions here and in other states against certain types of price fixing in the liquor industry.

THE outstanding perennials now blooming in gardens in this vicinity will be the focal point of a two-day program sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES, in Times Hall, 240 West Forty - fourth Street, New York City, on Tuesday and Wednesday. Tickets may be obtained at the box office, starting today, for any of the three programs which will be held at 2:30 o'clock each afternoon, and at 8 o'clock Tuesday evening.

IF Gerald W. Johnson cares to find a more nearly correct cause of the great misjudging of the American temper, let him read through any ten American newspapers of the waning Thirties. Let him pay especial heed to the editorials and the letters to the editors.

PIETER GEYL is one of the leading Dutch historians. Once a Dutch newspaper man in London, he was appointed to the newly created chair of Dutch Studies at the University of London soon after the First World War.

Retail trade here did not fare particularly well last week. In a continuation of the downward trend, dollar volume slipped rather sharply. Department store sales were estimated at about 15 per cent under the corresponding week of last year.

The stock market is again taking verbal lashings from many masterminds. It has been called a "funny" market, puzzled and confused. Yet, the mere fact that its voice has sometimes this year softened to a whisper does not obscure the fact that a pretty thorough job of discounting has been operating beyond the eye range.

LONDON, May 21 -- The British bridge team went further ahead tonight in its championship match against the United States for the Crowninshield Cup. At the halfway mark, the English side led the Americans by 2,950 points.

IN THE vast sea of critical material that has been written about Miss Stein in the last decades there are discernible two general currents of thought, both of which I feel have carried our attitude toward her extraordinary work somewhat off the course of direct appraisal.

OMAHA, Neb., May 21 -- Three major threats to crops -- plant disease, insect pests and weeds -- loomed large in the battle planning of the rural Middle West this week as the winter wheat crop developed toward maturity and corn planting got under way.

DORIS MILES DISNEY is not to be confused with Dorothy Cameron Disney or Dorothy Salisbury Davis. (Something is going to have to be done about these names.) For that matter, she's rarely to be confused with herself. Starting with straight, if unusually sensitive, detective stories, Miss Disney moved over to the psychological suspense novel and ended by creating a form peculiarly her own -- the period suspense novel, with vividly realized turn-of-the-century setting.

AS this department was saying when it was so rudely interrupted by the exigencies of space, the American novel has given surprisingly little attention to the behavior of men in public life. Writing two weeks ago about the reflections prompted by a visit to the United Nations General Assembly.

Leaders of the steel industry are confident -- but not at all convinced -- that the current declining trend in the domestic steel operating rate will be brought to a halt in the fall after a pronounced setback during the summer months.
The New York Port of Embarkation ships an average of 625,000 tons each month at present against an average of 450,000 in 1948, it was said yesterday by Maj. Gen. Ewart G. Plank.

There has been an event in the theatre which thus far has not received the attention which it deserves: the extraordinarily fine performance of Dickinson Eastham, who has played opposite Mary Martin in "South Pacific" on the nights that Ezio Pinza has been indisposed.

Zoned air conditioning will be a feature of the $4,500,000 Federal Building scheduled for completion soon at the New York International Airport, it was reported yesterday by Guy B. Panero, head of the engineering firm that designed the air conditioning and other mechanical systems for the structure.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, signaling a change in Republican strategy on Government economy, today supported a move to cut nearly $2,000,000,000 from appropriations by a single operation.

On Feb. 7, 1946, Gerald L. K. Smith, the America Firster, conducted a meeting in Chicago. One of the speakers was the Rev. Arthur W. Terminiello, a Roman Catholic priest from Alabama, the "Father Coughlin of the South," then under suspension by his Bishop for utterances "detrimental to the church and the unity of our country." (He has since been reinstated by the church.)

EDWARD STREETER, who, during World War I, endeared himself to a large part of the American public with his "Dere Mable" letters, is going to endear himself all over again, and probably to an even greater audience, with his latest and most hilarious book.

ATHENS, Ohio -- Photography is formally recognized as a fine art at Ohio University, the first American college or university to offer a bachelor's and a master's degree in a four-year curriculum that combines photographic instruction with a liberal-arts training.

Thirty-seven dogs, eighteen cats, four fish, six turtles, and various other pets, including lizards chameleons, birds, and a pigeon were exhibited yesterday by their owners -- children between the ages of 3 and 14 years -- at a pet show held at Greenwich House, 27 Barrow Street, a settlement in Greenwich Village.

Republican efforts to recapture the lost farm vote, particularly in the Midwestern breadbasket of the nation, and Democratic efforts to hold and solidify it have both been ineffective to date, a survey by correspondents of THE NEW YORK TIMES disclosed yesterday.

Representatives of the New York State Joint Legislative Committee on Indian Affairs asked yesterday that the State Legislature be freed from many obstructions in the area of Indian affairs by placing jurisdiction over Indian civil actions under the state courts.
NEW developments of major interest were observed in business last week. The slow easing in both trade and industry which has been under way for five months or so continued to be the main trend.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., May 21 -- William J. Wallin, chancellor of the University of the State of New York, predicted today that cooperative efforts by state officials and library groups would put library service in New York "far ahead in this respect of any other state, or any country in the world."

LONDON, May 21 -- Fifty years ago two United States undergraduates at Oxford founded an educational center there to enable working men to spend at least a year in an atmosphere of academic culture. Today Ruskin College, the product of their vision and enterprise, celebrated its jubilee.

At 2 o'clock yesterday, big Johnny Lindell was a .153 batter, lowest, by far, of any of the Yankees. At 4:12, following three fruitless turns, he had fallen to .145, but at 4:13 Lindell was the proudest .159 hitter imaginable.

ST. LOUIS, May 21 -- Staging an 8-run ninth inning as a topper to a game in which they already led, the Dodgers today lambasted the Cardinals, 15 -- 6, moved into sole possession of third place and gave Rex Barney his first triumph for pitching three-and-one-third innings of relief.

LONDON (By Wireless). "I TOOK over direction of the Foreign Office under the impression that * * * what was now at stake was not only our eastern provinces but the much wider issue -- namely, whether there would prevail in the Russian Government a pro-Polish or an anti-Polish attitude, the striving for Pan-Slav fraternization of Russians and Poles against Germans or the desire for a Russo-Prussian combination."

MR. TAYLOR has made a name for himself as the author of a garden encyclopedia, a garden dictionary, a wild flower guide and other compilations of value to the amateur botanist. This present book offers an account of the narcotic plants -- a subject that has dramatic connotations.

"Kiss Me, Kate," the hit musical, yesterday became a major target for the investigation into ticket scalping in Broadway shows. John M. Murtagh, Commissioner of Investigation, issued a subpoena for the box-office treasurer of the Century Theatre, where the Cole Porter musical is playing to capacity.
Thirty-six years ago a man moved and in doing so hoped to change the nature of his work.

PITTSBURGH, May 21 -- Negotiations for fourth-round wage demands and changes in general insurance benefits between Big Steel and the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, will open on June 15, it was disclosed here today.
HANOVER, N. H., May 21 -- Pennsylvania's never-say-die track squad overcame a seemingly hopeless deficit and conquered Dartmouth, 74 1/3 to 65 2/3, today on the Memorial Field Oval.

Gen. K. Musteikis, former Lithuanian Minister of Defense, who arrived in this country a week ago after spending five years in a displaced Persons camp in the American zone in Germany, voiced a warning yesterday to Americans and the peoples of "other free nations'' to be on guard against the dangers of complacency and urged an all-out fight against Communist infiltration.

The New York Personnel Management Association soon will begin a survey of its more than 300 member companies to determine how each one conducts six vital phases of personnel administration. Robert F. Moore, association chairman, disclosed last week. He said the survey is a preliminary step in the association's effort to show members how to streamline personnel administration with the objective of reducing maintenance costs.

IN this, her twenty-seventh novel, Sheila Kaye-Smith has written a quiet, pleasing study of rural Sussex and its native farmers, and of one lonely man and a briefly idyllic love. Kemp Silverden, widowed young farmer who works his land with part-time help and lives alone, falls in love with Alice Candelin, wife of a recently arrived gentleman farmer of much talk and theory and little competence.

AS a compass for the new reader, the editors, both Professors of English at the University of Hawaii, have organized their pages into sections for Hawaii, New Zealand. Australia, the Philippines, Polynesia, Micronesia and Melanesia, and they have included early and late accounts -- many not easily accessible -- of travels and hardships and valor, stories and poems, and translations of folk tales and native myths, some of great charm and ethnological interest.

Despite the establishment of Israel as a state, the Near East is an inviting target for the next Communist move westward, Representative Jacob K. Javits said last night at a dinner in the Roosevelt Hotel opening the annual convention of the American ORT (Organization for Rehabilitation Through Training) Federation.

Scoring in all but two events, Bishop Loughlin left thirteen opponents far behind yesterday to take the senior team title in the thirty-third annual track and field games of the Athletic Association of Private Schools at Van Cortlandt Park stadium.

ALTHOUGH program changes are a normal occurrence with each new season, next fall is going to witness a record number of shifts and cancellations. The latest show to be parting company with its sponsor is "Duffy's Tavern," its star, Ed Gardner, having secured a release from his contract. Mr. Gardner reportedly has his eye on a television venture, among other activities.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 21 -- United Nations circles were guarded today in predicting the outcome of the meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers, but reliable sources indicated that the Western powers would present a united front in proposing the amalgamation of the Soviet occupation zone of Germany with the Western zones to form a single federal state.

THE little man behind the table full of gadgets picked up two mussel shells and rubbed them gently together, producing a dull croaking sound. "That, Your Majesty," he said, "is how we represent a bullfrog."
WASHINGTON, May 21 (UP) -- The House Appropriations Committee has made "a few substantial cuts" in President Truman's plans for European recovery spending, Chairman Clarence Cannon disclosed tonight.

BOSTON, May 21 -- Joe Dobson pitched a classy shut-out today as the Red Sox climbed over the Indians into sixth place by beating the world champions, 4 -- 0, before the largest seated crowd since Tom Yawkey took over ownership of the Boston club.

A READER of this column wrote in last week to ask, "If you use the Blackwood four no trump, do you have to go on to a slam then, or can you stop?" An extreme example that, nevertheless, comes close to epitomizing the general misconception of slam-bidding conventions and their purpose.

THANKS to Maurice Evans, Bernard Shaw's "Man and Superman" is in town again and still full of quizzical delight. This is the comedy about the "life force" which Mr. Shaw wrote nearly a half century ago when he was a young man of about 44 and beginning at last to earn a respectable living.

A HIGH point of the spring garden season is the flowering of the tall bearded iris. Their spectacular blossoms on stately stalks provide the climax to a parade that starts with the small spring flowering bulbs and the daffodils. The bearded iris start to bloom in May with the last of the Breeder tulips and continue well into June.

THE approaching three-day week - end for which sunshine has been ordered by the entire population will officially open the season for fresh-air feasting. With it in mind, city shops worked through March winds and April showers to assemble equipment.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 21 -- The recent decision by United Nations officials to install a non-denominational prayer room in the permanent world capital now going up on Manhattan's East Side has brought the greatest spontaneous influx of laudatory letters ever received at this international peace headquarters.
PORT HUENEME, Calif., May 21 -- Port Hueneme, familiar to a multitude of Navy veterans, is swinging into another cycle in its peculiarly spasmodic history.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., May 21 -- The New Jersey Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs authorized its executive committee today to protest to the State Department and the national federation against the attitude of Dorothy Kenyon, former Municipal Court Justice, of New York, as United States representative to the United Nations Commission on the Status of Women.

AUGUSTA, Me., May 21 -- When the Legislature completed its biennial session just a week ago its membership was chided publicly by Gov. Frederick G. Payne for what he termed its failure to find new sources of revenue to meet demands for additional state services.

BEING friends with the librarian in a small town is always pleasant, but Nora Pritchard, who was nearly 9, found it could lead to adventures too. Miss Quinn, the librarian, was a special kind of person, and in a room which could be reached only by a trap door she had a special kind of collection.

PORTLAND, Ore., May 21 (AP) -- A transcontinental mass flight of light planes took off today for Portland, Me.

WHAT is the status of the mother of the house? Is she a servant? Is she a mother? Is she a participant in family life, or what is she? Designing the kind of a house which best expresses the mother's role, says Oskar Stonorov, Philadelphia architect, has been consciously or unconsciously the aim of residential architecture for the past ten years.
OTTAWA, May 21 -- No clear indication has been forthcoming so far as to how this country will vote in the general election to be held June 27.

ALTHOUGH Hal Wallis has never poured champagne over Betty Hutton, tossed a polo mallet at Henry Ginsberg, dropped $10,000 on the turn of a card, made a colorful slip in grammar, or given Bing Crosby the hot foot, he is recognized in Hollywood as one of the ablest producers in the motion picture industry.

ALAN SWALLOW'S beautifully printed little book of selections from Wyatt's poems may be a straw in the wind. It recalls the enthusiasm for early Tudor and Elizabethan lyrics at the turn of the century, when reprints poured from the presses.
UTICA, N. Y., May 21 -- Four objectives in the political action program of the Americans for Democratic Action were adopted today at the second annual state convention of the group.

ONE of the most eye-catching ads of recent months in subways and buses bore the admonition "Don't lick this card" above pictures of five-flavored candies so startlingly real that the injunction made sense. Another ad on subway platform walls showed a loaf of bread which seemed to jut out and protrude into the space along which the strap-hanger walked.

PARIS, May 21 -- The annual Paris Fair, described as the largest commercial exhibition in the world, opened today. About 9,500 exhibitors showed goods that in most instances were available to anyone with money.

THE Du Mont television network is planning a thorough revision of its schedule for the summer months with three new programs expected to make their debuts within the next two weeks, although no time or day has yet been set.

Unfortunately, because the sources are so slender, it must be said that what would have made an excellent article has instead become a drawn-out book, which is often dull.

BOSTON, May 21 -- New England farmers and city-dwelling gardeners alike expressed concern this week over the lack of spring rain. The dry spell was all the more damaging because of the winter's light snow and the protracted drought of the late summer and fall of 1948.
PITTSBURGH, May 21 (AP) -An eighth-inning explosion that netted seven runs enabled the Boston Braves to rout the Pittsburgh Pirates, 8 to 2, today and take the rubber game of their three-game series.

LINCOLN, Nebr., May 21 (AP) -- The Missouri Tigers won their third successive Big Seven Conference outdoor track and field title with an amazing show of team power that clicked for 113 13-45 points on a wet and slow cinder layout today.

MEDIEVAL beauty, present-day scholarship and a romance of the art world have combined to enable the Cloisters, the branch of the Metropolitan Museum in Fort Tryon Park, to present the result of the combination in a unique setting.

DALLAS, May 21 -- Department store sales in the Eleventh Federal reserve district during the last week registered gains over the corresponding week of last year, but were behind sales of the preceding week. It was the fifth week since Jan. 1 that sales showed a gain over last year.

NORTHFIELD, Vt., May 21 -- The state of Vermont, aware of the small manufacturer's growing importance to its economy, has re-organized its Bureau of Industrial Research to do the same job for him that the Agricultural Extension Service does for farmers.
CHICAGO, May 21 (AP) -- Today's report ofI the markets in the Union Stockyards by the I United States Department of Agriculture follows:
There was a parade of winning favorites at Belmont Park yesterday. Drum major in it was Fred W. Hooper's Olympia.

GENEVA, May 21 -- In an economic as well as in a political sense Germany remains the key to the future development of Europe. Whatever the results of the Foreign Ministers' Conference, the problem of how to get Germany off the dole must be tackled in terms of the realities of the European and world situation in 1949.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 21 (AP) -- The Norwalk Tire and Rubber Company has filed a petition in bankruptcy in the United States district court here in an attempt to reorganize. The move was made yesterday a few hours after Superior Court Judge William J. Shea in Bridgeport had lifted an injunction restraining the management from starting bankruptcy proceedings.

JAPANESE iris are the triumphant end of the iris flowering season which begins very early in the spring with various dwarf varieties, so suited to rock gardens. Blooming in June and July, this late type rounds out the year for this family.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif. THERE'S a fight raging today over the last big waterhole in the Southwest, but it is being fought with oratory and statistics in Washington instead of with blazing guns and Sheriff's posses out on the desert.

THE extreme point reached so far by twentieth-century art in its flight from natural appearances is nonobjectivism. That it has never aroused the curiosity and hostility accorded far less revolutionary varieties of contemporary art is odd; possibly its clean-cut, machine-like appearance flatters those who nervously applaud all evidences of what they like to think, mistakenly in this case, is inspired by the scientific spirit.

THE continuing argument about reissues of old motion pictures, which labor, independent producers and some independent exhibitors carry on against the major distributors of films, came up last week before the embattled Motion Picture Industry Council.

Every Friday afternoon -- and it has been a practice for the last year -- six World War II veterans take over the Capitol Bowling Alleys at 1680 Broadway.

READERS of Mrs. Chanler's absorbing book of reminiscences, "Roman Spring," will recall that throughout her long life music has been an affair of passionate interest. As a girl she had ambitions to become a professional pianist, and when typical nineteenth-century family opposition quashed these hopes she became, instead, the voracious and discriminating lover of music that she has remained.

The Senate Foreign Relations Committee last April 27 began hearings on the Atlantic treaty. During the following three weeks (sixteen days of actual hearings, totaling about seventy-five hours) ninety-seven witnesses appeared before the committee and gave testimony totaling nearly a half million words.

PARIS, May 21 -- The United States, Britain and France were reported tonight to have agreed that economic unity of Germany could not be brought about by the forthcoming Paris meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers unless the Soviet Union was willing to link such an objective to political unity and to make major concessions on reparations and currency.

ONE comes refreshed and gratified from a reading of Mr. Rusk's long-awaited biography. In recent decades the stature of Ralph Waldo Emerson -- at least as a matter of the public record -- has seemed appreciably to be diminishing. The pontifical "Essay" is no longer a congenial literary type, and the dogged optimism of "Compensation" strikes modern sensibility as intolerable. even as obscene.

TO city dwellers who follow the flower seasons as spectators, late May and early June are portrayed by iris. Gardeners, too, count on their stunning blooms to supply the main display between spring flowering bulbs and the June peonies and roses, although the several types are used as well for spring and summer color.
BUENOS AIRES, May 21 -- The expected commercial accord between Argentina and Britain, which has been in the process of negotiation since three months ago tomorrow, did not materialize this morning.

THE most important fact about the present state of business is the growing reluctance to spend money. The drop in the willingness to spend is indicated by the decline of retail sales in relation to personal income. During the first three months of 1949, personal incomes were running about 4.8 per cent above the corresponding period of 1948, but retail sales were running about 1.7 per cent below 1948.

IN reviewing a concert of Chamber Music of the Columbia Festival, Mr. Downes ended the paragraph concerning Edgar Varese's "Integrales" with this remark: "Music? Probably not. We can beg that question."

Joe Westman, St. John's Prep sophomore ace, led his school to the team honors in the Eastern interscholastic tennis tournament for private day and boarding schools while crushing John Devendorf, LaSalle Military Academy, in the singles final at the Boulevard Gardens Courts in Woodside, Queens.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 21 -- A five-year grant of $100,000 for recruiting able college graduates for teaching has been made to Princeton University's Woodrow Wilson Fellowship Program by the Carnegie Corporation of New York, Dr. Harold W. Doods, president of the university, announced today.

ST. JOHN'S, Nfld. -- Newfoundland will get its visitors this summer as the tenth province of the Dominion of Canada, a role it assumed on April 1. But there will be few changes discernble to the visitor.

ST LOUIS, Mo., May 21 -- There are impressive opportunities for new business in the farm-equipment industry, a survey of farmers' opinions taken by one of the nation's leading farm-management services indicates. Farmers reported that equipment manufacturers are failing to meet practical every-day needs, that much equipment is too light and wears out too easily.
A new Metropolitan Baseball champion was crowned at Brooklyn College Field yesterday when, after a three and a quarter hour struggle, St. John's walloped the Kingsmen, 19 -- 6.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Employment in nonagricultural establishments leveled off at 43,900,000 in mid-April, arresting the decline of the preceding three months, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

SIBERIAN iris, one of the loveliest and, paradoxically, one of the most overlooked groups of the iris family, are suddenly claiming a popularity they long have deserved. These charming perennials require little attention, seldom have to be replanted, supply long-lasting cut flowers and are almost entirely free from diseases or pests.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- No one ever expected, least of all members of Congress, the progress that is being made today on Capitol Hill toward adoption of the recommendations of former President Herbert Hoover's Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government.

Prices in selective stock issues last week moved into new low territory. Further "readjustment" in industry, with the downward trend of basic indicators more pronounced, continued to haunt financial markets. However, it was the specter of a fourth round of wage increases issuing from the executive board's meeting of the CIO that was held generally to have precipitated the market's new setback. Yesterday's two-hour period ended Saturday trading sessions until October.

Responding to a poll conducted in recent weeks by the Commercial and Financial Chronicle, 799 dealers in securities, or 68 per cent of those making returns, said that they favored repeal of the Maloney Act, the statutory basis for the self-policing function now played in the securities industry by the National Association of Securities Dealers.
Sixteen domestic air carriers, including both trunk and feeder lines, have asked the Civil Aeronautics Board for a nine-month extension of the Family Fare Plan, it was learned yesterday.

Barring the highly improbable revision of the Robinson-Patman act, members of the toiletries and cosmetics industry were urged last week to accept the necessity of conforming to that section of the anti-trust laws which prohibit price discrimination in dealing with retailers.

Assailing the decision of the United States Supreme Court in the case of the Rev. Arthur W. Terminiello, involving free speech, Rabbi William F. Rosenblum in Temple Israel, 210 West Ninety-first Street, held yesterday that the majority of the court "overlooked the fact that every citizen is entitled to be protected from slander and libel."

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., May 21 -- With its varsity oarsmen supplying the crusher in the feature race, Boston University's crews captured all three races in the seventh annual Dad Vail Regatta on the Hudson today. The victory enabled Jim Nesworthy's varsity to retire the Dad Vail Trophy as a result of taking the race three years in a row.

Fire thwarted an attempt to crack a safe early yesterday morning. How long the thieves had been working when the flames sent them running was not known. However, the blaze was extinguished quickly with negligible damage.

BERLIN, May 21 -- A Civil Service hearing on Alexander Saks to determine whether the New York lawyer should be dismissed from Military Government employment was ordered reopened on instructions of Gen. Lucius D. Clay, Maj. Gen. George P. Hays, Deputy United States Military Governor said today.

THE annual 500-mile automobile race at Indianapolis serves not only as one of the nation's leading sports events but also as a testing ground for automobile, tire and motor fuel developments. Engineers and researchers of virtually every segment of the automotive industry are expected to attend the Memorial Day event at the Speedway, as they have the elimination trials held for several weeks preceding the contest.

KABUL, Afghanistan, May 21 -- Afghanistan will ask Great Britain and, if that fails, possibly the United Nations Security Council to intervene in her explosive dispute with Pakistan over the so-called Free Tribal Area that separates the two countries and contains the strategic and historic Khyber Pass, gateway between Central Asia and the Indian subcontinent.

Although swayed by reverse reasoning, no angler receives news of good bay and offshore fishing with greater delight than the dry-fly purist, for he knows this fishing will attract thousands of anglers who have been "cluttering up" the trout streams.

LONDON, May 21 -- Marshal of the Royal Air Force Lord Tedder, chief of the Air Staff, received a citation at the United States Embassy here today in recognition of his leadership in World War II aviation and of the cooperation of Royal Air Force and United States air forces during and since the war.

MEDIA, Pa., May 21 -- Horses owned by C. Mahlon Kline of Ambler won the Rose Tree Plate, top brush event, and both divisions of the feature flat race today at the annual spring meeting of the Rose Tree Fox Hunting Club.

NEWARK, N. J., May 21 -- A reduction of 3 cents a quart in the retail price of milk in Northern New Jersey, the largest single drop in the memory of veteran dealers, will become effective Monday, it was disclosed today.

PLAINFIELD, N. J., May 21 -- Harold Sanderson and Dr. Stephen G. Lee of Canoe Brook, the defending champions, were upset in the second round of the New Jersey State pro-amateur match-play championship today at the Plainfield Country Club.

Reversion to the old general-store principle of stocking all the household needs under one roof and continued increases in the use of self-service are two notable trends in the grocery business today, according to an analysis of grocery operations given yesterday by Paul S. Willis, president of the Grocery Manufacturers of America.

CHICAGO, May 21 -- At least eleven persons are known to have been killed and more than fifty persons injured in a series of tornadoes which hit Palestine, in Crawford County, Ill., and parts of Sullivan County, Ind. Two of the deaths occurred in a park on the outskirts of Terre Haute.

A public school teacher who helped her young crippled niece walk normally twenty years ago by encouraging her to swim is applying the same method successfully at Far Rockaway High School, according to the testimony of doctors in that community.

PALMA, Majorca -- The Balearic Islands, counted among the most popular Mediterrenean vacation spots before the war, are getting ready for what is expected to be their first major post-war tourist year. Regular air service today will speed visitors from Barcelona or Valencia to Palma, capital of Majorca, in two hours.

MOSCOW, May 21 -- The Literary Gazette, organ of the Soviet writers union, reports to the public today, on the basis of a survey of American advertising, that it is easier for an American to become a criminal or a police spy than a millionaire or his own boss.

Although the double taxation of income is constitutional, the right to avoid double taxation is sometimes recognized by statute and upheld by the courts. This right extends also to reducing or avoiding taxes by legal means.
EVANSTON, Ill., May 21 -- The Western Conference henceforth will be called the "Big Ten," even though the new member, Michigan State College, will not compete until the 1950-51 school year.

Unless there is an early increase in the demands for power by heavy-industry customers, the electric light and power companies of the nation may consider a downward revision of their expansion budget.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The battle which was fought here this week between the left and right wings of the CIO has been long in the making. It was a culmination of the rightist majority's efforts over the past few years to adjust the CIO to a changing world.

I believe it is verifiable that most literary treatments of the hill folk display a kind of condescension which takes the form of a thesis that among their unspoiled simplicity is to be found a refuge from the complexity of the city.

AMID the headaches of the current theatre ticket investigation those concerned may garner a crumb of consolation from a passage in Hesketh Pearson's new biography of Charles Dickens. Mr. Pearson, reporting on the bloody scrimmages attending the rush for tickets to hear Mr. Dickens read from his works on his second American tour in 1867, says that what perplexed George Dolby, Dickens' English manager, was "the trade in tickets.
OTTAWA, May 21 (Canadian Press) -- For the first time since April, 1948, Canada had a debit balance on her foreign trade the past March of $16,900,000, the Bureau of Statistics reported today.
PRINCETON, N. J., May 21 -- Setting a new record for the mile and three-quarter course, Princeton's crew won the Carnegie Cup today.

ONCE more this summer railroad fans and amateur photographers from all over the world will be crowding aboard the Silverton, one of the most colorful trains in the Rocky Mountains, to make the trip between Durango and Silverton over the narrow-gauge tracks of the Denver and Rio Grande Western Railroad in the southwestern section of Colorado.

TWO Czechs who attained prominence in literature enter philatelys gallery on Czechoslovakia 4-koruna violet and 8k brown-gray stamps. Jiri Wolker, whose likeness is on 4k, was regarded as "the most talented Czech poet of his generation,'' his verse touching on social conditions.

A "Senior Forum on Loyalty, Security and Democracy" on Friday at 2 P. M. in Columbia University's McMillin Academic Theatre, will be a feature of pre-commencement activities for Columbia College's Class of 1949, Gene Rossides, chairmon of the forum committee, announced yesterday.

Yale University is now making available to the public a series of "packaged" language courses based on wartime teaching developments. The courses, which include printed texts and from eleven to twelve hours of recorded speech, are being produced at the university's Institute of Far Eastern Languages.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission says it is "routine" for security officers to slip pieces of uranium or other materials out of restricted areas at the commission's plant in Hanford, Wash., for a check on how well the place is guarded.

GENEVA, May 21 -- The United Nations Economic Commission for Europe decided unanimously tonight to establish a permanent committee for the development of East-West trade. Both Russia and the United States voted for the measure.
CHICAGO, May 21 (AP) -- A series of newspaper reports that some Illinois newspapermen have been on the state's payroll has stirred up widespread interest, criticism and controversy.

"BE careful what you say or do," runs a line in W. H. Auden's poem. "The Witnesses," from which Miss Berridge has taken the title of her first novel; and it is this sense of oppressive conformity, of a deterministic pattern governing lives, which is the theme of the book.

DETROIT, May 21 -- Negotiation between the Ford Motor Company and the striking United Automobile Workers, CIO, neared a breaking point tonight with a rejection by the company of a modified proposal by the union for settlement of the walkout, now in its seventeenth day.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 21 (UP) -- Joseph Angyal of the New York Athletic Club, rowing over the rough Charles River as if it were a millpond, won the two top singles events in the American Henley Regatta today.

BOSTON, May 21 -- Considering that industrial conditions in New England are probably as depressed as in any section of the country, merchants are surprised by the local department store sales. The gain for the week ended May 14 was in contrast with a drop for the country as a whole and an analysis of Federal Reserve figures shows the Boston district did better than any part of the country except the Southwest.

Mrs. F. H. La Guardia, widow of the former Mayor of New York, will officiate this week at the renaming of a converted Army transport in honor of her husband. American Export Lines, Inc., which has chartered the liner La Guardia from the Maritime Commission, yesterday made public details of the naming ceremony, to take place at 11 A. M. Tuesday.

MAY I shout my thanks to you for printing Gerald W. Johnson's penetrating discussion of the failure of current American literature to give a true picture of contemporary Americans? Judging from that literature, we are a nation of perverts and prigs, brutes and bores, and there is no health or courage in us.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., May 21 -- Rutgers snappy football combination -- Herm Hering and Frank Burns -- clicked on the baseball diamond here this afternoon as the Scarlet downed Princeton, 3 -- 0.

IF it were possible to conjure up all the annoyances of an under-rehearsed opening night on the West End stage and a Grade B motion picture, that would be British television when I first ventured into it before the war and right after the seven-year hiatus forced by the fighting in Europe.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- A Senate subcommittee sought by subpoena today to force the Justice and State Departments to turn over 168 files bearing on its investigation of alien subversives.

A proposal to conduct a "test case" to determine by court decision the legal status of certain classes of salesmen was made in a letter written yesterday by the National Council of Salesmen's Organizations, 80 West Fortieth Street, to Hugh Jackson, executive vice president of the Better Business Bureau of New York, Inc.

HELSINKI. COVERING almost the whole of one of the long walls in the room where Prime Minister Karl August Fagerholm presides over Finland's cabinet of Labor ministers is a large colorful painting. It shows Czar Alexander I receiving a pledge of fealty from the nobility, the clergy, the peasants and purghers, representing the four estates of the Finnish Diet.

The Council of Foreign Ministers -set up at Potsdam in the summer of victory in 1945 to write peace treaties -- began its fifth meeting in London on Nov. 25, 1947. The Big Four Foreign Ministers then were Marshall of the U. S., Molotov of the U.S.S.R., Bevin of Britain and Bidault of France.

LONDON, May 21 -- Sir Stafford Cripps, Britain's economic chief, impressed upon cotton textile operatives today that they were in the forefront of Britain's struggle for economic survival. His address to a conference of United Textile Workers in Blackpool underlined the warning issued last night by his aide at the Treasury, W. Glenvil Hall, that the Government feared that a slump might come.

CHICAGO, May 21 -- College seniors in Central Western schools are appraising with misgivings their chances of obtaining jobs after graduation next month. They realize that they may find themselves on the selling end of a buyers' market for the first time in eight years.

OAKLAND, Calif., May 21 (AP) -- California's powerful varsity crew, 1948 Olympic champions, closed out its Coast rowing activities today by easily defeating the University of Wisconsin Badgers over a three-mile course on the Oakland estuary.
It is remarkable how in the crisscross of world events we have lost sight of the gravest problem of our democracy, potentially more dangerous than the Soviet army.

FRANKFORT, Germany, May 21 -- Western German officials in the Parliamentary Council have been alerted for possible summoning to Paris during the meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers, an authoritative source disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Pinkerton's National Detective Agency, Inc., and a unit of the CIO Longshoremen's Union, which organized Pinkerton guards on the San Francisco waterfront, were found guilty today of violating the TaftHartley Law for refusing work to four guards who did not pay their union dues.

THE twenty-third Festival of the International Society for Contemporary Music, which took place in Sicily from April 22 to 30, was more interesting in the choice of works than last year's Amsterdam festival. More trends in modern composition and more musical forms were represented in the course of the crowded nine days.

A denial that Mayor O'Dwyer or members of his administration had ever sought to interfere with the policies of the Board of Education was entered last night by Charles J. Bensley, a Bronx member of the board.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- A rise in the number of high school students who hold jobs from 4 per cent in 1940 to 19 per cent was reported today by the Census Bureau. For college students the percentage increased from 16 to 23 per cent.

BUFFALO, N. Y., May 21 -- A proposal that the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the U. S. A. meet biennially rather than yearly, as has been the custom since 1788, was overwhelmingly defeated here today. The 860 commissioners refused to accept the recommendation of a special committee on structure and functioning and upheld instead a substitute proposal offered in a minority report.

NEXT time they try to feed you a studio publicity release about how profligate the movie compames are, you can send that dish right back to the kitchen. Paramount, for instance, has been so profligate as still to have in stock, twenty-five years after she left the company, Miss Gloria Swanson's whole wardrobe of size 2 1/2 shoes.

How does the director of a laboratory devoted to fundamental research direct? How does he decide which projects are to be carried out and which rejected? Dr. Ellice McDonald, director of the Biochemical Research Foundation, Newark, Del., goes into these and other matters in an article which appears in the current issue of The Journal of the Franklin Institute.

John Kohout, president of the New York and Richmond Gas Company, which has a monopoly on manufactured gas in Staten Island, announced yesterday that his company had made application to the state Public Service Commission for permission to convert to natural gas.

Fields, George Lashwood ("the London Dandy"). Clarice Vance, Fred Niblo's perennial troupes, that excruciating paper hanger, Willard Simms, whose slapstick with ladders, paste and rolls on rolls of wall paper was so hilarious?

FRIDAY will see the start of the year's first big holiday week-end. By falling n Monday, Memorial Day provides a four-day week-end to many who will take advantage of the extra time for short excursions to country and shore resorts.

WITH fresh radio programs so few and far between the listener is probably well advised to approach any new show rather gingerly, lest an unkind word drive another ambitious soul off to the wonderland of television.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The State Department's Voice of America and the British Broadcasting Company are making distinct progress in their campaign to crash through Communist jamming with an assault of sixty-one broadcasting stations and to reach the Russian people with the news of the Paris conference of Foreign Ministers on German issues and of the world generally.

Backed by the usual pledges of volunteer promotional support from leaders in the financial world and other quarters the Treasury opened on schedule its spring E-bond savings bond drive. Government workers and private citizens will be engaged in a six-week effort to foster increased acquisitions of Government bonds through systematic subscription plans, such as payroll savings and bond-a-month acquisitions deductible from bank accounts.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- A rise in the number of high school students who hold jobs from 4 per cent in 1940 to 19 per cent was reported today by the Census Bureau. For college students the percentage increased from 16 to 23 per cent.
SOPERTON, Ga., May 22 (AP) -- The Mayor of a small south Georgia town told today of ripping off the masks of "three men in Ku Klux Klan regalia who frightened several ladies."

CHARLOTTE, N. C., May 22 (AP) -- A surprise choice, the University of Richmond, today joined Wake Forest, Kentucky and Mississippi State in accepting invitations to play in the third annual District 3 N. C. A. A. baseball tournament at Griffith Park here June 9-11.

PARIS, May 22 (AP) -- Miss Louise Brough, America's No. 2 ranking women's tennis player, was beaten in the fourth round of the French international tournament today. Miss Joan Curry, British Wrightman Cup star, turned the trick, 4 -- 6, 9 -- 7, 6 -- 2.

PARIS, May 22 -- The broad lines of the policy for Germany to be upheld by the three Western powers at the meeting of the Big Four Council of Foreign Ministers opening here tomorrow at 4 P. M. were endorsed today by Secretary of State Dean Acheson, British Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin and French Foreign Minister Robert Schuman.

HARLECH, Wales, May 22 (AP) -- Miss Grace Lenczyk, the rhythmic swinger from Newington, Conn., goes afte rher international "grand slam" of golf titles tomorrow in the British women's amateur tournament.

TOKYO, May 22 -- Traders are commencing to complain that floor prices set by the Occupation and the Board of Trade are smothering Japan's export trade. The floor prices are now said to be so high for raw silk and finished cotton goods that Japan cannot hope to compete in her usual markets -- and the bulk of Japan's export has been in these items.

The American Radio Association, CIO, with 2,000 members on all three coasts who serve aboard merchant ships, lodged a strong protest last week with the Federal Communications Commission against its proposed restrictions on the employability of physically handicapped operators.

A decrease in dollar volume of business in 1948, compared with the previous year, was suffered by the majority of men's wear stores throughout the country, according to the twentieth annual survey by the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers, released today.

This country will rightly agree with President Truman in regarding the death of James Forrestal as a casualty of the war. His tragedy is directly traceable to his overwork on behalf of his country. All those who came into contact with him knew how relentlessly he drove himself and how no sacrifice of strength and energy could be too much.

TEANECK, N. J., May 22 -- Eighty-six years old last month, Louis Rich of 290 Wyoming Avenue, South Orange, will complete his first year at college Wednesday morning. His last class of the year at Bergen College here will be in psychology.

"Ruth," a Pentecost oratorio by Mordecai Sandberg, Israeli composer now resident in this city, was presented in Hebrew last night at Town Hall. Frank Kneisel conducted the work, which was sung by Ingrid Robertson, soprano; Arlouine Goodjohn, mezzo-Soprano; Alice C. Mack, contralto; Aaron Freudman, tenor; Manfred Hecht, baritone, and Leon Lischner, bass.

PARIS, May 22 -- The Russians, forced on the defensive by the march of events in Germany since December, 1947, must do the talking and make concessions at the meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers opening here tomorrow, in the opinion of Western experts on Soviet foreign policy.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., May 22 -- In a downpouring sou'easter twenty craft went out today in the inaugural championship regatta of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound, which was held by the New York Yacht Club.

Following installation of Francis R. St. John as chief librarian of the Brooklyn Public Library in the central building on Grand Army Plaza tomorrow at 3 P. M., 600 visitors are expected to take a "behind the scenes" tour of the library.

Extending his "affection and gratitude" to clergy, members of religious orders and the laity of New York, "many of them not of my faith," Cardinal Spellman yesterday prayed that God would bless the Roman Catholic Church of New York in continuing its essential mission "the salvation of souls."

ZURICH, May 22 -- To the keen satisfaction of all investors in Switzerland, ordinary shares of two more American concerns, the Eastman Kodak Company and the United States Steel Corporation, have been listed for dealing on the stock exchanges of Zurich, Basle and Geneva as of May 16.

With California shipping 778 carloads of new potatoes one day last week, the abundant season for this vegetable is in full swing here. Though there are a few newly dug spuds on the market all year round, they're most plentiful from this month until the last of the Long Island crop is harvested in July.

Reorders for summer merchandise received by the wholesale apparel market here last week centered on popular price and low-end dresses, with emphasis given to cotton styles, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- President Truman, members of his Cabinet and other leading officials paid tribute today to James Forrestal as one who had served his country with "devotion and great distinction" through long and difficult years.

FRANKFORT, Germany, May 22 -- Two United States Army constabulary soldiers, whose arrest and imprisonment by the Czechoslovak police when they wandered over the German border resulted in official protests by the United States, were "pardoned" and released today.

PORTMARNOCK, Ireland, May 22 (AP) -- Willie Turnesa, the United States amateur titleholder, has been installed favorite to regain the British amateur golf crown in the championship match play tournament starting tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (UP) -- In a daring sea maneuver 500 miles off New York, the aircraft carrier U. S. S. Philippine Sea today pulled alongside a small transport ship and took off a passenger, critically ill, for transfusions of a rare-type blood.

Services attended by members of the city government and Congress, together with representatives of foreign countries, were held in many parts of the city yesterday in commemoration of the heroism of American dead in both world wars.

WESTBURY, L. I., May 22 -- A house pet from the Giralda Farms of Madison, N. J., the 3-year-old German shepherd, Giralda's Gelmar, went to best in show this dreary day in the forty-seventh all-breed event of the Long Island Kennel Club on the grounds of the Meadow Brook Club.

When the City Planning Commission adopted a zoning amendment limiting to a maximum of thirty feet the height of new buildings around a half-mile radius of the boundaries of private airports, the question to Commissioner Orton was simply whether New York would participate in the benefits of non-commercial air travel, or whether it would remain in what he termed the aviation "horse and buggy days."

YONKERS, N. Y., May 22 -- If the dandelion in the front lawn is felled by a spray, garden flowers bloom in December, potatoes stop sprouting in the vegetable bin and aquatic weeds no longer get snarled in the motorboat propeller, the chances are that Dr. William Crocker is at the root of the phenomena.

PITTSBURGH, May 22 -- The volume of orders for steel last week was reported to have held at good levels but to be continuing along more normal lines. Most of the business that swelled order books for July delivery and beyond was actively "sought after," and it was said indications were that salesmen would have to work hard and fast to keep books full enough to support a high operating rate.

The news that Frances Taussig plans to retire as executive director of the Jewish Family Service is a matter of general regret to the entire field of social work. Quite apart from the dynamic and wise leadership she has given to the profession itself, her contributions over the years have left a definite imprint on family life in this city and have extended well beyond the immediate community of New York.

PITTSBURGH, May 22 (AP) -- Dick Sisler came through with a ninth-inning pinch-hit double today to score Jackie Mayo with the winning run as Philadelphia nosed out the Pittsburgh Pirates, 6 to 5, before a crowd or 31,465. The second game of a scheduled double-header was called on account of wet grounds.

CINCINNATI, May 22 -- The Reds finally beat the Dodgers at Crosley Field today after nearly a two-year lapse, but it required a remarkable one hit performance by the veteran southpaw, Ken Raffensberger, to snap the streak that had extended to nineteen games.

The visit of President Dutra of Brazil to this country has already shown tangible and felicitous results. The White House has been able to announce a sympathetic agreement on a program of mutual economic and cultural advancement. At least two new treaties are forecast, one to stimulate private investment in Brazil and the other to provide a cultural accord, and there is a possible third compact in the projected talks to avoid double taxation.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 22 (AP) -- This city today began a week-long festival to celebrate its three hundredth anniversary.

Negotiations at the top level between Canada and the United States will open today in an effort to reach an agreement on Canada's urgent demands for picking up more air-line passengers in this country, it was learned yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, May 22 -- The Giants and Cardinals today indulged themselves in what might be termed a one-day thumping tournament that produced some rather startling results. In each instance the side that did the most thumping came out second best.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., May 22 -- Federal specifications issued by the United States Bureau of Standards should be used as a guide to our purchasing, declared George J. Cronin, purchasing agent for the Commonwealth of Massachusetts and vice president of the National Association of Purchasing Agents, at a meeting of the New England purchasing officials group.

BROOKVILLE, L. I., May 22 -- The Cherry Valley No. 1 combination of Dr. O. V. Wibell, Frank Simonson, Reinert Torgerson and Howard Westphal scored 326 to wrest the Long Island Golf Association team championship from the defending titleholder, Rockville, in the eighteenth tournament at the Brookville Country Club today.

PARIS, May 22 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson, British Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin and French Foreign Minister Robert Schuman were reported to have approved an agreement today that no political unity formula would be accepted for Germany in the forthcoming meeting here of the Council of Foreign Ministers unless it was based upon the extension of the Bonn Constitution to the Soviet zone.
For the second time, compulsory health insurance will be the principal issue in the annual election of officers of the Medical Society of the County of New York today.

LONDON, May 22 -- Sentiment in the financial markets here has not been helped by events of the past week. On the contrary, the feeling of unsettlement and vague apprehension has increased. The City has a feeling that we are drifting slowly toward something unpleasant in either economics or politics or in both.

A diminishing job market for young people and longer waiting periods for those seeking advice on plans for work and training from free vocational agencies were reported yesterday by the Vocational Advisory Service.
