HAWTHORNE, N. Y., May 22 -- Donald A. Bleakley of 252 Marietta Avenue was found at 1 A. M. today, pajama-clad and carrying a bottle, trudging in front of Paul Wetzel's home at 291 Marietta Avenue. Mr. Wetzel summoned State Policemen Joseph Brown and John Murray from the Troop K barracks near by.
UTICA, N. Y., May 22 -- Jonathan B. Bingham of New York City was re-elected chairman of New York State Americans for Democratic Action at the closing business session of its annual convention today.

BOGOTA, Colombia, May 22 (UP) Conservative President Mariano Ospina Perez organized a Government of Army men and Conservative politicians today to replace the coalition Cabinet disrupted last night by the resignation of six Liberal Ministers.
ROME, May 22 -- Republican party officials said this evening that their labor representatives had formally withdrawn from the Communist controlled CGIL (Italian General Labor Confederation).

A new blast of tornadoes and windstorms struck in widely scattered areas of the country yesterday, The Associated Press reported. These storms followed a series of tornadoes which whipped the Midwest Saturday night. They raised the week-end death toll to forty-six and the number of injured to more than 229.

The states of Ohio, Oregon and Louisiana will be borrowers on serial bond issues in the market for tax-exempt obligations this week. On Wednesday, Ohio will offer $12,500,000 of veterans bonus bonds, and Louisiana will take bids on $1,749,000 of institutional improvement obligations.
Eleven years ago today Sally was four -- and frightened. It was her first day in nursery school and there was so much noise, so many voices. Sally was unaccustomed to sound.

It wasn't a fit day for man, beast or baseball players yesterday, so the scheduled Yankees-Browns double-header, the first of the year at the Stadium, was postponed. But the real news emanated from the inner council and had nothing whatsoever to do with the weather.

Mayor O'Dwyer's campaign to obtain assurance of improved wages and working conditions for taxicab drivers as a condition of his approval of pending local legislation to increase taxicab fares by 27 per cent has made progress, it was learned yesterday.

BERLIN, Monday, May 23 -- The first death and a toll of 1,000 injured were reported in the Berlin rail strike today after hours of continued violence between strikers and heavily armed Communist railway police.

With hopes tempered by past disappointments, the eyes of the world turn today to Paris, where four men, comprising the Council of Foreign Ministers and representing all the effective power in the world, meet around the diplomatic bargaining table in a new effort to determine the fate of Germany, which involves the fate of Europe.

The manner in which Owen Davis Jr., son of the playwright, was drowned remained obscure yesterday despite a post-mortem. Dr. Theodore J. Curphy, Nassau County Medical Examiner, said further tests would be necessary.

PARIS, May 22 -- French exports in April reached their highest level since the liberation at $145,800,000 for total sales abroad. Experts are now figuring in dollars so as to have a more stable basis of comparison than the franc. They are also keeping account of variations in the purchasing power of the dollar in order to increase that stability.

BOSTON, May 22 (AP) -- Mel Parnell, Red Sox left-handed pitcher, belted a sharp single into left field in the last of the twelfth today, scoring Al Zarilla from second base with the needed run for a 3-2 Boston victory over the Detroit Tigers.

VIENNA, May 22 -- The introduction of a new Constitution, incorporating Soviet political forms; the final liquidation of Kulaks, resumption of the campaign against the Roman Catholic Church and the imposition of further police restrictions on liberty and freedom of movement; are expected to be early sequels to last Sunday's election in Hungary, according to advices received here.

CLEVELAND, May 22 (AP) -- Stan Stanczyk, weight-lifting star representing the York (Pa.) Bar Bell Club, broke three world records today in capturing the A.A.U. light heavyweight championship at Masonic Auditorium.

CHICAGO, May 22 (AP) -- The Braves shelled Johnny Schmitz for five runs in the first three innings and coasted behind Johnny Sain for a 7-2 victory over the Cubs before 15,113 fans today. One run off Sain was a homer by Cal McLish, who succeeded Schmitz in the third.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Senator Bourke B. Hickenlooper of Iowa, who fought hard two years ago for Senate confirmation of David E. Lilienthal as chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, urged President Truman today to request Mr. Lilienthal's resignation on grounds of "incredible mismanagement."

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The story of how Louis Johnson succeeded James Forrestal as Secretary of Defense was told recently by Mr. Johnson with the permission of President Truman, it was learned tonight.

PAWTUCKET, R. I., May 22 -- The H and B American Machine Company of this city, manufacturer of textile machinery, will close May 27 until "early July" because production has caught up with a backlog of orders, company officials announced over the weekend.

SHANGHAI, Monday, May 23 -- The broad military situation around this city was frozen Saturday and Sunday. The Nationalists seemed to have halted the seaward exodus of their men and machines of war. The Communists have still not opened an all-out drive to pinch off the Nationalist escape route at the mouth of the Whangpoo.
Two developments of the past few days have served to add fresh fuel to the long smoldering controversy over European currency devaluation.

CHICAGO, May 22 -- Government support prices in grain do not mean that the markets will not sell below the loan level, as was thoroughly demonstrated on the Board of Trade last week when the May delivery in various grains went off the blackboards yesterday below the loan level in all instances with fairly liberal amounts of cash wheat and corn delivered to holders of the May futures.

BERLIN, May 22 -- The United States Military Government has reluctantly approved press laws passed by the Wuerttemberg-Baden and Bremen State Legislatures and will relinquish its newspaper licensing powers in these two States about June 1, it was learned today.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) -- The White Sex rallied for two runs with two out in the eighth inning, then clustered four runs with two out in the ninth to defeat Washington, 6 -- 4, today.

PHILADELPHIA, May 22 (AP) -- Joe Kirkwood Jr., a front runner from the start, wobbled precariously in the home stretch today but had enough left to win the sixth annual Inquirer invitation golf tournament by four strokes.

PARIS, Monday, May 23 -- The Finance Committee of the French National Assembly approved the Government's controversial fiscal program early today after it had ripped into the Government's reform measure and amended it drastically.

PLAINFIELD, N. J., May 22 -- Andy La Pola and Pat Mucci of Preakness Hills won the New Jersey State pro-amateur match-play championship today by defeating Danny Williams Jr. and Bob Zbikowski of The Knoll, 2 up, at the Plainfield Country Club.

Alva Johnston, whose profile on Wilson Mizner ran in The New Yorker a few years ago, is at work on a biography that has the working title of "Wilson Mizner: His Life and Times." It is based on new material obtained by Mr. Johnston through talks with persons who knew Mr. Mizner and visits to places where he made his reputation. Farrar, Straus plans the book for publication next year.

The city's accident control program will be extended to 90,000 municipal employes today, when thirty representatives of ten city departments meet for a week-long series of conferences at the Bureau of the Budget in the Municipal Building.

As one who has been privileged to consult with the President's Council of Economic Advisers as a participant in its Business Advisory Committee, I was interested to read the editorial in your issue of May 12 praising "the swing to economy" in Federal Government expenditures.
Summer theatres announced new plans for the coming season's productions here yesterday.

James Vincent Forrestal rose, in nine years of outstanding service to his country, from one of the "anonymous secretaries" of the late President Franklin D. Roosevelt to become the first Secretary of Defense. As head of the National Military Establishment he made the beginnings of a new chapter in the defense history of the United States.

Prices of cotton for future delivery in the domestic market had only insignificant changes last week. At the week's end active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange registered changes ranging from a net decline of 6 points to an advance of 12 points, compared with declines of 6 to 17 points in the week previous.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 22 -- With just a little more than two weeks to go until it must adjourn, the Connecticut General Assembly finds itself still in the same stalemate in which it convened in January.
PARIS, May 22 -- Charles de Gaulle, addressing the closing session of the national council of his followers in Vincennes today, gave warning that the Bonn Constitution would reconstruct the Reich.

Vice Admiral John D. Price, vice chief of Naval Operations, asserted yesterday that land-based and mobile air power "are neither duplicative nor in competition but are complementary." He emphasized that the development of both types "is essential to the most effective destruction of the enemy's industrial potential and will to fight."
Acceptance of Christianity as the basis for a secure order of life was urged yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Sidney Malcolm Berry of London, general secretary of the International Congregational Council.

DETROIT, May 22 -- Negotiations to settle the strike against the Ford Motor Company were suspended indefinitely at 11:30 tonight, just thirty minutes before the expiration of a deadline that had been set by the United Automobile Workers, CIO.

The city's observance of National Maritime Day will culminate today in a colorful ceremony honoring the thirteen Coast Guard men who lost their lives last January aboard the cutter Eastwind when that vessel Collided with a tanker.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., May 22 -- Show horses qualified themselves for track running as "mudders" and normally immaculate riders were near unrecognizable mud-shattered specimens at the annual spring Hutchinson horse show staged today at Teddy Gussenhoven's Hutchinson Farms on Wilmot Road.

Investment protection in bilateral treaties plus tax incentives to provide conditions conducive to the flow of American private capital abroad in support of President Truman's Point 4 was recommended over the week-end by the National Foreign Trade Council.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- A large majority of the 40,000 new car dealers of the United States are definitely opposed to any extension of the present credit control law, according to a statement submitted today to Senator A. Willis Robertson, chairman of the subcommittee on credit law extension of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee.

Daylight Saving Time is supposed to be unpopular among cows, and persons who must travel between Standard and Daylight zones occasionally find EDT annoying, but now as twilight falls a little later each night it is evident that the chief losers at Daylight Time's annual arrival are neither cows nor travelers.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., May 22 -- Proving the best competitors over a rain-drenched, fog-shrouded course, the team of William Walker and Robert Marquard posted a 68 yesterday for a thirty-six-hole total of 130 to win the second annual member-guest best-ball golf tournament at Essex County Country Club.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif, May 22 -- Joseph Mankiewicz tonight received the first annual award of the Screen Directors Guild for directorial achievement with his Twentieth Century-Fox picture, "A Letter to Three Wives." The award was presented at a dinner in the Hollywood Roosevelt Hotel.

Since 1901 the people of Guam have been petitioning the United States Congress for definition of their political status. The most recent of such petitions was personally presented by Guam Assemblywoman Concepcion Barrett to the House Subcommittee on Territories and Insular Possessions at an open hearing on May 5.
BIRMINGHAM, England, May 22 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Orchestra received an ovation tonight at the first concert of its English tour.

iVfortimer P. Stern of Pine .Bluff, .ark.; 1V@argin L. Stone of Burlington, Vt., and Harold T. Scarlett of Fort Worth, Tex., have won the $1,500 Pulitzer traveling scholarships, annually awarded to outstanding students in Columbia University's- School of Journalism, Carl W. Ackerman, dean, announced yesterday.
The unusual action of the Batory's operator in connection with Gerhard Eisler's escape raises a question of much greater public importance than that of his extradition.

TAMPA, Fla., May 22 (AP) -- A radio station manager and two free-lance radio commentators are on the Florida state payroll, and two newspaper columnists recently have drawn state money for special services, James A. Clendinen, state news editor of The Tampa Morning Tribune, said capital records showed today.

PHILADELPHIA, May 22 (AP) -- The Athletics captured both ends of a double-header from the Indians today for the first time since 1945. Lefty Lou Brissie pitched a five-hitter to annex the nightcap, 7 to 3, after an eighth-inning double by Pete Suder scored Wally Moses with the winning run in a 5-to-4 opener. Rookie Alex Kellner hurled his fifth victory of the season.

Give antique furniture skilled care if you want it to look its best and to keep in good condition, advises George Takacs, who, with twenty-five years' experience as a cabinetmaker and antiques restorer, looks after the furniture on display at the New York Historical Society.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., May 22 -- Ralph A. Beals, director of the New York Public Library, became president today of the New York Library Association at the final session of the group's annual conference.

President Eurico Gaspar Dutra of Brazil spent his first day in New York yesterday attending mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral, lunching with Cardinal Spellman and paying a brief visit to the Radio City Music Hall.

The desire to establish an indigenous "national" language is a conspicuously recurring hallmark of nationalist movements. It has become so well recognized, indeed, that its absence would be striking. Several examples have been given in current news. In Ireland there is a desire for the reestablishment of Gaelic as the national tongue.

MOSCOW, May 22 -- The Soviet public was warned today that the Western powers might be preparing a virtual ultimatum at the forthcoming Paris meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers in which Russia would be told, "Either agree with our plan unconditionally or there will be no agreements."

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 22 -- Yugoslav sources take the view that any compromise at the Council of Foreign Ministers in Paris would create an atmosphere in which the regime of this country could maneuver more easily against the external pressures exerted upon it.

Federal funds for education have skyrocketed to the record sum of $3,400,000,000 this year, jumping from $100,000,000 in 1940. Two hundred separate educational programs are sponsored by a score of Federal departments and agencies.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., May 22 -- Having defeated two of his most formidable opponents, Edgar T. McCormick of East Orange, former Princeton varsity captain, suffered his first reverse in the third round of the championship tournament at the Log Cabin Chess Club, today. His opponent was Herman Hesse of Bethlehem, Pa., who took the lead with three straight to his credit.

Whether square dancing stirred up fashion or fashion designers caused the revival of early American quadrilles and polkas, the fad is on and there are skirts and blouses and one-piece dresses, formal and informal gowns, as well as discussion of just what is right for the Saturday night social of 1949.

A new alignment of democratic and Christian religious traditions "in these days of witch hunting" was called for yesterday morning by the Rev. Dr. Guy Emery Shipler, editor of The Churchman, independent Protestant Episcopal weekly, from the pulpit of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity, Clinton and Montague Streets, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- As the country's first Secretary of Defense, James Forrestal was confronted by national security problems of peculiar gravity, and the responsibility of their attempted solution bore heavily on him.

BUFFALO, N. Y., May 22 -- The United Nations has demonstrated to the world that it can effectively prevent war, Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, acting mediator of the Palestine Commission of the United Nations, said today in a message read before the 161st General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America.

In an editorial in THE NEW YORK TIMES of May 10, the abstention of the United States on the resolution before the Political Committee of the General Assembly was condoned on the basis of unimportance. I feel this is not justifiable.
Performance details of the Air Force's new "triple threat" transport plane were revealed here yesterday.

KABUL, Afghanistan, May 11 -- Afghanistan's continual conflict with the British, which burst out in three wars, 1838, 1879 and 1919, has come alive again in the present boiling dispute with Pakistan over the status of the "free tribal area" at their border.

MOSCOW, May 22 (UP) -- The Government paper Izvestia reported today that its "expose" of Prof. S. D. Antipin, who taught that man's degeneration was the result of his walking upright, had resulted in the professor's dismissal.

At almost the last minute a strike of 3,800 New Jersey brewery workers was averted yesterday by the signing of a contract between Local 843, International Brotherhood of Teamsters, AFL, and the New Jersey Brewers Association.

Cardinal Spellman celebrated yesterday his tenth anniversary as Archbishop of New York by blessing and dedicating the new administrative office building of the archdiocese at 451-453 Madison Avenue, and then announcing the establishment of nine new parishes.

Important among the week's art events is the annual exhibition of work by newly elected members of the American Academy of Arts and Letters and by the recipients of the Academy awards. It will be held at the headquarters of the Academy, Broadway and 155th Street, and will open to the public on Saturday.

The city relief caseload continued to increase for the fifth successive month. Welfare Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard announced yesterday. Assistance was given in April to 150,672 cases, he said, compared with 147,801 in March, an increase of 2,871 cases.

Resignation of Borough President Hugo E. Rogers as leader of Tammany is expected as a result of the election of Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., candidate of the Liberal and Four Freedoms parties for Representative, in the special election in the Twentieth Congressional District last Tuesday.

SEOUL, Korea, May 22 -- Rufino Lunna, Philippine representative to the United Nations Commission on Korea, last night declared he strongly opposed the withdrawal of United States troops from Korea. He added he was convinced the Korean Republic would be unable to defend itself against attack at the present time.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls during the period May 14 to 20 are given in the appended tabulation:

JONES BEACH, L. I., May 22 -- The bathing season will open formally next Saturday at Jones Beach, New York State's most famous ocean-front park. Officials and several hundred painters, carpenters, beach-combers, gardeners, plumbers, caterers and bulldozer experts have been rushing the annual spring housecleaning and repair work so as to have no delay when the visitors begin to arrive.

A spirited controversy over the extension or renewal of the city's $167,000 contract with Harrison, Ballard Allen, the consultants retained a year ago to aid the City Planning Commission in its general rezoning survey, will soon come to Mayor O'Dwyer and the Board of Estimate for a decision, it was indicated yesterday.

The first regional convention of the New York and Northern New Jersey members of the American Guild of Organists will start today and run through Thursday. Musical events and meetings will take place at intervals on the following schedule:
REGINA, Sask., May 21 (AP) -- Early indications point to the worst grasshopper infestation since 1938 on the western Canada grain belt.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- James Forrestal, former Secretary of Defense, jumped thirteen stories to his death early this morning from the sixteenth floor of the National Naval Medical Center.

LONDON, May 22 -- On completion today of half the scheduled 120 boards, the American bridge team of John Crawford, Peter Leventritt, Samuel Stayman and George Rapee finds itself 2,950 points behind the English team of Terence Reese, Boris Shapiro, N. Harrison-Gray and Kenneth Konstam.

Linen, increasingly popular for upholstery weaves, and jute, its long-wearing country cousin, have arrived in new guises at the showroom of Dan Cooper, 21 East Seventy-second Street, in time for summer re-covering jobs. Both yarns are to be found among a group of plaids and other new designs in the fabric this house imports from Scotland.

TORONTO, May 22 (AP) -- Gem Thief, third favorite in the winter book at 10-to-1 odds to win the ninetieth rnewal of the King's Plate May 28, is "definitely out," owner Willie Morrisey of Toronto announced today.

BOOKER WASHINGTON BIRTHPLACE, Va., May 22 -- A replica of the log cabin in which Booker T. Washington, Negro educator, was born will be dedicated here tomorrow and proclaimed by Gov. William M. Tuck a shrine of Virginia.
Raymond C. Firestone, vice president of Firestone Rubber and Tire Company, has been appointed in charge of research and development, with headquarters in Akron.

HYDE PARK, N. Y., May 22 -- In the presence of 500 students, educators and distinguished citizens, Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt unveiled a bronze plaque at the Roosevelt School here, commemorating the fact that Franklin Delano Roosevelt first went to school in the structure.

The city's new Traffic Commission submitted yesterday its first acceptable report to Mayor O'Dwyer and said it was studying the establishment of a separate self-supporting agency to handle the complex problem of parking.

Two anniversaries were marked yesterday morning at the Madison Avenue Baptist Church, Madison Avenue and Thirty-first Street. On the church's centenary of founding, the Rev. George Caleb Moor, now 77 years old, celebrated the beginning of the thirtieth year of his pastorate. "

MODESTO, Calif., May 22 (AP) -- The eighth annual Modesta Relays went into the record books today listing a world record-bettering performance in the 880-yard four-man event and the highest pole vault made in the country this year.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, May 22 -- The two American soldiers who strayed into 'CzechoslovakiaJ more than five months ago' and] were sentenced by the Czechs to !lon?irton' terms :'as:,spies;,' 'e released .on the.frontier te'dayaftr .having/received .a. ::pardon/from' President Klement C,o.twald.

Misjudgment of economic factors and relationships, as well as of socio-psychological factors, is among the reasons for errors made by one group of forecasters on the effects of the transition from the war boom to peacetime production.
Nine new films, including importations from England and Italy, are slated to open in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:
WARSAW, May 22 -- Polish political leaders and newspapers have reopened a campaign to support Poland's claim to maintaining the Oder-Neisse line as Germany's eastern frontier.

Shipments of American merchandise to the Philippine Islands declined sharply the first quarter of this year after a "fairly good" 1948 in which $750,000,000 worth of American products were imported into the islands, according to a survey by Mercantile, Inc., 24 Stone Street, publishers of Robot Statistics.

Early signs of increased promotional preparation for Father's Day were seen by a number of ad officials last week as indicating a possible record effort at boosting sales. The number of large-scale carefully planned promotions was cited as evidence of an all-out bid for business, spurred by higher competition and continuing buyer resistance in men's wear and other articles of masculine consumption.

ALBANY, N. Y., May 22 (AP) -- Supplies of most milk products in storage throughout New York State on May 1 showed a marked increase over totals reported on the same 1948 date, the State Agriculture Department said today.

Frank Roane, Negro baritone, who won the American Theatre Wing's second annual concert award, yesterday afternoon gave the recital in Times Hall which was his prize. Singing before a large crowd of friends and well-wishers, he displayed voice of much natural beauty and received the warm applause with modest dignity.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, May 22 (Reuters) -- Incidents and clashes in the first municipal elections in Cyprus since 1946 were being reported "one every few minutes," the police stated tonight.

Sacrifice of quality and the "many confusing elements" involved in the output of tax-free fur garments make their manufacture undesirable, it was concluded, after several meetings last week of the Mouton group of the Associated Fur Manufacturers, Inc., and independent manufacturers.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The Senate will begin debate tomorrow, with the expectation of reaching a final vote Tuesday, on a bill designed to increase the operating effectiveness of armed services unification.

Twenty years ago today, two Bell Telephone Laboratories researchers -- then deep in the problem of trying to find how to make the wires strung on poles about the country carry more phone conversations without putting up more wires -- filed a patent for a strange new device that might do the trick.

A program for training more displaced persons and refugees was adopted yesterday by the American ORT Federation (Organization for Rehabilitation Through Training) at the closing session of its two-day annual convention in the Hotel Roosevelt.

Look for "Blackouts," Ken Murray's immensely successful variety show, to arrive Sept. 12 on Broadway, it was said yesterday by Dave Siegel, sponsor of the attraction, which has been running without interruption at the El Capitan, Los Angeles, since June 24, 1942.

William Z. Foster, national chairman of the Communist party of the United States, cited yesterday the Supreme Court decision in the Schneiderman case as proof of the party's contention that its doctrine and policies fall within constitutional limits, and always have.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., May 22 (AP) -- Monroe County voters rejected a 2 per cent sales tax yesterday. The voters in a referendum also decided against a proposed $4,000,000 bond issue for construction of a community memorial building.

The directors of Common Cause, Inc., 444 Madison Avenue, and the American Association for a Democratic Germany, 131 East Seventeenth Street, yesterday urged the United States to be firm with Russia during the conference of the Big Four Foreign Ministers opening in Paris today.

CHICAGO, May 22 -- Prices of corn held within relatively narrow limits last week on the Board of Trade with only a moderate turnover in evidence. The May delivery was held in check by fair deliveries of the cash grain despite the fact that No. 2 yellow corn in the cash market sold at 4 to 5 cents a bushel over May.

RANGOON, Burma, May 22 (AP) -- Burmese troops occupied the Karen stronghold of Insein today, an official army announcement said. The shell-battered suburb ten miles north of Rangoon had been the scene of bitter fighting for months.

SHANGHAI, Tuesday, May 24 -- The tide of war swept to the front door of the world's fourth largest city yesterday. Residents moved en masse to the housetops to watch the fireworks across the Whang-poo River and garrison headquarters issued a warning that the city's entire waterfront was now within range of Communist guns.

PARIS, May 23 -- The conference that opened today is the first session of the Council of Foreign Ministers where the Western Powers are in so strong a position that they are confident the Soviet Union must either beat an orderly diplomatic retreat from its present positions on Germany and Austria or accept continuation of the geographical schism in those countries, a schism that favors Western Europe.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- An Administration spokesman termed President Truman's health insurance program today as the only alternative to state medicine, but Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican, of Ohio said that he was wrong.
CAMDEN, N. J., May 23 (AP) -- Tacaro Briar, flying the silks of E. L. Hall, Jr., raced to a thrilling nose triumph today at Garden State Park in the featured Ardmore Purse at six furlongs.

While Thomas F. Farrell, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, painted yesterday a brighter picture for future housing, Robert F. Wagner Jr., chairman of the City Planning Commission, declared that private construction was not geared to grasp the opportunity of the increasing demand for housing.
I noticed in THE NEW YORK TIMES an article stating that Kate Wollmann had given $600,000 to the city to build an ice-skating rink.

Henry !forgenthau Sr., financiz and a former United States Ambassador to Turkey, left a net estate of $1,458,855 when he died at the age of 90 in 1946, an estate tax appraisal filed yesterday with the state showed.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The largest peace-time field training program for the National Guard in this country's history will begin early next month, the National Military Establishment announced here today.

Walter P. Chrysler Jr., whose colors have been carried on many of the major racetracks in this country, particularly in the East and in Florida, will dispose of all his thoroughbred holdings because of the "pressure of other business," it was announced yesterday.

This country's top poloists will ride against Argentina in a resumption of play for the Cup of the Americas at Buenos Aires in November, it was announced yesterday at a luncheon tendered by the United States Polo Association at the New York A. C.

TOKYO, May 23 -- Although occupation textile officials admit the floor-price system has been abused in other fields, they deny it is adversely affecting Japan's export trade in their own field. The slump in raw silk, they say, is not due to price considerations since silk must be considered a "special material."

The five-story business building on a lot 20 by 80 feet at 1026 Park Avenue, near Eighty-sixth Street, has been sold by Martin J. Folk to Sidney Kramer for investment. It recently was renovated at a cost of more than $25,000 and was sold in a deal reported yesterday by Brener Lewis, Inc., and Realto Realty, the brokers.

The Lionel Corporation, manufacturer of toy electric trains and accessories, in the fiscal year ended with last February had the heaviest volume of sales in its history, Lawrence Cowen, president, reported yesterday. The total of $15,559,276 compared with $12,167,290 a year before.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- The Association of American Railroads is planning a part embargo on June 1 on shipments of grain in the winter wheat belt, designed to allow movement of grains only where unloading or storage space is available.

The House of Representatives is scheduled this week to act on a veterans' pension bill that would materially liberalize present benefits for disabilities that have nothing to do with service in the armed forces. In essence, this bill would grant a pension of $72 a month to veterans of both World Wars when they reach the age of 65, if they are unemployable and if their incomes do not exceed a certain low minimum.
DETROIT, May 23 -- The United Automobile Workers, CIO, offered late tonight to submit to arbitration the crucial issue in its walkout against the Ford Motor Company.

LONDON, May 23 -- A requisition from the United States Government for the extradition of Gerhart Eisler, German Communist who jumped bail in New York, was sent to the British Foreign Office today by the United States Embassy.

Federal Judge Murray Hulbert issued an order yesterday restraining immigration authorities from deporting Peter Harisiades, Greek writer, pending a hearing Tuesday on his request for a declaration that his deportation warrant is illegal.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Clinton Industries, Inc., of St. Louis, Mo., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 150,000 shares of its $1 par value capital stock that is to be offered to the public at a price to be filed by amendment.

PARIS, May 23 -- The Soviet Union was bluntly warned today that if Russian slowness to fulfill provisions of the New York agreement on lifting of the Berlin blockade continued the three Western powers would raise the question at the meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Hearings on approval of the international wheat agreement were ended by a Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee today. It heard strongly favorable testimony from representatives of the National Farmers Union, the American Farm Bureau Federation and the National Grange, the three major farm organizations.

The Junior League of the City of New York once more is dwelling in marble halls -- this time at 130 East Eightieth Street, in a five-story mansion built by Vincent Astor -- after "roughing it" for nearly a year in a storage warehouse.

This morning the Security Council will discuss further the application of Nepal for United Nations membership. The outlook for the Himalayan kingdom is not as bright as it should be. The Soviet Union has indicated that Nepal may be regarded as under the domination of Great Britain and therefore not suitable for membership.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 23 -- Three teams finished in a deadlock for first place with 64 cards, 7 strokes under par, during the regular weekly one-day amateur-pro of the Long Island P. G. A. at the Garden City Country Club today.

BERLIN, Tuesday, May 24 -- Street fighting broke out again last night in Berlin's three-day-old rail strike, leaving two dead and a score or more injured. A mob of strikers and supporters, incensed by the killings, threatened to renew action at every rail station held by East sector police.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- "The testimony of statesmen of all parties to Castlereagh's gifts and charm is in strong contrast with the flood of calumny poured out by those who knew him not."

The swollen inventory of unsold tax-exempt bonds evidently cannot be laughed off any longer with pleasantries like "this is either the strongest weak market in municipal bond history or the weakest strong market." The market continued to be complacent about the rising float of unsold bonds until two developments came along at about the same time to flash a red light.
Winston Churchill, the world's most famous amateur painter, for the first time has surrendered one of his signed pictures to be sold, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Members of the Joint Atomic Energy Committee of Congress decided today to engage an outside consultant to investigate all aspects of the loss of a small amount of enriched uranium oxide at the Argonne National Laboratory several months ago.
With baskets of giant cotton daisies set on every counter, the new Bloomingdale's branch store in the Fresh Meadows Housing Development in Queens will open for business this morning.

CHICAGO, May 23 (AP) -- The Braves took undisputed possession of first place in the National League race by defeating the Cubs, 11 to 4 today before a ladies' day gathering of 8,155. This broke a first-place tie with the Giants, who were idle along with the rest of the circuit.

Dr. Franklin Clark Fry, president of the United Lutheran Church in America, said here yesterday that Dr. Rees Edgar Tulloss, president of Wittenberg College, Springfield, Ohio, would direct the church's $6,000,000 campaign in 1950 to raise educational funds.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 23 -- India called upon the United States today to aid in developing the enormous potential demand for consumer's goods among millions of Asiatics as an effective answer to the threat of overproduction and depression in Europe and North America.

JERUSALEM, May 23 -- The Church of the Dormition of Mary on Mount Zion, which was alternately in Arab and Israeli hands during some of the most bitter battles of the Palestine war, will be returned to the custody of the Franciscan order by the Israeli Government, it was learned today.

LONDON, May 23 -- The controversial Ireland Bill recognizing the new independent status of the Republic of Ireland and incorporating guarantees for Irish resident in Britain received a second reading without a division in the House of Lords today.

WASHINGTON, MAY 23 (AP) -- The Senate today passed, by voice vote, and sent back to the House a bill outlawing so-called "overtime on overtime" pay claims in industry generally on a retroactive basis.

LONDON, May 23 -- The stock market today was dull, due to anxiety over the poor April export figures and the home rail dispute. At the opening jobbers lowered prices, but with both buyers and sellers hesitant to enter the market there was no further startling relapse.

The economic and business outlook for Brazil during the balance of this year and in 1950 is extremely favorable, spokesmen for Gen. Eurico Gaspar Dutra, President of the United States of Brazil, declared yesterday at a luncheon in his honor attended by approximately 300 industry members at the Plaza Hotel.

At the end of the fighting war in late midsummer, 1945, the Administration indicated that it entertained serious apprehensions of a possible runaway inflation. These chills, however, were to give way almost overnight to a fever induced by a new conviction that the immediate danger was not inflation but deflation.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The Secretary of the Treasury announced tonight that bids for $904,524,000 of 91-day Treasury bills to be dated May 26 and to mature on Aug. 25, which were offered on May 20, have been accepted.

A comprehensive assortment of furnishings and accessories just arrived from Finland comprise an exhibition that opened yesterday at the Finnish Art Shop, 41 East Fiftieth Street. Furniture, fabrics, glassware, ceramics, lamps and basketwork are all represented in the collection.

When the pupils of Public School 74, at 2474 Crotona Avenue, the Bronx, say they are going to school, they may mean they are going to Chinatown, Central Park, Grant's Tomb, the Yankee Stadium, or even to City Hall.

! Fifteen hundred persons watched l yesterday from sidewalks, roofs ! and apartment windows of Twelfth Street as Cardinal SpeUman laid tle cornerstone for the new $5,000,000 Alfred E. Smith Memorial Building of St Vincent's Hospital I ' ' at Seventh Avenue.

BOSTON, May 23 (AP) -- Junior Stephens' eleventh homer of the season, a mighty drive into the right field bullpen with Ted Williams on base, clinched the Boston Red Sox' 4-0 shutout over the Detroit Tigers for Ellis Kinder today.
The "Admiral Broadway Revue," sponsored on both NBC-TV and the Du Mont television net work this season, will return only to NBC in the fall, it became known yesterday.
JERSEY CITY, May 23 (AP) -- George Bamberger ran his string of scoreless innings to 27 tonight in pitching the Jersey City Giants to a 4-1 triumph over Syracuse.

A new book by Ben Ames Williams, "Fraternity Village," has been scheduled by Houghton Mifflin for July 12 publication. It is a collection of short stories about the Maine village Mr. Williams created and about which he has written between 1919 and 1941.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 23 -- Walter S. Doxsey of Cleveland, president of the American Steel Warehouse Association, today told executives of that industry "the pre-war pattern of participation by warehouses will obtain rather than the post-war scheme," in the future.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 23 -- Robert Rossen, independent producer at Columbia, has acquired screen rights to "The Brave Bulls," a new novel by Tom Lea about bull fighting in Mexico, the studio announced today. Rossen will produce and direct the film adaptation as his next project at Columbia, and will begin work on the scenario as soon as he finishes editing "All the King's Men."

Justice Dudley F. Sicher of the Domestic Relations Court proposed last night that the jurisdiction of the court be increased to include all domestic relations matters, including divorce. He spoke at the annual meeting of the Big Brothers of the Jewish Board of Guardians at the home of Mrs. Henry L. Heming, chairman of the board's volunteer services, at 270 Park Avenue.
Several Congressional surveys or investigations of the performance characteristics of current aircraft and of related aircraft procurement contracts are planned, it was learned yesterday.
I ' John W. Brooks will join Springs Mills, Inc., on June I as Sles man- ager of' finislQed ,goods for theI over-the-counter wholesale and re-I tail textile trade.
WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- Theodore C. Achilles, one of the chief framers of the North Atlantic Pact, has been named deputy director of the State Department's Office of European Affairs.
BOSTON, May 23 (AP) -- The Government introduced a 9,000-page brief today as its anti-trust civil suit against the United Shoe Machinery Corporation went to trial in Federal court.

Dr. Nahum Goldman, recently elected chairman of the American section of the Jewish Agency, who returned from Israel on Sunday, said in an interview yesterday that at least $800,000,000 a year was necessary to take care of the 25,000 to 30,000 immigrants arriving monthly in the new state.
DALLAS, Tex., May 23 -- The Dallas Morning News, Texas' oldest publishing firm, today formally dedicated its new $6,000,000 plant.
DETROIT, May 23 -- The General Motors Corporation announced today its second $10-to-$40 reduction this year in the prices of all of its passenger cars and trucks, effective immediately.

DETROIT, May 23 (AP) -- World Middleweight Champion Marcel Cerdan and Jake La Motta, two fighters with more punching power than boxing finesse, signed today for a title fight at Briggs Stadium on June 15.

LONDON, May 23 -- Winthrop Aldrich, chairman of the board of directors of the Chase National Bank and one of the world's most influential financiers, emphatically dissociated himself today from those Americans who were reported to be advocating devaluation of the pound sterling in relation to the dollar.

Negotiation of bilateral agreements with foreign countries for improvement of underdeveloped areas was urged yesterday by the National Association of Manufacturers to implement President Truman's "bold new program."

CINCINNATI, May 23 (AP) -- Sharpshooting Joey Maxim of Cleveland tonight left-jabbed his way to National Boxing Association recognition as American light-heavyweight champion with a unanimous fifteen-round decision over Gus Lesnevich of Cliffside, N. J.

CHICAGO, May 23 -- Price cutting, declining order backlogs and other conditions of the 1949 market are providing a test for sales managers after eight years of inactivity, the annual convention of the National Federation of Sales Executives was warned today. Speakers called it a sales managers' market.

Holding that many cotton mills now in difficulty can be aided only by merger with other mills that have tresources and managerial talent to restore them to production. Dr. C. T. Murchison, president of the Cotton Textile Institute, yesterday termed the proposed "anti-monopoly bill (H. R. 2734) as destructive, impracticable and unnecessary."

Some fashions are constant, knowing no season or year. The sweaters by Pringle of Scotland, presented in a show held yesterday on the roof of the St. Regis Hotel, proved themselves to represent this type of fashion.

BOSTON, May 23 -- President Truman paid tribute today to the Boy Scouts of America as having "earned a special place in the hearts of the American people." He sent the message to the thirty-ninth annual meeting of the National Council, of which he is the honorary head.
LONDON May 23 -- American chance of winning the Crowninshield Bridge Cup seemed brighter today when the American team gained a lead of 910 points over the English.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 23 -- Several score college students under the sponsorship of the Civil Rights Congress, described by the Attorney General as a subversive organization, appealed today for intercession by the Human Rights Commission of the United Nations in the case of six Negro men sentenced to death for the slaying of a Trenton (N. J.) junk dealer in a hold-up.

Senator Hickenlooper of Iowa, ranking Republican member of the Congressional Joint Committee on Atomic Energy, has called for the resignation of David E. Lilienthal from his post as chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission on the ground that "our atomic program is suffering from equivocation, misplaced emphasis and waste."

For the first time since the war, Sloane-Blabon, Inc., has begun production of lower price linoleum and felt base hard surface floor coverings, R. C. Robinson, sales manager, reported yesterday. Shipments to distributors of both types of goods have started, he said.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- James Forrestal, the nation's first Secretary of Defense, will be buried in Arlington National Cemetery at 11 A. M. on Wednesday.

CHICAGO, May 23 -- Failure of cash grain prices to decline after the expiration of trading in May contracts brought in scattered commission house buying and prices ranged higher on the Board of Trade today. The aggregate trade, however, was small, and business was confined to limited quantities, with professional operators doing little.
The famous old liner Matsonia, renamed the Atlantic of the Home Lines and completely reconditioned, slipped into port yesterday almost unnoticed after a fast nine-day trial run from a Genoa shipyard.

Initiative for creating new space for parking automobiles off the streets must come chiefly from three directions: the municipal government, the garage and parking lot industry looking for profits, and, lastly, from merchants interested in providing convenience for their customers and thus encouraging business for themselves.

EASTVIEW, N. Y., May 23 -- Miss Ruth Taylor, who helped to pay for a Vassar education by working as a college janitor, is now the biggest spender of public money in Westchester and one of the few women in the nation handling more than $9,000,000 a year.

The structure, utilization and translation of languages, the basic essence of communication between groups and peoples, must be improved as a prerequisite for solving the problems of modern society, according to Chester I. Barnard, president of the Rockefeller Foundation.
WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- A former Army investigator said today he had punched German prisoners who did not move quickly enough or who talked back to him.

PARIS, May 23 -- A furious attack on the Government's financial and economic program by Paul Reynaud, leader of the Moderates and Independents, today threw such confusion into Government ranks as normally would point to a Cabinet crisis.
JAWORZNO, Poland, May 23 (AP) -- New high brick walls and sentry towers stick out like a sore thumb in this southern Polish town.

In a brief ceremony yesterday in his office in the Municipal Building, Borough President Hugo E Rogers of Manhattan presented a bouquet of poppies on behalf of the Army and Navy Union to Miss Ella E. Mathews of 41 East Forty-ninth Street.
An exhibition of stained glass panels was opened yesterday afternoon at the Cooper Union Museum for the Arts of Decoration with a private showing for members.

SEOUL, Korea, May 23 -- The United Nations Commission on Korea today adopted a resolution disclaiming responsibility for "the timing or the facilitating of the withdrawal of the forces of the occupying powers" from Korea.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., May 23 -- In an action virtually without precedent in the labor movement, delegates to the convention of the International Handbag and Luggage Union, AFL, have repudiated their president of ten years in a special pre-session caucus.
Elmont of the Golden Acres Stud scored a three-length victory in the Belmont National Maiden Hurdle, the $5,000 stake event on the program at Belmont Park yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, May 23 (AP) -- Cleveland's owner, Bill Veeck, flew into town tonight and saw his world champions finally break into the victory column as they pounded out ten hits and thrashed the Philadelphia Athletics, 7 -- 3. It was the Indians' first victory since last Thursday and only their second in ten games since starting their Eastern swing.

A group of thirty-five Pan American Airways officials and newspaper representatives will fly to Europe this week to obtain a first-hand study of the European travel situation, it was announced yesterday.
The tragedy of "Jim" Forrestal had its origins in what Freud described as "the great subterranean pool of the subconscious" mind.

Brig. Gen. William E. Riley of the United States Marine Corps, Chief of Staff to Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, acting United Nations Mediator on Palestine, arrived at La Guardia Airport yesterday from Damascus. He left immediately for Lake Success for consultations with Dr. Bunche.

Powerful propulsion equipment, designed to make the United States Lines' new superliner one of the fastest vessels afloat, will be constructed at Philadelphia by the Westinghouse Electric Corporation.

CHICAGO, May 23 -- Twenty-seven United States airlines, which completed among them more than four billion passenger miles without a death last year, today were named winners of the National Safety Council's 1948 aviation safety awards.
Dr. Kenneth M. Lewis, vice president of the Medical Society of the County of New York, was chosen early today as president-elect of the society at its 144th annual meeting at 2 East 103d Street.

The beer strike appeared no nearer a settlement last night when union officials turned down an offer by the Brewers Board of Trade that would have given the strikers terms identical to those granted to New Jersey workers in the contract signed Sunday with the New Jersey Brewers Association.

PARIS, May 23 -- An air of elegance hangs over the palace of rose marble on the Avenue Malakoff in which this afternoon four men, two thin and two fat, listened to the opening decibels of another Big Four Foreign Ministers' Conference.

PARIS, May 23 -- At its opening session today in the Palais Rose, the conference of the Big Four Foreign Ministers accepted an agenda proposed by the Western powers and agreed to discuss the Austrian treaty after Germany. The Ministers also heard a plea by Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky that a date be set for a meeting of the Big Four with China to discuss a peace treaty for Japan.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, May 23 -- It was learned here today that the Belgian, Dutch and Luxembourg Ambassadors in Paris have presented a joint note to the United States, British and French delegations asking that their countries be kept informed as to progress of the Council of Foreign Ministers and expressing the hope that they will be consulted before any binding decisions are taken.

The widespread use of atomic energy for power production in this country will not come for at least twenty to thirty years, the American Gas Association meeting at the New Yorker Hotel was told yesterday.

PARIS, May 23 -- The Government today closed the nationalized Nord airplane factory in the Paris suburb of Issy les Moulineaux as a consequence of alleged sabotage of warplane construction by the Communist-led General Confederation of Labor aircraft workers.

CHICAGO, May 23 -- The tax philosophy of the Administration's "so-called liberals" has made it increasingly difficult for small companies to compete with large corporations, Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange, said today.

BUFFALO, May 23 -- The 161st General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A. today urged its 8,500 local congregations throughout the country to continue week-day classes of religious instruction, "so long as there be no violations of the law."

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- Postmaster General Jesse M. Donaldson accused the publishing industry today of waging an "unethical campaign" to retain present postal rates and "keep on enjoying a generous subsidy at the expense of the taxpayers."

Creation of a permanent international fellowship of Congregational churches will be one of the principal projects to be acted on at the Sixth International Congregational Council in Wellesley, Mass., June 17-24. Dr. Sidney M. Berry of London, who will serve as moderator, made the announcement yesterday.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, May 23 -- Theophilus E. Donges, Acting Minister of Economic Affairs, announced in Parliament today what amounts to a total ban for the second half of the year of all finished consumer goods from overseas -- from sterling countries as well as America.

In your issue of May 19, Taraknath Das comments on Prof. Clyde Eagleton's letter dealing with the status of Hyderabad. I am in general agreement with Dr. Das' thesis that the Indian Government has a just case on the merits.

Iris will be the featured flower at the two-day garden program sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES at Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, today and tomorrow. Many other perennials now in bloom also will be displayed in the flower show and the demonstrations on stage.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., May 23 -- Former Mayor Frank Hague was reported as inhospitable toward a suggestion made this morning to extend the olive branch to Mayor John V. Kenny, who put the Hague machine out of office in Jersey City, so that all Democratic forces in Hudson County might work together in the campaign of State Senator Elmer H. Wene for Governor of New Jersey.

There was always about Mary Antin Grabau, who died recently, a quality, fascinating and dramatic. She was slight, small of stature, gentle-voiced and unassuming; yet there was about her to all who read her book, heard her lecture, or met her in private something unforgettable.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Finland may soon obtain a loan from the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development to be used to buy timber-cutting machinery.
TRENTON, N. J., May 23 (AP) -- The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that overpayments of dividends on non-cumulative preferred stock might be recovered from subsequent purchasers of the shares.

NEWARK, N. J., May 23 -- Improvement and augmentation of physical connections between New York and New Jersey must be supplemented by unification of policy and elimination of artificial barriers, Howard S. Cullman, chairman of the Port of New York Authority, told the Joint Council of Municipal Planning Boards in Essex County here tonight.

Only 10 per cent of the juvenile delinquents in this city are Jewish, Justice Justine Wise Polier of the Domestic Relations Court declared yesterday. She observed that this was a particularly low figure in a population where Jews numbered more than 30 per cent.
HARLECH, Wales, May 23 (AP) -- Two of three American contenders for the British women's amateur golf championship breezed blithely through their opening matches today.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., May 23 -- Dr. Israel Tabak of Baltimore, president of the Rabbinical Council of America, discussed today the reports that "a systematic attempt is being carried on to suppress the religious, social and cultural life of the Jewish people in Poland, Rumania, Hungary and other countries under Soviet domination."
Welcoming its customers to the "Sun and Sand" shop, Gimbels held a fashion show last evening on the third floor of the store.
New York paid homage yesterday to President Eurico Gaspar Dutra of Brazil.

In last place, twelve lengths removed from the top so early in the race, the Browns were no match for the Yankees in their after-dark duel before 37,376 fans at the Stadium last night. No contest after the second inning, the poorest game witnessed here this season wound up with the Yankees coasting home, 10 -- 3.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Capt. George M. Raines, the Navy psychiatrist who had treated James Forrestal since April 2, declared tonight that the former Secretary of Defense took his life during a sudden fit of despondency "extremely common" to the severe type of mental depression he suffered.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., May 23 (AP) -- The executive secretary of the National Association of Mutual Insurance agents said today home owners will soon be able to insure any accidental loss through a new "all-risk" policy.

Fear that the airlines of the United States would be sacrificed to Canadian political interests was expressed here yesterday by airline men who were not admitted to the first meeting of top level Washington and Ottawa officials, here to negotiate a bilateral air agreement with the Dominion.

Two more films have been added to the list of newcomers, thereby bringing the total of this week's arrivals to eleven. The added starters, both of which open on Saturday, are "Jigsaw," which begins at the Mayfair, and "Hellfire," which starts a stand at the Gotham.

BONN, Germany, May 23 -- Existence of a new Western German state to be known as the Federal Republic of Germany and embracing about two-thirds of the population and half of the territory of the former German Reich was proclaimed here today by the Parliamentary Council, which wrote its constitution.

PHILADELPHIA, May 23 -- Harold E. Stassen, president of the University of Pennsylvania, announced today the receipt of a $100,000 gift to the Donner Diagnostic Clinic in memory of the late William L. McLean, publisher of the Philadelphia Evening Bulletin from 1895 to 1931.

Mackerel, like gold in the hills, late where you find them, and there are occasions when you can scatter ground mossbunker chum over several assorted miles of ocean and still fail to cross the path of a mackerel.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- A bill permitting national banks and state member banks of the Federal Reserve System to deal in bonds of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development was approved today by the House Banking and Currency Committee.

It was impossible to do any work yesterday. It was just as impossible yesterday as it was the day before, and the one before that. Nor is the outlook good for today and tomorrow, and since the cumulative effect of inertia is what it is, the entire future is subject to gloomy speculation.

Stock prices resumed their downward drift on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, closing at the lowest levels in a month. Steel, motor and oil shares led the list into lower ground as the volume dropped to the lowest since May 10. Sales aggregated 720,000 shares, compared with 740,000 on Friday.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- A Senate Commerce subcommittee told the airlines today that the pressure of public opinion against high subsidy payments should warn them to invoke economies in operations on their own initiative.

A 17-year-old Queens student, who at the last minute changed her mind and her entry, won first prize yesterday in the twenty-seventh annual inter-high school poetry contest. Student poets from twenty-nine city schools competed in the event, held at Washington Irving High School, 40 Irving Place.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The vigorous Truman Democrats of Mississippi declared war today on their whole delegation in Congress, classing them as "Dixiecrats" who would be opposed as they came up for re-election.

The Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc., announced yesterday that Charles H. Tuttle, a member of its committee on education, had written to Senator Irving M. Ives in opposition to the recently revived St. Lawrence Seaway and Power Project. The letter termed the project "another extension of governmental subsidy tending toward nationalization of privately owned and managed business," and asked Senator Ives to oppose the plan in Congress.

A plot of about one-half acre at 191 Oraton Street, Newark, N. J., was sold by the Louis Schlesinger Company, broker, for Joseph C. La Fera, to the Mercury Construction Company of Bayonne, which will improve it with a storage building to be occupied by the Radio Corporation of America.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- Senator Milton R. Young, Republican, of North Dakota, said today the Agriculture and Commerce Departments were working at cross purposes in dealing with fats and oils with "disastrous" results. Senator Young said the Agriculture Department was supporting hog prices at the same time that the Commerce Department was refusing to allow any substantial hog exports.

MONTREAL, May 23 -- Psychiatry for the public -- for the thousands who need and want help with their emotional difficulties but who cannot afford private care -- was urged today by Dr. William C. Menninger of the Menninger Foundation in Topeka, Kan.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Marked by tributes to the late James Forrestal, first Secretary of Defense, debate was begun in the Senate today on the bill intended to effect further unification of the armed services.
GENEVA, May 23 -- The Committee on the Development of Trade established by the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe last week met today to seek means of improving East-West trade.

LOS ANGELES, May 23 (AP) -- The so-called "unfriendly ten," who refused to tell the House Un-American Activities Committee whether they were Communists, filed an anti-trust suit today against ten major film producers, demanding $52,000,000.

An average 10 per cent increase in retail sales promotion efforts and expenditures was termed essential for buyer market success yesterday by Howard P. Abrahams, manager of the sales promotion division and visual merchandising group of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

Borough President Hugo E. Rogers said yesterday that he had no immediate intention of resigning as Tammany leader, even though an insurgent bloc among the district leaders was being organized to displace him. Mr. Rogers said he expected to seek another four-year term as Borough President of Manhattan this fall.

Nineteen classrooms of the twenty-three in Public School 36 at 251 Stagg Street, Brooklyn, were damaged over the week-end, it was found yesterday morning when teachers and custodians arrived. The police of the Stagg Street Precinct, which is across the street from the school, began an investigation on the belief that pupils in the upper grades or slightly older hooligans from the neighborhood had done the mischief.

Jed Harris decided yesterday afternoon to close his production of Herman Wouk's melodrama, "The Traitor," after Saturday night's performance, the sixty-seventh. The attraction originally was to have shut down on May 16, but an upturn in business encouraged the producer to keep it going.

Coffee futures declined moderately yesterday in quiet trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Scattered long liquidation was absorbed by trade covering. At the close contract "S" was 12 points under last Friday's final prices on sales of 4,000 bags.

The food industry, largest in this country, has been called "the life line of America." How this line of essential processes moves food onto our tables shows in single segments of the industry. Today "News of Food" starts a series on one such segment -- the manufacture of dairy products near and for New York.

The Housing Expediter states that he will consider a "fair return" to be 25 per cent of the gross in the case of large buildings, after allowing a maximum of 16 per cent of the gross for depreciation.

DETROIT, May 28 -- The current campaign of the British, Dutch and certain other nations to raise the price of crude rubber by getting the United States to restrict its production of the man-made product is not only a threat to our national security but is a "cartel road which leads to totalitarianism," John L. Collyer, president of the B. F. Goodrich Company of Akron, Ohio, said today.

KABUL, Afghanistan, May 12 -- This remote kingdom the size of Texas, landlocked in the fastnesses of Asia, is bringing its 12,000,000 peasant farmers and sheepherding nomads from a Biblical civilization to the present with a swiftly moving program of public works.

WILLIAM BEEBE, the director of the department of tropical research of the New York Zoological Society, has been studying birds and beasts, fish and insects for fifty years. One of the most distinguished of living American scientists, he is also one of the best known to the general public because he is nearly as able a writer as he is a naturalist.
BRONXVILLE, N. Y., May 23 -- A petition asking that Congress "deflate the overmanned bureaucracies"
WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox scored twice with two out in the ninth inning to defeat Washington, 3 -- 1, tonight behind the three-hit pitching of Randy Gumpert.

Federal Judge Harold R. Medina at the Communist trial yesterday denied all defense motions to throw out the Government's case and directed the defense to proceed immediately with its own case. It did so by calling as its first witness one of the eleven defendants, John Gates, editor-in-chief since 1947 of The Daily Worker, official party organ.

PORTMARNOCK, May 23 (AP) -- Willie Turnesa, the American champion, led five of his countrymen safely through the opening round of the British amateur golf championship today over the wind-swept Portmarnock links hard by the Irish Sea.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The cost-of-living index went up one-tenth of 1 per cent between March 15 and April 15, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- John L. Lewis will open the coal wage conference at Bluefield, W. Va., on Wednesday for the United Mine Workers, it was announced here today.

As the Big Four Foreign Ministers met in Paris yesterday to begin their discussion of a political settlement for Germany and for Europe, another no less significant international meeting at Geneva provided both a revealing background to the Paris gathering and a clue to its convocation at this time. This other meeting is being held by the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe, representing twenty-six nations from both sides of the Iron Curtain.

Dom Novak blanked the opposition on five hits as the St. John's University nine, Metropolitan Collegiate Conference champion, finished its league season yesterday by beating Hofstra College, 3-0, at Dexter Park, Woodhaven.

Thirty-day workhouse sentences were imposed yesterday in Special Sessions on a man and a woman who had pleaded guilty to rent-gouging charges. Another woman was fined in lieu of a three-month sentence.

The first new excursion boat to make her appearance in local waters in twenty-five years, the 223-foot all-steel Liberty Belle, will start a series of harbor trips at the end of the month, it was announced yesterday by F. F. James, district manager of the Wilson Line.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The United States is determined to push strongly ahead with plans for the economic rehabilitation of Japan despite some doubts and objections by other Allied powers in the Pacific, it is now learned from authoritative sources here.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 23 -- The retail store profit system is becoming a loss system with the break-even point so high a loss of 10 or 15 per cent in sales will more than wipe out the entire profit of many companies, Jay D. Runkle, vice president of Crowley Milnes and Company of Detroit, said today.
LONDON, May 23 (Reuters) -- The King and Queen were present at Lords today to see the New Zealanders recover from a perilous position against the M. C. C.

Expansion of Brooklyn's settlement house program was urged yesterday by Supreme Court Justice George J. Beldock, who said there was no adequate substitute for the friendly, voluntary advice, counsel and assistance of the good neighbor.

A pageant depicting early Manhattan history and a City Hall reception for Father Knickerbocker on his return from a seventeen-day global flight combined yesterday to start the city's observance of World Trade Week.

BOSTON, May 23 -- The Port of Boston Authority purchased today the Boston Albany Railroad pier in East Boston for the sum of $2,000,000. This will clear the way for construction of new facilities at an additional cost of $4,500,000.

Ten of the city's leading private clubs became involved yesterday in the ticket-scalping investigation. Subpoenas were issued by Investigation Commissioner John M. Murtagh, requesting these clubs to produce records dealing with their purchases of theatre tickets.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- A bipartisan drive for a single, consolidated appropriation bill that would measure Government spending against its income as money recommendations were made was revived in Congress today. It was a part of economy efforts that persisted despite setbacks until the House Appropriations Committee cut 15 per cent from the fund of the Economic Cooperation Administration this morning.
DAMASCUS, Syria, May 23 -- Further Syrian-Israeli armistice talks, completely deadlocked after seven weeks of negotiations and new proposals by Dr. Bunche, are now awaited.

Record buyer attendance and active purchasing marked the Popular Price Shoe Show yesterday at the New Yorker and McAlpin Hotels under the joint auspices of the New England Shoe and Leather Association and the National Association of Shoe Chain Stores.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Influential members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee are considering accompanying its approval of the North Atlantic treaty with a statement defining and limiting the nature of the American military commitment to Western Europe.
The exterior of Brooklyn's Borough Hall is scheduled to receive its first general cleaning since its completion in 1849.

Eleven years ago today a 17-year-old lad wrote a letter. "I would like to go some place where no one will laugh at me," he said. "Is there a school where there are others disabled like me, where people will understand me and I can learn a trade?

CHICAGO, May 23 -- Seven hundred and fifty 'teen age boys and girls who run their own companies tonight were told by Air Secretary W. Stuart Symington that the experience they are acquiring in management control was the best security for the country as well as the greatest need in government.

PHILADELPHIA, May 23 -- The latest post-war developments in office equipment and business machines were displayed today at the opening of the thirtieth annual international conference and exposition of the National Office Management Association.

The New England Telephone and Telegraph Company won a decisive victory in the Massachusetts Supreme Court yesterday when that tribunal ordered an immediate rate increase of $7,000,000 a year, thus bringing the company's rate of return on capital to 6 2/3 per cent.

LOS ANGELES, May 23 -- The commercial practice of "fair trading" -- maintaining retail prices by contract -- was hit today by Herbert A. Bergson, Assistant United States Attorney General in charge of the Anti-trust Division.

Welcome news, long awaited by rowing coaches, came at the final crew luncheon of the season at the New York A. C. yesterday in the announcement that the course on the Hudson for the Poughkeepsie Regatta will be changed.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- A few minutes before reporting a foreign-aid bill to the House today the Appropriations Committee ordered a cut of 15 per cent, or $629,730,000, in European recovery funds for the fiscal year beginning July 1.
The cotton futures market opened 2 points lower to 1 point higher on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday and closed 5 to 6 points lower. Fluctuations were within a very narrow range all day.

LONDON, May 24 -- Conservative members of the House of Lords proposed today to delay until October, 1950, the nationalization of the British iron and steel industry so that the electorate might have a chance to pass on the Labor Government's bill calling for public ownership of the industry.
CHICAGO, May 24 -- The Cubs, whose lowly standing has provoked a number of investigations in these parts to determine the cause of it all, gave the right answers themselves today.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The Western powers have reached an impasse with the Soviet Union in their efforts to effect a temporary trade and currency agreement between Eastern and Western Germany.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, May 24 -- The head of Czechoslovakia's 9,000,000 Roman Catholics today threatened the excommunication of all Catholics who help the Communist Government against the Church. A Catholic who is excommunicated is barred from receiving sacraments of the church and from association with faithful members.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., May 24 -- Convention Hall in the Boardwalk here was transformed today into the world's largest restaurant as $2,500,000 worth of food products and kitchen equipment was displayed at the thirtieth National Restaurant Convention and Exposition, largest in the industry's history.

lfany luncheon parties were given yesterday at the formal opening for the seuon of the Outdoor Garden of the Ritz-Carlton. frs. 'E. Raymond McOlung, wife of Captain IVfeClung, USN, gave a lu-'ncheo there for IM[rs. BernBieri, United States Naval Representative Unibed Nations Committee.

PHILADELPHIA, May 24 -- L. S. Buckmaster, president of the United Rubber Workers, CIO, since 1945, was removed from office today by the union's general executive board after a month of closed meetings here.

Despite a substantial increase in sales, earnings of the Food Machinery and Chemical Corporation for the quarter ended with last March declined somewhat from the comparable three-month period a year before, according to the report issued yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, May 24 -- With Jackie Robinson's two home runs against Bob Chesnes driving in four runs, the Dodgers tonight trounced the Pirates, 6 -- 1, and big Ralph Branca chalked up his seventh triumph without a defeat.
PORTMARNOCK, Ireland, May 24 (AP) -- Champions Willie Turnesa and Frank Stranahan led a reduced American contingent into the third round of the British amateur championship golf tournament today.

Margaret Guy, young Alabama-born pianist, made her debut in Carnegie Recital Hall last night before a sizable and enthusiastic audience. Hers was a serious program, and she matched it with a performance of care and thoughtfulness.

A budget for low-income families is among the standards the Welfare Council of New York City is preparing for its member agencies, Mrs. Richard J. Bernhard, first Vice president, reported yesterday at the council's twenty-fourth annual meeting in the Henry Hudson Hotel.

BLUEFIELD, W. Va., May 24 -- The united front of the Southern coal operators was shattered today when two of the fourteen affiliates of the Southern Coal Producers Association bolted the wage conference with the miners, scheduled to open here tomorrow.

For the second year in a row a New Jersey team became champion of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's Interclub team Series 1 as these matches were concluded over the North Hills Country Club course in Douglaston, L. I. yesterday.
SHANGHAI, Wednesday, May 25 (AP) -- Green-uniformed Communist troops marched into this city from the southwest early today to the pealing of church bells -- apparently the city's welcome.

While the Four-Power conference in Paris is discussing the fate of Europe, a matter which directly involves American security, some members of Congress are indulging in maneuvers which, if successful, must inevitably impair the value of the two trump cards held at this conference by the West.

The annual reports of the Rockefeller Foundation have always been more than reviews of what it has accomplished through its grants-in-aid. Under the presidency of George E. Vincent and Raymond Fosdick, who retired only recently, the reports have summarized the state of science and indulged in much philosophical and sociological rumination.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 24 -- The Yugoslav and Italian Governments have reached an agreement in principle on the question of Italian property claims in the territories ceded to Yugoslavia after the war.

GENEVA, May 24 -- Dr. Tadeusz Lychowski of Poland was elected chairman of the Committee on Development of Trade of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe, a newly established body to promote exchange between East and West Europe's, at the body's second meeting today.

CAIRO, May 24 -- A series of conferences starting here today with Sir William Strang, British Permanent Under-Secretary for Foreign Affairs, was reported authoritatively to be the beginning of an effort to work out a new United States and British approach to the Middle Eastern question.

PARIS, May 24 (AP) -- Three Los Angeles tennis stars -- Frank Parker, Richard (Pancho) Gonzales and Budge Patty -- reached the semi-finals of the French international championships today along with Eric Sturgess of South Africa.

We have read the stories of the resignation from the New York City school system of Ethel Dammrich, a teacher assigned to the Youthbuilder program. This has jolted us out of the false sense of security into which we were lulled by conferences with the then president of the Board of Education, Andrew G. Clauson Jr., and the Superintendent of Schools, William Jansen, on the subject of the Youthbuilder program.

Commissioner Murtagh's investigation of theatre ticket speculation has brought to light the need for much-needed reform in the distribution and sale of tickets in New York's tremendous amusement industry.

Fans and blowers in the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel will be capable of pumping four tons of fresh air through the shaft for each automobile that is expected to pass through at a peak period, engineers reported yesterday.

" Mr. Adam" is tonight's premiere at the Royale. In this presentation, divided into two acts of two scenes each, Jack Kirkland doesn't share responsibility with anyone. He figures in the triple capacity as producer, adapter of Pat Frank's best-seller of the same name and director.

BOSTON, May 24 (AP) -- After his homer had lifted them into an early tie, Bobby Doerr lashed a two-run single with the bases loaded to give the Red Sox a ten-inning 8-7 victory today and a sweep of a three-game series with the Tigers.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- It costs the Government $4,837,000 a year to pay the wages of civilian and military personnel needed to operate the armed forces' nonprofit commissaries within the continental limits of the United States, a House armed services subcommittee was told today.

DETROIT, May 24 -- The Ford Motor Company accepted with important qualifications today the proposal of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, that the major stumbling block to settlement of the "speed-up" strike be submitted to arbitration.

Hedge-selling in volume depressed rubber futures prices on the Commodity Exchange to the lowest level in a year yesterday. At the close, losses ranged from 50 to 58 points with every delivery except the July, setting new lows for the life of the contracts.
