Exercise, it is said by people who indulge in it, is a wonderful thing. To exercise, says the dictionary, is to train for the sake of well-being or development. Well-being, to pursue the matter further, is defined as a condition of happiness or prosperity.
CINCINNATI, May 24 (AP) -- The Reds squeezed Johnny Wyrostek home from third on Ray Mueller's bunt in the eleventh inning tonight to defeat the Phillies, 4 -- 3, before a crowd of 16,111.

CHICAGO, May 24 -- To keep production and employment at the high levels of 1948, our economy should increase its output at an average rate of 3 per cent a year during the next ten years, Leon H. Keyserling, vice chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, declared here today.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Construction of a suspension bridge across the narrows in New York Harbor, linking Staten Island and Brooklyn, received final military approval today.

The nation's "last frontier of profits" was described yesterday as being more efficient and economical sales and advertising methods. In giving this appraisal of the present struggle with high-break-even profits in an address to the Advertising Club of St. Louis, Harold S. Barnes, director of the Bureau of Advertising, ANPA, declared that broad, general standards of market measurement must be replaced by detailed local analyses such as are offered by many newspapers.

The article by your Berlin correspondent, Sydney Gruson, in THE TIMES of May 8, entitled "Barred Nazis Hold No United States Zone Posts" should be pondered by all those who are concerned about the problem of Germany, particularly at a time when we are handing over the reins of government to the Germans.

VIENNA, May 24 -- The Austrian Government expressed its satisfaction at a Cabinet meeting today over the news that the Austrian treaty had been placed on the agenda of the Big Four Foreign Ministers conference in Paris, Dr. Karl Gruber, Foreign Minister, will go to Paris at the end of the week to be on hand for the discussion of his country's case.
Prof. Seymour E. Harris in his letter in THE TIMES of May 20 expresses the main economic current with precision, as a problem of "preventing a small decline from snowballing into a large one."

PARIS, May 24 -- On the basis of today's session of the Council of Foreign Ministers and on the basis of information on Moscow's attitude, it is not yet clear whether the Soviet Union intends to use the conference merely as a propaganda forum seeking to thwart the development of democracy in Western Germany or whether a basic shift in the Kremlin attitude will develop.

CHICAGO, May 24 -- The wheat market on the Board of Trade again showed considerable strength today, the July position at one time being up 1 3/4 cents to a new high level since early in February and 21 cents above the low point of the season.

John Gates, editor of The Daily Worker, Communist official organ, denied on the witness stand at the Communist trial yesterday that he ever had advocated violent overthrow of the Government. He also insisted the party aimed only at peaceful social reforms, and asserted it had taught revolution could come in the United States only by majority action.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 24 -- Lebanon and Syria reopened the frontier between the two countries today after having kept it theoretically closed for a week in a dispute over Lebanon's refusal to release three Syrian soldiers and a captain who had murdered a political fugitive in Lebanese territory.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- With Speaker Sam Rayburn directing strategy, the Administration began an uphill fight today to reverse recommendations of the House Appropriations Committee cutting European recovery funds $629,730,000 under the $4,198,200,000 asked by President Truman for the fiscal year of 1950.

MONTREAL, May 24 -- Research indicates that automobile drivers with high accident records are carrying out the same anti-social behavior that characterizes their personal lives and are persons who show marked intolerance for, and aggression against, any authority, dating from their childhood.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 24 -- The refusal of the Civil Aeronautics Board to allow American Airlines to provide scheduled passenger service from the Westchester County Airport in Purchase is discriminatory against Westchester and Connecticut, County Executive Herbert C. Gerlach said today in a letter to J. J. O'Connell, chairman of the CAB.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 24 -- Reflecting the growing determination here to show that the United Nations can act effectively to further the economic development of backward areas, the organization's Economic and Employment Commission recommended today the abolition of two expert subcommissions in the interest of greater efficiency.
LONDON, May 24 (AP) -- The estate of "Lawrence of Arabia" has decided against a public printing now of his secret $500,000-a-copy book "The Mint."

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Dr. Clarence F. Hiskey, a professor at Polytechnic Institute, Brooklyn, N. Y., was accused today of having been "an active member of the Communist party" in Knoxville, Tenn., in 1939-40. The accusation was made by Paul Crouch, an admitted former Communist, now an enemy of that party, before the House Committee on Un-American Activities.

The Port of New York Authority showed New York harbor yesterday to 1,500 guests, including consular officers, public officials, exporters, importers and shipping officials, as part of New York World Trade Week.
Newport Industries, Inc., has declared a regular quarterly dividend of $1.06 1/4 on the preferred stock, payable on July 1. For the second successive quarter no action has been taken on the common.

Bernard Katzen, president of the National Republican Club, urged last night that Congress award the Congressional Medal of Honor to James Forrestal, who committed suicide last Sunday. He said Mr. Forrestal had sacrificed his life as wartime Under-Secretary of the Navy, as Secretary of the Navy and as Secretary of National Defense.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 24 -- The nation's steel industry, as a whole, is in for a "readjustment shakedown," Edward L. Ryerson, chairman of the board, Inland Steel Company, said here today.

Mrs. Fiorello H. La Guardia formally renamed the completely reconditioned former Army transport Gen. W. P. Richardson the Laguardia in honor of her husband, the late Mayor, in a ceremony yesterday aboard the 18,000-ton liner at Pier 84, North River.

CHICAGO, May 24 -- Directors of Eversharp, Inc., at a special meeting today removed Martin L. Straus 2d as chairman of the board and then amended the company's by-laws to abolish the post. The action was taken late this afternoon in the company's offices after a meeting of stockholders in the morning had been adjourned to June 21.

Effectiveness this week of more than $16,000,000 of common stock financing by the Columbia Gas System and the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation will see six stand-by offerings of public utility stock to stockholders going on at the same time.

Your editorial "Taxes and Transit," in your issue of May 18, is sound and logical, but its application is much broader than you indicate. The case of the Long Island Rail Road is not an isolated one. The entire public transportation policy of this country, if it can be called a policy, is wrong.

Unless certain controversial provisions of the Lanham Trade-Mark Act of 1946 create difficulties not now apparent, immediate administrative amendments were termed unnecessary yesterday by Joe E. Daniels, Assistant United States Commissioner of Patents.

Price shakeouts and inventory losses for the dress industry have about reached their end and manufacturers can look forward to more stabilized conditions this fall, according to I. A. Agree, general manager of the National Dress Manufacturers Association.

TORONTO, May 24 (Canadian Press) -- A seven-goal splurge in the second half gave Newcastle United, first division English Football League Club, an 8-2 victory over the Ontario All-Stars today. The United trailed by 2 -- 1 at halftime.
The Board of Superintendents of the New York public school system has renewed its ban on the weekly magazine The Nation, Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, announced yesterday.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 24 -- Pollution of a community atmosphere by industrial fumes can cause discomfort, but it cannot be termed a cause of disease or death except in very rare instances, the Smoke Prevention Association of America heard here this afternoon.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 24 -- Israel's General Labor Federation [Hisdadrut] will follow the Americans, British and Dutch out of the World Federation of Trade Unions but will not join the World Labor Federation sponsored by the Western democracies.

Summer dresses, pottery and stuffed toys that blind people made "just for fun" were displayed yesterday at a program planned to show various activities of the recreation department of The Lighthouse, 111 East Fifty-ninth Street.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, May 24 -- A blueprint for Czechoslovakia's domestic and international future as a "People's Democracy" will be worked out in the next five days by the country's most authoritative body of individuals -- about 1,000 delegates to the Ninth Congress of the Communist party who gathered here tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- E. V. (Eddie) Rickenbacker, president of the Eastern Airlines, Inc., said today that the best cure for the ailing civil aviation industry is to force it to stand on its own feet. He testified before a Senate Commerce sub-committee.
The migration of displaced persons from Europe is penetrating deeper into the rural areas and inland cities of the United States as the percentage of newcomers settling in New York dwindles.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today authorized the Staten Island (New York) Edison Corporation to effect a recapitalization and to offer for sale at competitive bidding $2,750,000 of thirty-year, first mortgage bonds and 40,000 shares of $100-par value preferred stock.

The first day of business at the Fresh Meadows branch of Bloomingdale's, New York department store, brought a crowd of shoppers and sightseers yesterday estimated at 25,000 by J. Edward Davidson, chairman of the board of the store.

Furniture retailers are purchasing new bedroom suites in greater quantity than plans called for prior to introduction of new lines by major manufacturers early this month, the merchandise manager of a leading local home furnishings chain reported yesterday.

BOSTON, May 24 -- The Most Rev. Richard J. Cushing, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Boston, and the Rev. Dr. Luther A. Weigle, dean of the Yale Divinity School, were among six who received today the Award of the Silver Buffalo at the closing session of the thirty-ninth annual meeting of the National Council of the Boy Scouts of America.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., May 24 -- The Rabbinical Council of America today reaffirmed its call to American Jews to recognize the Chief Rabbinate of Israel as the central religious authority for world Jews. The action was taken in a resolution approved by 150 rabbis from the United States and Canada at the thirteenth annual convention of the council here.

ALTHOUGH India is a republic now, connected by the most intangible of bonds with the British Commonwealth, that ancient and miserable land is only halfway to freedom in the opinion of Margaret Bourke-White. Maharajas still wield despotic powers. Landowners, money lenders and industrialists still trample upon the prostrate masses.

CHICAGO, May 24 -- The second major power-generating unit completed as part of the Commonwealth Edison Company's expansion program will be put into service in a few weeks, Charles Y. Freeman, chairman, informed stockholders at their annual meeting here today.
The American Theatre Wing staged a party yesterday afternoon to draw attention to the fact that it is seeking funds.

LONDON, May 24 -- The United States and British Governments are studying the problem of the sovereign status of the island of Formosa, according to reports here. With the Chinese Communists daily increasing their sway in China and with the recognized Nationalist Government of China fast losing its control over the country the question of who rightfully owns Formosa is becoming more important.

Members of the Parents Association of Public School 150. Long Island City, Queens, one of the largest in the city, will cast ballots tonight in an election of officers that has aroused considerable neighborhood controversy over charges of "leftist" leadership, it became known yesterday.

DETROIT, May 24 -- Victor Reuther, brother of Walter Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, was mysteriously shot and wounded at his home tonight. Victor is educational director of the UAW.

A motion by the American Clinical Thermometer Guild to withdraw its original petition for trade practice rules for the industry was denied yesterday at a trade practice conference held by the Federal Trade Commission at the Lexington Hotel. The industry has an estimated annual production of $10,000,000 at retail.

DETROIT, May 24 -- A New York tax officer told more than 800 city fiscal experts convened here today that retail sales taxes not only produce needed revenue but they make for "responsible and responsive citizenship."
Regular helicopter passenger service between airports and city centers was predicted by Clarence M. Belinn yesterday as a likelihood in the near future.

ST. LOUIS, May 24 (AP) -- Stan Musial spoiled Johnny Antonelli's second pitching start of the season with a two-run fifth-inning homer to lead the Cardinals to a 3-1 victory over the Braves tonight. Harry Brecheen hurled his third victory for St. Louis.

The Bethlehem Shipbuilding Division suggested yesterday to the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers, CIO, that it withdraw a request for a wage reopening in the union's interest as well as the company's.

LONDON, May 24 -- The influence of the threatened troubles with dock and rail workers here, coupled with the drastic ban by the Union of South Africa on imports and the proposed 15 per cent cut in United States aid, had a restraining effect in the stock market here today.
Two Bronx gas customers of the Consolidated Edison Company have brought suit in Municipal Court to recover alleged overcharges from a company attempt to increase rates between meter readings.

A report from Cat Cay, that small angler-inhabited island off Miami, states that a new 15-thread tuna record has been set by Maury Webster of Santa Monica, Calif., while fishing with Capt. Tommy Gifford out of Cat Cay.
PARIS, May 24 (AP) -- Following is the text of the Soviet proposals on Germany made at the conference of Big Four Foreign Ministers, as given by United States sources:

Spring perennials in blazing colors and artful array were on display yesterday at the opening of the two-day Flower Arrangement Show presented by THE NEW YORK TIMES at Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

DEVON, Pa., May 24 -- Robert Egan of Beverly Hills, Calif., established a new riding standard tonight by skillfully guiding the four first place thoroughbreds in a jumping class at the fifty-third annual Devon Horse Show and Country Fair.

ATHENS, May 24 -- The Turkish Ambassador, Rusen Esref Unaydin, called today upon Foreign Minister Constantin Tsaldaris upon a matter directly connected with the soccer football game that took place Friday when an Italian team defeated a Turkish team by three goals to two in Athens.

Yesterday's negotiations between representatives of the National Maritime Union, CIO, led by Joseph Curran, president, and the committee for the companies and agents -- Atlantic and Gulf Coasts -- departed from the formula of step-by-step examination of the union's contract demands with the presentation of a series of counter proposals by the employers' group.

President Eurico Gaspar Dutra of Brazil, who is on a ten-day visit to the United States as the guest of our Government, spent yesterday in a second round of receptions and dining with business and social leaders of New York.

A nation-wide survey of hospitals to reduce the loss of life from fire will be undertaken soon by the National Board of Fire Underwriters in cooperation with hospital and medical organizations, it was announced yesterday.

KABUL, Afghanistan, May 13 -- A month ago, not twenty years after she had received her first Constitution following the public hanging of the Bandit King. Afghanistan held her first free election. The voters welcomed the new democracy by electing the anti-Government candidates.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Senators seeking to harden the new military unification bill denounced it today as one that would promote "separatism" among the armed forces and as a negation of "true" unification.
LAKE SUCCESS, May 24 -- Mediation officials of the United Nations have drafted a new boundary proposal in an attempt to break the deadlocked Syrian-Israeli armistice negotiations.

Wall coverings of the scrubbable, non-paper type now boast designs that may be selected for their own sake rather than just for the virtues of the material on which they are printed. This is evident in two new groups introduced yesterday, one of Varlar patterns available at Gimbels and the other of new handprints on Stylon, a product obtainable through decorators from Wall Trends, 509 Madison Avenue.

The taste in interior decoration of a New Yorker of forty years ago is illustrated by a drawing room that was opened yesterday afternoon at the Museum of the City of New York at a preview for members.

By a vote of 17 to 2 with three members abstaining, the City Council voted approval yesterday of two resolutions requesting city department heads to grant city employes leaves of absence with pay during two approaching religious days.

Highlights of the early weeks of the thirty-second season of Stadium Concerts, featuring the Philharmonic-Symphony, were announced yesterday. Fritz Reiner will be the first conductor, his stint being the first four days of the first two weeks.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The Federal Trade Commission today charged eight manufacturers of malleable iron chain and their trade association, the Malleable Chain Manufacturers Institute, Chicago, with "combination and conspiracy to fix prices and otherwise suppress competition."

The furniture division of the Mengel Company yesterday notified retailers of a price reduction of 7 per cent on two bedroom suites and an 8 per cent cut on a third suite. James McNew, Eastern sales manager of the division, said reductions are the result of lower production costs.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 24 Norman Taurog was named today by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer to direct "Please Believe Me," a comedy in which Deborah Kerr, Robert Walker and Peter Lawford will play the leading roles. The photoplay by Nat Curtis deals with an English girl who comes to Texas to claim a ranch bequeathed to her by an American soldier whom she befriended during the war. Val Lewton will produce the film starting late next month.

WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -- The House of Representatives today approved, with a vote of 158 to 28, compromise legislation giving the Commodity Credit Corporation power to acquire storage facilities for crops on which it makes loans to maintain farm price supports.

Joe DiMaggio stayed out of uniform, four Yankees were victims of pre-game mishaps and Vic Raschi could not complete his game because of a "kink" in his back but no number of casualties could make the Bombers appear anything but vigorously healthy against the forlorn Browns yesterday.

Custom smelters reduced zinc prices 1 cent a pound here yesterday, setting a new level of 11 cents, East St. Louis, for prime western grades. The price weakness was reported in trade circles to be a result of rumors that government stockpiling purchases of zinc will not be required next year.

SHANGHAI, Wednesday, May 25 -- The central and western sections of the world's fourth largest city fell to the Chinese Communists today. Moving down the principal avenues from the west, the troops fanned out into the downtown section of the city while the Nationalists manned a lightly defended rear guard line along Soochow Creek.

Nearly 1,000 Brooklynites and other guests of the Brooklyn Public Library attended the induction yesterday of its new chief librarian, Francis R. St. John. To mark the occasion -- the high point of Brooklyn Library Week, which began last Sunday -- the thirty-nine branches of the library system were closed for the day.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Counsel for the International Typographical Union. AFL, told the National Labor Relations Board today that it should withdraw from the General Counsel. Robert N. Denham, authority to ask for court injunctions in unfair-practice cases because he had abused his discretion.

A Saturday-night variety show will be introduced over WABD, Du Mont television's New York outlet, starting June 4. "Cavalcade of Stars" is the name of the program which will be seen from 9 to 10 P. M. and will feature Jack Carter as master of ceremonies.

While no specific projects are authorized, the City Planning Commission's action in adopting a master plan for the development of a Manhattan civic center in the areas adjacent to Foley Square and City Hall is important as a guide to future development and as a barrier against haphazard building and zoning.

LONDON, May 24 -- Despite his lawyer's appeal for an immediate hearing on the United States Government's demand for his extradition, Gerhart Eisler, German Communist fugitive was ordered back to prison for three more days by a London magistrate today.

The individual-size tin of corned beef hash, now being introduced by Crosse Blackwell, indicates one trend in the food industry helpful to live-aloners and small families. Packing of vegetables, fruits, soups, etc., in seven - or eight-ounce cans, suspended during the war, has resumed on a far greater scale than ever before.

Many thousands of your readers applaud the fact that your editorial "Subsidized Farm Prices" was chosen as Clipping of the Week by the Foundation for Economic Education and given even wider circulation than that of THE TIMES.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Leaders set out today to adjourn this session of Congress by July 31, even if measures high on the Administration's program and platform have to go over to next year.

BATON ROUGE, La., May 24 -- Thanks to the development of "cold" rubber the United States is now potentially independent of foreign sources of rubber and has a synthetic rubber of a quality unequaled by any natural source anywhere in the world, A. L. Freedlander, president of the Copolymer Corporation, said here today.

The report of the Consolidated Railroads of Cuba showed yesterday a reduction in net income to $895,111 for the nine months ended on March 31 from the $3,995,657 net income shown in the corresponding period of the previous year.

Richard H. Crowe, former assistant manager of a branch of the National City Bank, pleaded guilty before Federal Judge Samuel H. Kaufman yesterday to embezzling $883,660 of the bank's funds on March 25. The court set June 14 for sentence and continued the defendant in $10,000 bail.

Net income for the year 1948 of the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation, one of the major independent utilities in the East since the General Public Utilities Corporation disposed of its common stock interest in the company four months ago, was $4,740,872, equal to $4.64 a share, compared with $4,636,005 in 1947, when share earnings were $4.62 each.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- In a determined spurt of economy, the House of Representatives rejected today the Administration bill to increase the pay of the armed services. The bill, according to Administration estimates, would have cost an extra $360,000,000 in the next fiscal year, and $406,000,000 in the fiscal year 1951.

The Bethany Baptist Church of Brooklyn has purchased the four-story, six-family apartment house with three stores on a plot about 21 by 100 feet at 465 Sumner Avenue, in Brooklyn, from the Jablin Realty Company, in a deal by Thomas Calderone, broker.

Stockholders of the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company will vote at a special meeting on June 29 on a proposal to increase the authorized shares of common B stock from 13,000,000 to 15,000,000 shares and act on the board's recommended plan of simplfiying the capital structure of the company.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- James J. Andrews of New York was nominated by President Truman today to be Superintendent of the United States Assay Office there.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Mrs. James Forrestal, widow of the former Secretary of Defense, said tonight that there was "no foundation for criticism" of the National Naval Medical Center at Bethesda, Md., where her husband jumped to his death early Sunday.

The preacher son of a former Solomon Island head hunter arrived on the Cunard White Star liner Mauretania yesterday to renew acquaintances with American service men he aided in the Pacific and to stimulate interest in the missionary work of the Seventh Day Adventists Church.

Hunter College students, whose athletic activities are mainly confined to the minor league of women's sports, showed off their prowess yesterday at the college's annual field day on the Bronx campus, Bedford Park Boulevard and Goulden Avenue.
The Hudson River Day Line, under new management and with its four excursion vessels refurbished and gleaming under coats of fresh paint, will start its 1949 season this week.

LONDON, May 24 -- Late tonight, by a scant margin of thirty points, the value of one overtrick, the Crowninshield Cup, representative of the European-American team-of-four bridge championship, came to rest in English custody. It will remain in England until the tournament is played next year.

Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. of 120 East End Avenue was sworn in yesterday by Mayor O'Dwyer at City Hall as Deputy Commissioner of the Department of Hospitals at an annual salary of $9,000. Mr. Cavanagh will fill the vacancy created by the recent resignation of George H. Burns who had been questioned by District Attorney Frank Hogan in the investigation into paint contracts awarded by the city.

Honorary degrees of Doctor of Sacred Theology will be conferred today on six prominent churchmen at the annual commencement of the General Theological Seminary, 170 Ninth Avenue. The graduation exercises will begin at 11 A. M.

John M. Murtagh, commissioner of investigation, announced yesterday that he had moved for revocation of the license of a second ticket agency. He added that his investigation of ticket scalping for hit shows would lead to revocation requests for at least eight more of the thirty-two ticket agencies whose records he has been checking.

RICHMOND, Va., May 24 -- In a final spin around the Hermitage Country Club course, where the thirty-first National Professional Golfers Association championship starts tomorrow, many of the 134 competitors indicated that their games were well tuned by soundly smashing par.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 24 -- Francis H. Russell, director of the State Department's Office of Public Affairs, sketched here today a picture of China that was "not entirely gloomy," partly because, in his view, the Chinese were a liability to any country that tried to dominate them.

The need to further athletic programs as a means of developing the youth of Israel and preventing juvenile delinquency was stressed by speakers last night at the National United States-Israel Sports Committee at its organizational meeting in the Paramount Hotel.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- John L. Sullivan formally left his post as Secretary of the Navy today with a colorful ceremony outside the Pentagon Building sending him on his way.

CRESTWOOD, N. Y., May 24 -- With a best-ball round of 32, 33 -- 65, six under par, at Leewood today, Century's Harry Dee, assistant pro to Willie Goggin, and Jim Raymond, a Knollwood amateur, won the Westchester County Golf Association's second one-day tournament of the season.

The stock market was forced again yesterday into lower territory as several key industrial issues plunged to fresh lows for the year. The new decline placed the list in highly critical ground, within striking distance of the year's worst levels and in an area where on previous occasions resistance developed.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, May 24 -- Field Marshal Jan Christiaan Smuts entered his eightieth year today in perfect physical form and apparently prepared to prolong his political career indefinitely.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Investigating Senators learned today that two bars of uranium had been removed in a security test from the atomic plant at Hanford, Wash., and kept for three months without being missed.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., May 24 -- Samuel Reinlib, ousted president of the International Handbag and Luggage Union, AFL, made a dramatic reappearance today at the organization's convention here.

PARIS, May 24 -- The vigorous appeal by the three Western foreign ministers for the development of a German self-government leading to eventual independence and the restoration of Germany to the comity of Europe placed Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Y Vishinsky in an extremely difficult position on the second day of the meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., May 24 -- The Kiefer-Stewart Company, wholesale drug and liquor company, was awarded damages of $325,000 today in Federal Court in its anti-trust suit against Joseph E. Seagram Sons, Inc.

It is the present plan of the Department of Agriculture to withdraw all market supports for foods with the exception of "storables," John I. Thompson, Assistant Administrator for Marketing of the Production and Marketing Administration of the department, declared yesterday.

PARIS, May 24 -- The four-power Foreign Ministers Council broached the basic differences between the Soviet Union and the West today when Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky proposed resumption of the former four-power control of Germany with the Soviet Union sharing in the direction of the Ruhr, which is now in the hands of the three Western powers.

William H. Byrne, president of Byrne Associates, Inc., of 50 Broadway, has been selected to head the temporary organization of the city's Bureau of Smoke Control as consulting engineer, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Key Republicans in the House, moving even before formal framing of party strategy, led an attack today on the Administration's national housing bill as the measure came up before the Rules Committee for clearance to the floor.

LONDON, Wednesday, May 25 -- The Moscow radio broadcast early today a rejection of the charges made by the British Embassy in Moscow that Soviet authorities were attempting to influence the Russian staff of the British Embassy.

The method of repaying a $50 loan, on the basis of 10 per cent weekly interest, was detailed yesterday in Special Sessions as the trial of William Luke Bender on charges of unlicensed money lending at excessive rates of interest went into its fifth day.
MOSCOW, May 24 -- The Soviet press published today a Tass report running more than a column on the Paris conference but offered no editorial comment on the initial session.

Issued today in book form is "United States Participation in the United Nations," a report by President Truman to the Congress, covering 1948. The book contains a record of the work of the United Nations and several appendices on the various organizations, their work and their membership.

Reversing the usual order of things, yesterday's show held by the Tailored Woman on the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, began with a summer bride. She was a pretty thing, both the girl and the gown, all done up in nylon net with countless frills of white edged with Valenciennes lace (there were 250 yards of swirling ruffles all told).
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay predicted today that an agreement would be reached with the Soviet Union at the Foreign Ministers' Conference in Paris.

BERLIN May 24 -- The Soviet-controlled German railway police and strikebreakers quietly withdrew from West Berlin railyards and elevated stations tonight in response to an order from the United States and British commandants of this troubled city.

Flying Missel registered a popular victory in the Aletern Classified Handicap, yesterday's feature attraction at Belmont Park. Although the 4-year-old son of Equestrian was not the favorite -- a distinction that was given to the Greentree Stable's Doubtless II -- he was well played, as evidenced by his mutuel return of $6.90, $4, and $3.30 across the board.

Henderson, Ky., announced the sale yesterday of an issue of $3,000,000 of electric light and power revenue bonds due from 1953 to 1979 to Equitable Securities Corporation and associates. The winning bid designated a premium of $316 for interest rates of 2 1/4 per cent, 2 1/2 per cent, 2 3/4 per cent and 3 per cent, an interest cost of 2.9047 per cent.

Acting in compliance with an order by the Federal Power Commission, the Tennessee Gas Transmission Company will use competitive bidding for the first time in its history in an early offering of $50,000,000 of first mortgage pipeline bonds, due in 1969, it was announced yesterday.

Four new films will arrive today. At the little Cine Met, the attraction is "Woman Trouble," an Italian-made comedy-drama, starring Anna Magnani. Mario Camerini directed from a screen play by Piero Tellini. Dialogue of the Lux Film release is Italian and there are English titles.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Mrs. Harry S. Truman, soon to leave for Independence, Mo., to spend the month of June, gave to the press today one of her rare expressions of opinion.

A much-needed revision of the Displaced Persons Act of 1948 is now waiting for consideration by the House of Representatives. Although H. R. 4567 is not perfect as it comes from the Judiciary Committee, it represents a tremendous improvement over the "all but unworkable" law passed last year.
Production plans for the hot-weather season were announced yesterday by various playhouses.

HARLECH, Wales, May 24 (AP) -- America's chances of winning the British women's amateur golf championship for the third year in a row collapsed today with the double defeat of Miss Grace Lenczyk and Miss Peggy Kirk.

SHANGHAI, Wednesday, May 25 (AP) -- Small groups of Communist troops reached downtown Shanghai about 7:30 this morning. They wore emblems on green uniforms identifying themselves as the "Peoples' Liberation Army."
LONDON, May 24 -- Queen Elizabeth was in the packed audience in Royal Albert Hall tonight for the first London concert of the Philadelphia Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Eugene Ormandy.

The cotton futures market yesterday closed 4 points lower to 5 points higher, with activity on the New York Cotton Exchange at a minimum. Trading started 2 to 6 points lower, and business dwindled as the day progressed. A spot was credited with selling about 2,500 bales of July, and the trade bought a little cotton on the scale-down.

The packaging committee of the Maritime Association of the Port of New York announced yesterday that it will begin its survey on shipment damage causes with a check of four vessels scheduled to sail soon from New York Harbor piers.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 24 (AP) -- Counsel for Howard S. Palmer, former president of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad, and attorneys for the railroad agreed in Superior Court today to delay action on suits here and in New York City arising from his claim for a pension.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The Economic Cooperation Administration announced today regulations specifying that at least half of all Marshal Plan-financed recovery cargoes be carried on United States ships.

In "The Art of Egg Cookery" Ann Seranne gives sixteen recipes -- all of them delightfully different -- for scrambling eggs. They're an effective answer to anyone who doubts that it's possible to devote almost 200 pages to the preparation of this one food.

The nation's gasoline stocks last week declined 799,000 barrels to 120,469,000 at the week-end, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Gasoline production, however, was increased 724,000 barrels during the week to 18,230,000 barrels.

PARIS, May 25 -- The Soviet Union's huge reparations claims on Germany were flatly rejected as a condition of economic unity by Secretary of State Dean Acheson today and the Soviet Union was challenged to show economic cause for the addition of the Eastern zone to the Western German state.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) -Following is the text of the letter by Chairman David E. Lilienthal to the Atomic Energy Commission to Senator Brien McMahon, Democrat, of Connecticut, chairman of the Congressional Joint Atomic Energy Committee, asking the committee for a full hearing on charges of maladministration:

Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt has another stakes-winner in his barn -- the 2-year-old filly, Bed O' Roses. She whisked through the Widener chute at Belmont Park yesterday to a three-length decision in the filly division of the $24,570 National Stallion Stakes. She was the $3.70-for-$2 favorite.

Isaac Deutscher's excellent article in THE TIMES Magazine of May 22 and your leading editorial of May 23 are based on a justified premise that Poland will again be the main issue at the Paris conference.

Hal Newhouser, generally accepted as baseball's premier southpaw, appeared a veritable tyro in comparison with youthful Tommy Byrne as the rampaging Yankees turned back the Tigers, 6 -- 2, at the Stadium yesterday. It was the fourth triumph in a row for the league-leading Bombers and Detroit's sixth consecutive defeat.

Gustav Metzman, 63-year-old president of the billion-dollar New York Central Railroad, tossed a note of gloom yesterday into the thirty-fifth annual meeting of stockholders, which was held in Albany, when he forecast "greatly" increased operating costs after Sept. 1.

CHICAGO, May 25 -- The National Federation of Sales Executives today advocated that the right of salesmen's unions to strike be made a "public issue," in order that through the exercise of this right there could be developed from experience a body of laws reconciling public interest with union prerogatives in this field.
WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) -- The Administration's compulsory health insurance plan is the wrong prescription for the nation's ills, the American Medical and Dental Associations told Congress today.

Mrs. Ruth Goldberg of 39-65 Forty-seventh Street, Long Island City, Queens, was chosen president of the Parents Association of Public School 150, Forty-third Avenue and Fortieth Street, in an election at the school last night supervised by the Honest Ballot Association.
The cotton futures market closed yesterday virtually at the lows of the day on the New York Cotton Exchange, down 11 to 20 points on the day.

Walter E. Lawlor, civilian hearing examiner for the Coast Guard, found twenty-three members of the crew of the freighter Flying Arrow guilty yesterday of refusing to proceed to sea at Singapore on Jan. 17. Technical four-month suspensions of their sailing papers were imposed on all.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- President Truman tonight appealed to the country to give its young military men "the same sort of treatment they would have received if they had stayed at home."

Expected approval by the Board of Estimate today of plans prepared by consultant engineers for eventual construction of Ferry Point Park in the Bronx is slated to pave the way for the second large public beach in the city's northernmost borough, it was announced yesterday at the Park Department.

BUFFALO, N. Y., May 25 (AP) -- Wells V. Moot, president of Sylvanite Gold Mines, Ltd., said today in the company's annual report "the time is rapidly approaching when managed paper moneys throughout the world with fictitious values must be adjusted to their true relative value of gold."

The Magazine Copy Advisory Committee, representing a majority of national magazine publishers, agreed yesterday to follow a set of standards designed to assure accuracy in the advertising of ammoniated dentifrices. While no formal "code" is involved, the committee's recommendations on acceptability of advertising by member publishers have the weight of one, it was noted.

DETROIT, May 25 -- The Ford Motor Company disclosed today that it was opposing the payment of unemployment compensation to nonstriking members of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, who were idle by reason of the national shutdown caused by the "speed-up" walkout.

The wide gulf separating Soviet Russia from the West grew wider at the opening sessions of the Four-Power conference in Paris when Mr. Vishinsky presented the first outlines of the Soviet program in terms that prompted the Western delegates to turn his program down immediately, emphatically and unanimously.

The Rev. William Howard Melish, who figured in the recent termination of the rectorship of his father, the Rev. Dr. John Howard Melish, at Holy Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Clinton and Montague Streets, Brooklyn, was guest of honor last night at a dinner held under the auspices of the board of directors of the National Council of American-Soviet Friendship.
SEOUL, Korea, May 25 -- An editorial in The Union Times yesterday strongly attacked United States foreign policy makers, accusing them of "making themselves liable for another tragedy for Korea."
BOSTON, May 25 -- The American Unitarian Association defeated today a proposal to change that part of its by-laws dealing with its statement of purpose.
Six outstanding members of nearby garden clubs demonstrated yesterday the skillful touch and painstaking care that turn a mass of cut blooms and foliage into a striking flower arrangement.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The Communications Workers of America has been sustained in the first three of thirty-six representation challenges filed by the Bell System as a result of the union's affiliation with the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

Coffee futures on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange became steady after early declines yesterday. Scattered long liquidation was absorbed by trade-hedge covering. Final prices for contract "S" were unchanged to 22 points higher, the near-by months were the steadiest.

Bendix Home Appliance, Inc., yesterday introduced a new fully automatic agitator type washer to retail for $179.95 at a local distributor and press showing in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The new unit is priced $100 to $120 below competitive nationally advertised automatic washers and is $80 less than the lowest priced comparable private brand, according to Judson S. Sayre, president.

Because of rowdyism by Brooklyn high school students at Ebbets Field, the students' privilege of free admittance to Dodger home games may be discontinued, an official of the Board of Education announced yesterday.
The books and records of nine clubs were taken yesterday to the office of John M. Murtagh, Commissioner of Investigation, who is looking into complaints of overcharges for theatre tickets.
CHICAGO, May 25 -- The Giants' first Western jaunt of the year ended on a damp and sour note today, as under cover of a leaden sky, they dropped their series finale to the tail-end Cubs, 3 to 2.

BERLIN, May 25 -- West Berlin again is being sustained to a great extent by the Anglo-American airlift. The great hopes for the city, inspired by the agreement that ended Russia's eleven month blockade were almost completely frustrated today. Soviet-controlled rail workers deserted switch boxes in the West sector rail yards and brought traffic between West Berlin and the Western zones of Germany to a standstill.

DETROIT, May 25 -- Surgeons removed the right eye of Victor G. Reuther today as hundreds of police officers attempted to track down the assassin who sought to kill him in the fashion of the attack thirteen months ago upon his better known brother, Walter, president of the United Automobile Workers, CIO.

Only financial arrangements remain to be completed before work can begin on the greatest bridge ever undertaken -- a slender steel and concrete roadway to swing 237 feet above the waters of the Narrows -- the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority said yesterday.

MINEOLA, L. I., May 25 -- Dr. Theodore J. Curphey, Nassau County Medical Examiner, reported formally today that Owen Davis Jr., son of the playwright and a television producer for the National Broadcasting Company, had met death by accidental drowning.

MADRID, May 21 -- The harassed Spanish Government is doing its best to conceal terrific disappointment over nonadmission to the United Nations and the North Atlantic pact, and especially over its failure to get a loan of $300,000,000, or part of it, from the United States.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The Association of American Railroads today ordered an embargo on all shipments of bulk grain for storage, effective on June 1, from all points in Kansas, Nebraska, Colorado, Missouri, Oklahoma and Texas, except from Port Arthur, Galveston and Houston.

KABUL, Afghanistan, May 14 -- Emerging from the isolation of countless centuries, Afghanistan, at the same time that she has started to bring her kingdom into step with its modern neighbors, has come to an alarmed consciousness of the country's strategic position at the triple junction of Far and Middle East with Soviet-dominated Central Asia.
Directors of American Machine and Metals, Inc., have taken no action on a common stock dividend. Last year the company paid 25c each in June and December.
LONDON, May 24 -- Lord Beaverbrook, impish and dynamic stormy petrel of British politics and journalism for the past thirty years, celebrated his seventieth birthday here today quietly -- for him.

THE distinguishing characteristic of a great umpire, they say, is that no one notices him or his work. That doesn't apply, as a rule, to great ball players. They usually are noticed and acclaimed in headlines. But the visiting Detroit Tigers have one star performer who rarely makes a headline because his flawless play generally is taken too much for granted.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, May 25 (AP) -- Archbishop Josef Beran, fighting restrictions on the Roman Catholic Church in Communist-dominated Czechoslovakia, has hurled the term "Judas" at Government figures aiding the action.

PARIS, May 25 -- Negotiations for a new trade agreement between the French Government and allied authorities in Western Germany have stalled just as the three Western powers are presenting a united front in the Council of Foreign Ministers against Soviet proposals for a return to four-power control over Germany.

The radioisotopes, common elements that have been made radioactive with atomic energy, offer "tremendous possibilities" for the solution of many problems in dentistry, it was reported last night at a special meeting of the First District Dental Society of the State of New York.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The United States again urged Russia today to return three icebreakers and twenty-eight frigates that were used as patrol vessels, all of which were provided her during the war under lend-lease provisions.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The Senate rejected today by 46 to 26 an effort to stiffen the military unification bill by giving the Secretary of Defense authority to reassign combat personnel from one armed service to another.

The shooting of Victor Reuther, a key policy maker and the educational director of the United Automobile Workers, is obviously reminiscent of the shooting a year ago of his older brother, Walter, president of the union. In that case a former official of a UAW local has been charged with the crime but not yet tried.

The New York City Housing Authority is looking forward to an early end of its rehabilitation of old tenements, an expensive operation it undertook only as an unwelcome necessity, it was learned yesterday. The current cost of refurbishing 767 apartments is estimated at $4,463,900, or an average of $5,820 each.

A "major step forward" was reported yesterday by Investigation Commissioner John M. Murtagh in his effort to clean up conditions along the New York waterfront, as he announced that public loaders had agreed to set up a uniform system of bookkeeping.

A washable all-steel porcelain enamel house that is easy to care for inside and out has joined the attractions at the Palisades Amusement Park, Cliffside Park, N. J. Shown yesterday to the press, it will be opened Saturday afternoon for the benefit of the Mark Hellinger Memorial Fund of the New York Heart Association and the New Jersey Heart Association.
Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday that he would not be a candidate for re-election next fall.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Conferees on the bills adopted in House and Senate to give broad reorganization to the President, ended their third meeting today without even approaching agreement.

Nine men who were said by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan to be members of a loosely knit combine of narcotics wholesalers whose annual sales totaled "millions of dollars" were taken into police custody last night as the culmination of a year's investigation.

A sample of what excursion-bent vacationists may expect on cruising up the Hudson this summer was offered yesterday for the benefit of 300 city officials and other guests by the new operators of the Hudson River Day Line.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 25 -- In its first meeting in two months, the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission heard the Soviet Union repeat its demand today for the adoption of its own double plan for the settlement of the long atomic control controversy.

Now that vaudeville is back at the Palace, twenty "old timers" at the Home for Aged and Infirm Hebrews staged yesterday a show for the home's forty-sixth annual Isaac and Regina Bierman garden party. The "SRO sign" was out in the home's garden at 121 West 105th Street as 425 of the 500 residents watched from wheel chairs and garden benches.

The attacks upon David E. Lilienthal and the Atomic Energy Commission, which continued in the Congress yesterday, stem fundamentally from the mistaken belief that secrecy is security, and from the naive and fallacious over-dependence of Congress and the public upon the atomic bomb.
The Esso Standard Oil Company announced yesterday a policy by which customers who purchased No. 2 heating oil for resale will be protected against declines in price during the summer fill-up season.

CHICAGO, May 25 -- Liquidation developed in the grain markets on the Board of Trade today and closing trades were about at the bottom. Wheat broke 1 1/4 to 1 3/4 cents a bushel, the July leading. After the close it was announced that 1,230,000 bushels of cash wheat had been tendered on May contracts.
ST. LOUIS, May 25 (AP) -- Howard Pollet pitched a six-hit game today and the Cardinals made it two straight over the Braves, 3 to 0.

CHICAGO, May 25 -- The investigation by a Federal grand jury of the du Pont industrial empire has been resumed after lying dormant about four months, it became known today when it was disclosed that subpoenas duces tecum had been issued recently in connection with the E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co.

LONDON, May 25 -- Two hundred 6-foot-tall officers and men of the First Battalion of the Welsh Regiment of Foot Guards marched in towering bearskins, scarlet tunics and blue trousers across the lawns behind Buckingham Palace here today to the familiar -- if somewhat startling -- air of "The Old Gray Mare, She Ain't What She Used to Be."

By a split vote, the four-man instructional affairs committee of the Board of Education refused yesterday to hear an appeal by Miss Freda Kirchwey, editor and publisher of The Nation, against the Board of Superintendents renewed ban on the weekly magazine.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Two atomic scientists who were associated during the war with the radiation laboratory at the University of California at Berkeley were questioned separately and at length in closed sessions today as the House Committee on Un-American Activities pursued its investigation into whether secrets of the atom bomb escaped to Russia.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- House leaders moved today to nullify the Appropriations Committee's action cutting $629,770,000 from European recovery funds for the 1950 fiscal year through an arrangement to permit the spending of the reduced appropriation in a shorter period of time.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Charges against the Atomic Energy Commission by Senator Bourke B. Hickenlooper, Republican, of Iowa, have created "a dangerous cloud of uneasiness" not only in the United States, but in other democracies of the world, Chairman David E. Lilienthal said today.

Federal Judge Harold R. Medina rebuked the defendants and their counsel at the Communist trial yesterday for trying to assume the status of "privileged persons" and for repeated "wrangling" in "disobedience" of his instructions to maintain order in court.

The railroads have long complained that they were at a competitive disadvantage with other types of transportation because of the numerous subsidies, visible and invisible, under which these forms of common carriers operate. Not until this week, however, so far as we are aware, has the unusual spectacle been witnessed of a leading representative of one of these competitors protesting publicly against subsidies to his own industry.

Declaring that New York was really governed by district leaders and not by its responsible elected officials, Adolf A. Berle Jr., state chairman of the Liberal party, said last night that he was opposed to any alliance with the Democratic party, as organized at present, for the city election in November.

At the end of the season comes our most memorably loathsome play. Jack Kirkland's "Mr. Adam," which lasted two hours at the Royale last evening, takes all awards for the worst play of the season and will have to be seriously considered for a historical rating close to the bottom.

Three American industrial executives discussed a program for averting socialism in the United States at the thirty-third annual dinner meeting of the National Industrial Conference Board at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Two Congressional investigations are now in view that can have unfortunate effects on national security, though not necessarily so. That will depend on the caliber of the Senate and House committees which will inquire into the administrative record of the Atomic Energy Commission and the procurement policy of the Air Force.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) -The Army would market at wholesale any hydroelectric power developed at flood-control dams under two bills introduced today by Senator Kenneth McKellar of Tennessee. Under the 1944 Flood Control Act, the Department of the Interior markets all public power.

LONDON, May 25 -- Prime Minister Attlee and Herbert Morrison, Deputy Prime Minister and political strategist of the Labor party, patched up today a rift that has developed in the party between the leadership and a sizable group of rebels.

What designers of furniture and fabrics in eight European nations are concentrating on these days may be seen in the exhibit that opened yesterday at the Architectural League, 115 East Fortieth Street, and will continue to June 11.

United States Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas speaking last night at a memorial for Rabbi Stephen S. Wise declared that the late Zionist leader who achieved prominence in various phases of Jewish life, "gave fresh vitality to the ancient tradition of the Hebrew prophets." Rabbi Wise's philosophy, Justice Douglas added, "was equally true to the genius of America."
The hobbies of the people in the Chelsea neighborhood were on exhibit last night at Public School 11, 320 West Eleventh Street.

LONDON, May 25 -- British official circles reacted favorably here today to the news that the United States had started consultations of non-Communist nations with interests in the Far East to frame a common policy toward the Chinese Communists.

Humphrey Armitage Lee, a British dealer in tapestry in this country for forty-five years, was killed at noon yesterday when the automobile he was driving crashed into a light pole on the exit of the Triborough Bridge at Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive.

The blame for the sharp decline in the private light plane market was laid on the doorstep of the light plane manufacturers yesterday by Grover Loening, veteran airplane designer and consultant to the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics.

Francis Keally, president of the Municipal Art Society, urged last night at the society's annual dinner in the Delmonico Hotel that the Municipal Art Commission receive control over the esthetic character of private as well as public buildings.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) -- Washington pounced on Steve Gromek and Sam Zoldak for six runs in the first two innings to defeat Cleveland, 6 -- 2, tonight behind the 7-hit pitching of Sid Hudson. It was the Senators' fourth victory in four games with the Indians.

"Twenty-seven Masters of Politics in a Personal Perspective," by Raymond Moley, has been scheduled for October publication by Funk Wagnalls. Mr. Moley, newspaper and magazine columnist and Professor of Public Law at Columbia University, has based his biographical sketches on personal acquaintance.

Bond men are putting finishing touches on preparations for the Bond Club's annual field day at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club, Scarborough, on June 3. The annual one-day edition of The Bawl Street Journal is in final-proof stage and Myron F. Ratcliffe of Lehman Brothers is taking $1-acopy advance orders.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended May 18, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:

The League of Women Voters of New York City adopted at its annual meeting a resolution calling for "the appointment of an impartial commission with full powers to survey the finances of the City of New York and recommend solutions for the city's recurring budgetary problems, so that adequate services and proper planning for capital needs may be provided."

A Roman Catholic version of the events that preceded the arrest and imprisonment for life of Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty by the Communist - controlled Hungarian Government was published yesterday under the title "Cardinal Mindszenty Speaks."

The New York Boxing Managers Guild yesterday turned down Madison Square Garden's offer of a settlement concerning television fees to be paid to feature event fighters performing in the Eighth Avenue arena.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 25 -- Harry Bridges, Pacific Coast longshore leader, was indicted by a Federal grand jury here today on conspiracy and perjury charges growing out of his successful bid for United States citizenship in 1945 after two moves to deport him to his native Australia had failed.
SHANGHAI, May 25 -- To prepare the outskirts of Shanghai for the defense that everyone knew was only a delaying action, the Nationalists destroyed some of the finest estates in China.
LONDON, May 25 (AP) -- England's Derby, scheduled for its 170th running at Epsom Downs on June 4, will be the richest and probably the largest race in the long history of the 3-year-old classic.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 25 -- Willard Marriott, of Washington, D. C., president of the National Restaurant Association, said today that the nation's restaurant business, after ten years of mounting prosperity, is now "starting to take the trail down to some leveling-off point."

Contributions totaling $2,500,000 were made last night to the United Jewish Appeal at a series of dinners throughout the city. The appeal is seeking to raise $250,000,000 for 1949 throughout the nation.

PARIS, May 25 -- There are reasons to believe that the United States is preparing to advance a compromise formula on Austria at the current meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers in an effort to achieve agreement on a peace treaty for that country.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, Acting United Nations Mediator for Palestine, told President Truman today that he could not accept a proffered appointment as Assistant Secretary of State.
BLUEFIELD, W. Va., May 25 -- Preliminary demands by John L. Lewis stalemated the wage conference of the United Mine Workers and Southern Operators almost as soon as it opened today.
There are a few big, weakfish moving around Peconic Bay, even though the average fish comes under the "one portion" size, and we had reports yesterday of several fish up to 6 pounds being taken.

CHICAGO, May 25 -- Unemployment compensation checks for 1,400 idle employes of the Ford Motor Company's assembly plant on the Chicago's South Side are being held up on orders from Samuel G. Bernstein, director of the Unemployment Compensation Division of the State Labor Department, it was learned today.

The stock market yesterday met the initial test of the so-called resistance levels with some success. However, the list's decline of more than a week was halted only after new lows for the year had been reached. Early losses of fractions to a point were in exact reversal in the late trading.
Edgar G. Sisson Jr. has resigned as vice president and director of radio for Pedlar Ryan, Inc., to become director of radio and television programming for N. W. Ayer Son, Inc.

FRANKFORT, Germany, May 25 -- Although pessimism still prevails as to the possibility of a satisfactory solution of the German problem in Paris, Western German public opinion has responded enthusiastically to the Western Allied stand in the opening sessions of the Council of Foreign Ministers.
PARIS, May 25 -- Premier Henri Queuille pulled his coalition Cabinet out of a near-crisis today, but not without having made promises that might be difficult to keep.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- James Forrestal received a military hero's burial today in the resting place of Americans who have given their lives for their country. In the presence of President Truman and his family, the leaders of this Government and the diplomats of others, final tribute was paid this morning to Mr. Forrestal in the amphitheatre of Arlington Memorial Cemetery.
LONDON, May 25 -- Business remained limited in the stock markets here today and prices declined in all sections.

Negotiations between the National Maritime Union, CIO, and a committee representing thirty-three East and Gulf Coast steamship operators adjourned at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon "without further progress." The next meeting has been set for June 2.

When fresh lobsters turn up not only in fine restaurants but in chain stores and other large markets, as they have recently, then one knows that the north Atlantic's great contribution to the table arts is back again in season.

New York State Electric and Gas Corporation will offer today to holders of its 880,000 shares of common stock the right to subscribe for 73,333 additional shares at $44.50 a share on the basis of one new share for each twelve held.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Francis P. Matthews was sworn in as Secretary of the Navy today in a brief ceremony that also elevated two other officials to the ranks of Under Secretaries of the Army and the Navy.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Persons who have eliminated Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., as a Presidential candidate on the ground of ineligibility may find that they were hasty in their judgment.

New Yorkers today and visitors to the city, alike, can hardly fail, we think, to take at least a curious interest in the picture of our big town presented by Appleton's Illustrated Handbook of American Travel, a wide-ranging survey of our country's tourist attractions, published in 1860, when the local population was figured at 1,000,000 souls.
Tom Casey turned in a handsome pitching job for New York University yesterday, but the breaks were against him and the Violet lost a 4-0 decision to the Holy Cross baseball team at the Polo Grounds.

Three thousand persons crowded Pier 54, North River, yesterday to inspect and bid bon voyage to the newly-refurbished passenger liner Atlantic, formerly the Matsonia, as the vessel started her initial run on the Home Lines' new service from New York to the Mediterranean.

PARIS, May 25 (AP) -- Five American tennis stars -- Frank Parker, Pancho Gonzales, Budge Patty, Mrs. Margaret Osborne du Pont and Miss Louise Brough -- advanced today to the doubles semi-finals of the French international championships.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- President Truman ended today the impasse with Hungary over the post of American Minister in Budapest by nominating Nathaniel P. Davis, now Ambassador to Costa Rica, to that office.

PITTSBURGH, May 25 -- Manager Barney Shotton jolted his critics no little today by benching the Dodgers' star outfielder, Duke Snider, and inserting the almost forgotten youngster, Tommy Brown, in left field in order to present a solid right-hand hitting line-up against Southpaw Bill Werle.

Ideas for those planning one-room apartments on a budget, temporary living quarters in an attic or new homes in the suburbs may be gleaned from several scale models that students of the New York School of Interior Decoration placed on exhibit yesterday.

Complaints from many displaced persons resettled on sugar plantations near New Orleans that they were underpaid, underfed, under-clothed and being otherwise exploited were found to be true and in some cases conditions were "far worse than reported," it was declared here yesterday.
CAMDEN, N. J., May 25 (AP) -- The Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers, CIO, today rejected a request by the Bethlehem Steel Company to pass up a wage increase demand this year.

WESTBURY, L. I., May 25 -Mrs. William R. Kirkland Jr. of Piping Rock, Long Island medal and match play champion, continues to lead the way in the Women's Long Island Golf Association's one-day tournaments. For the second time in two weeks, the Piping Rock player won low gross honors as she toured the Meadow Brook Club course today in 41, 40 -- 81.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (UP) -Rbert R. Granville, supervisor of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's New York office, said today he took "some papers" from Valentine A. Gubitchev's pocket when he arrested the Russian and Judith Coplon in midtown Manhattan March 4.
Formal requests for a contract reopening were served yesterday on the General Electric Company and Westinghouse Electric Corporation by the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, CIO.
Seventy-six German mariners are busy in the harbor familiarizing themselves with the operation of twelve American-built trawlers that they expect to sail to Bremen next month.

LONDON, May 25 -- In a small way Britain has started taking reprisals against Soviet diplomats for "interference" with and "persecution" of employes of the British Embassy in Moscow, a British Foreign Office spokesman said today. Entry to Britain has been denied to at least one Soviet diplomat.

Spokesmen for the bus companies operating under city franchises and the labor unions representing their 10,000 employes agreed yesterday at City Hall on the appointment of an impartial chairman to handle labor disputes and the interpretation of labor contracts.

Your news of May 2 from the free gold and currency markets of Paris gives a glimpse of what is happening to the dollar. According to this, gold sold in Paris on April 25 at 530,000 francs a kilogram, the United States dollar for 335 francs. As there are 32.1507 troy ounces of pure gold in this one kilogram French bar, gold was therefore selling for 16,485 francs per ounce.
After twenty-five years of service, Garrett W. Cotter, United States Commissioner for the Southern District of New York, announced yesterday that he was retiring next Wednesday.

Persons employed at a fixed weekly salary with unspecified hours of employment are entitled to overtime after forty hours of work at one-half instead of one and one-half times the fixed rate under the Fair Labor Standards Act, the Appellate Division ruled yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) -- Republican Senate leaders agreed today to continue their drive to reduce President Truman's spending estimates with a veto-proof rider designed to save about two billion dollars.

An exhibition of linoleum-printed paper panels four to ten feet long and ready to be hung on the walls of a child's room, a rumpus room, or used as a modern decoration in a living room will open this morning at 10 o'clock at the Brooklyn Museum.

The State of Ohio sold yesterday $12,500,000 of World War II veterans' compensation bonds due on Oct. 15, 1949, to April 15, 1964, to a banking syndicate headed by the National City Bank of New York at an interest cost of 1.39602 per cent.

BUFFALO, N. Y., May 25 -- A report recommending far-reaching changes in the organizational structure of the Presbyterian Church in the U. S. A. was adopted here today at the closing session of the denomination's General Assembly.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Representative James E. Van Zandt, Republican, of Pennsylvania, introduced a resolution today calling for a House investigation of recent changes in Air Force plans resulting in the award of large contracts to the Consolidated-Vultee Aircraft Corporation of San Diego.
The United States Golf Association outlined the qualifying program for three of its major amateur tournaments yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The Securities and Exchange today granted permission to the Columbia Gas System, Inc., New York, to offer 1,345,300 additional shares of its common stock for subscription at $10 a share by the holders of its outstanding 13,452,874 shares of common stock.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Representative Jacob K. Javits, Republican, of New York, told the House Rules Committee today that, if the Administration's national housing bill was cleared for a floor vote, it would have strong bipartisan support.

In a letter made public yesterday, Bernard J. Gillroy, Commissioner of Housing and Buildings, said that City Councilman Stanley Isaacs was "ignorant of the facts" when he recently criticized the department's Division of Housing in a council resolution. Mr. Gillroy's letter was addressed to Theodore L. Weigand, legislative assistant to the Council, who had asked the Commissioner for an opinion concerning the allegations.

First reactions on fall lines of popular and medium price dresses furnish a clear indication that the season will prove outstanding for volume producers, according to Henry Rosenfeld, president of the dress company bearing his name. Retailers are in a receptive mood to buy, he said yesterday in an interview at his New York showroom, and are willing to stock garments early for fullest sales potential.

Dr. Karl T. Compton, chairman of the research and development board of the National Military Establishment, declared yesterday that "the furnishing of military assistance to the free nations of western Europe is desirable in order to assure the security of the progress which they have made thus far and to stimulate the additional private investment which is required to carry recovery still further."

Two new films will open in midtown theatres this morning. At the Capitol the attraction is "Tulsa," a drama about the oil fields, starring Robert Preston, Susan Hayward and Pedro Armendariz. Walter Wanger produced and Stuart Heisler directed the Technicolor production from a screen play by Frank S. Nugent and Curtis Kenyon.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 25 -- Vincent Sherman will direct "The Victim," Joan Crawford's next vehicle at Warner Brothers, which is described by Jerry Wald, its producer, as "the story of a modern bad girl." Gertrude Walker has written a scenario, and production is scheduled to start about July 1.
BOSTON, May 25 (AP) -- The Browns supported effective pitching by Cliff Fannin and Tom Ferrick with 13 hits to snap a Red Sox four-game winning streak today with an 8-4 victory.

DEVON, Pa., May 25 -- With Robert Egan of Beverly Hills, Calif., in the saddle, Mr. Chips, owned by the Sterling Smith Stables of Ravenna, Ohio, tonight captured a leg on the Brian Boru Challenge Trophy at the fifty-third annual Devon Horse Show and Country Fair.

John D. Rockefeller 3d, citywide campaign chairman of the Greater New York Fund, expressed concern yesterday because the first thirty-one days of the forty-eightday campaign had brought in contributions totaling only $3,730,893, or 47 per cent of the $8,000,000 goal.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Representative Jacob K. Javits, Republican, of New York, told the House Rules Committee today that, if the Administration's national housing bill was cleared for a floor vote, it would have strong bipartisan support.

In a letter made public yesterday, Bernard J. Gillroy, Commissioner of Housing and Buildings, said that City Councilman Stanley Isaacs was "ignorant of the facts" when he recently criticized the department's Division of Housing in a council resolution. Mr. Gillroy's letter was addressed to Theodore L. Weigand, legislative assistant to the Council, who had asked the Commissioner for an opinion concerning the allegations.

The warm weather season approaching fast, Radio City's Center Theatre unfolds tonight another edition in the long series of ice entertainments produced over the years by the team of Sonja Henie and Arthur M. Wirtz. Labeled "Howdy, Mr. Ice of 1950," the new ice revue will feature the nation's top skating stars and ice comedians.

Both Houses of Congress have now approved, and sent to a conference committee, bills giving the President authority to make reorganizations within the Executive Branch of the Government in the interest of economy and greater efficiency. The two bills differ in a number of respects.

MONTREAL, May 25 -- Electroshock is being given "indiscriminately" throughout the United States and in many cases is "sadly misused" as a form of treatment, Dr. Abraham Z. Barhash of the National Committee for Mental Hygiene reported today.

The State Committee of the Communist party cracked down yesterday on Bronx Communists who had discriminated against Negroes by refusing to admit them to their clubs, to fraternize socially with them or to give them leading positions.
BUENOS AIRES, May 25 -- Imports from the United States were limited today by Government order to 25 per cent of the 1947-48 average because of the current dollar exchange shortage.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., May 25 (AP) -- Some 300 high school seniors took over the management of the big Johnson Johnson plant today to see how big business operates.

MOSCOW, May 25 -- The Soviet press reported today the deliberations of the Big Four Paris conference in confident, optimistic tones but raised the question whether the Western delegations would show the same desire for good-will and agreement that it said was being displayed by Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky.

Industrial Rayon Corporation has revised prices on viscose filament rayon yarn, it was announced yesterday. The 100 denier, 40 filament yarn on cones has been reduced to 91 cents a pound; 100 denier, 60 filament to 93 cents; 150 denier, 40 filament to 73 cents; and 300 denier, 80 filament to 59 cents.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The United States is seeking through diplomatic conversations with a dozen or more Governments having interests in China to encourage a common front for dealing with the Chinese Communists, it became known today.
Eleven years ago today Peggy was 11 and beginning life over again. Her father's desertion and her mother's sudden death had sent Peggy to live in a temporary shelter.

IN Mozart's "Don Giovanni" the valet, Leporello, estimates that his master has, in Italy, several hundred girls, in Germany, Turkey and France many dozen others, and, in Spain, more than a thousand. The gallantly aging British actor-manager who plays Don Juan on the stage and in contemporary London during Diana Forbes-Robertson's new novel, "A Cat and a King,"* is not anything like so lavish with his affections.

PORTMARNOCK, Ireland, May 25 (AP) -- Frank Stranahan and Willie Turnesa rolled into the fourth round of the British amateur golf championship tournament today as Ireland's whitehaired President, Sean T. O'Kelly, watched the play.

Apparently the idea behind "Manhandle," which opened yesterday at the Paramount, was to set up Dan Duryea as the paramount movie heel of the year. As a private investigator hungry for a dishonest dollar he not on]y physically abuses Dorothy Lamour but tries to pin on her innocent person full responsibility for a jewel robbery and murder.

SHANGHAI, Thursday, May 26 -- While most of Shanghai had been "liberated" yesterday and had returned to peaceful pursuits, the war still sputtered in front of the United States Consulate on the Bund and along Soochow Creek, which provides a natural defense line covering the continuing Nationalist retreat northeast toward Woosung.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 25 -- A global investigation by United Nations economic experts of discriminatory laws and policies applied against foreign private investors in many under-developed countries was called for today by an economic commission of the world organization.
JAMESTOWN, N. Y., May 25 (AP) -- Members of the New York State Telephone Association were told today that many rate increases are expected this year to give them "much-needed relief."

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- President Truman today renewed his pledge to fight for his civil rights program as he accepted the annual Robert S. Abbott award established in memory of the pioneer Negro journalist who founded The Chicago Defender, a weekly.

CHICAGO, May 25 (AP) -- A Federal Court suit is pending here in which the Rudolph Wurlitzer Company, which makes juke boxes, charges that a former officer profited from "secret" agreements that injured it.
CINCINNATI, May 25 (AP) -- The Reds came from behind today to defeat the Phillies, 3 to 2, and, although still in fourth place, moved within a game and a half of the league-leading Braves.

The Yardville plan for creating community gardens by cleaning up and consolidating groups of adjacent back yards has now been adopted in forty-one cities throughout the country, it was announced yesterday by Otis L. Wiese, publisher and editor of McCall's. Mr. Wiese spoke at a luncheon in the Ritz-Carlton Hotel under the auspices of the magazine, which originated the movement.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., May 25 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, gave his official blessing today to the new leadership of the International Handbag and Luggage Union.

ROME, May 25 -- Labor representatives of the Republican and Right-Wing Socialist (PSLI) parties began discussions this evening, designed to lead to the formation of a new labor confederation that would be independent of both the Communist-dominated Italian General Labor Confederation (CGIL) and the Pro-Catholic Free Labor Confederation (LCGIL).

Ernest Bevin, the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs of Great Britain, has made the claim that the lifting of the blockade of Berlin was an immediate result of the Atlantic Pact. I crave leave to point out that there is another event, to which also the Soviet action might with equal reason be attributed.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 25 -- While Lebanese and Syrian leaders were meeting today to settle their dispute over frontier incidents, the Beirut press reported another border violation last night by six armed Syrians who were said to have murdered a man and escaped back to Syria.
