Negotiations will continue tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Attorney General Tom Clark was urged today to order the Federal Bureau of Investigation into the hunt for the assailant of Victor Reuther, but there was no comment from the Department of Justice.

RICHMOND, Va., May 25 -- One of the Professional Golfers Association's top officials, George Schneiter of Ogden, Utah, blazed the way with a 66 in the first qualifying round of the organization's thirty-first championship over the Hermitage Country Club course today.
An increase of at least $1,000,000,000 a year in long-term private American investment in foreign enterprises is being sought by the Department of Commerce.

The branch building of the National City Bank of New York at 92-09 and 11 Union Hall Street, Jamaica, Queens, has been purchased by Title Guarantee and Trust Company for its Jamaica banking division through John J. Reynolds, broker. National City will vacate the Union Hall Street building when its new structure is completed on 164th Street, north of Jamaica Avenue.

The Government's loyalty program was defended yesterday by John Kirkland Clark, member of the President's Loyalty Review Board, as a necessary though imperfect instrument of national security and was assailed by Prof. Thomas I. Emerson of the Yale Law School as a "police state" device, not essential to the nation's security and created for political reasons.

In recent hearings of the Joint Committee on Atomic Energy, Senator Hickenlooper has attacked the efficiency and general competence of David Lilienthal and the Atomic Energy Commission personnel. We, the undersigned, believe that the AEC has done an extremely creditable job in taking over and greatly extending the work of the Manhattan District.

CHICAGO, May 26 -- Homer P. Hargrave, chairman of the Chicago Stock Exchange, announced today that the proposal to merge the Chicago Exchange and a number of other exchanges into one large "Middle Western" exchange will go through.

Earnings of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad Company were off $413,034 in April compared with the corresponding month last year, according to the company's announcement in New Haven yesterday. Net income in April was $687,433, against $1,100,467 in April, 1948.

The majority of the British people are firm believers in the country's national health program, but are becoming curious about the cost, according to John W. McPherrin, editor of The American Druggist, a drug industry trade publication.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The Federal Communications Commission announced today that it could not lift its "freeze" on the authorization of new television stations until "late fall" at the earliest. Originally the commission had hoped to take such action this spring.
Heavy demands for travel reservations highlighted preparations yesterday for the three-day Memorial Day week-end.

The outlook for the chronically ill, aged and infirm "is brighter than at any time in our history," Dr. Marcus D. Kogel, Commissioner of Hospitals, declared yesterday at St. Barnabas Hospital for Chronic Diseases at 183d Street and Third Avenue, the Bronx.

Despite fire losses of nearly $2,000,000 a day in 1948, the fire insurance business earned a small underwriting profit last year for the first time in five years, J. M. Haines, president of the National Board of Fire Underwriters, told the eighty-third annual meeting of the organization at the Commodore Hotel yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Job prospects for next month's graduates -- the largest crop ever -- are likely to be less favorable in many fields than in any year since the beginning of the war.

ROME, May 26 -- Italian Foreign Minister Carlo Sforza today told the Chamber of Deputies that the Italian Government was ready to listen to other proposals for a solution of the question of the former Italian colonies. But he added that any premise to agreement should take into consideration that "Italy has inalienable rights which are equal to those of any other country" to the development of the African territories.

Plans for the promotion of the world welterweight fight between Ray Robinson, Harlem boxer who holds the 147-pound crown, and Kid Gavilan of Cuba ran into a snag yesterday at the headquarters of the New York State Athletic Commission.

The Treasury issued yesterday, one of the largest war-loan accounts call in recent months. The larger banks will be required to provide $630,000,000, or 20 per cent of such deposits as of the close of business on May 25. Funds must be paid in three installments with two-thirds on June 1 and one-sixth on both June 2 and 3.

Defendants and their lawyers at the Communist trial staged such a violent demonstration against Federal Judge Harold R. Medina yesterday that he threatened to remand City Councilman Benjamin J. Davis Jr., one of the defendants, to jail for the rest of the trial.

LOUISVILLE, May 26 -- In a solemn ceremony of the Roman Catholic Church, Thomas Merton, author of the best seller, "The Seven Storey Mountain," was ordained a Trappist priest today at Our Lady of Gethsemani Monastery near Bardstown, Ky.

BERLIN, May 26 -- The United States Military Government will move soon to obtain revision of "odious" sections of press laws passed recently by Bremen and Wuerttemberg-Baden legislatures and approved by the Military Government.
Annual pay rises of $1,000 for the fifty City Magistrates, including Chief Magistrate Edgar Bromberger, were voted yesterday by the Board of Estimate.

TRENTON, N. J., May 26 -- The State Supreme Court found faults today in the compulsory arbitration procedure of New Jersey's Utility Anti-Strike Law and threw out the entire act as unconstitutional. The court ruled the act lacked standards to govern arbitrators.

Directors of Abbott Laboratories declared yesterday an extra of 5 cents and a quarterly dividend of 40 cents a share on the new common stock, both payable on July 1. This placed the stock on an annual basis of $1.60, the company announced.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., May 26 -- Painting of the 100-foot auxiliary schooner Blue Dolphin was completed today in preparation for a three-month cruise to Labrador on a hydrographic and oceanographic expedition under sponsorship of the Arctic Institute of North America.
DALLAS, May 26 (AP) -- That war between Electra, Tex., and the Fort Worth Denver City Railroad is over.

A one-day arbitration hearing in the wage dispute between ten tanker companies and the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, CIO, was held yesterday in the offices of the law firm of Kaye, Scholer, Fierman Hays, 149 Broadway, before Frederick R. Livingston, chairman of the board of arbitration.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 26 -- A message from Gen. Douglas MacArthur declaring that the peace treaty with Japan "is long, long overdue" was brought to San Francisco business men today by Dennis McEvoy, president of the American Chamber of Commerce in Japan.

The salt water angler can just about pay his money and take his choice for this week-end, provided the weather holds, and the trout fisherman is practically certain of good fly fishing under similar weather conditions.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., May 26 -- Five hundred members of Local 1247, International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, forced the resignation of their business agent, Edward Polo, by walking off four local piers and refusing to return to work as long as Mr. Polo represented them.

Formation of the Patent Leather Bureau, a style information and public relations center on patent leather servicing manufacturers, retailers and the press, was announced yesterday by the Tanners' Council of America through Irving R. Glass, executive vice president.

TORONTO, May 26 (Canadian Press) -- British and foreign films are praised and Hollywood's products covertly censured in the annual report of Ontario's Motion-Picture Censorship and Theatre Inspection branch released today.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The net income of 1,322 companies reporting to the Securities and Exchange Commission was $8,000,000,000 in 1948 compared with $6,600,000,000 in 1947, or an increase of 21.1 per cent, the agency announced today.

Leche Hombre, a winner on the flat and over the hurdles, scored over the big jumps for the first time in the $6,950 Spring Maiden Steeplechase at Belmont Park yesterday. Skillfully ridden by an ex-GI named Elwood Carter, Leche Hombre made good with three lengths to spare over his closest pursuer.

SHANGHAI, Friday, May 27 -- Virtually no sounds of fighting could be heard today and residents of the northeastern section of the city, to which Nationalists retreated from the Soochow defense line, said that the Communists were rounding up Government troops who are surrendering without resistance.
OXFORD, England, May 26 (Reuters) -- The New Zealand cricketers were out for 110 in their first innings today, their lowest total of the tour, against Oxford University.

The New York Botanical Garden is in the process of becoming the most striking and loveliest area in the city and will continue to be an internationally recognized leader in botany and horticulture, Dr. William J. Robbins, director, declared yesterday in his annual report to the board of managers and members.

A 19-year-old Columbia University freshman who disappeared on May 17 after telling a girl that he could no longer "live in the shadow" of his brother, a Columbia senior and varsity basketball player, was being sought yesterday by the missing persons bureau.

CHICAGO, May 26 -- Banks here and in other Illinois cities today considered action to be taken under the permissive five-day bank bill as the measure cleared its last legislative hurdle in the State Senate and was sent to Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson for his signature.

Ennio D'Alessandro, a former state parole officer who had pleaded guilty to "shaking down" a family of an ex-convict for $500, was sentenced yesterday by General Sessions Judge John A. Mullen to serve from one and a half to two years in state prison.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday and closed 1 point lower to 4 points higher.

More than 14,000 cases are pending trial in the southern federal court district of New York and many of these will not be brought before the court within four years, the Federal Bar Association of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut reported yesterday.

As 2,000 delegates, representing every section of the country, began gathering here for the opening today of the fifty-second annual convention of the Zionist Organization of America, Governor Dewey, United States Senators and high-ranking Federal officials in messages declared that the Zionist movement must continue as a strong force in support of Israel.

PARIS, May 26 -- Maurice Schumann, chairman of the Popular Republican party, today straddled the de Gaullist issue at the opening of the party's national convention, which will meet for three days in Strasbourg.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- Washington mauled Gene Bearden for five runs in the first three innings to defeat Cleveland, 15 -- 4, tonight. The game was called at the end of the first half of the eighth inning to allow both teams to catch trains.

Three new films will arrive in midtown theatres this morning. At the Roxy, the attraction is "The Beautiful Blonde From Bashful Bend," a Twentieth Century-Fox comedy with music, starring Betty Grable. The offering, produced, directed and written by Preston Sturges, features Rudy Vallee, Cesar Romero and Olga San Juan.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The Scott Paper Company, Chester, Pa., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering a proposed offering to the public of 45,000 shares of no-par value cumulative preferred stock.

DETROIT, May 26 -- The principal lead toward solving the attempted assassination of Victor G. Reuther, 37-year-old director of education of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, developed tonight when a small-arms manufacturer reported that the shotgun used in the assault Tuesday night was made in February and was one of only 2,000 made that month.

CHICAGO, May 26 (AP) -- The order of finish in the team competition as well as two individual races in the 1949 Western Conference track and field championships was revised today after a review of the official movies of the meet held at Northwestern University last Saturday.
CANTON, China, May 26 (UP) -- Acting President Li Tsung-jen charged today that the Chinese Communists were "thoroughly and completely controlled from Moscow."

RAPID CITY, S. D., May 26 -- The Department of Agriculture outlined today a broad program for intensive control and development of land and water resources in the Missouri River Valley to do in thirty years what would be the work of a century under present methods. It estimated the cost of the agricultural program at $8,503,516,575 in Federal, state and private funds.
ROME, May 26 (AP) -- Following is an unofficial translation of the Italian text of the papal bull that today announced the Holy Year of 1950:

As the season of maximum highway travel approaches we find, unhappily, that the accident rate is rising. In New York City cumulative figures of the Safety Bureau of the Police Department show an increase this year thus far, as compared with a like period last year, of 1,166 more accidents and 1,651 more injuries.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Maurice J. Tobin, Secretary of Labor, assured Congress today that enforcement powers of the Truman Administration's proposed Fair Employment Practices Act would be used only in "a last emergency."

Growing dissatisfaction of industrial concerns with the standards of a large number of trade shows was underlined yesterday with a report indicating a sharp decrease of participation in such events. The report, based on a survey of 711 companies regularly engaged in trade show promotions, was made by R. H. DeMott, president of the Exhibitors Advisory Council.
LAKE SUCCESS, May 26 -- France presented today the first outline for an international system of counting and checking the armed forces of the nations of the world.

The current inquiry into the work of the Atomic Energy Commission can be of great value. Arising out of charges of "mismanagement" and "maladministration" by a responsible Senator, the investigation has been undertaken by the proper body, the Congressional Joint Committee on Atomic Energy.

Contrary to widespread expectation, Mayor O'Dwyer has announced that he will not be a candidate for re-election to a second term in City Hall. He has also disavowed any immediate interest in the office of United States Senator or the Governorship of New York. He will be 59 years old when he finishes his four-year term as Mayor.

The State of Oregon sold yesterday an issue of $3,000,000 of veterans' welfare bonds due on April 1, 1962, and callable April 1, 1954, to a banking group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., at a bid of 99.209 for 1 3/4, an interest cost of 1.8203 per cent.

DETROIT, May 26 -- With the strike in its fourth week, the Ford Motor Company handed to the United Automobile Workers, CIO, tonight a new proposal outlining its concept of the question that should be submitted to an arbiter. Its details were not made public.

DEVON, Pa., May 26 -- Golden Chance, owned and ridden by 22 year-old Paul Faut of Warrenton Va., tonight won a leg on the coveted challenge trophy for the great International Hunter course stake at the fifty-third annual Devon Horse Show and Country Fair.
MOSCOW, May 17 -- What are the people of Moscow thinking about these fine spring days as the sun shines warmer and longer each day?

The battle to define and protect management's "prerogatives" seems likely to prove as stubborn a source of conflict between employers and unions as the original fight to establish labor's right to bargain collectively.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Industrial sugar users representing 90 per cent of United States consumption today asked the Secretary of Agriculture to make sugar reallocations "so as to avoid an unwarranted rise in sugar prices to consumers."

ATHENS, May 26 -- Today's General Staff report said the Army was pressing successfully its mopping up operations in the Thessaly and Roumeli areas of Central Greece and had wiped but the main rebel contingent in the Koziana- Achelous region.

The quarterly report of Federated Department Stores, Inc., issued yesterday by Fred Lazarus Jr., president, disclosed an increase of $3,647,957 in earnings for the fifty-two weeks ended with April over the same preceding period, but a decline in the income for the April quarter.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., May 26 (AP) -- Federal Judge John P. Hartigan, in the United States District Court, issued an injuction late today restraining Wallace K. Downey, California Insurance Commissioner, from taking possession of or interfering with the assets of the Rhode Island Insurance Company within the district of Rhode Island.

Noted for their novel and interesting ideas, fashion designers recently have offered a startling one -- the use of velvet on cotton. This combination, with one so typically summer and the other fall, is like that oft used phrase "June in January." Notwithstanding their hitherto seasonal differences, however, the results achieved are so extremely chic that women should be charmed.

A long week-end is coming up, and with it the start of the outdoor picnic season. Breakfast aside, it will be possible to have two meals under the trees on each of three days. To pick a nice-looking number completely at random, it is not implausible to suggest that 10,000,000 Americans may take part in the opening ceremonies of the season.

Dr. C. Charles Burlingame, president and psychiatrist-in-chief to Hartford's Institute of Living, raises the question of whether psychiatry is good for the American public in the large doses of publicity with which it is being administered. His opinion is that much of the publicity is "injudicious" and harmful.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Frank Lloyd Wright, titular head of American architects, as he styled himself, visited that plain Democrat, President Truman, today, and what a shellacking he delivered to American ideas and ideals.

Many New Yorkers who have seen the exhibition, "Three Rivers -- Around the Rim of Manhattan" that opened on May 6 at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue and 103d Street, have discovered aspects of their home town for the first time, both in the display and in actuality.

Business loans reported by banks in the New York area declined for the thirteenth conseuctive time in the week ended on Wednesday. This drop of $55,000,000 cut the outstanding total to $4,841,000,000, the lowest mark since October, 1947, it was revealed yesterday in the weekly statement of reporting New York member banks issued by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The reduction was laid to prepayments by publis utilities, tobacco and sales finance companies.

John M. Kelly, former chief supervisor in the Department of Markets, who charged fifteen years ago that he had been illegally dismissed from his post, has won the right to sue for $100,000, it was disclosed yesterday in Supreme Court.
Few persons in the heart of the world's greatest city paused yesterday afternoon to observe the passing of a great era for the North American Continent.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Efforts to cut Government spending to avoid deficits and increased taxes took a new spurt in Congress today. With late reports that the budget stood $1,273,955,000 in the red as of last Monday, developments were as follows:

BOSTON, May 26 (AP) -- Boston's Red Sox took full advantage of an error and a close play at second base in scoring four unearned runs in the eighth inning today for a 7-5 decision over the last-place St. Louis Browns.

Increase in use of local advertising in foreign countries has paid dividends for exporters of appliances, auto parts and other consumer goods, according to speakers at a meeting of the Export Advertising Association held yesterday in the Shelton Hotel.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- During the week ended May 25, member bank reserve balances decreased $275,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

THE track and field experts are generally much more reliable forecasters than Dr. Gallup, Elmo Roper or their baseball and football counterparts. By means of statistics, logarithm tables, slide rules, crystal balls and hunches they can predict track results with uncanny accuracy. Not only can they name winners in advance but they also can call the turn on records which will be broken.
WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- Attorney General Tom C. Clark today announced an anti-trust action against the Northern Pacific Railway Company and its subsidiary, the Northwestern Improvement Company.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- President Truman said in his news conference today that he had not abandoned hope of getting his $4,000,000,000 tax increase program passed at this session of Congress.

MONTREAL, May 26 -- The armed forces since the end of World War II have failed to apply many of the new psychiatric treatment methods, and they show "a marked neglect" of preventive psychiatry, it was reported today by Dr. Albert A. Rosner of Neurological Institute, New York, and Dr. Benjamin Harris Balser, Assistant Clinical Professor of Neurology at Columbia University.

The retirement of Cornelius H. Callaghan, manager and executive vice-president of the Maritime Exchange for fifteen years, was announced yesterday by James A. Farrell Jr., president and chairman of the board of directors of the Maritime Association of the Port of New York.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- President Truman announced today the appointment of five new Assistant Secretaries of State, completing the top-level reorganization of the State Department.

A vision of watchful eyes that appeared to her while in a Latin class won the grand prize for 15-year-old Annella Mystkowski of 901 East First Street, East Northport, L. I., in the National School Traffic Safety Poster Contest sponsored by the American Automobile Association.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on May 21 were 773,911 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 2,175 cars, or 0.3 per cent more than in the preceding week, 105,266 cars, or 12 per cent fewer than in the corresponding week of last year, and 116,694 cars, or 13.1 per cent fewer than in the corresponding week of two years ago.

Three large group shows of painting and sculpture and two one-man shows opening this week represent diverse attitudes toward contemporary art. The note of the exhibition at Pierre Matisse is one of fantastic invention, from Matta's complicated and anemically colored contraption in paint, to a pair of Dubuffet's African landscapes, which show a certain raw power if little else.

The Maritime Commission hearing of a complaint filed against two North Atlantic steamship conferences by the Isbrandtsen Steamship Company, Inc., came to an abrupt halt yesterday. C. W. Robinson, commission trial examiner extended until July 11 the time in which all interests involved may file briefs, after which he will make his recommendations to the commission.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The Senate passed tonight a bill to increase the official stature and authority of the Secretary of Defense over all the armed forces in a moderate strengthening of the Unification Act of 1947.
The editorial in THE NEW YORE TIMES of May 22 re "Maritime Week" suggest that an article is needed as to the actual conditions existing in our Merchant Marine.

TOKYO, May 26 -- Although they do not have a majority, the Socialists, Communists and former bureaucrats in the House of Councillors have been able to block passage of the Government's Personnel Organization Bill and to force a Diet extention from May 16 to May 31.
ROME, May 26 -- The Pope today proclaimed 1950 as a holy year with a papal Bull that, in keeping with tradition, was read from the steps of Rome's four major basilicas.

Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, Acting United Nations Mediator for Palestine, was named "Father of the Year" yesterday by the National Father's Day Committee at a luncheon attended by 1,000 persons at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

An expanded group of French Provincial furniture made by the Meldan Furniture Company was shown in homey room settings yesterday at the opening of the company's new showrooms, 328 East Fifty-third Street. In keeping with the provincial style are small-scaled documentary wallpapers and fabrics in each setting, as well as colorful pottery and accessories now carried by the company.

The stock market showed no disposition yesterday to make any further test of the year's low or to attempt a rally. In the dullest session in almost two weeks, prices drifted aimlessly, after some show of strength at the opening and then closed unchanged from Wednesday's final levels.

Tuberculosis has been increasing of late. One reason may be the conditions that prevail in Puerto Rico, whence come too many physically unfit migrants. It is enough to point out that since the tuberculosis death rate in Puerto Rico stands at 180 per 100,000 population as against the city's 38.4 we cannot afford to be indifferent. to immigration.

MOSCOW, May 26 -- The Soviet press reserved comment today on the Paris conference but published a series of dispatches from Germany reporting a growing movement in both the Western and Eastern zones for political and economic unity.

Opening for DP physicians will be sought as part of an intensified drive of the United States Lutheran Resettlement Service to get 7,000 more job and housing assurances for displaced persons by the state and local Lutheran committees.

Coffee futures were mixed on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Trade hedge-covering absorbed scattered selling, principally for profit-taking. Final levels in contract "S" were 15 to 20 points higher. After early steadiness, contract "D" eased late in the day on some selling.

American business men should be permitted to run their own enterprises without Government interference because "they know more about business than Government officials do," Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer declared here last night.

ALBANY, May 26 -- The New York State Court of Appeals cleared the way today for a test before the United States Supreme Court of the New York City regulation requiring a person to obtain a permit before making a public speech on city park property.

CHICAGO, May 26 -- Scattered liquidation was on in the grain markets on the Board of Trade here today with closing trades at about the lowest levels of the day. The July futures led the downturn. After the close it was announced that 860,000 bushels of cash wheat, 210,000 bushels of corn, 15,000 bushels of oats and 3,000 bushels of soybeans had been tendered on May contracts.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (UP) -- The Senate today rejected, 47 to 33, a compromise bill to return control of the Commodity Credit Corporation to the Agriculture Department and restore its authority to acquire storage facilities for surplus farm crops.
PORTMARNOCK, Ireland, May 26 (UP) -- Cards of the matches played by Willie Turnesa and Frank Stranahan of the United States follow:

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The National Conference on Community Responsibility to our Peacetime Service Men and Women, called here by the President's Committee on Religion and Welfare in the Armed Forces, took on the task today of arousing communities to the need of welfare services for the nation's service men.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 26 -- A statement defending the character and work of Dr. David J. Bohm, Princeton University physicist who has appeared before the House Committee on Un-American Activities, was issued today by an official spokesman for the university.

Secretary of Defense Louis Johnson ruled out last night any cut in the military budget to provide the $1,500,000,000 needed to finance the first year's military aid to Europe under the pending North Atlantic Pact.

Marketing for the pleasantly long week-end ahead may be somewhat complicated by recent rises in meat prices of 2 to 6 cents a pound on fourteen of the thirty-three cuts checked yesterday by the consumers' service division of the New York City Department of Markets.

Supreme Court Justice Charles S. Colden announced yesterday that he had resigned as president of the Queens Speech and Hearing Service Center, connected with Queens College, which he helped to organize a decade ago. His action is a protest against the behavior of the Board of Higher Education, he said.
MOSCOW, May 26 (AP) -- Soviet Russia ordered today an increase of 50 to 100 per cent in delivery of meat, milk and other animal products to the state in the next three years.

MARIETTA, Ga., May 26 -- A tumultuous home-town celebration today greeted Gen. Lucius D. Clay. Sitting on the tonneau of an automobile, General Clay rode through the city square, packed with thousands of people, who waved and cheered, sometimes giving the "rebel yell."

No sooner did Jack Kirkland absorb the devastating import of yesterday's reviews on "Mr. Adam," which he produced, directed and adapted from Pat Frank's best-seller of the same name, than he acted with commendable promptness.
Millions of sightseers and excursion loving persons will be served this year by a fleet of twenty-one excursion boats with a total passenger capacity of almost 42,000, it became known yesterday.

When the Chinese Communists undertake to organize an administration for Shanghai they will step into the middle of the test of their ability to govern China. The Chinese metropolis, dependent on the outside world for its very existence and dependent upon foreign experience, help, trade and even control for its growth and prosperity, offers no easy problem.

Mrs. Ogden Reid, chairman of the board of trustees of Barnard College, announced yesterday the election of three New York women, all alumnae of the college, to the board. They are Mrs. Frank Altschul of 150 Central Park South; Mrs. Leighton Coleman of 121 East Seventy-ninth Street, and Mrs. Maynard Wheeler of 1165 Fifth Avenue.

Summer is i-cumen in and the new ice show opened at the Center Theatre last evening. "Howdy, Mr. Ice of 1950," they call it, with a confident eye on next year's calendar. Without being too technical about details, let's call it the best of the nine-year series.
Igor I. Sikorsky, pioneer airplane and helicopter designer, last night became the first American to receive the Silver Medal of the Royal Aeronautical Society of London.

Plans for supplementing the food supply of the people of Israel through special packages of products approved by the Israeli Minister of Food Control were outlined yesterday by William Cholko, regional chief of missions for Southern Europe of the CARE organization.

For the eighth time since March 8, pig lead prices were reduced here yesterday. A leading custom smelter dropped prices 1 cent, setting 12 cents as the current price level, compared with 21 1/2 cents March 1. St. Joseph Lead Company continued to hold to its 15-cent price level.
BLUEFIELD, W. Va., May 26 -- John L. Lewis today forced a week's adjournment of the soft coal wage negotiations over the repeated protests of the Southern Coal Producers Association.
The Pacific Gas Electric Company and the Houston Lighting Power Company announced yesterday plans for the issuance of more than $90,000,000 of new securities.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- President Truman urged today that efforts be redoubled to carry out the recommendations of the Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government as pointing the way to "the same or better service to the public at a lesser cost."
SHANGHAI, May 26 -- This city and its millions seem to have swung into the Communist camp with a rush and not by degrees.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., May 26 -- Mrs. Ellis Baum of Winged Foot captured low gross honors with a card of 41, 42 -- 83 over the Wykagyl Country Club course today in the weekly tournament of the Westchester Women's Golf Association.

All national security needs for copper of the United States Government will amount to a record peacetime peak of almost 16 per cent of the annual normal supply of copper here, including imports, C. Donald Dallas, chairman of the board, Revere Copper and Brass, Inc., 230 Park Avenue, revealed in a statement here yesterday.

Dr. Emanuel Goldberg, Israeli scientist and inventor who fled the Nazis in 1937, asserted here yesterday that his country must take its place in the future with Switzerland, the United States and Sweden in the production of quality precision instruments.
MONTREAT, N. C., May 26 (AP) -- A warning was sounded to all Protestants tonight that there was danger "lest the Church herself may lose sight of her spiritual and redemptive purpose."

ST. LOUIS, May 26 (AP) -- The rejuvenated Cardinals exploded for seven runs in the first inning and went on to defeat the stumbling Pirates from Pittsburgh tonight, 13 to 6. Ralph Kiner pounded out his tenth homer in the first inning with two men on the bases.

LONDON, May 26 -- Reports reaching here from reliable sources in China say that the Chinese Communists are making plans to hold a provisional political consultative assembly in June and that this may be followed by creation of a Communist-led government by autumn.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- When Chairman Cannon of the House Committee on Appropriations announced today that a bipartisan agreement is near to put all spending in one bill at the next session of Congress and thereafter, the most promising means yet suggested to prevent casual Treasury deficits moved toward adoption.

With one event still to be contested, Cardinal Hayes took a commanding lead yesterday in the Bronx - Manhattan - Westchester Catholic High Schools Athletic Association track and field championships at Van Cortlandt Park. The running-broad jump, scheduled for yesterday, was postponed until Sunday because of a slippery take-off board.

SEOUL, Korea, May 26 -- Liberal Korean circles and qualified foreign observers of the Korean scene are watching with some alarm the rapid growth of what could conceivably develop into a State religion with all the trappings of ultranationalistic jingoism.
JAMESTOWN, N. Y., May 26 (AP) -- Members of the New York State Telephone Association were told today that good public relations are essential in the conduct of rate increase and refinancing programs.

BOSTON, May 26 -- Vice President Alben W. Barkley was cited tonight by the Massachusetts Committee of Catholics, Protestants and Jews for his "honest and sturdy championship" of national economic justice and fair play.

The Board of Higher Education was urged yesterday by the Teachers Union, Local 555, United Public Workers CIO, and the Town and Village Tenants Committee to End Discrimination in Stuyvesant Town, to reverse a decision by City College authorities that denied tenure to a probationary teacher allegedly because of his work with the tenants committee.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 26 -- Emergency contributions from Australia, Austria, Iceland, India, Luxembourg and Thailand [Siam], made in response to a last-gasp appeal, will infuse new life into the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund, Col. A1fred G. Katzin, coordinator of the appeal, reported today.

Mrs. Hartford Douglas of South Arlington, Vt., will sail today on the Queen Elizabeth, and will visit in England and France before joining early in July her son-in-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. Claiborne Pell, in Genoa, Italy, where Mr. Pell is Vice Consul General.

Characterized by assistant District Attorney Irving Slonim as "substantial operators," ten men rounded up Wednesday on charges of being members of a wholesale narcotics ring were remanded yesterday to City Prison to await hearings in Felony Court next week.

The National Urban League said yesterday in its annual report for 1948 that the problems of housing, health and employment were implicit in the migration from the South of more than 1,200,000 Negroes since 1940. The Far West received about 300,000.
BERLIN, May 26 -- Railway strikers said tonight that they would continue to tie up all rail traffic in West Berlin yards.

LONDON, May 26 -- Twin campaigns aimed at the ruthless elimination of anti-Soviet elements from Czechoslovakia and the development of the country as a military bulwark for the Soviet Union are being carried out of Prague with the greatest urgency, according to first-hand reports made public here today by the International Committee for the Study of European Questions.
SHANGHAI, May 26 (AP) - Behavior of Communist troops here makes clear one reason why they are winning the war.

The six-story, sixty-six-family apartment house at 955 Walton Avenue, facing Joyce Kilmer Park just north of 161st Street, in the Bronx, has been sold by a client of Delson, Levin Gordon, lawyers, to Samuel Halpern.

A letter-carrier, who received twenty-two citations for gallantry while serving in the Air Force during the war, was arrested yesterday in Brooklyn for committing two robberies and, according to the police, confessed to both crimes.

Extremely high prices of consumer products manufactured in France and Great Britain make it unlikely that retail stores here will attempt to increase their imports from those countries this year, Jack I. Straus, president of R. H. Macy Co., declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- President Truman came to the unqualified support of Chairman David E. Lilienthal and the Atomic Energy Commission today, and called the present Congressional criticism merely pre-election campaign material.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 26 -- Twentieth Century-Fox today purchased "Trumpet to the Morn," a screen story by Frank Nugent and Curtis Kenyon, at a reported price of $35,000. The story deals with Indian fighting in the West during the Civil War, and it will be assigned to a producer within the next two weeks.

Mayor O'Dwyer's sudden announcement that he would not be a candidate for re-election put the local political situation in such a scrambled condition yesterday that no one could tell what would be the outcome.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The House passed and sent to the Senate today a foreign aid appropriation of $5,617,470,000, including $4,642,470,000 for the European Recovery Program. The standing vote on passage was 193 to 27.

SHANGHAI, Friday, May 27 -- The battle for Shanghai ended today. The last organized Nationalist resistance collapsed. All of the world's fourth largest city belonged to the Chinese Commu nists. Government troops who had held out for two days in buildings along Soochow creek in the heart of the city gave up. A handful of Communist soldiers marched them off to prisoner of war camps.

An evaluation of the achievements of the United Nations up to date by Herbert Vere Evatt, president of the General Assembly of the United Nations, will be published by Duell, Sloan Pearce on June 14, entitled "The Task of Nations."

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., May 26 -- John J. Humm, Long Island amateur champion, and Edward Neu fired a 34, 35 -- 69 to capture the low gross prize in the first Long Island amateur best-ball tournament at the Hempstead Golf Club today.

Five members of the executive committee of the American Institute of Physics declared yesterday that fellowship holders of the Atomic Energy Commission without access to secret material should not be made to undergo the same investigation required of an AEC employe.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Industrial production in the United States dropped again in April for the fifth successive month to 179 per cent of the 1935-1939 average, the Federal Reserve Board said today. This figure compares with 184 per cent in March and 195 per cent in November, 1948.
Parents have triumphed over pet owners in a neighborhood spat about a vacant lot in the Sutton Place area.
PORTMARNOCK, Ireland, May 26 (AP) -- Frank Stranahan and Willie Turnesa rolled into the quarterfinal round of the British amateur golf championship this sunny day with a romp and a rally.

RICHMOND, Va., May 26 -- An unemployed professional, Ray Wade Hill of Shreveport, La., topped some of the biggest money winners in golf in capturing medal honors with a 36-hole aggregate of 136 as the qualifying tests for the P. G. A. championship ended today.

ALBANY, May 26 -- The Court of Appeals upheld in effect today the right of the trustees of the Frick Collection to accept from John D. Rockefeller Jr. a gift of six paintings and two pieces of sculpture valued at $1,700,000.

PARIS, May 26 -- The three Western powers, angered at Soviet delay in re-establishing communications between Berlin and the Western zones of Germany, are considering asking Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky for full implementation of Russian promises made in the New York agreement on the lifting of the Berlin blockade.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., May 26 -- Unethical price-cutting in the confectionery industry was decried here today by C. Rudolph Kroekel, chairman of the Pennsylvania Manufacturing Confectioners Association's research committee. He spoke at the third annual production conference of the association at Lehigh University, which was held in cooperation with the university's institute of research.

The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People told Senator Scott W. Lucas, the Majority Leader, yesterday that millions of Negroes were "shocked" by the failure of Congress to abide by the party platform and the President's promises regarding social legislation.

LONDON, May 26 -- The feature of a generally quiet stock market here today was the actions of bonds of European municipalities on latest moves connected with the resumption of interest payments. The Hamburg State 6 per cent issue and the Saarbruecken 4 1/2 per cent gained 2 points each.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., May 26 -- The Hudson County Board of Freeholders, last stronghold of the political machine of former Mayor Frank Hague, today railroaded resolutions providing for appointments and salary increases that will raise the county's payroll $371,000 a year.

Building Trades Week was designated yesterday morning at a ceremony atop a huge girder on the second floor of the United Nations construction site when John D. Rockefeller 3d nailed up a poster for the Greater New York Fund.

In an atmosphere of secrecy for which no high level authority will take responsibility, the negotiations for an air agreement between the United States and Canada were reported ready to be closed here today. Russell B. Adams, member of the Civil Aeronautics Board and head of the American delegation, refused last night, as he has done all week, to discuss the negotiations in any way.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 26 -- Stringent curtailment of imports, dumping of surplus goods in foreign markets and other policies designed to "export" unemployment in the event of a major recession are now planned by many countries throughout the world, economic experts of the United Nations reported today.

KANDAHAR, Afghanistan, May 15 -- Across the Khyber Pass, the paved road stops abruptly at a barrier and a sign, "Frontier of Pakistan." To go beyond, into Afghanistan, is to go back hundreds of years with one step, into a country hustling furiously to catch up with time.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Fear of being "blacklisted" by members of the Armed forces is preventing "hundreds and probably thousands of merchants" from protesting to Congress about the unfair competition of post exchanges and ship service stores, a House Armed Services subcommittee was told today.
The United States Open Golf Tournament, to be played at the Madinah Country Club near Chicago from June 9 to June 11, will be covered by the NBC radio and television networks.

Offerings of menthol from China have dried up almost completely, but substantial amounts from that country have arrived here after being rushed out in advance of the Red Army drive, Chas. L. Huisking Co., New York chemical and drug agents, 155 Varick Street, disclosed yesterday in their current market report now being mailed to chemical buyers.

PARIS, May 26 (AP) -- The first bid of United States Champion Richard (Pancho) Gonzales for a European tennis title ended suddenly today when he was upset by Budge Patty, a fellow Californian, in the semi-finals of the French international championship, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 3, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 3.

LONDON, May 26 -- Three Labor party members of Parliament will be ready tomorrow to stand bail for Gerhart Eisler, German Communist fugitive, who will appear before a magistrate for a hearing on the United States Government's demand for his return to the United States.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- China joined the Philippines in attacking, before the Far Eastern Commission today, the order recently given by the United States to halt further preliminary deliveries of reparations from Japan to the Philippines and China and to British and Netherland possessions in the Far East.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- A bitter behind-the-scenes struggle took shape today as the Democratic leadership of the House, pressing to bring the administration's national housing bill to a floor vote in the face of strong Republican opposition, found itself hampered by log-rolling within its own ranks.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 26 -- Harry Bridges arrived from New York by plane this evening to surrender on charges of perjury and conspiracy contained in indictments returned by a Federal grand jury here yesterday against him and two colleagues in the longshoremen's union.
Fifty-one students and teachers, the first to leave under the European tour program of the new Council on Student Travel, sailed yesterday afternoon on the Marine Shark for Channel ports.

BOSTON, May 26 -- Capt. John A. Glynn of Newton, Mass., commander of the Coast Guard cutter Eastwind when it was in collision with a tanker off the New Jersey coast on Jan. 19, was absolved of technical offenses today by a court martial, which deliberated an hour and thirty minutes.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The entire Air Force program, built around the multi-million-dollar giant B-36 bombers, with a background of broad political allegations, moved today toward "a thorough and searching investigation" by the House Armed Services Committee.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- Following is the text of a statement by President Truman after receipt of the final report of the Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government, headed by former President Herbert Hoover:

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- An agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation testified today that a "plain unmarked envelope" containing $125 in bills was found on Valentine A. Gubitchev on the night he was arrested with Judith Coplon on espionage charges.

Two four-story buildings containing a total of twenty-nine rooms at 54 and 56 West Eighty-seventh Street, between Central Park West and Columbus Avenue, were sold by Frederick Brown to Olga Junor, it was announced yesterday. They are assessed for $53,500 each and were sold through the Wood, Dolson Company, broker.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, May 26 -- Before today's session of the congress of the Czechoslovak Communist party, Premier Antonin Zapotocky declared that "we have not yet cleared accounts with all the remnants of capitalism among us."

A Charity fund to be solicited mainly among Harlem merchants was announced yesterday by the Uptown Chamber of Commerce. Proceeds will be distributed among "deserving Harlem charities with one contribution."

With Michigan State favored to lead Yale's defenders and New York University in a team race that may prove close but could develop into a Spartan runaway, competition in the seventy-third annual Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. outdoor track and field championships will open today at 3 P. M. in Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island.

The mllinery supply stores along Thirty-eighth Street between Fifth and Sixth Avenues were almost empty during yesterday's downpour, but the women who were at the counters were what a girl in one shop termed "shrewd customers."

WARSAW, May 26 -- A new weapon has been introduced into the Government's campaign of publicizing "injustices" by the Roman Catholic Church. With the usual publicity attendant upon any Government-sponsored action, the newspapers now are reporting widely that strikes are taking place on church-owned estates and farms.

PARIS, May 26 -- At today's meeting of the Big Four Council of Foreign Ministers, Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky made a long argument in favor of voting by the unanimity rule in the projected four-power control council for Germany.
Additional activities scheduled for the summer theatre circuit were announced here yesterday.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 26 (AP) -- Wesley A. Brown is to graduate from the Naval Academy next week, the first Negro ever to attain an ensign's shoulder boards at Annapolis.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 27 -- Mijalko Todorovitch, Minister of Agriculture, announced last night in Parliament that 20 per cent of all arable land in Yugoslavia had already been socialized and that the day was not far off when the economic power of the independent farmers would be broken.
The right to make a $185,000 profit on the sale of $3,405,000 of New York Housing Bonds to the New Jersey Disability Fund was defended yesterday by a bond broker from New York.

Discovery of a new hormone in the core (medulla) of the adrenal glands, described as of "far-reaching importance both medically and scientifically," is announced in the current issue of Science, official publication of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

The Hoover Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government made public yesterday the nineteenth and concluding report dealing with the monumental task which it recently brought to completion.

MONTREAL, May 27 -- New roles for psychiatrists in mental hospitals, because of the acute national shortage of men in that profession, were urged today by Dr. Harvey J. Tompkins, chief of the Psychiatry and Neurology Division of the Department of Medicine and Surgery, United States Veterans Administration.

Three Memorial Day ceremonies were held here yesterday. More than 100 members of the uniformed force of the Fire Department, members of their families and friends attended a service in departmental headquarters on the eleventh floor of the Municipal Building in honor of the twenty-seven members of the force who have died in the last year.

CHICAGO, May 27 -- The Truman Administration's Point Four program, which aims at aiding backward nations, "holds promise of untold benefit for the entire world," John R. Steelman, assistant to the President, said today.

A manifold report redefining the basic aims and structure of the world Zionist movement in relation to Israel and with emphasis on greater autonomy for national Zionist bodies was released yesterday as the Zionist Organization of America opened its fifty-second annual convention at the Statler Hotel.
BERLIN, May 27 -- The Soviet Union appeared tonight to be in the process of reimposing the Berlin blockade.

For those of us who still have the privilege of looking out on the back yards which were so long a New York institution of prime importance, life provides just now a fascinating employment. Things are doing out-there.

MOSCOW, May 27 -- The Soviet press accused the Western powers today of opposing Russian proposals on Germany with vague, ill-formed objections while not advancing any concrete program of their own at the Paris conference.

WEST POINT, N. Y., May 27 -- Members of the New York State Officers Club, Daughters of the American Revolution, made their annual pilgrimage here today to honor the memory of Margaret Corbin, heroine of the War of the Revolution.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 27-Describing recent happenings on the economic front as only a descent "from the dizzy heights of inflationary pressures," Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer said here today by any normal standards of historic comparison the American economic situation "is good."

New York will roll out a sandy, sixteen-mile welcome mat for bathers today. Green and black-clad lifeguards win clamber ten-foot watchtowers promptly at 8 A. M. and the official 1949 season at six municipal beaches and seventeen outdoor swimming pools will begin.

In the few cool days left before hot sultry weather sets in -- when no one in the family will feel like lifting a finger, let alone rolling up a rug -- homemakers may well begin putting inexpensive decorating tricks to work to make interiors look cooler.

Mayor O'Dwyer accepted yesterday at City Hall an invitation to attend the annual "feis," or Celtic festival, to be held at Fordham University on Sunday, June 12, under the auspices of the United Irish Counties Association of New York City. A delegation representing the association came to City Hall to extend the invitation.

SHANGHAI, May 27 -- While full "liberation" of this city by the Communist army still was unannounced, it appeared that the surrender of troops holding the American-owned power plant at 3 P. M. today had given the Communists control of virtually the entire city.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 27 -- The Rev. Leonard Feeney, S. J., publicly deprived of his priestly duties a month ago in the Boston College "heresy" case, said today that he had appealed to the Most Rev. Amleto Cicognani, Apostolic Delegate to the United States, in a new incident involving a student at Emmanuel College, a women's institution.

Colonial Airlines has instructed its Washington attorneys to file with the Civil Aeronautics Board and the State Department a formal notice of refusal to be bound by any decision of the United States and Canadian representatives meeting here in an effort to reach a bilateral air agreement with the Dominion.
FORT MEADE, Md., May 27 (AP) -- Fences, armed guards and barbed wire are on their way out in an Army effort to rehabilitate its young prisoners.

A zone system for the parking meters that the new Traffic Commission proposes to test here was discussed yesterday at a closed session of the agency, with indications that a minimum rate of 10 cents an hour would be recommended.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed firm, 9 to 13 points net higher.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., May 27 -- In one of his last acts before his retirement next Tuesday from the Army, Gen. Ewart G. Plank, commanding general of the New York Port of Embarkation, broke ground today for the nation's largest low-cost Army housing project.

VALLAURIS, France, May 27 -- Rita Hayworth, the motion-picture actress, and Aly Khan, son and heir of the Aga Khan, religious leader of Ismali Moslems, were married today in this tiny village in southern France. The ceremony was performed by the Communist Mayor, Paul Derignon.

Boston mastery over the Dodgers was badly fractured at Ebbets Field last night when, behind the six-hit pitching of Preacher Roe, the Brooks beat the Braves, 4 -- 0, and moved into a first-place tie with the National League champions, thanks to the cooperation of the Phils in smacking down the Giants.

LONDON, May 27 -- W. Averell Harriman, roving Ambassador for the European Recovery Program in Europe, arrived here by air from Paris today to confer with Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, at the latter's request.

The Securities and Exchange Commission obtained an order from Federal Judge Samuel H. Kaufman yesterday requiring the Third Avenue Transit Corporation to show cause in court next Wednesday why a trustee should not be appointed for it pending his decision on a petition or reorganization of the company under the bankruptcy laws.
An attorney for a Congressional investigation committee and a former rationing administrator respectively defended and criticized yesterday the loyalty program for Federal Government employes.

LONDON, May 27 -- Viscount Samuel, first British High Commissioner for Palestine, said tonight that "equity obviously requires" Israel to pay a proper price for land taken from the Arab refugees. There is no reason to doubt that the Israeli Government recognizes that duty, he added.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- Raymond M. McKeough, a Maritime Commissioner, asked Congress today not to make a change in the law that would put the Government "in the role of Santa Claus" for some American shipowners.

Dressed from stem to stern in gay signal flags, the completely reconditioned liner Laguardia of the American Export Lines, sailed at noon yesterday from Pier 84 North River on her maiden voyage as a passenger ship.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 27 -- Graduate students at Princeton University joined scientists at the neighboring Institute for Advanced Study today in voicing protests against what was termed "the intrusion of arbitrary political standards'' in the allocation of government funds for research.
WASHINGTON, May 27 (UP) -Joseph J. O'Connell Jr., chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, today questioned Eddie Rickenbacker's plan for operating five airlines without Federal subsidy.

VIENNA, May 27 -- The Allied Council decided today that the Austrian Government, until otherwise instructed, was still bound by the Allied Council decision in 1945 restricting the Austrian political parties to the People's, Socialist and Communist parties.

Prices on the New York Stock Exchange closed mixed yesterday in the final session of the week, after drifting moderately easier. Trading again was on a smaller scale as Wall Street made ready for an extended week-end holiday. Transactions on the Big Board faded to 690,000 shares, smallest in two weeks, and compared with 700,000 on Thursday.
A report in THE TIMES of May 22 on sermons delivered the preceding Saturday at New York synagogues mentions the marking of "National Youth Sabbath Week" by a West Side house of worship.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., May 27 -- Municipal officials, Chamber of Commerce and taxpayer organizations today were demanding a state investigation of yesterday's action by the Hudson County Board of Freeholders in granting salary increases and new jobs that added $751,000 annually to the county payroll.

DETROIT, May 27 -- A settlement of the strike against the Ford Motor Company in a matter of hours was forecast tonight by Arthur C. Viat, regional director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service. The strike started twenty-two days ago.
MOUNTAIN LAKES, N. J., May 27 -- One of New Jersey's most unusual orchestras will present tomorrow night its spring concert in the Mountain Lakes High School auditorium.
PARIS, May 27 (AP) -- Two American, one British and one South African doubles teams fought their way today into the finals of the French international tennis championships.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., May 27 -In the first distance race of the summer twenty-six yachts spread canvas off the breakwater tonight in the Storm Trysail Club's event out around Block Island, a matter of 183 miles. They are expected to finish Sunday morning at the Fairway bell buoy, Port Jefferson, L. I.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Brig. Gen. C. T. Lanham will leave his post as director of staff for the Personnel Policy Board on June 23 and later leave for service overseas, the National Military Establishment announced today.

TRENTON, N. J., May 27 -Agreement with state authorities was reached today by Sheffield Farms Company, one of the largest milk distributors involved in the North Jersey milk price war, to raise its quart price 2 cents. The price cutting competition appeared to be over.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Merchants of the historic naval town of Annapolis, Md., home of the United States Naval Academy, complained to Congress today about "unfair competition" that they said resulted from the Navy entering the retail business.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, May 27 (Reuters) -- Mass production of high-quality faked paintings and drawings supposed to be by the nineteenth century Dutch painter Vincent Van Gogh was alleged today by Jonkheer W. J. H. B. Sandberg, director of the Amsterdam Municipal Museum.

CLEVELAND, May 27 (AP) -- With 38-year-old Al Benton twirling six-hit ball, the Cleveland Indians came to life tonight and beat the Chicago White Sox, 4 to 0, before a "reopening day" crowd of 33,235.

The National Retail Furniture Association has begun a comprehensive study of the effect of fair trade laws on home furnishings store operations, Leo J. Herr, vice president, disclosed yesterday. He said the association's staff hopes to submit definite findings to the board of directors at its next meeting in July to aid the board in taking a possible definite stand for or against fair trade.

The Tournament of Champions, Inc., officially went out of existence yesterday. The boxing promoting organization which was formed a little more than a year ago for the purpose of bidding against the Twentieth Century Sporting Club for eminence in the field was purchased by the Madison Square Garden Corporation for a price not disclosed.

A new scheme for "stabilizing" the American economy has been drafted by a group of economic planners, according to current advices from Washington. It is now being put into legislative form and will be sponsored in Congress by Senator Murray of Montana, father of the original "Full Employment" Act of 1945, under the title of the Employment Expansion Act of 1949.

ALBANY, May 27 -- State Education Commissioner Francis T. Spaulding ruled today that the New York City Board of Education had full authority to bar the weekly magazine, The Nation, from high school libraries.

THEY were in all their murderous glory ten years ago this week. The Decade of Destruction was beginning. In uniforms that incredibly managed to parody the glittering splendor of Manhattan apartment-house doormen, they were putting the final touches on their plans to make a charnel house of the world.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 27 -- Foxterrier and Scottish terrier specialty shows drew an interesting entry to the grounds of the Garden City Hotel today. Smooth foxterriers were the leaders, and best of the variety was Mr. and Mrs. James A. Farrell Jr.'s Champion Downsbragh Speakeasy, handled by Bob Bolan.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Rejection by the British Government of the State Department's protest against her motion picture film quota arose today as a new controversy to be injected into the impending Senate fight over extension of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements program.

Pleas of not guilty to charges of negligence against the master and mate of the tanker Gulfstream, which collided with the Coast Guard icebreaker Eastwind Jan. 19 with the loss of thirteen lives, were made yesterday by the officers' counsel before a civilian examiner for the Coast Guard at a hearing at 80 Lafayette Street.
ANGOLA, La., May 27 (AP) -- Dr. James Monroe Smith, former Louisiana State University president whose peculations touched off the Louisiana scandals in 1939, died last night.

NEW DELHI, India, May 27 -- The Indian Constituent Assembly admitted today four representatives from the princely state of Jammu and Kashmir whose final allegiance is in dispute between India and Pakistan.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 27 -- Sale of the property of the Ventnor Boat Works, in West Atlantic City, to Mrs. Mollie A. Cohen of Philadelphia for $76,750, was confirmed here today by Superior Court Judge Vincent S. Haneman.
John P. Schwede has been appointed director of export sales for Union Bag and Paper Corporation, replacing R. A. Stevens, who has been named consultant to the export department.

World travel can do much to help correct the imbalance between exports and imports now distorting the world trade situation, Dr. Herbert A. Wilkinson, chief of the travel branch of the United States Department of Commerce, declared yesterday.
TOKYO, May 27 -- Japan's Diet virtually ended its fifth post-war session today.

Although Mayor O'Dwyer told reporters that his decision not to run for re-election was final, the movement to draft him for a second term gained momentum yesterday by announcement of formation of a "Draft O'Dwyer Committee," composed of representatives of business and labor.
WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- New offerings of stocks and bonds reached a two-year low in the first three months of 1949, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

In two widely separated neighborhoods in Brooklyn last evening armed holdup men got away with $500 in one case and $900 in another, after bundling their victims into big refrigeration chambers. All victims got out of their icy prisons soon afterward, shivering but little the worse for their experience.

Most fur coat lines for the new season will be ready for buyers next week and the following week, it was reported here yesterday. Manufacturers, facing greater competition for volume, are expected to quote prices substantially lower than those of a year ago.
PORTMARNOCK, Ireland, May 27 (UP) -- The cards of matches played by the leaders today:...
ROME, May 27 -- Italy, whose currency seemed on the verge of complete collapse two years ago, suffers today from many of the difficulties of having a "hard currency."

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- President Truman departed this afternoon on a week-end cruise, mostly to relax but also to do some work. He planned to go ashore only on Sunday morning for a church service at the United States Naval Academy at Annapolis.

Sarah Churchill, the eldest daughter of Britain's wartime Prime Minister, has displayed interest in plans being made to have her appear on the stage in this country during the coming summer, it became known yesterday.

The Health Department's Bureau of Food and Drugs estimated yesterday that 7,000,000 persons would visit the city's beaches over the three-day holiday week-end if the weather was good, and would consume 4,500,000 hot dogs, 2,100,000 ice cream cones and 5,205,000 bottles of soda pop.

Mathematics instruction today is centuries out of date and teachers are nothing more than "talking textbooks" who are content to turn out "calculating bipeds." This is the contention of Dr. Aaron Bakst, an instructor of mathematics at New York University's School of Education, who has just completed a study of the teaching of high school mathematics.

James L. Guilmartin, president of the New York Young Republican Club, charged last night- the administration of Mayor O'Dwyer with waste and incompetence and declared that the Democratic party under Tammany has forfeited the support of all persons interested in the welfare of the people of the city.

AMHERST, Mass., May 27 -- The Amherst College baseball team came up with an unearned run in the bottom of the eleventh inning today to give Righthander Don Dunbar a 2-1 victory over the Columbia Lions before 400 fans on Memorial Field.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 27 -The existence of an undemocratic class system in America is shaping the lives of adolescents and in many cases is contributing to juvenile delinquency, according to a Yale University sociologist.

CHICAGO, May 27 (AP) -- Johnny Schmitz hurled a five-hitter today to pace the Chicago Cubs to a 3-1 victory over the Cincinnati Reds before a chilled crowd of 6,174. It was the third straight victory for the Cubs, their longest streak of the season.

PARIS, May 27 -- The contrast between this reunion of the Foreign Ministers and their last meeting at the end of 1947 is as striking as the difference between Paris in May and London in November. At the London conference Molotov was stony from the start and the Western Ministers were placating and anxious for agreement.

Culminating four months of intensive work by more than forty students and four college departments, Dramsoc, City College drama group, presented the first American production of an English translation of Parts I and II of Goethe's "Faust" last night at the Pauline Edwards Theatre, Lexington Avenue and Twenty-third Street.
CHICAGO, May 27 (AP) -- Federal Judge Philip L. Sullivan today ordered liquidation of the Majestic Radio and Television Corporation.
Mrs. Annedore Leber, Berlin editor and publisher, disclosed yesterday that she had catalogued 3,974 Germans who had "disappeared" from Berlin since the beginning of the Soviet occupation.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- William C. Foster, who has been second in charge of Marshall Plan operations in Europe for the past year, soon will be named by President Truman to the post of Deputy Economic Cooperation Administrator, barring any unexpected change in White House plans.

DETROIT, May 27 (AP) -- Virgil Trucks pitched a six-hitter against the St. Louis Browns and beat them, 5 to 4, to snap the Tigers' six-game losing streak. Dick Kokos of the Brownies hit his eighth home run of the season in the eighth inning.

Two men charged with the hold-up-slaying of a tombstone setter in a lower East Side monument store were found guilty yesterday in General Sessions of first degree murder, but the jury urged leniency in the sentencing of one defendant.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Women have a part to play in the world today and they are not playing it, Mrs. Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit, Ambassador of India, today told the Women's National Press Club.

FORT MONMOUTH, N. J., May 27 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll headed a delegation of state officials and officers of the New Jersey National Guard today as guests of Maj. Gen. Francis H. Lanahan Jr., commanding general and his staff, on a tour of Fort Monmouth.
The left wing United Furniture Workers of America, CIO, has decided to comply with the Taft-Hartley law and file non-Communist affidavits and make public its financial affairs.

A committee of stockholders approved yesterday a compromise modification of the Central Railroad of New Jersey's reorganization plan under the Mahaffie Act. Application will now be made to the Interstate Commerce Commission for approval of the modification, which will become effective when assents are received from 75 per cent of the outstanding stock and 75 per cent of the bonds exclusive of Reading Company holdings.

In an admittedly gloomy survey of the world scene, E. M. Forster, noted English novelist, told a distinguished gathering at the American Academy of Arts and Letters yesterday that he sometimes felt "in pessimistic moments" that man's best chance for harmony might lie through "apathy, uninventiveness and inertia."

LONDON, May 27 -- A demand from the United States Government for the extradition of Gerhart Eisler, German Communist fugitive, was rejected on legal grounds today by the Chief Metro politan Magistrate of London and Eisler was set free amid the cheers of his British sympathizers.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 27 -- The American President liner General W. G. Gordon, last large United States passenger ship to leave Shanghai before the city fell to the Communists, arrived here today with a capacity list of 1,543 passengers.

MOSCOW, May 27 -- Dmitri Shostakovich, reporting his New York impressions in the humorous journal Krokodil, said he was struck by the fact a majority of the audience at a Leopold Stokowski concert sat sprawled in their chairs wearing coats and hats.

Nineteen Hundred Corporation, St. Joseph, Mich., manufacturer of home laundry equipment, will start its largest advertising program this fall with ads in key city newspapers and national magazines, it was announced yesterday. The campaign, devoted to the company's full line of Whirlpool washers, ironers and dryers, will also be carried out with distributor and dealer cooperative newspaper, radio and television advertising in principal marketing areas.

Spurred on by the Weather Bureau's promise of an almost flawless week-end, New Yorkers yesterday began pouring into all arteries of transportation and by nightfall there were indications that the largest Memorial Day week-end since the war was in the making.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Attorney General Tom C. Clark announced today that the United States had not abandoned efforts to bring about the return to this country of Gerhart Eisler notwithstanding his release in England.

More stability in the Florida citrus market was predicted for next year's crop as a result of legislation passed this week to control production, M. L. Toulme, executive vice president of the National American Wholesale Grocers Association, predicted yesterday.

In 1917 a filly named Wistful won the first running of the Coaching Club American Oaks. Today at Belmont Park a filly with the same name seems certain to be the favorite -- at even money or a reasonable facsimile thereof -- in the thirty-third edition.
WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -"It's the squeaking wheel that gets the grease," Senator Margaret Chase Smith, Republican, of Maine said in proposing that more publicity be given juvenile crimes.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The reorganization of the State Department, announced yesterday, carries out many of the recommendations of the Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government, headed by former President Herbert Hoover.

FRANKFORT, Germany, May 27 -- A private investigative agency is under contract to the United States Economic Cooperation Administration mission here to check carefully on what happens to food and other materials brought to Germany with Marshall Plan funds.

CHICAGO, May 27 -- General liquidation was on in the grain markets on the Board of Trade here today. Wheat led the decline and finished about at the bottom, with losses of 1 1/4 to 2 1/2 cents a bushel, the July position leading. Corn closed off 7/8 to 2 cents a bushel; oats, 7/8 to 1 3/8 cents; rye, 1 1/2 cents and soybeans 3/4 to 2 1/4 cents.

MADISON, N. J., May 27 -- The polo field of Giralda Farms and its immediate environs looked like a gigantic dog show, sans most of 2,637 dogs, today as preliminary work was finished for the nineteenth annual Morris and Essex Kennel Club event, America's biggest canine competition outdoors.

It isn't every day -- or night -- that the Athletics fail to score. In fact, the records show that when Connie Mack's club moved into the Stadium to start the "crucial" series with the Yankees last night it had been shut out only once this season. Mel Parnell, young Red Sox southpaw, was responsible for that one the first week of the campaign.

SAN MARINO, Calif., May 27 (UP) -- A fund of $42,613.20 was split today among 132 workers who made a futile but heroic attempt to rescue three-year-old Kathy Fiscus from a deep well pipe. The fund was contributed by thousands of persons as a reward to the men who risked their lives.
NEWARK, N. J., May 27 -- Summer sportswear for sea and shore were featured in a fashion show at Kresge-Newark here today.

Three thousand workers in seventy-five food warehouses here and in New Jersey have threatened to strike next Tuesday at midnight, tying up millions of dollars' worth of food, it was reported yesterday.

Hardier individuals may regard this long week-end as a "natural" for picnics and similar outdoorsy pursuits. It's to those of less active nature, who will venture no farther than the corner drugstore, that today's column is addressed. Even though nothing but a good book may figure in their plans, some entertaining is more than likely to be worked in, too.

LONDON, May 27 -- The stock markets here today were a little brighter after recent weakness, with the chief activity centered on Leoplodina rail stocks following the signing of the sale agreement. Despite some profit-taking in the late afternoon, prices were up to 4 points higher.

NEW CITY, N. Y., May 27 -There is sadness along the eight-mile scenic route of Charley's Bus from Nanuet to Haverstraw because the schedule through the Rockland County seat here has been stripped of all except early morning and late afternoon business runs. The curtailment is laid to families with two automobiles.

DEVON, Pa., May 27 -- Springsbury Farm's Moonlight Bay, a 5-year-old brown gelding, tonight retired the Dicksfield Farm challenge trophy for the best hunting performance at the fifty-third annual Devon horse show and country fair.
WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -Manufacturers' sales took a more than seasonal drop in April, falling to the lowest level yet reached in 1949, the Department of Commerce reported today.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- A bill to maintain the utmost in secrecy for all aspects of the Central Intelligence Agency, including all its activities, personnel and expenditures was passed unanimously today by the Senate.
CAIRO, May 27 -- Strong support for the Egyptian armament program was voiced in most of the press today following criticism of it yesterday by former Premier Ismail Sidky Pasha.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, May 27 -- The Czechoslovak Communist party congress today sent to Premier Joseph Stalin a declaration of its loyalty to the Soviet Union. It heard from Georgi M. Malenkov, a member of the Communist Politburo of Moscow and a Soviet Vice Premier, congratulations on the party's success in laying "the political and economic foundation of socialism."

PHILADELPHIA, May 27 -- Although the lights at Shibe Park shone with their customary brilliance tonight, the Giants still were unable to find their winning touch which they somehow mislaid a couple of weeks ago when they left the comforting shadows of Coogan's Bluff.
NEWARK, N. J., May 27 -- "Teen Age Corners" have been set up in ten New Jersey libraries as the result of a new program to aid high school students.

PORTMARNOCK, Ireland, May 27 (AP) -- Willie Turnesa, stouthearted little battler from Elmsford, N. Y., fought through to victory in two blistering matches today to reach the final of the British amateur golf championship while defending champion Frank Stranahan of Toledo bowed out.

In an opportune letter in THE TIMES of May 22 Elihu Stamm-Cooper stresses the growing danger of unemployment, attributing it to greed and irresponsibility, and says: "* * * the Russians do not have to lift a finger against us," but "merely have to sit and watch" our economy destroy itself.

RICHMOND, Va., May 27 -Only two former champions, Virginia-born Samuel Jackson Snead and big Jim Ferrier, a native of Australia, remained in the P. G. A. title tourney today after two eighteen-hole match rounds reduced the field to sixteen.
WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -Judith Coplon swore at her espionage trial today that she was innocent of wrongdoing, and charged that someone had hatched a "plot" to destroy her.

PATERSON, N. J., May 27 -Rocky Graziano, former middleweight boxing champion, recently reinstated by the New York Athletic Commission after a two-year suspension, was reinstated today by the National Boxing Association.

The International Harvester Company reported yesterday for the six months ended with last April, net income of $37,479,000, equal to $2.72 a common share, compared with $28,519,000 or $2.02 a common share earned in the similar period ended on April 30, 1948.
The Holland America liner Veendam sailed for Rotterdam yesterday with 571 passengers, among them Brian Faulkner of East Down, Northern Ireland, the United Kingdom's youngest member of Parliament.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Two Congressional committees considered today the advisability of curbing the authority of the Atomic Energy Commission to undertake major projects without prior clearance with one or both of them. Heretofore, the cloak of secrecy surrounding the atomic energy program has discouraged Congressional committees from asking too many details.

Jim Fuchs, 218-pound Yale junior from Chicago, provided a curtain-raising hit for the seventy-third annual Intercollegiate A. A. outdoor track and field championships yesterday by breaking the meet shot-put record with a mighty toss of 56 feet 3/8 inch.
