Giovanna Vernaci of 81-15 Northern Boulevard, Jackson Heights, Queens, a senior at Hunter College High School, won first prize in the nation-wide contest for students of French sponsored by the American Association of Teachers of French, it was announced yesterday at the high school.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (UP) -- Senator Clinton P. Anderson, Democrat, of New Mexico, and Senators from twenty-seven other cotton-growing states introduced today a bill to overhaul the 1938 cotton marketing quota law.

Labor and management at the plant of the Apex Electrical Manufacturing Company in Cleveland are too busy cooperating with one another to worry much about what is happening to their "prerogatives" in the process.

Ticket brokers decided yesterday to organize into a group that would drive from the theatre those brokers who have been charging exorbitant prices for tickets to hit shows. This announcement was made after brokers had conferred for two hours with theatre owners and producers and an official of Actors Equity.

TORONTO, May 27 (Canadian Press) -- Control of the administration of Buffalo Ankerite Gold Mines, Ltd., has been placed in new hands with changes in the board of directors. In effect control goes from Buffalo, N. Y., to Canadian hands.

In a forty-two page brief submitted in Ottawa yesterday by the Canadian Pacific Railway Company, officials told the Royal Commission on Transportation that it is "in the best interests of Canada that the Canadian Pacific is to continue to function as a privately owned system with adequate earnings to enable it to continue to supply efficient transportation services at the lowest possible cost."
Canadian Ingersoll-Rand Company, Ltd., voted yesterday a dividend of $1 a share payable to common stockholders on June 28. In previous quarters shareholders received $1.50.

No way out of it, how can an honest baseball fan settle down to the more serious things while Joe DiMaggio is down at an ailing heel? This is the most famous heel since Achilles'. This is the heel that launched a thousand sighs in the bleachers and raised the toppling hopes of the opposition.

Social issues with which the churches are faced will form the basis of a study of "Christian Action in a Secular Society" when the Central Committee of the World Council of Churches meets July 9 to 15 in Chichester, England.
LIVERPOOL, England, May 27 (Reuters) -- One thousand Liverpool dockers stopped work today in sympathy with striking port workers in the Bristol area who refused to unload strikebound ships.

A Harlem group reported success yesterday in starting playgrounds in congested areas. The Lot Playground Association, Inc., a voluntary organization, expects to open four playgrounds in June with the aid of the city.

Permission for the Long Island Rail Road to increase basic one-way passenger fares has been asked of the Public Service Commission, trustees of the bankrupt line announced yesterday. The increase, if granted, would raise the coach rate from the present three cents a mile to approximately three and a half cents, and would bring in an additional $1,406,000 in annual income, according to the trustees' estimate.

KANDAHAR, Afghanistan, May 16 -- Occasional foreign travelers in the erstwhile "secret kingdom" of Afghanistan may come upon little bits of the United States in the most unexpected places -- in an oven-hot basin at Jalalabad, just across the Khyber Pass; at Zambuli and Chah-i-Anjir in the shimmering Nad-i-Ali desert; in an abandoned palace garden outside the old walled city of Kandahar.

ST. LOUIS, May 27 (AP) -- A combination of tight pitching by lefty Al Brazle and a two-run homer by rookie Eddie Kazak gave the St. Louis Cardinals a 2 to 1 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates tonight.

A five-to-twenty-year prison sentence was imposed yesterday in Queens County Court on Edward Bracken, 17 years old, of 306 South Fifth Street, Brooklyn, who was arrested last January on a charge of setting fire to papers in the hallway of a Long Island City apartment house.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., May 27 -- Dr. Israel S. Chipkin of New York, executive director of the American Association for Jewish Education, said tonight "an American Jewish school system is in the making."

PARIS, May 27 -- The preliminary sparring stage of the four-power Foreign Ministers' Council seemed to have ended today when discussion of Soviet proposals was stalled and a promise was given that the positive Western program so far held in reserve would be presented.
WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- The Senate today put off action on a bill to block temporarily any antitrust suits against companies using the so-called "basing point" price system.

National Lead Company announced yesterday a series of price reductions on lead products reflecting recent 1 cent reductions in pig lead. Effective last Thursday, prices of paint materials were reduced from 1/2 cent per pound to 1 cent.

ESSEX FELLS, N. J., May 27 -Mrs. George Zaharias of Ferndale spread-eagled the field in the first annual Eastern open 54-hole medal play championship by carding a one-under-women's par 38, 36 -- 74 over the Essex Fells Country Club links today.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Two new air-freight carriers, scheduled to begin operations on June 24 as certificated, non-subsidized lines under Civil Aeronautics Board permit, today asked the Senate Commerce Committee to help them to be able to run on equal terms with the large mail-passenger lines with whom they will be in competition.

A series of developments here and in London during the last few days has dimmed prospects for an early settlement of differences between the American and British film industries, it became known yesterday. They are:

Appointment of Theodore W. Kheel as impartial chairman to arbitrate labor disputes on the city's privately owned bus lines is good news for labor, management and the public. An able young lawyer who served with great distinction last year as director of the city's Division of Labor Relations, Mr. Kheel brings to his new post an intimate knowledge of the techniques involved in settling strikes before they start.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, May 27 (Reuters) -- An appeal by members of the crew of the Canadian ship Tridale (7,312 tons) against the sentence of four weeks imprisonment for continued refusal to obey the lawful commands of their master was dismissed by the Chief Justice in the Supreme Court today because of a technicality.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Thirteen-year-old Kim Calvin of Canton, Ohio, became the nation's champion schoolboy speller today in competition so fierce the runner-up fainted moments after the contest ended.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 27 -- The name of Gerhart Eisler, fugitive "No. 1 Communist of America,'' was linked with the Harry Bridges case today as Government counsel vainly sought to have bail of $20,000 set for the West Coast longshore leader. Mr. Bridges is charged with perjury and fraud in obtaining United States citizenship.

Coffee futures ruled strong in quiet trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Demand from trade interests advanced prices for contract "D" 19 to 23 points. Contract "S" closed 1 point lower to 5 points higher.

PARIS, May 27 -- The four occupying powers of Germany were reported here tonight to be "on the verge" of reaching an important payments agreement that could facilitate the resumption of full scale East-West interzonal trade.

One scene of the play, "The Mad Haberdasher," which European diplomatic circles have reported to be the "most vicious" of the growling repertoire of anti-American plays in Russia, became available yesterday with the arrival here of the magazine Soviet Art.
Eleven years ago today a group of prominent citizens tried to imagine what New York City would be like without its voluntary agencies -the ones we support

HANOVER, N. H., May 27 -- -- Cornell's baseball forces handed Dartmouth its second Eastern Intercollegiate League setback, 4 -- 1, today as Bob Rider walloped a long home run with two aboard in the seventh inning before 2,000 thoroughly drenched onlookers at Memorial Field.

The first cutback in basic steel production by a subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation because of a softening in the martket for steel was effected last night when the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation shut down five open-hearths and curtailed electric furnace operations in the Monongahela Valley district.
Boston, Mass., sold yesterday an issue of $5,000,000 of temporary-loan notes, due on Nov. 10, 1949, to Halsey, Stuart Co., at a bid of 1.07 per cent, plus a premium of $76.

I was shocked to read of the New Jersey Federation of Business and Professional Women's attack on Dorothy Kenyon, our United States delegate to the United Nations Commission on the Status of Women. The charge seemed to be that she did not support women's rights.

CAMDEN, N. J., May 27 (AP) -- Front-running Olympia gets another chance tomorrow to show whether he can carry his speed a mile and one-quarter. He must do it to remain in consideration for the 3-year-old turf crown.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 27 -- "Cable From Arabia," a screen story by Steve Fisher, has been purchased by Columbia and assigned to Maurice Adler for production, the studio announced today. The story deals with the building of an oil pipeline in the Middle East, and although the studio says that no cast has been discussed for the property, trade sources indicate that it is designed as a vehicle for Glenn Ford and William Holden.

Will you, in fairness of debate, allow a Duff to comment upon the educational pronouncements of another Duff? Dr. John Carr Duff of New York University publishes what he calls an improvement in examination procedure in THE TIMES, May 23. He advocates abandoning the traditional form of heavy-duty tests in favor of allowing students to arrange their own questions, selected at random from a series of assertions on the term's work brought in by students.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 27 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie proposed today that the first meeing each year of the United Nations General Assembly be opened with a minute of silence for prayer and meditation and in memory of "those who have died for United Nations ideals."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 27 (AP) -- United States District Court Judge Carroll C. Hincks has appointed Wallace W. Delaney of Bethel trustee of the Norwalk Tire and Rubber Company, Norwalk. The judge approved the company's petition for reorganization earlier this week.

The magic of floodlights and grinding cameras transformed a Queens classroom into a "Hollywood" location as the Board of Education began work yesterday on the first of a series of 16-mm. color films about the city's schools.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission today authorized two Pittsburgh subsidiaries of the Columbia Gas System, Inc., to make changes in their natural gas systems in New York and New Jersey.

Plied yarn rayon fabrics, which were among the weakest in the period of drastic price declines, are showing definite signs of recovery, it was pointed out in the trade yesterday. Mills supplying these goods in the gray are getting from 2 1/2 to 5 cents a yard more than they did a month ago and all indications point to tightening up of supply.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Completion of a vast rebuilding program for the transport system of Greece was announced jointly today by the Economic Cooperation Administration and Louis Johnson, Secretary of Defense.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Average primary market prices advanced 0.3 per cent in the week ended on Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index was 156.5 per cent of the 1926 average, 0.3 per cent above four weeks ago and 4.9 per cent lower than in the comparable week in 1948.
Third-degree burglary indictments were returned yesterday against four men accused of planning to rob the offices of the New York Giants baseball team, 100 West Forty -- second Street.

John Robert Gregg, creator of the Gregg shorthand system studied by 18,000,000 persons and founder of the Gregg Publishing Company that was sold for $1,900,000 after his death, left an estate of $3,250,372, according to an accounting filed yesterday in Surrogate's Court.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The Colorado Central Power Company, Englewood, Col., registered today with the Securities and Exchange Commission 21,429 shares of its $10 par value common stock that is to be offered to its common stockholders at the rate of one additional share of common for each two and one-half shares held.

The appointment of James A. Wechsler as editor of The New York Post Home News was announced yesterday by Mrs. Dorothy Schiff, president and publisher. She also named Paul Sann executive editor; Henry Moscow, managing editor, and James F. Graham, city editor.

PHILADELPHIA, May 27 -Completing a year-long inquiry into City Hall scandals, a special grand jury returned today two final presentments bristling with charges of "conspiracy," "outright thievery" and political interference in affairs of this municipality.

Retail sales continued to decline here last week compared with the corresponding period a year ago. Department store sales were estimated to be about 14 per cent below last year. Sales last week were 12 per cent below the corresponding week in 1948.

We don't believe for a moment, and so far as we are aware no one has suggested, that Mayor O'Dwyer is declining to run again because of an inadequate pay envelope. But $25,000 is too little salary for the Mayor of a city of 8,000,000 population with 200,000 city employes.

New capital issues coming to the public market following the holiday make up a considerable variety, although the total volume is not heavy. Railroad equipment-trust issues scheduled for bidding include $6,450,000 by the Northern Pacific and $1,800,000 by the Chicago Eastern Illinois, both on Wednesday, and $3,435,000 by the Seaboard Air Line on Thursday.

The National Broadcasting Company television network, on Sunday, June 5, will bring its audience a view of the pageantry of Jewish confirmation ceremonies in the celebration of Shabuoth, the Festival of Weeks.

A new edition of "United States in World Affairs," by John C. Campbell with the assistance of the research staff of the Council on Foreign Relations, has been scheduled for September publication by Harper. Mr. Campbell, a former State Department official, discusses the development of American foreign policies, from the beginning of 1948 through the North Atlantic Defense Pact negotiations.

A new edition of "United States in World Affairs," by John C. Campbell with the assistance of the research staff of the Council on Foreign Relations, has been scheduled for September publication by Harper. Mr. Campbell, a former State Department official, discusses the development of American foreign policies, from the beginning of 1948 through the North Atlantic Defense Pact negotiations.

This week-end is expected to break all existing records for angling pressure on Maine waters, according to Bob Elliot of Augusta, who reports that fishing-camp operators from all parts of the state, as well as all hotels on popular fishing water, have record bookings for the next three days.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The National Labor Relations Board ruled today that a union-shop agreement obtained by the United Mine Workers under pressure of a strike violated the Taft-Hartley Law.

A two-story frame building at Seton Hospital, a 500-bed tuberculosis institution on Henry Hudson Parkway, the Bronx, has been declared unsafe and its ninety patients have been removed, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- Eastern Air Lines asked today for permission to extend its route to Newport News, Va., to "link the lower peninsula area with one carrier service to sixty-eight cities on Eastern's system with a population of 33,518,235."
LAKE SUCCESS, May 27 -- The feeding program of the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund is switching its emphasis from Europe to the Far East.

The impression Sam Boal's "Treatise on Texas and the Texans" leaves with me, a citizen of that state, is that he kept his eyes at least partially closed during his trip through the "staggering length of Texas."

FORTY-ONE years as a movie photographer have instilled in William J. Miller a deep respect for his craft and a good-natured intolerance for the chichi surrounding it. Miller got his start with the old New York Motion Picture Company in 1908, when he was 14.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Senator Bourke B. Hickenlooper of Iowa announced today that he was ready to "produce the proof" of his charges against David E. Lilienthal, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission.
CLEVELAND, May 28 (AP) -- Cleveland's Indians got some priceless pitching from Early Wynn today and defeated the Chicago White Sox, 3 to 2, in an 11-inning battle.

The Wisconsin Alumni Research Foundation maintains a laboratory at the University of Wisconsin, Madison, where more than twenty species of insects are bred and used to test for manufacturers the efficacy of insecticides. Each day the laboratory must produce some 8,000 adult flies, about 1,000 cockroaches, 1,000 clothes moths, 500 pea aphids and hundreds of milkweed bugs, red spiders, carpet beetles and other species.

How often does a cast-off return to plague the club that dealt him away? Only the bravest of the brave would dare ask this question of Burt Shotton after what happened to him and his Dodgers yesterday at Ebbets Field, where the Brooks, ahead, 6 -- 0, at one stage, dropped a 7-6 decision to the Braves.
GENEVA, May 29 (AP) -- Representatives of the East and West labored for four days here this week to find a mutually agreeable way of exchanging information to help expand their trade, and failed.

A DICTIONARY, from the reviewer's standpoint anyway, is different from an historical novel. You can't say of a dictionary, for instance, that the plot is weak, or contrived. The plot simply non est. There are other major distinctions, but that is perhaps the most prominent.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 28 -- The Yugoslav Parliament adjourned tonight after a three-day session in which basic laws were passed accelerating the tempo of socialization and establishing a new administrative structure for more efficient government.

CHATTANOOGA, May 28 -- President Eurico Gaspar Dutra of Brazil won the acclaim of thousands of Southerners this week in a whirlwind visit through the Tennessee Valley, where he inspected TVA installations and applauded the work of that Federal agency.

A CONGRESSMAN'S mind and his emotions are under a continual state of siege from people who want him, if not to believe as they do, at least to do as they wish. They call upon him in droves, individually and in delegations. They shower him with letters, telegrams, petitions and resolutions.

MANY years ago some other young scientists and I were discussing the popularity of a new book by William Beebe. Some of them were disparaging this type of work but their criticism was abruptly ended by an English artist who made the statement: "The reason some scientists don't like Beebe is that he makes natural history interesting."

DIRECTORS of the Virginia Music Festival, which recently concluded its third annual presentation here, feel that the grass roots of a statewide movement are developing, and plans are being made to widen its scope next year.
THE rocket -- one of the deadliest weapons of war -- has potentialities for peacetime use that stagger the imagination.

THE hiking and climbing clubs across the nation have planned an ambitious program of outings in the United States, Mexico and Canada for the summer of 1949. All types and varieties of trips have been scheduled, from the simple and rugged to the de luxe, with the hiker's every whim taken care of just short of supplying him with a sedan chair.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 28 -- Construction activity over the Ninth Federal Reserve District for the first third of 1949 fell below the dollar level of the same period last year, the bank in Minneapolis reported this week. The drop was about $2,000,000 from the $45,858,000 recorded in the January-April period of 1948, reports from eighty cities showed, with a 16 per cent drop in April largely responsible.

THE last book of S. J. Simon, whose "Why You Lose at Bridge" was popular with American bridge players when it was published here in 1946, has just made its appearance in England. The title is "Design for Bidding" and it is a posthumous publication: Mr. Simon died in July, 1948, after completing the writing but before his manuscript had been put in type.

Sales of four key chemicals used by the country's largest industries continue to decline. This was interpreted last week by chemical industry members as indicating that no general business recovery is in sight, at least for the near future.

COLUMBIA knows how to make haste when it has a good thing in the works. It managed to get to the market its disks of the two hit musicals, "Kiss Me, Kate" and "South Pacific" within a few weeks after the completion of the recording sessions, and now it is selling its recording of the final scene from Salome about two months after the music was captured on masters.

THE Vienna State Opera Company gets around. It has traveled in force since the war to give performances in England, Holland, Belgium and Italy. This summer it will visit and play in Florence and Brussels.

Election of Sidney R. Diamond, realty man and builder, as president of the Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association of the Bronx was announced yesterday by Dr. Emanuel Saxe, retiring president of the group.

THE Federal Trade Commission is currently studying a ruling regarding the advertising and exhibition of films which may have far-reaching effects. The recommended order, recently handed down by FTC Trial Examiner Abner E. Lipscomb, is an outgrowth of a complaint against the showing by United Artists of a shortened version of the British-made film, "The Life and Death of Colonel Blimp."

BUENOS AIRES, May 28 -- Despite charges brought before the court by five employes of the Government-owned telephone system that they had been tortured by the police, the chief of the Presidency's Political Information Division has commended the action of the police involved.

MOUNT MORRIS, N. Y. -Here in the heart of western New York State's rolling countryside, where the high banks of the Genesee River are a spectacular scenic attraction, a "sidewalk superintendent's" dream is beginning to take form.

At the present rate of progress and in the inactivity in Wall Street, grass certainly will be sprouting in the lanes of the financial district before the Justice Department's anti-trust suit against seventeen of the nation's foremost investment banking firms and the Investment Bankers Association even reaches a semblance of actual trial.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The forthcoming investigation of the national atomic energy program, which promises to last well into the summer, will have much in common with important Washington investigations of the past. It will be concerned on the surface with obvious facts and happenings, but it will also be subject to deep undercurrents which may or may not be decisive.
SCHENECTADY, N. Y., May 28 (AP) -- Trackmen from Boys' High School of Brooklyn won four events and tied for first in a fifth today in the ninth annual Schenectady interscholastic sports carnival.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, May 28 -- The deadlock between the Roman Catholic Church and the Czechoslovak State has been accentuated, it was disclosed today, by a decision of the Roman Catholic Bishops of Czechoslovakia at a meeting held here early last week to make no compromises with the present regime and in particular to refuse to make the declaration of loyalty to the state demanded by the regime.

High school vocational guidance directors in recent years have been diverting many students from the engineering fields. The assumption has been that these fields are overcrowded, particularly with GI students.

ESSEX FELLS, N. J., May 28 -- Babe Didrikson Zaharias shattered all women's records by scoring even men's par 70 to add to her first round 74 in the first annual women's 54-hole Eastern open championship at the Essex Fells Country Club today.

An improvement in the wholesale credit picture has been evident in the last two weeks, it was learned yesterday. Collections have improved in the billion-dollar garment and textile trade, according to credit men in New York, and the number of cases requiring credit adjustments has shown a definite decline.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Mediation efforts directed from Washington have had no effect so far on the Hawaiian waterfront strike that is slowly throttling the islands' economy.

AMERICANS are frequently told that the occupation of Japan has not achieved the spiritual goals set for it. Moreover, say the critics, it seems likely to miss many of the material objectives for which the Pacific war supposedly was fought.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 28 -Latin America's bid for high priority treatment in the proposed United States' program of aid to underdeveloped countries and in the correlated economic program of the United Nations received solid support today in a special report listing scores of improvements sorely needed throughout most of the whole economic field.

The proposal made recently before a Senate subcommittee to amend the Fair Labor Standards Act to bring "outside" or traveling salesmen under the protection of its provisions "runs counter to the best interests of salesmen," according to Nat Roth of Miami, president of the National Association of Women's and Children's Apparel Salesmen, who was in New York last week.

" THE basic difference between the Contemporary point of view in decoration and the Traditional is that Contemporary stresses the total concept, the inter-relationship of all pieces in a room, while Traditional is most concerned with the individual piece as a 'work of art' in itself."
DURING the last week Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, the cinema's strongest citadel, has been shaken by vicissitudes which beset two of its most ambitious productions, "Annie Get Your Gun" and "Qua Vadis."

Miss Maud B. Raxter's letter, "Pioneer Spirit," in your May 15 issue really hits the spot. In view of the reported shortage of females in Alaska, she is quite right with her question, "Why don't you tell us girls how to get to Alaska?"

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Recent Congressional disposition of important appropriation measures describes a pattern that may mean serious trouble ahead for the European Recovery Program and American prestige abroad.

Washington economic policies seem to be suffering at present from a complete lack of realism. On the one hand, President Truman is pressing for passage of his anti-inflationary control measures, including new taxes in the amount of four billion dollars. On the other hand, Congressional leaders would cut government expenditures to the extent of two to three billion dollars so as to avoid either new taxes or deficits.

THE experimental group of the Katherine Dunham School will present "Caribbean Backgrounds," a program of dances and songs traced from origins in Africa and Europe through the Antilles to rural America and the cities," at a West Indian party called "La Boule Blanche" on Friday at the Irving Plaza, 15 Irving Place.
IN general, the season that is now closing has been a disturbing one. It has been busy enough, but not very creative; it has been a worried season. The trouble? Money, of course.

Wistful ran exactly according to pattern and expectations as she won the Coaching Club American Oaks at Belmont Park yesterday. The Calumet Farm's half-sister to Coaltown, well back among the fourteen competitors in the early stages of the $50,000 added mile and three-furlongs event, improved steadily under the skillful guidance of Jockey Steve Brooks to gain the lead in the stretch and go on to win by a half-length over Mrs. W. M. Jeffords' Adile.

MR. W. H. LAWRENCE, in his review of "My Life In the Red Army," grossly misrepresented the nature of my book. He insinuates that I somehow betrayed the Allies because I "deserted" from the Soviet Army to serve with the Polish forces organized by General Anders.

Increasing their league lead to five and one-half games, the Yankees beat the Athletics, 2 -- 1, in the fourteenth inning yesterday after tying the score with two out in the ninth. The Dodgers fell out of a firs-place tie with the Braves by losing to Boston, 7 -- 6, on Pete Reiser's four-run homer in the eighth, while the Giants bowed to the Phillies, 5 -- 2.

Six hundred world authorities on arthritis, rheumatic fever, gout and allied diseases, including 150 foreign delegates, will take part this week in the Seventh International Congress on Rheumatic Diseases, opening at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel tomorrow morning for five days of crowded sessions.

WASHINGTON. THIS is the story of the man with the greatest secret in the world, how he tries to keep it and how that effort has affected him. He is David E. Lilienthal, chairman of the United States Atomic Energy Commission. He knows, because his job requires it, how many atomic weapons we have, how powerful they are, at what rate we are producing them and how they are made.

THESE two books can be warmly recommended to Christians and Jews, and it is mainly a question of whether one wishes a long book or a short one. For both works cover with equal sincerity and scholarship the forty centuries starting with the nomad shepherd Abraham providing his desert clan with the attributes of what would later be called the Israelitish nation -- namely, faith, land and people.

ONE of the most difficult command requirements in a democracy's army is that of reconciling the hardships of war with the personal needs of the citizens under arms. The soldier's attitude toward the machines and methods of war is in itself a weapon.

PARIS, May 28 -- Frank Parker of Los Angeles, America's third-ranking tennis player, won the French international singles championship for the second straight year today by defeating Budge Patty, a fellow townsman, 6 -- 3, 1 -- 6, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 4.

LONDON, May 28 -- The United States bridge team of Samuel Stayman, John Crawford, Peter Leventritt and George Rapee started a 96-board challenge match against a selected team of English bridge champions headed by Dr. Sydney Lee, captain of England's 198 gold cup team.

PARIS, May 28 -- With the introduction of the Western powers' proposals for the accomplishment of German unity today, there is a growing feeling here that discussion of this issue should not be interrupted by raising the question of Berlin's difficulties before the Council of Foreign Ministers.

ROBERTA HILL'S first novel asks no questions and answers none. It contents itself with a fevered recitation of facts, omitting the description necessary to forming visual pictures. The sadistic entertainment this tale of family tyranny provides encourages swift reading; to linger is to find the book barren of the philosophy necessary to the communication of any tragedy.

NEARLY all of Africa between 15 degrees north and 20 degrees south -- an area larger than the United States -- lies under the blight of the tsetse fly, carrier of sleeping sickness. Included in the tsetse belt are Somaliland, Kenya, Uganda, Tanganyika, Northern Rhodesia, part of Southern Rhodesia, Nyasaland, Portuguese East Africa, Belgian Congo, Portuguese Angola, French Equatoria, the Cameroons, Nigeria, the Gold Coast, Sierra Leone, and Liberia.

THE youngest operative of the Starlock Agency in Chicago, Ed Hunter is called on his first solo assignment to the near-by town of Tremont, where a murder has been committed by the side of the road. The corpse is that of a man whose throat has been torn out as if by a wild animal.

We celebrate tomorrow the fifth Memorial Day since the surrender of Germany, the fourth since the end of the war with Japan. This day of remembrance, of honor to our war dead, should properly be a time of meditation and appraisal. We should survey those four years in the light of the sacrifice that we commemorate to discover if we have truly kept faith with those who died on our behalf.

LAREDO, Tex. -- Trailer travel through Mexico is now a possibility for the non-trailer owner with the opening of a service which not only rents trailers, but also organizes guided trailer tours and arranges all travel details.

DR. ALBERT EINSTEIN'S achievements are as difficult for the average person to comprehend and appreciate as they are great. The present volumes have a common purpose -- to make Einstein's life and work understandable to boys and girls in their teens.

EVERY now and again one is reminded that some of the major victories of modern art are being won in the field of sculpture and that, after much of the painting that now clamorously fills our galleries has been consigned to the attic or to the sociologist, the work of a Brancusi, say, will be found to embody, in its unique and private way, the ideal vision of our time.

Activity in the wholesale dress market here last week centered on low-end and popular price bembergs and cottons, with retail prices ranging from $2.98 to $5.98, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buying office.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (UP) -- House members were assured tonight of a chance to vote soon on a compromise pay rise for the military in which rookies, as well as generals, would receive some increase.

A PACKAGE of mixed seed of annual scabiosa gave a greater return in my garden last year than any investment I had made in many years. The flowers lived up to the enthusiastic catalogue description and were produced in such enormours numbers that we could scarcely cut them fast enough to keep them from going to seed.

Large numbers of top ranking scientists are being kept out of atomic research because of faulty security procedures, three nuclear energy authorities asserted yesterday at a press conference. Two of the scientists were employed on Manhattan Project for the development of the first atomic bomb.

Top management officials and personnel directors of nineteen leading companies in manufacturing, banking, service industries and retailing will meet in New York on June 6 to attempt to arrive at standards on the effectiveness of executive selection procedures, Dr. F. F. Bradshaw, president of Richardson, Bellows, Henry Co., disclosed in an interview last week.

EVER since I came to the United States it was my dream once more to go through the unforgettable experiences I once lived through when assisting the birth and watching the growth of such contemporary operas as Alban Berg's "Wozzek," Kurt Weill's "Dreigroschenoper," Ernst Krenek's "Johnny spielt auf," or Jaromir Weinberger's "Schwanda."
A forty - ton, 100 - foot girder slipped into place at Queens Plaza station yesterday to accomplish the main engineering achievement in the linking of the BMT and IRT transit systems.

As a result of the month-by-month rise of basement department store sales over last year's figures, many main store buyers are buying greater quantities of medium and low priced lines for fall, it was learned here last week.

MADISON, Wis., May 28 (AP) -- The University of Wisconsin crew, taking an early lead, swept to its first victory of the season today, defeating Navy by almost three lengths. The Badgers' time for the two-mile Lake Mendota course was 9:32.4.

TOMORROW'S holiday starts the summer crowd to moving and to thinking of blossom trails and wide open spaces. From now through June and later, sight-seeing motorists will be hard put to it not to travel along roads flanked by masses of laurel blooms.

A strictly technical decision of a conservative British magistrate has put an end to the case of Gerhart Eisler. His claims of the status of political refugee were not even discussed. Indeed, they were never at issue except in his own confused mind and in the bewildered ideas of some of his sympathizers and co-Communists.

THE Chorus of the University of Puerto Rico, visiting America for the first time under the auspices of the Puerto Rican Government, sings tonight in Carnegie Hall. The chorus, founded in 1936, is the product of its conductor and founder, Augusteo Rodriguez.
LONDON, May 28 -- In recent weeks Britain has been nervously taking her own economic pulse, feeling her head for signs of financial fever and ransacking the medicine cabinet for commercial cure-alls.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Wherever they may lie buried, in military cemeteries here or abroad, the American dead of World War II will be honored on Monday with Memorial Day ceremonies across the world.

The forty-second annual memorial service for dead members was held yesterday by the Honor Legion of the Police Department in the rotunda of Police Headquarters, 240 Centre Street. Two hundred and fifty relatives and friends of members of the department were present.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 28 -- Cornell went into a four-way tie for the Eastern Intercollegiate League lead by defeating Yale, 12 -- 3, today. It was the second triumph of a two-day New England trip for the Ithacans, who beat the Dartmouth nine yesterday.

SOME years ago Thomas Mann, with his predilection for literary analogies and for detecting symbolic patterns in the murkiest of phenomena, prophesied his own death at 70 (his mother had died at 70). Now, at 73, Mr. Mann is an extraordinarily youthful-looking man, unobtrusively elegant -- dapper even -- whose physical and intellectual vitality might well be the envy of any man in any of his seven ages.
The nation today and tomorrow will reconsecrate itself to the cause of enduring peace as it pause to pay homage to the dead of its wars in the eighty-first annual observance of Memorial Day.

HOWEVER they may have differed from or resembled one another in other ways, the four figures whose portraits Mr. Lewis presents as his latest venture in biography have two characteristics in common: all were favorites of their sovereigns, but all were more than mere favorites.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 28 -- How Harry Bridges' strength with labor will be affected by his indictment on conspiracy and perjury charges was a foremost topic of discussion on the West Coast this week after the Government initiated action which presumably is leading to a new attempt to deport the Australian-born longshore leader.

JUNE is a time of peonies, closing of school, wedding, and, nicest of all, perhaps, strawberries. To be sure, the berries come to New York City the year round. But during June nearby vines are at their height, and the fruit is not only at its most profuse but also at its most pennywise, too.
AYER, Mass., May 28 -- The Fort Devens branch of the University of Massachusetts, established in 1946 for veterans studying under the GI Bill of Rights, closed its doors today.

LONDON, May 28 (AP) -- A plane called the Mayflower arrived in London today with forty-five United States press representatives and aircraft officials aboard, after a demonstration flight from New York taking 9 hours, 56 minutes.

WHEN United States military authorities last week approved plans for a suspension bridge over the Narrows between Staten Island and Brooklyn they brought one step nearer the realization of a dream long cherished by New York City planners as well as by many motorists throughout the East.

Stringent rationing of tires and all other rubber goods, will be inevitable in event of a war, according to a consensus of synthetic rubber experts here this week. While theoretically the United States can supply its own needs from the set-up of operating and "stand-by" rubber plants scattered through the nation, wartime demands would tax such facilities to the utmost, it was added.

The Communist movement in Russia and abroad has a new formualtion of Marx' theory of world revolution in which Soviet expansion is the key principle, William Z. Foster, national chairman of the Communist party of the United States, indicated in a document which is being distributed by the party today.

IF there happen to be among the readers of this column any earnest young folk who are thinking of movie writing as a possible career, we would like to commend to their attention several current and recent films. A careful perusal of these pictures might serve to enlighten them as to the intellectual standards of the average movie in this day and age.

CAMDEN, N. J., May 28 -- Fred W. Hooper's Olympia ran a 1:35 mile today. But he still had a quarter of a mile to go in the $58,800 Jersey Stakes, and at the end of the line he was a beaten colt -- beaten by Isidor Bieber's Palestinian. He also was beaten by the weights.

Although it is not specifically provided for by income tax statute, the doctrine of constructive "receipt" of income has become generally recognized by the courts. The principle no doubt had its origin in the Treasury Department, with a view to preventing the taxpayer from electing to report income in a taxable year most favorable to him.
VIENNA, May 28 -- A Communist attempt to organize Volksdeutsche [German expatriates] from all countries behind the Iron Curtain for a return to their homes was begun here yesterday.

GEORGE BELLAIRS has been justly acclaimed for years as one of the subtlest and wittiest practitioners of the simon-pure British detective story; and his adroit ironic Inspector Littlejohn is one of the more popular members of the fictional C. I. D. But neither Mr. Bellairs nor his Inspector will win new fans with the surprising slovenliness of their latest contribution.

PRINCETON - Teaching Princeton University has received a grant of $100,000 from the Carnegie Foundation of New York to advance the university's Woodrow Wilson Fellowship plan for the recruiting of able young men into the teaching profession. The program, established in 1945, originally was designed to attract men to the profession following discharge from the armed services.

As June approaches many anglers who evidenced only mild interest in the trout fishing and practically none in the off-shore and bay fishing are waiting with considerable impatience for word that the Atlantic salmon are beginning to move up the northern rivers.

THE great Army wheeze "You never had it so good" has come beautifully true for twenty GI's from Fort Bragg, N. C. The detail they drew was one many a civilian dreams of: being a movie actor -- for six whole weeks.

CHICAGO, May 28 (AP) -- Ken Raffensberger won an epic pitching duel from Dutch Leonard here today as the Cincinnati Reds captured an eleven-inning battle, 2 to 0, to snap a three-game winning streak of the revived Chicago Cubs.

Two new awards for distinguished journalism in the fields of medical research and public health are announced by the Albert and Mary Lasker Foundation, donor of the Lasker Awards since 1944 in varied medical fields. The 1949 awards are intended to encourage the writing and publication in general newspapers and magazines of outstanding articles on improvement of public health and the prolongation of life, especially through medical research and public health programs.

A COUNTRY-WIDE movement to reduce steadily increasing motor vehicle accidents will be one of the main objectives of the President's Highway Safety Conference opening Wednesday in Washington. The upswing in mortality among teenage drivers and among pedestrians will be stressed and remedies sought for this problem.

OCEAN VIEW, Va. -- Chesapeake Bay fishermen tell no more whoppers than others of their calling, and they do inject into their spring fish stories an air of authenticity that convinces the stranger he will find more and bigger fish biting in the Bay and adjacent waters than almost anywhere else. There is some basis for this view.

SOMETHING was said here recently about a promise to return to the half-chewed topic of the New York of the novelists. In my first discussion of the subject I ended by bewailing the fact that when our young writers do choose to write about New York, they give us stories about writers and publishers, newspaper and magazine tycoons, big shots of the advertising world.

PARIS, May 28 -- The Big Four Foreign Ministers Council entered a new phase today when the three Western powers formally proposed that Germany be united on the basis of the Bonn constitution, and that four-power control be revived but on the condition that decisions be taken by a majority of the four.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 28 -- Ira Godin, 21-year-old Harvard junior from Cleveland, set a new Eastern League strike-out record for a season today as he pitched the Crimson to a 5-1 victory over Pennsylvania at Soldiers Field.

THE little known Kafir-lily or Crimson Flag (Schizostylis coccinea), wish its spikes of deep crimson-scarlet flowers, makes a stunning house plant. It may be planted out in the garden now, and brought indoors before cold weather, for November bloom. In a sheltered spot, it may flower in the garden in late autumn.

DEVON, Pa., May 28 -- Dance King, a 6-year-old chestnut gelding owned by Courtney Burton of Warrenton, Va., and ridden by Miss Peggy Hamilton, today won the Green Hunter championship of the fifty-third annual Devon Horse Show and country fair.
Easing the social problems of children is more effective in combatting school truancy than levying fines on parents, a Board of Education study disclosed yesterday.
Through thirteen innings and more than three hours yesterday at the Stadium the heroic figure of towering Leland Victor Brissie menaced the Yankee winning streak.

MADISON, N. J., May 28 -- Champion Walsing Winning Trick of Edgerstoune, 2 1/2-year-old black brindle imported Scottish terrier belonging to Mrs. John G. Winant of New York, crowned a ring career of rare excellence today by taking best in show in the nineteenth Morris and Essex Kennel Club event on Giralda Farms.

STUDIES of contemporary composers often lack objectivity; impressions are too fresh, opinions too hasty. Early in his career Debussy was attacked for his bold harmonic and rhythmic innovations. After Debussy had achieved gradual recognition, mainly through "Pelleas et Melisande," he was attacked in later life for not continuing to compose in his early style.

During the recent biennial inspections of the Langley Aeronautical Laboratory of the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics even the layman could not fail to be impressed both with the bewildering complexity of the research problems which mark this age of flight and the energy, ingenuity and sense of order with which these problems are being attacked by the N.A.C.A.

Converted from a Liberty tanker to dry cargo status, the Yankee Fighter has left the Bethlehem Steel Company's Staten Island Yard bound for Hampton Roads, Va., to load its first solid cargo as a freighter.

BINGHAMTON, N. Y., May 28 -- Uncle Sam has been in big business in this up-state community since a week after Pearl Harbor and now in the post-war period is subject to the same harassments that have plagued private industrialists for generations.
PORTMARNOCK, Ireland, May 28 -- Sam McCready, a real fighting Irishman, won the British amateur golf championship today on his first try.

LONDON. AMONG the ideals of democracy a high place has always been given to the belief that political power should be impersonal. "A government of laws, and not of men," so it was phrased by the authors of the Massachusetts Constitution of 1780. And most of the devices elaborated by Western constitutionalism since then have had as their purpose the fulfillment of this objective.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 28 -- Maj. Gen. Abdul Monsef Mahmud Pascha, Director General of the Egyptian Coast Guard Administration, has announced that the Arab states were raising more hashish than ever before. He has asked that the Arab League take action to obtain an enforcement promise from the Arab countries to eradicate production of the drug.
DETROIT, Sunday, May 29 -Final terms for settlement of the twenty-three-day-old strike at the Ford Motor Company were accepted by both sides at 1:30 A. M. today.

The tragic death of James Forrestal brings into sharp focus a modern trend in journalism which portends much danger to the moral structure of our country. A significant concomitant of the two great wars of this generation has been a noticeable deterioration of ethics and good manners.

LONDON, May 28 -- Dressed in deep mourning, Queen Elizabeth arrived at her family seat, Glamis Castle, Scotland, today to attend the funeral of her elder brother, the Earl of Strathmore. Accompanying her on the train from London were David Bowes-Lyon, another brother; Lord Leveson-Gower, a nephew, and other relatives.

Twenty-eight Fire Department medals, including twenty-six for acts of heroism during fires and two for excellence of administration, will be awarded in City Hall Plaza at 12:30 o'clock in the afternoon on Wednesday, June 8, Fire Commissioner Frank J. Quayle announced yesterday.

HIGHTSTOWN, N. J., May 28 -- Three meet records fell and one was tied today in the annual Head-masters' and Coaches' invitation track meet of New Jersey as the Lawrenceville School took first place with a total of 48 3/5 points on the Peddie School track for the second year in a row.

TEEN-AGE boys and girls will enjoy this fast-moving story of high school sports. The action centers about young Marvin Bradley, first on the baseball diamond and later as a triple-threat man on the Oakmere High football eleven.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- A second and improved Viking rocket is being assembled for the Navy by the Glenn L. Martin Company's plant at Baltimore, it was announced today.

FRAN ALLISON, a tall, slender ex-schoolteacher from Iowa, is responsible for the middle word in what is probably television's most enigmatic program title: "Kukla, Fran and Ollie." She is, of course, the lady who acts as mother, sister and girl friend to a dragon, which is Ollie, and to a worrying, elfinish figure, which is Kukla.

UNDER the tongue-twisting title of "Mr. I. Magination," CBS television is offering at 7 P. M. Sundays a thoroughly rewarding half hour for viewers, both young and old. Practically the one-man achievement of Paul Tripp, who prepares the scripts, writes the lyrics, does the staging and plays the title role, it is essentially a sprightly excursion into fantasy which combines both entertainment and education.

A FEW years back Paramount placed a number of its stars and directors on display in a bubbly parfait called "Variety Girl." In the course of it a desperate and highly agitated director was heard to moan "who can fire DeMille."

INDIANAPOLIS, May 28 -- Death went through a refresher course at the "Mortality Corner" of the Indianapolis Speedway today during the closing hours of the qualifying runs for Mon day's 500-mile race. George A. Metzler of Indianapolis, a rookie driver, cracked up and was critically injured in the first right-hand turn on the track, about thirty feet from the spot where Shorty Cantlon was killed during the 1947 automobile race.

I OPENED those pages with high expectations. For nothing is more needed today than an uncompromising "demoralizer," ready to prick at every point our national optimism and complacency, our generous illusions, our terrible and potentially destructive innocence.

Except for the 3,236,710-share turnover on Nov. 3, 1948, Wall Street has not known a 3,000,000-share day in more than a year. So far this year the volume has not exceeded 2,000,000 shares on any trading day.

SALT LAKE CITY, May 28 -- Labor trouble is brewing in western mining centers. With contract time approaching in the metal mines of the Mountain States, residents fear an unprecedented wave of walkouts may tie up major mines and adversely effect economic conditions throughout the region by summertime.

Three weeks from this Tuesday the process of electing a Mayor of New York City will get under way with the filing of petitions for candidates. The primaries -- if there are party contests -- will be held on Sept. 6. The election itself comes on Nov. 8. The winner will serve for four years beginning next Jan. 1.

Steamboating on the Hudson River may be said to have opened its 143d season last week, counting from the season of 1807 when Robert Fulton's Clermont made its first trip from New York to Albany. There were no steamboats on the river before that and there are only a few today, but in between there have been many, and they have contributed greatly to the life and growth of the community.

JOHN JAY McCLOY, the former president of the International Bank who will shortly become United States High Commissioner for Germany, was picked for his new post by two Presidents: the late Franklin D. Roosevelt and Mr. Truman. Mr. McCloy, now 54 years old, was Assistant Secretary of War when the offer first came; Germany had not yet surrendered, and the Roosevelt death was only weeks away.
The Big Four Foreign Ministers' meeting on Germany got under way last Monday in Paris -- and late yesterday there was still no clear sign of where the conference was heading.
WHAT can be done to eliminate prejudice in the United States? What are our chances of removing the cancer of discrimination that is so alien -- and so threatening -- to the American ideal ?

ROME, May 28 -- The Ministry of Public Instruction announced today that the painting of St. Sebastian by Andrea del Castagno [1390-1457], which was sold by an art dealer to the New York Metropolitan Museum had been exported illegally from Italy.

WOOSUNG, May 28 -- The roads leading toward the wharfs south of this town, which were the embarkation point of Nationalist troops fleeing Shanghai, bear fantastic witness to a military disaster com parable to the evacuation of Dunkerque.

MELBOURNE, Australia, May 23 -- In the winter sunshine of Central Queensland 200 men have begun to harvest the first crop of grain sorghum, estimated at 1,000,000 bushels, planted by the Queensland-British Food Corporation on its vast farm at Peak Downs.

A bronze plaque, the gift of Queen Juliana of the Netherlands, marking the restoration of the Voorlezer's House, the oldest elementary school building in the United States, was presented late yesterday afternoon at ceremonies in the old Richmond County Court House on Center Street, Richmond, S. I.
This article inaugurates a series of reminders and hints for the week-end gardener, which will appear each Sunday this summer.

PARIS, May 28 -- The Simplon Orient Express from Lausanne brought Princess Margaret of Great Britain to a Paris resplendent with sunshine this morning for a three-day visit. A police cordon surrounding the Gare de Lyon held back an enthusiastic crowd including many characteristically Parisian midinettes on their way to work.

FRANKFORT, Germany, May 28 -- The refugee situation in Western Germany has become so critical that the United States mission of the Economic Cooperation Administration here is exploring the possibility of setting aside Marshall Plan funds to alleviate it.

Chill winds and threatening skies kept those unable to leave the city for the Memorial Day week-end close to home yesterday. The city's beaches, set to welcome millions of one-day vacationists, were almost deserted; automobile and local bus and rail travel in the metropolitan area was light and only neighborhood playgrounds and amusement places drew large crowds.

Many of the branches of the New York Public Library will open on Wednesday new art exhibitions for June. Scenes of Central Park and other points in the city will be depicted in pastels and oils by Helene Hollander at 127 East Fifty-sixth Street.

PAN AMERICAN AIRWAYS will preview this week a new service across the Atlantic which will be, the airline says, "the most de luxe service ever offered the air traveler." Regular flights will start on June 10.

I read with interest the report about Prof. Eugene G. Rochow in "Science in Review" for May 15, 1949. Professor Rochow believes that the world can support a population of 15,000,000,000 if we make the most of the chemical knowledge that we have. He says our chemical knowledge will enable us to grow enough trees and convert the wood to sugar for human consumption.
PHILADELPHIA, May 28 -- If ever the Giants get back to the Polo Grounds alive they may yet have to do it crawling on their hands and knees.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The decline in consumer prices through the fall and winter has not continued. For five straight months the index of the Bureau of Labor Statistics drifted until the low point was reached in February. March and April readings reversed the trend, though not very much.

IN business the big question is: "How long watchful waiting?" This has been the guiding policy in many quarters since early in the year. The waiting is to see when prices will be lowered sufficiently to bring back active demand in both consumer and industrial markets.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., May 29 -- Sixteen Headliner Medal winners for journalistic achievement in newspapers, radio and photography in 1948 were announced today by the National Headliners Club.

THE Brooklyn Botanic Garden is holding Spring Rose Day on Thursday. Members of the Garden and their guests are invited to attend the program in the rose garden at 3 P. M. A discussion lead by Dr. George S. Avery Jr., director of the Garden, will describe steps that should be taken to protect roses from insects and diseases.

WITH vacation days just over the horizon, the major networks are busy at work whipping their summer replacement schedules into final shape. For the benefit of the listener who wants to organize his hot weather listening plans early, some of the newer shows announced are listed below:

Retail promotions of nylon bathing suits, sheer cotton and chiffon dresses, denim and cotton separates, and straw handbags attracted a strong consumer response here last week, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the Retail News Bureau, Inc.

FOR the first time New York camera club contest jury, composed of judges with different professional backgrounds in art and photography, was successfully used recently in the Carbide Camera Club competition of the Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation.

HOUSTON, Tex., May 28 (AP) -- Independent oil men in Texas are asking Congressional help to curb foreign imports of petroleum. One operator in east Texas told a House small business committee at a hearing in Dallas this week that increased foreign crude imports have reduced domestic producers' income approximately 50 per cent.
In sermons preceding Memorial Day, rabbis here yesterday emphasized the importance of promoting peace in this atomic age and deplored the "cold war" between East and West.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -A rebellion is boiling up in the House Un - American Activities Committee against what one member called "almost complete inactivity" and "iron curtain" secrecy.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 28 (AP) -- The starting line-up for the 500-mile race at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway Monday:
MOSCOW, May 13 -- Soviet youngsters are being taught to learn "the magic word" and to watch out that they don't put on the cap of the boastful rabbit.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -- President Truman cruised on the yacht Williamsburg toward Patuxent, Md., in Lower Chesapeake Bay, after an early morning departure today from Blakistone Island in the Potomac River. He will return Monday evening.

Not only is this the week-end that launches for 1949 the outboard speed boat season but at 1 o'clock tomorrow afternoon, abeam the Ocean City (N. J.) Yacht Club, the first of the long succession of inboard events will be started on their dangerous courses that makes the dare-deviltry of speed-boating one of the most exciting of sports spectacles.
BOSTON, May 28 (AP) -- Ted Williams and Tex Hughson rescued the Boston Red Sox today as they pulled out a 5-4 decision over the hustling Washington Senators before a crowd of 13,389 fans.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The use of rayon and other synthetic fibers reached a new peak in 1948, rayon consumption being 1,017,000,000 pounds and other synthetics 70,703,000 pounds, the Department of Agriculture reported today.

HANOVER, N. H., May 28 -- Brown's baseball forces, behind Bill Hayes' six-hit pitching, downed Dartmouth, 5 -- 3 this afternoon before 1,800 spectators at Memorial Field, thus giving the Big Green its second E. I. L. drubbing in two days.

BERLIN, May 28 -- For the second time in a quarter of a century Germans are prepared to try their hand at a full-bodied parliamentary democracy. All that remains to be done to bring the Second German Republic to life is the election of a Parliament and a President and the choice of a Chancellor.

CAIRO, May 28 -- The United States diplomatic corps in the Middle East has been urging so steadily, if cautiously, resettlement as a solution of the greater part of the Palestinian Arab refugee problem that certain Arab states are beginning to indicate an interest in how much Washington is willing to invest.
Miss Peggy Ann McCay, who will be graduated from Barnard College next Wednesday, has received the Helen Prince Prize for excellence in dramatic composition, it was announced yesday.

The study of Hebrew, both as a college-entrance subject and as a college course, is steadily growing in popularity, Dr. Abraham Katsh of New York University reported last week. His report was based on a survey of 1,021 colleges and universities, similar to one he conducted in 1934.

ROME, May 28 -- With the continued success of the European Recovery Program, Italy will soon present the United States with the first real test of the consistency of the United States' tariff policy, in the opinion of economic observers here.

Drs. Laurence W. Kinsell, George D. Michaels, C. H. Li and William E. Larsen -- the latter a lieutenant junior grade in the United States Navy Medical Corps -- all of the University of California's medical school, have devised a method which apparently halts the progress of gigantism and acromegaly.

SUCCESS with winter house plants depends considerably upon the care given them during the summer. All too often they are just put out under a tree to be battered by summer storms, and left to fend for themselves. A certain amount of attention now will pay rich dividends next winter.

THE appointment of Archibald MacLeish to the Boylston Professorship at Harvard directs attention again to the old question of how the poet fares in our economic society. Historically, the perspective is depressing.

THE movie depression has now left its mark on Hollywood premieres, too. Last week, Leonard Levinson, impresario of the animated cartoon company known as Impossible Pictures (slogan: "If it's a good picture, it's impossible"), unveiled four of his "Jerky Journeys" travelogues aboard a Los Angeles street car, complete with popcorn, motion- picture projectionists, are lights and cinema celebrities.

A series of 100 musical programs for veterans' and civilian hospitals and other institutions in New York, the Bronx and Brooklyn will be presented this month by Local 802, American Federation of Musicians, during the month of June, it was announced yesterday by Richard McCann, the local's president.

The title of one of your leading articles in the May 11 issue -- "Action on Genocide" -- is somewhat misleading. Your article merely states that the ratification by the United States of the Convention on Genocide that was approved by fifty-five nations in Paris last December is proceeding very slowly.

FROM. Mr. Duvoisin's front-piece drawing of Mrs. Willburdrive hurrying through the rain to Sue and Bill's house it is obvious that here is the kind, reliable, conscientious sitter that all parents long for. She arrives in good spirits, ready to mind the children.

Although the additional trading of shares in two more American companies -- Eastman Kodak Company and the United States Steel Corporation -- on the stock exchanges of Switzerland was held a welcome sign in the revival of foreign investing in United States securities, brokers believed that no widespread restoration of dealings in our stocks and bonds would occur until foreign exchange restrictions are lifted by many countries.

OMAHA, May 28 -- Population trends, long a source of concern to the rural Midwest, resumed top rank as a conversation piece this week after Secretary of Agriculture Brannan announced his thirty-year Missouri River Basin plan to safeguard farm fertility and indirectly to stabilize the agrarian population.

In a lecture which he delivered before the Royal Society of Arts, Dr. W. H. J. Vernon of the Chemical Research Laboratory in Great Britain's Department of Scientific and Industrial Research discussed corrosion inhibitors. Of these, sodium benzoate has received the most scientific attention.

Regarding Senator Hugh H. Humphrey's article "The Case for National Health Insurance," medical care by taxation (let us not euphemistically call it "by insurance") would prove unsatisfactory in this country.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The number of persons receiving public assistance reached a record 3,500,000 in the fiscal year ended June 30, 1948, the Federal Security Agency reported today.

PHILADELPHIA, May 28 -- Pennsylvania Railroad carloadings last week totalled 117,065, against 145,407 a year ago, a decrease of 19.5 per cent; and for 1949 to date totalled 2,226,151 to compare with 2,468,802 last year, a decrease of 9.8 per cent.

THE coming of independence to India in August, 1947, was accompanied by a tremendous upheaval of populations. From five to seven million Moslems, Hindus, Sikhs and members of other sects took part in a long and weary exodus brought about by the partition of the subcontinent when the British moved out.

MR. VON HAGEN'S informal history of Ecuador does not fill a need particularly, but it is a pleasant, unpretentious book intended more to entertain than to instruct. The story of the little Andean republic, famous for its shrunken heads and panama hats, has been told any number of times, once before by the present author himself.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The progress of armed service unification moved ahead decisively this week as a strengthened National Security Act was approved by the Senate.

In the Truman Administration there have been two main approaches to the problem of getting the President's program through the Eighty-first Congress. Mr. Truman has steadily insisted that Congress pass his whole program, promptly and without compromise.

THIS new collected edition of Robert Frost's poems makes it appropriate for us to survey his total achievement and ask ourselves where Frost stands in the American poetic scene. Frost was born seventy-four years ago and he was discovered as a poet in England, where his first volume of poems, "A Boy's Will," was published in 1913.

LONDON, May 28 -- In a slashing campaign attack on the Labor Government and its policies, Winston Churchill today warned his Conservative followers that the Government might call a snap general election this coming autumn.

Something for nothing -- everybody likes that. And that's why everyone ought to enter the Greater New York Fund vacation contest. Hop a plane to Mexico City, visit glamorous Acapulco, see the buried city of Cuernavaca, Tasco Guadalupe, the Pyramid of the Sun and Moon -- and do it without spending one cent.

MITCHEL FIELD, L. I., May 28 -- Continuing air exercises designed to perfect defenses of New York and other areas against potential enemy bombers have been in progress since early in May, the Continental Air Command made known here today.

With the summer season officially opening tomorrow at most resorts -- after a week-end of preview -- owners of cottages and hotels and beachfront concessionaires are looking hopefully for a "good season" financially, but are keeping their fingers crossed.

DETROIT, May 28 -- Three premises which are being advanced in xplanation of the attempted assassinations of Walter P. Reuther and his younger brother, Victor G. Reuther, of the United Automobile Workers (CIO), fall far short of plausibility.

WEST POINT, N. Y., May 28 -- Bill Hawkins is becoming a most troublesome gent for Amy. With 6,000 persons looking on at Doubleday Field, Hawkins spun a neat five-hitter as Navy's baseball team routed the cadets, 8 to 2, in an Eastern Intercollegiate League battle today.

WHILE this book by a new writer has both mystery and suspense, it is actually a full- fledged novel based on a crime. A down-at-heel, faded blond night club entertainer is found stabbed to death in her tawdry hotel room.

THE truest feat of the imagination in fiction is to create and people a private world, which is what the good novel always does. To accomplish this with no apparent effort, so that the reader simply loses sight of how the thing is done in his enjoyment of what it is, may very well be called the supreme test of the maker of fiction.

WEATHER SHIPS - North Atlantic weather stations on vessels of six nations will remain in operation for a new three-year period in compliance with an agreement recently signed in London by member states of the International Civil Aviation Organization. Ten stations stretching from the Western Hemisphere to the coast of Norway will continue to make weather observations and send in radio reports at frequent intervals for the benefit of transoceanic air and steamer traffic.

THE eleven generals in this book are all American, but they are not the Washingtons, Lees, Grants, Pershings or Eisenhowers. They are the executors of combat -- the lesser known and less understood generals who directly led troops in battle.

DETROIT, May 28 (AP) -- Lefthander Ted Gray pitched the Tigers into fifth place in the American League today as he tossed a five-hitter to shut out the Browns 8 -- 4. It was the first shut-out by a Detroit hurler this season.

The British Extradition Act of 1870, following the long British tradition of providing asylum for political refugees, ruled that no person could be extradited (returned forcibly to a country from which he had fled) unless he had committed an offense recognized in Britain as criminal rather than political.
BERLIN, May 28 -- Communist-controlled delegates from the Soviet zone converged on this strike-harassed city tonight to set up their own German republic.
Customs Service inspectors found six packets of heroin, totaling about five pounds, with an estimated retail value of $150,000, aboard the Italian liner Saturnia yesterday afternoon.

AGAINST his wife's approval, Dr. Rodman Quean had invited some strange guests to Fair Acres, his country estate: a foreign actress and patient of Dr. Quean; her producer; a playwright; a wealthy alcoholic and his friend Betty.
THE pleasure from a garden in May is more than doubled by cutting some flowers for use in the house. These arrangements may be as varied as the flowers.

MODERN taste has had its quota of vulgarities and blunders, but among its brightest triumphs has been the appreciation of certain primitive artists' creative genius. Today we recognize greatness in objects that our grandfathers would have considered fit for nothing but dusty showcases in an archeologist's parlor -- totems from Africa and the South Seas; figurines from Crete and Teotihuacan; jewels of the Visigoths; paintings by a Pittsburgh laborer or a French toll collector.

IN his third novel Frederick Wight attempts to enter Marquand's special realm, the wealthy Boston family, without that author's satiric view. Alternating between a psychiatrist's office and a Cape Cod seascape with racing regattas, beach shack picnics and the shipyard activities of yachtsmen, "Inner Harbor" is pleasant and innocuous reading, but it never quite gives off the tang of salt air.

CHICAGO, May 28 -- Major business components during April showed a mixed trend with construction contracts, bank debits to individual accounts, and department store sales highlighting the favorable side. Contracts awarded on building projects were 1,517, the highest April mark on record.

MYSTIC, Conn. -- A seaport street, exactly as it appeared in 1850, when the whaling industry was at its peak, is being reconstructed here by the Marine Historical Association as part of a project that will transform the waterfront area into a living picture of a century-old port of call for clipper ships and whaling vessels.

Entomologist, Long Island Agricultural and Technical Institute A WALK through the garden at this time of the year shows ample evidence that destructive bugs are back again. Since damage is obvious and their numbers, in many cases, seem reinforced, there should be no delay in starting a program of prevention and remedy.

The question of appropriating Federal funds for educational purposes has been receiving considerable attention lately in academic quarters and in Congress, particularly since passage in the Senate of a bill to provide $300,000,000 a year for the support of public schools; a similar measure is pending in the House.

MEXICO CITY, May 28 -- With the beginning on Monday of an underwater search for oil off the Gulf coast of the Isthmus of Tehuantepec the faith of Edwin W. Pauley in the type of foreign exploitation contract that Mexico now offers -- in legal conformity with her expropriation laws -- will be put to the test.

THIS final work by the late Karl Vollmoeller, author of the celebrated pantomime "The Miracle," is a long romance. It is a story of miracles and adventures, of most worldly conduct by those wearing the garments of unworldliness, of true sanctity in unexpected persons and places.
The current case of "atomic jitters" in Washington is not unrelated to the apathetic reception given to the arms-aid program by Congress.

The prolonged effort by banks to obtain a reduction in the premium rate of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation received new impetus last week when Jesse Jones, former head of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, publicly advocated prompt "suspension" of such payments.

More than 4,300 academic degrees will be awarded to graduates of seventeen schools and colleges of Columbia University at the 195th annual commencement at 4 P. M. Wednesday on the university's South Court. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Columbia's thirteenth president, will preside for the first time.

George Soule, in his comforting article, "Have We Learned the Lesson of 1929?" does a nice self-convincing job. He follows the common pattern of accentuating favorable subsidiary issues and disregarding fundamentals -- deficiences of an economy initially supported by exploitation of resources, living off fat, and further artificially stimulated at a critical juncture by war-created funds.

MY criticism that the term "Afrikanders" is used by South Africans to denote a breed of cattle and not people still stands. The trouble stems from Afrikaans, a relatively young language spoken for only about a century and recognized as official in South Africa only since 1925.

HARRISON, N. Y., May 28 -- Amid the colorful surroundings of the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club and in an atmosphere that smacked more of the county fair than the race track, the Adjacent Hunts staged another of their highly interesting annual race meetings today.

GLADYS MALVERN'S latest romance for teen-age girls is set in old New Amsterdam, at the historical moment when the city turns into New York. The Sparrow sisters and their widower father, English settlers from Connecticut, come to the Dutch metropolis and settle down in a cottage owned by the rich and kindly Widow van Kelt.
Forty-two-year-old Hugh Hicks has always wanted a college education. He is now getting one in a double-barreled dose.
CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, May 28 (AP) -- A jury of nine men and three women tonight convicted Dr. Robert C. Rutledge Jr. of St. Louis of second-degree murder.

Peonies will be in bloom for Decoration Day this year. The two belong together, somehow, though the season does not always cooperate in timing their arrival. For the peony is a remembrance flower, as Decoration Day, in its more formal name, is Memorial Day.

FIFTEEN centuries ago St. Simeon Stylites lived for thirty years on a pillar, but he would have seen more had he lived for part of six years on the slopes of Mount Pilchuck, 5,334-foot peak of the Cascades, with Messrs. Higman and Larrison.

ONE of 1948's best-sellers has been certified a classic at Yale. Recently browbeaten into choosing another of those lists of the World's "Great" Books, the Yale faculty went to the polls and selected 191 titles, all of which are now on display in the University Library.

DOROTHY L. SAYERS, known to thousands as the inventor of Lord Peter Whimsey, is known to only hundreds, or perhaps tens, as a writer of deep religious conviction. "Creed or Chaos?" is a collection of articles and speeches, delivered during Britain's time of crisis, for which "inquiries" have been made, so that she has thought it "a good idea" to issue them handily under one cover.
SHANGHAI, Sunday, May 29 -This city was completely "liberated" at 9 A. M., Friday, according to an official announcement over the Communist radio last night.

I suppose that W. H. Lawence will be interested in the answer to his question, "Why Do They Confess?" * * * I discussed the same problems -- torture, promises, drugs and hypnosis -- in connection with the purge trials of 1937 in Moscow ("Self - Accusation," Tagebuch, Paris, Feb. 27, 1937) which aroused as much discussion as the Mindszenty and Bulgarian pastors' trials have aroused today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass. AFTER twenty-four years of separation, Harvard University is moving toward a reconciliation with Broadway. In memory of the late Prof. Theodore Spencer, action is already being taken to bring celebrities of the professional drama to Cambridge for lectures, and well- informed optimists see many other possibilities.

More labor furloughs and the failure of industry thus far to show any material spring recovery had a depressing effect on financial markets again last week. As a result, prices on the New York Stock Exchange continued to decline, touching new low levels since February before meeting support.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 28 -- The retail food price index from principal cities in the Twelfth District for the four weeks ending April 15 showed varying trends. Meat prices accounted for the greatest increase in prices, with gains ranging from 1.5 to 23.3 per cent.

TWICE in the history of America the people have had a chance on a large scale to prove their urge for creative recreation. The first instance was the popularity of the WPA community centers; the second was the response of GI's, under their Bill of Rights, to education in arts and crafts.

IN two Manhattan theatres and a rented studio a new and lavish musical is beginning to take shape. To the non-theatrical observer it seems at first to lack appreciable pattern, for the actors, singers and dancers, mostly in blue jeans and slacks, are rehearsing separately, some at the Music Box (dialogue), some at the New Amsterdam Roof (dancing), some at the studio (singing).

BIGGER and better peonies at this year's shows represent a triumph for enthusiastic hybridizers on both sides of the Atlantic. The huge, beautifully colored, vigorous and varied blooms are the results of a labor of love that began over one hundred years ago.
