WASHINGTON, May 28 -- An investigation covering "every aspect" of the country's domestic surface transportation system, including rates, wages and working conditions, was projected today by the chairman of a Senate subcommittee, Senator Francis J. Myers, Democrat, of Pennsylvania.

THIS book is composed of five lectures sponsored by the William W. Cook Foundation and delivered by the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of New Jersey at the University of Michigan. It is a rapid survey of the present state of the law, a consideration of the principal defects and causes of discontents, and practical suggestions for reforms and remedies.

PERHAPS it is due to her long eclipse as a united nation that Poland's arts and crafts are, with a few exceptions, little known outside her own borders. Many readers of this latest volume of the "Made in -- " series will be surprised at the richness and variety of her artistic traditions.

SOME of the correspondence that comes to this desk is difficult to answer satisfactorily. For example, a diligent student engaged in an erudite project asks for the "esthetic criteria" that control the criticisms printed in this Sunday pasture. He is beating his brains out on the philosophy of art.
CHICAGO. May 28 (AP) -- Today's report of the markets in the Union Stockyards by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:
We students at International House are deeply appreciative of Gertrude Samuels' " 'One World' Under One Roof." No one who has not actually lived here can understand the experience.

HAVANA, May 28 -- Confidence that the United Nations Economic Commission for Latin America, which convenes here tomorrow for its second session, will work out means for economic development of the Latin American countries was expressed today by Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations.

IMPERSONATION, when pulled out of the hat at the end of a mystery novel, is one of the lowest tricks in the business. (Never trust a character in an English novel who has been a member of the Oxford University Dramatic Society.)

Expressing belief that Mayor O'Dwyer will yield to the draft movement and run for re-election unless the Republican and fusion forces take early action to nominate a strong fusion ticket, Edward Rager, Republican City Councilman, sent yesterday a telegram to Thomas J. Curran, chairman of the New York County Republican Committee, to call a meeting of the committee.

THIS is the pleasantly satiric story of a wedding day in a small Virginia town, where the wealthy Lathrop family wield social power and where in the due course of events young Celia Lathrop, beautiful, spoiled and unhappy, grimly fulfills her duty as a bridesmaid.

WITH the end of May come not only the rare days of June but also the termination of Actors Equity contracts, symbolizing the official close of the 1948-49 theatre season on Broadway. Traditionally this has been the time, too, for a departmental glance over the shoulder at the record for the expiring term and a statistical summary thereof.

THOSE who explore the ensuing pages will find them marked by a certain ribaldry, even when they discuss topics commonly regarded as grave. I do not apologize for this, for life in the Republic has always seemed to me far more comic than serious.

Twenty - five hundred families living on West Ninety-sixth Street between Central Park West and Amsterdam Avenue were without water for two hours late yesterday as a result of a break in a four-inch feeder main.

WITH the revelation last week that for the second time since the opening of "South Pacific" Ezio Pinza had been unable to appear because of laryngitis, the Broadway rumor factory went to work on a twenty-four-hour shift.

BEIRUT, May 28 -- Reports from Damascus, Syria, said that Premier Husni Zayim still refused to consider any solution that did not entail the liberation of Syrian Captain Akram Tabbara and the three soldiers who came into Lebanese territory and murdered the Palestinian Arab political figure Kamel Hussein el Yussef.

RICHMOND, Va., May 28 -- Samuel Jackson Snead today came through to the quarter-final round of the Professional Golfers Association championship. He staged a rousing rally to beat a newcomer to the tournament, Dave Douglas of Wilmington, Del., by 1 up.

A wild pitch by Tom Casey with the bases loaded in the last of the eleventh allowed Fordham to register its first baseball victory over New York University in two years, the Rams winning, 5 -- 4, in a Metropolitan Conference battle yesterday at Fordham Field.

The Maritime Commission's approval of the construction subsidy application of the Mississippi Shipping Company, operators of the Delta Line, cleared the way last week for the building of a $14,000,000 combination passenger-cargo vessel. Invitations to bid are to be sent out in the near future.

MOST of the many books on writing published in the past half century have been too mercenary in outlook to raise our prose standards; or too idealistic to give practical aid to potential writers and speakers; or too patronizing or perfunctory to do anything for anybody wanting only to put together a few sentences and make sense.

David E. Lilienthal, 49, has had sixteen years as a high-level administrator -- one of the longest such records in Government. He has fought through many controversies. As director and later chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority he contended with private power interests and other critics of the New Deal.

Dr. Emanuel Neumann, outgoing president of the Zionist Organziation of America, in opening the business session of its fifty-second annual convention at Carnegie Hall last night, called on 2,000 delegates not to relinquish "the administration and management of American Zionist funds."

SINCE the four short stories by Mr. Maugham, which comprise "Quartet," all have been published before, what makes this book of special interest is the fact that, coupled with each story, is the screen play derived from it by R. C. Sherriff.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., May 28 -- What had been a procession of International Class sloops out on Long Island Sound today became a scramble with finishes by whiskers between them when a breeze shift and softening set in.

THE second annual show of the Boys' Athletic League's photography classes, representing ten of the league's centers throughout the city, opened last week at Bloomingdale's. It will continue through June 10. The theme of the show and contest, "Youth Looks at New York," produced a wide variety of interesting, some original, pictures by boys ranging from 13 to 21 years of age.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The Democratic leaders of Congress attempted last Tuesday to persuade the President to accept the realities of the prospect of his legislative program at this session and apparently thought they had done so when they spoke to reporters at the White House and the Capitol. But on Thursday Mr. Truman declined publicly to concede it.

Speaking in the name of all the Western nations at the Four-Power conference in Paris, Secretary Acheson has informed Soviet Russia that it can expect no further reparations from either Western Germany or a united Germany, and that as a condition of German unification it will have to surrender the bulk of the German industries it has seized in its own zone.
WORCESTER, Mass., May 28 -- Holy Cross gathered five unearned runs to defeat Columbia here today, 5 to 3, for its twelfth victory of the season.

One of the strongest impressions gathered at last week's steel meetings here was the indifference of executives of steel companies to the possibility of strikes this summer by the nation's coal miners and steel labor.

THE statement that even cookbooks are written for men nowadays, while there is practically no literature on childcare for fathers, is one we've been saving to accompany some comment on Dads -- notably a pithy little compilation called "Fathers Are Necessary."
STANTON, Del., May 28 (AP) -- The 32-day race meeting at Delaware Park got under way today as Royal Governor, owned by Mrs. Ester Dupont Weir of Wilmington, won the featured Wilmington Handicap.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- A former Polish Embassy military attache said today that a Communist spy network controlled by the Soviet Secret Police Chief stretches from Moscow through the United States.

Inauguration of international trade fairs in the United States to stimulate imports into this country and aid generally in expansion of world trade has now become a definite objective of United States Government officials concerned with foreign commerce.

FRANK CHESS was a "fiddlefoot," a drifter, and it was inevitable that he join Rhino Hulst in what seemed like a smart game wherein horses were bought cheap and resold at good prices as cavalry mounts. He had to impersonate an Army officer, but that was just part of the game -- a game that was easier to get into than to quit.
ITHACA, N. Y., May 28 -- The Harvard crew, pride of the East, gave Tom Bolles his long-awaited first varsity victory on Cayuga's waters today.

AMONG the many phases of television's growth and expansion as an entertainment and advertising medium, not the least interesting to contemplate is the contradictory attitudes which have developed among large corporations using video as a showcase for their products.
STAMFORD, Conn., May 28 -- Railroad station branch banking is catching on with Connecticut and Westchester County commuters.
MR. VIRSKI'S letter above illustrates, I think, my main objections to his book -- it is highly emotional, based on prejudice rather than fact, and replete with wild exaggerations.

PARIS, May 28 -- For the first time since the Council of Foreign Ministers was constituted to simplify the peacemaking task of the victorious great powers, the three Western members have begun a meeting confident not only in their cause and objectives but in the strength of their bargaining position.

FROM Rio de Janeiro comes word that Brazil's 3.80-cruzeiros stamp issued to commemorate President Dutra's visit to the United States is expected by philatelists to bring as high as fifteen cruzeiros in the open market because of the relatively small number printed. A correspondent explains:

ANNUALLY the American Academy of Arts and Letters, which is the inner sanctum of the National Institute of Arts and Letters, announces newly elected members of both bodies and recipients of the Institute's awards in art, literature and music.

BUENOS AIRES -- One of the most unusual jaunts out of Buenos Aires is a boat trip up the River Parana, which after five or six days can lead to almost anything, such as the great Falls of Iguazu (mightier than Niagara) or the capital of remote Paraguay (Asuncion), with its startling red soil and tropical flowers.

Tomorrow, at the first meeting in ten years of the International Congress on Rheumatic Diseases, 600 physicians will gather here to discuss the twin chronic diseases, arthritis and rheumatism. Hundreds of physicians attending the congress are from foreign countries: thirty each from Britain and Canada; ten each from Denmark, Norway, and Sweden; twelve from France and Belgium, five from Spain, and others from Turkey, New Zealand and a score of other countries.

Pre-holiday influences affected the course of retail trade last week, aiding some lines and retarding others. Department store volume ran well below a year ago, estimates putting the decline at about 14 per cent. The general average of food sales was reported down, with competition increasing.

Andy Stanfield and Horace Smith scored smashing double victories and three more meet records fell yesterday as Michigan State's powerful squad rolled smoothly to its expected team triumph in the seventy-third annual Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. outdoor track and field championships.

The majority of stores have benefited by modernizing, according to a national survey completed last week by John W. H. Evans, president of the Store Modernization Institute and managing director of the Store Modernization show to be held here June 19 to 24 at Grand Central Palace.

Some fifty large paper and pulp companies planning expenditure of $588,000,000 for new plant, expansion and equipment programs in the United States and Canada this year will also include extensive control instrumentation in these improvements.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., May 28 -Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, Republican, of Michigan, told members of the Inter-American Bar Association tonight that "momentous peace events" might "at this very moment" be on the "trestle board" of the four-power Foreign Ministers' Council in Paris.

High commendation is due Senator Humphrey for his fair and detailed appraisal of health insurance ("The Case for National Health Insurance''). Faced with a choice between the two, the observer must give preference to compulsory over voluntary insurance.

Your interesting picture gallery "Birds About Town," showing migratory birds that pass through the metropolitan area every spring contains one species that does not "belong" in this company. I refer to the herring gull.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (UP) -Congressional investigators had under study tonight an official paper believed to be a report on wartime losses of atomic documents by the Army.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 28 -- Princeton University's varsity baseball team dealt Dick Weber his first setback in eighteen intercollegiate starts, producing a surprise 5-3 victory over Rutgers on University Field today.
PARIS, May 28 (AP) -- Following is the text of the joint United States-French-British proposal for German unity submitted at today's session of the Council of Foreign Ministers:

PARIS, May 28 -- Georges Bidault was elected chairman of the Popular Republican party (MRP) at its congress today by a heavy vote that indicated the party had composed its differences and intended to remain behind the present middle-of-the-road coalition.

Shipping circles believe the possibility of a shipping strike on June 15 still looms large despite the fact that negotiations between Congress of Industrial Organizations-affiliated maritime unions and Atlantic and Gulf Coast ship-owners, although not particularly productive, nevertheless have proceeded on a most friendly basis.

KANDAHAR, Afghanistan, May 18 -- After driving more than 800 miles in Afghanistan, from the Khyber to Kabul, up into snowcapped spurs of the Hindu Kush, down to the blazing deserts of the south and on to the Pakistan border, the final, over-all impression is that here is a country that is making a gigantic forward leap in time, and needs help.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 28 -- Charles P. Taft of Cincinnati, Yale '18, a son of former President William Howard Taft, and until recently president of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America, is one of a number of prominent prospects for the presidency of Yale University, it was learned here today.

Andy Stanfield and Horace Smith scored smashing double victories and three more meet records fell yesterday as Michigan State's powerful squad rolled smoothly to its expected team triumph in the seventy-third annual Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. outdoor track and field championships.

The majority of stores have benefited by modernizing, according to a national survey completed last week by John W. H. Evans, president of the Store Modernization Institute and managing director of the Store Modernization show to be held here June 19 to 24 at Grand Central Palace.

Some fifty large paper and pulp companies planning expenditure of $588,000,000 for new plant, expansion and equipment programs in the United States and Canada this year will also include extensive control instrumentation in these improvements.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., May 28 -Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, Republican, of Michigan, told members of the Inter-American Bar Association tonight that "momentous peace events" might "at this very moment" be on the "trestle board" of the four-power Foreign Ministers' Council in Paris.

High commendation is due Senator Humphrey for his fair and detailed appraisal of health insurance ("The Case for National Health Insurance''). Faced with a choice between the two, the observer must give preference to compulsory over voluntary insurance.

PARIS, May 29 -- For Robert Schuman, French Foreign Minister, a proper solution of the German question would ipso facto offer a solution of the problem of the Soviet Union, he told the closing session of the Popular Republican Congress meeting in Strasbourg today.

RICHMOND, Va., May 29 -- Samuel Jackson Snead slammed his way past the genial Texan, Jimmy Demaret, and gained the semi-final round of the Professional Golfers Association championship over the Hermitage Country Club course today.

DETROIT, May 29 -- The Ford strike will have cost those directly affected more than $200,000,000 by the time production has been resumed in full, it was estimated tonight by union and company sources.
JERSEY CITY, N. J., May 29 (AP) -- Jersey City ran its winning streak to six straight today by taking both ends of a double header from the Newark Bears, 7 -- 5 and 4 -- 1, before a crowd of 8,035.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., May 29 -- Ninety-three suits of sails, one set to a craft, were out today in the second Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound regatta, that of the Douglaston Yacht Squadron over on Little Neck Bay. It was the largest number of craft so far this season.

PARIS, May 29 -- The Council of Foreign Ministers will begin the second week of its present session here tomorrow, probably by listening to further comments by Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky on the Western plan for German unity presented yesterday. Mr. Vishinsky was reported to have discussed the subject with Moscow by telephone today.

SHANGHAI, May 29 -- The Russians today closed their consulate in Communist Shanghai. "A new regime, which our Government does not officially recognize, has come to Shanghai; we are not remaining open," a Soviet spokesman said.

KEANSBURG, N. J., May 29 -- The body of one of two men missing since last night when their outboard motorboat capsized a half mile off the New Jersey shore in Raritan Bay, was washed ashore here late this afternoon. He was identified by police as Lloyd Dorer, 44 years old, an electrician, of 8 South Arlington Street, East Orange, N. J.
LONDON, May 29 -- Striking locomotive engineers and firemen brought most of the railway services in northeastern England to a standstill today for the second consecutive Sunday.

The Maud E. Warwick Fund for War Orphans, Inc., 551 Fifth Avenue, has awarded scholarships for 1949-50 to six students now in college and to one who will enter college next fall, it was announced yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 29 -- Westchester's new medical examiner system, established as a safeguard against undetected murders and unexplained suicides in this sprawling county of 448 square miles is taking shape rapidly under the guidance of Dr. David M. Spain, a 36-year-old scientist and professor from New York.

JAMESTOWN, N. Y., May 29 (AP) -- The gtate conference of the iNational Association for the Advance- I ment of Colored Peoples asked to-I day for a state-wide investigation: of discriminatory practices in! housing,

The Matson Line is preparing to return most of the crew of the Lurline to San Francisco by air from Honolulu, it was made known yesterday. This followed an exchange of cable messages between officials of the line and the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, CIO, on a proposal that the liner be released from involvement in the Honolulu waterfront strike, and a refusal by the union.

Every year on Memorial Day the 500-mile automobile race on the Indianapolis Speedway proves, among other things, that the traditional send-off -- "may the best man win" -- is a substantial over-generalization. It should be -- may the best man win, with the best car and the best mechanic.

VIENNA, May 29 -- Although a score of evidences speak for the eagerness of Russia and her satellites to resume trade with the West, Austria, which once depended chiefly on commerce with iron curtain countries, has become skeptical of their ability to pay for what they want.
Calls for peace were sounded yesterday in places high and humble as a prelude to the martial music that will do honor today to this nation's war dead.
PARIS, May 29 -- Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin has proposed to Secretary of State Dean Acheson that Four Power talks should be held to seek means of ending the Greek civil war.
BETHESDA, Md., May 29 -- W. A. Julian, Treasurer of the United States since 1933, was killed in a head-on automobile collision near this community today.

LONDON, May. 29 -- Moscow Radio reported today the publication of the tenth volume of Joseph V. Stalin's collected works in which the Soviet Premier "stresses the importance of the Soviet Union as the base of the world revolutionary movement."

Sandy beaches this season promise to show a captivating array of styles, with variety the keynote. Sun and sea bathers can be as frilly as they wish in suits touched up with ruffles and embroidery, or neatly clad for swimming in a one-piece maillot.

Arrested after a chase in which an alleged confederate exchanged shots with a patrolman and was wounded seriously, German Echevarria, 18 years old, of 51 Varet Street, Brooklyn, was arraigned yesterday in Brooklyn Week-end Court.

A total of 70 per cent of the members of the National Federation of Independent Business, Inc., have expressed disapproval of H. R. 4003, a bill to repeal the Miller-Tydings Fair Trade Law, it was announced over the week-end in Washington.
Five Bronx hitch-hikers, accused of stealing an automobile after attacking its occupants, were arrested yesterday on charges of assault and robbery.

Many leading American educators are concerned at the threat to academic freedom caused by the dismissal of college teachers because of their political activities. However, they are virtually unanimous in upholding the ouster of Communist party members from their faculties.

PARIS, May 29 -- The plan for a unified Germany sprung on Saturday's meeting of the Foreign Ministers was the first joint proposal the three Western Powers have ever made at an international conference. The United States, Great Britain and France spoke as one in offering definite suggestions for organizing Germany as a whole.
A large site for an industrial building in the Maspeth section of Queens and an estate in the Piping Rock section were involved in Long Island sales reported by brokers yesterday.

Unseasonably cool weather and intermittent light rain curbed holiday gaiety here again yesterday. It was the second successive day in the long Memorial Day weekend to be marred by dreary skies. Beach concessionaires looked glumly at huge stocks. It seemed unlikely that they would recoup today as the Weather Bureau forecast another chill twenty-four hours.

Jacob Perlow has added to his holdings of Manhattan realty by purchasing the five-story building at 52 West Twelfth Street from the Knickerbocker Properties in the first change of ownership for this house in thirty years.
Cairo, May 29 -- Discovery by Egypt that the barren sands of Arabia spout dollars has given new hope to the Americans in charge of United States trade to the Middle East.

The Chorus of Puerto Rico, under Augusto Rodriguez, gave its first New York concert last night at Carnegie Hall. Heard in a fascinating and carefully devised, program, the ensemble of forty mixed voices made an uncommonly deep impression, at once establishing itself as one of the foremost groups of its kind now before the public.

LUCERNE, Switzerland, May 29 -- The third annual technical conference of the International Air Transport Association closed in Burgenstock, near here tonight with a series of strong recommendations aiming to increase the reliability and cut the cost of scheduled air transport throughout the world.

BERLIN, May 29 -- German Communists will send a delegation to the meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers to present "just demands" of the People's Congress, Wilhelm Pieck, co-chairman of the Socialist Unity [Communist] party announced today.

CLEVELAND, May 29 (AP) -- Manager Lou Boudreau's pinch single with the bases loaded drove in the winning run in the eleventh inning today as the Cleveland Indians defeated the Chicago White Sox, 2 -- 1, in the second game of a double-header before 47,769.

Recalling Christ's "tender love of the human person," manifested in His miracles in behalf of the bodies as well as the souls of His contemporaries, Msgr. John S. Middleton, secretary of education for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, yesterday condemned "rigorism" as a "very dangerous philosophy which is spreading even among Catholics:"

The National Legion of Decency has placed the French-made feature film, "Devil in the Flesh" ("Le Diable Au Corps"), in its "Class C or Condemned" category, it was learned yesterday. According to the Roman Catholic reviewing group, the importation was condemned because "this picture in its theme and treatment presents immorally and indecently a sympathetic portrayal of illicit actions. A sordid and suggestive atmosphere pervades the film."
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 29 -- The entire editorial staff of fifteen of Sweden's leading Communist daily newspaper, the Stockholm Ny Dag (New Day), has been dismissed suddenly.

CARLSTADT, N. J., May 29 -- A veteran regatta pilot from Flushing L. I., Joseph Stager, dominated the twentieth annual spring regatta of the New Jersey Outboard Association on the Hackensack River that ushered in the metropolitan racing season here today.

SHANGHAI, May 29 -- The scope of the Nationalist debacle in the battle of Shanghai and in the "Dunkerque" evacuation that followed appeared to have increased today with a Communist estimate that 100,000 Nationalist troops had been captured or had defected.

CHICAGO, May 29 -- Business will emerge from the present readjustment in a healthier condition than if the war tempo had continued to a breaking point, Henry H. Heimann, executive manager of the National Association of Credit Men, said today in his organization's Monthly Review. He said trade leaders who had gone through a real depression were not taking a gloomy view of the trend.

ZURICH, May 29 -- Speaking in London on May 23, Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the board of the Chase National Bank, evoked deep concern among leading Swiss bankers by dissociating himself "from those Americans, if there be any such," who advocate early devaluation of sterling in terms of the dollar.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 29 -- Approximately 100 workers, fifty soldiers and several mine executives, including at least two from the United States, have been killed in fighting in the rich Patino tin mines, reports from the scene said tonight.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 29 -- Auto racing's biggest show, the annual 500-mile Indianapolis Speedway Classic, will get under way at noon (Eastern daylight time) tomorrow with a crack field of thirty-three drivers shooting for the record $185,000 in prize money.

TORONTO, May 29 -- Thirty-five countries will be represented at the Canadian International Trade Fair which will be officially opened here tomorrow by United States Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer. Mr. Sawyer will speak at an inaugural luncheon which will be attended by Canadian Trade Minister C. D. Howe, the president of the British Board of Trade J. Harold Wilson, and the heads of many foreign missions in this country.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., May 29 -- Wives of 178 married seniors at Lehigh University will receive certificates of recognition at the June 20 commencement exercises.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- The Battleship Missouri and nine destroyers will sail from Norfolk, Va., June 6 with about 1,200 midshipmen from the Naval Academy and reserve midshipmen from eight eastern colleges.
ST. LOUIS, May 29 (AP) -- Bob Muncrief came in to retire Eddie Kazak in the last of the ninth and stop a Cardinal rally, giving the Pittsburgh Pirates a 4-to-2 victory over St. Louis today.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., May 29 -- A suggestion that state education laws be enacted to compel children to spend at least one-half of their compulsory school period in the public schools was made here tonight by Prof. John L. Childs of Teachers College, Columbia University.

LONDON, May 28 -- The General Assembly of the Church of Scotland, which is meeting in Edinburgh, voted today to join other churches in a fight against communism. The committee on religious instruction of youth in Christian action declared that the challenge of communism affected the life and work of the whole church at home and abroad.

BOSTON, May 29 (AP) -- Paul Calvert, Washington right-hander, had his sinker ball working to perfection for seven innings today while hurling the Senators to a 10-4 victory over the Boston Red Sox, who dropped into third place. The Senators belted fourteen hits, including two-run homers by both Clyde Vollmer and Eddie Robinson.

The youngster stood back, cocked his head, then stepped forward and put another dab of red on the landscape he was painting. He was Kenneth Chapman, 14 years old, of 169-32 Twenty-third Avenue, Flushing, Queens, youngest exhibitor at the art festival of the Queens Botanical Garden Society held yesterday at the gardens in Flushing Meadow Park, Queens.

Secretary General Trygve Lie chose the opening meeting of the second session of the United Nations Economic Commission for Latin America to reveal the budgetary plans for carrying out the United Nations aspects of the Truman program of aid to underdeveloped areas.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 29 (AP) Aided by the former British star, Aidan Roark, the Tortugas polo club from the Argentine defeated the Golden Gate club 5 to 4 today. They thus won the series, two games to one.

BERLIN, May 29 -- An attempt to draw from the Western powers a more detailed formula for German unity than was contained in the proposals submitted to the Council of Foreign Ministers yesterday is expected by some British and United States diplomats before Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky flatly rejects the Western program.

The Rev. Daniel F. X. Corbett, associate director of the Jesuit Seminary and Mission Bureau, 51 East Eighty-third Street, celebrated a solemn high mass yesterday morning at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Francis Xavier, 30 West Sixteenth Street, to mark the coming departure of seven Jesuit missionaries to the Philippines.

HOUSTON, Tex., May 29 -- As some 1,000 delegates moved into this city for the opening tomorrow of the forty-fifth annual convention of the Advertising Federation of America, a twenty-five member delegation from Miami, Fla., announced its intentions to have the admen hold their 1950 convention in that Florida city.

The Board of Estimate has acted wisely, we believe, in voting $160,000 to continue the study leading to modernization of the city's zoning regulations. It would have been wasteful folly to halt or suspend this project in mid-stream, and disperse an experienced staff, after $167,000 had already been spent on a year's work.

BOSTON, May 29 (UP) -- Use of a new drug easily taken in tablet form has alleviated hay fever and other allergic conditions in more than 85 per cent of all patients tested, the Boston Dispensary said last night.

CHICAGO, May 29 -- July corn at its low point yesterday on the Board of Trade showed a decline of nearly 6 cents a bushel from the high of the week and sold at about 28 cents a bushel under the prevailing Government loan rate.

LONDON, May 29 -- Sir Hartley Shawcross, Attorney General of the Labor Government, referring to a speech by Winston Churchill, said tonight that the British Conservatives were re-introducing tactics they had used in the 1945 general election campaign, "tactics of the late Dr. Goebbels."

DETROIT, May 29 -- The twenty-four-day strike against the Ford Motor Company was ended formally tonight when an overwhelming majority of the workers voted to return to their jobs, leaving to arbitration the main issue in the "speed-up" protest walkout.

Most of the new pottery vases by Rose Krebs that Ernst Schwadron, Inc., 754 Madison Avenue, now has on exhibition are characterized by brown, tan and green glazes applied over a rough-textured surface. Some pieces, simple in shape, resemble primitive pottery; others, with the appearance of tree bark, make natural foils for fresh flowers or leaves.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., May 29 -- Trees, from the Adirondack Mountains to Morristown, N. J., are being attacked by the most extensive infestation of spring canker worms on record, according to Dr. C. H. Curran, curator of insects and spiders at the American Museum of Natural History.

Approximately half the luncheon patrons of Nino's Chez Jean order French pancake filled with chicken hash, a specialty of the house. But delicious as it is, it is not better than other dishes served there. Care and skill are evident throughout the table d'hote menu, both at noon and at the dinner hour.
Players and attractions to be presented in the summer theatres were listed yesterday by operators of the playhouses.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., May 29 -- The second annual Irish field day known as Aeridheacht was held here today. On the campus of Iona College 280 men and women from the metropolitan area participated in traditional Irish competitions.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., May 29 -- Concern for the future of the fishing industry in this, one of the oldest fishing ports in America, is mounting as a result of the recent publication and distribution of a State Department report on the "Effects of Foreign Competition on the United States Fishing Industry." The report declared that despite industry protests there was no need to curb the imports of fishery products into this country.

The Germans are still Nazis at heart; they have not learned anything nor have they forgotten the Hitler ideology, Dr. Hans Erich Fabian, member of the Supreme Court of Western Berlin, said yesterday on arrival here aboard the liner General Henry Taylor. He was one of 180 Jews on the ship, most of them displaced persons.

In your issue of May 23 you carry a letter by Miles Pennybacker, member of the Business Advisory Board of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, in which he deplores your advocacy of government economy and recommends instead increased government spending to be financed partly by increased taxes and partly by increasing the public debt.

AMSTERDAM, May 29 -- Complaints are being received from Indonesia that Indonesia in practice is prevented from large-scale buying of consumer and capital goods in the United States owing to adjournment of the Marshall Plan and other factors.

The Rev. Dr. Adam Clayton Powell Jr., pastor of the Abyssinian Baptist Church, 132 West 138th Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning that God's "availability" was not restricted to any person because of race or nationality.

BOSTON, May 29 -- The fate that overtook the Kelly, Crump and Hague machines in Chicago, Memphis and Jersey City is casting its shadow over this year's quadrennial drive to end the dynasty of James Michael Curley in Boston's City Hall.

To veteran Mediterranean travelers the cuisine, cocktails and service aboard the reconditioned liner Atlantic, which opened a new service from New York to Italy last week, will bring back memories of the luxurious liners Rex and Conte di Savoia, sunk during the war.

Members of New Stages have so much on their minds relating to the future policies of the group -- artistic and commercial -- that another meeting has been called for Thursday at their headquarters, 159 Bleecker Street, to go into those topics a bit more thoroughly.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- While Senate leaders still pondered the State Department's request of Friday to speed consideration of the North Atlantic treaty, it was learned today that department officials had given to the Senate every assurance that the pact involved no secret arrangements with any country.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (UP) -- Representative Walter Norblad, Republican of Oregon, today accused the Economic Cooperation Administration of buying canned fish from other countries while the Pacific Northwest salmon pack is going begging.

After backing and filling last week in generally slow trading, prices of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange ended with net losses of 3 to 15 points. In the preceding week the market recorded net changes ranging from a decline of 6 points to an advance of 12 points.

PRAGUE, May 29 -- A Czechoslovak delegation will begin negotiations with the British Board of Trade in London tomorrow on means by which Czechoslovakia can work off an unfavorable balance of 30,000,000 that has developed in her trade with Britain since the war on the settlement of British claims to compensation for the nationalized property and future of trade between the two countries generally.

LONDON, May 29 (UP) -- Police mounted a round-the-clock guard on stables housing favorites in Saturday's Derby as Scotland Yard threw out a nation-wide net for a ring alleged to have doped several horses at Epsom Downs and other tracks during the past three months.

The Rev. Kenneth Ripley Forbes, former rector of St. Andrew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Stamford, Conn., was guest preacher yesterday morning at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity, Clinton and Montague Streets, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- Senator Millard E. Tydings, Democrat, of Maryland, said today "it is more or less unimportant" whether the Air Force's big B-36 bomber or the Navy's Banshee jet fighter would come off best in a mock air battle.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Railroad managements and unions are deeply concerned over warnings by impartial sources of the danger of "a bad wash-out on the track ahead" that may derail the Railway Labor Act and lead to possible Congressional action.

The Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, in his morning sermon yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street, praised the action of sixteen United States Senators who on Friday introduced in the Senate a resolution "to give a spiritual interpretation to the North Atlantic pact."

BUCHAREST, Rumania, May 29 (AP) -- Scanteia, official newspaper of the Workers party, charged today the Most Rev. Gerald P. O'Hara, Bishop of Savannah-Atlanta, Ga., and Papal Regent to Rumania, had instructed Roman Catholic Bishops in Rumania to adopt "anti-democratic political activity."

PHILADELPHIA, May 29 -- The Giants snapped a four-game losing streak and bounced into a three-way tie for the National League lead today as they flattened Ed Sawyer's Phillies in both ends of a double-header.
MONTICELLO, N. Y., May 29 (UP) -- Two persons were killed in a four-car crash one mile north of here tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (UP) -- Defense Secretary Louis Johnson and his top military chiefs in speeches and statements today urged the nation to keep faith with its war dead by remaining so strong no enemy would dare start another war.

On July 1 the Columbia University School of Business will become a graduate school and its name will be changed to the Graduate School of Business of Columbia University, Dean Philip Young disclosed last week in an interview in the university offices. Expanded graduate programs include seminars and courses making fullest possible uses of New York business, financial and manufacturing facilities, Dean Young emphasized.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 29 -- Interrupting a week-end cruise, President Truman attended chapel with the graduating class of midshipmen at the United States Naval Academy here this morning to hear the baccalaureate sermon.

The "desired goal" of an era that was expected by some persons to follow World War II and be known as "the century of the common man," could not be reached without the aid of the "common man" himself, the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman declared in his morning sermon yesterday at Christ Church (Methodist), Sixtieth Street and Park Avenue.

In discussing the widespread failure of the political experts to foresee the victory of Mr. Truman at the polls last November, Mr. James Reston, diplomatic correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, wrote on Nov. 3:

LONDON, May 29 -- Britons who hoped for a decisive demonstration of English bridge superiority over the United States suffered a setback today. The American team of John Crawford, Peter Leventritt, Samuel Stayman and George Rapee met and defeated Dr. Sydney Lee's championship team by 6,000 points in a challenge match at the Hamilton Club.

The Rev. Dr. Samuel Trexler, former president of the United Lutheran Synod of New York, was honored last night at a service commemorating his fifty years in the ministry. The golden ordination anniversary service was held in the Evangelical Lutheran Church of the Holy Trinity, Central Park West and Sixty-fifth Street.
The usually conservative Connie Mack threw the book away yesterday before 41,099 fans at the Stadium and brought an abrupt end to the six-game winning streak of the Yankees.

NEWARK, N. J., May 29 (AP) -- Rookie hurler Geosa Heard missed pitching a perfect no-hit game by one strike today as the Houston Eagles topped the Philadelphia Stars, 1 -- 0, in the second game of a twin bill at Ruppert Stadium.

QUETTA, Baluchistan, May 18 -- Wild, dry, thinly populated Baluchistan is a semi-tribal, semi-provincial territory where the plains are more than a mile high. Law and order of a sort are kept by tribal levees and a special military organization, the Pakistan Frontier Corps, that includes what may be the last horse-mounted infantry in the world.

MOSCOW, May 29 -- American women are afraid to be caught in the rain because their dresses shrink so badly a child could hardly wear them and American men's suits must be worn most carefully because they fall apart like paper, according to "first-hand" impressions of life in the United States presented to readers of the magazine Znamya.
William A. Julian, who was killed in a motor mishap in Maryland yesterday, denounced the automobile in a shipboard interview thirteen years ago.
PARIS, May 29 -- To permit more general observances, Memorial Day was observed in Paris and throughout France today instead of tomorrow.

Harold R. Murdock has been appointed head of the paper and chemical department of Robert Co. Associates of Atlanta, architect and engineering concern. He was previously head of the pulp and paper industry in the forestry division of the Supreme Command of Allied Powers in Japan.
The keel for the British India Steam Navigation Company's new liner Kenya has been laid, it was announced yesterday by the Cunard White Star Line, general agents for the company in this country.

TOKYO, May 29 -- Japan's new constitution, written in English by Gen. Douglas MacArthur's Occupation headquarters and then translated into Japanese, is beginning to strain at the seams. Already some anomalies and contradictions have become evident and the Cabinet is considering forming a joint Diet committee to consider necessary amendments.

PARIS, May 29 (AP) -- Frank Parker of Los Angeles and Mrs. Margaret Osborne du Pont, Bellevue, Del., who won the singles championships in the French International Tennis Tournament, today gained shares in the doubles titles.
The Board of Transportation announced yesterday it had asked Board of Estimate permission to substitute buses for trolleys on the Myrtle-Court line, Brooklyn and Queens.

Jackie Robinson, whose status as clean-up hitter in the Brooklyn batting order survives all Burt Shotton switches, regardless of whom the opposition pitches, won another ball game for the Dodgers yesterday at Ebbets Field.

In answer to the Soviet program of returning Germany to the chaos of 1945, the Western representatives at the Four-Power Conference in Paris have now outlined their own program for the creation of a peaceful, united and democratic Germany fit to return to the comity of nations, but without the possibility of becoming a new menace to the world.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- The Senate, in its faltering economy drive, once again is demonstrating a familiar weakness that long has been recognized by students of government as a major obstacle to substantial reductions in Federal spending.
PATERSON, N. J., May 29 -- A "Plaza of Memories," patterned after New York University's Hall of Fame, will be dedicated tomorrow in Eastside Park here.

PITTSBURGH, May 29 -- Important progress for America and American industries is listed in the annual report of the Mellon Institute, issued yesterday. It is technical, of course, but the research work touches almost every phase of development.

MANHASSET, L. I., May 29 -- The annual horse show of the Oaks Hunt, held here today on the Greentree Polo Field, drew well over 450 entries, with keen competition through the day despite the biting cold. The hunter championship went to Miss Althea Knickerbocker with Victory Lad scoring 14 points to edge out Mrs. Lewis M. Gibbs' Halethrope with 13.
WASHINGTON, May 29 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls during the period May 21 to 27 are given in the appended tabulation:
ALBANY, N. Y., May 29 (AP) -- Mortgage debt on farms in New York State rose 3.2 per cent to $160,368,000 during 1948, the State Department of Agriculture reported today.

Accounts Galileo Corporation of America, Inc., North American distributor for Officine Galileo of Florence, Italy, manufacturer of Condor I 35mm. cameras, to the New York office of Wilson, Haight Welch, Inc.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 29 -- Because of the postponement of Metro - Goldwyn - Mayer's "Quo Vadis" until next year, Albert Lewin, who was to have gone to Italy as a supervisor of the project, instead will produce his own independent picture, "Pandora and the Flying Dutchman," either in the fall or early spring. James Mason and Ava Gardner will play the leading roles, and the picture will be distributed by Metro.
The City Department of Welfare has drawn up plans for the first work relief program in the metropolitan area since the depression, it became known last night.

NORTH PLAINFIELD, N. J., May 29 -- Champion Twin Ponds Belle, the Welsh terrier that got what amounted to the consolation award the day before at Morris and Essex, went to the top in a lesser but nevertheless important fixture today, the seventh one of the Plainfield Kennel Club.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Although President Truman said Thursday that Congress should stay in session until it finished its job, it was still thought likely today that there would be much "unfinished business" whenever adjournment comes.

LOS ANGELES, May 29 -- Inculcation of synthetic "emotions" into the present "electric brain" calculating machines is a quite conceivable future development, Dr. Norbert Wiener of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, declared today.

OAK RIDGE, Tenn., May 29 (AP) -- A group of scientists and engineers in this atomic-project city has expressed opposition to Government clearance for the Atomic Energy Commission's fellowship recipients.

The prospects for passage of the City Council bill to increase taxicab fares about 27 per cent are less favorable today than at any time since the measure was introduced on Oct. 14, 1948, it was learned last night. The bill is now dormant on the Council's calendar and admittedly cannot pass unless Mayor O'Dwyer gives it the "green light."

France and other European nations receiving American aid look forward to a brighter economic future than at any time since the end of the war, Jefferson Caffery, former United States Ambassador in Paris, said yesterday on arriving here on the liner America.

NOYACK, L. I., May 29 -- Two fishermen, who had put out in a rowboat from the north side of Peconic Bay, were drowned near here, on the south side of the bay, this afternoon. State police, who recovered the bodies, identified them as John Ruggiero, of 127-21 Ninety-fifth Avenue, Richmond Hill, Queens, and Walter Benkiert, of Forest Hills, Queens.

A contract for construction of the twenty-five mile concrete-lined East Delaware Tunnel extending from the Pepacton Reservoir at Downsville, N. Y., southeast to Lowes Corner on Rondout Reservoir will be let late in June, it was learned yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 29 -- Liquidation was on in the grain markets on the Board of Trade last week with wheat selling at a new low for a month and corn in the lowest ground since late last March. Without exception the new crop deliveries of grain are selling materially below the announced or prospective Government loans on the 1949 harvest, and cash grain is bringing well below parity.
Seven new films, including importations from England, France, Germany and Austria, are slated to open in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

Pound sterling showed a firm undertone last week, reversing the trend and canceling out the nervousness which had been hanging over the markets of the last month. Observers pointed to the fortnight declaration of a prominent New York banker, presently abroad, that he did not wish to associate himself with those Americans advocating sterling devaluation. This statement, supplemented by equally vigorous views of British spokesmen, proved the factor controlling the upturn.

Symbolic of the transition from war to peace in the land of Israel is the opening of the Hebrew University-Hadassah Medical School, the first in Palestine. The effects of war on this work of peace have not yet been blotted out, but the opening of the school, dedicated to the cause of human welfare irrespective of religion, race or nationality, is one more hopeful sign of the coming of peace to this troubled area.

Charged with being a fugitive from justice in New Jersey, Peter V. Mineo, 19 years old, of 94 Butler Street, Brooklyn, was held yesterday in $1,000 bail by Magistrate Joseph B. Glebocki in Brooklyn Felony Court yesterday for hearing Friday.

Eliahu Blath, Israeli Ambassador to the United States; Dr. Abba Hillel Silver, prominent Zionist leader, and other officials emphasized yesterday that Zionism must continue as a potent force on behalf of Israel and for the Jewish people throughout the world.

The shutdown of six big New York baking companies will go into its fourth month today, with indications that the ovens that normally produce 70 per cent of the city's supply of wrapped white bread may soon be warm again.

In an effort to bring mass pressure to bear upon the trial of eleven leaders of the Communist party on a charge of conspiracy to teach and advocate the overthrow of the government by violence, the party began wide distribution yesterday of the 25,000-word "statement" of William Z. Foster, its national chairman.
MOSCOW, May 29 -- A Soviet commentator declared today that the extension of the Bonn principles to Eastern Germany would "lead only to the widening of the springboard of preparations for a new war."
MOSCOW, May 29 (UP) -- The crew of the Russian whaling ship Slava reported from Odessa today that they made the first catch on record of a live baby sperm whale during a hunt in the Antarctic.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, May 29 -- The ninth Czechoslovak Communist party congress ended tonight with the re-election of President Klement Gottwald as chairman and of Rudolf Slansky as secretary general heading the seventy-nine-member Central Committee with thirty-two deputy members.

LONDON, May 29 -- The stock markets and indeed the city generally have experienced another gloomy week. From many quarters has come discouraging and disturbing news. It is not so much a question of standing up to current events but to what it is feared is coming in trade and politics.

The movement to draft Mayor O'Dwyer for renomination and re-election, which has been interrupted by the Memorial Day holiday, will be in full action tomorrow when the committee headed by John A. Coleman, former chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, opens headquarters in the Commodore Hotel.

Betty will soon hear wedding bells, but she will not see her bridal gown. Her sight was lost through an accident. Only after a teacher on the staff of one of New York's voluntary services for the blind told Betty that she, too, was sightless could Betty be persuaded to attend the agency's workshop.

Monday in the Spring Although it is contrary to established beliefs, growing old is any Monday morning in the spring. Tradition says that growing old is autumn's falling leaf or winter's cold, but that tradition ignores the facts of Monday in the spring.
HAVANA, May 29 -- The second session of the United Nations Economic Commission for Latin America opened here at 9 o'clock tonight in the House of Representatives.

ESSEX FELLS, N. J., May 29 -- Miss Beverly Hanson of Indio, Calif., provided the fireworks in the third and final round of the first annual women's Eastern 54-hole medal play championship today when she beat women's par by 2 strokes with a 37, 36 -- 73.

DETROIT, May 29 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers slammed out 14 hits as they beat the St. Louis Browns, 6 to 4, today to sweep their three-game series. Hoot Evers of the Tigers and Jerry Priddy of the Brownies each hit a two-run homer.

Deems Taylor's new work, "Music to My Ears," is the only book issued today. Mr. Taylor, music critic, composer and author of "Of Men and Music" and "The Well-Tempered Listener," has based his new book about composers and music on his series of radio talks at the Sunday afternoon concerts of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra. It is published by Simon Schuster and sells for $3.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce Lumber Survey Committee, a business men's group, reported that a slump has hit the lumber industry. A summary of its report, released today by Secretary of Commerce Sawyer, included these comments:

CHICAGO -- May 29 -- Lard prices were on the downgrade on the Board of Trade last week. Weakness in vegetable oils was the dominating influence and more than offset the effect of a rapid upturn in hogs to a new high in about two months.

PARIS, May 29 -- French industrial production dropped considerably in April, according to official statistics issued today. In March the steel output topped the record set in 1929 by reaching 825,000 tons, but in April it fell back to 751,000 tons, a decrease of 9 per cent.

Before a crowd of 15,000 which sat blissfully through a series of rain squalls and enjoyed every minute of the action despite the uncovered stands, the Belfast Celtics of Ireland defeated the Scottish international soccer team, 2 -- 0, at Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 29 (AP) -- After losing the opener of a doubleheader today with the Cincinnati Reds, 4 to 1, the Chicago Cubs captured the nightcap, 10 to 2, by exploding nine runs in the sixth inning to rout Herman Wehmeier.
WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- Fresh orange juice now can be kept tasty and healthful for two or more weeks by a new packing process, the Department of Agriculture said today.

BRISTOL, England, May 29 (Reuters) -- Striking dockers meeting here today affirmed that they were ready to return to work tomorrow, provided that they were not called upon to unload the Canadian steamer, Montreal City, which is involved in the Canadian seamen's dispute.
To deal with real life, religion must satisfy the desire for adventure as well as for safety, the Rev. Dr. Louis Pitt, visiting chaplain at Columbia University, declared yesterday afternoon.

With the Chinese Communist conquest of Shanghai the Soviet Union has given evidence once more that it proposes to pursue a policy of the strictest legalistic sort, at least for the time being, in its relations to China. On the ground that Shanghai had been taken over by a regime not recognized by the Soviet Union, the Soviet Consulate in Shanghai was promptly closed.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Europe, including Russia, stands a good chance of reaping a favorable grain crop this summer, although the yield will not be as heavy as last year's, the Department of Agriculture estimated today.

Despite an abbreviated holiday week, the local art season continues its pace with new group and one-man shows in the galleries. Today's openings include summer group exhibitions of work by artists associated with the respective galleries at Kraushaar's, Milch's, the Argent and, at the Artists Gallery, a selected retrospective exhibition illustrating the activities of that show place during the last three years.
CHICAGO, May 30 -- Norge division of Borg-Warner Corporation announced today price cuts of $10 to $40 on five models in its house-hold refrigerator line.

SHANGHAI, Tuesday, May 31 -- During the past few days the Chinese Communists here have shouldered the burdens of finance and big business on a scale dwarfing their previous activities in this field. They have taken over at least thirty-five textile mills and fifteen banks.

In reference to the letter of May 18 relative to the Youthbuilders program which appeared in your columns of May 25, I should like to quote, in its entirety, the most recent report submitted to any committee of the Board of Education by a member of the superintendent's staff.

A strong military program was urged yesterday by United States military leaders in Memorial Day messages at home and abroad. The day also brought prayers for world peace at services held in every community where there are American war dead and in thousands of bereaved homes.

The so-called deficit-averting plan of Representative Wilbur D. Mills, Democrat, of Arkansas, affecting corporate income-tax payments, is a "dangerous" and "deceptive" proposal, according to a report issued yesterday by the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York.

The city's rapid transit and surface lines have lost so many fare-paying passengers because of higher fares and free transfer privileges that they will not regain their 1947-48 passenger traffic levels until January, 1953, according to a study released yesterday by the Citizens Budget Commission.

Soviet Russia has delivered a double-barreled reply to the Western program for the unification of Germany on the basis of the Bonn Constitution and the Western Occupation Statute. At Paris, Foreign Minister Vishinsky has rejected the Western proposals in terms which permit little room for compromise, and has denounced them as contrary to the Yalta and Potsdam agreements, as violation of "democratic principles," and as an attempt to partition Germany and "sabotage" the Four-Power Conference.

The boys' apparel industry will adopt the measurement sizes for apparel developed by the National Bureau of Standards, it was announced over the week-end. Following the lead of the underwear industry which was the first to adopt sizing on the basis of actual body measurements, manufacturers will use standardized sizing on shirts, trousers, jackets and other boys' apparel.

I have been listening to commentators and reading editorials concerning the suicide of former Secretary of Defense Forrestal. I have been sick at heart that it required a tragedy to vocalize what our intelligent reporters and commentators have been saying since his death.

RICHMOND, Va., May 30 -- Sam Snead started a rally with a brilliant eagle 2 at the twenty-first hole that delighted a big Virginia gallery of well-wishers and snatched a 3-and-2 triumph today from Jim Ferrier, the Australian-born titleholder of 1947, to gain the final of the Professional Golfers Association championship for the third time.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, May 30 -- Following the conclusion of the Czechoslovak Communist party congress, a meeting of high ranking foreign delegates representing the Communist Information Bureau or broader group was believed under way somewhere in Czechoslovakia today.

CULVER, Ind., May 30 -- Culver Military Academy completed a major step in its current construction program this afternoon when the $150,000 Beason Hall was dedicated. Funds for the construction were provided by Ross Beason and the late Mrs. Beason of Los Angeles in memory of their son, Ross Jr., a 1939 Culver graduate who was killed in the war when his fighter plane crashed into the Tyrrhenian Sea near Naples.

Manufacturers of full fashioned hosiery should take measures to guard against retail promotions in which their product is featured as a loss leader, it was pointed out last week. Some trade spokesmen were critical of recent price cuts on branded lines which, they said, will not bring any increase in volume in the traditionally slow hosiery sales months of July and August.
LOS ANGELES, May 30 -- Progress in the fight against infantile paralysis was reported at the opening session of a convention of the Western Branch of the American Public Health Association.

Before a crowd of 53,053, largest gathering in the National League this year, the Giants and Dodgers battled for nearly six hours at the Polo Grounds yesterday and when the firing ceased neither of these arch foes nor the distant Braves were able to change the three way, first place tie with which the day had started.

BERLIN, May 30 -- Gerhart Eislet, who jumped bail after having been convicted of falsifying a State Department application and of contempt of Congress and fled from the United States, was elected today a member of the People's Council of the Soviet occupation zone of Germany.

LA PAZ, May 30 (AP) -- More mine officials were seized as hostages today by striking miners as labor troubles spread in Bolivia's tin-producing area high in the Andes. Two more mines and a railroad were reported shut down.
LONDON, May 30 -- The Ford Motor Company announced tonight that it had issued suspension notices to more than 1,000 employes who have adopted "go slow" methods since Wednesday.

A testimonial bronze plaque will be presented on June 13 by the Broadway Association to Lee Shubert, veteran showman, who operates a large string of legitimate playhouses, it was announced yesterday by T. J. McInerney, managing director of the association.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 30 -- Tanjug, official Yugoslav news agency, announced tonight that the Hungarian Government had ordered a Yugoslav reparations mission and a mission on the restitution of plundered property to leave Budapest not later than noon yesterday after an exchange of diplomatic notes in which the Hungarians virtually cancelled their reparations to Yugoslavia by unilateral action.
WASHINGTON, May 30 (U.P.) -- The farmer who grows tobacco is getting only about half as much money out of it as the Government's tax collectors, the Department of Agriculture reported today.

PRINCETON,, N. J., May 30 (AP) -- Prof. Henry De Wolf Smyth, head of the Princeton University physics department, took the oath of office today as newly appointed member of the Atomic Energy Commission.
Throughout the metropolitan area yesterday Americans stood in community gatherings, large and small, in tribute to the memory of the nation's fallen war heroes.

LOS ANGELES, May 30 -- A new type of "electric brain" calculating machine, capable not only of performing complex mathematical problems but even of translating foreign languages, is under construction here at the United States Bureau of Standards Laboratory at the University of California's Institute of Numerical Analysis.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 30 -- Paramount has signed a new five-year contract with Paulette Goddard under which the actress will make one picture annually, beginning in 1950. Her first assignment is not yet scheduled, according to the studio, although she previously had been announced to play opposite William Holden in "Beyond the Sunset," a western which Mel Epstein will produce and George Marshall will direct.
CHICAGO, May 30 -- Traffic deaths are already running ahead of the toll for last year, the National Safety Council reported today after a national survey covering the first third of 1949.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, May 30 (AP) -- A military court today convicted three former Rumanian officials -- one of them a general -- of high treason and sentenced them to serve up to twenty-five years in prison.

Applications for state unemployment insurance benefits will pass the half-million mark early in June, Industrial Commissioner Edward Corsi predicted yesterday. He based his forecast of a substantial increase over the present level of 468,000 claims on the opening of a new "benefit year" next Monday.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 30 -- The Northern Baptist Convention, representing 1,500,000 members, was called upon tonight at the opening of its annual meeting to raise its voice against "foes, strong, deeply entrenched, that array themselves against the church of the twentieth century."
MARTINSBURG, W. Va., May 30 -- Luck that passeth understanding is all that kept Martinsburg from entering six names on the roll of violent deaths over the Memorial Day week-end.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., May 30 -- Eight of the nation's top utility executives took the temperature of industry today and found it slightly below normal. Their thermometer was power production figures, one of the most sensitive measures of industrial health.
IRWINTON, Ga., May 30 -- A young Negro was taken from a jail cell in the sheriff's residence early today and shot and beaten to death. The lynching was the country's first this year.
Vulcan's Forge, whose specialty is rising to occasions, rose to one yesterday.

LONDON, May 30 -- Mass air exercises involving for the first time British, United States and Western Union air units from the Continent will be held here during the week starting June 25, the Air Ministry announced here today.

A uniform expiration date of June 30 for all contracts between the city's principal private bus lines and Michael J. Quill's Transport Workers Union, CIO, was fixed yesterday in an arbitration award settling a two-year-old dispute between the companies and the union.

Struck from behind by two men as he was questioning two others at 3:30 A. M. yesterday outside a closed bar at 46 Third Avenue, Brooklyn, a plainclothes patrolman captured two of his assailants after a short chase.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- David E. Lilienthal today accused Senator Bourke B. Hickenlooper, Republican, of Iowa, of a "calculated" attempt to arouse fears of an "approaching collapse" in the atomic bomb program with "vague, un-American" statements.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- A bill embodying a new approach to the problem of providing adequate health care for everybody has been prepared by a group of independent Republicans for introduction tomorrow in the House and Senate.
The trial of Alger Hiss, former State Department official, on perjury charges is scheduled to start today in the United States Court House in Foley Square.

Sponsors and processors of leading wet chlorination shrink-resistant processes have offered to guarantee to sweater manufacturers that wool treated by their methods will meet Army requirements for the high-neck sweater, it was announced over the week-end by the National Knitted Outerwear Association.

NANKING, May 29 -- The United States State Department has ordered the United States Consulate General in Mukden to close down after fruitless efforts to establish a de facto working relationship with the Chinese Communists in Manchuria.

Your editorial "Private Flying" in THE TIMES of May 23 is a useful contribution to the discussion of an increasingly important subject. However, one point needs to be set right in the minds of all concerned.

The hopes of the maritime industry for legislative assistance at this session of Congress rest on a bill scheduled to be introduced in the House today by Representative Schuyler O. Bland, chairman of the House Committee on the Merchant Marine and Fisheries, in the opinion of industry leaders here.

LONDON, May 30 -- An agreement was reached here today on a financial arrangement between Israel and Britain that will enable the new state to spend nearly 7,000,000 (about $28,000,000) in the sterling area during the next six months on the urgent needs of its immigration and colonization program.

DETROIT, May 30 -- Workers of the Ford Motor Company, the strike over, began returning to their jobs today. Meanwhile, representatives of the company and of the CIO United Automobile Workers scheduled a meeting for tomorrow to attempt to select an arbitrator to settle the main issue in a dispute that caused the twenty-five-day strike.

A plaque inscribed with the names of 166 Frenchmen, residents of the United States who died in action with French units in World War II, and twelve Americans, killed in service with the French Army prior to this country's entry into the war, was unveiled yesterday.

LONDON, May 30 -- Today was "gloomy Monday" in the stock markets here. The week-end railway strike, the dock strike and uncertainties about the Berlin situation gave the clue to professional "bears," while brokers found a few selling orders awaiting them but no buying inquiries.

BOSTON, May 30 (AP) -- Boston's Red Sox moved back into second place in the American League today by twice whipping the Philadelphia Athletics, 10 -- 2, in the opener and coming from behind for a 4-3 decision in the closing contest, which was decided by Ted Williams' homer.
An operating budget of $6,434,000 for the next fiscal year has been adopted for the New York University-Bellevue Medical Center, it was reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 30 -- David E. Lilienthal, whose direction of the Atomic Energy Commission is under Congressional attack, received the support today of the Federation of American Scientists.

Occupational disorders arising from overstrain, faulty working posture, work pressure, nervous tension, and wear and tear on the muscles of the skeletal system are often wrongly diagnosed as rheumatism and neurosis, two Norwegian physicians reported yesterday at the International Congress on Rheumatic Disease at a clinic session at the New York Hospital.

Senator Hickenlooper has announced that he will go today before the Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy, of which he is the ranking Republican member, to request an opportunity to produce proof of his charges of "incredible mismanagement" on the part of Mr. Lilienthal in his direction of the affairs of the Atomic Energy Commission.

Arthur M. Okun, a Columbia College senior, will receive the Albert Asher Green Memorial Prize, annually awarded to the student with the best record in scholarship at the college's Class Day exercises today at 10:30 A. M. on Columbia University's Van Amringe Quadrangle.

" It Pays to Be Ignorant," the Tom Howard travesty on quiz shows, will join the list of television attractions next week, having been signed as the summer replacement for Arthur Godfrey's "Talent Scouts" at 8:30 P. M. Mondays over CBS-TV.

WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP) -- The American Federation of Labor Teamsters Union said today its nationwide highway survey of the union status of truck drivers in April was so successful in planned similar checks in the dairy, bakery and beverage industries.

OCEAN CITY, N. J., May 30 -- Trying out for his first race of the year a newly rigged Gold Cup craft and engine, Joseph Van Blerck Jr., veteran regatta headliner of Freeport, L. I., today captured for the second straight year the John E. Fite Memorial marathon over a tricky forty-three-mile twisting course that began and finished off the Ocean City Yacht Club.
DETROIT, May 30 -- Dr. Neil E. Gordon, Professor of Chemistry at Wayne University, leaped to his death today from the twelfth floor of the Sheraton Hotel, where he had lived for several years.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., May 30 (AP) -- Richard R. Peppler, 47, automobile salesman, threatened with divorce, shot to death his heiress wife and a couple who tried to protect her early today. Then he killed himself with the shotgun he had used on his victims.

Plans are under way for the eighth edition of "Fashions of the Times," the annual show THE NEW YORK TIMES has held for seven consecutive years in Times Hall. The 1949 production will be a week later than last year's. The eight public showings will take place an the afternoons and evenings of Nov. 1, 2, 3 and 4.

SAN JUAN, P. R., May 30 -- Jose Ferrer in his greatest theatre triumphs never received a more moving tribute than came from 3,000 spectators at the University of Puerto Rico commencement this morning when Chancellor Jaime Benitez conferred an honorary degree of Doctor of Fine Arts upon the actor.

Repeating their performance on the occasion of their debut here, the Belfast Celtics played to a 3-3 tie against the Philadelphia Nationals, champions of the American Soccer League, in the first game of the double-header at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island, yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 30 -- The Yankees split their holiday double-header with the Senators today before an overflow gathering of 33,081, the season's largest crowd at Griffith Stadium.

The decline in magazine advertising support of the Advertising Council's economic system campaign will be more than offset by new material being prepared for newspapers and other media, a council spokesman declared over the week-end.

TORONTO, May 30 -- Canada's second International Trade Fair, which last year attacted 30,000 buyers from seventy-three countries, was informed here today by Secretary Sawyer that Detroit and Atlantic City were planning similar fairs next year.

The Whitney Museum of American Art, in the heart of Greenwich Village since its small beginnings in 1908, will leave its home at 10 West Eighth Street for a new and larger building to be erected in midtown, it was announced yesterday.

TORONTO, May 30 -- A United States Cabinet officer gave Russia and her satellites a broad hint today that they could get a chance to buy more of the United States goods they wanted by changing their ways.

Unusually cool weather kept the Memorial Day holiday crowds at beaches and other resorts in the metropolitan area generally smaller than had been anticipated yesterday and for the entire three-day week-end.

That news story the other day reading out of the headline, "Tests Don't Upset N. Y. U. Class as Students Write Own Questions," must have been scanned closely by many an exam-wise, skeptical eye. Several weeks ago it was Page 1 news that University of Michigan students were grading members of the faculty on teaching performance.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, which powerfully supported President Truman in the last election, rebuked the Democratic Congress today and demanded that its leaders abandon any notion of an early adjournment.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- The journalistic interview, like the abridged biography that has become known as a "profile," is one of the oldest press methods of conveying information to the public. Radio and television, though they have devised no improvements except those mechanically contributed by hearing and seeing the subject, have adopted the method.
ANNECY, France, May 30 (AP) -- Czechoslovakia said today United States export controls violated five articles of the 1947 Geneva tariff agreement.
WASHINGTON, May 30 (U.P.) -- The White House is keeping a wary eye on the new plan of Congress to lump all Government spending into a single appropriations bill next year.
MENLO PARK, N. J., May 30 -- The first unit of the new diagnostic center for New Jersey's State institutional administration will be in operation by October.
TORONTO, May 30 (AP) -- Brisk selling pressure of last week's session continued in today's market on the Toronto Stock Exchange as all groups dropped.

PHILADELPHIA, May 30 (AP) -- The Phillies and the Braves split a double-header today, the Phillies winning the nightcap by 6 -- 5 in ten innings after the Braves had won the opener, 7 -- 3, before a crowd of 21,933. Del Ennis tripled with one out in the extra inning and scored the deciding run of the second game on Andy Seminick's fly.

WASHINGTON, May 30 (UP) -- Coal operators said today they probably would ask the Government tomorrow to step into their wage contract dispute with John L. Lewis and his United Mine Workers. The dispute threatens a nation-wide strike when the current wage agreement expires on June 30.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 30 -- Utah wheat bought by the Army from the Commodity Credit Corporation to help feed the Japanese civilian population will be loaded on the liberty ship Henry Teller here next week, marking the first grain movement through the newly completed Islais Creek grain terminals.

Robert B. Blaikie, only Tammany leader to support Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. in his successful campaign for Congress earlier this month, has been ousted formally from the regular Democratic leadership of the Seventh Assembly District, it was learned yesterday.

Reorders for popular price summer dresses were so heavy here last week that some dress manufacturers had to refuse orders because they were temporarily oversold, according to reports on the New York apparel market prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.
The strike of 106,000 workers in the Ford Motor Company, in progress for twenty-four days, has now finally been terminated.

ARMONK, N. Y., May 30 -- The police waited impatiently in headquarters here today for Raymond Heath, 37 years old, a handyman on private estates, to surrender on charges of reckless driving and leaving the scene of an accident. Finally going to his home, they found him dead, a shotgun at his side.

Details of the prototype cargo vessel, to be known as the C-3-S-DX 1, were made public yesterday by the United States Maritime Commission. The vessel is being planned as a typical cargo carrier for use in future national emergencies, and bids for its construction, for which a $5,000,000 appropriation is available, have been invited from fifteen shipyards.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., May 30 -- Michael A. Stavitsky of Newark, N. J., was re-elected president of the American Association for Jewish Education at the closing session of the tenth annual convention here today.

A report from Washington has it that some members of the House Un-American Activities Committee are planning a "rebellion" against the "secrecy" and "inactivity" of the committee since its reorganization early this year. Particularly in respect to the charge of "secrecy," this is one of the most encouraging comments on the work of the committee that we have heard in some time.

LONDON, May 30 -- The British Government is undecided whether to follow the United States' lead in waiving reparations from Japan, Hector McNeil, Minister of State for Foreign Affairs, told the House of Commons today.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- Fleet Admiral William F. Halsey today sparked an otherwise reverently routine observance of Memorial Day in the national capital by raising his voice in the current controversy over the relative fighting merits of the Air Force's B-36 heavy bomber and the Navy's carrier planes.

The original address of Trofim D. Lysenko, which caused an international furor in the field of biology, will soon be available in English in book form. It is one of the sixty addresses by scientists included in "The Situation in Biological Science," a stenographic report of the session of the Lenin Academy of Agricultural Sciences, from July 31 to Aug. 7, 1948.

David N.
