Fields, named yesterday as president of the Association for Improvement of Mental Hospitals, charged that patients in mental institutions still failed to receive adequate care, because Governor Dewey had failed to ask the Legislature to appropriate sufficient funds for staffing the hospitals.

NEW DELHI, India, May 30 -- The results of a referendum scheduled in five French Indian colonies in June and December may be disregarded by the Indian Government unless the voting is held under acceptable conditions, a spokesman of the External Affairs Ministry said today.

CHICAGO, May 30 (AP) -- Two unearned runs on the error of Luke Appling, veteran shortstop, in the ninth inning let Detroit take the opener of a holiday double-header, 3 to 2, but the Chicago White Sox today tapped Hal Newhouser for a 2-to-1 victory in the nightcap behind the six-hit hurling of Lefty Bill Wight.

With the formal closing of Broadway's 1948-1949 season today, the summer theatre phase of activities will receive added impetus. Tonight the Olney (Md.) Theatre will swing open its doors with a two-week engagement of "Private Lives," starring Tallulah Bankhead.

LONDON, May 30 -- The United States bridge team of John Crawford, Peter Leventritt, Samuel Stayman and George Rapee faces an uphill battle in its last scheduled challenge match against a championship British team. Tonight the American players trail the Lyndhurst Club by 580 points at the halfway mark of a scheduled eighty-board match.

India has nearly recovered from the shock of partition and is rapidly becoming stabilized, Devadas Gandhi, youngest son of the late Mohandas K. Gandhi, said on his arrival at La Guardia airport yesterday from London.

NEWARK, N. J., May 30 (AP) -- Jersey City's six game winning streak was broken in the first game, 4 -- 2, but the Little Giants got an even break in their holiday double-header today by downing the Newark Bears in the nightcap, 8 -- 1.

NANKING, May 29 -- After one month of Communist occupation, the former capital of Nationalist China has settled down to an orderly and peaceful existence under a military control commission headed by the fabulous Gen. Liu Po-cheng.
It's hard to believe but it's true. Three million persons -- one out of every three in New York -- are served directly by the 423 agencies participating in the Greater New York Fund.

Application will be made on June 15 for further approval of the Board of Estimate of the nonprofit, cooperative Queensview Housing project. If such approval is forthcoming, indications are that groundbreaking for the apartment center will take place during the latter part of July or the first week in August, according to Louis H. Pink, Queensview president, in the project's offices at 362 Fifth Avenue.

Mrs. Marcella Dubreuil arrived from Miami yesterday for a reunion with five women substituting for the five who thirty years ago joined her in a pledge to meet every ten years on the northeast corner of Twenty-seventh Street and Broadway.

A mystery that the First Army believed it had solved -- what had happened to a soldier reported missing in action in France in 1944 -- became an enigma again yesterday when the returned veteran disappeared from his home at 17 Victory Boulevard, Tompkinsville, S. I.

Executives of Colonial Airlines moved baggage and did other unaccustomed tasks yesterday at La Guardia Airport, to keep holiday traffic moving after an early morning strike had been called by a group of 160 ground employes.
Columbia University and La Salle College each won two of the four eight-oared races in the Memorial Day Regatta of the New York Rowing Association on the Harlem River yesterday.

BRISTOL, England, May 30 -- Bristol dockers decided today to send delegates to the ports of London, Liverpool, Southampton and Leith to explain why they are on strike. They will make no request for sympathy strikes, but will allow dock workers in other ports to decide for themselves what action to take.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 30 (AP) -- Nothing is impossible for the Negro in America, the United Nations mediator for Palestine said today.

Columbia, behind the two-hit pitching of right-hander Bob Swanson, closed its home season at Baker Field yesterday by trouncing Fordham's nine, 12 -- 0. The victory broke the six-game losing streak of the Lions.

As the Zionist Organization of America closed its fifty-second annual convention yesterday at the Statler Hotel, dissolution of the Committee of Progressive Zionism was announced. This assurance of the settlement of internal conflict within the organization was hailed as "a happy augury for the entire Zionist movement in the United States."
RIVERHEAD, L. I., May 30 -- Two men are missing, and two men and two women had a narrow escape as a result of fishing mishaps in the waters off Suffolk County over the Memorial Day week-end.

PARIS, May 30 -- Soviet Foreign Minister Vishinsky's effort a week ago to get the Council of Foreign Ministers to agree on establishing peace-making machinery for Japan had no repercussions among the Western diplomats assembled here to search for a solution to the German problem.

RYE, N. Y., May 30 -- It was the fourth day of a dry nor'wester, a rare wind-blow out on Long Island Sound, and the third Yacht Racing Association series championship, held by the American Yacht Club this Memorial Day, had many tired sailors when they came ashore.

The session of the Japanese Diet that is scheduled to conclude today may properly be regarded in some respects as the most successful thus far under the occupation. Two measures of large consequence were adopted, the slash in the Japanese bureaucracy and the defining amendment of the labor law.

The assertion by the Federal Trade Commission that the "disappearance" through mergers of 2,450 companies from 1940 through 1947 indicates a serious weakening of competition was questioned over the week-end by the research department of the National Association of Manufacturers.

CLEVELAND, May 30 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians won their first double-header of the season and fifth game in last six starts by defeating the St. Louis Browns, 2 -- 1 and 5 -- 0, before 33,809 today.
LONDON, May 30 (Reuters) -- The New Zealand cricketers had a day of mixed fortune when they continued their match against Sussex at Hove today.

THE first customer to arrive outside the Polo Grounds for yesterday's double-header with the Dodgers was still rubbing the sleep out of his eyes when he waltzed up to the box office at 6:20 A. M. Perhaps he still was a trifle dizzy from looking at the standings, which showed the Giants, Braves and Brooks all locked in a three-way tie for the lead.

Summer afternoon gatherings on terrace or lawn call for cooling refreshments, but serving them at a spot far removed from the kitchen brings up new problems for a hostess. Much of the inconvenience of outdoor entertaining is removed by several ingenious aids new to the market this season.
WEST HILLS, L. I., May 30 -- A new movement is being organized to buy Walt Whitman's birthplace here to insure its preservation. It is the third such attempt in about thirty years.

A shower of vacation checks will descend on dress factories in the metropolitan area today. Business agents representing the Dress Joint Board of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, AFL, will visit shops employing 85,000 dressmakers to distribute $2,700,000 in vacation allowances.

DEVON, Pa., May 30 -- Wing Commander, a 6-year-old chestnut stallion from the Dodge Stables, Lexington, Ky., tonight retired the My Golden Dawn Challenge Trophy at the fifty-third annual Devon Horse Show and country fair.

ROME, May 30 -- The possibility that Msgr. Joseph Patrick Hurley, Bishop of St. Augustine, Fla., and at present Papal Nuncio in Belgrade, might leave his post was connected by Vatican circles today with the news that Msgr. Pietro Sigismondi had been sent to Yugoslavia to fill a position equal to that of a charge d'affaires.
PITTSBURGH, May 30 (AP) -- The National League tail-enders, Chicago and Pittsburgh, divided a double-header today before 38,089, the biggest Forbes Field crowd of the year.
TOKYO, Tuesday, May 31 -- One person died and a score were injured late last night as a mob of 1,500 Japanese protested proposed measures for control of public meetings and demonstrations.

PARIS, May 30 -- The Soviet Union flatly rejected the Western powers' proposal for German unity under the Bonn Constitution when the Council of Foreign Ministers met today. It did so, as Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky said, on the grounds that the proposal violated democratic principles and the Potsdam decisions and that the federal system of Bonn was aimed at dismembering Germany.

The crew of the J. M. Davis -- a 36-year-old vessel of the Pratt Steamship Company that foundered in the sea of bankruptcy -- is high and dry on the beach at Buenos Aires. The men apprehensively are watching the tide of inflation lap at the $2,500 average that each salvaged from the wreckage through a lawsuit against the concern.
BERLIN, May 30 -- With one dissenting vote the Russian-dominated People's Congress today adopted a constitution for the "German democratic republic" in Eastern Germany.

PARIS, May 30 - -Experts of the Marshall Plan Council deadlocked regarding the United States proposal for transferable and convertible credits under the European trade agreement, have decided to pass the problem to the steering committee of Cabinet members that will meet here June 3.

Transatlantic passengers on American Overseas planes have been noticing from time to time the last year and a half that some of the routine flight reports they received were in rhyme. These, it seems, were the products of Callan B. McNeely, navigator. He's got rhythm.

CAMDEN, N. J., May 30 (AP) -With the largest crowd of the season, 35,110, looking on, the Palatine Stable's Quiz Show zoomed to an exciting length triumph today at Garden State Park in the $10,000 added William Penn Stakes.

More than half of the net earnings of the national banks of the United States last year were retained in their capital structures after substantial transfers to reserves for bad debts, the American Bankers Association reported today.
HOUSTON, Tex., May 30 -- The Advertising Federation of America, holding its forty-fifth annual convention here, went through its first business sessions today.

Warner Brothers have scheduled an international sales convention to be held at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel from June 9 through 11. This will mark the company's first an nual sales meeting in three years. . . . The Selznick Releasing Organization has formed a new Canadian sales organization, Selznick Alliance, Ltd., in association with J. L. Smith and Ray Lewis of Alliance Films, Ltd.

BERLIN, May 30 -- United States Military Government officials said today that the Western powers were seeking additional guarantees of rail and road access to Berlin from the Western zones of Germany in negotiations with the Russians for a new trade pact between East and West Germany.

MONTREAL, May 30 (AP) -- The steady downward movement that started on the Montreal Stock Exchange last week continued today and 100 issues closed lower. Losses ranged as high as 4 1/2 points. Trading remained light. Mines also moved into lower ground.
WASHINGTON, May 30 -- Maj. Gen. William J. Donovan, wartime commander of the Office of Strategic Services, today vigorously opposed sending additional United States military aid to China.

ESTES PARK, Col., May 30 -- The United Packinghouse Workers, CIO, badly beaten in a ten-week strike against the major meat packers last year, reported today that it had successfully repelled raids by rival unions and had gone on to win organizing victories in twenty-six new plants.

PARIS, May 30 -- Trade relations between France and Switzerland, which were abruptly interrupted on May 1, will be resumed and talks will start on a new agreement soon. The first result of this understanding will be the introduction of the Swiss franc upon the French free exchange market here on Wednesday.
LONDON, May 30 -- Home Secretary Chuter Ede declared today that Eisler had "no justifiable claim for compensation against this country."

INDIANAPOLIS, May 30 -- Victory came sweet to Bill Holland, who won the 500-mile Memorial Day automobile classic today in the record time of four hours seven minutes 15.97 seconds, for in 1947 and 1948 he finished second in close finishes to Mauri Rose, and Mauri was the man he had to beat today.

I feel that something should be done about the situation in Central Park. Not only is there inadequate police protection, but where a parent has more than one child to watch during the day it is practically impossible not to suffer losses.

This is the second of three articles aiming to put the spotlight on some of the complicated processes required in the United States to move food from farm to table. The subject is dairy products made near and for New York. This column takes cheese from factory to kitchen; the third will report on ice cream.

LONDON, May 30 -- The American community in Britain, headed by United States Ambassador Lewis W. Douglas, paid reverent tribute today to the Americans who lost their lives in two world wars. For Mr. Douglas, who wore dark glasses, it was the first public appearance since he severely injured his left eye on April 4.

Work will start at once on the Bronx Zoo's Conservation Exhibit as a result of Governor Dewey's authorization of $275,000 for the basic construction, it was announced yesterday. The exhibit will show what New York is doing to protect living natural resources.

DAMASCUS, Syria, May 30 -- Premier Husini Zaym has formally abolished all political parties in Syria and announced that they would be tolerated again only when he had established a satisfactory "democratic" regime. A decree signed yesterday was made public only through a press conference late last night, but came as no surprise here.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 30 -- A plea for American strength and leadership to maintain world peace was made today by Gen. Lucius D. Clay, who retired recently as military governor of the United States zone of Germany.

The first major air training group from the Naval Air Station in Brooklyn left Floyd Bennett Field at 9:20 A. M. yesterday for Pensacola, Fla., to begin a two-week training period. Forty-seven planes carried the 229 Naval Reserve officers and enlisted men making the cruise.
WASHINGTON, May 30 -- Herbert Hoover believes that former Presidents might well hold advisory seats in the Senate, although he himself wishes no such office.

ST. LOUIS, May 30 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals took full advantage of ineffective work by Cincinnati pitchers to sweep a Memorial Day double-header, 8 to 6 and 9 to 2, before a crowd of 29,000. Howie Pollet stopped the Reds with five hits in the second game after the Cards had rallied to wipe out a five-run deficit in the opener.

PARIS, May 30 -- In preparation for the Council of Foreign Ministers' discussion of an Austrian peace treaty, the deputies of the Big Four Ministers met today with the limited objective of trying to write an agreed report for presentation to the Council.

Residences near the waterfront and seashore points on Long Island were involved in several sales reported yesterday. One of the transactions involved the home of Mrs. Elizabeth Pedian on Jefferson Boulevard, in Atlantic Beach, purchased by Julius Ames of Lawrence through John H. Reynolds and Leo Taub, brokers.

The Army Crafts Contest for members of the First Army Command has closed with the selection of six judges, it was announced yesterday by Army headquarters. The contest, which is being conducted on a world scale by the Department of the Army through its Special Services Division, will be judged finally in Washington.

MOSCOW, May 30 -- Russia today emphasized through a leading editorial in Pravda the active Soviet interest in a solution of the Greek crisis. The editorial called upon the United States to state plainly its reaction to a three-point Soviet program for ending the Greek civil war.

WASHINGTON, May 30 (UP) -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, may be the next top labor leader to end his holdout against signing a Taft-Hartley Law non-Communist affidavit.
TUSKEGEE, Ala., May 30 -- The killing of a Negro at Irwinton, Ga., today was the first incident of its kind in the United States this year, Tuskegee Institute said.
TEHERAN, Iran, May 23 -- The Iranian Government said "open sesame" and the great vault in the bank here unlocked to show nineteen visitors from America the state treasure.

Noel Coward, who arrived here last week after a sojourn in Jamaica, B. W. I., has written a new comedy, entitled "South Sea Bubble," which is scheduled for production on Broadway this fall by John C. Wilson. Gertrude Lawrence, who starred in a number of earlier Coward works, may have the lead in this one.
To a young out-of-town couple here for the Memorial Day weekend -- the Fialkows of Boston -- New York is "wonderful, fabulous, glamorous, beautiful, and any other adjectives you can think of."
PHILADELPHIA, May 31 (AP) -- The Braves scored the winning run in the ninth inning without a hit after overcoming a five-run deficit to defeat the Phillies 7 -- 6, today.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- John L. Lewis scathingly denounced coal operators and state mine safety officials today for eir alleged failure to comply voluntarily with recommendations of Federal mine inspectors designed to abate dangerous conditions in the coal pits.

BERLIN, May 31 -- The Soviet delegation to the Council of Foreign Ministers will make only "limited compromises" over Germany while husbanding its political forces in this country for the "decisive moment," according to Major Patent of the Soviet Army.

PARIS, May 31 -- The French National Assembly returned to the financial reform bill today in a more favorable mood as the advisory second house, the Council of the Republic, was debating a measure for the sale of gasoline, earlier removed from the bill.

Pointing out that summer, with its expected epidemics of infantile paralysis was "just around the corner," the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis issued yesterday a list of precautionary measures to be observed by those in charge of children.
OMAHA, May 31 (AP) -- A spectacular fire sweeping through a petroleum storage yard here tonight has destroyed more than 500,000 gallons of oil.
ALBANY, May 31 -- An exhibit depicting the history of "comics" during the last 20,000 years will be opened officially in the State Library next Monday by Acting Governor Joe R. Hanley.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 31 -- Andrei A. Gromyko, former Soviet representative to the United Nations, reported to Premier Stalin last Christmas that the American people did not want war, and that American economic help to the Soviet Union and the Soviet satellites would be available "once the political atmosphere cleared," the United Nations World reported today in its June issue.

The Appellate Division unanimously reversed yesterday the conviction of Broadway - Sheridan Arms, Inc., which operates an apartment house at 545 West 111th Street, and David B. Ancowitz, an officer, on charges of violating provisions of the Multiple Dwelling Law.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 851, against 1,729 last week and 920 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 143 arrivals yesterday, compared with 871 last Tuesday.

NANKING, May 30 -- When I called recently on a Communist official I had known in North China several years ago we talked cordially about "old times" and mutual friends as a secretary recorded our conversation in her stenographic notebook.

Eleven hundred production workers who had refused since May 19 to cross an office workers' picket line outside the I. Miller Sons, Inc., plant, 43-10 Twenty-third Street, Long Island City, Queens, returned to work yesterday.

BRISTOL, England, May 31 (Reuters) -- Pulled by tugs operated by the Dock Office Staff, the Canadian ship Gulfside, held up at Avonmouth docks near here by the Canadian Seamen's dispute, slipped out early today.

The board of directors of the American Radio Relay League, organization of amateur radio operators, has voted to oppose in toto the Federal Communications Commission's proposed new rules governing the amateurs, it was made known yesterday.
BUFFALO, N. Y., May 31 (AP) -- A state-financed educational program to convince industry that men past 40 make good employes was proposed today.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 31 (AP) -- The city commission voted today to set up a "buffer" zone between Negro and white residential sections on the west side of town. Three unoccupied houses bought by Negroes were dynamited in the area in March.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture today offered to pay 10 cents a bushel to farmers to store a surplus of upwards of 500,000,000 bushels of 1948-crop corn on their farms another year.

Hearings were begun yesterday to determine if a ticket broker charged with failing to keep his books in order should lose his license. The defendant was John T. Ahearn of the Ahearn Ticket Agency, 101 West Fifty-first Street.

MONTREAL, May 31 (AP) -- Owners of the six National Hockey League clubs today approved a seventy-game schedule for the 1949-50 season. Sixty games were played by each team in the regular schedule last year.

PARIS, May 31 -- At today's meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers the United States, Britain and France refused a Soviet request that the Council receive the delegation named yesterday by "the third Congress of the German People," which met in the Soviet zone of Germany under Soviet leadership.

PARIS, May 31 -- Yesterday and today Mr. Vishinsky answered the key question of the Foreign Ministers' Conference. The other delegates came to Paris mainly to find out what Moscow had in mind in asking for this meeting with the West and now they know its objectives were strictly limited.

The trustees of Sailors Snug Harbor, in an agreement reached with State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein, abandoned yesterday their plan to charge the aged and disabled seamen for their maintenance at the charitable institution's Staten Island home.
TRENTON, N. J., May 31 -- Four cases brought pickets to New Jersey's Capitol today.

TRENTON, N. J., May 31 -- Storage and transportation of inflammable liquids and dangerous chemicals would be closely supervised by the State Department of Labor and Industry under a legislative measure introduced today as a result of the Holland Tunnel truck explosion and fire May 13.

" The public interest demands a prison sentence for this woman," General Sessions Judge Jacob Gould Shurman declared yesterday in sentencing Mrs. Rachelle A. Knight, 44-year-old widow, to serve from one to two years in the State Prison for Women.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 31 (AP) -- Midshipman Lionel M. Noel, vice president of the graduating class, was named honor man at the Naval Academy today.

ALBANY, May 31 -- The attorney for the alleged "lonely hearts" killers took to the Court of Appeals today his attempt to have his clients tried in Michigan, which does not have capital punishment, instead of in New York, where they face possible death in the electric chair.

Supreme Court Justice James B. M. McNally yesterday signed an order requiring the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority to show cause on Friday at 10 A. M. why it should not be restrained from collecting increased tolls from motor carriers on the Triborough and Bronx-Whitestone bridges.
MONMOUTH BEACH, N. J., May 31 -- The Coast Guard is finding the amphibious DUKW (duck) an effective "Mercy Ship" in offshore rescue work along the North Atlantic coast.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- William C. Foster of Scarsdale, N. Y., was formally designated by President Truman today to be Deputy Economic Cooperation Administrator, succeeding Howard Bruce, whose resignation also was announced at the White House.
Brooklyn College finished its baseball season in grand style yesterday by trouncing Queens College, 6 -- 2, at the Brooklyn field.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The Democratic Congressional leaders, responding quickly to a rebuke from Philip Murray, assured him today that there would be no adjournment until much more had been accomplished on the Truman "Fair Deal" program.

Any kinship between a fluffy pie topping and an adhesive for sealing cork into bottle caps would seem non-existent. And yet a preparation so new that it is not yet in commercial production is useful alike as a pastry embellishment and a glue.
PITTSBURGH, May 31 (AP) -- Pennsylvania's mine safety law is "more rigid" than the Federal mine safety code, Richard Maize, the state's Secretary of Mines, said today.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (UP) -- The city of Chicago today asked the Supreme Court to reconsider its decision setting aside the disorderly conduct conviction of the Rev. Arthur W. Terminiello, self-styled "Father Coughlin of the South."

A Greek-born physician who became an American citizen in 1927 but who fought with the Greek Army in World War II charged in a suit filed in Federal Court yesterday that the State Department had denied him a passport permitting his return here because he had once served as provisional Mayor of the town where he was born.
ROME, May 31 -- The Italian Government declared late tonight it would support proposals for self-government and independence in the former Italian colonies in Africa.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The United States Circuit Court of Appeals ruled today that a strike at the Boeing Airplane Company Plant at Seattle last year was a violation of contract and law because the union failed to file a sixty-day termination notice as required by the Taft-Hartley Act.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today decided a Missouri Pacific Railroad fireman was entitled to $30,000 damages on a claim that he was disabled by occupational silicosis, a lung ailment.

Evidence in the fatal shooting early yesterday morning of a 22-year-old youth by an off-duty patrolman will be presented to the Kings County Grand Jury. District Attorney Miles F. McDonald announced yesterday.

Mrs. Shirley Spalter was sitting on the front porch of a two-story dwelling at 2845 West Twenty-third Street, Coney Island, about 2 P. M. yesterday when she saw her brother, Jack Lipstadt, 29 years old, with whom she had been talking, pitch forward on his face.

The statement of operations of R. H. Macy Co., Inc., mailed to stockholders yesterday showed an increase in sales for the fifty-two weeks ended on April 30, but a decline for the quarterly period from the volume reported a year ago.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 31 -- Frederick L. Roth, a soft-spoken, silver-haired man of 68, is not litigious but he looks forward eagerly to the day when some skeptical lawyer will shake a finger at him menacingly and demand to know "where were you at 9:23 P. M. Jan. 27, 1903?"
DETROIT, May 31 -- Negotiations on a new contract between the Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers, CIO, will begin Thursday afternoon, the company and the union announced today.

Preserving the fiscal stability of the United States should be the first concern of all real liberals today because all the social advances of the past depend on it, as does the freedom of Europe from Communist domination, Senator Irving M. Ives, New York Republican, said last night.

LONDON, May 31 -- Britain's reply to Poland's protest against the arrest of Gerhart Eisler, Communist fugitive from the United States, has been sent to Warsaw but its contents have not yet been published.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The thing that inpresses well-informed observers here about the Paris meeting of the Big Four Foreign Ministers is that the economic considerations that tend to unify Europe are beginning to make progress against the political considerations that have divided Europe since the end of the war.

SPRINGFIELD, N. J., May 31 -- Claude Harmon, Winged Foot professional and 1948 Master's open champion, and William Campbell, 6 foot 4 inch amateur of Huntington, W. Va., tied for medal honors with 142 in the 36-hole Metropolitan qualifying round for the National Open championship over the lower and upper courses of the Baltusrol Golf Club today.
A permanent injunction to prevent wiretapping in New York State was sought yesterday in Federal Court by the New York County Criminal Courts Bar Association and its president, Herman Hoffman.

Eight hundred adults who had completed courses in the city's evening elementary schools and special grade classes were graduated last night in a city-wide ceremony in the auditorium of the Central High School of Needle Trades, 225 West Twenty-fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Delos W. Rentzel, Administrator of Civil Aeronautics, predicted today that within five years air navigation aids would enable regular transport planes to take off with their landing space "reserved" at their destinations.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today temporarily halted a proposed increase of commutation fares by the Erie Railroad between New York City and various stations in New York and New Jersey.

LONDON -- May 31 -- The tone of the London stock markets generally was weak today with industrial issues sustaining small losses, although there was no pronounced selling pressure and most of them closed slightly above the lows.

Dr. Hermann Joseph Muller, winner of the Nobel Prize for research in zoology, and Charles E. Wilson, president of the General Motors Corporation, are among eleven persons who will receive honorary degrees from Columbia University at its 195th commencement today.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Officials of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation described today as "old" a suggestion by Jesse H. Jones, former chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, that the FDIC be allowed to suspend assessments on member banks so long as its capital funds remained above $1,000,000,000.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 31 -- The private utilities scored President Truman and a Cabinet member here today on the politically potent issue of public power and began a program that may alter the future of power distribution in the United States.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- A mysterious "written piece of paper" figured prominently today in a renewed effort by Speaker Sam Rayburn to find a formula for settling the dispute between the Federal government and the states of Texas, Louisiana and California over offshore oil deposits.

ROME, May 31 -- Roberto Tremelloni, Minister of Industry and Commerce, today assured the Italian Senate that United States aid to Italy under the European Recovery Program for 1949-50 would bring about further increase in Italian economic activity.

PITTSBURGH, May 31 (AP) -- It cost Bob Chesnes $300 today to learn Manager Billy Meyer was boss of the Pirates. The sophomore pitcher was fined that amount for "insubordination and display of temper."
HAMILTON, N. Y., May 31 (AP) -- Colgate University today announced the appointment of Howard N. Hartman as varsity basketball coach and Frank J. O'Hora as baseball mentor.

Although the holiday week-end was disappointing to many, due more to wind than to weather, the Long Island anglers had few complaints. Those who fished for mackerel on the Cholera Banks really hit the jackpot.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (UP) -- The Senate Appropriations Committee today approved an $859,000,000 money bill to help run the Government until June 30. The second deficiency bill of the current session, it carries $188,000,000 more than voted by the House, but is $56,000,000 below President Truman's request.

STANTON, Del., May 31 (AP) -- Mrs. Harry K. Hickey's Ocean Front, who recorded his last victory in 1948 at Delaware Park by beating Christiana stables' Camargo, turned the trick again in today's featured Caesar Rodney Purse.

The opening of the British-made historical drama, "Saraband," slated for this Saturday at the Little Carnegie, has been changed to Saturday, June 11, it was reported by the management . . . "Marked Girls," the French-made drama starring Viviane Romance, will not arrive at the Ambassador this Friday as previously announced by the management.
WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) -- The National Automobile Dealers' Association said today that auto makers are turning out heavy trucks faster than dealers are selling them.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 31 -- Dr. Jose G. Guerrero, vice president of the International Court of Justice, has agreed to a French request to name neutral observers to watch the plebiscites that are scheduled to determine the political future of five French colonies in India, it was learned today.

FRANKFORT, Germany, May 31 -- In a sudden burst of activity, the United States Military Government pressed today for the implementation of anti-trust policies and succeeded in forging an agreement with the British for the first sale of any of the I. G. Farben chemical trust properties.
WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) -- Col. Roscoe Turner, the veteran speed pilot, told Senators today the major airlines had made a "catspaw" of the Civil Aeronautics Board.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., May 31 -- Municipal employes here were requested today to submit affidavits to the new city commission detailing what, if any, campaign funds they had contributed to the Frank Hague organization in the Presidental election campaign of 1948 and the city commission campaign that ended May 10 in the defeat of the Hague regime.
SALT LAKE CITY, May 31 (UP) -- The country's oldest jurist has retired, but word of it came to light today only in a way that would tickle the keen sense of humor of 91-year-old Tillman D. Johnson.

TRIPOLI, Libya, May 31 (AP) -- The one-eyed Mufti of Libya says he would lead his more than 700,000 Moslem followers in a fight to death if the United Nations re-imposed Italian rule over Tripolitania.
WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) -- Attorney General Tom C. Clark today ordered a grand jury investigation of reports that there had been attempts to tamper with witnesses who testified against Harry Bridges.

LONDON, May 31 -- After playing more than 400 boards since its arrival in London on May 18, the United States bridge team of John Crawford, Peter Leventritt, Samuel Stayman and George Rapee approached the end of its last English challenge match tonight.
Versatility in cooking an egg "any style" won first honors yesterday for Ray Resseque, 14-year-old basketball star of the Madison Square Boys Club, in its annual cooking competition.

An alleged hold-up man was captured on West Forty-sixth Street near Ninth Avenue at 6:30 o'clock last night by Detective James Pritchard of the Manhattan West Squad when he saw two men fleeing past the barber shop at 646 Ninth Avenue, where he was getting a hiar-cut.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 31 (UP) -- The Bolivian Government tonight decreed general mobilization of all able-bodied male citizens from 19 to 50 years old to combat the labor and political unrest growing out of what the regime has described as revolutionary strikes.

A hundred pickets, carrying signs denouncing Great Britain for "dividing" and "enslaving" Ireland, marched yesterday outside the Empire State Building on Fifth Avenue at Thirty-fourth Street. The British Consulate General is in the building, but J. K. O'Donoghue, the consul, said he had received no communication from the pickets.
TOKYO, Wednesday, June 1 -- Japan's most productive post-war Diet session ended at midnight.
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The keel of the suspended 65,000-ton super aircraft carrier may be used to build the largest merchant ship in the world.

A letter from a Brooklyn correspondent, protesting against the proffered gift of an artificial ice-skating rink to be in Central Park, asks, "Hasn't the city enough rinks? Look in the Red Book and see how many." There are but two artificial rinks in Manhattan.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 31 -- The statement of Attorney General Clark was an aftermath of a visit paid to Mervyn Rathborne, former secretary-treasurer of the California CIO Council and a key witness in the Grand Jury investigation here, by two of Harry Bridges' lawyers.

LONDON, May 31 -- The increasing labor unrest, especially on Britain's state - owned railways, which is causing the Government grave concern, led today to the first major effort to assuage some of labor's wage claims.

It has often been said that mathematics is a language. This being so, those wonderful electronic calculators that multiply two 14-digit numbers together to give a 28-digit answer in a fiftieth of a second and handle a dozen simultaneous equations in a minute are ingenious chatterers.

TORONTO, May 31 -- Attendance at th esecond annual Canadian International Trade Fair was reported here today to have exceeded 11,000 visitors. During the second day of activities, exhibitors said more than half of the buyers here registered from Canadian companies compared with foreign concerns.

The usual holiday outflow of funds, together with an excess of bill purchases over redemptions, as well as the Treasury calls due last Thursday and Friday, combined to keep the money market tight yesterday. Federal funds were quoted at 1 7/16 per cent, the level prevailing since Thursday night.
LONDON, May 31 (AP) -- United States Ambassador Lewis Douglas and British public leaders praised Danny Kaye, stage and screen star, today at a luncheon in the Savoy Hotel.

Prices of stocks took the worst plunge in six months yesterday. The selling generated such force that quotations reached the lowest rates in more than a year as values gave way 1 to more than 3 points leaving the price average 2.19 points lower on the day.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) -- The Supreme Court ruled today that the Secretary of the Interior may include offshore lands in a reservation for the use of Karluk Indians of Alaska, but may not give them exclusive fishing rights in those areas.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 31 -- Robert Ryan will play the leading male role opposite Joan Fontaine in RKO's "Bed of Roses," the screen adaptation of Anne Parrish's 1928 novel "All Kneeling," it was learned today. The picture is scheduled for a late June start, with Nicholas Ray directing from a scenario by Charles Schnee and Edith Sommer.

SHANGHAI, May 31 -- The Military Control Commission moved yesterday to freeze all bank accounts and seal all safe deposit boxes and warehouses. Warehousing companies were told to submit inventories of what was stored in their buildings.

Highlights of the first fall fur collection of the season, viewed yesterday in the Ritter Brothers, Inc., presentation at the Hampshire House cottage, pointed toward the flaring-skirted fitted coat, the box coat, slim to the front with inverted pleat-back fullness, the tunic and dipping-back hemline jackets.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 31 -- A recommendation that the Northern Baptist Convention change its name to American Baptist Convention, as a means of perpetuating a designation used by its constituent societies since before the Baptists split on the slavery issue a century ago, was received late today by the annual meeting of Northern Baptists.

Lake Placid has been selected as the waterway for the long-projected plan of Guy Lombardo to try, in Henry J. Kaiser's new super - streamlined and super-powered speed boat, to lift the world record of 141.47 miles an hour.

Created to meet a war-time emergency and antedating statutory unification of the armed forces, the Armed Forces Medical Procurement Agency, whose headquarters are at 84 Sands Street, Brooklyn, is the prize exhibit of those who contend that substantial economies and increased operational efficiency can be achieved by merger of the components of the military establishment.

Orders for $5,500,000 worth of American steel mill and ore mining equipment will be placed in the United States by the Alpine Montangesellschaft, leading steel producer in Austria. it was reported here yesterday by Otwin Cuscoleca, vice president of the company.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 31 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission has reached the half-way mark in the reconstruction of the once sprawling utility empires of the country, but any thoughts that coupletion means the end of Holding Company Act administration is a misconception.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Congress should reduce its budget and be willing to take a 5 per cent cut in the pay of its members, Senator Millard E. Tydings, Democrat, of Maryland, told the Senate Committee on Expenditures in the Executive Departments today.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, May 31 -- "Any further efforts" at negotiation between the Roman Catholic Church and the state are "vain and hopeless," Archbishop Josef Beran has informed the Catholic clergy of Czechoslovakia.

BUENOS AIRES, May 31 -- After more than three months of negotiation, Britain and Argentina today announced an accord that would put their trade for the next five years on a basis of parity. In effect it writes finis to the historic triangle by which Argentina converted her surplus British pounds sterling into dollars for purchases in the United States.

A steady and general slowing down of collections in the drug field was listed among important trends yesterday in a report on credits and collections released to members of the National Wholesale Druggists Association.

LONDON, May 31 (AP) -- Galley Proof, a 100-to-1 shot, was withdrawn today from the English Derby, scheduled Saturday at Epsom Downs, reducing the field for the mile-and-a-half classic to thirty-three.

In comments from the bench at the Communist trial yesterday, Federal Judge Harold R. Medina said that if he let the Communists have their way. they would make the whole administration of justice in the United States look ridiculous.

BERLIN, May 31 -- Soviet zone officials tonight moved to end Berlin's eleven-day-old railroad strike by announcing that a settlement had been reached between the general directorate of German railways in the Eastern zone and railroad workers of FDGB, Russian-dominated trade union.

TRENTON, N. J., May 31 -- The New Jersey Legislature, in special session today, received fifty-six vetoed bills from Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll and took first action on his revised low-rent housing program.

What do they do on a rainy night in Mexico City? The best way to find out is to see for yourself. And the most enjoyable way to see for yourself is to enter the Greater New York Fund Vacation Contest and win a two-week vacation for two.

Some days ago in the columns immediately to the left it was observed that there are those who have birthdays at Christmas or the Fourth of July, but that the really fortunate folk have theirs in mid-May.

A crowd estimated by the police at 8,000 to 10,000 persons gathered at the American Export Lines' pier at West Forty-fourth Street yesterday to see off friends and relatives on the Italian liner Saturnia, which sailed at 12:20 P. M. with her largest list of the travel season -- 1,451 persons.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 31 -- Progress in world reconstruction and economic development in the last year has fallen short of optimistic expectations, David A. Morse, director general of the International Labor Organization, reported here today.

Mayor O'Dwyer gave further indications yesterday that he was not a candidate for re-election, as he spoke at a ceremony at City Hall Plaza in which medals for conspicuous acts of bravery were presented to twenty-five members of the Police Department.

Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation soon may set up the first radio manufacturing plant in Israel, Benjamin Abrams, president, revealed during a press conference yesterday. The project is still in the discussion stage and neither expenditure nor site has been decided upon yet, he said.

Eleventh hour efforts to avert a a strike by 3,000 food handlers in seventy-five New York and New Jersey warehouses were under way last night at the offices of the State Mediation Board, 270 Broadway.
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay, former United States Military Governor for Germany, retired today from the Army at the age of 52 after thirty-one years of military service.

New dramatic triumphs for the recently synthesized adrenal hormone that has enabled rheumatoid arthritis cripples to walk again, and even to run and dance jigs, were reported yesterday at the Seventh International Congress on Rheumatic Diseases in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

For outstanding work in their various fields, five newspaper men received George Polk Memorial Awards last night at the second annual dinner of the journalism department of Long Island University, held in the St. George Hotel, Brooklyn, and attended by 125 persons.
HAMBURG, Germany, May 31 (AP) -- Four United States consular employes were held by the Russians for more than twenty-four hours after a week-end holiday.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 31 -- The United Nations Subcommission on Freedom of Information and of the Press was urged today to focus its attention on examining the "adequacy of news" now available throughout the world.

LONDON, May 31 -- In the course of daily high level consultations between the British and United States Governments over Far Eastern policy the British Government has recently pressed the State Department for clarification of its attitude toward Formosa.

ESTES PARK, Col., May 31 -- The United Packinghouse Workers, CIO, will demand pensions and social security benefits besides wage increases from the meat packing industry, Ralph Helstein, union president, said in his keynote address at the organization's convention here.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) -- Sweeping new powers to control farm production were requested today by Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan, in laying a full draft of the Administration's farm program before Congress.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The State Department said today it was planned to continue consulates in operation in such Chinese cities as Peiping, Tientsin and Nanking, where unsatisfactory conditions such as had brought about the order to close the consulate at Mukden, Manchuria, have not developed.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) -- Federal construction subsidies for all United States merchant ships used in foreign trade were backed today by the Association of American Ship Owners and the American Legion.

Dr, Mario Einaudi, son of Luigi Einaudi, President of Italy, said yesterday he was convinced that the colonial empire, as such, was "obsolete," and that he did not think there should be "any outright return of her former colonies to Italy."

Responding to lower prices that manufacturers have set for children's and infants' wear, retailers are placing orders for upward of 50 per cent of their back-to-school requirements, it was learned yesterday at the fall showing of the Metropolitan Juvenile Style Mart.

Mary Margaret McBride walked to second base at the Yankee Stadium yesterday as a crowd of 40,000 women and a scattering of men cheered the woman whose informal radio talks in the last fifteen years have sold them on human rights and household products.

The Appellate Division yesterday, by a vote of three to two, ordered the release of Mrs. Marianne Lynch Teitelbaum from the Women's House of Detention, where she had been under arrest as the result of charges that she stole her four children by a prior marriage from the home of their father, Zoel N. Lynch of Coalings, Calif.

Lloyd Paul Stryker, counsel for Alger Hiss, moved for dismissal of a two-count perjury indictment against the 44-year-old former State Department official as his trial began yesterday in Room 318 of the United States Court House.
SINGAPORE, May 31 (AP) -- British officials moved today to thwart a Communist propaganda campaign aimed at Malaya by the Peiping radio.
Thank you for publishing the editorial entitled "The Schools and The Nation."

Philip Morris Co., in its fiscal year ended on March 31, had the largest sales and earnings in its history, according to the annual report of Alfred E. Lyon, board chairman, issued for publication today.
As a result of sluggish sales here last week, various retailers admitted yesterday that the "heaviest June close-out sales in ten years" may be seen before the month ends.

Coffee futures were mixed on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Prices held steady early in the day on scattered demand but drifted lower as demand dwindled. In a quiet day final prices in contract "S" were 2 points higher to 1 point lower.

IF the baseball season were a one-mile race, it would be eminently proper to describe the contestants as having reached the first quarter. It is much too early to venture any guess as to possible winners and only the St. Louis Browns have been lapped, definitely out of the running. The favored Boston Red Sox have sprinted into a contending position at long last and the Brooklyn Dodgers have started to move.

Two books by Albert Schweitzer, philosopher, theologian, musician, doctor and missionary, will be issued in honor of his first visit to America in July. Holt will reissue in July his autobiography, "Out of My Life and Thought," first published in 1933.

President Truman, in a message to the Zionist Organization of America, hailed its fifty-second annual convention, which just ended, and called on the general membership to support Israel so that it may become a "bastion of democracy."
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Sizable Government purchases of grain under the price-support program were reported in cumulative totals announced today by the Department of Agriculture.

Columbia University is definitely committed against a policy of "witch-hunting" but cannot allow infiltration into its faculty of persons ideologically pledged to destroy free institutions, Provost Albert C. Jacobs said yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 31 -- The International Refugee Organization, operating thirty ships and chartering scores of planes and trains, expects to resettle 342,500 displaced persons in the twelve-month period between July, 1949, and July, 1950.

Anthony V. Martino, the GI who had been given up for dead in France in 1944 and who turned up several weeks ago at a local Army recruiting station -- only to vanish again -- was located last night in the Commodore Hotel.

MELBOURNE, Australia, May 26 -- Militant tactics of Australian dock workers since the war, aided and abetted by seamen. are said to be making serious inroads upon Australia's overseas trade, according to shipping companies.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The Government introduced in Judith Coplon's espionage trial today twenty-eight papers purportedly found in her purse when the 28-year-old Government worker was arrested last March and accused of acting as a Communist espionage agent.

Much that is useful may be accomplished by the Highway Safety Conference which opens in Washington this morning. At the first conference held in 1946 Paul G. Hoffman, who has served so notably in the promotion of traffic safety, expressed the hope that the fatality rate of 6 per 100,000,000 vehicle-miles could be achieved.

A proposal to establish a new classification of residence use district under the city's zoning law to provide a "buffer" between choice residential districts and areas solidly built up with apartment houses will be the subject of a public hearing by the City Planning Commission at its meeting at City Hall today.

HAVANA, May 31 -- Economic development projects in Latin America must be practical and productive to obtain financing from the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, Richard H. Demuth, bank representative, told delegates to the Economic Commission for Latin America today.

A varied assembly of displays accompanied by demonstrations and lectures, intended to show the relationship between the fine arts and daily living at home, comprise the first annual Arts and Industry Show opening today at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

With the increasing interest shown by Americans in international affairs and in the plight of less-privileged peoples, this year's college and preparatory school graduate finds himself in a position to play an important part in building "not only a new world but one world," Porter McKeever, information director of the United States Mission to the United Nations, declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Registration statements covering more than $30,800,000 of new financing were filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by two companies.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The House Armed Service Committee unanimously voted today to start within a few days a complete study of this country's air-power program. It also de cided to ask the House for $50,000 for the inquiry as well as the power of subpoena for the investigators.

PARIS, May 31 -- The Soviet Union will propose free elections for all Berlin and the re-establishment of the four-power Kommandatura with a veto when the Council of Foreign Ministers begins its discussions on the future of the divided city, according to reports heard here tonight.

PLYMOUTH, N. H., May 31 (AP) -- Thomas A. Doxsee, 22 years old, of Fayetteville, N. Y., a Dartmouth College junior, went on trial before a Superior Court judge today on a charge of first-degree manslaughter in the death of a fellow-student in his dormitory room.

The "draft O'Dwyer" movement assumed substantial proportions yesterday. A formidable group of business and labor leaders met at the Commodore Hotel under the auspices of close friends and associates of the Mayor and announced they would seek a million signatures petitioning the Mayor to reconsider his decision not to run again.

Although the Four-Power conference in Paris seems to be running into a deadlock on major issues, its course thus far has revealed clearly that in contrast to previous meetings of this had the Western Powers are now in a stronger position than the Soviets, both morally and materially.

The Department of Commerce census of wholesale, retail and service business will go into full swing in Manhattan on Friday. From the top of the Empire State building to underground shops, 150 enumerators will visit 90,000 establishments in the greatest area of business concentration in the country.

Four men suspected of having operated extensively around the Times Square area as "celluloid strip" burglars, preying principally upon persons in the entertainment field, were arrested last night by two midtown detectives who had been observing them for five days.

Safe Arrival survived the merest bit of unpleasant sailing to get home first in the Cravat Classified Handicap, main attraction at Belmont Park yesterday. Opposing four others in the test for 3-year-olds and upward, Safe Arrival, owned by the King Ranch, registered by a length over Nathaniel of the Lazy-F-Ranch and in doing so provided a measure of satisfaction for the crowd of 17,548.

The Terminal System, operator of one of the largest fleet of taxicabs in the city, has declined to go along with Mayor O'Dwyer's insistence that drivers' commissions be increased as a condition to approving higher fare rates, Daniel G. Arnstein, president of the company, said yesterday.

FRANKFORT, Germany, May 31 (AP) -- West German political leaders today tentatively set Sunday, July 17, as the date for the election of their first government since the Nazi era. They planned to make the final cleeision Friday at Bonn.

RICHMOND, Va., May 31 -- They didn't have to play "Carry Me Back to Ole Virginny" today when they presented the P. G. A. championshop trophy that Ben Hogan, the convalescing Texan, could not defend, for Samuel Jackson Snead was on hand to receive it.
WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) -- Dr. Paul R. Hawley said today the Truman compulsory health insurance plan would be a "long leap into a welfare state" and might wreck the United States Treasury.
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Gen. Omar N. Bradley, Army Chief of Staff, appealed as a soldier today for military pay rises on the ground that "inferior inducements attract second-rate men."

Just one month before the opening date set for most children's summer camps, registrations are considerably below the figure for last year, Otto K. Rosahn, president of the New York section of the American Camping Association, said yesterday.
BERLIN, May 31 (AP) -- East German Communists threw a cloak of mystery today about their time-table for Eastern Germany.

ATLANTA, Ga., May 31 -- The Georgia Bureau of Investigation today joined the hunt for the lynchers of a Negro near Irwinton, Ga., and the Federal Bureau of Investigation in Atlanta disclosed it was making reports on the case to the Department of Justice in Washington.

The International Trade Organization, as outlined in the Havana Charter, "leaves much to be desired," and the immediate need is an instrument to negotiate reductions of trade barriers rather than a device to compel their elimination.

Freddie Haas Jr. of New Orleans and Dr. Cary Middlecoff of Memphis gave par a terrific whaling yesterday to lead sectional qualifying tests for the National Open tournament next week. The forty-ninth Open championship will be contested June 9-11 over the Medinah Country Club course near Chicago.

In ruling that the Board of Education of our city acted with full legal authority in refusing to subscribe to The Nation, Commissioner Spaulding has given reassurance to many sincere Americans who are working for the amelioration of inter-group relations.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- During collective bargaining, an employer may not lawfully, without consulting the union, give his employes a general pay increase larger than he offered the union, the Supreme Court ruled today.

Advertising Council material for the American Heritage campaign during the next nine months will center on five national holidays, beginning with the Fourth of July, it was announced yesterday. The additional occasions, on which newspaper and radio advertising will stress rights and duties of good citizens in order to raise citizenship standards, are: Labor Day, Thanksgiving, New Year's Day and Washington's Birthday.

PRAGUE, May 31 -- Gerhart Eisler, Communist leader who fled from the United States while under sentence, arrived here in a Czech airliner at 1:35 P. M. today. He declared he would stay here a few days, then probably to go to Poland and "eventually to Germany -- that's where I really want to go."

The undersigned charter members of the Fellowship of Reconciliation believe that the Senate should reject the North Atlantic Pact by proposing a positive program for peace as a substitute for it. We propose the following:
James Hill Jr., president of Sterling Drug, Inc., was elected yesterday to the additional office of the chairman of the board to succeed the late Edward S. Rogers.

BALBOA, C. Z., May 31 -- Two transport planes from the Caribbean Air Command left here early today for Bolivia. Officials said they had two more planes on "alert" status. Comment on the mission was declined, but it was presumed to be in connection with the possible evacuation of United States citizens threatened at the tin mines.

MOSCOW, May 31 -- After a week of cautious debate the Big Four Paris conference appeared today to be confronting frankly the basic issues on Germany in the dispute between the Western powers and the Soviet Union, Soviet dispatches to Moscow implied.

Turnover on the New York Stock Exchange dropped in May to the smallest total since February; it was also the dullest for a corresponding month since 1944. Sales crossed the million-share mark in only three sessions, the heaviest of which was 1,236,840 shares yesterday.
The Tufts Arena Theatre in Medford, Mass., which was among the theatres added to the summer roster yesterday, will present five plays.
It is wise for the United States to seek a common front with the Governments having interest in China in dealing with the Chinese Communists, especially about the recognition problem.

Chicago's Mayor is threatening to close down "The Respectful Prostitute" and "Hope Is the Thing With Feathers" on Saturday night, according to Lassor H. Grosberg, co-producer of the double bill with New Stages. By telephone from Chicago, Mr. Grosberg insisted that Mayor Kennelly sought to close the bill last night, but Sam Gerson, head of the Shubert theatrical interests there, had pleaded with him not to take such summary action.

Bound though he was by the limitations of his assignment, and hemmed in still further by the political and contractual hazards that dictate the transit fare. Edward Weinfeld as arbitrator has nevertheless brought in an award which should stabilize somewhat the labor relations on privately owned bus lines in New York City.

HOUSTON, Tex., May 31 -- In a busy session here today the Advertising Federation of America named "the advertising woman of the year" and elected the first ten individuals to advertising's "Hall of Fame."
The home run, a formidable weapon in anybody's hands, also can operate like a two-edged blade, and the Giants made that painful discovery about half an hour after midnight this morning.

CHICAGO, May 31 -- Prices of wheat futures suffered a sharp decline today, heavy and general long liquidation being accelerated by a further slump in cash wheat prices at Kansas City and by heavy and general rains throughout Western Canada.

Swelled by the largest offering of state and municipal bonds in more than a year, flotations of new bonds in May totaling $372,646,000 for fifty issues were the largest for a May since 1946. The total compared with $364,113,000 for forty-four issues in the preceding month and $354,383,000 for forty-two issues in May, 1948.
WASHINGTON, May 31 (UP) -- President Truman's Highway Safety Conference was told today that motor vehicles were "four times the killers after dark" than in daylight.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned easier yesteday in sympathy with the break in stocks and the weakness in grains, and closed 21 to 33 points net lower on the day.

DETROIT, May 31 (AP) -- Four thousand law enforcement officers bore down tonight on every known gambling den, hoodlum hangout and subversive headquarters in Wayne County (Detroit) in a renewed hunt for the would-be killer of Victor Reuther, director of education for the United Automobile Workers, CIO.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy gave full authority to Senator Bourke B. Hickenlooper today to develop his case against David E. Lilienthal at "confrontation" hearings beginning tomorrow.

LONDON, June 1 -- In preparation for a general election the annual conference of the British Labor party, meeting in Blackpool next week, will devote nearly half of its time to discussing its election platform, party headquarters announced today.
The meat that consumers have found hardest to select is veal. Because a new method of grading it by the Federal Government makes the job easier, it should interest all homemakers.

LONDON, June 1 -- In a declaration of the British Government's policy for the future of Jerusalem, the Lord Chancellor, Viscount Jowitt, said today that it favored placing the whole area under international control.
CHICAGO, June 1 (AP) -- Reasons for a shortage of equity capital were summarized in two sentences today by Robert Wilson, chairman of the Standard Oil Company of Indiana. They were:

The Hatteras prophecy concerning bluefish seems to be proving out, for blues scaling up to 2 1/2 pounds are being taken in small numbers at Fire Island Inlet, well in advance of the usual arrival date for these fish.

After a two-hour closed deportation hearing on Ellis Island yesterday, Ralph Farb, presiding inspector of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, recommended that Mrs. Gerhart Eisler be deported to Poland. The recommendation will be forwarded to Washington for final decision.
Edward J. Flynn, Bronx Democratic leader and National Committeeman, gave approval yesterday to the movement to draft Mayor O'Dwyer for a second term.

A proposed city tax of 2 per cent on sales of containers and packing materials appeared doomed yesterday after the finance committee of the City Council heard it condemned by spokesmen for seventy-seven business and civic organizations.

PARIS, June 1 -- After an all-night sitting, the National Assembly was preparing tomorrow to over-ride the Council of the Republic which rejected the Assembly's project for the sale of gasoline. The Assembly also was expected to complete the reading of the financial reforms.

Views were sharply divided yesterday on the question of Government action to provide dollar exchange transfer insurance for American exporters at the meeting of the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau at the Statler Hotel.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., June 1 -- The fabulous strong-room in the Mayor's office at City Hall, for years one of the most closely guarded secrets of the hierarchy of the Hague machine, was unveiled today by the new administration.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- An Administration bill to authorize construction of the St. Lawrence seaway and power project, one of the oldest controversies before Congress, was introduced today by Senator Scott W. Lucas of Illinois, Democratic Senate leader.

The first successful tests on human subjects with a new synthetic chemical compound that prevents the formation of dangerous blood clots in heart and vascular conditions was reported last night at the New York Academy of Medicine.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) -- A jingle penned by a German was the basis of many rumors that United States soldiers were brutal toward Germans accused of war crimes, Senate investigators were told today.

Supporting bids enabled prices on the New York Stock Exchange to react more favorably yesterday but only after reaching new low ground in the early trading. While fractional losses predominated at the close, the morning losses of 1 to 2 points were substantially reduced and eliminated in some instances.

William F. Ladd, 63 - year - old former New York Stock Exchange member and sportsman, died yesterday morning in his apartment at 45 Tiemann Place of self-inflicted pistol wounds of the head suffered on April 16 in his Palm Beach home, according to a report by Dr. Eugene Clark, an assistant medical examiner.
Stetson K. Ryan, executive secretary of the State Board of Education of the Blind of Hartford, Conn., received yesterday the Migel Medal of the American Foundation for the Blind.

Although the local premiere of "Miss Liberty," the Irving Berlin-Robert E. Sherwood-Moss Hart musical, is more than a month away, the mail order sale of seats has already approached $200,000, Mr. Berlin reported yesterday. The box-office at the Imperial, where the attraction will open on July 7, has been flooded with 17,225 applications for tickets.

New York real estate and special franchises will be taxed for the coming fiscal year on an aggregate valuation of $18,112,231,179 -- a rise of $527,738,966 over the current figure -- according to final assessment lists for 1949-50 submitted to Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday by William E. Boyland, president of the Tax Commission.

ZURICH, Switzerland, June 1 (AP) -- The world's silk manufacturers, for the first time in history, have reached agreement on a universal system for testing the quality of silk, H. Lee Moss, secretary of the American Silk Council, said today.

With all the talk of inflation and deflation, the market analyst of one brokerage house feels that the nation is really going through "a major lull in a basic long-term inflation" which started at the time of the war and which, conceivably, may well spread itself, first in the price of goods.

LONDON, June 1 -- The United States bridge team of John Crawford, Peter Leventritt, Samuel Stayman and George Rapee met its first sizable defeat last night since its arrival in Britain on May 17. Playing slowly and laboriously and obviously showing the strain of the prolonged competition, the United States team went down in defeat to the British Lyndhurst Club team.

MELBOURNE, Australia, May 27 -- Strikes among seamen and waterside workers, shortage of labor in ports and inadequate cargo-handling equipment in some ports are delaying overseas ships in Australian harbors to such an extent that one authority declares them to be spending three times as much time there as before the war.

Rudolf Bing, artistic director of the Edinburgh Festival and general manager of the Glyndebourne Opera Company in England, will become head of the managerial direction of the Metropolitan Opera on June 1, 1950. He will succeed Edward Johnson, general manager since 1935, who is retiring at his own request.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) -- The General Motors Corporation led its competitors last year in payments to key executives, reports by nine major automobile manufacturers to the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed today.
PHILADELPHIA, June 1 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Eagles reported today that they have banned television of home football games in order to bring more fans to Shibe Park.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Oscar R. Ewing, Federal Security Administrator, tonight called the new health insurance bill introduced in Congress yesterday by a Republican group "merely an effort to patch up the acknowledged deficiencies of the voluntary method."

PARIS, June 1 -- Representatives of the Western powers have extended the scope of the informal discussions taking place outside the Council of Foreign Ministers to include China and Greece, but on neither subject has an agreed line of action been decided upon.

In an expansion move, the East Brooklyn Savings Bank, of which Leo M. O'Neil is president, has acquired title to the vacant plot of 80 by 100 feet at the southeast corner of Avenue U and East Seventeenth Street, in Brooklyn, from a client of George P. Kennedy, the broker in the transaction.

The Seafarers International Union, AFL, is determined to carry out its threatened boycott of British-flag shipping and will do so unless "swift measures" are taken by the British dock workers to free ships under contract to the Canadian division of the union, it was asserted yesterday by Paul Hall and Morris Weisberger, officials of the organization and co-chairmen of the New York AFL Maritime Trades Council.

On the opening day yesterday of the Congressional investigation into the affairs of the Atomic Energy Commission, Senator Hickenlooper insisted that the grave charges he has made "go solely and entirely to the question of the administrative competency of Mr. Lilienthal as chairman of the AEC."

PHILADELPHIA, June 1 (AP) -- The much sought-after welterweight title fight between champion Sugar Ray Robinson and Cuba's Kid Gavilan today was signed for Philadelphia's Municipal Stadium on July 11.

Negotiations between East and Gulf Coast ship operators and the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, CIO, were adjourned yesterday afternoon with no date set for another meeting. The present contract expires June 15.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The Military Air Transport Service, combining Navy and Air Force airlift, celebrated its first anniversary at near-by Andrews Air Force Base today by frightening 200 aviation writers, here for the annual meeting of their association.

LAKE SUCCESS, June 1 -- Brig. Gen. William E. Riley, Chief of Staff for Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, the United Nations Acting Mediator for Palestine, left by air for Damascus, Syria, tonight with a final proposal for an armistice between Israel and Syria.

A group led by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., were successful bidders for bond issues totaling $11,250,000 offered by Boston, Mass., yesterday. For $8,750,000 worth of bonds in Lot 1, the group bid an interest cost of 2.1585 on securities maturing from June 1, 1950 to 1979, for 1 3/4 s, 2s and 2 1/4 s.
The Kreisel Company, 681 Fifth Avenue, has announced that Edward Dunay and Arthur Serkin have joined its management department.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Congressional efforts to avoid spending deficits and tax increases by directing the President to slice 5 to 10 per cent from appropriations for the approaching fiscal year got a jolt from Administration quarters today.

ESTES PARK, Col., June 1 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, who has been conducting a drive against Communists and other left-wingers in CIO international unions, today in effect endorsed the United Packinghouse Workers' middle-of-the-road course.
WEST POINT, N. Y., June 1 -- double to right-center field with two out in the ninth gave N. Y. U. a 3 to 2 victory over Army at Doubleday Field today.
CLEVELAND, June 1 (AP) -- Mickey Harris of the Red Sox pitched himself in and out of trouble tonight and finally beat the Indians and Bob Feller, 3 to 1.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 1 -- Delegates to the annual meeting of the Northern Baptist Convention demanded today, after debate, that a larger proportion of the demonination's budget for 1950-51 be allotted to work in foreign mission fields.

A new organization, known as Freedoms Foundation, Inc., has been incorporated under New York State charter for the purpose of making annual awards for outstanding contributions to a better understanding of the American way of life, it was learned yesterday.

In his first address as president of Columbia University General Eisenhower delivered yesterday a stirring reaffirmation of faith in the individual as a free man. It was a message needed in our time, when so many voices are crying for increased reliance on the state.

Gen. Lucius D. Clay, former military governor of Germany, warned yesterday that while the Paris Conference of the Council of Foreign Ministers might yield hope for a solution of the prob lem of Germany, the struggle between collectivism and democracy would continue "for years to come."

WASHINGTON, June 1 (UP) -- Great Britain and the Bahamas government have agreed to let the United States build radar tracking stations in the islands as part of its Florida-based, 3,000-mile test range for guided missiles, it was announced today.

Walter F. Downey, regional director of the War Assets Administration, announced yesterday the award of title to the 722-acre Plattsburg, N. Y., barracks to the State of New York for use as a state college.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- A bill to permit manufacturers to absorb freight rates and quote delivered prices provided they are "acting independently" was rammed through the Senate this afternoon by a unanimous voice vote.

Formation of a National Committee for Free Europe, Inc., the main purpose of which will be to assist refugees from the six Iron Curtain nations of Eastern Europe so they can furnish democratic leadership when these countries regain their freedom, was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Attorney General Tom C. Clark, under subpoena from a Senate Judiciary subcommittee to produce files on foreign government officials in this country, refused to do so today, but Chairman Pat McCarran, Democrat, of Nevada, already had modified the request.

Dr. William E. B. Du Bois, adviser on colonial affairs for the Council on African Affairs, Inc., a left-wing group that has been in open sympathy with Russian foreign policy in recent months, predicted yesterday a new day for Africa along the lines of "a mass awakening."

BERLIN, June 1 -- Striking railroad workers of Western Berlin made another move today toward settlement of the twelve-day-old deadlock on wages that has imposed upon Berlin's railroad system a blockade almost as effective as that established by the Soviet Military Administration a year ago.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) -- Some of the slips of paper found in Judith Coplon's purse were described with mystifying breviity at her espionage trial today but the prosecution withheld them from evidence on the ground of national security.

The ex-city employes-retired policemen (before 1940) are living on a pension that is a joke if it were not so serious. This condition can be remedied at Albany, but without the Mayor's support there is no chance for success. He has shown no concern for those oldsters.
FRENCH LICK SPRINGS, Ind., June 1 (AP) -- New drugs that help victims of shaking palsy were reported today to the American Academy of Neurology.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- While Senate "progressives" were optimistic over possibilities of passing a labor relations bill to satisfy all parties, Democrats on the House Labor Committee caucused tonight in an effort to heal a three-way split in their ranks.

LIMA, Peru, June 1 (UP) -- Peru's military Junta Government resigned in a body today, and Provisional President Manuel Odria promptly named a new Cabinet, including several carry-overs from the previous regime.

Perry Como, baritone, will have his own half-hour radio program next fall, occupying the niche at 10 P. M., Thursdays, over NBC. The present occupant of the spot, the Screen Guild Players, will move to another time. The booking means that Mr. Como will discontinue his present fifteen-minute program on NBC, where it has been heard at 7 P. M. on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays.

BOSTON, June 1 (AP) -- Boston's Braves took over first place undisputed in the National League tonight by once again coming from behind and beating the Pirates, 8 -- 6, in a long battle in which the teams used a total of nine pitchers.
TOKYO, June 1 -- Thomas Alva Edison has become one of Japan's 16,000,000 gods.

MOSCOW, June 1 -- The Soviet press today published virtually complete the text of Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky's declaration to the Paris conference, but suggestions as to the probable future course of developments were absent.

CAIRO, June 1 -- The British here have gone to some pains to convince party leaders and other political personalities that Foreign Secretary Bevin and Dean Acheson, United States Secretary of State, found time in Paris to try to work out a solution of the Palestine Arab refugee problem so as to get the Lausanne peace talks moving.
MONTREAL, June 1 (AP) -- Two major rule changes were approved by the National Hockey League at its annual meeting today.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 1 -- Charles E. Wilson, president of the General Electric Company, flung the charge of "big business" back at the Government today. He charged President Truman with being "two-minded about bigness" and listed several Federal organizations to back up his statement.
Back in the Army again, Anthony V. Martino underwent psychiatric examination yesterday wearing rose-colored spectacles, but his outlook was clouded by uncertainties.

HOUSTON, Tex., June 1 -- The advertising women of New York garnered two second awards and one honorable mention as ten advertising clubs were cited for outstanding activities during the closing luncheon session here today of the Advertising Federation of America.

OTHERS abide our endless questioning about contemporary poetry -- Robert Frost stands free and serene and magnificent, for all the world as if he were the George Washington of modern American verse. The Pulitzer people have laureled him on four occasions, so far. In 1924 it was for "New Hampshire"; in 1931 it was for "Collected Poems"; in 1937 it was for "A Further Range"; in 1943 it was for "A Witness Tree."

With the roses that so appropriately symbolize the month of June already blooming like mad all over the countryside, it is high time to give the gardeners responsible a good pat on their backs for a job well done. It is also time to be very patient with them while waiting for the answer to the innocent question, "What's the name of that pretty red rose?"
