MARYKNOLL, N. Y., June 1 -- The first Nisei or American-born Japanese to become a Roman Catholic priest in the United States will be ordained a priest of the Catholic Foreign Missionary Society of America on Saturday, June 11, it was announced today.

DETROIT, June 1 -- A force of sixty detectives began screening today 247 persons arrested in the greatest dragnet in Detroit history in an effort to obtain information on the shooting on May 24 of Victor Reuther, educational director of the United Automobile Workers, CIO.

Almost the entire student body of 675 at Cooper Union is represented in an exhibition of its work that opens today in the Foundation Building at Cooper Square. This year's show falls on the ninetieth anniversary of the school and is the largest in its nine decades of existence.

WARSAW. June 1 -- In an extremely critical speech about the "enormous" shortcomings of the Polish labor movement, Vice Premier Alexander Zawadzki told 1,600 delegates attending the second post-war congress of trade unions today that their achievements were not keeping pace with Poland's needs.

Jay R. Hunt, formerly division manager for the east coast of South America, has been appointed foreign sales manager of the Schering Corporation, pharmaceutical manufacturers, Bloomfield and Union, N. J.
PHILADELPHIA, June 1 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Phillies pushed across two runs in the tenth inning to defeat the Cincinnati Reds, 4 to 3, tonight in a game in which the score was tied three times.

Being one of the "millions" of laymen to whom you referred in your editorial "Psychiatry for Millions," on May 27, I was delighted with your statement that "none of our medical men and none of our scientists are better trained than psychiatrists."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 1 -- Scientists at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology expressed regret today that the twenty-five balloons they sent aloft to measure cosmic rays had caused another flurry of "flying saucer" reports in southern New England.
BENGAZI, Libya, June 1 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of a statement today by E. A. V. de Candole, the British administrator, on self-government for Cyrenaica:

Up to a few days ago the President insisted at every opportunity that he had an ironclad "mandate" to enact legislation dealing with every detail of every plank in the 1948 Democratic platform without delay and apparently without compromise of any kind or degree.

Volume XXIII, No. 1 of The Bawl Street Journal, published annually on the occasion of the Spring outing of the Bond Club of New York, was previewed yesterday by members of the financial press. This annual satire of the financial world in newspaper form will be distributed to more than 500 members tomorrow at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club, Scarborough, N.Y.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 1 -- Holy Cross evened its baseball series with Yale today, registering a 3-1 victory behind the excellent pitching of Tom Donavan.

Former Secretary of Defense James Forrestal, who leaped to death from the National Naval Medical Center at Bethesda, Md., on May 22, left his estate in trust for the benefit of his widow and two sons, it was learned yesterday in Surrogate's Court where his will was filed for probate.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 1 -- While tail-coated waiters glided about in the sumptuous Narodni Club, Eisler offered to the press this afternoon his impressions of United States "reaction."

Efforts to combat rheumatism are of vital importance to the entire world "because peace and progress in the family of nations depend upon the health and strength of the people," President Truman said in a message read last night at a dinner of the International League Against Rheumatism.

The nation's 530 mutual savings banks made 152,000 mortgage loans amounting to $1,325,000,000 in 1948, it was announced yesterday by the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks. The figures compare with 121,000 loans of slightly more than $1,000,000,000 in the previous year.

Edward W. McDonald, an assistant United States Attorney until his resignation Tuesday, was sworn in by Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard yesterday as United States Commissioner for the Southern District of New York.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, speaking yesterday at his first commencement as president of Columbia University, hit at "the modern preachers of the paternalistic state" as "the demagogues of right and left."

Dean Millicent Carey McIntosh, speaking at a Barnard College diploma ceremony yesterday after the Columbia University Commencement exercises, warned the 302 graduates against succumbing to disillusion and skepticism.

PURCHASE, N. Y., June 1 -- Five small planes piloted by women in a 1,340-mile race from Montreal, Can., to Miami, Fla., flew in here today from the north, stopped for one hour at the Westchester County Airport and then went southward.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., June 1 -- The policing of intellectual expression was assailed here today by Dr. Howard Mumford Jones, member of the Harvard University faculty and president of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, at the commencement of Sarah Lawrence College.

The number of workers seeking state unemployment benefits went up by 17,892 last week, bringing the total, to a record high for the year of 486,759. This represented a rise of 76 per cent over the 293,000 total on the unemployment insurance and veterans' readjustment rolls last October, when the current slump in employment began.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 1 -- John T. Dunn Jr., chairman of the Connecticut Liquor Control Commission and a member of the Republican State Central Committee, was suspended from his post this afternoon by Gov. Chester Bowles, a Democrat.

Studies at the Harvard Medical School suggesting the possibility that cortisone, the recently synthesized hormone of the cortex (outer layer) of the adrenal gland, may prove useful in the treatment of epilepsy were reported yesterday at the International Congress on Rheumatic Diseases at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The United States liner America sailed for Cobh, Havre and Southampton at 4 P. M. yesterday with 984 passengers, among them a spry, 81-year-old tax collector from Oradell, N. J., who was carrying out a life-long ambition -- an ocean crossing "to the Shakespeare country."

In a purchase carrying with it ownership of several realty landmarks in this city, a syndicate headed by Alfred R. Glancy Jr., of Detroit, yesterday contracted to buy Realty Associates, Inc., and Realty Associates Securities Corporation from the Consolidated Realty Corporation, a subsidiary of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

Whittaker Chambers, ex-Communist party courier, began laying the groundwork of the Federal Government's perjury prosecution of Alger Hiss when he took the witness stand yesterday against the former State Department official.
CHICAGO, June 1 (AP) -- Gus Zernial, injured outfielder of the Chicago White Sox, whose .355 tops American League hitters, may be benched as long as nine weeks.

A special K. L. M.-Royal Dutch Airlines plane is scheduled to arrive here today at 11:10 A. M. with forty-three Dutch seamen to man the Victory ship Villar. The plane left Amsterdam yesterday for New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens.

Consolidated earnings of A. G. Spalding Bros., Inc., sporting goods manufacturers, amounted to an estimated $400,000 for the six months ended on April 30, after all charges including $210,000 provision for estimated taxes on income, C. F. Robbins, president, reported yesterday.

The American and British Governments have now cited the Communist-dominated regimes of Bulgaria, Hungary and Rumania before the bar of world opinion for suppressing human rights and fundamental freedoms, and have invoked the peace treaties imposed on these former Axis satellites to compel action on their indictment.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The Democratic leadership of the House set the wheels in motion today to by-pass the Rules Committee, if necessary, to bring the Administration's multi-billion-dollar housing program to the floor for a vote.

PHILADELPHIA, June 1 -- The S. S. Ras Al Ardh, a supertanker capable of carrying 240,000 barrels of crude oil or enough to heat 6,500 homes a year, was launched today at the Sun Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company's yards in near-by Chester.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The Joint Chiefs of Staff have turned down a proposed mock battle between the Air Force's giant B-36 bomber and jet fighter planes of the Air Force and the Navy, it was announced here today.

Housewives are trying to kill two birds with one stone -- get combination maids and baby-sitters. This was the newest trend in household help demands reported here yesterday by the United States Employment Service.

FRANKFORT, Germany, June 1 -- General elections for a Western German government -- the first free national elections in Germany in sixteen years -- are planned for Aug. 14, it became known today as the three Western powers agreed on the text of an electoral law and authorized German officials to promulgate it.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The killing of young persons and children on the thoroughfares of this country was emphasized today as a major problem at the opening of the third annual President's Highway Safety Conference here.

MONTREAT, N. C., June 1 (AP) -- The legislative body of Southern Presbyterians today "accepted" a report advocating that Christians should protect the "basic rights" of all men. The 89th general assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the U. S. then adjourned after reaching an agreement to increase cooperation with the northern denomination with a view to reunion.

Directors of the Follansbee Steel Corporation declared yesterday in Pittsburgh a dividend of 25 cents a share, payable June 30. This represents a reduction of 50 cents a share from the previous quarterly rate of 75 cents.

Waring Products Corporation yesterday notified its distributors that it has reduced the list price of its automatic steam iron from $19.95 to $17.95. F. B. Biren, sales manager, Joseph Kurzon, Inc., local distributors for the company, said the product has been reduced $4 in all since it was introduced to list at $21.95.

The Ballet Theatre, Inc., of 25 West Forty-fifth Street, made public yesterday a letter from the Soviet Embassy in Washington to Blevins Davis, president of the Ballet Theatre Foundation, which appeared to be tantamount to a declination of Mr. Davis' offer to present ballets in Russia at his own expense.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Senator Bourke Blakemore Hickenlooper kept his case against David E. Lilienthal on a series of recipe cards in the inside pocket of his blue-gray coat today and every few minutes he reached in and flicked one off the pack.

FLEMINGTON, N. J., June 1 -- Earnings of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) in the first half of this year will be about 30 per cent less than in the same period of 1948, F. W. Abrams, the chairman, told stockholders at the annual meeting here today.

In connection with the repaving job planned for this summer, Forty-second Street will be widened in places to bring its roadway to a fairly consistent width of 60 feet from Second Avenue to Twelfth Avenue, Borough President Hugo E. Rogers of Manhattan announced yesterday.

It is evident from George Streator's article under the heading "State Laws Urged to Benefit Indians" in THE TIMES of May 22 that Mr. Streator has certain serious misconceptions of my views concerning the bill now before the United States Senate to confirm New York State civil jurisdiction over reservation Indians.
The Sperry Corporation's initial public financing will take the form of an offering today of $20,000,000 of 3 1/8 per cent sinking fund debentures maturing June 1, 1969.

There's another stakes-winner in the barn of Isidor Bieber and Hirsch Jacobs, the gentlemen from Forest Hills who spend much of their time these days accepting congratulations after race track victories. The name: Up Beat, 4-year-old son of Pharamond II and Rhythmic.

Frederick H. Zimmer has been appointed to the new office of vice president in charge of domestic business development of the Colonial Trust Company, it has been announced by Arthur S. Kleeman, president. Mr. Zimmer has been vice president in charge of the William Street office, and will be succeeded in that post by William H. Bassett, who has been vice president in charge of the Kingsboro office, in Brooklyn.

In its first change of ownership since 1909, the six-story apartment house for twenty families on a plot 50 by 100 feet at 242-46 East Fiftieth Street, near Second Avenue, was sold by Stephen Jacoby and Jeanne J. Beckman to a syndicate headed by Joshuah Sidney Shultz.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 1 (AP) -- A petite blonde in a picture hat became the toast of the Navy today at the Naval Academy's parade of parades. Smiling with pride, Marie Badecker of Teaneck, N. J., officiated at the presentation of the colors, a traditional June Week ceremony.
ST. LOUIS, June 1 (AP) -- Eddie Yost and Sam Dente hit home runs -- their first of the year -- to lead the Washington Senators to a 16-to-5 triumph over the St. Louis Browns tonight.

Amazingly full of life for a club put through the overtime wringer three days in a row, the Giants spotted the Cubs four runs yesterday, then roared back against the formidable Johnny Schmitz and two successors to capture an 11-to-5 decision at the Polo Grounds.

Almost everyone connected with the stage seems to be preoccupied these days with ambitious plans for the rustic circuit. Joan Blondell, stage and screen star, has agreed to appear in "Happy Birthday" the week of July 4 at the McCarter Theatre, Princeton, N. J. She will have the role Helen Hayes created in the Anita Loos play.

SHANGHAI, June 1 -- There are growing signs that China's Communist leaders do not intend to throw an impenetrable iron curtain around the country. After the Yangtze River was opened to shipping yesterday the first American ship, the Far East liner China Victory was cleared for entry next Tuesday.

WINNIPEG, June 1 (Canadian Press) -- Generally favorable reaction in the West today greeted the announcement from Ottawa that the Canadian Wheat Board would take over marketing of coarse grains -- oats and barley -- on Aug. 1.
LONDON, June 1 -- The stock markets again were weak here today. The overnight break in commodities and stocks in the United States was a depressing influence.

ROME, June 1 -- Italy's progress toward internal and external financial stability, one of the main objectives of the European Recovery Program, has been good enough to permit taking several further significant steps toward viability, Minister of the Treasury Giuseppe Pella told the Italian Senate today.
TORONTO, June 1 -- Most of the active buying at the second annual Canadian International Trade Fair here is concentrated on tools, machinery and hardware items, exhibitors revealed today.

As an aftermath to the explosion of chemicals on a truck in the Holland Tunnel on May 13, two bills have been introduced at the special session of the New Jersey Legislature. One would strengthen New Jersey's own laws regarding storage and transportation of dangerous cargo.

A partly crippled Air Force veteran who had spent two years in a Nazi prison camp was accused yesterday in General Sessions of mulcting home-seekers of $30,000 in down payments for bungalows that never were erected.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Otis Co. of Cleveland, investment banking concern, won another round from the Securities and Exchange Commission today in a court battle resulting from the failure last year of a $10,000,000 common stock offering of the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation.

CHICAGO, June 1 -- A stronger tone dominated the wheat trade today, with some mill buying of July in evidence and also considerable profit-taking by shorts. Commission absorption broadened on the setbacks, while there was less liquidating pressure.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The Michigan Consolidated Gas Company, Detroit, a subsidiary of the American Light and Traction Company, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering $25,000,000 of sinking fund debentures, due July 1, 1967, that are to be sold at competitive bidding.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Senator Bourke B. Hickenlooper of Iowa cited a two-year turnover of 87 per cent in personnel of the Atomic Energy Commission today as evidence of "incredible mismanagement" under David E. Lilienthal, its chairman.

While continuing to deny any advocacy of force and violence in the United States, John Gates admitted at the Communist trial yesterday that the party's program could lead to force and violence to suppress "reactionary" opposition.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., June 1 -- Because he "hates trains" and "planes are expensive," George F. French, 20-year-old Princeton University sophomore will take off from Convention Hall on the Boardwalk here at midnight tomorrow in an effort to reach the Pacific Coast the hard way.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (UP) -- Rent controls have been lifted on more than 250,000 housing units in twenty-nine states since the new rent law went into effect two months ago, Government figures showed today.
It took all kinds of people to make possible the pageant of America that 1,600 boys and girls displayed for two hours yesterday at the Joan of Arc Junior High School, 154 West Ninety-third Street.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 1 -- The press today quoted the Government - sponsored Catholic Church Gazette's announcement that it would henceforth be the sole official organ for the publication of "all matters concerning church administration," such as decrees, directives, announcements of personnel changes and priestly vacancies emanating from the church's officialdom.

The Welfare Department's plans for a work-relief program are still in the preliminary stages, but in view of the present business uncertainties it represents sound judgment to be prepared. The department's case load began to rise in December. Total cases on the rolls numbered 136,440 in November.

Capturing five firsts and scoring in nine of the fifteen events, Sid Elstein's Boys High squad retained its City P. S. A. L. outdoor track and field championship at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island, yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 1 -- Tommy Henrich's tenth home run of the campaign and a voluble double by Yogi Berra tonight bought the Yankees victory over the White Sox before 30,371 fans at Comiskey Park, as Vic Raschi blanked Jack Onslow's sixth-place club, 3 to 0.

HUNTINGTON, L. I., June 1 -- Mrs. Charles Leichner of Willow Brook and Mrs. J. B. Balding of The Creek each turned in cards of 80 in the one-day medal round tournament of the Women's Long Island Golf Association at the Huntington Country Club today.

Two new films will open in midtown theatres this morning. At the Radio City Music Hall, the attraction is "Edward, My Son," Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's adaptation of the Broadway stage hit, starring Spen cer Tracy and Deborah Kerr. The drama was filmed in England from the screen play by Donald Ogden Stewart and the play by Robert Morley and Noel Langley. George Cukor directed and Edwin H. Knopf produced.
STANTON, Del., June 1 (AP) -- The first of a series of five Montchanin Handicaps was run in two sections at Delaware Park today with eight candidates in each end.
DETROIT, June 1 (AP) -- Virgil Trucks of the Tigers survived a shaky start and beat the Athletics, 5 to 4, in ten innings tonight.
MOSCOW, June 1 -- Dollars are the theme of a successful new musical comedy called "Dollar Princess," now delighting Russian audiences at the Operetta Theatre.
Initial payments from the retirement fund of the dress industry of New York were made yesterday in the ballroom of the New Yorker Hotel before 1,000 persons eligible for similar awards.

PLYMOUTH, N. H., June 1 (AP) -- A 22-year-old Dartmouth College junior, Thomas A. Doxsee of Fayetteville, N. Y., received a fine of $500 and a suspended sentence today on a manslaughter charge in the dormitory death of a fellow student.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Citizens who try to follow political leaders are, or should be, cynically accustomed to inconsistency when these leaders encounter strong group pressures. A current example is provided by members of Congress who, after much denunciation of "federalism" and insistence on local self-government and responsibility, are supporting a bill granting federal assistance to local education on a broad and expensive scale.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 1 -- Yugoslavia stands to lose $70,000,000, in addition to a great amount of unreturned looted property, as a result of the Hungarian Government's unilateral action in ceasing reparations deliveries, according to statistics published here today.

GRANVILLE, Ohio, June 1 -- Dr. Austin M. Brues, director of the Biological Division of the Argonne National Laboratories at Chicago, indicated today that it would be at least ten years before the use of atomic energy would be feasible in engineering projects.
Camera fans with a liking for shots of entertainment celebrities and models in bathing suits will have a chance to indulge their fancies, free of charge, for the next four weeks.
PARIS, June 1 -- Britain's decision to recognize Emir Sayed Idriss El Senussi as the head of the newly proclaimed Cyrenaican Government, follows five days of secret discussions in London and Paris.

A wave of trade and commission-house selling of rubber futures resulted in the sharpest price decline in eighteen months on the Commodity Exchange yesterday. All active deliveries were at new lows for the life of the contracts. At the close, prices showed losses of 43 to 58 points in a turnover of 264 contracts.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 1-- Twentieth Century-Fox today announced the purchase of "Storks Do Not Bring Babies," a screen comedy by S. K. Lauren, as a possible vehicle for Betty Grable. The property reportedly brought a good price, which the studio declined to divulge; although it is understood to be in the neighborhood of $50,000.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The House approved today after brief debate a bill providing pensions of $72 a month for virtually all veterans of military service reaching the age of 65. The only exceptions would be those with private incomes greater than $1,200 for single men or $2,500 for those with wives or minor children.

Mary A. Norse, author of two histories of the Far East, has signed a contract with Bobbs-Merrill for a new book, "Ferment in the Far East: A Historical Interpretation." The book, scheduled for fall publication, will have a foreword by Alice Tisdale Hobart and maps by James MacDonald.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The first reservation to the North Atlantic treaty yet publicly proposed -- a recommendation that the United States deny even an implied obligation to go to the military rescue of a treaty partner -- was offered today.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The State Department announced today that the United States was invoking the clauses of the peace treaties with Bulgaria, Hungary and Rumania to bring about enforcement of their guarantees of human rights and fundamental freedoms, on the ground of violation of those rights by the present Governments of the three countries and their rejection of vigorous protests by the United States.
LA PAZ, June 1 (UP) -- Police today arrested the acting head of the National Revolutionary Movement, which the Government has accused of engineering a revolutionary plot.

PARIS, June 1 -- The experts who have discussed the United States proposal for a freer and more competitive European trade agreement among the Marshall Plan countries have drawn up a report to submit to the steering committee of the Ministers that will meet here Friday, with Sir Stafford Cripps, representing Britain.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission lopped off today nearly $200,000 of a total of $639,068 claimed by parties to the reorganization proceedings of the Central Railroad of New Jersey for compensation and expenses.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were somewhat steadier yesterday than in previous sessions this week and final prices were 3 to 15 points higher.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Correspondents who covered the invasion of Europe were told by President Truman today that "we are closer to world peace now than at any time in the last three years."

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended May 25:

VIENNA, June 1 -- The International Telephone and Telegraph Company has succeeded in making an agreement with the Hungarian Government under which its three Hungarian factories, two of which already had been nationalized, will be restored to the company for operation.
Thirty-seven women who have been taking a course on how to invest money wisely made a field trip yesterday -- to the New York Stock Exchange.

PARIS, June 1 -- The Big Four Council of Foreign Ministers began its discussion of Berlin today by sharp divergence on how far any power should have the right to veto in a four-power control authority for the city.

Already one of the city's great assets, the Bronx Zoo, is about to receive a unique addition that will increase its recreational value and make it even more important as an educational center. Work will soon begin on a novel and imaginative outdoor exhibit that will demonstrate how the nation's natural resources are being depleted and how they can be restored.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Rounding out its action in connection with commutation fares in the New Jersey area, the Interstate Commerce Commission today suspended for a period of seven months a second attempt by the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad to adjust its rates upward in line with those recently authorized for the Jersey Central.
Sales in New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a decline of 11 per cent in May, compared with the same month last year, according to the survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

THE St. Louis Cardinals have finished either first or second every year since 1940, a most remarkable record for consistency. But the once fast-flying Redbirds, who could sprout new wings whenever the occasion demanded, now flutter along without the infusion of vigorous young blood which used to perform the anatomical feat of supplying the new wings.

LONDON, June 1 -- Winston Churchill, in receiving today the freedom of the Royal Borough of Kensington, London, said he had a "growing hope" that "we may avert forever the horrible vision of a third World War."

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 1 -- A new hitch has arisen in the expected settlement of the Syrian-Lebanese dispute that has closed the border between the two countries. It was announced today that a decision by the Egyptian-Saudi Arabian arbitration team expected during the day had been indefinitely postponed.

LONDON, June 1 -- In a declaration made unexpectedly at Bengazi today, Britain agreed to the formation of a government in the former Italian North African colony of Cyrenaica and recognized Emir Sayed Idriss El Senussi, spiritual and temporal leader of the colony's 250,000 Senussi Arab tribesmen, as head of the government.

A nine-man United States track and field squad will leave via Pan American World Airways today at 5 P. M. from Idlewild International Airport for meets in London on June 6, Dublin on June 8-9, Belfast on June 10 and Glasgow on June 11.
A middle-aged Brooklyn housewife was arraigned yesterday in Federal Court, Brooklyn, on a charge of attempting to smuggle $15,500 in diamonds into the United States by air.

Esquire, Inc., announced yesterday general expansion of its sales service departments, covering research, sales promotion, merchandising, sales presentations and press information. Five expansion-connected promotions also were announced.
The text of the Commencement Day address by General Eisenhower at Columbia follows:

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The wide attention being given to the proposed Economic Expansion Act of 1949, which would set up an anti-depression program, may foreshadow an eventual swing away from the Administration's controversial economic policy, a survey indicated today.
The showing that Maximilian offered yesterday at 20 West Fifty-Seventh Street, is best described by the single word, "opulent."

Tommy is 10 and in trouble. He has a touch of genius and a tendency to take things not his own. Tommy is not delinquent, but a neglected child, in need of more care than an older brother can give him.
A middle-aged Brooklyn housewife was arraigned yesterday in Federal Court, Brooklyn, on a charge of attempting to smuggle $15,500 in diamonds into the United States by air.

Esquire, Inc., announced yesterday general expansion of its sales service departments, covering research, sales promotion, merchandising, sales presentations and press information. Five expansion-connected promotions also were announced.
The text of the Commencement Day address by General Eisenhower at Columbia follows:

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The wide attention being given to the proposed Economic Expansion Act of 1949, which would set up an anti-depression program, may foreshadow an eventual swing away from the Administration's controversial economic policy, a survey indicated today.
The showing that Maximilian offered yesterday at 20 West Fifty-Seventh Street, is best described by the single word, "opulent."

Tommy is 10 and in trouble. He has a touch of genius and a tendency to take things not his own. Tommy is not delinquent, but a neglected child, in need of more care than an older brother can give him.

Shelby County, Tenn., sold yesterday $4,100,000 of school and sea wall bonds. The National City Bank of New York and associates were successful bidders for the issues, which will mature from June 1, 1950, to 1972. The bonds were purchased at 100.2065, for 2s and 2 1/4s, at an interest cost of 2.175.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved the International Wheat Agreement today by 10 to 0, with one abstention, and will shortly recommend that the Senate ratify it.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- Dr. Leona Baumgartner, former New York City Assistant Commissioner of Health, was sworn in today as associate chief of the Children's Bureau. The ceremony was held in the office of the Federal Security Administrator, Oscar R. Ewing, who said:

Under cross-examination at the Communist trial yesterday, John Gates repeatedly refused to answer questions about the party's top leadership, but backed down after Federal Judge Harold R. Medina declared him in contempt and indicated he was prepared to mete out punishment.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Declaring that the Securities and Exchange Commission was "throttling'' the capital markets instead of creating order in them, Cyrus S. Eaton, Cleveland financier and industrialist, demanded today that the agency's appropriation for the fiscal year 1950 be "drastically reduced."

The gangland slaying of an East Side hoodlum, who was shot to death in 1946 in retaliation for holding up participants of a "floating crap game," was believed solved with the arraignment yesterday of two men in Felony Court on homicide charges.

A bronze bust of Dean Emeritus Virginia Crocheron Gildersleeve was unveiled and presented to Barnard College yesterday afternoon. The ceremony was the first event of Barnard Alumnae Day, which included the annual business meeting of the alumnae, a faculty reception, and a trustees' dinner in honor of reunion classes.

Prices of new carpet grades to be introduced at semi-annual industry openings next month will be extremely firm and any reductions made will be "very nominal" a spokesman for a large mill declared yesterday. He said there is no basis for retail predictions that new grades will be introduced at substantially lower prices.

SKYTOP, Pa., June 2 (AP) -- The nation faces "gradual erosion of our entire productive machine" unless Congress authorizes a more liberal depreciation policy in the tax structure, Charles S. Munson, executive committee chairman of United States Industrial Chemicals, Inc., said today.

The veterans' pension bill as reported from committee was bad enough, but as it passed the House of Representatives it is very much worse. It would set an unwise precedent in veterans' legislation; it would establish more firmly than ever a privileged class in this democracy; it would impose a crushing financial burden on future generations.

In the passing of Don Fernando de los Rios the world lost more than a distinguished scholar, a valiant democratic political leader. What we lose is the man of all men most able to break down the barriers that still obstruct understanding between the two great cultures that share our continent the Anglo-Saxon and the Spanish and Portuguese.

BLUEFIELD, W. Va., June 2 -John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, agreed today to bargain with the Southern Coal Producers Association in executive session just when the joint wage conference seemed on the verge of collapse. The first meeting will be held tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Roscoe Drummond, Washington correspondent of the Christian Science Monitor, today was appointed European Director of Information for the Economic Cooperation Administration. Mr. Drummond succeeds Alfred Friendly, Washington Post reporter who will return to that newspaper soon after a year's leave of absence.

ROME, June 2 -- Emir Sayed Idriss El Senussi's proclamation in Bengazi announcing Cyrenaica's independence and plan to form a national government composed of representatives of the native population was said today to have caught the Italian Government completely by surprise.

PARIS, June 2 -- At the suggestion of Secretary of State Dean Acheson, the Big Four Foreign Ministers' Council decided today to go into secret sessions beginning tomorrow to discuss a United States proposal for re-establishing four-power control and a single provisional government for Berlin.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and Lieut. Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, commanding officer of the First Army, saw thirty-seven former war correspondents off from La Guardia Airport yesterday on a return visit to the historic beach-heads and battlegrounds they covered five years ago.

The proposed international wheat agreement, which was approved yesterday by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, may not meet an serious opposition in the Senate although it is not considered in the grain trade as favorable to the exporting nations as was the previous agreement that failed of ratification.

Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday that John T. DeGraff, counsel for the State Association of Civil Service Employes, would direct a two-year survey intended to revamp the city's civil service set-up on the basis of an equitable adjustment of job classifications and pay rates.

The unloading of the Liberty Ship Howard T. Ricketts, which arrived here last Friday with a full cargo of lumber from Portland, Ore., has been halted since noon on Tuesday because of an intra-union dispute of Brooklyn longshoremen.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee was unable today to obtain unanimous acceptance of the first draft of the report with which it ultimately will recommend ratification of the North Atlantic treaty.

" No progress" again was the report yesterday on negotiations between East and Gulf Coast ship operators and the National Maritime Union. Yesterday's meeting adjourned in the late afternoon, subject to call by the local office of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, which has been watching the situation.
Trainer Jack Skinner made a one, three hit in the $9,475 Corinthian Steeplechase Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday with Mrs. Stephen C. Clark Jr.'s Trough Hill and the Rokeby Stables' American Way.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., June 2 -- The rolling hills and tricky greens of the Pelham Country Club course proved too difficult for the majority of the large field that took part in the weekly one-day tournament of the Westchester and Fairfield Women's Golf Association today.

Declaring that this country is still living in war economy, Jarvis Cromwell, president of William Iselin Co., Inc., factors, warned credit men last night not to count on normal business conditions. He spoke at the thirtieth annual banquet and commencement of the New York Chapter, National Institute of Credit, in the Statler Hotel.

Fog shut in the New York Harbor and tributaries early yesterday morning, delaying ferry commuters on the average by fifteen minutes, canceling all plane arrivals at La Guardia Airport and hampering shipping from a few minutes up to five hours.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- President Truman said today that the "frightful slaughter on our streets and highways continues," and added that many of the states had failed to establish driver-licensing systems for motor vehicles "worthy of the name." He termed the procedures now in use in those areas as "scandalous."

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- A plan of liquidation for the United Light and Railways Company and its subsidiary holding company, the Continental Gas and Electric Corporation, both of Chicago, was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

LAKE SUCCESS, June 2 -- Dr. Ralph Bunche acknowledged today that resentment against "Jim Crow" practices in Washington was one of the reasons that he had turned down the offer of the post of Assistant Secretary of State.
Magistrate J. Roland Sala and his automobile were in the limelight again yesterday -- without the automobile.

All private bus lines operating in Manhattan and the Bronx were authorized last night by the Public Service Commission to file new fare tariffs calling for an increase of 1 cent in their present interim rates. The lines of the Surface Transportation Company, operating in the Bronx and Manhattan, were authorized to file tariffs for an interim fare of 8 cents to replace the present 7-cent rate.
CLEVELAND, June 2 (AP) -- Manager Lou Boudreau, playing with a broken finger, belted a single and a double tonight as the Indians defeated the Red Sox, 8 to 3.

European recovery and United States prosperity are jointly being stimulated by the growing volume of American travel to Western Europe, Robin Brook, a director of the Bank of England and deputy chairman of the British Tourist and Holidays Board, declared here yesterday.

The spice industry is facing the greatest consumer demands of all time, Lester W. Jones, president of the American Spice Trade Association, disclosed yesterday at their forty-third annual luncheon for food editors and writers in the Astor Hotel.

Objections lodged with Mayor O'Dwyer by Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, AFL, have resulted in cancellation of a series of free summer concerts by the Police Department band in Forest Park, Queens, it was made known yesterday by James A. Burke, Borough President of Queens.
With reports from Mexico of collections of drafts termed excellent, a greater air of confidence in the peso was exhibited by bankers here yesterday.

L. S. Sparrell, manager of ship repair sales for the Bethlehem Steel Company's shipbuilding division, was elected president of the Propeller Club of the Port of New York last night at the club's annual meeting in the Downtown Athletic Club.

Geraldine Fitzgerald, who hasn't acted on Broadway since "Sons and Soldiers" (1943), is to return next season in a dual capacity, according to her husband, Stuart Scheftel, a director of The New York Post and president of Young America Films.
Harrison Dillard, Olympic 100-meter sprint champion, was winging his way back to London last night to appear before the British as the world record-holding high hurdler.

TOKYO, June 2 -- Japan's economic problem no longer is inflation but deflation, Finance Minister Hayato Ikeda told the press at Hiroshima today. He indicated that measures were being prepared to cope with the money shortage induced by the past year's economic program.

Meat is going to be the problem in this week-end's shopping, with many prices from 2 to 6 cents higher for the second successive Friday. In fact, it will take considerable scouting to find anything economical in the butcher department today.

STANTON, Del., June 2 (AP) -The first dead heat of the Delaware Park meeting resulted in the featured Felton Purse today when J. Howard Rouse's Three Dots and Ella K. Bryson's Equibit reached the end of the six furlongs as a team.

The Giants had the misfortune last night to go up against Emil (Dutch) Leonard when the 40-year-old knockle-ball expert of the Cubs was at his baffling best. The result was a three-hit 3-0 shutout of the home side, which was made to look futile, indeed.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 2 (Reuters) -- A suspended Roman Catholic priest, Father Josef Lukacovic, today defied the Archbishop of Prague by calling on the Czechoslovak clergy in a newspaper article to support the present Government.
Price reductions on steel appear imminent, purchasing agents reported yesterday. They based their prediction on reciprocal deals now being made by some steel mills.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (UP) -- George L. Googe, vice president of the International Printing Pressmen's Union, AFL, told Congressional investigators tonight that the union "had no right" to pay the $26,900 in back income taxes that the late George L. Berry owed the Government.

The report of the North American Rayon Corporation for the twelve weeks ended on March 26, issued yesterday, showed net profit of $720,522, equal to $1.41 a share, compared with $741,341, or $1.45 a share, for the similar period of 1948.

NOORDWIJK, the Netherlands, June 2 (AP) -- Richard (Pancho) Gonzales of Los Angeles moved into the quarter-finals of the Dutch international tennis tournament today with a 6 -- 3, 6 -- 4 victory over Huub Wilton of the Netherlands.

Publication of the valuation of New York City real estate for tax purposes in the fiscal year 1949-50 invites comparisons with the past, and these comparisons may contain surprises for some. The assessment list for real estate and special franchises is set at $18,112,231,179, an increase of $527,738,966 over the present year.

ALBANY, June 2 -- The Court of Appeals unanimously affirmed today jail sentences and fines against seven New York City residents convicted of having exacted "excessive charges in connection with rental agreements."
Imported silk decorative fabrics in a variety of weaves, all of them luxurious in effect, are a new addition at the decorators' showroom of Greeff Fabrics, Inc., 49 East Fifty-third Street.

Zinc was reduced 1/4 cent yesterday by a western custom smelter and primary zinc producers here said they expected to follow suit today. At the new quotation of 10 3/4 cent per pound, East St. Louis, zinc is 6 cents a pound below the post-war high of 17 1/2 cents that prevailed from November, 1948 to March, 1949.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Members of the Inter-American Bar Association were told by President Truman today that the United States wanted other countries to feel it was a good neighbor and that the situation on this side of the world was proof that we were.
The incessant ringing of a burglar alarm is a public nuisance. When an off these alarms ring loudly and constantly until shut off, disturbing even one within hearing.

The most troublesome problem raised by the current recession is likely to be the matter of price adjustment, according to the National City Bank of New York. Potential buyers of many consumers' goods, businessmen and farmers, the bank declares in the current issue of its Monthly Letter, published today, are operating on a "hand-to-mouth" basis, awaiting price cuts.
The futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 2 points lower to 2 points higher yesterday after holding within a narrow range all day.

BATAVIA, Java, June 2 (AP) -- The exiled Indonesian Republican leadership plans to get in touch Saturday with its guerrilla stronghold in northern Sumatra to confer on Dutch-Indonesian terms for a cease-fire.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (Science Service) -- More infantile paralysis cases were reported during the week ended May 28 than any corresponding week for the last six years. The total reported to the United States Public Health Service here was 155, compared to 101 the preceding week.

MANILA, Friday, June 3 -- The National Bureau of Investigation said today two men had confessed to planting unwittingly a time-bomb aboard the Philippine Airlines plane that crashed May 7, killing thirteen persons.

A collection of H. L. Mencken's comments on a variety of subjects will be published next Friday by Knopf, entitled "A Mencken Chrestomathy." The book contains more than 300 items culled from his out-of-print books and also from his magazine and newspaper articles which have never been published in book form before.

LONDON, June 2 -- A. V. Alexander, British Minister of Defense, left here today in a military plane on what was described as a twelve-day visit to the Middle East and Far East. It is understood a main purpose of his trip is to inspect new defense preparations at Hong Kong.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 2 -Lebanon has given in to Syria on the question that has kept up tension between the two countries during the last two weeks. Capt. Aksam Tabbara, with the three Syrian soldiers of his team that killed a Palestinian Arab in Leba

TRENTON, N. J., June 2 -- An injury award of $43,000 by a Middlesex County jury to Thomas J. Rourke of Orange, against the Public Service Coordinated Transport was sustained today by the Appellate Division of the New Jersey Superior Court.
May I be allowed to submit some observations concerning your editorial of May 23 "France Acts on Cochin China"?

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- An important and possibly crucial Senate Democratic caucus tomorrow will discuss a five-point program on labor legislation designed to win over liberal Republicans and moderate Southerners.

LONDON, June 2 -- Two crucial meetings will be held tomorrow in an effort to halt the railway labor disturbances that are threatening the Whitsun holiday travel plans of hundreds of thousands of Britons and delaying the delivery of vital food supplies and exports.

New clinical evidence that a number of crippling diseases with little superficial similarity may have a common origin in a mysterious cell malfunction in the human body was presented yesterday morning before the International Congress on Rheumatic Diseases at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

BERLIN, June 2 -- Striking non-Communist rail workers in Western Berlin overwhelmingly rejected a compromise wage offer by the Soviet railroad management tonight and voted to continue their thirteen-day-old walkout.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- State Department officials said today that the Soviet Government had taken over control of the only Roman Catholic Church in Moscow but was permitting a French priest to continue services.

OAK RIDGE, Tenn., June 2 (AP) -- Authorization for 2,000 employes of Oak Ridge's largest atomic plant to strike next Thursday was asked by Local 288 tonight in a telegram to Martin Wagner of Washington, president of the United Gas, Coke and Chemical Workers, CIO.

Whittaker Chambers supported Government charges of perjury against Alger Hiss yesterday when he testified in Federal Court that he had received State Department documents on munitions from Mr. Hiss between February, 1937, and April, 1938.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The first thirty years of airmail service, ended last year, cost the Post Office Department $107,439,430 more than receipts, Postmaster General Jesse M. Donaldson told a Senate committee today.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (UP) -The Senate Armed Services Committee today voted to authorize $311,000,000 to erect facilities for the design and testing of supersonic aircraft and guided missiles.

The Board of Education deferred decision yesterday on the Board of Superintendents' renewed ban on the weekly magazine, The Nation, after listening for nearly three hours to impassioned speeches for and against the action.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The speaking tour in behalf of his program will be unnecessary this year, President Truman said today, but left it open as a probability for next year. That will be a Congressional campaign and election year.

ST. LOUIS, June 2 (AP) -- Eddie Yost's home run into the left-field bleachers with two mates on the bases climaxed a four-run rally in the eighth inning that enabled the Senators to hand the Browns their eighth straight defeat tonight, 4 to 1.

An Air Force veteran, partly paralyzed since last Aug. 19 when he was stabbed nine times while protecting his fiancee, was carried into Bronx County Court yesterday to testify against his alleged assailants.

Furniture dollar volume at the factory level has declined about 18 per cent in the first five months of the current year, according to an estimate made in a report yesterday by Seidman Seidman, accountants for many leading furniture producers.

General Bradley was frank to the point of bluntness and at the same time right and persuasive when he stated the case for the revision of pay scales in the armed services in an address in Washington this week. The measure that would effect this needed step has been sidetracked in the Congress.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- For the second time in two weeks, the defense attorney in Judith Coplon's espionage trial was fined $100 today for contempt of court.

Tantalizing glimpses of what sort of painting young internationals are up to in Paris are provided in the Hugo Gallery' group show to which, in most cases, each painter has contributed a single picture. All under 25, the thirteen painters here have been christened by Paul Eluard "les mains eblouies," a title more poetic than exact.

A wide range of promotional activities aimed at increasing the use of apparel wool was reported yesterday by the Wool Bureau, Inc. Summarizing the sales-stimulating efforts, the report said that the bureau's drive on behalf of men's tropical worsted suits will be aided further with a new series of six retailer advertisements for local use.

CHICAGO, June 2 -- The strength of the Yankees' "deep" pitching seldom will be demonstrated more eloquently than it was in the 3 hours 8 minutes consumed by today's skirmish with the White Sox at Comiskey Park.

TAUNTON, England, June 2 (Reuters) -- Three batsmen scored all but thirty-nine of the Somerset first innings' total of 191 when play was resumed today against the New Zealand cricket tourists. By close of play the New Zealanders had 194 for the loss of three first innings' wickets.

A good many thousand New Yorkers -- and numerous Southerners-in-exile, you may be sure -- have filtered through the pleasant rooms and corridors of the New York Historical Society these last few weeks to view the Confederate exhibit there.

PARIS, June 2 -- Western diplomats have just about concluded at this stage of the Council of Foreign Ministers' meeting that Soviet Foreign Minister Andre J. Vishinsky has been instructed to make no major concessions but to try to extract expanded East-West trade facilities from an agreement on a modus vivendi for Berlin.

IN a remote valley in Nevada nearly fifty years ago an early October blizzard swept down upon the Bridges' ranch and seemed to bring with it a melodramatic crisis which involved all six members of the family. While the storm howled disaster struck, uncovering long-festering evils and putting the character of every Bridges to a fearful test.

Walter P. Chrysler Jr.'s twenty-four-horse racing stable was sold at auction at Belmont Park yesterday for a total of $221,000, an average of $9,208. Chrysler announced recently that he was quitting the sport because of the pressure of other business.

Eleven trolley lines in Brooklyn will be left operating when the city completes its present program of substituting buses for trolleys throughout the five boroughs, it was learned yesterday at the Board of Transportation.

Delayed by heavy fog for the third consecutive arrival, the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary berthed yesterday at Pier 90, North River, six hours late, with 1,850 passengers from France and England.

The stock market relapsed yesterday into the familiar pattern of inactivity and aimlessness. Tuesday's eruption, which sent prices to the worst levels in more than a year followed by a faint recovery on Wednesday, left traders bewildered and unwilling to hazard a move in either direction.

VALHALLA, N. Y., June 2 -Mount Pleasant town officials prepared today to have axes and crowbars used to eliminate an alleged building violation here that thirty months of litigation have failed to correct.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The eight-year-old barrier against radio broadcasting stations expressing their personal views on public questions over the air was relaxed by the Federal Communications Commission today.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- A new approach to economy in government spending was advanced today as a Senate committee ran into discouragement in seeking ways to have $1,000,000,000 to $3,000,000,000 slashed from appropriations made for the coming fiscal year.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 2 -- "Born Yesterday," the Garson Kanin play for which Columbia is paying $100.000 a year for ten years, has been put on the shelf for at least four months because Harry Cohn, Columbia production chief, is going to Europe, the studio announced today.

A new issue of $3,435,000 Seaboard Air Line Railroad Equipment Trust, Series F, 2 3/8 per cent certificates was offered yesterday by a banking group headed by Salomon Bros. Hutzler. The certificates mature on June 1 from 1950 to 1964, and are priced to yield 1.40 to 2.65 per cent.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Senate hearings on six bills for Federal aid to school construction opened today with major emphasis on 395 "distressed school, districts" into which the Federal Government moved during the war.

ALBANY, June 2 (AP) -- Brig. Gen. Ames T. Brown, the State Adjutant General, today urged qualified veterans of the New York National Guard and Naval Militia to apply for Federal retirement benefits before June 30.

LONDON, June 2 -- Wall Street's steadier session yesterday resulted in cautious "bear" covering in most sections of the Stock Exchange here today. This resulted in a number of small gains at the opening, but the improvements in many cases were lost in later trading.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Opposition of common stockholders to a plan for modifying the outstanding securities of the Central Railroad of New Jersey resulted in the filing of a changed plan today with the Interstate Commerce Commission.
DETROIT, June 2 (AP) -- The Tigers spotted three runs to the Athletics in the first inning and beat them, 5 -- 4, in 10 innings today in a virtual repetition of their tussle last night.
Of 3,778 fatal accidents in New York City last year, 1,974 occurred in homes, the Department of Health reported yesterday.
RYE, N. Y., June 2 -- The Westchester County Golf Association's one-day pro-amateur best-ball tournament held over the Apawamis Club golf course today resulted in a three-way tie for first place.

A pine paneled room that transforms a portion of the New York Public Library at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street into a library of an English country squire, was opened yesterday for the institution's collection relating to tobacco.

The students of Queens College traded in yesterday a baseball field for a science building. Ground-breaking ceremonies were held on the Flushing campus to mark the start of work on the new unit, the first in the college's proposed building program.

Fear of loss of goods because of looting has increased as the political situation in China deteriorates, according to the consensus at the meeting yesterday of the Chinese Importers Committee of the Handkerchief Industry Association at 274 Madison Avenue.

EPSOM, England, June 2 (AP) -Musidora, a bay filly the critics had said wouldn't stay, today captured the 171st Oaks Stakes, historic forerunner of Saturday's Derby. Pulling out that extra zip in the last 50 yards, she beat the French filly, Coronation V, by a neck for first money of $41,080.
A "new" Michael J. Quill -- calm and conciliatory -- appeared yesterday before the Board of Transportation to present twelve demands by the Transport Workers Union, CIO.

NEW DELHI, India, June 2 -- The All-India radio said tonight that Government circles were "surprised" by the appointment of neutral observers by the International Court of Justice to investigate French charges that India was exerting an economic blockade on five French Indian colonies and to report on the feasibility of a plebiscite in these territories.

LONDON, June 2 -- The first series of meetings of the International Ruhr Authority formed by the Western powers to control the coal, coke, iron and steel output of the Ruhr was concluded today with an announcement that the Authority expected to begin exercising its functions in July.
PARIS, June 2 (UP) -- Following is the text of a United States proposal on the control of Berlin approved by Britain and France:

Four soldiers will arrive in New York this morning to enjoy a long week-end of shows, nightclubs and ball games as the guests of the First Army under a new program of rewarding "outstanding soldiers of the month" in this area.
ROME, June 2 -- The second year of the Marshall Plan will test whether Italy can become a going concern, in the opinion of both United States and Italian economists.

PITTSBURGH, June 2 -- Business in the Pittsburgh district showed a further drop last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. All the decrease was accounted for by a sharp reduction in the volume of trade; industrial production and originating freight shipments were up slightly.

LONDON, June 2 -- Bruce Woodcock retained his British, Empire and European heavyweight titles tonight by knocking out Freddie Mills, world light heavyweight champion, in the fourteenth round of a scheduled fifteen-round bout. It was one of the most thrilling fights staged here in years.

The nation's gasoline stocks declined 136,000 barrels last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end they stood at 120,661,000, compared with 120,797,000 a week earlier. Light fuel oil stocks rose 1,620,000 barrels, to 55,971,000, and heavy fuel oil 284,000, to 63,758,000.

The report of the Columbia Pictures Corporation, issued yesterday, showed a net profit after taxes and all charges of $304,000 for the thirteen weeks ended on March 26, equal to 34 cents a share on the 654,311 shares of common stock outstanding.

Dollar volume of sales of all business concerns will show an average loss of only 3.3 per cent in the second half of 1949 compared to the corresponding period last year, according to a nationwide survey made by Dun Bradstreet, Inc., and released yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Ralph S. Damon, president of Transcontinental Western Air, told the annual meeting of the Aviation Writers Association tonight that his company had signed a contract with the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation to buy twenty more Constellations of the latest type.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Housing Expediter Tighe E. Woods disapproved today a recommendation by the New York City Rent Advisory Board for an amendment to the rent regulation.

CAIRO, June 2 -- Beshir Al Saadawi, central figure of the Libyan Liberation Committee; Abdul Rahman Azzam Pasha, secretary general of the Arab League, and a large section of the Egyptian press expressed rage or bitter disappointment today over the declaration of Emir Sayid Idriss El Senussi of Cyrenaica's independence and the British Government's home-rule pledge for it.
The gentleman was 82 and to him all cities were Cincinnati.

ANNECY, France, June 2 (AP) -- The United States declined to ship coal mine drills to Czechoslovakia because they appeared to be intended for uranium mining, a United States delegate told the World Tariff Conference today.
HARTFORD, Conn., June 2 -Gov. Chester Bowles asked leaders of the Legislature today to abolish the Liquor Control Board and replace it with a single full-time Liquor Commissioner.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 2 -- An invitation to all Baptist groups in the country to join the Northern Baptist Convention in forming a single denomination of some 15,000,000 members was voted today by the annual meeting of Northern Baptists.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- James Lawrence Fly, former chairman of the Federal Communications Commission and now a practicing lawyer in New York, today told a press conference that he had personally presented to Attorney General Tom C. Clark a petition for a thorough investigation of wire-tapping in New York.

Lee Shubert, operator of the Majestic Theatre, where the musical hit "South Pacific" is playing, spent an hour yesterday with John M. Murtagh, commissioner of investigation, who is looking into the alleged overcharging for tickets to Broadway show hits.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 2 -- The newspaper Politika published today reports of serious economic difficulties in Bulgaria and Albania that may throw some light on the Soviet Union's renewed insistence that the capitalist West aid the economies of the Communist states of Eastern Europe.

Edward C. Maguire, coordinator of the Draft O'Dwyer Committee, announced yesterday that the goal for signatures to petitions to draft the Mayor for re-election had been raised from a million to 1,500,000 because of the tremendous response to the draft movement received at the committee's headquarters in the Commodore Hotel.

LINCOLN, Neb., June 2 -- Disturbed by the "current confusion across the nation," the Board of Regents of the University of Nebraska incorporated into its governing policy today a resolution of strong opposition to subversive doctrines.
The city's annual war on ragweed will start today, the Department of Health announced yesterday for the encouragement of hay-fever sufferers.

In the annual writing contests at Hunter College Ilona Karmel, a Polish student who came to this country thirteen months ago, won two prizes for short stories based on her experiences in a concentration camp and in a Swedish hospital.

Dr. Fernando de los Rios, former ambassador of the Spanish Republic to the United States, was buried yesterday morning beneath the flag he helped bring into being and which he had lived to see forbidden in his native country.

" The Aldrich Family" will be taking leave of the NBC airwaves on June 23, with its future next fall apparently depending on its potentialities as a television attraction. A video run-through of the program was made last week on kinescope film. If the film meets with a cordial reception from the sponsor, the program probably will be renewed.

Air Commandant Felicity Hyde Hanbury, director of the Women's Royal Air Force and top-ranking military woman in Great Britain, said yesterday that girls throughout the British Isles were enlisting for four years' service in the W. R. A. F. at the rate of 120 a month.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The bottle that contained some uranium-235, which mysteriously vanished from a Chicago atomic laboratory in February, has now been found, it was announced today.

At the annual meeting of stockholders of the National Department Stores Corporation held here yesterday, Harry H. Schwartz, president, disclosed that the sales trend has been and may continue to be consistently downward.
ORANGE, N. J., June 2 -- Four teen-age Girl Scouts from the Oranges will do their bit toward cementing international relations when they attend a Girls Guide Encampment in Quebec next month.
HANOVER, Germany, June 2 (AP) -- The influential Social Democratic party called today for German unity, with Germans deciding the form of their own economy and culture.

DETROIT, June 2 -- The issue was joined today on the first of two major fronts along which the Congress of Industrial Organizations will battle this summer for a fourth-round pattern calling for company-financed pensions, health life and care insurance, and a living-cost wage increase for its 6,000,000 members.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- By a resounding voice vote, the House passed and sent to the Senate today a bill liberalizing the Displaced Persons Act of 1948 so that 339,000 victims of Nazi or Communist oppression might find a permanent haven in this country.

FRANKFORT, Germany, June 2 (AP) -- A Brooklyn-born youth who "fell in love with Germany" said today that he intended to renounce his United States citizenship and become a German. He identified himself as Daniel F. McCarthy Jr. of New Hyde Park, Long Island, N. Y., son of a New York stockbroker who died in 1947.

Gene McDonald, the young wallpaper designer whose papers have been seen occasionally in special settings at Lord Taylor and Modernage, gave his first complete showing for the press this week at the Laurel Galleries, 108 East Fifty-seventh Street.
Three hundred friends and associates of Rose Schneiderman, retiring president of the New York Women's Trade Union League, attended a luncheon in her honor yesterday at Sherry's, 300 Park Avenue.

Wage earner families plan to buy 2,500,000 mechanical refrigerators, nearly 2,000,000 automobiles and 800,000 television sets, according to the Wage Earner Forum, sponsored by Macfadden Publications, Inc.

PARIS, June 2 -- Overriding the opinion of the advisory second House, the French National Assembly voted today for a system of double marketing of gasoline as a means of raising funds to meet the budget deficit. The new system for selling gasoline becomes law upon this second reading, and will be made effective Saturday.

LAKE SUCCESS, June 2 -- The first comprehensive global program to raise living standards in economically backward countries was outlined today in a United Nations proposal calling for an outlay of $85,942,383 during the first two years.
I have a few suggestions to make which I believe will help to reduce the great number of traffic accidents which we have in our city.
Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, president of Columbia University, paid his "personal" tribute yesterday afternoon to the American nursing corps of World War II.
A country fair atmosphere pervaded East Sixteenth Street between Third Avenue and Rutherford Place yesterday as St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church opened an old English Whitsuntide Fair.

Despite the realization that the line of policy thy have adopted may lead to hostilities, the Russian leaders do not want war at present, Lieut. Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, former Ambassador to Russia, declared yesterday.

A FAVORITE expression of the press box tenants of recent years is to say that so-and-so is "a real pro." Perhaps it's a term as old as baseball but it never before was used with such great frequency as it has been of late. Could it possibly be that there are such comparatively few pros in the big leagues that the ones still left are distinctive and a class apart?

CHICAGO, June 2 -- Long liquidation in wheat was resumed today and was especially heavy in the July position. After a firm opening the absence of demand was quickly noted and local selling increased. Shorts who covered yesterday turned to the selling side.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -The Senate today approved a bill to set up a National Monetary Commission for a study of the nation's money and credit system. The measure now goes to the House.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- During the week ended June 1, member bank reserve balances increased $49,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

CHICAGO, June 2 (AP) -- Prices of live hogs receded a little today for tile first time in [ more than two weeks. Most offerings were 25c a hundredweight lower, with receipts running well above trade expectations. Cattle were steady to 25c higher and sheep were mixed. Tile report by the United States Department of, [ A 2rlcuiture IoIlow:

SHANGHAI, June 2 -- Evacuation of Tsingtao, the last Nationalist pocket in North China, was reported in full swing tonight with the last units of the United States Navy completely clear of the seaport and Government units pulling out as fast as possible.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Department store sales in the week ended May 28 were 8 per cent below sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1948:

Britain's recognition of the Emir Sayid Idriss as head of the Government of Cyrenaica and Britain's pledges to that government are honorable and realistic. In 1942 the British Foreign Secretary, Anthony Eden, gave Britain's word that the faithful Senussi would not again be subject to Italian rule.

First awards to be granted this year by the new Freedom Foundation, Inc., for activities furthering better understanding of the American way of life will approximate $60,000, it was indicated yesterday in an official announcement of the organization's establishment.

LIMA, Peru, May 29 -- Gen. Manuel Odria, whose military junta has controlled Peru since the October, 1948, revolution, believes that a period of great expansion and new opportunities for foreign capital lie ahead in this country.

A new 8,000-foot instrument runway that will almost double the "bad-weather approach" capacity of the airports in the metropolitan area was put into regular operation yesterday at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.

Margaret O'Brien, 12-year-old actress, who was released from Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer contract, has been signed to record the voice of Alice in Walt Disney's projected all-cartoon version of the Lewis Carroll fantasy, "Alice in Wonderland," it was announced by the Disney office yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, June 2 (AP) -The Phillies hit five of their six home runs in the eighth inning to tie the major league record for circuit blows in one frame tonight as they defeated the Cincinnati Reds 12 -- 3. Andy Seminick hit three homers, two in the ten-run eighth, and the others were off the bats of Del Ennis, Willie Jones and Schoolboy Rowe.

Diamond prices advanced last month in Antwerp, after stabilization of price levels in all the diamond polishing centers of the world in April, it was reported yesterday by Albert E. Haase, executive director of the Jewelry Industry Council.
The Dodgers started playing ball at 8:30 last night at Ebbets Field, but it was 12:05 this morning and fourteen innings later when they conceded a 7-4 victory to the Cardinals.

Governors Island looked more like Coney Island than an Army post yesterday as the children of Fort Jay staged their third annual circus on the East Lawn opposite Building 100. A calliope played by a sergeant drowned out bugle calls, and Army tents along the midway housed everything from a baby elephant just flown in from Singapore to colonels' wives turned palmists for the day.

Summer being the season of sundresses, bathing suits and bare shoulders in one way or another, there has come the need in a smart girl's wardrobe for the cover top. Taking the cue, several designers have created a fine array of chic jackets and shirts which serve a multitude of purposes in both town and country.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -Congress passed today a compromise bill to provide critically needed storage facilities for the nation's bumper wheat crop. The compromise, which broke a long deadlock, was approved by both Senate and House and sent on to President Truman for his signature.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The national banks of the country had total assets of $85,000,000,000 on April 11, or about $3,000,000,000 less than the amount reported for Dec. 31, 1948, Preston Delano, Controller of the Currency, announced today.

BOSTON, June 2 (AP) -- Lefty Warren Spahn gave up but five hits while gaining his sixth victory for the Braves tonight with a 4-1 decision over Pittsburgh. Spahn had the Pirates blanked with only one more putout to go. The Tribesmen clinched matters with a two-run rally against Tiny Bonham in the fourth inning.

The week-end fishing possibilities are varied and promising at this writing, but with the weather man changing his mind every few minutes the angler is apt to leave home in bright sunshine and arrive at his fishing base in a howling downpour.

BOSTON, June 2 -- A strike of 2,212 employes of the Eastern Massachusetts Street Railway Company for a 15 - cent wage increase caused serious disruption of transportation today for 500,000 commuters in the seventy-eight communities served by the line.

In a special bulletin sent yesterday to retailers by the National Retail Dry Goods Association, warning was given against large consumer groups demanding preferential discounts. Lew Hahn, president of the association, named the American Federation of Labor and the National Student Association as two groups which have asked discounts in this manner. He warned reailers to resist all such efforts.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., June 2 -- If the private utility industry follows through on the numerous plans discussed here for the last three days to halt the expansion of public power, Gordon R. Clapp, chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority, Secretary of the Interior Julius A. Krug and other leading proponents of public power may expect a series of opposition moves from the "grass roots," industry and Congress itself.
A re-examination of the conditions under which benefit shows are staged in New York and elsewhere will be undertaken during the next three months by the Theatre Authority.

Although reluctant to commit themselves officially pending House action on the measure, steel industry officials admitted privately yesterday that the O'Mahoney Bill amending the Federal Trade Commission Act, passed unanimously by the Senate on Wednesday, seems to provide the authority they have been seeking to meet competitors' prices.

The United States Court of Appeals refused yesterday to order the reinstatement of three major league players suspended for five years when they jumped to the Mexican League in 1946 but said that their anti-trust suits against organized baseball should be tried as soon as possible.

HAVANA, June 2 -- The need to re-establish commerce between Latin America and Europe was voiced today at a meeting of the Economic Commission for Latin America by Gustavo Martinez Cabanas, executive secretary of the organization.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 2 -- Under the blue skies that have favored June-week exercises and the town's tercentenary since Monday, the Navy's flight exhibition team, the Blue Angels, gave a spectacular pre-graduation air show today over the United States Naval Academy.

MIAMI, June 2 (AP) -- Peggy Lennox of St. Petersburg, Fla., a former Royal Air Force ferry pilot, won the $2,000 Montreal to Miami all-woman air race on a figurative shoestring today. She landed more than an hour ahead of her nearest rival.

Demand by trade and producer interests advanced coffee futures on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Final prices in contract "S" were 9 to 33 points higher. Contract "D" followed a similar pattern and finished 20 to 28 points higher. The near-by months were the steadiest.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 2 -- H. A. Brassert, president of H. A. Brassert and Company of New York, a leading steel engineering firm, arrived tonight in Belgrade to discuss a proposal submitted by the Yugoslav Government early this year for the modernization and expansion of this country's steel industry.

PATERSON, N. J., June 2 --An nouncement was made here today that the Clifton Trust Company of Clifton, will become part of the First National Bank and Trust Company, of this city at the end of business on Friday, June 10 when liquidation will begin.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Economic policy revisions designed to increase Western Germany's contribution toward European recovery while removing restrictions on its trade with Marshall Plan countries are in preparation here incident to the shift from military to civilian administration of the bizonal area.

Earning assets of the reporting New York City member banks rose $50,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday, although business loans dropped $43,000,000. The decline in business loans, according to the figures issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, was the fourteenth in succession and brought the total outstanding to $4,798,000,000, the lowest level since Oct. 8, 1947.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- The first piece of President Truman's controversial civil rights program started today on the long and probably rough road through Congress.

Mayor O'Dwyer announced last night that the United States Air Force Materiel Coral mend would conduct an experimental flight, beginning at 9 P. M. on Monday, during which a new night illuminating device would be tested from a B-17 plane flying over the North and East Rivers.
EAST LANSING, Mich., June 3 (AP) -- Four first-string Michigan State baseball players were declared ineligible today by Western Conference Commissioner Leonard L. (Tug) Wilson.

The action of the Public Service Commission on Thursday, authorizing five private bus companies in Manhattan and the Bronx to file new tariffs calling for a one-cent rise in their interim present fares may bring to a head the controversy between the city and the state agency over the power to alter fares fixed in the franchises granted by the city to the companies, it was indicated yesterday.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 3 (AP) -- Yugoslavia served firm notice tonight that she would stand pat on her claim for "substantial reparations" and revision of its boundary with Austria as the price of an Austrian treaty.

High school seniors throughout the city will seek admission to New York's four municipal colleges under a new uniform entrance procedure that will be instituted this fall, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Harry D. Gideonse, president of Brooklyn College and chairman of the college's administrative council.

June and roses are synonymous. With the most popular of all flowers now blooming in gardens from Alabama to New Hampshire, they are the natural choice for arrangement. Although perfect greenhouse grown blossoms are available from florist shops twelve months of the year, garden roses make it possible for anyone to enjoy them for the next few weeks.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 3 -- The Yugoslav Government released today the text of its May 23 note to the Soviet Government in which it accused the latter of having transformed the Soviet-Yugoslav treaty of friendship, mutual assistance and post-war cooperation into a scrap of paper.

Federal Judge Harold R. Medina sent three defendants in the Communist trial to jail yesterday for contempt of court. He also notified all six members of defense counsel that he would take action against them later for persistent contempt throughout the twenty-week trial.

LONDON, June 3 (AP) -- Less than twenty-four hours after he knocked out Freddie Mills, British Heavyweight Bruce Woodcock signed today to fight Lee Savold of Englewood, N. J., for this country's version of the title vacated by Joe Louis.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 3 -- John S. Graham, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, speaking at commencement exercises at the United States Coast Guard Academy today, urged the fifty-seven graduating cadets to remember that they were dedicated to "a life of public service."
Twenty-five hundred persons attended a "Fight for Free Schools" rally last night in Carnegie Hall for which the Teachers Union, CIO was sponsor.
