WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Senator Bourke B. Hickenlooper declared today that "the possibility of espionage cannot be discounted at all" in the loss of some uranium 235 from a Chicago atomic. laboratory.

LONDON, Jun 3 -- South African gold-mining shares held the center of the stage in the stock markets here today. Following what was reported as a "fabulous" gold strike by Free State Gold Areas, a comparatively littleknown company, all of the Orange Free State issues made sharp rises.

The thirty-second annual summer series by the Goldman Band will open on Friday, June 17, at the Central Park Mall bandstand, with WNYC and WNYC-FM carrying the concert from 8:30 to 9:55 P. M. Sharing the baton with the perennial Edwin Franko Goldman for the initial concert will be Virgil Thomson and Robert Russell Bennett.
PHILADELPHIA, June 3 (AP) -The Philadelphia Phillies and the Cincinnati Reds ended today's double-header just where they started -- tied for fifth place in the National League pennant race.

Restrictions by Brazil on imports will continue under the new bill now being considered by the Brazilian Senate, "becoming tighter or looser in line with exchange availability, until the influx of dollars into Brazil through bigger investments and United States purchases make restrictions unnecessary," according to Jose Garrido-Torres, director of the Brazilian Government Trade Bureau here.

PARIS, June 3 -- The Ministry of the Interior announced today that it had arrested sixteen persons for allegedly plotting to overthrow the Government. The conspiracy, which did not appear to be very extensive, was apparently an effort on the part of a number of Charles de Gaulle's Reunion of the French People [RPF] to set up an anti-Communist intelligence network.
BERLIN, June 3 -- For the first time since June 16, 1948, the Russian commandant in Berlin, Maj. Gen. Alexander G. Kotikov met with his United States, British and French opposite numbers here today.
BOWLING GREEN, Ohio, June 3 (AP) -- Joe E. Brown, actor, today received the honorary degree of Doctor of Humane Letters from Bowling Green State University.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 3 -Francis P. Matthews, Secretary of the Navy, described the World crisis today as a "head-on collision" between Western Christian civilization and Marxist materialism that constituted the "gravest challenge" ever to threaten this country.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed 6 points higher to 4 points lower than the day before.

Hundreds of families are leaving hand-hewn homesteads and farms in the lush valley of the East Branch of the Delaware River in the south-central tier of the state to insure an adequate supply of drinking water for New York City, some 120 miles distant.

FRANKFORT, Germany, June 3 -- Dr. Kurt Schumacher, head of the Social Democratic party in Germany, threatened today to pull his party out of the elections planned next Aug. 14, when the new Western Government will name an executive and a legislature.

Although Bill Depperman is reported to be considering the idea, no one has yet worked out a radar attachment for a varmint rifle, so 'chuck shooters are unable to locate their quarry through the knee-high grass now clothing the pastures.

The Federal Communications Commission has granted a stay until July 1 of its ruling that would deny to Press Wireless, Inc., the right to handle Government traffic as it has been doing for the last seven years, William J. McCambridge, president of the carrier, announced yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, June 3 (AP) -- A Circuit Judge, denouncing the gift of automobiles to spectators by the St. Louis Cardinals, today accused Cardinal owner Fred Saigh of tying the club "to the tail of a gift enterprise lottery."
PARIS, June 3 -- Meeting in a secret session today, the Council of Foreign Ministers "definitely made progress" toward a solution of the Berlin problem.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., June 3 -- A Philadelphia pediatrician today raised the question of whether current idea of the best way to rear children is truly the best way for the long run of life.

Hutchens Advertising, Inc., has leased the entire eleventh floor in 16-18 West Forty-sixth Street for five years at an aggregate rent of $60,000 from the Botany Worsted Mills, Inc., in a transaction negotiated by Byrne, Bowman Forshay, Inc.
The Public Service Commission approved yesterday the sale of $16,000,000 of twenty-year 3 3/4 per cent sinking-fund debentures by the Long Island Lighting Company to four insurance companies.

Resurging from their three-hit shut-out of the night before, the Giants pounded the ball far and frequently yesterday to rout the Cubs, 15 -- 5, before 7,505 paying spectators and several thousand ladies day guests at the Polo Grounds. The triumph preserved their second-place tie with the Dodgers, one and a half games in back of the idle Braves.
It was with great interest that I read the recent NEW YORK TIMES article on the alleged waste of state moneys in the Department of Mental Welfare's handling of retarded children.

After a run of 265 performances, "Life With Mother" will end its local engagement at the Empire Theatre tonight. The successor to the record-shattering "Life With Father," which was performed here 3,213 times, had the longest run to date of any production to open on Broadway during the last season.

LONDON, June 3 -- The terms in which the management of the British state railways rejected tonight an ultimatum presented by the strikers has created a situation that is considered to be the most critical that has yet faced a nationalized industry in this country.

The official report of the National Health Assembly, held in Washington last year, will be brought out in early July in book form by Harper, entitled "America's Health: A Report to the Nation." The volume will include a digest of the assembly's debate and findings on the controversial issue of medical care as well as an introduction by Osear R. Ewing, Federal Security Administrator.
DETROIT, June 3 (AP) -- Present automobile prices will remain at their present level for a long time, a Ford Motor Company official told the Michigan automobile dealers' convention today.

OTTAWA, June 3 -- The 6,000-man Canadian Seamen's Union was suspended tonight by the Trades and Labor Congress, Canadian counterpart of the American Federation of Labor. The union's critics have charged that it was led by Communists.

Cause and effect were seldom more quickly wed than in the State Public Service Commission's endorsement of an 8-cent fare on several New York City bus lines. On Monday an arbitrator had brought in an award of nearly a million dollars in retroactive pay rises for bus drivers.
WASHINGTON, June 3 (UP) -Following is the text of the explanatory statement distributed to Democratic Senators on the Hill-Douglas-Morse-Aiken amendments to the Administration's labor bill:
JERSEY CITY, N. J., June 3 -- Frank Hague suffered another political defeat tonight when he withdrew as director of the campaign to elect State Senator Elmer Wene Governor on the Democratic ticket.

CLEVELAND, June 3 (AP) -- A suit to remove Alvanley Johnston, head of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers, as a trustee of the union's assessment mortuary fund was filed in Common Pleas Court today.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Eastern railroads asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today for permission to increase passenger fares in coaches, and in sleeping and parlor cars, by 12 1/2 per cent. This would make coach fares 3.375 cents a mile, and sleeping and parlor car fares 4.5 cents a mile.
The new Army looked even newer yesterday as four soldiers arrived in town and were told by a high-ranking officer to "go out and have a helluva good time."
WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- A Navy diver died today after suffering chemical burns and becoming unconscious during a dive yesterday in the naval gun factory's eight-foot deep experimental tank.

The ancient Jewish festival of Shabuoth, commemorating the giving of the Ten Commandments to Moses on Mount Sinai, was celebrated yesterday in temples and synagogues throughout the city. Reform Jews ended their observance at sundown last night, and members of the Orthodox and Conservative faiths will end their commemorative programs at sundown tonight.

A memorial honoring those who served in the last war and symbolizing the need for universal peace will be dedicated at 4 P. M. tomorrow in St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street.

HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., June 3 -- Recreation leaders in Westchester will converge here tomorrow for the housewarming of the new $80,000 Hastings Youth Center, the first specially designed municipal clubhouse for teen-agers that any community in the county has succeeded in constructing.

Six instances of false testimony were admitted yesterday by Whittaker Chambers as Lloyd Paul Stryker, defense counsel for Alger Hiss, continued to hammer at the character of the key witness for the second successive trial day.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 3 -- Egmont Arens, New York City industrial designer, said today that automatic merchandising is Americas fastest growing industry and is now at the beginning of a tremendous boom.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- A proposal of the Maine Central Railroad Company to modify its outstanding 30,000 shares of 5 per cent cumulative preferred stock from a par value of $100 to $185, thus taking up an arrearage of $85 in dividends, will be submitted to stockholders if the Interstate Commerce Commission accepts the recommendations made today by its examiner, John L. Bradford.

The Public Service Commission authorized the New York Telephone Company yesterday to increase its charges for monthly service by 8 per cent on an interim basis and to adjust its tolls for long distance service within the state to produce 10 per cent more from this source.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- W. Stuart Symington, Secretary of the Air Force, denied "categorically" today reports of political and other factors influencing the Air Force's choice of the large B-36 bomber as its primary weapon.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 3 -- The Northern Baptist Convention, with its 1,500,000 members, was put on record at its annual meeting today as opposing "the present national policy of preparation for atomic war" and as favoring "the development of atomic energy along peacetime and constructive lines, such as medical and biological research."
EPSOM, England, June 3 (AP) -- Gordon Richards rode five winners in succession at Epsom Downs yesterday and today and kinked hopes that his luckless record in the Derby would end tomorrow.

TRENTON, N. J., June 3 -- A second New York bond dealer, Nat Tollner, testified today before an investigating commission to a profit in a bond deal with New Jersey. The inquiry stems from the $185,000 profit that Saul Schwamm, of Schwamm Co., New York brokers, made last fall in selling $3,405,000 of New York State housing bonds to the $50,000,000 New Jersey disability insurance fund.

MOSCOW, June 3 -- Dispatches from Paris indicate that thus far the Big Four Foreign Ministers' discussions have done more to reveal the basic differences in Western and Soviet viewpoints than to indicate possible grounds for a mutual agreement on German questions.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., June 3 -- Studies at the Cornell University Medical College and the New York Hospital have revealed a new mechanism that regulates the circulation of the blood in the peripheral blood vessels, it was reported here today at the annual meeting of the American Heart Association.

ROME, June 3 -- Italy is now in a position to undertake and "carry out aggressively" an expanded investment program, Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, said today in a special message on the Italian recovery program.

Johann Wolfgang von Goethe will be shown to New York as an important biologist, anatomist and physicist as well as one of the worlds great writers when an exhibition dedicated to his 200th birth anniversary is opened to the public Monday at the New York Academy of Medicine, 2 East 103d Street.
Imagine what New York City would be like without its voluntary hospitals, health and social welfare agencies -- the ones we support not through taxes but through contributions given voluntarily.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The Truman Administration will retreat from its hitherto unyielding position favoring its own labor relations bill and will accept the best bill it can get in the form of a revised law. This was the major development of a Democratic Senatorial conference today at which "middle - of - the - road" members urged adherence to five bipartisan amendments.

American Airlines and United Air Lines announced yesterday that they had requested the Civil Aeronautics Board to extend the "family-fare plan" of reduced rates to the end of March, 1950. Under the last CAB extension of the air travel plan, June 30 is the deadline for such service.

Charles L. Morse Jr. of Hemphill, Noyes Co. was elected president of the Bond Club of New York at the annual meeting held yesterday in connection with the club's field day at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club at Scarborough, N. Y. He succeeds George J. Leness of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane, who has been president for the last year.

It was reported yesterday in Democratic circles that Senator Robert F. Wagner, who has been in ill health for several years, would resign before the deadline of July 8 to enable his successor to be elected this year and that his son, Robert F. Wagner Jr., chairman of the City Planning Commission, had strong labor support for the Democratic nomination.

PARIS, June 3 -- After ten days of sharp discussions, the National Assembly passed today Premier Henri Queuille's financial reform bill, which aims to cover all estimated deficit of about 80,000,000,000 francs in the budget. As adopted by the Assembly the measure is expected to raise the needed funds with help of a special law raising the price of gasoline which was voted yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, June 3 -- The United States is expected to demand rigid screening and extensive paring down of many of the global projects tentatively scheduled by the United Nations in its two-year $85,942,383 program of aid for economically backward countries.
Your recent editorial, "Policy in the Pacific," touched upon a timely and important question relating to the future of practically the whole of Asia.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The New England Power Company, Boston, field today with the Securities Exchange Commission a registration statement covering $5,000,000 of series C bonds, due July 1, 1979, to be sold at competitive bidding.

SEATTLE, June 3 (AP) -- A chief gunner's mate hurled a blazing 20 MM. shell magazine overboard from the Navy destroyer Maddox yesterday, preventing serious damage to his vessel and possibly saving the lives of several of her Naval Reserve crew.

CHICAGO, June 3 -- After touching new lows today since early last spring, the wheat market on the Board of Trade reversed its trend in the late trading, recovered early losses and finished above the previous close. The basis for the buying was the rise in the Kansas City cash market, which was 4 to 5 cents higher for old-crop wheat.
TOKYO, June 3 -- Premier Shigeru Yoshida gave the Cabinet today a new ten-point policy program. An outline of it follows:

MIAMI, Fla., June 3 (AP) -- Help reached the distressed 10,803-ton oil tanker flagship Sinco in the Atlantic off Florida today. The big steamship wallowed with her stern only two feet out of the water as the Coast Guard cutters Aurora and Blackhaw pulled alongside.

The Cunard White Star liner Franconia put to sea Thursday on the first run of her service between Liverpool and Quebec with Capt. Charles S. Williams, a veteran of thirty years sea experience, on her bridge.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 3 -- Czechoslovak relations with Yugoslavia took a turn for the worse today with the official announcement that a group of Czechoslovak mechanics erecting a steam plant at Skoplje had been recalled in reprisal against the maltreatment of one of them by Yugoslav militiamen.
Four companies announced yesterday omission of declarations of dividends customarily made about this time of year. Two other companies deferred action and another reduced it rate.

For more than a decade the question of ownership of off-shore oil lands has been at issue between the federal and state governments. These lands, lying off the California and the Gulf coasts, have produced millions of dollars' worth of oil and are potential producers of many millions more.

OSSINING, N. Y., June 3 -- An unnamed Sing Sing prisoner remained near his cell here tonight waiting to see whether he would develop leukemia, one of the most deadly forms of cancer, after having volunteered for a perilous medical experiment in an effort to save the life of an 8-year-old girl.

The Congressional decision to postpone Senate consideration of the Atlantic pact and to defer -perhaps to another session -- any discussion of an arms-aid program must inevitably weaken the position of our negotiators at the Paris meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers.
MOSCOW, June 3 (AP) -- A new decree of the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet today provided increased benefits to mothers. The presidium acts for the Soviet, or parliament, when it is not in session.

Girl Scouts are carrying on their programs abroad under extreme difficulties with the utmost resourcefulness, Miss Clementine Miller, chairman of the International Committee of the Girl Scouts, reported yesterday at its national headquarters, 155 East Forty-fourth Street.

The week-end will witness the arrival of three new films at midtown theatres. Both of today's entries come from abroad, one from Austria and the other Germany. "Operetta," writen, directed by and starring Willy Forst, will open at the Fifty-fifth Street Playhouse.

Hezekiah Cobb invites our attention to the announcement by a scribe of the Thoroughbred Racing Association of the United States that "another Derby" is due to be run today. And he wonders what Englishmen think of that way of designating the grandfather of all Derbys.

The New York Council of the American Association of Advertising Agencies announced yesterday that records of successful candidates in the 1949 examinations for advertising aspirants here have been prepared according to job categories for concerns seeking new personnel.
In the midst of the great debate on economy in government, I hope THE NEW YORK TIMES will allow me to submit a postscript to my previous letter on tax and spending policy.

The stock market edged closer yesterday to the low marks of last year as the moderate support that had nipped the plunge earlier this week evaporated in the face of limited offerings. Only a few exaggerated declines on the Stock Exchange developed as a result of the fresh selling, and the composite rate there was reduced 0.66 point.

Recent studies indicate that a surprisingly large number of persons being treated for "arthritis" or "rheumatism" are actually suffering pangs engendered by maladjustments in home or business life, according to speakers who addressed the International Congress on Rheumatic Diseases yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Elimination of unfit drivers and vehicles, more pedestrian control and the curbing of political protection for highway offenders were designated today as outstanding road safety needs at the closing session of the President's Highway Safety conference here.

To the experienced housewife the task of keeping pots and pans sparkling clean is just part of the day's work. But those who are still neophytes in the kitchen find this an onerous job. They're the ones who undoubtedly will be pleased with a newly invented liquid, Pantastic, that simplifies the cleaning of cooking utensils.
DETROIT, June 3 -- Mrs. Anna Ganley, 45-year-old Russian-born wife of Nat Ganley, editor of The Michigan Worker, a Communist publication, was arrested today and held for deportation proceedings.
New York's sixty-five-day-old brewery strike probably will come to an end today or tomorrow, it was learned yesterday.

The A. O. Smith Corporation, manufacturer of automotive parts and equipment for other industries, reported yesterday a net profit of $4,826,919 for the nine months ended on April 30. This is equal to $4.83 a share and compares with $4,807,346 or $4.81 a share earned in the corresponding period of the previous fiscal year.

LAKE SUCCESS, June 3 -- The Israeli Government has offered to allow 230,000 Arab refugees to make their homes in Israeli territory. provided that Egypt turns over to Israel the Gaza coastal strip, where the refugees now are, usually well-informed sources said today.

R. W. Steere Jr. has been appointed assistant chief engineer of the Plymouth Motor Corporation, replacing A. W. Ross, who has been transferred to an executive assignment with the Chrysler Corporation's central engineering division.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 3 (AP) -- Czechoslovakia offered today to restore citizenship to 180,000 German nationals still living in the country. Their Czechoslovak citizenship was taken from them after the German Army of occupation was driven from the country in 1945.
WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -The threat of an Oak Ridge atomic energy strike Thursday was eased today by the prospect that the case would be taken over by a Federal labor panel.

Seventy thousand daily passengers -- including racing fans traveling to Belmont Park -- were without bus service in Queens yesterday when 168 employes of the Jamaica Bus Lines struck in protest against alleged reduction of service by the company.

ORADELL, N. J., June 3 -- Miss Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches won low gross honors with a record one under women's par 38, 34 -- 72 at the Hackensack Golf Club course in the women's New Jersey Golf Association weekly one-day tournament today.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- An International officer of the International Printing Pressmen's Union, AFL, told House investigators today that he knew of no protests being made by members against the acts of the late George L. Berry as president.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Miss Rosamond Gilder, chairman of the Panel on Dramatic Arts of the United States Commission for UNESCO, today issued an appeal to 2,000 professional, school and community theatre groups to dramatize world peace, human rights, and international understanding.
DETROIT, June 3 (AP) -- Hal Newhouser stopped the Philadelphia Athletics with eight hits today as the Detroit Tigers took a 4-3 decision for a sweep of their three-game series here.
Within a comparatively few months New York's millions will begin to feel the benefits of broadened and improved municipal hospital service as institutions under construction reach completion.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, was challenged today by Senator James P. Kem, Republican, of Missouri, to debate publicly the question of the use of Marshall Plan funds to aid the recovery of participating countries that had nationalized basic industries.
WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- An attorney for the General Accounting Office expressed concern today "at the complete lack of fiscal control by Congress" over armed services' post exchange transactions.

There'll be a weighty problem before the house in the No. 1 attraction at Belmont Park today. It's the $15,000 added Peter Pan Handicap, a mile-and-a-furlong run for 3-years-olds, and Handicapper John Blanks Campbell's weight assignments make it a three-star puzzler for the form scholars.

Club and college athletes from this area will tune up for forthcoming championship and international competition in the 153d Spring Games of the New York Athletic Club at Travers Island today. First event is at 3 P. M.

Andrew G. Clauson Jr., Board of Education member from Richmond and as former president, confirmed yesterday a report that he had refused to accept the chairmanship of a special committee offered to him by Maximilian Moss, his successor in a bitterly contested election three weeks ago.

Manufacturers of better lines of women's apparel need have no qualms concerning the success of the fall season, according to Paul Parnes, president of the couture house bearing his name. A combination of circumstances, he said, favor the placement of early orders for the higher priced merchandise and there is very little doubt that the smart retailer will order in depth.

Retail sales continued to decline during the week, compared with the corresponding period last year. Department store sales here were estimated to be about 15 per cent below last year. Sales last week were 9 per cent below the corresponding week in 1948.

The decision of the Federal Communications Commission to relax its ban against radio stations editorializing in their own name raises perhaps more questions than it answers. As suggested in a statement by Commissioner Edward M. Webster, the commission's new policy is likely to leave the broadcaster "in a state of quandary" on this important aspect of freedom of speech on the air.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- British rejection of a United States protest against the quota system applied to American motion-pictures was called "completely unacceptable" today by two major Hollywood organizations.

MACON, Ga., June 3 (UP) -- A Federal grand jury has indicted a deputy sheriff and seven other residents of Harris County, Ga., in connection with the alleged mob beating of a Negro more than a year ago, it was disclosed today.

Emily Investors, Inc., sold to an investing client of Herman M. Glassner, attorney, the six-story apartment house for forty-two families, on a plot 100 by 100 feet, at 3439 Knox Place, the Bronx, through Elroy-Clark Co., brokers, and Anne Inselstein, co-operating broker.

Federal Judge Samuel H. Kaufman denied yesterday a request of the Securities and Exchange Commission that he appoint a receiver for the Third Avenue Transit Corporation pending his approval or rejection of a petition for reorganization of the company under the bankruptcy laws.

WINDSOR, Ont., June 3 -- The economic demands of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, parallel in effect to those being advanced by the union in the United States, were rejected flatly today by the Ford Motor Company of Canada.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 3 -- A new dispute has arisen between Lebanon and Syria just when relations were believed to have been restored to normal, it was reported tonight. The Syrians, without advance notice, have been turning back shipments of Lebanese threads and textiles on the ground that they are preparing new protective laws for their own industries.

BLUEFIELD, W. Va., June 3 -John L. Lewis plied Southern coal operators today with more questions about the affairs of their organization, but they turned most of them aside and insisted that he get down to the business of negotiating a contract.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., June 3 -- A dawn visit to the empty fire-scarred tenement at 671 Montgomery Street, in which five persons lost their lives May 4, resulted, the police said, in a confession today from Joseph C. Lorden, 31-year-old unemployed laborer, that he had started the fire.

MOUNDSVILLE, W. Va., June 3 (AP) -- Fourteen "dangerous" criminals disappeared in this upper Ohio River Valley area today after quietly cutting their way out of the "tough section" in West Virginia's State Penitentiary.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 3 -- Monte Proser, producer of the Broadway musical, "High Button Shoes," disclosed today that he and the Nasser brothers, owners of the General Service Studios, are forming a corporation to be known as Proser-Nasser Productions which will film the musical comedy here late this summer.
WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- The Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service intervened today in an effort to head off threatened strikes in the shipping industry on the East, Gulf and West Coasts.
The "toothaches" that Edward Francis Murphy complained about when he visited Brooklyn dentists during the last year became one big headache yesterday in Brooklyn Felony Court.

After more than forty-five years in the same family, the two-story commercial building at 522 East Seventy-fourth Street has been sold by Edward F. Opitz to Dr. J. Sterling for use as an animal crematorium. The sale was arranged for cash by Hardy, Brauneis Naumann, Inc., Martin D. Greenwald and Sidney C. Edelman, brokers.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- Federal attorneys said today the Government might have to drop the six-week-old espionage trial of Judith Coplon if the trial judge ruled they must disclose "vital secrets."

If the Dodgers had their way, Stan Musial, a menace with a bat, would never be permitted to approach the plate, let alone swing at a pitch. This, however, comes under the heading of wishful thinking, since the rules dictate that every man is entitled to his turn.

The 400th anniversary of the first English printing of the Book of Common Prayer will be observed beginning tomorrow by Protestant Episcopal churches in the United States arid churches of the Anglican communion all over the world.

New low prices for the season were registered again in cottonseed oil futures on the New York Produce Exchange yesterday. Lower cash markets in the South encouraged hedging pressure, selling and liquidation. Prices broke 22 to 45 points.

The L. G. Corporation has purchased the vacant plot on the west side of Grand Avenue, south of Sheffield Avenue, in Englewood, N. J., for improvement with three new store, buildings, according to the Rothman Realty Corporation, the broker in the transaction.

LONDON, June 3 -- Rudolf Bing, Vienna - born impresario who reached the pinnacle of musical fame with his appointment as next managerial director of the Metropolitan Opera Company in New York, today was high in his praise of the quality of young American singers.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The National Military Establishment withdrew today its Consolidation Directive No. 1, which had been criticized as a "gag" on the public statements of military officials.

A plea to business leaders to join in eliminating racial and religious discord in the community was made yesterday by Vincent R. Impellitteri, president of the council, in presenting awards to two business executives on behalf of the National Conference of Christians and Jews.
STANTON, Del., June 3 (AP) -Bobanet Stable's Attention Mark, owned and bred by R. Bruce Livie of Baltimore, scored an impressive victory in the Delmar Purse at Delaware Park today.
The 167th convention of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York will convene in adjourned session on Oct. 25 to elect a bishop coadjutor, it was learned yesterday.
Harlem gave an enthusiastic welcome yesterday to James Edward, Negro star of the motion-picture play, "Home of the Brave." The actor praised New York for its show of democracy.

LAKE SUCCESS, June 3 (UP) -Russia today lost her fight in the United Nations subcommission on freedom of information to gain priority for debate on anti-warmongering measures; then won a propaganda battle on definition of the warmongering issue.

An offering of $20,000,000 in super-highway bonds will be made by Cook County, Ill., in which the City of Chicago is situated, on June 21. The bonds, bearing interest not to exceed 4 per cent will be dated July 1, 1949, and will be due on July 1, 1969 with optional retirement dates July 1, 1950-68.

NANKING, June 3 -- Six weeks after she first became involved in battle with Communist shoreline batteries the British sloop Amethyst is still stranded in the Yangtze River off Silver Island, about forty-five miles northeast of Nanking. Thus far the new captain, Lieut. Comdr. J. S. Kerns, has been unable to obtain a safe-conduct pass that would permit the damaged vessel to return to Shanghai.

PRAGUE, June 3 -- Religious questions are inseparable from the struggle to establish socialism in Czechoslovakia, Premier Antonin Zapotocky told 11,000 Communist party functionaries of the Prague region in a speech last night on the lessons of the ninth party congress.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended May 28, 1949, totaled 784,824 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 10,913 cars, or 1.4 per cent, more than for the preceding week; 119,933 cars, or 13.3 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 45,381 cars, or 5.5 per cent, fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

A well-dressed thief paid a ten-cent fare for Harry Wolff, 35 years old, of 190 East Third Street, yesterday, but it cost Mr. Wolff's concern, the Ford Fish Company, of 113 South Street, in the heart of the Fulton Fish Market, $1,308.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board declined today to authorize further unlimited operations by "large irregular carriers" in spite of a direct request to do so made by Senator Edwin C. Johnson, Democrat, of Colorado, chairman of the Senate Commerce Committee.

In his stimulating address on "Man and Science" before the International Congress on Rheumatic Diseases David Sarnoff emphasized the need of an integrated approach to man and his ills by groups of scientists, an approach that has been advocated editorially for years by this newspaper.

CHICAGO, June 3 -- The end of the Ford Motor Company strike in Detroit will not prevent 1,450 of the company's workers in Chicago from receiving unemployment pay for the time they were idle, Samuel C. Bernstein, director of the State Unemployment Compensation Division, said today.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, Va., June 3 (AP) -- Federal Security Administrator Oscar R. Ewing told the drug industry today that national health insurance would increase its business.
Decision was reserved yesterday in the appellate term of Special Sessions on an appeal to set aside the vagrancy case convictions of Nancy Fletcher Choremi and two other women.

The National Retail Furniture Association, representing 8,000 independent home furnishing stores, yesterday asked Congress to curb operations of Army Post Exchanges and Navy Ships Service Stores which represent unfair competition to private home furnishings merchants.

A number of durable goods manufacturers have started a drive against psychological factors of the current recession by guaranteeing distributors against losses on inventories in a variety of lines. Two types of plans are now being pushed.

PARIS, June 3 -- New proposals for a general return to competition in trade among the European nations by reduction of quotas and licenses were made today both by Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the British Exchequer, and Maurice Petsche, French Finance Minister, to the ministerial steering committee of the European Marshall Plan Council.

The decision of the Eastern railroads to seek a further rise of 12 1/2 per cent in passenger fares at this time came yesterday as a surprise to the financial community. With passenger traffic smaller than it was a year ago and with costs of operation higher little doubt was expressed that the railroad needed more revenue from passenger business in order to make ends meet.

ALBANY, June 3 -- The Court of Appeals held today that charges of exceeding the fifty-mile-an-hour speed limit on state highways must be accompanied by proof that the State Traffic Commission had not authorized a higher limit for the particular part of highway involved.
Fundamentally it was the same as any high school graduation. There was a valedictorian, there was a class, and as the graduates stepped forward to receive their diplomas, the audience applauded.

New York fashions travel far afield, but Elizabeth Kiendl reversed the usual direction of the business flow when she decided to become a dress designer. Formerly a sportswear model in this city, she took off not long ago for the Virgin Islands and set up her own business.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., June 3 -- A father-and-son team shared qualifying honors with a best ball score of 33, 37 -- 70 in the annual member-guest tourney of the Hempstead Golf Club. Dan Casey senior and junior collaborated on a round that was equaled only by the former Long Island amateur champion, Mal Galletta of North Hills and Paul Engels of the home club.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- Hearings are to be started June 14 by the House Commerce Committee on a bill to increase the working capital of the Federal Barge Lines, Representative Hale Boggs, Democrat, of Louisiana, said today.
LAKE SUCCESS, June 3 -Backed by the Western delegations, China formally moved today to dismiss further debate on the Soviet Union's proposals for control of atomic energy.
WEST ORANGE, N. J., June 3 -The annual member-guest invitation golf tournament of the Rock Spring club resulted in a three-way tie for top honors today with a best ball of 66.

Sir Frank Beaurepaire, chairman of the Australian Olympic Committee, said yesterday there still was a possibility that the 1956 games in Melbourne would be held in December and January to accommodate American college athletes.

Courtesy is "a friendly nod -- the flash of light that can make a weary path a bright one." It is "the back of the coin of charity." It is "a manner of living which you hardly think about as you go about your daily routine."

PARIS, June 3 -- Since the Paris Conference is the direct result of the Atlantic Pact, the Senate's decision to put off ratification while the fate of the Conference hangs in doubt is badly timed, to say the least. It was confidently expected here that the treaty would be reported out of committee with unanimous endorsement on the day this meeting opened.

The decks are at last cleared for the opening of debate in the Senate Monday on the controversial issue of labor legislation. A group of Administration leaders has been conferring with Republican liberals on the matter for several days past, and has agreed on a "five-point program" designed to win over liberal Republicans and moderate Southerners.

Edward C. Maguire, coordinator of the Draft O'Dwyer Committee, announced yesterday that Generoso Pope, newspaper publisher, would start a personal letter-writing campaign to New York residents of Italian ancestry to get support for the draft movement.
ST. LOUIS, June 3 (AP) -- The Missouri-Pacific Railroad won out today in a legal battle over control of the Gulf Coast Lines, a subsidiary group.

NOORDWIJK, The Netherlands, June 3 (AP) -- The United States tennis champion, Richard Gonzales of Los Angeles, reached the semi-finals of the Dutch international tournament today along with the man he defeated in the title match at Forest Hills last year, Eric Sturgess of South Africa.

PARIS, June 3 -- According to a secret protocol governing economic relations between the Soviet Union and its five principal satellites in Eastern Europe, those countries are "obligated" to follow Moscow's advice on industrial and commercial affairs for a period of twenty years.

At best, life today is only primitive if judged by the standard set at the first International Inventors Exposition in Grand Central Palace, where almost 400 new-fangled contrivances go on public display for a week beginning at noon today.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Robert K. McConnaughey, a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission for the last five and a half years, will leave the agency on Sunday to return to private business, the White House announced today.
Congratulations on your valuable editorial "A Strike That No One Won," giving pertinent facts regarding the Ford strike.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.3 per cent in the week ended May 31, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index was 156.1 per cent of the 1926 average, 0.6 per cent higher than four weeks ago and 5.2 per cent lower than in the comparable week of 1948.

The DP bill as passed by the House of Representatives represents a tremendous improvement over the illiberal and unsatisfactory law now on the statute books. While not perfect, it goes far to redeem the hitherto timorous position of the United States on refugee questions.

PRETORIA, South Africa, June 13 -- South Africans were stirred today by news of a "fabulous strike" and the magic word "gold" is again on every lip. After a song series of sluggish months, prices made wild jumps on the Johannesburg Stock Exchange.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, June 3 (UP) -Union leaders called off the nation-wide railway strike today. Bolivia's six-day labor crisis appeared near an end.

ST. LOUIS, June 3 (AP) -- The Washington Senators combined fourteen hits with five Brownie errors to overwhelm the slump-ridden St. Louisans tonight, 12 to 3. It was the cellar dwellers' ninth straight defeat and their eighth in as many contests with the high-flying Senators.
LONDON, June 3 -- Harold Wilson, president of the Board of Trade, said today prices of British goods in Canada must come down even if it meant lower profits than could be made in other markets.
CLEVELAND, June 3 (AP) -- A six-run first inning enabled Early Wynn to coast to an 8 to 1 victory today over the Boston Red Sox. His Cleveland Indian team-mates slashed out 10 hits.

Mayor O'Dwyer's announcement that a two-year survey will be made looking to reclassification of civil service jobs and revision of pay scales constitutes recognition of one of the essentials of good government. The Mayor took a preliminary step in this direction last December when he designated the Budget Director and the president of the Municipal Service Commission to make such a study, in six months.

"THE SCANDALS AND CREDULITIES OF JOHN AUBREY," edited by John Collier, lightened the encircling gloom of the early depression years for a good many people who happened to read that raffish garland of sketches by the seventeenth-century Englishman who was at once Winchell and Pepys and Boswell to many of the celebrated and/or notorious people of his day, or thereabouts.

SHANGHAI, Saturday, June 4 -In the week since Communist armies drove the Nationalists out of this city, foreign businessmen who stayed behind to try to operate under the new regime have found the Communists promoting evolution rather than revolution and mutual respect between labor and management rather than class warfare.

SAN FRANCISCO -- It does a New Yorker en route good, and an expatriate New Yorker even more good, to ride the San Francisco Bay ferryboats. For the salt air and the feel of a deck rolling underfoot the way only a snub-nosed ferry boat rolls will remind him of home.
PARIS, June 4 (AP) -- Two industrialists were arrested today and charged with being members of a band plotting to "demoralize the army." Government sources said the band is anti-Communist.

DEEMS TAYLOR has made a third book out of the radio talks that he has delivered during the intermissions of the Sunday afternoon broadcasts of the New York Philharmonic - Symphony Orchestra. Like the first two, "Of Men and Music" and "The Well- Tempered Listener," the latest, "Music to My Ears," is full of good, fresh talk.

ST. LOUIS, June 4 -- For a few moments at Sportsman's Park today the Browns threatened complications for the Yankees. Before a gathering of 4,257 incredulous observers, midway of the opening game between the clubs at the two extremes of the American League standing, the cellar-dwellers of Zach Taylor crept to within a run of the league-leaders.
PARIS, June 4 -- It was fairly evident by the end of this week that any lingering hopes of an agreement between the Soviet Union and the Western powers had vanished.

THESE strange adventures of a little Indian boy will appeal to most youngsters from 5 to 8. Ali has always dreamed of caring for the Maharaja's animals. When a baby elephant is captured, Ali makes friends with him.

ONE of the things that worry many of us in the American theatre is that the drama has no real roots in our country's life. We have no national theatre; there is no fountainhead of dramatic experimentation; there is no permanent repertory for the classics of the theatre and, with a few notable exceptions, drama seldom becomes a community project.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 4 -- The Mufti of Jerusalem and Syrian Premier Husni Zayim have reached an agreement on military cooperation, it is learned from a highly reliable Arab source. Personal representatives of the Mufti, Haj Amin el-Husseini, have recently finished talks with General Zayim in Damascus and a special Palestinian regiment of the Mufti's men, to be attached to the Syrian Army, is being formed.
BERLIN, June 4 (AP) -- West Berlin's railway strikers proposed today that the German railroad administration split itself into two business offices along East-West lines to end the two-week walkout.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (UP) -- The Democratic National Committee announced tonight that top-ranking party leaders, labor officials and representatives of farm groups will meet at Des Moines, Iowa, June 12 "to consider the farm situation."
COLORADO SPRINGS -- Loyal Coloradans will tell you this summer that the loftiest state in the Union has something to satisfy the whims, however capricious, of every conceivable kind of traveler.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 4 -- The official organ of the Czechoslovak Communist party indicated today that the Government would try to halt the flow of "directives, instructions and announcements" that have been contained in recent letters from Archbishop Josef Beran to the Roman Catholic clergy and members of the Government.

Maj. Gen. Philip B. Fleming, whose nomination as chairman of the United States Maritime Commission was recently approved by the Senate, will be sworn into his new post tomorrow morning in the commission's Washington offices.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The National Military Establishment disclosed today a program for a six-day ten-state aircraft detection exercise early in September with thousands of civilian spotters working in conjunction with radar stations.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Representative Eugene D. O'Sullivan, Democrat, of Nebraska, today said that Congress should investigate the "right-wingers" as well as the "left-wingers."

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The transfer from the House to the Senate of the immediate struggle over new labor legislation has outlined more clearly the political factors that dominate the legislative issues. That is because the Senate is a much smaller body than the House, and the play and counter-play of the political forces there are easier for the spectators to see.

YOU sit at home beside your packed suitcase, one eye on your fretting wife, the other on the clock that points nearly to 10. It is the first morning of your vacation. By this time, according to schedule, you should be relaxed in a chauffeured limousine heading up the parkway.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Prospects for an adjustment of the threatened strike at the Oak Ridge (Tenn.) atomic-energy plant increased today when President Truman completed the organization of the special three-man labor relations panel that is authorized to settle disputes at atomic energy plants.

The New York Stock Exchange, in an effort to stimulate business, has ruled that member brokerage firms may reduce the initial margin requirements on new transactions to a minimum of $500 from the previous rate of $1,000. The new minimum will be effective tomorrow.

A SIMMON BROTHERS enlarger in the medium-price field has just been announced by the company. The new unit is the Omega B-4, a manual-focusing enlarger for negatives from 2 1/4x3 1/4 inches to 35mm, selling for $99.50 plus tax. With a Bausch Lomb 3 5/8-inch lens, the price is $134.75, tax included.
HOUSTON, Tex., June 4 (AP) -- Two persons were in critical condition today following a head-on automobile collision that killed six persons, including five members of a Texas-Indiana family.

Widely hailed new methods for inhibiting tooth decay, such as the impregnation process and ammoniated dentifrices, have been "foisted on the public" without adequate clinical testing, while dentists have been "carried along on the wave," the annual meeting of the American Academy of Dental Medicine was told yesterday.

LONDON, June 4 (Reuters) -- A fifth-wicket stand of sixty-seven in as many minutes by F. Smith (43 not out) and Martin Donnelly (36) redeemed some slow batting by the New Zealanders against Glamorgan at Cardiff today. The tourists had scored 204 for five at close of play.
AT this time of year, porches and terraces become inviting places. While these outdoor living rooms are being fixed up for several months' use, they may be brightened with a few plants.

TORONTO -- The opportunity of catching a glimpse of the frontiers of civilization is attracting many vacationists to northern Ontario. New roads, built since the end of the war, new resorts, new air services and fishing camps attest to the growing popularity of the area which starts about 200 miles north of Toronto and stretches up to Hudson Bay.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., June 4 -- Jim Fuchs and Vic Frank, Yale's Olympic weight-throwers, stole the spotlight from the runners and the jumpers with record-breaking performances in the shot-put and discus throw in the 153d Spring Games of the New York Athletic Club at Trivers Island today.

ASBURY Park -- The boardwalk, as exemplified by those at Asbury Park and Atlantic City, is a strange institution. On the very edge of broad beaches and the rolling Atlantic Ocean, the boardwalk offers so many counter-attractions that one could, if one were so inclined, spend a vacation on the boardwalk without ever setting foot on sand or in the water.

When, after considerable delay, Congress voted United States' participation in the World Health Organization of the U. N. a year ago, the move was rightly regarded as an obvious and necessary step toward international cooperation. At that time, however, the House of Representatives placed a permanent ceiling of $1,920,000 on our contribution to the organization's annual budget.

The request of Eastern railroads for a 12 1/2 per cent increase in passenger fares, on top of several others granted since 1942 and a pending appeal for a 13 per cent rise in freight rates, points up the urgency of the need for making a rounded study of all forms of transportation.

The trial of eleven Communist leaders in New York Federal court began on Jan. 17 -- just twenty weeks ago tomorrow. They are being tried on charges of conspiracy to advocate the violent overthrow of the United States Government. During the twenty weeks there has been almost continuous wrangling between the defendants and their lawyers on the one hand and Judge Harold R. Medina on the other.

BUFFALO, June 4 (AP) -- A young engineer summoned to appear before the House Un-American Activities Committee said today "someone in our Government" permitted a top Russian agent to get away after he had helped build an airtight case of espionage against him.

Improved tinplate supply and recent easing of Government restrictions on some can manufacturing make renewal of controls for can makers unlikely after expiration of shortage allocation orders on Sept 30, an official of a large user in the food field declared yesterday.
MAY I be permitted to make some correcting remarks on the subject of H. W. Heinsheimer's article about my opera, "Down in the Valley," which appeared in your issue of last Sunday?

A group of physicians and surgeons have been appointed as medical advisers to the new committee on industrial health and safety of the National Association of Manufacturers, it was announced yesterday by Earl Bunting, managing director of the association.

Bolivia, landlocked by Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Paraguay and Peru, is a country of extremes. Geographically it varies from the high, cold Andean plateau, where most of its 3,500,000 people live, to hot, low, sparsely settled jungle. Economically, there is a tremendous gap between the hard life of its Indian workers and the few wealthy families.

CHICAGO, June 4 (AP) -- Wheat prices moved ahead after a hesitant start on the Board of Trade today. The July contract led the advance, which extended to around a cent a bushel at times. Other cereals held steady but did not show as much strength as wheat.

THIS department has been much interested in certain letters it has received in connection with its comments of May 15 on the Pulitzer awards in literature. They are letters bearing on my remarks about the indifference with which the majority of professional reviewers and, I suspect, the bulk of the reading public regard the annual choice that is made in the field of poetry.

IN her latest novel, Anne Powers sets her scene in Elizabethan England at that moment when the signing of the death warrant against Mary Stuart was being hotly advocated and as ardently opposed. Philip Hapsburg of Spain was collecting the vessels of the Invincible Armada; and such English seamen as Drake.

LAST month the millionth visitor to enter the home of Franklin D. Roosevelt at Hyde Park, just north of Poughkeepsie, since it was opened as National Historic Site in 1946, went through the gracious mansion on the Hudson.

A cockney accent is not necessarily cricket, especially for a French student learning correct English pronunciation. Yet a young lady from France, who was enrolled in an English class for foreigners at the Young Women's Christian Association's Central Branch, said things like: "I 'ave 'eard that 'is mother is no longer 'ere."

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- President Truman today named Surgeon General Leonard A. Scheele of the Public Health Service to head the United States delegation to the second World Health Assembly starting in Rome June 13.

Perhaps one cannot quarrel with Gertrude Samuels' identification of espionage as crime in "American Traitors: A Study in Motives." But she also seems to imply that the whole "psychological development" which leads up to espionage -- though not inevitably, since many stop short of it -- is also a nascently criminal process.

PORTLAND, Me. -- The lakes and streams of Maine are favorites with energetic vacationists who know how to handle a canoe, and the Allagash River trip is one of the most popular trips. This is a ninety-seven-mile paddle through lakes, ponds and streams with plenty of rapids, to Fort Kent near the Canadian border.

CHICAGO, June 4 (AP) -- Michigan State Athletes in the now defunct Jenison scholarship program will retain their eligibility for Western Conference competition. Commissioner Kenneth L. (Tug) Wilson ruled today.

LIBERTY, N. Y. -- The resort and playgrounds area of the Catskill Mountains, which during 1948 experienced a generally spotty season, except for the larger and most luxurious hotels, is looking for better things from this summer.

OTTAWA, June 4 -- There has been a perceptible quickening this week in the Canadian electoral campaign since the Newfoundland provincial results went overwhelmingly in favor of the Liberals. Of the twenty-eight seats in the Provincial Legislature they have won twenty with one district still to be heard from.

UNLESS you are committed to a schedule of masterworks for this summer's reading, you will find "Pleasure Island" satisfactory on all accounts. Mr. Maier's novel might be classified as a pleasant romance, but that term does not accurately define either its charm or its attributes.

MONTREAL -- Last week cruise ships of the Canada Steamship Lines, operator of what is described as the largest inland fleet in the world, started their summer trips along the lower St. Lawrence and Saguenay Rivers, passing through the heartland of French Canada.

AS he has proved in earlier books, Mr. Dean is thoroughly at home in the rich history of the region surrounding Lake Champlain, which now furnishes background for a vigorous tale of Revolutionary days.

EVEN at this advanced stage of the air age, a week-end in Europe is slightly preposterous. Or was, until last week-end when, in order to help inaugurate its de luxe President Stratocruiser service to London, Pan American World Airways took a party of forty-two newspaper men and women across the Atlantic Ocean to spend Decoration Day week-end abroad.

THE other day the International Court of Justice, the World Court, handed down a historic opinion. It held that the United Nations has an international legal personality, like a state, and that just as states have the right to demand protection of their citizens from unlawful injury by other states, so the United Nations can demand protection for its officials.
The jailing of three of the eleven defendants in the Communist conspiracy trial resulted yesterday in protests and demonstrations by sympathizers.

ATLANTA, Ga., June 4 -- Although the nation's first lynching of the year may not, as one resident put it, have "stopped a checker game in Irwinton, Ga.," this attitude was not generally shared in Georgia or the rest of the South.
ROCHESTER, N. Y., June 4 (AP) -- The Rev. George P. Hetenyi has been adjudged sane and must stand trial on a charge of first-degree murder in the slaying of his wife on April 22.

CAIRO, June 4 -- Egypt's large armaments and army program is now interpreted by responsible British sources here as primarily preparations in the event of a British withdrawal from the Suez Canal zone.

Four homers, three of them struck successively in the sixth inning, helped the Giants rout the Reds yesterday, 9 -- 3. With two runs in the eighth, the Dodgers defeated the Pirates, 8-6, to remain tied with New York for second place.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. -- The summer vacation season in Pinellas County, which includes St. Petersburg, will serve as a test of the housing situation free of Federal rent controls. Last month Tighe E. Woods, Federal housing expediter, removed controls from the 22,000 rental units in this country.

Ponder the Calumet Farm's Kentucky Derby champion, won horse-of-the-day honors at Belmont Park yesterday and made it clear to all hands that he'll be the short-priced favorite for next Saturday's Belmont Stakes.

ALEXANDRIA BAY -- Tourists who come this year to the Thousand Islands region, which extends along the St. Lawrence River from Cape Vincent to Alexandria Bay, will find their vacations a mite easier on their budgets than they have been in recent summers.

After almost two weeks of meetings, in Paris, it appears that the Big Four Foreign Ministers will not achieve a major political settlement -- but that they may reach some sort of economic understanding. This is not assured. Nothing is certain about a Foreign Ministers conference but debate (about 2,500 words at an average daily meeting of three and one-half hours) and translations (into English, French and Russian).

More than 250 debutantes of the 1949-50 season are making ready for the gay whirl that will mark their first year in society. Many of them will be introduced this month at parties in country homes in Long Island, Tuxedo Park, Baltimore and Philadelphia.

THE Battle of the Clam Chowder, according to the latest word from the front, continues. Despite its age, the argument is still so hot that the tactful traveler touring the East Coast this summer will immediately decide on a nonpartisan stand.

EPSOM, England, June 4 -- Nimbus, bred by a bookmaker and owned by the wife of a lawyer, today won the richest English Derby in the classic's 170 years in a photo finish.
HASTINGS, June 4 (Reuters) -- A modern Battle of Hastings is raging here. The "battlefield" is the town's ancient castle, bought by the town corporation last month for 5,000 ($20,000).

ROME, June 4 -- The Italian economy, in mid-convalescence, presents one of Europe's best examples of the difficulty of reconciling government welfare programs with the objective of establishing a functioning economic system.

Scientists of the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics are dropping weighted models from airplanes and thus approaching in a new way the problem of transonic and supersonic flight. This phase of the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics' research program was described at the recent joint New York meeting of the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences and the Royal Aeronautical Society by Floyd L. Thompson, chief of research at the Langley Aeronautical Laboratory of the NACA.

Furniture purchases at the Chicago summer home furnishings market next month will be substantial, local buyers declared last week. The event, largest and most important trade show in the furniture field, will run for two weeks beginning July 5.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- A trial examiner of the National Labor Relations Board ruled today that three West Coast maritime unions violated the picketing practices allowable under the Taft-Hartley act.

IN a village store near Minsk, Poland, scores of children crowd anxiously around the brisk young doctor in the "Danmark" Red Cross uniform as he directs his Polish and Danish medical assistants to examine, test, vaccinate.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 4 -- Almost 2,000 alumni from twenty-three classes are expected to attend the 248th commencement of Yale University Saturday, June 18, through Tuesday, June 21.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- "American" whisky may be added to the Scotch-Irish-Canadian nomenclature of distilled liquors. The Internal Revenue Bureau's Alcohol Tax Unit today scheduled a public hearing for July 11 on proposals to change its regulations so that whisky so labeled would be legal.

Retirement of twelve Navy captains and reassignment of six others. all to take place this month. was announced at headquarters of the Commandant Third Naval Disstrict here yesterday. A Marine Corps colonel also will be retired.

IN his first novel Ray Morrison, a Los Angeles probation officer, attempts to do in fiction what "The Quiet One" achieved forcefully as a documentary movie. The locale is a progressive reform school. ALBANY, June 4 -- Governor Dewey's office said today that 827 additional state scholarships, with a total four-year value of $1,143,000, would be filled before the start of the next school year in September.

PARIS, June 4 -- Despite a long, exhaustive and impassioned defense of his position by Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Y. ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., June 4 -- The ninety-eighth annual meeting of the American Medical Association, largest medical organization in the world, will open here on Monday morning for five days of sessions. PHILADELPHIA, June 4 (AP) -- Ken Heintzelman's six-hit pitching combined with a seventh-inning home run by Andy Seminick gave the Phillies a 1-0 victory today over the Chicago Cubs.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 4 -- Business indices in the Ninth Federal Reserve District showed little change this week in the general trend toward a slackening of business activities over the area. WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Sincere, impartial and vigorous enforcement of all antitrust laws by the Federal Administration was called for today by George J. ASBURY PARK, N. J. -- Although yachting and deep-sea fishing are major summer sports along the Jersey shore, swimming remains its primary attraction. The state's broad beaches have become so popular with vacationists that today there are very few feet of sand which have not been developed either by municipalities, private groups or individuals.

Eliahu Elath, Israeli Ambassador to the United States, was among the 1,973 passengers who left here yesterday afternoon for Cherbourg and Southampton aboard the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary. The ship left Pier 90, North River, at 12:30 P. M.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The Soviet Government is presenting a Chinese puzzle of its own in its official attitude toward China. It is one that has the Western powers guessing, though the State Department considers it obvious that it is deliberately calculated to serve Russian propaganda aims.

QUETTA, Baluchistan, June 4 -- Anywhere from the Khyber Pass to the sea, one may run into the Frontier Corps, a conglomeration of scouts, militia, constabulary and possibly the world's last mounted infantry. MIAMI, Fla. -- The accent is on economy, more living accommodations and better transportation facilities in the Florida east coast's bid for more visitors than ever this summer. Columbia University's American Press Institute will open its first seminar on women's pages in daily newspapers tomorrow, Floyd Taylor, director of the institute, announced yesterday. Thirteen newspaper women from nine states and the District of Columbia will attend the two-week seminar at the Columbia School of Journalism, which will be the last to be held by the institute in the 1948-49 academic year.

Regaling a gathering of 16,413 with a varied offensive that included three successive home runs in one inning to tie a record, the Giants held to the pace of the front runners in the National League flag race by deftly polishing off the Reds at the Polo Grounds yesterday. The score was 9 to 3.

IT SHOULD be easier for vacationers in western United States and Canada this year to see a rodeo than to miss one, because the list of 176 events already arranged primarily for tourists is about three times as big as last year's.

LONDON, June 4 (UP) -- The Royal and Ancient Golf Club at St. Andrews today posted a final entry list of 250 competitors for the eighty-first British open championship to be played at the Royal St. George course at Sandwich, July 4 to 8.

VIENNA, June 4 -- Reports from Paris that the prospects have improved for an Austrian peace treaty at the current meeting of the Big Four have raised hopes here. But Austrians are aware that agreement will not be easy. What they would like to have is a guarantee that, even if agreement is not reached, the occupation forces will get out.

Something new in privately financed European relief, a prefabricated "furniture package" weighing 325 pounds and containing the necessary furnishings for two rooms is now available for shipment to needy families abroad, Newton Randolph, director of Save a Friend in Europe, Inc., announced yesterday.

THE occasional protests of nature-lovers against the use of chemicals to control insects rose to a clamor with the introduction of DDT. The chief criticism of insecticides was and is that they may upset the "balance of nature," and that in the long run we would be better off without them.
THE London street cry of three hundred years ago will be re-echoed this month; the sense, if not the phrase, will be the same:

WEST ORANGE, N. J., June 4 -- Two of three teams that had tied for the medal in yesterday's qualifying round were knocked out in the first round of match play in the Rock Spring Club member-guest tournament today.
The story of construction carried on "not just as fast as possible, but faster," was told yesterday by the New York City Housing Authority in its fifteenth annual report.

WASHINGTON. June 4 -- It now seems likely that East and West in the Paris meeting of the Big Four are going to disagree on politics and agree or compromise on trade, and this trend emphasizes both the tragedy and the hope of the post-war era.

PANAMA CITY -- A number of bargains will be available to travelers visiting Central America this summer as a result of special tourist airline rates, good until Sept. 30. These are considerably lower than the regular round-trip fares.

ROGERS HORNBY always has been an outspoken individual who says what he thinks and lets the chips fall where they may. But the Rajah bluntly dropped a conversational bombshell the other day that had baseball men aghast. It was as though Winston Churchill had lauded Stalin, Dr. Morris Fishbein had recommended socialized medicine and John L. Lewis had come out in favor of the Taft-Hartley Act.

Indications are that Congress will take no action on the Havana Charter for an International Trade Organization at this session, according to views in foreign trade circles here last week. By the same token, no action is expected on proposed legislation to simplify United States customs procedure, which has been urged by importers for a long time.

Timid teachers who are "afraid" to have their pupils discuss controversial issues have no right to instruct in the social studies, according to a guide prepared for New York public school teachers and supervisors.

AMATEUR radio operators in the metropolitan area, under the auspices of the Hudson Division of the American Radio Relay League, plan to sponsor this fall what promises to be the biggest radio show in New York in several years.

ONE feature of nineteenth-century imperialism and industrial expansion was a vastly increased opportunity for scientific effort in many directions, among them the field of biology. For machinery generated surplus wealth, a modicum of which found its way into the financing of collecting and explorative expeditions, of zoological gardens, museums, schools and laboratories.

GERALD JOHNSON'S demand for "respect" in American literature has no support in the history of creative writing. But his position represents that of a good many journalistic critics of today and for this reason deserves answer for all of its absurdity.

IN response to an invitation from the Architectural League of New York, seven countries in Europe have sent samples for the current exhibition: "European Furniture and Fabrics: 1949." Since not all of those invited were able to participate, the collection cannot be called completely representative. But it does give a rough sketch of contemporary trends abroad, which makes an interesting comparison with the current design picture here.
FRANKFORT, Germany, June 4 (AP) -- Daniel McCarthy, the former GI who wants to be a German, was set free today to get a sample of what German life is like. United States authorities waived $500 bail.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 4 -- A resourceful Yale nine parlayed four hits into six runs today to maintain its baseball domination over Princeton. The score was 6 -- 2. A crowd of 3,000 saw the Elis use two hits in each of a pair of big innings to inaugurate their annual series over the favored Nassau nine.

UNTIL this week everything pointed to another Benjamin Britten world premiere at the Berkshire Music Festival this summer. The English composer had completed "A Spring Symphony," based on poems old and new, scored it for large orchestra, mixed chorus, boys' chorus, soprano, contralto and tenor solos and dedicated it to Serge Koussevitzky in time for the scheduled performance on Aug. 13.

DETROIT, June 4 (AP) -- Jake La Motta, three days late in arriving to start training for his June 15 title bout with middleweight champion Marcel Cerdan, was ordered today to appear before the Michigan Boxing Commission.

The Yiddish Culture Chorus, under Vladimir Heifetz, gave its nineteenth annual concert last night at Town Hall before an enthusiastic audience. Alexander Kontorowicz, violinist; Isobel Walters and Feigl Sunshine, sopranos; Esther Levine-Hartblay, alto, and Sol Tisman, baritone, were the assisting artists.

NOBODY will be particularly surprised, it is safe to assume, that the Soviet Union has declined with thanks the offer of Blevins Davis to take the Ballet Theatre to Russia for a four-week season with all expenses paid. Even Mr. Davis himself can scarcely be dumfounded.

EARLY summer group exhibitions and a few belated one-man shows opening in the abbreviated holiday week present further satisfactory evidence of the vitality and variety of contemporary American art. All the artists associated with the Downtown and Kraushaar galleries are represented in their respective shows.

INVENTORS and manufacturers of gadgets have been busy during the winter and spring devising and producing accessories that will, they say, make life in general and certainly vacations easier on the motorist. The emphasis appears to be about equally divided on safety and comfort, which are related because a comfortable driver suffers less from fatigue and is, therefore, a safer driver.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., June 4 -- Statements from Iowa's Senator Bourke B. Hickenlooper, charging Chairman David E. Lilienthal of the Atomic Energy Commission with "incredible mismanagement," came as a shock to thousands of Mr. Lilienthal's associates in the Deep South who had known and worked with him since 1933.

IN "The Story Behind Great Books" Mrs. Montgomery told how some of the best-loved children's classics came to be written. Her present volume gives similar information for thirty-seven of the most popular recent books for boys and girls.

PARIS, June 4 -- Among the failures of international communism in Western Europe since the end of the war, none is more pronounced or significant than the failure of the German Communists to achieve substantial success even within the range of Russian rifles.

At a number of points we are continuing our familiar clash with the Soviet Union and its satellites. The Council of Foreign Ministers has been debating the problem of the German future and the present situation in Berlin. The Western Ministers have rejected the Soviet proposals for Germany and the Soviet Union has rejected the Western program.

CHICAGO, June 4 -- A price drop in women's wearing apparel, to be reflected in the retail field by fall, will be evidenced at the Chicago National Wash Apparel Show which opens here tomorrow, according to leaders in the industry. Glenn G. Hayes, executive director of the show, described the week of its duration as probably the most significant market week since before the war.

FOUGAYROLLES is a village of a thousand inhabitants in Cevennes, that mountainous country in southern France immortalized by Alphonse Daudet and Robert Louis Stevenson. As a child, Miss Saleil came there summer after summer with her family -- her mother, referred to throughout these rambling, innocuous pages as "Madame Mere"; her young sister and her father, whose interests ran to Romanesque arches and the muscular strength of snails.

JUNE will probably always be known as the month of roses, for the most sensational burst of bloom comes at this time. However, the hybrid tea and floribunda roses will continue to to produce an abundance of flowers throughout the summer and fall as well.
The last of the art treasures collected by the late Joseph Brummer will be auctioned in a third and final sale on the art dealer's premises, 110 East Fifty-eighth Street, on Wednesday and Thursday.
WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- Senate Republicans battling to keep a big part of the Taft-Hartley Law contended today that a Democratic compromise drive plays into their hands.

THERE are two kinds of sweet alyssum. One is the trailing, old-fashioned type and the other is the low-growing, compact variety. Seeds of either may still be sown to prove an asset to the summer border.

IF the estimates of the commercial airlines and the travel agencies are only 50 per cent accurate, the coming summer should see more Americans flying to vacation spots than ever before. The airlines and the travel people have planned it that way.

LAST summer Ray Sprigle of The Pittsburgh Post Gazette, disguised as a Negro, spent four weeks traveling the South. It should be said at the outset that Mr. Sprigle's newspaper stories, on which this book is based, were written honestly and without undue attempt at sensational effect.

The Commerce and Industry Association of New York has branded the recently revived St. Lawrence Seaway and Power Project as "another extension of governmental subsidy tending toward nationalization of privately owned and managed business," and has called on Senator Irving M. Ives to oppose it vigorously in Congress.
Despite reports to the contrary from outside their industry, steel spokesmen reiterated in a survey just made that at the moment there is no prospect of lower base prices for steel.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Nancy Henderson MacLennan, a reporter for THE NEW YORK TIMES for seven years, has been appointed by the State Department as an information officer in the United States Information Service at Cairo, Egypt.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, June 4 -- With the trout season now under way on lakes and streams throughout most of the Mountain States, "Closed -- Gone Fishing" signs are posted on Main Street stores in scores of towns.

HARTFORD, Conn. -- There are several special celebrations on Connecticut's calendar which should add considerably to the pleasure of the 500,000 visitors the state expects to entertain this summer at its beaches, lake resorts and country inns.

BURLINGTON, Vt. -- Paradoxically, the development of winter sports is helping to make the beauties of Vermont's rugged Green Mountains more accessible to summer sightseers. The state boasts some 900 peaks with altitudes above 2,000 feet, and for years only visitors with enough time and stamina to climb the difficult trails could enjoy the views they offer.

STROUDSBURG, Pa. -- The Pocono Mountains' $30,000,000 resort industry, cognizant of a buyers' market, is just now completing a million-dollar program of improvements in accommodations, sports equipment and resort facilities. The reasoning behind this move, as it was formulated at late winter and spring meetings of the Pocono Mountains Vacation Bureau, was the desire to give "our guests more for their vacation dollar in the Pocono Mountains than anywhere else."

AS business nears the half-way mark in the year there are redoubled efforts to estimate what will happen in the second half. This was the period about which general doubt was expressed when the 1949 forecasts were framed almost six months ago.

The effects of the general economic readjustment on production and corporate earnings became quite decisive in the first quarter of this year. Temporary spurts are expected in some lines, but the general trend is heading back to a normal peace-time basis which is expected to be above the pre-war level.

Mrs. Golda Myerson, Israeli Minister of Labor, Social Insurance and Housing, arriving here yesterday, emphasized the critical housing shortage in Israel. She termed it the major problem of her country, and asserted that 160,000 housing units were needed immediately to take care of the heavy influx of immigrants.
Victor Vincent in his letter to the editor was right when he said I was "a brave man trying to summarize 'Vaudeville's Ideal Bill' in ten acts."

Styles in labor relations, as well as in coats, suits and dresses, are being set by the city's multimillion dollar garment industry. Other industries throughout the country are copying the impartial chairman system of arbitration that has kept the garment industry free of major strikes for many years.

TO its chain of twenty-five national parks which stretches from the Atlantic to the Pacific, Canada is preparing to add three more in the near future. One of these, in the province of New Brunswick, will be partly open to the public this year.

HIGH in the credo of the occasional theatregoer is the conviction that it is well-nigh impossible to get desirable tickets to a New York stage hit on short notice. This is a half truth. Contrary to general opinion such a coup may be consummated without summoning your Bishop as a character witness or getting a loyalty certificate from the House Un-American Activities Committee.

THERE is a slight catch to the happy report to motorists that the outlook as to highway conditions this summer throughout the country is generally good, and that roads will be in better condition than at any time since the war.

ALTHOUGH Shriner matters brought him into town the other day, Harold Lloyd is not entirely concerned with fraternal organization business. The comedian-producer also is planning his movie future.
