Heading these plans is "Daydreams," a comedy "with some fantasy in it," which he will produce and in which he, naturally, will star.

Is a two-week vacation contest for two worth a penny postcard to you? That's all you have to do to receive full information about the Greater New York Fund Vacation Contest. Imagine flying to Mexico City and soaking up the sun on the famous beach at Acapulco. Or picture yourself cruising leisurely to Bermuda.

PARIS, June 4 -- The conflict between United States and British policy regarding freer and more competitive European trade remained unsolved when the two-day meeting of W. Averell Harriman, chief representative in Europe of the Economic Cooperation Administration, and the Finance and Foreign Ministers of the eight-nation steering committee of the Marshall Plan countries ended here tonight.

Wednesday's recorded concert at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street, will include the music of Mendelssohn, Dvorak, Debussy and Barber. The selections will include Pierne's "Gyration, ballet" and Elgar's "Pomp and Circumstance."

COMING off the madding streets of midtown Manhattan into William Beebe's rooms, is to find one's self in an agreeable, insulated haven. Among the modulated tones of the room -- the dull shine of leather bindings, the patina of natural woods -- the eye picks out Mr. Beebe (who, as a naturalist, may have the knack of taking on protective coloration wherever he is).

THE story of Long Island's phenomenal growth as New York City's playground has been told most vividly during the past year or two and terms of expanding parking and highway facilities. Almost every sunny week-end, well over a million New Yorkers sprawl out in the city's big backyard to take advantage of its seemingly unlimited recreation opportunities.

NORTH CREEK, N. Y. -- The Adirondack Mountains constitute the biggest recreation area in New York State and the state itself, through its Adirondack Park is the biggest host to vacationists within the region.

A trend away from the more costly and not always satisfactory program of campus interviewing for employment recruitment by large companies was reported yesterday by W. Gail Camp, member of the board of governors and spokesman for the Association of Private Office Personnel Agencies, 19 West Forty-fourth Street.

BUENOS AIRES, June 4 -- The outbreak in Bolivia, in which two United States engineers were among the hostages killed by infuriated miners and which has led to martial law, is the outgrowth of a labor situation that cannot be judged by United States standards.

SWEET WOODRUFF (Asperula odorata) is called Waldmeister in Germany, where this lovely herb grows wild in forests. Cultivated in this country, it makes a perfect ground cover or choice border perennial for shady places under trees or in the rock garden.

A TWO-DAY Peony and Rose Show is being held by the Horticultural Society of New York on Thursday and Friday. Staged in the Colonnades Ballroom of Essex House, Fifty-ninth Street and Central Park South, the hours on opening day are from 1 to 6 P. M., and on Friday from 10 A. M. to 4 P. M.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., June 4 -- With the first sou'wester of the Yacht Racing Association Regattas so far this season, eighty-eight starters set sail today. It was the first event of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club.

THE Canadian northland comes alive in this career story of young Bill Hanson during his first year as a ranger around Temagami and Algonquin Park in Ontario. Bill is ably assisted in his adventures by his Irish terrier Mickey and his friend Bun Higgins, a pilot with the Provincial Aid Service.

IN his review of "Post Stories, 1948," in the issue of May 1, your C. V. Terry makes a few remarks that need challenging. He implies that the stories selected by Martha Foley for her annual anthology, "The Best Short Stories," are less popular than the "machine-made" stories found in the pages of The Saturday Evening Post simply because the latter is for what he calls the "general reader" (whoever that is!).

CAUX-SUR-MONTREUX, Switzerland, June 4 (AP) -- Dr. Frank N. D. Buchman told the world assembly of Moral Rearmament at its opening today that the movement he founded eleven years ago is a force adequate to remake the world.

The Defense Establishment has acted wisely in rescinding a large part of its Consolidation Directive No. 1, which had been widely interpreted as placing a "gag" on persons in the armed services and unduly restricting the flow of news. The part that pertains to consolidation of the security review sections has been retained, as it should be.
BOSTON, June 4 -- Summer vacations appeared to be uppermost in the minds of many New Englanders this week after they sampled holiday trips over the Memorial Day week-end.

THE ramblers glorifying city back yards, and their thousands of more sophisticates relatives now holding forth in the public gardens around the town, herald the arrival of another June in New York City. For even in the midst of Manhattan, roses will stage a spectacular display this week.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- House spy investigations are set to break their first big case of industrial espionage next week -- one involving asserted Russian efforts to pick off wartime military secrets at the Bell aircraft plant.

PRETORIA, South Africa, June 4 -- Should the hopes raised by yesterday's gold strike in the Orange Free State be realized, it was calculated today, the eventual operators would obtain, even at present prices, more than $16,000 a ton of ore extracted at a cost of only $160.
WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- For the first time in its history the National Labor Relations Board is about to go into seeking enforcement of an order against a labor union.
Section 1621 of the United States Criminal Code gives this definition of perjury:

A reduction in the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation's assessment rate appeared in prospect last week after the disclosure that officials of the agency and representatives of the American Bankers Association and other banking groups were nearing completion of their studies of the problem.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (UP) -- Sponsors of an increase in military pay, rebuffed once by the House when they proposed increases for generals and no rises at all for recruits, offered a revised plan today that they said should meet all objections.

Your editorial commending the restraint of Chairman Woods of the House Committee on Un-American Activities is a welcome note in these days of un-American hysteria. We have been witnessing most disturbing attacks upon the fundamental guarantees enshrined in our Bill of Rights.

FOR the benefit of those to whom her work is unfamiliar, it may be as well to begin by saying that Miss Compton-Burnett was brought up in a large, well-to-do family living outside London at the end of the Victorian era.
MOUNDSVILLE, W. Va., June 4 (AP) -- Eight of the fourteen long-term convicts who cut their way out of West Virginia's old state penitentiary were recaptured today.
THIS is a provocative book on labor from the standpoint of a devoted rank-and-file trade unionist who is now in the lower echelons of officialdom.

ON the basis of a Presidential decree saying that "stamps constitute an appropriate medium of cultural propaganda." Venezuela plans to issue 384 stamps, including 216 for airmail use. Whether all will be released at one time or scattered over several months or years is not stated in the document, a copy of which, dated March 18, was received here last week by Henry Goodkind, editor of Aero Philatelist's News.

After weary months of moving in a narrow range, prices on the New York Stock Exchange broke sharply last week. A dearth of good news and further drops in business thermometers -- indicators of the economic health of the nation -- were held responsible for the sell-off.

In "Timber Graveyard" (TIMES Magazine, May 1) Richard Neuberger voices the official propaganda line of the United States Forest Service for its program to socialize the forests of the United States through Federal legislation.

BOGOTA, Colombia, June 4 -- Well over a million voters will elect members of the national House of Representatives, fifteen state legislatures and 800 municipal governments tomorrow after a campaign that became so bitter the Government suspended the usual political activities until after the election.

WELLESLEY, Mass., June 4 -- Dr. Margaret Clapp, 39-year-old Pulitzer Prize winner for biography and assistant Professor of History at Brooklyn College in New York, has been named the eighth president of Wellesley College.

THE rustic covered bridges, which are so dear to the heart of the landscape painter, the photographer and the motorist who searches them out as remains of the vanishing early American scene, are paradoxically neither anachronistic, vanishing nor truly American.

AS the title indicates, this group of poems, representing the latest work of Robert P. Tristram Coffin, deals with the life on a one-horse, salt-water Maine farm, deals with it in all its various aspects of season, task and plan.
Put down the Securities and Exchange Commission's case against Otis Co. in connection with the now ancient Kaiser-Frazer stock offering, as a dead issue.

Two more alleged members of the so-called Brooklyn "toothache gang," who are said to have held up twenty dentists' offices and made away with $4,000 in cash and gold pellets, were picked up yesterday by detectives.

The first machine parts made of ductile cast iron, a new engineering material, have been bought by agricultural equipment companies, executives of International Nickel Company disclosed here yesterday. From April 24 to May 24 seven new licenses have been issued to foundries to cast ductile iron using the International Nickel process, and a total of thirty companies are now licensed to use the material.

TO THE EDITOR: IN a recent communication from Parnassus a gentleman named James enclosed a clipping from THE NEW YORK TIMES Book Review in which a conversation was reported between James (who is still unknown to me), Melville (who is with me now) and myself.
The newly created Calendar Classification and Control Term in the Brooklyn and Queens Supreme Courts will begin functioning tomorrow. It will handle only negligence cases.
As a graduate forester (M.F., Yale School of Forestry, 1948) I feel I am in a position to refute some of Richard Neuberger's statements (in "Timber Graveyard"). * * *

Yachtsmen's children may go without shoes. The galley up forward may serve slumgullion instead of caviar. Sometimes because fuel is expensive a skipper will stand still over a week-end, tugging at his mooring. But no self-respecting yachtsman would be found without a Lloyd's Register on his bridge. It is one of the "musts" of the sport.

AMERICA is a land of travelers. To take to the open road is part of our tradition of freedom. It was the pioneer's way when trade got slow, when the soil grew thin, when his neighbor's smoking chimneys crowded too close, to pick up and depart for fresh pastures and a new horizon.

LOS ANGELES -- Summer visitors to Southern California may have up to 20 per cent less competition for accommodations and other vacation facilities than previously. On the basis of travel during the first part of the year, the Automobile Club of Southern California projects a total for the year of 825,000 cars compared with last year's all-time high of more than 1,000,000.

MOSCOW, June 4 -- Pravda, organ of the Communist party in Russia, today characterized the Bonn Constitution as a "conspiracy against the unity of Germany" and applied the word "monstrous" to the proposals on Germany submitted to the Council of Foreign Ministers in Paris by the Western powers.

Railroad policy, so far as rates are concerned, is rapidly becoming a grave threat to our entire economy. With the unanimity of a trained chorus, railroad presidents at recent annual meetings of stockholders have continued to harp on the old theme -- "Only higher tariffs can save us." "Save us" from what? -- from the slump in revenues directly traceable to the higher tariffs already imposed on freight, express and passengers.

BLOWING ROCK, N. C. -- Here on the crest of the Blue Ridge Mountains the visitor finds that the slogan, "If you want to get cool, go South" contains truth as well as paradox. At this resort, nearly 4,000 feet up and said to be the highest point on the Blue Ridge Parkway where accommodations are available, the average summer temperature is 64 degrees and you sleep under blankets all year round.

OMAHA BEACH, France, June 4 (AP) Lieut. Richard J. Forman of Omaha, Neb., piloted a Flying Fortress over the narrow beachhead on the Normandy coast on which the first waves of GI's sloshing on D-Day -- June 6, 1944 -- opening the great Allied invasion.

BERLIN, June 4 -- Dr. Bedrich Bruegel, acting chief of the Czechoslovak mission in Berlin, has fled to Western Germany after having informed the Government of Czechoslovakia it was running a "corrupt police dictatorship" and bleeding Czechoslovakia economically through its Soviet-inspired trade with Eastern Germany.
ENGLEWOOD, N. J., June Twenty-five thousand persons lined the main streets here this afternoon to witness a parade three miles long in honor of the fiftieth anniversary of incorporation of the city.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Attorney General Tom Clark tapped a blooper into the ditch in front of the first tee, Baseball Commissioner A. B. (Happy) Chandler fouled off a couple before con necting for one down the middle, Arthur Godfrey shot a 59 for nine holes and Sam Snead turned in a sizzling 65 for eighteen.

Rutgers University will establish on July 1 a new Department of Geography. one of the few such departments in the northeastern United States and the only one in New Jersey offering geography courses to students of liberal arts, business administration and engineering.
THE first city-sponsored spring festival of the San Francisco Symphony Orchestra, under the direction of Dimitri Mitropoulos, recently brought to a close this city's major musical season.

PATERSON, N. J., June 4 -- Because a small group of former athletes liked to meet socially once a year to discuss sports, this city today can boast of an organization that has helped to train hundreds of boys in baseball, basketball, boxing and track, and become a model for similar organizations in neighboring municipalities.

Negotiators representing 6,000 striking beer workers and eleven breweries -- including some of the nation's biggest -- moved steadily closer yesterday toward settlement of their two-month-old dispute.

AN angler, to be worthy of the term, must be an optimist, and the reports now flowing in from Canada to North Carolina indicate that there is every reason for the brotherhood to anticipate one of the best fishing seasons in years.

WOODS HOLE, Mass. -- They tell of a Cape Cod whaling captain, returned from a long voyage, who walked the streets of his home town trying to find his own house by calling "House ahoy!" During his absence it had unaccountably vanished.

SINCE colonial times the inhabitants of the Atlantic Seaboard and the Gulf Coast have journeyed in the hot summer months to the springs and spas of the upland interior. The Blue Ridge and the Southern Appalachians were especially noted for the number and excellence of their watering places.

Bishop Loughlin High School's track team, which, under the guidance of Coach Billy Miles, rates as one of the top scholastic units in the East, gave another demonstration of its well-balanced power yesterday as it swept to an impressive victory in the 23d annual Catholic high schools Track and field championships.

ATHENS, June 4 -- The Greek Government refused tonight to issue a passport to the former Premier, Gen. Nicholas Plastiras, whose declared intention was to visit Paris to discuss the rebel peace proposals with the Big Four Foreign Ministers.

DALLAS, June 4 -- Farmers took the business spotlight in Texas this week as the wheat harvest got in full swing and started a race for government-sanctioned storage bins. In Dallas on Friday wheat trucks lined highways into the city in mile-long parades leading to grain elevators.

STEPHEN SPENDER'S article in Horizon, "The Situation of the American Writer," is the best piece of literary inquiry that has been published here for some time. Spender has always been an addict of "tendencies" and "trends": he has never flinched from them as the rest of us do, never has the temptation (which we have) to discuss the tendency to write about trends, and takes naturally to the prophetic role.

From water tunnels at the California Institute of Technology, in which unprecedented speeds of 100 feet per second have been attained, will come new knowledge to aid engineers who design ships' propellers and water wheels.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Senator Brien McMahon, Democrat, of Connecticut, suggested today that the number of atomic bombs held by the United States might have to be revealed for any fair judgment of the "incredible mismanagement" charge against David E. Lilienthal, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission.
ITHACA, N. Y., June 4 (AP) -- Dr. Edward R. Eastman, member of the State Board of Regents, observed today that Americans were living in a "gadget civilization."

Indications that the rift between the Amateur Hockey Association of the United States and the A. A. U. would be healed were evident when representatives of the two groups conferred at a meeting at the Hotel New Yorker yesterday.

LONDON, June 4 -- Conservative party leaders in Britain have lately been setting off alarms among their followers about the possibility, whether it be danger or opportunity, that the Labor Government may soon dissolve Parliament before the end of its five-year term and call a snap general election.

This is the season when the surf-caster comes into his own, and beaches from Hatteras to Cape Cod soon will be dotted with anglers who accept fishless days and nights with a fortitude and calm equaled by no other follower of the sport.

DR. MILLSPAUGH begins his book with a conventional but useful analogy. Suppose you had an eighteenth-century stagecoach in perfect condition. No matter how much you tinker with it, add gadgets, change drivers, you still have just a stagecoach.

WORDS, spoken rather than sung, occupy the major share of attention in this morning's dissertation on records. In two of the three sets of disks the words are accompanied by music, which has some bearing on the case; in the third, music appears only among incidental sound effects.

THE question of civil rights, as it affects Communists in America, has generated intense emotion among extremists on both sides. The emotion has served to obscure what would in any case be an exceedingly difficult problem.
ALBANY, June 4 -- Lieut. Gov. Joe R. Hanley said today he was convinced that Thomas E. Dewey would seek and win a third term as Governor.

INDEPENDENCE, Mo. -- A large rambling white frame house at the intersection of Delaware Street and Truman Road in Independence has during the last four years become a major attraction for tourists from all states and countries.

MEXICO CITY -- Five major highway "firsts" are open to tourists this year under Mexico's intensified road-building program. Included are two new routes south from the Rio Grande to the center of the country, and a highway that reaches virtually to the Guatemalan border.

THE elephant had friends, the giraffe had friends, the tiger had friends; but Crosspatch, the baby lion, had no friends because he was so cross. Having no friends made Crosspatch even crosser. He was so terribly cross that he scowled, howled, growled, roared -- and drove all the animals' friends away.

"A NICE little auxiliary sloop that sleeps four, so you can invite another couple along or take the kids. That's what people want, but we can't give it to them." These are the words of a leading yacht broker in the month of June, 1949.

TICKET investigation or no ticket investigation, there's likely to be plenty of grousing should the Irving Berlin-Robert E. Sherwood musical, "Miss Liberty," become another of the town's smash hits when it opens at the Imperial on July 7.

ONCE more the commencement season is with us; and once more the size of graduating classes reminds the country what a change has swept over higher education. In 1948 a fair computation showed that the United States had more than 2,400,000 college and university students, a number doubtless maintained through the spring of 1949.

Gertrude Samuels' "American Traitors: A Study in Motives." mentions some problems which should be tackled by a task force of psychiatrists, sociologists and historians. It was amazing how the gifted intellectuals in the Canadian spy ring could be so critical of capitalist nationalism.

HARRISBURG, Pa. -- Fish so thick that the ducks have no room to swim and must skitter across the surface of the water -- this is one attraction promised tourists in western Pennsylvania's vacationland by the Recreation Bureau of the State Department of Commerce. The fish-duck show may be seen at Pymatuning Lake in the north-western section of the state.

Progress in the retail grocery business during the next five years will be at a "less stormy pace," Rudolph L. Treuenfels, coordinator of the Food Industry Training Center at City College School of Business, predicted last week at the graduation exercises of the food retailing and wholesaling classes.

THOUGH every recent survey in the furniture business has shown a steadily increasing demand for modern things, it is simultaneously true that the demand and the prices for fine antiques have kept going up and up, too. According to a distinguished New York importing firm, the market value of the better antiques has doubled and in some cases tripled since 1938.

SOFT-SHELL crabs, tender as an omelet, powdered over with flour, sauteed buff brown, and with them, corn on the cob, meaty, flawless tomatoes, and a long frothy glass of cool beer. Ah, the good taste of summer!

Commencement exercises for 555 graduating students of Pratt Institute were held yesterday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Charles Pratt, president of the institute, conferred degrees and presented certificates to 274 art school students, 100 home economics students, 127 in engineering, thirty-two in the library school and twenty-two students of the School of Leather and Tanning Technology.

CONCORD, N. H. -- New Hampshire has a new reservation, Mount Sunapee State Park, ready for visitors this summer. Built on the slope and at the base of the North Peak of Sunapee Mountain, it lies in Newbury at the southern end of Sunapee Lake.

CLEVELAND, June 4 -- Social welfare programs in this country and overseas will be examined during the golden anniversary program of the National Conference of Jewish Social Welfare, which will open here Tuesday. Six hundred delegates from almost every state and abroad are expected.

In THE TIMES of May 29 Dr. B. P. Sandler takes chemists to task for "taking knowledge obtained in the field of chemistry and applying it to human nutrition without considering facts obtained in clinical medicine." This, of course, is simply not so. Responsible experimenters in the field of nutrition test out their ideas first on animals, and later, perhaps, on human beings, with the cooperation of competent specialists.

Prof. Earlen R. Caley of Ohio State University's Chemistry Department finds that the Romans for several centuries efficiently refined the metal from which their coins were struck. He examined gold pieces ranging from a Persian Daric of the fourth century B. C. to a Roman coin minted during the rule of Julius Nepos, 474-475 A. D.

At the annual meeting of the Board of Trustees of the American Merchant Marine Library Association, 45 Broadway, held last week Capt. Granville Conway, president of the Cosmopolitan Shipping Company, Inc., was elected president of the organization.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The inquiry that began this week into the operation of the Atomic Energy Commission reflects some of the deep misgivings over the nation's system of atomic energy control. Some of this apprehension over the whole scope and system of control

A GRIEVOUS mechanical error in my review of "The 27th Division in World War II" in the Book Review of May 22 results in a misrepresentation of the action of two battalions of the 105th Infantry Regiment in the great Gyokusai charge on Saipan, July 7, 1944.

WALNUT RIDGE, Ark., June 4 (UP) -- A murder investigation was ordered today into the deaths of three small children found crammed into a sharecropper's ice box. Authorities believed the tragedy was not accidental.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., June 4 -- The guiding fathers of this town are beating the drums harder. They are blowing the trumpets throughout New England to an ear-splitting crescendo and come next Friday this town's populace will go overboard in a four-day celebration to honor the late illustrious P. (Phineas) T. (Taylor) Barnum.
WEST POINT, N. Y., June 4 -- In the final game of the season for both teams, Columbia defeated Army at baseball today on Doubleday Field, 4 to 1.

I DO not wish to appear otherwise than grateful, which I certainly am, for the kind review Robert Hillyer wrote of the book I edited and helped to write, called "Writers on Writing." There is a point, however, I should like to take up with the understanding that it is correction and in no sense a complaint.

PROVIDENCE, R. I. -- The world's largest shore dinner hall, designed to seat 3,000 persons on its single floor extending out over Narragansett Bay, will be one of the major new tourist attractions in Rhode Island this summer.

As one who had been staying away from the movies on the basis of comments by friends that there were no pictures worth seeing, I decided to gamble time and money on a personal investigation. I therefore spent my three-day holiday last week-end in going to the movies, taking in three pictures a day for a grand total of nine.

Conscientious Americans cannot be satisfied or pleased over the juxtaposition of two items in the recent news. At one point is the expression of dismay and reproach by China and the Philippines that the United States should have unilaterally decreed an end to the idea of reparations from Japan.

SALT LAKE CITY, June 4 (AP) -- A New Jersey newspaper, The Daily Journal at Elizabeth, won top honors tonight in the daily newspaper division of the general excellence contest sponsored by the National Editorial Association.

GREAT NECK, L. I., June 4 -- Heirs of Great Neck estates of two financiers -- Henry Phipps, industrialist and partner of Andrew Carnegie in steel, and Payne Whitney -- have given large portions of their holdings for public benefits.

THIS is Mr. Davis' second novel since "Honey In the Horn," which won him the Pulitzer Prize in 1936. Like his prize novel, "Beulah Land" is a story of pioneering -- in this case the travels in 1851 of four people, from North Carolina (then part of the Cherokee Nation), through the Southwest, Kansas and the Oregon Trail.

With cotton goods prices at their lowest figure since the end of the war, textile sellers have been successful in outmaneuvering buyers who have exerted heavy pressure for prices that would push them into heavy loss positions, it was pointed out in Worth Street last week. According to observers, the market is "scraping bottom" so far as prices are concerned, with only a limited number of downward quotations possible.

About 800 physicians, some of whom came from Europe, gathered in New York last week to attend the Seventh International Congress on Rheumatic Diseases. It cannot be said that the Congress added much of scientific importance to what is known about the cause of arthritis. Indeed, the state of that knowledge is no credit to medicine.

The Van Woert Scholarship Fund Prize, valued at $100, and the Alpha Omega plaque, the two top awards for academic excellence awarded annually by Columbia University's School of Dental and Oral Surgery, have been given to Julius K. M. Richmond, 29-year-old student from Georgetown, British Guiana, who was graduated from the school this last week.
The text of the Polish Ambassador's statement regarding the Batory and the Eisler case follows:

LONDON. WITH the signing of the Atlantic Pact in Washington and the subsequent signature in London of the statutes of the Council of Europe, a nation that has been held at arm's length by its neighbors since the end of the war returns formally to the community of Western Europe. Italy, it is true, is a member of the Marshall group.

WITH a patriotic drum-roll and appropriate fife-flourishes, it might have been noted here last Sunday, and should be noted today, that the fiction department of the best-seller list to the right was last week, and continues to be, manned entirely by Americans -- from J. P. Marquand of Massachusetts down to Frances Gaither of Mississippi.

For the first time since 1941, overstocks of steel products have appeared among inventories of old established distributors in the Eastern states. Common nails had remained scarce here until last week, but now they are plentiful, and only pipe remains as a major steel product difficult to obtain.

CHICAGO -- Summer holidays in the Great Lakes region fall into two classifications -- vacations ashore and vacations afloat -- and as the 1949 season gets under way, the recreation picture shows these main characteristics:

AUBURN, N. Y. -- The scenic attractions, varied recreational facilities and richly historic communities of the Finger Lakes country long have recommended it to the vacationist. This season, when the traveler is expected to be more cost-conscious than in recent years the area's moderate prices for food, lodging and entertainment will add considerably to its attraction.

BUENOS AIRES, June 4 -- Six years after the "colonels' revolution'' and three years after his inauguration as President, Juan D. Peron remains today not only the dominant single Argentine but the most challenging figure in Latin America.

PHILADELPHIA, June 4 -- Pennsylvania Railroad carloadings last week totaled 117,745, a decrease of 21.2 per cent -- the largest weekly percentage decrease thus far in 1949 -- in comparison with the like 1948 week for which total loadings were 149,433.

NEARLY every bridge player knows that vulnerability has a great effect on bidding tactics. Nevertheless, too few players know when vulnerability should and does affect the decision to bid or to pass, and when it should not and (with a good player) does not.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., June 4 -- A total of $2,850,000 was raised by the American Heart Association and its affiliates in its 1949 campaign, it was announced here tonight at a dinner closing the annual meeting of the association by Harold E. Stassen, president of the University of Pennsylvania, campaign chairman.

A PUZZLING impression is made by the Summer Exhibition at the Milch Gallery. Here is an interesting group of American paintings, from the Eighteen Eighties to the present day, that seem to indicate that American art has not advanced in the contradictory and violent steps that one had gradually come to assume, but, instead, has glided in a graceful series of ever-widening circles away from the splash of Impressionism.

MRS. GRANT has chosen a serious and deserving theme. She sets out to tell the story of a young girl's confusion and eventual awakening when she discovers for herself an adult interpretation of the meaning of freedom. Unfortunately, her heroine is not a credible human being and so the theme is not worked out in terms of character.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- House investigators heard testimony today that the International Pressmen's Union, AFL, was led to believe that only $2,587 was involved when it voted to cancel a $25,000 note of its late president, George L. Berry.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 4 -- A portrait of Vanderbilt University's third chancellor, Dr. Oliver Cromwell Carmichael of New York, was unveiled at the university today by his daughter-in-law, Mrs. Oliver C. Carmichael Jr., of South Bend, Ind.
ARCADIA, Calif., June 4 (AP) -- June Bride, owned by C. H. Jones and sons of Los Angeles, won the $25,000 Hollywood Oaks Handicap at Hollywood at Santa Anita Park before 32,000 fans today.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Unemployment charts are watched with growing interest these days. The subject crops up more often in official conversations. There is not much anxiety, but there is some caution in viewing the future.

ROSES should look their best at their height of bloom, this month. Too often, however, they do not. I have seen shrubs, climbers and even hybrid teas that have gone to weeds and grass, which steal moisture and food from the plants all summer.

BOSTON, June 4 -- The Brook meade Stable's Going Away, 3-year-old son of Whirlaway, lived up to his name by defeating the Greentree Stable's favored One Hitter by two and a half lengths in the fourteenth Yankee Handicap today at Suffolk Downs.

The Westchester Electric Railroad Company and the Westchester Street Transportation Company, subsidiaries of the Third Avenue Transit Corporation operating in Westchester County, filed yesterday with the Public Service Commission new tariffs calling for 2-cent increases in their present interim fares.
Could Mr. Wheeler be wrong in interpreting as derisive Mr. Crankshaw's statement about "the American dream of bringing the joys of mass production and the drug store to every African village"?

The world oil markets, which have been in the hands of United States corporations since the inception of the industry, definitely are passing to British interests, according to leading executives in the international end of operations. The trend was emphasized last week when the British Government concluded an agreement to supply the petroleum needs of Argentina for the next five years.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., June 4 -- Archbishop Thomas J. Walsh of the archdiocese of Newark conferred this afternoon degrees upon 1,948 graduates at the ninety-third commencement exercises at Seton Hall College here.

NORTHFIELD, Vt., June 4 -- Godfrey Lowell Cabot, Boston philanthropist, has presented to Norwich University a gift of more than $500,000 for the support of a program of training in aviation and the construction of a science building, President Homer L. Dodge disclosed tonight.

MOSCOW, June 4 -- A hooded Klansman waiting at a gallows with a hangman's rope was the illustration chosen by the editors of Moscow's satirical weekly Krokodil to epitomize Alexander Pushkin's characterization of America in today's issue commemorating the 150th anniversary of Pushkin's birth June 6.

SHANGHAI, June 4 -- Following yesterday's announcement of regulations requiring the turning in of all foreign exchange, the People's currency sank more in value on the open market than at any time since the Communist entry into this city.

THIS Wednesday, Frank Lloyd Wright will celebrate his eightieth birthday. The chances are that he will be too busy to spend much time on the celebration. On his drawing boards there are dozens of houses, hotels, a museum, offices. However, he may take time out to reflect that at last a battle has been won. Only last March the American Institute of Architects awarded him its gold medal.

SAXONBURG, Pa., June 4 -- Atomic Energy Research officials and thousands of the public at-Etended a preview today of the new $1,500,000 cyclotron of Carnegie Institute of Technology, which is said to be the world's most powerful atom smasher.
IRWINTON, Ga., June 4 (AP) -- Two white men were arrested tonight and held on charges of suspicion of murder in the lynching Monday of Caleb Hill Jr., Negro.
DETROIT, June 4 (AP) -- A field of nineteen boats was under consideration today for the three American places in the British International (Harmsworth) trophy speedboat race here July 29-30.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The Congressional economy drive has recovered an inch or so of lost ground after yards of reversals on all of the first four regular appropriations bills to be passed by the Senate. There still is hardly any hope however, of averting a deficit in the 1949-50 fiscal year by budget-cutting.

Shunted into comparative obscurity by recent accounts of alleged thefts of money running into six figures, perpetrators of more unorthodox forms of thievery are still active, as these samplings from divers parts of the country attest:

For the first time since 1938, a considerable number of iron foundries in the New York area has cut back operations to a three-day-a-week schedule because of lagging orders. Industry members revealed here yesterday that foundries in this district are now generally on a reduced work week, with most plants operating only three days, a few on four-day weeks, and some on two-day weeks.

CHICAGO, June 4 (AP) -- If Samuel Jackson Snead can bag the $2,000 top prize in the United States Open at Medinah, Ill., next week, he will be within hailing distance of is money-winning championship season of 1938.

BUENOS AIRES -- North American tourists setting out for their first trip to South America will do well to spend an evening studying the map of the exciting continent they plan to explore. Such study may dispel some of their illusions, but those are well lost; a little knowledge of this part of the Western Hemisphere is essential to a good vacation here.
DETROIT, June 4 -- The CIO United Automobile Workers has issued a call for a June 16 conference to put the final touches on forthcoming demands against the Chrysler Corporation.
Six elementary school students from the metropolitan area participated yesterday in a current events quiz broadcast over WQXR and sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES as part of the weekly youth forum.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 4 -- The consensus in Government circles today was that financial aid to Brazil would await the arrival in the United States this month of Finance Minister Pedro Luis Correa Castro.
COSMOPOLITAN Stockholm lies on hilly islands in the sparkling waters of Lake Malar where it joins the Baltic. It is a little like Paris, a little like Venice, with a northern charm all its own.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- A Midwestern woman banker is slated to become Treasurer of the United States.

WILLIAM HAINES, once one of the leading stars of the silent screen, is today one of the leading interior designers of Hollywood homes. Among the picture personalities whose domiciles he has helped decorate are a number of profiles with whom he appeared in pictures two decades ago, including Joan Crawford, Constance Bennett and Leila Hyams

MIAMI BEACH -- The summer, or off season, at Miami Beach is bargain time for the holidayer. From now until late in the autumn, he will be able to enjoy the same kind of vacation, facilities, food, and accompanying luxuries at about half the price paid by those who were here during the winter rush.

NOORDWIJK, The Netherlands, June 4 (AP) -- Richard (Pancho) Gonzales of Los Angeles, United States singles champion, and Felicissimo Ampon of the Philippine Islands won two matches to gain the doubles final in the international tennis tournament today.

ENGLAND'S present age of austerity is agreeably haunted by chuckling ghosts who in one way or another have illustrated Pepys' masterly summing-up: "But Lord! to see the absurd nature of Englishmen." Satire, in the nineteenth century, had a field day with the smuggest audience.

In the brotherhood of the world's democracies, Denmark is among the smallest but also among the steadiest. There are few countries, small or large, for which Americans have a friendlier feeling or a deeper respect; and it is, accordingly, pleasant to salute the Danish people on this the one-hundredth anniversary of their Constitution.

Companies participating in plant and community programs devised by major advertising groups to increase understanding of the American economic system now number more than 360, compared to 210 in January, it was disclosed last week by Ken Wells, operations director of the joint committee sponsoring the over-all campaign.

VILLANOVA, Pa., June 4 -- Secretary of Defense Louis Johnson condemned today the caste system in the armed forces under which graduates of the service academies usually fared better than other officers.

The citizens of Washington, who for three-quarters of a century have been American DP's (disfranchised persons), have reason to rejoice. And so have their sympathetic fellow-citizens outside the confines of the District of Columbia. For the Senate has passed and sent to the House a bill that would restore to Washingtonians a privilege that most other Americans, not unreasonably, take for granted -- the privilege of running their own municipal affairs.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 4 -- Two seniors at New Jersey College for Women, Rutgers University, jointly received today the first Heritage Award given by the Associate Alumnae at the Reunion Day luncheon for an outstanding contribution to the heritage of the college.

In a letter you published recently a professor of astronomical physics argues that principles of the "new subject of social physics" indicate the inadvisability of federal aid to education. Might a professor of the more conventional sort of sociology point out the following:

During "Make It a Case for a Kid" Week, beginning June 13, the Salvation Army will collect used luggage in good condition to be given to children from 6 to 12 who are going to fresh-air camps this summer, it was announced yesterday by Commissioner Donald McMillan, Eastern territorial commander.

PORTLAND, Me. -- That cosmopolitan character, the American tourist, whose peregrinations in Maine provide the state with a sizable source of income -- $115,000 last year, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston -- is already stirring, and this easternmost of the forty-eight states is ready to welcome him.

CHICAGO, June 5 -- Active liquidation of long lines of wheat by traders who are convinced that a tremendous amount of winter wheat soon will be moving to market found a thin demand on which to unload, and the last week brought a drastic decline in prices for wheat futures on the Boards of Trade.

Steamship passenger traffic between the United States and Puerto Rico is expected to increase if a measure recently introduced into Congress by Antonio Fernos-Isern, resident commissioner of Puerto Rico, is adopted.

Four years ago, when Allied victories brought thoughts of postwar readjustments to millions of American servicemen, the New York State Department of Commerce began to get inquiries from them on the outlook for setting up a butcher shop in up-state Batavia, a radio store in Rochester and a variety of other small business establishments in towns and villages of the state's 57 counties.
BOSTON, June 5 (AP) -- The resurging Cardinals dropped the Braves into second place in the National League today by thumping the Bostonians, 8 -- 1, as lefthander Al Brazle twirled his sixth victory.

PRETORIA, South Africa, June 5 -- In the House of Assembly in Capetown last week Erich H. Louw, Minister of Economic Affairs, just back from the United States as leader of South Africa's delegation to the United Nations General Assembly, announced that import control would be extended to books and publications generally.

ROME, June 5 -- A combination of refrigeration, fertilizer and modern marketing methods may yet prove the golden key to make Italy another California with an economic future instead of only a colorful past.

Specialists in the practice of medicine have been accused of overlooking the whole man in their effort to cope successfully with the afflictions in which they are interested. The truth is that no good specialist ignores the whole man. Sometimes his contribution to his specialty is such that he assumes a kind of symbolic importance.

As a rule when we see or use the word "censorship" in respect to the press we think of only one type of operation. We call up a mental image of some government functionary who reads through the dispatch of a correspondent or the story of a reporter and deletes from it any matter that he finds objectionable or rejects it in toto.

CHICAGO, June 5 (AP) -- The White Sox and Senators split one-run decisions today with Washington using a ninth-inning squeeze play to take the opener, 7 to 6, and Chicago using a home-run by Cass Michaels and eleven other blows to triumph, 5 to 4.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (UP) -- Chairman Tom Connally, Democrat, of Texas predicted today that his Senate Foreign Relations Committee would give unanimous approval this week to the North Atlantic Security Pact.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) -- The Brookings Institution today announced the election of William R. Biggs of Washington as chairman of its board of trustees. He is vice president of the Bank of New York and the Fifth Avenue Bank.

PARIS, June 5 -- Jacques Rueff, French economist who is president of the Interallied Reparations Agency in Brussels, has just made a proposal that a part of the Marshall Plan dollars should be utilized by the beneficiaries for gold purchases.

TETERBORO, N. J., June 5 -- The twenty-second anniversary of the first transatlantic plane flight in which a passenger was carried was celebrated here today by a group of airmen, many of whom were fliers before World War I.

Albert J. Fitzgerald, national vice-president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations and president of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, accused the national CIO yesterday of sponsoring a program of "disruption" and "dictatorship" within unions.

LONDON, June 5 -- The crumbling process in the stock markets here continues. Under the impact of Wall Street's fresh break last week and the growing restlessness and truculence of workers in Britain, particularly railway men, this process has been accelerated, while the steady accumulation of disconcerting domestic and foreign events has brought more liquidation of securities than had been experienced in many months.

Hardly a day goes by now without news of another summer theatre unveiling its schedule for the hot-weather season. Who knows how many there are? Equity estimates 125 union companies in the East, but there are dozens and dozens whose art is unblessed by formal labor relations.

VIENNA, June 5 -- Hungarian Communist leader Matyas Rakosi's denunciation of "chauvinism" and "cosmopolitanism" among Hungarian Communists last week, and the Workers' party purge that followed it are only one of many evidences that "Titoism" is proving a highly infectious disease among Soviet satellites.

CLEVELAND, June 5 (AP) -- Sensational relief pitching by Rookies Bobby Shantz and Charley Harris and four Philadelphia homers enabled the Athletics to sweep both ends of a double-header, 3 -- 0 and 4 -- 2, against the Indians today.

The new $73,000,000 superliner to be constructed for the United States Lines will be equipped with twenty of the most modern lifeboats ever designed, each with a carrying capacity of more than 140 persons, it became known yesterday.

Increasing use of non-leather soles during the last few months has resulted in fairly substantial declines in the prices of heavy hides suitable for sole leather or heavyweight leather of a type used for the uppers of combat boots, Army service shoes and work shoes, it is reported by the National Shoe Institute.

The American Export Lines announced yesterday the establishment of direct express passenger service between New York and Palermo beginning Friday, when the new Laguardia, of 18,000 gross tons, departs from the Sicilian port for New York on the westbound leg of her maiden voyage in Mediterranean service.

After being eighteen months under construction, six months less than the original time estimate, the new elevated ramp of the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive on Manhattan's East Side between Eighteenth and Twenty - fifth Streets will be opened to traffic at 11:30 o'clock this morning.

WILDWOOD, N. J., June 5 (AP) -- Mrs. Betty Bush of Hammond, Ind., today successfully defended her title and the Elizabeth Bolton Clough Championship Trophy in the second Eastern States women's amateur golf tournament.

The Treasury Department is sending out circular letters asking "We the people" to invest in bonds "in our democracy." Will the officials of our Government never learn that we are a republic and not a democracy? Not as long as the Democratic party is in power, I fear.

Four seamen were removed from the Polish liner Batory yesterday by Immigration authorities, but they were taken back to the ship at Pier 88 late last night and her captain announced that the vessel would sail today on schedule.

CHICAGO, June 5 -- The corn crop was about all planted by the middle of last week and, as a result of recent good rains, the start of the growing season appears to be extremely auspicious for this grain. There may be an increase in acreage as compared to March estimates, since in some sections there appears to have been a decided shift from soybeans to corn.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., June 5 -- After rival teams fired all sorts of golf from birdies to a hole-in-one at them during the course of two rounds today. Bill O'Malley and John Humm, the Long Island amateur champion, finally bowed in the member-guest tourney of the Hempstead Golf Club.
AMSTERDAM, June 5 -- There is a remarkable divergence between official and private views on Dutch economy.

NOTRE DAME, Ind., June 5 -- John S. Burke, president of the B. Altman Co. department store of New York City, spoke this afternoon to 850 students in the graduating class of the University of Notre Dame.
A two-day "quickie" strike involving 168 Queens bus drivers was ended last night through the efforts of Daniel Kornblum, deputy director of the City Labor Relations Division.

An end to segregation and discrimination is needed immediately in the country's military and naval services, speakers told a commission of inquiry into the wartime treatment of Negro service men, at hearings yesterday afternoon and evening in the Community Church Center, 40 East Thirty- fifth Street.
WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls during the period May 28 to June 3 are given in the appended tabulation:

ZURICH, Switzerland, June 5 -- A worldwide campaign to revitalize the demand for silk fabrics whose popularity has been declining fast since the outbreak of World War II was inaugurated here by the International Silk Congress of May 30 and 31 which was attended by 165 delegates from eighteen countries.

One after another the automobiles pulled up in front of the Grand Street Boys Clubhouse at 106 West Fifty-fifth Street yesterday and delivered to the ballroom thirty-three couples, married at least fifty years. A few of them walking with canes, but most of them still spry, they seated themselves about a horseshoe table to enjoy the organization's thirteenth annual Golden Wedding Party.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, June 5 (UP) -- A group of Bolivian political exiles were arrested by Argentine police yesterday after an attack by their followers on the Bolivian frontier town of Villazon, a Government communique said today.

CHICAGO, June 5 -- Operating officers of the Loop banks here are scheduled to meet tomorrow to work out a program that will enable the Chicago Board of Trade to operate normally when the banks go on a five-day week with Saturday closings, starting on Aug. 6. It is expected that skeleton forces will be maintained for the purpose of taking care of banking needs of the grain traders.
MOSCOW, June 5 (AP) -- Pravda and other Soviet newspapers accused the American delegation at the Big Four meeting in Paris today of giving one-sided information to the press on closed sessions.

WARSAW, June 5 -- Describing Britain as "junior partner in a combination dominated by America's militant imperialism," George Chandos Bidwell, director of the British Council in Poland, announced today he had given up his British citizenship and resigned from his post to become a Polish citizen.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., June 5 -- Cardinal Spellman called upon doctors, scientists and all loyal Americans today to take an active part in combating subversive movements and not stand idly by while disloyal groups work to undermine faith in God and free institutions.

This space was given over last week to a discussion of a paper by Michael Sapir in which he analyzed the economic predictions made by an influential group of government economists in 1945 to see where and why they went wrong.

LEWISBURG, Pa., June 5 -- Dr. Joseph W. Henderson, Philadelphia lawyer, will become acting president of Bucknell University when Dr. Herbert L. Spencer leaves that office July 1, it was announced at the university's ninety-ninth annual commencement exercises today.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, June 5 -- All Denmark was festively bedecked with flags today to celebrate the centenary of the Danish Constitution.

A step from tires to textiles has recently put the United States Rubber Company into the fashion world. Although the company has been treading lightly in the field of apparel for some time, manufacturing rubber shoes and coats and spinning lastex yarn, it is only within the last year that plans have been moving toward large production of cotton and rayon fabrics.

PITTSBURGH, June 5 -- The national steel ingot rate dropped 2 points last week to 92 per cent of rated capacity. The decline this week may not be so great because a few plants were affected last week by the Memorial Day holiday.

Firemen fought for more than two hours early today in an effort to subdue a stubborn and smoky blaze in the St. Nicholas Arena, 53-69 West Sixty-sixth Street, for which four alarms had been turned in up to 2:07 A. M. Thirty firemen, meanwhile, had been overcome by smoke and were attended by Dr. Harry Archer, Second Deputy Fire Commissioner and Fire Department surgeon.
OMAHA BEACH, France, June 5 -- The Western Allies remembered today those who died fighting in the great invasion of Normandy five years ago.

The demand for summer merchandise, centered mainly on popular price and low-end dresses and sportswear, continued strong in the wholesale apparel markets here last week, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

Representative Vito Marcantonio, state and New York County chairman of the American Labor party, announced yesterday that Eugene P. Connolly and Benjamin J. Davis, Manhattan members of the City Council, had been designated as candidates of the Labor party for re-election.

VALPARAISO, Ind., June 5 -- The honorary degree of Doctor of Laws was conferred here today by Valparaiso University on Maj. Gen. Luther D. Miller, Army Chief of Chaplains, and, in absentia, on Miss Rachel K. McDowell, retired religious news editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

A bronze memorial tablet honoring the Rev. Dr. Dwight Witherspoon Wylie, seventh pastor of the Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street, was dedicated yesterday by the present pastor, the Rev. Dr. Theodore Cuyler Speers.

"Yes Is for a Very Young Mare," a play about France during the Nazi occupation, by the late Gertrude Stein, will be presented for the first time in New York tonight at 8:40 at the Cherry Lane Theatre, 38 Commerce Street, by Off Broadway, Inc., a recently organized theatre group.
WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The National Labor Relations Board reported today that the number of non-Communist oaths on file from labor leaders rose by 9,198 in May.

UPTON, L. I., June 5 -- The occasional award of an Atomic Energy Fellowship to a political extremist will do no harm, according to a statement made public here today by the Association of Brookhaven Scientists. Moreover, "we must also duly consider the enormous sum of money that would have to be spent in investigating all the candidates," the statement said.
LEWES, Del., June 5 -- Two freighters collided early today in a dense fog six miles off Cape Henlopen, Del., at the mouth of Delaware Bay.
WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) -- Major league baseball tonight welcomed back all players who presently are under five-year suspensions for jumping to the outlawed Mexican League in 1946.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- A new air agreement has been signed between the United States and Canada, granting almost all the Dominion's demands for access to the air travel markets of the United States in return for confirmation of rights previously enjoyed by United States aircraft at Gander, Nfld., and the granting of some minor routes in the West.

The rapid expansion in television broadcasting in this city during the last year. is evidenced in a new survey by Ross Reports, to eb issued today. The volume of programming by the six metropolitan video outlets reached a total of 300 hours per week during early May.

LONDON, June 5 -- Britain's spreading rail strike virtually halted all railroad transport in the eastern and northeastern parts of the country today and interrupted plans of thousands of Britons holiday-bound over the sunny Whitsuntide week-end.

The first week in June finds the art season prolonged in a number of exhibitions. One-man shows of painting on view today are those of Alo Altripp at Van-Dieman-Lilienfeld, oils and pastels by Helen L. Hollander at the Fifty-eighth Street branch of the Public Library, drawings by Trude Waehner at the Laurel Gallery, and paintings by Sara Berman-Beach at the Ladies Garment Workers Union.

In three years 30,000 adults have taken more than 100 courses ranging from rhumba dancing to the operation of a small business, Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, noted yesterday in making public a report on the Board of Education's community center program.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., June 5 (AP) -- Jersey City's league-leading Little Giants earned an even break in their four game series with Baltimore's lowly Orioles today by taking both games of a double header, 6 -- 5 and 3 -- 0, before a crowd of 6,714.
TETUAN, Spanish Morocco, June 5 -- The Caliph of Spanish Morocco and the daughter of the late Sultan of Morocco were married today at the climax of a $600,000 three-week festival.

PHILADELPHIA, June 5 (AP) -- The Chicago Cubs used the ancient but effective squeeze play to score a run in the top of the ninth inning and beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 8 to 7, in the nightcap of a double-header at Shibe Park.

Rumor, followed by denial, and repeating the maneuver several times over with respect to the devaluation of the pound sterling last week left bankers and dealers in the foreign exchanges as much in the dark of its imminence or probability as has centered in this topic since first bruited about two years ago.

Under the Veterans Preference Act of 1944 veterans receive virtually an absolute preference in federal job retention. No provision is made for length of service, efficiency ratings or special qualifications which non-veteran employes may possess. In any reduction of personnel, such as is now in progress, a veteran having achieved a permanent status of even a day's duration must be retained until all non-veterans in his classification have been discharged.

The Westchester Electric Railroad Company and the Westchester Street Transportation Company, subsidiaries of the Third Avenue Transit Corporation operating bus and street car lines in lower Westchester County, will begin this morning to collect the 7-cent interim fare approved Saturday by the Public Service Commission.

ALBANY, June 5 -- Encouragement of greater responsibility among younger drivers through "Man-to-Man" and "Dad-to-Daughter" pledges between parents and their children is the aim of a program to begin on Father's Day, June 19, A. H. Bartlett of Rochester, chairman of the sponsoring committee, announced today.

The setback to the truce and plebiscite negotiations under United Nations auspices between India and Pakistan over the Kashmir issue is somewhat discouraging. The original cease-fire agreement reached at the beginning of this year was a triumph of conciliation and naturally led to high hopes for a speedy settlement of the entire dispute.

For tiny, white-haired Mrs. Helen Preston Keating and the small group who gathered with her in the Apex Recording Studio on West Fifty-seventh Street yesterday afternoon was a special occasion. For sixty minutes Mrs. Keating held her auditors enthralled with her musicianship and technical ability at the piano. She will be 92 years old on July 22.
WASHINGTON, June 5 (UP) -- The Census Bureau reported today that United States cities employed 1,249,000 persons in October, 1948, an increase of 47,000 over the previous year.

SAMUEL ADRIAN BAUGH, a gentleman rancher from Texas, has formally announced that the next football season will be his final one in professional ball. Considering the fact that Slingin' Sammy has as many retirements to his credit as Geraldine Farrar, there may be some skeptics who are not completely convinced that the forward passing wizard of the Washington Redskins really means it.

A diocesan service of thanksgiving commemorating the 400th anniversary of the Book of Common Prayer was held yesterday afternoon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. Similar observances were held in Anglican churches throughout the world.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) -- Elizabeth T. Bentley, former Communist courier, today named six additional Government employes and four others she said had been information suppliers for the Soviet Government.

IVY COMPTON-BURNETT, whose brilliantly peculiar novels have been ecstatically admired in England for twenty-five years and more, was introduced to American readers a year ago with her "Bullivant and the Lambs." That perversely fascinating book came to us decked with critical raptures from English critics and fellow novelists and was greeted with equal enthusiasm here by American critics and novelists.
WEST POINT, N. Y., June 5 -- Twelve members of the United States Military Academy corps of cadets were honored for academic proficiency today at a colorful retreat review.

Compelled to choose between continuance in union office and membership in the Communist party, Max Perlow, secretary-treasurer of the United Furniture Workers of America, CIO, announced yesterday that he had quit the party.

Advertising in the eight major New York City newspapers during May totaled 14,510,295 lines, a gain of 8.19 per cent over the like month of last year, according to an analysis of Media Records. Categories recording gains were: Automotive, up 42.29 per cent; retail, 12.58 per cent, and financial, 5.09 per cent.
CADIZ, Ohio, June 5 (AP) -- Three life-term convicts who, with eleven other inmates escaped from the West Virginia State Penitentiary were recaptured near this town today.

DETROIT, June 5 (AP) -- Manager Joe McCarthy cracked the whip on his Red Sox today just before the Sox split a double-header with the Tigers. The Tigers won the nightcap, 11 -- 5, after losing the opener, 5 -- 3.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 5 -- Princeton University today greeted the combined track and field forces of Oxford and Cambridge Universities, the first English track team slated to compete in this country since 1937.
A 32-year-old Army veteran who is driving a taxicab to finance a course in interior decoration jumped into the East River early yesterday and rescued a young woman.
ROCHESTER, N. Y., June. 5 (AP) -- A new process for making full-colored pictures from black and white negatives was announced today by the Eastman Kodak Company.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 5 -- Samuel Goldwyn has named David Niven for leading role in "Beloved Over All" with Ann Blyth, Farley Granger and Joan Evans, the producer announced this week-end. Negotiations are in progress for David Miller to join Goldwyn as a director and to handle "Beloved Over All" as his first assignment.

ST. LOUIS, June 5 -- Billy Johnson bounced a couple of home-runs around Sportsman's Park this afternoon, but only one of them paid dividends and the Yankees had to be content with a division of their twin bill against the lowly Browns after touching their season's top of six victories in a row.

ALBANY, June 5 -- Five communities in the State, including Flushing, in Queens, have selected "community ambassadors" to go abroad this summer and spend six weeks living with families in communities overseas.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) -- Senate Democratic leaders talked today of new compromises in a drive to get rid of as much of the Taft-Hartley Law as possible. Senate debate on the Administration bill to repeal the law is slated to start tomorrow.

OLD WESTBURY, L. I., June 5 -- A 45-yard shot by Alan Corey 3:34 minutes after the start of the sudden death overtime period enabled the Bostwick Field poloists to defeat the Blind Brook team from Purchase, 7-6, in a thrilling high goal match on Bostwick Field today.

The New York Infirmary at Fifteenth Street and East Stuyvesant Park in 1947 and 1948 had the largest operating deficits in its ninety-six-year history, according to a report yesterday by Mrs. Frank A. Vanderlip, chairman of the board. The infirmary is the only hospital in the city staffed by women physicians.

BERLIN, June 5 -- Economic experts of the four occupying powers are scheduled to meet here again tomorrow to resume negotiations for a new trade pact between East and West Germany that some observers believe may decide the fate of the Council of Foreign Ministers talks in Paris.

Fordham University opened its 104th Commencement week yesterday morning with the Baccaulaureate exercises. An academic procession of 1,300 graduates, deans and faculties of the various colleges of the university marched from Keating Hall into the gymnasium where high mass was celebrated by the Rev. Joseph J. Comyns.

SUMMIT, N. J., June 5 -- Miss Helen Adams of New Brunswick won her second jumping championship in two weeks today with her gelding Unanimous. She captured four ribbons in the finals of the Watchung Riding and Driving Club horse show.

Bringing up five children and being assistant pastor in her husband's church did not deter Mrs. Mercedes Quiroga, 37 years old, from realizing a twenty-year ambition to be a college graduate. She will receive a bachelor of arts degree this month from Hunter College.

Controversy between former President Herbert Hoover and the Republican National Committee arose last night after the Democratic National Committee charged that the Republicans were using comments by the former President on governmental reorganization for political purposes.
Two early morning traffic accidents took a toll of two lives in Brooklyn yesterday and left several injured, one critically. The mishaps occurred in widely separated points of the borough.

NEW CITY, N. Y., June 5 -- A campaign is under way to have Rockland County dogs, both of the native and summer visitor variety, go to school to become better neighbors and respecters of man's property rights. The school starts Tuesday night at Knightscroft Kennels.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 5 -- Dick Webb of Mamaroneck, who takes his aged bay gelding, Tops'l, down South for the winter while he is attending Duke University, finished studies for the semester and brought the mount back North last week, and placed him in local competition for the first time this year in the twenty-fourth Harrison Horse Show, which completed its two-day run at the Kentucky Riding Stables this afternoon.
MOSCOW, June 5 -- For the second time within three days the Soviet press published today a report of price drops on the New York Stock Exchange.

Over-the-road common carriers have been invited to submit formal applications for tenancy in the new $9,000,000 New York Union Motor Truck Terminal by the Port of New York Authority, Howard S. Cullman, chairman, announced yesterday.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., June 5 -- Fred Eberhard and Des Sullivan of Essex Fells won the Rock Spring Club's member-guest golf tournament today with a 6-and-5 victory in the eighteen-hole final over G. C. Dunn and William A. Butler of Wykagyl.
Please permit me to solicit the interest of your readers in the United Negro College Fund.

The recurrent water famines that have plagued New York will in a few years be only unhappy memories, 150 civil engineers were told yesterday as they ended a two-day inspection tour of the sprawling Delaware water project.

Three meet records were broken and three were tied, with three other marks disallowed because of a favorite breeze, as the New York Athletic Club outscored the New York Pioneer Club and the Police Sports Association in a close team battle at the Metropolitan A.A.U. junior track and field championships yesterday.

Ralph Kiner, the current Mr. Big among the Who's Who in the National League, walloped his thirteenth homer of the season and gave the Pirates a 5-4, 10-inning victory over the Dodgers at Ebbets Field yesterday. Kiner's game-winning round-tripper was at the expense of Rex Barney, third and, of course, losing Brooklyn hurler.

ATHENS, June 5 -- The current rebellion seeks to place the Greek territories of eastern Macedonia and Thrace within the framework of the "People's Democratic Bulgaria," according to a document seized by national forces in the northern battle area and published here today.

Damage suits against organized baseball will be continued despite Commissioner A. B. Chandler's action in reinstating suspended players, attorneys for three former major leaguers under ban said last night.

Moderate declines were shown last week in the domestic cotton market although a portion of the sharp inroads of Tuesday were recovered. At the close of trading on Friday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were 5 to 29 points lower on the week, following losses of 3 to 15 points in the preceding week.
Eight new films, including importations from Italy and Great Britain, are slated to open in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

Fourteen students -- thirteen women and one man -- in a home economics course at New York University are completing their studies with few employment worries. Twelve already have received job offers, and two have decided to accept them.

The days when a postal clerk made $480 a year and the city's daily shipment of European mail was delivered at the Battery by rowboat came in for a thorough going-over yesterday, when 600 retired New York postal employes held their annual reunion at the Statler Hotel.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 5 -- Archbishop Josef Beran at Whitsunday Mass in the Saint Vitus Cathedral this morning appealed to the Roman Catholics of Czechoslovakia to remain loyal to the Church and the Pope and not be tempted "by those who use beautiful words and paint the most persuasive picture of other churches and authorities."

In these times of relative prosperity it will be for noted that the practice of whistling is more widespread than it is during lean years. The whistler, like anyone else, performs better on a full stomach. Broadway season offering a good musical also encourages whistlers, feeding them as it does with new material.
I have read with interest your editorial "Coddling the Airlines" in THE TIMES of May 26, in which you praise Mr. Rickenbacker's stand before the Senate Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee.

"Siam Doctor," by Jacques M. May, an account of eight years as a practicing physician in Bangkok and Hanoi, will be brought out on June 23 by Doubleday. Dr. May went to Siam in 1932 and remained until the fall of France in 1940.

DETROIT, June 5 -- A high Detroit Police Department official today accused the CIO United Automobile Workers of hindering the police in the search for the person who shot two UAW officials. The officer said the union was "competing rather than cooperating" in the investigation.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- President Truman declared tonight that the United States would continue to dedicate its strength and resources to building a peaceful and prosperous world, but he stressed that the great hope of achieving this goal rested in "developing a sense of unity among the free nations."

TOKYO, June 5 -- With little of the usual double talk, the Government is going to make a deliberate attempt to choose "troublemakers" for dismissal when pruning 172.000 employes from its top-heavy payroll.

EAST LANSING, Mich., June 5 -- David E. Lilienthal, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, upheld today the right of criticism as one of the sources of the country's strength and said that any "stifling" of criticism, even "when it gets pretty rough, is wrong."

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 5 -- One trooper was killed and twenty-six persons were wounded by gun fire in a clash between carabineros and mass demonstrators, called by President Gabriel Gonzalez Videla "Communists and Fascists," in front of the Caupolican Theater here today.

Rhubarb, like corn, is most delicious when it's eaten as soon as possible after being picked. Except for suburbanites who may have a few plants in their back yards, most city dwellers will find this the best time to make use of the herb that's called a vegetable and used like a fruit.

A World War II shrine honoring the parish war dead was dedicated yesterday afternoon in St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street. The Rev. Roelif H. Brooks, rector of the church, officiated.

PARIS, June 5 -- Foreign Minister Robert Schuman in a speech today at Sarreguemines made an offer of trade with Eastern Europe. Discussing the recent French trade accords with Switzerland, Spain and Yugoslavia, M. Schuman said:
Yesterday's warm weather attracted the largest crowds of this season to some of the nearby beaches, despite early cloudiness.

Prosaic utility and adventurous make believe have been teamed in an imaginative fashion in the new model playroom designed by Joseph Aronson that opens for exhibit today at the headquarters of the American Toy Institute, 200 Fifth Avenue.

Equivocation on moral issues of the day can rob the church of its effectiveness, the Rev. Samuel H. Sweeney, pastor of St. Mark's Methodist Church, St. Nicholas Avenue and 137th Street, declared in his sermon yesterday.

Recovery of fifty-two acres of state-owned oceanfront lands at Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn, will be the objective of a nonpartisan bill to be introduced in Congress this week, State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein announced last night.

FRANKFORT, Germany, June 5 -- United States Military Government officials have expressed the belief that the $800,000,000 requested by Washington for allotment to Germany by the Army and the Marshall Plan is too high, it was learned today.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., June 5 -- The church has never before had such a platform for world-wide work as today, the Right Rev. Henry Knox Sherrill, presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the United States, told a capacity gathering in the Cathedral of the Incarnation here today.

The four-story garage building at 519 West 161st Street was sold by Lebrad, Inc., to a client of Moses Kooperstein, attorney, who resold it within twenty-four hours to Gerald B. Schwarz, represented by William Reiss, attorney. Assessed for $57,000, the property is 50 by 100 feet and was sold subject to a first mortgage of $24,909 held by the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank.
NEWARK, N. J., June 5 (AP) -- Toronto started its second southern swing, sweeping a twin-bill with the slumping Newark Bears by 5 -- 1 and 11 -- 2 today.

VIRGINIA BEACH, June 5 -- Keeping the American people "food minded" and providing them with nutritious foods at lowest prices so that they will continue to spend a good share of their dollar at the grocery store is the prime job of the grocery industry, it was emphasized here today by Paul S. Willis, president of the Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc.

PITTSBURGH, June 5 -- Mayor William O'Dwyer of New York City confined himself to philosophy and advice here today in a short address before the largest graduating class in the history of Duquesne University.

CAIRO, June 5 -- Arab sources report that Tripolitanian political leaders are preparing to announce the formation of an independent Tripolitanian government that would undertake to negotiate an elaborate commercial and economic accord with Italy in return for an Italian agreement to back immediate independence for Tripoli.
PARIS, June 5 -- Evidence now can be assembled indicating that a political purge is quietly taking place in the Soviet Union.

PARIS, June 5 -- Negotiations among European financial authorities within the next fortnight are expected to determine how far the Marshall Plan countries will go toward meeting the United States desire for greater competition and lower prices in trade among those countries.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, added his voice today to the opposition of Administration leaders to a $1,500,000,000 China aid bill that has been introduced in the Senate.

Fresh impetus to the movement to get Mayor O'Dwyer to run for re-election was added yesterday when Dorothy Norman, former newspaper columnist, announced formation of the non-political Independent Citizens Committee to Draft O'Dwyer.
Municipal issues scheduled for sale this week aggregate $145,383,391, compared with $35,432,505 last week, and brings the weekly average offerings so far this year to $64,183,739.

It is just two years since General Marshall, then Secretary of State, made his historic speech at Harvard University in which the architect of the military victory in the last war launched a new campaign to save peace and freedom through that vast enterprise in international cooperation known as the Marshall Plan.

PARIS, June 5 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Foreign Minister, is studying the draft of the United States proposals for a division of the powers between a government of a united Berlin and a quadripartite Kommandatura, it was learned tonight.

MELBOURNE, Australia, June 1 -- Within sight of Mount Kosciusko, the highest peak in the Australian Alps, in the southeastern corner of New South Wales, are the sources of Australia's largest river systems, those of the Murray, the Murrumbidgee and the Snowy.
Following are the texts of the addresses by Gen. George C. Marshall and President Truman last night at the Marshall Plan anniversary dinner, as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., June 5 -- Another sou'wester, dry and lively despite an early threat of dampness from overhead, wafted out on Long Island Sound today for the regatta of the Huguenot Yacht Club, which was the fourth championship series of the Yacht Racing Association.
PARIS, June 5 -- After signing the Cochin China Bill today. President Vincent Auriol sent a message to Bao Dai, former Emperor of Annam, telling him the way had been cleared for peace in Indo-China.
A series of additional bills for summer theatres were announced here yesterday.

James F. Ross has been appointed assistant to A. L. Hammell, president of the Railway Express Agency, with headquarters at 230 Park Avenue. Samuel D. Stainton has been appointed to succeed Mr. Ross as general manager of the agency's New York City department, with headquarters at 219 East Forty-second Street.
BOGOTA, Colombia, June 5 (AP) -- Fragmentary returns from today's Congressional elections gave the Liberal party a slight but inconclusive lead.
