ROME, June 5 -- Palmiro Togliatti, Communist leader, today warned the pro-Catholic Democratic Christian Government of Premier Alcide de Gasperi that any attempt to outlaw the Italian Communist party would result in "grave danger for Italy."
MIAMI, Fla., June 5 (AP) -- The steamship Flagship Sinco reached the safety of the harbor of Charleston, S. C., today after two days of distress on the Atlantic, the Coast Guard reported.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Senator Scott W. Lucas, Democrat, of Illinois, announcing a bill to strengthen the deportation laws, said today that more than 3,000 aliens were subject to removal from this country.

A newly arrived, rather poorly dressed immigrant from the Azores, zealously guarding a collection of assorted trunks on a local steamship pier, recently aroused the suspicion of a customs inspector. Engaged in the routine task of examining the luggage of other passengers, the officer ordered the man to display his seemingly valuable possessions.

The Giants didn't tie or break any records at the Polo Grounds yesterday, but they did crack the spirit of Bucky Walters' Reds in practically no time at all and for immediate purposes that served just as well.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., June 5 -- Senator John L. McLellan of Arkansas assailed tonight proposals for compulsory health insurance as "false doctrine and a hope that is only a delusion." He addressed the National Conference of County Medical Society Officers on the eve of the opening here tomorrow of the annual meeting of the American Medical Association.
MIAMI, Fla., June 5 (AP) -- The steamship Flagship Sinco reached the safety of the harbor of Charleston, S. C., today after two days of distress on the Atlantic, the Coast Guard reported.

Again attacking highly advertised new methods of preventing tooth decay, the American Academy of Dental Medicine declared yesterday that "the health of millions of American children may suffer irreparable damage if the exaggerated emphasis now placed on the isolated problem of dental caries is not corrected immediately."

"I was sick for a while and we had a hard time meeting expenses. One night my husband did not come home. The next day he sent me a note saying he could not face the responsibility of caring for all of us.

Dealer and distributor inventories of Silex Company's obsolete glass coffee maker line will be exhausted by July 1, William S. Cary Jr., New York district manager, declared last week. Dealers have been offering old models at 50 per cent price reductions since the company removed the old line from fair trade arrangements last December to make way for introduction of new models the following month.

ALBANY, June 5 -- A comprehensive exhibit covering the history of comics, or stories in pictures, from the caves and tombs of thousands of years ago to the contemporary comic strip, will be formally opened here in the State Education Building tomorrow.

FONTANA, Calif., June 5 -- Henry Kaiser's war-time "dream" steel plant, anomalously rearing up amidst vineyards and citrus groves of the Southern California hinterland, is expanding apace under the impetus of the West Coast's post-war steel needs.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture has reported that farmers had stored a record quantity of 346,581,000 bushels of corn under Government price-support programs by May 1. Largest amount ever before put under support programs was 302,000,000 bushels, from the 1939 crop.
BOSTON, June 6 -- The high rate of excise taxes was blamed today for a "substantial decrease" in the volume of liquor sales.

To its ineptness in handling the Eisler case the Justice Department has added a certain churlishness in its treatment of the passengers arriving on the Polish liner Batory, on which Eisler made his ignominious escape last month. While entirely legal, the performance was petty, undignified and unworthy of the United States of America.

LAKE SUCCESS, June 6 -- Twelve journalistic experts, meeting here under United Nations auspices, today adopted a work program to consider such issues as ways of raising journalistic standards, defining press responsibilities and the possibility of drawing up an international "code of honor."
LONDON, June 6 (AP) -- A touring United States track and field team defeated athletes from five European nations to win the British Games today.

Gordon Glisson was the hit of the show at Belmont Park yesterday. The 19-year-old apprentice jockey from Seattle thrilled a crowd of 22,078 fans with riding performances that saw him bring home four winners out of six mounts.

BUENOS AIRES, June 6 -- Five hundred rubber workers invaded the plant office of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company last Tuesday and threatened to "do what they did in Bolivia" to the American supervisors, it was learned today.

DETROIT, June 6 -- The United Automobile Workers, CIO, offered $200,000 today as a reward for information leading to the conviction of the assailants of Walter P. Reuther and his brother Victor, its president and director of education, respectively.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) -- The United States should "openly or otherwise" subsidize foreign newspapers and radio networks, Representative John D. Lodge, Republican, of Connecticut, said today, in order to further the State Department's overseas information program.
Mayor O'Dwyer embarked last night on the campaign he had previously promised -- to educate the people of the city on their municipal problems in advance of the coming Mayoralty campaign.

Complaints of Negro merchant marine officers over their inability to obtain employment on United States ships since the end of the war will be considered in Washington next week, it was disclosed here yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 6 -- Wheat, as well as other grains, were on the down grade on the Board of Trade here today, reflecting lack of confidence on the part of buyers, while the free covering by shorts late last week left the market technically in a weaker position.
MILLEDGEVILLE, Ga., June 6 (AP) -- Thirteen of the fifteen doctors at Georgia's 10,000 - patient mental hospital tried to resign today. They were discharged instead.

Shortly after noon yesterday Mayor O'Dwyer and Hugo Rogers, Manhattan Borough President, using garden shears, cut the red, white and blue ribbon to open formally the new elevated ramp of Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive between Eighteenth and Twenty-fifth Streets.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- American imports declined from $632,000,000 in March to $534,000,000 in April, the Department of Commerce announced today. The April figure was approximately 10 per cent below the average of $596,700,000 for the first quarter of 1949, the department said.

WILMINGTON, Del., June 6 (AP) -- Unleashing a powerful stretch drive, Foxcatcher Farms' Rose Beam, an eligible for the $25,000 Sussex Handicap, won by two and a half lengths in today's Forest Lin Purse at Delaware Park.

ARROMANCHES, France, June 6 -- Germans, former members of the Wehrmacht and now free farm workers in France, were among the many visitors to the Normandy beachheads, where ceremonies commemorating the fifth anniversary of the Allied landings were held yesterday and today.
WASHINGTON, June 6 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved the North Atlantic Treaty today by 13 to 0 and urged its ratification by the Senate.
The widely heralded photoreconnaissance flight of an Air Force B-17 over the city took place last night but, from a spectator point of view at least, was not so awe-inspiring as had been expected.
LAKE SUCCESS, June 6 -- India and Pakistan have rejected truce proposals set forth by the United Nations Commission for India and Pakistan, the commission reported today.

BOSTON, June 6 (AP) -- The red hot St. Louis Cardinals made it five victories in their last six road games today and twelve out of their last fourteen by thumping Boston's Braves, 7 -- 3, easing the pennant defenders out of second place in the ever changing fight for the National League lead.

BERLIN, June 6 -- Declaring that the "hour has come for our church to speak," Bishop Otto Dibelius, chairman of the German Protestant Council of Churches, has written a pastoral letter comparing the Soviet zone of Germany to the Nazi Reich with the Gestapo come to life again in the form of the security division of the "People's Police."

Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, called on the Transport Workers Union yesterday to clean left-wing elements out of control of its Miami airline local. The local represents 2,000 mechanics and ground personnel of Pan-American Airways.
WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) -- The House passed a bill today to repeal long-standing racial restrictions that deny citizenship to some 85,000 Japanese and "other Asians" living in the United States.

Spurred by the appeals of both Secretary Acheson and Former Secretary Marshall for prompt ratification of the North Atlantic Treaty, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee has now given unanimous approval to the Pact. The action guarantees that there will be an overwhelming vote for the Treaty in the Senate as well.

Plans were announced yesterday for a new structure to replace the large and odorous building at Fulton and South Streets in which is conducted a small but important part of the business of the Fulton Fish Market. The new building will increase the property's fish handling facilities by utilizing space now occupied as a garage.

LONDON, June 6 -- The political temperature of Britain rose another degree today when Winston Churchill, Conservative opposition leader, issued a statement accusing Herbert Morrison, second in command of the Labor party, of having falsified remarks made by Mr. Churchill at a political rally on April 28.

The annual exhibition of recent accessions was opened yesterday afternoon at the New York Historical Society, Central Park West and Seventy-seventh Street, by a private view for members. A lecture on the "Cavalcade of American Legend" was presented by Carl Carmer in connection with the annual old-time strawberry festival at the same time.

A total of thirty-four dailies in eighteen states and the District of Columbia will be used during the next two months by the Maiden Form Brassiere Company, Inc., it was announced yesterday. Departing from its method of presenting several bra styles in each ad, Maiden Form will use larger space to promote one specific model in each piece of copy.

TUCKAHOE, N. Y., June 6 -- The home club talent repelled all invaders as Toney Tiso, the professional, won the pro-amateur best ball weekly Westchester County P. G. A. tournament in conjunction with three home club partners over the tricky Vernon Hills Country Club course today.
BLUEFIELD, W. Va., June 6 -- Southern coal operators asked the United Mines Workers today to add a half-hour to the work day. Also, they indicated they wanted many other changes in the contract.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- In the Supreme Court of the United States today, George F. Dillemuth, William C. Levy, and Michael J. DeSantis of New York City, were admitted to practice and the following proceedings were had:

SAN FRANCISCO, June 6 -- James Caesar Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, AFL, opened the union's fifty-second annual convention today with an attack on both labor leaders and legislators who had trimmed sails in the campaign to repeal the Taft-Hartley Act.

ALBERT BENJAMIN CHANDLER has received so few pats on the back during his stormy tenure as baseball commissioner that this one will have to be delivered gently. Otherwise it is liable to knock him over. It was a wise move that he made in reducing the suspension of the Mexican League jumpers from five years to three.

BLACKPOOL, England, June 6 -- By a margin of more than six to one the fortieth annual conference of the British Labor party, which opened here today, confirmed a decision of the party's leadership to expel Konni Zilliacus, the party's most prominent supporter of the Communist "peace campaign."

CHICAGO, June 6 -- The American Guild of Variety Artist, AFL, at the opening session of its national convention here today, "prepared'' to withdraw its participation in the East Coast and West Coast Theatre Authorities, which are the controlling agencies and clearing houses for all benefits engaging theatrical talent.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) -- Former Representative Andrew J. May and the munitions makers, Henry and Murray Garsson, appealed to the Supreme Court today from their convictions on charges of bribery and conspiracy to defraud the Government during the war.

SHANGHAI, June 6 -- Gen. Chen Yi, member of the Central Committee of the Chinese Communist party, Mayor of Shanghai and commander of the Communist armies in East China, was reliably reported to have said last night that aid from any foreign nation -- including the United States and Britain -- would be welcome, provided it was offered on the basis of sovereign equality.

An exhibition devoted to the scientific achievements of Johann Wolfgang von Goethe was opened last night in the New York Academy of Music. The exhibition, organized by the Rudolph Virchow Medical Society, is part of the world-wide commemoration of the poet's 200th birthday anniversary, June 6.

Sales of New York City and Brooklyn department stores declined 19 per cent last week compared with the corresponding week a year ago, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., June 6 -- A collection of five birdies and two eagles on the back nine for a nine under par 28 enabled Merlin Rosenbaum of Glen Head and Arthur Stuhler, unattached, to card a 60 for the winning card in the amateur-pro tournament of the Long Island P. G. A. at the North Hempstead Country Club today.

A five-room dwelling at 122 Rose Lane, the first in a group of forty-five houses with expansion attics being erected in the Lakeville Manor development in New Hyde Park, L. I., has been purchased by Robert Ross, civil engineer, according to Lane Realty, sales representative. The development covers fifty acres between Union Turnpike and Hillside Avenue.

In spite of the fact that Congressional action on an organic act for Guam is still delayed, specific problems are being met and some progress is being made. On Saturday the Guam Congress took final action to clear up the basis of its earlier difference with the Naval Governor when it adopted an act specifically empowering the Congress to subpoena witnesses.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 6 -- A reduction of 9.43 per cent of the cost-of-living bonuses of all Westchester employes and officials will become effective on July 1 because of a drop in living costs as indicated by the Consumers Index of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, county officials said today.

Idle for fourteen weeks as a result of the shutdown of six big New York baking companies, 4,000 bakers and drivers will take steps today to set up a cooperative baking plant of their own and to operate it on a permanent basis in competition with other bread producers.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- A recent top secret report of the Atomic Energy Commission was drafted by a person who had once been suspended because the Federal Bureau of Investigation had raised questions about his loyalty, the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy was told today.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., June 6 -- The campaign committee to promote the candidacy of State Senator Elmer H. Wene for Governor was formed here today when Democratic leaders met in the law offices of former Gov. A. Harry Moore, Senator Wene's campaign manager.

Park Department concessionaires are as sunny as the weather. Their cash registers are playing a lively, welcome tune at bootblack and newsstands, beach refreshment stations and the plush Tavern-on-the-Green.

PARIS, June 6 -- Despite Western concessions, the Soviet delegation remained immovable today and the Council of Foreign Ministers ended the last of its first three secret sessions without reaching a solution of the Berlin problem.

TRENTON, N. J., June 6 -- The New Jersey Legislature, in special session today, received a bill to require arbitration of strikes involving public utility companies. It would correct a state act held unconstitutional by the State Supreme Court.
Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower took no part yesterday in ceremonies marking the fifth anniversary of D-Day, the storming of the Normandy beach by the Western Allies, of whom he was supreme commander.

Efforts by the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service to avert a threatened nation-wide strike by the National Maritime Union, CIO, received a new impetus yesterday with the arrival of Cyrus S. Ching, national director of the service.

Fleet Admiral Ernest J. King has signed a contract with W. W. Norton Co. for the publication of his memoirs. He is at work on the book in collaboration with Walter Muir Whitehill, Librarian of the Boston Aythenaeum.

In the field of entertainment many of the stars and customs of an age past have been revived in the last few years. Vaudeville is back at the Palace. Disk jockeys who feature old-time records have seen their shows' Hooper ratings skyrocket. Al Jolson and Maurice Chevalier now have expansive radio shows of their own. Old tunes are heard in the juke boxes.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) -- The Maritime Commission today swapped an admiral for a general as its new chairman. Maj. Gen. Philip B. Fleming, former Federal Works Administrator and trouble-shooter for Presidents Roosevelt and Truman, was sworn in as head of the agency.

Thirty-eight Negro longshoremen took over the offices of the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, at 265 West Fourteenth Street for five hours yesterday in a demonstration against alleged discrimination in the distribution of work on the Brooklyn waterfront.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- The appointment of Mrs. Georgia Neese Clark, banker and all-around first citizen of Richland, Kan., as Treasurer of the United States, with a salary of $10,330, was sent to the Senate today by President Truman.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., June 6 -- The trustees of the American Medical Association exploded a bombshell here today in the direction of Dr. Morris Fishbein, its internationally known editor, spokesman and chief apologist.

Since everyone knows how Gertrude Stein played games with words, let's not waste time in looking surprised because her last drama is full of double, triple and quadruple talk. It is entitled "Yes Is For a Very Young Man," and it was put on last evening at the Cherry Lane by a group called Off Broadway, Inc.

LAKE SUCCESS, June 6 -- The recent setting up of a British-approved regime in Italy's former African colony of Cyrenaica was condemned today as "null and void" by the official spokesman here for the Libyan independence movement.

BERLIN, June 6 -- The three Western powers formally notified the Russian authorities today that no trade agreement between East and West Germany would be signed "as long as the Berlin railway strike continues."

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., June 6 -- Dr. Searle Harris of Birmingham, Ala., today received the 1949 Distinguished Service Medal from the House of Delegates of the American Medical Association. The award, highest honor for medical achievement by the AMA, was voted Dr. Harris for his outstanding work of hyper-insulinism (over-activity of the pancreas), a condition opposite to diabetes. The medal will be presented tomorrow night.

ATLANTA, June 6 (U.P.) -- Homer B. Chase, Georgia chairman of he Communist party, was put under a $5,000 peace bond today in an action said to be unprecedented against a political leader. He was jailed when he failed to post the amount.

BOSTON, June 6 -- Christian Scientists attending the annual meeting here today of the Mother Church, the First Church of Christ, Scientist, heard a report from their board of directors that cited a growing need for "more direct evidence of spiritual power."

Among the many public administrators and civic-minded business men who feel the need for educating the public in vital fields are two who have joined the City College faculty to do something about it.

ROME, June 6 -- In a report released today, the Israeli Government was charged by a Franciscan father, Alberto Gori, who has the official title of "Custodian of the Holy Land," with having carried out a policy hostile to the interests of the Roman Catholic Church in Palestine.

Proposals for a new contract for the Third Avenue Transit Corporation and its subsidiaries similar to those already submitted to the Board of Transportation covering city workers were ratified last night at a meeting of Third Avenue employes at Transport Hall, 153 West Sixty-fourth Street. The old agreement expires June 30.

LONDON, June 6 -- With indications pointing to a nation-wide rail tie-up next Sunday and on Sundays thereafter, it was reported tonight that the Executive of the National Union of Railwaymen, the biggest of Britain's three major railway unions, would meet in a special session here tomorrow to consider what steps to take to quell the worsening situation.
Details of business space leases in Manhattan were reported by renting agents yesterday as follows:

The stock market plunged yesterday to a two-year low and was only prevented from breaking to the bottom level for five years by a subsidence of pressure in the final hour. Losses matched and in some cases exceeded those suffered a week ago, but the resistance to the decline by a few key issues held the drop in the composite rate to 1.52 points.
WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) -- Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder and his top aides on international finance plan to visit Europe next month.
Conversion of a Hudson River pier into a terminal for trucks bringing fruit and vegetables to the city was called for yesterday by a produce industry committee.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- A private sale by the Long Island Lighting Company, Mineola, N. Y., of $16,000,000 of debentures due in 1960, to four insurance companies, was cleared today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The Bankers Trust Company has been appointed New York paying agent and registrar for $10,000,000 Potomac Electric Power Company First Mortgage bonds 2 7/8 per cent series dated May 1, 1949 due May 1, 1984.

After years of critical shortages of hospital facilities in New York, it is cheering to learn that construction work is going full speed ahead on much-needed city hospitals totaling, in estimated cost, $41,936,000. For a long time we have had to accept these facilities as something for the relatively distant future.

Expansion plans of textile finishing plants are proceeding according to schedule despite the drop in fabric production and sales this year, according to manufacturers exhibiting wet processing finishing machines at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory yesterday.

Leonard Steiner, seeded second, Charles Masterton, ranked one notch below, and the fifth-ranked Alastair Martin scored victories in the annual Brooklyn tennis championships which got under way at the Knickerbocker Field Club yesterday.

Former President Herbert Hoover, speaking yesterday at the graduation exercises of the Institute for the Crippled and Disabled, said that the voluntary institution was "eliminating human and national wastes in the best way -- outside the Government."

The decline in the demand for copper has resulted in a rather sharp curtailment of production. The Phelps Dodge Corporation, the nation's second largest producer of the metal, announced yesterday that it has decided to cut its domestic output about 5,000 tons monthly.

Back in the dog days of last year, after Mr. Truman had been nominated for the Presidency, he called the recently adjourned Congress into special session. The task set before the legislators was, in his declared opinion, quite modest; he stated that the job could be completed "in fifteen days if they wanted to do it."

In granting the New York Telephone Company an interim rate increase the Public Service Commission hinted that the day of the nickel phone call is nearing its end. Soon, then, if official prophecy is fulfilled, one of the last citadels of the ancient and ubiquitous five-cent piece will have fallen.

Two small youngsters met their new foster mothers for the first time yesterday at the foster home bureau of the Jewish Child Care Association, 329 East Sixty-second Street. There was nothing unusual in this procedure, except that it marked the 1,400th baby placement by the association.

Hits were a dime a dozen and runs a nickel yesterday as Penn State and St. John's College won the opening two games in the District 2 elimination baseball tournament of the National Collegiate Athletic Association at Dexter Park in Woodhaven.

VIRGINIA BEACH, June 6 -- Development of good human relations by American business is the only means of stopping the continuing trend toward a welfare state in America, three speakers at the mid-year meeting of the Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., in the Cavalier Hotel, warned here today.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- The contempt of court conviction of John L. Lewis and the United Mine Workers of America, for failure to halt a strike last year, was upheld today by the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals. The tribunal ordered the UMW leader and the union to pay fines to a total of $1,420,000.

Coffee futures declined in early trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday but rallied sharply toward the close. Final prices for contract "S" were 10 points higher to 5 points lower. Contract "D" also rallied after early declines.

Having decided to welcome home the misled athletes who jumped the reservation in '46, organized baseball stretched itself today to demonstrate that it really has a heart as big as a Georgia watermelon.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 6 -- Thomas Ray of New York, director of research for the CIO National Maritime Union, was called before the Federal grand jury here today as it resumed an inquiry which has already led to the indictment of Harry Bridges and two other West Coast longshore leaders.

George Stern bought the four-story nine-family apartment house at 415 Watkins Street, in Brooklyn, from Fannie Fisher, subject to a mortgage of $8,000, in a deal negotiated by A. H. Kaufman. Title to the property was insured by City Title Insurance Company, which also provided title insurance to Camella Iannella and Alfredo Rubicano, who purchased the six-family tenement building at 325 Stagg Street, from the City of New York.
On April 20, 1949, Bern reported that Switzerland had released $47,000,000 to Germans not living in Germany. On May 9 your correspondent George Morison attempted to give the Swiss point of view.

Furs by Ralph Marano, ranging from the classic pyramid coat to the last-word jacket cape, were shown yesterday at Russeks Fifth Avenue. Between these two extremes of the conservative and the novel the fur designer had many other models.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (UP) -- Senator Pat McCarran, Nevada Democrat, told the Senate today that his immigration subcommittee had information that Capt. Jan Cwiklinski of the Polish liner Batory engineered Gerhart Eisler's escape "on orders from Moscow." He made his statement shortly after the vessel sailed from New York.

The stepped-up tempo of police protection against muggers, purse snatchers and degenerates in Central Park after dark has resulted in 100 per cent more arrests in the first five months of this year than in the first six months of 1948, according to Capt. John J. McCoy, in charge of park detectives.

PRETORIA, South Africa, June 6 -- After an enforced Sunday lull, South Africa's most recent gold boom continued today with renewed force. Johannesburg remained the frenzied center of stock exchange operations but a wave of speculation swept the whole country.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (UP) -- The United States Court of Claims ruled today that Louis H. Crook, 61-year-old head of the Aeronautics School at Catholic University here, was the inventor of an ignition shielding system which prevents radio interference in planes, tanks and other military equipment.

PRINCETON, Me., June 6 -- Some insist that this area is a contradiction in terms, for Grand Falls Lake is not a lake but a river, and the town of Princeton is only a tiny village. However no one ever questions the statement that it is one of the finest small-mouth bass regions to be found.

This closes a series of three articles on dairy products made near and for this city. It outlines essential processes in the preparation of ice cream. These are just a sample of the multitude of processes demanded in America's largest industry, that which moves food from farm to table.

Consolidated net income of the American Cable and Radio Corporation, a subsidiary of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, was $152,743 in the first quarter of this year, contrasted with a loss of $800,922 in the comparable period of 1948, it was announced yesterday.

An empty space along the side wall of the garage tells its own mute little story. It does not tell of the arrival of a new car, no, not that, this year. Nor does it tell of a picture which may once have hung there, an early Westchester primitive, or of a map of the flower garden or Cape Cod.

NEW DELHI, India, June 6 -- Tan Malaka, Indonesian Communist leader implicated in an attempted kidnapping of Sutan Sjahrir, then Republican Premier, in June, 1946, was executed at Blitar, East Java, April 16, the Indonesian information service here announced today.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 6 -- James Miller Robinson, 35-year-old Negro from Chicago, sat on a bed in a third-class Prague hotel under pictures of President Klement Gottwald, Lenin and Stalin today and said that he had renounced his American citizenship, "which was second-class at best."

Propane liquid gas shipments may be substituted for Berlin air lift shipments of coal, saving fifteen carrier flights per day and $700,000 per month in fuel delivery costs, it was learned yesterday. Liquid gas equipment required could be amortized in two weeks, a survey disclosed.

RKO has signed Michael O'Shea and Julie Bishop to appear in "Terror," which starts today. O'Shea also is interested in an independent company, Mid-Continent Films, which has been formed to produce Western pictures in Utah, with him as the star. . . .

Eight hundred and thirty-seven students of Long Island University's College of Arts and Sciences received degrees last night at the nineteenth annual commencement exercises, held in the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) -- Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, advised small business men today they will have to work to get business abroad. "It's not laid in your lap," he said.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., June 6 (AP) -- Wes Westrum, husky Jersey City catcher, tonight broke an International League record that has stood up for 66 years when he walloped his fourth home run of the season with the bases loaded to give the Little Giants a 10-6 victory over Buffalo in the opener of a four-game series.

List price reductions on television receivers "from here on in" be distress selling rather than "bona fide price cuts," S. W. Gross, president, Tele-Tone Radio Corporation, declared yesterday. He made this statement at a conference in the St. Regis Hotel called to introduce a new lower-priced television receiver by the company.

Whittaker Chambers, ace witness for the Federal Government in its perjury prosecution of Alger Hiss, testified yesterday that Henry Julian Wadleigh was a second "source" of State Department documents for transmission to a Soviet spy ring.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) -- An anti-lynching bill was approved today by the Senate Judiciary Committee. Introduced by Senator Homer Ferguson, Republican of Michigan, it was the first civil rights measure to be approved by a Senate committee at this session of Congress. No roll call vote was taken.

New York University's Letter Club presented its first annual trophy to Irving (Moon) Mondschein last night at the University Faculty Club, 22 Washington Square North. The ceremony was the highlight of a general meeting of the Club in which prominent sports celebreties acted as guest speakers.

Behind the brilliant four-hit pitching of Don Newcombe the Dodgers downed the Pirates, 5 -- 1, under the Ebbets Field lights last night and moved even with the Giants at the top of the National League standings.
Soviet Russia has embargoed shipments of chrome ore to the United States as another retaliatory move in the trade war between the U.S.S.R. and this country, it was reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) -- The Senate confirmed today the nomination of Thomas C. Buchanan of Pennsylvania to be a member of the Federal Power Commission.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Senator J. Howard McGrath, Democratic national chairman, congratulated former President Herbert Hoover today for repudiating political distortion in rebroadcasts of a series of radio talks he made earlier on Government reorganization.

Five hundred pickets staged a noisy four-hour demonstration in sunlit Foley Square, yesterday morning to protest the jailing of three of the eleven Communist leaders on trial for conspiracy in Federal Court.

FOREST PARK, Pa., June 6 -- Almost three-quarters of the non-union dress factories in the New York metropolitan area have been put under union agreements as a result of the organizing drive in which William Lurye, a special organizer for the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, AFL, was fatally stabbed May 9.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 6 -- Seven Connecticut tool and die and contract manufacturing shops with assets of more than $1,000,000 have joined forces to set up a new corporation to be known as the Connecticut Mechanical Industries, Inc., according to papers filed here today by Paul W. Adams, counsel for the group.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday and final prices were 2 to 25 points net lower than on Friday.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Three war workers told the House Committee on Un-American Activities today that a State Department request to "hold off a while longer" made possible the escape of a Russian spy trapped by the Federal Bureau of Investigation with their help.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) -- Southwestern private utility operators told a Senate Appropriations Subcommittee today that they now are willing to transmit public power over their lines to serve Government customers, such as Rural Electrical Administration cooperatives.

A large influx of out-of-town buyers shopped New York's wholesale garment market yesterday to begin the initial three-week period of women's apparel purchasing for fall. The first contingent of buyers crowded coat, suit and dress manufacturers' showrooms and a substantial number stayed after the showings to write their fall orders.

Slightly behind schedule and with her crew intact, the Polish liner Batory left port yesterday with flags flying and her band playing a sprightly polka. She began slipping away from Pier 88 into the North River at 12:35 P. M., after Federal investigators had forbidden visitors aboard and had stood by until the gangplanks were removed.

St. John's Prep, behind the five-hit pitching of left-hander Jim Green, moved into the final round of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association baseball championships yesterday by defeating Cardinal Hayes, 4 -- 1, at Fordham Prep field.

While hundreds of Communist sympathizers engaged in mass picketing outside the Federal Court House, the Circuit Court of Appeals denied yesterday an application by John Gates for release on bail in the Communist trial. The court agreed to hear argument next week on his appeal from his jail sentence for contempt of court.

Replying to Stanley Judkins, who complains of slow-moving mail from White Plains to his New York office and compares such glow delivery with the expeditious service on outgoing mail from New York to an unnamed town in New Hampshire:

Something for nothing -- everybody likes that. And that's why everyone ought to enter the Greater New York Fund Vacation Contest. Hop a plane to Mexico City, visit glamourous Acapulco, see the buried city of Cuernavaca, Tasco Guadalupe, the Pyramid of the Sun and Moon -- and do it without spending one cent. Or perhaps you'd prefer a trip to Bermuda to see the Marine Gardens, the coral reefs?

Irving Sommers, who recently bought the fifteen-story apartment building at 41 Fifth Avenue, southeast corner of Eleventh Street, from the New York Life Insurance Company, has resold it to an investor, it was announced yesterday. The New York Life took title to the property in September, 1947.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 6 -- "The All-American," a screen story by Vincent X. Flaherty and Douglas Morrow dealing with the career of Jim Thorpe, famous Indian athlete of the Carlisle Institute, has been purchased by Warner Brothers as a vehicle for Burt Lancaster. Everett Freeman will produce the picture.

NANKING, June 6 -- A distinctive feature of the Communist occupation of the Yangtze Valley is the introduction in the big Chinese coastal cities of the Tang Ko dance and of a new string of ideological ditties first sung by the Communists in the rural hinterlands.
LONDON, June 6 (Reuters) -- A day of untinterrupted sunshine inspired several batsmen to flay the bowling for big scores in today's English County cricket.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, June 6 (AP) -- A new Sears, Roebuck Co. store opened here today and police were needed to ease the crush of first-day customers.

NOORDWIJK, Holland, June 6 (UP) -- Eric Sturgess, the Great Stonewaller from South Africa, recovered after a poor first set today to upset Richard (Pancho) Gonzales of Los Angeles, 2 -- 6, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 2, and win the Dutch international lawn tennis tournament.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) -- An Interstate Commerce Commission examiner has recommended that the dividend rate, on the Maine Central Railroad Company's preferred stock be kept at 5 per cent, if and when the par value is increased.

Ramming into four double-plays, two under the league record, the Giants dropped a 4-3 decision to the Reds in the series finale at the Polo Grounds yesterday. Considering that the home team scored two runs on a Cincinnati error and the other on a pop-fly homer, the New Yorkers, conducting themselves unlike a first-place outfit, were lucky to make it close.
PARIS, June 6 (AP) -- Russia's Vyacheslav M. Molotov was reported today to have received the task of wooing the Chinese Communists into alignment with Soviet communism.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Mayor James Peterson of Soperton, Ga., who charged into five members of the Ku Klux Klan recently and ripped the masks off three of them, was complimented on his action by President Truman today.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board today defended the new air-transport agreement with Canada, signed last Saturday, as giving to the United States all that could be expected from negotiations conducted in good faith.

LAKE SUCCESS, June 6 -- Andrew W. Cordier, executive assistant to Secretary General Trygve Lie, will leave by air tomorrow for Lausanne, Switzerland, to check up on difficulties holding up the work of the United Nations Palestine Conciliation Commission, it was announced tonight.

Pointing out that the number of arrests on the city's rapid transit facilities had grown from 1,500 in 1942 to an indicated 13,000 this year, spokesmen for the New York City Transit Patrolmen's Benevolent Association requested the Board of Transportation yesterday to increase the number of transit policemen from 300 to 1,000 men.
MITCHEL FIELD, L. I., June 6 -- New York held still and watched the birdie tonight while its picture was taken 130 times from an Army B-17 circling 3,000 feet overhead.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 6 -- Gerard Graham Dennis, the society "Raffles" who was arrested in February on charges of ransacking country estates on the East and West Coasts and in Canada, was brought into County Court here today for trial on twelve indictments charging thefts of $140,150 from Westchester estates.

IS there any such thing as the "spiritual authority" of a writer? Franz Schoenberner thinks there is. Since he is both an impressively learned and a highly intelligent man, Mr. Schoenberner is not so naive as to think that the mere fact of being a writer carries with it any spiritual authority. There are too many fools and knaves with access to typewriters for that.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- President Truman issued today an executive order formally establishing the position of the United States High Commissioner for Germany, who "shall be the supreme United States authority in Germany." Mr. Truman has nominated John J. McCloy for the position.

The City Stores Company and its subsidiaries transacted the largest sales for any April quarter on record and the largest volume for any twelve-month period in the company's history, according to the report for the quarter and twelve months ended on April 30, released today.
The Hiss-Chambers case has undergone a remarkable transformation in its move from the House Caucus Room in Washington to the Federal Court on Foley Square.

A banking syndicate headed by Blyth Co., Inc., will offer today to investors an issue of $25,000,000 of new cumulative preferred stock of the Caterpillar Tractor Company. The stock has a par value of $100 per share and will carry a dividend of 4.20 per cent. It is priced at par.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- The power of New York State court judges to sentence a murderer to death even though the jury recommends life imprisonment was upheld in the Supreme Court by 7 to 2 today. Justice Hugo L. Black wrote the majority opinion, to which Justices Frank Murphy and Wiley B. Rutledge dissented.

When the Taft-Hartley Law was approaching enactment in mid-1947 William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, denounced it in a nation-wide broadcast as "slave-labor legislation." Other labor leaders attacked it as "extreme," "punitive" and "vindictive"; and President Truman, in his veto message, predicted that its effect would be to "weaken the union movement."
Grand jury criminal informations were returned yesterday accusing eight alleged rent gougers of having obtained $11,000 in illegal bonuses from apartment seekers.

The new summer home of the Philharmonic-Symphony will be a steel - framed, aluminum-sheathed, hydraulically powered concert stage in Lewisohn Stadium. The structure is permanent, replacing the wood and cloth affair of former years.

An informal hearing into the causes of the collision early Sunday morning between the freighters Exmouth and Hellenic Beach in a dense fog six miles off the Delaware coast will be held today by the Coast Guard. Lieut. Comdr. Alf S. Lie, who conducted a preliminary investigation yesterday, will preside.

VENICE, Italy, June 6 (AP) -- Dr. Norman Edwin Himes, 49, sociologist and author of books on marriage and birth control, died here today after an accidental fall in his hotel bathroom. Death was due to a fractured skull.
Wives and children of veterans living in Quonset hut housing in the East Bronx received their first visit yesterday from a library on wheels, a new bookmobile operated by the New York Public Library.

A series of dramatizations of contemporary novels will be launched by the NBC University Theatre at 6:30 P. M. Saturdays, starting June 18. The opening bill will be Budd Schulberg's "What Makes Sammy Run?" Other novels to be adapted to radio will include John P. Marquand's "Point of No Return"; "Guard of Honor," by James Gould Cozzens; "The Ides of March," by Thornton Wilder, and "Brighton Rock," by Graham Greene.

The high cost of living has upset many a vacation plan or contemplated purchase, but for Howard Stein, 26-year-old Columbia University student, an anonymous well-wisher has made possible fulfillment of a cherished dream.

The idea that liberal arts colleges are training girls away from marriage is outmoded and growing more so every year, Miss Margaret Clapp, newly elected president of Wellesley College, told a press conference at the New York Wellesley Club in the Barclay Hotel.

DETROIT, June 6 (AP) -- The Red Sox outlasted the Tigers in a free-hitting and free-walking game today and took a 10-9 decision. The Red Sox clubbed out a dozen hits, including a homer and two triples, and were aided by ten walks given up by Tiger pitchers. Detroit had eleven hits and eight passes to first.
JERUSALEM, June 6 -- The Jewish community in Jerusalem is preparing for a conflict that, although internal, promises to be fierce and ruthless.

According to the latest arrangements, Ken Murray's West Coast perennial, "Blackouts," will bow in at the Ziegfeld Theatre on Sept. 6, or six days earlier than previously announced. The opening date, by a coincident, happens to fall on the birthday of Billy Rose, proprietor of the theatre.

While a bag of gems valued at $75,000 to $100,000 was overlooked, a ten-carat diamond ring and a pair of earrings, with a total value of $26,000, were taken from the Hampshire House apartment of William G. Helis, wealthy oil operator, the police reported yesterday.

CLEVELAND, June 6 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians, with Manager Lou Boudreau playing third base for the first time since his minor league days, exploded with nine runs in the eighth inning tonight to defeat the Philadelphia Athletics, 11 -- 5.

CHICAGO, June 6 -- Eight Legislatures have given a larger share of state taxes this year to their cities, the American Municipal Association reported today. The association, composed of state municipal leagues representing more than 9,000 cities, said Indiana municipalities' share of motor user taxes would be doubled by recent legislation.
WASHINGTON, June 6 -- The fight to repeal the Taft-Hartley Labor Law opened in the Senate today.

Samuel Seabury, who was the father of the fusion movement that led to the nomination and election of Fiorello H. La Guardia as Mayor in 1933, declared yesterday that the need for a fusion movement existed this year whether or not Mayor O'Dwyer was a candidate for re-election.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- The Senate Commerce Committee today heard a prominent airline executive say that the Government had failed to keep its promises to the airlines, and that this was responsible for the financial plight of the lines.

MOSCOW, May 22 -- Higher Education Minister Sergei Kaftanov has ordered a general reorganization of the training of journalists in Soviet universities to increase the technical and scientific aspect of their studies.

The O'Dwyer Administration had dropped its proposal to impose a 2 per cent sales tax on containers and other packing material, Vice Chairman Joseph T. Sharkey of Brooklyn, Democratic majority leader, announced in the City Council. At the same time the Democratic majority in the Council directed Mr. Sharkey to withdraw a proposed 2 per cent sales tax law amendment applying to certain types of printing.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 7 -- University will share the spotlight with nearly 5,000 returning alumni during a six-day program that will begin Thursday with class reunion activities and close Tuesday with Princeton's 202d annual commencement on the tree-shaded North Campus in front of Nassau Hall.

Max N. Natanson, who purchased the former Altman warehouse at 207-13 East Thirty-Sixth Street and 204-10 East Thirty-seventh Street last fall, has resold the property to John Stuart, Inc., furniture wholesalers, who will use the building in their business.

The Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, one of three maritime unions affiliated with the Congress of Industrial Organizations, met yesterday under the auspices of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service at the service's headquarters at 341 Ninth Avenue to negotiate with the least and Gulf Coast shipowners.

CHICAGO, June 7 -- Michael Arlen Marten, the six-week-old daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Henry Marten of this city, and named after the British novelist and playwright, will be christened this week-end in New York City attired in a dress first worn by an infant member of Mrs. Marten's family 150 years ago.

CLEVELAND, June 7 -- The 50,000 Jewish displaced persons who have entered the American labor market since 1940 have created an equal number of new jobs for American workers, Dr. Herman A. Gray reported today. Dr. Gray is former chairman of the New York State Advisory Council on Job Placements and Unemployment Insurance.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Parts of a statement made last week by Cyrus S. Eaton, Cleveland financier and industrialist, demanding that the Securities and Exchange Commission's appropriation for the fiscal year 1950 be "drastically reduced" were "grossly misleading," Edmond M. Hanrahan, chairman of the SEC, said today.

" Her Man Gilbey," a British-made farce starring Michael Wilding in the title role, Lilli Palmer and Peggy Cummins, which opens at the Forty-second Street Embassy, is this morning's lone film newcomer. The J. Arthur Rank production is being released here through Universal-International.

St. John's University, Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference champion, defeated Penn State by 3 -- 0 at Dexter Park in Woodhaven yesterday to reach the final round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association District 2 eliminations.

MUNICH, Germany, June 7 -- Because the International Refugee Organization is due to go out of existence next year, plans have been initiated to transfer those displaced persons in Germany who have not yet been repatriated or resettled into the care of German voluntary agencies.

CHICAGO, June 7 -- July deliveries of grain were all relatively strong today, with closing prices at about the best level of the day on the Board of Trade here. The deferred deliveries also registered gains, but buying of the July futures was especially active.

The pamphlet report for 1948 of the Royal Dutch Petroleum Company for publication today shows a net profit of 83,090,610 florins, compared with 66,992,287 in 1947. This represents dividends received from various companies in the group after expenses and taxes.

A merger of the New York Dispensary, the second oldest in the country, with the New York Infirmary is awaiting approval of the New York State Department of Social Welfare and the State Supreme Court, it was learned yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, June 7 (AP) -- The St. Louis Browns used a ten-hit attack -- including four doubles -- back up Red Embree's six-hit pitching and defeat the Boston Red Sox 6 to 2 tonight. It was the twelfth victory of the season for the American League's cellar team.
LONDON, June 7 (UP) -- It's the medium length and "the Russian look" for Soviet fashions next year, the Moscow radio reported today.

Two thousand five hundred persons attended a rally in Union Square yesterday afternoon to protest the jailing of three of the eleven Communist leaders on trial for conspiracy. They heard seventeen speakers attack Judge Harold Medina and the ruling that remanded the three defendants.

In selecting a job in the fashion world, graduates should look to the ultimate goal and how rapidly it may be reached rather than to the initial responsibility and salary, E. W. Carter, president of the Broadway Department Store, Los Angeles, said yesterday.

Mayor O'Dwyer at a reception yesterday told 100 prominent citizens of New York, including many municipal officials, that he was holding a party on the lawn of Gracie Mansion on the evening of June 28 and added that he would "like you all to attend."

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Louis Johnson, Secretary of Defense, approved today the Navy's second plan for assuring racial equality for its personnel but he rejected for a second time a similar effort by the Army.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- A group of ninety-one members of the House of Representatives formally asked the United States Government today to press for the strengthening of the United Nations in the form of a world federation armed with powers of enforcing world law against aggression.

The State of Minnesota financed yesterday war bonus payments to the state's World War II veterans by borrowing $84,000,000 on tax-exempt bonds due in one to ten years at an interest cost of 1.45769 per cent.

The Philharmonic-Symphony will expand its Saturday morning Young People's Concert Series by one event next year, it was announced yesterday. Dean Dixon, last year's winner of the Alice M. Ditson award, will appear for the first time at these concerts, the announcement added.

Restrictions on the use of French francs have been modified to stimulate heavier American buying of quality goods for immediate and early fall delivery, according to reports which were being checked by banking officials late yesterday. The move is one which bankers here have been expecting for some time and which some of them consider to be necessary if France is to overcome objections by American buyers to prevailing high prices for luxury goods.

Fordham University's College of Arts and Sciences held its 104th annual commencement exercises last night in the University gymnasium with 454 graduates receiving their degrees. The class was the largest in the history of the college. The Most Rev. Joseph F. Flannelly, Auxiliary Bishop of New York, presided and presented the degrees.
BERLIN, June 7 (AP) -- The three- power Western Kommandatura today ordered the airlift to start carrying Berlin's mail.

In spite of the attempt of his brother's chauffeur to save him, George Brette Glaenzer, retired executive of the American Hard Rubber Company, 11 Mercer Street, plunged to his death yesterday at 3:30 P. M. from his thirteenth floor suite of The Yale Club, 50 Vanderbilt Avenue.
One-room apartments and television settings appear to have been the main concern of designers for the new furniture shown yesterday by the Valley Furniture Corporation, 428 West Fourteenth Street.

Coffee futures closed mixed in moderate trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Demand from trade interests provided the support and absorbed scattered selling. The major share of the volume was due to hedge covering of the near-by months with replacement in the more distant deliveries.
Founding a cooperative nursery school certainly was logical, and perhaps inevitable, is a place like Riverside Campus.
The Greenwich Savings Bank will open tomorrow its new branch at 3 West Fifty-seventh Street with the unveiling of a set of paintings depicting the growth of the bank and of the city since 1833.

NEW DELHI, India, June 7 -- India has taken over the semi-independent state of Sikkim in the Himalayas, on the border of Tibet. Troops marched into the state capital of Gangtok last Thursday and an Indian administrative officer assumed full administrative functions yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, June 7 (AP) -- Four hits in the ninth capped by Andy Seminick's single gave the Philadelphia Phillies two runs and a 6-5 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates tonight.
CHICAGO, June 7 (AP) -- The outstanding pros, in the habit of snubbing par-golf in winning tournaments, now have great respect for that figure as the National Open championship approaches.

BLACKPOOL, England, June 7 -- The widely advertised revolt by supposedly disgruntled trade unionists against the British Labor Government's wage-freezing policy came to naught at the Labor party's annual conference today. Instead of a big bang there was a dull phut.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) -- Federal District Judge Edward A. Tamm ruled today that under the Taft-Hartley Law the National Labor Relations Board must hold hearings on charges of jurisdictional fights between rival labor unions.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Government counsel at hearings by the Civil Aeronautics Board on a proposal by Pan American Airways, Inc., to acquire American Overseas Airways, Inc., asked the board's examiner today to subpoena the leading officials of half a dozen major airlines.

Preacher Roe, the Dodgers' veteran southpaw hurler, who boasts about any season in which he makes five hits, slammed two singles and batted in two runs as he downed the Cubs, 7 -- 1, at Ebbets Field yesterday. Emil (Dutch) Leonard, the knuckleball artist, was the victim of Roe's offensive outburst, the Preacher's second safety driving Leonard to the showers in the sixth inning.

ALBANY, June 7 -- State Controller Frank C. Moore said today that the Department of Audit and Control was not "concerned" over reports in legal circles casting doubt upon the constitutionality of the appointment of Benjamin F. Feinberg as chairman of the Public Service Commission.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- A broad program to increase the country's grain storage facilities and protect Southwestern wheat producers against "forced sales" at distress prices was outlined today by the Secretary of Agriculture, Charles F. Brannan.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 7 -- Communists in the Arab states are intensifying their activity in spite of all efforts to suppress them, according to good Arab sources here and in other Middle East countries. This is confirmed by other sources.

" The Man in the Moon," as the translation called it, an operetta, or burletta, by one Franz Josef Haydn, an entertaining trifle which contains some delicious music, nearly two centuries old, made its American debut last night at the hands of the Lemonade Opera Company, which functions happily and to the great satisfaction of its audience in the basement of the Presbyterian Church on West Thirteenth Street.

Wider use of refrigerating cabinets to store and display fruits and vegetables in retail stores will be seen during the coming year, members of the National Association of Food Chains predicted here yesterday at a clinic on merchandising of these foods held in the Statler Hotel.

Two young robbers took $19,565 from Columbia University yesterday at 9:25 A. M. in a hold-up on the steps of the university's chief administration building, University Hall. The money, in two canvas bags destined for the bursar's office, was taken from two guards of the Wells Fargo Armored Service Corporation, one of whom was armed.

Extension of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act is a "must" on the legislative program for this session; but it is a disturbing report that the Senate Republican leadership plans "one of the stiffest fights of the year" on this essential piece of legislation. It is surprising, too, inasmuch as in the House of Representatives a majority of the Republicans who voted on the bill when it passed in February were recorded in its favor.

Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 2,663, compared with 851 last week and 3,973 in the similar week a year ago, according to the listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 1,365 arrivals yesterday, against 143 last Tuesday.

NEW DELHI, India, June 7 -- Controversy between France and India about the referendum to be held in five French Indian colonies expanded today as Chandernagore prepared to vote "under protest" June 19.

Dress buying for fall was accelerated yesterday as more manufacturers in the popular and medium price field opened their lines in crowded showrooms. Merchandise men and women indicated that they will make a cautious approach in selecting dresses for the new season, but will be ready to order substantially in the next two weeks.
One ticket broker lost his license yesterday, a second will have a revocation hearing tomorrow and Commissioner of Investigation John M. Murtagh requested revocation of a third broker's license.
The start of demolition on the site of the New York University-Bellevue Medical Center was marked yesterday by a noontime ceremony.

On the occasion of the passage of the new Displaced Persons Bill in the House, and your praiseworthy editorials on this subject, I should like to express sincere thanks and gratitude on behalf of displaced persons, both in the United States and still awaiting the important day when they too will be able to start life anew in this country.

BOSTON, June 7 -- The New York Central System's $2,000,000 streamliner, the New England States Limited, made a round trip trial run to Springfield, Mass., today, and officials called it and its twin ready to go into regular overnight service between here and Chicago on Thursday.

Raymond M. Hilliard, Commissioner of Welfare, reported yesterday that "there has been no increase in the number of applications for care of children away from their homes." He also said that the number of dependent and neglected children receiving foster care has been reduced 33 per cent from 21,000 in 1939 to about 14,000 this year.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., June 7 -- A parliamentary maneuver, designed to prevent a threatened open breach in the ranks of the American Medical Association, succeeded today after much behind-the-scenes activity in keeping "l'affaire Fishbein" in a quiescent state, at least temporarily.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 7 -- The official news agency said tonight that fifteen Czechoslovak citizens, some of whom had "admitted contact with British Capt. Philip Wildash," had confessed at a secret trial now in progress to having plotted to overthrow the Czechoslovak Government.

Twenty-five hundred members of the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, took matters into their own hands yesterday morning and brought to an abrupt end thirteen weeks of picketing of their union's president, Joseph P. Ryan, for alleged discriminatory practices against Negro longshoremen in Brooklyn.

Tomorrow should be the final day of decision on the part of Mayor O'Dwyer, whose announcements that he is not a candidate for re-election have been met with a determined "draft" movement sponsored by his closest friends.

ROME, June 7 -- A proposal that the United States, Britain, France and Italy reach agreement in principle on the question of the former Italian colonies before the next session of the United Nations next fall was understood to have been advanced today by Premier Alcide de Gasperi during a conversation with United States Ambassador James Clement Dunn.

There's a likelihood of the famous Rainbow Room on the sixty-fifth floor of 30 Rockefeller Plaza being transformed into a theatre to give "arena" or "theatre-in-the-round" performances, starting in mid-September, under the chaperonage of Norman Bel Geddes and Eddie Dowling. it became known yesterday.
DETROIT, June 7 -- Dr. Harry Shulman, Sterling Professor of Law at Yale University, today was named chairman of an arbitration panel to rule in the speedup dispute at the Ford Motor Company.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, June 7 (UP) -- Dr. Ralph Bunche, former United Nations Mediator in Palestine, is being urged to accept the post of United States member of the three-nation Palestine Conciliation Commission, informed sources said today.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it would approve a plan filed by the Ogden Corporation of New York, providing for the distribution of certain assets in escrow of its subsidiary, the Interstate Power Company of Dubuque, Iowa, if the plan is modified in several minor respects.
A spokesman for Strato-Freight, Inc., operator of the airplane that crashed off Puerto Rico yesterday, insisted that the craft was not overloaded despite the large number of passengers aboard.

Whittaker Chambers sought yesterday to explain seven specific instances of perjury by saying that he had preferred to jeopardize himself rather than Alger Hiss and other friends who, he said, had formerly worked with him in Communist espionage activities.

In a cash transaction, the 45-45 Thirty-seventh Street Corporation has purchased the two-story commercial building at 45-45 Thirty-seventh Street, in Long Island City, Queens, from the Spiegel Realty Corporation, through the Pettit-Waterman Company.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The Republican Policy Committee ruled out today provisions in any new labor law that would permit commitments by the Government to unions while seized property was being administered by a federally-designated agency.

Ramirez Miguel, who is 39 years old and came here from Puerto Rico, ventured into the field of forensic logic yesterday, in Flatbush Court. His argument was readily demolished, but it still won freedom for Ramirez Miguel and eleven others.

Peggy Wood has been signed to play the title role of Mama in the television adaptation of the Kathryn Forbes book, "Mama's Bank Account," from which the Broadway play, "I Remember Mama," was derived. The series will start on June 17 over the CBS television network, having been assigned to the 8 o'clock period on Friday evenings.

CHICAGO, June 7 -- Weakness in the market price of the 5 per cent, series A, convertible preferred stock of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad Company drew attention today to substantial sales of Rock Island securities recently by James Norris, Chicago, a director of the railroad.

The $126,000,000 municipally owned power and light system of Seattle, Wash., reported yesterday that operations in 1948 resulted in a net income of $4,263,185. While no comparison with the previous year's net income was available, electric operating revenues were $12,662,247, a rise of 8.78 per cent over the $11,640,286 reported for 1947. Excluded from these revenues was $117,411 from sales of power to other utilities, an increase of $115,845 over the $1,566 shown for 1947.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The leadership of the House today moved to expedite a full-dress investigation of military air plans of the United States as that program has developed around the giant B-36 bomber.

Manikins modeled gay summer attire yesterday up and down the aisles of the cars on the special train provided by the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad to carry passengers to and from New York for the musical "As the Girls Go."

BOSTON, June 7 -- The nation's liquor wholesalers were urged today by a Louisville, Ky., distiller to maintain a strong credit standing in order to retain "maximum bargaining power" with suppliers as more whisky became available.
PARIS, June 7 (AP) -- The text of a statement by Secretary of State Dean Acheson in explanation of Paragraph 4 of the United States proposal of June 2:

WASHINGTON, June 7, -- Following is an abstract of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee's article-by-article report on the North Atlantic pact, except for Article 5, where the committee's interpretation is given in full. Material in quotation marks is verbatim from the report.

VIRGINIA BEACH, June 7 -- Larger producers of advertised brands of groceries are eyeing the export market as a "sales cushion" in the event of a volume decline in a softening market, it was declared here today by Willis H. Gurley, vice president of the Borden Company, New York.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- President Truman proposed today a little Marshall Plan for the new republic in southern Korea, requesting Congress to appropriate $150,000,000 to aid that country's recovery for a year.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, June 7 -- Metropolitan Timothy Evangelides of Rhodes has been elected Greek Orthodox Archbishop of New York, it was announced here today by the Holy Synod of the Ecumenical Patriarchate.
John Boe has been promoted from general sales manager to vice president of the P. F. Collier Son Corporation, 250 Park Avenue.

Richard Weil Jr. has been elected president of Macy's New York, Jack I. Straus, president of R. H. Macy Co., Inc., announced yesterday following a meeting of the board, Mr. Weil will take over his new duties at once and will remain as a vice president, a member of the board of directors and of the executive committee of the parent.

LAKE SUCCESS, June 7 -- Sir Benegal N. Rau, permanent representative-designate of India to the United Nations, said today that a free and impartial plebiscite in Kashmir was impossible while the Azad pro-Pakistan forces held their positions in the princely state.
SUN VALLEY, Idaho, June 7 (AP) -- Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder said today the nation's financial and economic situation is "basically sound."

MOSCOW, June 7 -- Pravda today accused the United States and Western delegations at the Paris conference of attempting to apply the "method of diktat" [dictation] and with submitting proposals that they knew in advance would be unacceptable to the Soviet Union.

Immigration, border patrol and investigation officers were out in force again yesterday to greet the 11,000-ton Sobieski, inbound from the Mediterranean with 447 passengers. She is a sister ship of the Gdynia America liner Batory, on which Gerhart Eisler left the United States.
WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) -- The Corn Belt Livestock Feeders Association proposed before a House Agriculture subcommittee today that the Government abandon all support prices for hogs.
SEOUL, Korea, Wednesday, June 8 -- President Syngman Rhee expressed gratitude today over Mr. Truman's request to Congress for $150,000,000 in aid for Korea for the next year.

Frederick Brown, operator, has bought for cash from the City Bank Farmers Trust Company, as trustees of the William Waldorf Astor estate, the two-story business building at the northwest corner of Lexington Avenue and East Eighty-seventh Street.

The promotion of closer understanding and friendship between the peoples of Turkey and the United States was urged here yesterday at a meeting attended by diplomats and business men at which an American-Turkish Association was formed.

PRINCETON, Me., June 7 -- Although there was some talk of the excellent landlocked salmon fishing now found on Big Lake, we decided to pass up this in favor of the small-mouth bass opportunities on Grand Falls Lake, for many Maine waters have land-locks, but few offer this kind of bass fishing.

What may be the final attempt to reach an out-of-court settlement of the long-standing lease controversy between the Port of New York Authority and eight major commercial airlines will be started at 2:30 o'clock this afternoon at the University Club, 1 West Fifty- fourth Street.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 7 -- Changing his mind after yesterday's refusal to plead guilty, Gerard Graham Dennis, international jewel thief, induced the authorities to take him from the county jail to county court here this afternoon.

International friendship was the keynote yesterday of the Washington Square Outdoor Art Exhibit as New York consuls of several countries of the United Nations and United Nations officials made a tour of the open-air display.

CHICAGO, June 7 -- Unanimous acceptance of a proposal which would set up a television authority governing actors' working conditions and wages and drawn a few weeks ago by the presidents' committee on television jurisdiction and organization of the Associated Actors and Artistes of America, AFL, was voted today by the convention of the American Guild of Variety Artists, a 4A affiliate.
If New York public school girls wear unflattering hats and the boys outlandish neckties it won't be the fault of the Museum of Modern Art -- or of Picasso and Cezanne.

The trend in fall millinery to higher crowns, draping and a "more hat" feeling was strongly in evidence yesterday at the Waldorf- Astoria Hotel at the seventh annual showing of the Millinery Designers League, in which thirty designers associated with midtown concerns participated.
WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's message to Congress today proposing $150,000,000 in new economic aid for Korea:

READERS who know Gerald Warner Brace only through his memorable "The Garretson Chronicle," one of the finest novels of the last decade, may be surprised and not much pleased when they sample his new novel, "A Summer's Tale."* That such a serious, subtle and ambitious writer should perpetrate such airy nonsense may seem like a sad case of literary schizophrenia.

Factory sales of pianos have dropped off to some extent but manufacturers are in "a far stronger position than those in many other industries," Chauncey D. Bond, vice president and general manager, Weaver Piano Company, declared yesterday.

FOREST PARK, Pa., June 7 -- David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, AFL, told the union's general executive board here today that the employment situation in the women's garment industry was "better than expected."

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., June 7 -- This community is preparing to celebrate on Thursday the 158th anniversary of the birth of John Howard Payne, author of "Home Sweet Home." At the same time, Long Island historians have renewed the battle over the place of his birth.

CHICAGO, June 7 -- The lumber industry is not returning to the same kind of a buyers' market it left in 1940 nor is the same kind of merchandise as plentiful, Wales T. Turner, president of the National-American Wholesale Lumber Association, warned here today.
CHICAGO, June 7 (AP) -- Lou Brissie came through with ten strikeouts under the Comiskey Park lights tonight in hurling the Athletics to a 7-to-4 triumph over the White Sox.

Your persistent efforts to keep the Hickenlooper-Lilienthal matter before your readers in a clear, impartial light, as again evidenced in your editorial of June 2, must evoke not only my own admiration but that of many others, too.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee formally put the North Atlantic treaty before the Senate today and asked its ratification as a way "greatly to increase the prospect" of averting a third world war.
In her eloquent millinery fashion, Sally Victor had quite a few things to say for herself yesterday when she exhibited her fall collection in her 18 East Fifty-third Street showroom.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- A coalition of Republicans and Southern Democrats demonstrated today the control they exert in the House Rules Committee by refusing clearance for floor debate and a vote to the Administration's national housing program.

DETROIT, June 7 -- For a combination of reasons which are immaterial at the moment, a meeting between the sorrel-topped Ed Lopat and the Tigers has been delayed since the start of the season until today. And, tonight, the Yankee southpaw is convinced if the meeting had been indefinitely delayed, or had never occurred at all, it still would have arrived too soon.

Raymond K. Price in your issue of May 30 attempts to answer the masterly argument by Miles Pennybacker in favor of increased government spending to prevent further unemployment. Mr. Price argues: "The falling demand for commodities is directly traceable to the unprecedentedly high level of taxes, which in turn is due to an unprecedentedly high level of government expenditures."

HARTFORD, Conn., June 7 -- The stalemate between Gov. Chester Bowles, a Democrat, and Connecticut's Republican - controlled House of Representatives remained unbroken tonight, twenty - four hours before the constitutional hour for final adjournment of the Legislature.

PASADENA, Calif., June 7 -- Scientists and laymen from seven western states assembled here today and dedicated the California Institute of Technology's new $400,000 phytotron, a huge, complex instrument for the study of nature.

With the season for pressing olive oil just winding up in Mediterranean countries, the product is more readily available here and lower priced than at any time since 1940, according to the Olive Oil Association of America. From $10 to $11 a gallon in 1948, the price has dropped to the current range of $8.50 to $9.50.

At a time when such genuinely important foreign policies as the Atlantic Treaty and the Hull Trade Agreements program demand the country's serious attention it is unfortunate, to put it mildly, that such unrealistic schemes as the so-called international wheat agreement should be permitted to force their way onto the same stage and share at least a part of the spotlight.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 7 -- An Israeli spokesman, Lieut. Col. Moshe Pearlman, categorically denied tonight charges made in Rome that the Government had been carrying out a policy hostile to Roman Catholic interests.

Reports covering the country-wide metal-working industry for the first five months show output off approximately 12 per cent, compared with a year ago, and no prospect of improvement before November, industry spokesmen disclosed here yesterday.

Premium promotions are now a "must" for a large variety of advertisers, some 500 members of the Sales Executive Club were told by a five-member panel yesterday at the Roosevelt Hotel. This year they will spend $1,250,000,000 at wholesale value for merchandise to stimulate sales, it was estimated by Howard W. Dunk, premium consultant, who was panel chairman.

Consolidated Gas, Electric Light and Power Company of Baltimore today is offering its stockholders rights to subscribe for $13,000,000 of common stock. Holders of the utility's common are being permitted to subscribe for 219,546 additional shares at $60 per share on the basis of one for each share held on June 2.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 7 -- Princeton Theological Seminary conferred today 113 degrees at its 137th annual commencement exercises in the Princeton University Chapel. John A. Mackay, president, presented degrees of Bachelor of Divinity to sixty-seven, the degrees of Master of Religious Education to twelve, and degrees of Master of Theology to thirty-two.

SAN JUAN, P. R., June 7 -- A twin-engined transport plane bound for the United States with seventy-five Puerto Rican passengers and six crew members dived into coastal waters in a rainstorm early today and fifty-four persons apparently perished.

Department stores which realistically accept the existence of a buyer's market and quickly meet its demands will find plenty of business, Fred Lazarus Jr., president of Federated Department Stores, Inc., declared at the annual stockholders' meeting held here yesterday.
A child's fairy-tale belief that toy dolls can dance and a teacher who didn't like "schmaltz" may not provide first-class "inspirations," except, perhaps, to an aspiring composer.

The rock market became irregular yesterday in the wake of the sharp plunge on Monday and, despite a small dip in the composite rate, the list as a whole ended on the better side. The firmer tone only appeared, however, in the afternoon after new low ground was reached in the morning.

Andrea Radio Corporation yesterday introduced a new line of five new television receivers, three of which are priced $109.50 to $200 lower than comparable units which they supersede. The new line was shown to the press and dealers in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) -- President Truman favors a distribution of shipbuilding work along all the country's coasts, Representative Henry M. Jackson, Democrat, of Washington, told a House merchant marine subcommittee today.

Henry Dreyfuss, industrial designer, who has planned the interiors of the "Four Aces" of the American Export Lines, has been retained to design the public rooms and passenger cabins for the two 20,000-ton luxury liners now building for Export, it was announced yesterday by John E. Slater, executive vice president.
CLEVELAND, June 7 (AP) -- In a wild three-hour game, which included a near-riot among players, the Cleveland Indians tonight edged the Washington Senators, 13 -- 11, before 18,000 fans.
John Gates, who is under a thirty-day jail sentence for contempt in refusing to answer one question at the Communist trial, refused to answer another one yesterday.
