A suspended patrolman on trial for murder went berserk yesterday morning in the detention pen of Kings County Court. After attacking a guard the prisoner, John Moore, slashed his throat and left arm with a piece of broken glass.

ALBANY, June 7 -- Nathaniel L. Goldstein, state attorney general, announced today that his office intended to prosecute at least six persons in at least three communities for alleged fraud against the state retirement system.
STANTON, Del., June 7 (AP) -- Palatine Stable's Hash Night won the featured mile-and-a-sixteenth Kennett Square Purse at Delaware Park today.

The United States Court of Appeals reserved decision yesterday on a request by the National Labor Relations Board for enforcement of a board order forbidding the National Maritime Union, CIO, from discriminating in favor of union members through its hiring halls.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Louis Johnson, Secretary of Defense, stated emphatically today that the National Military Establishment had "no desire" to take over the atomic energy program from the civilian Atomic Energy Commission. He made his position clear in replying to a letter from Senator Brien McMahon, chairman of the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy.

TOKYO, June 7 -- Despite an earlier announcement that reparations deliveries from Japan had been ended, claimant nations will continue to receive goods now being processed, according to a headquarters announcement today.

PARIS, June 7 (AP) -- Following is the text of a United States proposal regarding exercise of controls in the city of Berlin. (It has reference to paragraph 4 of the United States proposal of June 2.)
Warner Bros. Pictures, Inc., and its subsidiaries had a net profit of $5,624,755 in the six months ended on Feb. 26, according to the report issued for publication today.

The administrative committee of the American Jewish Congress voted yesterday to uphold the expulsion of two affiliated organizations, both left-wing groups, on the ground of "conduct hostile to the program" of the congress.

The Physicians Forum charged last night that the inaugural address of Dr. Ernest Irons as president of the American Medical Association was restricted to "high - sounding generalizations" that ignored "the actual problems of medical care that are facing this country."

BOSTON, June 7 (AP) -- Pinch Hitter Tommy Holmes scored the winning run on Al Dark's foul fly to right with the bases loaded in the ninth to give the Boston Braves a 6-5 victory over the Cincinnati Reds tonight before 15,031. Eddie Stanky drew a pass to force in the tying run in that same frame.

Making his first appearance in the Brooklyn tennis championship, top-seeded Richard Savitt of Cornell University breezed past two foes to enter the quarter-final round yesterday at the Knicker-bocker Field Club.

Although the domestic steel operating rate has been declining for the last eight weeks, the industry's output for the first five months of 1949 was substantially above the production for the similar period of last year. In fact, the output for the first five months of the current year will probably be about 3,700,000 tons above the 35,852,794 tons produced in the like period of 1948.

Stan Musial, he whom they call The Man, proved practically an entire ball club last night at the Polo Grounds as he sank the Giants with two devastating home runs in the opener of a three-game series before a gathering of 43,328 onlookers.
WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Gordon Gray was nominated by President Truman today to be Secretary of the Army.

Advertising in the eight major New York City newspapers during the first five months of 1949 totaled 64,769,497 lines, a gain of 5.24 per cent over the like period of last year, an analysis of Media Records showed yesterday. Categories recording gains were: Automotive, up 55.29 per cent; retail, 5.91 per cent, and general, 2.42 per cent.
WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture has set July 23 as the tentative date for a nation-wide referendum of farmers on rigid production controls for the 1950 wheat crops.

Mrs. Grundy has just left, having spent the greater part of the afternoon. She was, it must be stated at once, in excellent form. In a voice trained down the years to speak each climax in a confidential whisper, she reported everything that had happened since her last visit.
LONDON, June 7 -- Apart from excitement in gold shares the stock markets here were dull today. The fresh setback on Wall Street and the labor unrest at home depressed prices in most sections.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., June 7 -- Holding its first official meeting since its installation May 17, the City Commission at noon today handed out jobs totaling $90,000 in salaries yearly to supporters of the Freedom for All Ticket.
BLUEFIELD, W. Va., June 7 -Southern coal operators and the United Mine Workers are making a record in their wage talks here, but they are far from making a contract.
WEST POINT, N. Y., June 7 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay today served notice that those forces intent upon destroying freedom would be "recognized as enemies and treated accordingly."

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange became fairly active yesterday, and final prices were 32 points higher to 3 points lower than on Monday, led by the strength in the old July contract.

The seventy-five-year lease-hold property at the southeast corner of Yonkers and Belmont Avenues, in Yonkers, on which a taxpayer store building was erected last year, has been sold by the Skillman Building Corporation, Irving Feder, president, for cash above a mortgage of $75,000 held by the Teachers Insurance Fund.

PARIS, June 7 -- The deadlock between the Soviet Union and the Western powers over a new regime for Berlin was formally acknowledged by the Council of Foreign Ministers today through publication of the opposing proposals giving documentary evidence of the gulf that separates the two sides.

CINCINNATI, June 7 -- Business men were told here yesterday that they should be thankful the present economic readjustment was not longer in coming. This advice was given by Dr. Vergil D. Reed, associate director of research of the J. Walter Thompson Company, in an address before the Institute of Cooking and Heating Appliance Manufacturers.

SHANGHAI, June 7 -- Ambassador John Leighton Stuart is due to leave Nanking late Saturday for a short visit to Shanghai preliminary to his expected return to Washington late in the month to report to President Truman.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 7 -- The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association began its season with a field of sixty-eight Class A players whose handicaps range from scratch through 16 over the Metropolis Country Club course today.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 7 -Because the annual convention cost of the American Federation of Musicians, AFL, is putting the union in the red financially, the 1,000 delegates to the union convention considered today a proposal from the union's president, James C. Petrillo, to make conventions biennial.

CLEVELAND, June 7 (AP) -- Cleveland Cliffs Corporation is paying $3,200,000 to a group of preferred shareholders in the Cleveland-Cliffs Iron Company which was consolidated with the parent Cliffs Corporation in 1947.

So far as the Hebrew Sheltering and Immigrant Aid Society is concerned, Dinah Room, is not down on their books as owing them money. But Dinah, a German- Jewish war orphan, not yet 17, sees it differently.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- A Federal Bureau of Investigation report disclosed today that Russia received a shipment of atomic research devices from the United States in 1947 and that two other shipments were blocked in 1948 and 1949.
Without a single vote to spare, the O'Dwyer Administration obtained in City Council yesterday the renewal for three years, beginning July 1, of the 2 per cent sales tax.

In his letter captioned "Dangers in Loyalty Oath," Nathaniel Phillips points out the almost ludicrous situation existing in California where a lawyer must not only swear allegiance to the United States and the Constitution but, as provided on May 9th by the State Senate, take a loyalty oath, as well.
Most amateur observers of Manhattan's skies Monday evening reported that the appearance of the much-heralded Air Force plane on a night photographic mission was somewhat of a dud.

Miss Dorothy Shaver, president of Lord Taylor, was interviewed yesterday over the Voice of America broadcast on the program "Women's World." The broadcast was beamed to all of the European countries and excerpts of it were translated into twelve languages.
The National Leagues' Mexican jumpers seeking reinstatement to organized baseball were advised yesterday to get clearance first from any other existing contracts, The Associated Press reported.
The Public Service Electric and Gas Company borrowed $75,000,000 yesterday on thirty-year first mortgage bonds at an interest cost of about 2.84 per cent.

The front page news printed in THE TIMES of June 4 on the transfusion of blood from a girl suffering from leukemia into the veins of a healthy Sing Sing prisoner who gave, in exchange, his own blood to the suffering girl, is open to considerable criticism from both a scientific and also from a purely humanitarian point of view.

WINTER PARK, Fla., June 7 -- Paul A. Wagner, 31 years old, a businessman-educator of Chicago, has been named to succeed Hamilton Holt as president of Rollins College. Dr. Holt, who is 76, is retiring after twenty-four years.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Unemployment reached a possible postwar high mark on May 14, with an estimated 3,289,000 persons being without jobs, according to figures released today by the Bureau of the Census.

Graduates of the Columbia Law School in the classes of '98 and '99, including members and former members of the judiciary, were guests of their fellow members of the alumni association at its annual meeting yesterday in the Lawyers Club, 115 Broadway. Vermont Hatch of the class of '16 welcomed the guests.

Following its unanimous vote in favor of the North Atlantic Treaty, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee now calls upon the Senate as a whole to approve the Pact as the best promise of averting a new world war and declares that failure to ratify would have disastrous consequences. We think that the recommendation and the warning will both be endorsed by the overwhelming majority of the American people.
The Public Service Electric and Gas Company borrowed $75,000,000 yesterday on thirty-year first mortgage bonds at an interest cost of about 2.84 per cent.

GLEN COVE, L. I., June 7 -- Dr. Harry S. Eisenberg of Rose Hill shot 86 -- 18 -- 68 to win low net honors in the Metropolitan Golf Association one-day handicap tournament at the Nassau Country Club course today.
A continued demand for business quarters in Manhattan was indicated by the latest reports of leases by brokers. Details of the leases follow:
Theodore W. Kheel, former chairman of the city's Division of Labor Relations, formally took office yesterday as New York's first impartial chairman for the private bus lines.
ALBANY, June 8 -- The State Health Department reported today that the health of the people of the state was never better than during the first three months of 1949.
The Chemical Bank and Trust Company has been appointed transfer agent for the 4.35 per cent preferred stock of Atlantic City Electric Company.

It is probable that Ray Resseque, aged 14, some day will have occasion to be grateful to the Madison Square Boys Club. It was Master Resseque who, the other day, walked off with a silver cup in the club's annual cooking competition after turning out a prize-winning omelet and scrambled eggs on toast.

SHANGHAI, June 8 -- During the last few days a series of import and export foreign exchange regulations have been issued here, which presumably will govern China's trade with the outside world for a number of years to come.

" Pemberley Shades," a first novel by D. A. Bonavia-Hunt, has been scheduled for Sept. 9 publication by Dutton. Described as a continuation of Jane Austen's "Pride and Prejudice," it takes up the story of Elizabeth Bennet and Mr. Darcy after their marriage.

HARTFORD, Conn., Thursday, June 9 -- Gov. Chester Bowles and the Democratic-controlled State Senate reached an eleventh-hour compromise early today with the Republican - controlled House of Representatives on a state budget and fiscal program for the next two years.

Documentary and educational 16-mm films are greatly needed by social and welfare agencies devoted to youth, Samuel S. Fishzohn, director of the youth department of the American Jewish Committee, told 125 persons yesterday at the June luncheon meeting of the New York Film Council held at Rosoff's Restaurant, 147 West Forty-third Street.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (UP) -- -- The pared-down military pay raise bill underwent another $6,800,000 cut as it was approved today by a House Armed Services Subcommittee. The full committee will consider the bill tomorrow. Representative Paul J. Kilday, subcommittee chairman, said he hoped to get the measure to the House floor next week and predicted that it would pass.

Labor unions use better facts and figures than industrial management groups in collective-bargaining sessions, Cyrus S. Ching, director, Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, Washington, D. C., told more than 400 executives yesterday.

The area around 265 West Fourteenth Street returned to normal yesterday, with no picketing of the offices of Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, by disgruntled members of the union's Local 968 and no counter measures by other ILA members in support of their union head.

CHICAGO, June 8 (AP) -- Alex Kellner survived a bad start to pitch his seventh victory with a six-hit job today as the Athletics set down the White Sox, 5 to 2. Kellner had the assistance of Eddie Joost's thirteenth homer and a two-run triple by Elmer Valo.

CHICAGO, June 8 -- The surprise announcement yesterday by the Government that loans of 75 per cent of the normal loan would be made available to wheat growers for a period of ninety days on wheat piled on the ground or held in temporary shelters was the signal for a wild rush of buying at the opening of trading on the Board of Trade this morning.

RYE, N. Y., June 8 -- One hundred and fifty industrial leaders, public officials and heads of publishing companies met at the Westchester Country Club here this afternoon and voted to establish a new advisory organization to speed the development of Westchester County.

A centrifugal-force machine used in grinding sugar exploded at 8:40 o'clock last night in the Long Island City plant of the National Sugar Refining Company, injuring five workers, three seriously. The nine-story building is at 2-03 Fifty-fifth Avenue.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 8 -- The simultaneous Middle East tours of Samuel Kopper of the State Department and Sir William Strang, Permanent Under-Secretary of the British Foreign Office, has accentuated interest in a supposed rise in British-United States rivalry in the Middle East generally.

Eighteen members of the I. F. Kamraterna Football Club of Goteborg, Sweden, arrived yesterday at Idlewild Airport, Queens. Officials of the Scandinavian Athletic Club of Chicago, which is sponsoring the nine-match tour of United States and Canada, and Melcher Stamberg of Brooklyn, president of the Swedish American A. C. here, greeted the team.

Alger Hiss will take the witness stand in his own defense against a two-count Federal perjury indictment, it was learned yesterday as his trial moved into its seventh day with Whittaker Chambers holding the spotlight as his chief accuser.

DUESSELDORF, June 8 (Reuters) -- Demonstrations and mass protests were spreading throughout the Ruhr tonight against the British Military Government order to dismantle eleven important German synthetic product factories listed as "prohibited industries."

MOSCOW, June 8 -- For the third time within a week the Soviet press has reported a sharp break in stock prices on the New York Stock Exchange. The accounts published today described the break as "undoubtedly reflecting a general worsening" of the United States economic situation.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) -The House Appropriations Committee refused today to approve $10,000,000 for work on a new Senate office building but said the Senators might buy new swivel chairs and refrigerators.

Family ties that have stood the test of war and extermination camps continued yesterday in the case of two Polish cousins who arrived here aboard the Army transport Gen. J. H. McRae from Bremerhaven, Germany. The transport, carrying 1,005 displaced persons, docked yesterday morning at West Twenty-first Street.
The law is working its tedious way in the Hiss-Chambers case, but so far it has merely emphasized the contradictory nature of two fabulous personal stories.

BERLIN, Thursday, June 9 -- Four angry Russian officers using their bare fists early today beat back leaders of a mob of 200 striking railway workers who had pushed their way into the American sector headquarters of the Russian-controlled Berlin railway last night.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed mixed, 16 points higher to 22 points lower.

Several hundred persons watched yesterday noon as medals were presented to members of the Fire Department and to the next of kin of four firemen who died in line of duty during 1948. The ceremony was held in front of City Hall.

URBANA, III., June 8 -- By following some of the methods used in the garment industry, home economics students at the University of Illinois are learning to sew twice as rapidly and much more accurately than formerly. As a result, their instructors report, they are sewing twice as many garments in a semester as under earlier methods of dressmaking taught at the College of Agriculture.

Four private bus lines in Manhattan presented evidence yesterday that, despite the fare increases granted in the last ten months, they still suffered substantial operating losses in the first three months of this year.

" Sorcery and Seeds" was the title of the flower show staged yesterday by Long Island garden clubs in the parish house of Christ Protestant Episcopal Church, Manhasset, from 2 to 9:30 P. M. "Sorcery" in its various aspects was the theme of the flower arrangements; "seeds" referred to the specimen blooms.
Cardinal Spellman will preside at the 104th annual commencement of Fordham University today at 4:30 P. M. at Keating Hall on the Bronx campus.
WASHINGTON, June 8 (UP) -- Committees in both houses of Congress moved today to slap contempt citations on three witnesses who refused to discuss their alleged relationship with the Communist party.

Two months ago, when Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, Sir Stafford Cripps, presented his uncompromising budget to Parliament, predictions were heard ranging from a party revolt against his economic leadership to a demand for his resignation. Here and there a Labor member did rise in the Commons to assail his proposals for continuing the high purchase tax and the wage "freeze."

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14, a group of motion pictures to be shown, tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified. The programs follow:

NANKING, June 8 -- Hsiao Chun, editor of the weekly magazine, Culture in Harbin, and one of China's best-known modern writers, is now under heavy attack in the Communist press here for allegedly "erroneous thoughts" on Sino-Soviet relations and on the nature of the Chinese revolution.

WARSAW, June 8 -- Two high Polish trade officials have been arrested by the Government for having negotiated a contract calling for the delivery of 500 airplane engines to Spain, reliable sources reported today.

CLEVELAND, June 8 (AP) -- Pitcher Bob Lemon socked his first home run of the year tonight for Cleveland and beat the Senators, 8 to 3. It was Lemon's fourth victory against one loss this season and swept a two-game series for the Indians. Paul Calvert was the losing pitcher.

Capt. Styfiamos Macris, master of the freighter Hellenic Beach, which was in collision early Sunday morning with the vessel Ex-mouth off the Delaware coast, denied yesterday that there was any fog at the time of the accident, as previously reported, and sought to place the responsibility for the mishap on the other ship.

TORONTO, June 8 (Canadian Press) -- Hockey will be reinstated on the Winter Olympic Games program when the Amateur Hockey Association of the United States and the Amateur Athletic Union "make their peace," J. S. Edstrom of Sweden, president of the International Olympic Committee, said today.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., June 8 (AP) -- The State Senate Committee on Un-American activities today listed numerous motion-picture personages, writers, musicians and other prominent individuals as having "followed or appeased some of the Communist party line program over a long period of time."

A $1,400,000 damage suit brought by an affiliate of the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, against the ILA, the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, AFL, and Daniels Kennedy, a trucking corporation, was dismissed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Algeron I. Nova in Brooklyn.

Originality of design and efficiency in sewing won awards for nine women last evening at a party given by the National Needle-craft Bureau. The awards were presented after a fashion show held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel at which forty-six of the 20,000 entries were shown.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- In a characteristically dramatic move, John L. Lewis today ordered the more than 450,000 miners in soft and hard coal pits of the country to stop work one week starting Monday, June 13, for what he called "a brief stabilizing period of inaction."

PARIS, June 8 -- In the National Assembly tomorrow a dangerous debate on military credits, which is one of the major obstacles facing the Queuille Cabinet before the summer recess, is scheduled to begin.

PARIS, June 8 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson asked the Council of Foreign Ministers today to instruct the four military commanders in Berlin to complete their negotiations on trade and transport there by next Monday. Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky said that he was willing to discuss this suggestion tomorrow.
PHILADELPHIA, June 8 (AP) -- A self-help housing project in which families will work with their hands, instead of cash, to turn a dismal row of houses into livable apartments was announced today

In an Administration not distinguished for the excellence of its appointments, the naming of Gordon Gray as Secretary of the Army comes as a welcome and encouraging surprise. Although a little of the glow is taken away by the fact that he was the President's second choice, the nation has cause for thanks that Mr. Gray has finally been picked for the post he so clearly deserves.

For the first time since 1935, a move to evaluate the trend in type faces and typography has been started by the National Board of Printing Type Faces, it was announced yesterday by the Advertising Typographers Association of America, Inc. Manufacturers have been invited to submit recent type faces for evaluation by the board, and for approval and recommendation to advertisers, it was disclosed.

A committee to represent a large majority of the country's retailers was appointed yesterday to oppose "waste and extravagance" in Government and to "arouse all retailers to the advantages of the Hoover Commission's report of re-organization of certain Government agencies."

Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday the appointment of Special Sessions Justice Irving Ben Cooper to a second ten-year term to begin July 1, when his present term expires. Justice Cooper will be sworn in for the new term today at a ceremony in City Hall at 11:45 A. M. today.

PHILADELPHIA, June 8 -- The directors of the Pennsylvania Railroad announced today that Martin W. Clement will retire on June 16 as president and will become the first chairman of the board in the 102-year history of the nation's largest railroad.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- A bill passed by the Senate last week to permit manufacturers to absorb freight rates sad quote delivered prices, provided they are "acting independently," was swiftly approved today by a House judiciary subcommittee after a minimum of discussion.

After more than two weeks of futile debate, the Four-Power conference in Paris remains deadlocked on all major points and the Western Powers are beginning to prepare for its end in disagreement by warning the Germans not to expect any new developments from it and to resign themselves to a prolonged partition of their country.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Communists should be excluded from employment as teachers, a group of prominent education advisers declared today. The group, which included Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, president of Columbia University, spoke through a fifty-four-page handbook made public by the National Education Association.

LAKE SUCCESS, June 8 -- A move by the smaller nations to enable private persons and groups to complain to the United Nations against alleged violations of their fundamental freedoms was rejected today by the Commission on Human Rights.

John Gates was confronted at the Communist trial yesterday with writings of Joseph Stalin, William Z. Foster, Eugene Dennis and himself to disprove his testimony that the Communist party did not advocate violent overthrow of the United States Government.

The art collection of the late Joseph Brummer, antiquarian and dealer, entered the final phase of dispersal yesterday as two auction sessions all but cleared the four-story Brummer Gallery, 110 East Fifty-eighth Street.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Louis Johnson, Secretary of Defense, today restricted to possible breaches of security the material that may be eliminated by the armed forces public information officers from military officials' speeches and statements.

The decline in delinquent consumer loans made by banks throughout the country was most marked in property improvement and automobile financing in April, according to a report issued yesterday by the American Bankers Association.

What do they do on a rainy day in Mexico City? The best way to find out is to see for yourself. And the most enjoyable way to see for yourself is to enter the Greater New York Fund Vacation Contest and win a two-week vacation

I am not in complete agreement with your editorial on reparations from Japan appearing in THE TIMES of June 5. For one thing, it did not state all the pertinent issues and secondly it was very weak on the question of our obligations to China and the Philippines.

Leon M. Silberstein and S. Richard Silbert, of the Silbert Construction Company, have taken title to eight and one-half acres at First Street and Bradley Place, in Mineola, L. I., where they plan to construct 208-family garden apartments, it was announced yesterday.

VIENNA, June 8 -- Recent admissions by Communist party leaders in Soviet satellite states and by their party organs reveal that communism is having almost as much trouble with the workers as with the "kulaks," or richer peasants.

VIRGINIA BEACH, Va., June 8 -- There will be no tampering with the quality of national brands of foods and grocery products no matter what happens in connection with the problem of maintaining satisfactory earnings in the face of rising costs and declining prices.
Paul O'Dwyer, an attorney and brother of Mayor O'Dwyer, was held in contempt yesterday by Judge Louis Goldstein in Kings County Court.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, warned an economy-minded Senate Appropriations Committee today that a $1,000,000,000 cut in funds for the European Recovery Program "would wreck it" and urged a return to deficit financing, if necessary, to provide the $3,568,470,000 voted by the House.

Last summer the delegates of more than fifty nations who attended the International Congress for Mental Health in London decided that the resources of psychiatry should be invoked to deal with the problems of mental health on a world-wide scale. The World Health Organization, which is to meet in Rome this month, will therefore be asked to appropriate at least a million dollars as a beginning to frame and carry out the first international program.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 8 -- Colin Miller, independent producer, has concluded a deal with Samuel Goldwyn to borrow David Niven from Goldwyn for the leading male role in "A Kiss for Corliss," with Shirley Temple. The picture will go before the cameras next Wednesday at the General Service Studio, with Richard Wallace directing from a scenario by Howard Dimsdale based on the characters created by F. Hugh Herbert in his 1945 play, "Kiss and Tell."

With the end of warfare still not in sight, the New York Boxing Managers Guild yesterday turned down a second offer of a settlement pertaining to radio and television fees to be paid main event fighters performing at Madison Square Garden.

Although there was definite information that Mayor O'Dwyer will tell members of the Draft O'Dwyer Committee today at City Hall he will not be a candidate for re-election, the committee started its drive yesterday for 1,500,000 signatures to draft petitions in all five boroughs of the city.

Representatives of eight major United States airlines and officials of the Port of New York Authority met for the first time yesterday to discuss the long-standing controversy over leases at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.
HONG KONG, June 8 (UP) -- British Defense Minister A. V. Alexander indicated today that additional reinforcements would be sent to Hong Kong if needed to protect it from possible Communist attacks.

A smooth plastic floor covering that lies flat without being fastened to the floor was shown yesterday by the Sandura Company, Inc., at Hampshire House. Company officials recommended the new product, called Sanduran, for use especially in home laundries, kitchens and bathrooms, since it is impervious to strong soaps and detergents.
Protests arose from many quarters last night over the dropping at City College of Morris Swadesh Associate Professor of Sociology and Anthropology, and Dr. Lee Lorch of the Mathematics Department.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Fredric March, Edward G. Robinson and other major figures in the West Coast film colony were alleged in a secret report of the Federal Bureau of Investigation today to be members of the Communist party.

Annual contributions for social insurance in the United States recently have risen to $4,500,000,000, the National Industrial Conference Board reported yesterday in The Social Security Almanac, the last in a three-year series of reports on studies in individual and collective security.

MONTREAL, June 8 -- Beginning the business meetings of the International Civil Aviation Organization here today, Dr. Edward P. Warner, United States president of its permanent council, told the assembly that far greater progress had been made within the year toward a world-wide uniformity of civil air practices than he had expected.

Another Daniel, among educators, come to judgment! According to THE NEW YORK TIMES May 28, Dr. Bakst of New York University's School of Education announces with an adjectival exuberance that somehow sits not well with the cool and objective mind of a scientific investigator, that "mathematics instruction today is centuries out of date," and that our methods are making our students "calculating bipeds."

St. John's University, playing in the National Collegiate Athletic Association baseball play-offs for the first time, qualified as the Middle Atlantic (District 2) champion yesterday. The Redmen will meet Boston College, winner of the New England (District 1) eliminations, at Dexter Park in Woodhaven on Monday in a doubleheader.

Clendenin J. Ryan, whose charges against the administration of Mayor O'Dwyer were countered by a grand jury investigation of wiretapping and indictment of several persons, announced last night that he had withdrawn from the Mayoralty campaign and that he would cease publication of his weekly newspaper, The Public Guardian, after its issue tomorrow.

Representatives of the American Radio Association, third of three Congress of Industrial Organizations maritime unions involved in contract talks, met yesterday afternoon with East and Gulf Coast ship owners under the auspices of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service.

Chicken "squab" on Thursdays and babas au rhum on Fridays are among the specialties cooked to order in Christie's Kitchen, a new shop at 350 East Seventy-fourth Street. Spick-and-span with fresh white paint, the establishment is presided over by Bernice and Arthur Christie, who have been in the food business only since the first of the year.

The first large-scale, organized move toward a French adaptation of American business' techniques of personnel administration and public relations was announced here yesterday by four top industrial executives of that nation.

Governors of the New York Stock Exchange once more will consider at a time yet to be selected the question of permitting stock exchange firms to incorporate. The present interest on the part of the governors stems from the fact that the subject has again become a topic for discussion among members and member firms.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Acting Secretary of State James E. Webb said today the United States would "cooperate wholeheartedly" with the United Nations in its program for an expanded program of technical assistance for economic development in various countries.

Fur buyers paid a top of $58 for "breath-of-spring" mutation minks at the opening of a three-day sale yesterday at the New York Auction Company. A top price $47.50 was paid for "royal pastel" grade in the auction being held for the Mutation Mink Breeders Association.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (UP) -- Dr. Hans Kindler, former conductor of the National Symphony Orchestra, today announced that he has received United Nations approval for a plan to promote an international "exchange of artists."
Both Brooklyn Barneys were happy yesterday after the Dodgers had beaten the Cubs, 3 -- 1, to retain first place.

BLACKPOOL, England, June 8 -- Two evangelists for socialism, Herbert S. Morrison and Aneurin Bevan, members of the British Labor Government, roused the Labor party's annual conference to a roaring pitch of election fervor for the first time today.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The Atomic Energy Commission was accused today of violating the law by permitting the shipment of radioactive isotopes to Norway for metallurgical research of possible value in developing non-atomic weapons, such as jet engines.

The Socony-Vacuum Oil Company sold the gasoline station at 1701 Bedford Avenue, in Brooklyn, to Moe Friedel, in a transaction in which a purchase money mortgage of $56,000 was executed, according to City Title Insurance Company, which furnished title insurance. The service station is on a plot 151 by 200 feet and is assessed for $70,000, of which $64,000 is on land.
FOREST PARK, Pa., June 8 -- The International Ladies Garment Workers Union, AFL, pledged today to purchase $1,000,000 of bonds to help finance a housing project in Israel.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 8 -- Eleven Hungarian Jewish leaders, all identified with the Zionist movement, have been arrested and will go on trial June 17 on charges of having promoted illegal mass emigration of Jews from Hungary, it was disclosed today.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., June 8 -- The board of trustees of the American Medical Association made public today an elaboration of a revised twelve-point program for the advancement of medicine and public health as a counter-proposal to President Truman's national health program.

Duluth, Minn.. Independent School District sold yesterday $600,000 of bonds due on June 1, 1950 and 1951, to the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company and associates at a bid of 100.03 for interest of 1 per cent.

A SPORTS journalist strives to be impartial and objective at all times. Contrary to popular belief, though, he also is human and therefore subject to likes and dislikes. In spite of himself, however, he is bound to have favorites and a rooting interest of sorts. So this corner is unashamedly going on record as being a whole-hearted supporter of Byron Nelson in the about-to-begin National Open Golf championship at Chicago's Medinah Country Club.

Under continued softening in the demand for steel, three large steel companies yesterday cut back their operations and furloughed more than 1,000 employes, while another major producer reduced its prices on plates to the lowest level of its competitors.

MOSCOW, June 8 -- The United States was charged today with adopting a "dollar policy" toward Germany and attempting to turn the country into a "reservation of reaction and a colony for American monopolies."
CHICAGO, June 8 -- Formation of a protective committee to represent shareholders of the Tucker Corporation was disclosed today in Federal District Court.
CHICAGO, June 8 (AP) -- George Metkovich, one of the Pacific Coast League's leading hitters, has been purchased by the White Sox. He will fly here to play against Boston in a night game Friday.

LONDON, June 8 -- Prime Minister Attlee intervened directly today in the growing strike situation that has paralyzed Britain's docks and railways during the last three weeks. Abandoning his policy of abstaining from interference in labor conflicts, Mr. Attlee, who is busy with the annual Labor party conference in Blackpool, issued through his office in Downing Street the following message to the 8,500 Liverpool dock strikers:

The office girl's "shopping-around" period for jobs is over, Mrs. Mary E. Moore, director of employment and vocational guidance at the Central Branch Y. W. C. A., Lexington Avenue and Fifty-third Street, declared yesterday.

The prevention of fires, explosions, gas poisoning and occupational diseases in New York State's factories, tunnels and mines is the job of eight doctors, eleven chemists and twenty-two engineers in the State Labor Department's Division of Industrial Hygiene.

LAKE SUCCESS, June 8 -- Two members of the Chinese delegation to the United Nations have recently obtained appointments to the United Nations secretariat, and a number of others have applied informally as a result of the continued successes of the Chinese Communists.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., June 8 -- A new name will be engraved on the William Rice Hochster memorial plaque as Joseph Gagliardi of Winged Foot won the 1949 event with rounds of 73, 73 -- 146 over the Quaker Ridge golf course today.

Commuter reaction was about evenly divided as a result of the first test yesterday of the proposed broadcasting of "canned music" over loudspeakers on all ferryboats plying between St. George, S. I., and South Ferry, Manhattan.

CARACAS, Venezuela, June 8 -- 8 -- The return of Outfielder Luis Olmo to the Dodgers appeared to be stymied tonight by a demand by the Pastora club of the Venezuela League for a bonus, reported to be $10,000.
Children from the second through the fifth grades at Public School 51 at 519 West Forty-fourth Street are learning their lessons by handling foreign-made objects.

CLEVELAND, June 8 -- The primary welfare need in Israel today is for the training of therapists to help emotionally disturbed refugees, Louis Kraft, president of the International Conference of Jewish Social Work, declared today.

ST. LOUIS, June 8 (AP) -- Ned Garver allowed eleven scattered hits as the St. Louis Browns won their second victory from the Boston Red Sox -- 5 to 2 -- before 5,328 fans tonight. Garver also figured in the scoring, hitting a single, then scoring the first Brownie run in the third inning.

BUENOS AIRES, June 8 -- Municipal authorities have closed the Argentine production of Albert Camus' play, "Le Malentendu," (The Misunderstanding) and this morning's Prensa deplores the censorship which was applied at a time when the French existentialist playwright himself was about to come to Buenos Aires for a lecture series.

TOKYO, June 8 -- The brokerage business has dropped by one-third since the Tokyo Securities Exchange reopened last month with the "American" system of trading Member concerns, especially large outfits with many branches, are complaining bitterly, Kisuji Kobayashi, president, declared when interviewed today.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Major speeches in the Senate today clearly outlined the opposing views on labor legislation that have resulted in a sheaf of bills to repeal or modify the Taft-Hartley Act of 1947.
DUBLIN, June 8 -- Invading American track and field stars set four new Irish records tonight in sweeping all seven events from their European rivals in a meet here.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The Senate Committee on Foreign Relations, in its unanimous report approving the North Atlantic Pact without reservations, asserted that nothing in Article 5 of the treaty "increases or decreases the constitutional powers of either the President or Congress" with respect to the use of the armed forces in war or in establishing a state of war.

A figure of God over the main portal of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine was unveiled and blessed yesterday by the Right Rev. Charles K. Gilbert, bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York. The unveiling took place after the evensong service at 5 P. M. when Bishop Gilbert and other members of the clergy associated with the cathedral took part in a procession with the choir to the main portal.

Zinc was reduced 3/4 cent yesterday in the ninth price cut since March 23, and custom smelters cut 5/8 cent from copper prices. New prices quoted were 10 cents per pound for zinc and 17 cents for copper from custom smelters, although primary copper producers continued to quote a range of 18 1/2 cents to 23 1/2 cents.

A decline last week of 1,555,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end supplies were 119,106,000 barrels, against 120,661,000 at the end of the previous week.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today that it will pay farmers storage allowances on 1949-crop wheat, soybeans and flaxseed held off the markets under the Government's price-support program.

PERTH AMBOY, N. J., June 8 (AP) -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey took part in the formal opening today of a $60,000,000 electric generating station and hailed it as "another outstanding evidence of the tremendous growth and progress New Jersey has made over the years."

SAN FRANCISCO, June 8 -William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, denied today the accusation of John L. Lewis, head of the United Mine Workers, that the AFL and the Congress of Industrial Organizations had made a "secret" compromise on amendments to the Administration's labor bill.

The Fumay Holding Corporation purchased for cash over a mortgage of about $24,500 the building containing twenty apartments and occupying a plot 40 by 100 feet at 527 West 135th Street through the M. Morgenthau-Seixas Company, broker, and A. J. Clarke, co-broker, and insured title with the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

Toma Babin, former Yugoslav shipping official here who broke with Marshal Tito's administration, was arrested in this city yesterday on a deportation warrant based on the fact that the official no longer was an accredited representative of the Yugoslav Government.

DETROIT, June 8 -- In an atmosphere of wildness and excitement tonight the Yankees suffered another one-game dent in their American League lead as the second-place Tigers tossed them into their third straight defeat and their second in a row at Briggs Stadium, 3 to 2, in eleven innings before 54,919 chilled fans.

BLUEFIELD, W. Va., June 8--The United Mine Workers publicly rejected the Southern coal operators' contract demands today. The wage conferences, in their third week, recessed for six days without any counter-demands from the union.
OAK RIDGE, Tenn., June 8 (AP) -- Agreement was reached tonight on a new labor contract to prevent a threatened strike by 2,000 CIO employes of Oak Ridge's largest atomic production plant.

Two new films will open in midtown theatres today. At the Capitol, the attraction is "Neptune's Daughter," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer comedy with music in Technicolor starring Red Skelton and Esther Williams. Ricardo Montalban, Betty Garrett and Keenan Wynn are among the principals.
LAKE SUCCESS, June 8 -- Industrial production increased during the first quarter of 1949 in most countries but dropped in the United States, according to United Nations statistics published today.

The new base established by the stock market on Tuesday was improved upon yesterday as modest bidding produced the best advance in more than a month. The fact that prices have not worsened since the break, which began last week and which was extended on Monday, gave support to opinion in Wall Street that a worthwhile recovery might be in the making.
Failure to use chemical tests in determining "drunken driving" is causing a miscarriage of justice, two safety experts declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The Administration is preparing to inject into the economy a $2,000,000,000 shot of plasma in the form of dividends to veterans on their war insurance. Whether this will be done next fall to steady the wavering economy or next year for its vote-getting effect in the Congressional elections is a matter of White House strategy.

A good pitching performance by Dave Koslo, making his first appearance as a starter, went to waste yesterday when Gerry Staley of the Cardinals subjected the Giants to their second straight shutout, 2 -- 0, before 13,941 spectators at the Polo Grounds. It was the fifth victory in a row for the soaring Redbirds, who now have won fourteen of their last sixteen games.

Four new issues of bonds and stocks of railroad, public utility and industrial enterprises aggregating more than $35,000,000 in market value will be offered to investors today by underwriting syndicates. The offerings are:

ELIZABETH, N. J., June 8 -- A breakdown in the negotiations between the Singer Manufacturing Company and Local 401, United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, CIO, representing 7,000 of the 9,000 employes of the struck sewing machine plant, was announced today by Mayor James T. Kirk.

LONDON, June 8 -- Expectations that the start of the new account in the stock market here today would see an extension of business were not realized, and with the exception of British Government bonds and gold mining shares, prices tended to drift downward again.

CHICAGO, June 8 -- Almost all of the 162 competitors who will start play tomorrow in the forty- ninth United States open golf championship at the Medinah Country Club were paying deep respect to par tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- A charge that the Army Corps of Engineers was blocking a final vote on Presidential reorganization powers was made today as the battle in the Senate-House conference, long deadlocked on the bill, was brought into House debate.

Apropos the charge that the Israeli Government restricted the free movements of Catholic clergy, may I say that during the height of the fighting I was requested to accompany a group of Franciscan Fathers of Jerusalem who wanted to visit churches and parishes outside the Holy City.
LONDON, June 8 -- For the first time since the war, the British Government is prepared to take a significant step away from strict bilateralism in the conduct of foreign trade.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The new Canadian-United States air agreement was assailed today by Senator Edwin C. Johnson, chairman of the Senate Commerce Committee, as "illegal" and "adversely affecting" the interests of the United States.

Signs of a "nativism" that could be as dangerous to the Roman Catholic Church in America as secularism and totalitarianism were to the church in Europe have appeared in this country, the Rev. Dr. John C. Murray, editor of Theological Studies and a professor at Woodstock College, Woodstock, Md., said yesterday.
BERLIN, June 8 (AP) -- The United States Army dug into its own pocket today to preserve the Western radio voice operating in Berlin.
STANTON, Del., June 8 (AP) -- The winners of last week's split Montchanin Handicaps came back today to take first and third honors in the second of the series of five handicaps at Delaware Park.

Only five of 111 passengers taken to Ellis Island from the Gdynia America liner Batory upon the vessel's arrival here last week will be held for further investigation by a special board of inquiry, Edward J. Shaughnessy, district director of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, announced yesterday.

According to a news item which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES on June 2, it is proposed to concede "nominal ownership in the Federal Government" of "the oil fields in the so-called tidelands" and then divide the revenue between the states and the Federal Government.

YOU can trust Wyndham Lewis to be original. He is always, as Ogden Nash once said in another connection, sui generis to a fault. In a gloomy moment you might say that his works are full of stuff and nonsense. But the stuff is often good, and the nonsense usually has a certain cheerfully readable dash and exuberance to it. Particularly when he is being as devastating as all getout.

Coincidental with the debate in a Senate Appropriations subcommittee hearing on a House-approved bill that would give the Southwestern Power Administration $9,000,000 for construction of transmission lines in a seven-state area in the Southwest, the $109,000,000 Arkansas Power and Light Company is waging vigorous opposition to the SPA in its annual report for 1948, which will be released today.

Price declines ranging up to 35 per cent from a year ago on fur garments have proved heartening to the hundreds of fur buyers making their first selections for fall, it was learned yesterday. Comparison shopping of the new styles and combinations will take from a week to ten days, according to buyers, and they will then be ready to place good-sized orders for August and September promotions.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 8 -- Some of those named today in the FBI report commented as follows:

DETROIT, June 8 -- Holding that the strike by two locals of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, against the Ford Motor Company was national in its effects, the Michigan Unemployment Compensation Commission denied benefit payments today for the nonstriking employes who were made idle because of the twenty-four-day tie-up.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The House authorized unanimously today a full-dress investigation of the whole strategic air program of the United States, with particular emphasis on the giant B-36 Air Force bomber and the circumstances of its development.

The tragic airplane accident in which more than fifty lives were lost in the waters near San Juan has a peculiar poignancy. Crowded into a converted troop carrier were nearly fourscore men, women and children, many of them en route home to New York after visiting their families in Puerto Rico.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 8 -- James C. Petrillo, the militant leader of the American Federation of Musicians, AFL, stirred the organization's annual convention today by coming out for lower wages for musicians -- to a limited extent. He urged that, in the interests of reviving vaudeville, union locals adjust their wage demands to what theatre managers could afford to pay.

To the King Ranch's 5-year-old mare, But Why Not, went first money of $11,450 in the $16,875 Top Flight Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. To her backers in the crowd of 20,011 went $4.20 in exchange for each $2 win ticket. She was the favorite in the field of three fillies and two mares.

Reports recommending 1949 capital budget funds amounting to $130,000 as the city's share of the Wollman Memorial ice-skating rink and recreation center in Central Park, and $184,000 for immediate repairs to the roof of the Metropolitan Museum of Art were forwarded to the Board of Estimate yesterday by the City Planning Commission.

Lee J. Cobb, star of "Death of a Salesman" on Broadway, has been signed as narrator for "Citizen of the World," the first radio documentary from the pen of Norman Corwin in two years. The program, which is to run a full hour, will be offered at 10 P. M. on Sunday, July 10.

LONDON, June 8 (AP) -- The Right Hon. Robert Craigmyle, Baron Morrison, becomes a Privy Councilor. He created a stir not long ago in the House of Lords by advocating Government control of football pools.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The Administration's proposed $150,000,000 recovery program for south Korea, as a "terribly important" democratic outpost in Asia, was sharply challenged today by Republican critics in its first test in Congress.
PAWTUCKET, R. I., June 8 (AP) -- Narragansett Park opened its summer meeting on schedule today only after management had agreed to jockeys' demands for a higher inner rail "to insure safer racing."

PARIS, June 8 -- Despite the fact that the United States Senate has not yet ratified the North Atlantic pact, it is planned that United States Air Force units and a small detachment of United States Army ground forces will join with France, Britain and the Benelux countries (Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg) in joint military maneuvers during the latter part of September.

A newcomer in show business, Robert L. Redd, who hails from the West Coast, has acquired the rights to the wistfully remembered Winchell Smith-Frank Bacon play, "Lightnin',". His plans are to produce it on Broadway early next winter in musical form.

The thoughtful and penetrating discussion of the responsibility faced by the American educational system in our troubled world which was published yesterday by the National Education Association is an important document. Through its clear vision and practical common sense, it should wield a vigorous, wholesome influence.
BOSTON, June 8 -- The Wine and Spirit Wholesalers of America, Inc., adopted today a resolution reaffirming its endorsement of fair trade practices for the industry.

GENEVA, June 8 -- The thirty-second conference of the International Labor Organization opened today with overtones of the East-West ideological struggle breaking through the preliminary official proceedings.

CINCINNATI, June 8 (AP) -- The twenty-five-player limit may be exceeded for only thirty days by major league baseball clubs holding contracts of men Commissioner A. B. Chandler reinstated last Sunday.

Mrs. Harry McNaughton of the North Hempstead Country Club shot 39, 38 -- 77, three strokes over course figures, to win the low gross prize in the one-day tournament of the Women's Long Island Golf Association at the Oakland Golf Club in Bayside yesterday.

BOSTON, Thursday, June 9 (AP) -- Four hours and nine minutes after the teams began their game last night Jim Russell early today lashed a mighty fifteenth-inning, bases-loaded hit off the wall in right center to drive in the run needed for an 8-7 victory for Boston's Braves over the Cincinnati Reds.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended June 1, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:
Mrs. Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt, chairman of the sponsoring committee of a benefit show for the Urban League, asked yesterday for the support of people of means for a worthy cause.

Coffee futures moved higher in moderately active trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Trade buying and hedge-covering of the near-by delivery months, coupled with support from producer interests, advanced prices in contract "S" 21 to 35 points.
Dr. Henry Noble MacCracken, president emeritus of Vassar College, warned yesterday that a "follow the leader tendency" was responsible for many great tragedies of world history.

In a NEW YORK TIMES editorial of May 30 the Board of Estimate is commended for voting $160,000 to continue the zoning studies being conducted by a firm of experts under the direction of the City Planning Commission.
WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) -- A Navy admiral said today it is not in the interest of national defense now to divide the building of Navy ships among shipyards of the various coasts.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (UP) -- John Koehler, Assistant Secretary of the Navy, disclosed today that drastic curbs had been imposed on Army, Navy and Air Force post exchanges to take them out of competition with private merchants and make them collect taxes that non-service people must pay.

A bid of $600,000 cash for the Langham Apartments occupying the blockfront on Central Park West from Seventy-third to Seventy-fourth Street, has been tentatively accepted by Supreme Court Justice Bernard Botein.

PRINCETON, Me., June 8 -- Although we have not had what Mahlon Slipp calls "good fishing," due primarily to the strong wind, we have had an opportunity to try out a lot of flies, streamers and bucktails, and twenty-five to thirty smallmouth bass a day is not our idea of "bad fishing."
PHILADELPHIA, June 8 (AP) -- Rookie Outfielder Stan Hollmig's second home run in two days with Del Ennis on base in the sixth carried the Phillies to a 2-0 victory over the Pirates tonight.

Construction of a bridge for pedestrians across the Harlem River from Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive at 103d Street to Wards Island will start in September, the Department of Parks and the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority announced yesterday.

The Marine Tiger, operated by the United States Lines, sailed for Cobh, Plymouth and Havre at 4 P. M. yesterday with 560 passengers, among them 177 students and teachers enrolled in the European tour and study program of the Council on Student Travel.

People who imagine there is a sharp dividing line between traditional and modern lines in furniture may have a hard time classifying the new collection from Italy that was put on display yesterday at Lord Taylor. It is the work of Guglielmo Pecorini, a designer-craftsman who has a small workshop on the outskirts of Florence.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., June 9 (AP) -- Montreal and Jersey City divided a double-header tonight, the Royals taking the opener, 11 -- 6, with the Giants coming back to take the nightcap and break a four-game losing streak, 5 -- 3.

SHANGHAI, June 9 -- The entrance to the Yangtze River, linking this metropolis and the great artery into the heart of Asia with the seven seas, was reported mined today. This development made even more serious the critical supply problem that is facing the Communists here.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The International Refugee Organization is running far behind schedule in finding homes for Europeans and will not complete its mission in the time allotted, a Senate investigating subcommittee reported today.

There was this to be said in winter's favor: winter encouraged routine. There was always the possibility, of course, that a two-foot snowfall might rearrange one's pattern of living for a day or so, but except for meteorological surprises routine thrived on winter's monotonies.

The deserted beach belle need no longer be the woman with the mature or fuller figure. This season several clever designers kept her in mind when creating smart swim suits. Fashion continues right along from the sylph-like twelves and fourteens up to a full forty-four, with many attractive designs reserved exclusively for the higher sizes.

Although marking their fifteenth successive weekly decline, business loans made by banks in this area during the week ended on Wednesday slipped only $17,000,000, the smallest reduction since March 2. The drop, according to the figures covering the reporting New York City member banks issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, brought the total outstanding to $4,781,000,000, the lowest point since Oct. 8, 1947.

Michael J. Quill, president of the New York City CIO Council, threatened yesterday to place Loew's and RKO Theatres in the metropolitan area on the "unfair" list for 400,000 CIO union members within the next week unless immediate steps were taken to settle the ten-month-old contract-renewal controversy involving the Screen Publicists Guild and the Screen Office and Professional Employes Guild.

The last of the Joseph Brummer art collection was auctioned yesterday at the late dealer's gallery at 110 East Fifty-eighth Street. The sale, clearing the four-story building of all art objects and gallery equipment, wound up the auction season for the Parke-Bernet Galleries, under whose management it was conducted.

Coffee futures were active and higher on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Hedge-lifting in the near-by delivery months by trade interests, short-covering and scattered new buying advanced prices in contract "S" 10 to 26 points. Spot July, however, declined 1 point. Contract "D" also was firm on trade demand.

Once upon a time the Giants used to be called the pulverizing Polo Grounders, boasting one of the most devastating attacks in the game. But that was in the days before a resurgent band of Cardinals swooped down on the Harlem with their airtight pitching and suffocating defensive play.

YONKERS, N. Y., June 9 -- Although the American schools are helping young people to become better citizens, much remains to be done before education can effectively prepare youth for adult responsibility, a panel of young high school students agreed here today.

President Truman's request for an appropriation of $150,000,000 for a recovery program for South Korea is sound and modest. We have assumed an obligation in Korea and that obligation should be discharged. The Republic that has been set up under United Nations auspices cannot survive without our help and we and the United Nations are vitally interested in its survival.
Three men were arraigned yesterday in Kings County Court on an indictment charging them with conspiracy and grand larceny in connection with a grocers' association they allegedly organized in 1947.
CHICAGO, June 9 (AP) -- Mrs. Eleanor D. Boyd of Long Beach, Calif., today was re-elected president of the American Gold Star Mothers.

Directors of the Lehman Corporation declared yesterday a dividend of $2.95 a share, payable on June 25. About $1.62 of the dividend is from net profits on the sale of securities in the fiscal year ending on June 30, Robert Lehman, president, stated. The balance of about $1.33 is a final distribution of net ordinary income for the period.

PARIS, June 10 -- Playing at the headquarters of the French Bridge Federation tonight the United States bridge team consisting of John Crawford, Peter Leventritt, Samuel Stayman, and George Rapee, started play against the French team composed of Baron Robert De Nexon, Dr. J. Blaizot, Baron J. De Hatvany and M. Koytchon.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that the Delaware Light and Power Company, Wilmington, had filed with it a registration statement covering $10,000,000 of first mortgage and collateral trust bonds, due July 1, 1979, and 50,000 shares of $100 par value cumulative preferred stock.
PHILADELPHIA, June 9 (AP) -- The Phillies put togeher a single, double and a long fly in the eighteenth inning today to defeat the Pirates, 4 -- 3, in the longest major league game since 1946.

In the vast remodeling job being done at Gimbels by Raymond Loewy, a new corset department, all pretty and pastel, emerged yesterday afternoon. To celebrate the occasion, Warner Brothers, one of the leading houses in the design of foundation garments, presented a show in the new shop.
The futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 9 to 21 points net higher yesterday in a moderate volume of business.

During warm summer days, the fewer the accessories in the room, the cooler the effect. But since lamps are a necessity no matter what the weather, those destined for summertime settings are made of materials that are cool in appearance.

Tenants of the block bounded by Washington Square South and Sullivan, Macdougal and West Third Streets in Greenwich Village, who have been resisting demolition of their homes to clear a site for the proposed Law Center of New York University, were served yesterday with notices of a new eviction proceeding.
Most of the paintings on view in this week's art exhibitions do little more than follow the well-worn furrows of modern art.

Until an agreement is reached between Israel and Syria there will be a danger of renewed fighting on their frontier, Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, United Nations Mediator for Palestine, said last night in an address at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

A somewhat grim picture of the international situation was presented yesterday by Foreign Secretary Bevin in a report to the British Labor party. With the diplomatic optimism that is necessary to continue any negotiations, Mr. Bevin declared that something may yet emerge from the Four-Power conference in Paris; but he made it plain that his hopes on that score are not bright.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- President Truman told his news conference this afternoon that the proposal to outlaw the poll tax as a prerequisite to voting by means of a Constitutional amendment was just an effort to prolong the agony.

SARANAC LAKE, N. Y., June 9 (AP) -- The Will Rogers Memorial Hospital for Tubercular Show People was taken over today by Variety Clubs International. The institution, operated since 1936 by the Will Rogers Memorial Fund, will be known henceforth as Variety Clubs-Will Rogers Hospital.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 9 -- Missile guidance by automatic star tracking and the commercial possibilities of pilotless aircraft were discussed today by approximately one hundred aviators, mariners and military personnel at the opening of the fifth annual meeting of the Institute of Navigation.

Hosiery shipments in April totaled 11,714,026 dozen pairs, compared with 12,802,915 shipped during the same month of 1948, according to the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers. Delivery of women's full-fashioned increased to 3,817,037 dozen pairs, as against 3,728,373 in the corresponding month last year.

Conflict between labor and management over the right to exercise managerial functions has entered the "decade of the showdown," Edward T. Cheyfitz, assistant to the president, Motion Picture Association of America, Inc., told more than 400 executives yesterday.

The headquarters of Local 213, Utility Workers Union, CIO, at 111 East 125th Street were raided yesterday by seven men who locked union officials in a room, ransacked the place and left with most of the organization's records.
John Gates, editor of The Daily Worker, admitted under cross-examination at the Communist trial yesterday that he had lied under oath three times, and insisted the end justifies the means in lying.

City Controller Lazarus Joseph announced yesterday that the City of New York has borrowed $21,500,000 on 1 3/8 per cent tax anticipation notes from twenty-six local banks and trust companies. The notes are dated June 10, 1949, and are payable as follows: Aug. 5, $4,000,000; Sept. 2, $2,000,000; Nov. 4, $2,000,000; Feb. 3, 1950, $1,000,000 and June 9, 1950, $12,500,000.

About a year and a half ago THE TIMES was kind enough to give space in its columns to a letter from me, in which I pointed out the danger to passengers falling off crowded subway platforms onto the tracks below. I suggested that guard railings be installed on all platforms.

The one-story taxpayer containing seven stores and occupying a plot 100 by 105 feet at 204 to 220 West 238th Street, 225 feet east of Broadway, in the West Bronx, was sold by the B. F. V. Realty Corporation, Y. Ben-Zeev, president, to Morris Friedman for investment for cash over a mortgage of $23,000. Allan S. Feldman Co. were the brokers in the sale of the property, which is assessed for $47, 000.

PHILADELPHIA, June 9 -- The National Wallpaper Wholesalers' Association, ten widely known wholesale concerns in seven cities and seven individuals were fined more than $50,000 today by the United States District Court on charges of illegal price fixing.

With the objective of bringing New York's fire-fighting facilities fully into line with present-day needs, Fire Commissioner Frank J. Quayle announced yesterday that he would submit to the City Planning Commission a $10,295,825 program calling for twenty-seven new firehouses and three new fireboats between 1950 and 1953.
BUDAPEST, June 9 (AP) -- Hungary's veteran Davis Cup team sped to a 2-to-0 edge over Switzerland today in the opening matches of Europe's third-round play.

Innocent fun turned into feverish excitement on the lower East Side last night for two little girls who found a small tin can in the street near their homes. As they kicked it about, it burst open and was found to be crammed with bills of various denominations which, by a police count later, amounted to $550.

PARIS, June 9 -- Paul Ramadier, Minister of Defense, assured the French National Assembly tonight that the United States would take up the question of interim military aid soon after the expected ratification of the North Atlantic treaty in Washington.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 9 -- Visiting representatives of the State Department and the British Foreign Office both talked today with Lebanese leaders, and though the subjects discussed were not revealed there is a growing impression of some concerted Anglo- United States moves to coordinate the respective policies in the Middle East, of the United States and Britain.

TOKYO, June 9 -- Premier Shigeru Yoshida said today that, in a sense, Japan was now attending a peace conference. The Prime Minister dampened hopes that a peace treaty would be immediately forthcoming, the hopes that had been rising last week as a result of his cryptic remark that the nation "might expect a great surprise before the end of the summer."

BOSTON, June 9 (AP) -- The Braves belted fourteen hits, nine of them for extra bases, for right-hander Bob Hall today to sweep a three-game series with the Reds, 10 -- 2. They thereby stayed in the thick of the National League pennant race.

All of the five men accused yesterday by Whittaker Chambers as having supplied Government documents to him when he was a Soviet spy ring courier had been mentioned previously by Mr. Chambers or other witnesses before the House Committee on Un-American Activities or Federal grand juries investigating Communist activities.

The crash of a twin-engine chartered airplane off San Juan, Puerto Rico, last Tuesday, resulting in the death of fifty-four persons has focused attention on what is probably one of the most heavily traveled air routes in the world.

Many thousands of years ago, so the anthropologists tell us, our ancestors lived in a mode suggestive of permanent picnic. In spite of the rigors of outdoor life, they survived and passed on to us an atavistic urge to get out of doors.

LAKE SUCCESS, June 9 -- A spokesman for the Israeli delegation to the United Nations today attacked a reported attempt by the United States to induce Israel to start readmitting some of the Arabs who fled from Israeli territory during the fighting last year.

HONOLULU, June 9 -- Half a million residents of the Hawaiian Islands waited today without much optimism for Presidential intervention or some other break in the longshore strike which has virtually severed the territory's "lifeline" for thirty-nine days.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Eugene Holman, president of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, told a House small-business committee today that America's independent oil producers had no reason to fear "floods of foreign oil imports." Such fears, he added, "are unfounded in economics."
The Bendix Aviation Corporation reported yesterday for the six months ended on March 31, consolidated net income of $5,143,399 after all charges, including $3,850,783 provision for taxes.

License Commissioner Edward T. McCaffrey accepted yesterday the license of the Phil Rosen Ticket Service, Inc., of 786 Seventh Avenue, just before the concern was to have a hearing on its revocation as recommended by Investigation Commissioner John M. Murtagh.
BOSTON, June 9 -- Unceasing vigilance to curb the rising toll of highway accidents was stressed today at the annual meeting of the Eastern Conference of Motor Vehicle Administrators here.

Four new films will open in first-run theatres this morning. At the Roxy, the attraction is "It Happens Every Spring," a Twentieth Century-Fox comedy, starring Ray Milland. Paul Douglas and Jean Peters are among the principals in the offering, which was directed by Lloyd Bacon and produced by William Perlberg from a screen play by Valentine Davies and a story by Mr. Davies and Shirley W. Smith.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The House Armed Services Committee, seeking to overhaul this year a military pay structure that has been growing hit-or-miss for forty years, reported today a bill scaling down the increases asked in a measure that failed to pass last month.
Those who intend to "sell" safety to the public must employ salesmanship methods used in commercial enterprises, a Connecticut safety official declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- President Truman today told his news conference that he did not believe that anyone who favored destruction of our form of government ought to teach in the nation's schools.

A further cutback in steel operations is set for this week when the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation, chief operating subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation, effects the second curtailment in two weeks at its Duquesne works in Pittsburgh.

The license of the F. M. Schaefer Brewing Company of Brooklyn has been suspended for five days for violations of the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Law, the State Liquor Authority announced yesterday.

Several cuts of beef are 3 to 4 cents a pound higher than last Friday and 9 to 10 cents more than before the most recent upward price movement began three weeks ago, according to the consumers' service division of the City Department of Markets.

Some solution to the economic crisis threatening Great Britain -- a problem charged with political implications -- was seen yesterday as resting on early stabilization of this country's economy and leveling off in world commodity prices.

Washington's varsity crew, winner of the Poughkeepsie Regatta last year, drew the No. 1 lane near the West shore of the Hudson River yesterday for the Intercollegiate Rowing Association regatta June 25.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 9 -- Scoring 39, 38 -- 77 at Knollwood Country Club in ideal golfing weather today, Mrs. Donald C. O'Brien of Winged Foot became the fourth winner of the season in Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association one-day competition.
WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- Evidence of American counter-spying which may have reached into the Soviet Embassy here went into the record of the Judith Coplon espionage trial today.

" A place for everything and everything in its place" may become more nearly a reality in more households with the advent of new storage aids. These are intended to hold such hard to store items as hot irons or vacuum cleaners, or to bring needed order in to closets.

Mayor O'Dwyer's announcement two weeks ago that he would not be a candidate for a second term caught the city by surprise. What must be accepted, we believe, as his final no was given yesterday. All the considerations that went into that decision, and the varying weight given them, will probably never be known.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., June 9 -- Dr. Elmer L. Henderson of Louisville was named unanimously today president-elect of the American Medical Association, highest honor within the gift of organized medicine in America. He will take up the presidency at the next annual meeting of the association in San Francisco in June, 1950, succeeding Dr. Ernest E. Irons of Chicago, who became president this week.

With the building industry again in a buyer's market which may result in a 10 per cent decline in private construction activity this year, a leader in the field yesterday presented an eight-point promotional program which he said might remove some of the major influences holding down current operations.

PRAGUE, June 9 -- The Czechoslovak State Tribunal today sentenced five men to death, eight to life imprisonment and two to twenty-five years hard labor on charges of plotting to to overthrow the Government.

Supply and demand came close to a balance yesterday in the stock market. Although there were various items of unfavorable industrial news, prices drifted in a restricted range in trading that was marked by a sharp drop in volume.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The Army's action in finding Mr. Clapp "unemployable" for the assignment in Germany was based on reports by its intelligence division. Army officials declined to elaborate on the findings, either as to their possible content or to the time they were made.

Peonies and roses filled the Colonnades Ballroom of Essex House on Central Park South yesterday for a two-day flower show, sponsored by the Horticultural Society of New York. This typical June display opened to the public yesterday afternoon and may be seen today from 10 A. M. to 4 P. M.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 9 -- Gov. Chester Bowles today ordered a fresh study of Connecticut revenue resources and governmental needs to be used as the basis for drafting a new budget and fiscal program to be submitted to a special session of the General Assembly he has called for next Tuesday.

Thirty-five thousand dollars worth of sables and other costly clothing and accessories -- all the property of Sonja Henie, skater -- was stolen from a locked truck yesterday evening, a few hours before the entertainer was due to start for California.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 9 (AP) -- The Maryland Court of Appeals declared invalid today a key section of a Baltimore court rule governing publication of crime news under which three radio stations and a commentator were fined.

ALBANY, June 9 -- The State Motor Vehicle Bureau warned law enforcement agencies and magistrates throughout the state today that charges of speeding on state highways must be supported hereafter by proof that the State Traffic Commission had not issued an order permitting a speed greater than 50 miles per hour on the highway where the violation was charged.

LONG BRANCH, N. J., June 9 -- The last unit of the once fabulous oceanfront estate of the late James A. Hearn, New York department store founder and art collector, is being torn down. The debris of what was the luxuriously appointed recreation hall is being used by the City of Long Branch in building a modern, municipally operated pavilion on the beachfront.

WESTFIELD, N. J., June 9 -- Youth took a back seat at the forty-eighth New Jersey state golf championship when J. Wolcott Brown of Manasquan River won the qualifying medal with one-over-par 35, 37 -- 72 over the Echo Lake Country Club course today.
