Currency restrictions in world markets and the desire of European countries to sell soft goods while refusing to buy will result in a serious crisis in the world textile trade before the end of 1949, according to William De Min, retiring president of the Textile Export Association of the United States.
DETROIT, June 9 -- Yankee prospects suffered a couple of painful jars at Briggs Stadium today before 20,543 onlookers.

PARIS, June 10 -- British, Belgian and French experts are negotiating a compromise trade payments plan for Europe that they hope British and United States officials can accept. A meeting of the ministerial steering committee adjourned Saturday, deadlocked on this question.

Jacob Fogelson has been appointed executive secretary and counsel for the New York Lamp and Shade Manufacturers Association, it was announced yesterday. He also represents the Electrical Manufacturers of New York, Inc., an association of switchboard manufacturers, as well as several companies here.

VIENNA, June 9 -- An alleged deal with incriminated Nazi leaders to switch Nazi votes to the People's party in next autumn's general elections threatens to create a political scandal in Austria reminiscent of that caused by Chancellor Leopold Figl's conversations with Communist party chieftains two years ago.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 9 -- The Israeli Cabinet today published the findings of the Government inquiry commission that investigated the Jerusalem disturbances between zealous Sabbath observers and the police. The report blamed hotheads on both sides for excesses.

PITTSBURGH, June 9 -- Dr. John C. Warner, head of the chemistry department of the Carnegie Institute of Technology and one of the country's most distinguished scientists, today was named president-designate to succeed Dr. Robert E. Doherty on the latter's retirement, effective July 1, 1950.

Eight thousand persons attended a rally in Madison Square Garden last night under the auspices of the United World Federalists in support of a resolution in Congress for strengthening the United Nations and developing it into a world federation as a policy for permanent peace.

The Jewish Agency for Palestine has purchased the five-story residence at 18 East Sixty-sixth Street for expansion of its operations, including establishment of an economic department to promote and direct private investment in Israel.

The Western Union Telegraph Company announced yesterday that it had embarked on an internal reorganization drive, involving top personnel, in an effort to facilitate its $70,000,000 mechanization program.

CALAIS, Me., June 9 -- We left the big lakes today in favor of the small ponds, as much to get a varied picture as to escape the wind, and although we worked hard, the total catch was smaller than on the big water.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Lewis L. Strauss, member of the Atomic Energy Commission, testified today that radioactive isotopes exported by this country were useful in "a vast field of industrial and military applications," including biological warfare.
BOSTON, June 9 (AP) -- A Boston lawyer's bid for more than $50,000,000 from five Massachusetts horse and dog racing organizations foundered today in a State Supreme Court decision.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The House Armed Services Committee adopted a program today for investigation of the Armed Forces so sweeping that it indicated studies of weapons and procedures still rated as secret by the highest authorities.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- During the week ended June 8, member bank reserve balances increased $94,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
BERLIN, June 9 (AP) -- Western Berlin railroad strikers declared tonight they had crippled a nerve center of the Russian zone railway system by sealing off its headquarters with a picket line.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on June 4 were 698,824 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 86,000 cars, or 11.0 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week, 122,382 cars, or 14.9 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 201,923 cars, or 22.4 per cent, fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

LONDON, June 9 -- Princess Elizabeth virtually stole the show at the spectacular Trooping the Color ceremony here today when her chestnut horse Winston began unexpectedly to curvette and prance in alarm at the noise of the massed military bands and the unwonted attention of hordes of insects.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 9 -- From sources close to the Israeli Government it was learned today that the United States had requested Israel to unbend and admit a "certain" part of the refugees so that the Lausanne discussions might proceed. It appears that a stalemate has been reached and that someone has to concede to avert failure.

LAKE SUCCESS, June 9 -- The United Nations' Commission on Human Rights today agreed to include in the future covenant on human rights two articles guaranteeing to all peoples the right of assembly and freedom of association.

The aim of the Harvard University Graduate School of Business Administration -- better known as the Harvard Business School -- is "to train young men for positions of responsibility in private business or in the business of government." How well it has succeeded in that aim is indicated by a striking tribute paid the school with the announcement today that John D. Rockefeller Jr. has contributed $5,000,000 toward a fund-raising campaign for $20,000,000.

Walter E. Lawlor, a Coast Guard civilian hearing examiner, reserved decision yesterday on charges of negligence brought against two officers of the tanker Gulfstream as the result of the collision last January between that vessel and the Coast Guard icebreaker Eastwind.

The trustees of the bankrupt Long Island Rail Road and the standard railway labor organizations representing its non-operating employes have reached an agreement under which the forty-hour week and a 7-cent-an-hour wage increase are granted, it was announced last night.

The Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service is hopeful about the chances of averting a crippling East and Gulf Coast maritime strike when the present agreements of three Congress of Industrial Organizations-affiliated maritime unions expire Wednesday
VIENNA, June 9 -- The 220-mile Austro-Hungarian frontier is now completely closed by a system of barbed-wire fences, watch towers, light signals searchlights and even mines, it was learned today.

The election of William E. Birdsall and Arthur Hobson Dean, New York lawyers, as members of the Corporation of the Presbyterian Hospital of the City of New York was announced yesterday by Charles P. Cooper, president of the hospital.

GLEN COVE, L. I., June 9 -- The little gray frame building, 105 years old, known as Station 10 of the New York Yacht Club, sailed away this afternoon from Morgan Memorial Park atop a former United States Army scow, bound on her last voyage. The quaint Gothic, one-room club, original building of the yachting organization, will be placed tomorrow in a marine museum in Mystic, Conn.

Work is to begin immediately on extensive alterations to the Washington Bridge over the Harlem River under a $736,996 contract for a section of the work announced yesterday in Albany by the State Department of Public Works as having been let to Poirer McLane of 33 West Forty-second Street.

CHICAGO, June 9 -- The women of Illinois and operators of beauty parlors are awaiting action by the State House of Representatives on a bill passed Tuesday by the Senate that provides for strict control over the sale of home permanent wave kits.

CHICAGO, June 9 -- First round scoring honors today in the United States open championship over the Medinah Country Club's No. 3 course went to 33-year-old Les Kennedy of Pawtucket, R. I., whose chief previous claim to fame had been three New England professional titles.

Kent Miller's remarkable Elkridge, who is in approximately his third colthood at the ripe old racing age of 11, won the No. 1 over-the-jumps contest of Belmont Park's spring meeting yesterday. Few of the 19,474 fans thought he could do it; the world's leading money-winning steeplechaser was the $16.90-for-$2 fifth choice in the thirty-fourth edition of the Meadowbrook Handicap.

For the second time this year John L. Lewis has called the nation's 450,000 coal miners off their jobs. He has "authorized" union members in both the soft and hard coal regions to stop work for a week beginning next Monday to effect what he is pleased to call "a brief stabilization period of inaction."

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., June 9 -- The House of Delegates of the American Medical Association gave a nod of approval for the first time today to lay-sponsored voluntary pre-payment health plans when it voted to forward a set of twenty principles to county and state medical societies for their guidance in determining the eligibility of such plans for approval.

Thirteen billion dollars are spent annually by the American people through public and private agencies for social security, health, correction, welfare and recreation, it was reported yesterday by Community Research Associates, Inc.

Actual production of synthetic glycerin may reach a higher figure than was originally anticipated, M. W. Leland, manager, economic research department, Shell Chemical Corporation, declared yesterday. He addressed more than 150 members of the Chemical Market Research Association at the annual business meeting at the Biltmore Hotel. At the moment, however,
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 9 (AP). -- The deaths of three children trapped in an ice box at a farm home near Walnut Ridge, Ark., were checked off by authorities today as "an unfortunate incident."
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Science has concluded that man's whisky capacity is a quart a day.
PARIS, June 9 -- The Council of Foreign Ministers agreed today that each of the four powers would instruct its commander in Berlin to finish negotiations over the blockade by Monday.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., June 9 -- The text of the twenty principles, as acted upon today, by the American Medical Association follows:

Fredric March, actor named during the Coplon espionage trial as reportedly a member of the Communist party in 1947, issued a formal denial here yesterday, together with his wife, Florence Eldridge, whoso name was also brought into the court proceedings.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- A proposal for a new plan of United States aid to the Chinese Nationalist Government was submitted today to Acting Secretary of State James E. Webb by Dr. Kan Chiehhou as personal representative of Li Tsung-jen, acting President of China.

GENEVA, June 9 -- The current conference of the International Labor Organization will consider the adoption of a recommendation to member states to pass legislation establishing joint labor-management committees in all industrial plants.
ST. LOUIS, June 9 (AP) -- The Browns, after losing eleven straight, racked up their fourth straight victory today with an 11-0 shut-out over the Red Sox.

In a quick turnover, Louis Cooper has sold the one-story taxpayer with six stores on a plot 100 by 100 feet at 83-89 Rockaway Avenue, Valley Stream, L. I., to Harry Liebler, who bought the property subject to a first mortgage of $50,500. Fenster Co. were the brokers. Louis Schlesinger was the attorney for the purchaser and Olesker Sylvan for the seller.

As the operator of an independent radio station I cannot share the fears expressed in your editorial of June 4 that the FCC decision to permit editorializing by radio stations has opened up a Pandora's box of bureaucratic regulation. In matters such as this, practical common sense rather than doctrinaire logic should be our guide.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 9 -- A pledge by John D. Rockefeller Jr. to contribute $5,000,000 toward the $20,000,000 needed by the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration was announced tonight by Dr. James B. Conant, president of the university.

A loan of $15,000,000 was made yesterday to Keren Kayemeth L'Israel, Ltd., Jerusalem, by the Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association of San Francisco, representing the first major, straight commercial loan made by an American bank to a corporation in Israel since the new republic came into being a year ago.

Two business partners accused of developing an intricate plan of deception to victimize banks out of $20,000 in fraudulent loans were arraigned yesterday in Felony Court charged with grand larceny, forgery and the filing of false automobile registrations.
CHICAGO, June 9 (AP) -- The Athletics converted a walk, Luke Appling's two-base throwing error and an infield roller into a run in the twelfth inning today to beat the White Sox, 1 to 0.

The latest national list of individuals charged with being Communists or Communist-sympathizers has been made public, as it were, by inadvertence. It is contained in a previously secret FBI report brought out over the objections of the prosecution at the trial of Judith Coplon in Washington.

PARIS, June 9 -- The executive board of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization ran against a snag at opening of its sixteenth session here today when Henry Birecki, substitute Polish member, bitterly reproached the French Government for allegedly refusing a visa to Stanislas Arnold, the regular Polish member.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Willing to bury the hatchet for another quarter-century, the 3,000 Seneca Indians in New York offered today to sign a twenty-five year non-aggression pact with the Empire State.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 9 -- The Brazilian Congress is in an uproar after publication of a letter allegedly written by the Minister of Finance, Pedro Correa e Castro, to the Secretary of the Treasury, John Snyder of the United States, in which a loan of $300,000,000 for Brazil was solicited.

Carrying placards reading "We Want a House to Learn In" and "Part-time Education Means Part-time Citizens," 1,000 parents and pupils of Public School 102, in the Parkchester section of the Bronx, staged an hour-long parade to emphasize the area's need for additional school facilities.

BLACKPOOL, England, June 9 -- Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin said today that if the Western powers and the Soviet Union were unable to agree "how we shall live," at least they might agree "to live together."

The United States Treasury issued yesterday a call on its War Loan accounts with the Class B banks. Payable on June 14, the call on the accounts of the larger banks is on the amount of 20 per cent of the balances at the close of business on last Wednesday.
Lieut. Commdr. John Harold Speckin was appointed yesterday United Stares Shipping Commissioner for the port of New York by Rear Admiral Merlin O'Neill, acting Commandant of the Coast Guard.

One of the most tragic stories in the nation's public health history unfolded yesterday afternoon during a press conference at Columbia University conducted by Dr. Leonard A. Scheele, Surgeon General of the United States Public Health Service.
STANTON, Del., June 9 (AP) -- The Mater, favorite at $4.30, recorded a three-length triumph in the featured six-furlong Ridgely House Purse at Delaware Park today.

LONDON, June 9 -- The stock markets here today opened in brighter mood and in the first hour or two of trading it looked as if they would be able to stage a rally. But the cheerfulness was short-lived and prices fell again during the afternoon.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Sharp debate on the President's "inherent powers" to seize property during an emergency enlivened debate in the Senate today on labor legislation.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 9 -- "All Out Arlene," a novel by H. I. Phillips which Twentieth Century-Fox acquired in 1943 for production by the late Ernst Lubitsch, has been revived by the studio and assigned to Julian Blaustein for production, with Betty Grable and Dan Dailey in the leading roles.

CHICAGO, June 9 -- Capt. E. Hamilton Lee, 57 years old, of United Air Lines, one of the country's pioneer pilots, retired from active flying today with a record of more than thirty years and about 4,400,000 miles of flying.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Personal incomes in the United States declined to an annual rate of $213,700,000,000 in April, $1,000,000,000 below the March level, the Office of Business Economics of the Department of Commerce announced today.
AKRON, Ohio, June 9 (AP) -- Lower prices to distributors for its Silent Grip line of tires were announced today by General Tire and Rubber Company.

One hundred and one graduates, including seventeen women, received degrees of Doctor of Medicine last night at the ninety-third annual commencement exercises of the Long Island College of Medicine, held in the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Five hundred persons attended.
Two hundred thousand railroad workers will be made idle by the week-long shutdown of the coal mines ordered by John L. Lewis, the Association of American Railroads estimated yesterday.

LONDON, June 9 -- Britain's rail and dock strikes, which have been gathering momentum slowly here in the last three weeks, both took a sharp turn for the worse today. Ignoring Prime Minister Attlee's personal appeal of last night to return to work in the interest of the country, Liverpool dockworkers decided by an overwhelming vote this afternoon to continue their walkout.

In its first change of ownership since 1909, the five-story and penthouse apartment building at 58 East Eighty-sixth Street has been sold by Ralph A. Gamble, administrator of the estate of Mary Jamieson, to an investing client of Edward L. Timmons, broker in the deal. Assessed for $70,000, the property is 21 by 102 feet and was sold for cash over a first mortgage of $30,000.

CHICAGO, June 9 -- Grain markets had an irregular movement today on the Board of Trade following the violent rise in wheat yesterday on the new loan policy of the Commodity Credit Corporation. In wheat the July position was relatively firm, while there was considerable pressure much of the session on the deferred futures, mill buying being a steadying influence in the near month.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., June 9 -- Robert W. Kenny, former State Attorney General and one-time supporter of Henry A. Wallace, made application today to re-enter the Democratic party and indicated that he sought forgiveness for being politically wayward.

Scrubbed and polished youngsters, 90,000 strong, marched to the strains of "Onward Christian Soldiers" and other martial airs in various sections of Brooklyn yesterday in the 120th annual parade of the Brooklyn Borough Sunday School Union.

Arthur F. Pocock of Cleveland is the winner of Random House's Servicemen's Prize Contest for his book, "Red Flannels and Green Ice." It is a humorous account of his experiences with the Coast Guard's Greenland Patrol. The book is scheduled for Aug. 9 publication.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 9 -- Harry Bridges, West Coast long-shore leader, lost today his first effort to delay the Government's third attempt to deport him to his native Australia.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The United States has protested to Great Britain against her five-year trade agreement with Argentina on the ground that it would exclude some American goods from the Argentine market, the State Department said today.

Hollywood has a certain amount of communism but it is "not powerful or effective," in the opinion of Douglas Fairbanks Jr., actor, who sailed yesterday for Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Caronia. The vessel left Pier 90, North River, at 4:10 P. M. with 845 passengers.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- President Truman today called John L. Lewis a headline hunter. He remarked with a wry smile that the one-week coal mine shutdown called by the president of the United Mine Workers was not supposed to be a strike but some sort of special sitdown.
WASHINGTON, June 9 (UP) -- Carl R. Gray Jr., Veteran Administrator, said today that $2,000,000,000 in dividends on veterans' World War II life insurance would be paid early next year.

More than 20,000 Rotarians and members of their families from more than fifty countries of Europe, Asia, Africa and North, South and Central America, are expected here for the fortieth annual convention of Rotary Organizations, which begins Sunday and continues through Thursday.

Special Sessions Justice Irving Ben Cooper was sworn in yesterday by Mayor O'Dwyer for a second 10-year term to begin July 1. About 125 city officials and jurists of state and city courts witnessed the ceremony in the official reception room at City Hall. Also present were Justice Cooper's wife and two children and his mother, Mrs. Rachel Cooper.

Campaign on New Salad Oil Clinton Industries, Inc., will open an extensive campaign this month for its Lettuce Leaf Oil in New York, New Jersey and New England. It will be extended as distribution is established. Newspapers, radio and women's publications are scheduled.

CHICAGO, June 9 (AP) -- The National Collegiate Athletic Association today pointed an accusing finger at sixteen of its member colleges with a warning to comply with its Sanity Code or face expulsion at the annual meeting in New York City next January.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- George V. Allen, Assistant Secretary of State and former Ambassador to Iran, charged today that Russia had long tried to intrigue with the Kurds in an effort to create unrest in Iran, Iraq and Turkey.

Distribution of partial and complete Bibles by the United Bible Societies increased from 14,000,000 copies in 1947 to 17,500,000 last year, it was reported yesterday to delegates from nineteen nations meeting with the group for the first time in this country.

The Rev. Laurence J. McGinley, president of Fordham University, delivering the commencement address at the University's 104th annual commencement exercises yesterday said that "the entire dynamic of modern progress is today being deviously manipulated by a certain few to ends destructive both of Christianity and of democracy."

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 9 -- Leon Henderson, former OPA Administrator and a key figure in the Roosevelt Administration, today predicted that the current economic readjustment will continue from nine to twelve months and, unless guided along proper channels: "could add to the possibility of financial panic in this country."
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Mrs. Georgia Neese Clark of Richland, Kan., was confirmed unanimously as Treasurer of the United States by the Senate today.
Contributions totaling $3,250,000 were made yesterday to the United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York at a series of luncheons and dinners held mainly by the industrial divisions of the campaign.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- A former Government worker testified today that she does not "know" Gerhart Eisler, fugitive Communist leader, but that she once entertained him at dinner for four in her home. She said she herself was no Communist.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 9 -- The formation of an organization to be known as "Catholic Action," sponsored by the Czechoslovak People's party, will be announced tomorrow, Minister of Transport Alois Petr, head of the People's party, said in an interview today.
LONDON, June 9 (Reuters) -- Essex and Oxford University won their matches against Nottinghamshire and Sussex, respectively, today.

NBC, which thus far has followed a relatively conservative course in the matter of giveaway shows, now has completed plans for its major prize offering designed to garner the early Sunday evening audience. Starting on July 10, it will devote the hour from 6:30 to 7:30 on Sunday nights to "Hollywood Calling," which will boast a jackpot in the neighborhood of $30,000.

EAST WILLISTON, L. I., June 9 -- John Layton and Dale Scott of the Brookville Golf Club shot a 73 -- 8 -- 65 to win the Long Island handicap amateur best-ball net championship at the Wheatley Golf Club today.

Richard Strauss, famous composer, will be 85 years old tomorrow. He expects to celebrate his birthday with his family at the home of his son, Franz Strauss, in Garmisch, Bavaria, and afterward will return to Switzerland, where he has lived since the war.

The Coast Guard hearing into the causes of the crash early last Sunday between the cargo ship Exmouth and the Greek freighter Hellenic Beach off the Delaware Coast took a new turn yesterday when damaging testimony against the master of the American Export Lines vessel was given by a member of his crew.

PARIS, June 9 -- Using documents turned up mostly by United States authorities in official archives in the Wilhelmstrasse in Berlin, a French publishing house, Editions de l'Elan, will issue next week a book in which the Nazi official reports from France are made to exonerate Pierre Laval of many charges brought against him at his trial before a High Court of Justice here in 1945.
NANKING, Friday, June 10 -- The Chinese Communists are asking the Western powers to withdraw their recognition of the Nationalist Government of China, it was reported authoritatively today.
TRENTON, N. J., June 9-Debate on a vetoed measure to liberalize municipal police and firemen's pension systems was choked off tonight by sudden adjournment of the Republican-controlled Assembly
Mayor O'Dwyer repeated yesterday that he would not run for re-election under any circumstances and asked the members of the Draft O'Dwyer Committee to cease their efforts to get him to run again.

MOSCOW, June 9 -- The Soviet proposals for settlement of the Greek situation again today drew attention in the Moscow press with publication in all newspapers of a favorable reaction from Athens sources to Russia's plan for ending the Greek civil war.

BUENOS AIRES, June 9 -- President Juan Peron has dropped Rodolfo Freude, son of Ludwig Freude, former No. 1 Nazi in Argentina, whom the Allies tried in vain to have turned over to them during the war.

For four hours yesterday sharps, flats and just plain notes were sent across the expanse of the Carl Fischer Concert Hall at 165 West Fifty-seventh Street as forty-four public school children competed for tuition music scholarships under symphony orchestra and concert stage performers.

Conflict between Alger Hiss and Whittaker Chambers came into sharper focus yesterday as the Hiss perjury trial moved into its eighth day with seventeen prosecution witnesses corroborating some major points of Mr. Chambers' testimony.
CHICAGO, June 9 -- The national convention of the American Guild of Variety Artists, AFL, ended early this morning, after delegates had taken the following action:

FRANKFORT, Germany, June 9 -- Gordon R. Clapp, chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority, has been declared ineligible by Army authorities in Washington for a special assignment with the Military Government, presumably for reasons connected with his political and social beliefs.

PARIS, June 9 -- The Israeli Government has proposed that the pre-war frontiers at the northern and southern extremes of the former mandated territory of Palestine should be accepted as the permanent borders between the new state of Israel and Lebanon and Egypt respectively.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Representative Emanuel Celler, chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, called upon the New York State Public Service Commission today to withdraw its authorization for the Long Island Lighting Company to sell $16,000,000 in debentures to four big insurance companies.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, bluntly told the Senate Appropriations Committee today that he would rather resign than accept responsibility for carrying on the European Recovery Program with funds cut to $3,500,000,000 in the twelve months of the 1950 fiscal year.

Sales of department and specialty stores this year throughout the nation will be about 6 per cent below 1948, the annual report of the Controllers' Congress of the National Retail Dry Goods predicted yesterday. The report also estimates that net profits will fall between 20 and 35 per cent this year.

HENRY LEWIS MENCKEN, the skeptical sage of Baltimore, began writing professionally when he was 19 years old. Today at 68 he still writes with undiminished relish and gusto, with virtuoso mastery of his own private subdivision of the American language. His eminence as a philologist is so widely acclaimed that he probably feels no need to cry into his beer over his lost rank as the idol of young intellectuals.

When a steamer from abroad enters the Port of New York ten to twenty persons, on the average, are detained in Ellis Island for further examination. When the Polish liner Batory arrived in New York 111 of the passengers were sent to Ellis Island to undergo further hearings and immigration procedures.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Department store sales in the week ended June 4 were 8 per cent less than sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1948:

Ralph Branca blew sky high in the eighth inning yesterday but the foresighted Dodgers had bolstered themselves so comfortably against just such a contingency that they breezed home well ahead of the hapless Cubs.

FOREST PARK, Pa., June 10 -- An end to the present "do-nothing" policy that is endangering the economic future of this country was called for today by Leon H. Keyserling, vice chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers.

Among the reassuring events of the past week in Washington is the unequivocal statement of the Secretary of Defense that the "military establishment has not attempted and will not attempt to take atomic energy away from civilian control and turn it over to the military."

RUTHERFORD, N. J., June 10 -- An outdoor show to "bring fine art into the homes of Mr. and Mrs. Suburbanite" will be staged tomorrow and Sunday in Lincoln Park here by the Rutherford Art Association. While the organization has had three other shows, this will be the first to be held in the open.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission drew the fire of members of a Senate Banking and Currency Subcommittee today when it declined to approve, or disapprove, a bill to permit national banks to deal in the bonds of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development.

LAKE SUCCESS, June 10 -- Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, acting United Nations Mediator for Palestine, holds that the British Government's decision to resume arms shipments to the Arab states is a matter for the Security Council to decide, a spokesman said today.

GENEVA, June 10 -- Four member states of the governing body of the International Labor Organization were indicted before the annual conference today for "lamentable" failure to submit reports in the last year on conventions ratified by their governments.
PINE BLUFF, Ark., June 10 (AP) -- The Pine Bluff City Council today removed any threat that the city would be "closed up tight" on Sundays under blue laws dating back to 1872.

HAVANA, June 10 -- The imperative need for further study of the problems that are hindering the economic development of Latin America, before any specific action can be taken, were recognized by the delegates to the meeting of the United Nations Economic Commission for Latin America which will end here early next week.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The Port of New York Authority and others interested in fresh fruit and vegetable traffic into the New York area were successful today in persuading the Interstate Commerce Commission to hold another hearing on the charges, ranging from $1.50 to $2 a ton, levied by railroads for the unloading of fresh fruit and vegetables at New York and Philadelphia beginning last Nov. 1.

Richard Kollmar, who is the "Dick" in the "Dorothy and Dick" radio program broadcast by WOR, will replace Danton Walker as master of ceremonies on the National Broadcasting Company television program "Broadway Scrapbook," beginning tomorrow. The show is televised from 7 to 7:30 P. M.

Reverberations of last month's bitterly contested fight for the presidency of the Board of Education were still being heard yesterday with the refusal of a second board member to accept committee appointments from the new president.
BOSTON, June 10 (AP) -- Naming Frank Frisch as manager of the Cubs today, owner Philip K. Wrigley said it was "the best way to get the club ahead."

Retailers have an unprecedented opportunity to increase fur garment sales among consumers in the lower-income brackets, it was pointed out yesterday by Robert A. Love, director of the extension division of The City College School of Business. Cutting fur prices, he said, should overcome consumer resistance among people with relatively small means who hold a large proportion of the "discretionary" spending power.
The slow but steady advance of the Communist armies toward Hong Kong and the impending withdrawal of the last United States troops from Korea may precipitate another crisis in the Orient.

With the local political situation clarified by general acceptance of Mayor O'Dwyer's decision not to be a candidate for re-election, leaders of all political parties and groups began yesterday to give serious consideration to selection of Mayoralty candidates.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York issued yesterday a revision of its Operating Circular No. 19, relating to transactions in foreign exchange, transfers of credit and the export of coin and currency. The amended regulations continue in effect the requirements of earlier regulations calling for monthly reports by banks, bankers and brokers or dealers in securities, and for quarterly reports by certain other persons.

NEWARK, N. J., June 10 -- With the help of Congress, several Government agencies and Federal District Court Judge Thomas F. Meaney, the third attempt of the Spanish brothers Jose Perez Llosa, 18 years old, and Manuel Perez Llosa, 20, to enter the United States as stowaways may be successful.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- President Truman today asked Congress for $147,597,761.44 additional funds. They are to cover anticipated expenses in the forthcoming fiscal year 1950 and certain outlays in the fiscal year 1949 and earlier.

BERLIN, June 10 -- Soviet authorities tonight delayed answering Western proposals for new four-power sessions on German trade and transportation problems, called for by the Council of Foreign Ministers in Paris with instructions to finish by Monday.

Mrs. Nancy Gross Hawks, who was divorced on Thursday from Howard Hawks, the motion-picture producer, and Leland Hayward, prominent Broadway producer, were married yesterday afternoon at Manhasset, L. I., it was announced by a spokesman for Mr. Hayward.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 10 -- A Hungarian Government, announced today, does not contain the name of Laszlo Rajk, formerly Foreign Minister and before that Minister of the Interior. Therefore unless some new post is being created for him outside the Government, the belief will persist among the public that he is in disgrace.

Boys and girls at Public School 54 who used to consume hot dogs and soda pop for lunch took a lesson from some guinea pigs and now they eat vitamin-packed meals that include milk, fruits and vegetables.

CHICAGO, June 10 -- A decision of Samuel C. Bernstein, Commissioner of Illinois' Unemployment Compensation Division to make unemployment payments to some 1,400 Chicago Ford Company employes who lost work because of the three-week Detroit Ford strike, was appealed by the company today, Carl H. Urist, Ford attorney here said.

Officials of the anti-discrimination commissions in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and Massachusetts said yesterday that "as far as possible" their offices would work for the passage of a Home Rule law for the District of Columbia as a step toward ending racial segregation in the National Capital.

Six hundred and sixty-three employes in the local area offices of the Veterans Administration, many of them career workers in Government service, ended their employment yesterday. The lay-offs were the result of a cut of $28,000,000 in the appropriation for administration for the fiscal year beginning July 1.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- Extracts from a Federal Bureau of Investigation report said today that two War Department aides employed on a "secret Russian desk" were suspected of leaking confidential data to the NKVD, the Russian secret police.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- A railroad spokesman today questioned officially the subsidy program for airlines on the ground that the Government was creating unjustified competition for surface carriers.
TRENTON, N. J., June 10 -- Walter R. Darby, state director of local government, refused today to permit Hudson County to give $500 pay increases to about 2,700 of its employes.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 10 -- James C. Petrillo, the militant president of the American Federation of Musicians, AFL, since 1940, was re-elected today over his first opponent in his entire incumbency.

Mayor O'Dwyer told an outdoor audience in Brooklyn yesterday that his "one regret" in not seeking another term of office was that he would not have another opportunity to challenge the State Legislature to adopt his program for liberalizing the city's fundraising powers.

CHICAGO, June 10 -- Indictments charging violations of the mail fraud statute and the Securities Act of 1934 were returned today by the Federal Grand Jury against Preston T. Tucker, president of the Tucker Corporation, Chicago, a $25,000,000 post-war automobile venture, and seven of his present and former business associates.

SHANGHAI, June 10 -- People's Bank notes, the currency of Communist China, continued steady today after the ominous inflation of the past few weeks. The Official Foreign Exchange Market made its debut today With currency quoted at 1,800 to the United States dollar.

With few exceptions, every major Protestant denomination in America is seriously debating church union -- either in quiet preliminary negotiation or at a stage where actual merger is but a step or two from consummation.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- An official forecast today of wheat crop this year, the second largest on record, virtually assured a return to production controls in 1950.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- A confessed former holder of a Communist card testified today that he was "recruited" into the party by Giovanni Rossi Lomanitz while both were working in an atomic laboratory at the University of California, Berkeley, about six years ago.

CAIRO, June 10 -- Egypt will not benefit in the immediate future from the Middle East oil bonanza and accordingly the outlook for United States trade in the Egyptian market, which is the most important in the area, is steadily deteriorating.

There was no connection between the two, but while the Giants were losing a ball game, yesterday they simultaneously lost a coach. Frank Frisch, Leo Durocher's chief aide, resigned from the New York club to become field manager of the Cubs, succeeding Charlie Grimm, who moves into the front office of the Chicago organization as vice-president.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 10 -- A new landing control device to make air traffic control at crowded airports safer and more economical was outlined today for the Institute of Navigation at its fifth annual meeting here.

LAKE SUCCESS, June 10 -- Maj. Gen. Lowell W. Rooks, coordinator of the United Nations Appeal for Children, announced today that the Italian Government had donated 500,000,000 lire (approximately $870,000) to the work of the International Children's Emergency Fund.
LAUSANNE, Switzerland, June 10 (UP) -- Mark F. Ethridge, United States member of the Palestine Conciliation Commission, left today to return to private life in the United States.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Public presentation of any more case examples in the investigation of loyalty of Atomic Energy Commission employes was barred today by a 9-to-8 decision of the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy.

Six hundred shipping men representing every segment of the industry and allied fields attended a luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday honoring Cornelius H. Callaghan, who has just retired as executive vice president of the Maritime Association of the Port of New York. It was given under the auspices of the organization in the Wedgwood Room.

LONDON, June 10 -- Konni Zilliacus, member of Parliament, whose expulsion from the Labor party was confirmed this week by the annual party conference, published today an appeal he and Pierre Cot, member of the French National Assembly, have sent to President Truman to rescind the ban against their entering the United States.

AUSTIN, Tex., June 10 (AP) -- A high official of Mexico's Government oil monopoly told a conference here today it was high time for "frank discussions" between Texas and his country over economic relationships.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Corporations' sales totaled $25,800,000,000 in the first three months of this year, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported yesterday. This was $400,000,000 more than in the corresponding period of 1948, but $2,500,000,000 below the peak of the last quarter of 1948, which included heavy Christmas buying.

LONDON, June 10 -- Faced by a steadily worsening strike situation on Britain's nationalized railways and at some of its major ports, Prime Minister Attlee hurried down from the Labor party's annual conference at Blackpool tonight to preside over a Cabinet meeting called especially to consider the situation.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 10 -- The possibility developed tonight that Harry R. Bridges, West Coast longshore leader, may never go to trial on his recent indictment for perjury and conspiracy in allegedly concealing Communist party membership in his 1945 naturalization.
Eight arriving and departing liners with more than 5,500 transatlantic passengers kept the North River waterfront busy yesterday in a period of shipping activity reminiscent of the pre-war era.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 10 -- Broderick Crawford and John Ireland have been named by Columbia to head the cast of "The Tougher They Come," a photoplay by Lionel Houser about the American Merchant Marine. Houser will produce the film and Earl McEvoy will direct, starting June 22.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., June 10 -- This city went all out today with a three-ringed din that will keep up until next Tuesday in honor of the late Phineas Taylor Barnum, the legendary showman who in the distant yesteryear said: "There's a sucker born every minute."
Safety officials were urged yesterday to make safe living a positive goal to replace the "intellectual climate of living dangerously."

TOKYO, Saturday, June 11 -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur's occupation intervened today in the strike of conductors on railways of the Japanese Government. Robert T. Amis, chief of the Labor Relations Branch of General MacArthur's headquarters, ordered the union leaders to end the walkout, terming it both illegal and inimical to the aims of the occupation."

Attaining $5,157,000 of the prescribed goal of $8,000,000 for the Greater New York Fund, John D. Rockefeller 3d, campaign chairman, announced yesterday at the final report luncheon that solicitation would continue through this month with the expectation of exceeding last year's total of $5,235,000.

CHICAGO, June 10 -- A soft-spoken 37-year-old reddish-haired Long Island professional, Al Brosch of the Cherry Valley Club in Garden City, led the field at the halfway mark in the United States Open championship over the Medinah Country Club's No. 3 course with a 36-hole aggregate of 141 today.

Forty-eight branch stores, mostly in suburban sections of the metropolitan area, have been established by department stores in central areas of the New Jersey-New York-Connecticut metropolitan region, a survey by the Regional Plan Association, Inc., showed yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, June 10 -- Twenty-three former members of the crew of the freighter Flying Arrow today filed a $2,300,000 libel suit in the United States District Court here against the Isbrandtsen Steamship Company of New York.

BOSTON, June 10 (AP) -- The Braves dropped the Cubs into the National League cellar by capturing the opener of a four-game series, 6 -- 2, tonight before 20,551 fans. Lefty Warren Spahn held Chicago to six hits and had a shutout until the seventh.

CLEVELAND, June 10 -- Stifling a Tribal uprising in the ninth inning which threatened momentarily to sweep victory from his grasp, Vic Raschi tonight pointed the Yankees back on the right track with a triumph over the Indians, 3 to 2, before a gathering of 67,031 thrilled onlookers.

This is to congratulate you on Topics of The Times for June 6, regarding whistlers in buses, subways, elevators and other public places. Those who indulge in this habit of piercing the ears of their fellow-passengers are showing a lack of good manners and consideration for other people.

BLACKPOOL, England, June 10 -- Delegates to the British Labor party's forty-eighth annual conference departed from Blackpool today with an injunction from the party's campaign manager, Deputy Prime Minister Herbert Morrison, to begin making detailed preparations for the next general election, which will determine whether Labor is to have another five years in office.

The Joint Distribution Committee, 270 Madison Avenue, will open a school in Versailles, France, next October to train Jewish welfare workers abroad in American social service methods and techniques, it was learned yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, June 10 -- Two jet fighters crashed almost head-on today in a training dogfight at an altitude of 25,000 feet, killing one pilot while the second parachuted to earth. The accident took place about forty miles north of here.

EASTON, Pa., June 10 -- Gen. Omar N. Bradley, Chief of Staff, United States Army, emphasized today that this country must retain its atomic bomb monopoly and keep its armed forces strong to assure enduring peace and security in the world.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The National Labor Relations Board ruled today that an employer cannot give his workers a day off with pay to celebrate the defeat of a CIO union in a bargaining election.

ALBANY, June 10 -- The Greenwich Savings Bank, 1356 Broadway, New York City, was authorized by the State Banking Department to change the location of its branch office from 2 West Fifty-seventh Street to 3-5 West Fifty-seventh Street.
Banshees are comparatively rare in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn, and this well known fact was a puzzling feature of something that happened there on Thursday night.

PHILADELPHIA, June 10 (AP) -- The Phillies snapped the Cardinals' winning streak at six games tonight as they drove Alpha Brazle from the mound with two runs in the seventh and scored a 3-2 victory behind the careful nine-hit pitching of Ken Heintzelman.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., June 10 -- A birdie 3 on the first hole enabled Reinert M. Torgerson and John Murphy of Oakland to win the medal with 36, 31 -- 67 as the qualifying round of the Cherry Valley Invitation Member-Guest Tournament ended today.

Three men -- two alleged bookmakers and a bewildered tie peddler -- were arrested yesterday and held in $50,000 bail each as material witnesses to the fatal stabbing on May 9 of William Lurye, special organizer for the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, AFL.

Commuters of western Nassau have banded together to protest to the Governor's office fare increases on the Schenck Transportation Company buses totaling 50 per cent in the last five months, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- The Air Force today ordered its base at Waco, Tex., to be named for Col. James T. Connally, B-29 bomber squadron commander, who was killed in a raid over Japan on May 29, 1945. The Colonel was born in McGregor, Tex., was graduated from Texas A. and M. College in 1932 and learned to fly at Randolph Field, San Antonio, in 1933.

HONOLULU, June 10 -- Fears that both sides were determined to sit it out in the longshore strike that has dealt Hawaii a critical blow during the last forty days were accompanied today by demands for action, both in Washington and Honolulu.

Those apartment dwellers who can barely fit another frying pan into their kitchenettes will have no interest in this column. Today this space is devoted to news for those happy householders who have space in which to breathe -- and room for a home freezer as well. Or perhaps they merely rent a locker in a plant near by.

Coffee futures continued firm on strong demand for the near-by delivery positions by local trade interests on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. There also was some buying from outside sources in the distant months.
